(Midgette) Classical Music 'ABSOLUTE ARABIAN NIGHTS' (Tomorrow) Conceived by Kristjan Jarvi, the adventurous young conductor who founded the hip Absolute Ensemble, and the Swiss-born composer Daniel Schnyder, ''Absolute Arabian Nights'' is, the presenters state, a classical, jazz and ethnic music fusion of the sights and spirit of the Middle East. This ensemble's guests for this timely program include Marcel Khalife on oud and vocals, Bachar Khalife on hand percussion and Bassam Saba on nay. At 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824, the-townhall-nyc.org; $37.50 and $40. (Tommasini) * BARGEMUSIC (Tonight, tomorrow, Sunday and Thursday) This floating concert hall, moored at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge, is making the most of its intimate atmosphere by having the musicologist Maya Pritsker on hand tonight and tomorrow to discuss the music on the programs. Tonight, the pianist Daniel Vaiman plays sonatas by Rachmaninoff, Scriabin and Prokofiev. Tomorrow, the violinist Michael Vaiman and the pianist Dina Yoffe play sonatas by Mozart, Shostakovich and Schumann. On Sunday, the New York Chamber Soloists perform Bach's ''Musical Offering'' as well as Mozart's Adagio and Rondo in C minor (K. 617) and the premiere of Gerald Fried's ''Chess Game,'' a work inspired by ''Alice in Wonderland.'' On Thursday, the pianist and composer Dick Hyman leads an ensemble that also includes clarinet and strings in works by Gershwin and Rodgers and Hammerstein, as well as his own ''Baby Boom'' and Sextet. Mozart's exquisite Clarinet Quintet and a Leclair sonata fill out the program. Tonight, tomorrow and Thursday at 8 p.m., Sunday at 4 p.m., Fulton Ferry Landing next to the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083, bargemusic.org. $35 tonight and tomorrow; $40 on Sunday; $45 on Thursday. (Allan Kozinn) THOMAS BUCKNER (Thursday) The baritone Thomas Buckner, here presented by the World Music Institute as part of the Interpretations series (which he curates), has long been a champion of avant-garde music. He will perform new works for voice and various instruments, including William Duckworth's ''Their Song'' for baritone and piano. Petr Kotik conducts the New York premiere of Christian Wolff's ''37 Haiku'' for baritone, oboe, horn, viola and cello, and the world premiere of ''A People's History'' by R. Chris Dahlgren for baritone, flute, clarinet, percussion, piano, celeste, violin and cello. At 8 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 501-3330, kaufman-center.org; $10; $7 for students. (Vivien Schweitzer) SARAH CHANG (Tuesday) Sarah Chang, a former prodigy who has matured into a gifted artist, and Ashley Wass, a pianist, play Beethoven's ''Kreutzer'' Sonata and Prokofiev's Violin Sonata No. 2. Sandwiched between these two extroverted works is the New York premiere of Richard Danielpour's introverted ''River of Light,'' written in memory of Isaac Stern. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $25 to 79. (Schweitzer) COLLEGIUM VOCALE GENT (Sunday) Whatever your religious persuasions, for a music lover there is no better way to spend Easter Sunday than listening to the Collegium Vocale Gent under Philippe Herreweghe perform Bach's ''St. John Passion.'' The ensembles (both chorus and orchestra) are first-rate, the music breathtaking, the soloists (including Camilla Tilling and Christoph Prégardien as the Evangelist) reliable: superlatives fail us. Just go. At 3 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $60. (Midgette) CUTTING EDGE ENSEMBLE (Monday) The conductor and composer Victoria Bond is the host of a series of concerts that bring together music and other art forms -- in this case, weaving and digital art. Pamela Topham's ''Water Music,'' a tapestry inspired by the East Hampton landscape, will be paired with Libby Larsen's ''Slow Structures,'' a composition inspired by water as it freezes. Judith Shatin's ''Penelope's Song,'' for cello and electronics, uses the sounds of a weaver's loom. And Kenji Bunch's ''Crawl Space,'' ''Sarabande'' and ''The 3 G's'' will be accompanied by video of digital painting and animation. At 8 p.m., the Thalia at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org; $15; $10 for students. (Kozinn) EITHER/OR FESTIVAL (Tonight and tomorrow night) Concerts presented by Either/Or offer new works for solo instruments and unconventional chamber ensembles. A mini-festival offers solo and chamber works for piano, guitar, violin, cello and percussion. The lineup tonight features music by Michael Gordon, Richard Carrick, Xenakis and premieres by Nick Didkovsky, Andrew Byrne and Mauricio Rodriguez. Tomorrow's concert features a premiere by Mr. Carrick and pieces by Helmut Lachenmann, Keeril Makan and Massimo Lauricella. At 8, Tenri Cultural Institute, 43A West 13th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 645- 2800, eitherormusic.org; $15, $10 for students, $25 for both concerts. (Schweitzer) RICHARD GOODE (Thursday) This pianist's work has been consistently thoughtful and enlightening. He addresses himself here to Bach's Partita No. 5, Mozart's Rondo in A (K. 511), Brahms's Fantasies (Op. 116) and Debussy's Preludes, Book II. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $28 to $90. (Kozinn) * JERUSALEM STRING QUARTET (Thursday) This young ensemble played a memorable concert at the 92nd Street Y last season in which it framed a Brahms Piano Quintet with American and Israeli works. The group's program at Zankel Hall looks more cautious -- the repertory is Beethoven's Quartet in F (Op. 18, No. 1), Janacek's gritty ''Kreutzer Sonata'' Quartet, and Tchaikovsky's Quartet No. 1 -- but presumably these musicians play this works with the same electricity that enlivened their performance last year. At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $30 to $42. (Kozinn) WOLFGANG HOLZMAIR AND HERMINE HASELBÖCK (Monday) Hot on the heels of their exploration of the songs of Hugo Wolf, Mr. Holzmair, a baritone, and Ms. Haselböck, a mezzo-soprano (both excellent Austrian singers), turn their attention to the songs of Franz Schreker, a major opera composer of the early 20th century whose music was branded ''degenerate'' by the Nazis. The event is offered in tandem with the American premiere of Schreker's 1910 opera, ''Der Ferne Klang,'' in a concert performance by the American Symphony Orchestra and Leon Botstein. At 8 p.m., Austrian Cultural Forum, 11 East 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 319-5300; acfny.com; free, but reservations are required. (Schweitzer) MIKLOS PERENYI AND ANDRAS SCHIFF (Wednesday and Thursday) Two distinguished Hungarians, the cellist Mr. Perenyi and his friend the pianist Mr. Schiff, take on Beethoven's cello and piano repertory with back-to-back concerts at the 92nd Street Y. At 8 p.m., 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500, 92y.org; $45. (Holland) NEW YORK FESTIVAL OF SONG (Wednesday and Thursday) Latin song has become a great passion among the many wide-ranging passions of Steven Blier, the polymathic co-founder, co-director, accompanist and speaker of the New York Festival of Song. ''Amores Nuevos'' is a new program of music by Alberto Hemsi, Maria Grever, Gisela Hernández and many other composers one will probably be glad to have heard of at evening's end. Michelle Areyzaga, Jeffrey Picon and Ricardo Herrera are the soloists. At 8 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $48. (Midgette) NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC (Wednesday and Thursday) This week's focus is on Shostakovich's first violin concerto, introduced by Peter Schickele at an ''Inside the Music'' event on Wednesday, performed by Lisa Batiashvili with the conductor Sakari Oramo on that night and Thursday. For Mr. Oramo, however, another highlight is his compatriot Sibelius's Sixth Symphony: the rising star, who successfully succeeded Simon Rattle in Birmingham, is recording a complete Sibelius cycle. Wednesday at 6:45 p.m., Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nyphil.org; $24 to $60 for Wednesday, $28 to $94 for Thursday. (Midgette) * POMERIUM (Tomorrow) Alexander Blachly leads his superb choir in a program of Renaissance Passion and Resurrection motets for Easter. Among the composers represented in this broadly international program are Dufay, Gesualdo, Monteverdi, Senfl, Lassus and Byrd. At 1 and 3 p.m., the Cloisters, Fort Tryon Park, Washington Heights, (212) 650-2290, metmuseum.org; $35. (Kozinn) ILYA YAKUSHEV (Tomorrow) Ilya Yakushev, the winner of the 2005 World Piano Competition in Cincinnati, is a graduate of Mannes College of Music and currently studies with Vladimir Feltsman. Mr. Yakushev, a 25-year-old native of St. Petersburg, Russia, has been executive director of the International Keyboard Institute and Festival at Mannes since 2002. In his Alice Tully recital debut, he will play Haydn's Sonata in D (Hob. XVI:37), Prokofiev's Sonata No. 7 (''War Sonata 2/Stalingrad'') and Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition.'' At 8 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $20. (Schweitzer) Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. * AILEY II (Wednesday and Thursday) Alvin Ailey created a second, or junior, company in 1974, almost casually, as a way of working on new choreography. Ailey II is now a world-class troupe, filled with dancers who not only are good but also perform with a youthful hunger for their art, along with a reverence for dance that is a part of the mission of the company director, Sylvia Waters, whom Ailey himself chose to direct that first group. Now Ailey II is coming home, performing in the black-box theater that is part of the Ailey headquarters -- newer, grander and more gleaming than Ailey ever envisioned. The repertory will include new dances by Abdel Salaam, Darrell Grand Moultrie and Jessica Lang, along with Ailey's ''Streams'' and a chunk of Ailey highlights. (Through April 22.) At 8 p.m., Ailey Citigroup Theater, 405 West 55th Street, Chelsea, (212) 868-4444, alvinailey.org; $40; $10 student rush tickets available. (Jennifer Dunning) * 'THE ART OF FALLING' (Thursday) This free performance-installation, choreographed by Catherine Hourihan with video by Pam Kray, juxtaposes live dancers' bodies with projected images of New York City and its architecture to suggest the inherent fragility of solid, everyday life in the 21st century. (Through April 20.) The installation alone will be visible April 13 to 20. At 7:30 p.m., Lower Manhattan Cultural Council Swing Space, 15 Nassau Street, between Cedar and Pine Streets, Lower Manhattan, (877) 919-8326, chourihan.com (Dunning) JONAH BOKAER AND LIUBO BORRISOV (Monday through Thursday) If you find yourself in Chelsea this month, hop into Dance Theater Workshop to see if there's ''A Cure for Surveillance.'' This public media piece, by Jonah Bokaer and Liubo Borrisov, marks the workshop's new Gallery Installation Fellowship. (Through April 28.) During theater hours; Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org; free. (Claudia La Rocco) JOHN BUTLER: AN AMERICAN MASTER (Tuesday through Thursday) John Butler's dances have been performed by companies from Australia to Canada. Next week, several of the late choreographer's works will get a new look by some artists closer to home, including Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, the Richmond Ballet and Desmond Richardson. (Through April 14.) Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Friday at 7 p.m., Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m. Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800; $42. (La Rocco) DANCE AT DNA (Tonight, tomorrow and Thursday) Ellis Wood and her all-female modern-dance company perform Ms. Wood's new ''Flat Affect,'' a piece about women's irrational fears. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tami Stronach Dance follows on Thursday, through April 15, in Ms. Stronach's ''Pinchas the Fisher-People and the Great Flood.'' This retelling of the ancient myth, set to klezmer music, is from the perspective of mermaids. Thursday at 8 p.m., Dance New Amsterdam, 280 Broadway, at Chambers Street, TriBeCa, (212) 279-4200, dnadance.org; $17. (Dunning) 'DANCE CONVERSATIONS AT THE FLEA' (Tuesday) This free series of performing and discussion continues with work by Sasha Welsh, Roxanne Steinberg, Jackie Moynahan and HoffTanzt/Daniela Hoff, all chosen by Yasuko Yokoshi. At 7 p.m., Flea Theater, 41 White Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 645-6462, theflea.org. (Dunning) 'DANCING WITH BISHOP' (Tonight through Sunday) This piece by Saskia Hegt combines poetry and letters written by Elizabeth Bishop with movement and music. Tonight and tomorrow at 10 p.m., Sunday at 5:30 p.m., La MaMa E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, East Village (212) 475-7710, lamama.org; $15. (Dunning) 'GREEN SPACE BLOOMS: DANCE IN QUEENS' (Tonight through Sunday) This program features a performance each night by Valerie Green and her Dance Entropy, with the guest companies and musicians Stankovic Ballet Company and Andreas Altmann (tonight), Duncan Dance Collective and Sami Abu Shumays (tomorrow) and Alan Good Dance and Graciela Carriqui (Sunday). (Through April 15.) At 8 p.m. Green Space Studio, 37-24 24th Street, between 37th and 38th Avenues, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 956-3037, Greenspacestudio.com; $20; $15 for students, dancers and 65+. (Dunning) PHILIPPA KAYE COMPANY AND AIR BAND (Tonight) In Ms. Kaye's ''Ritual for a Non-Repeating Universe,'' computers track dancers' moves and translate them into digital animation, to music performed live by AirBand. At 8, Location One, 26 Greene Street, Manhattan, (212) 334-3347, location1.org; $20. (Dunning) * AMANDA LOULAKI AND SHORT MEAN LADY (Thursday through Sunday) In ''Delirium, or That Taste in My Mouth,'' the Crete-born choreographer Amanda Loulaki and her collaborators explore the choices people make in their bodies, before the mind can fully weigh in -- and given the bodies in question, these should be some captivating decisions indeed. At 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194; $15. (La Rocco) MOVEMENT RESEARCH AT THE JUDSON CHURCH (Monday) Carrie Ahern, Jeffrey Peterson and Sasha Welsh investigate works in progress in the latest installment of this terrific series. Doors open at 7:45, and seating is limited. At 8 p.m., 55 Washington Square South, Greenwich Village, (212) 598-0551, movementresearch.org; free. (La Rocco) ODYSSEY DANCE THEATER OF UTAH (Tonight through Sunday) In its New York debut, the company will perform two programs of jazz-ballet dances, created by its director, Derryl Yeager, and Mia Michaels, Eddie Ocampo, Dee Caspary, Liz Imperio and Mandy Moore. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m., tomorrow at 3 p.m., Sunday at 2 p.m., Ailey Citigroup Theater, 405 West 55th Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444; $20; $10 for students and 65+. (Dunning) PALISSIMO (Thursday) Injuries to two cast members forced the postponement of ''Le Petit Mort/Now It's Time to Say Goodbye'' by Pavel Zustiak. Mr. Zustiak's company is back in business now, with a new work that ponders death and confrontations with mortality. (Through April 15.) At 8 p.m., Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101, ps122.org; $20; $15 for students and 65+. (Dunning) BETH SOLL & COMPANY (Tomorrow and Sunday) This modern-dance company will perform ''Black Flower'' and ''Rustling Solo,'' choreographed by Ms. Soll, a longtime and major presence in the Boston dance scene. At 8:30 p.m., Merce Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street, at Washington Street, West Village, (212) 927-0476; $15. (Dunning) Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. Museums * BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'GLOBAL FEMINISMS,' through July 1. Too much of the work in this sprawling, international assembly of recent pieces by nearly 90 women from nearly 50 countries is body-oriented and doesn't venture far beyond the essentialism of Judy Chicago's indomitable 1975-79 installation opus, ''The Dinner Party,'' whose enshrinement in the new Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art this exhibition celebrates. Thoroughly dominated by photography and video, with a documentary slant to many of its better moments, the show is more about information, politics and the struggle for equality than it is about art in any very concentrated or satisfying sense. That doesn't keep parts of it from being energetic and illuminating, especially as a record of the way that feminism has gripped and jump-started the imaginations of women around the world. 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org. (Roberta Smith) BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'KINDRED SPIRITS: ASHER B. DURAND AND THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE,' through July 29. This show of about 60 works by one of the greats of 19th-century American landscape painting has as its centerpiece ''Kindred Spirits'' (1849), a tribute to the landscapist Thomas Cole and his friend the poet-journalist William Cullen Bryant. A founder of the Hudson River School but one of its less dramatic painters, Durand (1796-1886) favored the realistic approach to landscape advocated by the English critic John Ruskin, rather than the metaphorical view held by Cole and other Hudson River artists that its representation ought to express God's sublimity. Obeying Ruskin's call for truth to nature, Durand explored forest interiors with close attention to the ways of trees, foliage, rocks and ground cover in smaller works, while his larger and more elaborate exhibition pictures, influenced by European masters, are Arcadian visions suffused with light, color and atmospheric perspective. If the show reveals some of Durand's weaknesses -- repetitive themes and borrowings from other artists -- it also reveals his strong sense of artistic mission and his potent role in shaping the aesthetic of 19th-century America. (See above.) (Grace Glueck) FRICK COLLECTION: 'GEORGE STUBBS (1724-1806): A CELEBRATION,' through May 27. One of the finest horse painters ever, Stubbs knew his subjects from head to hoof and skin to bones. He painted other mammals too: dogs, lions, tigers, oxen, monkeys and humans. This intimate show of 17 Stubbs paintings from English collections reveals his admirable range, although the people he portrayed in two large, late canvases have the stiffness of figures on a candy box. His horses are his true monuments. 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, (212) 288-0700, frick.org. (Glueck) GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM: 'FAMILY PICTURES,' through April 16. This show sounds ripe with possibilities. The results, however, are more mixed. The exhibition is drawn from the museum's collection, which explains some of its exclusions and limitations. Many artists you associate with contemporary photography and the family are not in attendance: Richard Bellingham, Tina Barney, Malerie Marder. There is also a sense of false advertising in the exhibition's title. The museum's news release extends the exhibition's exploration into ''representation of families and children in contemporary art and video.'' Images of children, you quickly realize, can operate as a completely different genre. Rineke Dijkstra's ''Beach Portraits'' of adolescents awkwardly posing against stark seascape horizons are isolated (and isolating) images of children on the threshold of adulthood. You don't think about family when gazing at these photographs. Sally Mann is perhaps the best-known contemporary photographer of children, specifically her own. Ms. Mann, represented here by black-and-white photographs from the late 1980s and early 1990s of her ethereally gorgeous children, has been accused of everything from neglect to child abuse. The questions raised by her dual role as artist and mother, simultaneous protector and potential exploiter of the family, remain vitally interesting. 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, guggenheim.org. (Martha Schwendener) * METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: 'VENICE AND THE ISLAMIC WORLD, 828-1797,' through July 8. At its peak in the Renaissance, Venice, the Most Serene, was a giant, clamorous Costco-on-the-Rialto. All the necessities, and most of the luxuries, of life flowed into and through it, with many items arriving from Islamic Africa and the Near East. With classic Met largesse, this exhibition suggests the spectacle of two different cultures meeting in one fantastic city, in which commerce and love of beauty, those great levelers, unite them in a fruitful bond. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Holland Cotter) * THE MET: 'INCISIVE IMAGES: IVORY AND BOXWOOD CARVINGS,' through Nov. 25. This extraordinary show, drawn almost entirely from the Met's vaults, presents an array of nearly 100 carved figures, crucifixes, reliefs, containers, hand-held weapons and the occasional piece of furniture. It is an engrossing hive of religious fervor, Classical erudition (and occasional naughtiness), style shifts and multicultural cross-currents. And among the many feats of drop-dead artistic skill are several of traffic-stopping caliber. Don't miss it. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (See above.) (Smith) MORGAN LIBRARY & MUSEUM: 'APOCALYPSE THEN: MEDIEVAL ILLUMINATIONS FROM THE MORGAN,' through June 17. Even in the contemporary art world the symbolism of the Book of Revelation, with its demons and lakes of fire, has a subversive appeal. This new exhibition at the Morgan Library celebrates a facsimile of ''Las Huelgas Apocalypse'' (1220), the largest surviving Spanish illuminated commentary on the Apocalypse. The show, which includes 50 leaves from the original text, unbound and installed around the gallery's perimeter, offers a walking tour of the medieval imagination. 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 685-0008, morganlibrary.org. (Andrea K. Scott) MUSEUM OF MODERN ART: 'COMIC ABSTRACTION: IMAGE-BREAKING, IMAGE-MAKING,' through June 11. This unimaginative and uniformed treatment of a big idea -- the healthy and essential contamination of Modernist abstraction by popular culture -- should be seen if only because it is such a dispiriting symptom of the Modern's paralysis where contemporary art is concerned. Although it promises work that addresses ''perplexing questions,'' nearly everything here is perfectly pleasant and innocuous. The exceptions are provided by Gary Simmons, Ellen Gallagher and Sue Williams. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (Smith) * MOMA: JEFF WALL, through May 14. This majestic show makes a great case for Mr. Wall as the most complete, if traditional, of the untraditional artists who emerged from the turmoil of Conceptual Art. His often immense color transparencies mounted on light boxes are enthralling vehicles, intent on giving pleasure while making a point or two about society, art, history, visual perception, the human animal or all of the above. An imposing blend of painting, street photography and movies, they blur reality and artifice, narrative and form, detail and the big statement. You can't stop looking at them. (See above.) (Smith) * NEUE GALERIE: 'VAN GOGH AND EXPRESSIONISM,' through July 2. The Neue has, as usual, gathered a stellar roundup of Expressionist art. In one of the show's most exciting rooms, a third-floor gallery devoted mostly to self-portraits, two extraordinary van Goghs hang at opposite ends: ''Self-Portrait With Straw Hat'' (1887-88), from the Metropolitan Museum's collection, filled with energetic, radiating brushstrokes, and the National Gallery's vibrant self-portrait of the artist holding a palette and brushes, painted about a year later. The most compelling pairing in this room, though, is van Gogh's ''Bedroom'' from 1889, the second of three versions he painted of his room in Arles, with Egon Schiele's obvious homage, ''The Artist's Bedroom in Neulengbach,'' painted in 1911, in a darker palette and with a perspective tipped precariously toward the viewer. 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200, neuegalerie.org. (Schwendener) WADSWORTH ATHENEUM MUSEUM OF ART: 'FAITH AND FORTUNE: FIVE CENTURIES OF EUROPEAN MASTERWORKS,' through Dec. 9. One of the most appealing things about this gathering of some 400 treasures is the mix, with knockout paintings keeping company with small sculptures, elaborate table furnishings, decorative platters, Meissen knockoffs of Chinese pottery, a porcelain birdcage and vases and such. Strolling through the galleries, you'll find treasures like ''Saint Francis of Assisi in Ecstasy'' (about 1594-95), said to be the first authentic Caravaggio in an American museum; Fra Angelico's poignant, poetic fragment ''Head of an Angel'' (about 1455-50); and Francisco de Zurbarán's fearsome portrayal of a dead martyr, ''Saint Serapion'' (1628). But the pièce de résistance is an entire gallery made into an art and curio cabinet, with a planned clutter of brilliant objects that play to a viewer's inner acquisitor: exotic shells mounted in gold; an extraordinary Baroque ivory carving (presumed to be before 1650) of Adam and Eve; an automatic tabletop clock (about 1619) with a standing lion that could roll its eyes, open its jaws and stick out its tongue when the hours struck. Dazzlement prevails. 600 Main Street, Hartford, (860) 278-2670, wadsworthatheneum.org (Glueck) WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: 'GORDON MATTA-CLARK RETROSPECTIVE,' through June 3. I have no doubt that Matta-Clark is now being turned into a hot commodity, but at least at the Whitney you can see what he aspired to be. He came up with various wonderfully harebrained ideas. Literally, in one case: after letting his hair grow for a year, he cut it off as a kind of performance and phrenological gag. The preserved hair, dutifully tagged piece by piece, opens the show like a holy relic. He also sautéed a Polaroid of a Christmas tree in grease. The copy he sent to Robert Smithson, golden brown on the outside, is here too, and none too appetizing, I might add. At the center of the exhibition is ''Splitting.'' To a plain single-family suburban frame house in Englewood, N.J., he made a cut straight down the middle, bisecting the building, then severing the four corners of the roof. The retrospective consists of films, drawings, photographs and some of the architectural pieces he cut out of buildings. The drawings are casual and not too interesting, but the luxurious black-and-white photographs from Paris speak more to Matta-Clark's formal elegance. The big message was: Life as art, and art as life, a philosophy dependent on our being properly attuned and keen to the moment. (212) 570-3676, whitney.org. (Michael Kimmelman) * WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: 'LORNA SIMPSON,' through May 6. This tight, refined and impassioned survey covers more than 20 years of Lorna Simpson's career, from her photo-and-text meditations on race and sexism in the 1980s, to her more recent short films, which unite American history and personal history in forceful and lyrical ways. It would be easy to put some of this work on a shelf as ''identity art,'' but with an African-American woman holding one of the highest offices in the United States government, an African-American man running for president, and the nation embroiled in what some people view as an ethnic war, this art is entirely of the moment. (See above.) (Cotter) Galleries: Chelsea JEAN SHIN: KEY PROMISES The idea is obvious, if you're as keen as this artist on recycling everyday objects: an installation using the word commands of countless computer keyboards to orchestrate a flow of suggested actions, desires and emotional states across four walls of a small gallery. From esc and shift to return and home. Art lite, perhaps, but expertly done. Frederieke Taylor Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, (646) 230-0992, frederieketaylorgallery.com, through tomorrow. (Smith) Galleries: Other 'GIFTS OF THE FOREST: NATIVE TRADITIONS IN WOOD AND BARK' Drawn from the collections of the Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center in Connecticut, this show celebrates the trees of the rich forests that once covered the Northeast, yielding essential materials to the Pequot and other Eastern Woodland cultures. The objects run from ancient woodworking tools to contemporary objects that carry on tribal traditions, like the simple and beautiful wooden flute made in 1999 by Hawk Henires (Nipmuc) and adorned with an elegantly carved bird motif. Many things here were made in the 19th and 20th centuries: handsome woven baskets, carved bowls and spoons, decorated cradle boards for carrying babies, birch bark canoe models, an elegant birch-bark hamper whose sides bear a stylized tree motif. UBS Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, between 51st and 52nd Streets, (212) 713-2885, through April 27. (Glueck) * 'EARLY CHINESE BUDDHIST SCULPTURE,' Asia Week is over, but its essence lingers on in this exhibition of beautiful carved stone figures of Buddhas and bodhisattvas dating from the Northern Wei to Tang periods in China. This is the type of work that elicited rapturous responses when shown in London and Washington a few seasons back. Throckmorton Fine Art, 145 East 57th Street, third floor, (212) 223-1059, through April 14. (Cotter) Last Chance * MORGAN LIBRARY & MUSEUM: 'PRIVATE TREASURES: FOUR CENTURIES OF EUROPEAN MASTER DRAWINGS,' through Sunday. This show is drawn entirely from an anonymous private collection. Despite the veil of secrecy, a couple of things are obvious: the collector had significant capital for investing in old masters and either an exceptional eye or a good adviser (or both). The strongest concentration is in Italian drawings. The earliest works come from a period when drawing wasn't an autonomous practice but was used as a form of exercise, to apply one's craft, to experiment and to make preliminary sketches for larger works. The best example -- and the most historically significant work here -- is a black chalk drawing, ''The Dead Christ'' (1529-35), by Agnolo Bronzino. With more than 90 drawings in the show, being a diligent observer quickly becomes exhausting. In which case, put down the guide, find a few drawings you like, and enjoy them while you can. After all, you don't know where they came from, where they're going, or when you'll see them again. (See above.) (Schwendener) * JOHANNES VANDERBEEK The debut solo show of this artist at is a poetic, storybook tableau with a full-scale sculpture of a medieval knight reclining on his tomb and a walled-up archway set in the gallery wall. Both are made of papier-mâché made from old copies of Time and National Geographic. The beautiful little tree that stands between them is also of paper and paste. And check out the time-and-space-warped sleepers in the back room. Zach Feuer Gallery, 530 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-7700; closes tomorrow. (Cotter)

Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Lisandro Alonso In Spanish, with English subtitles 82 minutes; not rated The mesmerizing two-minute opening shot of ''Los Muertos'' is filmed from the viewpoint of a man lost in the jungle, weaving among the tree trunks and underbrush, looking up at the sunlight streaming down, fleetingly glancing at two dead, butchered boys lying on the ground, then glimpsing the figure (but not the face) of a passing man holding a bloody knife.

A senior British diplomat met with the Palestinian prime minister in Gaza on Thursday to discuss the fate of a kidnapped BBC correspondent, Alan Johnston. It was the first meeting between a senior Hamas official and an official European Union envoy since the new Palestinian unity government was formed in mid-March. European Union countries, along with the United States and Israel, have said they will not deal with Hamas because they consider it a terrorist group.

The owner of an Ohio nuclear plant has asked its insurer to pay for two years of lost production because of corrosion that it called ''unexpected and unforeseeable,'' even though it had resisted government pressure to inspect for acid leaks just before the problem was uncovered in 2002. MATTHEW L. WALD

Jon S. Corzine, the governor of New Jersey, has agreed to let two outside ethics advisers review whether his former romantic relationship with the head of a leading state workers' union local influenced recent contract negotiations with the union, the governor's spokesman said yesterday. The decision to request an independent review followed calls by Steven Lonegan, a Republican who is the mayor of Bogota, N.J., and others for the governor to release more information about his relationship with Carla Katz, the union leader.

Blubbering Clementine Gallery 623 West 27th Street, Chelsea Through April 21 ''Blubbering,'' a collection of Neil Farber's latest mixed-media works on paper, brings to mind Dante's ''Divine Comedy.'' But instead of focusing on the experience of hell and purgatory in the afterlife, Mr. Farber takes on the madness of contemporary civilization.

A coalition of advocacy and neighborhood groups filed a lawsuit yesterday in State Supreme Court seeking to overturn the state's approval of the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, charging that the review process was flawed. The suit, filed by 26 groups, stated that the Empire State Development Corporation intentionally understated or played down the potential costs and traffic and pollution effects of the project in its zeal to approve it in December. The $4 billion project, proposed by the developer Forest City Ratner, calls for eight million square feet of housing and office space and a basketball arena near Downtown Brooklyn. ANDY NEWMAN

RAWSON--Rebecca Hobart, 59, died peacefully on April 2, 2007. Loving mother of Jennifer C. Rawson. Devoted daughter of Edward Rawson. Adored sister of Edward Rawson (Ric). Rebecca will be missed and always remembered by family and friends. A memorial service will be held at The Cathedral of St. John the Divine. For additional details, please call (212) 779-9595. If desired, memorial contributions may be made to The Cathedral of St. John Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10025.

Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Sori In Japanese, with English subtitles 114 minutes; not rated Those with fond memories of desultory games of table tennis at the local Y.M.C.A. will be totally unprepared for ''Ping Pong,'' probably the most extravagant celebration of a childhood game ever committed to film. Based on Taiyo Matsumoto's popular comic and fetishizing teenage angst as only the Japanese can, the movie examines male friendship through the prism of extreme sport. And if you don't think Ping-Pong is extreme, prepare to be persuaded otherwise.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the turnaround effort at the Ford Motor Company misstated the number and timing of plant closings under its restructuring plan. Ford will close 16 plants, not 14. And nine of those plants, not all 16, will close by 2008. The rest will close by 2012.

Christie's expects Andy Warhol's 1963 painting ''Green Car Crash (Green Burning Car I)'' (detail below), based on photos of fatal accidents, to set a record for Warhol at auction. Inside Art, Page 32.

When all the text messages and phone calls were tallied following Tuesday's ''American Idol'' performances, Gina Glocksen failed to make the cut. The 22-year-old singer's departure was announced on Wednesday on the half-hour ''Idol'' results show. She leaves behind eight competitors, all of whom received more votes of the 33 million cast, a new record this season. According to Nielsen's estimates, 25.3 million viewers tuned in for the results at 9 p.m., helping Fox win the night's ratings over all. CBS and ABC shared second place, with CBS drawing more total viewers and ABC faring better among adults 18 to 49. Although ABC's ''Lost'' (11.5 million) led the 10 p.m. hour in both categories, its ratings in the 18 to 49 demographic fell to yet another new low. Meanwhile, on the CW, ''America's Next Top Model'' (5.2 million) posted a first-place finish among adults 18 to 34 in the 8 p.m. hour, ranking second among adults 18 to 49 to the time slot leader, Fox's ''Bones'' (10.3 million). On Monday, according to Nielsen's final numbers, 40.3 million viewers watched all or part of CBS's coverage of the N.C.A.A. basketball championship, an increase of 6 percent over the 2006 final game. BENJAMIN TOFF
GOLD--Sidney. April 6, 1972. Dad, you are always in our hearts and thoughts. Your loving Daughter & family

Like most great New York spectacles, the Easter Parade is participatory, informal and fashion-driven. Less a parade than a costumed stroll, the event was born in the 1800s, when Manhattan's elite would preen in their holiday finery in front of St. Patrick's Cathedral and other grand churches, then still in the northern outskirts of the city. Before they realized that New Yorkers consider it gauche to gawk, the less privileged would travel uptown to mingle with the wealthy. But over the years the procession (which has no official organizer) evolved from a stiff observance of society types to a casual, silly affair for the wildly dressed masses (and their pets). And one key part of the tradition, the Easter bonnet, has survived, though now the custom-made chapeaus and top hats are joined by towering creations involving action figures, stuffed animals, feathers, and of course eggs. Lee Ilan, 41, an environmental planner and 10-year veteran of the parade, has worn the Chrysler Building, Shea Stadium and the Gates on her head; this year she will be sporting the Coney Island Cyclone. ''The first year I saw somebody who had done the Last Supper made out of Ken dolls,'' she said. ''That was heavy. Literally.'' Go celebrate the new season and the creativity of urbanites; gawkers welcome. But hopping in is better. (Sunday, Fifth Avenue, between 44th and 57th Streets, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.) MELENA RYZIK

Met Opera Gets $10 Million Gift A $10 million gift to the Metropolitan Opera, announced yesterday, will enable the company to finance new productions in the next four years and support the appearance of world-renowned stars. Of the $10 million given by the Annenberg Foundation to meet the Met's artistic goals through the 2009-10 season, $7.4 million will go toward new productions; $1.6 million will be dedicated to the establishment of the Annenberg Principal Artists Fund to underwrite the performances of two to four singers during each of the four seasons beginning with 2006-7; and the rest will cover the production costs of the Met's 40th anniversary gala celebration, which took place on Tuesday to commemorate its tenure at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. Tribeca Festival Former Vice President Al Gore, below, will serve as host when the 12-day Tribeca Film Festival opens on April 25 with seven short films presented under the auspices of S.O.S., the campaign behind the international Live Earth concerts scheduled for July 7 to draw attention to global warming. The short films also focus on the climate. The sixth annual Tribeca Film Festival will close on May 6 with ''The Gates,'' a documentary by Antonio Ferrera and Albert Maysles about the 26-year Jean-Claude and Christo project that ended in 2005 with the installation of 7,500 fabric-paneled gates in Central Park. Coke Protests Jesus Film A protest by the Coca-Cola Company of a movie scene depicting Jesus drinking a can of Coke in the desert has prompted an Italian distributor to postpone the opening of the film, scheduled for today -- Good Friday, Variety.com reported. Starring Luca Ward, the film is ''7 KM da Gerusalemme'' (''Seven Kilometers From Jerusalem''), based on an Italian best seller about an ad executive from Milan whose midlife crisis sends him on a pilgrimage to the present-day Holy Land. There, in the desert near the biblical Emmaus, he gives Jesus a ride in his jeep, hands him a Coke and, while Jesus is alleviating his thirst, says, ''My God, what a testimonial!'' In a letter to the producers, Graziano Prota and Angelo Seconda, Coca-Cola demanded that the scene be cut, saying that it was likely to give Coca-Cola a negative image and that the use of the brand was unauthorized. ''We are not interested in this kind of product placement,'' said a spokeswoman for Coca-Cola Italia. The distributor, Mediafilm, pulled the film, and Artika, which co-produced it with RAI Cinema, said that unless it can persuade Coca-Cola's lawyers to change their position, it will have to re-edit the film and be unable to release it until the end of the month. 'Concert for Diana' Broadcasts NBC and VH1 will broadcast the ''Concert for Diana,'' a commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, scheduled to take place in London at the new Wembley Stadium on July 1, which would have been her 46th birthday, Reuters reported. Among the performers at the event, a benefit for charity, will be Elton John, above, and her favorite band, Duran Duran. Ensemble Studio Theater Has New Artistic Director The Ensemble Studio Theater, the influential 25-year-old Off Off Broadway theater that was founded and run by Curt Dempster until his death in January, has named a new producing artistic director. He is William Carden, who was the artistic director of the HB Playwrights Foundation and Theater from 1994 to 2006 and acted in and directed plays at the Ensemble, where he was a member and served on the board until 1994. Kristin Chenoweth, Jane Krakowski, right, Marian Seldes, Tony Roberts and Huey Lewis are among the performers scheduled to appear at ''Don't Quit Your Night Job,'' an after-hours revue put together by Broadway actors, which will begin a run on April 26 at the Ha! Comedy Club at 163 West 46th Street in Times Square. Ron Livingston (of the film ''Office Space'' and the television series ''Standoff'') and Jason Patric (''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' on Broadway) will star in ''In a Dark Dark House,'' Neil LaBute's latest play for MCC Theater, scheduled to being performances at the Lucille Lortel Theater on May 16. Playboy Indonesia Editor Acquitted An Indonesian court found the editor of Playboy Indonesia not guilty of indecency yesterday, angering conservative Muslims who have been fighting to shut down the magazine since its first appearance last year. The prosecution argued that Erwin Arnada, below, the magazine's editor, was guilty of indecency for selling pictures of women and sought a jail term of more than two years. But the presiding judge, Erfan Basuning, said the arguments did not hold up against laws passed in 1998 guaranteeing freedom of the press. ''This is not only a victory for Playboy, this is a victory for all of the press in Indonesia,'' said Mr. Arnada in an interview. The months-long trial highlighted growing divisions between a rising conservative movement and the majority moderate Muslim population. Hundreds of conservative Muslims, most of whom belong to the Islamic Defender's Front, a hard-line organization that has led the fight against Playboy, protested outside the courtroom during the verdict. Hundreds of police officers were stationed nearby. Playboy Indonesia, published monthly since last April, contains no nude photos, only scantily clad women and articles about Indonesian politics and culture. Far racier magazines are available in all of Indonesia's major cities.
To the Editor: Re ''Finding Doomsday Asteroids'' (editorial, April 3):

THERE'S a rhythm to watching, eating and pedaling your way through the 667-mile Tour de Georgia, a roving, carnivalesque professional road cycling race (held this year April 16 to 22) that brings about 500,000 visitors to some of Georgia's highest mountains and most colorful hamlets. About 120 are competitors in the race. For most of the rest, the tour is part sports spectacle, part Appalachian sightseeing trip and part movable party. Over seven days, the tour moves through a landscape of sandstone ridgelines; gushing, rhododendron-lined creeks; blooming dogwoods; and green mountain vistas. Quirky distractions are inextricably linked to stops along the way: Peachtree City, where cars are banned and residents tool around on 85 miles of golf-cart trails; Dalton, home to more than 100 carpet outlet stores; Rock City, where visitors roam through a network of mountaintop caves adorned with glow-in-the-dark gnomes; Stone Mountain, where a laser light show illuminates the faces of Confederate leaders carved into a massive hunk of granite.

Nyehaus 15 Gramercy Park South, Manhattan Through April 14 Decadence, decay and the dark side have become the province of horror films and death-metal bands, but artists like Albrecht Dürer and Hieronymus Bosch laid the foundation for this centuries before record bins overflowed with kitsch versions of ''The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.'' Now Anj Smith, a young British painter, is trying to reclaim part of that legacy.
To the Editor: Re ''Presidential Candidates Jockey for Position in Campaign Fund-Raising Sweepstakes'' (news article, March 30):

An article on Wednesday about an analysis of studies on the effects of hormone therapy for menopause misstated the results of a study on the risks of taking estrogen alone as hormone therapy. Estrogen alone increased the risk of stroke; it did not also increase the risk of breast cancer. The article also omitted the name of the journal that published the analysis. It was the Journal of the American Medical Association.

It's been a busy couple of months for the choreographer Larry Keigwin, but luckily he seems to function on a ridiculously high energy level. He finishes up Gender Benders, the latest installment of Keigwin Kabaret, tomorrow at Symphony Space. Then on Thursday he heads downtown to the Skirball Center, where Keigwin and Company will present a new commissioned work, ''Bolero NYC,'' as part of a split bill with Chris Elam's Misnomer Dance Theater, which is also presenting a premiere. While the provocative burlesque spectacles that can unfold at Keigwin Kabaret (with Julian Barnett, above) are in no need of young-audience outreach, the Skirball evening is specifically aimed at drawing a youthful crowd, and will include postperformance dance parties with a live D.J. In an e-mail invitation, Mr. Keigwin described the Kabaret as a bachelor party (''bawdy and restless''). His Skirball show, of course, is the wedding, and for the premiere of ''Bolero NYC,'' he has invited a diverse guest list, bringing on dozens of nonprofessional dancers to augment his company's performance. Known for his interest in capturing the peculiarities of contemporary life, often in small-scale, portraitlike works, Mr. Keigwin has now turned his attention to the Big Apple. Here's hoping it's a good match, made in some no doubt frenetic heaven. (Keigwin Kabaret runs through tomorrow at 8:30 p.m. at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, 212-864-5400, symphonyspace.org; $21 to $25. Keigwin and Company performs April 12 and 14 at 8 p.m., Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, 566 La Guardia Place, at Washington Square South, Greenwich Village, 212-279-4200, www.skirballcenter.nyu.edu; $20 to $30) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

New Jersey Transit service on the Montclair-Boonton Line was suspended for more than seven hours during the morning rush yesterday after a hydrant broke, flooding the tracks, the agency said. Service was suspended on the line around 5:45 a.m., said Penny Bassett-Hackett, a spokeswoman for New Jersey Transit, after more than a foot of water rose over the tracks near the Watsessing station, near Montclair State University. A delivery truck crashed into the hydrant in the parking lot of a nearby Home Depot store. Pumps were brought in to remove the water and commuters were diverted to bus and Newark PATH lines. Service was restored about 1 p.m., Ms. Bassett-Hackett said. JOHN HOLL

SCHERR--Albert E. III., on March 28, 2007 at his home in Williamstown, MA. Husband of the late Elizabeth Babcock Scherr, and father of Elizabeth, Albert, Alexander and Edward. Born November 26, 1921 in Mt. Vernon, NY, as the only son of Albert Edward Scherr, Jr. and Marguerite Christine Schwiers. A 1942 graduate of Yale University and a WWII Navy veteran, he married in 1949, and moved to Williamstown in 1950, where he worked for Sprague Electric Company of North Adams until his retirement as Vice President in 1986. He and his wife subscribed to the Metropolitan Opera, were members of numerous New York City museums, and visited the city regularly. He is survived by his four children and their spouses, and grandchildren Anna, Charles, William, Elizabeth, McKenzie and Isabella.

Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Carl Colpaert 90 minutes This feature by Carl Colpaert, who wrote and directed, may be a mixed bag, but it is so impressive in so many ways that it demands to be taken seriously. It's a black comedy about a returning Iraq war veteran named Jesús (Joe Arquette) that aims for an absurd, satirical tone (think ''Dr. Strangelove'' by way of ''Coming Home'') but rarely hits the mark.
Introduced on Thursday: Maserati GranTurismo Is it real? As certain to go into production as Giada De Laurentiis is to pronounce GranTurismo with a sudden Italian accent.

An article on March 30 about France's debate over national identity and its role in the presidential election misstated a provision of a law that regulates the wearing of head scarves by Muslim girls and women, one of the cultural issues with which the nation has struggled. The 2004 law bans head scarves in French primary and secondary schools; it does not apply to higher education.
Matthew Brannon's prints mix art, language and advertising and design motifs in a Manhattan-in-the-'50s style. (Below, ''Steak Dinner,'' 2007.) Review, Page 34

(Tonight through Thursday) A three-week series of seriously obscure American musicals, presented as only Bruce Goldstein, the canny repertory programmer of Film Forum, knows how to do. The ''B-Musical'' umbrella is a bit misleading in that several of the pictures don't fit the strict constructionist interpretation of a B-picture (seldom more than 70 minutes; made for the bottom half of a double bill; booked at a flat rather than percentage rate), but who's counting? Among this week's highlights are an Andrews Sisters triple bill on Sunday (including ''Buck Privates'' with Abbott and Costello); three films starring the yodeling country comedian Judy Canova, introduced by her daughter Diana Canova, on Monday; and ''Crazy House,'' Olsen and Johnson's rarely seen follow-up to their great surrealist burlesque, ''Hellzapoppin','' on Tuesday. An exceedingly strange triple bill on Thursday consists of musicals by directors best known for violent, angst-ridden films noirs: Phil Karlson's ''Ladies of the Chorus'' (1949, left, with Marilyn Monroe and Rand Brooks), Anthony Mann's ''Moonlight in Havana'' (1942) and Joseph H. Lewis's ''Minstrel Man'' (1944). The series ends April 19 with a tribute to the queen of the B-musicals, Columbia Pictures' tap-dancing Texan, Ann Miller. (Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, west of Avenue of the Americas, South Village, 212-727-8110, filmforum.org; $10.50.) DAVE KEHR

The waters behind Pac-Bell Park in San Francisco have been relatively calm this month. Yes, Barry Bonds is off to his usual slow start; with only one home run as of Thursday, he still needs 21 more to surpass Hank Aaron's career record. But if the Bay has been placid, the usual undercurrents that surround Bonds have been stirring up the ingredients for the perfect baseball storm: pressure, spotlight, history in the making, and the game's most controversial, temperamental player. What good can come of this? Well, a lot, says Michael Lewis, the author of the best-selling "Moneyball''and "The Blind Side,'' who also wrote a compelling profile of Bill Parcells for the November issue of Play last year.

KAPLAN--Jack, 73 years old, died on April 5th, 2007. He was a representative and consultant for Anti-Hydro International for over 50 years. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Services Friday, 11:30am, at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

Jazz tribute albums are often concessionary in nature: the subject dictates a repertory and, in many cases, a style. Not so, though, with ''Gardenias for Lady Day'' (Columbia), a 2003 album by the saxophonist James Carter. In name and spirit it's a valentine to Billie Holiday, yet only half of its chosen tracks can be found in the Holiday discography. One of those, the chilling lynching narrative ''Strange Fruit,'' features a vocal by Miche Braden -- but with a stentorian projection quite unlike her predecessor's. And the anchor of that performance is a bitterly caterwauling catharsis, an enactment of violence through timbre; it's not something one associates with Holiday, except perhaps through the early example of one of her inheritors, Abbey Lincoln. Elsewhere the album is more decorous, with string arrangements and debonair ballad interpretations indirectly suggestive of Holiday's general era. The instrumental palette is prodigious -- Mr. Carter, above, deploys tenor, baritone, soprano, mezzo-soprano, F-mezzo and bass saxophones, along with bass and contrabass clarinets -- and the mood is more nervy than cloying. (Mr. Carter pulled off a similar maneuver in 2000 with ''Chasin' the Gypsy,'' which pursued a modern mirage of the guitarist Django Reinhardt.) Of course the balance will probably tip even further toward the emphatic when Mr. Carter performs the music from ''Gardenias'' for the first time on a New York City stage. Along with Ms. Braden and the Akua Dixon String Ensemble, his group will include some Detroit-based colleagues heard on his 2004 Warner Brothers album ''Live at Baker's Keyboard Lounge'': the trumpeter Dwight Adams, the pianist Gerard Gibbs, the bassist Ralphe Armstrong and the drummer Leonard King. At times the only thing linking the performance to Holiday might be the simple magnetism of an artist in command of an instrument, engaged by the flicker of a moment. (Wednesday at 8:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $44.) NATE CHINEN

An article on Saturday about a delay in a deposition for lawsuits against New York City over arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention misstated the context of a response by Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman. Mr. Browne was responding to a general question about a pre-convention surveillance program when he said, ''No comment on anything that may have a bearing on pending litigation.'' He says he was not in fact addressing a question about an apparent discrepancy between statements by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and himself about whether that surveillance had uncovered a plot to bomb a subway station.

NACK--Harriet Wexler, 81, died peacefully March 31, 2007, in Manhattan. A beloved mother and sister, she is survived by her sons David and Jonathan and her sister Edith Milchen. She was predeceased by her parents Sarah and Ben Wexler, and her brother Frank. A life-long resident of New York City, she received a masters degree in education from City College and went on to a career as a public school teacher in Harlem and Co-op City. A founding member of the United Federation of Teachers, she was a rank and file veteran of the Civil Rights Movement and Vietnam War protests, and many struggles for social justice and peace. Kind, caring and giving by nature, friendly and positive, strong and sensible, she will be dearly missed.
Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today because of Good Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

Through the 1990s the German photographer Thomas Struth became an art-world celebrity for his outsize, absorbing portraits of crowds interacting with artwork in the world's great museums. As a follow-up, he is presenting the American premiere of two new series of pictures of audiences beholding single masterpieces in the Museo Nacional del Prado in Madrid and the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia. The show, at Marian Goodman Gallery in Midtown, is one of the most visually sumptuous and thought-provoking in the city. Both series of photographs are from 2005, though they are completely different in style, tone, spirit and intent. The pictures of students and tourists at the Prado (above), milling about and chatting in front of various paintings of great attention, fame and devotion, contrive to get us thinking about a cocktail of cultural concerns -- the aura of masterpieces, museums as promenades, art tourism -- to which he adds a touch of farce. Almost nobody in the pictures is looking at the paintings. By contrast, the pictures of crowds pressed in close around Leonardo da Vinci's ''Litta Madonna'' and ''Benois Madonna'' at the Hermitage are deviously direct, the artist zooming in his lens on the facial expressions of the crowd to the exclusion of the paintings. These pictures are a sort of guilty pleasure, owing almost entirely to the cleverness of the artist, who allows us safely to look at others looking at art. You only hope that he is not lurking around the gallery here somewhere with a camera at the ready. (Through April 28, Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, Manhattan, 212-977-7160, mariangoodman.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

GOLDMAN--Eugene, 74, died on April 2, 2007. Beloved husband of Marion Rolnick Goldman and the late Judith Ann. Loving father of Pamela and Danny Fried, Laurie and Jeffrey Goldberger and Michael. Cherished grandfather of Kyle, Jared, Jamie, Perry, Sydney and Cody. Adored brother of Howard and Beth, Allan and Fran, and Harriet. A kind and gentle man, Gene will be missed and always remembered by the family he loved and who loved him so dearly. Funeral Thursday, April 5th, 11 am, at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. Donations in Gene's memory may be made to the Dysautonomia Foundation, 315 West 39th St., Suite 701, New York, NY 10018.

To the Editor: A company's property rights must not trump an individual's right to life and self-defense. The bills you describe in ''Workers' Safety and the Gun Lobby'' (editorial, March 30) protect property owners and employers from liability, while giving employees a means for self-defense while in their employer's public-access parking lot.

Four warships and two military helicopters joined a fleet of commercial vessels that rushed to evacuate 1,200 passengers, mostly Americans, and 300 crew members from a cruise ship that ran aground off the Aegean island of Santorini while trying to dock. The authorities said the cruise ship, the Sea Diamond, operated by Louis Hellenic Cruise Lines, began listing after striking a bed of rocks about a mile from the coast. The ship was later towed from the rocks. It had left Greece's main port of Pireaus on Monday for a weeklong island-hopping cruise in the Aegean. ANTHEE CARASSAVA

People Bruce Evans, formerly of Goldman Sachs, will join Deutsche Bank Securities as a managing director in the mergers and acquisitions group. Based in New York, Mr. Evans will oversee the origination and execution of transactions. Deutsche Bank has also hired two consumer investment bankers: Marco Habert, formerly of Citigroup, joins as a managing director to handle household and personal care companies, and Jane E. DeFlorio, formerly of UBS, joins as a managing director to handle mid- to large-cap retailers.

COHEN--Oscar J, on April 4th. Former assistant District Attorney for Frank Hogan. Loving husband of Shirley. Devoted father to Debbie Marcus. Dear brother to Millicent Aronoff. Adored grandfather to Danielle Gross and greatgrandfather to Jacob Tyler Gross. Services 11:30 today at Midwood Memorial Chapel 1625 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn (corner Avenue M).

SHIPPING SOYBEANS TO CHINA -- As its appetite turns from tofu to pork, poultry and beef, China has turned to Brazil to provide it with soybeans to feed livestock. Vanishing cropland and diminishing water supplies are hampering China's ability to feed itself, changing the profile of global agricultural trade. [Page A1.] KERKORIAN BIDS FOR CHRYSLER -- Kirk Kerkorian's investment arm, the Tracinda Corporation, made a $4.5 billion offer for the struggling Chrysler Group that hinges on winning the exclusive right to negotiate with DaimlerChrysler and a deal with the United Automobile Workers union that could mean worker concessions. [C1.] $28 MILLION FOR 4 MONTHS' WORK -- The Ford Motor Company paid its new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, $28.18 million in his first four months on the job, the automaker said. [C6.] STABILITY CONTROL TO BE STANDARD -- All new vehicles will be required to have antirollover technology, called electronic stability control, by the 2012 model year, the government said. [C6.] ZELL GETS A VETO AT TRIBUNE -- The Tribune Company disclosed new details of its plan to go private in a deal engineered by the real estate tycoon Samuel Zell. Although Mr. Zell will control a minority of the board, he will have the right to veto any major transactions. [C1.] BITTER RIVALRY GOES TO COURT -- A federal trial is about to begin over the contention that Splenda, the artificial sweetener, misleads consumers when it says it is made from sugar and is natural. The plaintiff? Splenda's rival, Equal. [C1.] PLEA FROM CORPORATE OFFICES -- Many executives of large companies are starting to call for a national approach to fixing health care, warning that an employer-subsidized health system is unsustainable. [C1.] FEDERAL OFFICIAL HELD STOCK -- A senior official at the federal Education Department sold more than $100,000 in shares in a student loan company even as he was helping oversee lenders in the federal student loan program. [A1.] NEW LEADER FOR PARENT OF AIRBUS -- The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company named a new German co-chairman, tapping an aerospace engineer who also played a central role in conceiving the group's delicate management structure. [C3.] GERMANY'S SUPERVISORY BOARDS -- An unusual law that shapes the oversight of German companies by requiring labor representation on supervisory boards is again being re-examined after corruption scandals at Siemens and Volkswagen. [C3.] NEW THEME FOR AMERICAN EXPRESS -- American Express is making an unusually quick switch in advertising campaign themes. The current theme -- ''My life. My card.'' -- will be supplemented by one that asks the rhetorical question, ''Are you a cardmember?'' Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C3.] CABLE NETWORKS TURN AWAY EBAY -- Turner Networks, Discovery, Lifetime, and other cable networks have decided to boycott an online exchange designed by eBay to sell advertising time, the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau said. [C3.] A WINEMAKER'S RISING PROFIT -- Constellation Brands, the world's biggest winemaker, said its quarterly profit grew 26 percent as strong wine sales in the United States helped offset heightened competition in Britain and a drop in sales of imported beer. Earnings after paying preferred dividends climbed to $70.2 million, or 29 cents a share, from $55.8 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier. [C2.] A CHAIR IN THE BOARDROOM -- A new effort among women lawyers seeks to get more of them seats on corporate boards. [C5.] SLIGHT GAINS END THE WEEK -- Wall Street ended a holiday-shortened week with a quiet advance as investors adjusted portfolios ahead of a three-day weekend. [C8.] JOBLESS CLAIMS ROSE LAST WEEK -- New jobless claims rose by 11,000 last week, more than was forecast, but analysts said the labor market remained on solid ground. [C2.] DOG BISCUITS ARE RECALLED -- A recall of tainted pet food has been widened to include dog biscuits made by Sunshine Mills, of Red Bay, Ala. [A15.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Some of the payments at the center of Conrad M. Black's criminal fraud trial were reported to federal regulators in a timely fashion and not hidden as prosecutors have suggested, jurors were told. (REUTERS) Qualcomm, the wireless chip developer, requested an arbitration ruling in its legal battle with the cellphone maker Nokia to resolve their dispute over a technology license agreement. (REUTERS) Shares of Biosite Inc., a tiny maker of diagnostic tests, jumped after Inverness Medical Innovations announced that it would make an unsolicited cash offer to buy the company for $90 a share, trumping an acquisition bid from a third rival. (AP)

KERNOCHAN--Adelaide. Beloved wife of Jack, adored mother of John, Denny, Sarah, Wayne and Rose. Author and educator, her extensive travels and tireless work for UNESCO produced UN bestseller ''World Concerns and the United Nations'', innovative model teaching units for schools worldwide, which is still in use. She will be missed and remembered for her fortitude and dynamism. Memorial at 11am, Friday, April 20, All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. Donations to UNICEF instead of flowers appreciated.

Kentucky's basketball coaching vacancy, which hovered over the recent N.C.A.A. tournament and spurred countless rumors about which prominent coach would land in Lexington, was settled today with Billy Gillispie leaving Texas A&M to take over the Wildcats. Gillispie, who had swiftly taken Texas A&M's basketball program from obscurity to Big 12 Conference power, was introduced as Kentucky's new coach today.
WEIL--Lawrence Earl, devoted son of Inga and the late Kurt Weil, loving father of Jacob, Lydia and Amanda Weil. Services were held privately.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Dutch Soldiers Stress Restraint in Afghanistan In Uruzgan Province, Afghanistan, where the Taliban operate openly, a Dutch-led task force of about 2,000 soldiers has mostly shunned combat. Its counterinsurgency tactics emphasize efforts to improve Afghan living conditions and self-governance, rather than hunting the Taliban's fighters. American military officials have expressed unease about the Dutch method. A1 10 Soldiers Dead in Iraq Six American and four British soldiers were killed in separate attacks around Iraq, coalition officials said, and an American helicopter crashed south of Baghdad, wounding four soldiers. Four of the Americans died Wednesday and four were wounded when their vehicles were hit by roadside bombs in southern Baghdad and north of the city, the American military command said. A12 War Crimes Inquest in Somalia European diplomats said that they were investigating whether Ethiopian and Somali government forces committed war crimes during heavy fighting in Somalia's capital. The fighting, some of the bloodiest in 15 years, killed more than 300 civilians and reduced blocks of buildings to rubble. A8 French Candidate Skips Visit Nicolas Sarkozy, the conservative French presidential candidate, abruptly canceled a campaign visit to a Lyon neighborhood as demonstrators gathered, holding signs and chanting that he was not welcome. A6 Detained Britons Arrive Home The 15 British marines and sailors held captive in Iran for nearly two weeks arrived back home. But Britain's relief at their safe return was accompanied by questions about how they behaved during their detention and why they had been captured in the first place. A10 The British official in charge of reaching out to disaffected Muslims indicated in a speech that the government intended to take some steps to regulate and try to influence the affairs of Muslim religious institutions and mosques. A10 British authorities charged three Muslim men with conspiring to help with reconnaissance and planning for the attack on the London transit system in July 2005 that killed 52 people. The charges were the first brought in the attack, which was carried out by four British suicide bombers of Pakistani origin. A10 Pakistani Rival Gains on Unrest As the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, wrestles with swelling public disaffection over his rule, one of his key political rivals, Benazir Bhutto, above, has embarked on an international campaign to revive her political standing. A3 NATIONAL A14-17 S O S for 911 Systems In the Age of Cellphones In many areas of the country, more 911 calls come from cellphones than land lines. But 40 percent of the nation's counties cannot yet pinpoint the location of cellphone callers, though the technology has been available for at least five years. A1 Felons Regain Voting Rights Gov. Charlie Crist persuaded Florida's clemency board to let most felons easily regain their voting rights after prison, saying it was time to leave the ''offensive minority'' of states that uniformly deny ex-offenders such rights. A14 Panel Seeks Gonzales Account The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee asked Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to provide the panel with a written account of his role in the dismissals of eight United States attorneys at least two days before his scheduled April 17 testimony. A16 Giuliani Rules Out Abortion Ban Rudolph W. Giuliani, campaigning in South Carolina, firmly stated that as president he would not seek to make abortion illegal. A17 Pet Food Recall Widens A recall of pet food tainted with melamine, a chemical used to make plastic products, has been widened to include 22 types of dog biscuits, the F.D.A. said. A15 EDUCATION New Links to Loan Companies A senior official at the federal Education Department who oversees lenders in the federal student loan program held and sold shares in a student loan company for more than $100,000 at a time when he was helping regulate the industry. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 F.B.I. Agent Fatally Shot Outside New Jersey Bank A veteran F.B.I. agent on a bank robbery stakeout was fatally wounded, apparently in an accidental shooting by another agent, during a confrontation with three gunmen outside a bank in a quiet town in north-central New Jersey, the authorities said. A1 2nd Chance for Development? David Bistricer, whose initial attempt to buy the Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn was rejected by federal regulators, now has a well-regarded architect, powerful lobbyists and something he was missing from his first go-round: potential backing from two politically influential black ministers. B1 Golf Outing Ends in Plane Crash The three men who died when a twin-engine plane that took off from the Westchester County Airport crashed in Maryland were inseparable golf buddies headed for a few days of golf in North Carolina with the fourth member of their usual foursome, who waited in vain for their plane to arrive. B1 ESCAPES F1-10 Aging With the Like-Minded For some Americans approaching their golden years, choosing the right place to grow old is less about golf and weather than about finding neighbors who share their attitudes and interests. Developments that cater to specific populations have popped up around the country. F1 OBITUARIES C9 Darryl Stingley A receiver for the New England Patriots who became a quadriplegic after an intentionally violent hit in a 1978 game, he was 55. C9 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 A $4.5 Billion Bid for Chrysler Kirk Kerkorian's investment arm, Tracinda Corporation, made a $4.5 billion offer for the Chrysler Group that hinges on winning the exclusive right to negotiate with DaimlerChrysler and a deal with the United Automobile Workers union that could mean concessions. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Guantánamo follies; no recess from bad appointments; not just New Jersey. Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas L. Friedman.
