Anton Kern Gallery 532 West 20th Street, Chelsea Through April 14 With his third solo show in New York, the wildly popular Polish painter Wilhelm Sasnal extricates himself further from the long shadow of Luc Tuymans, the Belgian painter who is famous for his seductive surfaces, thorny subtexts and painterly purity. Mr. Sasnal's surfaces are noticeably not seductive, his subtexts are all but obscure, and his mediums are tacitly impure, even if they mix mostly in the mind of the beholder.
''We're not here to fight the Taliban. We're here to make the Taliban irrelevant.'' HANS VAN GRIENSVEN, a Dutch colonel serving in Afghanistan. [A1]

ROSIER--Peter, physician with unbridled passions and intolerance for injustice, died tragically March 15 at 65. With indomitable will he traveled to the tropics in his last days though paralyzed and ailing. An alumnus of Dartmouth, SUNY - Downstate, and Duke, his practice in pathology in Ft. Myers, Florida set a high standard in medicine. After his beloved Patricia (Delman) died he created homes in Manhattan and Massachusetts with the former Eleni Goltsis. In 2005 he moved to Arizona with wife Gail Fouts. Closest to his heart, children Elizabeth and Jacob mirror his charisma and restless capacity for kindness. Elizabeth's partner, Ruth Sternberg, Jacob's wife Vicki, grandsons Patrick and Jackson are richer for his love as are stepchildren Connor Strobel and Logan Bernstein. A donation to Memorial Sloan - Kettering, Doctors Without Borders, or Hospiceof-the-Valley, Phoenix would honor his noble spirit.

Many children easily master their A B C's. But even adults can have trouble understanding their A's, T's, C's and G's. In biology A, T, C and G stand for adenine, thymine, cytosine and guanine, the four bases that are the chemical building blocks of DNA and the foundation of life. But while their action is complex, appreciating their basic function doesn't require an advanced degree. According to ''Genome: The Secret of How Life Works,'' a touring exhibition at the New York Hall of Science in Queens, the easiest teaching aids are in your kitchen. ''We like to use a recipe analogy, so think of the genome as the cookbook of life,'' Thomas G. Turi, a genomic scientist with Pfizer, said recently as he led a tour of the show, which Pfizer financed. ''The chromosomes might be a chapter, and the genes individual recipes.'' These comparisons infuse several displays in the 5,000-square-foot exhibition, including a whimsical assembly line, the Cookie Factory, which might have been created by a geneticist with Willy Wonka sensibilities. Here a cell's nucleus is a home office, which sends out recipes for proteins to the cell's ribosomes, or factories. But dessert isn't the only metaphor. Proteins are likened to origami -- how they're shaped determines their function -- and principles of heredity are illustrated by a slot machine. Pull the lever and see how hypothetical genes might line up for traits like dimples. Fortunately, the exhibition is more than clever simplification. While a first grader can turn a wheel to compress a DNA model into a double helix, older children and adults can absorb more sophisticated science via filmed interviews, text panels and computer displays. Some information is fascinating, some humbling. What a piece of work is man -- and yet 50 percent of our genes are the same as a banana's. (Through May 6 at the New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens, 718-699-0005, nyscience.org. Free with admission: $11; $8 for ages 2 through 17, students and 62+; under 2, free. Free to all Fridays from 2 to 5 p.m. and Sundays from 10 to 11 a.m.) LAUREL GRAEBER

To the Editor: ''No Pet Left Behind'' (March 30) notes that the Gansevoort South in Miami Beach will provide pets with ''a bed mat of 100 percent Egyptian cotton embroidered with the dog's name.'' Last year, I spent over $400 to buy my labs new beds, which, I explained to them, are the Cadillacs of dog beds. Still, one prefers the old couch, and the other likes to lie against the front door where his back can catch the draft. I suspect they would be unimpressed by 100 percent Egyptian cotton. Karin J. Lauria Marlborough, Mass.

HALPERIN--Jerome. Jerry was our special friend. His smile and sense of humor will never be forgotten. His deep devotion to family has created a legacy for generations to come. Our deepest condolences to his entire family. Deedy and David
ROSENFELD--Anne. Years go by -so much we should be sharing. Miss you so. Love, Debbie and Alison
To the Editor: Re ''Pelosi's Delegation Presses Syrian Leader on Militants'' (news article, April 5):

ROTHSCHILD--Diane, The One Club and its board of directors mourn the loss of Diane Rothschild, esteemed former member of the board, award winning copywriter and 2005 Creative Hall of Fame inductee. She fought bravely with lung cancer. Diane began her legendary career as a copywriter at Doyle Dane Bernbach. In 1986 she founded Grace & Rothschild with fellow Creative Hall of Fame member Roy Grace. She was recently Vice Chairman of Della Femina Rothschild Jeary and Partners. Diane will be missed by her many friends and colleagues. We extend our deepest sympathies to Alan, Alexandra and Brenda.

The French architect Jean Nouvel, below, has been chosen to design the first large concert hall to be built in Paris since the Salle Pleyel opened in 1927. The $260 million hall, to be known as the Philharmonie de Paris, will be built in the northeastern neighborhood La Villette beside the existing Cité de la Musique. The 2,400-seat hall, to be completed in 2012, will be Mr. Nouvel's third major project in Paris, after the Institut du Monde Arabe and the Musée du Quai Branly. Mr. Nouvel's design will be unveiled next week. It was chosen over designs by Francis Soler, Christian de Portzamparc, Zaha Hadid, the Vienna-based firm Coop Himmelb(l)au and the Dutch firm MvRdV. ALAN RIDING

The Muse, the Fugitive and the Frequency Bellwether 134 10th Avenue, at 18th Street, Chelsea Through April 14 Subtlety is a hallmark of Tanyth Berkeley's work. Her first solo show of photographs featured women who hovered between odd beauty and homeliness and induced a thrilling state of anxiety by forcing you to question your own definitions of beauty.

Dr. Elizabeth Nabel, a practicing cardiologist and researcher studying the genesis of plaque in coronary arteries, became director of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute on Feb. 1, 2005. A firm believer in prevention, she exercises vigorously nearly every day and can recite her blood pressure, blood cholesterol and body mass index. Here are the five things she thinks everyone should know about heart disease.

The timing of Mike Huckabee's full-show interview on CBS's "Face the Nation" is, let's put it this way, a mixed blessing. On the one hand, it's Easter Sunday, so many of the evangelical voters that the former Arkansas governor and Baptist pastor is courting in his bid for the G.O.P. presidential nod might be focusing more on tomorrow morning's Easter egg hunt than on national politics. On the other hand, presumably because it's Easter, NBC's "Meet the Press," which competes with "Face the Nation" in many markets, has only a pundit panel scheduled. So maybe viewers will flip channels in search of harder news.
Nicholas D. Kristof revisits the rape victim who has created a sanctuary for women in Pakistan.

As a group from the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum toured the auto show earlier this week, one woman stopped in front of the Lincoln MKR design study and asked suddenly: "Why do none of the concept cars have door handles?" She was right.

In Sunday's column, I wrote about Hasina Bibi and her struggle to get justice after the murder of her daughter - and, more broadly, about Mukhtar Mai's own crusade to help people like Hasina Bibi. I know some readers will want to know how they can help.
If you want your product to be famous, like Campbell's Soup, Coca-Cola or Brillo, get an artist like Andy Warhol to immortalize it.

Tony Pena did not see videotape of his son's at-bats against Boston's Daisuke Matsuzaka last Thursday, so he was curious when I recounted how he had one. The younger Pena, the rookie shortstop for the Royals, grounded out to Matsuzaka twice, but he saw a total of 11 pitches and did not seem unnerved. "I talked to him, but we didn't get into the game," Pena, a Yankees coach, said. "When I talk to him, I try to make it father and son. When he has time away from the ballpark, I want him to be relaxed and not make it about baseball." Pena smiled as I told him how professionally his son had handled himself in postgame interviews. Pena Jr. praised Matsuzaka, but did not sound as if he had just faced the reincarnation of Tom Seaver. "He was normal," he said of Matsuzaka. "He's got good stuff." Real good stuff. Matsuzaka pitched seven innings and whiffed 10 to power the Red Sox past the Royals, 4-1. Pena will get to see Matsuzaka on April 21, when he is scheduled to start against the Yankees at Fenway Park.

Formula One is definitely an "us" and "them" sport. There is what Jackie Stewart likes to call the "inner sanctum" of the paddock, and then there are the cramped grandstands or grass and dirt areas surrounding the circuits where the spectators assemble. There are several levels of spectator areas, from concrete seats to Paddock Club lodges. Some people attend races on buses, others in their cars left in dusty or muddy parking lots, and others fly in by helicopter. The eating habits of race goers ranges from gourmet in the Paddock Club to hot dogs or their equivalent in the outer reaches of the circuit area. The F1 parties vary from the camp fire get togethers to galas with the cream of the Paddock club and a region's social elite.
Marc Santora of The Times analyzes the foreign policy message in Rudolph W. Giuliani's new stump speech and finds that 9/11 is a "constant backdrop," even if he rarely mentions the terrorist attacks.

The entry period for "Win a Trip" closed last night. I hope everybody was able to get their applications in on time. What's next? A team of folks at The Times will read through the thousands of applications we've received and select roughly a dozen students and a dozen teachers as finalists. We'll be in contact with the finalists in the coming weeks.
What saves “Five in the Morning” from being an abstract exercise is that it’s rooted in its struggling, neurotic characters.

The Mets are off to a scorching start. Not only are they 4-0 but they have outscored their opponents 31-3. The Mets' +28 run differential through their first four games is the second best mark for a team with four straight wins to start a season in the past 100 years, according to ESPN. The Milwaukee Brewers had a +32 run differential through the first four games of the 1978 season. The Brewers went on to 93-69 record but finished third in the American League East (this was before there were three divisions and the Wild Card, and the Brewers were in the American League) and did not make the playoffs.
James Blake made short work of Spain’s No. 1 singles player, defeating Tommy Robredo while Andy Roddick capped a sweep for the United States against Fernando Verdasco.

An article on Thursday about a new push to confront racial imbalance in the Greenwich, Conn., public schools misstated the content of full-page advertisements placed recently in local newspapers by a group calling itself Concerned Citizens of Greenwich. The ads raised concerns about a proposal to spend $23 million rebuilding Glenville School, and offered a broader critique of a new task force considering topics including racial balance and redistricting. The ads did not ask that neighborhood schools “not be made to suffer in the rush to bolster other schools.”.
Lawyers for the city withdrew a manslaughter charge against a 13-year-old boy accused of fatally injuring his classmate in a schoolyard fight in East Elmhurst, Queens.
The Yankees have lost two of their three games this season, and the starters have an 8.76 earned run average, allowing 20 hits and 8 walks over 12 1/3 innings.
Without Stephon Marbury for much of the game, the Knicks saw their already faint hope of making the playoffs grow even dimmer Friday night against Minnesota.
The Nets’ most lopsided loss since they fell to the Orlando Magic by 33 points on Feb. 2 has taken them out of the race for the Atlantic Division title.
Coming off their three-game sweep against the Cardinals, the Mets continued to receive excellent starting pitching, this time by Oliver Pérez, and contributions up and down their lineup.
Israeli helicopters fired into the Gaza Strip, killing one Palestinian militant in what residents said was the fiercest exchange between Israeli forces and militants since a November truce.

Detectives in Atherton arrested two people in a $100,000 wine theft from the cellar of a private residence. The 450 bottles that were stolen between Dec. 28 and Jan. 4 included a rare 1959 magnum from Château Pétrus in Bordeaux. The suspects, Zhi Mua Deng, 50, a domestic worker who had access to the house, and Xiao Yan Xiang, 52, were taken into custody after cameras installed by the police caught them returning to the cellar. “It was just greed on the part of the crooks,” said Detective Sgt. Joseph C. Wade, who was in charge of the investigation. “The cellar was locked, but she had a key.” The two are charged with burglary, conspiracy and possession of stolen property. At the suspects’ residences, the police found wine boxes, but only three bottles of wine. “We are still looking at what happened to the wine,” Sergeant Wade said.

Prosecutors want the entire United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit to recuse itself from the latest appeal for Mumia Abu-Jamal, who is on death row for murdering a police officer in 1981, because Gov. Edward G. Rendell, whose wife serves on the court, was district attorney during Mr. Abu-Jamal’s 1982 trial. Mr. Abu-Jamal, left, in his latest appeal accuses prosecutors of practicing racial discrimination during jury selection. Prosecutors deny that. “Since Mr. Rendell was the elected district attorney at the time in question, and so would have been responsible for the supposed ‘routine’ racially discriminatory practices of Philadelphia prosecutors, Abu-Jamal’s accusations necessarily implicate Mr. Rendell personally,” Hugh J. Burns Jr., an assistant district attorney, wrote in a motion last week.

A federal appeals court ruled that United States courts did not have the authority to prohibit allied military forces in Iraq from transferring to Iraqi government custody an American who has been sentenced to death.

A suburban amusement park outside Sacramento has gotten so many complaints from neighbors about bloodcurdling screams that it has instituted a no-shrieking rule for its new ride, the Scandia Screamer, a windmill-like contraption that sends people plunging 16 stories at nearly 60 miles per hour. “After the first complaint, our rule was no profanity,” said Steve Baddley, general manager at the park, the Scandia Family Fun Center. “Then neighbors said it wasn’t just that — it was the crazy, excessive screaming. Then they said it was really all of it, the loud laughing, everything.” The rule was imposed March 29. As passengers are strapped in, the operator recites a warning that begins: “We are required to remove you from this ride if you make any noise. If you feel you might make a noise, please cover your mouth tightly with your hand.”.

A Massachusetts judge temporarily barred federal officials from deporting a group of illegal immigrants snared in a factory raid last month. The judge, Richard G. Stearns of Federal District Court, granted an emergency request from lawyers for the immigrants, who argued that about 110 of 360 workers arrested might have agreed to waive an appeal of their deportation order under duress or with improper translators. The order lasts 10 days and does not apply to detainees who had been ordered deported before they were arrested in the March 6 raid at the Michael Bianco Inc. factory in New Bedford. The company makes equipment and apparel for the American military.
Chris Bosh had 23 points and 13 rebounds last night to help Toronto win its first division title with a 94-85 victory against the host Philadelphia 76ers last night.

An article in The Arts on Thursday about CNN’s new anchor team for its program “American Morning” misspelled the given name of one anchor. She is Kiran Chetry, not Kieran. The article also misstated the schedule for a new program with Soledad O’Brien, one of the morning anchors who is being replaced. The program, “CNN: Special Investigations Unit,” will be shown weekly, not occasionally.

An article in Business Day yesterday about a dispute between the makers of Equal and Splenda referred incorrectly to an earlier legal battle between makers of pasta sauce. Conopco, which unsuccessfully sued Campbell Soup in 1996, was the maker of Ragu — not Prego, which Campbell produces. Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the gender of the judge overseeing the Equal-Splenda case. Gene E. K. Pratter is a woman.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about residues of pharmaceuticals and personal care products in the nation’s waterways misstated the given name of a scientist at the Environmental Protection Agency. He is Christian Daughton, not Christopher.
Corrections

A picture caption on Thursday with a music review of Battles, at the Bowery Ballroom, reversed the identities of two band members. Ian Williams was at left, and Dave Konopka was the second from the right.

An article on Wednesday about bald eagle hatchings in the wild of Santa Catalina Island misstated the amount of money allocated for eagle restoration in the Channel Islands under a settlement between the federal government and Montrose Chemical Corporation, the company chiefly responsible for DDT pollution in the islands. It is $6.2 million — not $30 million, which is the amount for restoration of all animals harmed by DDT.

A brief article in the Westchester section this weekend about the shutdown of the Indian Point 3 reactor on Tuesday was printed before a fire yesterday forced the plant to close again. An article on B3 today reports on the latest developments.

An article on Tuesday about the history of a mansion for sale on Riverside Drive in Manhattan referred incorrectly to Victoria Sanders, a great-granddaughter of the original owner, Morris Schinasi. She was not in fact raised in the mansion.

A television review in Weekend yesterday about “Entourage,” which starts its new season tomorrow on HBO, misstated the history of the television career of Carla Gugino, who is joining the show. She has starred in two series that were canceled, not one. Besides “Karen Sisco,” she was also in “Threshold.”.
The “S.& P. 100 Stocks” chart in Business Day yesterday was published in error. A corrected chart appears on Page C7.

An article yesterday about a decision by Florida’s clemency board to let most felons easily regain their voting rights after prison misstated the year a ban on voting by felons was added to the state Constitution. It was 1868, not 1968.

Divers and the Coast Guard searched for two French tourists, a 45-year-old man and his 16-year-old daughter, reported missing after hundreds of other tourists, including more than 700 Americans, were safely evacuated after their cruise ship hit rocks while trying to dock at the island of Santorini and issued a distress call on Thursday. The ship, the Sea Diamond, left, operated by Louis Hellenic Cruise Lines, sunk yesterday morning, 15 hours after it began taking on water.

Some 600 girls at the Villa de las Niñas outside Mexico City, a boarding school run by Roman Catholic nuns, have been struck by a mystery illness that the authorities say is psychological, raising questions about conditions inside the school. Mother Superior Margie Cheong said that it was unclear what had caused the symptoms, which include difficulty walking and nausea, but that “the diagnosis by health authorities is of a psychological ailment.” She said she had only recently alerted parents and the authorities, despite the first cases having appeared in October, because she did not want to cause panic. Some students have complained of overly strict disciplinary measures.

Pasteur Bizimungu, a Hutu who was Rwanda’s first post-genocide leader, walked free from prison after serving two years of a 15-year term after a surprise pardon from his successor, President Paul Kagame, a Tutsi, on the 13th anniversary of the start of the 1994 genocide. Mr. Bizimungu resigned as president in 2000 after disputes with the Tutsi-dominated governing party. He set up a rival party, which the government immediately banned, and was later charged with illegal political activity and threats to state security.

China is investigating United States claims that a Chinese company exported contaminated wheat gluten implicated in pet deaths in the United States, the first time the government has weighed in on the matter. Xia Wenjun, an official with the General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine, which monitors exports, was quoted by the Xinhua News Agency as saying that a “sampling and examination” of wheat gluten was under way nationwide. The United States has blocked imports of wheat gluten from the Xuzhou Anying Biologic Technology Development Company, saying it suspects that gluten it shipped for pet foods was contaminated with melamine, a chemical used to make plastic products. Mary Peng, a manager of the International Center for Veterinary Services in Beijing, and Zu Shuxian, an animal rights activist, said they had received no domestic reports of any animals sickened by pet food.

Russia will convert its Pacific fleet into its biggest naval force to meet security threats in Asia, said Sergei B. Ivanov, the defense minister who was promoted to first deputy prime minister this year. He said Russia’s Northern fleet was its strongest during the Cold War but asked, “Now, who are we going to fight there?” Relations with NATO are not bad, Russian news agencies quoted him as saying during a trip to Khabarovsk in Russia’s Far East, “but here the risks are greater.” Of Russia’s four fleets, three — the Black Sea, Northern and Baltic fleets — are designed to cope with Western threats. But the Pacific fleet lacks any of the system of agreements and mechanisms intended to keep peace in Europe, Mr. Ivanov said. “This is a region where there is a risk of conflict,” he said. “Here you have the United States, China, Korea and Japan, and there are absolutely no rules of the game.”.

On Wednesday morning, Don Imus called the students who play for the Rutgers University women's basketball team a bunch of ''nappy-headed ho's.'' Even for Mr. Imus, a nationally syndicated radio host who knows his way around an insult, it was a shocking remark, one that seemed to impugn both the physical and moral characteristics of a team composed mostly of black players.

A television review in Weekend yesterday about ''Entourage,'' which starts its new season tomorrow on HBO, misstated the history of the television career of Carla Gugino, who is joining the show. She has starred in two series that were canceled, not one. Besides ''Karen Sisco,'' she was also in ''Threshold.''

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the private equity firm, agreed to pay nearly $27 billion for the First Data Corporation in one of the largest buyout offers so far this year. Under the terms of the deal, shareholders in First Data, a credit card processor, would receive $34 a share in cash, a 26 percent premium. One of the largest buyout firms, Kohlberg Kravis has led a string of notable deal offers. Along with the Texas Pacific Group, it has bid $44.4 billion for the Texas energy giant TXU, the largest leveraged buyout offer ever.

Since it was created in 1988, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has been criticized from all sides at one time or another. Some scientists and industry representatives contend that it has played up dire findings; earlier this year, other scientists and environmental campaigners complained that its forecasts for rising seas in a warming world were far too conservative.

An article in Business Day yesterday about a dispute between the makers of Equal and Splenda referred incorrectly to an earlier legal battle between makers of pasta sauce. Conopco, which unsuccessfully sued Campbell Soup in 1996, was the maker of Ragu -- not Prego, which Campbell produces. Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the gender of the judge overseeing the Equal-Splenda case. Gene E. K. Pratter is a woman.

As the New York International Auto Show opened, Detroit's automakers hoped visitors would be entranced by new products and overlook weak March sales. All three companies lost market share last month as they cut back on low-margin deliveries to rental-car companies and failed to increase sales at their dealerships. Toyota, on the other hand, had its best month ever and said it had sold half a million hybrid cars.

Beijing Checks Idol Worship Government censors in Beijing moved yesterday to rein ''Happy Boy,'' China's version of ''American Idol,'' Agence France-Presse reported. The finale of last season's version of the show, ''Super Girl,'' won by Li Yuchun, right, was watched by 400 million viewers, roughly one-third of China's population. ''No weirdness, no vulgarity, no low taste,'' were among the restrictions imposed on the show's producers by the State Administration of Radio, Film and Television, according to a notice posted on the administration's Web site. In addition, relatives and contestants must do their best not to cry, scream or wail in order to ''maintain a happy and inspiring atmosphere,'' and the judges are prohibited from ''mocking or humiliating contestants.'' Contestants must only sing ''healthy and ethically inspiring'' songs, and the show must not indulge in ''gossip.'' The censor's notice said the rules were aimed at ''preparing a good atmosphere'' before the Communist Party's national congress late this year. The publication of the new rules came amid the initial search for ''Happy Boy'' contestants. Ten thousand people have already applied in Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province. The search goes nationwide today. A Photographer's Legacy The foundation established after the death of the celebrity photographer Herb Ritts is donating $2.5 million and 189 of his works to the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, which plans to create a photography gallery in his name, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Mr. Ritts, who died in 2002 at 50, photographed the famous, often for magazines like Vogue and Vanity Fair. The museum mounted a show of his work in 1996 that was derided by many critics but proved to be one of its most popular exhibitions. ''The museum was making a major statement about accessibility, about what we thought was art, and what we thought were the preoccupations of a younger generation in America,'' said Malcolm Rogers, the Boston museum's director. The gift is the largest ever by the Herb Ritts Foundation, which has focused largely on AIDS-related causes since it was founded in 2003. Venice's Pop Menace Conservation organizations say that St. Mark's Square in Venice, below, could be damaged by two concerts to be staged there on June 5 and 6 June by Elton John, The Art Newspaper reported on Thursday. A 1989 concert there by Pink Floyd was attended by about 200,000 people, who left a mess that took three days to clean up. Two sixth-century columns next to the Basilica of St. Mark's were damaged when fans climbed them to get a better view. Anna Somers Cocks, who leads Venice in Peril, a group seeking to preserve the city, said, ''There is no parallel with the Pink Floyd concert as the numbers for Elton John will be strictly controlled, but there is some concern about the weight of the open-air theater and the people on the square as there is a complex system of drains underneath it.'' Maurizio Zanetto, secretary of the Venetian branch of the heritage organization Italia Nostra, said, ''We will do what we can to lobby against the Elton John concerts and raise awareness of the potential damage that will be done to St. Mark's Square.'' But Maurizio Calligaro, chief of staff for the mayor of Venice, noted that a crowd of 5,000 -- the size to which each concert will be limited -- pales beside the 35,000 people who gather in the square on New Year's Eve. Tickets are already on sale online for the concerts, though the city, which will be paid about 200,000 Euros ($268,730) for the use of the square, is not expected to give its permission for the events until next week. Gary Farrow, a spokesman for Elton John, said the singer ''looks forward to a beautiful and harmonious event in the city.'' Art and Abbatoirs Some neighbors of the artist Damien Hirst in the Cotswolds, in central England, are upset over plans to include an ''abattoir rail'' at one of his studios, The Guardian reported on Thursday. The rail could be used to move animal carcasses before they are suspended in formaldehyde, a technique Mr. Hirst, below, made famous through works like ''Mother and Child Divided,'' a cow and a calf each cut in half and displayed in a tank of the preservative. A petition has been started and placards posted around the studio, an old manufacturing plant. Vicky Radwell, whose home overlooks the studio, pronounced herself ''gobsmacked'' by the news. ''Most people around here are quite horrified that there are going to be dead animals there,'' she said ''Dead animals in art is just outrageous. It's not beautiful, is it?'' A spokeswoman for Mr. Hirst said: ''This is nothing to do with an abattoir. It is an area where we will be using formaldehyde. That has been approved and we have planning permission for it. We never have -- and never would -- need an abattoir.'' Who's the Wild One? The founder of the company that produces the ''Girls Gone Wild'' video series has defied a federal judge, refusing to surrender to United States marshals on a contempt citation, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Judge Richard Smoak of United States District Court ordered the company's founder, Joseph R. Francis, into custody after settlement negotiations stalled in a lawsuit brought by seven women who were minors when Mr. Francis' company, Mantra Films, videotaped them at the beach in Panama City, Fla. Mr. Francis, 34, who makes an estimated $29 million a year through the videos of girls exposing their breasts, drew the contempt order on Wednesday after lawyers for the women said Mr. Francis had threatened them during negotiations. ''This judge has gone as far as to call me the devil and an evildoer,'' Mr. Francis said on Thursday. ''It is a case of a judge gone wild.'' Mr. Francis's lawyers have appealed the order, which would send him to jail.

HOWITT--Nathan G., D.D.S., at the age of 96, passed away peacefully on April 3, 2007, at his home in Pompano Beach Florida. He was a distinguished Oral Surgeon and former president of the Bronx County Dental Society and former director of the Bronx Lebanon Dental Clinic. He will be sorely missed by his beloved wife Florence, his two loving daughters, Valerie and Karen, his three granddaughters and five greatgrandchildren.

The Food and Drug Administration yesterday ordered drug companies to stop making and selling anti-nausea suppositories containing a drug that the agency said did not work when used in that form. The move was part of a campaign by the agency to re-evaluate drugs approved before 1962, the year drug makers had to start proving that their products worked. Before 1962, they had to prove only that they did no harm.

Adored grandfather of Rebecca, David and his wife Phoenix, and Elizabeth. Dear brother of the late Max. Service Sunday 11:30 am at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street at Amsterdam Avenue.

Nicola Bulgari entered his Manhattan office as if he owned it, which, of course, as the grandson of Sotirio Bulgari, the great Roman jeweler, he did. In the big room, with windows overlooking Tiffany and Vuitton, almost everything looked fairly old, at least since the last generation, including the portrait of his father leaning against the wall, still unhung. Only a new white sofa stuck out. It did not match his sensibility. ''I'm getting a dark-green leather one,'' he said, taking his place behind the desk and calling out for colored jewels, for new collections, to show off. Bring more and then more again, he commanded a young woman who had already brought several trays. One diamond ring, with a stone as sparkling as an Arctic morning, was admired. ''Two and a half million dollars,'' he said proudly.

LEVINE--Joshua, a resident of Rye, NY, and Palm Beach, FL, died April 6, 2007, at age 90. Born May 24, 1916, in New York City to Jack and Lillian Levine. Josh served in the U.S. Army during World War II, beginning as a Private and discharged as a Captain. In the European Theater of Operations, he investigated claims against the U.S. by Europeans who suffered noncombat damage. Josh graduated from CCNY and NYU School of Law, where he served as President of the student body Pre-Bar Association. Mr. Levine was formerly the managing partner of Davis & Gilbert, where he spent his entire legal career, starting as a law clerk in 1936. He represented many of his firm's leading clients, including Doyle, Dane Bernbach, Benton & Bowles, Ogilvy & Mather, Weight Watchers International, Muzak, and Best Foods. He successfully lobbied the enactment of legislation permitting the manufacture and sale of yellow margarine. Josh handled a broad range of advertising, corporate and securities law problems and engaged in negotiating and consummating the acquisition of advertising agencies worldwide. He was one of six founders of Beth Emeth Synagogue in Larchmont and served as President. He was active in, and was honored by, UJA. He was an avid fisherman and raconteur. Josh was a righteous man, always maintaining the highest morals. A loving husband, father and Poppy, he touched all who knew him. Survived by his wife, Selene, daughters Judi Levine (Bernie Bornstein), Beth Levine (Henry Abarbanel), and Linda (Eric) Spellman, grandchildren Brett, Sara, Lindsey and Matthew, and brother, Harold. Funeral service Sunday, 11:30 am, Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck, 914381-1809; followed by interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Contributions to UJA or Joshua Levine Scholarship Fund (1938), NYU School of Law, 161 Avenue of the Americans, NY, NY 10013.

A brief article in the Westchester section this weekend about the shutdown of the Indian Point 3 reactor on Tuesday was printed before a fire yesterday forced the plant to close again. An article on B3 today reports on the latest developments.

The United States reached a free trade agreement with South Korea, its biggest since the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico. The deal, if ratified by Congress, means cheaper Hyundai and Kia cars for American consumers; Washington agreed to lift 2.5 percent tariffs on South Korean cars. The deal will also remove South Korea's 8 percent import duty on cars and phase out heavier tariffs on beef and oranges, helping American car companies, ranchers and farmers expand in South Korea, where consumers are developing a taste for foreign goods.

Mr. Zell, the Chicago real estate mogul, managed to win control of the Tribune Company this week in an $8.2 billion deal in which he is to invest only $315 million. The deal, which carries a debt of almost $13 billion, seems far from concluded, however. It left a loophole for others to offer more money than Mr. Zell's $34 a share. Breaking the deal with Mr. Zell would cost a relatively low $25 million.

To the Editor: Re ''3,400 Layoffs Send a Message to Millions,'' by David Leonhardt (Economix column, April 4), detailing how corporations like Circuit City are trying to do away with ''expensive'' older workers:

A brief article in the Westchester section this weekend about the shutdown of the Indian Point 3 reactor on Tuesday was printed before a fire yesterday forced the plant to close again. An article on B3 today reports on the latest developments.

The Nets have been inching toward solidifying a playoff spot, and they have become secure enough with themselves to withstand setbacks. By that standard, Friday night's brutal 105-74 loss to the Chicago Bulls at the United Center did not leave them floored. It was the Nets' most lopsided loss since they fell to the Orlando Magic by 33 points on Feb. 2, their worst loss of the season.

CBS breezed to an easy victory on Thursday night as ''CSI,'' now in its seventh season, garnered the night's highest ratings and 21.5 million total viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. A repeat of ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' in that hour drew 8.4 million viewers. CBS's ''Shark'' at 10 earned 15.3 million viewers, a new record and considerably better than the No. 2 show in the time slot, ABC's ''October Road'' (7.7 million). Fox and ABC shared second place for the night. ABC posted a slight edge in total viewers, while Fox fared better among adults 18 to 49. The Fox quiz show ''Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?'' (10.2 million) finished second at 8 behind CBS's ''Survivor: Fiji'' (13.3 million). NBC was fourth over all with a lineup of 40-minute ''supersized'' episodes of ''The Office'' at 8 (6.7 million), ''30 Rock'' at 8:40 (5.2 million) and ''Scrubs'' at 9:20 (5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

LEE--Jeremy S., 68, of New Canaan, CT, formerly of West Roxbury, MA, died suddenly on April 4th. Former President of TBWA Health. Beloved husband of Jane O'Connell Lee and loving father of Marcia Lee Taylor. Funeral from the George F. Doherty & Sons Funeral Home, 477 Washington St., Wellesley, MA on Tuesday at 10:00 am. Funeral mass in St. Pauls Church, Wellesley, MA at 11:00 am. Relatives and friends kindly invited. Visiting hours on Monday 5-8 pm. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Wellesley, MA. Donations in his memory may be made to the ALS Association, Greater New York Chapter, 116 John St, Suite 1304, New York, NY 10038. Online guestbook at www.gfdoherty.com.

An article on Thursday about a new push to confront racial imbalance in the Greenwich, Conn., public schools misstated the content of fullpage advertisements placed recently in local newspapers by a group calling itself Concerned Citizens of Greenwich. The ads raised concerns about a proposal to spend $23 million rebuilding Glenville School, and offered a broader critique of a new task force considering topics including racial balance and redistricting. The ads did not ask that neighborhood schools ''not be made to suffer in the rush to bolster other schools.''
To the Editor: Re ''The Rich Are More Oblivious Than You and Me'' (Op-Ed, April 4):

On April 15, when the Yankees play in Oakland, Mariano Rivera may not be the only Yankee wearing No. 42. Rivera is currently the only major leaguer wearing No. 42, which was retired throughout the majors in 1997 to honor Jackie Robinson, who wore it while breaking baseball's color line for the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947. All players who were wearing 42 at the time it was retired were allowed to continue wearing it.

SILBER--Pauline R, ''Nafla Ateret Rosheinu'' Most devoted wife of the late Joseph F. Beloved mother of William L, Joy, and Jinny Pinsky. Loving mother-in-law of Lillian Silber and Jerry Pinsky. Adoring and adored grandmother and great-grandmother. She leaves a tremendous void and will be sorely missed. Shiva begins after Pesach.
The ''S.& P. 100 Stocks'' chart in Business Day yesterday was published in error. A corrected chart appears on Page C7.

After failing to line up new financing, New Century Financial became the largest mortgage company to file for bankruptcy protection since the market for loans to people with weak, or subprime, credit collapsed this year. In the next 45 days, the company plans to auction its three principal assets: its mortgage lending business, its servicing platform and its loan portfolio. It is unclear, however, how much the company will make from the sales since many other lenders are also up for sale.

INTERNATIONAL A1-7 Emissions Already Shaping World Climate, Panel Says The earth's climate and ecosystems are already being shaped by greenhouse gases, the world's leading scientific panel on climate change said. While limits on emissions could lower long-term risks, it said, vulnerable regions must adjust promptly to shifting weather patterns and coastal hazards. A1 Britons Describe Iran Captivity Six of the 15 British marines and sailors who arrived home after being held in Iran said days of psychological pressure extracted ''confessions'' from some of the captives that they strayed into Iranian waters. They said they were separated, put in pajamas and placed in cells. A1 Zambia to Exhaust U.N. Rations Within weeks, rations provided by the United Nations World Food Program will run out for 500,000 Zambian paupers, including thousands of people wasted by AIDS who are being treated with American-financed drugs that make them hungrier as they grow healthier. A1 Chlorine Truck Bomb in Iraq A suicide truck bomb loaded with chlorine gas exploded in Ramadi, killing as many as 30 people, many of them children, a security official said. The blast was at least the sixth chlorine bomb detonated in Anbar Province since late January. A6 Gandhi Heir Fights for Base Rahul Gandhi, the 36-year-old heir apparent to India's ruling political dynasty, is facing his first test of political mettle: whether he can save his Congress Party from becoming irrelevant in Uttar Pradesh, India's most populous state and the Nehru-Gandhi family's home base. A3 NATIONAL A8-11 Top Aide to Gonzales Announces Resignation A top aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, Monica Goodling, resigned, another casualty of the political storm that has rocked the Justice Department since the firings of eight United States attorneys. A1 Charity Act Raises Questions One of Japan's richest real estate developers, Genshiro Kawamoto, is making good on a plan to open eight houses he owns in one of Honolulu's most exclusive communities to poor families of Native Hawaiian descent. But while his act of charity has made headlines around the world, it has also raised plenty of questions. A8 A Faster 'Road Home'? Louisiana homeowners may get faster access to rebuilding grants after a surprise ruling from Washington that is forcing the state to change its slow-moving $7.5 billion ''Road Home'' program to repair houses damaged or destroyed by the 2005 hurricanes. A8 Many Unhappy With School Law As the president and some Democrats push to renew the No Child Left Behind law, discontent with it in many states is threatening to undermine the effort in both parties. A10 California Psychiatrist Arrested A prominent California child psychiatrist who had treated four generations of troubled youth and preached sex education on public television was arrested, accused of sexually abusing three of his charges. A8 Orders to Stop Sale of Drug The Food and Drug Administration ordered drug companies to stop selling anti-nausea suppositories containing a drug that they said does not work when used in that form. A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Fourth Man Arrested In String of Bank Robberies A fourth man was arrested in connection with a string of recent bank robberies in New Jersey, one day after an F.B.I. agent was killed, apparently by another agent, while following the suspects, the authorities said. The charges filed against three of the men may be amended to include murder, officials said. An article on Wednesday about bald eagle hatchings in the wild of Santa Catalina Island misstated the amount of money allocated for eagle restoration in the Channel Islands under a settlement between the federal government and Montrose Chemical Corporation, the company chiefly responsible for DDT pollution in the islands. It is $6.2 million -- not $30 million, which is the amount for restoration of all animals harmed by DDT.

YOUNG--Andrew, died tragically on April 4, 2007. Andrew's unique combination of heart and head and his love of life made him a successful restauranteur and hotelier, on land and at sea, and endeared him to family and friends. He was a beloved husband, brother, uncle and cousin and he will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held at the Weinstein Mortuary 640 Farmington Ave, Hartford, CT, at 11am Sunday, April 8. The Young, Dubroff, Michel, Weil and Herf families invite you to join them in remembering Andrew.

The Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., which is facing a $2.8 million shortfall at the end of its season, is continuing its efforts to stay afloat. About $300,000 in donations collected over the past few weeks will keep the theater running and allow the production of ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers,'' above, to begin on Wednesday as scheduled, said Kenneth Thorn, the chairman of the theater's board of trustees. The board is working to secure a bank loan that would cover the rest of the season, Mr. Thorn said, though it is continuing to solicit contributions to lower the amount needed. The Paper Mill will hold a rally on Monday at the theater, with several state officials and Broadway performers expected to attend. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

LERNER--Mimi. The New York City Opera deeply mourns the passing of mezzo-soprano Mimi Lerner after a long and valiant struggle with cancer. We fondly recall her rich, warm voice and memorable performances here in operas including Alcina, Norma, and Central Park; and just as vividly recollect her joie de vivre, generosity, sense of humor, and radiant smile. She shared those gifts with opera companies worldwide and, in recent years, with Pittsburgh's CarnegieMellon University as chair of its voice department; and Rodef Shalom Congregation as cantorial soloist and music director. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband Martin, her son Daniel, and her scores of friends worldwide. She will truly be missed. Paul Kellogg General and Artistic Director

ELEER - DAVIDSON--Erika Dagmar, of Manhattan, former photographer of MET Opera News & Guild, died on March 21, 2007. Memorial service: 6:30pm, April 23, 2007, at John Barrett & Son Funeral Home, 424 W. 51st St., NY, NY.

In a season of limited golf swings and loads of back pain, Fred Couples arrived this week at Augusta National Golf Club seeking a few good golf shots and the continuation of a Masters streak. By sundown Friday, he had achieved both. Couples, the 1992 champion, shot a four-over-par 76 to make his 23rd consecutive cut at the Masters, tying the record held by Gary Player.

An article in The Arts on Thursday about CNN's new anchor team for its program ''American Morning'' misspelled the given name of one anchor. She is Kiran Chetry, not Kieran. The article also misstated the schedule for a new program with Soledad O'Brien, one of the morning anchors who is being replaced. The program, ''CNN: Special Investigations Unit,'' will be shown weekly, not occasionally.

Ever since 1952, when a Republican senator, Arthur H. Vandenberg, coined the phrase, it has been said that in American foreign affairs, politics should stop at the water's edge. Now, with President Bush confronting an opposition party in control of Congress, that fiction is becoming harder to maintain. With a final stop in Lisbon on Friday, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi headed home to a Washington that is still ringing with complaints from senior Bush officials that her stop in Damascus to visit with Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president, bolstered the image of Syria at a time when United States policy is to isolate it.

The Tracinda Corporation, the investment arm of Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor, bid $4.5 billion in cash for the Chrysler Group, 12 years to the month after an earlier attempt by Mr. Kerkorian to buy the company, which was acquired eventually by Daimler-Benz of Germany. Mr. Kerkorian joins three other bidders for Chrysler.

Job Growth Surged and Wages Rose in March Wages climbed and job growth rose last month by the largest numbers this year, the Labor Department said, as strong consumer spending led to hiring in restaurants, bars, department stores and educational services. The unemployment rate fell to 4.4 percent from 4.5 percent. Every team in the majors has had a starter pitch five innings at least once this season. Every team, that is, except the Yankees. The season, of course, is only three games old. And the man who is arguably the most important pitcher in the organization, Phil Hughes, had a strong debut at Class AAA Scranton last night -- five innings, two hits, two runs and six strikeouts.

The union representing East Coast dockworkers has been hemorrhaging assets and members in the past two years, according to a new financial report. Yet the union's president was paid twice as much as several labor leaders who head unions more than 30 times larger. The union, the International Longshoremen's Association, paid its president, John Bowers, $587,078 last year, according to the annual report that the union submitted to the federal government late last month. That made him one of the nation's highest-paid union officials. Mr. Bowers's son John Jr., a union vice president, was paid $292,440 last year, the report said.

Investors have long complained that too many top executives walk away with enormous paychecks for average performance, or worse. Analysts often point the finger at employment and severance contracts, which can guarantee big salaries and bonuses long before on-the-job performance can be assessed and call for additional payments if the executive is ousted. Companies argue that this is necessary to attract and motivate top talent, and is the price they pay to induce executives to sign noncompete agreements.
There have been several groundbreakings for a Second Avenue subway in New York. William Neuman revisits some of the failed starts as the city prepares to break ground again.

The political polling season is already upon us (a bit prematurely, but everything is ahead of itself these days), and polls taken in the past couple of weeks reveal a pattern that commentators are busy explaining. When the question asked is, which party do you trust to do a better job with the economy, the war, global warming, the environment, education, the deficit, immigration, reputation abroad, the administration of justice, the rebuilding of New Orleans?, the Democratic party wins - and in some categories by impressive margins. The same polls show that 60 to 70 percent of the American people believe that the country is heading in the wrong direction, and there is no doubt that President Bush's rating numbers are also headed in the wrong direction. Why then do Hillary Clinton, John Edwards and Barack Obama consistently lose to Rudy Giuliani and John McCain in head-to-head matchups? (The three Democrats do outpoll Mitt Romney, but who wouldn't?)The answer usually given is that it's early. Two years out voters are reacting to personalities, or rather, to their perception of personalities. When things get more serious, and the candidates are put under the lens of relentless scrutiny and have to answer hard questions about hard issues, the ratings, we are told, will turn less on personality and more on policy, and the numbers will change.

When I was growing up, college was presented to me not as an option, but as an absolute must. I knew that in August of 2004, after I graduated from high school, I would pack my suitcases and journey to whichever college I chose. That turned out to be a small private school named Dillard University, in New Orleans, La. The Dillard recruiters had come to a college fair and captured my attention. The university's small size, community orientation and religious affiliation had intrigued me.

Politics is all about opportunity and fashion is all about symbols, and when the two elements meet, as they did last week in Iran, you have a ground for propaganda. That's what a number of newspapers and blogs saw in photos of the 15 released British seamen in their grimly fitting, Tehran-issued suits. Essentially, people connected the ugliness of the three-button suits to an ugly purpose: humiliating the British government. A serviceman without uniform or insignia is powerless. And the suits are the opposite of the smartly tapering Savile Row kind, perhaps a statement in itself. Inevitably, some people just saw the horrible sartorial gaffs; one reader of the Guardian, in London, pointed out that men should never button their jackets over a vest and "never, ever" button the top button of the jacket.

A system error in ESPN.com’s Fantasy Baseball League has disrupted live scoring and roster moves since Tuesday. “We’re fantasy players ourselves, and we recognize that it is not acceptable for our players to have anything short of a great experience,” an ESPN.com spokesman, Paul Melvin, said in a written statement. “We also recognize that getting every problem resolved is what will ultimately satisfy our players.” In 2005, ESPN.com was forced to apologize to fans for traffic problems with its Fantasy Football League. ESPN.com would not disclose how many users play fantasy games through its Web site, and would not say how many users have been affected by the most recent problem.

An article last Sunday about a class-action lawsuit over mortgage lending practices referred incorrectly to the loan-to-value ratio that is considered prudent for mortgages. It is a maximum of 80 percent, not a minimum of 80 percent. (The loan-to-value ratio is a measure of risk that compares the size of the total loan on a property to the underlying collateral.).

9 P.M. (22 , 26) THE WIND IN THE WILLOWS He may be the world’s most exasperating amphibian. But Mr. Toad, the exuberant spendthrift (played by the British comedian Matt Lucas, above) with a fondness for boats, cars and snazzy attire who is at the center of this new “Masterpiece Theater” adaptation of the Kenneth Grahame children’s classic, has friends to spare. They include the stern Badger (Bob Hoskins), the easygoing Ratty (Mark Gattis) and the ever-loyal Mole (Lee Ingleby). Anna Maxwell Martin brings up the rear as the Jailor’s Daughter, who befriends Toad after his shenanigans land him in prison, and Imelda Staunton is the Barge Lady, who almost outwits the clever green schemer after his prison break. But who can blame the group for their misadventures? As Ratty says to Mole as they row dreamily down the stream, “Believe me, my young friend, there is nothing — absolutely nothing — half so much worth doing as simply messing about in boats.”.

A review on March 18 about “The First Man-Made Man: The Story of Two Sex Changes, One Love Affair, and a Twentieth-Century Medical Revolution,” by Pagan Kennedy, refers incorrectly to Michael Dillon, the main subject of the book, who was born a woman. Dillon’s sex change is considered the first of the modern era because of its surgical sophistication and its early use of testosterone, starting in 1938. But he was not “the first person on record to undergo surgery to change his gender.” (Records of surgery to alter sexual characteristics go back to ancient times.).

An article and a picture caption last Sunday about the Getty Conservation Institute's effort to document all the ways photographs have been developed over the years misidentified an instrument used to analyze the chemical makeup of old prints. It is an X-ray fluorescence spectrometer, not an infrared spectrometer. (The infrared instrument is also used in such work.)

IT is a season of renewal for Christians and Jews as they commemorate momentous events in their histories: for Christians, the resurrection of Jesus; for Jews, the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from slavery in Egypt. As Jews began celebrating the eight days of Passover at sundown last Monday, Christians observed the final, most solemn days of Lent in preparation for Easter services this weekend. Here are a handful of stories about different faith communities around the region. Standing tall behind mahogany desks, their sheet music splayed before them, the members of the children's choir of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield, Conn., looked as serious as the music they were about to sing.
RICKS--Emily, age 101. Funeral Services 11:00am, Monday, April 9, 2007, at AME Mother Zion Church, 140 W. 137th Street, Harlem, NY. Interment Trinity Cemetery, 155th St. at Broadway.

EVERY morning, as I climb the stairs and trudge down the hall to my office, I pass over a section of floor that gives a noticeable groan. In former years, I made a mental note to one day pry up the offending plank and pad it with another layer of butcher paper. I also conceded this probably would come after about 200 other pressing chores. The beauty of this task deferred is that I've grown accustomed to the sound. In fact, I now regard it as a greeting from an old friend.

To the Editor: Patrick Garbiras, the homeless man profiled in ''Marking Time, Making Do'' (April 1), may be in a desperate situation, but he is not without hope. There are agencies that can assist him with his Social Security issues.

A report in The Week column last Sunday about the replacement of faded state road signs misstated the completion date for the project. Statewide, it is scheduled to be completed by early 2008, not by Memorial Day this year. Completion by Memorial Day is expected only in Monmouth and Ocean Counties. Because of an editing error, the report also misstated the signs' longevity. They have a seven-year warranty, not a seven-year life span.

IT is a season of renewal for Christians and Jews as they commemorate momentous events in their histories: for Christians, the resurrection of Jesus; for Jews, the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from slavery in Egypt. As Jews began celebrating the eight days of Passover at sundown last Monday, Christians observed the final, most solemn days of Lent in preparation for Easter services this weekend. Here are a handful of stories about different faith communities around the region. Sunday school was under way at the Segunda Iglesia Pentecostal Juan 3:16, a squat, unassuming group of buildings that make up one of the oldest Spanish churches in Port Chester, N.Y. In one of the small, interlocking rooms, Eva Manani led her class through the week's lesson. ''Jesús es bueno, sí?'' she asked. The 22 boys and girls, all 5 to 7 years old, called back, ''Sí!''

These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

Gordon Ramsay, the celebrity chef known for such food programs as ''Hell's Kitchen'' in the United States and ''The F-Word'' in Britain, has opened yet another eating establishment in a city already overpopulated with dining rooms bearing his brand. Adding to his roster of nine other London restaurants -- including one at Claridge's and another in the Savoy -- not to mention his outposts in New York, Dubai and Tokyo, Mr. Ramsay last month opened an upscale pub (above) on the banks of the Thames in the East End. It is called the Narrow, and the menu features such dishes as potted Cromer crab and Gloucester pig cheeks with bashed neeps. Guests who don't fancy a pint of beer can always try the pub's original cocktails--though the Wallpaper (Cachaça, passion fruit, vanilla gomme and a touch of chili) sounds more like what the river just washed up than a tasty cocktail. What's next for Mr. Ramsay? Later this year he plans to open yet another ''gastropub,'' the Warrington, in the Maida Vale section of London.

TWO of the dresser drawers in my 12-year-old daughter's room were broken. It was not the drawers' fault, nor Annie's. It was time. The top of the waist-high dresser had served as a changing table for our four children, and our oldest is now a college freshman. If that baby boy lay on that dresser today, his size 12 feet would scrape the floor. So we threw out the dresser, which led to a reorganization of Annie's clothes, which somehow turned into a major revamping of Annie's room that took most of the weekend. As Annie noted about two hours in, ''This turned out to be an official room-cleaning project, didn't it, Dad?''

To the Editor: I was irritated, but not surprised, when I read about the reaction that residents of Hillcrest, Queens, were having to the proposal of a rehabilitation and detoxification center residing in their neighborhood (''No Welcome Wagon for a Rehab Center,'' April 1). Yet again, the resentment is evident when people are confronted with the unfamiliar, and it is clearly time for New Yorkers to become familiar with current substance abuse and alcohol treatment.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''As Cheerleaders Soar Higher, So Do the Risks,'' March 31: I am 16 years old and a former cheerleader. I have been a cheerleading coach for the past two years. I was glad to see the article because not many people understand how dangerous cheerleading is, and most people don't even consider it a sport.

BOYER--Renee S. In memory of my mother, who died suddenly at Lenox Hill Hospital on April 3rd, 2006. Remembered as a gifted student and piano player, loving daughter and mother, and always as an animal lover, caring for many animals during her lifetime in Murray Hill. Rest in peace, you are dearly missed.

A brief report in the Suits column on March 25, about the inaugural flight of the superjumbo A380 to Kennedy International Airport, misstated the plane's maximum weight on takeoff. It is more than 1.2 million pounds, not 1.3 million tons.

Urban Safari Shorts are back -- in a small, small way. And while they seem to be getting teenier on the bottom, this spring you'll find something up top, too. No longer just for painters, safari guides and Charlie's Angels, one-piece jumpsuits are fast becoming city staples. The sexy onesie for grown-ups has its perks (getting dressed is a snap) but the trend can be tricky to pull off. ''They're great for going from daytime to clubbing, but you've got to have the body,'' said Maggie Wachsberger, whose Los Angeles boutique Malgosia, (323) 782-9188, can't keep Serfontaine's disco-inspired jean jumpsuit ($255) in stock. Pair it with stilettos and Pilates-toned legs and you've got a look. AUDREY DAVIDOW

A few hedges and some gravel will soon turn an empty lot next to a 7-Eleven in the Village of Southampton into a site where day laborers can wait for work. ''It's not a designated hiring site,'' said Mayor Mark Epley, who announced the plan on March 30. ''We're not changing the use of this lot, but trying to get it better organized and make it safer when trucks pull over to hire the workers.''

COULD it be that the mere presence of an English accent is enough to bewitch American audiences into overrating performances by British actors? That's the cheeky suggestion made recently by the British actor, novelist, critic and all-around cultural Renaissance guy Stephen Fry. ''I shouldn't be saying this -- high treason really -- but I sometimes wonder if Americans aren't fooled by our accent into detecting a brilliance that may not really be there,'' he told the British magazine Radio Times. ''I mean, would they notice if Jeremy Irons or Judi Dench gave a bad performance? Not that those two paragons ever would, but it's worth considering.'' Blimey, that's food for thought, as is this: ''When American TV and movies call for a twist of limey in their cocktail, it's usually a character they're after -- supervillain, emotionally constipated academic, effete eccentric, that kind of thing.'' He may be on to something there. After all, didn't the creators of the three-part ''Die Hard'' franchise twice reach out for Britons -- Mr. Irons and Alan Rickman -- to play foils both evil and classy enough to square off against Bruce Willis?

The debate goes to the core of a wounded nation's effort to reconcile with its painful past. 1 American fighter jets carried out an airstrike against Shiite militiamen in the Iraqi city of Diwaniya as battles continued in some neighborhoods there for the second straight day, American and Iraqi officials said. 10 Crackdown in Zimbabwe In response to the latest surge of political unrest in Zimbabwe, scores, perhaps hundreds, of people critical of President Robert G. Mugabe's rule are being cornered on sidewalks, hauled to jails or abducted from their homes in night raids and savagely beaten. 14 Cease-Fire Eroding in Gaza Israeli Army helicopters fired at Palestinian militants in the northern Gaza Strip, killing one, the military said. It was the third Israeli military strike in Gaza in 10 days, indicating a further erosion of the cease-fire that was declared in November. 6 Rift Over U.N. War Trial The war crimes trial for an ethnic Albanian former guerrilla commander who was briefly Kosovo's prime minister has created a stark divide between the case's prosecutors and diplomats from the United Nations and Western governments, who are usually the U.N. tribunal's biggest supporters. 12 NATIONAL 16-23 Lessons of Heart Disease Medical research has revealed enough about the causes and prevention of heart attacks that they could be nearly eliminated. The Mets have tentative plans to place replica bases in the parking lot of their new ballpark, Citi Field, to commemorate the site of the infield at Shea Stadium. The more immediate concern to the team's fans may be finding a parking spot to watch José Reyes and his teammates run around the real bases this season. Sandra Van Meek, the Mets' director for market development, said that stadium construction would make 2,100 spaces unavailable in the east parking lot for this season, including tomorrow's home opener against Philadelphia.

THORSON--William L., aged 69, a retired IBM executive of Chappaqua, NY died on Sunday, April 1, 2007 after a long courageous struggle with Parkinson's Disease. He served in the US Army and joined IBM where he held positions in marketing. He devoted himself to raising funds for research on Parkinson's Disease and supporting those with the disease. He is survived by his wife Susan, daughter Jennifer and brother Robert. A memorial service will be held at Scarborough Presbyterian Church, Route 9, Scarborough, NY on April 14 at 11:00 am. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to The Parkinson's Unity Walk. 1-866-789-9255 www.unitywalk.org

To the Editor: It is an unfortunate omission to not include the work of Jamie Foxx in Caryn James's ''Out on the Tightrope, Where Comics Try Acting'' [March 25]. Mr. Foxx not only emerged as a stand-up comedian (''Def Comedy Jam''), but he also appeared in the same comic ensemble television show (''In Living Color'') that Jim Carrey did. Further, in 2005 Mr. Foxx won the best actor Oscar for his role in ''Ray'' and was nominated for best supporting actor for ''Collateral.'' Bill Stephney Randolph, N.J.

An article last Sunday comparing the independence of today's United States attorneys with that of past federal prosecutors misstated the middle initial of a law professor at the New York University School of Law who commented on the danger of mixing politics and enforcement. He is Stephen M. Gillers, not Stephen J.

Richard R. Sarles has been at New Jersey Transit for nearly five years, working on expanding and creating light rail service in South Jersey, Newark and Hudson County. Now he will be running the entire agency. After a three-month national search, New Jersey Transit announced that it had tapped Mr. Sarles to serve as its executive director. He succeeds George D. Warrington, who served five years and announced his retirement in January.

PAU GASOL The Memphis forward, speaking about his Grizzlies (19-59), who will probably finish with the worst record in the league after three seasons of 45-plus wins.

Nancy Silverton is rebelling a little later in life than most. At 52, the Los Angeles chef, who translated her training at LenÃ$(4$)tre into a widely respected career as a pastry chef, cook and business owner, has really gotten into prepared foods. ''I'd forgotten how good V8 juice tastes!'' said Silverton, who spent a year combing the aisles of supermarkets and specialty stores in search of kitchen catalysts for her seventh cookbook, ''A Twist of the Wrist: Quick Flavorful Meals With Ingredients From Jars, Cans, Bags and Boxes'' (Knopf). ''I'm waiting to get the phone call from Alice ... ,'' she said of her mentor, the world-renowned food purist Alice Waters.

EVERY morning, as I climb the stairs and trudge down the hall to my office, I pass over a section of floor that gives a noticeable groan. In former years, I made a mental note to one day pry up the offending plank and pad it with another layer of butcher paper. I also conceded this probably would come after about 200 other pressing chores. The beauty of this task deferred is that I've grown accustomed to the sound. In fact, I now regard it as a greeting from an old friend.

Suprema Specialties Inc., of Paterson, N.J., appeared to be doing remarkably well selling all-natural Italian cheeses. The company's stock (its Nasdaq listing was CHEZ) rose when it reported strong sales results from July 2000 to January 2002. But $400 million in sales were phony, and a federal jury last week convicted two of the company's top executives -- Mark Cocchiola, 51, of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and Steven Venechanos, 48, of New Milford, N.J. -- of 38 counts, including conspiracy and bank, mail and wire fraud.

To the Editor: I admired Clive James's review (March 25) of the new Leni Riefenstahl biographies very much, but I wondered why James, almost throughout the essay, referred to Riefenstahl by her first name. The men he discusses -- Hitler, Goebbels, Julius Streicher, Jesse Owens -- are all called by their last names, but Riefenstahl is ''Leni.'' This often happens with female artists, and it always carries a note of condescension. (Would I, in this letter, speak of James as ''Clive''?) The curious thing is that in his recent book, ''Cultural Amnesia,'' James nowhere places himself on a first-name basis with his female subjects. Why the reversion to the double standard with Riefenstahl? And do the editors of the Book Review think it's O.K. to treat men and women differently in this regard?

EIZENSTAT--Sylvia. We extend our deepest sympathy to Stu and Fran Eizenstat and their family on the passing of Stu's mother, Sylvia, on April 5th. She passed away at 93 after a full and happy life. She was a source of unending love and inspiration for her closely knit family and friends. Graveside services were in Atlanta, and Shiva will continue at the Eizenstat home in Chevy Chase, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Sunday nights. Contributions may be made to the Eizenstat Memorial Lecture Fund, Ahavath Achim Synagogue, 600 Peachtree Battle Ave., NW, Atlanta 30327. Hilary and Orin, Jane and Ralph, Alice and David, Bonnie and Simon, Margo and Joe

One important item that hit the cutting room floor recently when New York lawmakers produced a new state budget was the Bigger, Better Bottle Bill. This bill -- known as the BBBB in Albany -- would make one of the state's best environmental laws even better. A bill like the BBBB that cuts down on litter, encourages recycling, saves natural resources and provides funds to help the environment should be an easy step for New York's legislators and Gov. Eliot Spitzer. Overall, New York's environment did reasonably well in Mr. Spitzer's first budget. The previous administration had severely cut back on the number of experts who are supposed to protect and monitor the state's air, land and water. The new budget adds more than 100 scientists, engineers and enforcement officials to the Department of Environmental Conservation, including a badly-needed new office of climate change. And the Senate approved Assemblyman Alexander Grannis of New York City to be the new environmental commissioner despite a misguided campaign by the gun lobby.

IT is a season of renewal for Christians and Jews as they commemorate momentous events in their histories: for Christians, the resurrection of Jesus; for Jews, the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from slavery in Egypt. As Jews began celebrating the eight days of Passover at sundown last Monday, Christians observed the final, most solemn days of Lent in preparation for Easter services this weekend. Here are a handful of stories about different faith communities around the region. To accommodate the children, the Seder last Monday night in the basement recreation room of the Bach Jewish Center in Long Beach, N.Y., began with a sensible nosh: some cucumber salad, some chicken fingers, broccoli and enough soda and water to hydrate the bleachers at Yankee Stadium.

Of all the blessings of the new church -- the airy sanctuary under the white-pine planked dome, the bronze statuary, the 400 parking spots -- perhaps the most welcome were the green-cushioned kneelers in each pew.

To the Editor: Both David Orr's apt critique of The New Yorker (''Annals of Poetry,'' March 11) and Dana Goodyear's excellent New Yorker article about Poetry magazine would have us believe that the battle for poetry's survival is being waged in the pages of magazines with, respectively, millions of subscribers or millions of dollars in Eli Lilly stock. This is not true. With few exceptions, the best contemporary poetry is being published by hundreds of small presses and little magazines across the country. To name just a few: Ugly Duckling Presse and Circumference in New York, Flood Editions and LVNG in Chicago, and Atelos and Hambone in the Bay Area. Readers who explore these venues will find that poetry is alive and well. Indeed, they'll find the spirit (and the financial uncertainty) of Ezra Pound's collaboration with Poetry magazine's founder, Harriet Monroe.

To the Editor: Re ''A Lyrical Approach to a Subject That Shocks'' [April 1]: It's finally occurred to me that Dennis Lim's article on the film ''Zoo'' isn't a satirical parody. This will probably brand me as a hopeless square but here goes: There isn't any ''lyrical'' side to the subject of bestiality. Chip Mergott Doylestown, Pa.

To the Editor: It's not surprising that Howard Blum sees national implications in the inconveniences that he is forced to suffer. He is, after all, a contributing editor at Vanity Fair who lives in Connecticut and feels compelled to tell us, twice, that he wears a cashmere topcoat.

IN January, a 13-year-old wielding what looked like a .38-caliber revolver tried to rob a Chinese restaurant in Mount Vernon, N.Y., until workers wrested the gun from him. In February, a 16-year-old boy in Clifton, N.J., accompanied by a friend, stuck what appeared to be a .45-caliber handgun in a man's chest and stole his cocker spaniel.

To the Editor: Re ''Running for Dollars'' (editorial, April 5): What if nobody gave? The problem with the American political system is that it is not controlled by the voters and has not been for many years. Major corporations, the Republican and Democratic National Committees and the media dictate who the nominees will be, and to a large degree, who our next president will be.

IT is a season of renewal for Christians and Jews as they commemorate momentous events in their histories: for Christians, the resurrection of Jesus; for Jews, the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from slavery in Egypt. As Jews began celebrating the eight days of Passover at sundown last Monday, Christians observed the final, most solemn days of Lent in preparation for Easter services this weekend. Here are a handful of stories about different faith communities around the region. Standing tall behind mahogany desks, their sheet music splayed before them, the members of the children's choir of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield, Conn., looked as serious as the music they were about to sing.

IT is a season of renewal for Christians and Jews as they commemorate momentous events in their histories: for Christians, the resurrection of Jesus; for Jews, the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from slavery in Egypt. As Jews began celebrating the eight days of Passover at sundown last Monday, Christians observed the final, most solemn days of Lent in preparation for Easter services this weekend. Here are a handful of stories about different faith communities around the region. Sunday school was under way at the Segunda Iglesia Pentecostal Juan 3:16, a squat, unassuming group of buildings that make up one of the oldest Spanish churches in Port Chester, N.Y. In one of the small, interlocking rooms, Eva Manani led her class through the week's lesson. ''Jesús es bueno, sí?'' she asked. The 22 boys and girls, all 5 to 7 years old, called back, ''Sí!''

By now, for better or worse, we've become inured to the sight of fashion models who appear menacing or dazed or drugged or otherwise detached from reality (Style, March 25). But what purpose could possibly be served by throwing a baby into the mix? I found the photographs depicting detached, self-involved, hostile motherhood to be deeply disturbing.

To the Editor: Re ''Paul Taylor's Women Take a Leap Forward'' by Gia Kourlas [March 25]:

Part good-will gesture, bigger part clever marketing ploy, some of New York's premier stationers are offering discounts on custom hand-engraved papers to the roughly 50,000 Upper East Siders being booted from their cherished 10021 ZIP code come July 1, into one of two new Zip codes: 10065 and 10075. Dempsey & Carroll, (877) 750-1878, is providing a free copper return-address plate, worth $90, with every bespoke order from within 10021. Even Mrs. John L. Strong, the luxury paper company at 699 Madison Avenue since 1929, will no longer be able to claim Manhattan's most coveted ZIP code as its own; in honor of that predicament, the firm is offering a 21 percent discount on most personalized stationery orders from any ZIP code until June 1. Call (212) 833-2060 to order. NADINE RUBIN

A report in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about a publicist for the Barnum & Bailey Circus from 1881 to 1907 misstated his given name. He was Richard Hamilton, not William. (He went by Tody.)
An article last Sunday about solar projects in New Jersey misstated the average cost to install a 10-kilowatt system, according to the New Jersey Clean Energy Program. It is $77,500, not $7,750.
