EARLIER this year, the Maplewood Memorial Library in New Jersey became the center of controversy over what is a growing problem throughout the region and across the country. Faced with unruly middle school students who were flocking to the library after school, library officials announced plans to close on weekdays from 2:45 to 5 p.m. The resulting uproar was so intense that the town's mayor stepped in. In addition to the town's providing security guards at the library's two buildings, community groups decided to extend the hours of after-school programs and expand their offerings.
A brief article in the Westchester section today about the shutdown of the Indian Point 3 reactor on Tuesday was printed before a fire on Friday forced the plant to close again.

IN January, a 13-year-old wielding what looked like a .38-caliber revolver tried to rob a Chinese restaurant in Mount Vernon, N.Y., until workers wrested the gun from him. In February, a 16-year-old boy in Clifton, N.J., accompanied by a friend, stuck what appeared to be a .45-caliber handgun in a man's chest and stole his cocker spaniel.

An article last Sunday about a class-action lawsuit over mortgage lending practices referred incorrectly to the loan-to-value ratio that is considered prudent for mortgages. It is a maximum of 80 percent, not a minimum of 80 percent. (The loan-to-value ratio is a measure of risk that compares the size of the total loan on a property to the underlying collateral.)

An article last Sunday about the Kraft Nabisco Championship, a golf tournament in Palm Springs, Calif., that is the centerpiece of a spring social gathering for lesbians, referred incorrectly to the tournament. It is the first of the four annual major tournaments for the Ladies Professional Golf Association; it is not the first L.P.G.A. event of the year.

As its women's basketball team kept winning in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, Rutgers kept winning off the court too. Despite the team's loss in the championship game last Tuesday, sales of Scarlet Knights merchandise have ''been through the roof,'' university officials said. The 59-46 loss to Tennessee in Cleveland did little to slow sales of the team's merchandise on the Rutgers campuses or to stop companies from seeking manufacturing contracts with the university, said Marybeth Schmutz, the assistant director for trademark and licensing at Rutgers.
To the Editor: Re ''No Separate but Equal in Marriage'' (editorial, April 1):

The creationism-versus-evolution debate is a quintessential hot-button issue that continues to pop up in the news, and in American courtrooms, with persistent regularity, so it almost always seems to be the right time for a revival of ''INHERIT THE WIND.'' This 1955 courtroom drama, by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee, is based on the Scopes ''monkey trial'' of 1925, in which a Tennessee schoolteacher named John Thomas Scopes was charged with breaking a state law that made it illegal to teach any theory denying the concept of creation as taught in the Bible. Two Tony-winning powerhouses will duke it out in the current revival, directed by Doug Hughes (''Howard Katz''). Brian Dennehy is the prosecutor Matthew Harrison Brady, based on William Jennings Bryan, and Christopher Plummer takes up the defense as Henry Drummond, modeled after Clarence Darrow. In previews; opens on Thursday, Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com; $26.25 to 96.25. There's more than one revival with a starry cast opening this week: Kevin Spacey assays another of Eugene O'Neill's alcohol-soaked loners in ''A MOON FOR THE MISBEGOTTEN,'' the third O'Neill play in which Mr. Spacey has appeared on Broadway. This transfer from the Old Vic in London also marks the first collaboration between Mr. Spacey and the director Howard Davies since O'Neill's ''Iceman Cometh,'' which grabbed five Tony nominations in 1999. Mr. Spacey is James Tyrone Jr., and Eve Best plays Josie Hogan in this 1943 heartbreaker about longing, loneliness and love (the unrequited kind). Opens Sunday at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-4100, ticketmaster.com; $26.50 to $102.50. No need to stick to Broadway: The big names in theater don't, and plenty of them are taking part in the Naked Angels Theater Company's ''ARMED AND NAKED IN AMERICA: A NAKED ANGELS ISSUES PROJECT.'' A two-week series of one-acts about life during wartime, it includes new plays by the Academy Award nominee José Rivera (''The Motorcycle Diaries''), Itamar Moses (''Bach at Leipzig''), Theresa Rebeck (''The Scene'') and the Tony winner Warren Leight (''Side Man''). Wednesday through April 22, the Duke on 42nd Street, 229 West 42nd Street, Manhattan,(212) 239-6200, telecharge .com; $40.

ELEER - DAVIDSON--Erika Dagmar, of Manhattan, former photographer of MET Opera News & Guild, died on March 21, 2007. Memorial service: 6:30pm, April 23, 2007, at John Barrett & Son Funeral Home, 424 W. 51st St., NY, NY.

From quarters in piggy banks to love letters from actors, the outpouring of support for the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn has been overwhelming since it was revealed last week that the theater was operating on life support. ''I'm elated, but it's exhausting,'' Kenneth H. Thorn, the theater board's chairman, said of the groundswell of support. ''I just wish we didn't have to have a crisis to generate this level of energy for getting the theater back on its feet.''
NYRO--Laura. 10 years of lost music and friendship. Love, Charles, Anne, Ali and Laura Johnson

A profile on March 25 about the rare-book and archives dealer Glenn Horowitz referred incompletely to M.G. Lord, his first wife. Her last work in the field of political cartooning was some 15 years ago; she is known today as a writer. The profile also misstated the year that the University of Texas in Austin acquired the Watergate notebooks of Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein. It was 2003, not 2004.

To the Editor: ''The Middle Ages,'' by Niobe Way and Diane Hughes (Op-Ed, March 25), underscores compelling reasons that teachers need training about how to talk about race relations with middle schoolers.

SILBER--Pauline R, ''Nafla Ateret Rosheinu'' Most devoted wife of the late Joseph F. Beloved mother of William L, Joy, and Jinny Pinsky. Loving mother-in-law of Lillian Silber and Jerry Pinsky. Adoring and adored grandmother and great-grandmother. She leaves a tremendous void and will be sorely missed. Shiva begins after Pesach.

MAKING WAVES The News -- The American swimmer Michael Phelps broke five world records at the world swimming championships in Melbourne. Australia, and tied Mark Spitz, the 1972 Olympic champion, as the only man to win seven gold medals in a major meet. Behind the News -- Swimming all four strokes, Phelps, winner of six gold medals at the 2004 Olympics, was unstoppable. As The New York Times's Christopher Clarey put it: ''In a sport in which the numbers after the decimal point usually make the difference between first place and second, Phelps overwhelmed the paradigm at age 21, pulverizing records by a second or two.'' Mark Schubert, the United States coach, called it ''the greatest performance of all time.'' BEING CAREFUL The News -- New York City said that it gave away five million new subway-themed condoms in a month, demolishing the previous record of 2.5 million in July 2005. Behind the News -- Could it be that spring is in the air? That's about two condoms for every man living in the city. Packaged in wrappers with lettering mimicking the logos of the city's subway lines, the condoms are distributed free to doctors, businesses, bars, restaurants and other groups. The release of the city-branded condoms on Valentine's Day coincided with the launch of a Web site -- www.nyccondom.org -- with information on where they are available. The site received nearly 35,000 visits in its first month, Feb. 14 to March 14. FLYING HIGH The News -- Boeing announced that it had sold more than 500 of its fuel-efficient 787 passenger jets since the first plane was ordered in April 2004, making it the fastest-selling commercial airplane in history. Behind the News -- The company has orders from 43 customers for 514 of the jets, though the first one is not scheduled for delivery for more than a year. The plane is designed to burn 20 percent less fuel than comparable airplanes by using more lightweight composites. The biggest of the models can carry up to 330 passengers and travel 3,500 miles without refueling. The Boeing 737 NG set the old record for the fastest-selling plane, with 473 orders before the first was rolled out in December 1996. RAISING CASH The News -- Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination said it had raised $26 million in the first three months of this year, about three times as much as the previous record at this stage of the race. Behind the News -- The money race is off to a furious start. Senator Barack Obama raised $25 million over the same period; former Senator John Edwards, $14 million. The first-quarter results were seen as an important test of strength. For the first time since public financing for presidential races was adopted in 1974, after Watergate, the top candidates plan to reject public money -- and the spending limits that come with it -- so they can raise as much as they can. RIDING THE RAILS The News -- France's bullet train, the black-and-chrome TGV, set a record for conventional rail trains by reaching a speed of 357.2 miles per hour. Behind the News -- The record exceeded by 37 m.p.h. the previous mark, set in 1990, also by a French train. Credit the performance enhancements. The train normally runs at about 186 miles per hour. But engineers outfitted it with a 25,000-horsepower engine, increased the electrical power from overhead cables, added larger wheels to cover more ground with each rotation and treated the tracks so the wheels could make perfect contact. For all that, it still missed the overall record -- 361 m.p.h., set by Japan's magnetically levitated train in 2003.

VOLK--Herbert, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is saddened by the passing of Dr. Herbert Volk, a member of Einstein's founding faculty in the Department of Surgery. He was a valued member of the Einstein community from 1955 to 1991. We extend our condolences to his wife, Irma, and the entire Volk family. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

SHWAM--Ruth, born and raised in Brooklyn, died April 2, at age 87. She was the beloved mother of Paula and Marcy; GM of Donna, Marjie, Matthew, Luke and Daniel; GG of Ariel, Talia, Andrew, Ruth Zoe, Eliana, Danny, Lena, Jonah and William; and matriarch of so many more. As the last surviving member of the storied Shwams of Brooklyn and Newark, she leaves with us the memories and hopes of a remarkable family. Strong of mind and heart, and fiercely loyal to her family, Ruth brightened the lives of all those around her. She will be sorely missed as she moves on to join her beloved Danny.

HUGHES--Sidney, 84, died peacefully at home on April 5th, 2007. He is survived by his wife, Cloty of 53 years, his children Nancy and Tom, his daughter - in - law Catherine, and grandsons Philip and Matthew, who remember a man of great good humor, gentleness and generosity. He illuminated the days of his family with love, and those of his many friends with story telling, hospitality and fellowship. His favorite verse of the Bible was ''Be not forgetful to entertain strangers: for thereby some have entertained angels unawares''.

John F. Burns, the Baghdad bureau chief of The New York Times for the last four years, reflects on the Iraq war in a lengthy interview for a recent Canadian Broadcasting Corporation documentary. Video excerpts are at: nytimes.com/weekinreview On the financing behind the insurgency: ''It's sustained in part by the $2 billion in tin trunks that Saddam Hussein's eldest son, Qusay, drove out of Baghdad.'' On the broader dangers of a potential Sunni-Shia civil war: ''The Iranians are not going to see this first Shiite government on their Western frontier in at least 350 years -- they're not going to see it go down.'' On the American military's new ''surge'' strategy for Baghdad: ''My experience among Iraqis is, in both Shiite and Sunni communities, that whatever they may have felt about the invasion, they now want American troops, because they see them as the only option for stabilization.''

Cherished grandmother of Melanie, Eric, Lana, Fara, Ethan and Matthew. Devoted daughter of the late Joseph and Mae Klein. Dear sister of the late Irwin (Buddy). Services Sunday 12:45 pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

TRIMINGHAM--Shorty, 87, noted yachtsman, parliamentarian, and photographer. DeForest Wheeler Trimingham, C.B.E., of Bermuda died at his home, in Paget, on March 30, 2007, of acute leukemia. Born in 1919 to a family of yachtsmen, the sailor known worldwide simply as Shorty became one of the most successful sailors on the international circuit. In 1954, he was the first non-Englishman to win the Prince of Wales Cup, the top prize of the International 14s. He represented Bermuda at the 1960 Olympics in Italy. In ocean racing, he competed in countless Bermuda and Fastnet Races and was co-founder of the Onion Patch series. He served as Member of Parliament from 1958 to 1980 and as Bermuda's Minister for Tourism from 1972 to 1977. In 1978, he was made Commander of the British Empire by the Queen of England for his services to the island of Bermuda. As merchandising manager for Trimingham Bros., he traveled extensively throughout Europe and Asia. These travels inspired his eventual return to the art of photography. A collection of his photographs titled, ''Buddha: The Living Way'' was published by Random House in 1998, with a foreword by the Dalai Lama and text by Pico Iyer. He leaves behind his wife, Dorothy, daughter, Barrie Trimingham, and three grandsons, Stephen, Peter, and Thomas VanDyck.

Tom Delavan, editor at large at Domino magazine, describes his personal style as a gradual regression. ''In my 20s I was working at Goldman Sachs and wearing bespoke suits,'' he said. ''In my 40s, it's all about jeans and army jackets. Now I can actually wear clothes that I want to wear because I'm actually doing something that I want to be doing.'' Mr. Delavan, 43, who produces photo shoots for Domino, strives to achieve the kind of balance in his wardrobe that he does in the rooms he styles. ''We want our pages to look polished but relaxed -- if a room looks too perfect, we'll mess up the bed a little. It's the same with my clothes. To me, a Thom Browne shirt has the right balance, because it's unironed yet custom-made.'' Too, he has replaced his bench-made shoes with Adidas out of sheer necessity. ''I spend half my day riding my motorcycle to appointments all over the city,'' he explained. ''The rest of the time I'm on shoots, moving couches and hanging paintings.''

President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could be considered something of a C.E.O. His company? Kremlin Inc., overseer of a vast network of oil and banking concerns. As more of Russia's economy falls under state control, meetings in the Kremlin are becoming an important part of any deal maker's playbook; many analysts say the big deals cannot get done without such gatherings. So it should come as no surprise that the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, Lloyd C. Blankfein, has written a letter to Mr. Putin asking for a meeting. The Kremlin's Web site announced the request last week. It was a Goldman analyst who first formulated the idea that the fast-growing so-called B.R.I.C. economies -- Brazil, Russia, India and China -- would inevitably outpace today's largest economies.

Winn, an expert in quality of cancer care, was a consultant to NQF, chaired NCCN's Guidelines Steering Committee and was EditorIn-Chief of JNCCN. He founded MD Anderson's CCOP program. He was on the boards of Planned Parenthood and Capital Area Hospice. Winn is survived by wife, Patricia; son, Matthew; daughter, Amanda; three grandchildren, William, Nicholas and Fielden; and sister, Dilys Winn. There will be a memorial at the Cosmos Club, in Washington, DC at 11 AM on April 14.

Would a chief executive really raise the rent on his own mother by more than $1,500 a month? Jonathan M. Tisch, the co-chairman of the Loews Corporation, who runs its Loews Hotels unit, may have no choice. His mother, Joan Tisch, lives in an apartment in the Loews Regency Hotel on Park Avenue in Manhattan, which she rents for $55,000 a month. (She also rents an additional hotel room for $4,200 a month.)

EARLIER this year, the Maplewood Memorial Library in New Jersey became the center of controversy over what is a growing problem throughout the region and across the country. Faced with unruly middle school students who were flocking to the library after school, library officials announced plans to close on weekdays from 2:45 to 5 p.m. The resulting uproar was so intense that the town's mayor stepped in to keep the doors open. And in addition to the town's providing security guards at the library's two buildings, community groups decided to extend the hours of after-school programs and expand their offerings.

To the Editor: Re ''Our Crumbling Foundation,'' by Bob Herbert (column, April 5): Our federal, state and local governments seem still to be guided by the outdated principles of ''planned obsolescence.'' If a school, levee, highway or bridge is crumbling, build a new one. Finance it with bonds for our children to pay.

To the Editor: I just read ''Hotel Trends: The Latest Amenity: A Hypoallergenic Room'' (Practical Traveler, March 25) by Michelle Higgins. As one who has had lifelong food and environmental allergies, I say ''bravo.'' Readers should know, however, that some hotels now permit pets in guest rooms. I had a recent reservation at a hotel in Boca Raton, Fla., which was under new management. Upon checking my hotel reservation before departure, I learned that cats and dogs were permitted to stay in guest rooms. I was assured by the desk clerk that the ''rooms are cleaned thoroughly'' after checkout. But cat dander becomes a permanent fixture; there is no way, short of demolition, that these rooms can be restored to their original dander-free state. Those with cat allergies could develop breathing difficulties upon entering a dander-filled room. Since many hotel guests do not appear to be aware of the current trend to allow pets in rooms, I recommend that travelers inquire about a hotel's pet policy before making reservations. Janice Lichter Milwaukee
To the Editor: The Travel section continues to underestimate the intelligence of its readers.

To the Editor: Re ''Gridlock's Other Toll'' (editorial, April 1): I am puzzled as to why every solution to the traffic problem in Manhattan increases the divide between the rich and middle class and poor of our city. It is the rich who will benefit from a fee system.

APT--Helen, beloved mother of Stephanie, Charles and Michael, devoted grandmother of Alexis, Julia, Katherine, Teddy, Austin, Annalise and Lillian, beloved wife of her recently departed soul mate, Harold, passed away on Thursday, April 5 after a brief but valiant battle against cancer. The earth has lost one of its angels. We will miss her. Funeral service April 11, 10:30 am, All Souls Unitarian Church, NYC, interment to follow at Pinelawn Memorial Park.

Q. When my 24-unit building changed owners a number of years ago, the former landlord returned the security deposit on my rent-stabilized apartment. The new landlord made no request for a deposit until recently. On my last lease renewal I was asked to send in a partial deposit, and this year the landlord is demanding the remainder for the full deposit. Since I have lived here now for over a decade without a deposit, can the new landlord demand one now? A. ''The Rent Stabilization Code permits an owner to hold one full month of rent as security,'' said Robert Sokolski, a Manhattan lawyer who represents tenants. ''And the rent-stabilized lease form contains a provision that the security deposit increases along with the rent.'' Normally, Mr. Sokolski said, security deposits are not given back to the tenants when the building is sold but are passed along to the new owner.

Kimberly Ann Hamm, a lawyer, and Alexander Elias Rendon, a writer, were married Friday morning at the New York City Municipal Building. The bride, 35, will keep her name. She is an associate at the London office of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, the New York law firm. She graduated from the University of Florida and received a law degree from New York University.

To the Editor: Thank you for ''Accepting an Identity, and Gaining Strength,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, April 1). You do the youth of America, and their families, a great service; I pray that more and more people will come to accept that we are who we are and that love and support are what we all need, regardless of our sexual orientation or any other God-given characteristic.
Chapter 1

LEE--Jeremy S., 68, of New Canaan, CT, formerly of West Roxbury, MA, died suddenly on April 4th. Former President of TBWA Health. Beloved husband of Jane O'Connell Lee and loving father of Marcia Lee Taylor. Funeral from the George F. Doherty & Sons Funeral Home, 477 Washington St., Wellesley, MA on Tuesday at 10:00 am. Funeral mass in St. Pauls Church, Wellesley, MA at 11:00 am. Relatives and friends kindly invited. Visiting hours on Monday 5-8 pm. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Wellesley, MA. Donations in his memory may be made to the ALS Association, Greater New York Chapter, 116 John St, Suite 1304, New York, NY 10038. Online guestbook at www.gfdoherty.com.

LEVINE--Joshua. The attorneys and staff of Davis & Gilbert LLP are profoundly saddened by the death of our partner and mentor Josh Levine, a brilliant lawyer, compassionate friend, and loving husband, father and grandfather. A ''lawyer's lawyer'', Josh joined our firm in 1937 and, but for his service in the United States Army during the Second World War, gave his next 49 years to our practice, retiring in 1986. Even then, he would return often to offer his guidance, support and warmth of heart. Once described by Mary Wells Lawrence as the best agency lawyer in the business, Josh was an expert in, indeed he developed much of, the law of advertising. Among his many devoted clients, was William Bernbach with whom Josh formed the advertising company Doyle Dane Bernbach, precursor to todays Omnicom Group Inc. We are deeply indebted to Josh for his professional abilities, his leadership, his vision and integrity, all of which enhanced our practice and greatly enriched our lives. $(6$)LEVINE--Joshua, a resident of Rye, NY, and Palm Beach, FL, died April 6, 2007, at age 90. Born May 24, 1916, in New York City to Jack and Lillian Levine. Josh served in the U.S. Army during World War II, beginning as a Private and discharged as a Captain. In the European Theater of Operations, he investigated claims against the U.S. by Europeans who suffered noncombat damage. Josh graduated from CCNY and NYU School of Law, where he served as President of the student body Pre-Bar Association. Mr. Levine was formerly the managing partner of Davis & Gilbert, where he spent his entire legal career, starting as a law clerk in 1936. He represented many of his firm's leading clients, including Doyle, Dane Bernbach, Benton & Bowles, Ogilvy & Mather, Weight Watchers International, Muzak, and Best Foods. He successfully lobbied the enactment of legislation permitting the manufacture and sale of yellow margarine. Josh handled a broad range of advertising, corporate and securities law problems and engaged in negotiating and consummating the acquisition of advertising agencies worldwide. He was one of six founders of Beth Emeth Synagogue in Larchmont and served as President. He was active in, and was honored by, UJA. He was an avid fisherman and raconteur. Josh was a righteous man, always maintaining the highest morals. A loving husband, father and Poppy, he touched all who knew him. Survived by his wife, Selene, daughters Judi Levine (Bernie Bornstein), Beth Levine (Henry Abarbanel), and Linda (Eric) Spellman, grandchildren Brett, Sara, Lindsey and Matthew, and brother, Harold. Funeral service Sunday, 11:30 am, Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck, 914381-1809; followed by interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Contributions to UJA or Joshua Levine Scholarship Fund (1938), NYU School of Law, 161 Avenue of the Americans, NY, NY 10013.

David Eyre's pancake recipe (Food, March 25) has been a weekend breakfast staple at our house since it was first printed in 1966. When the recipe for the Moroccan pigeon pie bisteeya came out, it also entered my repertory for entertaining. What a delight to see these recipes paired!

ROTHSCHILD--Diane, The One Club and its board of directors mourn the loss of Diane Rothschild, esteemed former member of the board, award winning copywriter and 2005 Creative Hall of Fame inductee. She fought bravely with lung cancer. Diane began her legendary career as a copywriter at Doyle Dane Bernbach. In 1986 she founded Grace & Rothschild with fellow Creative Hall of Fame member Roy Grace. She was recently Vice Chairman of Della Femina Rothschild Jeary and Partners. Diane will be missed by her many friends and colleagues. We extend our deepest sympathies to Alan, Alexandra and Brenda.

THURGOOD--Allen. With great sorrow, family and friends announce the death of the consumer advocate and coop pioneer. He was a true visionary who tirelessly exchanged ideas and enthusiasm across coop sectors, state and regions, and diverse cultures. Survived by brothers Frank and Robert Connolly, sisters Lilian Prieto and Evelyn Thurgood. Memorial Service, 2pm, April 29, 3 West 51 St. Club. RSVP: 212877-2033 or ThurgoodRSVP@ hotmail.com

For the first time in more than a month, the Rangers exhaled. They skated off the ice Saturday after losing to the Pittsburgh Penguins, 2-1, not knowing who their first-round opponent in the postseason would be. Only when they stepped into the locker room did they learn that they had clinched sixth place in the Eastern Conference and would play the Atlanta Thrashers in the first round.

EVERY morning, as I climb the stairs and trudge down the hall to my office, I pass over a section of floor that gives a noticeable groan. In former years, I made a mental note to one day pry up the offending plank and pad it with another layer of butcher paper. I also conceded this probably would come after about 200 other pressing chores. The beauty of this task deferred is that I've grown accustomed to the sound. In fact, I now regard it as a greeting from an old friend.

GOLDMAN--Eugene. The Dysautonomia Foundation deeply mourns the passing of Eugene Goldman. A kind and gentle man, Gene was a strong supporter of the Foundation's work to advance research and medical care for familial dysautonomia (FD). We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Marion Rolnick Goldman, his children Laurie and Jeffrey Goldberger, Pamela and Danny Fried, and Michael, and his grandchildren Perry, Sydney, Cody, Kyle, Jared and Jamie. He will truly be missed.

To the Editor: Regarding ''South Africa: In the Dark in the Park, With the Wild Things'' (Journeys, March 18): Rob Nixon makes clear his view that nighttime drives into the wildlife parks of Africa are a great idea and a boon for tourists wanting to see African animals. Doesn't he realize that these animals are being forced to deal with increasing human intrusion -- now not only during the day-- but at night as well, when humans would normally have retreated? Why do humans think it's their right to disturb wildlife wherever it exists? It would be nice to read about the negative impact of this sort of activity. In other words -- a balanced view. Heather G. Irons Berkeley, Calif.

ROCHE--Anne Ferretti, on April 2, 2007 of Chappaqua, NY. Reposing Tuesday 5:307:30 pm at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY. Funeral mass Thursday 10:30 am, The Church of Our Savior, 38th and Park Ave, NYC.

David Rieff paints what he calls ''Democratic antiwar protesters'' with too broad a brush (March 25). Many of us protest the Iraq war for its futility rather than as a retreat from American influence and power in the region. A drawdown would enable us to confront the larger Iranian threat without being exposed and weakened by our involvement in Iraq.

IN 1970, not long after Lesley Dormen moved to New York City, she was asked out on a date. Ms. Dormen, a new college graduate from Ohio, was working in Midtown at a magazine published by the Girl Scouts of America. When the designated Friday evening arrived, ''I came out of my office, and it was raining and there weren't any cabs available,'' she said. ''I didn't know how to take the subway. I couldn't ask; I didn't dare. It was too shameful not to know. So I walked.'' Her destination was Park Avenue and 90th Street. ''I remember he dried my hair with a towel when I got there,'' she said.

IT is a season of renewal for Christians and Jews as they commemorate momentous events in their histories: for Christians, the resurrection of Jesus; for Jews, the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from slavery in Egypt. As Jews began celebrating the eight days of Passover at sundown last Monday, Christians observed the final, most solemn days of Lent in preparation for Easter services this weekend. Here are a handful of stories about different faith communities around the region. Standing tall behind mahogany desks, their sheet music splayed before them, the members of the children's choir of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield, Conn., looked as serious as the music they were about to sing.

COULD it be that the mere presence of an English accent is enough to bewitch American audiences into overrating performances by British actors? That's the cheeky suggestion made recently by the British actor, novelist, critic and all-around cultural Renaissance guy Stephen Fry. ''I shouldn't be saying this -- high treason really -- but I sometimes wonder if Americans aren't fooled by our accent into detecting a brilliance that may not really be there,'' he told the British magazine Radio Times. ''I mean, would they notice if Jeremy Irons or Judi Dench gave a bad performance? Not that those two paragons ever would, but it's worth considering.'' Blimey, that's food for thought, as is this: ''When American TV and movies call for a twist of limey in their cocktail, it's usually a character they're after -- supervillain, emotionally constipated academic, effete eccentric, that kind of thing.'' He may be on to something there. After all, didn't the creators of the three-part ''Die Hard'' franchise twice reach out for Britons -- Mr. Irons and Alan Rickman -- to play foils both evil and classy enough to square off against Bruce Willis?

COLE--Rosanne E., Ph.D., on April 6th, 2007. Beloved of Cole and DiPaola families and countless friends. She was an internationally respected economist, with a career as consultant and economic forecaster including long service with the IBM corporation. Friends may call Sunday, April 8th, 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., mass of Christian burial Monday, 9:30am at St. Catherine of Siena Church, 411 East 68th St.

The Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor was shut down for nearly a day last week after a water-pump control device malfunctioned. The plant was also forced to retest its new emergency system after problems arose with 123 of 150 new sirens. Jim Steets, a spokesman for Entergy Nuclear Northeast, which owns and operates the plant, said the shutdown occurred at 4 a.m. Tuesday after operators noticed that the water level in the steam generators had dropped. The reactor was in the process of being brought back to full power after a scheduled 24-day refueling procedure.

SCHAEFFER--Irene. Chai Lifeline mourns the recent death of Irene Schaeffer, beloved mother of Richard Schaeffer, generous benefactor, Awards Dinner Chairman, 2005 Man of the Year, and a good friend to our children. Mrs. Schaeffer's halfcentury of philanthropy was a lifelong lesson for her children. She leaves a legacy of kindness and concern for others that is a model not only for Richard and his siblings, Susan and Hal Martin, and Donald and Joan Schaeffer, but for all of us. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Chai Lifeline Samuel Zaks, Executive Director, Development

WOOSTER--Edward. Be loved husband of Beatrice, loving father of Allen Wooster, Scott and Bonnie Wooster and Randy and Jennifer Wooster. Cherished grandfather of Evan, Allison, Samantha, Leigh and Lindsey. Accomplished Trial Attorney and good friend.

I first heard voices in my head in the 1980's while attending an Ivy League university (Daniel B. Smith, March 25). Since graduation, I've become a lawyer, a spouse, a mother and an active volunteer in my community. Throughout, I've searched for someone to assure me that I'm ''normal'' -- as the voices periodically return. Everyone in the mental-health field has recommended medicating them away. Contrary to their advice, I minimize the voices through exercise, vitamins, hobbies, work and a regular sleep schedule. Thank you for helping me feel normal.

HALPERIN--Jerome R., Esq. To my close friends Kyle, Guy and family, I hope you are comforted during this difficult time knowing that Jerry appreciated your devotion and endless compassion. Steven M. Simon

TWO of the dresser drawers in my 12-year-old daughter's room were broken. It was not the drawers' fault, nor Annie's. It was time. The top of the waist-high dresser had served as a changing table for our four children, and our oldest is now a college freshman. If that baby boy lay on that dresser today, his size 12 feet would scrape the floor. So we threw out the dresser, which led to a reorganization of Annie's clothes, which somehow turned into a major revamping of Annie's room that took most of the weekend. As Annie noted about two hours in, ''This turned out to be an official room-cleaning project, didn't it, Dad?''

To the Editor: With technology companies like KenCall emerging in Africa, Thomas L. Friedman's key observation that something is stirring on the continent is right on point (''The Africa Connection,'' column, April 4).

In the event that you are immune to the glories of ''The Sopranos,'' which returns for its final season on Sunday, you will need something to hold your attention, and that something just might be the ''Masterpiece Theater'' production of ''THE WIND IN THE WILLOWS,'' on PBS the same evening. Based on Kenneth Grahame's children's book about a few anthropomorphized members of the animal kingdom, this adaptation stars Bob Hoskins and the British comedian Matt Lucas, among others. Just like ''The Sopranos,'' the story features a scalawag son of great wealth, but his name isn't Anthony Jr. It's Mr. Toad. Also returning for a new season Sunday is ''ENTOURAGE'' (HBO, at 10 p.m.). Ari has been fired as Vince's agent. Replacing him now is another young power agent, Amanda (Carla Gugino), who wants Vince to break out of the box, play against type. What is her idea for him exactly? A costume drama based on an Edith Wharton novel. (What fun Wharton would have had with the codes and excesses of young millennial-era celebrity!) If you have had it with urbanites in their 30s, obsessing about conception, pregnancy, baby nurses and Lamaze classes, and if you just can't help feeling wistful for the days when young marrieds just drank too much and cheated, then tread cautiously toward the premiere of ''NOTES FROM THE UNDERBELLY'' on Thursday (ABC, 10 p.m.), directed by the filmmaker Barry Sonnenfeld. The series makes a fetish of everything prenatal. An exercise in Gucci-free earnestness, ''THE BRICK AWARDS,'' to be broadcast on Thursday (CW, 9 p.m.), honors young adults who have done something good for the world in public health, environmental preservation and other fields. Whither the spirit of Britney?

An article last Sunday about Congressional actions intended to end the Vietnam War misidentified the Democratic senator who co-sponsored an unsuccessful amendment with Senator Mark Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, that would have forced a withdrawal of all American troops by the end of 1971. He was George McGovern of South Dakota -- not Frank Church of Idaho, who was involved in other antiwar legislation.
HELSEL--Clara. April 1. Loving stepmother, grandmother, GG to all The Helsels. She will not be forgotten.

To the Editor: As a former theater critic (1010 WINS Radio) and former Drama Desk president, I welcome the availability of computer-enhanced orchestras on the road and in schools. Giving audiences of all ages the opportunity to hear something approximating a full complement of musicians if their only option is tape or a truncated orchestra seems worth the downside. The same reasoning does not apply to Broadway productions however. People come from all over the world to Broadway, and they want something they can't get at home. It should be live theater, with a live orchestra in the pit. Leida Snow Manhattan

SEDERBAUM--William, on April 5, 2007. Beloved husband of Pearl and the late Harriet. Devoted father of Caroline and the late Arthur D. Adored grandfather of Rebecca, David and his wife Phoenix, and Elizabeth. Dear brother of the late Max. Service Sunday 11:30 am at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street at Amsterdam Avenue.

A review on March 18 about ''The First Man-Made Man: The Story of Two Sex Changes, One Love Affair, and a Twentieth-Century Medical Revolution,'' by Pagan Kennedy, refers incorrectly to Michael Dillon, the main subject of the book, who was born a woman. Dillon's sex change is considered the first of the modern era because of its surgical sophistication and its early use of testosterone, starting in 1938. But he was not ''the first person on record to undergo surgery to change his gender.'' (Records of surgery to alter sexual characteristics go back to ancient times.)

To the Editor: So the musicians' union is concerned that computer software might replace Broadway musicians? Boo hoo. This trend is sweet payback for the decades in which the union forced Broadway producers to hire ''walkers'': surplus musicians whose only job was to show up once a week for a paycheck. I pay to see and hear live actors, live singers and live dancers. Their accompaniment can be a jukebox, for all I care. If that knocks a few dollars off my overpriced ticket, I'll cry all the way to the box office. F. Gwynplaine MacIntyre Manhattan

In a move that government officials call economical, logical and mutually beneficial, the Town of North Hempstead will acquire 9 parks and 12 roads from Nassau County. County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi and Town Supervisor Jon Kaiman announced a plan on March 29 to transfer 230 acres and 26 miles of roads from the county to the town.

With just over a minute and a half remaining in the Nets' game Saturday night, point guard Jason Kidd missed a 3-pointer from the wing, caught his own rebound as it sailed over the baseline and threw the ball off the back of Wizards forward Jarvis Hayes to keep possession for the Nets. The sequence pretty much summed up what the Nets have become: a gritty bunch who make things difficult for themselves.

The health risks of smoking may not be enough to persuade the State Legislature to authorize a $2-a-pack tax on cigarettes proposed last week by Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive. As part of his Healthy Nassau campaign, Mr. Suozzi joined with Assemblyman Earlene Hooper and Judith A. Jacobs, the County Legislature's presiding officer, in asking the State Legislature last Tuesday to allow the counties surrounding New York City and upstate Rensselaer County to impose cigarette taxes. He said he hoped the tax would dissuade youths from beginning to smoke and encourage smokers to quit.

The New York State Legislature passed a practically on-time budget last week with a lot in it to be happy about. That good news was obscured almost immediately by rounds of loudly self-serving analysis by lawmakers over the way the budget distributes education aid to the New York suburbs. Neither the complaining (in Westchester) nor the crowing (on Long Island) was entirely appropriate. It's complicated, but let's discuss. One of Gov. Eliot Spitzer's prime directives on taking office was to overhaul New York's perverse system of doling out school aid. It is called a ''formula,'' a label meant to give the appearance of mathematical objectivity to what has been a yearly exercise in political scheming and muscle-flexing.

While most of the spring exhibitions are already in full swing, the GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM is gearing up for a series of shows beginning Saturday and running throughout the summer. Occupying large portions of the Guggenheim's Frank Lloyd Wright building, they will include everything from paintings and sculptures to video and site-specific installations. Using only works from the museum's permanent collection, curators have organized a series of four sequential shows under the overall title ''THE SHAPES OF SPACE.'' All the art will explore the meaning of space as an abstract concept. Rather than tackle the subject chronologically, each exhibition will combine works from different periods, from the early 20th century to the present. Much of the art will be organized by theme, illustrating the artistic meaning of space in all its permutations. Several large-scale contemporary works recently acquired by the Guggenheim will form the core of the exhibition. On the ground floor, visible from the outside of the building at night, will be Alyson Shotz's ''Shape of Space,'' a 2004 work from which the show is derived. It is a giant, shimmering wall of more than 18,000 ovals of hand-cut plastic that captures and refracts light. Another monumental work in the show is Pipilotti Rist's ''Himalaya's Sister's Living Room,'' from 2000, which recreates a dimly lighted, cluttered domestic interior meant to explore the thoughts and memories contained within a household space. Other artists on view are Piet Mondrian, Larry Bell, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Sarah Morris and Piotr Uklanski. Through Sept. 5, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, guggenheim.org. ''The Shapes of Space,'' coincides with another exhibition opening Saturday at the Guggenheim, this one documenting the continuing restoration of the museum's Frank Lloyd Wright building. ''FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT'S GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM: RESTORING A MASTERPIECE,'' on view through July 8, will include photographs, drawings and computer-generated images as well as interviews with the team involved in the restoration, repair and conservation. Every part of the project will be explored, from restoring the exterior of the building to reinforcing the upper ramp walls and replacing the windows.

CARUCCI--Enrico T. ''Rick''. In Connecticut Hospice, March 31, 2007, Enrico T. ''Rick'' Carucci, 83, of Turtle Bay Dr., Branford. Beloved husband of Anne Betty Carucci. Loving father of Ellen Carucci Tracy and husband Will of Short Beach and NYC and Rick Carucci and wife Julee of Louisville, KY. Funeral Mass was held in St. Elizabeth Church, Branford. Burial with Military Honors was in St. Lawrence Cemetery.

To the Editor: Jonathan Allen's ''India Made Easy'' (March 25) forgot one vital detail about traveling from America to the opposite side of the world. No matter how well planned your travels, when you return home it typically takes days to make the physical transition to your home time zone. The common rule is: one day for every one hour difference in time. Some people flying to India make the transition to that time zone with greater ease than others. However, rarely have I seen it the other way around. No matter the sleep aids, drugs, or homeopathic remedies are -- on a return it takes days to get back to everyday life. Realities of our body's time clock should not be forgotten in planning and enjoying a trip. Maxine W. Davis Minneapolis

FOULKE--William G. 94, on March 30th, 2007, at home in Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, PA. Retired Chairman of Provident National Bank (a predecessor to PNC Bank); civic leader in Philadelphia. He established Provident as a leading provider of trust services, thus laying the groundwork for PNC's investment management business. Upon retirement from Provident he became Chairman of Pardee Resources Company, a family enterprise founded by his grandfather. A graduate of St. Paul's School, Concord, NH and Princeton University, he was known for his foresightedness, gentle humor and kindness. At the height of the energy crisis of the 1970s, he commuted by train from Chestnut Hill to conserve energy but steadfastly refused to fire the driver provided by the bank to take him to various meetings saying that the man had a wife and children to support and that the crisis would not last forever. In 1934, he captained the Princeton tennis and squash teams and won the squash intercollegiate championship. Many years later, he became a national senior doubles court tennis champion. He was an avid fly fisherman and boating enthusiast. He had a marvelous 67 year marriage to the former Louisa Lawrence Wood, who predeceased him in 2001. Ten years previously, they both broke their necks in a car accident but miraculously survived without spinal column injury. He always said he was a lucky man. We were lucky to know him. He is survived by three married children, Louisa and Bill Newlin, of Washington, D.C., Walter and Wendy Foulke of Philadelphia, PA, and Bill and Wendy Foulke of Bedford, NY, and by eight grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas' Church, Whitemarsh, PA at noon on Friday, April 20th. In lieu of flowers, contributions will be gratefully received by St. Thomas' Church, Whitemarsh, PA; or St. Paul's School, Concord, NH; or College of the Atlantic, Bar Harbor, ME.

I commend the Ethicist for an apt response to the inquiry about the ethics of using a wheelchair to speed the way through airport security (March 25). However, it overlooks the fact that faking illness makes it harder for those who are disabled -- especially if the disability is not easily discerned -- to obtain necessary help.
A MODEL SUMMER By Paulina Porizkova. 324 pp. Hyperion. $23.95.

One important item that hit the cutting room floor recently when New York lawmakers produced a new state budget was the Bigger, Better Bottle Bill. This bill -- known as the BBBB in Albany -- would make one of the state's best environmental laws even better. A bill like the BBBB that cuts down on litter, encourages recycling, saves natural resources and provides funds to help the environment should be an easy step for New York's legislators and Gov. Eliot Spitzer. Right now, however, the bottle redemption bill itself needs to be redeemed. Many lawmakers have been wanting to pass the bill, a perfect fit for those in both parties who label themselves environmentalists. But the bill faces powerful lobbyists from the beverage industry who have been working against it for years because they earn millions of dollars when consumers fail to redeem their bottles and cans.

To the Sports Editor: I enjoyed the article about Derek Jeter's quiet approach to leadership (''Public Figure, Private Leader,'' April 1). It is admirable that he leads by example and communicates directly with teammates instead of through the news media. But some may find his assertion that, ''It's not my job to change the way fans act,'' somewhat hypocritical, if unintentional. Jeter was defending his public nondefense of Alex Rodriguez throughout all the booing that Rodriguez endured last season. Fair enough. But fans don't forget how Jeter supported Jason Giambi when the boos were directed at him.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended March 24, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. NANCY CUNARD: Heiress, Muse, Political Idealist, by Lois Gordon. (Columbia University, $32.50.) A biography of Cunard (1896-1965), a poet, publisher, journalist and tireless supporter of the disenfranchised. THE SECOND CHILD: Poems, by Deborah Garrison. (Random House, $19.95.) A former New Yorker editor celebrates motherhood and domestic life. GHOSTS OF SPAIN, by Giles Tremlett. (Walker, $26.95.) The legacy of Francoism: part modern social history, part travelogue. CHANCE AND CIRCUMSTANCE, by Carolyn Brown. (Knopf, $37.50) Twenty years of dancing with Merce Cunningham and John Cage. CRAZY '08, by Cait Murphy. (Smithsonian/Collins, $24.95.) An argument that 1908 -- the last time the Chicago Cubs won the World Series -- was the greatest year in baseball history. ONCE UPON A COUNTRY, by Sari Nusseibeh with Anthony David. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.) A nuanced assessment of his country's national life from a Palestinan scholar. COLLECTED PLAYS & WRITINGS ON THEATER, by Thornton Wilder. (Library of America, $40.) An anthology of theatrical writing by a great and misunderstood playwright. ASTRID & VERONIKA, by Linda Olsson. (Penguin, paper, $14.) A writer from New Zealand moves to a remote Swedish village. IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF THE PROPHET, by Tariq Ramadan. (Oxford University, $23.) A biography of Muhammad by a Muslim scholar who has been barred from the United States argues that Islam and Western democracy are compatible. WHY THE FRENCH DON'T LIKE HEADSCARVES, by John R. Bowen. (Princeton University, $27.95.) An account of the controversy that culminated in a 2004 law forbidding conspicuous religious apparel in French schools. RIPPLE EFFECT: New and Selected Poems, by Elaine Equi. (Coffee House, $18.) A thoughtful, curious poet explores the link between heart and mind.The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

FEAREY--Mary Senior, of Edgartown, MA and formerly of New York City, died in her home, on Sunday, April 1. She was the widow of the late Morton Fearey, who died in 1988 and who was a partner in the law firm of Davis, Polk and Wardwell. Mrs. Fearey, a graduate of Concord Academy in 1932 and Vassar College in 1937, was on the board of Goddard Riverside Community Center since the 1950s and served as Vice President from 1969-1972. She was also a Co-Chair and then Chair of the Women's Division of the Legal Aid Society from 19621965. She is survived by her three children, Morton Fearey, Jr. and Mary F. Lollis, both of Edgartown, MA, and John L. S. Fearey of Old Greenwich, CT; nine grandchildren and 15 great-grandchildren. Her daughter, Julia F. Habgood, predeceased her in 1983. Services will be held at St. Andrews Church, 34 North Summer Street, Edgartown, MA on Saturday, April 21 at 11:00 am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Goddard Riverside Community Center, 593 Columbus Avenue, New York, NY 10024 will be greatly appreciated. $(6$)FEAREY--Mary. The Board and Staff of Goddard Riverside Community Center mourn the loss of one of our founding Board members. Her many years of leadership, generosity and fervent commitment to our work will be remembered. Stephan Russo, Exec. Dir.

FOR school districts in the suburbs of New York City, there was much to celebrate in the new state budget: lots of new money, for rich districts and poor alike, much more than Gov. Eliot Spitzer had originally proposed. But the deal that legislative leaders struck with Mr. Spitzer, allowing the budget to be pushed through at the last minute, contained a new formula for what is called high-tax aid.

GERNSBACK--Madelon, 98, on March 29, 2007, in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL of natural causes. Born July 19, 1909, in New York City, daughter of famed inventor, publisher and ''father of science fiction'' Hugo Gernsback and Rose Harvey Gernsback. She spent most of her adult life in Italy working for her father's publishing house covering scientific and cultural affairs throughout Europe. Beloved half-sister of Bertina Baer and Jocelyn Neichin. Dearest sister of the late M. Harvey Gernsback. She is also survived by her cherished niece and nephew Wendy Davidson and Mark Gernsback.

YEN--Amos, 45, born on March 24, 1962, died on April 4, 2007. Survived by mother Mary Huang Yen, sister Dora Edelman, brothers John, Edward and Dewey. Predeceased by his father Victor Yen. Visiting 10:00am Monday, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry (Exit 17 Sawmill).

EARLIER this year, the Maplewood Memorial Library in New Jersey became the center of controversy over what is a growing problem throughout the region and across the country. Faced with unruly middle school students who were flocking to the library after school, library officials announced plans to close on weekdays from 2:45 to 5 p.m. The resulting uproar was so intense that the town's mayor stepped in to keep the doors open. And in addition to the town's providing security guards at the library's two buildings, community groups decided to extend the hours of after-school programs and expand their offerings.
An article last Sunday about the annual Golden Gloves amateur boxing competition misstated the length of the rounds. Each round is two minutes -- not one or two minutes.

Alex Rodriguez slapped his hands as he rounded first base yesterday afternoon and then nearly plowed into the third-base coach Larry Bowa as he rounded third. Before touching home plate, he heaved his batting helmet toward the sky, a smile on his face every step of the way. Rodriguez has been playing in the major leagues for 13 seasons. But with one swing of the bat, he became a kid again.

If the chairman is named Penske and the president is named Penske, why not call the whole company Penske? That's what United Auto Group, a network of car dealerships, is asking its shareholders to do at the company's annual meeting next month. Roger S. Penske has been the company's chairman and chief executive for eight years and in January, his son, Roger S. Penske Jr., was promoted to president. The elder Penske is a well-known race car driver and race team owner.
John F. Burns was incorrectly identified in the March 11 column. He is The Times's Baghdad bureau chief, not a former bureau chief there.

A system error in ESPN.com's Fantasy Baseball League has disrupted live scoring and roster moves since Tuesday. ''We're fantasy players ourselves, and we recognize that it is not acceptable for our players to have anything short of a great experience,'' an ESPN.com spokesman, Paul Melvin, said in a written statement. ''We also recognize that getting every problem resolved is what will ultimately satisfy our players.''

''OPERATION HOMECOMING'' is an unusual documentary that explores the experience of living through war, as told by the American soldiers who are fighting in it. Robert Duvall, Aaron Eckhart and Josh Lucas are among the actors doing dramatic readings of various soldiers' writings. These private works, including letters, poems, essays, journals and fiction, open a window into the personal impact of recent conflicts. The film is an initiative created by the National Endowment for the Arts, which worked with the documentary maker Richard E. Robbins. It had its debut in February at Film Forum in New York and opened theatrically on Friday in Los Angeles and Boston but will also be released this week in Seattle, St. Louis and other cities. Those who miss it in theaters can catch it on April 16 on most PBS stations. ''AQUA TEEN HUNGER FORCE COLON MOVIE FILM FOR THEATERS'' is a movie better seen late, perhaps in an altered state of some kind. This R-rated, 2-D animated feature is about three crime-fighting fast food items -- Frylock, Master Shake and Meatwad -- seeking truth and justice (not really). It's a feature-length riff on the animated series created by a couple of offbeat slackers, Matt Maiellaro and Dave Willis, whose series can be seen be seen on the Cartoon Network's late-night block of programming, Adult Swim. The creators' sense of humor makes ''South Park'' look positively tame. (One of the more printable things they do is set a poodle on fire.) The series has a cult following, natch, so screenings might be raucous affairs. Opens nationwide Friday.

To the Editor: Thank you for the poignant and compelling article about Zach O'Connor (''Accepting an Identity, and Gaining Strength,'' by Michael Winerip, Parenting, April 1). It succinctly described his pain and suffering in the closet, while sharing his spiritual liberation and self-acceptance after ''coming out'' at 13.

DROHAN--William N. Died peacefully at his home in Germantown, MD, on Sunday, March 25, following a four-year battle with metastatic lung cancer. Dr. Drohan, formerly of Springfield, VA, and Santa Monica, CA, was 60. He was a well-known microbiologist and educator who will be remembered for many contributions to science, especially his commitment to improving blood safety, his pioneering work in transgenic proteins to treat hemophilia and other bloodrelated disorders, important contributions made in investigating mad cow disease in the blood supply, and his development of novel ways to treat traumatic injuries including bandages to stem hemorrhage. He received a B.A. degree in Bacteriology from UCLA and a Ph.D. in Medical Microbiology and Immunology from UCLA School of Medicine. Dr. Drohan was equally dedicated to scientific research and to mentoring students and young scientists. His career included important positions with the National Cancer Institute, the American Red Cross, and private companies dedicated to treating bloodborne disorders, most recently as Chief Scientific Officer at STB, Ltd., as well as Chief Scientific Officer at Inspiration Biopharmaceuticals, Inc., and previously Chief Scientific Officer of Clearant, Inc. He also served as Professor in the Graduate Program of the Department of Genetics of George Washington University and formerly as Adjunct Professor in the Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering at the University of Maryland. Dr. Drohan published more than 145 scientific papers and holds 30 U.S. patents. He served on the editorial boards of several scientific journals, and was a member of the Scientific Steering Committee for Blood Products at the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research and Chairman for the Panel on Biotechnology of the National Research Council. Bill is survived by his beloved wife, Marian, and their five children, Colleen (Ross), Maureen, Kathleen, Laura, and Craig; his brothers and sisters, Robert, Judy, Christina, Deborah, Brian, and Theresa; as well as numerous cousins, nieces, and nephews. He leaves to them and to his friends, colleagues, and students, a legacy of scientific achievement and inspirational leadership accompanied by an extraordinary level of kindness and generosity. The Coalition for Hemophilia B has established a scholarship fund in Bill's name. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to The Dr. William N. Drohan Scholarship Fund, 225 West 34th Street, Suite 710, New York, NY 10122. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, April 14, at 1:00pm at St. Paul's Catholic Church, 9240 Damascus Rd., Damascus, MD.

It is a cruel irony that Adam Greenberg, whose achievements owed little to luck and everything to hard work, talent and determination, should have his career brutally thwarted, if not yet quite ended, by the ill luck of one errant pitch during his first at-bat as a major leaguer. One applauded Barry Bearak's (March 25) sensitive and rightfully compassionate portrait of this valiant young man until the final sentence, which, though ostensibly cheering, unnecessarily reminds us that everything can indeed change ''in the blink of an eye.''

Those looking for understated baubles will do better passing on the jewelry company Lia Sophia's latest collection, Rue Royale. With its giant dome rings, cabochon necklaces and cuff bracelets adorned with colored crystals, the line was designed with one purpose in mind: to make a statement. ''The goal is to be noticed, to have people come up to you and talk about the jewelry,'' said the line's designer, Dani Stahl, who is also the accessories director at Nylon magazine. ''It's not for the shy.'' Extroverts like Sienna Miller, Teri Hatcher and Kate Hudson have been seen in the Art Deco-inspired pieces in the line, which range in price from $150 cocktail rings to $1,200 medallion necklaces, and can be purchased at liasophia.com. LOLA OGUNNAIKE

Funeral 2:30, April 8th at Montefiore Cemetery, Queens. Memorial service 1:00, April 9th, at Clearbrook. Donations to Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation or Princeton Home Care Hospice Program.

IN January, a 13-year-old wielding what looked like a .38-caliber revolver tried to rob a Chinese restaurant in Mount Vernon, N.Y., until workers wrested the gun from him. In February, a 16-year-old boy in Clifton, N.J., accompanied by a friend, stuck what appeared to be a .45-caliber handgun in a man's chest and stole his cocker spaniel.

At some companies, changes in chief executives' pay roughly corresponded with changes in their shareholders' total return last year. Several exceptions were in favor of shareholders, while other outliers favored C.E.O.'s. Entergy J. Wayne Leonard $15.5 million His pay includes $7.8 million in stock, which can be cashed out in only three years. General Electric Jeffrey R. Immelt $15.2 million Mr. Immelt's 2006 pay includes a $6.3 million stock award that is subject to cash flow and investor return over 5 years. Citigroup Charles O. Prince III $24.9 million Among Wall Street chiefs, the embattled Citigroup boss received the lowest annual pay package. Merrill Lynch E. Stanley O'Neal $46.4 million A change-in-control at Merrill could land Mr. O'Neal a $251 million exit package. Berkshire Hathaway Warren E. Buffett $214,250 In 2006, Mr. Buffett received $100,000 in base pay. Of course, he holds $40.7 billion in Berkshire shares. Apple Steven P. Jobs $1.00 Mr. Jobs received only $1 in total compensation. But his year-end holdings of Apple stock exceeded $414 million. AT&T Edward E. Whitacre Jr. $31.5 million Mr. Whitacre can also expect about $74 million in deferred pay and $84 million in pension in retirement. Occidental Petroleum Ray R. Irani $52.1 million Even with a pay cut, Mr. Irani was second on the 2006 list; he also cashed out $270 million stock option profits. Washington Mutual Kerry K. Killinger $18.1 million Mr. Killinger's pay fell by nearly 30% while shareholders enjoyed a 9.3% return in 2006. Amgen Kevin W. Sharer $18.6 million Mr. Sharer's pay rose about 11% in 2006. Amgen's stock dropped 13.4% drop last year. Texas Instruments Richard K. Templeton $12.4 million In 2006 less than 20% of his pay was tied to concrete performance targets. Toll Brothers Robert I. Toll $23.4 million Mr. Toll received a $17.5 million bonus last year, about 2.5 percent of profits, as shares fell 21.7%. Motorola Edward J. Zander $12.7 million Mr. Zander's pay in 2006 included $350,999 for personal use of corporate aircraft. Goldman Sachs Group Lloyd C. Blankfein $54.3 million Mr. Blankfein was the highest paid chief on Wall Street and off. Graph tracks 2006 shareholder total return* and change in chief executive's compensation from previous year for selected companies. Off the Charts A look at some of the outliers shows examples of extreme growth in pay. Three of the N.B.A.'s leading scorers got an assist from Steve Candeloro last month. ''LeBron James was throwing a party for his son, and he asked me to send him 500 basketball-shaped mugs,'' said Candeloro, the concierge manager at the N.B.A. Store in Manhattan.

With the New York City Opera's ''FLAVIO'' safely under way, more Handel opera arrives this week at the Metropolitan Opera in the form of ''GIULIO CESARE.'' The two Handels battle it out on Tuesday night at Lincoln Center, separated by only a few hundred feet. There will be more breathing room between the two later in the week. ''Flavio'' repeats Thursday and Saturday, ''Cesare'' on Friday. Handel operas have become a major new archaeological dig for opera companies and an increasing audience favorite; ''Cesare'' has helped lead the restoration. The Met offers a splendid pair of principals: the countertenor David Daniels and the soprano Ruth Ann Swenson, along with Patricia Bardon and Alice Coote. Harry Bicket conducts. Tuesday and Friday at 7:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $375. Two other interesting opera productions visit from across the Atlantic this week. Benjamin Britten's ''CURLEW RIVER'' comes to the Japan Society by way of the Rouen/Haute-Normandie Opera. Yoshi Oida, based in Paris, directs. Thursday through Saturday at 7:30 p.m., 333 East 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 715-1258, japansociety.org; $52. Mozart's familiar ''ZAUBERFLÖTE'' gets a spiffy update from the South African director William Kentridge. Expect high-tech fantasy and undertones of apartheid in this production from La Monnaie in Brussels, at the Brooklyn Academy Of Music. Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday at 7:30 p.m., 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; $30 to $125.

Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive of Ford, has a big fan in Funkmaster Flex, the hip-hop disc jockey and car aficionado known for his eye-catching car customizing. The host of ''Ride With Funkmaster Flex'' on Spike TV, the D.J. was on hand at the New York auto show last week, where he introduced the Ford Expedition Funkmaster Flex Edition, the latest project he has done with Ford. His Navigator, decked out in red and black paint with orange pinstripes, will be sold in limited quantities beginning this fall.

IT is a season of renewal for Christians and Jews as they commemorate momentous events in their histories: for Christians, the resurrection of Jesus; for Jews, the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from slavery in Egypt. As Jews began celebrating the eight days of Passover at sundown last Monday, Christians observed the final, most solemn days of Lent in preparation for Easter services this weekend. Here are a handful of stories about different faith communities around the region. Sunday school was under way at the Segunda Iglesia Pentecostal Juan 3:16, a squat, unassuming group of buildings that make up one of the oldest Spanish churches in Port Chester, N.Y. In one of the small, interlocking rooms, Eva Manani led her class through the week's lesson. ''Jesús es bueno, sí?'' she asked. The 22 boys and girls, all 5 to 7 years old, called back, ''Sí!''

Julia Otis, 25, of La Jolla, Calif.: ''I was in Dakar for about seven months on an internship with Human Rights Watch, then left to take this crazy loop through West Africa. The train ride was the beginning. It was like a ghost train. It went about five kilometers an hour and would stop in every frontier town with a population of five and some lady selling bananas. In the photo, I was trying to get a breath of fresh air and a little space from my seatmate, whom we had dubbed Madame Crazy. She had some strange habits, including scratching flakes of skin off her feet and brushing them onto me. We had a very intimate time together, Madame Crazy and I, sleeping curled up next to each other like kittens. Despite the filth and the heat, it was a great way to start off the trip: 48 hours with absolutely nothing to do but think about what I was embarking on and stare out the window watching the baobab trees go by.'' As told to Seth Kugel

Jay Leno The big story, Iranian President Mahmoud has released those 15 British captive soldiers. He released them after they were held hostage for 13 days. Or, as we call that in this country: JetBlue. The sailors were brought to the palace to meet with the Iranian president before being released. The sailors were given suits but no ties, because ties are considered a Western extravagance. You know, as opposed to living in a palace.

Harris McMillian arrived at Barry Avenue African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church in Mamaroneck, N.Y., almost four years ago, the youngest member of her new congregation was 65.

Should you happen to wander into Dance Theater Workshop's gallery space this month, be prepared to be confronted with your own likeness, or some version of it. In ''A CURE FOR SURVEILLANCE,'' Jonah Bokaer and Liubo Borissov have used motion-capture technology to record images of the dancers Michelle Mola and Douglas Letheren. This archive of movements will be intertwined with live images of people entering the gallery; that means you, boys and girls. ''Surveillance'' inaugurates the workshop's Gallery Installation Fellowship program, so expect more experiments in the coming months. Monday through April 28, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily, with a public reception on Friday from 6 to 7:30 p.m., 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-007, 2rem.net/projects/cure4s; free. While Mr. Bokaer and Mr. Borissov toy with the fear that somebody is always lurking and watching, a new work by Amanda Loulaki and Short Mean Lady goes in the opposite direction, exploring the fear of emptiness. In ''DELIRIUM, OR THAT TASTE IN MY MOUTH,'' Ms. Loulaki, a Crete-born choreographer, working with the performers Carolyn Hall, Rebecca Serrell and Pedro Osorio, plays with a nonlinear structure, making free association more important than more traditional notions of context and narrative. Thursday through Sunday at 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194, danspaceproject.org; $15. Two days before Palissimo presented the premiere of ''LE PETIT MORT/NOW IT'S TIME TO SAY GOODBYE'' at P.S. 122 in December, the dancer Ellen Cremer injured herself falling off a ladder. On opening night another dancer, Saar Harari, tore his meniscus, and the rest of the run had to be canceled. Perhaps the choreographer, Pavel Zustiak, should consider a more hopeful title for his next dance. But first, ''Le Petit Mort'' lives again. In addition to Mr. Zustiak and his fine ensemble of dancers, including the terrific Gina Bashour, the dark, sexually charged show boasts contributions from the video artist Tal Yarden and an accompanying exhibition by the photographer Jose Aragon. Thursday through next Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Saturday and Sunday at 4 p.m., 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101, ps122.org; $15 to $20.

''Rare'' concert appearances are usually not so rare; touring pays, so if they can get a gig, most musicians will sooner or later find their way back to New York. But this week is a true rarity: JANDEK, a Texas singer, guitarist, occasional keyboardist and all-around musical sphinx who since the late 1970s has released dozens of strange and challenging albums while having virtually no public persona. Creaky and dissonant, with vocals that go from wounded groans to screams, his music is a nightmarish variation of folk-rock, and over the years he has become a kind of Thomas Pynchon of music. For years no one was sure if the gaunt figure pictured on Jandek's album covers was even him. But a few years ago Jandek -- whose real name may or may not be Sterling Smith -- started to break out of his shell with a very light touring schedule that included a couple of shows in New York. Onstage he was appropriately enigmatic: Beanpole-thin, with a pale, severe face, he played stark, squally music with a small band, not speaking a word to his audience. But everybody clapped madly nonetheless, and is sure to do again on Saturday when Jandek returns for one show, backed by Tim Foljahn (of Two Dollar Guitar) on bass and the drummer Jim White (of the Dirty Three). To date Jandek is believed to have played fewer than 30 concerts. Who knows when, or if, he will return again? 8 p.m., Abrons Arts Center, Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Lower East Side, (212) 598-0400, henrystreet.org; $20.

In many multibillion-dollar deals, conflicts of interest are an unavoidable way of life. The multiple roles that Merrill Lynch and Citigroup played in the $8.2 billion sale of Tribune — advising the company in the sale process as well as providing financing to the winning bidder, Samuel Zell — show these conflicts on a grand scale, DealBook wrote in a column in Sunday’s New York Times. Tribune, a publishing and broadcasting giant, did take steps to preserve objectivity, forming a special committee and hiring an outside adviser. But the situation still raises questions about whether Mr. Zell was given a privileged seat at the negotiating table.

Carl Pavano won tonight for the first time since May 22, 2005. When we talked with him after the game, someone said it must have felt like a lifetime since he won.

The talk show host was taken off the air for two weeks after an outcry over racially disparaging remarks he made about the Rutgers University women's basketball team. During his program last Wednesday, Mr. Imus referred to the players as "nappy-headed ho's."
Let us count the ways.

My Tuesday column (the last from my Afghan/Pakistan trip) is about democracy in Pakistan and our excessively close embrace of Musharraf. The larger point I was trying to make is that the best way to fight terrorism and fundamentalism is often by building schools, not shipping weapons.

It's not uncommon, at least in some Democratic circles, to ponder the possibilities of a joint presidential ticket of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama. And in most conversations, the names are listed in precisely that order.

Whenever companies sue each other, my ears perk up. Not that I really care who wins, but lawsuits often showcase hidden vulnerabilities. Inevitably, as the fight plays out, the market thinks a lot differently about the long-term prospects of both parties, and money often sloshes away to play elsewhere.

I wasn't planning on seeing "Grindhouse" this weekend. I had imagined it packed with film students and cinema buffs, laughing out loud at obscure film references. And as big of a Quentin Tarantino fan as I am, I was fully prepared to wait out the first weekend blitz.

The city inspector who gave a KFC/Taco Bell in Greenwich Village a passing grade one day before television crews taped rats scurrying around the restaurant was forced out today after two city agencies reviewed the episode.
The more we learn about Wal-Mart's security operation, the more it sounds scary.
Six Democratic presidential candidates will be participating in the virtual town hall meeting tomorrow night that has been set up by MoveOn.org, the liberal on-line advocacy group.

Wall Street's collective heart was set aflutter earlier Monday after a report from a British newspaper said that Dow Chemical would be the target of a $50 billion leveraged buyout. If true, the deal would have been the biggest trophy yet for private equity firms, two of whom have not even completed the $45 billion takeover of TXU, the Texas energy giant.

Kaye, the chief judge for the State of New York, held an extraordinary new conference in Albany on Monday to lament the fact that the long-delayed raise for the state's judges was delayed again this year when it was left out of the budget agreement between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Legislature.

An observation, otherwise known as something I've never understood: During the pre-game introductions at Shea today, the fans here booed the Phillies' video coordinators, equipment managers and trainers. Shares of Palm were down 2.6 percent to $17.16 in late-afternoon trading Monday, even as the major stock indexes hardly budged. Investors may simply have been nervous ahead of Palm's analyst and investor day on Tuesday. Or they may have been reacting to statements by Palm chief executive Ed Colligan in an interview with Bloomberg News, in which he said that he is not concerned about calls for his company to be sold. Just a few weeks ago, reports on Unstrung.com, CNBC and elsewhere fueled takeover speculation about Palm, which makes the Treo smartphone, lifting its shares as high as $19.50 in intraday trading. No bid materialized, and the stock has fallen more than 11 percent.

Carried interest, a major source of fees for private equity funds, has been the subject of controversy in recent weeks, as some lawmakers started talking up the notion of taxing it at a higher rate. Now comes more fodder for debate: Buyouts magazine reports that some midsize private equity firms are raising their carried interest (essentially their cut of the profits from a fund's investments) from the industry standard of 20 percent to 25 percent. As described by Dan Primack of PE Week Wire, the higher fee is part of a tradeoff: In exchange for the extra 5 percent, a firm agrees to hold down the size of the fund it is raising.

BMO Capital Markets, the investment banking arm of the Canadian securities firm BMO Financial Group, said Monday it hired Scott R. Singer as a New York-based managing director in its media, communications and technology group. Mr. Singer was previously the head of Deloitte's United States media and entertainment practice.
