Here's the quote of the day in media land, from The Los Angeles Times article on Samuel Zell, who plans to take control of the Tribune Company:

Fashion designers take the bows, yet the fashion world knew of Steven Robinson, the assistant to John Galliano, who died suddenly last week in Paris at 38. Steven worked with John at both Dior and Galliano, on men's and women's, on haute couture and ready-to-wear, and they worked together from the late 1980s, when chronically short of money, everything rode on hopefulness and John's genius. When John went to Dior, so did Steven and Bill Gaytten, his other longtime assistant. I always thought of them as the luckiest boys in fashion - hard-working, yes, but lucky, lucky to be in Paris at that time in their lives. Steven helped make real John's fantastic ideas, though somehow this doesn't really touch all that he did. Steven was usually the first person I'd see backstage after a show. A burly figure, he always looked flushed and happy and in a hurry. "Did you like the show?" he'd say, and, of course, I knew that he knew that I did. "Yes, Steven." It took nothing away from Steven Robinson that he was the assistant in the house. It is a great pity that he is gone.

As a topic of discussion and cause for hand-wringing among restaurant lovers, myself included, the difficulties and exigencies of getting reservations in a city like New York seems to grow only more and more popular.
Despite the huge hauls being reported by some of the top candidates in both the Republican and Democratic 2008 fields, fundraising efforts begin revving up again this week.

In these days of flush private equity funds, the markets seem afraid to discount even unlikely-seeming rumors of a leveraged buyout. Consider Dow Chemical, whose shares hit a 52-week high on Monday after a British newspaper reported over the weekend that an investor group was considering a $50 billion bid for the company. Such a deal, if it happened, would be the largest buyout transaction ever, topping the recent proposal to take Texas energy company TXU private.

Canaan Partners, after injecting $8.5 million along with Yahoo in BharatMatrimony.com, is opening its wallet once again for an Indian start-up. The Business Standard reports that the venture capital firm has invested about $2.5 million in an unnamed Delhi start-up that provides remote desktop services for American and British customers.
Ah, the Shea Stadium press box. Such a sight for sore eyes, and I'm not sure how many times I've ever felt the need to say that.

Alexei Mordashov may still have mergers on his mind. The chief executive of Severstal, who once tried unsuccessfully to combine with Belgium's Arcelor to help fend off Mittal Steel, told the Financial Times that he is interested in pursuing a deal with one of his fellow Russian steel makers. In an interview with the paper, Mr. Mordashov said that he would not rule out a deal with any of his competitors, Evraz, Novolipetsk or Magnitogorsk.

Adam Frieman, until recently the deputy head of United States equity capital markets at UBS, has joined Probitas Partners, a placement agency. Mr. Frieman becomes a principal in Probitas's New York office, focusing on relationship and liquidity management, Probitas said. San Francisco-based Probitas provides services including placement of private equity funds

Farallon Capital Management, the $26 billion hedge fund, has agreed to buy the manufactured home community business of Affordable Residential Communities for about $1.8 billion. In a statement, Affordable said it would keep its insurance business and use the sale's proceeds to finance additional acquisitions. The company owns and operates about 57,264 home sites in 275 communities in 23 states.
The chipmaker, whose forecast was well below Wall Street’s expectations, announced a restructuring to lower costs.
From The Empire Zone notebook published today:

Can you be placed on the government's "terrorist watch list" for delivering an anti-Bush lecture? Walter F. Murphy, emeritus professor of law at Princeton, thinks that's what happened to him. "On 1 March 07, I was scheduled to fly on American Airlines to Newark, N.J., to attend an academic conference at Princeton University, designed to focus on my latest scholarly book, "Constitutional Democracy," published by Johns Hopkins University Press this past Thanksgiving," Murphy writes at the group legal blog Balkinization. "When I tried to use the curb-side check in at the Sunport, I was denied a boarding pass because I was on the Terrorist Watch list." Murphy adds:

The fact that we were going to take a long weekend in Savannah, before we sat down with another architect, shows just how much my attitude about building our dream home had changed in just a matter of months.

The Warner Music Group is considering a merger with EMI by making a direct appeal to shareholders to undermine the opposition of EMI's management, The Times of London reported on Sunday. The EMI board last month rejected what it described as a "preconditional offer" at 260 pence per share. Any deal between the two companies, which rank No. 3 and No. 4 in recorded music sales, would require clearance by competition regulators.

While Wall Street eyes the Blackstone Group's looming initial public offering with jealousy, investors looking for an edge into learning how one of the world's most-connected money manager's trades can study the holdings of its equity hedge fund. The New York Post takes a look at filings made by Blackstone's Kailix Advisors fund and finds that the $1.3 billion fund has made a massive wager on the energy sector.

Not so long ago, the talk about hedge funds was about their money -- the art their managers bought or the salaries they paid themselves. But now as the discussion has moved to whether hedge funds bid up the price of oil, or even if they are the virus that could kill the market, New York Magazine has devoted its latest issue to those lightly regulated investment pools.

Morgan Stanley and Time Warner settled claims against them in a 2003 lawsuit that alleged AOL Time Warner fraudulently inflated its online advertising revenue and subscriber counts, the investment bank said in a regulatory filing Friday. Morgan Stanley was named as a defendant for its role as Time Warner's adviser in the merger with America Online in 2001 and as underwriter of bond offerings completed in 2001 and 2002.

Goldman Sachs won a contract to advise Emirates Bank International and National Bank of Dubai on merging, the lenders said on Monday. The two banks, in which the government of Dubai has stakes, said last month they would merge to create the Gulf's biggest lender.

Now that Samuel Zell has won Tribune, is he planning to sell off The Los Angeles Times? That question was on industry observers' minds after Mr. Zell and his wife, Helen, dined Friday with Hollywood mogul David Geffen, who has for some time now been angling to gain control of the newspaper.

Mirant, a power company with a market capitalization of more than $10 billion, said early Monday it had hired J.P. Morgan Chase to help it explore strategic options including a possible sale of the entire company. The strategic review, which Mirant said was intended to "enhance stockholder value," comes less than a year after Mirant withdrew its hostile bid for a rival, NRG Energy, after the $8 billion offer sparked a shareholder revolt. A few months ago, the Texas utility TXU agreed to be acquired by a pair of private equity firms, leading some analysts to suggest that Mirant could be a possible takeover candidate as well.
The cult status of James J. Cramer, the host of the CNBC television show "Mad Money," may derive more from the manic atmosphere he creates on the show than the sagacity of his stock tips.

Some of Silicon Valley's most powerful venture capitalists and technology investors have joined an investment group that is preparing to challenge cellphone carriers, cable and satellite companies for valuable radio spectrum that will be freed when television broadcasters convert to digital signals.

The private equity consortium stalking J Sainsbury offered the British supermarket chain's shareholders a quarter of the company in stub equity as part of its 9.7 billion pound ($19 billion) takeover bid, according to The Times of London.

The Daily Reel, which filters and reviews user-generated video in search of the next rising star, has landed seed financing on the way to a first round. Prism VentureWorks, based in Westwood, Mass., provided the six-figure seed round. According to the Red Herring, The Daily Reel employs editors to separate creative Web gems from Aunt Mathilda's vacation video and hopes to gain the support of advertisers and sponsors eager to hook up with the creative community.

A consortium of Middle Eastern investors and American buyout firms is reportedly preparing a $50 billion bid for the Dow Chemical Company in what could be the biggest leveraged buyout ever. According to The Sunday Express, a financing package has been put in place for a break-up bid of between $52 and $58 a share and a formal offer valuing the company at at least $50 billion could come by the end of this week.

Half of Congress makes its way back to Washington this week as the Senate returns to challenge the Bush administration on stem cell research in addition to the war in Iraq and the firing of eight federal prosecutors.

In what could be the year's largest initial public offering to date, MetroPCS Communications is looking to raise as much as $1 billion when it goes public April 18. The wireless phone service provider last week filed to price 50 million shares for its upcoming I.P.O. at between $19 an $21 each.

The Primedia Enthusiast group still has the attention of several potential bidders, but the $1 billion price tag for the media group has given some pause, according to The New York Post. Those still eyeing the group, whose titles include Motor Trend, Powder, Surfing and the Practical Horseman, are Veronis Suhler Stevenson, with backing from Leonard Green Partners; Curtco Media, in conjunction with the Blackstone Group; Elevation Partners; and Quadrangle Group, the report said.
In an effort to bring Wall Street veteran Vikram Pandit into the fold, Citigroup is considering shelling out as much as $600 million for the former Morgan Stanley banker's hedge fund, Old Lane.

A few more names have been added to the line-up of potential bidders for the Chicago Cubs. A wealthy Chicago businessman, Don Levin, who has turned the city's minor-league Wolves into a winner in hockey, has been contacted by the baseball team's owner, Tribune, and is putting together a bid, he told The Chicago Tribune.

Kraft Foods, which exited the candy business two years ago, may be looking to get back into it in a big way. The Chicago Tribune reports that Kraft may have its eye on London-based Cadbury Schweppes, which under pressure from investor Nelson Peltz announced plans to sell its soft drinks business, which includes Dr. Pepper, Snapple and 7 Up.

Cisco Systems may be gearing up for some big plays, according to BusinessWeek. In an effort to increase growth at the networking company, Ned Hooper, who heads up business development, which includes mergers and acquisitions as well as venture capital investments, is looking to make bigger-and potentially riskier-acquisitions than the company has ever done before, according to the magazine.

The $10 billion medical devices giant about to be spun off from Tyco International plans to introduce itself to the world next week in Fenway Park. The company, Covidien, has signed a multiyear deal estimated to be worth seven figures to become a sponsor of the Boston Red Sox, a pact that will give Covidien's new logo prime real estate in the middle of the left-field wall at the ballpark.

Citigroup has agreed to buy Taiwan's Bank of Overseas Chinese for 14.1 billion Taiwan dollars ($426 million) amid growing foreign interest in Taiwan's undervalued banking sector. Citigroup will acquire 100 percent of the company in the all-cash deal, a board member, Weng Chien, told Reuters. Under terms of the deal, Citigroup will pay 11.80 Taiwan dollars per share, the companies said in a statement. The acquisition will increase Citigroup's Taiwan-based assets to $22.8 billion.

Harrah's Entertainment shareholders approved a $17.1 billion buyout by two private equity groups Thursday in the largest deal ever to take a publicly held casino company private, officials said. Shareholders controlling 66 percent of outstanding stock approved selling Harrah's, the world's largest casino company, to the Apollo Management Group and the Texas Pacific Group, Harrah's officials announced. Harrah's board had unanimously recommended approval.

Many of the most interesting nuggets on executive pay are buried so deep in the new corporate filings that it helps to bring along a calculator and a shovel. The Securities and Exchange Commission's new disclosure rules were supposed to make it easier for investors to understand how top managers were being paid. But piles of new data and proxy statements that are about as easy to parse as the federal tax code have even experts scratching their heads.

It has all the makings of a standard Italian financial melodrama, with the usual cast of characters. There is a struggling company that is a takeover target, and the controlling shareholder trying to squeeze what he can from a bad investment. Add to that a just-resigned chairman, a group of minority shareholders excluded from the deal, and foreign buyers facing a reluctant government and skeptical financial establishment.

Berkshire Hathaway, the company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, says it has acquired a 10.9 percent stake in Burlington Northern Santa Fe, becoming the railroad company's largest shareholder. Berkshire owned 39,027,430 shares of Burlington Northern with a market value of $3.23 billion as of April 5, according to a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Before Friday, Berkshire had not disclosed a stake in the railroad, America's second-largest behind Union Pacific.

HERSHKOWITZ--Dorothy, 62, of Newton Centre, MA, formerly of Queens, NY, on April 6, 2007. Loving mother of Alexander and Jonathan Bohn and cherished wife of Dave Evans. Beloved friend and teacher of so many. Also survived by her brother, Noah Hershkowitz and his wife Rosalyn and her two nieces, Deborah Hershkowitz and Elaine Catz. Services at the Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA on Tuesday, April 10. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to National Ovarian Cancer Coalition, Inc. 500 NE Spanish River Blvd, Suite 8, Boca Raton, FL 33431. For further information, please call the Levine Chapel at 617-277-8300.

STUART--Catherine, Ph.D., The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and Society are deeply grieved by the sudden loss of one of it's most treasured and beloved colleagues. Dr. Stuart was intimately involved in almost every vital aspect of Institute functioning; as Training and Supervising Analyst; Member of the Council of Fellows and the Training and Admissions Committees; Co-Founder of the Eating Disorders, Compulsions and Addictions Service; Chair of the Diversity Committee; teaching faculty in several divisions and cogent supporter of the application of psychoanalysis to organizational work. She offered her professional expertise and fine intellect with singular generosity, and applied herself to all tasks with passionate energy. Cathy's colleagues, students, and patients were the fortunate recipients of her wisdom and of her warmth, curiosity, and lively humor. She embraced life fully with a profound love for her family for whom our sympathy is beyond words. The psychoanalytic community has lost one of it's bright lights. Dr. Joerg Bose, Director Dr. Charles Harrington, President, Board of Trustees Dr. Clark Sugg, President, White Society

Bright Eyes ''Cassadaga'' (Saddle Creek) Excess helped make Conor Oberst endearing. As the singer and songwriter of Bright Eyes for a decade, he has been almost too sincere, too articulate, too sensitive, too self-conscious and too ambitious. Yet all that passion added up to a precocious charm. His willingness to detail every romance and reverie made him startlingly prolific and made his fans feel like confidants. But he's not a teenager from Nebraska anymore: he's a 27-year-old bandleader and one of indie rock's biggest stars. And he paused to think about it, which can be a mistake.

Magazines remain a healthy place for advertising, with growth everywhere except for the home furnishings and financial, insurance and real estate categories, which reflects the downturn in housing starts and home sales. Direct-to-consumer ad campaigns remain a strong vehicle for pharmaceutical companies, and the drug category led the field with 15.8 percent growth from 2006. Even in those categories where the number of advertising pages fell -- food, apparel and technology -- there was an increase in revenue. SHELLY FREIERMAN

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.03 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 5.09 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 5.08 percent.

FERBER--Andrew H., of Bronxville on March 30, 2007. Beloved Husband of Carol Makovich, father of James, son of Jerome and Rosalind Ferber. Andy was an attorney for the NYS Court System. A memorial is scheduled at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 1 to 3 pm, Sunday April 22, with remembrances at 2 pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the American Heart Association.

Laura Veirs ''Saltbreakers'' (Nonesuch) Laura Veirs starts her sixth album with an apology -- ''Sorry I was cruel/I was protecting myself'' -- and she goes on to sing often about the heartbroken aftermath of a breakup. Her voice is girlish and unassuming, sometimes breathless, and her songs often begin with acoustic guitar picking. But she's no coffeehouse folkie all wrapped up in herself.

To our mimi who we loved and will be a part of us forever. Love, Rod and Cliff $(6$)SINGER--Leona. We our saddened to announce the peaceful passing of Leona Singer at her home at age 89 on April 8th, 2007. Adored wife of the late Herbert, loving mother of Ellen Sussman (Gordon) and Connie Stein (Richard). Loving mimi to Rodney, Pamela (Keith), Clifford and Bradley (Ken). Private interment. Family will receive visitors at her residence Wednesday 48pm and Thursday 2-8pm.

Dino Saluzzi/Anja Lechner ''Ojos Negros'' (ECM) The art of the Argentine bandoneón player Dino Saluzzi occupies the gray areas among tango, jazz and classical chamber music; he was part of the development of Tango Nuevo in the 1960s. ''Ojos Negros,'' his new duet album with the classical cellist Anja Lechner, is a slow, luxurious version of that gray. It relates to specific musical styles and histories only in passing. Moving through original harmonic routes, thick with intelligent emotion, the record is original, easy to understand and difficult to absorb. Its small dramatic gestures keep momentarily stunning you, and it takes a while to make out the overall architecture of each piece.

Governor Spitzer's original budget proposal called for charging New York's nuclear power plants $13 million to help pay for the costs the state incurs from using its National Guard to provide extra security at the plants. But the energy companies that own the plants are major campaign contributors, and employ well-connected lobbyists in Albany to protect their interests. The proposal was killed by the Legislature.

Something to keep in mind around mid-April: The state's new $1.3 billion school property tax relief program is taxable. That's right, for those who itemize property tax deductions on either their federal or state returns, New York's property tax rebate checks, which were doubled this year, are effectively taxable income, according to Edmund J. McMahon, director of the Empire Center for New York State Policy, a conservative group. Because of differences between New York and federal tax rules, more New Yorkers are likely to itemize on their federal returns and not on their state returns, Mr. McMahon said. In a hypothetical situation he described in a research note last week, Joe and Debbie Jones have a $5,000 property tax bill and get a $400 rebate check from the state. Because they itemize their deductions, they can claim only $4,600 in property taxes paid on their 2007 federal return.

LEVINE--Joshua. The attorneys and staff of Davis & Gilbert LLP are profoundly saddened by the death of our partner and mentor Josh Levine, a brilliant lawyer, compassionate friend, and loving husband, father and grandfather. A ''lawyer's lawyer'', Josh joined our firm in 1937 and, but for his service in the United States Army during the Second World War, gave his next 49 years to our practice, retiring in 1986. Even then, he would return often to offer his guidance, support and warmth of heart. Once described by Mary Wells Lawrence as the best agency lawyer in the business, Josh was an expert in, indeed he developed much of, the law of advertising. Among his many devoted clients, was William Bernbach with whom Josh formed the advertising company Doyle Dane Bernbach, precursor to todays Omnicom Group Inc. We are deeply indebted to Josh for his professional abilities, his leadership, his vision and integrity, all of which enhanced our practice and greatly enriched our lives.

GRAHAM--Colin. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of director Colin Graham, whose imaginative staging of John Corigliano's The Ghosts of Versailles contributed so much to the success of that opera's world premiere here in 1991. We also remember him for two new productions of Britten's Death in Venice (U.S. premiere in 1974 and a second production 1994), as well as his La Traviata (1981), and Cosi fan tutte (1982). We offer our sincerest condolences to his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

Esa-Pekka Salonen, the onetime wunderkind from Finland who has led the Los Angeles Philharmonic as music director for 15 seasons, has decided to leave the orchestra when his term ends in 2009. His successor? A wunderkind from Venezuela named Gustavo Dudamel, one of the hottest -- and youngest -- conducting properties around. Mr. Dudamel, 26, is a product of his country's extraordinary youth orchestra system, founded three decades ago to help disadvantaged youngsters. It has grown into a network of scores of ensembles, training hundreds of thousands of musicians. He is music director of its capstone, the Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra, which he joined as a violinist at 11.

''Imus in the Morning'' is scheduled to start this morning like any other, with Don Imus and his crew cracking wise about the weekend's events, riffing off the news and chatting with Evan Thomas, one of Newsweek's top guns. Later Tom Oliphant, Washington author and former op-ed columnist for The Boston Globe, will check in for some political talk. Given that Mr. Imus spent part of last week describing the student athletes at Rutgers as ''nappy-headed ho's,'' you might think he'd have trouble booking anyone, let alone A-list establishment names. But Mr. Imus, who has been given a pass for this sort of comment in the past, also generously provides airtime to those parts of the news media and political apparatus that would generally be expected to bring him to account.
To the Editor: You are right to critique the disturbing pattern of growing income inequality in the United States (''It Didn't End Well Last Time,'' editorial, April 4).

HUGHES--Sidney, 84, died peacefully at home on April 5th, 2007. He is survived by his wife, Cloty of 53 years, his children Nancy and Tom, his daughter - in - law Catherine, and grandsons Philip and Matthew, who remember a man of great good humor, gentleness and generosity. He illuminated the days of his family with love, and those of his many friends with story telling, hospitality and fellowship. His favorite verse of the Bible was ''Be not forgetful to entertain strangers: for thereby some have entertained angels unawares''.

An Unfamiliar Face Wins the Green Jacket Zach Johnson, a player in his fourth full year on the PGA Tour, outlasted the four-time champion Tiger Woods to win his first Masters in Augusta, Ga. Johnson birdied three of the last six holes for a final-round 69. His one-over-par 289 total tied the highest winning score in Masters history. Woods shot a 72 in the final round and finished tied for second place. INTERNATIONAL A3-9 New Iraq Plan Shows Signs Of Slowing Death Squads Nearly two months into the new Baghdad security push, there has been some success in reducing the number of death squad victims each day. While over all death rates for all of Iraq have not dropped significantly, a few parts of the capital have become calmer as some death squads have decided to lie low. A1 Moktada al-Sadr, the Shiite cleric and power broker, exhorted Iraqi security forces to unite with his militiamen to show their objections to the American military in Diwaniya, an embattled southern city in Iraq. He did not go so far as to call for violent confrontation. A8 Freed Britons May Sell Stories Some of the 15 British sailors and marines captured and released by Iran seemed to have decided they have a story to sell. In a highly unusual decision, Britain's Ministry of Defense acknowledged that it had agreed to permit them to offer their experiences for sale to newspapers and television stations. A9 Captors Give Israel Demands Hamas militants said that they had sent Israel a list of Palestinian prisoners to be released in exchange for an Israeli soldier they have held for over 10 months. Israeli news media quoted unidentified Israeli officials as saying that they had received the list, but a spokesman for the prime minister's office would not confirm the reports. A9 Captain Cites Currents in Crash The captain of a cruise ship that slammed into a volcanic reef before sinking off the island of Santorini blamed strong sea currents for the crash, Greece's state-run television reported. A4 Iran Searches for Ex-U.S. Agent A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Mohammad Ali Hosseini, said Iran was searching for a former F.B.I. agent, Robert Levinson, who has been missing in Iran for almost a month. He disappeared when he was on the Iranian island of Kish, where he was reported to be working on a film. A9 NATIONAL A10-14 Army Sharply Increases Prosecution of Deserters Army prosecutions of desertion and other unauthorized absences have risen sharply in the last four years, resulting in thousands more negative discharges and prison time for both junior soldiers and combat-tested veterans of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. A10 Hunger Strike at Guantánamo A new hunger strike has broken out at the American detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, with more than a dozen prisoners subjecting themselves to daily force-feeding to protest their treatment, military officials and lawyers for the detainees said. A12 Ranchers Fight Land Acquisition In Colorado, a proposed expansion of the Army's Piñon Canyon Maneuver Site threatens to uproot local ranchers, who are set to testify before state lawmakers in support of a bill that would keep the Army from acquiring nearly a half-million acres for training grounds. A10 Gingrich Criticizes Gonzales Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich became the latest Republican to criticize Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales for the dismissals of eight United States attorneys and said Mr. Gonzales should consider resigning. A12 Trial in Minister's Death Jury selection begins today in McNairy County, Tenn., in the unusual case involving a woman who is accused in the killing of her husband, a minister. A13 OBITUARIES A14-15 Sol LeWitt An artist whose deceptively simple geometric sculptures, drawings and wall paintings established him as a lodestar of modern American art, he was 78. A15 Johnny Hart The creator of the award- winning ''B.C.'' comic strip, he was 76. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Construction to Resume On New Subway Line The Second Avenue subway, which has had at least three groundbreakings in the last 40 years, is getting another on Thursday when Gov. Eliot Spitzer gives a speech and hoists a pickax, symbolically beginning construction again where it left off three decades ago. A1 Program for Black Students While many school districts have long worked to close the achievement gap between minority and white students, the Ossining, N.Y., school system has placed its second- and third-grade African-American boys in a special mentoring program in an effort to get black male students to college. A1 Town Succumbs to Sprawl The 400-acre Washington Town Center near Trenton, designed as a remedy to suburban sprawl, has become a victim of its own success: So many families have flocked to Washington Township that the schools are overflowing, property taxes are skyrocketing and the main streets are clogged. B1 SPORTSMONDAY D1-8 Johnson Wins Masters Zach Johnson won his first major championship and second PGA Tour victory at the Masters Tournament, following one of the most difficult weeks in the event's history. D1 Searching for the 'Big Horse' Which 3-year-old thoroughbred will take the nation's breath away in the Kentucky Derby and, for at least two weeks, conjure thoughts of a Triple Crown? The conversation is focusing on two colts: Nobiz Like Shobiz and Street Sense. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 New Bidders, Old Airwaves Frontline Wireless, an emerging Silicon Valley investment group, is preparing to challenge cellphone, cable and satellite companies for a valuable radio spectrum that will be freed up when television broadcasters convert to digital signals. C1 Keeping the Printers Rolling Despite record revenue and profit, Hewlett-Packard is worried that people are growing accustomed to reading only on-screen. The company is devising ways to get customers to print more Web pages. REDDY--John Joseph. John J. Reddy (Jack) passed away on Good Friday evening, April 6th, 2007, he was 87. Jack was survived by his spouse, Mary Faughnan Reddy. He was predeceased by his first wife Teresa Finn Reddy. Jack was survived by his five children, Marie T. Reddy, Bernadette A. Cahalane, Kathleen R. Walsh, Monica R. Wood and John J. Reddy, Jr. He was also survived by sixteen grandchildren, his step-daughters, Nadine Faughnan and Thomasina Faughnan and six stepgrandchildren. A parishioner at St. Joan of Arc Church for nearly 60 years, Mr. Reddy was a former Chairperson of the Bishops Lay Committee for Catholic Charities for the Diocese of Brooklyn and the former President of the Board of Directors of Catholic Charities. Mr. Reddy was retired; he had been an officer in the Commercial Factoring Division of Wells Fargo Bank, formerly United Merchants and Manufacturers. ROTHSCHILD--Diane. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Diane Rothschild. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memories bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President George Asch, Secretary $(6$)ROTHSCHILD--Diane. Died peacefully at home, surrounded by family and loved ones, on April 3rd, 2007, after a courageous five year battle with lung cancer. Born in New York City, Diane spent her adult years in Manhattan and Sagaponack, NY. Upon graduating from Adelphi University, she began a long and distinguished career in advertising. She was the most awarded copy writer during her tenure at DDB and she went on to open Grace & Rothschild with her partner Roy Grace, in 1986. She subsequently merged the agency into Della Femina Rothschild Jeary in 2000. In 2005 she was inducted into the One Club Creative Hall of Fame, one of only four women to receive that honor. After learning she had lung cancer she devoted her creative skills to creating a campaign for the Lung Cancer Alliance, designed to combat the stigma of lung cancer, and the resulting inequities of research funding. But most of all, those of us who loved her, will remember a beautiful, intelligent and gracious person, who always put others needs before her own, who was charming and witty, but never at the expense of others, and who was always compassionate and caring. We miss you so much already. Alan, Ali, Brenda and Lily. Donations will be gratefully accepted in her name for the Lung Cancer Alliance, Washington DC or The Lung Cancer Research Foundation, NYC.

MERENDINO--Vincent J, M.D. died at Englewood Hospital on Sunday morning, April 8, 2007, following a courageous battle with numerous complications. Vincent was born on January 5, 1917, in New York City. He graduated from Columbia College in 1937, and received his M.D. from New York Medical College in 1942. He was a Captain in the Marine Corps during WWII, where he was Chief of Surgery for the 112th Evacuation Hospital. Vincent had a long and distinguished medical career. Among the positions he held were; Chief of Gynecology, Prospect Hospital, (1948-1976), Professor of Clinical Obstetrics and Gynecology, New York Medical College (1976-1988); he was Chief of Service, Obstetrics and Gynecology, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital (19751986); Lecturer in Obstetrics and Gynecology, Mt. Sinai School of Medicine (1976-1986); Attending Gynecologist, Metropolitan Hospital (1954-1988); Associate Attending Gynecologist, Lenox Hill Hospital (1976-1986). Vincent is survived by his wife, Rita, his daughter, Melissa, Rita's daughter, Debra Solomon and his grandchildren, Charles and Lesly Solomon. He is further survived by his innumerable friends and family who loved and respected him dearly. Funeral services for Vincent J. Merendino will be held at 11 am on Wednesday, April 11th, at Gutterman Musichant Funeral Home, in Hackensack, NJ. Contributions may be made to Englewood Hospital.

While state lawmakers give taxpayer money to anti-gun organizations in the new budget, they also give grants to gun and hunting clubs. Then there is $2,000 for nut allergy awareness, $100,000 for a soccer hall of fame and $10,000 for a boxing hall of fame, not to mention $5,000 for a roller hockey club in Lynbrook, on Long Island, and much more for Little League and Pop Warner football teams throughout the state, depending on legislators' clout. Lawmakers also give tens of thousands of dollars to interest groups like AARP and the Empire State Pride Agenda, which lobby elected officials.

Six NATO soldiers were killed in a roadside blast in southern Afghanistan on Sunday, NATO said in a statement issued from the Kandahar air base. All six soldiers were Canadian, according to the Canadian Department of National Defense, which said on its Web site that a roadside bomb had exploded near their vehicle west of Kandahar City and that two Canadian soldiers were also wounded, one seriously.

After the Senate rejected his budget proposal to require nickel deposits on bottles of noncarbonated beverages like water and iced tea, Governor Spitzer said he was still ''hopeful that we will have a bottle bill, in some form, this legislative session.''

Philips Electronics, Amsterdam, decided to keep its worldwide media account, with spending estimated at $600 million, at Carat, part of the Aegis Group. The decision came after a review that was narrowed to Carat and Mediaedge:cia, part of the WPP Group. Chrysler Group, Auburn Hills, Mich., part of DaimlerChrysler, shifted the national creative duties for Jeep to Cutwater, San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group, from the Troy, Mich., office of BBDO Worldwide, also part of Omnicom. About half the estimated $350 million that Jeep spends each year is devoted to national ads. BBDO retains the rest of the Jeep account, including dealer ads and direct marketing. The decision came after a review that included BBDO, Cutwater and other Omnicom agencies.

An article last Monday about the reopening of the Ferry Building on Ellis Island incorrectly described some of the exterior restoration and architectural features. Don Fiorino, the project manager for the National Park Service, said workers peeled lead-coated copper (not lead) off the building's cupola (not off the eagles perched atop it). The copper was replaced with zinc-coated copper, not zinc. And the eagles are stamped, not carved.

A headline in Business Day last Monday with an article about the translation of course materials at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology into Chinese misstated the location of the project. It is based in Taiwan, not mainland China.

An article in Science Times on March 27 about graduate students who have killed their professors referred incorrectly to the case of Theodore Streleski, a Stanford University student who bludgeoned Karel deLeeuw, a Stanford math professor, to death. At the time of the killing, Mr. Streleski's academic adviser was Halsey Royden, not Dr. deLeeuw. Mr. Streleski was told by Dr. Royden that his research was sufficient to earn him a doctorate if he wrote a dissertation; Mr. Streleski was not told that after 19 years of graduate school he was not going to get a doctorate.

Mitt Romney's campaign fired off an announcement last week, trumpeting a new poll that found Mr. Romney had taken the lead among Republican presidential candidates in New Hampshire. ''Zogby: Romney Rockets!'' it said. Election day is 19 months away. No matter. The 2008 campaign cycle has been distinguished by a blizzard of polls, being conducted by news organizations and independent (and not-so-independent) groups. They are providing a near-daily measure of who is up and down in the Democratic and Republican primaries and even offering hypothetical match-ups for the general election.

Kendrick Scott Oracle ''The Source'' (World Culture Music) Kendrick Scott is a jazz drummer conversant in an ultramodern sense of propulsion: lightweight yet heavy-gauge, with room for tumbling accents and textures. He has brought this feeling to a few contemporary groups, notably the one led by the trumpeter Terence Blanchard. Now he has planted it at the center of Oracle, a cohort of smart and sympathetic players.

A front-page article on Wednesday about the drought in the West referred incorrectly to the level of Lake Powell on the Utah-Arizona border. While the lake is at the same level it was in 1973, it is not the lowest it has been since then. It was briefly lower in early 2005.

The headline on the Economic Scene column in Business Day on Thursday, about the effect of the Internet on intellectual property law, misidentified one of the areas facing the most significant challenges. It was copyrights, not trademarks.

VYING FOR RADIO SPECTRUM -- Some of Silicon Valley's most powerful venture capitalists and technology investors have joined an investment group that is preparing to challenge cellphone carriers and cable and satellite companies for valuable radio spectrum that will be freed when television broadcasters convert to digital signals. [Page C1.] THE FUTURE OF PRINTERS -- The Internet era has been good to makers of printers so far. But looking ahead, Vyomesh I. Joshi of Hewlett-Packard is concerned that if people find printing Web pages too hard and start printing less, he will have fewer coffee talks where he crows about record revenue, profit, margins and market share. [C1.] PRESS RIVALRY IN THE HAMPTONS -- This week perhaps the biggest story in The East Hampton Star involves the paper itself. The Southampton Press, the venerable paper one town over that belongs to the Louchheim family, will introduce a direct competitor, The East Hampton Press, which will come out a day earlier than The Star and will be free. (The Star costs $1.) [C1.] NO MORE SLOW BOATS FOR BOOKS -- The post office's decision to stop transporting goods via cargo ship for individual customers may not hurt big online retailers like Amazon.com, which can qualify for discounts. But thousands of smaller used- and rare-book merchants, like Rob Stuart, above, owner of Frenchboro Books in Maine, say they will suffer, because they rely on foreign demand. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi. [C6.] A MERGER COMES UNDONE -- Miles S. Nadal, the chairman and chief executive of MDC Partners, hopes to get ahead in the intensely competitive advertising industry with a contrarian strategy of almost continuous change. But following that philosophy can be fraught with risk, as was demonstrated last week with the unraveling of an acquisition and merger involving two New York agencies, which Mr. Nadal orchestrated less than two years ago. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C1.] PROXIES CLEAR AS MUD -- The Securities and Exchange Commission's new disclosure rules on executive pay were supposed to make it easier for investors to understand how top managers were being paid. But piles of new data and proxy statements that are about as easy to parse as the federal tax code have even experts scratching their heads. [C4.] A NEW XBOX 360 FEATURE -- Microsoft plans to announce today that it will make its Windows Live Messenger service available on its Xbox 360 game consoles, bringing instant messaging from the computer to the television. [C7.] FOUNDATION TAKES ON CLIMATE ISSUE -- The Doris Duke Charitable Foundation is creating a $100 million program to support research intended to encourage policies aimed at reducing the threat of global warming. [C6.] A FAKE MYSPACE PROMOTION -- The MySpace fan page with a hot pink background, tribute to Robin Sparkles, a one-hit Canadian teenage pop star from the early 1990s, was just gushing enough to be real. But it wasn't. The MySpace page was a plant, concocted by the producers of the CBS sitcom ''How I Met Your Mother,'' to play off a storyline in the show's Nov. 20 episode. [C8.] EXCLUSIVE TO THE CHICAGO TRIBUNE -- Samuel Zell, who has agreed to buy the Tribune Company, gave his first interview exclusively to The Chicago Tribune. There was no conference call with any other Tribune Company reporters who were tracking the deal, including those at The Los Angeles Times or Newsday, or in Baltimore or Hartford. [C8.] A STOCK TIP MISSES -- Jim Cramer, host of the CNBC television show ''Mad Money,'' recommended on the March 28 episode that viewers sell shares of Dendreon, a biotechnology company in Seattle. The next day, Dendreon's shares tripled when its prostate cancer vaccine was endorsed by a Food and Drug Administration panel. Some viewers are upset. [C8.] PLASTIC DOUBLES AS FUEL -- A chemistry professor has developed a ''fuel-latent plastic'' that can be used like ordinary plastic, for packaging or other purposes, but when it is waste, can easily be turned into a substitute diesel fuel. [C5.]

To the Editor: I would like to heartily second Steve Hallock's plea for legal action to ensure that Amtrak begins to have priority use of railroad tracks over freight trains (''Sidetracked Again,'' Op-Ed, April 4).

LeBLANG--Nancy Baron. Beloved wife, mother, sister, grandma, teacher and friend, passed peacefully on March 31st. She will be missed dearly and always remembered with a smile by all those whose lives she touched.

QUARTERLY REPORTS -- Earnings season gets under way with the first Dow component, Alcoa, reporting first-quarter results (Tuesday), followed by the BlackBerry maker Research in Motion (Wednesday), Rite Aid (Thursday) and another Dow component, General Electric (Friday). SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY -- The main economic news will come on Friday, with the producer price index for April and the trade deficit for March. Retailers will report their same-store sales for March (Thursday). The Federal Open Market Committee will issue minutes of its March 21 meeting (Wednesday). PAINKILLER REVIEW -- An advisory panel for the Food and Drug Administration is scheduled to meet to discuss Merck's application to market the painkiller Arcoxia in the United States (Thursday). NACCHIO TRIAL -- The defense in the trial of Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, is expected to wrap up Monday or Tuesday, and Mr. Nacchio may take the stand in his own defense.

Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich on Sunday became the latest Republican to criticize Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales for the dismissals of eight United States attorneys, and he said Mr. Gonzales should consider stepping down. ''This is the most mishandled, artificial, self-created mess that I can remember in the years, in the years I've been active in public life,'' Mr. Gingrich said on ''Fox News Sunday.''

DUBIN--Robert A. Formerly of Seagram Company. Beloved husband of Nancy, devoted father of Adam and Jon, father-in-law of Teresa Romero, loving brother of Ellen, son-in-law of Ellie Edelstein. Passed away on April 6th, 2007. Funeral services will be Tuesday, April 10th, 11:45 am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the free-trade agreement between South Korea and the United States misstated a middle initial for the director of the Global Business Center at the University of New Haven, who discussed the benefits of the deal to the American economy. She is Usha C. V. Haley, not Usha C. H.

Jubilant but careful not to lose his balance, Ted Nolan did a high-step on tiptoe along the edge of his bench, then bear-hugged his players. His first season as the Islanders' coach would roll on, tilting on its axles. Needing a victory to make the playoffs, the Islanders defeated the Devils, 3-2, on Sunday in a shootout at Continental Arena.

HILSENRATH--Elaine, Devoted wife of Joseph. Loving mother of Craig, Shelley, Dan, Jon. The glue that bound our family. Please send donations to Israel Hospital Fund, started by Dr. and Mrs. Hilsenrath, c/o Jon Hilsenrath, 100 Bar Beach Rd., Port Washington, NY 11050.

Grinderman ''Grinderman'' (Mute/Anti-) Nick Cave has knocked about before without his longtime band, the Bad Seeds, usually producing roughly similar results. But Grinderman -- his new collaboration with Martyn Casey on bass, Jim Sclavunos on drum and Warren Ellis on electric bouzouki, violin and guitars -- has the heft of something other than a spinoff. The group's self-titled debut is a 40-minute slog of coarseness and vexation. And it sounds terrific, in a turbulent fashion.
The answer to the question depends on many factors. Compare the costs of buying and renting equivalent homes.
Kurt Vonnegut's dark comic talent and urgent moral vision caught the temper of his times.

In a stark reversal of the housing market, it's now clear that people who chose renting over buying in the last two years made the right move. In much of the country, including large parts of the Northeast, California, Florida and the Southwest, recent home buyers have faced higher monthly costs than renters and have lost money on their investment in the meantime.

Think about this: in the history of baseball, only one player has ever hit more home runs in the first seven games of a season than Alex Rodriguez. That was the Hall of Famer Mike Schmidt for the Phillies in 1976. A-Rod is one of eight others who have hit six homers in the first seven games.
The Democratic presidential candidates gathered tonight - or, actually, their voices did - for what was billed as the first Virtual Town Meeting of the 2008 campaign. Topic: Iraq.

Despite the fact that the three top contenders (at this point) for the Democratic nomination say they won't take part in a September debate in Detroit sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus Institute and Fox News, the C.B.C. released a statement tonight announcing that it stands by its plan.

The Twins' starter tonight is Boof Bonser, who is 1/3 of the greatest trade in modern baseball times (in my opinion): A.J. Pierzynski to the Giants for Joe Nathan, Bonser and Francisco Liriano in 2003. Still hard to see why the Giants gave up three young pitchers for a catcher they would cut after one year.

Doug Mientkiewicz was in the on-deck circle at the Metrodome last night when a fan heckled him. This is not unusual in Minnesota, where some fans find it cool to boo Mientkiewicz even though he did not leave via free agency -- the Twins traded him in 2004.
Tom Friedman on how America can regain its international stature by taking the lead in alternative energy and environmentalism.
Pâté de campagne, or country pâté, is a variation of meatloaf that's elegant enough to serve at dinners where you want to impress your guests.

The stunningly bad proofs of my senior portraits arrived in the mail when I was home over spring break, wallowing in anxiety about my lack of post-graduation employment. The proofs themselves are of a fine quality; it is my panicked expression that ruins them.

MONTGOMERY -- The remarks by Don Imus are reverberating in the presidential campaign, with Rudolph W. Giuliani telling reporters today that the remarks were "wrong, very wrong," but adding he would continue to appear on the show in the future.
So now I have two cases of wine in my parlor beckoning me to start drinking.
Report card: Republicans give D's to Spitzer. [Capitol Confidential]
Senator John Kerry and Newt Gingrich debated climate change today.

At their news conference today, the Rutgers women's basketball team took a few questions from the media about Don Imus, the racially charged remarks he made about them and the controversy that has engulfed them.
As he was assailing Congressional Democrats for delays in passing an Iraq war spending bill, President Bush stopped to make sure he got his Democratic terminology straight.

Martin A. Armstrong, the financial adviser who has spent seven years in jail for contempt of court, was sentenced Tuesday to five additional years in prison for running what prosecutors say was a $3 billion Ponzi scheme. Judge John F. Keenan of the Southern District of New York also ordered Mr. Armstrong to pay restitution to the fraud victims, who are to receive $80 million -- plus one dollar more -- from Mr. Armstrong and others involved in the alleged scheme.

When top-producing Lehman Brothers investment banker George H. Young III abruptly resigned in February, neither Lehman nor Mr. Young -- known as Woody -- offered much in the way of a public explanation for the rift.

The struggle for the Chicago Board of Trade is more than just another bidding war. To hear the Chicago Tribune tell it, it represents a larger power grab by big New York investment banks, who favor a late bid from the IntercontinentalExchange over the previous offer from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. It is, the Chicago newspaper suggested Tuesday, the Big Apple versus the City of Big Shoulders, with New York interests working hard to make sure their city tops Chicago in the market for exchange-traded derivatives.
And in the 96th season at Fenway Park, I can see the entire field. Well, almost.

J.P. Morgan Chase has added another investment banker to its financial institutions group, according to an internal memo. Tod Perkins, who will be a managing director, comes to J.P. Morgan from HSBC Securities, where he was head of the depository institutions group for the Americas. Prior to that, Mr. Perkins was a managing director at Credit Suisse, where he focused on banks.
The V-22 Osprey, a hybrid aircraft, will be deployed to Iraq this September. Critics say its limitations may make it vulnerable to attack.
2008 Subaru Tribeca
2008 Suzuki SX4 Sedan

For a company whose raison d'etre is publishing financial data, Bloomberg LP is remarkably stingy with details about its own financial picture. But that has not stopped Fortune magazine from trying to guess how much the company, founded by New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, is worth. Using lots of back-of-the-envelope estimates, bolstered by some hitherto unreleased financial information from the company itself, Fortune calculates that Bloomberg LP may be worth about $20 billion. That would give Mr. Bloomberg, who owns more than two-thirds of the company, a stake worth a cool $13 billion.
Subaru stylists baffle me. Without getting into the nuances of each model, I wonder how a company that can design a car as outright handsome as the Legacy can also step on its own toes so often.
Too bad I didn't spot this the day it went up-April Fool's day.

Here's a peculiar investment strategy: Sell something for $39, and then buy it back less than a year later for more than $100. That's essentially what MasterCard International is proposing to do with its own stock.

Shares of BCE, which owns Bell Canada, were up as much as 7 percent Tuesday after it was reported that the company's largest shareholder was contacting other investors about a possible takeover bid. The New York Times reported that the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan has reached out in recent weeks to Caisse de Dépôt et Placement du Québec and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about pursuing a takeover, which could be valued at $45 billion, including assumed debt. DealBook has also learned that Ontario Teachers' held talks with Providence Equity Partners, a United States-based private equity firm that specializes in media and telecommunications investments.
Tour a cottage on the Georgia coast, a condo in downtown Denver and a contemporary house on the Hawaiian island of Oahu.
Princeton University is staging the premiere of a version of Pushkin’s 1825 play “Boris Godunov,” which ran afoul of the Russian government in the 1930s.

During a March conversation at Harvard, strategists for Mitt Romney accused his Republican rivals of playing up, albeit subtly, the former Massachusetts governor's Mormon faith. Dan Balz has the story in The Washington Post:
A harsh truth of the hedge-fund world is that someone's painful loss is usually someone else's big gain.

PPR, the French conglomerate whose brands include Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent, will offer 5.3 billion euros ($7.1 billion) for the German sportswear company Puma after reaching a deal to buy out a leading shareholder, PPR said Tuesday. Puma welcomed the offer and said it would recommend the bid to its shareholders.

The Senate is expected to pass legislation this week that would ease the Bush administration's limits on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research. The measure, passed by the House, is identical to the bill that passed the Senate 63 to 37 last year before being vetoed by President Bush.

Last week, Senator John McCain turned to Frederic V. Malek to help his fundraising efforts. Right away, some liberal groups brought up Mr. Malek's carrying out a request from President Richard M. Nixon in 1971 that he count the Jews at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

One week after Kohlberg Kravis Roberts dropped out of the running for J Sainsbury, two other buyout firms have followed suit. The Blackstone Group and the Texas Pacific Group have left the consortium bidding for J Sainsbury, a chain of grocery stores, after the founding family opposed an offer of less than 600 pence ($11.85) a share, Bloomberg News reported citing unnamed sources.

United Rentals, an equipment rental chain with a market capitalization of about $2.2 billion, said Tuesday it had hired UBS and Credit Suisse to help it explore strategic options including a possible sale of the company. It also said its chief executive would retire in June.

Sirion Therapeutics has picked up five new institutional investors in a Series B private equity financing that raised $45 million for the company. A new investor, Aisling Capital, led the latest round of funding. Other new investors include Advent International and Bear Stearns.

Hercules Technology Growth Capital said on Monday it had provided $22.5 million of debt financing to Ikano Communications, a provider of Internet services. Hercules is a specialty finance company providing growth capital to venture capital and private equity backed technology and life science companies.

J.P. Morgan Chase said it plans to add up to 100 people to its mutual fund services division in Boston and move the unit to new space downtown. The financial services giant said it has hired more than 150 for the Boston group since last year, which now numbers 450 and provides custody, accounting, and investment operations for mutual fund companies.

The former head of the independent movie production house First Look Studios, who left the company in March after reportedly falling afoul of the company's hedge fund backers, is back at the helm. Henry Winterstern, who resigned last month as chief of First Look, will be running the company again alongside Avi Lerner, whose Nu Image/Millennium Films bought the struggling First Look last month.

Morgan Stanley shareholders will vote Tuesday on a resolution that would give them a greater say in how the investment bank pays its top executives. The securities firm is just one of many companies facing such resolutions at their annual stockholder meetings; others include Bank of New York and Citigroup.
News on a new directing job for James Naughton and a production from the Persona Theater Company of Greece.

Bertelsmann, the owner of the publisher Random House, agreed to buy Time Warner's stake in the Bookspan book club for a reported $150 million to become the biggest operator of book, music and DVD clubs in the United States. Bookspan, a 50-50 joint venture between the biggest media companies in the United States and Europe, will be fully owned by Bertelsmann after the purchase.
April 10 - Presidential candidate Barack Obama appeared on 'The Late Show with David Letterman' Monday night, the possibility of a double ticket with Hillary Rodham Clinton.

The third time may be a charm for the Kohlberg Kravis Roberts-led consortium looking to gain control of the Australian retailer Coles Group. Coles said Tuesday that the Kohlberg consortium may top a bid of 19.7 billion Australian dollars ($16.1 billion) for the retailer by Wesfarmers.
Christopher Ashley, the director of the coming Broadway production of “Xanadu,” has been named the new artistic director of the La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego.

Despite fears that burdensome federal regulations are scaring companies away, markets in the United States are getting more foreign listings, TheStreet.com reported. During the first quarter, 19 percent of the 67 initial public offerings on the New York Stock Exchange, the Nasdaq Stock Market and the American Stock Exchange were foreign-based, according to Dealogic. That's up from 16 percent for all of last year.

The Nasdaq Stock Market posted its strongest first quarter performance for initial public offerings listings since the beginning of 2000. The total number of public offerings for the first quarter of 2007 came to 42, Nasdaq said. Six of the 10 largest offerings in the United States by proceeds raised listed on the exchange in the first quarter, led by National CineMedia -- the largest so far this year, according to Nasdaq.

Two former executives at Endocare, a medical products company based in Irvine, Calif., were indicted Monday for allegedly helping to inflate company revenue in a fraud that cost investors more than $200 million. A former chief executive, Paul W. Mikus, and a former chief financial officer, John V. Cracchiolo, were charged with wire fraud, securities fraud, filing false statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission and lying to Endocare's accountants.

Shares of Imax fell nearly 10 percent Monday after a private equity fund manager said it was seeking support from other bondholders to oppose the giant screen maker's bid for more time to file its 2006 financial results. The Catalyst Capital Group of Toronto said in a statement that it is organizing opposition to Imax's move to seek consent from bondholders for a waiver from certain financial reporting defaults.
Nicholas D. Kristof reports from Pakistan on what happens when villagers vote the 'wrong' way in elections.

The takeover drums are once again pounding out the name Algoma Steel. Algoma shares jumped 2.36 Canadian dollars to close at 53.89 Canadian dollars ($46.96) Monday on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The activity was fueled by several factors, including a report in the industry newsletter Steel Business Briefing, word that Algoma's management will brief potential bidders for the company this week, and the steady rise in steel prices.

Amid reports that Citigroup may buy the hedge fund Old Lane, The Financial Times writes that Citi's chief executive, Charles Prince, once dismissed the notion of acquiring a hedge fund manager as the "flavor of the moment." Breakingviews suggests Old Lane could bring both financial and personnel headaches for Citi.

China Citic Bank plans to raise up to 30.14 billion Hong Kong dollars ($3.86 billion) in an initial public offering ahead of its Hong Kong listing on April 27, a news report said Tuesday. The indicative price range of the "H" shares - Hong Kong dollar-denominated shares of companies based in mainland China - is 4.72 Hong Kong dollars to 6.17 Hong Kong dollars each, according to a term sheet seen by Dow Jones Newswires.

Much ink has been spilled on the question of whether social networking site Facebook will sell out and, if so, for how much. Following Google's $1.65 billion acquisition of YouTube last year, rumors percolated that Yahoo and Viacom were interested, and that Facebook's founder and chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, was holding out for a $2 billion offer.

Salesforce.com, best known for its hosted sales applications, is pushing into Web content management. The company on Tuesday expects to detail new products and the acquisition of start-up Koral, which created a Web content management service tied to Salesforce.com. Terms of the purchase of Koral, a nine-person firm based in San Mateo, Calif., which first launched its product last fall, were not disclosed.

For those wondering if private equity could sustain it's run of record fund-raising, the answer is: yes, it apparently can. Fund-raising by private equity firms in the United States rose 67 percent in the first quarter, according to Dow Jones Private Equity Analyst. Sixty-eight funds have raised $44.3 billion in the first quarter of 2007, compared with the 46 funds that raised $26.6 billion in the first quarter of last year, the newsletter said. In 2006, private equity firms raised a total $246.3 billion in 359 funds.

Take-Two Interactive Software's chief financial officer became the latest casualty at the beleaguered video game publisher following a shareholder revolt spearheaded by several activist investors. The financial officer, Karl H. Winters, announced his resignation Monday, less than two weeks after the chief executive and several board members were ousted by shareholders.

The defense rested its case Monday in the insider trading case of Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, ending widespread anticipation that Mr. Nacchio might take the stand on his own behalf.

Charles O. Prince III spent his first two years as chief executive of Citigroup adding more compliance officers and improving the bank's controls after a series of messy scandals. Now, Mr. Prince is looking to slim its bulging compliance ranks in an effort to keep the bank from getting bogged down.

Defense lawyers at the fraud trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black produced documents on Monday that a prosecution witness agreed showed that payments at the heart of the case had been publicly disclosed.

A second corporate advisory firm is urging shareholders of The New York Times Company to withhold their votes for directors at the company's annual meeting this month, underscoring the mounting investor discontent over the dual-class share structure of the Times Company and some of the strategic decisions taken by management.

After finally agreeing to sell itself to Samuel Zell following a complicated auction, Tribune is now facing a roadblock on a smaller deal. An arbitrator has ruled that Tribune's sale of The Advocate of Stamford to Gannett violated a union contract by failing to require Gannett to honor the newsroom employees' collective bargaining agreement, according to court papers filed Monday by the union.

New Century Financial, the subprime lending giant that filed for bankruptcy protection last week, should not be allowed to sell $50 million worth of mortgages to a subsidiary of the Royal Bank of Scotland, a United States trustee said Monday in court papers.

One of Canada's largest pension funds is in early talks with other pension funds and a private equity firm to form a consortium to mount a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, The New York Times reported Tuesday, citing people briefed on the discussions. Such a takeover bid would be the largest buyout in history and represent a rare effort by a pension fund, rather than a private equity firm, to lead a buyout of this size.

James J. Needham, the first full-time paid chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, died on Friday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 80. The cause was complications related to myelodysplastic syndrome, a bone marrow disorder, his son-in-law, Tim Donahue, told The New York Times.

The Mexican cement maker Cemex said that an Australian rival, Rinker, had accepted an increased takeover bid of $15.85 a share. Cemex's initial offer on Oct. 27, 2006, was $13 a share. The $15.3 billion offer is the biggest ever by a Mexican company and one of the largest in Australian corporate history.
