Compare the costs of renting and buying equivalent homes.
Behind Closed Gates.
What is the rent-vs.-buy debate like in the New York region? Two examples:.
Daisuke Matsuzaka, the dynamic pitcher from Japan, will play his first game at Fenway Park tomorrow against the Seattle Mariners.
Larry Birkhead, the former boyfriend of the late Anna Nicole Smith, said a Baharmian judge had accepted his conclusions that he was the father.

The Titans' Adam “Pacman” Jones was suspended for the entire 2007 N.F.L. season and Bengals receiver Chris Henry was suspended for the first eight games for violating the leagues personal conduct policy.
There were conflicting reports about the death toll after some of the worst fighting since the new Baghdad security plan began two month ago.
The committee’s chairman told the attorney general that the Justice Department had fallen short in its cooperation.
Members of the Palestinian faction are primed to resume attacks in Israel, the Israeli internal security service said.
The young women athletes said today that they were “deeply saddened” by the words of the radio show host.
The president asserted that Democrats are being irresponsible in not passing a bill to his liking to finance the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
The Macao government is prepared to release $25 million in funds linked to North Korea, the Treasury Department said today.
Four former paramilitary policemen were sentenced for up to 20 years in jail for their role in the 1995 massacre.
Cablevision said it would appeal a federal court ruling that blocked its rollout of a digital video recorder service.
Interest rates were unchanged for a second month after consumer prices fell and recent data signaled that economic growth in the U.S. may slow.

The French fashion retailer PPR will make a voluntary offer to take over German sportswear group Puma after reaching a deal to buy out a leading shareholder, PPR said today in a statement. A PPR unit, Sapardis, said in the statement that it would offer 330 euros of $440.40 a share of cash. The offer values Puma at close to 5.56 billion euros or about $7.43 billion, according to calculations based on Reuters data. The bid of 330 euros offers a 5 percent premium to Puma’s last closing share price of 314.25 euros. PPR said it had already agreed to buy a 27.14 percent stake from Puma’s largest shareholder, Mayfair. Closing of the agreement between Mayfair and Sapardis is subject to antitrust clearance, Puma said. Under German law, a takeover offer is only mandatory once a shareholder crosses the 30 percent threshold.
With the loss, the Knicks fell four games behind Orlando for the eighth and final playoff spot, with five games to play.

A sports article in some copies on Friday about the Rangers’ 3-1 victory against the Montreal Canadiens referred imprecisely to the Rangers’ point total and advantage over Tampa Bay in the N.H.L.’s Eastern Conference standings. The Rangers had 94 points, not 93, after that game and were ahead of Tampa Bay by 2 points, not 1. (The Rangers subsequently finished the regular season with 94 points, 1 point ahead of Tampa Bay.).

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Saturday about condemnation of the radio host Don Imus’s remarks about the Rutgers’ women’s basketball team referred incorrectly to Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, one of many politicians and media figures who have appeared on Mr. Imus’s show. Although he was formerly a Democratic senator, he was re-elected as an independent.

A picture caption in Business Day on March 29 about a new openness in Japan’s business culture misstated the surname of the actor who plays a banker in “Vulture,” a television show about a fictional investment fund. He is Kyohei Shibata, not Shibano. A second caption misstated the name of the actor playing the technology entrepreneur. He is Ryuhei Matsuda — not Osamu Nishino, the character Mr. Matsuda portrays.

The Media Equation column in Business Day yesterday, about comments by Don Imus regarding the Rutgers women’s basketball team, referred imprecisely to the 1996 Washington press dinner at which Mr. Imus made some offensive comments. The dinner was sponsored by the Radio and Television Correspondents’ Association, not by the White House Correspondents’ Association.

A front-page article on Wednesday about reaction to a Supreme Court decision that said the federal government had the authority to regulate heat-trapping gases misstated the cuts in carbon emissions that Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich has proposed in Illinois. By the year 2050, the proposal would restrict carbon emissions to 40 percent of 1990 levels — not 60 percent.

An article on Friday about fund-raising by Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts who is seeking the Republican presidential nomination, misidentified the profession of L.E. Simmons, one of Mr. Romney’s top donors. He is president of a private equity fund that invests in the energy service and equipment companies; he is not a software executive.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the sale of the Tribune Company misstated the background of Robert C. Embry Jr., who has tried to buy the company’s newspaper in Baltimore, The Sun. While Mr. Embry is president of the Abell Foundation, which was named for A.S. Abell, the founder of The Sun, he is not a member of the Abell family.

A music review on Saturday about a solo guitar performance by Mick Barr, at Studio B in Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to the band Hella and to Mr. Barr’s association with the band. While Mr. Barr has released duo recordings with Zach Hill, Hella’s drummer, Hella is not a duo and Mr. Barr is not a member.

A front-page article on Wednesday about reaction to a Supreme Court decision that said the federal government had the authority to regulate heat-trapping gases misstated the cuts in carbon emissions that Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich has proposed in Illinois. By the year 2050, the proposal would restrict carbon emissions to 40 percent of 1990 levels — not 60 percent.

A front-page article last Tuesday about Samuel Zell’s acquisition of the Tribune Company for $8.2 billion misstated one aspect of an “S” Corporation, which Tribune will eventually become under the takeover proposal. Foreigners who are residents of the United States can invest in an “S” Corporation; investors are not restricted to United States citizens.

A picture caption with a Sports of The Times column on Friday, about experiencing the Masters in person for the first time, referred incorrectly to the body of water near the 16th green at Augusta National. It is a pond — not Rae’s Creek, which runs at the back of the 11th green and in front of the 12th green, and which has a tributary at the 13th tee.
The Yankees stomped the Minnesota Twins on Monday, with Bobby Abreu and Alex Rodriguez hitting homers off onetime Yankee hurler Sidney Ponson.

Indonesia’s consumer confidence index rose in March for the first time in five months after inflation slowed and residents expected lower prices to leave them with more money to spend. The index rose to 93.3 last month, from 92.4 in February, according to the central bank, which surveyed 4,650 respondents in 18 cities. A reading below 100 indicates that pessimists outnumber optimists.

The ZTE Corporation, the biggest publicly listed telephone equipment maker in China, won orders from the China Mobile Communications Corporation to equip part of the nation’s first high-speed wireless network. The equipment will help China Mobile build a network based on domestically developed wireless technology after negotiations are completed, ZTE said in a statement to the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, without specifying financial terms. The government has said it will offer 3G service for the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

The Mexican cement maker Cemex said that an Australian rival, Rinker, had accepted an increased takeover bid of $15.85 a share. Cemex’s initial offer on Oct. 27, 2006, was $13 a share. The $15.3 billion offer is the biggest ever by a Mexican company and one of the largest in Australian corporate history. Cemex, based in northern Mexico, operates in more than 50 countries. The deal will give it a bigger slice of the American market.

The trade surplus widened 21 percent in March from the previous month, because of higher prices for copper, the country’s top export. The trade surplus rose to $2.03 billion in March from $1.68 billion in February, the central bank said. The surplus was smaller than the $2.89 billion surplus in March 2006 but was in line with analysts’ forecasts. Chilean exports rose to $5.5 billion, from $4.57 billion the previous month, while imports climbed to $3.47 billion, from $2.9 billion, the bank said.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg convened a group of “independent leaders” to stand behind him at a news conference as a show of support for his proposals.

Citigroup said that it had agreed to buy a midsize bank for 14.1 billion Taiwan dollars ($425 million) to further its expansion in Asia. In an all-cash deal, Citigroup will pay 11.8 Taiwan dollars (36 cents) a share to acquire the Bank of Overseas Chinese. The deal, which was under negotiation for nearly a year, is expected to be completed by year’s end. After the acquisition, the two banks will have total assets of $22.8 billion and 66 branches on Taiwan. The Taiwan bank’s 55 branches on the island will change their name to Citibank. Citigroup has 11 branches in Taiwan. The deal comes as Citigroup, based in New York, is seeking to increase revenue outside its home market, and as foreign banks continue to increase operations in Taiwan, which has robust trade and investment ties with China.
Gentrification continues to sweep over East Harlem, engulfing, it seems, a neighborhood parish school — much to parents’ dismay.
pro football.
The city’s Health Department is revamping the way it inspects restaurants for potential rodent infestation after a review prompted by a video of rats swarming in a Greenwich Village fast-food eatery.

Johnson & Johnson agreed to add new warnings to its overactive bladder medicine, Ditropan, after regulators linked it to hallucinations and agitation in children. The frequency of these side effects is “disproportionately higher” among children taking Ditropan than among adults, Food and Drug Administration staff wrote in a review on the agency’s Web site. The agency recommended adding age-specific risks to general precautions already in the prescribing information.

The remains of 10 American airmen, missing in action since a World War II mission over New Guinea, have been identified and will be returned to their families for burial, the Pentagon said. A B-24 Liberator with the airmen was returning to the aerodrome at Nadzab, New Guinea, after bombing enemy targets near Hollandia on April 16, 1944. The aircraft altered course because of bad weather when it disappeared. A team surveyed the site in 2002 and recovered remains as well as identification tags and other objects. Scientists used dental records, DNA and other tools to identify the remains.

The mother of a man sentenced to death for murdering two law enforcement officers over a land dispute is not eligible for the death penalty, the State Supreme Court ruled. The court upheld a lower court decision that the woman, Rita Bixby, 74, could not face the death penalty because she had been charged with accessory to murder, not murder. The authorities have said she knew her son, Steven, was planning to kill officers who set foot on the family’s land. Her trial date has not been set. Steven Bixby’s father, Arthur, 77, has also been charged with murder and is awaiting trial.

A judge recommended that a man who spent 10 years in prison for a gang rape be exonerated after a prosecutor acknowledged that his arrest had been a case of mistaken identity. If the appeals court formally approves the recommendation as expected, the man, James C. Giles, 53, will become the 13th Dallas County man to be exonerated since 2001 with the help of DNA evidence. Mr. Giles was arrested for the 1982 crime even though he lived 25 miles away and did not match the description of the attacker given by the victim, said his lawyer, Vanessa Potkin. Investigators ignored a man with a similar name: James E. Giles, who lived across the street from the victim. James C. Giles has had to register as a sex offender since his release, 14 years ago.

A federal appeals court upheld a ruling that found that federal agencies under the Bush administration had neglected to plan sufficiently for the protection of endangered salmon and steelhead in the Columbia and Snake Rivers.

A federal judge modified the conditions of presentencing release for Richard M. Scrushy, left, the former HealthSouth chief executive whom prosecutors accused of testing the government last month, when he took an unapproved trip by yacht from Palm Beach, Fla., to Miami. In June, a federal jury convicted Mr. Scrushy of bribing former Gov. Don Siegelman. His sentencing date has not yet been set. Under the new conditions, Mr. Scrushy must wear a tracking device when leaving Alabama, must submit a precise itinerary for such trips and must use only commercial air travel.

The Fish and Wildlife Service recommended upgrading the manatee’s status to threatened from endangered, a move that indicates the animal has rebounded from the brink of extinction. The manatee remains protected under the federal Endangered Species Act, making it illegal to harass, poach or kill the animals. A five-year review by the agency of manatee populations in Florida and Puerto Rico found that the species no longer fit the criterion to be deemed endangered: immediate risk of extinction. Threatened status means a species could become endangered in the future if protections are not maintained. This year’s manatee census recorded 2,812 in Florida water. In 1991, the survey’s first year, 1,267 manatees were counted. Patrick Rose, executive director of the Save the Manatee Club, said a classification switch could mean changes in boating and development restrictions that were established to protect manatees.

Public school students got an extra day of spring break in Bay City after vandals deflated the tires on all 88 of the district’s school buses. “We will proceed in any way possible to take action against whoever is responsible,” said Superintendent Carolyn Wierda, who canceled classes because of the lack of transportation. The vandals hit over the weekend, said the district transportation director, Michael Gwizdala. “They opened the valves and took the core out,” Mr. Gwizdala said. “There were no punctures or anything.”.

Internet game operators in China must deter young people from playing online more than three hours a day to combat what the government regards as online addiction, according to a circular issued by eight government departments, including the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Public Security. Game companies must develop a system that cancels half a minor’s earned gaming credits if he remains online for more than three hours a day. If the young person plays for more than five hours a day, all of that player’s credits will be taken away. Online gamers will also be required to register using their real names and identity card numbers, which will indicate if they are under the age of 18. Companies must develop an anti-addiction system by June 15, fully test it by July 15 and implement it thereafter, according to the circular.

More than half of children in India are subjected to sexual abuse, but most do not report the assaults to anyone, a new government study said. Parents and relatives were mostly found to be the perpetrators of child sexual abuse, said Women and Child Development Minister Renuka Chowdhury. Separately, nearly 65 percent of schoolchildren reported facing punishment beatings by teachers, mostly in government schools, the study said. The ministry’s study covered 13 of India’s 28 states and questioned 12,447 children in the 5-to-12 age group and 2,324 young adults. It covered different forms of child abuse, including physical, sexual and emotional abuse, as well as female child neglect. The study did not have a margin of sampling error. Last year, the government barred the employment of children under age 14 as domestic servants or in hotels, restaurants or small teashops because children were often subjected to physical violence, mental trauma and sexual abuse.

The number of ethnic attacks in Russia rose sharply in the first part of this year, a Russian human rights group said. In January, February and March, 13 people were killed in ethnic attacks and 50 were wounded, Alexander Brod, the head of the group, Moscow Bureau for Human Rights, told the Interfax news agency. In the same period a year ago, two people were killed in such attacks and 30 people were wounded. People originating from former Soviet republics like Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan, Armenia and Georgia, along with North Koreans and Africans, were the most likely to fall victim to attacks, the group said. Last month, another rights group, Sova, said the number of victims of ethnic attacks for all of 2006 had jumped 17 percent, to 539, of whom 54 died.

China officially appointed Donald Tsang, left, as Hong Kong’s chief executive for a second term after an election last month, the territory’s first leadership contest under Chinese rule. Mr. Tsang received the formal “book of appointment” at a ceremony held at the Zhongnanhai compound for China’s leaders in Beijing, according to the Xinhua news agency. At an afternoon meeting with the Chinese president, Hu Jintao, Mr. Tsang was promised the backing of Beijing. “You have to work hard to accomplish things in Hong Kong,” Mr. Hu said. “The central government will support Hong Kong.”.

Anwar Ibrahim, the former deputy prime minister once regarded as the heir apparent to Mahathir Mohamad, the man who dominated Malaysia as prime minister for two decades, said he would return to politics despite a ban against his seeking office until 2008. Mr. Ibrahim, who was fired in 1998 when he appeared to be mounting a challenge to Mr. Mahathir and was then imprisoned on what were widely believed to be politically motivated charges of corruption and sodomy, said he would run for the leadership of his party, Keadilan, next month. He was released from prison in 2004, after the sodomy conviction was overturned. But his corruption conviction bars him from running in general elections or holding political office until April 2008. Malaysia’s general elections, held at least every five years, are not due until early 2009, but political parties have been preparing for the possibility of an early vote.

United Nations helicopters flew in extra ballots to remote polling centers that ran short as East Timor saw surprisingly high turnouts in its election for a new president, officials said. Preliminary results are expected in the next few days.

A sailor on a Russian merchant ship was arrested near disputed waters in the Kurile chain after he sailed an inflatable boat to the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido to buy a case of beer, the police said. As he headed back, he was seized on charges of fishing for highly prized sea urchins without the necessary documents, the police said.
The Mavericks can ease up for the last five games of the season. They have already clinched the league’s best record — and homecourt advantage throughout the playoffs.

Women with AIDS delivered 139,000 babies infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, in the last six months, Unicef reported. The agency also said that 146,000 women carrying the virus had been given drugs to prevent its transmission to their babies. Nearly one in six Mozambican adults carries the virus. The Health Ministry estimates that 20,000 children under the age of 5 died of AIDS last year.

Chad said it repelled a major attack by rebel groups seeking to overthrow President Idriss Déby that was opened from Sudan, but Sudan accused Chad’s army of killing 17 of its soldiers and threatened a strong response.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,269 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.

Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday joined John Edwards in shunning a debate that the Congressional Black Caucus and Fox News had scheduled for September in Detroit, a bow to liberal online groups who have demanded that Democratic candidates boycott the network’s events. Neither the Obama nor the Clinton campaign criticized Fox in confirming that the candidates would not appear at the debate. Mr. Obama’s camp said he would be in a debate in January sponsored by the black caucus and CNN.
The founders of Student Loan Xpress explicitly marketed to the financial aid offices of schools to  corral a bigger share of the lucrative student loan business.
Don Imus agreed that the suspension was appropriate and promised to change the tenor of his show, MSNBC said.
The $45 billion takeover bid from a consortium led by a Canadian pension fund would be the largest buyout in history.
An attack on a joint patrol of Afghan and Dutch troops underscored the difficulties of the war.
A showdown between President Hugo Chávez and U.S. and European companies over key oil projects could wind up with all sides losing.
Gen. David H. Petraeus has recommended that troop levels in Iraq be maintained at least through September, Pentagon officials said.
The manatee’s future, however promising the short-term numbers, remains full of perils that should not be compounded by regulatory rollbacks.
The Bush administration, facing Congressional pressure on trade, has lodged complaints against China three times in the last three months. The big question is what happens next.
Congress and state governments have to assess the extent of irresponsible and predatory lending in the subprime market, and determine whom to hold accountable.
The Supreme Court’s ruling in the Watergate tapes case, and other legal and historical precedents, make it clear that executive privilege should not keep Congress from getting the testimony it needs.
Genetic tests are forcing some immigrant families to confront unexpected and sometimes unbearable truths.

NEWARK, April 9 (AP) — Former Mayor Sharpe James, after more than three decades in New Jersey politics, said on Monday that he would not seek re-election to the State Senate seat he has held since 1999.
The Turkish mission objected to references in the exhibit to the Armenian genocide in Turkey at the time of World War I.
John Ford, a longtime state senator, was caught in an F.B.I.  sting and charged with bribery and extortion.
The new chief executive for Corbis is expected to respond to the rise of low-cost online rivals that threaten to undermine its sales.
A second corporate advisory firm is urging shareholders of The New York Times Company to withhold their votes for directors at the company’s annual meeting this month.
Tens of thousands of protesters loyal to Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr demanded an end to the American military presence in Iraq.
American Home Mortgage said it would pay out a smaller dividend because it was being asked to buy back and write down certain loans.
New Orleans’s belatedly appointed Hurricane Katrina recovery chief, Edward J. Blakely, brings a mix of realism and fatalism to his post.
Hampton University, a Div. I-AA school on the Eastern shore of Virginia, had five players at the N.F.L. combine, more than major programs like U.S.C. and Wisconsin.
A shareholder revolt claims another executive job at the beleaguered video game maker.
The operator has been accused of cheating the Treasury out of more than $70 million.
The complaints came after the Taliban said it had killed an Afghan colleague of the Italian journalist freed in a prisoner swap.
Joseph P. Nacchio, charged with insider trading, never took the stand on his own behalf.
While Vince Carter is poised to surpass his own single-season scoring record, it is difficult to believe the Nets will advance past the first round of the playoffs.
As the Mets were enjoying a seven-run inning, the fans at Shea Stadium picked a perfect time to torment their newest enemy, Phillies shortstop Jimmy Rollins.
Paul D. Wolfowitz said he arranged for a job at the State Department for a woman friend only after consulting the bank’s executive board.
Iran’s announcement was greeted with skepticism by Western diplomats and nuclear experts.
Under pressure from investors, Citigroup’s chief is looking to slim its compliance ranks to keep the bank from getting bogged down.
April 9, 2007.

TRENTON, April 9 — State Senator Wayne R. Bryant pleaded not guilty on Monday to federal fraud and corruption charges and then waived his right to a trial within 70 days, setting the stage for a trial to be held next year.
Tim Montgomery, the Olympic gold medalist and former 100-meter world-record holder, pleaded guilty in federal court to bank fraud.
A crackdown on one extended family — U.S. citizens all — exhibits growing tension in Suffolk between immigrants and longtime residents.

A butcher convicted of stabbing his wife to death on a city street with a boning knife was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 23 years to life in state prison. The butcher, Sergio Parra, 28, was convicted of second-degree murder last month for killing his wife, Jahaira Parra, 27, in Washington Heights on Sept. 16, 2004. The police said Mr. Parra stabbed his wife more than 20 times outside the barbershop where she worked, while bystanders watched.

Four people escaped from a burning apartment building in Bronxdale yesterday morning, including two children who jumped 10 feet from a fire escape and were caught by police officers, the police said. The fire, which officials said was caused by a candle in the living room, began shortly after 10 a.m. in the building at 2504 Bronx Park East. Of the four people who escaped, three refused medical treatment. The fourth was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, the department said. Twelve firefighters were treated for injuries, the most serious described as burns to the ear. The officers who caught the children were identified as Paul McLaughlin and Maximo Rosado, both assigned to the Bronx.

Former Gov. James E. McGreevey, who resigned in 2004 after announcing that he was gay, is seeking joint custody of his 5-year-old daughter and is seeking to bar her from accompanying his estranged wife on a tour to promote her book. In court papers filed on Thursday in State Superior Court, Mr. McGreevey also asks the court to ensure that he is not cut off from his child, Jacqueline, because of the “seemingly irrational fears” of his estranged wife, Dina Matos McGreevey, about his sexual orientation. A lawyer for Ms. Matos McGreevey, John N. Post, did not return telephone or e-mail messages for comment. Ms. Matos McGreevey’s tell-all book about their marriage is scheduled to be released on May 1.

Trump Entertainment Resorts filed an objection yesterday with the National Labor Relations Board that seeks to set aside the results of a March 31 election in which dealers at Trump Plaza Hotel voted to join the United Auto Workers union. The U.A.W. is also trying to organize workers at the Trump Marina Hotel Casino. Union officials did not respond yesterday to messages seeking comment. The basis of the challenge is a March 25 rally in which the union and politicians counted pledge cards signed by dealers. The company, which is seeking a new election, claims that the rally gave the impression that the U.A.W. was already the dealers’ certified representative.

A man apparently burned to death in his car over the weekend after its gas tank ruptured as he drove on a rough dirt road in the woods near Ringwood State Park, the Ramapo police said yesterday. Officials said that they had not identified the man, but they said that the car, a 2002 Subaru Impreza, belonged to Francis McCloskey, 79, of Ringwood, who was reported missing on Saturday. The car was found on Sunday by mountain bikers on a dirt road less than a quarter-mile from the park, said Lt. Brad Weidel of the Ramapo police. The police theorized that the driver was lost and that the gas tank ruptured after the car tires went flat.

Gov. M. Jodi Rell’s nominee to be the chief justice of the State Supreme Court was unanimously approved yesterday by the Judiciary Committee, a joint committee of the General Assembly’s House and Senate. The nomination next goes to both houses for a vote. The nominee, Judge Chase T. Rogers, 50, of Appellate Court, is expected to win confirmation. If confirmed, Judge Rogers would become the second woman to serve as chief justice in Connecticut. Chief Justice Ellen Ash Peters served from 1984 to 1996.

Just weeks after abandoning a bid for New York’s thoroughbred horse racing franchise, the casino magnate Steve Wynn announced yesterday that he would join one of the four consortiums still vying for the prize. Mr. Wynn, along with two real estate developers, Steven Roth and Richard D. Bronson, will invest in Excelsior Racing Associates. At stake are rights to run the Saratoga, Aqueduct and Belmont racetracks, which take in $2.7 billion a year in bets. The move comes on the eve of public hearings at which the bidders will present their investment plans to a panel picked by Gov. Eliot Spitzer.

After 10 years as executive director of Habitat for Humanity-New York City, Roland Lewis, left, is leaving to become president and chief executive of the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance. The alliance is a nonprofit group that advocates for public access to the city’s shores and waterways. It had been a project of the Municipal Art Society of New York from 1999 until it was spun off as an independent entity last week, said Kent L. Barwick, president of the art society. Mr. Lewis, 46, who lives in Flatbush, Brooklyn, said yesterday that he hoped to build the alliance into a “large not-for-profit agency that will be dedicated to finding common ground” among waterfront developers, government officials and the public.
It is impossible to know the precise reason for Johnny Damon and Hideki Matsui’s injuries, but one factor is the Yankees’ new strength and conditioning program.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed legislation yesterday that will officially move up the presidential primary by one month, adding New York to the growing number of states that are making similar changes. The Democratic and Republican primaries will now be held on the first Tuesday in February — which falls on Feb. 5 in 2008, a presidential election year — rather than on the first Tuesday in March. “Moving the primary date to February, we will help secure New York’s large and diverse population an influential voice in selecting the 2008 presidential nominees,” Governor Spitzer said in a statement.
The tourism minister is denounced by radical clerics after she was pictured holding a male colleague after a parachute jump.
The sky watchtower has taken its place on the streets of New York as a highly visible police presence at public events, busy intersections or high-crime sites.
James J. Needham was the first full-time paid chairman of the New York Stock Exchange.
The merger of two big nonprofit health insurers and their planned conversion to a for-profit business has political leaders and union officials fighting for a piece of the billion-dollar windfall.
On a record-setting opening day, with construction of the new Mets ballpark moving ahead, officials and fans got a chance to test the new parking arrangements.

ALBANY, April 9 — New York’s chief judge said on Monday that she was infuriated that the new state budget failed to include a long-sought raise for the state’s judges and threatened to sue the state if the judges do not get raises by June.
A man who was fired last week attacked former co-workers with a shotgun in Detroit, but was apprehended after a high-speed chase.
Predatory practices aimed at military service members and their families would be curtailed.
As many as 13,000 National Guard soldiers were told that they should expect possible deployments to Iraq by year’s end or in 2008, sooner than scheduled.
Judith R. Shapiro, who has been the president of Barnard College since 1994, announced that she plans to step down at the end of the 2007-8 school year.
Investors grew anxious about first-quarter earnings and hopes dimmed for interest rate cuts, despite a steep drop in oil prices.

NEWARK, April 9 — One stared straight ahead, impassively. Another kept shaking his head and closing his eyes as though trying to extinguish a bad dream. A third wept. And the fourth kept telling his lawyer that he wanted to kill himself.
Four senators are concerned that the Justice Department has not turned over all relevant documents related to the dismissals of eight United States attorneys.
A federal trial now getting under way is expected to shed light on the 1992 killings of a young couple from Queens who robbed a series of mob social clubs.
It is not clear how many players, coaches and managers will wear No. 42 on Sunday to honor Jackie Robinson, but the number is definitely growing.
Louis Flores Ruiz built a modest enchilada factory in the San Joaquin Valley into the nation’s largest producer of frozen Mexican foods.
The Halliburton Company said that its subsidiary that does business in Iran had completed all its commitments and was no longer working in the country.
The government announced a 60 percent rise in salaries to compete with the private sector and avoid corruption.
In the wake of his unexpected victory, Zach Johnson will face demands, expectations and opportunities to cash in on his triumph.

Adam Everett hit a two-run home run off Bob Howry in the eighth inning to lead the Houston Astros past the Chicago Cubs, 5-3, in the Wrigley Field home debuts of Manager Lou Piniella and center fielder Alfonso Soriano.
The ban came too late to prevent two of the 15 ex-captives from recounting their experiences in return for payment.
The chipmaker, whose forecast was well below Wall Street’s expectations, announced a restructuring to lower costs.
Taking China to court over suspected trade barriers and piracy was seen as necessary to send a signal to Beijing.
Tourists flock to an 11th-century monastery to hear Gregorian chant, bringing unwanted fame to the reclusive monks.

The aircraft carrier Intrepid, the floating military museum, is scheduled to move again early today, but this short voyage should be much smoother than the ship’s difficult departure from Manhattan last year.

NEW HAVEN, April 9 (AP) — The federal Department of Labor has sued a Connecticut nursery and its recruiter, supporting migrant workers who claim they were forced to work nearly 80 hours a week and were paid less than the minimum wage.
When the defense-minded Rangers face off against the firepower of the Thrashers, the playoff series will likely swing on which style can prevail.
Three former college students who set fire to churches in rural Alabama in February 2006 were sentenced to prison on Monday on federal arson charges.
Raymond Murphy was awarded a Medal of Honor for his service during the Korean War and later served in a regional office of the Veterans Affairs Department.
Mr. Lockhart was an actor who won acclaim for his roles as underworld figures in 1970s blaxploitation films.
Mr. Smith was a lifelong criminal whose role in the 1963 kidnapping and killing of a police officer inspired Joseph Wambaugh’s true-life crime novel “The Onion Field.”
A consumer advocacy group has asked the F.D.A. to ban the television ad, saying it gives a false impression about its safety.
A mixologist who travels the globe teaching bartenders the art of cocktail-making is often accompanied by his caricaturist wife, who sketches whoever catches her eye.
The Mirant Corporation said it might put itself up for sale to capitalize on growing interest in power companies from buyout firms and other investors.
Documents that defense lawyers produced showed that payments at the heart of the case had been publicly disclosed.
Sustained by the belief that embracing all comers is a living example of Christ’s love, Pilgrim United Church of Christ now faces a profound test of faith.
It was the first public statement by Gao Zhisheng, one of China’s most outspoken dissidents, since his conviction in December.
New Century Financial should not be allowed to sell $50 million worth of mortgages to a subsidiary of the Royal Bank of Scotland, a U.S. trustee said.
An arbitrator has ruled that the Tribune Company’s sale of The Advocate of Stamford to the Gannett Company violated a union contract.
The fight over cars and carbon dioxide moves to a federal courtroom in Burlington, Vt., this week, in a case that could reshape vehicles sold in parts of the United States.
President Bush said  that tougher enforcement and a new fence at the Mexican border had sharply reduced the influx of illegal immigrants.
The company’s new $20 million campaign emphasizes the  high-tech features of Sony’s camcorders and digital cameras.
The changes come as the magazine struggles to recover from a recent flawed article about children’s car seats.
The world’s largest exporters of natural gas plan to establish a high-level group on gas pricing, but denied that the group aimed to establish a cartel.
Europe’s courts must stand up to terror against Muslims.
Don Imus’s comments about the Scarlet Knights of Rutgers University were no surprise.  But they were a new low.
SanDisk and Yahoo will start selling a digital music player, the Sansa Connect, that lets users download songs wirelessly.
Travel companies and trade associations are protesting the growing cost of taxes, many of them financing initiatives that have nothing to do with travel.

MAKING MONEY AGAIN After six consecutive years of losses, the global commercial aviation system is expected to post an overall profit of $3.8 billion this year and an estimated $7.6 billion profit next year, the International Air Transport Association says. The total of passengers this year is expected to be 2.2 billion, continuing a steady growth in traffic since 2003.
Business travel has forced me to get into shape. I can go the distance, with barely a hitch in my breath, as I try to make my flights.
A new chief for N.Y.U. Institute, Avery Fisher Career Grants winners announced, James Naughton to direct David Epstein’s play at Symphony Space and more culture news.
Mr. Hart, who was known for his widely syndicated comic strip “B.C.,” evoked an entire prehistoric world with eloquent simplicity.
The Mets took advantage of the Phillies’ relievers and a crucial error to score seven runs in the eighth inning.
If humorlessness were the measure of good art, Bernard Weinraub’s play could rank among the best productions of the year.

To the Editor:.
A late-night cable talk show on the Fox News Channel, with its libertarian politics and wacky local news stories,  finds an audience.
The forthcoming publication of “The Diary of Petr Ginz: 1941-1942” adds another adolescent voice to the literature of the Holocaust.
Thomas Struth’s show at Marian Goodman — rapturous, magisterial photographs of museum visitors — culminates one of the memorable art projects of the last 20 years or so.
Philippe Herreweghe elicited a gripping account of Bach’s towering Passion from the Collegium Vocale Gent Choir and Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday.
Is there any difference in how the body deals with calcium from food versus supplements?
In this extraordinary look at several months in the singular culture of amateur wrestling, there are no big stadiums, no March Madness, no payday. Just plenty of determination.

8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL The way things are going this season, it’s anyone’s guess who will survive tonight’s round, in which the eight remaining contestants perform Latin-tinged songs after being coached by Jennifer Lopez. Tomorrow night, Ms. Lopez, left, will get sultry in “Qué Hiciste” (“What Have You Done”), the first single from her new Spanish album, “Como Ama una Mujer” (“How a Woman Loves”), and one competitor will say “adios.”.
While financial planning is important, there are also psychological and physical implications to retirement preparation.
In studies, about 15 percent of women report having experienced multiple orgasms.
For couples who know they want a girl or a boy, there is always the fertility clinic. But is there a lower-tech method?
While this show may not set the world on fire, it gets its job done in a 90-minute production that, bright and flower-studded, deliberately avoids slickness.
New this week is “The Mario Bava Collection, Volume 1,” an opportunity to discover a once-obscure Italian genre filmmaker.
Human sexual behavior is not a free-form performance, biologists are finding, but is guided at every turn by genetic programs.
Climate change on Mars, how fruit flies fly and minuscule power plants.
Celebrity culture so hates a vacuum that reclusive geniuses have created some ideal opportunities for cons.
Randall White is one of the world’s leading experts on prehistoric cave paintings, sculptures, carved figurines, and necklaces from France.
In her “Rustling Solo” on Saturday Beth Soll seemed like a being from another time — and the sense of chilled distance lasted throughout the program’s other piece, “Black Flower.”
Instead of asking people about their mate preferences, scientists can now watch mating rituals in real time.
Pepper Schwartz is both a respected sociologist and a sex columnist for magazines and the author of more than a dozen popular books about love and relationships.
The company said it was working with labor officials to establish a union at restaurants in southern Guangdong.
Smokers take more than a week more annual sick leave than nonsmokers, a new study suggests.
Women whose weight gain during pregnancy meets the current recommendations are more likely to have a 3-year-old who is overweight, researchers report.
Only 24 percent of surgeons referred more than three-quarters of their patients for plastic surgery, a new study found.
A new study found that the benefits of the vaccine might extend even to children who are not fully vaccinated.
Love Is a Many-Flavored Thing.
Fighting Climate Change.
Psychotherapy is more effective than short-term treatment for alleviating depression associated with bipolar disease, new research suggests.
It is rarely age per se that accounts for declines in libido among those in the second half-century of life.
A growing number of elderly and retired people are telling their stories with Internet video.
One way to slow the aging process? Exercise, and plenty of it.
With the growth of the casino industry, an increasing number of retirees are working as ticket writers, card dealers, even floor managers.
A consulting company helps senior executives and professionals make the transition to a mix of paid work, leisure, travel and lifelong learning.
As the prices of second homes move out of reach for many Americans, older couples are buying time shares as an alternative.
Employee Stock Ownership Plans — or ESOPs — provide small-business owners an alternative marketplace for selling equity.
As the number of older Americans grows, retirement for many means a chance to devote themselves to social and political causes.
To help them move from their town house into a retirement community condominium, Judy and Richard Franken sought the services of a relatively new profession, the “senior move manager.”
We live in such an affluent society that you can eliminate plenty of expenses without becoming a cheapskate.
More companies have moved away from traditional pension plans and towards giving employees a fixed amount when they leave.
Immediate annuities provide the guarantee of lifetime income, but financial advisers say they are not for everyone.
The growing number of female business travelers has had a significant effect on hotel safety and the travel experience.
The Mets have played Gilligan to the Yankees’ Skipper long enough. If Roger Clemens hits the sales rack, the Mets should make an offer.

SIX years ago, Walter Flaherty of Boston was the chief financial officer at Eastern Enterprises, a utility, energy and transportation company with $1.4 billion in revenue. When the company was sold, Mr. Flaherty, 58, came to New Directions, a company that helps senior executives and professionals make the transitions in their lives. He was looking for another high-paying job with a public company. “Then things began to change,” he said. After the Enron and Arthur Andersen scandals, federal legislation added new accounting regulations, increasing the demands on financial officers at public companies, Mr. Flaherty said.

Carlos Delgado is known for his power, not his bunting or his speed, which were his most meaningful contributions in the Mets' 11-5 victory against Philadelphia. Delgado, who went 3 for 3 to raise his average to .267, exploited the Phillies' infield shift in the second inning by bunting Cole Hamels's first pitch to the third-base side of the mound for an easy single. ''Great footwork,'' Carlos Beltrán said of Delgado's bunt.

Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday joined John Edwards in shunning a debate that the Congressional Black Caucus and Fox News had scheduled for September in Detroit, a bow to liberal online groups who have demanded that Democratic candidates boycott the network's events. Neither the Obama nor the Clinton campaign criticized Fox in confirming that the candidates would not appear at the debate. Mr. Obama's camp said he would be in a debate in January sponsored by the black caucus and CNN. ''CNN seemed like a more appropriate venue,'' said Bill Burton, Mr. Obama's spokesman.

DIESENHOF--Ellen W., of Genesee, CO, was born in Brooklyn, New York on November 23, 1940. She was raised and educated in Brooklyn, meeting her future husband, Martin Diesenhof, in kindergarten. She and Martin spent summers at Masad Camp in Pennsylvania. She attended the University of Michigan and married Martin soon after graduation in 1962. Ellen was a devoted and wellloved teacher of English and College Counselor at Ramsey High School in Ramsey, New Jersey for 23 years before moving to Colorado in 1998. She taught English at Red Rocks Community College from 2000-2006. Ellen loved to work with teenagers and tutored many generations of students preparing for college entrance examinations and b'nai mitzvot. She had recently turned her attention to her adored grandsons. Ellen was the loving wife of Martin of Genesee, CO; mother of Kenneth Diesenhof, MA and Michael (Cynthia) Diesenhof, Avon, CT, and grandmother of Abraham (Avi) and Eli, of Avon, CT. Ellen will also be missed by the multitude of friends, colleagues, and students whose lives she touched. Funeral service will be held on Wednesday, April 11, 2007 at 10:00am at Congregation Beth Evergreen, Evergreen, CO. Interment in Mt. Nebo Memorial Park in Aurora, CO. The family suggests that memorial contributions be made to the Congregation Beth Evergreen Scholarship Fund.

A picture caption in Business Day on March 29 about a new openness in Japan's business culture misstated the surname of the actor who plays a banker in ''Vulture,'' a television show about a fictional investment fund. He is Kyohei Shibata, not Shibano. A second caption misstated the name of the actor playing the technology entrepreneur. He is Ryuhei Matsuda -- not Osamu Nishino, the character Mr. Matsuda portrays.

NEUMANN--Ina E., lived in New York for many years and worked for an International Publishing Company, died Wednesday April 4th, 2007. Hans Neumann, her beloved son of St. Louis, held a private memorial service on FridayApril 6. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends. Memorial donations can be made to her eldest son Hans Neumann at 9125 Cherry Brook Lane. Messages of condolences may be left on our Family email address: HNeum90735@sbcglobal.net
THE CLAIM Timing and sexual position can influence a baby's sex. THE FACTS For couples who know they want a girl or a boy, there is always the fertility clinic. But is there a lower-tech method?

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Saturday about condemnation of the radio host Don Imus's remarks about the Rutgers' women's basketball team referred incorrectly to Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, one of many politicians and media figures who have appeared on Mr. Imus's show. Although he was formerly a Democratic senator, he was re-elected as an independent.

The Senate is expected to pass legislation this week that would ease the Bush administration's limits on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research. The measure, passed by the House, is identical to the bill that passed the Senate 63 to 37 last year before being vetoed by President Bush. Senate Democrats now think they have 65 votes, one shy of what is needed to rebuff a veto. Senator Bob Casey, left, a freshman Democrat from Pennsylvania who campaigned as a social conservative, has said he will vote against the bill. Democrats hope for support from Senator John E. Sununu, Republican of New Hampshire, who may face a tough race next year. MICHAEL LUO

To the Editor: Re ''Reports From Four Fronts in the War on Warming'' (April 3): Robert O. Mendelsohn is quoted as saying that it is easier to sell the idea of reducing greenhouse emissions to industrialized countries when it seems that we are ''all in this together.'' This is certainly true, so Dr. Mendelsohn would be wise to keep trying to sell it. We are all still on the same collision course with climate change, and the crash will come sooner than expected for the industrialized world if it continues to consider itself beyond harm. Julia Meisel Pittsburgh

DOHERTY--Thomas A., on April 7th, 2007, at his home in Vero Beach, Florida, after a long battle with cancer. Loving husband of Marianne; devoted father of Arlene, Karen, Bryan and Linda. Survived by his brother Frank and sister-in-law Joanne. Cherished grandfather of nine grandchildren. Visiting at Francis P. Devine Funeral Home Inc., 293 South St., Oyster Bay, NY, Wednesday 79pm, Thursday 3-5pm and 79pm. Funeral Mass Friday, 11:00am at St. Dominic's Church. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery, Huntington, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Thomas A. Doherty Scholarship Fund, St. Joseph's College, 245 Clinton Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11205.

Women with AIDS delivered 139,000 babies infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, in the last six months, Unicef reported. The agency also said that 146,000 women carrying the virus had been given drugs to prevent its transmission to their babies. Nearly one in six Mozambican adults carries the virus. The Health Ministry estimates that 20,000 children under the age of 5 died of AIDS last year. MICHAEL WINES

To the Editor: Re ''Drugs Are in the Water. Does it Matter?'' (April 3): The general tone of Cornelia Dean's article on pharmaceutical and personal care products being detected in the water is that if they don't affect us, they're not really a problem. Since marine ecosystems are already damaged from overfishing, habitat destruction, toxic chemicals and conventional pollutants, they certainly are being further impaired by the effects from pharmaceuticals released into the water. Whether or not these chemicals are hurting humans, the answer to her question is: Yes, it does matter. Judith S. Weis Newark

An article on Friday about fund-raising by Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts who is seeking the Republican presidential nomination, misidentified the profession of L.E. Simmons, one of Mr. Romney's top donors. He is president of a private equity fund that invests in the energy service and equipment companies; he is not a software executive.

BERKULE--Leon, age 93, of Scarsdale, New York, died Saturday, April 7, 2007 at St. Vincent's Hospital. He is predeceased by his wife, Mildred Berkule. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Law School, admitted to the Bar in 1945. He is survived by his three children, Barbara (Sheldon) Cohen, Lynne (Stephen) Stavrides and Steven Berkule.

The Media Equation column in Business Day yesterday, about comments by Don Imus regarding the Rutgers women's basketball team, referred imprecisely to the 1996 Washington press dinner at which Mr. Imus made some offensive comments. The dinner was sponsored by the Radio and Television Correspondents' Association, not by the White House Correspondents' Association.

To the Editor: Re ''In Testing For Allergies, A Single Shot May Suffice'' (March 20): Allergy skin testing is neither painful nor dangerous as documented by several recently published studies. Indeed, a study of 16,204 people examined with a variety of medical procedures found a significantly greater number of adverse reactions due to blood drawing than allergy skin testing.

JACKIER--Rose G., 95, died April 8, 2007. Widow of James, loving mother of Roberta (Arthur) Schain, Kenneth (Karen), proud grandmother of Eric, Diane, and Michael. Graveside service April 11th, Sharon Gardens 2pm.

AFTER 30 years in the corporate world, getting up at 5 a.m. and not getting home until after 6 p.m., Diane Capstaff was ready for a change. ''I didn't want another full-time job,'' said Mrs. Capstaff, 62, of Marblehead, Mass., who retired five years ago as a senior executive at John Hancock Financial Services in Boston. ''But I knew I'd miss the structure of the office.''
HUGHES--Sidney. Holland Lodge #

To the Editor: Re ''Finding Hope in Knowing the Universal Capacity for Evil'' (Conversation, April 3): Philip G. Zimbardo is right in applying lessons from his legendary Stanford Prison Experiment to the atrocities of Abu Ghraib. But he mischaracterizes the broad findings of psychological research when he states: ''Human behavior is more influenced by things outside of us than inside.''

It is still not clear how many major league players, coaches and managers will wear No. 42 this Sunday to honor Jackie Robinson, but the number is definitely growing. Richard Levin, the senior vice president of Major League Baseball for public relations, confirmed yesterday that three teams -- the Pittsburgh Pirates, the St. Louis Cardinals and the Los Angeles Dodgers -- would have every player wear Robinson's number. Other teams have told Major League Baseball they plan to have at least several players wear No. 42.

GINSBERG--Jerome, 94, on April 8, 2007. Founder of Magna Book Distributors, decorated veteran of WWII, longtime champion of social causes. Remembered to the end for his ready wit and love of sports. Survived by son Robert, daughter-in-law Cynthia, granddaughter Rachel Beth, sister Rosalie, brotherin-law Henry and many loving nieces and nephews. Predeceased by wife Blanche and son Richard. Services to be held on April 11 at 11:00 am, New Mount Carmel Cemetery.

Q. Is there any difference in how the body deals with calcium from food versus supplements? A. Calcium is found naturally in foods, is added to fortified foods like orange juice and is sold in various forms as nutritional supplements. ''Calcium that is absorbed from any of these winds up exactly the same way in the body, mainly as the mineral hydroxyapatite in bones and teeth,'' said Dr. Sheldon S. Hendler, co-editor of The Physician's Desk Reference for Nutritional Supplements.

A front-page article last Tuesday about Samuel Zell's acquisition of the Tribune Company for $8.2 billion misstated one aspect of an ''S'' Corporation, which Tribune will eventually become under the takeover proposal. Foreigners who are residents of the United States can invest in an ''S'' Corporation; investors are not restricted to United States citizens. An article in Business Day last Tuesday about Samuel Zell using an Employee Stock Ownership Plan, or ESOP, in a transaction for the Tribune Company omitted a condition for an owner to avoid capital gains taxes on the proceeds of a sale of company shares to such a plan. In addition to the ESOP holding the stock for at least three years, the company has to be private for at least one year before the sale.

A picture caption with a Sports of The Times column on Friday, about experiencing the Masters in person for the first time, referred incorrectly to the body of water near the 16th green at Augusta National. It is a pond -- not Rae's Creek, which runs at the back of the 11th green and in front of the 12th green, and which has a tributary at the 13th tee.

Four senators said Monday that they suspected that the Justice Department had failed to turn over all relevant documents related to the dismissals of eight United States attorneys. The department has released more than 3,000 pages of e-mail messages and other files. But, the senators wrote in a letter to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, ''We are concerned that additional documents relevant to the committee's investigations are missing or have been withheld.''

The latest phase of the Mets' makeover is under way on a construction site about 600 feet from home plate, with Caterpillars soon to push aside an aging Shea Stadium that was born in the ''Flipper'' and ''Bewitched'' era, with cranes rising above Queens like index fingers as if to say, we're No. 1. Symbols of superiority and renewal are not misplaced in this case. The Mets have earned the confidence around what is, and the excitement over what will be, after having lived through an inferiority complex fed by forever playing Gilligan to Skipper in their race for respectability and relevance against the Yankees.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the sale of the Tribune Company misstated the background of Robert C. Embry Jr., who has tried to buy the company's newspaper in Baltimore, The Sun. While Mr. Embry is president of the Abell Foundation, which was named for A.S. Abell, the founder of The Sun, he is not a member of the Abell family.

Women whose weight gain during pregnancy meets the current recommendations are significantly more likely to have a 3-year-old who is overweight than those who gain less than the recommended amount, researchers report. Guidelines from the Institute of Medicine say that a woman with a normal body-mass index of 19.8 to 26 should gain 25 to 35 pounds. Women with a lower than normal B.M.I. should gain slightly more, and those with a B.M.I. greater than 26 should gain 13 to 25 pounds.

To the Editor: Re ''A Patient's Demands Versus a Doctor's Convictions'' (Essay, April 3): I do not agree with Dr. Sandeep Jauhar's essay. It's one thing to give patients a choice of several acceptable alternatives. But ultimately, the doctor needs to use his or her objective and educated judgment about what is acceptable.

Last week, Senator John McCain turned to Frederic V. Malek to help his fund-raising efforts. Right away, some liberal groups brought up Mr. Malek's carrying out a request from President Richard M. Nixon in 1971 that he count the Jews at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. When Mr. Malek's role in the incident became public in 1988, George Bush, running for president, removed him as the Republican Party's deputy chairman. But Mr. Malek apologized and was soon co-director of Mr. Bush's re-election campaign.

PETLZ--Claire. The Board of Directors of Triarc Companies, Inc. extends its sincere condolences to our company's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Nelson Peltz, and his family on the passing of Mr. Peltz's mother, Claire Peltz, on April 5, 2007 at the wonderful age of 108.

Four people escaped from a burning apartment building in Bronxdale yesterday morning, including two children who jumped 10 feet from a fire escape and were caught by police officers, the police said. The fire, which officials said was caused by a candle in the living room, began shortly after 10 a.m. in the building at 2504 Bronx Park East. Of the four people who escaped, three refused medical treatment. The fourth was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, the department said. Twelve firefighters were treated for injuries, the most serious described as burns to the ear. The officers who caught the children were identified as Paul McLaughlin and Maximo Rosado, both assigned to the Bronx. MICHAEL WILSON

A front-page article on Wednesday about reaction to a Supreme Court decision that said the federal government had the authority to regulate heat-trapping gases misstated the cuts in carbon emissions that Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich has proposed in Illinois. By the year 2050, the proposal would restrict carbon emissions to 40 percent of 1990 levels -- not 60 percent.

A music review on Saturday about a solo guitar performance by Mick Barr, at Studio B in Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to the band Hella and to Mr. Barr's association with the band. While Mr. Barr has released duo recordings with Zach Hill, Hella's drummer, Hella is not a duo and Mr. Barr is not a member.

A year after Wal-Mart Stores unionized all its stores in China under pressure from the government, McDonald's is cooperating with China's large state-controlled union to allow the formation of more unions in its 750 outlets here. A McDonald's spokesman said Monday that the company was working with union officials to help establish a union at its stores in southern Guangdong Province, one of the country's wealthiest regions.

The 56,227 fans who watched the Mets play the Phillies yesterday set a record for opening day at Shea Stadium and gave team officials a chance to test their new parking arrangements. When workers broke ground in August on the Mets' new ballpark, Citi Field, which is expected to be finished for the 2009 season, one consequence of the construction was the loss of 2,100 parking spaces within yards of the entrance gates to Shea.

MERENDINO--Vincent J. M.D. Goodbye to a kind, generous buddy who treated the indigent ill with great compassion. We shall miss you. Madeline & Jack Freedman $(6$)MERENDINO--Vincent J. We deeply mourn the passing of our very special, irreplaceable ''Vinnie''. We will sorely miss our close friend, lovable traveling companion, unique golfing partner and, most of all, we will miss his incomparable dry wit. Claire and Sherwin Kaufman $(6$)MERENDINO--Vincent J, M.D. died at Englewood Hospital on Sunday morning, April 8, 2007, following a courageous battle with numerous complications. Vincent was born on January 5, 1917, in New York City. He graduated from Columbia College in 1937, and received his M.D. from New York Medical College in 1942. He was a Captain in the Marine Corps during WWII, where he was Chief of Surgery for the 112th Evacuation Hospital. Vincent had a long and distinguished medical career. Among the positions he held were; Chief of Gynecology, Prospect Hospital, (1948-1976), Professor of Clinical Obstetrics and Gynecology, New York Medical College (1976-1988); he was Chief of Service, Obstetrics and Gynecology, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital (19751986); Lecturer in Obstetrics and Gynecology, Mt. Sinai School of Medicine (1976-1986); Attending Gynecologist, Metropolitan Hospital (1954-1988); Associate Attending Gynecologist, Lenox Hill Hospital (1976-1986). Vincent is survived by his wife, Rita, his daughter, Melissa, Rita's daughter, Debra Solomon and his grandchildren, Charles and Lesley Solomon. He is further survived by his innumerable friends and family who loved and respected him dearly. Funeral services for Vincent J. Merendino will be held at 11 am on Wednesday, April 11th, at Gutterman Musicant Funeral Home, in Hackensack, NJ. Contributions may be made to Englewood Hospital. $(6$)MERENDINO--Vincent J. Goodbye, Uncle Vinny. We'll never forget all the wonderful times together. Our deepest condolences to Rita and Missy. Micky, Jeanny, Micheline and KitCat

New Life at Caramoor For Monty Python's 'Brian' Eric Idle (book and lyrics), below, and John Du Prez (music) aren't finished mining Monty Python material. Creators of the Broadway hit ''Spamalot,'' the two have come up with a comic oratorio, ''Not the Messiah (He's a Very Naughty Boy),'' inspired by Monty Python's ''Life of Brian.'' It will have its United States premiere in two performances on July 1 at the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah, N.Y. Mr. Idle will serve as soloist and narrator. His first cousin Peter Oundjian, Caramoor's artistic adviser and principal conductor, will lead the Orchestra of St Luke's with the Collegiate Chorale and featured soloists. Mr. Idle said: ''As the 'Messiah' was to the Bible, so 'Not the Messiah' is to 'Life of Brian.' '' Avery Fisher Grant Winners Announced The Borromeo String Quartet, the violinist Yura Lee and the double bassist DaXun Zhang, above, are to be named the winners today of the annual Avery Fisher Career Grants. The awards, raised this year to $25,000 from $15,000, are intended to recognize and assist instrumentalists and chamber ensembles with potential for major careers. Among the more than 100 recipients of the grants since they were established by Avery Fisher in a major gift to Lincoln Center in 1974 are Joshua Bell, Leila Josefowicz, Gil Shaham and David Shifrin. James Naughton to Direct The Tony Award-winning actor James Naughton (''City of Angels,'' ''Chicago'') will direct the world premiere of David Epstein's ''Surface to Air'' at Symphony Space. The second in Symphony Space's annual Summer Stock on Broadway series, the play, about a people forced to confront repressed emotions when the remains of a family member are recovered 30 years after he was shot down in Vietnam, will run from July 11 through Aug. 5. The Persona Theater Company of Greece will present its production of ''Clytemnestra's Tears,'' a one-women lamentation written and directed by Avra Sidiropoulou and performed by Themis Bazaka, at La Mama E.T.C. from May 17 through June 3. 18 Brides for 5 Mothers Mamma mia! Reality television in Italy has taken a new turn, with the introduction of a show that lets mothers choose their son's wives, Reuters reported. Critics responded immediately by saying that the show, ''Perfect Bride,'' insulted women and demonstrated that Italian television, which already carries reality programming like ''Big Brother'' and ''Celebrity Island,'' had fallen to a new low. In the first episode of ''Perfect Bride,'' carried on RAI, the state broadcaster, the jury of mothers of five single men quizzed 18 bridal candidates about their suitability as wives. Beginning next week the mothers and potential daughters-in-law will live in a ''Big Brother''-style house where the candidates' ability to handle household chores can be scrutinized. Viewers will have a chance to take part in voting off the brides they dislike. The mothers are known by their first names, like Mamma Teresa and Mamma Ambra. Mamma Teresa said she was looking for ''a simple, intelligent classy girl'' for her son Claudio. ''I would like someone who's not too ostentatious and who knows how to take care of the family.'' As for Claudio, she said: ''He has too many girlfriends. I want to find him his ultimate woman.'' Prize for Elizabeth Spencer Elizabeth Spencer has been named the winner of the 20th annual PEN/Malamud Award. The accolade recognizes a body of work that demonstrates excellence in short fiction. Ms. Spencer, who teaches writing at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, is the author of seven collections of short fiction, nine novels, a memoir and a play. Reviewing Ms. Spencer's 2001 collection ''The Southern Woman,'' Molly Haskell wrote: ''Her light touch, cool ironies and subtle class distinctions have enough in common with Henry James or British writers like Elizabeth Bowen and Muriel Spark to unsettle readers expecting the danker moss-laden landscape of deep-Southern fiction. Eudora Welty once compared her to Katherine Mansfield, and the great Canadian short story writer Alice Munro is perhaps a sister under the skin.'' The PEN/Malamud Award includes a reading in the PEN/Faulkner reading series at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington and $5,000.

Radio Host Is Suspended Over Racial Comments CBS Radio and MSNBC suspended Don Imus, the morning talk host, for two weeks after his racially disparaging comments about the Rutgers women's basketball team. MSNBC said Mr. Imus had agreed that the suspension was appropriate and promised to change the tenor of the program. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Sex Offender Roils Church A church in Carlsbad, Calif., has been plunged into a painful dilemma by the request of a convicted child molester to join. Congregants are asking how to ensure the safety of their children and wondering if an offender who says he has accepted Christ has truly changed. PAGE A14 Ex-Captives Can't Sell Stories After howls of protest, Britain's defense secretary abruptly reversed a decision to allow some of the sailors and marines captured by Iran to sell their stories to the media. Two of them already have. PAGE A11 SPECIAL TODAY Retirement As life spans lengthen, experts on aging say it is more important than ever to prepare for the physical and psychological aspects of retirement. SECTION H The Science of Desire Scientists are gaining new and surprising insights into the nature of sexual desire. They are tracing the differences and similarities in how men and women respond, studying what makes some people straight and others gay, and even analyzing speed dating to determine what turns people on -- and off. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F1 Iran Claims Nuclear Progress Iran claimed that it was now capable of industrial-scale uranium enrichment, a development that would defy two United Nations resolutions passed to press it to suspend its enrichment program. Western diplomats and nuclear experts were skeptical about Iran's progress. PAGE A3 The Woman in the 'Moon' In her Broadway debut, Eve Best plays Josie Hogan, Eugene O'Neill's rural giantess, in ''A Moon for the Misbegotten,'' which opened last night at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. A review by Ben Brantley. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 Mets' Hearty Welcome Home In front of 56,227 fans, the largest turnout for a home opener in franchise history, the Mets scored seven runs in the eighth inning to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 11-5, at Shea Stadium. SPORTSTUESDAY, PAGE D1

LOEWY--Hanna, of Manhattan, died March 31. She was 81. Born in Vienna to Psychiatrist/Neurologist Paul and Alice ''Lili'' Loewy, she immigrated in 1938 and later became a vital part of the circle of intellectuals, writers, and artists that gathered at the Princeton home of her mother and stepfather, the philosopher Erich Kahler. Burial was in Princeton Cemetery. Memorial Service will be announced.

The government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi came under fierce attack on Monday after the Taliban said it had killed an Afghan hostage who was a colleague of the Italian journalist freed last month in a prisoner swap. That journalist, Daniele Mastrogiacomo of La Repubblica, was freed on March 19 in exchange for five Taliban fighters released by the Afghan government. Italy had lobbied Pakistan to make a deal. At the time, the Italian government spokesman said, ''We think that the life of a person is very precious.''

The Sidney Ponson era in Yankees history never would have happened if Carl Pavano had been healthy. The Yankees were desperate for rotation help in Pavano's absence last summer, and they turned briefly to Ponson. On Monday night at the Metrodome, Pavano pitched against the man who replaced him. It was not a fair fight. The Yankees bruised Ponson for 8 runs and 10 hits, and Pavano earned his first victory since May 22, 2005.

A front-page article last Tuesday about Samuel Zell's acquisition of the Tribune Company for $8.2 billion misstated one aspect of an ''S'' Corporation, which Tribune will eventually become under the takeover proposal. Foreigners who are residents of the United States can invest in an ''S'' Corporation; investors are not restricted to United States citizens. An article in Business Day last Tuesday about Samuel Zell using an Employee Stock Ownership Plan, or ESOP, in a transaction for the Tribune Company omitted a condition for an owner to avoid capital gains taxes on the proceeds of a sale of company shares to such a plan. In addition to the ESOP holding the stock for at least three years, the company has to be private for at least one year before the sale.

STUDENT LOAN XPRESS SUSPENSIONS -- The CIT Group has suspended three officers in its Student Loan Xpress subsidiary after new disclosures involving ties to some university financial aid officials. [Page A1.] BATTLE FOR CONTROL OF OIL -- An ambitious plan by President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela to take control of several important oil projects from American and European companies is nearing a showdown. But in the end, all sides could wind up losing. [A1.] PATIENCE WITH CHINA WANING? -- For years, President Bush has avoided confronting China with sanctions or legal challenges to its trade practices, preferring to use diplomacy to press China to bring down its trade deficit with the United States. That stance may be hardening. [A1.] PFIZER DRUG ISN'T SELLING -- Exubera, the only commercially available inhaled insulin treatment for diabetes, is turning into an expensive flop for Pfizer. The drug maker had regarded Exubera as a potential blockbuster but after six months of marketing to doctors, only about one of every 500 prescriptions for insulin is for the drug. [C1.] AS CELEBREX AD IS CRITICIZED -- Public Citizen, a consumer group, has asked the Food and Drug Administration to ban a television advertisement for Pfizer's painkiller Celebrex on the ground that it gives consumers a false impression that the prescription drug has no more safety risks than some other painkillers. [C8.] MORE HOME LOAN PROBLEMS -- Mortgage difficulties appear to be cropping up in some loans made to borrowers with decent credit, as the lenders American Home Mortgage and M&T Bank Shares, both based in New York, have learned. [C1.] SHORING UP AN ARCHIVE -- Corbis, a corporation founded and owned by Bill Gates that holds rights to 100 million photographs, has appointed a new chief executive who is an expert in rights law. He is expected to plot the company's response to the rise of low-cost online photo services that threaten to undermine its lucrative photo sales. [C1.] DON IMUS IS SUSPENDED -- NBC News and CBS Radio have both suspended the radio host Don Imus for two weeks over his racially disparaging remarks about the Rutgers University women's basketball team. [C1.] NEW BUYOUT RECORD POSSIBLE -- One of Canada's largest pension funds is in talks with other investors to form a consortium to make a $45 billion takeover bid for the parent company of Bell Canada in what would be the biggest buyout in history. [C1.] UNHAPPY WITH THE TIMES COMPANY -- A second corporate advisory firm, Glass, Lewis & Company, is urging shareholders of The New York Times Company to withhold their votes for directors at the company's annual meeting later this month. [C7.] MIRANT PONDERS A SALE -- The Mirant Corporation, the electricity producer that abandoned a bid for rival NRG Energy last June, says it may put itself up for sale to capitalize on growing interest in power companies from buyout firms and other investors. [C5.] PAPER'S SALE VIOLATES CONTRACT -- An arbitrator ruled the Tribune Company's sale of The Advocate of Stamford to the Gannett Company violated a union contract by failing to require Gannett to honor the newsroom employees' collective bargaining agreement. [C2.] NEW CAMPAIGN FOR SONY -- Sony's new ad agency has produced a series of humorous ads tied into the ''Spider-Man 3'' movie to emphasize features on its camcorders and digital cameras that can solve age-old photography problems like blurriness and shakiness. [C3.] MCDONALD'S AGREES TO UNIONS -- A year after Wal-Mart Stores unionized all its stores in China under pressure from the government, McDonald's is cooperating with China to allow more unions in its 750 outlets. [C3.] REVAMPING CITIGROUP -- Citigroup chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, below, will announce plans tomorrow for the bank's first major overhaul since a merger forged Citigroup a decade ago. It is part of broad effort to streamline the bank's global operations and get costs under control. [C9.] FIRST N.Y.S.E. CHAIRMAN DIES -- James J. Needham, the first full-time paid chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, died on Friday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. [B6.] A KING OF MEXICAN FOOD HAS DIED -- Louis Flores Ruiz, who built a modest enchilada factory in California into the nation's largest producer of frozen Mexican foods, has died. [B6.] ONLINE MORE PIECES, STILL A PUZZLE -- New rules were supposed to paint a fuller picture of executive pay, but more information has not brought more clarity. A special report on executive pay is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. THE CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER of the beleaguered video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software announced his resignation, less than two weeks after a shareholder revolt that ousted the chief executive and several board members. (AP) JACKSON HEWITT TAX SERVICE said that a franchisee named in civil lawsuits filed last week by the Justice Department had agreed to temporarily suspend operations. (REUTERS) THE DEFENSE DEPARTMENT has drafted rules to curb lending practices it considers predatory -- including payday loans, car title lending and tax refund anticipation loans -- to military service members and their families. (REUTERS)

KEHOE--Veronica Lally, 64, peacefully at home after a two year illness she bore with great grace, strength and dignity and at the same moment the Easter Vigil service at St. Ignatius Loyola Church she loved so much for so many years was beginning. She is survived by her loving husband, John P. (Jack) Kehoe, her devoted sister, Maureen Lally, her beloved daughter, Allise Dickson, Allises husband, Bradley, and her adored granddaughter of three months, Lilly Grace, for whose birth and first months of magical life God spared her to enjoy, and by Jacks four children and five grandchildren. An alumna of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, summa cum laude graduate at Fordham Universitys College at Lincoln Center and a member of the WFUV-FM Advisory Board, Veronica, an AFTRA and SAG member, actor and theatrical producer, for 25 years supported and encouraged new American plays and playwrights through the activities of her not-for-profit Gypsy Road Company in association with 33 of the leading writing programs among Americas colleges and an Advisory Board chaired originally by Ms. Helen Hayes. Family visiting at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (at East 81st Street), New York, NY 10028, (212) 288-3500. Monday, April 9th, 7 9 PM, Tuesday April 10th, 2 5 PM and 7 9 PM.
