In Lieu of flowers, the family welcomes donations to Fordham University Theater Department, or the Marian Francis Harriott S.C. Scholarship at College of Mount Saint Vincent.

Roger Bagnall, a Greek and Latin scholar, has been hired to head a new Institute for the Study of the Ancient World at New York University. The institute, a center for advanced studies and doctoral education, is being founded with a $200 million gift from the Leon Levy Foundation announced last year. Mr. Bagnall, who is to assume his new post on July 1, teaches in the history and classics departments at Columbia University. He is the Jay Professor of Greek and Latin Languages and specializes in the study of ancient papyruses as well as Hellenistic and Roman history. The new institute has stirred controversy among archaeologists because Mr. Levy, a financier who died in 2003, and his wife, Shelby White, collected Greek and Roman antiquities that some experts assert were looted from archaeological sites. N.Y.U. said the new institute was expected to start hiring faculty in the next academic year and begin admitting students for the fall of 2009. ROBIN POGREBIN

GREEN--Beatrice Stella, 91, of Oak Hill Manor, Ithaca, New York, died on April 3. She was born in Brooklyn, New York on September 1, 1915 to Yetta and Wolf Kosofsky. She is survived by her daughters, Victoria Borus and Stefanie Green, and her grandson, Joseph Lehman. She loved poetry, history, music, art and horticulture. She had a boundless curiosity about the world and the people who live in it. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends.
LIEF--Arthur. Five years gone, deeply loved and sorely missed by 3 generations of his family. Ninety-three years weren't enough

After 10 years as executive director of Habitat for Humanity-New York City, Roland Lewis, left, is leaving to become president and chief executive of the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance. The alliance is a nonprofit group that advocates for public access to the city's shores and waterways. It had been a project of the Municipal Art Society of New York from 1999 until it was spun off as an independent entity last week, said Kent L. Barwick, president of the art society. Mr. Lewis, 46, who lives in Flatbush, Brooklyn, said yesterday that he hoped to build the alliance into a ''large not-for-profit agency that will be dedicated to finding common ground'' among waterfront developers, government officials and the public. PATRICK McGEEHAN

Just weeks after abandoning a bid for New York's thoroughbred horse racing franchise, the casino magnate Steve Wynn announced yesterday that he would join one of the four consortiums still vying for the prize. Mr. Wynn, along with two real estate developers, Steven Roth and Richard D. Bronson, will invest in Excelsior Racing Associates. At stake are rights to run the Saratoga, Aqueduct and Belmont racetracks, which take in $2.7 billion a year in bets. The move comes on the eve of public hearings at which the bidders will present their investment plans to a panel picked by Gov. Eliot Spitzer. NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed legislation yesterday that will officially move up the presidential primary by one month, adding New York to the growing number of states that are making similar changes. The Democratic and Republican primaries will now be held on the first Tuesday in February -- which falls on Feb. 5 in 2008, a presidential election year -- rather than on the first Tuesday in March. ''Moving the primary date to February, we will help secure New York's large and diverse population an influential voice in selecting the 2008 presidential nominees,'' Governor Spitzer said in a statement. NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

REINSTEIN--Harvey, died at 78. Harvey Reinstein, a well known and widely respected television syndication salesman for such companies as Four Star, Metromedia, MGM and Lorimar, died early on the morning of his 78th Birthday on April 6th at his home in Lake Worth, Florida. His loving daughter, Beth, was at his Bedside, as she had been through his illness. Harvey Richard Reinstein, formerly of Dix Hills, NY, was born on April 6th, 1929, in the Bronx, New York. The son of David Reinstein, a furrier, and Marcella Reinstein, a singer and homemaker. Although he was an imposing 6'5'' tall, Harvey often disarmed people with his warmth and humor. This charm earned him numerous friends and associates that have become his extended family throughout the years. Besides his daughter, who lives in California, Harvey is survived by his son, Adam; daughter-in-law Lisa, and grandchildren Joshua, Danielle and Lillian, all residing in Ohio. He is predeceased by his loving wife of 41 years, Myrna and brother, Joel. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday April 10th, 12 noon at Schwartz Bros./Jeffer Memorial, on Queens Blvd and 76th Road. Donations in Harvey's name can be made to the American Cancer Society. Harvey was large in life, and larger than life. He will always be loved and now missed.

To the Editor: Re ''Britons Say They Feared for Lives in Iran Captivity'' (front page, April 7): It is terrible that the recently seized British sailors and marines were treated poorly in captivity while in Iran, but it should not be a surprise if one considers how the policies of the United States, Britain's major ally, regarding prisoners and ''detainees'' have evolved in the years after 9/11.

A large proportion of breast surgeons never refer their patients to a plastic surgeon for reconstruction, a new study reports. Researchers surveyed 365 surgeons with 1,844 patients in Detroit and Los Angeles in 2002. Only 24 percent of surgeons referred more than three-quarters of their patients for plastic surgery, and 44 percent referred fewer than one-quarter.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Shiites Rally to Demand End to U.S. Presence in Iraq Tens of thousands of protesters loyal to Moktada al-Sadr, the Shiite cleric, rallied in the holy city of Najaf to demand an end to the American military presence in Iraq. Residents said the demonstration was the largest in Najaf, the heart of Shiite religious power, since the American-led invasion in 2003. A1 Iran Claims Defy 2 U.N. Edicts Iran claimed that it is now capable of industrial-scale uranium enrichment, a development that would defy two United Nations resolutions. Western diplomats and nuclear experts said the declaration seemed to have more to do with political showmanship than technical progress. A3 China Dissident Cites Coercion Gao Zhisheng, one of China's most outspoken dissidents until his conviction on sedition charges late last year, said in a recorded statement that while he had received a light sentence in exchange for his confession, it had been made under mental and physical duress. A10 New Heat on Italy Captive Swap The government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi came under fierce attack after the Taliban said it had killed an Afghan hostage who was a colleague of the Italian journalist freed last month in a controversial prisoner swap. A12 Ban on Sailors' Selling Stories After protest over a decision to allow some of the sailors and marines captured by Iran to sell their stories to the media, Britain's defense secretary reversed the decision, banning sales entirely. A11 NATIONAL A14-19 Loan Company Officials Are Placed on Leave Three officials of Student Loan Xpress were put on leave after a series of revelations that several college officials held stock in the company. A1 Immigration Turns to DNA Tests Federal officials are increasingly turning to genetic testing to verify the biological bonds between new citizens and the overseas relatives they hope to bring here, particularly those from war-torn or developing countries where identity documents can be scarce or doctored. But the tests can uncover unexpected and sometimes unbearable truths. A1 Convict Tests Church's Faith A church in California, sustained by the belief that embracing all people is a living example of Christ's love, faced a profound test in faith when a convicted child molester asked to join. Congregants are now wondering if all are truly welcome. A14 A Challenge to Emission Rule The fight over cars and carbon dioxide moves from the Supreme Court to a federal courtroom in Burlington, Vt. The auto industry is suing to block a 2004 California regulation, which Vermont would follow, from taking effect. A19 Guard Told of Deployments About 13,000 National Guard soldiers from Indiana, Ohio, Oklahoma and Arkansas got an official heads-up that they should expect possible deployment to Iraq by year's end or in 2008, sooner than scheduled and underscoring just how profoundly the National Guard's role has shifted since 2003. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5; 8 Raid on Home Shines Light On Immigration Tensions A raid by federal agents on the home of a Hispanic family in East Hampton, N.Y., is the latest escalation in a wave of crackdowns driven by complaints against immigrants. The family members, all of whom are American citizens, see the raid as a violation of their rights. But to some residents, it was an overdue response to long-simmering concerns about illegal immigration on Long Island's East End. B1 They Robbed the Mob A federal trial now getting under way is expected to shed light on the 1992 execution-style killings of a young couple from Queens who robbed a series of mob social clubs armed with an Uzi submachine gun. A man prosecutors say is a Gambino crime family captain has been charged. B1 New Restaurant Rat Patrol New York City's health department is revamping how it inspects restaurants for potential rodent infestation after a review prompted by a widely seen news video of rats swarming in a KFC/Taco Bell restaurant in Greenwich Village. B3 BUSINESS DAY C1-11 U.S. Turns Up Heat on China The United States announced it would take China to court at the World Trade Organization over allegations of trade barriers and piracy of books, music, videos and other goods. The confrontation is the latest episode suggesting that the conciliatory approach is being reconsidered, if not discarded. MURPHY--Charles E., Jr., died April 5th, 2007 at 12:55 am PDT. He was 83 years old. Born and raised in Brooklyn, New York he graduated from Dartmouth College and Columbia Law School. During World War II he served actively with the United States Marine Corp from 1942 to 1946. He separated from the Service as First Lieutenant. Following Law School, he served during the Korean War on active duty from 1950 to 1952. Following his Honorable Discharge as a Captain in 1952, he became a staff attorney for the Texas Company until 1954 when he joined the firm of Wandless, Havens, Stitt & Tighe. Becoming a partner in 1956, he rose to Senior Partner and merged his firm with Whitman and Ransom in 1976. He remained a Senior Partner of Whitman and Ransom until 1993 when he again merged the firm. He then became ''of counsel.'' In 2004, he retired from Satterlee Stephens Burke & Burke. Mr. Murphy spent the major part of his life in New Castle, New York where he served on the Town Board, the New Castle Zoning Board, and the Adoption Service of Northern Westchester, now Family Services. He also served on various Boards of Directors including Fleet/Norstar, The John A. Hartford Foundation of which he was a Director, Vice Chairman and Chairman of the Grants Committee and Chairman of the Finance Committee. He is survived by his wife Anne Hogate, two sons, Charles (Reva) of Berkley, California, Kenneth (Diane) of Boise, Idaho, ten grandchildren and three great-grandchildren, a brother Thomas Sawyer of Rye, New York and sister Elizabeth Orteig of Scarsdale, New York. There will be a memorial service at the Quaker Hill Country Club, 1013 Quaker Hill Road, Pawling, New York, 12564 on Friday, April 13, at 11:30 am. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Boise Chapter of Make-AWish Foundation, 4355 Emerald St, Suite 280, Boise, Idaho, 83706 would be appreciated.

To the Editor: Re ''Lessons of Heart Disease, Learned and Ignored'' (''Six Killers'' series, front page, April 8): You are quite right to highlight the many missed opportunities to prevent heart attacks and save lives by early recognition of heart disease symptoms and consistent, timely use of the best available medications and technologies. But early recognition of heart attack is a sadly limited approach to heart disease prevention. We have long known that populations with comparable genetic susceptibilities, living in different environments, experience dramatically varying rates of heart disease. Most experts concur that routine application of what we already know about healthful lifestyle could reduce heart disease rates in the United States by 80 percent.

Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini, right, with Edie Falco, who plays his wife, Carmela) and fellow mobsters returned to HBO on Easter Sunday for the first episode of the Season 7, leaving network television feeling the heat. Opposite ''The Sopranos'' at 9 p.m. ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' delivered its lowest ratings ever among adults 18 to 49, excluding clip shows and repeats. Ratings for the ''Sopranos'' premiere were not available yesterday, but Nielsen's estimates for the networks show that ''Housewives,'' in its first new episode since March 4, earned a below average (although still dominant) 15.7 million viewers. ABC remained the night's leader in the 18 to 49 set, winning both the 8 p.m. hour with ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (12 million) and the 10 p.m. hour with ''Brothers & Sisters'' (11 million). CBS ranked second among viewers 18 to 49, but fared slightly better than ABC in total viewers. CBS's ''60 Minutes,'' with its profile of Senator John McCain, led the 7 p.m. hour (12.9 million), and CBS's ''Without a Trace'' was the most watched show at 10 (14.1 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

Terry Francona, the manager of the Boston Red Sox, spoke honestly about his level of communication with Daisuke Matsuzaka, the Japanese pitcher. There is not much. A few words, some nods. But Francona is trying.
I love my friends and family, but I've seriously considered sending this memo to every one of them:

Last week, a new study showed that radiologists don't need no stinking machines. Radiologists read mammograms, at $120 a pop, to look for breast cancer. One out of every 200 films shows a suspicious pattern the radiologist recognizes from years of experience. It's tedious work in a dark room with a magnifying glass. And mammograms are often read twice - another $120. A new system called computer-aided detection, or CAD, can identify the same patterns a doctor can, by referring to a database of known cancer films. And now a third of all second mammogram readings are done by CAD, for $20 each. But the study from the University of California, Davis, showed that a radiologist with CAD was statistically no better than a radiologist alone in finding cancer. Round 1: Doctors.

New York and six other Northeastern states have joined in a regional pact to reduce mercury emissions low enough for advisories against eating freshwater fish to be lifted some years in the future.Satisfied that they have reduced the amount of mercury pollution generated within their own borders as much as possible, the states are trying to focus attention on mercury pollution that drifts into the region from the Midwest, particularly from states where coal-fired power plants are the prime source of electricity.

New York City wants to strengthen its hand against recalcitrant landlords by giving itself broad new powers not simply to make patchwork emergency repairs in long-troubled buildings but to overhaul entire systems, like heating or plumbing, and then force the landlords to foot the bill.A bill to be introduced in the City Council, with the support of the Bloomberg administration, would give the city's housing agency the right to go into buildings with dozens of serious housing-code violations and a history of unpaid emergency repairs, do a "cellar to roof inspection" and fix not only immediate problems but whole underlying systems.

The New York City Water Board is expected to approve an 11.5 percent increase in city water rates, the largest annual increase in 15 years. The first public hearing on the rate change was this afternoon in Queens, but more are planned around the city: Here's the full schedule.

That is the name that the conservative Manhattan Institute for Policy Research has given to the list [two formats: pdf or Excel spreadsheet] it has compiled of pork-barrel member item projects found in the 2007-08 state budget. There are some 5,800 obvious ones, but the institute adds that it may have missed some fine print.

The latest issue of Trader Monthly, which features a list of the 100 top-earning hedge fund managers, writes that Daniel Loeb's "venomous tongue has fallen silent of late and his legendarily incendiary memos have disappeared." We beg to differ. Proof to the contrary came Wednesday in a blistering letter to the board of PDL Biopharma, a drug development company in which Mr. Loeb's hedge fund firm, Third Point, owns a 9.7 percent stake. In the letter, which was distributed in a press release, Mr. Loeb urges PDL to remove its chief executive, Mark McDade, whom he describes as being "fixated on when his boat slip in the marina adjacent to the new corporate headquarters will be ready" rather than on his company's underperforming stock.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's April 11 column, "Upsetting the Balance."
Madison Park, Seattle - Brian Jacobsen and other business owners told host Hattie Bryant that they have processes in place to treat data like cash.
Tires Plus, Minneapolis - Tom Gegax told host Hattie Bryant that there are four steps to coaching employees.  He started and grew Tires Plus to 2,000 employees.
Tires Plus, Minneapolis - Tom Gegax started and grew Tires Plus to 2,000 employees.  He told host Hattie Bryant that nobody wants a boss and everybody wants a coach.
Zubi Advertising, Miami - Tere Zubizaretta helps customers reach the Hispanic market.  Tere told host Hattie Bryant that being small is not a good reason to be shy.
Rodgers Chevrolet, Woodhaven, MI - Owner Pamela Rodgers has an MBA in finance.  With confidence she tells host Hattie Bryant that being nice translates to the bottom line.
Gadabout SalonSpas, Tucson - Founder Pam McNair tells host Hattie Bryant that the more training she provides the more profit she realizes.

While he was New York's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer was known as the "sheriff of Wall Street" for his efforts to root out wrongdoing in the financial-services sector. Mr. Spitzer went on to become New York's governor, and now his top lieutenant from his A.G. days, Michele Hirshman, has found new work as well: Ms. Hirshman will join Paul Weiss as a partner in the law firm's litigation department.
Oregon Log Homes, Maupin, Oregon - Founder Mike Neary tells host Hattie Bryant that he should have given employees more detailed guidance when he first started hiring.
Oregon Log Homes, Maupin, Oregon - Host Hattie Bryant talks with founder Mike Neary and marketing expert John Wargo. Mike says moving to a busy highway increased his sales.
Katz's Deli, Bar and Gallery, Austin - Marc Katz brought New York deli food to Austin nearly 3 decades ago. Marc tells host Hattie Bryant how he keeps customers coming back.
Nicole Miller, New York City - Judy Scarpola tells host Hattie Bryant that when she started at Nicole Miller she never dreamed that she would become a vice president.
Joseph's Lite Cookies, Deming, NM - Founder Joseph Semprevivo tells host Hattie Bryant that as long as he is working at Joseph's the people on his payroll will be too.
Auntie Anne's Pretzel, Gap, PA - Founder Anne Beiler tells host Hattie Bryant that she can teach anybody how to make a pretzel and run a store.

Wednesday brought two developments related to CNBC correspondent Maria Bartiromo: One brought some closure, the other was a closing. The Financial Times reported that Todd S. Thomson, the Citigroup executive whose dismissal raised questions about his ties to Ms. Bartiromo, has reached a deal with Citi over his severance package. What's next for Mr. Thomson, who was once considered a contender to lead Citi? Bloomberg News said he has set up a real estate development firm called Headwaters Capital as he considers his options. In other real-estate news -- yes, we are reaching for a segue here -- The New York Observer reports that Ms. Bartiromo and her husband, Jonathan Steinberg, have closed their purchase of a five-level, $6.5 million townhouse on Manhattan's Upper East Side.
Cloud 9 Shuttle, San Diego - John Hawkins bought a shared-ride company out of bankruptcy. He tells host Hattie Bryant how he brought it back to life.
Understanding Financial Statements - Veteran entrepreneur and author, Jim Schell, helps owners face the facts. He tells host Hattie Bryant that monitoring trends is vital.
Gadabout SalonSpas, Tucson - One employee explains to host Hattie Bryant why Gadabout SalonSpas is such a special place to work.
Ironbound Valve Actuation Company - Ironbound's owner Howard Kent tells host Hattie Bryant that for decades he has found ways to use technology to increase profits.
Sundance Catalog, Salt Lake City - Harry Rosenthal explains to host Hattie Bryant that making a famous person the face of your business can backfire.
Weatherend Estate Furniture - Gil Harper's company builds heirloom quality furniture in Rockland, Maine. He tells host Hattie Bryant how he spends advertising dollars.
The Band Of Angels, Silicon Valley - Hans Severins and Fred Hoar tell host Hattie Bryant why angel investors look for new ideas.
Fess Parker Winery, Los Olivos, CA - Fess Parker tells host Hattie Bryant that he learned about financing ideas from his first boss, Walt Disney.
Ebby Halliday Real Estate, Dallas - Ebby's team will do six billion in sales this year. She tells host Hattie Bryant that her success strategy is no secret.
National Assn. Independent Truckers - Cheryl Womack's company in Kansas City provides insurance for big rig owners. She tells host Hattie Bryant about her mostly-female team.
Boston Duck Tours, Boston - Boston Duck is the cities' most popular tourist attraction. Founder Andy Wilson tells host Hattie Bryant how he ran out of his own cash.
On Target Supplies & Logistics, Dallas - On Target distributes supplies and provides warehouse logistics. Owner Albert Black tells host Hattie Bryant how he cultivates people.
Angell & Phelps, Daytona Beach - Angell & Phelps makes chocolates. Owner Al Smith tells host Hattie Bryant that he may sell chocolate but he's in the people business.

A plurality of Americans say Senator John McCain is making the situation in Iraq sound better than it actually is, and a strong majority still do not think the United States will ultimately succeed in the war despite Mr. McCain's assertions to the contrary, according to the latest CBS News Poll.
Now that you've debated the importance of height and looks and income in the dating market, let's consider something else that people note in their personal ads: race.
I've got a question for our Bats readers: Why do so many fans take the issue of Alex Rodriguez so personally?

In Iowa tonight, Senator Christopher Dodd is expected to provide his vision for ending the war in Iraq and beyond, urging the other contenders in the 2008 Democratic field to support the Reid-Feingold measure that calls for withdrawal of all troops and a funding cutoff by March 31, 2008.
Candy & Candy, the high-end London developers who are expected to produce record sales when One Hyde Park is completed in Knightsbridge, are taking their bespoke style to Beverly Hills.

Initial public offerings "are back - and tech I.P.O.'s are really back," writes Brian Caulfield of Forbes.com. But "the most heavily hyped segment of the tech boom -- the glitzy 'Web 2.0' companies -- has produced a grand total of zero stock offerings. What gives?" There are various meanings of Web 2.0, and this article doesn't quite offer up a definition, but it makes reference to the kind of buzzy, Web-based companies backed by venture investors such as Benchmark Capital, Draper Fisher Jurvetson and Sequoia Capital and contrasts them with the networking- and telecom-related tech firms that have held I.P.O.'s this year.

It appears someone may have pulled a fast one on Bloomberg News -- and, by extension, DealBook. Bloomberg reported early Wednesday morning that Edward Pastorini, an American investor, was planning a bid for Gold Fields, the world's fourth-largest mining company. DealBook included a link to the Bloomberg item in Wednesday's e-mail newsletter. One problem: More and more, the story looks like a hoax.

Fred Thompson told Fox News today that he was diagnosed with a type of lymphoma in 2004, but that the cancer is "fortunately a good kind if you can ever call something like that a good kind," and has been in remission.

We hate to pile on a company when it's down, but we couldn't resist running some numbers on Vonage Holdings, the upstart Internet-based phone company whose initial public offering last year has gone from bad to worse to apocalyptically awful. With the latest downtick in Vonage's stock, coming after a federal judge ordered it to stop using technology licensed by Verizon, the I.P.O. is by far the worst of 2006, according to Thomson Financial. At $3, the stock has lost more than 82 percent of its value since last May, when it was sold to the public at $17 apiece. The shares are now below the average price paid by Vonage's pre-I.P.O. investors, a prestigious group of venture and private equity investors including New Enterprise Associates, Meritech Capital Partners, 3i, and Bain Capital.

The bidding for J Sainsbury came to an end on Wednesday, as CVC Capital Partners called off the 10 billion pound ($19.7 billion) bid for the British grocer after failing to meet the founding family's desired price. Though CVC offered the board 582 pence a share, the family, which holds about 18 percent of the retailer, wanted at least 600 pence a share.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Reader responses to David Leonhardt’s column on renting versus buying a home.

Shares of Citigroup declined more than 1 percent Wednesday after the company gave details about its long-awaited plan to cut costs. Citi's stock -- which has made only modest gains in the past three years, frustrating many investors -- had been rising in recent days in anticipation of the announcement, which followed a companywide review led by Citi's chief operating officer, Robert Druskin. Analysts said the plan, which includes 17,000 job cuts and 9,500 job reassignments or relocations, was generally in line with what Wall Street had expected.
The campaign of Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona and presidential contender, released the advance text of his remarks given at the Virginia Military Institute.

Item 1 The Bloomberg administration, fighting Gov. Eliot Spitzer's proposal to close some business tax loopholes - or to raise business taxes, depending on your perspective -- warns that the proposals would harm companies like Citigroup. Mark Page, the mayor's budget director, tells the City Council in March that Citigroup told the city that the governor's proposal would cost it $60 million more in taxes each year.''If it's more expensive to be located here, that's obviously a major incentive to be less located here,'' Mr. Page said.

The soon-to-conclude not-TV-it's-HBO series "The Sopranos" is the most cynical television drama in history, suggests Matt Zoller Seitz in The Star-Ledger. The show is "a worst-case scenario look at human nature in which the inhabitants of an insular, paranoid, highly materialistic subculture are confronted with the choice between doing the right thing and the convenient thing, and nearly always go with option B." He adds:
We took the scenic route from Savannah on our way north to Beaufort, bypassing Route 95 for the undivided Okatie Highway (on most of the route, "highway" was merely aspirational).
Two bombings in Algeria, one targeting the prime minister’s office in the country’s capital, killed at least 17 people.

On Monday, Adam Nagourney kicked off The Times's new online political columns that examine the candidates, the campaigns and the issues, with a look at early polling in the 2008 presidential campaign and the risks the candidates court when they rely on those numbers.

With Senator John McCain trying to revive his flagging campaign with a major policy speech on the war in Iraq today, The Times's Adam Nagourney and John Broder examine concerns among top G.O.P. officials that the war and other matters are hurting their chances to retain the White House.

Manor Care, a nursing-home operator, said Wednesday it had hired J.P. Morgan Chase to help it explore a "full range of opportunities" to add shareholder value. The company did not give any specifics about the alternatives under review but said in a news release that it was "well-positioned to consider taking advantage of currently attractive conditions in the financial markets." Manor Care's stock surged after the announcement, rising 11 percent in early trading Wednesday to $61.65, a 52-week high. At that price, the company has a market capitalization of about $4.5 billion.

The New York Times editorial page has condemned Don Imus for his "disgraceful behavior," and Gwen Ifill wrote on the op-ed page that the sincerity of Imus's apology "seems forced and suspect because he's done some version of this several times before." But there are some Imus defenders out there.
Update: It appears someone pulled a fast one on Bloomberg News -- and us. Click here for details.

The private-equity firms fighting to save their $27 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications are weighing their options ahead of a crucial vote on the deal next week, the New York Post reported citing unnamed sources. Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital -- which struck a deal last year to buy Clear Channel for $37.60 a share -- held serious discussions over the past week on whether to increase their offer for the radio giant in order to appease a group of cantankerous shareholders demanding a sweeter deal.

The boom in mergers and acquisitions that made retailers and apparel makers prized targets and resulted in ownership changes for marquee names such as Neiman Marcus, May Department Stores and Toys 'R' Us, is finally cooling, The New York Post said Wednesday. In year-to-date figures, retail and apparel companies accounted for just 2.9 percent of overall mergers and acquisitions activity compared with a recent high of 8 percent for the same period in 2005, the paper said, citing data from Thomson Financial.

Speculation over the fate of the three Trump Entertainment casinos in Atlantic City has heightened since mid-March, when the company disclosed that it had hired Merrill Lynch to "explore all our options," as Donald Trump, who owns 30 percent of the holding company, put it. That includes the possibility that the company might sell all three properties - or perhaps dispose of a single hotel to raise the capital to improve the other two.

Financial services firms helped office rents in Manhattan reach record highs in the first three months of 2007, the real estate brokerage firm Cushman & Wakefield said Tuesday. Financial services accounted for 35.7 percent of leasing during the quarter, as rents in Midtown reached a record average $70.77 a square foot, with some surpassing $150 a square foot, Cushman & Wakefield said.

Vision Investment Management, a manager of an Aisan fund that invests in various hedge funds, has raised about $55 million for a new vehicle that will seed and incubate hedge fund start-ups, Reuters reported. The firm's Vision Angel Fund is likely to invest with its first two managers within 30 to 45 days, Julius Wang, a managing director with the Hong Kong-based firm, told the wire service. He said that the investment target size will be between $100 million to $150 million.
Last weekend, visitors to the New York auto show had a great opportunity to check out some old cars along with the new models.

Barclays Bank's 80 billion pound ($158 billion) merger with ABN Amro took another step forward as ABN rushed to settle legal action over money transfers and the government regulator in The Netherlands said that, in principle, it did not object to takeovers by foreign banks. The Telegraph reported that ABN is attempting to reach an agreement with the United States Department of Justice over certain deficiencies in its anti-money-laundering systems.

Cerberus Capital Management, the Fortress Investment Group and D.E. Shaw are among the hedge funds who have been buying shares in bankrupt companies in an attempt to influence the restructuring or force acquisitions, according to Financial News. Shareholders typically have little say in bankruptcy proceedings, but funds with equity stakes have been taking active roles in cases involving Calpine, Northwest Airlines and Delphi, among others.

CVC, the private equity firm attempting to mount a bid for J Sainsbury, has enlisted the backing of the private equity division of Goldman Sachs in a last-ditch attempt to rescue its fast-collapsing proposed deal for the British supermarket chain, according to The Telegraph.

Goldman Sachs manages $147 billion in alternative assets, making the securities firm a behemoth in the hedge-fund business. So why, asks Thorold Barker of The Financial Times, doesn't Goldman enjoy the same heady market valuation as Fortress Investment Group, which recently went public? Part of the problem, he suggests, is the "black box" factor: Goldman simply doesn't tell investors and analysts much about its hedge fund operations. If the firm wants more credit for its hedge fund prowess, it might want to consider pulling back the veil a bit.

The bankruptcy filing of New Century Financial left several investment banks with hundreds of millions, if not billions, of dollars in claims. But what is the real risk for the Wall Street firms that extended credit to the subprime lender?

A private equity firm in London, Terra Firma Capital Partners and a biomedical research foundation, Wellcome Trust have confirmed that they are interested in bidding for Alliance Boots, the drugstore chain and pharmaceuticals wholesaler, a development that could lead to a bidding war with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

A WiMax equipment startup, Telsima, announced a new $50 million Series D round of venture funding that will bankroll the company's expansion plans in India and Eastern Europe. Telsima, which makes WiMax-based broadband wireless access technology, received the money from its initial investor syndicate, which includes NewPath Ventures, New Enterprise Associates, CMEA Ventures, and Intel Capital.

Biosite, the target of a billion-dollar biotech bidding war, said Tuesday it would sit down with a second suitor to discuss a hostile takeover bid priced at $90 a share, which is about $3 below its current share price.

A real estate company, Unibail Holding, said it had offered $15 billion in stock for a Dutch rival, Rodamco Europe, and that the board and a key shareholder of Rodamco had endorsed the deal. The companies estimated their combined real estate portfolios, focused primarily on European shopping malls, would have been worth 21.7 billion euros ($29 billion) in 2006 with rental income of 974 million euros.

The Nasdaq Stock Market is in talks to buy the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to gain a stake in the fast-growing options business, according to The Wall Street Journal. The report said Nasdaq has been discussing a link with the regional exchange for months, but a deal is not expected to be reached any time soon.

Vivendi's former vice chairman Edgar Bronfman Jr. sued the company Tuesday, alleging it improperly cut his pension payments by 65 percent. In a lawsuit filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Bronfman, now chief executive of the Warner Music Group, contends that Vivendi, the French entertainment group, reduced his pension last year after claiming it had erroneously been crediting him for 15 years of service beyond the 20 years of actual service Bronfman had already accrued.

With each passing day, big private equity firms are looking more and more like Wall Street investment banks, says BusinessWeek, noting that the Blackstone Group is advising on corporate deals and bankruptcy restructurings and that Bain Capital is a major middle-market lender.

Magna International, the Canadian auto parts supplier has teamed up with a Canadian private equity firm, Onex, to make a run at DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler Group, according to The Globe and Mail. The idea behind the bid for Chrysler is that Magna would bring its expertise to operating auto factories, while Onex would use its financial finesse to run Chrysler's credit arm, the report said.

Advisers to Barclays and ABN Amro could share about $100 million in fees for their work on what would be the biggest financial-services merger in history, based on comparable fees from previous deals, Bloomberg News reported. While hardly a small sum, the amount would be one-third less than what advisers charged last year for AT&T's purchase of BellSouth, underscoring how financial-services deals tend to bring relatively lower fees than transactions in other industries.

Sharyland Utilities says it considered bidding for a piece of TXU, which recently agreed to a record buyout offer from a consortium of private equity firms, but ultimately decided against making a bid after TXU threatened litigation.
Citigroup announced Wednesday that it would eliminate or reassign more than 26,500 jobs as part of a sweeping overhaul to cut costs and streamline the global bank's sprawling operations.

Investment banking firm Friedman Billings Ramsey Group plans to raise as much as $243.3 million through an initial public offering of its capital markets subsidiary. The bank will sell up to 13.5 million shares of its FBR Capital Markets unit at a price of $16 to $18 each, the bank said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Strauss Zelnick, Take-Two Interactive Software's new chairman, has taken on risky corporate overhauls in the past, but none have been as complex as the turnaround of Take-Two, which he called "the biggest thing we've done."

A federal prosecutor, Colleen Conry, portrayed Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest International, on Tuesday as a man who knowingly and unlawfully concealed Qwest's growing money troubles, while simultaneously cashing in on his stock options.

Activist investors in Europe have been increasingly flexing their muscles to block unwanted deals and encourage break-ups of under-performing companies. And now that French luxury group PPR has tabled a friendly $7 billion bid for the German sportswear outfit Puma, industry watchers are wondering if another battle royale is in the offing.
Sunglasses in any color, so long as it's white.

Lifted by 20 transactions worth more than $1 billion in the first quarter, technology deal-making started strong in 2007, with buyout shops and infrastructure-software transactions both major drivers. The analyst firm The 451 Group looks at whether deal-makers can keep up the pace.

The media magnate Conrad M. Black was urged by his company to use a corporate jet to travel to the Pacific island of Bora Bora on vacation because of safety concerns and did not represent an illegal siphoning off of claims, his lawyers suggested on Tuesday. A defense lawyer, Edward L. Greenspan, brushed aside the prosecution's claim, saying the audit committee of the board of Mr. Black's Hollinger International media empire urged executives to take the company's Gulfstream 4 jet as a security measure "because of the nature of the business this company was in."

A resolution that aimed to give Morgan Stanley shareholders a greater say in how top executives are paid failed to win a majority of votes cast at the firm's annual meeting Tuesday. The defeat -- only 37 percent voted in favor of the motion -- represents a setback for activist investors who are seeking to gain a greater say in how executives are paid at dozens of companies.

The Einstein Noah Restaurant Group, a chain of bagel stores controlled by a hedge fund, Greenlight Capital, filed Tuesday to sell as much as $125 million in stock in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq. The company, whose stock now trades on the Pink Sheets, said it owns or franchises about 600 locations in the United States under the names Einstein Bros. Bagels, Noah's New York Bagels and Manhattan Bagel. Morgan Stanley and Cowen are joint bookrunning managers for the offering.
Jon Tierney, critical care paramedic, tests first-aid kits.
Adult clubhouses have grown in popularity.
In Pasadena, Calif., a look at forward-looking houses, two powerful vacuums that go easy on closet space and more.
A new show on Bravo that features hairdressers facing off against each other for cash may seem like a very dull scissor.

Antigua is famous for having 365 beaches -- one for every day of the year. Apparently it's also becoming famous among second-home seekers thanks to its mixture of colonial charm and cosmopolitan flair. Or at least that's what the marketers of a new 40-acre development called NonSuch Bay are hoping. The development includes on-site amenities such as a restaurant, a private dock and moorings, shops, tennis courts, and at least one communal swimming pool. It's only 20 minutes from English Harbor and 25 minutes from the capital city, St. John's, and the island's V.C. Bird International airport, which offers direct flights to and from London in just eight hours.
A place apart, for children, guests or novelists.
A worker checks the radioactivity of drums containing nuclear waste at a power plant near Seoul, South Korea.Lee Jin-man/AP
The lively hip-hop documentary “Rock the Bells” demands neither familiarity with the music nor a hankering for rhyme.
It’s gratifying when an influential underground artist is profiled in an accessible  documentary.  For that reason alone, “Jack Smith and the Destruction of Atlantis” is worth seeing.
Hideki Nagata, right, is the new executive chef at Caviar Russe in Midtown, the Harry’s franchises expand their presence in the financial district this week and more.
The best place to learn about wine, says Eric Asimov, is at home and this do-it-yourself method works for anyone who loves wine, including beginners.
Kurt Vonnegut’s dark comic talent and urgent moral vision caught the temper of his times.
The move came after several days of widening calls for Mr. Imus to lose his job both on MSNBC and CBS Radio.
All active-duty Army troops now in Iraq or Afghanistan or headed to either country will serve 15-month tours of duty.
The lender has agreed to pay $2 million in order to resolve an investigation into its relationships with colleges.
The Democrats were reacting to President Bush’s speech prodding Congress to pass a war-financing bill with no dates for withdrawal from Iraq.

The three detectives charged in the shooting of Sean Bell returned to court for a 10-minute hearing today, surrounded by supporters and detractors who will likely become fixtures as the case winds its way toward trial.
The move is a response to outrage over the radio host’s racial slur against the Rutgers women’s basketball team.
Senator John McCain today accused his Democratic presidential rivals of playing politics in opposing the war.
The visit was seen as an important step forward in repairing diplomatic ties between the rivals.
It would be the first time in more than four years that North Korea has allowed U.N. nuclear inspectors.
Arms that American military officials say appear to have been manufactured in Iran as recently as last year have turned up in the past week in a Sunni-majority area.
Two bombings in Algeria, one targeting the prime minister’s office, killed at least 23 people today, marking a sharp escalation in Qaeda-linked violence in North Africa.
The the risks and opportunities the issue of health care presents for the candidates.
The bank also plans to move about 9,500 jobs from higher cost locations to less expensive areas overseas.

Attorney General Roy Cooper of North Carolina announced today that he is dropping all of the remaining charges against three former Duke students accused of sexually assaulting a stripper more than a year ago.
The White House is exploring ways to restructure the National Security Council by appointing an official to oversee the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.
With Eddy Curry planted on the bench for most of the evening, the Knicks, who once had modest playoff aspirations, moved to the brink of elimination Tuesday night.
Alex Rodriguez homered for the fourth game in a row, giving Andy Pettitte an early lead that grew as the game went on Tuesday night.
The three defendants in the Duke lacrosse sexual assault case were expecting an announcement from the North Carolina attorney general clearing them of all charges.

A Manhattan man yesterday admitted stabbing a store security guard while trying to steal two pairs of jeans at the Galleria shopping mall last August, prosecutors said. The man, Edgard Justiniano, 39, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to first-degree robbery, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. He faces up to 8 1/3 years in prison. Mr. Justiniano stabbed the guard, who suffered superficial wounds, after he was caught taking the pants, a spokesman for the district attorney said.

A lawyer representing some city construction contractors was arrested yesterday and charged with defrauding city agencies by allowing the contractors to avoid paying benefits to workers, federal prosecutors said. The lawyer, Steven Coren, 56, pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court to mail fraud, money laundering and obstruction of justice, said Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn. Prosecutors charged that Mr. Coren helped set up a fund in which contractors for agencies including the City Housing Authority, the School Construction Authority and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority deposited fringe benefits payments for workers, but the contractors then used the money for other purposes. Mr. Coren’s lawyer, Marc L. Mukasey, said his client “was at all times practicing law honorably and legally and expects to be fully exonerated.”.

The police said yesterday that they had identified a woman whose body was found in a black bag beneath a bridge in Frank S. Hackett Park on Saturday. The woman, whom the police identified as Christie Nelly, 36, of West 29th Street in Bayonne, N.J., died of compression to the neck, a spokeswoman from the medical examiner’s office said. Callers identified Ms. Nelly after the police released a sketch of her, the police said. The time of her death was unclear, but a passer-by saw the bag under the Fieldston Road entrance to the Henry Hudson Parkway and called 911 at 9:25 a.m., according to the police. No arrests have been made, and the investigation was continuing.

The Parks and Recreation Department announced yesterday that a policy of allowing dogs off leashes during overnight hours will become effective next month. Beginning May 10, owners with a license and proof of a current rabies vaccination will be permitted to let their dogs roam in designated areas of city parks from 9 p.m. to 9 a.m. Under an unofficial policy, the department has for years not given tickets to dog owners who let their pets run free at night in parks.

The remains of an Australian man who died in the World Trade Center attack on Sept. 11, 2001, have been identified through DNA analysis, the city medical examiner’s office said yesterday. The man, Alberto Dominguez, 66, a baggage handler for Qantas Airways in Sydney, was visiting family in the United States with his wife when the attack occurred. He was on American Airlines Flight 11, which crashed into the north tower. Mr. Dominguez, one of 10 Australians killed in the attack, had left his wife, Martha, in Boston to care for her sick sister. Mr. Dominguez’s remains were among six identified in the past week. The families of the other victims whose remains have been identified declined to allow their names to be released.

A 33-year-old man was killed on Monday night after a woman he had been dating ran him over with a car after an argument, the Essex County prosecutor said yesterday. The woman, Natasha White, 31, was charged with murder, said the prosecutor, Paula T. Dow. Ms. Dow said that about 11 p.m. Ms. White drove her silver Lexus into a pickup belonging to her companion, Zachary Sanders, after an argument outside a bar at Main Street and Lincoln Avenue. She then pointed her car at Mr. Sanders and ran him over, Ms. Dow said. Mr. Sanders was taken to University Hospital in Newark, where he was pronounced dead just before midnight. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A Rikers Island inmate was charged yesterday with trying to hire someone he believed was a hit man to kill his mother, prosecutors said. The inmate, Joseph Salvio, 30, of Astoria, is accused of asking an undercover police officer to kill his mother in exchange for three of her fur coats, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Salvio was serving a four-month sentence for drug possession when he tried to arrange the killing, Mr. Brown said. He added that Mr. Salvio told the undercover officer to make the killing look like a robbery at his mother’s home in Astoria and said he could keep three coats — a mink, a fox, and a raccoon — worth $10,000.

Howard H. Roberts Jr., a former Army soldier and veteran transit executive, has been chosen to lead New York City Transit, which runs the city’s subway and bus systems, transit officials said yesterday. As president, Mr. Roberts will oversee an agency that serves seven million riders daily, employs 47,000 workers and is an arm of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. In an interview, Mr. Roberts, 67, said his priorities would include safety, security, customer satisfaction and labor relations. The new job marks a homecoming for Mr. Roberts. He was New York City Transit’s vice president and chief operating officer for surface transit more than two decades ago. From 1989 to 1997, Mr. Roberts served as deputy general manager at the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, the fourth-largest regional transportation system in the country. He succeeds Lawrence G. Reuter, who retired.

A man who admitted to the 1971 shooting of a security officer on a Long Island college campus was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to one to three years in prison. The man, Frank Nelson, also known as Abdullah Ali, 69, was arrested in September 2005 after federal marshals learned that he was living in South Carolina, prosecutors said. He pleaded guilty last month to first-degree assault and other charges stemming from a Dec. 24, 1971, encounter with Officer Charles Cali at the State University of New York at Stony Brook in which the officer, now 63, was shot in the arm while chasing two trespassers.
The Nets finally seem to be getting the best out of their stars, and it is helping them achieve the results they have been seeking.

Machinery orders at Japanese companies fell more than expected in February from the previous month, but the figures did little to change the view that corporate investment remains strong. Core private sector machinery orders, an important gauge of corporate capital spending in the coming six to nine months, fell 5.2 percent in February from January. The figure was below economists’ median forecast of a 0.2 percent fall, and followed a 3.9 percent rise in January, the biggest gain since last August, when orders jumped 6.7 percent. The market reacted little, as the data did not alter the view that the Bank of Japan would raise interest rates gradually after lifting them to a decade-high 0.5 percent in February. In separate data, the government said that Japan’s current-account surplus rose to 2.4175 trillion yen ($20.31 billion) in February, 4.9 percent more than a year earlier.

The LG.Philips LCD Company, the world’s second-largest manufacturer of liquid-crystal displays, posted a loss in the first quarter amid a steep decline in prices. LG.Philips said it lost 169 billion won ($182 million) in the three months ended March 31, down from a profit of 48 billion won a year earlier. It was the fourth consecutive loss for the company, a joint venture between LG Electronics of South Korea and Royal Philips Electronics of the Netherlands. Sales in the quarter rose 10 percent, to 2.72 trillion won. Displays for flat-screen televisions accounted for 45 percent of the company’s revenue in the quarter, LG.Philips said.

The Coles Group, a retail chain, said a consortium led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts might top a takeover bid of 19.7 billion Australian dollars ($16.1 billion) made by Wesfarmers, possibly triggering a bidding war and pushing Coles shares to a record high. The bid by Wesfarmers, a conglomerate with operations ranging from home improvement sales to fertilizer manufacturing, is already the biggest ever in Australia. The chairman of Coles, Richard H. Allert, left, said in a statement that Kohlberg Kravis was confident it could equal or beat the Wesfarmers bid for Coles, which put itself up for sale in February. Wesfarmers bid 16.47 Australian dollars a share.

A real estate company, Unibail Holding, said it had offered $15 billion in stock for a Dutch rival, Rodamco Europe, and that the board and a key shareholder of Rodamco had endorsed the deal. The companies estimated their combined real estate portfolios, focused primarily on European shopping malls, would have been worth 21.7 billion euros ($29 billion) in 2006 with rental income of 974 million euros. Unibail is offering 0.53 share of Unibail for each share of Rodamco. The deal requires regulatory approval. Unibail’s chief executive, Guillaume Poitrinal, will become chief executive of the combined company.
It stands to reason that the Mafia took responsibility for killing Thomas and Rose Marie Uva, a young couple shot to death near their home in Ozone Park, Queens, on Christmas Eve 1992.

An article in The Arts last Wednesday about the success that Chinese classical musicians have found in the West referred incorrectly to Sa Chen, a finalist in the 2005 Van Cliburn piano competition, and misstated her age. While she is among a new crop of stars, she is not among those in their teens or barely out of them; she is 27, not 17.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the photography licensing company Corbis misidentified the photographer who took a well-known photo of John F. Kennedy Jr. playing under his father’s desk in the Oval Office. It was Stanley Tretick — not Cecil Stoughton, who also shot pictures in the Kennedy White House.

A sports article last Wednesday about the prospect of adding a statue of Mark McGwire to those honoring great St. Louis Cardinals players gave an incorrect given name in some copies for a catcher for the old St. Louis Browns whom the creator of the statues, Harry Weber, considered a baseball hero. He was Clint Courtney, not Cliff.

A sports article in some copies on Sunday about the Mets’ first loss of the season, to the Braves in Atlanta on Saturday, referred incorrectly to pitcher Tom Glavine’s pursuit of 300 career victories. He had been seeking his 292nd victory, not his 293rd.

An article on April 3 about problems faced by Michelle Bachelet, Chile’s first female president, referred incorrectly to the political affiliation of her predecessor, Ricardo Lagos Escobar. While both belong to the same coalition, they are not now of the same party. (Ms. Bachelet is a Socialist; Mr. Lagos is a former Socialist who founded the Party for Democracy, or PPD.).

An article on Monday about a brush fire on Staten Island that routed residents from their homes gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for the surname of a man whose property was damaged. He is Dan Archer, not Archerdiff.
A picture caption on Monday with a front-page article about a proposal for a blogger code of conduct misstated a Web site that has developed a set of standards. It is BlogHer.org, not BlogHer.com.

An article on Friday about the partial collapse of a wall at Chumley’s, a popular Greenwich Village bar and restaurant, misspelled the given name of the original owner. He was Leland Chumley, not Leleand, and was known as Lee.

A front-page article last Wednesday about the risky state of New Jersey’s pension fund for state and local government workers misidentified the office held by John O. Bennett, then a New Jersey senator, in 2001, when he abstained from a vote to increase teachers’ pensions by 9 percent. Mr. Bennett was the Republican majority leader of the State Senate at the time, not its co-president.
The headline with an article yesterday about the possible deployment of 13,000 troops from four states misidentified the soldiers. They are National Guard members, not “reservists.”.

An article on April 3 about problems faced by Michelle Bachelet, Chile’s first female president, referred incorrectly to the political affiliation of her predecessor, Ricardo Lagos Escobar. While both belong to the same coalition, they are not now of the same party. (Ms. Bachelet is a Socialist; Mr. Lagos is a former Socialist who founded the Party for Democracy, or PPD.).

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about the housing slump’s effect on state tax revenues misstated the status of a tax credit and local tax cap in New Jersey in some copies. The legislation has been signed into law, it is not awaiting approval.

A front-page article on Saturday about Ralph J. Phillips, who is serving a life sentence for having shot three New York State troopers, one fatally, after breaking out of jail, misstated the name of the prison where he is incarcerated. It is the Clinton Correctional Facility, a state prison in Dannemora — not the Clinton County Correctional Facility.
It is becoming clear that the Miami Heat will have to defend its title the hard way, without home-court advantage, because a slew of injuries has left the Heat staggering.

A section of the legendary slurry wall at ground zero — the sturdy concrete “bathtub” that kept the waters of the Hudson River from inundating the World Trade Center site before and after the twin towers collapsed on Sept. 11, 2001 — will be getting its own $10 million bathtub.

A 35-year-old British woman, Natallie Evans, left, who was left infertile after being treated for ovarian cancer, has no right to use frozen embryos against the wishes of her former fiancé, who provided the sperm, the European Court of Human Rights ruled. The court’s Grand Chamber, sitting in Strasbourg, France, confirmed a lower European ruling upholding a British law that stipulates consent from both parents is needed at every stage of the in vitro fertilization process. The verdict cannot be appealed, and the frozen embryos will be destroyed. The court said it felt “great sympathy” for Ms. Evans, but ruled that her desire to become a parent should not be accorded greater weight than her former fiancé’s right not to have a genetically related child with her. In 2001, before removal of her ovaries, six of Ms. Evans’s eggs were fertilized by sperm of the fiancé, Howard Johnston. But the couple split up, and Mr. Johnston withdrew his consent for her to use the embryos. Ms. Evans took the case through the British courts, and when she had exhausted that legal process, she appealed to the European courts, claiming her right to privacy and family life, and the embryos’ right to life, were being violated by Mr. Johnston’s refusal to grant permission for use of his sperm. “I am distraught at the court’s decision today,” Ms. Evans said. “It’s very hard for me to accept that the embryos will now be destroyed and that I will never become a mother.” Mr. Johnston said that while he sympathized, “I want to be able to choose when I become a parent.”.

A man hijacked a domestic airliner en route to Istanbul but surrendered to the authorities shortly after the plane made an emergency landing in Ankara, its 178 passengers unhurt, the authorities said. The man, identified by the Anatolian news agency as Mehmet Goksin, a Turk, boarded the plane with the rest of the passengers in southeastern Diyarbakir. Government forces are fighting Kurdish separatists in the area, and the hijacker was initially suspected of political motives. But he made no clear political demands, after falsely claiming that he was wearing explosives, the authorities said. The arrested man has a criminal record and a troubled family background, they said.

Officials at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo unveiled locks of 3,200-year-old hair from Pharaoh Ramses II, returned to Egypt after being taken 30 years ago in France and put up for sale on the Internet last year. The small tufts of brown hair were displayed in a glass case and will eventually be put on exhibit next to Ramses’ mummy at the museum. An Egyptian archaeological delegation traveled to Paris last week to retrieve the strands, which were put up for sale on a Web site last November by a Frenchman who offered them for $2,600. The seller apparently obtained the items from his late father, a French researcher who examined the mummy when it was brought to France in 1976 for treatment to stop the spread of a rare fungus. “I was so upset,” said Zahi Hawass, the chief of the Supreme Council of Antiquities. “How the hair of the mummy — of the greatest king of Egypt — can be sold on the Internet!”.

African migrants trying to reach the Canary Islands in a small, crowded boat hurled gasoline bombs at a Spanish patrol vessel that tried to stop them, the authorities said. It was believed to be the first time a patrol boat trying to detain people on the high seas had come under attack in the decade since the Canary Islands became a destination for Africans trying for a toehold in Europe. The police said the migrants also tried to slash an inflatable raft of the Civil Guard. No one was injured. The migrants’ wooden boat was carrying 57 people, including 2 children. The Spaniards gave up and let the boat continue on to the Canary Islands. When it arrived, all on board were detained.
President Aníbal Cavaco Silva gave his formal consent to a new law allowing abortion up until the 10th week of pregnancy. It brings Portugal into line with most of its European neighbors.

A long-suffering jeans maker appears to finally be on the mend.

.

A police search of the former astronaut Lisa Nowak’s car turned up bondage photographs on a computer disk, according to documents released by prosecutors. The documents do not say if the 16 photos and drawings feature Ms. Nowak. She is accused of trying to kidnap a rival for a space shuttle pilot’s affections in February. NASA dismissed Ms. Nowak after the police said she drove from Houston to Florida to confront the other woman and then pepper-sprayed her. The documents show that the police also found $600, 41 British pounds and dozens of orange pills in Ms. Nowak’s car. The police had earlier reported finding a steel mallet, a BB gun, a knife and rubber tubing. Ms. Nowak has pleaded not guilty to charges that include attempted kidnapping.

A federal judge in Miami refused to dismiss terrorism charges against Jose Padilla over claims that he was tortured in custody. The decision removes one of the last major obstacles to the start next week of the trial of Mr. Padilla, who is accused of being an operative of Al Qaeda. Judge Marcia Cooke said in an order filed Monday that she was not passing judgment on Mr. Padilla’s accusations. She said the effort to dismiss the case for “outrageous government conduct” was faulty on legal grounds.

Air-traffic controllers need schedule changes to ensure they get enough rest, a safety board said, noting that one worker may have had only two hours of sleep in the day before a 2006 crash in Lexington, Ky., that killed 49 people. The recommendation from the National Transportation Safety Board to the Federal Aviation Administration is a victory for controllers, who have said for months that they are short staffed and forced to work too-long hours, harming safety.

Maryland became the first state to approve a plan to give its electoral votes for president to the winner of the national popular vote instead of the candidate chosen by state voters. The measure would only take effect if states representing a majority of the nation’s 538 electoral votes decided to make the same change. Hawaii’s legislature recently passed a similar measure, sending it to Gov. Linda Lingle. California lawmakers adopted the measure last year, but Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger vetoed it.

A judge has ruled that the Berkeley Unified School District does not violate state law when considering race in assigning students to programs. The ruling stems from a lawsuit filed last year by the Pacific Legal Foundation, a supporter of a 1996 ballot measure designed to abolish the use of sexual and racial preferences in government hiring and contracts. The judge, Winifred Y. Smith of Alameda County Superior Court, ruled Friday that the district appropriately used racial demographics, rather than the race of individual students, in deciding student placement. But the judge let stand the lawsuit’s challenge to a mentoring and tutoring program.

A disk containing the names, birth dates and Social Security numbers of 2.9 million Medicaid and children’s health care recipients is missing, state health officials said. The state said the security breach was reported by Affiliated Computer Services, a private vendor. The children’s health care program involved in the data loss is called PeachCare. Officials said the information, also including addresses, went back four years and included some people who are no longer on the rolls.

Senator Tim Johnson’s campaign raised more than $660,000 in the first quarter this year, all while he has been recovering from a brain hemorrhage. According to Mr. Johnson’s office, about 30 senators have taken part in fund-raisers for him since he fell ill. Mr. Johnson, a Democrat, is up for re-election in 2008. He has been in a private rehabilitation center since February and has not announced whether he plans to run again. His office said his recovery was expected to take months.
The revised findings echoed complaints made by Republican politicians of widespread voter fraud.

ALBANY, April 10 — A Queens assemblyman is warning that New York City’s ratepayers could wind up paying for tens of millions of dollars that Consolidated Edison spent to repair its network in western Queens after a nine-day blackout last July.
Strauss Zelnick has taken on risky corporate restructurings before, but he says none have been as complex as at Take-Two Interactive Software, where he was named chairman two weeks ago.
Financial aid directors at three universities received stock in a student loan company in what may have been a violation of securities law.
Party leaders are concerned about dissatisfaction with the president and political fallout from the war in Iraq.
Joseph P. Nacchio faces 42 counts of insider trading related to his sale of more than $100 million in Qwest stock in 2001.
The daylong battle in the neighborhood of Fadhil appeared to be the fiercest since the start of the new security plan.
The teacher was arrested after a February meeting between the teacher and the student at a Comfort Suites Hotel.
Rudolph W. Giuliani offered a window into how he will deal with divisive topics on which more conservative voters might be inclined to disagree with him.
Despite a 99-year World Series drought, the Cubs are one of the most iconic teams in sports and are expected to fetch more than the $660 million that was paid in 2002 for the Boston Red Sox.
COLLEGE BASKETBALL.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (Reuters) — A study by Merck of its pain reliever Arcoxia showed similar risks of heart attacks and other cardiovascular problems compared with another painkiller, diclofenac, federal reviewers said in an analysis made public Tuesday.
On Monday, Alex Rodriguez became the first Yankee to hit five home runs in the team’s first six games.
A consumer group contends that a program that allows donations to the Red Cross via text messages is a business development strategy masquerading as charity.
The Indians are moving their three-game series with the Angels to Milwaukee because of mounting postponements at Jacobs Field due to a snowstorm.
With the Knicks on the verge of elimination from the playoff race, the trade that sent Eddy Curry from Chicago to New York 18 months ago could haunt the Knicks long after their season is over.
The plan comes several months after officials who run the water system said the city had more than $610 million in unpaid water bills.
For weeks now, human rights groups have been urging Ethiopia, which has a nettlesome human rights record, to shed some light on the detainees.
President Olusegun Obasanjo must move quickly to rein in the chaos and corruption threatening this month’s elections.
The New York City Housing Authority is facing an even bigger budget shortfall one year after announcing plans to save money.
The gift, from billionaire John Werner Kluge,  is to be one of the largest ever to an American university.
The town of Colden, N.Y., was stunned after police found the badly decomposed bodies of two women stuffed into sealed barrels in a small barn.
Four former paramilitary policemen were sentenced to up to 20 years in jail for the killings of six Bosnian Muslims from Srebrenica.
On Monday, President Bush showed once again that immigration is an issue he understands.
The delicate foam at the top of a 15-story-tall external fuel tank suffered thousands of dings in a hailstorm in February.
Sharpe James, a master of political longevity, is getting out of the game after 37 years.
A study shows that New York’s roughly 950,000 buildings are responsible for a vast majority of the city’s carbon dioxide emissions.
The Titans’ Pacman Jones was suspended for the entire 2007 N.F.L. season and the Bengals’ Chris Henry was suspended for the first eight games for violating the leagues personal conduct policy.
President Bush accused Democrats of behaving irresponsibly as the two sides moved closer to confrontation over withdrawing troops from Iraq.
The hallmark of the 2006-7 National Hockey League season has been an abundance of beautiful, creative goal-scoring.
A streetcar parked in Times Square is part of a promotion by a tourist board to get more people to visit New Orleans.
A theatrical production of Pushkin’s work, originally conceived by Sergei Prokofiev and Vsevolod Meyerhold, will debut at Princeton 70 years after being stamped out in Stalinist Russia.

The Red Sox pounded the World Series star Jeff Weaver for seven runs in the first two innings yesterday, celebrating their home opener with a 14-3 victory against Seattle. It was the Mariners’ first game since a blizzard snowed out their four-game series in Cleveland.
The aircraft carrier Intrepid, which is set for renovations, was taken to a dry dock in New Jersey on Tuesday.
In a surprise move, Henry Winterstern, who abruptly resigned as chairman of the independent studio First Look in March, has been named co-chairman of the studio, the company announced.
A high school in the Bronx is said to have failed to offer the required classes in English as a second language to immigrant children.
Warning of the threat posed by radical Islam, Mitt Romney said the military needed to change to respond to it.
The Bush administration is dispatching Deputy Secretary of State John D. Negroponte to Sudan, while Democrats are demanding a plan to address the crisis.
Romania’s low wages and recent membership in the European Union are fueling a wave of emigration that threatens to slow an economic boom in recent years.
Goaltender Wade Dubielewicz has led the Islanders to four straight must-win victories in the final six days of the regular season while filling in for starter Rick DiPietro.
One of the country’s largest political parties, the Awami League, rejected an extortion charge against its leader, the former prime minister Sheik Hasina Wazed.
Ms. Jolley’s distinctive literary voice and eccentric literary preoccupations made her one of Australia’s most acclaimed novelists.
The Rutgers women provided an example to all the politicians, commentators and reporters who have spent the last two days dissecting Don Imus’s racist behavior.
House Democrats ratcheted up efforts to obtain unedited copies of hundreds of documents pertaining to the dismissals of eight U.S. attorneys.
Viacom said the partnership with Yahoo covered sites for MTV, VH1, Comedy Central and Nickelodeon and could be expanded.
The media magnate Conrad M. Black was urged by his company to use a corporate jet to travel to the Pacific island of Bora Bora on vacation because of safety concerns, his lawyers suggested.
In the shifting universe of global academia, English is becoming as commonplace as creeping ivy and mortarboards.
The body of an Afghan journalist abducted and slain by Taliban insurgents after they freed his Italian colleague in a prisoner trade was delivered to Kandahar’s hospital.
Thirty-one square miles of river delta islands near the Bay of Bengal have vanished in the last 30 years.
The attacks, by militiamen known as the janjaweed, took place in the border villages of Tiero and Marena, leaving mass graves and destruction.
A former assistant superintendent and a former principal at a school for juvenile offenders were arrested on charges of having sexual contact with six boys.
Three men suspected in the bombing of an Internet cafe blew themselves up, and a fourth was fatally shot as he tried to detonate a bomb, the authorities said.
Japan and China are preparing for a summit meeting aimed at setting aside rancor over the past and focusing on ways to tame rivalry over energy and influence.
Stores that sell pet food made from free-range meat, organic vegetables and brown rice say business has increased since a recall of contaminated food.
Twelve days before the first round of a presidential election, a frenzied competition is under way to win over France’s large bloc of undecided voters.
Boston’s Daisuke Matsuzaka, the major league’s latest big-name Japanese import, will face Seattle’s Ichiro Suzuki, the Japanese icon who helped influence Matsuzaka’s decision to follow suit.

ImClone Systems said yesterday that its cancer drug Erbitux failed to help pancreatic cancer patients live longer in a study, a setback for the company’s plan to expand the market for its only product.
A veteran state auditor pleaded guilty Tuesday to stealing $1.2 million that was supposed to be used to help the mentally ill.
The Ducks won the Pacific Division this season for the first time, and as they prepare to open the playoffs Wednesday night against Minnesota, they are giving most of the credit to their knuckles.
A state law would require doctors to tell women seeking abortions that the procedure would “terminate the life of a whole, separate, unique, living human being.”
A bill that would impose a fine and a trip to the back of the queue on drivers who cut into ferry lines is one proposal intended to preserve Northwest nice.
The 29-degree game-time temperature Saturday failed to chill the Colorado Rapids as they opened their Major League Soccer season and their new sold-out stadium with a victory.
The euro advanced to a record against the yen and a two-year high against the dollar as signs of faster economic growth in Europe prompted traders to increase their bets on higher interest rates.
The offensive consistency of Shawn Green and Moises Alou has made it difficult for manager Willie Randolph to incorporate Lastings Milledge into the starting lineup.

Some 3,600 students and alumni of the university, one of the nation’s most conservative, have signed petitions seeking a “more appropriate” commencement speaker.
Martin A. Armstrong was sentenced to five years in prison and ordered to pay $80 million for running what prosecutors said was a $3 billion Ponzi scheme.
Some observers point to a growing split between hard-line members of Hamas and those in the government who want to refrain from attacks on Israel.
PPR bid about $7 billion for Puma, promising to keep its chief executive, Jochen Zeitz, at the helm of the company he turned around.
Mr. Barcelona traveled the world with Louis Armstrong and His All Stars and played on Armstrong recordings including “Hello, Dolly!”
The market for retail condominiums in Manhattan has skyrocketed in recent years. More than 560,000 square feet of retail condo space sold last year, a sharp increase from 28,000 square feet in 2003.
Texas freshmen Kevin Durant said in a statement that he was leaving college to enter the N.B.A. draft.
Stocks edged higher, giving the Dow Jones industrial average an eighth consecutive increase, though a modest one, for its longest streak since 2003.
Thirteen young diabetics in Brazil have been able to stop receiving insulin after being treated with stem cells taken from their own blood.
Werner Maser was the first historian to assert that the purported diaries of Adolf Hitler published by Stern magazine in 1983 were forgeries.
Mr. Chauhan began a campaign to create an independent state of Sikhs and was charged with sedition and other crimes in connection with his activities.
Alcoa reported its most profitable first quarter ever as rising metal demand from China and the aerospace industry bolstered prices.
D. R. Horton, the largest United States home builder, said yesterday that orders for new homes tumbled 37 percent last quarter and that the spring selling season had begun more slowly than usual.
As NBC’s “Today” prepares for its “Where in the World Is Matt Lauer?” feature, Hyundai will sponsor a Web site following the host.

Office rents in Manhattan reached record highs in the first three months of 2007, as constrained supply more than offset a dip in leasing activity, the real estate brokerage firm Cushman & Wakefield said yesterday.
Delays in handing over about $25 million in frozen funds could derail an agreement under which North Korea would shut down a plutonium-producing reactor.

I look at my students and realize that they are in the first generation to grow up knowing that there is no otherness to the insanity that threatens us now.
The Loblaw Companies, Canada’s largest grocery chain and once one of North America’s most innovative retailers, is struggling with inventory problems and its first annual loss in 19 years.
Until last summer, a 136-year-old building had been an eyesore at the center of Portland, Me. You would never know it now.
Anna Nicole Smith’s posthumous fame reveals the continuing American fascination with the messy celebrity story.
