“Stories in Stone: Conserving Mosaics of Roman Africa,” now at the J. Paul Getty Museum, sheds light on how wealthy Romans once lived in North Africa.

11 P.M. (Bravo) SHEAR GENIUS Twelve hairstylists snip and clip their way to a $100,000 prize from the hair products company Nexxus and a chance to show off their technique in Allure magazine in the latest of Bravo’s design-based competition series. The überstylist Sally Hershberger, above, who created the Meg Ryan cut and spawned its multitude of imitators, is lead judge with Michael Carl, fashion director of Allure, and Jaclyn Smith, pulling double duty as the show’s host. The stylist René Fris, channeling Tim Gunn à la “Project Runway,” acts as the salon manager for the contestants — some of whom will either be “cut,” in the words of the panel, or told they “blow away” the competition.
At South River Miso in Conway, Mass., the rich Japanese flavoring of miso has been made with exquisite care for more than two decades.

Arlene Hutton’s “Nibroc Trilogy,” in repertory at the 78th Street Theater Lab, ought to be seen by anyone who doubts the capacity of front porch drama to tell a meaningful story beyond its own perimeters.
Your assignment: buy the following wines and drink them. Take notes. The lists were compiled by Lyle Fass of Chambers Street Wines in TriBeCa and Joy Land of Sherry-Lehmann.

According to the oysters-“R”-in-season theory, this is the last good month for oysters until September. But today that is less true, so don’t shy away from them.
T. D. Thornton manages to communicate the weird allure of horse racing, even at a track like “Sufferin’ Downs,” which is a long way from Churchill Downs.

Bearing little resemblance to the tough bake-sale squares of yore, today’s brownie is a brilliant showcase for fine chocolate.
Le Sousbois, a rare Swiss artisanal cheese, is available to try in Manhattan, exotic honey from Hawaii and a new book of more than 200 recipes for fresh produce.

The Curious Cook column last Wednesday, about the chemistry of meat color, referred incorrectly to the chemical that binds with the pigment myoglobin to make nitrite-cured meat pink. It is nitric oxide (NO) — not nitrous oxide (N2O), a sedative used in dentistry.

Pâté de campagne, or country pâté, is simply a variation of meatloaf that is delicious and elegant enough to serve at dinners where you want to impress your guests.

A London-based operation that is building a fleet of 10 yachts, YachtPlus, is the latest company to jump into the  luxury shared-ownership market.

The Department of Defense has identified 3,280 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week: BROWN, Harrison, 31, Staff Sgt., Army; Prichard, Ala.; Third Infantry Division. Richmond Hill, Ga. WHAT: Three-bedroom house

A sports article in some copies on Sunday about the Mets' first loss of the season, to the Braves in Atlanta on Saturday, referred incorrectly to pitcher Tom Glavine's pursuit of 300 career victories. He had been seeking his 292nd victory, not his 293rd.

The Curious Cook column last Wednesday, about the chemistry of meat color, referred incorrectly to the chemical that binds with the pigment myoglobin to make nitrite-cured meat pink. It is nitric oxide (NO) -- not nitrous oxide (N2O), a sedative used in dentistry.

ROMITA--Louis. Senior VP of Castle Oil Corp. Loving husband of Anne. Devoted father of Lisa, Louis, Lynda, and the late Mauro. Loving grandfather of Noa McRiley and Louis McRiley. Cherished brother of Michael, Mary Digirolamo, Jack and Mauro. Reposing at Farenga Brothers Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Ave. Visitation on Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 10am, at the Holy Family Chapel in the College of New Rochelle.

To the Editor: Re ''Trash Talk Radio'' (Op-Ed, April 10): Thanks to Gwen Ifill for keeping the heat on Don Imus for his inexcusably hateful comments about the players on the Rutgers University women's basketball team.

Thomas Begel badly wants to buy the Cubs, and in his seat behind home plate at Wrigley Field on Monday, he offered a wealthy fan's sentiment sure to be repeated by other bidders. ''How could you not want to own this team?'' he asked on a brisk and overcast opening day when the ivy on the ballpark's outfield wall was still weeks from blooming. ''You're buying a shrine, a team and a great place to watch baseball.''

A new book, ''The Produce Bible: Essential Ingredient Information and More Than 200 Recipes for Fruits, Vegetables, Herbs & Nuts,'' by Leanne Kitchen (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $29.95), may be too big to haul to the Greenmarket, but it would pay to peruse it at the start of each season or even each month. The text is enlivened with stunning photography and each entry is followed by one or more recipes. I have no doubt that a gooseberry shortcake with a cream filling and lattice top will perfume my kitchen in a couple of months, just as the delicate fish in ginger broth did recently. The roasted beets with horseradish cream took care of some of the fresh horseradish left over from Passover.

To the Editor: In ''On Easter, Symbolism and the Exuberance of Spring'' (April 4), I was perplexed by Nancy Harmon Jenkins's opinion that mageiritsa is ''quite impossible to prepare in the United States, where there is almost no access to baby lamb, let alone to its innards or to wild fennel greens.'' Almost every butcher in Astoria can order baby lamb and sell any amount of innards necessary for the traditional Greek dish. Also, many greengrocers in the area carry wild fennel. The dish is made every year by Americans of Greek heritage. LISA DELANGE Jackson Heights, Queens

A man hijacked a domestic airliner en route to Istanbul but surrendered to the authorities shortly after the plane made an emergency landing in Ankara, its 178 passengers unhurt, the authorities said. The man, identified by the Anatolian news agency as Mehmet Goksin, a Turk, boarded the plane with the rest of the passengers in southeastern Diyarbakir. Government forces are fighting Kurdish separatists in the area, and the hijacker was initially suspected of political motives. But he made no clear political demands, after falsely claiming that he was wearing explosives, the authorities said. The arrested man has a criminal record and a troubled family background, they said. SABRINA TAVERNISE

KEHOE--Veronica Lally, 64, peacefully at home after a two year illness she bore with great grace, strength and dignity and at the same moment the Easter Vigil service at St. Ignatius Loyola Church she loved so much for so many years was beginning. She is survived by her loving husband, John P. (Jack) Kehoe, her devoted sister, Maureen Lally, her beloved daughter, Allise Dickson, Allise's husband, Bradley, and her adored granddaughter of three months, Lilly Grace, for whose birth and first months of magical life God spared her to enjoy, and by Jack's four children and five grandchildren. An alumna of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, summa cum laude graduate at Fordham University's College at Lincoln Center and a member of the WFUV-FM Advisory Board, Veronica, an AFTRA and SAG member, actor and theatrical producer, for 25 years supported and encouraged new American plays and playwrights through the activities of her not-for-profit Gypsy Road Company in association with 33 of the leading writing programs among Americas colleges and an Advisory Board chaired originally by Ms. Helen Hayes. Family visiting at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (at East 81st Street), New York, NY 10028, (212) 288-3500. Monday, April 9th, 7-9 PM, Tuesday April 10th, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Ignatius Loyola RC Church, 980 Park Avenue (East 84th Street), Wednesday April 11th, 10:00 AM. Internment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In Lieu of flowers, the family welcomes donations to Fordham University Theater Department, or the Marian Francis Harriott S.C. Scholarship at College of Mount Saint Vincent.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about the housing slump's effect on state tax revenues misstated the status of a tax credit and local tax cap in New Jersey in some copies. The legislation has been signed into law, it is not awaiting approval.

To the Editor: Human hubris is reaching new heights (''Backyard Pests? Think of Them as Dinner,'' April 4). In an urban landscape with few enough opportunities for contact with living things other than Homo sapiens, Steven Rinella has launched a war on the few species who have learned to survive with humans in our denatured world of concrete and cement. When we no longer feel the childish joy of watching frolicking squirrels, when we just ''thump them with a hammer,'' we are beyond cynical and inhumane: we are cruel and heartless and lost as a society. I suggest that Mr. Rinella be delivered into the Great North Woods with only a knife for survival if he needs to deal with his primitive longings for trapping and skinning our fellow creatures. Let him leave the few furry and feathered inhabitants of our city alone to scurry and scamper and provide a morning bird song. MARILYN KISS Staten Island To the Editor: Sparrows and squirrels are among the least pesky of all New York City creatures. I'll bet Mr. Rinella doesn't eat rat. ROSE CONSTANTINE New York To the Editor: All our songbirds are protected by federal and state laws, and ''thumping'' wild animals with a hammer is a crime, covered under cruelty-to-animals statutes. Migrating birds have enough problems as it is, and certainly don't need to be illegally trapped and killed by the likes of Mr. Rinella, apparently for his amusement. I spent 25 years in law enforcement in Suffolk County, N.Y., and can tell you that a number of people have been arrested and convicted of similar acts. I only hope such a fate befalls this so-called gourmet chef, and that they take away his ''thumping'' hammer as well. RICHARD E. WILLOTT Southold, N.Y. To the Editor: Since Steven Rinella's recent New York arrival, his macabre activities -- stealing pigeons, battering backyard sparrows and squirrels -- threaten any free-living animals who manage to live among us. Mr. Rinella, who authored a cookbook based on consuming animals whose freedom the chef has usurped, says cooking without ''game'' isn't fun -- as if systematically disrespecting other conscious beings merits admiration, or at least interest. Animal rights is a movement to overcome everyday domination, and to value other creatures' interests in living on their own terms. Plant-based cuisine puts that principle into action immediately. Thus the cookbook author, chef or anyone with access to a kitchen decides whether our culture moves in a nonviolent direction. The sign of a mature society might well be the idea that we could have a whole lot more fun, and enjoy our planet fully, were respect a hallmark of our species. PRISCILLA FERAL Darien, Conn. The writer is the president of Friends of Animals. To the Editor: Even though I'm an animal lover and a vegetarian, currently watching squirrels and birds peacefully enjoying a spring day outside, I find this article neither amusing nor relevant to ''Dining Out.'' The next time Mr. Rinella is rolling around on the ground from a painful shot in the eye of fluid released from a goose gallbladder, maybe he should consider the torture he inflicts on these helpless creatures with his homemade traps. PEGGY LYONS BRADLEY Rowayton, Conn.

In February, when the Apache Wells development in Mesa, Ariz., approved plans for a new $8.5 million community center, many homeowners were not happy with their share of the bill: $6,020 each. Opponents of the center, including some whose properties are second homes, have taken their disagreement to court, describing the voting process as flawed. Among the problems, they say, is that some absentee second-home owners did not have enough time to receive their ballots and mail them back -- an accusation the board's lawyer, Eric Jackson, said he is reviewing.

STEIN--Emil. The members of SSTT mourn the death of Emil Stein, loving husband of Mitzie Stein. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Stephen A. Klein, Rabbi Chanin Becker, Cantor Gerald Cohen, President

The honeybees on the island of Hawaii do not visit everyday clover or orange blossoms: they dote on the flowers of macadamia nut trees, ohia lehua blossoms and Christmasberry, also known as Wilelaiki. A company called Big Island Bees has just started selling its honeys on the mainland, through chefshop.com. The macadamia is dark and rich and has a nutty flavor. The organic Wilelaiki has a subtle spiciness, and the ohia lehua, also organic, is the most floral of the three, with a creamy texture. The honeys, in 9 1/2-ounce jars, are $8.99 each.

A front-page article last Wednesday about the risky state of New Jersey's pension fund for state and local government workers misidentified the office held by John O. Bennett, then a New Jersey senator, in 2001, when he abstained from a vote to increase teachers' pensions by 9 percent. Mr. Bennett was the Republican majority leader of the State Senate at the time, not its co-president.

The police said yesterday that they had identified a woman whose body was found in a black bag beneath a bridge in Frank S. Hackett Park on Saturday. The woman, whom the police identified as Christie Nelly, 36, of West 29th Street in Bayonne, N.J., died of compression to the neck, a spokeswoman from the medical examiner's office said. Callers identified Ms. Nelly after the police released a sketch of her, the police said. The time of her death was unclear, but a passer-by saw the bag under the Fieldston Road entrance to the Henry Hudson Parkway and called 911 at 9:25 a.m., according to the police. No arrests have been made, and the investigation was continuing. CARA BUCKLEY

House Democrats on Tuesday subpoenaed more documents from the Justice Department, ratcheting up efforts to obtain unedited copies of hundreds of documents pertaining to personnel matters surrounding last year's dismissals of eight United States attorneys. The new demand for more documents came as Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales spent nearly five hours working with aides in preparation for his appearance next Tuesday before the Senate Judiciary Committee. Defenders and critics alike say the hearing could determine whether he remains in office.

A lawyer representing some city construction contractors was arrested yesterday and charged with defrauding city agencies by allowing the contractors to avoid paying benefits to workers, federal prosecutors said. The lawyer, Steven Coren, 56, pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court to mail fraud, money laundering and obstruction of justice, said Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn. Prosecutors charged that Mr. Coren helped set up a fund in which contractors for agencies including the City Housing Authority, the School Construction Authority and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority deposited fringe benefits payments for workers, but the contractors then used the money for other purposes. Mr. Coren's lawyer, Marc L. Mukasey, said his client ''was at all times practicing law honorably and legally and expects to be fully exonerated.''
SHORTELL--Robert Edward, 57, of Yonkers, formerly of Tolentine Parish, Bronx, NY, on Tuesday, April 3, 2007. For Funeral arrangements call (914)963-6121.

The 200th episode of CBS's ''King of Queens,'' with Kevin James and Leah Remini, garnered the series's most viewers in more than three years, as 13.4 million tuned in on Monday, according to Nielsen's estimates. This nine-year-old comedy, which will come to an end in May, won the 9:30 p.m. time slot over all. CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' dominated the 10 o'clock hour (15.9 million), while ABC led from 8 to 9:30 with ''Dancing With the Stars'' (18.7 million). CBS and ABC tied for first among adults 18 to 49, although ABC edged slightly ahead in total viewers. In third, Fox finished even with NBC, whose new improv comedy, ''Thank God You're Here,'' made a respectable debut at 9, with 8.3 million viewers. In the evening news race, ABC's ''World News With Charles Gibson'' ranked first in total viewers, with an average of 8.1 million, posting its largest lead in a year and a half over the No. 2 newscast, ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' (7.6 million). Among adults 25 to 54, however, ABC's lead over NBC was a negligible 60,000 viewers. In third, the ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' drew 6.2 million viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

IF you can make meatloaf you can make what the French call pâté de campagne, or country pâté. It is simply a variation of meatloaf, a splendid one. It is denser, with more meat, and has no filler like bread crumbs. The addition of cream and spices makes it delicious and elegant enough to serve at dinners where you want to impress your guests. Meatloaf can't do that. Good pâté has the following qualities: meat of varying textures, some ground and some chopped. Spices in big enough pieces to have some bite. And the richness and flavor that come only from quantities of fat.

A 33-year-old man was killed on Monday night after a woman he had been dating ran him over with a car after an argument, the Essex County prosecutor said yesterday. The woman, Natasha White, 31, was charged with murder, said the prosecutor, Paula T. Dow. Ms. Dow said that about 11 p.m. Ms. White drove her silver Lexus into a pickup belonging to her companion, Zachary Sanders, after an argument outside a bar at Main Street and Lincoln Avenue. She then pointed her car at Mr. Sanders and ran him over, Ms. Dow said. Mr. Sanders was taken to University Hospital in Newark, where he was pronounced dead just before midnight. JOHN HOLL

KERSHAW--Mary Anna, 93, died April 6th at her home in Lenox, Mass. She was the spirited and loved wife of Dr. Joseph A. Kershaw; mother of David N. Kershaw and Stephen Kershaw; mother-inlaw of Sharon Kershaw Worthington; grandmother of Sarah Kershaw and Amy Kershaw; and her legacy will be cherished. She was strong and dignified in the face of life's hardest challenges. Her wit, intellect and extraordinary commitment to volunteerism, philanthropy and public service were an inspiration that will live on for generations. Donations gratefully appreciated to the American Cancer Society.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Fierce Fighting in Baghdad After Mosque Is Raided Sunni militants and residents of a Baghdad neighborhood fought a daylong battle with the Iraqi Army and American soldiers in what appeared to be the most sustained confrontation since the start of the new security plan. A1 A Call for 'Plan B' on Darfur While the Bush administration scrambles to make good on threats that the United States will hold the Sudanese government accountable for violence in the Darfur region, critics, including some lawmakers, say the efforts have been ineffective and are pressing the administration to switch to a Plan B. A6 Ethiopia Admits Detentions Ethiopian officials acknowledged that they had detained 41 terrorist suspects from 17 countries who had been fighting for Somalia's Islamist movement. Officials in Washington said later that American intelligence agents have questioned several of the detainees. A12 Unfocused Race in France With 12 days to go before the first round of France's presidential election, the campaign has entered a phase of improvisation that reflects the absence of any defining issue and a competition to win over the country's undecided voters. A3 Israel Accuses Hamas of Plots Interrogations of arrested members of Hamas in the West Bank produced information that the Islamic organization there was planning imminent terrorist attacks against Israel, the Israeli security service said. A8 4 Serbs Guilty of War Crimes A Serbian court convicted four former paramilitary policemen in the 1995 killings of six Bosnian Muslims from Srebrenica, where thousands of Muslims were massacred. A11 NATIONAL A13-18 Voter Data Played Down By Federal Agency A federal agency responsible for conducting election research played down the findings of experts last year who concluded that there was little voter fraud around the nation, according to a review of the original report . A1 G.O.P. Anxious About Future Republican leaders across the country say they are growing increasingly anxious about their party's chances of holding the White House, citing public dissatisfaction with President Bush and the political fallout from the war in Iraq. A1 Student Loan Scandal Grows A federal Education Department official and financial aid directors at three universities received stock in a student loan company from the current president of the company in what could be a violation of securities law, Senate aides say. A13 An Abortion Law is Revisited A South Dakota law that would require doctors there to tell women seeking abortions that the procedure would ''terminate the life of a whole, separate, unique, living human being'' will be revisited by the federal appeals court in St. Louis. A13 Romney Focuses on Military Mitt Romney made his most extensive remarks on military and foreign policy, saying that if elected president he would push to add at least 100,000 troops to the armed forces and increase military spending. A16 Donation Program Under Fire A new program that lets cell phone users send text messages to make donations to the American Red Cross during major natural disasters has come under fire by a consumer group, which contends that it is a business development strategy masquerading as charity. A15 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Billionaire Leaves Columbia A Gift of $400 Million Columbia University is planning to announce a gift of at least $400 million today, one of the largest ever to an American university, from John Werner Kluge, 92, a billionaire who has long been one of the university's strongest supporters. B1 City to Raise Water Rates New York City plans to raise rates 11.5 percent on the water that every New Yorker uses, the largest annual increase in 15 years. The proposed increase would add $72 to the average water and sewer bill for a single-family home. But whether he can save his career remains unclear. DOUGLAS--Bernice, passed away on March 11, 2007, surrounded by loved ones. The daughter of Mae Simon, a star of the Yiddish Theater, and Herman Rubenstein, the ''actor's lawyer,'' she was a quintessential New Yorker who loved music, art, and almost nightly performances at Lincoln Center. She was an extraordinarily independent woman from the days when being one was uncommon. A journalist and public relations specialist, she ended her career as the Director of Publications at Kingsborough Community College of CUNY. She touched many lives by her generosity. She gave financial assistance, gifts, mementos, reminders and her famous New York Times personal clipping service to her friends and extended family. She loved Italy and into her eighties, her favorite, if unorthodox, choice of travel there was via freighter. She lived life her way, and spread an impish joy to those fortunate enough to share her space. She was dearly loved and will be sorely missed. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held on April 15, 2007, at Manhattan School of Music, Greenfield Hall, 120 Claremont Avenue, NYC. Refreshments 10:0011:00 AM. Service 11:00 -Noon.

THE AMERICAN DREAM, REVISED -- For years, homeownership made more sense than renting. But now it is clear that people who chose renting over buying in the last two years made the right move. Economix: David Leonhardt. [Page A1.] IMUS AND THE RUTGERS TEAM -- For a third day, Don Imus apologized for a racially insensitive remark he made about the Rutgers women's basketball team, but it remained uncertain whether he could salvage his program, which generates about $20 million in annual revenue for CBS Radio, or his career. [A1.] A VIDEO GAME CHALLENGE -- Strauss Zelnick has taken on risky corporate restructurings in the past, but he says none have been as complex as a turnaround of Take-Two Interactive Software, where he was named chairman two weeks ago. [C1.] BETTING ON TRUMP -- Two years after Donald J. Trump's Atlantic City casinos emerged from bankruptcy proceedings, it is unclear whether they have the cash necessary to compete with their rivals. [C1.] CANADIAN GROCERY STRUGGLES -- The Loblaw Companies, Canada's largest grocery chain and once one of North America's most innovative retailers, is struggling with inventory problems and its first annual loss in 19 years. [C1.] 5 YEARS IN JAIL FOR EX-ADVISER -- Martin A. Armstrong, the financial adviser who has spent seven years in jail on a contempt of court charge, was sentenced to five years in prison and ordered to pay $80 million for running what prosecutors said was a $3 billion Ponzi scheme. [C3.] ALCOA RIDES A GROWING DEMAND -- Alcoa reported its most profitable first quarter ever as rising metal demand from China and the aerospace industry bolstered prices. Net income rose 8.9 percent, and sales 11 percent. Aluminum prices have more than doubled in the last five years. [C3.] CHINA UNHAPPY WITH U.S. MOVE -- The Chinese government expressed ''deep regret and strong dissatisfaction'' with the Bush administration's decision to file two complaints against China with the World Trade Organization. [C1.] ROMANIAN WORKERS MAKE AN EXIT -- Romania's low wages and recent membership in the European Union is fueling a wave of emigration that threatens to slow an economic boom in recent years. [C7.] A BID FOR PUMA -- The French luxury goods retailer PPR bid about $7 billion for Puma, the German sporting goods company, promising to keep its chief executive, Jochen Zeitz, at the helm of the company he turned around. [C3.] SPANNING THE GLOBE, AND THE WEB -- As NBC's ''Today'' prepares for this year's version of ''Where in the World Is Matt Lauer?'' Hyundai will sponsor a Web site following Mr. Lauer, left, as he travels the world. It is an example of efforts by networks to interweave traditional programming -- and advertising -- with the online media. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C4.] A BOOM IN RETAIL CONDOMINIUMS -- The market for retail condominiums in Manhattan has skyrocketed in recent years. More than 560,000 square feet of retail condo space sold last year, a sharp increase from 28,000 square feet in 2003. [C9.] EIGHT IN A ROW -- Stocks edged higher, giving the Dow Jones industrial average an eighth consecutive increase, though a modest one, for its longest streak since 2003. [C13.] QUESTIONS OVER FINANCIAL AID GIFT -- A federal Education Department official and financial aid directors at three universities received stock in a student loan company from the current president of the company in what could be a violation of securities law. [A13.] CELLPHONE CHARITY PROGRAM -- A new program that lets cellphone users send text messages to make donations to the American Red Cross has come under fire by a consumer group that points out the cellphone company can bill for the text message. [A15.] BIG DONATION TO COLUMBIA -- Columbia University plans to announce a gift of at least $400 million from John Werner Kluge, a 92-year-old billionaire whose multimedia company, Metromedia, was sold to Rupert Murdoch in 1986. [B1.] AN UPSIDE TO THE PET FOOD RECALL -- Stores and Web sites that sell pet food made from free-range meat, organic vegetables and brown rice say business has increased markedly since last month's recall of tainted pet food. [A14.] ONLINE HIGHLY PAID AT COACH -- The richest paydays are supposed to be reserved for Wall Street titans, oil barons and banking moguls. So what is a handbag maker doing atop the list? A special section on executive pay is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. NEW CENTURY FINANCIAL, the subprime lender, has asked a federal bankruptcy judge to speed up the auction and sale of its main lending business while it still has value, according to court papers. (REUTERS) UNITED RENTALS, the equipment rental company, said that it was exploring a possible sale of the company and that its chief executive, Wayland R. Hicks, would retire in June. (AP) FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT at Levi Strauss & Company rose 61 percent, providing the latest sign that the long-suffering jeans maker is finally on the mend. (AP)

RUNDBACK--Robert Joseph, a resident of Mount Kisco, NY, and Naples, FL, died April 8, 2007, at the age of 80. Bob was a devoted husband, loving father, cherished grandfather and uncle. He was born in New Rochelle, NY, and graduated from Brooklyn College with a Masters degree at University of Illinois. Bob retired in 1994 after almost 40 years as Senior Vice President of First Investors Corporation, where he will always be remembered for his leadership and ''Monday morning meetings''. He loved tennis, treasured time with his family, and adored the many years spent boating and vacationing at his summer home in the Poconos. Known as an avid whistler, music enthusiast, and for his quick sense of humor, Bob will be dearly missed by the many people who loved him. Each of us who knew him will be better people for all he taught us. Bob is survived by his wife Carol, sons Frederic (of Pittsfield, MA) and John (of Briarcliff Manor, NY), daughter-inlaws Lili and Barbara, grandson Matthew, nieces and nephews Barbara, Susan, Spencer, Emily and Heather. Donations can be made in Bob's name to the SW Florida Parkinsons Association or a charity of your choice.

A judge has ruled that the Berkeley Unified School District does not violate state law when considering race in assigning students to programs. The ruling stems from a lawsuit filed last year by the Pacific Legal Foundation, a supporter of a 1996 ballot measure designed to abolish the use of sexual and racial preferences in government hiring and contracts. The judge, Winifred Y. Smith of Alameda County Superior Court, ruled Friday that the district appropriately used racial demographics, rather than the race of individual students, in deciding student placement. But the judge let stand the lawsuit's challenge to a mentoring and tutoring program. CAROLYN MARSHALL
NUSSBAUM--Muriel (nee Leventhal), passed in peace on April 7, 2007. A celebration of her life will take place at Matthews Lockwood Mansion in Norwalk, CT, May 20th, at 1:00 PM.

If the Stanley Cup playoffs are anything like the just concluded regular season, hockey fans are in for a treat. Despite some persistent problems -- an epidemic of head injuries from legal but malicious checks, a pro-fighting backlash against new rules designed to reduce violence and lagging attendance in several cities -- the hallmark of the 2006-7 season has been an abundance of beautiful, creative goal-scoring. Buffalo and Detroit have scored those beautiful goals most often, the main reason they finished first in their conferences and are the favorites to win the Stanley Cup. Many of the Sabres' goals have come from gorgeous clockwork passing on full-tilt rushes to the net, reminiscent of the great Soviet teams of the 1970s. Many of the Red Wings' goals have come from precision combination play in tight spaces, an ingenious game of high-speed tic-tac-toe.

LEWITT--Sol, with great sorrow we mourn the death of Sol Lewitt, a remarkable artist, whose work and humanity enhanced our perception and our lives. We were privileged to have known him and to have published his prints. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Carol, his daughters, Sofia and Eva, and his very close associates Susanna Singer and Jo Watanabe. Richard Solomon, and the staff of Pace Prints. $(6$)LeWITT--Sol. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Sol LeWitt. The Museum was fortunate to have enjoyed a long and close relationship with the artist. From 1960 to 1964, LeWitt worked at MoMA, first at the book counter and later as a night receptionist. In 1978, the Museum hosted LeWitt's first major museum exhibition. His vibrantly colored recent wall drawing, currently on view in the Museum's lobby, attests to the artist's long-standing imaginative vision. We will remember LeWitt not only for his prodigious and deeply influential body of work, but also for his remarkable generosity, modesty, warmth, and wit. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Carol, and to their daughters, Sofia and Eva. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Ronald S. To the Editor: Re ''Iraq Protesters, Called by Cleric, Say U.S. Must Go'' (front page, April 10): With thousands of Iraqis, both Shiite and Sunni, engaging in peaceful protest and supporting democracy, it would seem that they've gotten the point.

A Rikers Island inmate was charged yesterday with trying to hire someone he believed was a hit man to kill his mother, prosecutors said. The inmate, Joseph Salvio, 30, of Astoria, is accused of asking an undercover police officer to kill his mother in exchange for three of her fur coats, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Salvio was serving a four-month sentence for drug possession when he tried to arrange the killing, Mr. Brown said. He added that Mr. Salvio told the undercover officer to make the killing look like a robbery at his mother's home in Astoria and said he could keep three coats -- a mink, a fox, and a raccoon -- worth $10,000.

SURELY if I put my mind to it I could learn how to shuck oysters without serious damage to myself. But I haven't done so, even though I love them when they are icy cold, filled with the briny flavor of the sea and ready to be slurped out of the shell. So when I ordered some Pacific oysters for dinner this past New Year's Eve -- they arrived just one day out of the ocean -- I took the coward's way out: I asked for a jar filled with oysters already shucked. And then I set about finding a way to make cooked oysters as memorable as raw.

Columbia University will announce a gift of $400 million today, one of the largest ever to an American university, from John Werner Kluge, 92, a billionaire who has long been one of the university's strongest supporters. Columbia's president, Lee Bollinger, said last night: ''Obviously, this is an extraordinary gift by any standard. It's huge in its consequences and effects on the university.''

COXE--Eckley B. The Trustees of Freedom Institute express profound sorrow at the death of Eckley B. Coxe and extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Buzzy served for many years as a member of the Institute's Board. He was a loyal supporter and a true friend. He will be missed. Nancy I. Stahl, Chairman Connie Murray, President $(6$)COXE--Eckley B. Eckley Brinton Coxe IV, 84, of Hobe Sound, Florida, and East Hampton, New York, died Wednesday, April 8, at home in Florida. Born May 4, 1922 in Philadelphia, PA, to Mary Owens Coxe and Eckley B. Coxe III, Buzz Coxe was a senior partner at Scudder, Stevens & Clark for many years. He was a caring husband, father and grandfather who participated meaningfully in a large number of charitable and community activities throughout his life. A graduate of Andover School and Yale University, he most recently served as councilman, commissioner, and vicemayor of Hobe Sound as well as a board member of the Jupiter Medical Center in Jupiter, FL, where he contributed an MRI machine for the use of the community. Most recently, he was president and chairman of the Jupiter Island Clinic in Hobe Sound. In East Hampton, he was a vestryman at St. Luke's Church, a past president of the The Maidstone Club, and a board member at Southampton Hospital in Southampton, NY. In Greenwich, CT, where he lived with his first wife, nee Judith Gratz, from 1944 to 1972, he was chairman of the Red Cross of Greenwich, president of the Greenwich Field Club, a member of the board of trustees of the Round Hill Club, and chairman of the board of trustees of the Greenwich Country Day School. He is survived by his wife, Susie Skidmore Coxe; two sons, Eckley Brinton Coxe V of Greenwich, CT, and Alexander B. Coxe, of Chicago, Ill.; two daughters, Sandra Coxe Ankarcrona of London, England, and Audrey Coxe Cadwallader of Darien CT; 11 grandchildren; two sisters, Mary Schueler of Delray Beach, FL, and Louisa Finch of North Palm Beach, FL; and two stepchildren, Catherine Harris Shraga and David Harris of New York City. Another sister, Elizabeth Coxe Spalding of Prouts Neck, ME, died earlier. The funeral will be held in Hobe Sound on Saturday at 4:00 p.m. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Jupiter Island Medical Clinic, 100 Estrada Square, Hobe Sound, FL 33455.

OF all the reasons to visit my friends with small children, grilled cheese sandwiches may be the best. Sure, I treasure the toddler rituals of dumping everything out of Aunty Melissa's purse, watching out the window for passing trucks (''Look! Elliot! Garbage truck!''), and playing dress up and hide-and-go-seek. But just as much, I love lunchtime, when almost every mother I know asks, ''Who wants grilled cheese?'' The loudest voice in the yes chorus is unfailingly mine.

When Ichiro Suzuki took his position in center field for the Seattle Mariners on Tuesday at Fenway Park, he noticed an advertisement behind him. The sign featured a Dunkin' Donuts coffee cup with ''Welcome to Fenway'' written in Japanese. ''Just by looking at that,'' Suzuki said, ''I can tell it's something big.'' The event that is big here, and bigger in Japan, is the first confrontation between Suzuki and Daisuke Matsuzaka, the dynamic pitcher for the Red Sox. When Matsuzaka makes his first start at Fenway on Wednesday night, he will throw his first pitch to Suzuki, who hails from Matsuzaka's former baseball home.

The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardt's April 11 column on the relative merits of buying and renting a home: I have been a Real Estate Broker in Central Florida for over 25 years and based on my experience you are totally wrong. You make it sounds like people are better of putting their money in to the stock market then buying a home. Well, let me tell you anyone that has put their money into the market lost lots more then the person that put it into real estate in the early 80s. Your information may be correct for New York or some other large city but not for the rest of the country. Owning real estate is one sure way for people to save money as they pay off their home. - Rosa Holloway

Le Sousbois is a rare artisanal cheese from Switzerland with a story to tell. Robert and Anne Henchoz from Rossinière, in the Vaud region of southwestern Switzerland, make about 2,000 of these cow's milk cheeses each month. The cheeses have a grassy aroma and come in thick disks about 3 1/2 inches in diameter. Beneath the cross-hatched ivory rind is a satiny, mildly pungent, spoonable interior. A band of spruce bark is wrapped around it. That band of spruce got the Henchozes in trouble with the people who make Vacherin Mont d'Or, a better-known Swiss washed-rind cheese that is similarly wrapped. But the couple was allowed to continue production when they proved that the wrapper was the only thing their cheeses had in common with Vacherin. Until recently Le Sousbois was sold only from early winter until mid-April, but production has increased, so it will be around at least until June. It is being served at Trestle on Tenth, left, where the whole cheese, for the table, is $16. It is also sold at Formaggio Essex in the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side, and at the Formaggio Kitchen stores in Cambridge and Boston, for $8.95; at formaggio-kitchen.com, it's $10.95.

To the Editor: ''No Longer Waiting for Rain, an Arid West Takes Action'' (front page, April 4), about how the West is dealing with long-term water shortages, was an important contribution to the issue. We here in Yuma, Ariz., are also developing an entirely new approach that emphasizes cooperation, not confrontation.

The public radio station WNYC-AM/FM is to announce today that it has received a $6 million gift from the Jerome L. Greene Foundation and that it will name the station's new 120-seat street-level performing space for Mr. Greene, a real estate executive and philanthropist who died in 1999. The gift is believed to be the largest ever received by a public radio station. The donation was made in conjunction with the station's $57.5 million capital campaign, which is also being officially announced today. Gifts of $42.4 million are already in hand, including $5 million from the Kaplen Foundation. The campaign money will also be used to set up a $12.5 million program development fund, with the remainder paying for the station's move in the fall to 160 Varick Street from its 84-year home in the Municipal Building. Laura Walker, the station's president and chief executive, said the money would enable WNYC to double its news staff of 18, adding an arts unit and reporters to cover the New York economy, immigration and the environment. ELIZABETH JENSEN

Republican leaders across the country say they are growing increasingly anxious about their party's chances of holding the White House, citing public dissatisfaction with President Bush, the political fallout from the war in Iraq and the problems their leading presidential candidates are having generating enthusiasm among conservative voters. In interviews on Tuesday, the Republicans said they were concerned about signs of despondency among party members and fund-raisers, reflected in polls and the Democratic fund-raising advantage in the first quarter of the year. Many party leaders expressed worry that the party's presidential candidates faced a tough course without some fundamental shift in the political dynamic.

GREEN--Beatrice Stella, 91, of Oak Hill Manor, Ithaca, New York, died on April 3. She was born in Brooklyn, New York on September 1, 1915 to Yetta and Wolf Kosofsky. She is survived by her daughters, Victoria Borus and Stefanie Green, and her grandson, Joseph Lehman. She loved poetry, history, music, art and horticulture. She had a boundless curiosity about the world and the people who live in it. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends.

Stars Align for 'Live Earth' at Giants Stadium Bon Jovi, the Police, Kanye West and the ''American Idol'' winner Kelly Clarkson are to perform on July 7 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., in the climax of ''Live Earth,'' a globe-spanning day of concerts intended to draw attention to global warming, The Associated Press reported. Others on the scheduled program are Alicia Keys, the Dave Matthews Band, Fall Out Boy, Ludacris, John Mayer, Melissa Etheridge, Rihanna and the Smashing Pumpkins. To be broadcast by more than 120 television outlets around the world and streamed live online, the concerts will take place in Shanghai, Johannesburg, Sydney, Tokyo and Rio de Janeiro, and organizers have also promised an event in Antarctica. Proceeds will create a foundation led by the Alliance for Climate Protection, with former Vice President Al Gore as chairman. Millions for Chinese Art A rare oil by the artist Xu Beihong went for $9.2 million at a Sotheby's auction in Hong Kong, a record for a Chinese painting at auction, Reuters reported. Mr. Xu, who lived from 1895 to 1953, is considered the father of modern Chinese painting. The work, ''Put Down Your Whip,'' above, depicting a 1939 anti-Japanese street play in China, went to an anonymous bidder on Saturday. In four days of sales that ended yesterday, Sotheby's sold a total of $135 million of mainly Chinese artwork, including $27.5 million in contemporary pieces. Despite strong demand, Henry Howard-Sneyd, Sotheby's deputy chairman for Europe and Asia, said in an interview that he expected the surge in prices of Modern and contemporary Chinese paintings to level off. ''The contemporary Chinese art market is no longer massively undervalued,'' he said, adding, ''We've still got some price jumps to come, but I think the jumps will be much less significant now.'' Encore for Movie Hounds In true show-business fashion, two black Labrador retrievers who took their act on the road and became a smash hit have been held over indefinitely. The retrievers, Lucky and Flo, above, lent to Malaysia by the Motion Picture Association of America to sniff out counterfeit DVDs, were originally to stay abroad for a month. Billed as the only dogs in the world trained to detect a chemical used in making the discs, they took part in raids on warehouses, shops and offices that uncovered 1.2 million pirated DVDs and CDs worth nearly $3.5 million. Adding drama and suspense to the dogs' exploits, Malaysian movie pirates have reportedly put bounties on their heads. At the request of the Malaysian government, Lucky and Flo will be based there ''for the foreseeable future,'' said Neil Gane, the motion picture association's senior operations executive. At the Japan Society After two years without a gallery director, the Japan Society in Manhattan has named Joe Earle, a curator at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Mr. Earle, who currently heads the department of Asian, Oceanic and African art at the Boston museum, is to assume his new role on Sept. 4 and will also hold the title of vice president. The previous gallery director at Japan Society, Alexandra Munroe, resigned in April 2005 amid considerable turmoil. After trustees complained about several staff departures and the cancellations of art exhibitions, Frank L. Ellsworth resigned as president of Japan Society in April 2006. He was replaced by Richard J. Wood, who has sought to revive the exhibition schedule. Mr. Earle said in a statement on Monday that he looked forward to building ''a distinctive, durable and popular exhibition program that covers many aspects of Japanese art, both traditional and contemporary.'' Japan Society is celebrating its centennial. China's Bruce Lee Series Bruce Lee, below, the kung fu star who died at 32 in 1973, will return as the subject of a 40-part television series filmed by China's national broadcaster, The Associated Press reported. China Central Television began filming ''The Legend of Bruce Lee,'' starring Chen Guokun, over the weekend in Shunde in Guangdong Province in southern China, the Xinhua News agency reported. Shunde is the ancestral home of Lee, who was born in San Francisco in 1940. Mr. Chen is best known for his role in the action comedy ''Kung Fu Hustle.'' The television series is to be broadcast in 2008. A Pharaoh's Stolen Hair Locks of 3,200-year-old royal hair, above, that were stolen 30 years ago were displayed yesterday at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, The Associated Press reported. The small tufts of brown hair from the pharaoh Ramses II were stolen while the mummy was in France for treatment to halt the spread of a rare fungus, and the theft was discovered when the hair was offered for sale for $2,600 last November on the Internet. The seller, identified as Jean-Michel Diebolt, a postman who is the son of the researcher who examined the mummy when it was in France, is being investigated there.

DOHERTY--Thomas. Sister Elizabeth A. An eighth of a yacht is better than none. Or so reasons Han Verstraete, chief executive of YachtPlus. A London-based operation that is building a fleet of 10 yachts, YachtPlus is the latest company to jump into fractionals, a shared-ownership structure that allows people to buy only part of a costly item. ''Wealthy people today do not invest in only assets but in experiences,'' Mr. Verstraete said. ''My typical customer will have three real estate assets and perhaps also do some sharing of jets. The yacht experience is the experience these people are seeking next.''

The Parks and Recreation Department announced yesterday that a policy of allowing dogs off leashes during overnight hours will become effective next month. Beginning May 10, owners with a license and proof of a current rabies vaccination will be permitted to let their dogs roam in designated areas of city parks from 9 p.m. to 9 a.m. Under an unofficial policy, the department has for years not given tickets to dog owners who let their pets run free at night in parks. TIMOTHY WILLIAMS
