Juan Padilla can't catch a break. The Mets announced tonight that all the elbow discomfort Padilla has felt since making his lone spring appearance, on March 11, is because of a partial tear of the flexor tendon in his right elbow. It will be the second major elbow surgery in 13 months for Padilla, who underwent reconstructive elbow surgery last March.
Some local and national politicians are promoting an increased Islamiziation. At the national level, an exemplary democratic counter movement is pushing back.
Islam in Indonesia is often fused with local cultures. But some of its more unorthodox practices have incited backlash from extremists.

In an institution that has grown increasingly partisan in recent years, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, a Hawaii Democrat, gave a warm tribute today to Alaska's Ted Stevens, in honor of his new status as the longest-serving Republican senator:
After 32 years of dictatorship, Indonesia found freedom in 1998. This victory allowed fundamentalist Islam to return. Now, an infant Muslim democracy fights terrorism.

Just spoke with General Manager Brian Cashman for an article to run in tomorrow's Times. Cashman said he spoke today with Mike Mussina, who received treatment for his strained left hamstring at the Coliseum in Oakland. According to Cashman, there's still a chance Mussina can avoid the disabled list.

Lewis Hamilton decided to clarify his statement about "tricking" Felipe Massa into going off the track at the Malaysian Grand Prix last Sunday in Sepang. It was Lap 6 and Hamilton was being chased by Massa until the Ferrari driver went off the track in a cloud of rubber smoke after making a bad judgment on the passing procedure. Hamilton, after the race, said he had tricked Massa into that, and then apologized. It was a nice moment in the press conference, in fact.
Five syllables can get you fired.

YouTube, the online video-sharing site, is upping the ante for candidate-voter outreach. As part of its YouChoose '08 channel, a new "Spotlight" will feature a different candidate each week with a video asking for user responses.

During a news conference today, Barbara Bartoletti, legislative director of the League of Women Voters of New York State, said the 51st Senate district looked like "Abraham Lincoln riding on a vacuum cleaner."

One of the two men fired by Dow Chemical on Thursday has rejected allegations that he held unauthorized talks with potential buyers of the company. "The behavior of the company is very unusual, and the accusations have absolutely no substance and are highly damaging to my reputation after 30 years of employment,'' Romeo Kreinberg told The Associated Press. Mr. Kreinberg, who had been an executive vice president at Dow, was dismissed Thursday along with Pedro Reinhard, a member of Dow's board, for holding what the company said were "highly inappropriate" talks with third parties about a possible sale of Dow Chemical.
The city's rent guidelines board has released a report [pdf] today on rent affordability.
An interesting fact about tonight's Tom Glavine/Jamie Moyer pitching matchup from our good friends at the Elias Sports Bureau:

Money cannot buy happiness, but it can help with optimism.A poll from The Los Angeles Times and Bloomberg reports that most Americans think a recession is at least somewhat likely over the next year. Those making less than $40,000 a year are far more likely to think that will happen. So are blacks, and women are much more pessimistic than men.

The market for initial public offerings of Internet startups has been weak in the past few years. So for venture investors and Silicon Valley entrepreneurs seeking a way to cash out, a sale to Google, Yahoo and a handful of other Web giants has become the brass ring. So what does Google, which has about $11 billion in cash and lots of high-priced stock to use as currency, look for in an acquisition target? According to its chief dealmaker, Google likes ideas that are "really crazy."

Something I discovered while wondering how many games this weekend will be rained out: Of the Mets starters, only two players have more walks than strikeouts this season. I'll give you three guesses, and the first two don't count. Still don't know? The first one is Moises Alou (4 BB, 3 K). The second is Jose Reyes - the same Jose Reyes who would swing at airplanes, ants and everything in between for the first few years of his career. In 2005, Reyes walked 27 times and struck out 78 times.

After a long and exacting review, federal environmental officials have decided that New York City's upstate water supply is still so clean and pure that it does not have to be filtered for another decade or longer.

Iraq public opinion is unfailingly fascinating, and reading opinion polls from Iraq are extraordinarily illuminating -- and depressing. Here's the latest, from ABC News, noting that 51 percent of Iraqis favor killing our troops, and 80 percent of Shiites disapprove of our presence along with 97 percent of Arab Sunnis. Read and weep.

The system failed the Duke University lacrosse team, and most of the finger-pointing has been aimed at Mike Nifong, the prosecutor. As I wrote in my column at the time, he indeed behaved disgracefully and disbarment seems to me about the right penalty.

The state of New York routinely fails to review the pollution permits of hundreds of factories, generating stations, sewage treatment plants and other operations that discharge billions of gallons of contaminated water into the state's rivers and lakes, according to a study [pdf] released today by Environmental Advocates of New York, a citizens group.

People often ask why the U.N. doesn't do more to stop the genocide in Darfur. Well, the answer is complex and largely involves the perfidy of Sudan's protectors on the U.N. Security Council, above all China. But this week has underscored that the U.N. can't even confront a genocide that happened in 1915.

The Politicker points out this report from Guyana, which says that Bernard B. Kerik has decided to pull out of his contract to serve as a security advisor to President Bharrat Jagdeo, because of the federal investigation here at home:

It seems that John F. Welch Jr.'s dream of becoming a newspaper baron will have to wait. Speaking before an audience at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the former chairman of General Electric said Thursday that The New York Times Company has made it clear that the Boston Globe is not for sale. Last year, Mr. Welch expressed an interest in buying The Globe, and he joined with Jack Connors, co-founder of Boston advertising agency Hill Holliday, to explore making an offer. But the Times Company has repeatedly said that The Globe is not on the block, and Mr. Welch appears to have gotten the message.
Saul Bolton has been kicking around New York City kitchens for a while. He worked under David Bouley. He worked under Eric Ripert.
Following is the draft script of the weekly "Only in New York" audio podcast. Listen at left or download it to a portable player.
Whoops! The 14 percent stake that WestLB took in DaimlerChrysler wasn't the beginning of a takeover play - it was a mistake.
As you may know if you watched my Times Web video this week, I've had a heck of a week.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was in Ohio this morning, where he unveiled a new ad for his Mayors Against Illegal Guns coalition. The ad -- posted on YouTube -- urges the repeal of an amendment to federal spending bills that Mr. Bloomberg's group says has restricted police departments from getting access to federal tracing data on guns used in crimes. The campaign has a Web site, too: protectpolice.org.
Driving around the suburbs of London, one sign has become ubiquitous -- that belonging to OliverFinn.

Three days after it insisted it was not up for sale, Dow Chemical has fired two executives it claims held unauthorized talks to sell the company. In a press release, Dow said Pedro Reinhard, a board member, and Romeo Kreinberg, an executive vice president, had "engaged in business activity that was highly inappropriate" and a violation of the company's ethics code. Mr. Reinhard was Dow's chief financial officer until late 2005.

In a last-ditch effort to save its A$11 billion ($9 billion) bid for Qantas Airways, the consortium of private equity suitors has reduced its shareholder acceptance requirement to 70 percent from 90 percent. The group of bidders, including the Texas Pacific Group and Macquarie Bank, will also extend its offer for Australia's largest airline to May 4.

Fortress Investment Group is not a stock for the faint of heart. Its shares surged 68 percent when they hit the market in February in what was the first public stock offering from a United States hedge fund and private equity firm. Since the offering, the shares have swung as high as $37 and as low as $23.34. The company generates eye-popping returns through its various funds, but many parts of its profit-making machine are proprietary secrets. So it was remarkable to learn, thanks to some filing-watchers at Financial News, that Fidelity Investments, the world's largest mutual fund company, has bought more than a quarter of the shares that Fortress sold in the I.P.O., giving it a 10 percent stake in the company.
With “Voice of a Murderer,” the unpredictable Korean director Park Jin-pyo returns to the docudrama form.

Beware the consequences of spurning a suitor. That might be the warning to take away from the latest twist in the proposed $45 billion buyout of TXU, the Texas energy giant. On Wednesday, two Texas legislators said they want the state's attorney general to investigate claims that TXU threatened to sue a potential bidder.

The Russians may be planning another multibillion-dollar deal in North America. Ipsco, a Canadian steelmaker with executive offices in the United States, said Thursday that it is in discussions that could lead to a sale of the company. Ipsco did not identify the potential buyer, but the statement followed a report in a Russian newspaper that Russian steel company Evraz Group was in takeover talks with Ipsco. Ipsco's shares jumped nearly 7 percent on Thursday, giving it a market capitalization of about $6.6 billion.

The results are coming in from the MoveOn Virtual Town Meeting, the Tuesday forum for Democratic presidential candidates to talk about Iraq. Tens of thousands of members of the liberal group voted for which candidate they believe best represented their views on Iraq.
The Times’s David Pogue illustrates why wireless home-networking remains one of life’s frustrations.
The Republican candidates, particularly Senator John McCain, appear to be stuck between Iraq and G.O.P. primary voters. In their analysis, The Times's John M. Broder and Adam Nagourney write:
“Modern Man,” the debut feature from Justin Swibel, may leave you seeing the world with fresh eyes.
Paulo Costanzo and Steph Song make a sweet screen couple in “Everything’s Gone Green,” but Vancouver is the real star of the movie.
All grunting, all goring, the witless action flick “Pathfinder” has little to recommend it.
The point of “Aqua Teen Hunger Force” is not “South Park”-style topical satire, but rather endless riffing on pop culture minutiae.

MedImmune, citing recent approaches from "major pharmaceutical companies" and dissatisfaction within its shareholder ranks, said Thursday it had hired Goldman Sachs to help it look for potential buyers. MedImmune, a biotechnology company whose products include the flu vaccine FluMist, had a market capitalization of about $9 billion based on Wednesday's closing share price; the shares surged more than 8 percent in premarket trading Thursday. The company said there was no guarantee it would be sold and added that it would not give any public updates on the process until it was complete.
There continues to be talk of moving the trial in the Sean Bell case.
American Scene blogger Reihan Salam endorses the White House's search for a "war czar," even if no one seems to want the job. Salam writes:

It was just yesterday that DealBook was observing how Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone company, has the dubious honor of being the worst initial public offering, by far, of 2006. Then came word Thursday morning that Vonage's chief executive, Michael Snyder, has abruptly stepped down and resigned from Vonages' its board of directors. Thursday's news release gave no reason for Mr. Snyder's departure, but the company is clearly in crisis mode. Its stock has lost more than 80 percent of its value since it went public in May, and Vonage is at risk of losing access to an important piece of technology that is the subject of a patent dispute with Verizon.

The mining company Xstrata said it would sell its aluminum business to Apollo Management for $1.15 billion. The business being sold, known as Noranda Aluminum, includes a primary smelter and three rolling mills in Tennessee, North Carolina and Arkansas along with other operations, the company said.

More details emerged about a fishy report by Bloomberg News yesterday -- picked up by news services including DealBook -- that an American financier was planning a bid for Gold Fields, one of the world's largest gold producers.

Light regulation of hedge funds has worked well so far and seems appropriate given the benefits the funds provide to the financial system, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Wednesday. Speaking at New York University Law School, Mr. Bernanke stressed that the purpose of hedge funds - investment pools aimed primarily at wealthy investors and institutions - was to take risks.

As last weekend's box-office take for the heavily promoted "Grindhouse" tumbled in at just $11.6 million, a chilly realization came with the numbers: Not all is well with the fledgling Weinstein Company.
David Pogue's horror story behind the installation of four 802.11n wireless routers.

SMG, the struggling owner of Scotland's two ITV franchises, plans to spin-off Virgin Radio, a pop and rock station, in an initial public offering as it seeks to cut debt and focus on its core television business. The offering of the station, which has 2.5 million listeners, will provide "a strong platform for Virgin Radio's future growth," according to SMG.

A private equity fund linked to the royal family of Qatar appears to be the favored bidder for the upscale department store Barneys New York, Women's Wear Daily reported. The trade paper said that an unnamed fund was edging out bids from other suitors with an offer of more than $1 billion for Barneys, which is owned by the Jones Apparel Corporation.

Shares in the Nordic stock exchange operator OMX soared as much as 18 percent Thursday after the company said it is discussing possible forms of cooperation with several exchanges and other market venues.

Citigroup's global cost-cutting effort will be felt especially keenly in New York, where Citi is the largest private employer. Of the 17,000 jobs the bank said would be cut, about 1,600 will be eliminated in the city, where Citigroup has 27,000 employees and its headquarters.

Look out Bill Gates, here comes Carlos Slim Helu. The Mexican telecoms mogul has breezed past Warren Buffett and is gaining on the Microsoft co-founder on the list of the world's richest men, according to Forbes.

If the EMI Group was hoping that the Warner Music Group would bring its bid for the British label more in line with the offer it made for EMI last year, one of its private equity owners dashed any such expectations.

Relational Investors, an activist fund led by Ralph Whitworth, has built a stake of nearly 1 percent in Sprint Nextel, the wireless carrier, and is calling for major changes, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing unidentified sources. Mr. Whitworth has met with Sprint's management and urged them to reduce capital spending and consider selling Sprint's fiber-optic networking and long-distance operation, the Journal said.

It looks like Overstock.com, the online retailer whose chief has been waging war against naked short selling and what he sees as a vast conspiracy to drive his company's stock down, will get its day in court. The California Court of Appeal for the First District in San Francisco seemed ready to let the online retailer get a full airing on its claims that a financial analysis company and a hedge fund conspired to put it out of business, The Recorder reports.

The Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan is the latest private equity investor to consider direct involvement with a buyout target. The Financial Times's Lex column suggests that cutting out the middle man is cheaper but may not produce the same quality results as the best buyout funds. And Lex also warns that "charities or pension funds could find themselves painfully exposed if they leap into oversized positions in single companies at this stage of the cycle."

Magna International's chairman confirmed that the Canadian auto parts maker is in talks with a private equity firm, Onex, about making a bid for Chrysler, the United States carmaker that DaimlerChrysler has put on the block. Separately, Chrysler's former chairman Lee Iacocca warned in his latest book that Chrysler could become a "shattered remnant" if sold, according to The Detroit Free Press.

The chief adviser to the two private equity firms that have agreed to buy TXU suggested that the buyout shops might walk away if the Texas House of Representatives decides that the deal for the energy company will require state approval. Texas lawmakers on Thursday will debate whether the $45 billion buyout of TXU by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group should require state regulatory approval.

Comcast, the nation's largest cable operator, announced Wednesday that it was buying the online movie ticketing service Fandango and starting a new Web site for watching TV and movies. The new site, Fancast.com, will be in place this summer and allow users to watch on-demand shows via television, the Internet and wireless devices.

NovaStar Financial, the struggling subprime lender, said Wednesday that it was exploring strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the company. The company also said it had obtained a $100 million financing commitment arranged by Wachovia Capital Markets.

The news Wednesday that the software maker Comverse Technology had named a chief executive to succeed its founder and former chief, who fled the United States last year to escape arrest over an options scandal, sparked speculation among some analysts that the company was headed for a sale or break-up.

A Hollinger International internal investigation found no proof that the board approved most noncompete payments to Conrad M. Black, then its chairman, or to two others on trial for stealing the money, a company lawyer testified on Wednesday.

Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, never exaggerated the company's growth rates to enhance the value of his personal stock, Herbert J. Stern, a defense lawyer, said Wednesday.

These days, hundreds of business schools hold competitions involving students presenting start-up ideas to a panel of judges. Usually, winners receive money, from $5,000 to $100,000 or more. In some cases, they are also given free legal, public relations and accounting advice.

Nestlé, the world's largest food company, agreed to buy the baby food giant Gerber for $5.5 billion in cash to extend its push into the health and wellness category. Gerber, famous for its Gerber Baby ads, is currently owned by Novartis, the Swiss pharmaceuticals company, which has been selling noncore businesses in recent years to focus on health care. Separately, Novartis said Thursday it had named Joseph Jimenez, previously of the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, to be chief executive of its consumer health division.
A sampling of current shows in Chelsea’s big-box galleries offers a map to some of the ways artists use space in, and also around, art these days.
CBS yielded to pressure when it canceled “Imus in the Morning,” ending a program that had been broadcasting for more than 30 years.
Images from the reinstallation of the Chinese galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
The Eugene O’Neill Theater Center will present its Monte Cristo Award posthumously to Wendy Wasserstein, and a musical based on the life of Ray Charles will open in November.
Take a tour of Calistoga, Calif., a Napa Valley spa town that attracts visitors with natural hot springs and unstuffy culture.
“Notes From the Underbelly” is a revolting sitcom about pregnancy. Watch and you’ll lose your appetite for life.
With less traffic, better public transportation and Mount Hood in its backyard, this self-styled City of Roses in Oregon doesn’t stand in anybody’s shadow.
A frugal weekend soaking up this colorful city's streets, plazas and historical sights.
Europe's culture capital for 2007, Luxembourg has loyal - and royal - visitors.
In a speech at the Virginia Military Institute in Lexington, Va., Senator John McCain issued a forceful call for the United States to press on in Iraq.
Another day, another leg injury for the Yankees. This time it was starter Mike Mussina, who left in the third inning with a strained left hamstring.
Italy proposed international standards for confronting the rising number of high-profile kidnappings in war zones.
The federal jail guards were charged with beating two inmates at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn.
The F.D.A. rejected Arcoxia because of concerns that the drug could cause as many as 30,000 heart attacks a year if widely used.
The apology by  Michael B. Nifong came one day after the state attorney general called him as a “rogue prosecutor.”
Federal environmental officials have concluded that New York City’s upstate water supply is still so clean that it does not have to be filtered for another decade or longer.
The ceremony was haunted by past failures, as every official who spoke alluded to the line’s history of starts and stops — mostly stops.
A memorial service today honored an agent who was killed last week in a confrontation robbery suspects.
The scientists said exploration of molecular-level relationships of ancient, extinct animals is now possible.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, who issued subpoenas for the documents, was skeptical that the e-mails are indeed missing.
Paul D. Wolfowitz apologized for his role in arranging a highly paid job at the State Department for a woman with whom he has a personal relationship.
An explosion struck the cafeteria inside the Iraqi parliament in one of the most serious breaches of security of the heavily fortified Green Zone.
CBS brought the week-long crisis over remarks by the radio host Don Imus to an end late this afternoon when it canceled the “Imus in the Morning” program, effective immediately.
Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China today pledged friendship with Japan, but also cautioned that Tokyo must match its past apologies for its wartime aggression with concrete actions.

A picture caption on the Calendar page in the Long Island section on Sunday carried incorrect details about a concert by the Brentano String Quartet, at the Sayville Middle School, this Saturday. Admission is $30; the concert is not free. Besides Beethoven and Mozart, the program will include the works of Bartok; it will not feature works by Horne. The caption also misstated the telephone number for information. The number is (631) 224-5420.
Kurt Vonnegut’s darkly comic novels became classics of the counterculture, making him a literary idol to students in the 1960s and ’70s.
Mike Mussina walked off the mound in the third inning Wednesday night, the latest victim of a leg injury and the latest casualty on the pitching staff.
Starting pitcher Oliver Pérez walked seven Philadelphia batters and hit one in two and two-thirds innings as the Phillies eased to a victory over the Mets Wednesday night.
Starting pitcher Oliver Pérez walked seven Philadelphia batters and hit one in two and two-thirds innings as the Phillies eased to a victory over the Mets Wednesday night.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 11 (AP) — The families of four workers killed when a parking garage under construction collapsed at the Tropicana Casino Resort in 2003 will share $101 million with 36 others who were injured in the collapse, under terms of a legal settlement approved on Wednesday night by a judge in State Superior Court.

Because of an editing error, a report in the Extra Time soccer roundup yesterday, about the Sunderland club’s turnaround in an effort to return to the English Premier League, referred incorrectly to the competition through which teams rise to that league from the next level, the Championship. The Championship’s top two teams — not just the top team — receive automatic promotions; the next four compete for one more spot, not for two.

A Media Talk report in Business Day on Monday, about the cult status of James J. Cramer, the host of the CNBC television show “Mad Money, referred imprecisely to the aftermath of his “sell” recommendation on Dendreon shares. Because trading was halted the morning after the recommendation, few investors would have been able to sell — causing them to miss an earnings opportunity — before trading in Dendreon shares resumed. Mr. Cramer’s recommendation did not necessarily cause investors to lose money.

An article on Tuesday about the New York Police Department’s use of a surveillance watchtower in a parking lot at Shea Stadium during the Mets’ home opener misstated the number of parking spaces that have been lost at the stadium this year because of construction — a point raised by a fan who complained about the tower taking up parking spaces. About 2,100 have been lost, not 20,000.

An article in The Arts on Saturday about condemnation of the radio host Don Imus for his remarks about the Rutgers women’s basketball team misidentified the book that Barack Obama, then a senator-elect, was promoting when he appeared on Mr. Imus’s show in November 2004. It was “Dreams From My Father” — not “The Audacity of Hope,” which was published in 2006.

The Executive Pursuits column in Business Day on Saturday, about tasting tequila, referred incompletely to the territories in Mexico that are allowed to call their agave-based drinks tequila. The Tequila Regulatory Council of the Mexican government recognizes five territories — not just Jalisco — as sources for the production of tequila. The others are Guanajuato, Michoacán, Nayarit and Tamaulipas. The column also misattributed a literary quotation about the process of going bankrupt, which was likened to overindulging in tequila. The reference to “gradually and then suddenly” was from “The Sun Also Rises” by Ernest Hemingway, not from F. Scott Fitzgerald.
Corrections: For the Record

A picture caption on Monday with an obituary of the artist Sol LeWitt carried an erroneous credit for one of the photographs shown. The one on the right, of an installation of wall paintings at the Whitney Museum of American Art, was by Librado Romero/The New York Times; it was not from the museum.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about mounting criticism of the Italian government’s policy in a hostage crisis in Afghanistan misstated the nation that Italy had urged to release prisoners belonging to the Taliban in order to win the release of a kidnapped Italian journalist. It was Afghanistan, not Pakistan.
An obituary by The Associated Press on Monday about the cartoonist Johnny Hart misidentified his hometown, where he died. It was Nineveh, N.Y., not Endicott, N.Y.

A report in the Playoff Shootout hockey roundup yesterday, about the disappointments that some N.H.L. teams experience before winning the Stanley Cup, referred incorrectly to the Detroit Red Wings’ breakthrough championship. It was in 1997, not 1996. (The Colorado Avalanche won the Cup that year.).

An article yesterday about Congressional investigations of the Justice Department decision to dismiss eight United States attorneys gave an incorrect job description in some copies for a Wisconsin official who was convicted of corruption charges brought by the United States attorney in Milwaukee. The official, Georgia Thompson, was a purchasing official in the state’s Department of Administration, not an aide to Gov. James E. Doyle. (After a federal appeals court heard oral arguments in the case last week, it ordered her immediate release from prison.).

Magna, the Canadian auto parts manufacturer, said that a former president, Belinda Stronach, left, the daughter of the company’s founder and controlling shareholder, Frank Stronach, would be returning to the company to be the executive vice chairwoman. The company said that Ms. Stronach would not seek re-election to the Canadian Parliament, where she has served since 2004. Magna has been discussed by auto analysts as a possible bidder for the Chrysler division of the DaimlerChrysler Corporation. “My father is looking to the future, the company is facing important strategic decisions, and the Canadian and global auto sector and economy are in a period of great challenge,” Ms. Stronach said in a statement.

The mining company Xstrata said it would sell its aluminum business to Apollo Management for $1.15 billion. The business being sold, known as Noranda Aluminum, includes a primary smelter and three rolling mills in Tennessee, North Carolina and Arkansas along with other operations, the company said. Xstrata, based in Switzerland, won control of the Canadian mining company Falconbridge last year after a battle against Inco and the copper miner Phelps Dodge Corporation. The $18.8 billion deal allowed Xstrata to diversify into nickel and aluminum and enter the North American market. Apollo Management is a private equity and capital markets investor with holdings in a range of industries in the United States and internationally.

A panel of the European Parliament is set to recommend that fees Europeans pay for making and receiving mobile phone calls outside their home markets be lowered by more than originally expected, dealing a setback to the telecommunications industry. Members of the Industry, Research and Energy Committee are expected to approve a proposal today to reduce so-called roaming charges to a maximum 0.40 euro for outgoing calls, and 0.15 euro for incoming calls, plus the value-added tax. Leaders of all major political parties on the 52-member panel except the Greens have endorsed the plan, according to a copy of their agreement obtained by The International Herald Tribune. If it receives the committee’s support, the proposal will go before the full Parliament on May 9.

The buyout firm CVC Capital Partners scrapped a £10 billion ($19.7 billion) bid for J Sainsbury, the British grocery chain, after CVC was abandoned by its bidding partners and Sainsbury’s founding family held out for more money. The family, which owns about 18 percent of the retailer, wanted more than the 582 pence ($11.46) that CVC bid for each share. “It became clear that the consortium would be unable to make a proposal” that would succeed, CVC said in a statement. The Blackstone Group, the Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company all left the bidding consortium in the last week. Selling to the private equity group would have risked damaging the company’s “strong balance sheet and a largely freehold property base,” said John Sainsbury, former chief executive of the company. “Eroding these attributes would make the company more vulnerable to competitive pressures.”.
State senators said they had been shocked to learn that they had voted again and again in recent years for measures that had left the state pension in great distress.
Tayshaun Prince’s short jumper broke a late tie, and the Detroit Pistons locked up home-court advantage throughout the Eastern Conference playoffs with a victory over Orlando.
The Ottawa Senators ruined Sidney Crosby’s playoff debut Wednesday night with a 6-3 victory over the visiting Pittsburgh Penguins in the opening game of their Eastern Conference first-round series.
Football.
North Carolina’s attorney general said an overzealous district attorney had wrongly accused lacrosse players of sexual assault.

The body of a man who had been shot to death was found early yesterday morning by a state trooper along Route 280 in Newark, the authorities said. The trooper found the body along an on-ramp on the westbound side of the highway shortly after 1 a.m., said Sgt. Jeanne Hengemuhle, a state police spokeswoman. The man’s identity was not released yesterday pending notification of his family, but officials with the Essex County prosecutor’s office said the man had died from several gunshot wounds. No arrests had been made by last night.
A federal judge overseeing the bankruptcy proceedings of the Roman Catholic Diocese in San Diego ordered an outside accounting expert to sort through the diocese’s accounting system.

The remains of a woman who died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center have been identified through DNA analysis, the city medical examiner’s office said yesterday. The woman, Carol Ann LaPlante, 59, of New York, was at work on the 97th floor of the north tower at Marsh & McLennan. Her remains were found in the original recovery effort, the medical examiner’s office said, but identification was not possible until recent improvements in DNA testing technology.

Property tax relief to homeowners and tenants in New Jersey will come as rebate checks in the fall, Gov. Jon S. Corzine said this week. The governor had wanted a direct credit against tax bills as a way to reduce the costs of the program. However, at a forum on property taxes on Tuesday, Mr. Corzine said that would not be feasible because of concerns about logistics and privacy. The governor this month signed into law a bill that gives most homeowners a 20 percent property tax cut. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A city education official promised members of the City Council yesterday that the Education Department would take steps to address reports of problems on city school buses. The official, Kathleen Grimm, the deputy chancellor for finance and administration, said the department would hire more investigators, improve record-keeping and standardize reporting of problems on the buses. Ms. Grimm testified before the Council Committee on Education, which convened a hearing in response to a series of reports in The Daily News that detailed physical and sexual abuse by students, bus drivers and monitors on school buses.

Federal agents charged 10 people yesterday with selling crack cocaine in the Westbury area of Nassau County, prosecutors said. Seven of the suspects are members of the Bloods street gang, said Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn. Ms. Mauskopf said F.B.I. agents seized two handguns, material used to make and package crack, and an unknown amount of material believed to be crack and powdered cocaine. She said the arrests followed an eight-month investigation by the F.B.I. and local police officers.
The Justice Department has turned up virtually no evidence of any organized effort to skew federal elections.

Police officers evacuated four buildings in Gravesend early yesterday morning after they found an AK-47 rifle, four handguns, ammunition and a mortar shell while searching an apartment on Ocean Parkway, the police said. The mortar shell was determined to be inert, the police said. Officers assigned to the Brooklyn South narcotics squad found the weapons while executing a search warrant at 2281 Ocean Parkway about 1:30 a.m., the police said. Two men, Christopher Ocera, 42, of 2281 Ocean Parkway, and Danny DiSpigno, of East Seventh Street, were arrested, the police said. Mr. Ocera was charged with weapons possession, selling marijuana and resisting arrest, and Mr. DiSpigno with assault, possession of marijuana and resisting arrest, the police said.

Judges in two cities issued bench warrants yesterday for the arrest of the rapper DMX, left, who failed to show up for either of his pending traffic cases. “In truth, I do not know where he is,” said Murray Richman, the lawyer for the 36-year-old rapper, whose real name is Earl Simmons. Mr. Simmons was due to appear yesterday in White Plains City Court to face speeding and other charges. He was also due in Yonkers City Court to face a charge of driving with a suspended license, and the Yonkers judge issued a warrant when he did not appear, said Lucian Chalfen, a spokesman for the Westchester County district attorney. Mr. Richman said his client was in Arizona on Tuesday and had promised to appear. “He said he missed a flight,” he said.

An elderly woman was found dead inside her Chelsea apartment after a fire yesterday morning , fire officials said. The fire, which was under investigation, began just before 11:45 a.m. at the back of the woman’s second-floor apartment at 246 West 18th Street, fire officials said. The woman, whose identity was not released yesterday, lived with her son William Pifer, 70, who was at a doctor’s appointment when the fire occurred. The police did not release her age, but neighbors said she was in her late 90s.

Marc Anthony, the singer and husband of Jennifer Lopez, the singer and actress, has agreed to pay $2.5 million in back taxes, interest and penalties for 2000 to 2004, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday. Mr. Morgenthau said that three companies controlled by the singer, whose real name is Marco Antonio Muniz, either failed to file tax returns or did not report all taxable income in those years. But he said Mr. Muniz was not prosecuted because he had relied on his brother Bigram Zayes, acting as his general manager, and his accountant, Philip Sarna, to pay taxes, and prosecutors could not prove that he was aware of their failure to pay taxes. Mr. Zayes and Mr. Sarna have pleaded guilty to tax law felonies, and will be sentenced to a conditional discharge after paying back taxes and fines. Mr. Muniz and Ms. Lopez file tax returns separately, prosecutors said, so Ms. Lopez is not involved.
The military has paid $32 million to Iraqis and Afghans  for noncombat-related killings, injuries and damage.

Nearly 9 out of 10 New York City businesses obey laws forbidding the sale of tobacco to people under the age of 18, city officials said yesterday. In the most recent round of inspections, investigators for the Department of Consumer Affairs found that 89 percent of businesses licensed to sell tobacco in New York check for identification and refuse to sell to minors, said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The department spot-checks businesses across the city using teams of inspectors and teenage workers. When the program started in 1998, 52 percent of businesses followed the rules, officials said.
The New Jersey Supreme Court says former Nets star Jayson Williams’s actions moments after a 2002 shooting could be presented to a jury as evidence of a “consciousness of guilt.”
The behavior of a pair of lawyers has become the main event at a judicial corruption trial taking place in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

Singapore’s prime minister, Lee Hsien Loong, responded to criticism of hefty government raises by saying he would freeze his current salary for five years and donate a 60 percent increase to charity, local news reports said. Speaking to Parliament, Mr. Lee, whose pay is to jump to about $2 million, defended the 60 percent raises for ministers announced this week as necessary to keep government incomes competitive but said he would donate his raise “to give me the moral standing to defend this policy to Singaporeans,” according to The Straits Times.

Protesting increasingly brutal attacks against Buddhist civilians in the predominantly Muslim south and what they said was inadequate security, several hundred outraged Buddhist villagers in Yala Province confronted the army chief, Gen. Sonthi Boonyaratglin, with the charred body of a 25-year-old woman burned and killed by insurgents. The general was in the province to meet with local officials, and the demonstrators, who carried banners reading “we have no place to retreat,” and “beheading or burning alive, no one is arrested,” took him out of the province’s government hall to see the body. The demonstration was the latest sign of fraying tempers among Buddhists in the deep south.

Jean-Pierre Bemba, the failed presidential candidate who had been holed up in the secure compound of the South African Embassy in Kinshasa, the Congolese capital, since clashes between his militia and government forces killed 200 last month and the authorities issued a warrant for his arrest, arrived in Portugal after being given permission to go abroad, ostensibly for medical reasons. He was accompanied by his wife and five children. A convoy of United Nations armored vehicles escorted them to Kinshasa’s airport.
The lawyers for the women accused in the beating and stabbing of a film director on a Greenwich Village street said that they were defending themselves against an anti-gay attack.

Europe is under no threat from missiles belonging to so-called rogue states, Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, left, said in an article in The Financial Times. “We are convinced that no threat of this kind exists to Europe or the U.S. today, or in the foreseeable future,” he wrote in outlining Russia’s stance on an American plan to install antimissile defenses in Poland and the Czech Republic against possible attacks from what the United States calls “rogue states,” meaning Iran or North Korea. Saying the shield plan had set off a debate in Europe on whether the continent needed it, he said, “Russia is ready to take part in these discussions at all levels and in any format.” He said it was “unacceptable for anyone to use the Continent as their own strategic territory, and said an antimissile system “would fundamentally alter the Continent’s geo-strategic landscape.”.

Hamas, the militant group now in a fragile unity government with the rival Fatah faction, criticized a $59 million American aid package authorized earlier this week to bolster Palestinian security measures as “dirty” and “ill intentioned” because most of the money is to be used to support the Fatah forces of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas. Hamas said all the money should be channeled through the Palestinian treasury. In Brussels, the Palestinian finance minister, Salam Fayyad, asked the European Union for $1.3 billion to avert an “acute financial crisis” this year. The European Union deals with Mr. Fayyad, an internationally respected independent member of the unity government, but boycotts Hamas, which it defines as a terrorist organization. The Union, which suspended direct aid to the Palestinian Authority when Hamas came to power a year ago, said it would not be resumed at this stage.
A report by the San Francisco city attorney cleared Mayor Gavin Newsom of any legal wrongdoing in relation to a cash payment made to a woman with whom Mr. Newsom had had an affair.
Ford Motor Company is recalling more than 500,000 Escape small sport-utility vehicles after 50 reports of engine fires caused by corroded brake parts.

A San Mateo County prosecutor said she would file additional charges today against Dr. William Ayres, the former head of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, who is accused of sexually abusing patients. “We have received a lot of phone calls from people over the last week saying: ‘Thank God. I thought I was the only one,’ ” the prosecutor, Melissa McKowan said. Dr. Ayres, 75, is charged with lewd and lascivious acts with a child under 14 from 1991 to 1996. The authorities say he groped three boys while they were his patients. Judge Kathleen M. McKenna of San Mateo County Superior Court signed an order preventing Dr. Ayres from practicing medicine and issued an order forbidding him from contacting accusers.

The House apologized “for the injustice, cruelty and brutality of slavery,” following up on the apology the Senate issued last week.

Bed Bath & Beyond said that fourth-quarter profit climbed 4 percent as the company used discount coupons to lure customers.
Workers at the Canadian National Railway have resumed picketing after overwhelmingly rejecting a tentative contract.

Jackie Robinson’s number 42 was retired throughout baseball in 1997, except for active players who were then wearing it. The only one left is Yankees closer Mariano Rivera.

North Korea said it would begin shutting its main nuclear reactor within a day of retrieving about $25 million that had been frozen in a Macao bank because of American sanctions, Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico said here on Wednesday. North Korea also offered to admit United Nations nuclear inspectors for the first time in more than four years, Mr. Richardson said after an official visit to North Korea and a meeting with senior officials there.

CASLOW--Rubin. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Rubin Caslow, beloved father of Eric and Madeline and Robert and Miriam. The Caslow family's historic commitment to Jewish life and learning was built on a foundation of unparalleled generosity through active participation on our Board of Directors and support of numerous agencies within our socialservice network. Such dedication continues through the service of the family and overflows with the spirit of klal Yisrael, enriching our work in New York, in Israel, and worldwide. We extend our deepest sympathies to Rubin's beloved wife, Charlotte; to his children, Eric and Madeline, and Robert and Miriam; to his grandchildren, Emily and Nathan Gindi, Heather and Jeff Pavell, David and Lisa Caslow, and Adam Caslow; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

Police officers evacuated four buildings in Gravesend early yesterday morning after they found an AK-47 rifle, four handguns, ammunition and a mortar shell while searching an apartment on Ocean Parkway, the police said. The mortar shell was determined to be inert, the police said. Officers assigned to the Brooklyn South narcotics squad found the weapons while executing a search warrant at 2281 Ocean Parkway about 1:30 a.m., the police said. Two men, Christopher Ocera, 42, of 2281 Ocean Parkway, and Danny DiSpigno, of East Seventh Street, were arrested, the police said. Mr. Ocera was charged with weapons possession, selling marijuana and resisting arrest, and Mr. DiSpigno with assault, possession of marijuana and resisting arrest, the police said.

WHEN Michael Garnier and Peter Nelson organized the first World Treehouse Conference in 1997, treehouses for adults were still pretty rare. ''It was the bolder people who were doing them, the pioneers,'' said Mr. Garnier, who builds treehouses professionally and runs the Out 'n' About Treehouse Treesort near Cave Junction, Ore., where the conference is held each October. But that was before an engineering breakthrough developed by conference participants, the so-called Garnier Limb, allowed treehouses greater stability and longer life, and before a spate of how-to and coffee-table books helped popularize them. Within a few years, elaborate treehouses, many costing upwards of $100,000, were becoming almost faddish.

The one on the right, of an installation of wall paintings at the Whitney Museum of American Art, was by Librado Romero/The New York Times; it was not from the museum.

O'REILLY--Owen R., Beloved husband of Laura (nee Cummins). Dear son of the late Margaret and Jerard. Loving Brother of Jerry, Mike, Oliver, Connie, Carmel, and Patrick. Dear Uncle of several neices and nephews. Reposing at the McManus & Ahern Funeral Home, 445 West 43 Street, New York, Thursday and Friday, 2pm to 5pm, and 7pm to 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated from the church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West 31 Street, Saturday, at 10am. In lieu of flowers please make donations in Owen's memory to the UNIFORMED FIREFIGHTER ASSOCIATION, WIDOWS AND ORPHANS FUND, 204 East 23 Street, NYC 10010.

After complaints from Hispanic leaders, PBS has decided to supplement Ken Burns's coming documentary about World War II with material examining the wartime experiences of Hispanic and American Indian veterans. The already completed 14-hour film, ''The War,'' won't be modified. But Florentine Films, Mr. Burns's production company, will assemble a team, including a Hispanic producer, to create additional material to run in conjunction with the broadcast, beginning on Sept. 23. The additional material will also be included on the DVD ''The War'' and in any subsequent broadcasts. Hispanic leaders praised the move. Mr. Burns, above right, in the middle of a 20-day promotional tour for his film, said in an interview that while the film was never intended to be encyclopedic or to tell every veteran's story, creating the new material was ''a win-win situation.'' He added that ''for us this was a discussion with an intent to work out the issues.'' The amount of new material has not been decided, he said, but added that he wanted to make sure it did not ''feel pasted on or token.'' PBS said it would also distribute to stations additional programs that deal with Hispanic contributions to the war. ELIZABETH JENSEN

''Open House: Architecture and Technology for Intelligent Living,'' an exhibition of visionary housing projects by 10 young architects, opens on Saturday at Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif. Standouts include Seoul Commune 2026, above left, a cluster of towers covered in vines that provide shade and regulate interior temperature, and the Jellyfish house, top right, which was designed to help clean toxic water on a stretch of reclaimed land on San Francisco Bay and is encased in an organic water jacket that reacts to changes in light and temperature. Dunehouse, center right, is sheathed in skin that responds to the climatic extremes of the Nevada desert, while Open the House!, above right, covers its occupants in temperature-responsive fabric. The show also includes vintage models of housing like Buckminster Fuller's 1928 Dymaxion House and the Monsanto House of the Future. Through July 1 at Art Center's South Campus, 950 South Raymond Avenue, Pasadena, (626) 396-4254 or artcenter.edu/openhouse. MICHAEL WEBB

GOULARD--Marion Reed, of Darien, CT, on April 8, 2007. Wife of the late Everett M. Goulard. Mother of James E. Goulard and Sarah R. Goulard. Grandmother of five and great-grandmother of 11. Memorial service and interment will be held at Noroton Presbyterian Church, Darien, CT, at a later date. Memorial donations may be sent to the Everett M. Goulard Memorial Scholarship Fund at Taft School, Watertown, CT, or to Dana Hall School, Wellesley, MA.

Senator John McCain's vigorous defense of President Bush's policy in Iraq on Wednesday served as a bold reminder of the remarkable degree to which his party, and all of its leading presidential candidates, stand united behind the president even as public support for the conflict erodes. Mr. McCain declared in a speech at the Virginia Military Institute that defeat or surrender in Iraq was not acceptable, but he acknowledged that the hour was late and the result remained very much in doubt. He might well have been referring to his own political aspirations, the near-term future of the Republican Party and the historical verdict on George W. Bush's presidency.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 U.S. Extends Troops' Tours In Iraq and Afghanistan The military announced that most active-duty Army units now in Iraq and Afghanistan and those sent in the future will serve 15-month tours, three months longer than the standard tour. A1 Arms that American military officials say appear to have been manufactured in Iran as recently as last year have turned up in the past week in a Sunni-majority area, the chief spokesman for the American military command in Iraq said in a news conference. A8 Bombings Kill 23 in Algeria Two bombings in Algeria, one aimed at the main government building in the capital, killed at least 23 people in a sharp escalation of the violence linked to Al Qaeda that has been spreading across North Africa in recent months. A1 Documents Give Glimpse of War Hundreds of claims submitted to the Army by Iraqi and Afghan civilians seeking payment for noncombat killings, injuries or property damage inflicted by American forces display the chaos faced by bystanders and troops in the two war zones. A1 Chinese Leader Visits Japan Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China began a three-day visit to Japan, in what both countries described as an important step forward in repairing diplomatic relations. A10 NATIONAL A14-19 All Charges Dropped In Duke University Case The attorney general of North Carolina dropped all charges against three former Duke University lacrosse players who had been accused of raping a stripper, ending a prosecution that provoked debate over race, class and the tactics of the Durham County district attorney. A1 New Light on Voter Fraud Data Five years after the Bush administration began a crackdown on voter fraud, the Justice Department has turned up virtually no evidence of any organized effort to skew federal elections, according to court records and interviews. A1 Panel Criticizes Walter Reed An independent panel assessing dilapidated facilities and red tape for wounded Iraq war veterans at Walter Reed Army Medical Center issued an indictment of leadership failures, inadequate training and staffing shortages. A14 New Health Care Proposal Massachusetts is poised to be the first state to make it possible for 99 percent of adults to be covered by health insurance with a plan that sets limits for the premiums people should be expected to pay. State officials said that under the plan, they expected that all but about 65,000 of the 328,000 adults who are currently uninsured would be able to get affordable coverage. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 City Seeks Right to Force Repairs on Idle Landlords A bill to be introduced in the New York City Council with the Bloomberg administration's support would give the Department of Housing Preservation and Development broad new powers to overhaul entire building systems in long-troubled properties and force landlords to pay for the work. B1 States Join Forces on Mercury New York and six other Northeastern states announced that they had joined in a regional pact to try to force the federal government to enact tougher standards on mercury emissions. B5 BUSINESS DAY C1-13 NBC Drops Imus Show NBC News dropped Don Imus, canceling his show from its MSNBC cable news channel after he made racially disparaging remarks about the Rutgers University women's basketball team. A1 Citigroup to Cut Jobs Citigroup, which has long carried the mantle as the world's biggest bank, said that it would shed or move more than 26,500 jobs, or about 8 percent of its work force in an effort to cut expenses. About 1,600 jobs will be eliminated in New York City, where Citigroup has its headquarters. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: Four years later in Iraq; the billion-dollar brushoff; Mr. Giuliani goes south; a bad choice, a quick exit. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge: E2 Weather: B8 Crossword: E6 TV Listings: E8
NEWMAN--Howard A. (Micky), February 2, 1921April 12, 2006. Honored for his acumen and philanthropy. Respected for his loyalty and integrity. Missed everyday by his family and friends.

SHATTEN--Michael Lee, retired General Attorney of Ohio Bell, formerly of Cleveland, OH, died Sunday, April 1, 2007, in Atlanta, GA, at age 88. His career with the Bell System spanned 45 years. He proudly served as a USAF Captain during WWII. Above all, he was devoted to his family. His beloved wife, Arlene Baldwin, whom he wed in 1943, predeceased him in 2000. He is survived by daughter, Jane Flowerree, and granddaughters, Laura and Christine. Cremation Society of the SOUTH, 770-420-5557.

The Top 2 albums on the Billboard chart last week traded places in their second week of release, and five new records arrived in the Top 10. Last week's No. 2, the 24th installment of the pop series ''Now That's What I Call Music!,'' rose to No. 1 with 213,000 sales, and Tim McGraw's ''Let It Go'' (Curb) dropped one spot to No. 2, with 177,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The country singer Martina McBride's new ''Waking Up Laughing'' (RCA) is No. 3, with 144,000 sales; Hilary Duff's ''Dignity'' (Hollywood) sold 140,000, to open at No. 4; and ''Timbaland Presents Shock Value'' (Interscope), by the hit producer Timbaland, reached No. 5, with 138,000 sales in its first week. A re-release of Beyoncé's ''B'Day'' (Columbia), featuring ''Beautiful Liar,'' her hit new duet with Shakira, sent the album up 63 spots to No. 6. The Houston rapper Paul Wall's ''Get Money Stay True'' (Atlantic) opened at No. 8, and Alison Krauss's new ''Hundred Miles or More: A Collection'' (Rounder) bowed at No. 10. BEN SISARIO

FOR space-starved homeowners, a backyard shed, shack, caravan or cabin can serve as an extra room -- an office free of the distractions of home, a playroom, a pool cabana or even a guest room for a visiting mother-in-law. In warm weather, even simple canvas tents can make for pleasant dining areas or outdoor bedrooms.

Bush Advisers' Approach On E-Mail Draws Fire Political advisers to the president may have improperly used Republican National Committee e-mail accounts to conduct government business, and some communications that are required to be preserved may be lost, officials said. The Executive Pursuits column in Business Day on Saturday, about tasting tequila, referred incompletely to the territories in Mexico that are allowed to call their agave-based drinks tequila. The Tequila Regulatory Council of the Mexican government recognizes five territories -- not just Jalisco -- as sources for the production of tequila. The others are Guanajuato, Michoacán, Nayarit and Tamaulipas. The column also misattributed a literary quotation about the process of going bankrupt, which was likened to overindulging in tequila. The reference to ''gradually and then suddenly'' was from ''The Sun Also Rises'' by Ernest Hemingway, not from F. Scott Fitzgerald.

To the Editor: David Brooks (''A War of Narratives,'' column, April 8) depicts his recent encounter with Arab intellectuals as pointless because his Middle Eastern interlocutors rejected his narrative about the region (it's all about Arab failures).

LEVENBROWN--Naomi. The Hebrew Academy of The Five Towns, and Rockaway, mourn the passing of our beloved Associate Principle, Mrs. Naomi Levenbrown. Naomi was a consummate professional, teacher, role model and cherished friend. She was the heart and soul of our institution, caring for the thousands of students she shepherded over her 25 years at HAFTR as if they were her own children. Her dedication knew no bounds and despite recent illness, she had an unwavering commitment to allowing each student to realize his/her potential. The officers, trustees, administrators, teachers and students join her husband, the honorable Dr. Jack Levenbrown, their daughter Andrea, and the entire Levenbrown family in mourning. May we all find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

RIEGER--Tina Susan (nee Grossman), 63, of New York and Pittsburgh, died Wednesday, April 11, 2007 of cancer at Beth Israel Hospital. Beloved wife of Howard Rieger, president of United Jewish Communities and past president of the United Jewish Federation of Pittsburgh. Devoted mother of Alec and his wife, Cara (nee Shuckett, of Winnipeg, Canada) of New York, and Miriam Rieger and her husband Alain Jachiet of New York, whose son Matan Rieger was her only grandchild. Loving sister of Laura Fukunishi of Kobe, Japan, fond aunt of Ayano and Sayaka Fukunishi of Japan. Also survived by an aunt, uncle and many cousins. The burial will take place in the Misgav region in northern Israel. Memorial contributions welcomed to United Jewish Federation of Pittsburgh, for the Tina Rieger Shaare Torah Congregation Fund.

VAN LEUVEN--Thomas Carter, 40, died Saturday, April 7th, following a massive heart attack. He was an equity research and strategy analyst for the past 15 years. He is survived by his wife Margaretta, children Susannah and Johnny, and parents Susan and Jim Van Leuven and Barbara and John Moran. A memorial service will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola Church at 84th and Park Avenue on Thursday, April 12th, at 1:30 pm. A scholarship fund is being established in his name at Georgetown University.

Under the Tree, an aptly named eight-foot-tall stainless steel outdoor shower, has multiple limbs. One is a shower head; the others can be used to hold towels, swimsuits or a bar of soap on a string. A garden hose can be screwed into the base of the shower, which is held in place by a 12-inch spike.

New York City Ballet has announced that it is offering free tickets to a final dress rehearsal of its new production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' on April 29. The tickets will be distributed beginning at 9 a.m. on Sunday at the New York State Theater box office. ''I've wanted to do this for years,'' said Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of City Ballet and the choreographer of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' which is to open on May 1. ''We finally found someone to underwrite it.'' CIT Group is the sponsor of the rehearsal and also of the $15 tickets available throughout the spring season. Mr. Martins said these gestures were partly a tribute to Lincoln Kirstein, the co-founder of City Ballet, whose birthday centennial will be celebrated throughout the season. ''He believed that there could be an American audience for ballet,'' Mr. Martins said. ''And he was right.'' ROSLYN SULCAS

MERENDINO--Vincent. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Rita, Debra and Jeffrey Solomon, and the entire family. Mark J. Shirvan, President
To the Editor: Re ''A Great Year for Ivy League Colleges, but Not So Good for Applicants to Them'' (Education page, April 4):

KELLNER--Zoe Margit, died April 9th, 2007, at age 22. She died peacefully at home. She is survived by her mother Robin Kellner and countless friends and relatives who adored and treasured her. Services Thursday, 11am, at Frank E Campbell -The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC.

The body of a man who had been shot to death was found early yesterday morning by a state trooper along Route 280 in Newark, the authorities said. The trooper found the body along an on-ramp on the westbound side of the highway shortly after 1 a.m., said Sgt. Jeanne Hengemuhle, a state police spokeswoman. The man's identity was not released yesterday pending notification of his family, but officials with the Essex County prosecutor's office said the man had died from several gunshot wounds. No arrests had been made by last night. JOHN HOLL

Gus, the Toronto company known for its well-priced modern furniture, now has a New York store. The shop will carry the entire Gus line of furniture, lighting and rugs. Many of the pieces are from its Essentials Collection, which can be shipped within 10 days. The 2,000-square-foot space has been kept simple to mirror the furniture, said Dan Bowman, right, the store's owner. The 82-inch Jane sofa, above, is covered in synthetic suede ($1,895); the 60-inch Return bench is wood and stainless steel ($795). The vinyl Thompson side chair, behind Mr. Bowman, comes in black or white ($245). Gus New York, 207 West 18th Street, (212) 206-7065 or gusmodern.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH
To the Editor: Re your April 10 news article about the possible deployment of 13,000 National Guard members to Iraq:

A picture caption March 29 with the Fine Points column, about jewelry that incorporates coins, referred incorrectly to a pair of Agas & Tamar cuff links. The Muslim coins in the cuff links were minted in A.D. 700, not 700 B.C.

SAUL--Joseph E. The Trustees, faculty, and staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Joseph E. Saul, an outstanding philanthropist. Mr. Saul's personal commitment to Mount Sinai included generous support for the Campaign for Excellence and Alzheimers research. His loyalty to Mount Sinai will long be remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Norma; his son Andrew, an esteemed Trustee; and the entire Saul family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center $(6$)SAUL--Joseph E., 1919-2007. Loving husband of Norma for 67 years. Fabulous father of Andrew and Jane Berkey, father-in-law of Denise. Loving grandfather of Kim and Aaron, Jennifer and Rob. Great-grandfather of William and Caroline. A true gentlemen and outstanding person. Services will be private.

A letter from Wingdale, N.Y., last Thursday about global warming referred incorrectly to the United States' production of heat-trapping gases. It is the leader in emissions over all, but not per capita.

A report in the Today in Business column in Business Day on Monday, about a recommendation by James J. Cramer, the host of the CNBC television show ''Mad Money,'' that investors sell Dendreon shares, misstated the timing of events after his comments. Dendreon shares began to rise two days -- not one day -- after the ''sell'' recommendation. (Trading was halted the first day, pending an announcement that Dendreon's prostate cancer vaccine had been endorsed by a Food and Drug Administration panel.)

RATH--Kermit. Beloved by wife Lisbeth, son Niles, and sister Linda. Services 4pm, Friday, April 13th at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. Donations may be made to The Buckley School, 113 East 73rd St., New York, NY 10021.

Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee, perhaps better known as the district attorney on the television drama ''Law & Order,'' disclosed Wednesday that he has been living with cancer for more than two years, but said it would not prevent him from considering a presidential bid. For more than a month, Mr. Thompson has been exploring jumping into the 2008 campaign, hoping to capitalize on a perceived void in the Republican field. He said that he is in remission from lymphoma, but that he decided to announce his condition so he could gauge the reaction before making his final decision.

A city education official promised members of the City Council yesterday that the Education Department would take steps to address reports of problems on city school buses. The official, Kathleen Grimm, the deputy chancellor for finance and administration, said the department would hire more investigators, improve record-keeping and standardize reporting of problems on the buses. Ms. Grimm testified before the Council Committee on Education, which convened a hearing in response to a series of reports in The Daily News that detailed physical and sexual abuse by students, bus drivers and monitors on school buses. JULIE BOSMAN

Hamas, the militant group now in a fragile unity government with the rival Fatah faction, criticized a $59 million American aid package authorized earlier this week to bolster Palestinian security measures as ''dirty'' and ''ill intentioned'' because most of the money is to be used to support the Fatah forces of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas. Hamas said all the money should be channeled through the Palestinian treasury. In Brussels, the Palestinian finance minister, Salam Fayyad, asked the European Union for $1.3 billion to avert an ''acute financial crisis'' this year. The European Union deals with Mr. Fayyad, an internationally respected independent member of the unity government, but boycotts Hamas, which it defines as a terrorist organization. The Union, which suspended direct aid to the Palestinian Authority when Hamas came to power a year ago, said it would not be resumed at this stage. ISABEL KERSHNER

To the Editor: Re ''City Health Dept. Plans to Promote Circumcision to Reduce Spread of AIDS'' (news article, April 5):

Nearly 9 out of 10 New York City businesses obey laws forbidding the sale of tobacco to people under the age of 18, city officials said yesterday. In the most recent round of inspections, investigators for the Department of Consumer Affairs found that 89 percent of businesses licensed to sell tobacco in New York check for identification and refuse to sell to minors, said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The department spot-checks businesses across the city using teams of inspectors and teenage workers. When the program started in 1998, 52 percent of businesses followed the rules, officials said.

A Media Talk report in Business Day on Monday, about the cult status of James J. Cramer, the host of the CNBC television show ''Mad Money, referred imprecisely to the aftermath of his ''sell'' recommendation on Dendreon shares. Because trading was halted the morning after the recommendation, few investors would have been able to sell -- causing them to miss an earnings opportunity -- before trading in Dendreon shares resumed. Mr. Cramer's recommendation did not necessarily cause investors to lose money.

Fox coasted to another easy victory in the ratings on Tuesday as the Top 8 ''American Idol'' contestants faced off under the mentorship of Jennifer Lopez, below, in a night of Latin-themed performances. According to Nielsen's estimates, the 8 p.m. show had 26 million viewers, considerably outperforming CBS's ''NCIS,'' which had 14.4 million viewers and ranked second for the hour. At 9, the former talk show host Leeza Gibbons became the third star eliminated from ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars,'' as Tuesday's results show attracted 17 million viewers, for a second-place finish behind Fox's ''House'' (21.6 million). For the night, CBS and ABC finished about even over all as distant runners-up to Fox. At 10, ABC's ''Boston Legal'' (10.5 million) edged ahead of a repeat of CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' (10 million). NBC ranked fourth over all. BENJAMIN TOFF

Silber. Pauline and her late husband, Joseph, were YU Guardians and founders of Syms Business School and generous scholarship donors to YU and its Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. We also extend our sincerest condolences to Joy Silber; and Jinny (and Jerry) Pinsky and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry Weiss, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Bernard L. Madoff Chairman, SSSB Board Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

A panel of the European Parliament is set to recommend that fees Europeans pay for making and receiving mobile phone calls outside their home markets be lowered by more than originally expected, dealing a setback to the telecommunications industry. Members of the Industry, Research and Energy Committee are expected to approve a proposal today to reduce so-called roaming charges to a maximum 0.40 euro for outgoing calls, and 0.15 euro for incoming calls, plus the value-added tax. Leaders of all major political parties on the 52-member panel except the Greens have endorsed the plan, according to a copy of their agreement obtained by The International Herald Tribune. If it receives the committee's support, the proposal will go before the full Parliament on May 9. KEVIN J. O'BRIEN

Federal agents charged 10 people yesterday with selling crack cocaine in the Westbury area of Nassau County, prosecutors said. Seven of the suspects are members of the Bloods street gang, said Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn. Ms. Mauskopf said F.B.I. agents seized two handguns, material used to make and package crack, and an unknown amount of material believed to be crack and powdered cocaine. She said the arrests followed an eight-month investigation by the F.B.I. and local police officers.

Senator John McCain of Arizona accused his potential Democratic presidential rivals on Wednesday of playing ''small politics'' by opposing the war in Iraq, saying withdrawal would lead to chaos across the Middle East, embolden Al Qaeda and expose the United States to ''another 9/11 -- or worse.'' Mr. McCain, a Republican whose presidential candidacy has been shaken by his support of the war, spoke in vivid and even apocalyptic terms as he issued a forceful call for the United States to press on in Iraq. And he repeatedly portrayed Democrats as acting out of political opportunism -- and Republicans as acting on principle -- in the debate over the war.

Women's Work: A Common Thread, a collection of 21 fabrics from Pollack, a company based in New York, was inspired by handmade textiles from the archives at the Museum of Art of the Rhode Island School of Design. Mark Pollack, the company's design director and an alumnus of the school, said he was ''amazed by the range of techniques'' he found there, and by ''the amount of labor that went into them.'' Hmong Plush ($130 a yard), below left, is a viscose jacquard based on a batik skirt made by women in Southeast Asia. A Touch of the Bubbly ($125 a yard), below right, a wool upholstery fabric, was suggested by pompoms on a 1960s American blouse. Gracious Home, 1217 Third Avenue (70th Street), (212) 517-6300. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

Weapons that appear to have been made in Iran were found in a Sunni-majority area of Iraq, an American military spokesman in Iraq said. He also said that detainees had indicated that Iranian intelligence operatives had helped Sunni insurgents, a new accusation. Article, Page A12.

To the Editor: I enjoyed ''The Presidency's Mormon Moment,'' by Kenneth Woodward (Op-Ed, April 9). I agree ''that no candidate for public office should have to apologize for his or her religious faith.'' I might add that no candidate for public office should feel that he or she has to have a religious faith. Bert Van Gorder Portland, Ore., April 10, 2007

FOR even the most basic outing into the woods, experts advise packing a first-aid kit. But the kits' customary bulk can be a deterrent for some. At a pound or less, the lightweight soft-sided first-aid kits tested here make it possible to take along some measure of protection without weighing down a pack. Jon Tierney, a critical care paramedic and instructor with the Wilderness Medicine Institute, an outdoor educational organization, tested these kits over eight days in the woods near Machias, Me. He evaluated them for weight, size, ease of use, quality and organization of contents.

Because of an editing error, a report in the Extra Time soccer roundup yesterday, about the Sunderland club's turnaround in an effort to return to the English Premier League, referred incorrectly to the competition through which teams rise to that league from the next level, the Championship. The Championship's top two teams -- not just the top team -- receive automatic promotions; the next four compete for one more spot, not for two.

Magna, the Canadian auto parts manufacturer, said that a former president, Belinda Stronach, left, the daughter of the company's founder and controlling shareholder, Frank Stronach, would be returning to the company to be the executive vice chairwoman. The company said that Ms. Stronach would not seek re-election to the Canadian Parliament, where she has served since 2004. Magna has been discussed by auto analysts as a possible bidder for the Chrysler division of the DaimlerChrysler Corporation. ''My father is looking to the future, the company is facing important strategic decisions, and the Canadian and global auto sector and economy are in a period of great challenge,'' Ms. Stronach said in a statement. IAN AUSTEN

An elderly woman was found dead inside her Chelsea apartment after a fire yesterday morning , fire officials said. The fire, which was under investigation, began just before 11:45 a.m. at the back of the woman's second-floor apartment at 246 West 18th Street, fire officials said. The woman, whose identity was not released yesterday, lived with her son William Pifer, 70, who was at a doctor's appointment when the fire occurred. The police did not release her age, but neighbors said she was in her late 90s. REBECCA CATHCART

RAPAPORT--Millicent, age 96, of New York City, passed away peacefully on April 9, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Stanley. Devoted mother of Lew and Sue, and Richard. Loving grandmother of Billy and John and proud greatgrandmother of Alexander and Nicholas. Her life was filled with beautiful music. We will love and remember her always. Services private.

An article on Tuesday about the New York Police Department's use of a surveillance watchtower in a parking lot at Shea Stadium during the Mets' home opener misstated the number of parking spaces that have been lost at the stadium this year because of construction -- a point raised by a fan who complained about the tower taking up parking spaces. About 2,100 have been lost, not 20,000.

Marc Anthony, the singer and husband of Jennifer Lopez, the singer and actress, has agreed to pay $2.5 million in back taxes, interest and penalties for 2000 to 2004, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday. Mr. Morgenthau said that three companies controlled by the singer, whose real name is Marco Antonio Muniz, either failed to file tax returns or did not report all taxable income in those years. But he said Mr. Muniz was not prosecuted because he had relied on his brother Bigram Zayes, acting as his general manager, and his accountant, Philip Sarna, to pay taxes, and prosecutors could not prove that he was aware of their failure to pay taxes. Mr. Zayes and Mr. Sarna have pleaded guilty to tax law felonies, and will be sentenced to a conditional discharge after paying back taxes and fines. Mr. Muniz and Ms. Lopez file tax returns separately, prosecutors said, so Ms. Lopez is not involved. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

Two new compact Dyson vacuums offer relief from dust and pet hair to anyone who needs a full-size model but does not have the space to store it. The Stowaway ($499.99), left, a canister with as much power as an upright, has a smallish body (11 inches wide by 17.7 inches deep) and a hose with attachments for hardwood and carpet that wraps around the machine when not in use. The Slim ($469.99), right, an upright, works on all types of floors and has a telescoping hose for hard-to-reach jobs. Both are bagless and have HEPA filters. At the Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street, (866) 755-9079 or conranusa.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.
