The New England Patriots, who established themselves as the early Super Bowl favorites with a free-agency spending spree this off-season, will have plenty of early tests for their revamped roster. In the N.F.L. schedule released yesterday, the Patriots open the regular season on Sept. 9 against the Jets, their American Football Conference East rivals, at the Meadowlands, and then play host to the Chargers, another Super Bowl contender whom they defeated in San Diego in the second round.

LEWITT--Sol, with great sorrow we mourn the death of Sol Lewitt, a remarkable artist, whose work and humanity enhanced our perception and our lives. We were privileged to have known him and to have published his prints. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Carol, his daughters, Sofia and Eva, and his very close associates Susanna Singer and Jo Watanabe. Richard Solomon, and the staff of Pace Prints.

Hockey fans in the New York area will see more ice in the next week than they did on the streets all winter. And they don't have to drive on it or even worry about slipping on it. For only the third time, the Devils, the Rangers and the Islanders are all in the Stanley Cup playoffs. And for the first time, they will be skating in three separate opening-round series, beginning tonight with the Tampa Bay Lightning in New Jersey, the Rangers in Atlanta and the Islanders in Buffalo.

Stamato, Kathleen Innocenti, and Ronald J. Stamato; seven grandchildren; three sisters; several nieces and nephews. Visiting Friday, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Contributions to St. Joseph's Hospital Foundation, 703 Main St, Paterson, NJ 07503. Visit www.bizub.com for driving directions and online condolences.

FOR most Americans the ideal yard is a weedless lawn. Garden writers may extol alternatives like ground covers and wildflower meadows, but a picture-perfect green velvet rug has remained the goal, even though attaining it seemed to require an arsenal of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides. But that is beginning to change as organic lawn care companies and organic lawn care products enter the mainstream. It's part of the same wave that has people buying organic food and hybrid cars, said Bruce Butterfield, research director at the National Gardening Association. ''Ten years ago the only people who bought organic fertilizers were wearing Birkenstocks,'' he said. ''Now it's soccer moms with minivans.''

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about mounting criticism of the Italian government's policy in a hostage crisis in Afghanistan misstated the nation that Italy had urged to release prisoners belonging to the Taliban in order to win the release of a kidnapped Italian journalist. It was Afghanistan, not Pakistan.

McDERMOTT--Kevin J., on April 11, 2007. Survived by loving daughters Lauren, Christine, and Jeanene. Also survived by his forever loving friend Susan Geiger. Former Ernst & Young partner. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell -The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st St.) Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, Saturday 10am.

A picture caption on the Calendar page in the Long Island section on Sunday carried incorrect details about a concert by the Brentano String Quartet, at the Sayville Middle School, this Saturday. Admission is $30; the concert is not free. Besides Beethoven and Mozart, the program will include the works of Bartok; it will not feature works by Horne. The caption also misstated the telephone number for information. The number is (631) 224-5420.

An article yesterday about Congressional investigations of the Justice Department decision to dismiss eight United States attorneys gave an incorrect job description in some copies for a Wisconsin official who was convicted of corruption charges brought by the United States attorney in Milwaukee. The official, Georgia Thompson, was a purchasing official in the state's Department of Administration, not an aide to Gov. James E. Doyle. (After a federal appeals court heard oral arguments in the case last week, it ordered her immediate release from prison.)

DOHERTY--Thomas. Sister Elizabeth A. Hill, President, the Board of Trustees, and the entire St. Joseph's College community would like to express their deepest condolences to the family of Thomas Doherty. As a member of the College's Board of Trustees for 21 years and as Chairman of the Board from 1992 to 1996, Tom was a dedicated supporter of St. Joseph's. His wisdom and counsel was an integral part of our success and growth as an institution. Tom was a gentleman in every sense of the word, and his kindness and generosity served as a living testament of our mission. We are truly saddened by his passing, and his loved ones are in our thoughts and prayers.

A report in the Playoff Shootout hockey roundup yesterday, about the disappointments that some N.H.L. teams experience before winning the Stanley Cup, referred incorrectly to the Detroit Red Wings' breakthrough championship. It was in 1997, not 1996. (The Colorado Avalanche won the Cup that year.)
GRASSO--Mary. 21 years ago you left us, we have not forgotten your beautiful smile and love for us. We will love and miss you forever. Patrick, Linda, Donald and Tommy

As you may know if you watched my Times Web video this week, I've had a heck of a week. I struggled for five days with four 802.11n wireless routers, trying to make them work the way they were supposed to.

Mariano Rivera was given No. 42 sometime during his rookie season in 1995, and it was two more years before he realized that Jackie Robinson had worn it for the Brooklyn Dodgers. The number was retired throughout baseball in 1997, except for active players who were then wearing it. The only one left is Rivera, who now feels a kinship with Robinson, who broke baseball's color barrier in 1947.
ROSENBERG--Sonia. Happy Birthday, I miss and love you very much! Love, Susan

YOCHIM--Leo R., 77, died suddenly Saturday April 7th, 2007. Owner of Printronic Corporation of America for 40 years retiring 1999. Born in Philadelphia, lived in New York City 25 years, Colts Neck ten years, and recently Manchester. Marine Tech Sergeant served 1948-1953. Member Direct Marketing Association, NY, NY. Trustee to Staten Island Botanical Garden, Thalia Mara Arts Foundation - Jackson MS, Long Island Symphony Orchestra and New York City Ice Theatre. Surviving-Lifemate Susan Ann Keenan, Sons Richard L., Carl J., Victor E., and Michael D., daughters Elaine T. Herter, Jean M. Almeida, Jane Hudak, Denise A. Ficara, Victoria F. Irving, and Susan Mallow, brothers, Louis and Victor, sisters Barbara Hatch, Marie Yetman, Loretta Thomas, and M. Patricia Yochim, 21 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Visitation Friday 2-4 and 7-9 at Oliverie Funeral Home 2925 Ridgeway Rd., Manchester, NJ. Funeral Liturgy, Sat 10am, St. John's Church, Lakehurst with private cremation. For directions or to send online condolences please visit our website at www.oliveriefuneralhome.com

An article in The Arts on Saturday about condemnation of the radio host Don Imus for his remarks about the Rutgers women's basketball team misidentified the book that Barack Obama, then a senator-elect, was promoting when he appeared on Mr. Imus's show in November 2004. It was ''Dreams From My Father'' -- not ''The Audacity of Hope,'' which was published in 2006.

IMUS OUT AT MSNBC NBC News dropped Don Imus, canceling his show on MSNBC a week after he made a racially disparaging remark about the Rutgers women's basketball team. CBS Radio, Mr. Imus's main employer, which has suspended the program for two weeks, said it would ''monitor the situation closely.'' [Page A1.] SIDEKICK POINTED THE WAY The attempt at humor that got Don Imus in trouble was one of the rare instances when he has taken the bait from his longtime sidekick and envelope-pusher, Bernard McGuirk. Prince III, announced a plan to cut costs that calls for shedding or moving more than 26,500 jobs, including the elimination of 1,600 positions in New York. Mr. Devaney has amassed a fortune by becoming a major dealer in asset-backed bonds through his company, United Capital Markets. [C3.] AWAITING DATA ON A CANCER DRUG Amgen said it would delay reporting first-quarter earnings until Monday to include data from an eagerly anticipated study of its Aranesp anemia drug among patients with small-cell lung cancer. The results of the study are considered to be critical to the future use of Amgen's most important product. [C9.] REALTORS FORESEE FALLING PRICES The problems in the subprime loan market will cause home prices to fall this year for the first time on record, the National Association of Realtors said. [C10.] SHELL SETTLES WITH SHAREHOLDERS Royal Dutch Shell agreed to pay European and other non-American shareholders about $450 million in a settlement to help resolve legal disputes stemming from its overstatement of oil reserves. [C11.] CANADIAN RAIL WORKERS PICKET Workers at the Canadian National Railway have resumed picketing after overwhelmingly rejecting a tentative contract. [C11.] NESTLÉ LOOKS TO BUY GERBER Nestlé, the world's largest food company, is expected to announce that it is buying the baby food giant Gerber for an estimated $5 billion. Gerber, famous for its Gerber Baby ads, is owned by Novartis, which has been selling noncore businesses to focus on health care. But since their corporate marriage in 2005, the two have been teaching each other lessons in marketing. Advertising. Small Business. [C5.] MEDICARE REFORM IN THE SENATE Senate Democratic leaders pushed for legislation that would allow Medicare to negotiate lower drug prices for millions of older Americans. Their bill does not go as far as one passed by the House, which requires such negotiations. MYSPACE, THE POPULAR ONLINE hangout, has blocked parts of the Web hosting service Photobucket, complaining that it has been encouraging users to incorporate an ad-supported slide show into their MySpace personal profile pages. (AP) MGM HAS BECOME the latest major film studio to offer downloadable movies on Apple's iTunes Store. The deal builds the iTunes catalog to more than 500 movies. (AP)

ROMITA--Louis. Senior VP of Castle Oil Corp. Loving husband of Anne. Devoted father of Lisa, Louis, Lynda, and the late Mauro. Loving grandfather of Noa McRiley and Louis McRiley. Cherished brother of Michael, Mary Digirolamo, Jack and Mauro. Reposing at Farenga Brothers Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Ave., Bronx, NY. Visitation on Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 10am, at the Holy Family Chapel in the College of New Rochelle. The family has requested that donations be made to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, (www.stjude.org/donate, or 800-822-6344) in lieu of flowers.

To the Editor: In ''Clearing of Atlantic Yards' Site Proceeds as Legal Thicket Grows Denser'' (news article, April 5), I was described as ''a spokesman for Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn, which opposes the scale of the plan.''
An obituary by The Associated Press on Monday about the cartoonist Johnny Hart misidentified his hometown, where he died. It was Nineveh, N.Y., not Endicott, N.Y.

BUSCEMI--Jean, on April 10, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Anthony, loving mother of George and Diane, devoted grandmother of Alex and Zachary, cherished sister-inlaw of Frances Cataldo. Reposing at Andrew Torregrossa & Sons Funeral Home, 345 Avenue U, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30am at Our Lady of Grace R.C. Church. Interment Rosehill Memorial Park, Putnam, NY. Viewing Thursday 2-5pm and 7-10 pm.

A few months back, I wrote about the miracle that was Futurephone: a service that offered free unlimited overseas calls.
Clips from the 1900s: "Frankenstein" by J. Searle Dewley is an American film, and "Jim le Glisseur (Slippery Jim)" by Ferdinand Zecca comes from France.
The Times Magazine asked 10 artists to design 'green' flags to illustrate Thomas L. Friedman's cover story. Here's how origami artist Robert J. Lang created his flag.

If you've been watching any of the Mets' games on television this season, perhaps you've seen camera shots of players sitting in the dugout wearing wool winter caps with the team logo on them. At the start of the season, players and team personnel are given every article of clothing imaginable with the Mets' insignia: socks, pants, several different types of T-shirts, sweatshirts, hats, polo shirts, dress shirts, and the list goes on. For the most part, those cloths are useful year-round. But the winter caps?

Each development in the saga of the fired United States attorneys story digs deep battle lines within the political blogosphere. The revelations that Bush administration and Justice Department staffers discussed the issue on their Republican National Committee e-mail accounts and that those e-mails may have been deleted added fuel to an already burning fire. While conservative blogs have been quiet so far on the case of the missing emails, the left-leaning blogs dug right in.
Iran's decision to continue uranium enrichment has led some  countries to consider pursuing civilian nuclear technology.
The romance between Kimberly Young and Stefano Rivella began on the dance floor.

Felix Hernandez of the Seattle Mariners turned 21 years old last Sunday, but he has already won 20 games in the major leagues and has the kind of stuff that makes me think he might win about 180 more.
What is the most useful thing you learned in college?
Richard and Hartley Neel talk about the painter, Alice Neel, in her apartment on West 107th Street.
Alice Neel feeds pigeons from the window of her apartment, plus an excerpt from Michel Auder's video documentary "Portrait of Alice Neel 1976-1982."

Google reached an agreement Friday to acquire DoubleClick, the online advertising company, from two private equity firms for $3.1 billion in cash, the companies announced, an amount that was almost double the $1.65 billion in stock that Google paid for YouTube late last year.

Most Democratic primary voters are satisfied with the current field of candidates for their party's Presidential nomination, while their Republican counterparts wish they had more choices, according to the latest CBS News Poll.

Or maybe you are. Carl Pavano has been scratched from his start tomorrow. All I've heard so far is it's a sore arm. I expect we'll have a lot more details when the clubhouse opens here in Oakland in about five minutes.

Mitt Romney has just reported his first quarter fund-raising numbers to the Federal Election Commission, and, as predicted, even though he raised significantly more than Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Romney's higher spending rate puts them on almost equal footing in terms of available cash.

When Al Gore wanted, in the early days of the Clinton administration, to illustrate the complexity and inefficiency of government procurement regulations, he went on David Letterman's show, picked up a hammer, and smashed a glass ashtray.

An all-out war for ABN Amro may be under way. Three bidders -- the Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander Central Hispano and Fortis -- have sent a letter to the Dutch bank asking to engage in "exploratory talks," ABN Amro said in a statement Friday.

My research assistant, Winter Miller, steadily developed an interest in Darfur, and a year ago she persuaded me to let her accompany me on . In retrospect, I probably shouldn't have agreed, because we traversed a rather dangerous no-man's-land that the Janjaweed was pillaging. At one point, our vehicle got stuck, and a bunch of Janjaweed kids helped push us out of the sand -- but, fortunately, their dad wasn't around.

Formula One may have added one full hour to Friday practice sessions this year, and Bahrain may be the first race for the two main support series, GP2 and the Porsche Supercup, but the Bahrainis still saw fit to come up with ways to fill in the down moments of a race weekend for the spectators.
A clubhouse turns its achy legs to you?

In a development that is growing steadily less surprising, Reuters reported Friday that trading of call options in Sallie Mae jumped Thursday ahead of a report by The New York Times that the student lender may go private. But some analysts said that the trading, while unusual, did not necessarily signal insider trading.
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his Apr. 13 column, "For God's Sake."

While we're still stressing out over tax day, the campaigns have an even more complicated set of numbers to turn in on April 15 (no, there's no grace period for them). First-quarter reports are due to the Federal Election Commission on Sunday, and the campaign of Rudolph W. Giuliani just filed, a few days before the deadline. [Message from reporters: Thank you!]

Cott, the Canadian maker of private-label soft-drink brands for retailers such as Wal-Mart, said Friday that it is in talks with potential partners and is "exploring the potential benefits of participating in possible industry consolidation." Cott didn't name any of the potential partners, but the press release included a reference to Cadbury Schweppes, which last month announced plans to split its candy division from its drinks division. The Wall Street Journal reported Friday that Cott is negotiating with private equity firms about combining its operations with Cadbury's beverage arm. The report sent Cott's shares up nearly 30 percent.

Citigroup agreed to buy hedge fund Old Lane Partners as part of a deal that puts a former top executive at Morgan Stanley at the head of its alternative investments group. Citigroup, the global banking giant, has spent months courting the executive, Vikram Pandit, who left Morgan Stanley in 2005 after he was blocked for a chance at running the investment bank. Financial terms were not disclosed, but The New York Times reported Friday that the transaction was expected to cost $600 million to $800 million.

If nothing else, this will be good news for cabbies of Greenwich, Conn. The newspaper in that town is reporting that Goldman Sachs has taken over the Greenwich offices formerly occupied by Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund firm that collapsed last year after losing about $6.5 billion on bad bets on natural-gas futures.

Readers responded to my last post with lots of theories and personal reports on people's preferences in interracial dating. Also some complaints that I seemed to be asking for comments about only whites and blacks -- an impression I didn't mean to give. Researchers have been studying other races, too. They've found that theories and anecdotal evidence aren't a very reliable guide to these questions: some of the common stereotypes don't match the data.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was non-committal this morning when asked if he could guarantee that the on-again, off-again Second Avenue subway line would finally be built.
Keith McDonald underwent hip resurfacing surgery, a newer alternative to total hip replacement.

As some people fret about conspicuous consumption, high levels of consumer debt and the world's growing income gap, Merrill Lynch has come up with a way for investors to profit from these trends. The investment bank has introduced a Luxury and Lifestyle Index, which it described in a press release as the first "tradable certificate" that tracks shares of luxury goods companies, such as BMW, Bulgari, and Bang & Olufsen. Merrill's new index also includes some less-exclusive names such as Avon and The Gap.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wryly shrugged off the honor of being named America's best mayor by Reader's Digest in its May issue. In its "America's 100 Best" tributes, the magazine said Mayor Bloomberg has "championed a ban on smoking and trans fats in restaurants, pushed for bodegas to sell fresh produce and reduced-fat milk and luanched a diabetes registry, among the efforts."
Images of Jean Nouvel's Philharmonie de Paris.
As Nick mentioned earlier we're back in India. There were a trove of great stories from our last trip here in Jan. 2006. The best tales were about Indian women with exceptional courage.

Having finally found (and hired) an architect, Alison and I headed off down a long country road in Beaufort for a celebratory (and working) lunch at the Shrimp Shack, a wonderful dive by the bridge to Hunting Island.
A poem by Kurt Vonnegut.
Who is Donald Shoup?

To improve its bid for Australian retailer Coles Group, the consortium led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts may partner with a public company, Reuters reported Friday citing an unnamed source. Analysts have said that a rival A$19.7 billion ($16.4 billion) bid by Wesfarmers, one of the country's biggest conglomerates, is more attractive because it is in cash and stock.

Conservative blogger "Captain Ed" Morrissey acknowledges that the Bush administration has to turn over the mysterious missing e-mails that Karl Rove and others sent using addresses owned by the Republican National Committee: "Now they have to open those files for Congress' inspection in order to demonstrate that they have complied with the 1978 Presidential Records Act, a law that comes straight out of Watergate." But that doesn't mean he likes it. Morrissey writes:

Shares of Sallie Mae were up as much as 11 percent in early trading Friday as investors reacted to a report that the United States' largest lender to college students was in talks about a possible buyout. The New York Times said the negotiations for Sallie Mae, formally known as SLM Corporation, were at a late stage and named Blackstone Group as one of the potential bidders. Sallie Mae's stock surged $4.44 to $45.19 early Friday, giving the company a market capitalization of about $18.6 billion. Despite the rise, however, the shares are still well below their 52-week high of $55.21, which they reached in May 2006.

As expected, Lastings Milledge was sent down to Class AAA New Orleans after Thursday's game to make room for today's starter, Mike Pelfrey. And as we have come to expect from Milledge, who has handled everything thrown at him during his brief stay (except major-league pitching) with grace and professionalism, he was particularly thoughtful in discussing his feelings.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is set to unveil her plan to modernize the government today in New Hampshire. Here's what she told The Associated Press, which noticed parallels to former President Bill Clinton's "Reinventing Government" initiative:
Can I sublet my apartment for the market rate and pay a fee to the landlord?

Midwest Air's board has again rebuff AirTran's hostile offer for the airline. In a statement on Friday, the board said it recommends that the company's shareholders reject the discount airline's revised $15 a share tender offer, saying the new bid remains too low. Nearly two weeks ago, after AirTran raised its offer a third time, Midwest's board told shareholders that it would evaluate the new proposal.
Imagine if the opening act of the 2008 presidential campaign was being played out on Capitol Hill, where the majority of the candidates hold their day jobs.

Sallie Mae, the nation's largest lender to college students, is in talks to be bought out by private equity in what could be a deal for more than $20 billion. A buyout, if completed, would be an impressive show of muscle-flexing by private equity firms, which have grown emboldened over the last two years by acquiring ever larger targets. Shares of Sallie Mae, formally known as SLM Corporation, jumped more than 11 percent Friday in premarket trading.
Which Web sites do you trust most to find the cheapest airfare, and why?

The irony of Thursday's spectacle at Dow Chemical, which fired two senior executives for allegedly engaging in rogue negotiations to sell the company, is that it may have whetted investors' and suitors' appetite for a Dow takeover. "I find it interesting how private equity had penetrated the highest levels of the company," HSBC Securities analyst Hassan Ahmed told Bloomberg News. The announcement "is telling us that there are parties interested in making that bid." Shares of Dow rose 2 percent Thursday as some suggested that, while these talks appear to have been bungled, Dow could still make an attractive takeover target for Middle East investors or private equity firms. Breakingviews said this may be an example of "the wrong people doing the right thing."

HowStuffWorks, an informational Web site for the mechanically minded, said it closed a new $75 million funding round that included investors Capital Research & Management and Chilton Investment Company. Billionaire financier Carl Icahn also participated in the round, The Deal said.

Merrill Lynch may end up becoming a full partner in Tom Cruise's United Artists, according to The New York Post. The Post reports that negotiations between Merrill Lynch and UA over a $500 million film-financing package are being held up because the investment bank is having trouble finding a partner for the equity portion of the deal and the bank may end up putting up the cash itself.

People's United Financial, a commercial bank based in Bridgeport, Conn., said late Wednesday that it expects to raise $3.4 billion by selling stock in a second-step offering that fully converts the bank from a mutual holding company into a publicly traded company.
Not since the human animal made the evolutionary leap have standards of beauty changed so dramatically. Daphne Merkin on cyborg chic.

Morgan Stanley is buying 13 hotels from Japanese carrier All Nippon Airways for 281 billion yen ($2.4 billion), the airline said Friday, in a transaction that would roughly double the investment bank's portfolio of hotels in Japan. The deal, to be completed June 1, includes high-end hotels in Tokyo, the resort island of Okinawa as well as northern and southern Japan, ANA said in a statement.

A Manhattan judge has declined to dismiss fraud and breach of fiduciary duty allegations against John Thain, the chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange, by a former seatholder of the exchange. But the judge, Justice Charles E. Ramos, dismissed breach of fiduciary duty and negligent misrepresentation claims against the exchange itself in connection with its 2005 merger with Archipelago Holdings and its transformation from a not-for-profit to a public company.

As other investment banks jostle to grab stakes in hedge funds, Morgan Stanley, which has made five such investments in as many months, shows no signs of slowing down anytime soon. David Sidwell, chief financial officer of Morgan Stanley, said at the bank's annual shareholder meeting: "We will continue to grow asset management through acquisitions, minority stakes, team lift-outs and targeted external hiring and internal transfers."

USA Today publisher Gannett said Thursday it will sell four daily newspapers to GateHouse Media for $410 million. Gannett, the largest U.S. newspaper publisher, is selling the Norwich Bulletin in Connecticut, the Rockford Register Star in Illinois, the Observer-Dispatch in Utica, N.Y., and The Herald-Dispatch in Huntington, W.Va.

Monster Worldwide replaced its chief executive, William Pastore, with former Symbol Technologies Chief Sal Iannuzzi, a week after the jobs-site operator cut its sales forecast. Mr. Pastore, formerly Monster's chief operating officer, took the helm after Andrew McKelvey left in October amid an investigation into the company's options practices.

Reports that steel pipe maker Ipsco is in takeover talks with a Russian rival, Evraz Group, may spark a bidding war for the Canadian company, The Globe and Mail says. The newspaper reports that the company is planning to auction itself off and cites India's Jindal, U.S. Steel, Nucor and Brazil's Companhia Siderurgica Nacional as likely suitors.

Pactiv, maker of the Hefty brand line of plastic bags, said Thursday it has agreed to pay $1 billion to acquire closely held Prairie Packaging, a maker of disposable tableware. Prairie, with five U.S. manufacturing facilities, employs 1,200 people and is expected to generate revenue this year of about $500 million, Pactiv said.

Following The New York Times report this week that one of Canada's largest pension funds is in early talks with other pension funds and a private equity firm to form a consortium to mount a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, analysts and industry watchers are wondering if more such buyouts are in the offing.

Aramark, a Philadelphia food concessionaire for colleges, hospitals and stadiums, won a judge's approval yesterday for last year's settlement with shareholders over the company's $8.3 billion management buyout in January.
Boston Red Sox principal owner John Henry is making big bet on a small life-extension research start-up that is preparing for an initial public offering.
Favorite color: mauve. favorite author: Umberto Eco. Favorite food: meyer lemon sorbetto. Favorite magazine: T.
Ever since real estate mogul Samuel Zell won the auction for Tribune, speculation has been rampant on what he plans to do with the various pieces of the struggling media company.

MTM Technologies, an information technology provider, announced Thursday that it has received an additional $3.8 million of equity financing from its existing investors, Pequot Ventures and Constellation Ventures. The company also announced that Francis J. Alfano, the company's chief executive, would be departing in the near term.
In Creating a dazzling persona, Louise Nevelson fused her art and her life. Leslie Camhi wonders if an artist can still look like one.

A day after a report surfaced that the Jones Apparel Group was nearing a deal to sell Barneys New York to a private equity fund linked to the royal family of Qatar, a second report has emerged that says it is in fact Istithmar, a private equity firm owned by the Dubai government, that is in the lead to buy luxury department store.
Sanjay Kumar, the former chief executive of Computer Associates, has agreed to pay almost $800 million in restitution to investors who lost money because of the company's accounting fraud.

Jurors at the fraud trial of the toppled newspaper tycoon Conrad M. Black heard on Thursday that Hollinger executives relied on the advice of outside lawyers and accountants for how to account for the payments they made to themselves.
The car crash that seriously injured Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey. Account according to the New Jersey State Police

Jury deliberations began Thursday in the insider-trading trial of Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, after three weeks of testimony about what he might have known, and intended, when he sold $101 million worth of stock six years ago.

Citigroup is expected to announce a deal to buy Wall Street veteran Vikram Pandit's hedge fund Old Lane at its annual meeting Tuesday, according to The New York Times. The deal, which has been the subject of numerous reports this week, would put a former top executive at Morgan Stanley at the head of its alternative investments group, but it is also being suggested that it would give Citigroup chief Charles O. Prince III a viable successor.
This spring the fashion forward take their hues from nature.
Many cars today are being made with push-button starters, which have also become standard on hybrid-electric vehicles.
If you want to see the pretty lead actress, Kristanna Loken, cut up and otherwise abused by wounds she magically takes from others, SciFi’s new series is for you.
Hip resurfacing, an alternative surgery to total hip replacement, can offer an interim solution to many younger patients.
With her lustrous hair and cover-girl smile, Kelly Klein remains the all-American poster child.
Even after it lurches from the far-fetched into the preposterous, “Perfect Stranger” leaves a clammy residue of unease.
Things happen in “Private Fears in Public Places,” much as they do in life. But because this is an Alain Resnais film, things happen in near-geometric alignment.
“Lonely Hearts”  succeeds better than many crime dramas in balancing the philosophical with the visceral.
The overripe morsel who gets batted around in the Japanese absurdithon “The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai” looks like she was conjured up by a teenage boy in dangerous hormonal overdrive.
“Year of the Dog” is funny ha-ha but firmly in touch with its downer side, which means it’s also funny in a kind of existential way.
An e-mail released today contradicted testimony last month in which the attorney general’s aide said that no successors were considered before the attorneys were fired.
The coach of the Rutgers team said she hoped the controversy could serve as a “catalyst for change.”

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about possible plans by a Canadian pension fund to form a consortium and mount a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, misstated the legal status of a rival company, Telus. While Telus had announced plans to convert to an income trust, it abandoned the move because of changes in the law.
A group that includes Al Qaeda in Iraq today claimed responsibility for the attack on the Parliament building.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine remained on a ventilator today as he recovered from a car accident yesterday in which it appears he was not wearing a seat belt.
New evidence suggested that Paul D. Wolfowitz had not been entirely candid about his role in giving his girlfriend a raise and transfer.
Led by defenseman Brian Campbell’s two goals, the Sabres used their superior speed to earn an easy victory over the Islanders Thursday night.
The Nets followed a gutsy game with one in which they barely showed up as the Cavaliers put together an unstoppable third quarter to cruise to a victory.
The state education commissioner acknowledged that he had failed to notice that the troubled Roosevelt, N.Y., school district had been spending millions it did not have.

After weeks of internal squabbling, state workers approved a four-year contract on Thursday that will give them a 13 percent overall pay increase but will also require that they pay part of their health insurance premiums for the first time. The new contract affects about 43,000 state workers affiliated with the Communications Workers of America and will take effect on July 1. Workers will contribute an extra half of 1 percent of their salary to the state’s troubled pension fund, and the retirement age for new employees will be raised to 60 from 55. The contract ratification is a political victory for Gov. Jon S. Corzine, who has been outspoken about his desire to control spiraling pension and health care costs.
Tom Glavine lasted six innings against Philadelphia’s 44-year-old Jamie Moyer, earning career victory No. 292 in the Mets’ victory against the Phillies.
Zach Parise is the type of player a team can lean on, and he proved that Thursday night by scoring two goals to lead the Devils to a victory in the series opener.
The Rangers played like a playoff-tested team holding a two-goal lead until late in the game to win their first playoff game in almost 10 years.

Four NATO soldiers died in roadside bomb attacks within 24 hours, the military said. The nationalities of the soldiers were not disclosed. Two were killed Wednesday in southern Afghanistan, where mainly Canadian troops are based, and two were killed yesterday in eastern Afghanistan, where mostly American soldiers are deployed.

Reports from outside the country trying to account for the firing of Pak Pong-ju, who had been prime minister since 2003, by the Supreme People’s Assembly at its annual meeting this week and the decision to replace him with Land and Transport Minister Kim Yong-il differed. No official explanation was given, but some analysts in South Korea said Mr. Pak may have fallen afoul of the military, while others cited speculation of a corruption scandal. Others said he might have been removed for failing to move the destitute economy. Some analysts focused on the transport expertise of his successor, saying he could be given the task of pushing ahead with train links with the South to build up the economy.

Thailand deported a Swiss man after he was given a royal pardon from a 10-year prison sentence for defacing pictures of the king, officials said. Oliver Jufer, a longtime Thai resident, was sentenced two weeks ago after pleading guilty to lèse-majesté, or insulting the monarchy. On Dec. 5, King Bhumibol Adulyadej’s 79th birthday, surveillance cameras showed Mr. Jufer spraying paint over posters of the monarch in Chiang Mai, where he lived. He had been in prison since then. The rules protecting the revered king are so precise that Thai news media have been largely silent about Mr. Jufer’s case. It nonetheless shined a spotlight on the lèse-majesté laws. Last week, after a short, amateurish clip that ridiculed the king appeared on YouTube, a video-sharing Web site, Thailand blocked access to the site. That clip was removed, but dozens more quickly went up.

The police clashed with about 400 protesting Chinese merchants in Milan after scuffles broke out over traffic controls in the city’s busy Chinatown area. Officials said the protest started when the traffic police, who want to tighten control of commercial traffic in the area, took away the license of a driver because he was carrying merchant goods in a private car. The district is full of wholesale stores, and residents have repeatedly complained about the noise and traffic.

India successfully test fired its new Agni III missile, capable of carrying nuclear warheads across much of Asia and the Middle East, the Defense Ministry said. A test of the missile last July failed when it plunged into the Bay of Bengal short of its target. India’s missiles are mostly intended for confronting its neighbor, Pakistan. The Agni III is its longest-range missile, designed to reach 1,900 miles, putting China’s major cities well into range, as well as targets deep in the Middle East.

A woman died after her estranged husband hit her with an ax while handing her a bouquet of flowers at their divorce proceedings in a Baku court, officials said. The man had smuggled the ax into the courtroom for a hearing on how to divide the couple’s property.

Offering the first hint of a timetable for a return to democracy, Fakhruddin Ahmed, left, the head of the army-backed caretaker government, promised parliamentary elections before the end of 2008. “I would like to state here categorically that we shall not stay in office a single day more than is necessary,” he said in a televised broadcast. In January, after months of clashes between the country’s two main political parties, the government declared emergency rule and a Jan. 22 general election was canceled. Political activity has since been barred and members of both parties have been arrested on charges of graft.
The former chief executive of Computer Associates will pay $800 million to investors who lost money because of the company’s accounting fraud.

Protesters stoned to death two people of Asian origin during a demonstration in the capital, Kampala, against a Ugandan-Asian company that wants to use 17,000 acres of the Mabira Forest Reserve to expand its sugar plantation, the police said. The protesters also vandalized a Hindu temple in the city, but they were repelled by the police.
Citigroup is close to buying a hedge fund as part of a deal that would put a former top executive at Morgan Stanley at the head of its alternative investments group.
Libyan and Eritrean military and security observers have been sent to the border between Sudan and Chad, the scene of recent clashes.

An article on Tuesday about the high salaries of Singapore government officials misstated the given name of a prominent writer who suggested in an essay that comparability with the private sector should not be the only consideration in setting government salaries. She is Catherine Lim, not Carolyn.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about possible plans by a Canadian pension fund to form a consortium and mount a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, misstated the legal status of a rival company, Telus. While Telus had announced plans to convert to an income trust, it abandoned the move because of changes in the law.

Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about the Seattle Mariners’ 3-0 victory against the Boston Red Sox referred incorrectly in some copies to the pitching performance by Félix Hernández of the Mariners. He took a no-hitter into the eighth inning — not a one-hitter, which was how he finished.
An article in some copies on Sunday about the discovery of a woman’s body under a bridge in a Bronx park misstated the name of the park. It is Frank S. Hackett Park, not Frank Shackett.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Bush administration’s acknowledgment that it froze $25 million in a Macao bank as a bargaining chip in negotiations with North Korea over its nuclear program described the frozen money incorrectly. It was distributed over 52 accounts of individuals or firms, including 17 with ties to North Korea. It was not in a single account.

A sports article on Saturday about the second round of the Masters referred imprecisely to the scoring for Phil Mickelson on hole No. 11, where he hit a ball into the trees. Mickelson took a free drop — not a penalty drop requiring an extra stroke — because there were cables and pipes in the way. (As the article noted, he did make a bogey on the hole.).

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a study showing that New York’s 950,000 buildings are responsible for a vast majority of the city’s carbon dioxide emissions referred incorrectly to those emissions. According to the city’s Office of Long-Term Planning and Sustainability, the volume of greenhouse gases produced citywide is rising — not being cut — each year.
Corrections: For the Record

A front-page article yesterday about the military’s decision to prolong combat tours for most active-duty Army units in Iraq and Afghanistan misstated at one point the duration of the extended tours. They will last 15 months, not 18.

A sports article on Tuesday about professional football prospects from Hampton University referred imprecisely to the university’s location. It is on the peninsula of the Hampton Roads region in southeastern Virginia; it is not on the state’s Eastern Shore.
college football.

William R. Phillips, a former New York police officer who was a star witness for a commission investigating police corruption in the 1970s, has spent the last 32 years in prison for murdering a prostitute and her pimp.
Democrats have seized on the announcement of troop extensions as evidence that the president and his inner circle are in denial about what is going on in Iraq.
Most active duty units in Iraq and Afghanistan will serve for 15 months, rather than 12.
An attack on Parliament was the worst in the International Zone since it was created four years ago.
The Sarafiya bridge, which tied Baghdad together literally and metaphorically, was destroyed by a truck bomb on Thursday.
Paul D. Wolfowitz apologized for his role in the raise and transfer of his companion, but was greeted by booing.
Pakistan’s generals are claiming initial success in their latest efforts to combat foreign militants and regain some control in tribal areas bordering Afghanistan.
CBS yielded to pressure when it canceled “Imus in the Morning,” ending a program that had been broadcasting for more than 30 years.
Since 1991, nail-gun injuries have risen about 200 percent, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports.
A plan to bolster port security with identification cards for 750,000 workers may miss a July 1 deadline at the 10 highest-risk sites, a Senate panel was told.

A judge in Centerville sentenced each of three former college students to two years in state prison for a series of fires at rural churches, adding to punishment they had received in federal court. The men, Matthew L. Cloyd, 21, and Benjamin N. Moseley and Russell L. DeBusk Jr., both 20, admitted setting the fires in Bibb County last year. They pleaded guilty to arson and burglary charges, and Mr. Moseley also pleaded guilty to animal cruelty for shooting a cow during what they have described as a night of drunken joy riding 45 miles south of Birmingham.

The Mississippi Supreme Court upheld the manslaughter convictions of Edgar Ray Killen, left, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, in the killing of three civil rights workers in 1964. Mr. Killen, 82, was convicted in June 2005 in the deaths of the workers, James Chaney, Andrew Goodman and Michael Schwerner. He was sentenced to three consecutive 20-year prison terms. In his appeal, Mr. Killen had argued that in the 1960s he would not have been convicted by a jury of his peers of any crime under the evidence presented in 2005.
What began as a falling-out between the owner of an Italian restaurant in Brooklyn and its chef has moved from the kitchen to the courthouse

Gov. Kathleen Sebelius signed into law a measure forcing an antigay pastor and his followers to keep their distance when protesting military funerals, but the church claims the new rules will have no effect on its demonstrations. Members of the Westboro Baptist Church, based in Topeka and led by the Rev. Fred Phelps, have picketed burials around the country of American troops killed in combat, claiming their deaths are God’s punishment for a nation harboring homosexuals. The law says protesters cannot be within 150 feet of a funeral one hour before the service, during it or two hours after it. The law will not take effect until the Kansas Supreme Court or a federal court upholds it as constitutional.

Four additional counts of child molesting were filed against a former head of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, who is accused of sexually abusing patients. A prosecutor said two new victims had come forward accusing the psychiatrist, Dr. William Ayres, 75, of molesting them each twice in 1991 or 1992. The boys were ages 9 to 12 when the assaults occurred, the prosecutor, Melissa McKowan of San Mateo County, said. Dr. Ayres faces 18 counts involving five victims.
A television report on Thursday reported that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel was able to respond to various questions with a slight tightening of his hand.
Italy’s government proposed international standards for confronting the rising number of high-profile kidnappings in war zones.
The filings regarding the stock holdings of an Education Department official raise questions about whether the department had reviewed his ownership in a student loan company.

TRENTON, April 12 — After weeks of internal squabbling, state workers approved a four-year contract on Thursday that would give them a 13 percent overall pay increase but would also require them to pay a portion of health insurance premiums for the first time.
Democrats stepped up their inquiry into officials’ use of Republican National Committee e-mail accounts.
Products like Mike’s Hard Lemonade, Bacardi Silver and Zima have become popular with young drinkers, health researchers say.

The City Council passed a bill yesterday extending death benefits to family members of sanitation and correction workers killed in the line of duty. The bill is expected to be signed by the mayor and would go into effect immediately with a retroactive date of September 2005. Sanitation Department officials say that that date would cover claims by the survivors of two sanitation workers and a supervisor who have died since 2005, two from heart attacks and one in a work accident. Survivors of firefighters and police officers killed in the line of duty already receive health care coverage. But the city must now act on a case-by-case basis to provide those same benefits to survivors of sanitation and correction workers, a process that could take months.

New Jersey has agreed to pay $485,000 to settle a claim by a former director of the State Parole Board who accused state officials of retaliating against him for questioning the release of a prisoner suspected of involvement in organized crime. The payment to the former director, Kenneth Connolly, was announced yesterday as a jury in State Superior Court in Mercer County was about to hear opening arguments in his whistle-blower lawsuit against the state, The Star-Ledger reported. The case stemmed from the 2002 release of Angelo Prisco, said to be a captain in the Genovese crime family. Mr. Connolly said he was transferred and demoted after charging that an aide to James E. McGreevey, the governor at the time, had intervened in Mr. Prisco’s release. Federal and state officials investigated the parole and found no wrongdoing.

A bill that would make Connecticut the second state in the nation to allow gay couples to marry passed its first legislative hurdle yesterday. The Judiciary Committee, a joint committee of the House and Senate, voted 26 to 15 to approve the measure, which now goes to the full House, where its prospects are uncertain. If approved, it would move to the Senate for consideration. Two years ago, Connecticut approved civil unions for gay and lesbian couples, granting them all of the rights and privileges that the state accords to married couples. Advocates for gay rights have called on the legislature to take the final step in the process and allow gay couples to marry. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A Queens man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 25 years to life in prison for fatally shooting a city worker in 2002, prosecutors said. The man, Taiquan Williams, 25, of Jamaica, was convicted last month of second-degree murder for shooting Eugene McMahon, an employee of the Department of Environmental Protection, as he sat in his department car in Flushing, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. McMahon, 46, was supervising a repair when Mr. Williams shot him in the head and stole his wallet.

An advocacy group yesterday asked the State Supreme Court to force New Jersey to allocate money to build new schools and repair old ones in some of the state’s poorest cities. The motion, filed by the Education Law Center, seeks to force the state to authorize more spending by June 30. Troubles in the state’s school construction program have delayed many projects, including a number in poor cities. Yesterday, Scott Weiner, chief executive of the State Schools Construction Corporation, said Gov. Jon S. Corzine was working with lawmakers to find a source for money to keep the school construction program moving forward.

A Bronx woman was indicted yesterday on a charge of second-degree murder in connection with the death of her 2-week-old son on Dec. 31, prosecutors said. The woman, Lucila Rojas, 25, is charged with placing a blanket over the face of her son, Anthony, preventing him from breathing, then leaving him in a trash bin in Jackson Heights, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. At first she told the police that someone had taken the boy from her at gunpoint, but later confessed to investigators, Mr. Brown said. Ms. Rojas has pleaded not guilty, a spokesman for Mr. Brown said.

The former president of the board of the Co-op City housing complex was charged yesterday with participating in a bribery scheme related to a $3.5 million painting contract, federal prosecutors said. The former president, Iris Herskowitz Baez, 59, was charged in Federal District Court with bribery and conspiracy, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Ms. Baez served as president and then secretary to the board from 2000 to 2003, prosecutors said. She has pleaded not guilty.

A State Supreme Court justice declined yesterday to take any action on a lawsuit to remove Dr. Mathieu Eugene from the ballot in a special election for the 40th Council District in Brooklyn. The ruling means that Dr. Eugene is one of two candidates who will remain on the ballot for the election, which is set for April 24. Dr. Eugene won a special election for the seat in February, but he declined to take the seat after the City Council asked for information verifying that he lived within the 40th District, which includes Crown Heights and Flatbush. A second special election was scheduled, and Dr. Eugene said he would be a candidate. John Ravitz, executive director of the New York City Board of Elections, said yesterday that only Dr. Eugene and Harry L. Schiffman, the director of government and community relations at Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center, remained on the ballot.

The New York City Council passed a bill yesterday enhancing whistle-blower laws to protect city employees who report conduct that is harmful to the health, safety or educational welfare of a child. Councilman Robert Jackson said the bill was aimed at protecting teachers from coercion to inflate test scores and those who report the failure of a school to follow through on federally mandated individual education plans for students with special needs. But some critics, including the mayor, say the bill would provide teachers facing poor performance reviews a tool to use against superiors. City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn rejected that notion yesterday, saying it would not hamper efforts to bring more accountability to schools. The Departments of Education and Investigation oppose the bill, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has signaled that he would veto it.

New emergency sirens around the Indian Point nuclear power plant, right, failed their latest test yesterday, with only 79 percent sounding an alarm, plant officials said. Engineers were scrambling to solve the problems before Sunday’s deadline. Installation of the new system was required by Congress. Of the 150 new sirens, 31 failed to sound, officials said. That success rate was below the 90 percent the Nuclear Regulatory Commission requires. An older siren system remains in place and could be used if needed. The sirens are meant to warn people within 10 miles of danger.
The American justice system views recantations as untrustworthy, acts not of conscience, but of sympathy.
A chess star at a Brooklyn high school skips a lot of school — but he is no ordinary truant.
Federal prosecutors in Columbus, Ohio, said the suspect, Christopher Paul, 43, began supporting terrorists in the United States, Africa and Europe in 1989.
Walter C. Cathie’s roles as university official and entrepreneur have made him an example of how administrators have become cozy with lenders.
American science needs to be freed from the shackles imposed by the Bush administration.
Defense ministers from NATO nations and other allies agreed to press for a new deployment of 3,400 trainers for the Afghan police and armed forces.
Mia Farrow and Steven Spielberg are involved in an effort to pressure China to stop protecting Sudan’s government.
The president of a bodega association plans to train other owners on how to deal with robberies and other crime.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine was on his way to a meeting between the Rutgers women’s basketball team and Don Imus.
Investigations produced evidence that Chinese criminal gangs had smuggled counterfeit currency, cigarettes and drugs made in North Korea into the United States.
It’s odd that Turkish leaders have not figured out by now that every time they try to censor discussion of the Armenian genocide, they only link today’s democratic Turkey with the now distant crime.
After about five hours, the jurors ceased deliberations and will resume on Friday.
Nielsen will release national ratings for TV viewing away from home in places like bars, hotels, gyms and offices.
Despite a rash of muscle-related injuries to five players in the past four weeks, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman is standing by the team’s revamped strength and conditioning program.
The nation’s largest lender to college students is in talks to be taken private in what could be a $20 billion deal.
An F.D.A. official said that they know they have not gotten 100 percent of the product out of the stores.
The head of Turkey’s armed forces said publicly on Thursday that he was prepared to conduct operations in northern Iraq to crush Kurdish rebels hiding there.
It is past time for the White House to provide America’s soldiers the care they are owed.
Dignitaries were among the 3,000 mourners who gathered Thursday in Pottstown, Pa., to bury Barry Lee Bush, the F.B.I. agent who was killed last week in New Jersey.
The time to read Vonnegut is just when you begin to suspect that the world is not what it appears to be.
A minister’s wife accused of killing her husband had become caught up in a swindle known as the Nigerian scam and was afraid her husband would find out, a prosecutor said.
An experiment hopes to pump life into the Chesapeake Bay by getting dairy farmers to apply for pollution credits that can be sold to developers.
Defense attorneys say an outside lawyer suggested that specific payments not be disclosed.
An unexpected increase in unemployment claims suggests economic weakness, while rising import prices hints at more inflation.
Edgar B. Young was the behind-the-scenes administrator who smoothed the way for the construction of Lincoln Center in the 1960s.

The Rent Guidelines Board, embarking once again upon the annual drama of deciding the size of the allowable rent increases for rent-stabilized apartments, reviewed yesterday a hodgepodge of statistics — some of them contradictory — intended to shed light on how much New Yorkers can afford to pay.
The Washington Nationals, with the third-lowest payroll in the major leagues, have started the season 2-8. But with a new stadium on the way, there are signs of hope for the future.
The world’s biggest food and drink company will have the largest share of the world’s baby food market.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled a campaign to pressure Congress to allow cities to share information about the source of guns used in crimes.
After meeting soldiers who had served in Iraq, Nets players witnessed things that touched them, made them think and, for Vince Carter, made the pain in his knees go away.
The students’ families are seeking Michael B. Nifong’s ouster and considering suing him for damages.
Lorena Ochoa shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to tie Laura Davies for the first-round lead in the Ginn Open at Reunion, Fla.
Opening statements are expected at the trial of one of the accused in the infamous Brown’s Chicken Massacre.
Dakota Staton was a highly respected jazz and blues singer known from the 1950s on for her bright, trumpetlike sound and tough, sassy style.
Don Imus never caught a breath because he was in the gunsights of a 24-hour news cycle.
Because of the lack of regular reviews, regulators cannot accurately keep track of the substantial amount of pollutants that are allowed to enter the state’s waters.
William M. Pastore will be succeeded by Salvatore Iannuzzi, who has served as chairman of the board’s executive committee since October.
Quality issues will delay the release, an uncharacteristic schedule slippage that is particularly embarrassing for Apple.
They were charged with beating two inmates, one so badly, officials said, that a pool of his blood lay on the cell floor.

After an exacting review that lasted several years, federal environmental officials have concluded that New York City’s upstate water supply is still so clean that it does not need to be filtered for another decade or longer.
Politicians and dignitaries gathered Thursday at the latest groundbreaking for the on-again-off-again Second Avenue subway.
Mr. Pyne helped Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller mold New York’s suburban transit system from a tangle of decrepit railroad lines.
Thomas M. Coughlin was back in court as an appellate court took up a prosecutor’s plea that Mr. Coughlin’s sentence was too light.
The Chinese prime minister said that his three-day visit to Japan was meant to “melt the ice” in the relations between the countries.
Analysis of proteins from Tyrannosaurus rex uncovered new evidence of a link between dinosaurs and birds, researchers said.
Valtteri Filppula and Nicklas Lidstrom scored in the first period, helping Detroit get started in a 4-1 victory over visiting Calgary in Game 1 of their first-round playoff series.
A Syrian-American's visit to Israel opened a new level of debate about the possibility of negotiations with the Syrian president.
Questions are being raised about whether civil unions for same-sex couples adequately fulfill the promise of the State Supreme Court ruling that led to the arrangements.
With one more loss or one victory by the Orlando Magic, the Knicks will officially be out of the playoff race. Their next game is Friday night against the Nets.
Henrik Sedin scored with 1 minute 54 seconds left in the fourth overtime to lift the Canucks to a 5-4 victory over the Dallas Stars on Wednesday night.
The acquisition of the Brooks and Eckert drugstore chains could be completed by the end of May.
The agency expressed concerns that Arcoxia could cause as many as 30,000 heart attacks annually if widely used.
Ronnie Belliard hit a go-ahead single in the eighth inning off John Smoltz, and the visiting Washington Nationals defeated the Atlanta Braves, 2-0, last night to stop a six-game losing streak.
The biotechnology, under pressure from investors to sell itself, could bring $45 to $50 a share.
ASIA.
The home furnishings retailer will close 60 stores as sales drop off.
Annika Sorenstam was supplanted in 2006 as player of the year by Lorena Ochoa, who can remove Sorenstam from the No. 1 ranking with a victory at the Ginn Open this week.
David B. Dahlstrom has had difficulty getting credit and at one point was detained by police officers as the result of having his identity stolen in 1990.
Oliver Pérez said he felt something wrong with his mechanics Wednesday, specifically that he was not bringing his knee up to his chest as he prepared to pitch.
A Federal Trade Commission report found that online promotions and a proliferation of unrated DVDs have eroded the entertainment industry’s promise not to entice youth with violent fare.
The Beatles are among the last big holdouts from digital music services like iTunes from Apple Inc.
The government estimates that 60 percent of New Delhi’s inhabitants live in slums, unauthorized developments or unplanned and unsafe buildings - a planner’s nightmare.
American officials said that they were working for the release of Amir Mohamed Meshal, an American who had been jailed in Ethiopia on suspicion of terrorist activities.
Rising gasoline prices, a rougher housing market and the possibility of higher interest rates are likely to make the retail business even tougher.
The rates of drug-resistant gonorrhea in the United States have increased greatly in the last five years.
Stocks resumed their advance as investors looked past higher oil prices and a somewhat cloudy picture for retail sales.
People.
SHOPPING.
Venture capitalists face a question: Is private equity becoming too public for its own good?
With no heir apparent, several little-known candidates have emerged as serious contenders for George Steinbrenner’s Yankee throne.
Our nation, historically bursting with generosity toward strangers, remains remarkably unkind toward its own.
Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, North Africa’s most active terrorist group, claimed responsibility for the twin bombings, which killed 33 and wounded more than 200.
With economic growth running at an annual pace of more than 8 percent, the attraction of investing in India is obvious.

An 18-year-old freshman is the star and producer of a benefit concert at the American Airlines Theater on Monday.
A sampling of current shows in Chelsea’s big-box galleries offers a map to some of the ways artists use space in, and also around, art these days.
Nominations for the second Man Booker International Prize announced, National Symphony Orchestra selects interim conductor and more culture news.
A musician’s musician offers a new piece for his famous fans at Carnegie Hall on Saturday.
Since not one soul in this revival has a flicker of Christopher Plummer’s fire, this play is not the crackling courtroom drama it was intended to be.
At Juilliard’s annual three-day festival, the electronic and interactive music was far superior to the video elements provided.

The dancers provided a high-energy, emotive presentation, but sadly, the choreographers didn’t draw anything unexpected from them at the opening of the company’s new headquarters on Wednesday.

9:30 P.M. (IFC) HENRY ROLLINS: UNCUT FROM ISRAEL Mr. Rollins, left, unfurls his biting tongue in a new season of raw talk, starting with this 90-minute special that weaves a spoken-word show in Tel Aviv with film from a journey around the Holy Land. Returning to Israel for the first time in 10 years Mr. Rollins gets a personalized tour from Ziv Korren, a photojournalist, with stops at the Western Wall, the Church of the Holy Sepulcher and the West Bank security wall, punctuated of course by Mr. Rollins’s commentary on pop culture, world events and the resilience of the Israeli people. (Working with the U.S.O. he has already let loose in Afghanistan, Djibouti, Egypt, Honduras, Iraq, Kuwait, Qatar, South Korea and Turkey.) At 11 p.m. “The Henry Rollins Show” moves into position with Marilyn Manson, discussing his new album, “Eat Me, Drink Me,” and Peaches as the musical guest. Janeane Garofalo joins the show full time with “The Disquisition,” a commentary segment filmed in her New York apartment.
The Metropolitan Museum’s expeditionary think-piece of a show pushes our knowledge of Chinese art forward with its use of themes and combination of old and new works.
The decision to broadcast “Operation Homecoming” unfiltered comes at a time when many stations have chosen to be overly cautious to avoid tangling with the F.C.C. on indecency issues.
Mr. Schiff addressed Beethoven’s music with assertiveness and clarity of detail, and Mr. Perenyi, by contrast, produced a modest sound at the 92nd Street Y on Wednesday.
Shrugging off the recent rise in the euro, the bank’s president said inflation would be monitored very closely — a phrase interpreted by financial markets to mean a rate increase in two months.
Wednesday’s staging of “La Traviata” failed in transcending the ordinary due to a  lack of chemistry between the performers.

Gino Dilorio’s brave drama may leave you questioning some of the playwright’s choices, but you’ll also leave knowing you have just seen two exceptional examples of naturalistic acting by the women in the cast.
The company will measure viewing habits using cellphone tracking devices that recognize the sound of TV.
Large views of Earth’s planetary neighbors can now be seen in a stunning set of photographs at the American Museum of Natural History.
James Ensor at Peter Freeman Inc., Philip Pearlstein at Betty Cuningham Gallery, “Across the Trees” at David Nolan Gallery and more.
Deborah Rodriguez tells the rollicking story of one of the strangest foreign-aid projects ever conceived, the creation of an academy to train Afghan beauticians.
The Morgan Library & Museum has acquired 67 portraits of artists, writers and musicians, by Irving Penn, taken from 1944 to 2006.
FOR CHILDREN.
Two Russian art sales at Sotheby’s and Christie’s feature works by Fabergé, including a rare enameled miniature chair that is estimated to sell for $1 million to $1.5 million.
For many, fractional ownership offers an opportunity to buy at least a bit of a high-end vacation home.

The deal fits with Nestlé’s focus on wellness and Novartis’s strategy of selling its noncore businesses.
A management reshuffling would make James Press, the director of North American operations, the highest ranking non-Japanese in the company’s history.
JAZZ.
POP.
Until recently, “boutique hotel” and “Jersey Shore” were two phrases rarely heard in the same sentence. But some hotels here have recently transformed themselves.
Selected dance events this week from dance critics of The New York Times.
Calistoga attracts visitors who want to soak in its natural hot springs or just enjoy one of the wine country's most laid-back areas.
A residential project in Marathon, Fla., and a resort community expansion in Mexico.
“I’ve been a fisherman for 25 years and everyone in my immediate family owns waders.”
More than 200 players will wear Jackie Robinson’s No. 42 on Sunday, a tribute that grew spontaneously from a request by one player and now seems to be growing by the day.
It appears that the company grew paranoid about its critics, and created a security operation that went too far.
Micheal Ray Richardson was a gifted athlete who snorted away his N.B.A. career. Now his C.B.A. coaching career has been derailed after making insensitive comments to a fan.
Boxing may fade from the sports consciousness for long stretches, but thanks to heavy marketing, it will be tough to ignore the May 5 fight between Oscar De La Hoya and Floyd Mayweather Jr.
When Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey was injured in a car accident Thursday, he was doing what most New Jersey governors do: spending a lot of time on the road.
Two senior executives were fired for holding a series of secret meetings about selling the company in a leveraged buyout.
There was a groundbreaking for the Second Avenue subway. It doesn’t get more miraculous than that.
A small town in eastern Germany showcases the strengths of a resurgent economy.

An article on last Friday about retirement communities for people with shared interests misstated the location of Rocinante, a community of aging hippies. As noted correctly in the picture caption, it is in Summertown, Tenn., not Summerville.

The Ahead column last Friday about the Tour de Georgia bicycle race misstated the status of cars in Peachtree City, a community on the bike race route. The city, a planned community where many residents drive golf carts on 85 miles of multiuse paths, also allows cars; they are not banned.
On Nevada’s Extraterrestrial Highway, reported alien sightings create mystery in a place of top-secret bases and unmarked military land.
Mexican-style celebrations from Wisconsin to California.

THESE new hotels on the Jersey Shore are open year-round, with rates varying by season and room; two- or three-night stays are sometimes required. All the marble, glass, silk and leather in the interior design makes them less than child-friendly — but they’re not intended to be.
There’s music to listen to, trails to stroll, chocolates to eat and a fiberglass cow to milk.
Standup paddling, with a big oar and on a huge board, can put you way out with the big waves.
Readers respond to recent articles in the Escapes section.
The infiltration of the federal government by large numbers of people seeking to impose a religious agenda  is one of the most important stories of the last six years.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Bush administration's acknowledgment that it froze $25 million in a Macao bank as a bargaining chip in negotiations with North Korea over its nuclear program described the frozen money incorrectly. It was distributed over 52 accounts of individuals or firms, including 17 with ties to North Korea. It was not in a single account.

SHORE--George, on April 10, 2007. Beloved husband of Florence, devoted father of Scott, cherished son of Samuel and Becky Schorr. Graveside service will be held Friday, 12:30pm at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn LI.

The Durham County district attorney apologized Thursday to the three former Duke University lacrosse players he had charged with sexually assaulting a stripper. ''To the extent that I made judgments that ultimately proved to be incorrect, I apologize to the three students that were wrongly accused,'' the district attorney, Michael B. Nifong, wrote in a three-paragraph statement a day after the state attorney general, Roy A. Cooper, dismissed all the charges and called him a ''rogue'' prosecutor.

VONNEGUT--Kurt. The Principals and staff of Wohl, Fried, Roth & Kirchenberg, C.P.A.'s extend our deepest sympathy to the family of Kurt Vonnegut. We were privileged not only to represent him, but to know him as a friend. He was a legend and will be sorely missed by all who came to appreciate his talent and wit, whether by reading his works or by knowing him through the twinkle in his eyes. $(6$)VONNEGUT--Kurt. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. His loss will be deeply felt.

SHATTEN--Michael Lee, retired General Attorney of Ohio Bell, formerly of Cleveland, OH, died Sunday, April 1, 2007, in Atlanta, GA, at age 88. His career with the Bell System spanned 45 years. He proudly served as a USAF Captain during WWII. Above all, he was devoted to his family. His beloved wife, Arlene Baldwin, whom he wed in 1943, predeceased him in 2000. He is survived by daughter, Jane Flowerree, and granddaughters, Laura and Christine. Cremation Society of the SOUTH, 770-420-5557.

''Red Road,'' the arresting first feature by Andrea Arnold (who won a best-short-film Oscar for ''Wasp'') takes place in a world where the daily activities of citizens are subject to constant surveillance. That is, it takes place in an ordinary city -- Glasgow, as it happens -- at the present time. The dire Orwellian warning that Big Brother is watching has evolved from a grim fantasy of totalitarianism into a banal fact of life, in democratic as well as in authoritarian societies. The security cameras fastened on lampposts and the sides of buildings, after all, are put there with our safety in mind, and we have learned to view them with more reassurance than alarm when we notice them at all. It is fitting, then, that Ms. Arnold's interest in the phenomenon of surveillance is less political than psychological. At the center of her film is Jackie (Kate Dickie), who works in a police observation center called City Eye where she sits in front of a wall of video monitors, punching a keyboard and toggling a joystick to pan and zoom across a disjointed panorama of urban life. Jackie is like a moviegoer and, given her ability to edit and refine the images she collects, like a filmmaker as well. Right from the start, then, the director, the heroine and the audience are all implicated in a queasy, curious game of intimate spying.

Offering the first hint of a timetable for a return to democracy, Fakhruddin Ahmed, left, the head of the army-backed caretaker government, promised parliamentary elections before the end of 2008. ''I would like to state here categorically that we shall not stay in office a single day more than is necessary,'' he said in a televised broadcast. In January, after months of clashes between the country's two main political parties, the government declared emergency rule and a Jan. 22 general election was canceled. Political activity has since been barred and members of both parties have been arrested on charges of graft. JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

Paula Cooper Gallery 534 West 21st Street, Chelsea Through April 28 Writing about abstract painting is like trying to slice an atom: with 50-plus years of history, differences among artists can be hard to describe. Julian Lethbridge keeps the dialogue fresh, all the while reminding viewers of the pleasure to be derived from looking at paint on canvas.
