A Queens man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 25 years to life in prison for fatally shooting a city worker in 2002, prosecutors said. The man, Taiquan Williams, 25, of Jamaica, was convicted last month of second-degree murder for shooting Eugene McMahon, an employee of the Department of Environmental Protection, as he sat in his department car in Flushing, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. McMahon, 46, was supervising a repair when Mr. Williams shot him in the head and stole his wallet.

Betty Cuningham Gallery 541 West 25th Street, Chelsea Through April 28 Anybody who brings the level of patience and single-minded devotion that Philip Pearlstein has applied for nearly 50 years to his paintings of nudes can only be said to be in a state akin to rapture. That's not the initial conclusion to draw from the pictures, whose deadpan manner has long been a problem for many people. They miss the point.

SAUL--Joseph E. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of the Jewish Home & Hospital Lifecare System extends its deepest sympathies to trustee Andrew Saul, Life Trustee Norma Saul and the entire family on the passing of their beloved father and husband, Joseph. Joseph's personal commitment to Alzheimer's Disease led to the founding support for the System's nationally recognized Norma & Joseph Saul Alzheimer's Disease Special Care Unit. His and Norma's generosity has greatly enhanced the quality of life of our residents with Alzheimer's Disease and supports research in the field. We are grateful to this involved, caring family for the many contributions they have made to our System over the years. Our thoughts will be with Andrew and Norma during their time of loss. Gene D. Resnick, M.D., Chairman of the Board Audrey Weiner, DSW, President & CEO $(6$)SAUL--Joseph. Diana and Larry Robbins express their heartfelt sympathy to the family of Joseph Saul. A warm and unusual man who will be sorely missed by all who knew him. $(6$)SAUL--Joseph E. The Board and staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and the Israel Museum, are saddened by the death of our longtime friend and supporter, Joseph E. Saul. We offer heartfelt condolences to Norma, Andrew and Denise and the entire family. Stephen S. Lash President, AFIM James S. Snyder Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir., Israel Museum $(6$)SAUL--Joseph E., 1919-2007. Loving husband of Norma for 67 years. Fabulous father of Andrew and Jane Berkey, father-in-law of Denise. Loving grandfather of Kim and Aaron, Jennifer and Rob. Great-grandfather of William and Caroline. A true gentlemen and outstanding person. Services will be private. $(6$)SAUL--Joseph E. Good Friend for over 50 years. He fought a long and valiant battle. An outstanding businessman and philanthropist, he had a wry sense of humor. Our personal memories include an image of him and Norma sailing in all weather conditions. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Debby and Frank Morgenstern $(6$)SAUL--Joseph. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Joseph Saul, a compassionate leader and esteemed friend whose lifetime of service included an unwavering commitment to the Jewish community and deep support of Israel, particularly focusing on children. Joe enriched millions of lives worldwide through his boundless generosity and dedication. Among his many roles at UJA-Federation, Joe served as a member and vice chairman of our Board of Directors. Joe's legacy is continued through his family's generosity, which profoundly impacts the most vulnerable, and strengthens Jewish life and learning in New York, in Israel, and worldwide. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Joe's beloved wife, Norma; to his children; Andrew and Denise, and Jane Berkey, to his grandchildren; Jennifer and Robert, and Kimberly; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

Kurt Vonnegut, whose dark comic talent and urgent moral vision in novels like ''Slaughterhouse-Five,'' ''Cat's Cradle'' and ''God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater'' caught the temper of his times and the imagination of a generation, died Wednesday night in Manhattan. He was 84 and had homes in Manhattan and in Sagaponack on Long Island. His death was announced by his wife, the author and photographer Jill Krementz, who said he had been hospitalized after suffering irreversible brain injuries as a result of a fall several weeks ago.

Nominations for Man Booker International Prize Fifteen authors were named yesterday to the judges' list of contenders for the second Man Booker International Prize. The $118,655 prize, awarded every two years, recognizes a living writer for achievement in fiction published either originally in English or generally available in English. The writers on the list are Chinua Achebe of Nigeria, Margaret Atwood of Canada, John Banville of Ireland, Peter Carey of Australia, Don DeLillo of the United States, Carlos Fuentes of Mexico, Doris Lessing of Britain, Ian McEwan of Britain, Harry Mulisch of the Netherlands, Alice Munro of Canada, Michael Ondaatje of Canada, Amos Oz of Israel, Philip Roth of the United States, Salman Rushdie of Britain and Michel Tournier of France. The winner will be announced in early June. Wordsworth Goes Hip-Hop William Wordsworth has been dead since 1850, but that dude could rap. And to mark the bicentenary of the publication of his poem ''Daffodils'' (''I wander'd lonely as a cloud''), the Cumbria tourist board in England has enlisted modern technology in the form of a pop video and rap version of his poem to peddle the virtues of the Lake District, The Guardian of London reported. Oh, and let's not forget MC Nuts, the zany red squirrel, right, that delivers the rap against scenic backgrounds to convey the idea that it's hip for young people to visit the Lake District National Park this summer. ''Wordsworth's 'Daffodils' poem has remained unchanged for 200 years,'' said a spokeswoman for the tourist board. ''To keep it alive for another two centuries, we want to engage the YouTube generation who go for modern music and amusing video footage on the Web.'' The video can be seen on www.golakes.co.uk/wordsworthrap. Running the Meter In what is billed as a first, the United States and British poet laureates are to give joint poetry readings in Chicago, Washington and London. Sponsored by the Library of Congress, the Poetry Foundation and the Poetry Society of London, the readings by the laureates, Donald Hall of the United States and Andrew Motion of Britain, are to take place in Chicago on May 7, Washington on May 10 and London on June 6. Dickens Park to Open It's nearly time to take the Great Expectations boat ride, frolic in Fagan's den and sample the atmosphere of Newgate Prison. A week from today, Dickens World, above, a $115 million theme park constructed in the naval dockyards in Chatham, England, where Charles Dickens's father once worked, will open to the first of an expected 300,000 annual visitors, Reuters reported. ''If Dickens were alive today, he would probably have built the place himself,'' Ross Hutchins, the manager, said. He said the theme park, depicting a dark, dirty, dank London inhabited by thieves, murderers and ghosts, will have an air of authenticity because it was constructed in consultation with experts from the Dickens Fellowship, a worldwide association of Dickens devotees. In response to critics who speculated that the Artful Dodger, Mr. Pickwick and Uriah Heep might stroll the grounds, 35 miles from London in southeast England, Mr. Hutchins said, ''If we were Disneyfying Dickens we wouldn't be talking to people like the Dickens Fellowship to ensure the correct historical facts.'' 'Kaffir Boy' Banned (Again) The award-winning ''Kaffir Boy,'' Mark Mathabane's 1986 memoir about growing up poor and black during apartheid in South Africa, has been banned from an intermediate school in Burlingame, Calif., after a parent complained about two paragraphs describing men paying hungry boys for sex, The Associated Press reported. An eighth-grade teacher was ordered by Superintendent Sonny Da Marto to stop using the book in her four English classes, although it had been approved by a review committee of parents, teacher, a librarian and a member of the school board. Mr. Da Marto told the Burlingame school board that he would allow an abridged version of ''Kaffir Boy'' to be taught, but that the paragraphs depicting child prostitution were inappropriate for 13- and 14-year-olds. The school board refused to reverse his decision. The American Library Association included ''Kaffir Boy'' on its list of ''Outstanding Books for the College Bound.'' The child rape scene also gave the memoir the No. 31 spot on the association's list of the 100 most frequently banned or challenged books.

'OPENING DOORS: A JOURNEY IN MUSICAL THEATER' (Tomorrow and Sunday) Take the songs of Stephen Sondheim, Cy Coleman and other modern composers and combine them with the talents of selected New York City middle and high school students, and you have this cabaret show, presented by Wingspan Arts. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 7 p.m., the Hypothetical Theater, the 14th Street Y, 344 East 14th Street, East Village, wingspanarts.org; suggested donation, $10. Reservations: RSVP@wingspanarts.org. OPERA TRIPLE BILL (Sunday) In ''Happy Feet'' Mumbles the penguin is ostracized because he can't sing; in ''Happy Tweet!'' Stumbles the penguin is ostracized because he can -- opera, that is. How Stumbles persuades his pop-loving peers to share his tastes is just one of three brief operatic stories to be presented by the Manhattan School of Music in its annual performance celebrating its school outreach program. At 2:30 p.m., Greenfield Hall, 122nd Street and Broadway, Morningside Heights, (917) 493-4428. Free, first come first served. PARENTING MAGAZINE FILM FESTIVAL (Tomorrow) A day of free -- yes, you read it right -- family movies, with perks like games and magic for children and chair massages for parents. The lineup is ''The Breakup'' (9 a.m.), ''Over the Hedge'' (11:10 a.m.), ''Shark Tale'' (12:55 p.m.) and ''Charlotte's Web'' (2:55 p.m.) At Clearview Cinemas, 1871 Broadway, at 62nd Street, parentingextras.com (the link is ''You're Invited''). Telephone R.S.V.P.'s: (212) 522-4551. 'SPRING SPROUTS' (Sunday) It sprouts, of course, from seeds, the focus of this drop-in program at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Children will learn all about seeds, taste the edible kind and find out which they can plant easily at home. From 2 to 4 p.m., the Discovery Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Crown Heights, (718) 623-7200, bbg.org. Free with admission: $5; $3 for 65+ and students; free for under 16 and members. 'TRIP THE LIGHT FANTASTIC' (Tomorrow) These lights will be truly fantastic: they are in the creations of Nam June Paik, James Turrell and Spencer Finch, artists whose work will be explored in ARTime's latest ''Saturday in the Galleries'' program for children 5 to 10. Each month a 90-minute art tour is followed by discussion and sketching. At 11 a.m. Reservations (required) and meeting place: (718) 797-1573 or ARTimeNY@nyc.rr.com; $25 for one child and adult; each additional child, $5. JIM WEST (Tomorrow and Sunday) Classic puppetry combines with classical music in two shows from Theatreworks/USA. Jim West, a master of large-scale puppets, will present ''Aesop's Fables'' tomorrow and ''Dinosaurs!'' on Sunday. At 10:30 a.m., the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 279-4200; $25.

A sports article on Saturday about the second round of the Masters referred imprecisely to the scoring for Phil Mickelson on hole No. 11, where he hit a ball into the trees. Mickelson took a free drop -- not a penalty drop requiring an extra stroke -- because there were cables and pipes in the way. (As the article noted, he did make a bogey on the hole.)

The former president of the board of the Co-op City housing complex was charged yesterday with participating in a bribery scheme related to a $3.5 million painting contract, federal prosecutors said. The former president, Iris Herskowitz Baez, 59, was charged in Federal District Court with bribery and conspiracy, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Ms. Baez served as president and then secretary to the board from 2000 to 2003, prosecutors said. She has pleaded not guilty.
ALSOP--Reese, M.D., 93, of Lloyd Harbor, NY, on December 19, 2006. Memorial Saturday, April 14, 11:00am, St. John's Church, 1670 Route 25A, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.

The National Symphony Orchestra in Washington, unable to find a successor to its music director, Leonard Slatkin, has put off the change for two years. In the interim, the orchestra said yesterday it would turn to Ivan Fischer, right, its principal guest conductor, for leadership. The orchestra will upgrade his title starting in the 2008-9 season to principal conductor and keep him on for an extra year after that. The National Symphony said in November 2004 that Mr. Slatkin would not renew his contract beyond next season, his final year. ''We haven't found the right person yet,'' said Patricia O'Kelly, a symphony spokeswoman. ''These things take time.'' She declined to elaborate. The Philadelphia Orchestra has done something similar, appointing Charles Dutoit as chief conductor while it looks to replace Christoph Eschenbach, who departs as music director after next season. The New York Philharmonic and Chicago Symphony Orchestras are also looking for music directors, suggesting that it is a sellers' market. DANIEL J. WAKIN

A front-page article yesterday about the military's decision to prolong combat tours for most active-duty Army units in Iraq and Afghanistan misstated at one point the duration of the extended tours. They will last 15 months, not 18

An article on last Friday about retirement communities for people with shared interests misstated the location of Rocinante, a community of aging hippies. As noted correctly in the picture caption, it is in Summertown, Tenn., not Summerville.

The City Council passed a bill yesterday extending death benefits to family members of sanitation and correction workers killed in the line of duty. The bill is expected to be signed by the mayor and would go into effect immediately with a retroactive date of September 2005. Sanitation Department officials say that that date would cover claims by the survivors of two sanitation workers and a supervisor who have died since 2005, two from heart attacks and one in a work accident. Survivors of firefighters and police officers killed in the line of duty already receive health care coverage. But the city must now act on a case-by-case basis to provide those same benefits to survivors of sanitation and correction workers, a process that could take months. RAY RIVERA

SALLIE MAE IN TALKS TO BE SOLD -- Sallie Mae, the nation's largest lender to college students, is in talks to be bought out by private equity in what could be a deal for more than $20 billion, people briefed on the discussions said. [Page C1.] DOW FIRES 2 FOR PLANNING BUYOUT -- Dow Chemical fired two executives who it said held a series of secret meetings with bankers and prospective investors about selling the company in a leveraged buyout. [C1.] CBS CANCELS IMUS PROGRAM -- CBS brought the weeklong confrontation over racial and sexual insults by the radio host Don Imus to an end when it canceled the ''Imus in the Morning'' show, ending a program that had been broadcasting for more than 30 years.[C1.] FLYING INTO A MAELSTROM -- During Don Imus's week of public mortification, his backers began to see what he did not: the drumbeat was not going to stop. The Media Equation: David Carr. [C1.] A EUROPEAN POWERHOUSE -- Germany's transformation from Europe's sick man to its most stalwart performer, thanks to an export-led recovery, is one more sign that the rest of the world does not depend as much on the American economy as it once did. [C1.] ROYALTY DISPUTE IS SETTLED -- The company that manages the Beatles' commercial interests and the EMI Group, which holds the rights to the band's recordings, said that they had settled a dispute over royalties, renewing speculation that a deal to release the Beatles' music in digital form might be near. [C3.] APPLE DELAYS OPERATING SYSTEM -- Apple said that the introduction of the new version of its Macintosh OSX operating system would be delayed as much as four months because of quality issues. The company had previously said the program would ship this spring. [C3.] VIOLENT FILMS DRAWING YOUTH -- The entertainment industry's promise not to entice youth with their violent fare has been eroded by online promotions and a proliferation of unrated DVDs, a Federal Trade Commission report said. [C3.] MEASURING OFF-SOFA VIEWERSHIP -- The Nielsen Company will begin providing national ratings for TV viewing away from home in places like bars, hotels, gyms and offices. For some types of programs, such as sports shows, the new ratings may provide a significant boost. Advertising. [C5.] VONAGE CHIEF STEPS DOWN -- Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone company, said that Michael F. Snyder, who has led Vonage for slightly more than a year, had stepped down as chief executive. Jeffrey A. Citron, who founded the company, will serve as chief executive until a permanent successor is found. [C3.] RETAILERS SEE CLOUDS AHEAD -- After robust sales in March, there are signs that consumers are already spending less, and many stores that reported sales surpassing expectations last month warned of disappointments ahead. [C2.] JURY GETS NACCHIO CASE -- Jury deliberations began in the insider-trading trial of Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications International.[C8.] F.D.A. PANEL REJECTS MERCK DRUG -- A panel of federal drug advisers voted 20 to 1 to reject an application by Merck to sell its pain pill Arcoxia because of concerns the drug could cause as many as 30,000 heart attacks annually if widely used. [A14.] A FIRST FOR THE TOYOTA BOARD -- Toyota announced a management shuffle that would elevate the president of its North American operations, James E. Press, to be the first non-Japanese to sit on the automaker's board. [C4.] SIGNS OF A EUROPEAN RATE INCREASE -- The European Central Bank fed widespread expectations that it would raise interest rates again in June, its eighth increase since December 2005. [C4.] THE COSTS OF NOTORIETY -- Hundreds of venture capitalists will gather in Washington next week. Among the questions on the table: Is private equity -- including venture capital -- becoming too public for its own good? V.C. Nation. [C6.] THE INVASION OF MUMBAI -- Mumbai, India's financial capital, is under siege as foreign investment banks and brokerage firms jostle for office space and bid for employees. [C6.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The number of workers filing new claims for jobless benefits rose last week to the highest level in two months. Another report said that import prices jumped 1.7 percent in March as crude oil futures prices surged. (AP) The drug company MedImmune said that it was willing to consider takeover offers because of interest from big pharmaceutical companies and investor unhappiness with the company's performance. (AP) Nestlé, the food and drink company, announced that it would buy the Gerber Products Company for $5.5 billion, giving the world's biggest food and drink company the largest share of the global baby food market. (AP) Jurors at the fraud trial of the toppled newspaper tycoon Conrad M. Black were told that Hollinger executives relied on the advice of outside lawyers and accountants for how to account for the payments they had made to themselves. (REUTERS) Pier 1 Imports, the home furnishings retailer, reported a wider quarterly loss and lower sales as customers gave a cool reception to its revamped product selection. (REUTERS) The case of the former vice chairman of Wal-Mart Stores, Thomas M. Coughlin, was back in court as an appellate court took up a prosecutor's plea that Mr. Coughlin's sentence was too light. (REUTERS)

Drawing more viewers than the competition on NBC, ABC, CBS and CW combined, ''American Idol'' led Fox to another dominant night in the ratings Wednesday. The hourlong 9 p.m. show, on which it was announced that Haley Scarnato had become the latest contestant cut from the competition, had 27.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The closest competitor in the hour, CBS's ''Criminal Minds,'' attracted 12.8 million. Fox led earlier in the night among adults 18 to 49 with two episodes of '' 'Til Death,'' one at 8 (7 million) followed by the season finale at 8:30 (8.6 million), although CBS's ''Jericho'' averaged slightly more total viewers in the hour (8.2 million). Also at 8, the season finale of NBC's ''Friday Night Lights'' garnered 6.3 million viewers and a fifth-place finish in the 18 to 49 age group, while CW's ''America's Next Top Model'' (5.6 million) ranked second. At 10, CBS's ''CSI: New York'' won the hour in total viewers (12.7 million), but ABC's ''Lost'' (11.9 million) remained far ahead among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

The rates of drug-resistant gonorrhea in the United States have increased so greatly in the last five years that doctors should now treat the infection with a different class of antibiotics, the last line of defense for the sexually transmitted disease, officials said yesterday. The percentage of drug-resistant gonorrhea cases among heterosexual men jumped, to 6.7 percent in 2006 compared with 0.6 percent in 2001, officials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.

The New York City Council passed a bill yesterday enhancing whistle-blower laws to protect city employees who report conduct that is harmful to the health, safety or educational welfare of a child. Councilman Robert Jackson said the bill was aimed at protecting teachers from coercion to inflate test scores and those who report the failure of a school to follow through on federally mandated individual education plans for students with special needs. But some critics, including the mayor, say the bill would provide teachers facing poor performance reviews a tool to use against superiors. City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn rejected that notion yesterday, saying it would not hamper efforts to bring more accountability to schools. The Departments of Education and Investigation oppose the bill, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has signaled that he would veto it. RAY RIVERA

Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition. Theater Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater. Previews and Openings 'ALL THE WRONG REASONS: A TRUE STORY OF NEO-NAZIS, DRUG SMUGGLING AND UNDYING LOVE' In previews; opens on Sunday. John Fugelsang is the son of an ex-nun and a former Franciscan brother. He tells his story in this solo show (1:30). New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 460-5475. 'AMERICAN FIESTA' Previews start tomorrow. Opens on April 26. Steven Tomlinson's new play, directed by Mark Brokaw, is about an avid collector of ceramic dinnerware whose family disapproves of his same-sex marriage (1:30). Vineyard Theater, 108 East 15th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 353-0303. 'CORAM BOY' Previews start on Monday. Opens on May 2. An adaptation of Jamila Gavin's novel about two orphans is the latest National Theater hit to move from London to Broadway (2:30). Imperial Theater, 249 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. 'DIXIE'S TUPPERWARE PARTY' Previews start on Wednesday. Opens on May 10. Dixie Wingate has left her Alabama trailer park to sell Tupperware in New York in this irreverent comedy. Ars Nova, 511 West 54th Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444. 'DEUCE' In previews; opens on May 6. The grandes dames Angela Lansbury and Marian Seldes play retired tennis players in this new Terrence McNally comedy. Michael Blakemore directs. Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. 'FROST/NIXON' In previews; opens on April 22. Frank Langella plays Richard M. Nixon in this acclaimed London transfer about the famous post-Watergate interview. With Michael Sheen. (1:40). Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. 'LEGALLY BLONDE' In previews; opens on April 29. Laura Bell Bundy plays the smiling, ditsy sorority girl who takes Harvard Law by storm in this musical adaptation. Jerry Mitchell directs (2:20). Palace Theater, 1564 Broadway, at 47th Street, (212) 307-4100. 'LOVEMUSIK' In previews; opens on May 3. The Tony winners Michael Cerveris and Donna Murphy star in a musical about the relationship between Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya (with songs by Weill). Harold Prince directs (2:30). Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200. '110 IN THE SHADE' Previews start today. Opens on May 9. Audra McDonald stars in the Roundabout's revival of the musical version of N. Richard Nash's ''Rainmaker.'' Studio 54, 254 West 54th Street, (212) 719-1300. 'REALISM' and 'JUMP!' The first play opens on Thursday; the second on April 26. The Exchange, formerly known as the Jean Cocteau Rep, presents in repertory these new works by emerging British writers (1:30 each). Kirk Theater, 420 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. 'TRANSFIGURES' In previews; opens on Monday. Created from sources that include the writings of Joan of Arc, scientific journals and Post-it notes from the desks of corporate secretaries, this new show examines the Jerusalem Syndrome (1:30). Julia Miles Theater, 424 West 55th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. Broadway * 'THE COAST OF UTOPIA' Lincoln Center Theater's brave, gorgeous, sprawling and ultimately exhilarating production of Tom Stoppard's trilogy about intellectuals errant in 19th-century Russia. A testament to the seductive powers of narrative theater, directed with hot and cool canniness by Jack O'Brien and featuring a starry cast (Brian F. O'Byrne, Jennifer Ehle, Martha Plimpton, Josh Hamilton and Ethan Hawke, among others) in a tasty assortment of roles. Vivian Beaumont Theater, 150 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200. (Ben Brantley) * 'COMPANY' Fire, beckoning and dangerous, flickers beneath the frost of John Doyle's elegant, unexpectedly stirring revival of Stephen Sondheim and George Furth's era-defining musical from 1970, starring a compellingly understated Raúl Esparza. Like Mr. Doyle's ''Sweeney Todd,'' this production finds new clarity of feeling in Sondheim by melding the roles of performers and musicians (2:20). Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'CURTAINS' This musical comedy about a musical-comedy murder -- featuring songs by John Kander and Fred Ebb and a book by Rupert Holmes -- lies on the stage like a promisingly gaudy string of firecrackers, waiting in vain for a match. The good news is that David Hyde Pierce, playing a diffident Boston detective, steps into full-fledged Broadway stardom. Scott Ellis directs a talent-packed cast that includes Debra Monk and Karen Ziemba. (2:45). Al Hirschfeld Theater, 302 West 45th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE DROWSY CHAPERONE' (Tony Awards, best book of a musical and best original score, 2006) This small and ingratiating spoof of 1920s stage frolics, as imagined by an obsessive show queen, may not be a masterpiece. But in a dry season for musicals, it has theatergoers responding as if they were withering houseplants finally being watered after long neglect. (1:40). Marquis Theater, 1535 Broadway, at 45th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) * 'GREY GARDENS' Christine Ebersole is absolutely glorious as the middle-aged, time-warped debutante called Little Edie Beale in this uneven musical adaptation of the notorious 1975 documentary of the same title. She and the wonderful Mary Louise Wilson (as her bedridden mother), in the performances of their careers, make ''Grey Gardens'' an experience no passionate theatergoer should miss (2:40). Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'HOWARD KATZ' The subject of Patrick Marber's comedy of unhappiness about a rabid talent agent, starring a baleful Alfred Molina and directed by Doug Hughes, is nothing more nor less than your standard-issue midlife crisis. This familiar topic gets the better of all the talented people here trying to make it seem fresh (1:30). Laura Pels Theater, 111 West 46th Street, (212) 719-1300. (Brantley) * 'JOURNEY'S END' A splendid revival of R. C. Sherriff's 1928 drama of life in the trenches during World War I. Acutely staged (by David Grindley) and acted by a fine ensemble led by Hugh Dancy and Boyd Gaines, this production offers an exemplary presentation of that theatrical rarity, an uncompromising, clear-eyed play about war and the experience of day-to-day combat. An essential ticket (2:40). Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'MARY POPPINS' This handsome, homily-packed, mechanically ingenious and rather tedious musical, adapted from the P. L. Travers stories and the 1964 film, is ultimately less concerned with inexplicable magic than with practical psychology. Ashley Brown, who sings prettily as the family-mending nanny, looks like Joan Crawford trying to be nice and sounds like Dr. Phil. Directed by Richard Eyre and Matthew Bourne (2:30). New Amsterdam Theater, 214 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4747. (Brantley) 'LES MISÉRABLES' This premature revival, a slightly scaled-down version of the well-groomed behemoth that closed only three years ago, appears to be functioning in a state of mild sedation. Appealingly sung and freshly orchestrated, this fast-moving adaptation of Victor Hugo's novel isn't sloppy or blurry. But its pulse rate stays well below normal (2:55). Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'A MOON FOR THE MISBEGOTTEN' Kevin Spacey gives a bizarre, beat-the-clock performance, as lively as a frog on a hot plate, as James Tyrone in this off-kilter revival of Eugene O'Neill's last play. Mercifully, he does not block the view of Eve Best, who maps the contradictory levels of Tyrone's strapping love interest with clarity and intelligence (2:50). Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) * 'PRELUDE TO A KISS' Craig Lucas's broken-hearted romantic comedy from 1990 receives a first-rate remounting, courtesy of the Roundabout Theater Company. Alan Tudyk and Annie Parisse play a young couple whose marriage founders shortly after the bride receives a kiss from an elderly stranger (John Mahoney). The kiss awakens all three to an unsettling awareness of love's frailty and, paradoxically, of its durability too (2:00). American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212) 719-1300. (Charles Isherwood) * 'SPRING AWAKENING' Duncan Sheik and Steven Sater's bold adaptation of the Frank Wedekind play is the freshest and most exciting new musical Broadway has seen in some time. Set in 19th-century Germany but with a ravishing rock score, it exposes the splintered emotional lives of adolescents just discovering the joys and sorrows of sex. Performed with brio by a great cast, with supple direction by Michael Mayer and inventive choreography by Bill T. Jones (2:00). Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) * 'TALK RADIO' The most lacerating portrait of a human meltdown this side of a Francis Bacon painting. Playing an abrasive radio talk show host with a God complex, the astounding Liev Schreiber seems to fill the air as inescapably as weather in Robert Falls's gut-grabbing revival of Eric Bogosian's 1987 play (1:40). Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'TARZAN' This writhing green blob with music, adapted by Disney Theatrical Productions from the 1999 animated film, has the feeling of a superdeluxe day care center, equipped with lots of bungee cords and karaoke synthesizers, where children can swing when they get tired of singing, and vice versa. The soda-pop score is by Phil Collins (2:30). Richard Rodgers Theater, 226 West 46th Street, (212) 307-4747. (Brantley) Off Broadway 'THE ACCOMPLICES' Bernard Weinraub, a former reporter for The New York Times, has chosen a worthy subject for his first play: In 1940, the young Zionist Peter Bergson was determined to persuade the United States government to open its arms to Jewish refugees fleeing the Nazis. Unfortunately, this production takes a hagiographic approach to its protagonist, emphasizing his heroism at the expense of more complex characterization. (2:00). Acorn Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. (David Ng) 'BILL W. AND DR. BOB' This insightful new play about the founders of Alcoholics Anonymous subtly makes the claim that the recovery movement was born as a series of accidents. Patrick Husted is excellent as Bob Smith, Bill Wilson's partner in combating addictions (2:15). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Ginia Bellafante) * 'BLACKBIRD' David Harrower's stunning new drama looks back at a sexual relationship -- between a 40-year-old man and a 12-year-old girl -- that transforms, cripples and paralyzes. Jeff Daniels and Alison Pill, both extraordinary, peel their characters down to their barest souls. Joe Mantello is the masterly director(1:30). Manhattan Theater Club at City Center Stage I, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212. (Brantley) 'THE DARK AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS' Jack Cummings III directs a respectable if reverential revival of William Inge's last major play. Seeking to access the poetry in Inge's homely tale of troubled lives in the Midwest in the 1920s, he can't quite hide its fundamentally prosaic qualities. Still, this Transport Group production gives audiences a chance to encounter a rarely seen drama from Broadway's heyday (2:35). Connelly Theater, 220 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101. (Isherwood) * 'DYING CITY' Christopher Shinn's crafty and unsettling play about grief and violence, set in the shadow of the Iraq war. Directed by James Macdonald and fiercely acted by Pablo Schreiber and Rebecca Brooksher, this quiet, transfixing production turns passive aggression into a theatrical dynamic (1:30). Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, 150 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-7600. (Brantley) 'EXITS AND ENTRANCES' Athol Fugard casts a tender glance back at an actor whose dedication to theater helped spark his own in this warm if insubstantial stage memoir. Morlan Higgins capably excavates the emotional core of a role that might have seemed generic, playing an aging gay actor reckoning with the end of an up-and-down career. William Dennis Hurley plays the Fugard stand-in (1:30). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200. (Isherwood) * 'IN THE HEIGHTS' Lin-Manuel Miranda's joyous songs paint a vibrant portrait of daily life in Washington Heights in this flawed but enjoyable show. Essentially a valentine to the barrio -- conflict of a violent or desperate kind is banished from the picture -- the musical contains a host of funny performances and brings the zesty sound of Latin pop to the stage. (2:10). 37 Arts, 450 West 37th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Isherwood) * 'JACK GOES BOATING' Bob Glaudini's gentle comedy about pothead losers in love is a reminder of how engrossing uneventful lives can be in the hands of the right actors. Peter DuBois directs the easygoing ensemble, brilliantly led by Philip Seymour Hoffman (2:00). Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555. (Brantley) * 'KING HEDLEY II' The Signature Theater Company concludes its season dedicated to August Wilson with a gritty, strongly cast revival of this play set in a violence-ravaged Pittsburgh in the 1980s. Russell Hornsby gives a galvanizing performance in the title role, as a man struggling to live down the errors of his past and plant the seeds for a promising new life (2:45). Peter Norton Space, 555 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 244-7529. (Isherwood) 'MARIE ANTOINETTE: THE COLOR OF FLESH' Joe Gross's intriguing play features impeccable performances by Amanda Jones, Samantha Ives and Jonathan Kells Phillips as the three corners of a triangle of love and friendship caught up in the French Revolution. It's no ordinary triangle: Ms. Jones plays Marie Antoinette, and Ms. Ives the real portraitist who often painted her (1:30). The 45th Street Theater, 354 West 45th Street, Clinton, (212) 254-9533. (Neil Genzlinger) * 'THE NIBROC TRILOGY' ''Last Train to Nibroc,'' ''See Rock City'' and ''Gulf View Drive'' make no mention of 19th-century Russian intellectuals but they do signal the arrival of a talented American playwright, Arlene Hutton. Set in Kentucky and Florida, between the beginning of World War II and the early 1950s, the plays track the life of a young couple whose individual ambitions conflict; they also clash with the goals of a changing American society. Straightforward and heartfelt, but never treacly, the works stand out in a cold, postmodern universe. Try ''See Rock City'' if you have time for only one (1:25, 1:30 and 1:55). 78th Street Theater Lab, 236 West 78th Street, (212) 352-3101. (Bellafante) 'OUR LEADING LADY' Kate Mulgrew stars as Laura Keene, who was starring in ''Our American Cousin'' on the night Lincoln was shot, in Charles Busch's uneven new comedy. An occasionally lively but mostly lumpen tribute to the glamour and grit of the theatrical life of a past era (2:00). Manhattan Theater Club at City Center Stage II, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212. (Isherwood) 'SERENDIB' David Zellnik's play about a group of scientists observing monkeys in Sri Lanka tackles questions about masculinity and social dominance within a framework that is too cute by half. That said, Mr. Zellnik seems to have more on his mind than many young playwrights (1:55). Ensemble Studio Theater, 549 West 52nd Street, Clinton, (212) 247-4982. (Bellafante) 'SOME MEN' Terrence McNally's hit-and-miss comedy about gay life is a parade of cleanly drawn types, zippy one-liners and sentimental set pieces, woven into a pageant of the ages à la ''Cavalcade,'' Noël Coward's generations-spanning tribute to the British stiff upper lip. Trip Cullman directs the agile, appealing cast (2:00). Second Stage, 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422. (Brantley) * 'SPALDING GRAY: STORIES LEFT TO TELL' A disarming collage of selections from the monologues and journals of Mr. Gray, the ultimate stand-up solipsist, who died in 2004. Directed by Lucy Sexton, and read by five performers, none of whom resemble Mr. Gray, with an affection that shrewdly stops short of hero worship (1:30). Minetta Lane Theater, 18 Minetta Lane, Greenwich Village, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) * 'WAKE UP MR. SLEEPY! YOUR UNCONSCIOUS MIND IS DEAD!' Richard Foreman's latest film-theater hybrid is a memorial service, of sorts, for the intuitive self, killed by a surface-worshiping world. It is also a dazzling exercise in reality shifting that is as invigorating as it is mournful (1:05). Ontological Theater at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101. (Brantley) Long-Running Shows 'AVENUE Q' R-rated puppets give lively life lessons (2:10). Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'BEAUTY AND THE BEAST' Cartoon made flesh, sort of (2:30). Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, (212) 307-4747. (Brantley) 'CHICAGO' Irrefutable proof that crime pays (2:25). Ambassador Theater, 219 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE COLOR PURPLE' Singing CliffsNotes for Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel (2:40). B 'HAIRSPRAY' Fizzy pop, cute kids, large man in a housedress (2:30). Neil Simon Theater, 250 West 52nd Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'JERSEY BOYS' The biomusical that walks like a man (2:30). August Wilson Theater, 245 West 52nd Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE LION KING' Disney on safari, where the big bucks roam (2:45). Minskoff Theater, 200 West 45th Street at Broadway, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'MAMMA MIA!' The jukebox that devoured Broadway (2:20). Cadillac Winter Garden Theater, 1634 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA' Who was that masked man, anyway? (2:30). Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE PRODUCERS' The ne plus ultra of showbiz scams (2:45). St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'RENT' East Village angst and love songs to die for (2:45). Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'SPAMALOT' A singing scrapbook for Monty Python fans (2:20). Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE 25TH ANNUAL PUTNAM COUNTY SPELLING BEE' ''A Chorus Line'' with pimples (1:45). Circle in the Square, 254 West 50th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) 'WICKED' Oz revisited, with political corrections (2:45). Gershwin Theater, 222 West 51st Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) Last Chance 'ESSENTIAL SELF-DEFENSE' Adam Rapp's new play is a quirky love story about a wholesome but anxious girl (the charming Heather Goldenhersh) and an automaton with a beating heart and a big vocabulary (Paul Sparks, impressively affectless). Dark, zany, entirely mannered and mostly empty (2:15). Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200; closes on Sunday. (Isherwood) 'LOS ANGELES' Julian Sheppard's play about a gamin lost in a Hollywood of aimlessness and empty sex is as thin as the slip dress she keeps wearing and, presumably, taking off (1:20). Flea Theater, 41 White Street, between Broadway and Church Street, TriBeCa, (212) 352-3101; closes tomorrow. (Bellafante) 'MY TRIP TO AL-QAEDA' Lawrence Wright, author of a deeply researched book about the rise of Islamic terrorism, conducts a theatrical seminar about the events leading to the horror of 9/11. He combines a linear narrative of the development of Al Qaeda with reminiscences about the experience of writing the book. Absorbing, and chilling too (1:30). Culture Project, 55 Mercer Street, at Broome Street, SoHo, (212) 352-3101; closes tomorrow. (Isherwood) 'PROMETHEUS BOUND' With a splendid performance by David Oyelowo, this is a smart revival of Aeschylus' 2,500-year-old play, rich in poetic imagery. It still has things to say about the abuse of power by an autocratic ruler who vindictively runs roughshod over anyone who disagrees with him (1:20). Classic Stage Company, 136 East 13th Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101; closes tomorrow. (Wilborn Hampton) 'TALL GRASS' Brian Harris's three short plays, black farces all, are not nearly as slight as any sound-bite synopsis would have them seem. Here Mr. Harris, a former stock analyst, explores the alliances formed between love and brutality in scenarios in which the tension builds to culminating shock (1:30). The Beckett Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200; closes on Sunday. (Bellafante) 'TEA AND SYMPATHY' The specter of the Ted Haggard scandal hangs over the Keen Company's revival of Robert Anderson's 1953 play about life in a psychologically stifling boys' boarding school. Girded by Jonathan Silverstein's skillful, understated direction, the play attains an unexpected timeliness as it evolves into a story about the dangers of sexual repression (2:00). Clurman Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200; closes tomorrow. (Bellafante) Movies Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/movies. 'AFTER THE WEDDING' (R, 119 minutes, in Danish) A modern creation with a classic theme involving haves and have-nots, bloodlines and family ties. The canned realism of the Danish director Susanne Bier is strictly Dogme-lite, but the spiky, screen-filling performances of her two male leads, Mads Mikkelsen and Rolf Lassgard, are really something to see. (Manohla Dargis) * 'AIR GUITAR NATION' (R, 82 minutes) Alexandra Lipsitz's breezy competition documentary follows pantomiming would-be rockers as they compete for the right to represent their country in a global championship based in Oulou, Finland. The movement, such as it is, aims to unite a war-torn planet in musical fantasy and to rawwwwwwk! -- but not necessarily in that order. Stylistically, it's nothing special, but the film's droll humor and wild performances are hard to resist. (Matt Zoller Seitz) 'Blades of Glory' (PG-13, 93 minutes) In this fast, light, frequently funny comedy about a male figure-skating team, Will Ferrell and Jon Heder stake an early claim to being the comedy couple of the year. (Stephen Holden) * 'BOY CULTURE' (No rating, 88 minutes) Q. Allan Brocka's absorbing drama follows an emotionally repressed gay hustler (Derek Magyar) as he rebels against the obsessions of his culture -- grooming, cruising, working out -- and a powerful attraction to his roommate. Only when he takes on a reclusive and much older client is he forced to pay attention to a story other than his own. (Jeannette Catsoulis) 'DEAD SILENCE' (R, 90 minutes) In this new film from the makers of the ''Saw'' series, a young man (Ryan Kwanten) whose wife was murdered by a demonic ventriloquist's dummy returns to his hometown to unravel the roots of a century-old curse. The film's playfully self-aware touches (like a grand old theater named the Guignol) distract from its leaden pacing, three too many final twists and various behavioral idiocies. (Seitz) 'FIREHOUSE DOG' (PG, 111 minutes) When a pampered Hollywood pooch trades his movie-star lifestyle for a rundown firehouse, it's not long before he is saving a father-son relationship and tracking down a serial arsonist. Yet the movie's wittiest moment -- a canine parody of Dudley Moore's first glimpse of Bo Derek in ''10'' -- will be appreciated only by parents, and in trying to straddle both age groups, ''Firehouse Dog'' proves decidedly less nimble than its furry star. (Catsoulis) 'FIRST SNOW' (R, 101 minutes) Guy Pearce, in his ''Memento'' mode, is a fast-talking salesman in this moody little thriller, which asks metaphysical questions about fate, death and fortunetelling. (Holden) 'GRINDHOUSE' (R, 180 minutes) A double feature, complete with fake previews for schlocky exploitation pictures, that pays nostalgic tribute to disreputable traditions of moviemaking and moviegoing. Robert Rodriguez contributes ''Planet Terror,'' a purposely incoherent zombie gross-out flick that flaunts is own badness the way Rose McGowan (as a go-go dancer named Cherry Darling) shows off her weaponized prosthetic leg. For his part, Quentin Tarantino, more of a connoisseur than his collaborator (and a much better filmmaker), turns out a brutal, talky and satisfying car-chase revenge movie in ''Death Proof,'' starring Kurt Russell. (A. O. Scott) 'THE HILLS HAVE EYES 2' (R, 89 minutes) Wes Craven's 1977 film, ''The Hills Have Eyes,'' in which suburbanites battled mutant cannibals, was a pulpy parable of the thin line separating civilization from savagery. Last year's remake was basically the same movie with glossier production values and a less satirical, more bludgeoning approach to violence. This follow-up, in which National Guard trainees are trapped on a former atomic test site and are stalked by flesh-eating freaks headquartered in a warrenlike mountain hideout, is essentially a catalog of transgressive images, lighted and edited like a heavy-metal video. (Seitz) * 'THE HOAX' (R, 115 minutes) A first-rate performance by Richard Gere drives this true story of Clifford Irving (Mr. Gere), who claimed to be the authorized biographer of Howard Hughes. Shadowed by the paranoia of its period (the early '70s), this movie, crisply directed by Lasse Hallstrom from an excellent script by William Weaver, is less a morality play than the entertaining portrait of a literary gambler. (Scott) * 'KILLER OF SHEEP' (No rating, 83 minutes) Largely hidden from view for three decades, Charles Burnett's lyrical film about a working-class family living in a broken-down home in a bombed-out stretch of Los Angeles is an American masterpiece, independent to the bone. (Dargis) 'THE LAST MIMZY' (PG, 94 minutes) This overstuffed yet warmhearted sci-fi drama follows a pair of wide-eyed siblings as they solve the riddle of a box from the future. Despite leaden direction (by the New Line Cinema honcho Robert Shaye) and a story crammed with pseudoscientific flotsam -- including palm reading, levitation and telepathy -- this wholesome entertainment doesn't talk down. Nevertheless, a film gazing this far into the future shouldn't be quite so unwilling to look beyond the frame. (Catsoulis) 'THE LOOKOUT' (R, 99 minutes) This directorial debut by the veteran screenwriter Scott Frank (''Out of Sight'') is a variation of an old, old story, about a nobody (a brain-damaged janitor played by Joseph Gordon-Levitt) who falls in with crooks who make him feel like somebody. Although the movie's no masterpiece -- the final stretch feels forced and unconvincing -- there's a lot to like here. (Seitz) 'MEET THE ROBINSONS' (G, 93 minutes) Actually, if you see them coming, run in the other direction. (Scott) 'THE PAGE TURNER' (No rating, 85 minutes, in French) A pretty young thing slithers into the bosom of a bourgeois family like an asp in this shivery little thriller from the French filmmaker Denis Dercourt. Not Chabrol, but not bad, either. (Dargis) * 'PRIDE' (PG, 104 minutes) The Zimbabwean-born filmmaker Sunu Gonera's directorial debut, ''Pride,'' about a swim coach (Terrence Howard, star of ''Hustle & Flow'') leading an urban recreational center's swim team to a championship, about 1971, is a silk ascot wrapped around an ear of corn. But when sinewy young idealists glide through water to the tune of ''I'll Take You There,'' the heart still swells. (Seitz) 'REIGN OVER ME' (R, 124 minutes) Mike Binder's comic drama of post-9/11 grief is wildly uneven -- by turns insightful and grindingly mawkish. Don Cheadle and Adam Sandler are two college buddies who reunite, somewhat improbably, some years after the attacks that robbed one of them of his family. The actors rise above the material, particularly in the longer, looser scenes that allow their contrasting temperaments -- Mr. Cheadle's tense understatement and Mr. Sandler's shaggy emoting -- to find a workable syncopation. (Scott) 'THE TV SET' (R, 87 minutes) Jake Kasdan's knowing satire of network television sends up the neuroses of writers and the ruthlessness of executives with minimal exaggeration. Nothing in this story of a writer (David Duchovny) pursuing his dream project seems implausible, which is less a limitation on the movie's comedy than it is its source. (Scott) 'WHOLE NEW THING' (No rating, 92 minutes) This minutely observed family drama, which tracks the growing pains of a precocious 13-year-old boy in rural Nova Scotia, is the rare film in which the actors playing parents and child feel biologically connected. (Holden) Film Series BEST OF 2006 (Tonight through Thursday) The BAMcinématek offers New York cinephiles the opportunity to catch up with some of last year's best films as determined by IndieWIRE's critics' poll. Tonight there's an advance screening of Julia Loktev's much-praised New York independent film ''Day Night Day Night'' (which will open commercially on May 9). Tomorrow brings the East Coast premiere of ''Il Caimano,'' a political satire by one of Italy's most accomplished active filmmakers, Nanni Moretti (''The Son's Room''), in which an underemployed filmmaker (played by Mr. Moretti's favorite alter ego, Silvio Orlando) agrees to make a flattering biography of Silvio Berlusconi, then Italy's prime minister. Robinson Devor's ''Police Beat,'' on Sunday, is one of the most beautiful and mysterious independent films in recent memory. It's a lyrical account of a Senegalese immigrant who works as a bicycle patrolman in Seattle. ''Climates'' (Tuesday), from the Turkish filmmaker Nuri Bilge Ceylan, is a worthy successor to his 2002 ''Distant,'' with Mr. Ceylan himself interpreting the central role of an egocentric academic whose relationship with an art director is slowly, and largely silently, falling apart. In ''Time to Leave'' (Wednesday), the French filmmaker François Ozon (''Swimming Pool'') looks at the last days of a gay fashion photographer (Melvil Poupaud) dying of cancer. On Thursday there's a preview of Mr. Devor's new feature, ''Zoo,'' a sympathetic portrait of a man who died after having sex with a horse. BAM Rose Cinemas, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; $10. (Dave Kehr) JUBILO (Tonight) Will Rogers's earliest surviving feature film (1919), about a drifter who finds a home on an Oklahoma ranch, gets a rare screening in a print preserved by the Museum of Modern Art. Ben Model provides piano accompaniment. Museum of Modern Art, Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters, (212) 708-9400, moma.org; $10. (Kehr) WEST OF THE TRACKS (Wednesday and Thursday) The Chinese documentary filmmaker Wang Bing took three years to capture this sweeping, nine-hour documentary about the transformations worked by encroaching capitalism on an industrial city, Shenyang, in northeastern China. As the aging, unprofitable factories are closed down by a distant government, it gradually becomes clear to the local workers that they have been forgotten in China's rush to riches. The film's three parts -- ''Rust,'' ''Remnants'' and ''Rails'' -- will be shown in rotation through April 24, beginning tonight with ''Rust'' and tomorrow with ''Remnants.'' ''Rails'' will be shown next Friday. Anthology Film Archives, 32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 505-5181, anthologyfilmarchives.org; $8. (Kehr) Pop Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. ART BRUT (Tuesday and Wednesday) Rock 'n' roll needs to celebrate as well as ridicule its own mythology, and Art Brut, sarcastically but exuberantly singing about the thrill of plugging in and making a ruckus -- ''Formed a band, we formed a band/Look at us, we formed a band!'' -- is one of the rare groups that can do both. Tuesday at 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; sold out. Wednesday at 8 p.m., Studio B, 259 Banker Street, between Meserole Avenue and Calyer Street, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 389-1880, clubstudiob.com; $12. (Ben Sisario) JOSEPH ARTHUR (Thursday) Romance, despair and the struggle for faith intermingle in Mr. Arthur's haunting songs, which can float in a gorgeous acoustic reverie or flare up in electrified anger. At 9 p.m., Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, near Sterling Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0236, spsounds.com; $15. (Sisario) * ROSANNE CASH AND ELVIS COSTELLO (Tonight) Rosanne Cash has been a frequent guest at the Rubin Museum of Art, a cozy gallery of Himalayan works in the former Barneys store in Chelsea; she was the first artist to perform in the museum's 144-seat theater three years ago, and has been there five times since. Tonight she is joined by Elvis Costello for an acoustic show on the enigmatic theme of ''Magic Numbers.'' At 7, 150 West 17th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 620-5000, rmanyc.org; sold out. (Sisario) CUTE IS WHAT WE AIM FOR (Thursday) At some point between Dashboard Confessional and Fall Out Boy, emo's polarity flipped: instead of grand gestures of sincerity, the hallmark of the genre became a verbose, smirky self-awareness. Cute Is What We Aim For, from Buffalo, tries hard to sound witty and effete, but the band falls as short on that front (''Are you perspiring from the irony/Or sweating to these lyrics?'') as it does with its sluggish riffs. With Circa Survive, As Tall as Lions and Envy on the Coast. At 7:30 p.m., Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, irvingplaza.com; sold out. (Sisario) * ROKY ERICKSON AND THE EXPLOSIVES (Tonight and Sunday) One of the godfathers of psychedelic rock, who howled like a werewolf over the flutter of an electric jug in his 1960s band the 13th Floor Elevators, Roky Erickson is also one of the most notorious casualties of that era. He spent years in a mental hospital and, despite genuine gifts as a songwriter, has struggled ever since to reclaim his career. At 59, in what his representatives say is his best mental health in many years, he makes what is believed to be his New York debut. Tonight at 9, Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, near Sterling Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0236, spsounds.com; Sunday at 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com. Both sold out. (Sisario) THE GOSSIP (Tomorrow) Based in Portland, Ore., but with roots in Arkansas, this trio of two women and one man plays a bare but potent blues-punk, dotting anthems of female empowerment with earthy ''oohs.'' With Chinese Stars and First Nation. At 8 p.m., Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3132, knittingfactory.com; sold out. (Sisario) PATTY GRIFFIN (Thursday) Patty Griffin may be best known as the songwriter of the Dixie Chicks' ''Let Him Fly'' and ''Truth No. 2.'' But on her own she is more cathartic, with songs that plunge into love as mysticism, desire and faith. Her songs may twang, but they can also cut deep. With Terremoto. At 8 p.m., Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 307-7171, beacontheatrenyc.com; $29 and $39. (Jon Pareles) GUSTER (Tonight and tomorrow night) Guster, a band from Boston, has followed the Dave Matthews Band's playbook for building an audience: touring constantly and singing unabashedly earnest folk-rock songs about the painful uncertainties of friendship, love and growing up. With Mason Jennings tonight and the Format tomorrow. At 8, Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 307-7171, beacontheatrenyc.com; $39 (sold out tomorrow). (Pareles) BUDDY GUY (Tonight) The blues arrive in burst after burst of adrenaline when Mr. Guy plays his songs, full of gut-level belting and speedy guitar curlicues. He makes nearly every excess sound heartfelt. With Danielia Cotton. At 8, B. B. King Blues Club & Grill, 237 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144, bbkingblues.com; $48. (Pareles) HOT CHIP (Thursday) With wobbly electronic rhythms and a strong command of the drippy, semi-ironic disco ballad, this English group plays wistful but still snarky dance music. Get too lost in the beats and you'll miss gags like the oh-so-art-rock countdown of nonsense words in descending size (''S-E-X-I-N-G, C-A-S-I-O, P-O-K-E''). With Tussle. At 6:30 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; $22 in advance, $25 at the door. (Sisario) ISLEY BROTHERS (Tonight) The Isley Brothers' career spans virtually the entire history of soul music, from their gospel-heated rave-ups of the late '50s and early '60s (''Shout!,'' ''Nobody but Me'') through the slithery funk of the '70s (''It's Your Thing,'' ''That Lady''), all the way to their recent collaborations with R. Kelly. Throughout, the libido has remained as intact as Ronald Isley's falsetto. Opening the show is Sharon Jones, the queen of an active local scene that recreates, spiritedly but not too pedantically, the musky sound of Stax/Volt '60s soul. At 8, United Palace Theater, 4140 Broadway, at 175th Street, Washington Heights, (212) 307-7171, concertstonight.com; $39.50 to $69.50. (Sisario) * JANDEK (Tomorrow) A singer, guitarist and occasional keyboardist from Texas, Jandek is also one of the great sphinxes of contemporary American music. Since the late '70s he has released dozens of strange, challenging albums -- his music is a creaky, nightmarish variation of folk-rock -- and maintained an almost total void in place of a public persona. (For years, no one was even sure what he looked like.) Recently he has begun to tour a little, and tomorrow, in a show presented by Tonic, he plays with two veteran underground musicians, the guitarist Tim Foljahn (playing bass) and the drummer Jim White. At 8 p.m., Abrons Arts Center, Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Lower East Side, (212) 598-0400, henrystreet.org; $20. (Sisario) NORAH JONES (Wednesday) For those who have missed her occasional unannounced gigs at small, no-cover Manhattan bars, in which she wears disguises and does everything from punk to country, Ms. Jones plays a fully official concert at a big, conspicuous place, leading her band in the music that made her famous: gentle, comforting soul-jazz. Opening the show is M. Ward, a gifted singer and guitarist better known for his work as a sideman (Cat Power, Bright Eyes) than for his tasteful and beguiling songs. At 8 p.m., Theater at Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741, thegarden.com; $39.50 to $60. (Sisario) * SALIF KEITA (Thursday) Salif Keita, from Mali, has long been celebrated for a cosmopolitan ear and a voice that can melt hearts, but lately his work has been even more entrancing than usual. His latest album, ''M'Bemba'' (Decca), has songs of love and tribute to ancestors, its acoustic guitars joined by instruments from Hawaii, the Caribbean and even medieval Europe. At 8 p.m., B. B. King Blues Club & Grill, 237 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144, bbkingblues.com; $41 in advance, $45 at the door. (Sisario) * KLAXONS, BONDE DO ROLE (Tonight) Klaxons' eerie rave-punk is punctuated by the peal of air-raid sirens and paranoid, shouted lyrics that allude to William S. Burroughs and Thomas Pynchon. How this British band manages to cram in such fear and loathing and still make exhilarating, danceable grooves is what makes it fascinating. With Bonde do Role, a raucous Brazilian trio that makes silly but contagiously high-energy pastiches of electronics and fist-pumping hard rock, à la the early Beastie Boys . At 10, Studio B, 259 Banker Street, between Meserole Avenue and Calyer Street, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 389-1880, clubstudiob.com; $12. (Sisario) * THE LOCUST, CATTLE DECAPITATION, DAUGHTERS (Tonight and tomorrow night) If noise-rock had superheroes, the Locust would surely be among them. Not only does this long-running San Diego band have a supreme control of its screamy hurricane of sound -- delivered in quick blasts of guitar, keyboards and indecipherable squeals -- but the group also dresses in skintight insect costumes from head to toe, all the way up to the black mesh over their eyes. (Perfect for Halloween merchandising!) It plays with Cattle Decapitation, a ''deathgrind'' metal band once affiliated with the Locust, and Daughters, a noisy band from Providence, R.I. Tonight at 6:30, Rebel, 251 West 30th Street, Manhattan, (212) 695-2747, rebelnyc.com; $15. Tomorrow night at 7, Europa, 98-104 Meserole Avenue, at Manhattan Avenue, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 383-5723, europaclub.com; $12. (Sisario) LOSER'S LOUNGE TRIBUTE TO HALL AND OATES (Tonight and tomorrow night) As Nick Lowe said, you've got to be cruel to be kind. Joe McGinty's enduring Loser's Lounge series, now 14, both honors and skewers pop greats with cleverly over-the-top performances, and turns its attention here to Hall and Oates, whose mega-selling soul-pop ranged from the sublime (''She's Gone'') to the farcical (''Portable Radio''). At 7 and 9:30, Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; $25. (Sisario) LURA (Tomorrow) A young Cape Verdean singer who was born in Portugal, Lura specializes in bubbly, lilting acoustic songs that are quicker and more danceable -- but no less sensuous -- than the morna tunes popularized by Cesaria Evora. At 8 p.m., Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, worldmusicinstitute.org or symphonyspace.org; $27; $15 for students. (Sisario) PLAIN WHITE T'S (Tuesday) Trite is a strong word, but when it comes to ''Hate (I Really Don't Like You),'' this Chicago power-pop band's irritatingly bland recent radio hit (''Hate is a strong word/But I really, really, really don't like you''), it may not be strong enough. With Boys Night Out, Lovedrug, and Dear and the Headlights. At 8 p.m., Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, irvingplaza.com; $16 in advance, $18 at the door. (Sisario) RJD2 (Tonight) As a D.J. and producer, RJD2 -- born R. J. Krohn -- has made a mark in underground hip-hop with productions and remixes for Aceyalone, Aesop Rock and El-P, as well as his collaboration with the rapper Blueprint in Soul Position. He likes crisp funk drum breaks overlaid with brooding chords for a mixture of heft and introspection. With Busdriver and Happy Chichester. At 6, Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; $20. (Pareles) RODRIGO Y GABRIELA (Monday) Once thrash-metal bandmates in Mexico, this guitar duo discovered what the Gipsy Kings have long known: Europeans and Americans go crazy for virtuosic acoustic renditions of their favorite '70s rock ballads. The Gipsy Kings did it with ''Hotel California,'' and Rodrigo y Gabriela's repertory includes a lush ''Stairway to Heaven.'' With Krystle Warren. At 8 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; $22 in advance, $25 at the door. (Sisario) Kenny Wayne Shepherd (Wednesday) A 29-year-old blues guitarist inspired equally by the Allman Brothers and Muddy Waters, Mr. Shepherd recently released ''10 Days Out (Blues From the Backroads)'' (Reprise), a CD-DVD package documenting his work with various blues greats, including B. B. King, Clarence (Gatemouth) Brown, Honeyboy Edwards and Etta Baker. Since working on it, several of his collaborators have died, but for this tour he is joined by Hubert Sumlin, Bryan Lee and Buddy Flett. At 8 p.m., Gramercy Theater, 127 East 23rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171; $35. (Sisario) PATTI SMITH (Wednesday) Her first flash of rock 'n' roll brilliance, and maybe still her best, was a cover: Them's ''Gloria,'' transformed from garage-rock swagger into an erotic rhapsody. So Patti Smith's new album, ''Twelve'' (Columbia), with versions of songs by the Rolling Stones, Nirvana, Jimi Hendrix and others, is especially promising. She offers a preview at the Hiro Ballroom. At 7 p.m., 371 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; sold out. (Sisario) UMPHREY'S McGEE (Tonight) One of the few jam bands to gain critical respect in the rock world, Umphrey's McGee, from South Bend, Ind., seamlessly incorporates the irregular meters and gnarled guitar patterns of classic progressive rock into the spoonful-of-sugar textures more common in its milieu, a feat of reconciliation that impresses the connoisseurs and keeps all others on their feet. At 9, Nokia Theater, 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street, (212) 307-7171, nokiatheatrenyc.com; $26.50. (Sisario) UNCLE MONK (Monday) There is life after the Ramones, but who knew that its sound would be bluegrass? Tom Erdelyi, better known as Tommy Ramone, the band's first drummer (and only surviving original member), plays a mean mandolin in this new acoustic duo, singing tautly written songs about the comforts and subtle politics of home life. With Copper Kettle. At 7:30 p.m., Parkside Lounge, 317 East Houston Street, between Clinton and Attorney Streets, Lower East Side, (212) 673-6270, parksidelounge.com. (Sisario) Jazz Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. RASHIED ALI QUINTET (Tonight and tomorrow night) Rashied Ali has led a substantial career in the jazz avant-garde over the past 40 years, beginning with his role in the late-period work of John Coltrane. His drumming drives this hard-bop band, featuring the trumpeter Jumaane Smith and the tenor saxophonist Lawrence Clark. At 8, 10 and midnight, Sweet Rhythm, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street, West Village, (212) 255-3626, sweetrhythmny.com; cover, $25, with a $10 minimum. (Nate Chinen) J. D. ALLEN TRIO (Tonight) J. D. Allen, a harmonically adventurous tenor saxophonist, enjoys strong support from Gregg August on bass and Rudy Royston on drums. At 8:30 and 10, the River Room, Riverbank State Park, Riverside Drive at 145th Street, Hamilton Heights, (212) 491-1500, theriverroomofharlem.com; cover, $5. (Chinen) PETER APFELBAUM AND NEW YORK HIEROGLYPHICS (Thursday) Peter Apfelbaum, a multireedist and pianist, celebrates the 30th anniversary of this adventurous African-inspired band, with collaborators including Abdoulaye Diabate on kora, Peck Allmond on trumpet and Charles Burnham on violin. At 10 p.m., Zebulon, 258 Wythe Avenue, near Metropolitan Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 218-6934, zebuloncafeconcert.com; no cover. (Chinen) STEVE BERESFORD / MICHAEL BATES (Wednesday) Mr. Beresford, a multi-instrumentalist long ensconced in British free-improvisational circles, teams up with the trumpeter Nate Wooley and the drummer Harris Eisenstadt. Then Mr. Bates, a bassist, leads Outside Sources, with Russ Johnson on trumpet, Tony Malaby on tenor saxophone and Jeff Davis on drums. At 8 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) * BOSSABRASIL FESTIVAL (Tuesday through Thursday) On Tuesday and Wednesday this festival showcases the pianist Cesar Camargo Mariano and the guitarist Romero Lubambo in a duo, and the jazz-pop singer Leny Andrade with the Cuban saxophonist and clarinetist Paquito d'Rivera. Thursday's lineup includes the guitarist Dori Caymmi and the singer known as Joyce, with a trio led by the American pianist Kenny Werner. (Through April 21.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080, birdlandjazz.com; cover, $35, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) AVISHAI COHEN / HIROMI'S SONICBLOOM (Tuesday through Thursday) Mr. Cohen is a bassist whose new album, ''As Is '' (Half Note), documents a recent run here with his groove-oriented band. The pianist Hiromi Uehara also has a new release: ''Time Control'' (Telarc), an audacious jolt of fusion with the core group featured here. (Through April 22.) At 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $25 at tables, $15 at the bar, with a $5 minimum. (Chinen) SHANE ENDSLEY BAND (Thursday) Shane Endsley, an adventurous yet lyrical trumpeter, leads a modernistic ensemble stocked with peers like the drummer Rudy Royston and the guitarist Mike Gamble. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Tea Lounge, 837 Union Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 789-2762, tealoungeny.com; donation, $5. (Chinen) E.S.T. / MATTHEW SHIPP (Tomorrow) The initials stand for Esbjorn Svensson Trio, a Swedish jazz-crossover group with an energetic new album called ''Tuesday Wonderland''; taking its lead from Esbjorn Svensson's piano, the ensemble favors somber harmonies and skittering rhythms. Mr. Shipp, in an opening solo piano set, will most likely suggest a darker ideal. At 8 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 501-3330, kaufman-center.org; $25 in advance, $30 tomorrow. (Chinen) ANAT FORT (Tonight) Ms. Fort is a prepossessing young pianist with an auspicious new debut album. She performs her own music with her working trio, the bassist Gary Wang and the drummer Roland Schneider. At 10:30, BAMCafé, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; no cover. (Chinen) JÜRGEN FRIEDRICH TRIO (Tuesday) ''Seismo'' (Pirouet), a recent album by the German pianist Jürgen Friedrich, proposes a daring and articulate strain of post-bop abstraction. As on the recording, Mr. Friedrich performs here with the support of an American rhythm team, the bassist John Hebert and the drummer Tony Moreno. At 10 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $8, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen) BILL FRISELL (Tonight through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) This weekend Mr. Frisell, the guitarist, leads his rubbery trio with the bassist Tony Scherr and the drummer Kenny Wollesen. Next week he welcomes some other familiar colleagues: the clarinetist Don Byron, the trumpeter Ron Miles and the violinist Jenny Scheinman. (Through April 22.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover, $25, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) VINCENT HERRING AND THE EARTH JAZZ AGENTS (Tonight and tomorrow night) Vincent Herring, an alto saxophonist with a tart and bluesy command, presents a driving hard-bop band featuring the pianist Anthony Wonsey. At 8, 10 and 11:30, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662, smokejazz.com; cover, $28. (Chinen) INGRID JENSEN QUARTET (Sunday) A fiery post-bop trumpeter with a book of sharp, original tunes, Ingrid Jensen performs here with the pianist Enrique Haneine, the bassist Carlo DeRosa and the drummer Alison Miller. At 10 p.m., the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) KALAPARUSHA (Tomorrow) Kalaparusha Ahra Difda, a multireedist formerly known as Maurice McIntyre, is a founding member of the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, and has kept that organization's commitment to sonic and spiritual exploration. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Sista's Place, 456 Nostrand Avenue, at Jefferson Avenue, Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, (718) 398-1766, sistasplace.org; cover, $25 in advance, $30 at the door. (Chinen) BIRÉLI LAGRÈNE AND GYPSY JAZZ (Wednesday and Thursday) Mr. Lagrène, a French gypsy guitarist, recently released a double album placing his rhythmically fleet playing in both a solo setting and at the helm of a big band. Here he traffics in the ebullient style of Django Reinhardt, his most famous forebear. (Through April 22.) At 8:30 and 10:30 p.m., Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $35, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) CHRIS LIGHTCAP'S BIGMOUTH (Thursday) This ensemble employs compositional forms as a springboard; Chris Lightcap, a bassist, has creative cohorts in the tenor saxophonists Tony Malaby and Matt Renzi, the pianist James Carney and the drummer Gerald Cleaver. At 8:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen) BILL MAYS TRIO (Tonight and tomorrow night) Bill Mays, a harmonically astute pianist, focuses on popular movie themes in this engagement with the bassist Rufus Reid and the drummer John Riley. At 8 and 9:45, Kitano Hotel, 66 Park Avenue, at 38th Street, (212) 885-7119, kitano.com; cover, $25, with a $15 minimum. (Chinen) * CHARLES MINGUS 85TH BIRTHDAY CELEBRATION (Tuesday through Thursday) Several of the most exuberant repertory bands in the city operate with a common inspiration, the bassist and composer Charles Mingus, and all of them will appear at Jazz at Lincoln Center over the next week. A bruising big band called the Mingus Dynasty holds court on Tuesday, while the more chamberlike Mingus Orchestra performs on Wednesday and Thursday. (Through April 22.) At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 258-9595, jalc.org; cover, $30, with a minimum of $10 at tables, $5 at the bar. (Chinen) WES MONTGOMERY TRIBUTE ALL-STARS (Tonight through Sunday night) Peter Bernstein occupies the hot seat in this salute to the guitarist Wes Montgomery, but he has plenty of company, including the trumpeter Jeremy Pelt, the saxophonist Eric Alexander and the drummer Ray Appleton, a Montgomery alumnus. At 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $30; $25 on Sunday. (Chinen) MIKE MORENO SEXTET (Thursday) The versatile young guitarist Mike Moreno has a new album, ''Between the Lines'' (World Culture Music), that establishes his graces as a composer. His sonorous band includes the saxophonists John Ellis and Marcus Strickland and the drummer Kendrick Scott. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $12; members, $10. (Chinen) SAM NEWSOME (Wednesday) Mr. Newsome, a soprano saxophonist, teams up with the pianist Lucian Ban to create a contemporary jazz informed by Romanian folk music. Their band includes Cristian Soleanu and Alex Harding on saxophones, Arthur Balogh on bass and Willard Dyson on drums. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $12; members, $10. (Chinen) AARON PARKS QUARTET (Tonight and tomorrow night) Aaron Parks, the precocious pianist in Terence Blanchard's working band, leads his own quartet with Mike Moreno on guitar, Matt Brewer on bass and Marcus Gilmore on drums. At 9 and 10:30, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $15. (Chinen) * SONNY ROLLINS (Tonight) Last year this tenor saxophonist released ''Sonny, Please'' (Doxy), his best studio recording in more than a decade. Performing his only area concert this year, he leads a trusted band, and presumably will offer searching solos, songbook obscurities and an unsinkable calypso. At 8 p.m., New Jersey Performing Arts Center, One Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722, njpac.org; $20 to $78. (Chinen) * SUN RA ARKESTRA/NUBLU ORCHESTRA (Tonight and Monday) The Sun Ra Arkestra, led by the alto saxophonist Marshall Allen, carries on the boisterous avant-gardism of its cosmic namesake with a ragtag, rhythmic brio. The Nublu Orchestra, conducted by the sagacious Butch Morris, creates a whorl of timbres in the service of groove. The two bands share a bill tonight; Mr. Morris and company perform alone at Nublu on Monday. Tonight at 7:30, Paul Robeson Theater, 40 Greene Avenue, near Adelphi Street, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 783-9794, ticketweb .com; $15. Nublu Orchestra plays on Monday at 10 p.m. and midnight, Nublu, 62 Avenue C, near Fifth Street, East Village, (212) 979-9925, nublu.net; cover, $10. (Chinen) * GONZALO RUBALCABA QUINTET (Tuesday through Thursday) Gonzalo Rubalcaba is an astonishing pianist technically, and he plays with a dramatic flourish and rhythmic depth evocative of his native Cuba. He has superb partners here: the trumpeter Michael Rodriguez, the saxophonist Yosvany Terry, the bassist Matt Brewer and the drummer Francisco Mela. (Through April 22.) At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $25. (Chinen) SLAVIC SOUL PARTY (Tomorrow and Tuesday) The percussionist Matt Moran leads this Balkan brass band, which has a spirited new album called ''Teknochek Collision'' (Barbès). At 10 p.m. tomorrow, 9 p.m. on Tuesday, Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10.
