(Chinen) SPIDER'S WEB (Tonight) The pianist Ross Lossing, the bassist John Hebert and the drummer Jeff Williams make up this ensemble, which strives for the flexibility and intricacy implied by its name. At 8:30, Center for Improvisational Music, 295 Douglass Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (212) 631-5882, schoolforimprov.org; cover, $10; $6 for students. (Chinen) TAIN AND THE EBONIX (Thursday) Jeff (Tain) Watts, one of the most dazzlingly propulsive drummers to emerge in the last 25 years, marks the release of ''Folk Songs'' (Dark Key Music), a new album with this band featuring Christian McBride on bass, David Kikowski on piano and Marcus Strickland on saxophones. At 9:30 p.m., the Cutting Room, 19 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 691-1900, thecuttingroomnyc.com; cover, $15. (Chinen) * TODO TANGO (Tonight and tomorrow night) The Argentinean bassist Pablo Aslan, a prominent figure in the burgeoning jazz-tango subculture, is a featured guest at this concert; it also happens to be the final Jazz at Lincoln Center performance by the Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra. At 8, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 721-6500, jalc.org; $37.50 to $127.50. (Chinen) * DAVID TORN (Tuesday) Mr. Torn is an inventive guitarist and producer whose new album, ''Prezens'' (ECM), suggests a texturally slippery approach to group improvisation. That has something to do with the alto saxophonist Tim Berne, the keyboardist Craig Taborn and the drummer Tom Rainey, who appear here; but it's also an expression of his gift for organizing sound. At 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; cover, $20, with a two-drink minimum. (Chinen) * VISION TONIC (Sunday, Tuesday and Wednesday) In response to the sudden closing of Tonic (see John Zorn, below), the Vision Festival has absorbed a few new bookings for an off-season series one block to the east. Sunday's schedule includes a group led by the harpist Zeena Parkins, while Tuesday's will include a rare performance by the Scandinavian trio called the Thing. On Wednesday the alto saxophonist Oliver Lake will perform with the multi-instrumentalist Eugene Chadbourne. At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Clemente Soto Vélez Cultural Center, 107 Suffolk Street, at Rivington Street, Lower East Side, (212) 696-6681, visionfestival.org; cover, $10, and a one-drink minimum per set. (Chinen) * JOHN ZORN IMPROV (Tonight) Noise is the currency at a John Zorn improv party, which can feature any number of audacious and open-minded musicians. Usually the action has a jubilant tinge, but this happens to be the final night of programming at Tonic, an avant-garde hub that Mr. Zorn helped establish nearly a decade ago. At 7:30 and 9:30, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501, tonicnyc.com; donation, $20. (Chinen) Classical Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music. Opera * 'ANDREA CHÉNIER' (Tomorrow and Wednesday) Ben Heppner, arguably the leading Wagnerian tenor of our day, continues his bold explorations of far-flung repertory with the title role of Giordano's swashbuckling verismo opera, in the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Nicolas Joël's 1996 production. Mr. Heppner may lack the vocal colorings and idiomatic expressivity of the heroic Italian tenors who excelled in this touchstone role, that of a poet with libertarian fervor during the French Revolution. But in his honest and compelling portrayal he sings with burnished sound, vigor and lyrical sensitivity. The rich-voiced soprano Violeta Urmana sings Maddalena for the final performance on Wednesday night, but the popular soprano Aprile Millo takes over the role tomorrow. The stentorian baritone Juan Pons sings Gérard. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $42 to $220 tomorrow, $15 to $175 for Wednesday. (Anthony Tommasini) * 'CURLEW RIVER' (Tonight and tomorrow night) Britten called his one-act opera ''Curlew River'' a church parable. Inspired by a Japanese Noh play, the work takes the form of a sacred ritual, with a procession of monks enacting a mystery play about a madwoman who crosses a river with a ferryman in search of her abducted son. The Japan Society offers a staging of this haunting and seldom-seen work, a co-production with L'Opéra de Rouen/Haute-Normandie. Directed by Yoshi Oida, it stars the tenor Michael Bennett as the madwoman, with musical direction by David Stern. At 7:30, 333 East 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 715-1258, japansociety.org; $52; $45 for members. (Tommasini) 'FLAVIO' (Tomorrow) Candy pink and candy green set the tone for Chas Rader-Shieber's antic production of an opera that consists of arias nestled side by side, bright and sweet as a box of fondants: much of a good thing, leaving a reasonably pleasant aftertaste. On the first night of the City Opera revival, the singers seemed to be fighting to find their pitches: making company debuts are Katherine Rohrer, a light mezzo with a nice tone who didn't quite find her feet on the first note; Gerald Thompson, a promising but sometimes wild countertenor; and the conductor William Lacey, who led a strong, lithe performance. David Walker did a fine job as the foppish, foolish king of the title. At 1:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 to $125. (Anne Midgette) * 'GIULIO CESARE' (Tonight and Tuesday) The auditorium of the Metropolitan Opera may be too big for Handel. But the cast that has been assembled for the company's revival of ''Giulio Cesare'' is so exceptional that the lack of intimacy does not matter. With a score of astounding richness and variety, the opera emerges as an affecting and psychologically astute masterpiece. With his alluring voice, the countertenor David Daniels excels in the daunting title role. The soprano Ruth Ann Swenson makes a vocally exquisite Cleopatra. Patricia Bardon, a rich-toned Irish mezzo-soprano, brings noble bearing and lyrical elegance to the role of Cornelia. Harry Bicket elicits a surprisingly stylish account of the score from the orchestra. The downside is John Copley's tacky production. At 7:30, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $205. (Tommasini) 'MADAMA BUTTERFLY' (Tomorrow and Wednesday) East-West relations go south in Puccini's famous melodrama. Shu-Ying Li sings Cio-Cio-San, and Christopher Jackson is Lieutenant Pinkerton in this New York City Opera production. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; sold out tomorrow;$25 to $115 for Wednesday. (Bernard Holland) 'TURANDOT' (Tomorrow, Monday and Thursday) For spectacle and big music, the Franco Zeffirelli production of Puccini's final opera, at the Met, is hard to beat. For compelling leads, you might have to look elsewhere: Andrea Gruber sounded wobbly and thin on the first night of this revival, and Richard Margison effortful, though he marshaled his forces for ''Nessun dorma.'' Only Hei-Kyung Hong's Liù, with her reliably floating pianos, was really worth the price of admission. But spectacle and size are evidently enough to keep tickets selling briskly for this one. Marco Armiliato conducts. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., Monday and Thursday at 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; sold out tomorrow and Thursday; $175 tickets remain for Monday. (Midgette) 'DIE ZAUBERFLÖTE' (Tonight and tomorrow night) The last two performances of this new look at the Mozart favorite by the South African director William Kentridge and the Belgian opera house La Monnaie. At 7:30, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; $40 to $125. (Holland) Classical Music AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (Sunday) Franz Schreker's much-discussed and little-heard opera ''Der Ferne Klang'' is taken up by the enterprising Leon Botstein in this concert performance. At 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $27 to $55. (Holland) CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER (Sunday and Tuesday) Nicholas Maw is one of the Chamber Music Society's 2006-7 ''season composers.'' Here the society presents his ''Roman Canticle,'' a setting of Robert Browning's poem ''Two in the Campagna,'' for mezzo-soprano, flute, viola and harp. Angelika Kirchschlager, the mezzo-soprano originally scheduled to perform the work, has been replaced by Peggy Kriha Dye, a soprano. The program also includes Charles Martin Loeffler's ''Quatre Poems'' for voice, viola and piano; Dvorak's Piano Trio in E minor; and Mendelssohn's String Quintet No. 1. Sunday at 5 p.m., Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org; $28 to $50. (Vivien Schweitzer) NELSON FREIRE (Thursday) New York audiences experience Mr. Freire's pianism only in glimpses, but this Brazilian returns to the Metropolitan Museum of Art with Bach, Beethoven and Chopin standards, Debussy's ''Children's Corner Suite'' and excerpts from Albéniz's ''Iberia.'' At 8 p.m., (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $50. (Holland) * OSVALDO GOLIJOV/DAWN UPSHAW YOUNG ARTISTS CONCERT (Tomorrow and Sunday) To foster collaboration between singers and composers, the soprano Dawn Upshaw, through the auspices of Carnegie Hall's Weill Music Institute, has presented joint workshops with leading composers, notably John Harbison in 2004 and Osvaldo Golijov this season. A roster of young composers, paired with young singers, has been collaborating in these workshops for some months, under the guidance of Mr. Golijov and Ms. Upshaw. The resulting works will be presented this weekend in two very affordable programs. Needless to say, each piece will be receiving its world premiere. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $15. (Tommasini) KALICHSTEIN-LAREDO-ROBINSON TRIO (Sunday) This venerable piano trio is celebrating its 30th anniversary since making its debut in 1977 at the White House for President Jimmy Carter's inauguration. On Sunday it performs Leon Kirchner's Trio No. 2 and is joined by the violist Pinchas Zukerman for Mozart's Piano Quartet in E flat (K. 493), and by the double bassist Harold Robinson for Schubert's ''Trout'' Quintet. At 2 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $23 to $75. (Schweitzer) * OLIVER KNUSSEN (Tonight) This British composer has a significant body of bracing and inventive scores to his credit. But in the last decade or so he has had a woeful record of meeting deadlines for commissioned pieces. An ambitious new work for the pianist Peter Serkin and a large chamber ensemble was supposed to have had its long-awaited premiere tonight at Zankel Hall. Alas, Mr. Knussen was not able to complete the score. In its place he will offer his ''Requiem -- Songs for Sue,'' a New York premiere. The program, featuring Mr. Serkin, the soprano Susan Narucki and the Zankel Band, boosted here to the size of a chamber orchestra, still looks enticing, with works by Messiaen, Magnus Lindberg and Julian Anderson. And Mr. Knussen is an accomplished conductor, which has been one of the problems, actually: his conducting has taken time from his composing. At 7:30, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $25 and $35. (Tommasini) * KARITA MATTILA (Wednesday) She's been called the leading lyric soprano of her generation -- though that was before she took on ''Fidelio'' and ''Salome'' -- and praised for her lied interpretations, particularly of Finnish song, represented by one set on this thoughtful and wide-ranging concert. The other pieces are Barber's ''Hermit Songs,'' a set of Wolf songs and Turina's ''Poema en Forma de Canciones.'' Martin Katz is the pianist. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $25 to $84. (Midgette) NETHERLANDS BACH SOCIETY (Wednesday) The Netherlands Bach Society, a period-instrument ensemble founded in 1921, says it is the oldest early-music group still performing in that country. On Wednesday Jos Van Veldhoven, its artistic director, leads the ensemble and soloists -- including the sopranos Dorothee Mields and Johanette Zomer, the alto Matthew White, the tenor Charles Daniels and the bass Peter Harvey -- in Bach's monumental Mass in B minor. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Museum of Art, (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $50. (Schweitzer) NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC (Today and tomorrow) Sakari Oramo conducts the orchestra in Sibelius's Sixth Symphony. Lisa Batiashvili is the soloist for Shostakovich's First Violin Concerto. Today at 11 a.m., tomorrow at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nyphil.org; $24 to $79. (Holland) * ORPHEUS CHAMBER ORCHESTRA (Tomorrow) A new piece by Ingram Marshall is a good reason to go to a concert. Perhaps the only reason Mr. Marshall is not better known is that he's not played more, and the Cheswatyr New Music Initiative, which teamed up with Orpheus and WNYC to commission ''Orphic Memories,'' is doing its bit to change that by ensuring that this piece is played on the orchestra's tour and broadcast. As for the music: think Romantic sensibility and lushness filtered through an electronics sensibility. The conductorless ensemble is adding to the program Gil Shaham in the Beethoven Violin Concerto, as well as Mendelssohn's Sinfonia No. 10. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $30 to $88. (Midgette) * POCKET CONCERTOS (Tomorrow) Miller Theater presents the second installment of its innovative Pocket Concertos series, a three-year project commissioning 12 composers to write 12 concertos. The lineup tomorrow features ''Spin 5,'' a five-movement violin piece by Charles Wuorinen performed by Jennifer Koh; ''People Mountain People Sea,'' a cello work by Huang Ruo performed by Jian Wang; Anthony Davis's ''You Have the Right to Remain Silent,'' for clarinet, performed by J. D. Parran; and Sebastian Currier's Piano Concerto, with Emma Tahmizian. Brad Lubman leads the Perspectives Ensemble. At 8 p.m., Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 854-7799, millertheater.com; $25; $15 for students. (Schweitzer) CHRISTOPHE ROUSSET (Thursday) Call it ''Family Ties'': the concert by this master harpsichordist features music by Louis Couperin and his nephew, the better-known François, and by Johann Sebastian Bach and one of his most famous sons, Carl Philipp Emanuel. François's harpsichord music represents an acme of the French style; Mr. Rousset will play a linked group of five pieces, or ordre, from the last of his four books of collected harpsichord works. From the Bachs, the offerings are the French Suite No. 3 by the father, and the third of the seminal ''Württemberg'' sonatas by the son. At 7:30 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $40. (Midgette) * UBS VERBIER FESTIVAL CHAMBER ORCHESTRA (Thursday) This chamber orchestra, whose members are chosen from the best current members and alumni of the UBS Verbier Festival Orchestra, will perform Mozart concertos with the first-rate violinist Maxim Vengerov as soloist and conductor. The program includes the Violin Concertos Nos. 2 and 4 (K. 211 and 218), with Mr. Vengerov's own cadenzas, and the Sinfonia Concertante in E flat (K. 364), with the violist Lawrence Power -- repertory this group recently recorded for a new disc on EMI. The concert also includes Shostakovich's Chamber Symphony. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $30 to $98. (Schweitzer) YOUNG CONCERT ARTISTS IRENE DIAMOND CONCERT (Wednesday) Young Concert Artists discovers talented instrumentalists, singers and composers through yearly auditions; the organization then presents them in concerts and assists in managing their careers. The group's annual Irene Diamond Concert spotlights two pianists and a flutist. Chu-Fang Huang plays Grieg's Piano Concerto in A minor; Dora Seres plays Mozart's Flute Concerto in G; and Gleb Ivanov performs Prokofiev's Piano Concerto No. 3. Scott Yoo, an alumnus of the group, conducts the Orchestra of St. Luke's. At 7:30 p.m., Rose Theater, Broadway at 60th Street, (212) 307-6656, yca.org; $15 to 35. (Schweitzer) Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. * AILEY II (Tonight through Sunday; Wednesday and Thursday) Alvin Ailey created a second, or junior, company in 1974, almost casually, as a way of working on new choreography. Ailey II is now a world-class troupe, filled with dancers who are not only good but also capable of performing with a youthful hunger for their art, as well as with a reverence for dance that is a part of the mission of the company director, Sylvia Waters, whom Ailey himself chose to direct that first group. Now Ailey II is coming home, performing in the black-box theater that is part of the Ailey headquarters: newer, grander and more gleaming than Ailey ever envisioned. The repertory will include new dances by Abdel Salaam, Darrell Grand Moultrie and Jessica Lang, along with Ailey's ''Streams'' and a chunk of Ailey highlights. (Through April 22.) Tonight and Wednesday and Thursday nights at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m., Ailey Citigroup Theater, 405 West 55th Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444, alvinailey.org; $40; $10 student rush tickets available. (Jennifer Dunning) 'THE A.W.A.R.D. SHOW!' (Sunday) The latest in a series of performances produced by Neta Pulvermacher displays new choreography by Ashleigh Leite, Kyle Abraham, Sara Jull and Jennie MaryTai Liu. Discussions with the choreographers follow the dancing. At 7 p.m., Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 334-7479, joyce.org; free. (Jack Anderson) * LES BALLETS GRANDIVA (Monday and Tuesday) The lads -- or lasses? -- in this all-male ballet troupe will present the world premiere of Brian Reeder's ''They Who Wore White Flowers,'' the local premiere of Victor Trevino's ''Grand Tarantelle'' and their own versions of war-horse classical ballet delicacies like the pas de deux from ''Spartacus.'' At 8 p.m., Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-4551, symphonyspace.org; $21 and $26; $15 for students and 65+. (Dunning) LES BALLETS JAZZ DE MONTREAL (Tuesday through Thursday) A Canadian company that refuses to adhere to strict definitions of either ballet or jazz dances its way through two new works: one inspired by Brazilian music and dance, the other set to both Vivaldi arias and folk songs from Quebec. Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $40. (Anderson) KIMBERLY BARTOSIK AND JENNIFER ALLEN (Thursday) Ms. Allen's ''Open'' explores the joys and terrors of childhood. Ms. Bartosik's ''Ecsteriority I'' is a meditation on distance and closeness, set in a debris-filled landscape. (Through April 21.) At 8 p.m., the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793, thekitchen.org; $10. (Anderson) * DANCE AT DNA: TAMI STRONACH DANCE AND 'OB.JECT.OB.JECT' (Tonight through Sunday, and Thursday) In the new piece ''Pinchas the Fish-People and the Great Flood,'' Ms. Stronach reconfigures a myth, telling the story from the perspective of mermaids. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Sunday at 3 p.m. ''OB.ject.ob.JECT'' focuses on dances by women, among them Jody Oberfelder, Preeti Vasudevan and Hana Van Der Kolk, as well as solos choreographed by Melinda Allen, Tiffany Rhynard, Andrea Woods and Tina Vasquez, and performed by Inspirit/Christal Brown. (Through April 22.) Thursday at 8 p.m. This beehive dance organization is also host to ''Works in Progress,'' in which choreographers show excerpts from new pieces for audience commentary. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., Dance New Amsterdam, 280 Broadway, at Chambers Street, TriBeCa, (212) 279-4200, dnadance.org; $17 (Stronach); $20 (''OB.ject'') and $10 (suggested donation for ''Works in Progress''). (Dunning) * DANCE PARTY (Tomorrow) In a shared program, Larry Keigwin and his company will present ''Bolero,'' a new work for 80 performers about the challenges of life in New York City, with Chris Elam and his Misnomer Dance Theater dancing Mr. Elam's new ''future perfect,'' which focuses on belonging and fulfillment. At 8 p.m., Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, 566 LaGuardia Place, at Washington Square South, Greenwich Village, (212) 279-4200, www.skirballcenter.nyu.edu; $20 and $30. (Dunning) * EIFMAN BALLET OF ST. PETERSBURG (Tonight through Sunday; Wednesday and Thursday) Boris Eifman, one of Russia's most flamboyantly theatrical choreographers, presents an opening gala tonight, with excerpts from six of his ballets and the world premiere of ''Cassandra,'' by the young choreographer Nikita Dmitrievsky. Next week the group will also perform ''Red Giselle'' and the New York premiere of Mr. Eifman's ''Seagull,'' based on Chekhov's classic play. Tonight and Wednesday and Thursday nights at 8, Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 2 p.m., City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212, nycitycenter.org; $35 to $100. (Anderson) * GENDER BENDER: THREE WEEKS OF SEXUAL CONFUSION IN DANCE (Tonight, and tomorrow and Thursday nights) This festival continues with performances by Les Ballets Grandiva (see above) tonight and tomorrow, ending next week with a program by Monica Bill Barnes and nicholasleichterdance. Ms. Barnes's modern-dance choreography is known for its theatricality and knowing humor. Nicholas Leichter explores race and sex with provocative pairings of dancers in work that draws from traditional and street dance styles. At 8:30, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org; $17 to $25. (Dunning) GREEN SPACE BLOOMS: DANCE IN QUEENS (Tonight through Sunday night) This program features a performance each night by Valerie Green and her Dance Entropy, with the guest companies and musicians Mariko Tanabe Danse and Anand Patole (tonight); Gloria McLean/Lifedance and Laurie Hockman (tomorrow) and Diane Vivona/DV Dance and Balkan Music (Sunday). At 8, Green Space Studio, 37-24 24th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 956-3037, greenspacestudio.com; $20; $15 for students, dancers and 65+. (Dunning) * LAR LUBOVITCH DANCE COMPANY (Tuesday through Thursday) Known for the rich flow of his modern-dance choreography, Mr. Lubovitch and his eloquent dancers will present two programs, which include ''Little Rhapsodies,'' with Rasta Thomas, a guest dancer, and Pedja Muzijevic, who will play the Schumann piano score and the music for ''Dvorak Serenade in E.'' The Limón Dance Company will be a guest in Mr. Lubovitch's ''Recordare,'' in programming that also includes his ''Love Stories.'' The performances on Tuesday and Wednesday include ''Love Stories,'' ''Little Rhapsodies'' and ''Dvorak Serenade in E.'' ''Recordare'' replaces ''Love Stories'' on Thursday. (Through April 21.) At 8 p.m., Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, 566 LaGuardia Place, at Washington Square South, Greenwich Village, (212) 279-4200, www.skirballcenter.nyu.edu; $35; $20 for students and 65+. (Dunning) BARBARA MAHLER (Thursday). ''There's No Place Like Home'' features choreography distinguished by tight focus and strong physicality. (Through April 22.) At 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194, danspaceproject.org; $15. (Anderson) NEW YORK THEATER BALLET: 'DANCE ON A SHOESTRING' (Tonight and tomorrow night) This company and its students will perform hourlong programs of new works, classics and revivals. At 7, Dance Gallery, 30 East 31st Street, Manhattan, (212) 679-0401, nytb.org; $20. (Dunning) * THE NOTHING FESTIVAL (Wednesday and Thursday) Tere O'Connor, the organizer of this two-week festival, asked several choreographers and groups to create new works out of nothing, dances with no stories, no music and no outside sources. This week's participants are Douglas Dunn, Hijack, Sam Kim and Dean Moss. (Through April 21.) At 7:30 p.m., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org; $20 and $12. (Anderson) PALISSIMO (Tonight through Sunday) Injuries to two cast members forced the postponement of ''Le Petit Mort/Now It's Time to Say Goodbye,'' by Pavel Zustiak. Mr. Zustiak's company is back in business now with a new work that ponders death and confrontations with mortality. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 4 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 4 p.m., Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101, ps122.org; $20; $15 for students and 65+. (Dunning) QUEENS THEATER ASIAN CULTURAL FESTIVAL (Thursday) The festival opens with American debut performances by the Pasha Dance Company of Korea, directed by Hwang Mi-sook. At 8 p.m., Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 760-0064, queenstheatre.org; $28; $26 for 65+; $20 for students. (Dunning) PILAR RIOJA (Today and tomorrow) The doyenne of Spanish dance in New York City will present a program that includes two new works: a stylized flamenco dance called ''Muero Porque No Muero'' (''I die because I can't die''), to music by Surinach, and ''Bamberas,'' whose title refers to a form of folk music that fuses flamenco with traditional Andalusian song to the beat of fandangos. (Through April 22.) Today at 11 a.m. and 8 p.m., tomorrow at 8 p.m., Repertorio Español Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 225-9920, repertorio.org; $30 to $50. (Dunning) AYNSLEY VANDENBROUCKE MOVEMENT GROUP (Wednesday and Thursday) ''And How Should I Begin?,'' a dance of connections and missed connections, takes its inspiration from T. S. Eliot's ''Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock,'' but the choreographer says you don't need to know the poem to understand the dance. (Through April 21.) At 8 p.m., Baryshnikov Arts Center, 450 West 37th Street, Manhattan, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com; $15. (Anderson) Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. Museums * American Museum of Natural History: 'GOLD,' through Aug. 19. Having delved into pearls, diamonds and amber, the museum applies its time-tested show-and-tell formula to the premier precious natural material, gold. This astounding array of art, artifacts and natural samples -- larded with fascinating facts and tales -- ranges from prehistoric times to the present. Stops along the way include pre-Columbian empires, sunken treasure, Bangladesh dowry rituals and the moon landing. It turns out that gold comes from the earth in forms as beautiful as anything man has thought to do with it, but that gold ingots have a brute force all their own. You are certain to emerge with mind boggled and eyes dazzled. Central Park West and 79th Street, (212) 769-5100, amnh.org. (Roberta Smith) * Chelsea Art Museum: 'DANGEROUS BEAUTY,' through April 21. A somewhat timely update of a well-worn idea, this show of contemporary works in a variety of mediums by 18 artists examines the beauty myth in art, advertising and the fashion industry. Eloquent but blunt imagery of anorexic girls, chiseled male beefcake and close-ups of surgically deformed faces predominates, reminding us of the violent extremes to which some people will go in pursuit of society's ideal of beauty and a designer body. The rest of the show -- often pointing an accusatory finger at skinny models, cosmetic labels and the mass media -- feels familiar in its critique, but the basic premise about the ideology of beauty in our culture is beyond argument. 556 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-0719, chelseaartmuseum.org. (Benjamin Genocchio) FRICK COLLECTION: 'GEORGE STUBBS (1724-1806): A CELEBRATION,' through May 27. One of the finest horse painters ever, Stubbs knew his subjects from head to hoof and skin to bones. He painted other mammals too: dogs, lions, tigers, oxen, monkeys and humans. This intimate show of 17 Stubbs paintings from English collections reveals his admirable range, although the people he portrayed in two large, late canvases, elegiac celebrations of farm workers raking and reaping grain, have the stiffness of figures on a candy box. His horses are his true monuments. 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, (212) 288-0700, frick.org. (Grace Glueck) INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: 'HENRI CARTIER-BRESSON'S SCRAPBOOK: PHOTOGRAPHS, 1932-46,' through April 29. Arrived by way of the Fondation Henri Cartier-Bresson in Paris, this show has more than 300 of the prints the photographer glued into an album and toted to New York for curators at the Museum of Modern Art to cull. Captured by the Nazis, he had been presumed dead when the Modern planned his retrospective. Then he turned up alive -- the ''posthumous'' exhibition opened, with him in attendance, in 1947. The current exhibition reconstructs as best as possible the layout of the scrapbook as Cartier-Bresson originally organized the pictures. It surveys the revolutionary work he shot in Spain, Italy, Mexico, Britain and France. His taste for uncanny detail linked him to Surrealism and Surrealist wit, but unlike many Surrealists, he remained committed to human values. Boys mug at his camera. Prostitutes swan. Their gazes equalize them with us. 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000, icp.org. (Michael Kimmelman) * JAPAN SOCIETY: 'Awakenings: Zen Figure Painting in Medieval Japan,' through June 17. Japan Society has a history of producing exquisite shows of Buddhist art. And this one, with four dozen paintings of Buddhists gods and saints hung in shrinelike alcoves, is transporting. And it covers an unusually broad swath of geography, bringing together 13th- to 16th-century hanging scrolls not only from Japan but also from China, where Zen Buddhism, called Chan in Chinese, originated. 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155, japansociety.org. (Holland Cotter) * metropolitan museum of art: 'Venice and the Islamic World, 828-1797,' through July 8. At its peak in the Renaissance, Venice, the Most Serene, was a giant, clamorous Costco-on-the-Rialto. All the necessities, and most of the luxuries, of life flowed into and through it, with many items arriving from Islamic Africa and the Near East. With classic Met largesse, this exhibition suggests the spectacle of two different cultures meeting in one fantastic city, in which commerce and love of beauty, those great levelers, unite them in a fruitful bond. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Cotter) * El Museo del Barrio: 'The Disappeared (Los Desaparecidos),' through June 17. The most potent show of contemporary political art of the season, and one of the most moving shows of any kind in the city right now. The title refers to a peculiarly chilling form of violence associated with political upheavals in Latin America over the past 40 years, and now becoming more common in Iraq. 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272, elmuseo .org. (Cotter) * Museum of Modern Art: JEFF WALL, through May 14. This majestic show makes a great case for Mr. Wall as the most complete, if traditional, of the untraditional artists who emerged from the turmoil of Conceptual Art. His often immense color transparencies mounted on light boxes are enthralling vehicles, intent on giving pleasure while making a point or two about society, art, history, visual perception, the human animal or all of the above. An imposing blend of painting, street photography and movies, they blur reality and artifice, narrative and form, detail and the big statement. You can't stop looking at them. (212) 708-9400, moma.org (Smith) * Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Lorna Simpson,' through May 6. This tight, refined and impassioned survey covers more than 20 years of Lorna Simpson's career, from her photo-and-text meditations on race and sexism in the 1980s, to her more recent short films, which unite American history and personal history in forceful and lyrical ways. It would be easy to put some of this work on a shelf as ''identity art,'' but with an African-American woman holding one of the highest offices in the United States government, an African-American man running for president, and the nation embroiled in what some people view as an ethnic war, this art is entirely of the moment. (212) 570-3676, whitney.org. (Cotter) Galleries: Chelsea * 'PAINTINGS, FLAGS & IRON: HAITIAN ART FROM THE LAST FIFTY YEARS' This splendid exhibition offers total immersion in the originality and continued vitality of Haiti's self-taught artists. Works by well-known painters like Hector Hyppolite, Toussaint Auguste and Rigaud Benoit range across religion, history and everyday themes. They include still lifes, landscapes and Pierre Joseph Valcin's enthralling rendering of a maternity ward. The forged and welded sculptures of Georges Liautaud and Gabriel Bien-Aimé are on a par with Bill Traylor's antic silhouette drawings. And there are no words for the extravagantly sequined and beaded flags depicting Voodoo spirits and saints, except fabulous. Edward Thorp Gallery, 210 11th Avenue, at 25th Street, (212) 691-6565, through April 21. (Smith) * Lamar Peterson Best known for his fanciful, Pop-inflected paintings of African-American suburban life, this young painter smashes that subject to smithereens in his new work, a promising advancement that is already yielding rewards. Fredericks & Freiser, 536 West 24th Street, (212) 633-6555, fredericksfreisergallery.com, through April 28. (Cotter) Galleries: Other 'Gifts of the Forest: Native Traditions in Wood and Bark' Drawn from the collections of the Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center in Connecticut, this show celebrates the trees of the rich forests that once covered the Northeast, yielding essential materials to the Pequot and other Eastern Woodland cultures. The objects run from ancient woodworking tools to contemporary objects that carry on tribal traditions, like the simple and beautiful wooden flute made in 1999 by Hawk Henires (Nipmuc) and adorned with an elegantly carved bird motif. Many things here were made in the 19th and 20th centuries: handsome woven baskets, carved bowls and spoons, decorated cradle boards for carrying babies, birch bark canoe models, an elegant birch-bark hamper whose sides bear a stylized tree motif. UBS Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, between 51st and 52nd Streets, (212) 713-2885, through April 27. (Glueck) * 'THOMAS STRUTH: Making Time' Through the 1990s, the German photographer Thomas Struth became an art world celebrity for his outsize, absorbing portraits of crowds interacting with artwork in the world's great museums. As a follow-up, he is presenting the American premiere of two new series of pictures of audiences beholding single masterpieces in the Museo Nacional del Prado in Madrid, and the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia. The show, which cannily allows us to look safely at others looking at art, is one of the most visually sumptuous and thought-probing in the city. Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 977-7160, through April 28. (Genocchio) Last Chance * KRISTIN BAKER: SURGE AND SHADOW In these clever, ambitious mergers of Pop, Minimalism and Abstract Expressionism, abstract painting takes another turn for the spectacular, aided by the freshly white-on-white Deitch space. Cataclysmic compositions and an all-plastic, labor-intensive process strike the eye with a dazzling newness, but the eye adjusts and is eventually bored. A series of smaller studies evades the prescribed soullessness. Deitch Projects, 18 Wooster Street, near Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 343-7300; closes tomorrow. (Smith) * 'Early Chinese Buddhist Sculpture,' Asia Week is over, but its essence lingers on in this exhibition of beautiful carved stone figures of Buddhas and bodhisattvas dating from the Northern Wei to Tang periods in China. This is the type of work that elicited rapturous responses when shown in London and Washington a few seasons back. Throckmorton Fine Art, 145 East 57th Street, third floor, (212) 223-1059; closes tomorrow. (Cotter) * ANYA KIELAR: 'LADY' The traditions of photomontage, collage and assemblage are sliced, diced and reconfigured here with surgical precision, feminist wit and a terrific sense of light, dark and color. The works range from two to three dimensions, with the best -- mysterious boxed collages that cross Hannah Hoch with Kembra Phaler -- landing squarely in between. Daniel Reich Gallery, 537A West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-4949, danielreichgallery.com; closes tomorrow. (Smith) * MOMA: Armando ReverÓn Unless you spotted his single smoke-puff of a painting at MoMA months ago, Armando Reverón probably means nothing to you. Why should he? The artist, who died in 1954, spent most of his life in a shack by the sea in his native Venezuela. Many of his contemporaries dismissed him as nuts. His white-on-white pictures are practically unphotographable. But chances are that if you visit this retrospective, you'll find yourself thinking about him a lot. His art and his story are like few others, and so is the museum's inspired installation: a single, long corridor with cabinetlike rooms of paintings on either side and, at the very end, against a sea-green wall, a life-size doll with giant bat wings floating overhead. (212) 708-9400, moma.org; closes on Monday. (Cotter) WILHELM SASNAL A truncated, slightly altered version of a Polish film from the 1960s provides the frame or caption for often drab, studiously incomplete paintings that reciprocate with hints of cinematic light or depictions of movie screens. A genuine sense of postwar Communist bloc deprivation is evoked, without giving the viewer much to work with. Anton Kern Gallery, 532 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 367-9663; closes tomorrow. (Smith) * 'David Shapiro: Rock Iraq,' A while back, David Shapiro filled a gallery with the empty containers of all the consumer products he had bought and used over two years. His current Pierogi solo takes up less space: it's an 8-by-8-foot tabletop model of an imaginary benefit concert. The exact cause espoused isn't stated. But with no musicians present, and corporate logos plastering the concert hall walls, emptiness and waste are the unmistakable themes. Pierogi, 177 North Ninth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-2144, pierogi2000.com; closes on Monday. (Cotter)

When Isiah Thomas called for his team to come together in a circle at the end of practice Thursday, the coaches and trainers outnumbered the eight players who were healthy enough to participate. With their season drawing to a close, the Knicks have been gutted by injuries -- so much that Malik Rose, a veteran forward not known for his ball-handling skills, ran plays at point guard during practice.

''We must expect this. It is worse outside in Baghdad so the violence will definitely, eventually reach into the International Zone. If you are unable to protect your people, eventually you will be unable to protect yourself.'' ASMA AL-MUSAWI, a parliamentarian, on a suicide bomber's attack in the Parliament building. [A9]

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Park Jin-pyo In Korean, with English subtitles Not rated; 122 minutes With ''Voice of a Murderer,'' the unpredictable Korean director Park Jin-pyo returns to the docudrama form he employed so provocatively in ''Too Young to Die,'' his 2002 examination of septuagenarian sex. That film was judged unfit for public viewing by the Korea Media Rating Board, but this time the filmmaker is playing it safe: ''Voice of a Murderer'' arrives complete with its own public-service announcement.

Paintings Peter Freeman Inc. 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo Through May 12 I'm not sure how this exhibition of 16 small paintings by James Ensor (1860-1949) landed in a SoHo gallery, but here it is, and it's a treat, a full-color follow-up to the survey of his works on paper at the Drawing Center in 2001.

KELLNER--Zoe M. Beautiful Zoe, your sparkling smile and dancing Brown eyes will be forever in our hearts. Your spirit never to be forgotten. All our love forever, Vanessa, Peggy, Marc, Brian and Kelli

HOLESHA -- Winifred M. ''Winnie'', 57, of Palm Harbor, Florida, passed away peacefully on Good Friday, April 6, 2007 at Hospice House Woodside, Hospice of the Florida Suncoast, in Pinellas Park, FL. Originally from the Chicago area, she was an Advanced Nurse Practitioner, with 27 years of RN experience including Loyola University Medical Center, UIC Medical Center, West Suburban Hospital, Alexian Brothers Medical Center, Mount Sinai Hospital, and most recent at Tampa General Hospital. She is a graduate of Trinity High School, River Forest, Elmhurst College and Loyola University's Masters of Science in Nursing. Winnie is the beloved wife of Jim; loving mother of Jamie Ann and Jennifer M. Holesha; cherished daugher of Concetta (the late Joseph) Farley; dear sister of Joseph (Susan) Farley; fond aunt of Andrew and Juliana Farley; daugherin-law of Bernice Holesha; sister-in-law of Sheryl (the late William). Winnie was cremated and her ashes scattered on the waters of the Gulf of Mexico by her family. Memorial Visitation Saturday, April 14, from 9:00 a.m. until time of funeral service 11:30 a.m. at Gibbons Funeral Home, 134 South York Road, (North of Saint Charles Road) Elmhurst, Illinois. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to any of the following: Susan G. Komen for the Cure, the Moffitt Cancer Foundation (Tampa), or the Hospice of the Florida Suncoast. For funeral information please call 1-630832-0018 or www. gibbonsfuneralhome.com

People Michele Hirshman, first deputy attorney general of New York under Eliot Spitzer, is joining Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison as a partner. She will focus on internal investigations and white-collar defense. Ptarmigan Capital, an asset management firm specializing in real estate-related investments, has named Arvind K. Bajaj, formerly of Credit Suisse, as a principal of the firm.

The January issue of Vanity Fair included an article by Christopher Hitchens, ''Why Women Aren't Funny,'' that explored a supposed humor gap between the sexes and in so doing raised the ire of plenty of writers, bloggers and, not surprisingly, funny women. New Yorkers need only head to the West End Theater to find a compelling counterpoint to Mr. Hitchens's essay. There nine red-nosed members of Kendall Cornell's Soon-to-Be-World-Famous Women's Clown Troupe, above, are presenting ''Not Just for Shock Value: A Femmes-Clowns Assemblage.'' The show, presented by Six Figures Theater Company, includes an hour's worth of sketches, dances and satirical scenarios performed by a cast of seriously silly madcaps who have trained under Ms. Cornell. Some vignettes toy with stereotypical male-female roles -- a wife in one scene (Ishah Janssen-Faith) aims to please by baking a pie for her gruff husband (Judi Lewis Ockler) -- only to twist them around and allow the role playing to descend into slapstick madness. Other sketches are darker and are reminders that the greatest clowns try to make people laugh to help stave off existential horrors: in one Ms. Janssen-Faith grapples with an imagined Pandora's box and discovers, as if new, a litany of disastrous events that have befallen humanity. Ms. Cornell, the group's founder and director, is a former dancer and sometime actor who studied under the big-time clowns David Shiner and Philippe Gaulier after first discovering clowning by accident. ''It was like a frying pan on the head,'' she said. ''It just called me.'' To Ms. Cornell men aren't the only ones who can be funny. ''Women can be funny if you let them, and if you look at them differently,'' she said. Ultimately the proof is in the laughter of course. (Through April 28, West End Theater, 263 West 86th Street, Manhattan, 212-868-4444, smarttix.com; $20). STEVEN McELROY

Opens today nationwide. Directed by Marcus Nispel 100 minutes All grunting, all goring, the witless action flick ''Pathfinder'' has little to recommend it, though Terrence Malick completists may be interested to know that it rips off a few setups from that master's magnum opus ''The New World.'' The time is the 10th century A.D., ''500 years before Columbus,'' or so it says in some introductory text, and the place is some pastoral if murkily shaded, almost monochromatic, stretch of coast, where native peoples hunt, fish and smile with what's meant to be the wisdom of the ages but registers as cultural cliché.

As masters of deception, the Nets put forth a very predictable performance against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Thursday night. They played defense for a half, following a gutsy game with one in which they barely showed up. They again swung from a team apparently heading in the right direction to one simply passing time until summer vacation.

In the world of spies Benjamin Tallmadge couldn't be further from James Bond. He didn't wield sophisticated weapons or drive a gadget-filled Aston Martin, and he most certainly was not a member of Her Majesty's -- or, in this case, His Majesty's -- Secret Service. A real rather than a fictional hero, Tallmadge practiced espionage the (very) old-fashioned way, doing his best to wrest the American colonies from the grip of George III. But Tallmadge (1754-1835), a Long Island native, was still an ingenious fellow, as families will discover tomorrow at the Fraunces Tavern Museum. Revolutionary War re-enactors representing his regiment, the Second Continental Light Dragoons (Tallmadge was an officer as well as George Washington's spy master), will recreate his times. ''The dragoons were the special ops of Washington's army,'' Sal Tarantino, the dragoons' captain, above, said in a phone interview. The re-enactors will perform drills and discuss Tallmadge's achievements, which included devising codes for transmitting information about British maneuvers in New York.

An obituary in some copies yesterday about the writer Kurt Vonnegut misidentified the novel in which a recurring Vonnegut character, Kilgore Trout, was introduced. It is ''God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater, or Pearls Before Swine,'' not ''Slaughterhouse-Five, or The Children's Crusade.'' The surname of another character, who appears in the novel ''Breakfast of Champions, or Goodbye Blue Monday,'' was misspelled. It is Philboyd Studge, not Sludge. (The obituary is reprinted today on Page A16.)

The Havens column last Friday about the Puna region of Hawaii referred incompletely to air service available at Hilo International Airport. There are flights between Hilo and Oakland, Calif.; service is not limited to flights to and from Oahu and Maui.

Several thousand pipers and drummers in kilts will march up Avenue of the Americas tomorrow for the ninth annual Tartan Day Parade. A celebration of Scottish culture, the parade is the culmination of Tartan Week in New York. Full pipe bands as well as individual pipers and drummers from around the country and the world, including New Zealand, Canada and Pakistan, will fill the streets of Manhattan with the high-pitched wail of their native instruments. Organizations like the Caledonian Club of New York and the American Scottish Foundation will also march. ''It's a real celebration of Scotland and America,'' said Michael Kellet, first secretary for Scottish affairs at the British Embassy in Washington, ''it should be a real occasion.'' Specific plaid tartans are associated with different Scottish clans or families, and hundreds of clans will be displaying their colors. ''I'll be at the parade, and I'll have my kilt,'' Mr. Kellet said. Albannach, a Glasgow band making its parade debut, will perform at St. Andrews Pub (120 West 44th Street, Manhattan) before the procession. A post-parade party at Stout will feature the music of Albannach, Scocha and MacTalla Mor. (Tomorrow, Avenue of the Americas, between 45th and 58th Streets, 2 p.m.; Stout, 133 West 33rd Street, 4 p.m., $25 in advance, $40 at the door; tartanweekny.com.) ROJA HEYDARPOUR

Opens today nationwide. Directed by Matt Maiellaro and Dave Willis 87 minutes Nothing else in ''Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters'' -- certainly not the labored title, which sounds like would-be ''Borat'' -- is as funny as the first five minutes. Let me qualify that: not much that I have seen in movies recently made me laugh as hard as the opening bit, in which a parade of singing cartoon movie snacks is disrupted by a caterwauling death-metal rendition of familiar pre-film warnings: don't talk or use your cellphone or otherwise disrupt the motion picture experience.

Toward the end of the civil rights movement Huey P. Newton and Bobby Seale founded the Black Panther Party in 1966 in Oakland, Calif. In hindsight the party had a fairly reasonable agenda for social change and the empowerment of African-Americans -- employment, education, decent housing, social justice and political representation -- but it was branded as a shadowy revolutionary organization and a threat to national security. This new exhibition commemorates the 40th anniversary of the founding of the Black Panther Party, bringing together almost 100 photographs of the group's leaders, demonstrations and other activities from about 1967 to 1973 by Stephen Shames, the party's unofficial official photographer. Most of the images are small black-and-white prints, but they have a disquieting, momentous presence. One especially powerful image, above, shows the militant posturing of a pair of Panther security guards (Glen Wheeler, left, and Claudia Grayson) outside a funeral for a slain party member at a church in Oakland in 1971. Mr. Shames photographed not only the public face of the movement but also private moments, including secret meetings of Panther leaders and their home life. Simple but thoughtful, the photographs humanize the group whose driving ambition was equality. (Through May 26, Steven Kasher Gallery, 521 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, 212-966-3978, stevenkasher.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Justin Swibel Not rated; 61 minutes This debut feature from Justin Swibel, which spends a little over an hour observing a young man silently cleaning a palatial suburban estate, is so minimalist that at times it feels as if a prank were being played on the audience. And yet Mr. Swibel's style is so assured, and the film's rhythms are so precise, that it would be a mistake to dismiss ''Modern Man'' as a pretentious goof.

Citigroup, the financial services giant, has spent months courting the executive, Vikram Pandit, who left Morgan Stanley in 2005 after he was blocked for a chance at running the investment bank.

The Day Trip column last Friday about art in New Haven misstated the year when Yale University's predecessor, a small Puritan college, moved to New Haven. It was in 1718 -- not 1701, the year the Puritan college received its charter.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about possible plans by a Canadian pension fund to form a consortium and mount a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, misstated the legal status of a rival company, Telus. While Telus had announced plans to convert to an income trust, it abandoned the move because of changes in the law.

After weeks of internal squabbling, state workers approved a four-year contract on Thursday that will give them a 13 percent overall pay increase but will also require that they pay part of their health insurance premiums for the first time. The new contract affects about 43,000 state workers affiliated with the Communications Workers of America and will take effect on July 1. Workers will contribute an extra half of 1 percent of their salary to the state's troubled pension fund, and the retirement age for new employees will be raised to 60 from 55. The contract ratification is a political victory for Gov. Jon S. Corzine, who has been outspoken about his desire to control spiraling pension and health care costs. DAVID W. CHEN

WHO -- Dr. Walton Reeves, 50, a physician from Atlanta, left, with a friend, Tom Maybank, 34 WHAT -- 1-bedroom house WHERE -- Sylva, N.C. I've been a fisherman for 25 years and everyone in my immediate family owns waders. I even proposed to my wife in the middle of a trout stream in north Georgia. I own a home site here in the Balsam Mountain Preserve community, where my long-term plan is to build a retirement home. Until then I have a fractional share of a cabin that entitles me to eight weeks of use a year, which is about all my family can manage time-wise.

CALL it the ultimate wine-country fantasy: Buy a weekend retreat in Napa Valley and swaddle the house in cabernet vines, then start bottling the yield into vintages good enough to attract the praise of the finicky wine news media. Well, Randy and Lisa Lynch did just that that five years ago. The Lynches, who own an advertising agency in San Ramon, Calif., bought a three-bedroom vacation home in Calistoga, in Napa's far north, and planted 12 acres of cabernet, merlot and petit verdot grapes. ''We were searching for agricultural property, but what drew us to this area was its beauty,'' said Mr. Lynch, who said the place cost a few million dollars but declined to be more specific. He then took weekend wine recreation to a new level when he bought an existing winery, Bennett Lane, and started producing cabernet sauvignon and red and white blends.

A Bronx woman was indicted yesterday on a charge of second-degree murder in connection with the death of her 2-week-old son on Dec. 31, prosecutors said. The woman, Lucila Rojas, 25, is charged with placing a blanket over the face of her son, Anthony, preventing him from breathing, then leaving him in a trash bin in Jackson Heights, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. At first she told the police that someone had taken the boy from her at gunpoint, but later confessed to investigators, Mr. Brown said. Ms. Rojas has pleaded not guilty, a spokesman for Mr. Brown said.

A sports article on Tuesday about professional football prospects from Hampton University referred imprecisely to the university's location. It is on the peninsula of the Hampton Roads region in southeastern Virginia; it is not on the state's Eastern Shore.

An article on Tuesday about the high salaries of Singapore government officials misstated the given name of a prominent writer who suggested in an essay that comparability with the private sector should not be the only consideration in setting government salaries. She is Catherine Lim, not Carolyn.

On the Web site for this Minneapolis band, its leader, Craig Minowa, above, lists 36 jobs he has held, including paperboy, U.P.S. truck loader, ''plasma seller'' and gas station attendant. The critical ones come at the end: environmental scientist and musician. Even in this era of biodiesel fuels and degradable eating utensils, Cloud Cult is especially passionate about green music practices. The group started a record label, Earthology, which uses recycled materials in its packaging, asking fans to donate old CD jewel cases to be cleaned and reused. On the road it puts solar panels atop its van and counters its carbon dioxide emissions with wind-power credits and tree plantings. But in its music Cloud Cult is less Al Gore than William Blake. ''The Meaning of 8,'' its fifth album, released this week, is a sprawling, kaleidoscopic invocation of the life force, with songs that veer from jubilation to simmering, prayerful meditation. ''Oh God it's beautiful/Insatiable/The way our chemicals collide,'' Mr. Minowa sings with wonderment, his squeaky, boyish voice resembling that of Wayne Coyne of the Flaming Lips, as an eccentric indie-rock orchestra -- guitar, cello, woodpecker percussion and throbbing, buzzing electronics -- surrounds him like kindly animals in a forest myth. He sounds as enchanted by the natural world as he is dedicated to protecting it. (Tomorrow at 9 p.m. and Sunday at 8 p.m., with Young Galaxy and Exit Clov, at the Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, 212-260-4700, mercuryloungenyc.com; sold out tomorrow, $12 on Sunday.) BEN SISARIO

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Paul Fox Not rated; 95 minutes In cloudy, gorgeous Vancouver, a disgruntled young man named Ryan (Paulo Costanzo) is fired from his tedious white-collar job on the same day that his girlfriend (Katharine Isabelle) breaks up with him. The hero then chances into a job with the local lottery, profiling winners for its public relations magazine while courting a set dresser (Steph Song) and getting pulled into a money-laundering scheme with her ex-boyfriend (J R Bourne) that affords Ryan fancy clothes, a shiny sports car and moral qualms.

A State Supreme Court justice declined yesterday to take any action on a lawsuit to remove Dr. Mathieu Eugene from the ballot in a special election for the 40th Council District in Brooklyn. The ruling means that Dr. Eugene is one of two candidates who will remain on the ballot for the election, which is set for April 24. Dr. Eugene won a special election for the seat in February, but he declined to take the seat after the City Council asked for information verifying that he lived within the 40th District, which includes Crown Heights and Flatbush. A second special election was scheduled, and Dr. Eugene said he would be a candidate. John Ravitz, executive director of the New York City Board of Elections, said yesterday that only Dr. Eugene and Harry L. Schiffman, the director of government and community relations at Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center, remained on the ballot. JONATHAN P. HICKS

I don't know about you, but I practice a disorganized religion. I belong to an unholy disorder. We call ourselves, ''Our Lady of Perpetual Astonishment.'' You may have seen us praying for love on sidewalks outside the better eating establishments in all kinds of weather. Blow us a kiss upon arriving or departing, and we will climax simultaneously. It can be quite a scene, especially if it is raining cats and dogs. Kurt Vonnegut, the author of ''Slaughterhouse-Five'' and many other novels, died on Wednesday. This poem was previously unpublished.

PELTZ--Claire. In loving memory of Claire Peltz, mother of Nelson Peltz, Co-Chairman of the Simon Wiesenthal Center. On behalf of the Simon Wiesenthal Center's 450,000 member families. Rabbi Marvin Hier, Founder and Dean Larry A. Mizel, Chairman Rhonda Barad, Eastern Director

Sixty years after Jackie Robinson shook the baseball establishment and broke the sport's color barrier, an unforeseen grassroots movement by today's players has suddenly shaped the way Major League Baseball will commemorate the anniversary. Hundreds of players will wear Robinson's No. 42 retired by baseball 10 years ago in ballparks across the country on Sunday, the anniversary of Robinson's first appearance with the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947. While the tribute has received baseball's approval, it grew spontaneously from a request by the Cincinnati Reds' Ken Griffey Jr., who asked Commissioner Bud Selig earlier this month if he could wear the number on April 15. What has evolved since is surprisingly organic for a group of famous, feted athletes with multimillion-dollar contracts.

A decade before Rosa Parks and the Montgomery bus boycott, two decades before Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. proclaimed "I Have a Dream," a signature event in the struggle for racial equality unfolded far from Dixie. On the afternoon of April 15, 1947, Jackie Robinson emerged as an inspiring figure in the civil rights movement when he became the first black man to play major league baseball in the 20th century, making his debut with the Brooklyn Dodgers against the Boston Braves at Ebbets Field.

Four NATO soldiers died in roadside bomb attacks within 24 hours, the military said. The nationalities of the soldiers were not disclosed. To the Editor: Re ''Columbia to Receive Its Largest Gift, $400 Million for Student Aid'' (news article, April 11):

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a study showing that New York's 950,000 buildings are responsible for a vast majority of the city's carbon dioxide emissions referred incorrectly to those emissions. According to the city's Office of Long-Term Planning and Sustainability, the volume of greenhouse gases produced citywide is rising -- not being cut -- each year.

DELAFIELD--Maturin L., of Princeton, died on April 11, 2007, in Princeton. Born in New York City in 1933, a member of the Class of 1955 at Princeton University where he was a member of the Charter Club. After graduation he joined the family investment business of Delafield and Delafield and in 1970, founded the firm of Delafield, Harvey, Tabell in Princeton. Delafield, Harvey, Tabell was purchased by the United States Trust Co. in 1992 and Mr. Delafield continued as a Principal of the firm until his retirement in 1995. He is survived by his wife, Louise M. Delafield, four stepchildren, Susan, Thomas, Lawrence and Douglas Ferguson, and three grandchildren. He was predeceased by a son, Maturin (Livy) Delafield. Family requests that donations be made to the Neurology Fund and Parkinson's Research Fund at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital Foundation, 8 Easton Ave., New Brunswick, NJ 08901. Call 732-745-7393.
LOVE--Alex. April 8, 2007. We'll miss you always my darling. Love, Cynthia

Tony Jaa fans, be warned: there's no kick boxing in this three-day, four-feature minifestival at the Museum of the Moving Image. Instead the main attractions are new films from two of the small crop of Thai directors who have broken into the American art-house circuit in recent years. ''The Unseeable'' (at 8 tonight) is a haunted-house movie, set in 1930s Bangkok, about a pregnant woman who comes to the city to find her baby's father and finds a compound full of ghosts (including the little girl above). It was directed by Wisit Sasanatieng, whose wild cowboy melodrama from 2000, ''Tears of the Black Tiger,'' finally opened here this year. His reference point in ''The Unseeable'' is Japanese horror rather than westerns and martial arts films, and both the plot and the color palette are more restrained than in ''Tears,'' but the aesthetic is similar: less attention is paid to chills and thrills than to the ways in which golden light reflects off the faces of beautiful, frightened women. Pen-ek Ratanaruang's ''Invisible Waves'' (8 p.m. tomorrow) is a companion piece to -- if not a remake of -- his last film, the 2003 ''Last Life in the Universe.'' Once again Tadanobu Asano, the hardest-working man in Asian movies, plays a Japanese slacker with criminal ties, cast adrift in Thailand. (Just to make the connection between the two films more complete his character, now named Kyoji instead of Kenji, again becomes involved with a woman named Noi, though this time she's played by a Korean actress rather than a Thai one.) Where Mr. Sasanatieng is movie-geek over the top, Mr. Ratanaruang is pan-Asian hipster minimalist: a Thai Jim Jarmusch, complete with long, slow takes and melancholy visual jokes. Fans of Haruki Murakami's fiction are likely to appreciate Mr. Ratanaruang's slightly chilly vibe; in ''Invisible Waves'' Kyoji fends off an amorous woman by saying he needs to get back to the sauce simmering on the stove, which could be an homage to Mr. Murakami's spaghetti-cooking heroes. (Tonight through Sunday night, Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue, at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens, 718-784-0077, movingimage.us.) MIKE HALE

WATERBURY--Jean Parker, writer, editor and historian, died at home in St. Augustine, Florida, Thursday, April 5. She was 91. Literary agent for Zora Neale Hurston, among others, in the 1950s. First woman president of the St. Augustine Historical Society, served on the boards of Collegiate School in New York, Monadnock Music and Peterborough Players, in Peterborough, NH, and the St. Augustine Historical Society. Also served as editor of and frequent contributor to El Escribano and the East Florida Gazette (historical society publications). Author of A History of Collegiate School (1965) and Laban Ainsworth: A Life (1990). Survived by her children Whit, Jonathan and Holly, and two grandchildren. Donations may be made to St. Augustine Historical Research Library, 271 Charlotte St., St. Augustine, FL 32084.

Corzine Is Seriously Hurt In Car Crash on Parkway Gov. Jon S. Corzine was in a major car accident on the Garden State Parkway and underwent surgery last night for injuries that included a broken leg, sternum and collarbone as well as six broken ribs on each side, officials said. PAGE B1 Shift Urged on Gonorrhea The rates of drug-resistant gonorrhea in the United States have increased so greatly in the last five years that doctors should now treat the infection with a different class of antibiotics, the last line of defense for the sexually transmitted disease, officials said. PAGE A10 Remembering Robinson Mets Manager Willie Randolph, who grew up in Brooklyn idolizing Jackie Robinson, will be among the major league figures wearing Robinson's number on Sunday, the 60th anniversary of his breaking baseball's color barrier. SPORTSFRIDAY, PAGE D1 Sallie Mae Is in Buyout Talks Sallie Mae, the nation's largest lender to college students, is in talks to be taken private in what could be a $20 billion deal. The possible buyout poses unusual problems, because the bulk of its portfolio is federally subsidized loans. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 University Official's 2 Roles A vice president at Widener University, a nationally known financial aid administrator who made a business of it, is an example of how university officials have become cozy with lending companies. PAGE A13 Dinosaur Protein Recovered In a retrieval once thought unattainable, scientists have used advanced research techniques to recover and identify proteins in a bone of a well-preserved Tyrannosaurus rex that lived and died and was fossilized 68 million years ago. PAGE A11 CBS Ends Imus Radio Show Off the Air After 30 Years CBS canceled the ''Imus in the Morning'' program, effective immediately, bringing a weeklong controversy over racial and sexual insults by the radio host Don Imus to an end. MSNBC, which simulcast the show, had removed it from its morning cable lineup a day earlier. CBS's decision means that Mr. Imus, who has been broadcasting his program for more than 30 years, no longer has a home on either national radio or television. BY BILL CARTER AND JACQUES STEINBERG, PAGE C1 Caught in a Wildfire For a few days, it seemed that Don Imus might pull out of the death spiral. Once he came under fire, Mr. Imus said he was sorry for the racial insult, then began a week of penance, raising money for sick children and turning up at various other microphones to renew his apology. But even as he went through the ritual of public mortification, his backers began to see what he did not: the drumbeat was not going to stop. THE MEDIA EQUATION BY DAVID CARR, PAGE C1

A front-page article on Thursday about the scant evidence of voter fraud that has been found since the Bush administration began a crackdown five years ago misstated a court ruling on a 2003 Texas Congressional redistricting law. While the Supreme Court ruled that the Texas Legislature violated the Voting Rights Act in redrawing a southwestern Texas district, the court upheld the other parts of the plan. It did not strike down the law.

An obituary on Friday and in some copies on Thursday about the writer Kurt Vonnegut referred incorrectly to the military role of the character Billy Pilgrim in the Vonnegut novel “Slaughterhouse-Five, or The Children’s Crusade,” set in Europe during World War II. Pilgrim was a chaplain’s assistant, not an infantry scout, although he encounters scouts in his travels and joins up with them.
Corrections

An article on April 3 about a plan by the New York City Department of Correction to reopen and expand the Brooklyn House of Detention in Boerum Hill referred incorrectly to a community leader who opposes the reopening. Sandy Balboza, president of the Atlantic Avenue Betterment Association, is a woman.

A dance review on Thursday about “John Butler: An American Master,” performed by the Richmond Ballet and guest artists at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan, misidentified the presenter. It was the John Butler Foundation, not the Richmond Ballet.

A listing of credits in Weekend on April 6 with a film review of “Grindhouse,” based on information provided by a publicist, omitted an editor of one part of the film and erroneously credited another editor with both parts. The “Planet Terror” segment was edited by Robert Rodriguez and Ethan Maniquis, not by Mr. Rodriguez and Sally Menke. Ms. Menke edited only the “Death Proof” part of the film.

An appraisal in The Arts on Tuesday about the cartoonist Johnny Hart, who died last Saturday, misspelled the given name of another comic strip artist who, like Mr. Hart, grew up listening to radio comedians and watching the movies of Charlie Chaplin and Laurel and Hardy. He is Mell Lazarus, not Mel. The appraisal also incorrectly rendered the name of a weekly publication Mr. Hart sold cartoons to early in his career. It was Collier’s, not Colliers.

An article in The Arts on Thursday about a dispute in which Alan Dershowitz, the Harvard law professor, is trying to block Norman Finkelstein, a political science professor, from gaining tenure at DePaul University in Chicago included an incorrect reference to DePaul that Mr. Finkelstein attributed to a dean there who opposes tenure for him. While DePaul is a Roman Catholic university, it is not Jesuit, and Mr. Finkelstein acknowledges that the dean, Charles Suchar, did not say that it is. The article also misstated Mr. Suchar’s middle initial. It is S, not E.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about an agreement by Sallie Mae, the nation’s largest student lender, to settle an investigation by New York’s attorney general into relationships between universities and student loan companies misidentified in some copies the lender that runs call centers for financial aid offices at Texas Tech and Wayne State University. It is Nelnet, not Sallie Mae.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about New York City Ballet’s offer of free tickets to the final dress rehearsal of its new production of “Romeo and Juliet” misstated the date when they will be distributed, beginning at 9 a.m., at the New York State Theater box office. It is April 22, not tomorrow.

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about an exhibition of Roman mosaics from Tunisia at the Getty Villa in Pacific Palisades, Calif., misstated the date of the battle of Thapsus, in which Julius Caesar ensured Roman control of North Africa. It took place in 46 B.C., not 47 B.C. Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the commander of Caesar’s opponents. They were led by Pompey’s father-in-law, not by Pompey, who had been murdered.

A front-page article on Thursday about the scant evidence of voter fraud that has been found since the Bush administration began a crackdown five years ago misstated a court ruling on a 2003 Texas Congressional redistricting law. While the Supreme Court ruled that the Texas Legislature violated the Voting Rights Act in redrawing a southwestern Texas district, the court upheld the other parts of the plan. It did not strike down the law.

A dance review on April 2 about “Colors of Rajasthan” at Symphony Space in Manhattan, citing information in the program, misidentified the musician who played the wooden blocks. He was Bhawroo Khan Langa, not Habib Khan Langa. (Habib Khan Langa played the bowed lute and double flute.).

A picture caption yesterday with an article about the trial of one man accused of killing seven people at a fast-food restaurant in Palatine, Ill., in 1993 misstated the date the picture was taken and referred incorrectly to the date the bodies were found. The picture was taken on Jan. 9, 1993, not Jan. 8. The bodies were found on Jan. 9, not two days earlier.

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about “The Diary of Petr Ginz: 1941-1942,” a teenager’s chronicle of life in wartime Prague, omitted a translator of an untitled poem in the book that was quoted in the article. While Elena Lappin translated the book from the Czech, David Curzon helped her translate that poem and another in the book called “Remembering Prague.”.

Nigerians go to the polls today to choose state governors and legislators in the first of two elections. President Olusegun Obasanjo, who must step down after eight years, has promised free and fair polls, but rights groups and foreign observers have voiced reservations.

Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China wrapped up a three-day visit to Japan, saying that the two nations had “reached broad consensus” on how to move their relations forward but still needed time to resolve their many differences. Mr. Wen spent his last day trying to show the softer side of China’s leadership to Japanese who have grown anxious in recent years of China’s economic rise and growing military strength. Mr. Wen met farmers and played baseball with students at Ritsumeikan University in Kyoto.

A British soldier was killed and two others wounded in a firefight in southern Helmand Province, a day after two NATO soldiers were reported killed in separate roadside bombings. The British death brings the number of NATO soldiers killed in the last week to 12. Of the other nationalities known, eight were Canadians who had been deployed in southern Kandahar and one was an American soldier, killed in the east. Fighting has also been reported in Helmand and Zabul Provinces.

President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela told a news conference that his close friend and ally Fidel Castro had “almost totally recovered” from his illness and had “reassumed a good part of his duties” as Cuba’s leader, although not formally. Mr. Chávez has regularly offered updates on Mr. Castro’s health in the more than eight months since the Cuban leader underwent emergency intestinal surgery and ceded his leadership responsibilities to his brother Raúl. The Cuban foreign minister, Felipe Pérez Roque, traveling in Vietnam, also said that Mr. Castro, who is 80, had resumed some of his leadership responsibilities. “He receives reports about the country’s situation and is directly involved in managing some important issues,” Mr. Roque said.

Lawmakers rejected a series of bills that would enshrine the country’s strict anti-abortion law in the Constitution, including one put forward by the far-right League of Polish Families to protect “life from the moment of conception,” in effect a total ban on abortion. Some of the proposed amendments won more than 60 percent of votes in the 460-seat Parliament, but fell short of the two-thirds majority required for constitutional changes. The League of Polish Families, a part of the governing coalition under President Lech Kaczynski, left, has just 29 seats, but managed to muster 165 votes for its proposal. The lawmakers also rejected separate proposals by Mr. Kaczynski to set the current law, which is already among the strictest in Europe and allows an abortion only in cases of rape, severe birth defects or danger to the woman’s life, in stone to prevent any liberalization by future administrations.

Nepal’s Election Commission said it would not be able to hold elections for a constituent assembly on June 20, as specified in a peace deal with former Maoist rebels. “We need at least 110 days before the polling day, even after necessary laws concerning the election are in place,” said Bhoj Raj Pokharel, the chief election commissioner. The voting is to select a special assembly to draft a new constitution and to decide whether Nepal remains a monarchy or becomes a republic.

8 P.M. (HBO) UNITED 93 (2006). The film opens with four Muslim men praying in a hotel room. It quickly cuts to the interior of a plane, where pilots have just picked up a dispatch warning them to guard against possible cockpit intrusion. Two minutes later, at 9:28 a.m., the men — Ziad Jarrah (Khalid Abdalla), Saeed al-Ghamdi (Lewis Alsamari), Ahmed al-Haznawi (Omar Berdouni) and Ahmed al-Nami (Jamie Harding) — have broken into the cockpit and taken control. What happens next is mostly unknown until 10:03 a.m. on Sept. 11, 2001, when, after passengers try to break down the cockpit door, the plane, United 93, plows into a field in Pennsylvania, killing everyone aboard. (Above, Becky London and Tom O’Rourke as the passengers Jean and Donald Peterson.) Using information from the 9/11 Commission Report, Paul Greengrass tells the story of the passengers who decided they would rather go down fighting.
Calvin Sims discusses the international courts and tribunals that prosecute leaders for large-scale human rights abuses with Times Paris correspondent Marlise Simons.

Richard Goode made his wider reputation playing the Germanic piano repertory, but his discovery of Debussy -- or our discovery of his discovery -- has come as a pleasant surprise. Mr. Goode had Bach, Mozart and Brahms on his Carnegie Hall program on Thursday night, and Book 2 of the Debussy Préludes came after intermission. In one sense, separate sets of values were at work. In another sense, Bach and Mozart succeeded in the first half for the same reasons Debussy did in the second. Bach's G major Partita can be played on a Hammond organ or an ensemble of kazoos, and it will still sound like Bach. The message supersedes the medium. For Debussy the resources of the piano -- not just the colors but also the possibilities of range and articulation -- are part of the construction process. Without them, everything collapses.

BROWNE--Roscoe Lee. We mourn the loss of our longtime Trustee and faithful friend. He was always to be counted upon to be supportive of the aims and purposes of the Society. He filled our lives with the soft sound of poetry as only he could recite it. Now the stage is empty and the lights are low. Frank T. Crohn, President The Edna St. Vincent Millay Society

An appraisal in The Arts on Tuesday about the cartoonist Johnny Hart, who died last Saturday, misspelled the given name of another comic strip artist who, like Mr. Hart, grew up listening to radio comedians and watching the movies of Charlie Chaplin and Laurel and Hardy. He is Mell Lazarus, not Mel. The appraisal also incorrectly rendered the name of a weekly publication Mr. Hart sold cartoons to early in his career. It was Collier's, not Colliers.

Having young conductors on the podium of the New York Philharmonic is not as novel as it sometimes seems: It's part of the business of a modern orchestral season, in which guest conductors lead an ensemble for more weeks than its music director does. Lately, the Philharmonic has been visited by a small parade of young but experienced conductors. Often they come with fresh ideas and infectious energy, and in a rational business, any of them might be considered in the search for a successor to Lorin Maazel. But the Philharmonic isn't about youth, freshness or energy. It considers itself entitled to a thoroughly established conductor, if not an elder statesman with a household name. Never mind that across the continent, the Los Angeles Philharmonic was able to excite its audiences this week, seize the national headlines and engender jealousy throughout the orchestra world all at a stroke by snagging the 26-year-old Gustavo Dudamel. Or that the New York Philharmonic's own postwar zenith was its appointment of Leonard Bernstein as music director when he was in his early 30s.
