Mimi Lerner, an internationally renowned mezzo-soprano and educator who came to the operatic stage late in life, died on March 29 in Pittsburgh. She was 61. The cause was complications of a heart tumor diagnosed 12 years ago, said her husband, Martin.

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about an exhibition of Roman mosaics from Tunisia at the Getty Villa in Pacific Palisades, Calif., misstated the date of the battle of Thapsus, in which Julius Caesar ensured Roman control of North Africa. It took place in 46 B.C., not 47 B.C. Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the commander of Caesar's opponents. They were led by Pompey's father-in-law, not by Pompey, who had been murdered.

A Brooklyn hospital has sued one of the city's largest health insurers, asserting it conspired with doctors and others to wrongfully deny coverage for patients. The suit, filed by Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, says the financially distressed hospital was forced to absorb a significant portion of costs that should have been paid by Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, a managed care organization commonly known as HIP.

The first complete book by J. R. R. Tolkien since the posthumous publication of ''Silmarillion'' in 1977 will be published next week by Houghton Mifflin. Tolkien, the author of ''The Hobbit'' and the ''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy, began ''The Children of Húrin,'' right, in 1918 but never finished it. Christopher Tolkien, 82, the author's son, edited the book from several drafts. Mr. Tolkien has also added hand-drawn maps and genealogy tables to the tale, whose story takes place thousands of years before ''The Lord of the Rings.'' Houghton Mifflin plans an initial printing run of 250,000 copies. MOTOKO RICH

An obituary on Friday and in some copies on Thursday about the writer Kurt Vonnegut referred incorrectly to the military role of the character Billy Pilgrim in the Vonnegut novel ''Slaughterhouse-Five, or The Children's Crusade,'' set in Europe during World War II. Pilgrim was a chaplain's assistant, not an infantry scout, although he encounters scouts in his travels and joins up with them.

To the Editor: According to ''Bush on the Border'' (editorial, April 11), the president displayed his understanding of the immigration issue when he said ''America suffers from a system that exploits people who come to do jobs that citizens won't do.''

The Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum has chosen Richard Gluckman as the architect for its renovation and has raised $21.5 million toward the project, the museum's director said yesterday. The renovation is part of a $43 million capital campaign to double the museum's exhibition space, expand the permanent collection, enhance education programs and increase the endowment. Construction is expected to start toward the end of the year. The Cooper-Hewitt also announced the appointment of Cara McCarty as the museum's new curatorial director. Ms. McCarty, who will start on July 10, is the curator of decorative arts and design at the St. Louis Art Museum. Mr. Gluckman's firm, Gluckman Mayner Architects, designed the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh; the new Museum of Contemporary Art, San Diego; and the Perelman Building of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. The Beyer Blinder Belle firm will be the executive architect on the project. ROBIN POGREBIN

A fire at a Tampa mosque and educational center was arson and is being investigated to determine if it was a hate crime, the authorities said. The fire began Thursday morning, when someone poured gasoline outside of a building adjacent to the Islamic Education Center of Tampa, the authorities said. Fire crews controlled the blaze at the empty building within 20 minutes. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, which investigates arsons at houses of worship, is involved in the investigation. Investigators found a plastic gasoline can at the scene and were ''assessing the situation and looking at the evidence,'' Special Agent Dave Couvertier said. TERRY AGUAYO

A listing of credits in Weekend on April 6 with a film review of ''Grindhouse,'' based on information provided by a publicist, omitted an editor of one part of the film and erroneously credited another editor with both parts. The ''Planet Terror'' segment was edited by Robert Rodriguez and Ethan Maniquis, not by Mr. Rodriguez and Sally Menke. Ms. Menke edited only the ''Death Proof'' part of the film.

Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China wrapped up a three-day visit to Japan, saying that the two nations had ''reached broad consensus'' on how to move their relations forward but still needed time to resolve their many differences. Mr. Wen spent his last day trying to show the softer side of China's leadership to Japanese who have grown anxious in recent years of China's economic rise and growing military strength. Mr. Wen met farmers and played baseball with students at Ritsumeikan University in Kyoto. NORIMITSU ONISHI

A picture caption yesterday with an article about the trial of one man accused of killing seven people at a fast-food restaurant in Palatine, Ill., in 1993 misstated the date the picture was taken and referred incorrectly to the date the bodies were found. The picture was taken on Jan. 9, 1993, not Jan. 8. The bodies were found on Jan. 9, not two days earlier.

A front-page article on Thursday about the scant evidence of voter fraud that has been found since the Bush administration began a crackdown five years ago misstated a court ruling on a 2003 Texas Congressional redistricting law. While the Supreme Court ruled that the Texas Legislature violated the Voting Rights Act in redrawing a southwestern Texas district, the court upheld the other parts of the plan. It did not strike down the law

Raoul Felder, a celebrity divorce lawyer who is chairman of a state commission that oversees judges, has been given a unanimous vote of no confidence by the other nine members of the commission for helping to write a book they said is racially and ethnically inflammatory. In a statement issued Friday, the commission members said the book, which Mr. Felder and the comedian Jackie Mason wrote, ''repeatedly invokes racial, ethnic and religious invective.''

Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., 81st St. Funeral April 16, 10am, Virgin Mary Church, 216 8th Ave., Park Slope, Brooklyn. A Joffrey Founder Resigns Gerald Arpino, right, announced yesterday that he would step down as artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet this summer, more than 50 years after he helped get the company started by touring the country in a rented station wagon, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Arpino, 84, who founded the troupe in 1956 with Robert Joffrey, will take the title of artistic director emeritus on July 1. The Price of Perks Starting this summer, the 750 volunteers at the Tanglewood Summer Music Festival in Lenox, Mass., will be required to donate money as well as time in exchange for free tickets and other perks. The Boston Symphony Orchestra, whose summer home is Tanglewood, is now requiring that volunteers donate at least $75 to its Annual Fund, The Berkshire Eagle reported on Wednesday. The changes reflect the orchestra's growing deficit and the fact that Tanglewood loses ''two to three million dollars a year,'' said Bart Reidy, the orchestra's director of development communications. The orchestra has also said that members of the Boston Symphony Association of Volunteers will receive free lawn tickets to concerts only after they have worked an eight-hour shift, and new restrictions have been placed on how they may use complimentary passes for guests. ''I think it's extortion,'' said Michael Durst of Pittsfield, who has been a Tanglewood volunteer for seven years. Foonotes Nicole Kidman, below, received the Companion in the General Division of the Order of Australia (AC), the country's highest civil honor, at a ceremony at Government House in Canberra. ''Not only are you a tremendous actress, but you are a great attribute to the nation,'' Governor-General Michael Jeffery said in his commendation. Snoop Dogg entered a no-contest plea to gun and drug charges on Wednesday and was given a three-year suspended sentence. The 35-year-old rapper, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, was also sentenced to five years of formal probation and ordered to perform 800 hours of community service by a Superior Court judge in Los Angeles. Trey Anastasio, formerly of the group Phish, pleaded guilty to attempted criminal possession of a controlled substance, admitting in court that he was in possession of Vicodin, Percocet, heroin and Xanax when he was pulled over for a traffic stop in upstate New York in December. To avoid jail, Mr. Anastasio must successfully complete 12 to 15 months in a drug program, make weekly court appearances, be subject to drug testing and perform community service. Julian Lennon, 44, the elder son of John Lennon, has sold a stake in the income produced by his father's compositions for the Beatles to Primary Wave Music Publishing, based in New York. Last year Primary Wave paid an estimated $50 million for a 50 percent stake in the music publishing catalog of Kurt Cobain, which it bought from his widow, Courtney Love. Mike Tyson will soon make his debut in Bollywood. Firoz Nadiadwala, a film producer, said in Mumbai that Mr. Tyson would star in a promotional video, to be shot later this month, for his forthcoming film ''Fool 'n' Final,'' an action-comedy starring well-known Bollywood actors like Sunny Deol, Suniel Shetty and Shahid Kapoor.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about an agreement by Sallie Mae, the nation's largest student lender, to settle an investigation by New York's attorney general into relationships between universities and student loan companies misidentified in some copies the lender that runs call centers for financial aid offices at Texas Tech and Wayne State University. It is Nelnet, not Sallie Mae.

COYNE--Msgr. James F., entered into eternal rest on April 11, 2007, after a long illness. Msgr. Coyne was born in the Bronx to Marie and James Coyne; and was ordained on June 2, 1956. Services by the Joseph W. Sorce Funeral Home Incorporated. (845) 358-4433

It was chilly in Cleveland yesterday afternoon, but Bob DiBiasio, the vice president for public relations for the Indians, said the sun was shining. DiBiasio had not seen any kind of consistent sunshine in a while, especially on a day when the Indians were scheduled to play a home game. ''It's a beautiful sight,'' he said. The Indians returned to Jacobs Field to play the Chicago White Sox last night, hoping that the snow that turned them into vagabonds this week was not about to return. There was no guarantee that the cold weather would at least remain dry and playable; some precipitation was expected -- yes, maybe even snow -- tonight and tomorrow in Cleveland.

His contribution to the creation of Lincoln Center and the move of The Juilliard School to its current home will always be deeply appreciated by the Juilliard Community. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Thursday about New York City Ballet's offer of free tickets to the final dress rehearsal of its new production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' misstated the date when they will be distributed, beginning at 9 a.m., at the New York State Theater box office. It is April 22, not tomorrow.
To the Editor: Re ''He's Not My Grandpa. He's My Dad'' (Thursday Styles, April 12):

The Royal Bank of Scotland Group and two other European banks approached ABN Amro about a possible takeover bid that could derail the current exclusive merger discussions between ABN and Barclays. Royal Bank of Scotland, Britain's second-largest bank after HSBC Holdings, teamed up with Banco Santander Central Hispano, Spain's largest bank, and Fortis, a Belgian banking group, and together sent a letter to ABN Amro inviting it to enter ''exploratory talks,'' ABN Amro said Friday. ABN Amro repeated it was in exclusive talks with Barclays but said it would consider the approach ''carefully'' and in line with its responsibilities. Investors and analysts have speculated that a bidding war could break out over ABN Amro ever since Barclays started the discussions last month, proposing a takeover that could be the biggest in the banking industry by valuing ABN Amro at more than $80 billion. ABN Amro, which is based in Amsterdam, started merger talks with Barclays after it came under pressure from hedge funds to either split itself up or to seek a buyer following years of poor share price performance. JULIA WERDIGIER
To the Editor: Re ''Canceled by Principal, Student Play Is Headed to Off Broadway'' (news article, April 12):

A British soldier was killed and two others wounded in a firefight in southern Helmand Province, a day after two NATO soldiers were reported killed in separate roadside bombings. The British death brings the number of NATO soldiers killed in the last week to 12. Of the other nationalities known, eight were Canadians who had been deployed in southern Kandahar and one was an American soldier, killed in the east. Fighting has also been reported in Helmand and Zabul Provinces. CARLOTTA GALL

INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Rebel Group in Iraq Says It Led Parliament Attack An umbrella insurgent group that includes Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia claimed responsibility for the suicide bombing on Thursday in the Parliament building in Baghdad. The attack killed one legislator and wounded at least 22 other people. Rachel L. Brand, by her own admission, has never prosecuted so much as a traffic case. But in January 2006, when Justice Department officials began to discuss removing some United States attorneys, Ms. Brand was proposed as the top federal prosecutor in the Western District of Michigan, an e-mail message released on Friday shows. In the end, Ms. Brand, who heads the Office of Legal Policy in the department, decided that she did not want the position and was not nominated to succeed Margaret M. Chiara, then the top prosecutor for the district. Ms. Chiara was later ousted.

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about ''The Diary of Petr Ginz: 1941-1942,'' a teenager's chronicle of life in wartime Prague, omitted a translator of an untitled poem in the book that was quoted in the article. While Elena Lappin translated the book from the Czech, David Curzon helped her translate that poem and another in the book called ''Remembering Prague.''

An obituary on Friday and in some copies on Thursday about the writer Kurt Vonnegut referred incorrectly to the military role of the character Billy Pilgrim in the Vonnegut novel ''Slaughterhouse-Five, or The Children's Crusade,'' set in Europe during World War II. Pilgrim was a chaplain's assistant, not an infantry scout, although he encounters scouts in his travels and joins up with them.

WEINGAST--David, 94, of Ridgefield, CT, and Fire Island, NY, died on April 12th. He leaves behind his beloved wife, Beatrice, four children, Beth, Erica, Jeremy and Victor; and six grandchildren. An educator and author he taught in Newark, NJ, and was Superintendent of Schools in Ridgefield, CT. Services will be held Sunday at 10:30 am, at Temple Shearith Israel, 46 Peaceable St., Ridgefield, CT 06877.

Roughly six months from now, the world will celebrate what would have been the 90th birthday of the pianist and composer Thelonious Monk. On Thursday night, concertgoers at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center got a generous head start, at the latest installment of Jack Kleinsinger's longstanding series Highlights in Jazz. Monk, who died in 1982 but withdrew from the public years earlier, has hardly slipped into oblivion. His piquant harmonic language and craggy instrumental style are enduring features of the jazz landscape, and show no signs of fading. The main attractions of Mr. Kleinsinger's tribute were the pianist Kenny Barron and a group led by the drummer Ben Riley, and neither had to adjust his style to suit the occasion.

An article in The Arts on Thursday about a dispute in which Alan Dershowitz, the Harvard law professor, is trying to block Norman Finkelstein, a political science professor, from gaining tenure at DePaul University in Chicago included an incorrect reference to DePaul that Mr. Finkelstein attributed to a dean there who opposes tenure for him. While DePaul is a Roman Catholic university, it is not Jesuit, and Mr. Finkelstein acknowledges that the dean, Charles Suchar, did not say that it is. The article also misstated Mr. Suchar's middle initial. It is S, not E.

In a March 31st Op-Ed column I critiqued Professor Stephen Prothero's claim (quoted in Time magazine's April 2nd issue) that the "academic study of religion ... takes the biblical truth claims seriously and yet brackets them for purposes of classroom discussion." I questioned how anyone could take something seriously by leaving it at the door or putting it on the shelf. And I said that in the absence of its truth claims - claims like salvation is through belief in Jesus Christ who rose from the dead and redeemed us by taking upon himself all our sins - a religion was nothing more than a set of stories and ritual practices bereft of any transcendent meaning of which they would be the expression. You can teach those stories and practices - just as you might teach the stories and practices of baseball (which is, I know, the religion of some people) - but you wouldn't, I insisted, be teaching religion, only its empty shell. Of the hundred or so comments I received, only a few indicated agreement with my point. The others raised a number of objections, and among those objections three were prominent: 1) I fail to understand that one can teach the truth claims of religion as historical and cultural facts without either believing or disbelieving in them: "To understand the works of Christians such as Chaucer, Dante, Milton or Shakespeare, one must understand something of Christianity. One must not, however, become a Christian." 2) Teaching the exclusive truth claims of a religion as matters of fact goes against the principles of liberal democracy and liberal education: "Teaching religious thought as dogma is not education, but theocracy." 3) What I said in this column is contradicted by what I said in earlier columns: "The argument you present seems to run counter to your prior claim that any potentially controversial topic can and should be studied within 'academicized' grounds." First of all, I stipulate to the usefulness of teaching the bible as an aid to the study of literature and history. I'm just saying that when you do that you are teaching religion as a pedagogical resource, not as a distinctive discourse the truth or falsehood of which is a matter of salvation for its adherents. One can of course teach that too; one can, that is, get students to understand that at least some believers hold to their faith in a way that is absolute and exclusionary; in their view nonbelievers have not merely made a mistake - as one might be mistaken about the causes of global warming - they have condemned themselves to eternal perdition. ("I am the way.") What one cannot do - at least under the liberal democratic dispensation - is teach that assertion of an exclusive and absolute truth as anything but someone's opinion; and in many classes that opinion will be rehearsed with at best a sympathetic condescension ("let's hope they grow out of it") and at worst a condemning ridicule ("even in this day and age, there are benighted people").

Is Ségolene Royal a gazelle, air hostess or France’s next Joan of Arc? Since this 53-year-old became the presidential candidate for France’s Socialist Party, opinions have remained divided. “She just looks so bourgeois for someone left-wing,” says Marisa Berenson. The designer Martine Sitbon, on the other hand, finds her “pretty well dressed.” She adds, “By wearing a skirt, she’s avoiding that frumpy trouser-suit look so prevalent amongst female politicians.” The shoe designer Christian Louboutin describes Royal as “physically, great” and someone whose appearance has “dramatically evolved since working for Mitterrand in the 1980s.” Pictures show a rounder person with big glasses and hair untidily tied back. Now it’s cheekbones, chiseled jaw, perfectly coiffed hair and contact lenses. “And two years ago, she replaced her Dracula fangs with caps,” says Lucien Pellat-Finet, the cashmere expert. “In France, we call it the presidential smile.” Terry de Gunzburg, the creator of By Terry cosmetics, is impressed by her “naturally perfect” complexion and how “she never looks tired.” The hairstylist Odile Gilbert refers to her do as “classic,” but because her hair is fine, he says she has no choice. Still, in terms of clothes, Gilbert thinks she could be “more jeans and cool, à la Hillary.” (Hillary cool?) Pellat-Finet is horrified that she favors Paule Ka, the staid French label inspired by Jackie O. He criticizes her red jackets, knee-length skirts and white coats for their “terrible” proportions. Louboutin likens her round-toed shoes to Minnie Mouse’s but appreciates her “terrific legs and ankles.” And apparently the mother of four is a fantasy figure for certain French men, says Louboutin: “They dream of having Ségo as a mother.” [?][?][?]Natasha Fraser

Bastien Gonzalez has always been hard to track down, flying from one capital to the next to tend to the toes of the rich and richer. In 2004 he inked an exclusive deal to bring his signature, polish-free, totally buffed medical Pedicure de Bastien to the One and Only resorts — in Dubai, the Maldives, Mauritius and Los Cabos, Mexico. He spends Sundays in Paris with his girlfriend; infrequent contact “is why we have so much love,” he said. This marathon plays out in 18,688 miles traveled per week; 3 passports owned; 10 clients per day; 3,000 pedicures in 2006; 18 pedicurists trained last year; 10 pedicurists fired last year; and 1 buffing chamois used per month. Price for Pedicure de Bastien: $140. [?][?][?]CHRISTINE MUHLKE.

A review on April 1 about “Once Upon a Country: A Palestinian Life,” by Sari Nusseibeh, referred incorrectly to the relationship between the prophet Muhammad and a woman Nusseibeh names as the progenitor of his own family. TODAY AND TODAY: Haiku. By Kobayashi Issa. Illustrated by G. Brian Karas. Scholastic Press. $16.99. (Ages 4 to 8) A master of haiku, Issa (born in 1763) wasn’t blessed with an “easy or happy” life, according to the artist’s note at the beginning of this affecting picture book. Karas chose 16 of Issa’s plain-spoken poems and arranged them by season. “Once snows have melted, / the village soon overflows / with friendly children” reads the first. “Here / I’m here — / the snow falling” reads one of the last. The pictures, in muted tones, may work too hard to supply a story — images of a hospital and a graveyard tell us the stooped grandfather from the early pages has passed on — but on the whole they complement the haunting simplicity of Issa’s art.

Baruc Corazón has taken the basic men’s button-down and reconsidered everything about it.
Now that spring is here, the city’s enormous outdoor museum is a match for any of its more famous (and more expensive) indoor ones.
If borrowers with less-than-stellar credit scores look in unexpected places, their efforts can yield pleasant returns.
Zoning changes have prompted residential development in downtown Brooklyn, whose 12 subway lines are poised to get a lot more round-the-clock use.
A newish all-explaining narrative has crept upon us willy-nilly and is now all around.
Instead of signaling that we will stay in Iraq to the last gasp, President Bush should be showing signs that our commitment is not open-ended.

I seem to recall that Russell Baker complained some years ago about the difficulty of opening a clamshell package (Consumed, Rob Walker. April 1). Baker's frustration led him to a hardware store, where he purchased a pair of pliers, contained of course in a clamshell package. His solution was to throw the packaged pliers under the wheels of a bus and return to his apartment to attack the other offending item.

Last month, Elizabeth Edwards's breast cancer recurred. Then Tony Snow, the president's press secretary, said his colon cancer was back. On Wednesday, Fred Thompson, the former Republican senator from Tennessee and a possible presidential candidate, said he has had lymphoma. News about cancer, it seems, is everywhere. But, as statisticians readily explain, impressions can be misleading. While cancer remains the second-leading killer of Americans, behind heart disease, and while no one would make light of the toll from the disease, cancer deaths are on the wane.

Cindy Dodard, a daughter of Marcia Dodard and Dr. Pierre Dodard of Glen Cove, N.Y., is to be married in Brooklyn today to Vaishnav Krishnan, the son of Vani Krishnan and Dr. Eshwaramani Krishnan of Manama, Bahrain. The Rev. Richard Hasselbach, a priest affiliated with CITI Ministries, is to officiate at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, a film production complex at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The bride and bridegroom, both 25, are fourth-year medical students, she at New York University and he at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas. They met at N.Y.U., from which they both graduated, the bridegroom summa cum laude.

To the Editor: I love ''Messiah.'' Hardly ever miss it and practically leap to my feet at the first note of the chorus. Inconveniently, I am not only a Jew but also a Holocaust survivor. To think that all these years I have been an enthusiastic part of a better-dressed and largely clean-shaven mob crying out for what in contemporary terms is nothing less than ''Death to the Jews!'' made me want to take a shower to wash off the stain. I already have tickets for this season's Rochester Philharmonic performance, but it will never sound the same to me again. Steven Hess Rochester, N.Y.

Jay Leno The Republicans issued a statement today demanding that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi get back to work. President Bush would have made the statement himself but he was on vacation on his ranch in Texas. First, NBC fired Don Imus. Then, CBS fired him. And then, this afternoon, ABC hired him just so they could fire him too.

MADOFF--Roger. April 25, 1973-April 15, 2006. Dear husband, son, brother, uncle, friend, each day with you was rich with laughter and love. Your hope, wisdom and generous spirit stay with us, always. Lovingly remembered today and everyday. $(6$)MADOFF--Roger. It has been a difficult year for all who knew and loved him. Many more will come to know of him and his indomitable spirit through his courageous book, ''Leukemia for Chickens''. Pamela and Jerry Goldman

FOR a winter that took so long in coming, this one seems to have taken just as long to leave. Even after the snow and ice were gone, winter's residue could still be found spread across the grass in the powdery leaves and twigs, the dirt shoved by the snowplow up onto the lawn, and all the other bits of dust it left in its wake. Our lawn is an uneven place to begin with. It is a combination of the broad, deep-green blades of Kentucky bluegrass and the thinner blades of fine fescue, a typical mix in this region. From time to time, we have also let the grass go to meadow, so add to that the timothy, ryegrass and patches of clover, along with the knotweed, crabgrass and dandelion, and you've got the rough texture of the common Northeastern lawn.

THE dance routines have lost some of their Hollywood gloss, and occasionally a hormone-hijacked voice threatens to derail a duet. But herds of young actors have been saying the same thing since last fall, when Disney's ''High School Musical'' started hurtling into school drama departments: The show is unstoppable. The TV movie that set off a million adolescent singalongs before its soundtrack went on to become the biggest-selling album of last year is currently rah-rah-ing its way across more than 1,300 school stages worldwide, according to Disney officials; more than 100 of them are in elementary, middle and high schools in the suburbs around New York.

To the Editor: Leon Wieseltier is surely an intelligent writer, capable of self-reflection and criticism. Still, his longstanding commitment to the intellectual defense of Israel and the consistent impugning of Palestinians -- even as he will offer discrete criticisms of Israel -- comes through clearly again, and makes him a disappointing choice to review Sari Nusseibeh's memoir, ''Once Upon a Country'' (April 1).

To the Editor: I am Jewish and have sung Handel's ''Messiah'' as a member of various choral societies more times than I can count, including at Carnegie Hall. For me, it has been and will continue to be the music, just as it is the music when I sing Masses, requiems, magnificats, glorias, passions and other similar works or when I sing with church choirs.

A photograph with an article last Sunday on the Around Westchester page, about the formula for financing schools in the new state budget, was published in error. It showed Anita F. Hill, a professor at Brandeis University, not State Senator Andrea Stewart-Cousins.

Husband of Margaret Otis Guiton, father of Nicolette Guiton, John Guiton (Linda Chesis) and the late Jacqueline Guiton, and grandfather of Sophie Guiton. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

Chief executives are more optimistic about the economy now than they have been in more than a year, according to the Conference Board's index of C.E.O. confidence for the first three months of 2007.

About 30 minutes after his team knocked the Knicks out of playoff contention Friday night, and about 15 minutes before he would learn that his team had clinched a playoff spot, the Nets' Vince Carter, wide-eyed and speaking in his matter-of-fact tone, said, ''I'm just glad we're just one step closer to our goal.'' For a team heading to the postseason for a franchise-record sixth consecutive year, making two N.B.A. finals appearances along the way, playoff qualification is typically anything but an achievement.
PHILLIPS--Anita, April 15, 2006. You are loved. You are missed. Naomi

In announcing last week that he would not seek another term as state senator, Sharpe James, the former Newark mayor, said that ''37 years in politics is a mighty long time.'' We agree with that; it's a long time for anyone.

The thousands of people who went to the New York International Auto Show in recent days saw first-hand the shabby state of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and its surroundings. For some time now politicians and developers have been trying to figure out how to improve both the center and the large, mostly untended patch of Manhattan around it. Now Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his new team are getting ready to put their own stamp on this painfully long-running story. It may be too much to hope for now, but the Spitzer people should try to make any new Javits Center better than just mediocre. Right now the planners seem determined to create a Javits Center that pleases almost no one. And that for only $2 billion, give or take a few $100 million.

A rendering with the Streetscapes column on Dec. 10, about a proposal to build a pair of towers atop the Parke-Bernet Galleries building on Madison Avenue, carried an erroneous credit. The rendering was by Foster & Partners, not Platt Byard Dovell White Architects. This correction was delayed because editors did not follow through after the error was pointed out.

To the Editor: An April 10 news article praises Edward J. Blakely, the executive director of New Orleans's Office of Recovery Management, for having a ''clinical, outsider's eye'' when in fact his eye is blind to the human rights of New Orleanians displaced by Hurricane Katrina. According to the United Nations Guiding Principles on Internal Displacement, people forced to flee their communities as a result of a natural disaster are ''internally displaced persons'' who have the human right to return to their communities.

VONNEGUT--Kurt. The American Civil Liberties Union mourns the passing of iconoclastic author and staunch friend of civil liberties, Kurt Vonnegut. Vonnegut's wise, freethinking writing touched Americans of all ages, and his steadfast support of civil liberties over his lifetime was uncompromising. He was a long-time and proud member of the ACLU. In 1973, the ACLU successfully sued a North Dakota school district on behalf of a schoolteacher who taught his famous novel Slaughterhouse-Five, which a local minister had called ''a tool of the devil,'' in the classroom. Vonnegut told the New York Times in September 2003, ''What I've said again and again is that if any official from a dogcatcher on up treats you in a way in which is clearly unconstitutional don't call the F.B.I., call the ACLU.'' The ACLU extends its deepest sympathy to Jill Krementz and the entire Vonnegut family on the loss of a great man. $(6$)VONNEGUT--Kurt. Kurt Vonnegut with his dog Flour on his favorite bench in Dag Hammarskjold Plaza. The Turtle Bay Association is saddened by the loss of Kurt Vonnegut, renowned author who shaped modern American literature, and a resident and chronicler of the Manhattan neighborhood of Turtle Bay. We will miss both his voluminous good humor, as well as his work as a community activist in preserving the quality of life in Turtle Bay. We join his wife Jill Krementz, daughter Lily Vonnegut, and dog Flour, in their immeasurable loss. In accordance with his wife and daughter's wishes, and in lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Turtle Bay Association, 224 East 47 St., New York, NY 10017. $(6$)VONNEGUT--Kurt. Jacob, Medinger & Finnegan, Peter A. Cross and Donald C. Farber are deeply saddened by the death of our good friend and client. We send warm wishes to the family. Every experience with Kurt was one that always left us feeling good and laughing, even when he was not happy with the injustices he envisioned in the world around him. Kurt was a profound thinker, a truly sensitive, caring person who empathized with all people, without any consideration of their station in life or where they hailed from. His life and work are an inspiration to all of us. We will miss him very much.
Chapter 2

Enough ink has been spilled on this week's politically minded PBS documentary series, ''America at a Crossroads,'' to choke a donkey and an elephant. Less has been said about the Sundance Channel's new environmental set of programs, perhaps because it bears the unfortunate title ''The Green.'' It kicks off this week too, with the premiere of the newsmagazine series ''BIG IDEAS FOR A SMALL PLANET'' and the documentary ''A CRUDE AWAKENING: THE OIL CRASH'' (both Tuesday). In the six-episode first season of the popular British series ''WILD AT HEART'' (BBC America, Saturday), a Cotswolds vet takes his fractious blended family to South Africa on a mission to return a smuggled monkey to the wild and perhaps find some household harmony along the way: ''All Creatures Great and Small'' meets ''Yours, Mine and Ours'' meets ''Daktari.'' Noncynical American families, or animal lovers, who enjoy the show will be pleased to know that the ITV network recently ordered a third season. Paper, pasta, gunpowder, fireworks -- and flowers? The ''Nova'' episode ''FIRST FLOWER'' (PBS, Tuesday) traces the efforts of botanists and geneticists to determine whether China was the birthplace not just of spaghetti and Roman candles but of the first blossoming plant as well. Don't get your hopes too high for a definitive answer, but in the meantime enjoy the absolutely gorgeous scenes shot in the Hengduan Mountains, which are indisputably the home of any number of plants we treasure, including lilies, irises, camellias, primrose and rhododendrons. They can be seen here in wild and riotously colorful forms unknown to the rest of the world. It's what HD was made for.

To the Editor: While Michael Marissen's article provided challenging food for thought, the decision to run it on Easter morning, the holiest day of the Christian year, was unfortunate. I was saddened but curious to see Mr. Marissen debunk the theory -- which I had been taught in grad school -- that Handel's Old Testament oratorios were patronized by a largely Jewish audience. I wonder, however, in the absence of hard facts, who is served by this information? If the origins of ''Messiah'' are indeed anti-Semitic, it seems safe to say that it has successfully outlived them.

RUSSELL--William T. In loving memory of a remarkable man whose integrity, keen intellect, dry wit, and unfailing kindness and grace continue to inspire us daily. March 24, 1915 -April 15, 1977. Mildred, Catherine, Margaret, and William T. Jr

First there was New York, then San Francisco. Now Los Angeles and Las Vegas will get the Michelin treatment. In November, the famed -- and often controversial -- Michelin Guides will expand to cover two more cities in the United States, awarding (and denying) stars based on reports from Michelin's team of anonymous inspectors.

To the Editor: Michael Marissen's article reminded me of Samuel Butler's quote: ''Handel is so great and so simple that no one but a professional musician is unable to understand him.'' Misunderstanding only begins to describe the many faults of Mr. Marissen's analysis. His contention that Handel's work is anti-Semitic is a preposterous leap. Undoubtedly Jennens, an evangelical Christian, participated in the debate of his day between deists and Christians (as common as the debate over global warming today). It is an unsupportable stretch to conclude that because the word ''heathen'' was changed to ''nations,'' Jennens (and Handel) had the Jews in mind. It is much more likely that Jennens meant all of humanity and its sinfulness.

AS Washington tussles over the fate of the nation's estimated 12 million undocumented immigrants, municipal governments are taking sides. Places like Morristown and Danbury, Conn., are cracking down. Others, like New Haven and New York City, are embracing their undocumented workers. City councils can't change the federal government's failed immigration policies, but they can choose whether to offset or intensify the damage. According to the Migration Policy Institute at New York University, United States municipalities passed 34 laws last year tightening the screws on undocumented immigrants; 56 more such measures are pending.

To the Editor: In ''36 Hours; Prague'' (March 25), Evan Rail repeatedly refers to the city and its inhabitants as ''Eastern European,'' which makes me want to point out that Vienna is to the east of Prague, yet hardly anyone would think of ranking Austrians among the Eastern Europeans. True, during the Communist regime, the Czech Republic, then Czechoslovakia, was part of the so-called Eastern Bloc -- part of the Warsaw Treaty indeed -- but both Czechoslovakia and the Warsaw Treaty are now, of course, a thing of the past. The Eastern Bloc term defined a political division that is no longer valid because Europe is becoming one. Most European countries, including those beyond the Czech Republic's eastern border, are now members of the European Union.

The National Perspectives article last Sunday, about a new mixed-used development on the west side of Annapolis, Md., misidentified the river that touches this part of the city. It is the Severn River, not the Potomac.

The first deadline for North Korea to shut down and seal its main facility for manufacturing nuclear weapons fuel expired Saturday, with no apparent move by the North to fulfill its commitments, while China asked angry officials in the Bush administration to show patience. The inaction leaves President Bush vulnerable to attacks from hawks in his own party, who have argued that it was a mistake to return $25 million in frozen funds to the North Koreans -- much of it believed to be from illicit sales of missiles and counterfeit currency -- and who doubt that the North Koreans will stop producing bomb fuel and give up their existing weapons.

MULLEN--Diane Macom, 75, of Spring Lake died on Wednesday April 11, 2007 at New York Presbyterian - Cornell Weill Medical Center in New York City. Prior to raising her family, Mrs. Mullen was a fashion model for the John Robert Powers and Frances Gill agencies in New York City. During her career, she appeared on the covers of numerous magazines, including Life, Look and Seventeen. She was also a featured model in live commercials on the Today Show, The Arthur Godfrey Show, The Arlene Francis Show and The Kate Smith Show. Born in New Brunswick, she lived in Highland Park, Bedminster and Mantoloking before moving to Spring Lake 10 years ago. She was predeceased by her parents Dr. J. Morgan and Claire Macom and by her son John R. Mullen Jr. Surviving is her husband of 53 years John R. Mullen, sons Michael K. of New Vernon, Shannon P. and his wife Eileen C. of Brick, daughters Paddy Mullen of NYC, NY, Neilli Mullen Walsh and her husband Peter of Kennett Square, PA and Mary Killeen Mullen of St. Petersburg, FL. She also leaves her brother Dr. J. Morgan Macom Jr. of Bay Head, sister Mary Marcia O'Connor of Merion Station, PA and 10 grandchildren. Visiting will be on Sunday from 2-5pm at the O'Brien Funeral Home Hwy 35 at New Bedford Road Wall. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday 11am at St. Catharine's RC Church in Spring Lake. Entombment will be at St. Catharine's Cemetery in Sea Girt. Donations may be made in her name to the Diane Mullen Scholarship Fund at The University Of Notre Dame, 1100 Grace Hall, Notre Dame, IN 46556-5612.

Indian Point 3 will remain closed for at least another two weeks as repairs are made to the nuclear reactor's two transformers, which were damaged by a fire on April 6, according to Jim Steets, a spokesman for Entergy, the company that owns and operates the plant in Buchanan. Mr. Steets said that the fire was probably caused by a worn-out bushing -- a type of porcelain insulator -- located on top of the transformer. Mr. Steets said one of the transformers will need to be replaced, having sustained considerable damage from the fire. He estimated the cost of a new transformer as $2 million to $3 million. The second transformer was ''slightly damaged'' and will not need to be replaced, according to Mr. Steets.
BERNSTEIN--Steven Jay. Always loved. Always missed.

There is a framed advertisement on the wall outside the office of Marie-Francoise Stouls at the fashion temple Le Bon Marché. The ad bears the tag line for the store's beauty department, which Stouls runs. It reads, ''Refuser les seconds roles,'' which, in a world that rewards the increasing mass-ification of perfume, amounts to a pledge to support the singular and the exquisite. Not an easy job.

WHEN ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire'' came out in July 2000, Amazon and FedEx collaborated on shipping 250,000 books overnight to Potter fans around the world, myself included. A few weeks ago, Amazon e-mailed its customers to offer first-day (and bargain-priced) acquisition of this summer's must read, ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,'' the seventh and last in the series. As a result, Amazon reported that advance orders were 547 percent higher than for Book 6, published in 2005. Like millions of others, I signed up for mine. But now, I'm having second thoughts. While researching the environmental effects of online shopping, I discovered that e-commerce isn't necessarily a greener way to shop. Indeed, a trip to the local bookstore might be ''cleaner'' than shopping online.

CRISP--Mary Dent, 83, passed on in her home in Phoenix, AZ on March 24, 2007. Born in Allentown, PA, she was the seventh child of Elizabeth Patch Dent and Harry Dent. Always positive and inspired by the world around her, Mary graduated in 1946 from Oberlin College and in 1948, married William Crisp with whom she reared three children. Mary's passion for this nation and its people led her into politics in which she remained active throughout her life. She began her service as a Deputy Registrar working at a grass roots level and ultimately was elected Republican National Committeewoman in Arizona in 1972 and Secretary of the Republican National Convention in 1976. Mary served as Co-Chairman of the Republican National Committee from 1977 until 1980 when, as the last official act of her term, she challenged the GOP's abandonment of the Equal Rights Amendment and their anit-abortion platform in her speech to the national convention. She chaired the Presidential Campaign of John Anderson and served as the National Director of Business Executives for National Security from 1984 through the mid-1990s. Holding principle over politics, Mary graciously and effectively worked during the following decades with members on both sides of the aisle to promote issues of women's freedom, opportunity, choice and peace. Mary was elected to the boards of numerous organizations including the National Political Women's Caucus, National ACLU, National Advocacy Board of Planned Parenthood, Project Vote Smart and the Thomas Jefferson Center for the Protection of Free Expression, and was a founder of the Republican National Coalition for Choice. Admired for her unwavering commitment to her country and a political system she greatly believed in, Mary was featured in numerous books and publications throughout her career. Her memoirs and correspondences are housed in the Schlesinger Library at Radcliffe College. Mary cared deeply about humanity as exhibited by her unique ability to help others see their own goodness, always having time to witness another with her compassion and grace. Well traveled both internationally and nationally, she loved most exploring the wilds of nature with her family, and in particular, hiking the Grand Canyon, which she did for the last time at the age of 69. She returned to live in Arizona in 2005. Mary Dent Crisp is survived by her son, William Dent Crisp, two daughters, Barbara Crisp and Anne Crisp of Phoenix, two grandchildren, Brian and Jessica Crisp, her brother Richard Dent of Schnecksville, PA, her sister Jesse Dent Cook of Arlington, VA, many nieces and nephews, and her companion, William Tayler. She is predeceased by her sister Jane and her four brothers Hal, Charlie, Jack and Pete. A memorial service will be held at Ingleside at Rock Creek, 3050 Military Road NW, Washington DC on May 19, 2007 at 2pm. Memorial contributions may be sent to: The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station P.O. Box 4777, New York, NY 10163. 800-708-7644 or The Grand Canyon Trust, 2601 N. Fort Valley Road, Flagstaff, AZ 86001. 928-774-7488

To the Editor: I must take issue with the tradition reflected in Edward Rothstein's review of ''The Bloodless Revolution,'' by Tristram Stuart (Feb. 25), that Hitler and many of his Nazi henchmen were vegetarians. In my book ''Hitler: Neither Vegetarian Nor Animal Lover,'' I cite numerous primary sources attesting that Hitler indulged in sausages, stuffed squab, liver dumplings, ham and caviar -- hardly what most people today would consider vegetarian.
An article last Sunday about the final season of ''The Sopranos'' rendered incorrectly the title of a novel A. J. Soprano was assigned to read. It is ''Billy Budd.''

JOE GRECO lives with his wife, Karla, and their two children in a recently built four-bedroom home in a small hamlet in Suffolk County. Although he does not consider himself a wealthy man, Mr. Greco has joined a growing number of taxpayers across the region who find themselves paying the alternative minimum tax, which was created almost 40 years ago to make sure the nation's millionaires paid their fair share. ''So, I earn a decent salary,'' said Mr. Greco, 41, of St. James, who makes about $150,000 a year running a ready-mix concrete business with his father and brother. ''But my property taxes are astronomical, well into five figures. And my state income taxes are also five figures. But if you make enough to pay them, you can't deduct them.''

To the Editor: Statelessness is alive and well in Europe (Week in Review, April 8). Despite 40 years of being a Bosnian, after being ''ethnically cleansed'' from our Sarajevo home at the beginning of the Bosnian civil war and then erased from government records, my family and I now celebrate the day when we arrived in the United States and became -- in our hearts, and soon thereafter in American government records -- nonhyphenated Americans. Ray Miles Dallas, April 8, 2007

FOR years I've coached my kids' teams -- my three sons' baseball and basketball teams, my daughter's softball team. I didn't do it because I was a great athlete; I didn't even play high school sports. I've coached because a lot of the coaching I saw when my oldest was starting out was very bad. I've found it hard to do well, and rarely do I feel I've achieved the right balance. It's fine to say winning doesn't matter, but try losing every game, as I did one year in our town basketball league. Kids lose interest. When you see the parents in town, you feel you owe them an explanation. (''That team we played last night was so stacked.'') The joy goes out of the game and the players do, too. In their overprogrammed lives, the 0-8 basketball team falls to the bottom of the list.

RIEGER--Tina. AMERICAN orchestras have historically been hidebound institutions afraid of alienating mainstream subscribers. Boards tend to hire the most renowned maestros they can attract and afford: sure bets, in other words, safe investments. And many orchestras are weighted down with the burden of having to be the public face of a city's higher cultural aspirations. In recent decades even some great conductors driven by lofty artistic principles have unwittingly contributed to the perception that orchestras are elitist. When Kurt Masur, during his tenure with the New York Philharmonic, faced criticism that the orchestra was loath to take risks, he often answered that, yes, yes, we should play new music and be more adventurous. But then he would grow misty-eyed and speak of the Philharmonic's sacred responsibility to maintain the timeless Germanic masterpieces from Mozart through Bruckner. It was impossible not to be affected by his passion. Sadly, it was also clear that such an Old World attitude was an impediment to change.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Captivating at Last, Mets Can Dare to Dream,'' April 10: Roger Clemens can never become a Met. He can't even decide if he still wants to pitch one more season. But he will look only for an opportunity to do what is best for Roger Clemens. Didn't they ever tell him in Little League that there's no I in team?

WURZER--Gerhard. April 30, 1941-April 8, 2007. Members of the International Fine Print Dealers Association mourn the untimely passing of esteemed friend and colleague Gerhard Wurzer, an internationally respected dealer of 19th and 20th century prints, paintings and drawings. Since its inception in 1980, his Houston-based gallery was celebrated for its impressive exhibitions of historical masters as well as contemporary artists. He was widely admired for his connoisseurship, forthright demeanor and joie de vivre. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and the many people whose lives he touched. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, Texas Gulf Coast chapter.

To the Sports Editor: ''Playoff Hockey to Suit Every Fan Around New York'' (April 12) cites the Devils but not the Buffalo Sabres. Buffalo, while not near Manhattan, is still in New York; New Jersey is not. Some of us New Yorkers also root for the only football team to actually play in the state: the Buffalo Bills. David Jelinek Brooklyn

KUTOSH--Steven Jordan, January 21, 2007. Survived by his mother, Eleanor Kutosh, daughter, Heather Gottlieb, grandsons, Samuel and Adam, son, Alexander Kutosh, and sister Margot Orlander, and nephew, Matthew.

LESLIE CAMHI: ''As a journalist, you want to focus on the other, so I spent a lot of my youth dressing to be invisible,'' says Leslie Camhi (near right, with her son, Asher), the photography critic for the Village Voice, who wrote about the artist Louise Nevelson (far right) in ''Designed for Living'' (Page 74). With her magpie array of couture, furs, jewels and turbans, Nevelson was hardly a minimalist -- but Camhi, who also writes about culture, found plenty to relate to. ''Nevelson never accepted that women should blend into the woodwork and become invisible with age,'' she says. ''I haven't gone for a head wrap yet, but when my son was born, I did buy myself a chartreuse Burberry coat.''

WEINGRAD--Irving, 90, of Lake Worth, Florida passed away peacefully at home on April 10, 2007. Beloved husband of Sylvia for 67 years. Devoted father of Mitchell Weingrad (Jane), Dr. Daniel Weingrad (Elizabeth) and Heidi Leon (Juan). Loving grandfather of Harris, Marlon, Julie, Marc and Rachel. Irving was adored by all for his generosity of spirit, sense of humor and passion for life. He will be deeply missed by the Weingrad and Garfinkel families. We will love and remember him always. Memorial donations can be made to the American Cancer Society or the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC).

''If I could get my hands on Sarkozy, I'd kill him.'' I had asked Mamadou, a wiry young man wearing gray camouflage pants and a tank top, what he thought of France's former minister of the interior, who is also the right's standard-bearer in this spring's presidential elections. ''I'd kill him,'' he continued and then paused as if savoring the thought. ''Then I'd go to prison. And when I got out, I'd be a hero.''

MOROCCO The News -- Three terrorism suspects implicated in the bombing of an Internet cafe in Casablanca blew themselves up on Tuesday as the police closed in, and a fourth suspect was shot as he tried to detonate a bomb. Behind the News -- The police said its investigation into the March 11 cafe bombing, which killed the bomber and four others, led them to the four men and to a wider plot to attack the port in Casablanca, as well as the police and tourist sites. The bombing rattled the country, which in 2003 was hit by five suicide bombings that killed 45 people. The police responded then by arresting thousands of reputed militants, including some accused of conspiring with Al Qaeda. EUROPE The News -- The European Union is considering expanding the powers of Europol, its law enforcement agency, to enhance its ability to fight terrorism. Behind the News -- The proposals, taken up at a hearing of the European Parliament last week, would extend the agency's mandate to criminal issues that are not strictly related to organized crime, and grant it greater access to data on people under investigation. The hearing coincided with the release of a report by Europol, which said that more than 700 people were arrested for terrorism-related offenses in the union's 27 nations in 2006, with half of those arrests involving threats from Islamic extremists. ALGERIA The News -- Two bombs targeting the Algerian prime minister's office and a police station killed at least 33 people and injured more than 200 on Wednesday. Al Qaeda's wing in North Africa claimed responsibility. Behind the News -- The suicide attacks in Algiers, the capital, were the deadliest in more than a decade and followed warnings by officials in the United States and Europe that Algeria was becoming a center for terrorism that could threaten Europe and North America. The group claiming responsibility, Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, is North Africa's most active terrorist group and seeks to establish an Islamic theocracy throughout the region. AFGHANISTAN The News -- With fears of a new Taliban offensive, officials from the United States and allied countries met in Canada to discuss a long-term strategy for Afghanistan. Behind the News -- The United States, with about 26,000 troops there, hopes to clear southern Afghan regions of fighters for the Taliban and Al Qaeda and follow with rapid investments in infrastructure in what is expected to be a long struggle to stabilize the country. Military officials were preparing for an offensive by Taliban and Al Qaeda forces that is likely to focus on hit-and-run attacks, suicide bombings and roadside explosives that have been used with such punishing effect in Iraq. PAKISTAN The News -- Pakistan's generals say they have reclaimed some control of tribal areas bordering Afghanistan from foreign militants aligned with Al Qaeda. Behind the News -- President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan said the army had joined tribal leaders in the fighting and had killed nearly 300 militants, though other officials say the number was much lower. Pakistan has been under heavy pressure from the United States to clear the tribal areas of militants -- mainly Uzbeks and other Central Asians who have been waging an insurgency in Afghanistan. Officials acknowledged that hundreds of foreign militants remain, probably including Osama bin Laden.

Re ''The Times's Picture of TV Viewing Is Fuzzier Than It Appears'' (April 8): The claim by Nielsen Media Research that it ''lacks 'the resources' to calculate the margin of error on the 'hundreds of rating numbers a week' '' sounds pretty fishy to me. Based on my recollection of Statistics 101, the margin of error should be easy to calculate from just a few key numbers, and any cheap computer would make short work of even hundreds of rating numbers.
CZUKOR--John C. 12/31/16-4/15/05. Gone for 2 years. Not a day passes that I do not think of you. Lester

Best known for his buzzed bob, Christiaan Houtenbos worked with everyone from Grace Jones to Calvin Klein in the 1980s. He was also a famously bad boy, once clipping a chunk of hair from an unsuspecting fashion editor's head. Though cutting back on hours, he's still got the best photographers wrapped around his curling iron. Is your work art? It is for me. Hair is the flag of the soul. Does your hair change? All the time. I often shave my head, and the hair grows back with different patterns buzzed into it. What about your style? I wear orange underpants every day. Is there life outside of hair? I love ceramics, landscape architecture and poetry. I also take lots of photos. When I compile 86,400 images, I will make a clock with a different picture every second for 24 hours. Armand Limnander

The Yankees lead the majors in errors, with 13 in their first 10 games. Their starting rotation is depleted by injuries, and their bullpen is exhausted. But they are always a threat to change a close game with one swing. It happened Saturday at the Coliseum, when Jason Giambi belted a home run to right center off Lenny DiNardo in the 13th inning, leading the Yankees to a 4-3 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

One glance at any magazine, billboard or department-store window makes it clear: shoppers are swimming in a sea of green. No longer confined to Phish concerts or food co-ops, eco-friendly clothing now caters to both taste and conscience, as major designers find more inventive, and more stylish, ways to love the earth. (Vegetable dyes are so '96.) But companies have different ways of defining green, and many slap on the natural label because it's in vogue. So it's wise to do your research. Here are nine items from brands striving to save the planet, one bamboo fiber at a time. ELLEN CARPENTER 1. The Pasadena dress by Loyale blends organic cotton and hemp in a vintage-inspired design ($185 at Organic Avenue in New York; 212-334-4593). 2. This elegant Icarus top by Linda Loudermilk is made of lyocell, a biodegradable fabric derived from wood pulp ($299 at Kaight in New York, 212-680-5630). 3. Vinyl billboards bound for landfills find new life in one-of-a-kind bags by Vy & El, like this hip and sophisticated attaché case ($187 at thegreenloop.com). 4. Patrol sneakers by Patagonia have hemp uppers, partly recycled rubber soles and a collapsible leather heel, which converts them into a comfortable slide ($85; more colors -- this one is ember -- and a men's version available at Patagonia.com). 5. For every purchase of silver bangles by John Hardy, bamboo seedlings are planted on a deforested island off Bali ($95 each at sustainableadvertising.org). 6. Mauri Pioppo uses recycled gold for her delicate LiveGreen necklace and donates 30 percent of all proceeds to the Natural Resources Defense Council ($365 at mauripioppo.com). 7. This pointelle hoodie from the New York company Panda Snack is made from bamboo, a highly renewable material, which doesn't require pesticides to thrive ($84 at Kaight). 8. These summery, cuffed capri jeans from Levi's Eco line are 100 percent organic cotton and washed in natural dyes ($70 at select Levi's flagship stores). 9. This itsy-bitsy string bikini by Anna Cohen is recycled, made from leftover scraps of fabric that were used to create Olympic speed-skater uniforms ($164 at btcelements.com).

To the Editor: Re ''More Pieces. Still a Puzzle.'' (Executive Pay: a Special Report, April 8), which described the new disclosure rules involving executive compensation: Why did the Securities and Exchange Commission even bother installing such ludicrously tiny windows in the castle of executive pay?

Moments after Chicago beat out Los Angeles on Saturday to be the United States' bid city for the 2016 Summer Olympics, representatives from Chicago's Olympic bid stopped floating and got serious. ''We're going to go to work, probably tonight, maybe tomorrow, certainly no later than tomorrow,'' said Pat Ryan, chairman of the city's bid committee. ''It's just the beginning. It's a long road.''

LeWITT--Sol. Sol and the group of like-minded friends founded Printed Matter in 1976. His generosity towards other artists and a wide range of radical art practices is revealed in that simple act. His own books run through his life's work like a thread, perpetually drawing us back towards his essential ideas. We remember Sol for his gentle penetrating humanity, his support of artists, friends, and art situations, his simple love of giving. The Staff and Board of Printed Matter, Inc.

Well, of course, women who eat ice cream at least twice a week have a lower risk of infertility (Peggy Orenstein, April 1). Babies aren't stupid. They need some assurance that they'll be eating well for those nine months in the womb. Because once they're born, it'll be just milk and gruel for months.

Kimberly Marie Young, the daughter of Ada Ortúzar-Young and Roger Young of Cedar Knolls, N.J., was married last evening to Stefano Rivella, the son of Liliana Perta Curtis of Cervaro, Italy, and Attilio Rivella of Turin, Italy. Mary Beaty, a chaplain of the American Humanist Association, officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. Ms. Young, 26, is keeping her name. She is a member of a group that structures and underwrites leveraged loans in the New York investment banking unit of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. She graduated cum laude from George Washington University and received a master's degree in economics from Boston University.

Wouldn't an executive earning more than $2 million a year be expected to pay at least part of the rent on his primary residence? At Hertz Global Holdings, not exactly. The car-rental company spent £2.4 million ($4.7 million) on a home in London for its top executive in Europe, Michel Taride. Mr. Taride does not have to pay to live there through June 2011, and he also does not have to pay any taxes on that benefit.

The Economic View column on April 1, about labor policies in the United States and Europe, misstated the status of efforts in Congress to raise the minimum wage. Separate bills to raise the wage have been approved by the Senate and the House, but legislation has not been enacted.

Style Map | Baden-Baden: The curative waters of Baden-Baden, Germany, a pristine spa town on the edge of the Black Forest, have lured the royal, rich and rheumatic since the 19th century. The bucolic setting also attracted Russian literary giants like Tolstoy, Turgenev and Dostoyevsky (who frittered away his last rubles at the local casino). Today the Russians still come, as do world leaders (like Bill Clinton and Hosni Mubarak, the president of Egypt) and even Posh Spice, who shvitzed and shopped with fellow football wives during the World Cup last summer. MAURA EGAN

Women are often portrayed as shopaholics, but on Nordstrom's board, it is the men who appear to be dropping the most money while shopping. The retailer offers its directors a 33 percent discount on all merchandise. According to the retailer's 2007 proxy statement, which discloses all pay and perks, the biggest spenders were men, led by the president, Blake W. Nordstrom, who received a break of $92,585. The company's lead outside director, Enrique Hernandez Jr., received discounts of $24,677.

CLEMENT--Gregory, III, Architect, died at home in Weston, CT, on Wednesday, April 11th, 2007, of melanoma, at 56. Managing Principal of Kohn Pedersen Fox and Fellow of the AIA. Graduate of St. George's School in Newport, RI, and The University of Pennsylvania. Oversaw numerous international and award-winning projects. Respected for his integrity and character. Survived by wife Elizabeth, daughter Lili, sister Tina, and nephews Anawa, Shane and Devin. Donations may be made to the Gregory and Elizabeth Clement Melanoma Research Fund, Abramson Cancer Center of The University of Pennsylvania, 3535 Market St., Suite 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104.
I can't understand the term ''anti-aging.''

HARTFORD now has the only fuel cell bus operating east of the Rocky Mountains, a zero-emission vehicle that is among a few dozen running anywhere in the world. The bus represents an important milestone on a municipal mass transit stage that is increasingly mindful of global warming and other pollution issues. But at $2 million, it is unclear whether it is cost effective. The price is nearly six times the cost of each of the 650 full-size conventional diesel buses running in Connecticut and $1.5 million more than each of two diesel hybrid buses that have been running in Stamford. ''That's the $64,000 question,'' said Michael A. Sanders, public transit administrator for the Connecticut Department of Transportation. ''There's a benefit to having no emission from a tailpipe, but it's not worth a million and a half to me.''

To the Editor: I disagree with Caroline Weber's assessment, in her review of ''Nancy Cunard,'' by Lois Gordon (April 1), that Cunard was a ''supporter of the disenfranchised.'' Weber failed to point out that Henry Crowder, the African-American jazz pianist she fell in love with and lived with, was a married man. There is nothing worthwhile when a white woman takes a good man away from a ''sister.'' Nancy Cunard had plenty of pickings and her choice of Crowder was cruel and thoughtless. Rosalind Ellis Baltimore

Dance will be jumping through both stages of Symphony Space. In the Peter Jay Sharp Theater the muscular men of LES BALLETS GRANDIVA will put on ballerinas' tutus for some pointed comic looks at the conventions of classical ballet. But there will be more than sight gags, as the troupe hopes to unite technical precision with theatrical flair. Over in the intimate Leonard Nimoy Thalia Theater, as part of the Gender Benders series, which features sometimes serious and sometimes lighthearted explorations of the sexes, two groups share a program. MONICA BILL BARNES & COMPANY examines contemporary issues facing women. NICOLAS LEICHTER DANCE presents dancers in pairings that are also culture clashes. Grandiva, Monday and Tuesday at 8 p.m.; $21 to $26, $15 for students and 65+. Barnes and Leichter troupes , Thursday through Saturday at 8:30 p.m.; $21 in advance, $25 day of performance. Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org. ''Mapa,'' by the Brazilian choreographer Rodrigo Pederneiras, unites Brazilian dance forms and rhythms with classical ballet. Azure Barton's ''Chambres de Jacques'' dances its way through both Vivaldi arias and folk songs from Quebec. Nothing's coming to Dance Theater Workshop, but that may be cause for rejoicing, for this nothing is really something. It's the two-week NOTHING FESTIVAL organized by Tere O'Connor, who asked various choreographers and groups to create premieres totally from scratch with no stories, no music and no outside sources. This week's participants are Douglas Dunn, Hijack, Sam Kim and Dean Moss. (Other dancers perform April 25-28.) Wednesday through Saturday at 7:30 p.m., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org; $20, $12 students and 65+.

THE dance routines have lost some of their Hollywood gloss, and occasionally a hormone-hijacked voice threatens to derail a duet. But herds of young actors have been saying the same thing since last fall, when Disney's ''High School Musical'' started hurtling into school drama departments: The show is unstoppable. The TV movie that set off a million adolescent singalongs before its soundtrack went on to become the biggest-selling album of last year is currently rah-rah-ing its way across more than 1,300 school stages worldwide, according to Disney officials; more than 100 of them are in elementary, middle and high schools in the suburbs around New York.

Senator John McCain said that the buildup of American forces in Iraq represented the only viable option to avoid failure in Iraq and that he had yet to identify an effective fallback if the current strategy failed. ''I have no Plan B,'' Mr. McCain said in an interview. ''If I saw that doomsday scenario evolving, then I would try to come up with one. But I cannot give you a good alternative because if I had a good alternative, maybe we could consider it now.''

BLINK: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $15.99.) Gladwell's best-selling first book, ''The Tipping Point,'' argued that small actions can ignite positive social change; ''Blink,'' a paean to the power of first impressions, makes the case for ''thin-slicing.'' There is, Gladwell suggests, a subconscious process through which we sift huge amounts of information, isolate telling details and come to rapid conclusions, even in the first two seconds of seeing something. '' 'Blink' is a book about those first two seconds,'' he writes. The book moves through dozens of stories about thin-slicing, from a Pentagon war game to New Coke, which tested well but flopped in the marketplace. Gladwell ''has us flying around the world and across disciplines at hectic speed, and he's always dazzling us with fascinating information and phenomena,'' David Brooks wrote in the Book Review. THE EAGLE'S THRONE, by Carlos Fuentes. Translated by Kristina Cordero. (Random House, $15.95.) The spirit of both Machiavelli and ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' hovers over the down-and-dirty politics of this skillfully translated epistolary novel, set in 2020, when Mexico's presidency -- the ''eagle's throne'' -- is soon to come up for grabs. Our reviewer, Terrence Rafferty, called ''The Eagle's Throne'' the ''most wickedly entertaining novel of Fuentes's career.'' UNCENTERING THE EARTH: Copernicus and ''The Revolutions of the Heavenly Spheres,'' by William T. Vollmann. (Atlas/Norton, $15.95.) Nicolaus Copernicus died in 1543 -- the same year his infamous book, ''The Revolutions of the Heavenly Spheres,'' was published in Nuremberg, announcing that the Earth revolved around the Sun. In ''Uncentering the Earth,'' Vollmann, the author of ''Europe Central'' (winner of the 2005 National Book Award for fiction), subjects Copernicus's dense, technical treatise to a close analysis. ABSOLUTE CONVICTIONS: My Father, a City, and the Conflict That Divided America, by Eyal Press. (Picador, $15.) Press, the son of a gynecologist in Buffalo, provides a balanced social history of the city's abortion wars of the 1980s and '90s in an effort to explain the murder of one of his father's colleagues, who was killed in 1998 by an anti-abortion activist. AS Washington tussles over the fate of the nation's estimated 12 million undocumented immigrants, municipal governments are taking sides. Places like Morristown, N.J., and Danbury are cracking down. Others, like New Haven and New York City, are embracing their undocumented workers. City councils can't change the federal government's failed immigration policies, but they can choose whether to offset or intensify the damage. According to the Migration Policy Institute at New York University, United States municipalities passed 34 laws last year tightening the screws on undocumented immigrants; 56 more such measures are pending.

A table last Sunday with a report on executive pay referred incorrectly to equity holdings of Michael L. Eskew, chief executive of United Parcel Service. Their total value, though listed at $535,010,884, included $514.5 million in shares he does not own; they are held in trusts he helps to control on behalf of the company. He owned $17.7 million in shares outright. The table also misstated the value of equity holdings of Glenn A. Britt, C.E.O. of Time Warner Cable. It was $10.5 million, not $25.8 million.

The recent controversy over allowing severely emaciated girls to walk the fashion runways was mostly played out in letters to the editor and in designer caucuses behind closed doors. The public greeted the news with a shrug, revealing the extent to which most people now regard anorexia nervosa as just another occupational hazard. Models starve themselves the way football players take steroids, jeopardizing their health and longevity for celebrity and wealth.

MAUCK--Ward, of Stonington, CT, beloved brother, father, stepfather and grandfather died April 6th at age 78. He is survived by his sons, Alden, Parker and Andrew and his brothers, F. Taylor Mauck and Osborne Mauck. Ward was born in Bryn Mawr, PA and graduated from the Hotchkiss School, Williams College, and Harvard Law School. He retired as President of the American Institute of Marine Underwriters. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:30 on Friday, April 27th at Calvary Church, 27 Church Street in Stonington, 06378. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Ward's memory to Calvary Church.
