An article last Sunday about the New York auto show misidentified a new Volvo model introduced there. It was the XC70 crossover, not the V70 station wagon.

It is possible to get many things at the Four Seasons Hotel in Westlake Village, Calif., but a blood-and-urine panel that analyzes the condition of your DNA is a relatively new development. The panel, offered through the California WellBeing Institute as part of several luxury-lifestyle packages, including a $2,800 executive physical, is boomingly popular: about 50 people signed up in January, the first month it was available.

A photograph with an article last Sunday on the Around Long Island page, about the formula for financing schools in the new state budget, was published in error. It showed Anita F. Hill, a professor at Brandeis University, not State Senator Andrea Stewart-Cousins, a Democrat from Westchester.

KOENIG--Richard. I regret to announce the death of Richard Koenig, Controller of the American Branch of the Cambridge University Press from 1969 to 1985. He died March 10th after a battle with cancer. A resident of Deerfield Beach, Florida, Richard was 87. He was a man of great wit and wisdom acquired over a life well lived. Richard was born in 1920 in Vienna, Austria and escaped as a young man in his late teens from the Nazi persecution. He was a passenger on the last ship out of Europe before the outbreak of World War II. He landed in New York in 1939 on the day war was declared in Europe without knowing a single person in the entire country and with four dollars in his pocket. He described spending the final night on the ship's deck and being rewarded in the morning with ''one of the most magnificent sights I have ever seen: the skyscrapers of lower Manhattan slowly emerging out of the darkness and mist, first as very faint silhouettes that seemed to change shape every few seconds and finally as buildings that appeared to grow out of the water.'' Having secured the promise of a job in Los Angeles before leaving Europe, Richard traveled by bus from New York to Los Angeles on a route that wound through Arizona and New Mexico to San Diego and then up the coast to Los Angeles. He described the journey as ''hot, uncomfortable and magnificent.'' Richard loved his adopted country and returned to New York by about 1945. He worked in publishing for the rest of his working life; first with Viking Press, then New American Library, Walker & Company and finally Cambridge University Press. Richard is survived by friends and colleagues at Cambridge who were honored to have known him and who will never forget this remarkable man.

STECHER--Beatrice (nee Seelav, Benedict). In Fort Myers, Florida, on April 12, 2007, after a brief illness. Survived by her daughter, Jo Anne Stecher, son-in-law Terrence Pardoe, and sister-inlaw, Jeanne Seelav. She served in the US Army for eight years during and after WWII at the Pentagon, in Frankfurt, Germany and Mitchell Field, ending her career as a Major. Contributions would be appreciated to Jewish National Fund or City of Hope Medical Center in Duarte, CA.

PYNE--Eben. The Juilliard community mourns the passing of Eben Pyne, trustee emeritus of the School since 2001 and a Board member appointed in 1972. With intelligence, elegance, and diplomacy, Eben served Juilliard in numerous ways. His wise counsel was of great importance to Juilliard at critical times in the School's history. A knowledgeable and dedicated supporter of all the performing arts, he was particularly involved in vocal arts activities at the School. Our condolences are extended to his wife, Nancy, and his entire family. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

To the Editor: What an odd piece of work this article is, combining a guilt-by-association worldview with a six-degrees-of-separation mentality. From the bishop Richard Kidder in the 1690s to the 17th-century scholar Henry Hammond to the librettist Charles Jennens to Handel ''and his contemporaries.'' Behold! An anti-Semitic conspiracy has been exposed.

FOR a winter that took so long in coming, this one seems to have taken just as long to leave. Even after the snow and ice were gone, winter's residue could still be found spread across the grass in the powdery leaves and twigs, the dirt shoved by the snowplow up onto the lawn, and all the other bits of dust it left in its wake. Our lawn is an uneven place to begin with. It is a combination of the broad, deep-green blades of Kentucky bluegrass and the thinner blades of fine fescue, a typical mix in this region. From time to time, we have also let the grass go to meadow, so add to that the timothy, ryegrass and patches of clover, along with the knotweed, crabgrass and dandelion, and you've got the rough texture of the common Northeastern lawn.

To the Editor: One reason for the drop in crime in the city that Franklin E. Zimring (''Little Changes, Big Results,'' Op-Ed, April 8) doesn't address is twofold: better access to birth control and the availability of abortion.

David Rosenthal says the actor Bradley Whitford seems to be a perfectly admirable guy. Mr. Whitford won an Emmy as Josh Lyman, the edgy White House deputy chief of staff, on ''The West Wing'' and founded the Clothes Off Our Back Foundation, where actors auction off their gowns and suits for charity. Mr. Rosenthal, though, says he does not think Mr. Whitford is the type of person he wants to speak at a Princeton graduation event. Mr. Whitford went to Wesleyan University in Connecticut and studied acting at the Juilliard School in New York.

JOE GRECO lives with his wife, Karla, and their two children in a recently built four-bedroom home in a small hamlet in Suffolk County. Although he does not consider himself a wealthy man, Mr. Greco has joined a growing number of taxpayers across the region who find themselves paying the alternative minimum tax, which was created almost 40 years ago to make sure the nation's millionaires paid their fair share. ''So, I earn a decent salary,'' said Mr. Greco, 41, of St. James, who makes about $150,000 a year running a ready-mix concrete business with his father and brother. ''But my property taxes are astronomical, well into five figures. And my state income taxes are also five figures. But if you make enough to pay them, you can't deduct them.''

To the Editor: Re ''Flexing Big Muscles for a Little Library'' (April 8): Equating the use of eminent domain for a public library with a private development and calling them both for ''the public good'' is equivalent to comparing a public school teacher to a Donald Trump.

BASKETBALL N.B.A. TORONTO RAPTORS--Signed F Luke Jackson for the remainder of this season and the 2007-08 season. FOOTBALL N.F.L. CLEVELAND BROWNS--Signed TE Steve Heiden to a four-year contract extension. INDIANAPOLIS COLTS--Re-signed QB Jim Sorgi. HOCKEY N.H.L. NHL--Suspended Nashville F Alexander Radulov one game for a hitting-from-behind incident involving San Jose F Steve Bernier in a game on April 13. American Hockey League GRAND RAPIDS GRIFFINS--Signed LW Jan Mursak. COLLEGE WICHITA STATE--Named Gregg Marshall men's basketball coach. WINTHROP--Named Randy Peele men's basketball coach.

LEVENTHAL--Paul. Brilliant, cheerful, much beloved brother, brother-in-law, uncle. Gloria and Warren Leventhal, Donald, Barry and Mary Miller Leventhal. Shari and Scott Goldstein. Bryan, Robyn, Sam, Emily and Sophie. Ever and loving memory.

Do you know of any (reputable) Web sites or services that list apartments for rent short-term (a week or 10 days) in Barcelona? I've tried searching but have been unable to find any for a solo traveler. I'd rather not stay in a hostel or a hotel, but would prefer a studio or one-bedroom in Barri Gòtic or Raval. -- Lloyd Miner, New York Renting an apartment can be a smart plan, giving you the unique experience of living in a foreign city and perhaps saving money with a cheap weekly rate and cooking in your own kitchen. But there is also the risk of locking yourself into a place that isn't ideal. Sarah Wildman, who has written extensively about Barcelona for the Travel section, recommends the well-organized www.apartmentinbarcelona.net, with locations around the city, a site she found on rentals.loquo.com, which has traveler reviews of apartments to help you check out an apartment first. Loquo was also suggested by one of our readers, who called it ''the city's version of Craig's List.''

Along with being the first American named to Toyota's board, James E. Press is a licensed pilot. That means executives at or near the top of the three biggest car companies in the American car market could all fly themselves to their next appointment.

BROCKWAY--Richard C. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with all of its officers and employees, mourn the passing of our former President, Richard C. Brockway. Mr. Brockway, a graduate of the Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, was born on February 18, 1908 in Rochester, New York. Prior to joining the Company as its President in 1966, he was the Executive Director of the Massachusetts Hospital Service (Blue Cross). Mr. Brockway was a beloved friend who guided the Company through changes that prepared it to become a larger and more competitive Company. Upon his retirement in 1971, the Board of Directors expressed its appreciation for his wise leadership during a period of unusual growth and challenge. He will always be remembered for his eloquence and for his passionate commitment to our mission. We will miss him greatly. Our sincere condolences to his daughters, Carla and Joanna. Thomas J. Moran Chairman, President & CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

To the Editor: I am personally devastated to learn that the ''Hallelujah'' chorus was written to celebrate the destruction of Jerusalem in A.D. 70. As a professional oboist taking part for 55 years in annual performances at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center, I was also spiritually moved by this great work. However, if I knew then what I have just learned, I would never have accepted those performances. Blatant anti-Semitism should have no place in music. Sampson Giat Forest Hills, N.Y.

BUNIS--Stephen. Beloved father of Kristopher and Matthew. Loving son of George and Joan, good spouse to Patty and great brother to Andrea. Passed on April 7, 2007. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. He was kind and generous to everyone. All our love, forever.

For today's travelers, iPods are as common as e-tickets. Not only do MP3 players store books and podcasts, they can also translate words and phrases, given the right software. McGraw Hill's iSpeak language-learning series, created for iPods, seems to fit the bill. Versions are available in Spanish, French, German and Italian, with Chinese, Japanese and Portuguese versions coming out this summer. Costing $12.95, each iSpeak is divided into categories like food, weather, entertainment and introductions (www.mhprofessional.com). Hyatt Hotels and Resorts is also courting the MP3 generation. Treating music like wallpaper, the chain is mixing special Hyatt playlists for two of its resorts and making them available for guests to download. The lobby of the Hyatt Regency Scottsdale Resort and Spa at Gainey Ranch features the smooth vibes of Ive Mendes and Jazzanova, while the Hyatt Regency Lost Pines Resort and Spa, outside Austin, Tex., is playing Texas swing numbers by bands like Asleep at the Wheel. Guests who like what they hear can buy the playlists for $22 at the hotels or through their Web sites, www.scottsdale.hyatt.com and www.lostpines.hyatt.com. Norwegian Cruise Line is rolling out Nintendo's Wii video game consoles on its ships. Games will include Wii Sports (tennis, golf, baseball, boxing and bowling), Wii Play (table tennis, air hockey and other games) and WarioWare (Smooth Moves and Excite Truck). The game consoles are hooked up to large screens in the atrium and other common areas, so guests can play one another (www.ncl.com). Volunteers are needed to complete work on the Continental Divide Trail, extending 3,100 miles from Canada to Mexico. Participants of all skill levels and backgrounds are welcome, from cooks to prepare meals for other volunteers, to experienced trail builders (www.cdtrail.org). The Ritz-Carlton, New Orleans, which reopened last December following repairs and renovations after Hurricane Katrina, is reopening its spa on Monday. It has a new cafe, a fitness center and a retail center. The spa, which has 22 treatment rooms, is 25,000 square feet and features treatments like the Marie Laveau Voodoo Love Massage and the Multicolor Masquerade Facial, above. On March 30, the Ritz-Carlton, Tokyo opened in a 53-story tower. The hotel has 250 guest rooms, a sky lobby, several restaurants and bars, and a health club and spa. Nightly rates start at 65,000 yen, about $545 at 121 yen to the dollar (www.ritzcarlton.com). Tokyo is scheduled to get another new hotel in September, the Peninsula Tokyo, looking out on the Imperial Palace Gardens. Plans are for 314 rooms, a rooftop restaurant and a spa. Rates are expected to start at 60,000 yen, or $495 at 121 yen to the dollar (www.peninsula.com). HILARY HOWARD

To the Editor: ''Don't Discard the Bottle Bill'' (editorial, April 8) is unrealistic. Adding beverages is a good idea, in theory. People discard their containers because they're too much trouble to redeem. Things need to change before adding new beverages.

Since New Jersey's smoke-free-air act went into effect a year ago, air quality in restaurants and office buildings has improved greatly, health officials said last week. But a state group that represents bars and restaurants still has misgivings. Fred M. Jacobs, commissioner of the State Department of Health and Senior Services, called the ban, which began a year ago today, ''a giant step forward in public health prevention.''

To the Editor: ''Bringing Back the Sunday Dinner'' (April 1) hit home. I should say the home I once knew. Sundays were family visiting days. Either our aunts, uncles, cousins and friends came to our house or we went to theirs. To this day, I get a bittersweet feeling on a Sunday afternoon when I long for those wonderful days of food, laughter and warmth.

Jonathan Cohn's article (April 1) gives us reason to be optimistic, but lest we become prematurely giddy about the possibility that the left and right can unite in a common cause for universal health care, we need to remember there are 1,001 trapdoors in Congress through which any proposal may fall. And there will still be plenty of special-interest groups around to pull the levers.

To the Editor: David Leonhardt's review of Brian Doherty's ''Radicals for Capitalism'' ( April 1) was very economical with the truth, claiming that the Cato Institute is ''struggling to persuade people that global warming -- the archetypal free-market failure -- is a hoax.''

To the Editor: ''DNA Test Offers Immigrants Hope or Despair'' (front page, April 10) recounts the poignant story of Isaac Owusu, a naturalized American citizen, who can bring from Ghana only one of his four sons to join him in the United States because DNA testing by immigration officials showed that only one is his biological son.

FOR a winter that took so long in coming, this one seems to have taken just as long to leave. Even after the snow and ice were gone, winter's residue could still be found spread across the grass in the powdery leaves and twigs, the dirt shoved by the snowplow up onto the lawn, and all the other bits of dust it left in its wake. Our lawn is an uneven place to begin with. It is a combination of the broad, deep-green blades of Kentucky bluegrass and the thinner blades of fine fescue, a typical mix in this region. From time to time, we have also let the grass go to meadow, so add to that the timothy, ryegrass and patches of clover, along with the knotweed, crabgrass and dandelion, and you've got the rough texture of the common Northeastern lawn.

An article last Sunday about Frank Music Company, a sheet music store, misstated the circumstances in which the owner, Heidi Rogers, acquired the store. She bought it on her own in 1978; her father, the composer Milton Rogers, never owned it.

An article last Sunday about Roosevelt Island residents' wish for additional access to the Queensboro Bridge misstated the years during which the island's only auto access was via an elevator from the bridge. The elevator was in use from 1916 to 1956 -- not 1930 to 1955.

DODSON--Glenn. The Curtis Institute of Music mourns the loss of Glenn Dodson, alumnus, longtime faculty member, and former principal trombone of the Philadelphia Orchestra. A larger than life figure, he was a master of his instrument, a gifted teacher, a raconteur without peer, and above all, a gentleman. Glenn Dodson played jazz, Dixieland, and big-band music, all with the same enthusiasm and consummate skill that he brought to his symphonic career. His former students now play in America's leading orchestras. His recordings under conductors such as Ormandy, Muti, and Sawallisch set the standard for future generations of trombonists. Everyone at Curtis sends their deepest sympathies to Glenn Dodson's family and condolences to his former students who have lost their mentor. H.F. (Gerry) Lenfest, Chairman Roberto Diaz, President The Curtis Institute of Music

Jens mortensen; Courtesy of La Shed Du Fred; courtesy of Laura Davidson Public RelationsFor a superstar hairstylist, Orlando Pita is as modest as a shampoo girl's tips. You won't find him bragging about Madonna, Gwyneth, Tilda and Naomi. And he's way too laid-back to boast about how many fashion shows and ad campaigns he's hot-rollered in the more than 20 years he's been at the top of the game. But there's nothing casual about how he approaches his work. ''I'm a stickler for perfection,'' Pita says, ''although of course, sometimes, perfection can be a perfect mess.'' 2. Between his many photo shoots and runway shows, a consulting gig for L'Oréal and the private clients he coifs at his minimal-chic downtown salon (Orlo, 34 Gansevoort Street; 212-242-3266), Pita rarely lets his hair down. But whenever he can, he and his partner, George Casson, retreat to Cotton House hotel, on the tiny Caribbean island of Mustique. ''My life is so crowded and social that when I get a week off, I prefer remote places.'' Go to www.cottonhouseresort.com. 3. For peace and quiet within driving distance, Pita and Casson shack up in their new country house on the Delaware River in Callicoon, N.Y. ''I love being on the water, and upstate is more me than Long Island,'' he says. The pair frequent the local home-furnishings shop La Shed Du Fred, for gifts, candles, and furniture and accessories by local artisans. Go to www.lasheddufred.com. 4. His most prized haircutting tool -- a vintage feather razor -- was a gift from a close friend. ''I like to use a razor the old-fashioned way, like scissors, to actually cut the hair, not just thin it.'' Similar razors can be found at www.classicshaving.com. 5. Pita's promoting platinum for spring. ''I think bold colors are in, and platinum is the boldest blond you can have,'' he says. ''Obviously, it's not for everyone. You have to be committed.'' Andre Viveiros, Orlo's celebrity colorist, adds, ''Platinum is modern if it's on the cool side, and not too golden.'' The supe du jour, Agyness Deyn, shown here, has the perfect hue. 6. The stylist goes through cases of Kérastase Résistance Double Force hair spray -- $32 at Orlo -- during show season. ''It's a great way to add texture to hair, especially the cropped cut I've been doing lately,'' Pita says. ''I spray it all over in sections and then brush it out. And I always run my fingers through the hair after I spray it.'' 7. His favorite secret address in Paris isn't a trendy boutique or scenester haunt. It's BVH, a department store at 14, rue de Temple, where le sous-sol, the basement hardware and crafts section, is creatively stocked. ''I'll go there two or three times for inspiration during Paris fashion week,'' he says. ''You can find amazing things -- great skins, shoe-mending supplies, chains, laces.'' He used materials he found there to make these hand-cut and hand-lacquered barrettes for John Galliano's fall 2007 Dior runway. 8. His favorite restaurant, Knickerbocker Bar and Grill (33 University Place), isn't exactly teeming with fashion types. ''People don't expect me to like a place like this, but when I take them there, they become instant converts. It's very neighborhood-y, and I'm obsessed with the short ribs.'' 9. As for his own wavy locks? Pita suds up with L'Oréal Vive Pro Nutri Gloss shampoo ($5 at Target). ''It's light but nourishing and leaves my hair really shiny. You don't need to use a lot, and I can even get by without conditioner.'' 10. Orlo clients are smitten with the Bespoke Labs T3 Overnight hair dryer ($130). ''I've never seen a travel dryer this good. It's tiny, folds up, has dual voltage and is as powerful as a full-size model.'' .

The thousands of people who went to the New York International Auto Show in recent days saw first-hand the shabby state of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and its surroundings. For some time now politicians and developers have been trying to figure out how to improve both the center and the large, mostly untended patch of Manhattan around it. Now Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his new team are getting ready to put their own stamp on this painfully long-running story. It may be too much to hope for now, but the Spitzer people should try to make any new Javits Center better than just mediocre. Right now the planners seem determined to create a Javits Center that pleases almost no one. And that for only $2 billion, give or take a few $100 million.
Time to jazz up your nails.

Re ''Reporting the News Even When a Competitor Gets There First'' (March 11): You write: ''The reality is that when significant news breaks -- even in the form of an exclusive in a competing publication -- The Times must be committed to getting on the story. Anything less seriously damages the paper's value to readers.''
EYRE--John, 1935-2007, died on March 8, in Newport, RI. His funeral mass will be held on Saturday April 21, 10:00 am at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue and 84th Street.

We have always been slightly uneasy - notwithstanding our growing cultural obsession with youth and physical perfection - about the enormous value we assign to female physiognomy, based as it is on nothing more substantive than an undemocratic rolling of the genetic dice. Clearly, although we have all been bequeathed a more or less similar arrangement of facial features (eyes, nose, mouth, neck, skin), there are some women who emerge, either by way of felicitous lineage or a hazard of good fortune, with mugs to die for. Audrey Hepburn. Vivien Leigh. Grace Kelly. Julie Christie. Julia Roberts. Halle Berry. Penélope Cruz. The variations may range from the gamine to the sultry, the classic to the exotic -- stopping along the way for the slightly more Nordic look that often goes with blond lovelies -- but the theme is the same. They are undeniably beautiful; we, by and large, however attractive or striking, are not. This tragic and unearned differential (one that is becoming ever more tragic in a ''looksist'' society) has led us to devise ways of minimizing beauty's importance with dispassionate abstractions or consoling, somewhat grandmotherly mantras. If you want to get high-minded about it, you can clutch for solace at the conjecture of the 18th-century philosopher David Hume that beauty ''exists merely in the mind . . . and each mind perceives a different beauty'' and hope that no one will notice that this observation, if it ever held up, preceded the invention of photography. Closer at hand is the adage ''Beauty is as beauty does,'' which is the kind of snippy comment Mary Poppins might have made if she came upon one of her charges preening before his or her reflection. Then there is the old platitude ''Beauty is in the eye of the beholder,'' which attempts a similar leveling of the playing field.

Like a soufflé hot out of the oven, newly created vocal works with instrumental accompaniment will be on display at Weill Recital Hall. They are the fruits of the collaboration of a group of young composers and a dozen singers, brought together in a workshop organized by Carnegie Hall and the Bard College Conservatory of Music. OSVALDO GOLIJOV, the Argentine composer, and the soprano DAWN UPSHAW, his longtime collaborator, oversaw the effort. The group developed the pieces in a workshop in November before rehearsals this month. A selection will be performed at Weill. Sunday at 3 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $15. For those who missed it two weeks ago, a second performance of CHARLES WUORINEN'S Percussion Symphony -- drum heaven, some might say -- takes place on Monday, courtesy of an unusual joint project by the percussion departments of the Manhattan School of Music and the Juilliard School. Complex, chaotic-sounding, fascinating and at times otherworldly, this 40-minute work is a pillar of the percussion world. 8 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 769-7406, juilliard.edu; free, but tickets are required. KARITA MATTILA, the immensely gifted soprano, gives a Carnegie Hall recital featuring an eclectic and offbeat program. The composers include Barber, Wolf, Turina, Kuula, Melartin and Granados. Wednesday at 8 p.m.; $25 to $84. The Metropolitan Opera will offer a grand reunion: the three one-act operas by Puccini written to be performed as ''IL TRITTICO,'' but more often done separately. They consist of ''Il Tabarro,'' a dark piece of grand guignol; the bittersweet ''Suor Angelica''; and the light, slightly acerbic ''Gianni Schicchi,'' with that beloved excerpt aria ''O mio babbino caro.'' This new production was created by Jack O'Brien, the Broadway director behind ''Hairspray.'' Maria Guleghina and Salvatore Licitra sing in ''Tabarro''; Barbara Frittoli portrays the ill-fated Sister Angelica; and Alessandro Corbelli sings that rascal Schicchi. James Levine conducts. Opening night is Friday. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $26 to $175.

Can the actress Salma Hayek help Hollywood figure out how to give a Latino lilt to mainstream entertainment? She has done it successfully with ''Ugly Betty,'' the Colombian telenovela reshaped for an American audience into the hit ABC show, for which she is executive producer. Now, she is teaming up with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which is slowly building new divisions and relationships to fill its distribution pipeline, to accomplish the same goal. The production company, called Ventanazul and half-owned by each party, will focus on making movies that have Latino themes but appeal to mass audiences. Ms. Hayek will be chief executive.

To the Editor: Re ''Japan's Whaling Obsession'' (editorial, April 1): Japan strongly supports the international protection of endangered whale species and advocates for the sustainable harvest of species in abundance only. Whaling for scientific research is indispensable to establish the proper conservation of whales and ocean resources. Japan is sincerely committed to researching whales' dietary habits and nutrition status, as well as the shift in whale populations by age over time.

DiNATALE--Ann. The entire Long Island College Hospital of Brooklyn family acknowledges with sadness the passing of Ann DiNatale, beloved mother of our dear friend and colleague, Diana Sullivan, Vice President of Operations. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. To Diana, her sisters, son-in-law Danny Sullivan and the entire DiNatale and Sullivan families, we extend heartfelt condolences. Rita M. Battles, President & CEO John Byrne, Executive V.P. and Chief Operating Officer Edmund Giegerich, M.D., Executive V.P. for Medical Affairs

They may not rank with the dueling ''Wild Party'' musicals of 2000, but three Off Broadway productions are now competing for the important theater-kitchenware demographic. Already running at New World Stages, ''SEALED FOR FRESHNESS'' uses plastic containers as a metaphor for the hermetic lives of five Midwestern housewives; their lids pop off when the cocktails come out at a Tupperware party. Audiences can share the feeling: a drink called a Tuppertini is sold at the bar. And at select performances ticket holders vie for sandwich holders in a raffle. Through April 29, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com; $65. There's no metaphor at ''DIXIE'S TUPPERWARE PARTY,'' starting previews on Wednesday at Ars Nova. Items are really on sale, and Dixie Longate, your hostess, is a real Tupperware top-seller, even if she's a tiny bit fictional. Created by Kris Andersson, Dixie is unapologetic trailer trash: Did you know that the Rectangular Cake Taker makes a handy caddy for 34 Jell-O shots? (Which can serve, she explains, ''two people and one of your kids.'') Despite this, and despite what Dixie does with product No. 426, the Tupperware people have approved the production. Opens May 10 and runs through June 17, 511 West 54th Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com; $20 to $25. ''AMERICAN FIESTA,'' now in previews at the Vineyard Theater, takes a step up the socioeconomic culinary-metaphor scale by offering Fiestaware -- the brightly colored table ceramics beloved of collectors -- as a way of looking at the divide between red and blue states. Written and performed by Steven Tomlinson, the play also concerns divisions within Mr. Tomlinson's own family over his plan to marry his male partner. Watch the crockery fly, or maybe not; a covered onion soup bowl in turquoise can fetch $8,500. Opens April 26 and runs through May 20, 108 East 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 353-0303, www.vineyardtheatre.org; $50.

A reader writes, ''God may be invoked because the explanatory power of science ultimately breaks down, leaving a vacuum that must be filled'' (Letters, April 1, in response to ''Darwin's God,'' by Robin Marantz Henig, March 4). But why should God be invoked in the face of the unknown? Is it not enough to say, ''I don't know''? Imagining supernatural answers precludes the possibility of finding verifiable answers. This makes God and ignorance synonymous.

To the Editor: The State Senate's Transportation Committee recently approved a bill authorizing $10 million in bonding to study where sound barriers are needed most on our highways (''Turning Roar of the Road Into a Whisper,'' April 8). I don't understand why any study is needed.
KLEINER--Harold. Remembered each day with a smile. Gill, Tommy, Jen, and Danielle

FOR years I've coached my kids' teams -- my three sons' baseball and basketball teams, my daughter's softball team. I didn't do it because I was a great athlete; I didn't even play high school sports. I've coached because a lot of the coaching I saw when my oldest was starting out was very bad. I've found it hard to do well, and rarely do I feel I've achieved the right balance. It's fine to say winning doesn't matter, but try losing every game, as I did one year in our town basketball league. Kids lose interest. When you see the parents in town, you feel you owe them an explanation. (''That team we played last night was so stacked.'') The joy goes out of the game and the players do, too. In their overprogrammed lives, the 0-8 basketball team falls to the bottom of the list.

Ben Wallace-Wells's article (April 1) was informative. Senator Obama comes across as a fresh face, and David Axelrod seems to have guided him well. The roughness of the political game was reflected in the story of Senator Clinton's important work for children like David Axelrod's son -- work that, Axelrod's wife, Susan, said, was ''one of the most important things anyone has done for epilepsy.'' And yet David Axelrod is now ''dedicated to derailing this woman's career.''

SAUL--Joseph E. The faculty and staff of The Mount Sinai Heart mourn the loss of Joseph E. Saul, a generous philanthropist. Mr. Saul's personal commitment to cardiology will long be remembered. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Norma; his son Andrew, an esteemed Trustee; and the entire Saul family. Valentin Fuster, M.D., Ph.D., Director, The Mount Sinai Heart $(6$)SAUL--Joseph E., 1919-2007. Loving husband of Norma for 67 years. Fabulous father of Andrew and Jane Berkey, father-in-law of Denise. Loving grandfather of Kim and Aaron, Jennifer and Rob. Great-grandfather of William and Caroline. A true gentlemen and outstanding person. Services will be private. $(6$)SAUL--Joseph. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Joseph Saul, a longtime friend, and generous supporter. This spring the fashion forward take their hues from nature.

Recently, as I lay naked below the waist while a stranger spread hot wax on my nether regions, I began to think about trust. Like most New Yorkers, I am wary of strangers -- even friends. If the woman telling me to flip over and spread my cheeks had tried to talk to me on the street, I wouldn't have made eye contact. And yet here we were, making tiny talk as she eyed my bikini line to make sure it was symmetrical. In 15 minutes, she'd be determining the sexual fate of yet another woman willing to pay to suspend suspicion in order to be pretty. How did we get here?

It's April, time for school board elections and budget approvals. That's right, only two more days before voters decide all things school-related in New Jersey. This year that date is April 17, and for most, such matters are about as enthralling as filling out a Form 1040.

Diana Kyung Kim, the daughter of Ki Sim Kim and Dae Youl Kim of Riverside, Calif., was married yesterday to Steig David Olson, a son of Colleen F. Olson and Dwight M. Olson of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Beth Waltemath officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn. Ms. Kim-Olson, 29, is an associate at Condon & Forsyth, a Manhattan law firm. She graduated from Johns Hopkins University and received her law degree from the University of California's Hastings College of the Law in San Francisco.

To the Editor: Re ''What Consultants May Not Know About Leadership,'' William J. Holstein's review of ''True North'' by Bill George (Off the Shelf, April 1): While I largely agree with the review -- and even with the idea that much of what is written and taught on the topic is likely worthless -- it misses a broader point about the leadership development field.

DUNBAR--Judge Gerald J., Civil Court Judge. The Honorable Gerald J. Dunbar, a judge in the Civil Court of the City of New York, died Thursday April 12 in New York Methodist Hospital after a short and sudden illness. Born in Peoria, Illinois, January 15, 1947 and raised in Buffalo, Judge Dunbar came to New York City as a teenager to attend New York University and stayed to become a prominent attorney in Brooklyn before winning his judgeship in a city-wide election in November 2005. Prior to taking his seat on the bench, Judge Dunbar was a partner in the Brooklyn law firm of Tenenbaum, Dunbar and Berger. Earlier he was in independent practice in Brooklyn and Manhattan. His specialties as an attorney included labor law, landlord/tenant law and election law. A lifelong supporter of liberal causes and reform politics, he was well known in Brooklyn as a legal advisor to reform candidates who often challenged the Kings County political establishment. Judge Dunbar lived in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn with his wife Christine Pasquariello, a physician and former attorney. They met when both were students at Brooklyn Law School and were married in 1990. In addition to a bachelor's degree from NYU, Judge Dunbar earned a juris doctor degree from Brooklyn Law School in 1974 and a masters of law in labor law from NYU Law School in 1975. He was predeceased by his mother, Marie Dunbar, and father, Gerald Dunbar. Family and friends are planning a memorial service to celebrate his life.

Fembot / (fem bot) / n. / in fiction, a powerful, lifelike android with sexy female attributes and blemish-proof skin, e.g., ''I love that episode of 'The Bionic Woman' where the deadly fembot has her face mask removed.'' In reality, a powerful, androidlike female with sexy accessories and blemish-proof skin: ''It all started with those RoboCop shoes, but now she's gone full fembot -- she's even getting DNA-based facials.''

Hard, brittle beats. Noisy new-wave grooves. A preening, party-obsessed lead singer. In many ways the duo GHOSTLAND OBSERVATORY from Austin, Tex., seems like an old-fashioned band, eager to recreate the sights and sounds of an earlier era. In this case that earlier era is 2002. Back then partyers and journalists were talking about a playful club scene sometimes known as electroclash, although the term came to be used as a punch line: a ridiculous name for a ridiculous scene that seemed to disappear as soon as it (noisily) arrived. But like many ridiculous pop-culture phenomena before it, electroclash has proved remarkably durable. The demand for danceable new music is, as economists would say, inelastic, and Ghostland Observatory has figured out a way -- hammy but apparently effective -- to satisfy it. The duo has built a cult following the even-older-fashioned way: through raucous live shows. Expect one Wednesday night at the Bowery Ballroom. 8 p.m., 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111; $13 in advance, $15 at the door. On Thursday and Friday nights, a different kind of dance party: HOT CHIP, a British band with a knack for creating moody and wriggly electronic tracks; thanks in part to some memorable music videos the group has found an American following that ranges from house-music connoisseurs to indie-rock purists. 6:30 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111; Thursday, $22 in advance, $25 at the door; Friday, sold out.

I would not deny poor people the satisfaction that comes with effective money management and savings (Rachel Louise Snyder, April 1). But I see little to celebrate in America Saves, where the daily deprivation of what most Americans take for granted (sweets and bread, for example) is necessary for a minimum-wage earner to accumulate even a small savings account. What kind of security can those meager savings buy for such times of real need as unemployment, retirement and health crises? Let's address the frugality training to the privileged, whose excessive consumption withdraws money from the public good and deteriorates our environment.

ZELTZER--Pearl. The National Foundation for Jewish Culture extends its sincere condolences to George Mike Zeltzer, founder of the NFJC, and to his family on the passing of his beloved wife Pearl. Pearl was a visionary patron of the arts and an avid supporter of dance. Her legacy lives on in her contributions to the Jewish community. Carol B. Spinner, President Charlotte Newberger, Chairperson Elise M. Bernhardt, Executive Director

To the Editor: Your support for a proposed beverage-container law allowing the state to seize unredeemed deposits held by wholesalers (''Don't Discard the Bottle Bill,'' editorial, April 8) shows an apparent misunderstanding of how the law works now. We pay a 5-cent deposit on each beer or soda container. If we do not return them, we lose our nickels, the retailer does not pay a refund and the wholesaler still has our nickels. These nickels are the target of the proposal.

To the Editor: Thank you for ''Preservationists Scramble to Buy Vital Link to Rowayton Nature Sanctuary'' (April 8). We land trust volunteers believe we are doing the right thing by saving this ''greenbelt of shoreline, marsh and meadow on Farm Creek, an inlet off Long Island Sound.''

WILSON--John H., died in New York on March 21, at age 84. As a company manager for Sol Hurok and Harold Shaw, and presentations manager for the Metropolitan Opera, John was a consummate professional. His friends knew him as a New England gentleman of strongly held opinions who will be dearly missed.

BROWN--Jack M., died peacefully at his home at Princeton Windrows, Princeton, NJ on April 10, 2007 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife Dorothy Taylor Brown, his devoted sister Madelyn Brown Harris of New York and nephews Jack Brown Harris of New York and Steven Brown Harris of Washington, DC and their families. He was active in real estate as President of Frederick Brown, Inc. as well as various philanthropic and charitable causes in New York and St. Croix. He was a graduate of Horace Mann, Princeton University class of 1935 and the Harvard Business School class of 1937. He was former Chairman and President of the Jewish Hospital and Home for the Aged in New York City. An avid sailor, he was Commodore of the Storm Trysail Club and a member of the New York Yacht Club. He also belonged to the University and Harmonie Clubs. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to a charity of your choice.

To the Sports Editor: The reason Alex Rodriguez's Yankees tenure is so emotionally tortured is never spoken. When he became a Yankee, Derek Jeter should have volunteered to move to center field. Everyone knew Rodriguez was the superior shortstop.

The Chess column last Sunday, about the effect of technology on cheating, included incorrect information from the United States Chess Federation about Steve Rosenberg, a player who was expelled from the World Open last July after a tournament director said he found a wireless receiver in Mr. Rosenberg's ear. Although the federation's ethics committee has indeed ordered that he be suspended from playing in tournaments, that suspension is not in effect because Mr. Rosenberg is appealing. His case will be heard in August.

In a probation hearing last week, Richard M. Scrushy, a former HealthSouth chief executive, took the stand in his own defense -- something that he declined to do in both of his criminal trials. Mr. Scrushy has been on presentencing release since a federal jury in Montgomery last year convicted him of bribing former Gov. Don Siegelman of Alabama. (Before that, Mr. Scrushy was acquitted in a case involving accounting fraud at HealthSouth.)

1964 That's the house in Connecticut. I look like my mom. My sister is much more blond.; 1970 Graduation day -- I went to P.S. 6 in New York. I've always had long hair. I just like it long. The one thing that I haven't really changed in my life.; 1985 That was when I was single, in the Hamptons with Tommy Cohen, renting houses with friends every weekend.I was working for Ralph Lauren during the week.; 1986 Calvin and I on our wedding day. I remember spending a day or two in Rome, and then we were off to buy fabric.; 1995 At the Council of Fashion Designers of America. I was wearing a Calvin dress. When he first did the bias slip dresses, I wore them all the time.; 2006 Tony Melillo and me at Art Basel Miami. We were shopping for clothing. The Raleigh Hotel has a little boutique, and we were taking a break from all the events.

The strange relationships that can emerge when two people assume the roles of driver and passenger come into play in the economy-size ''FARES TO REMEMBER.'' This series, which includes seven creakers, charmers and classics, is part of a larger, somewhat dubious centennial tribute to the first gas-powered taxi in New York City, organized by the Design Trust for Public Spaces. (You can read more about the celebration at taxi07.org.) New Yorkers who have either narrowly escaped death by cab or are currently experiencing slow death by fumes may wonder what there is to celebrate about any machine with a gas-hungry internal combustion engine. Those still mourning the Checker may also find little to celebrate. Still, despite some capricious choices -- including non-New York titles like Neil Jordan's 1986 British drama ''Mona Lisa'' -- the series makes for diverting viewing. In Mitchell Leisen's 1939 screwball comedy ''Midnight,'' a marvelous Claudette Colbert and a game Don Ameche run amok inside a Parisian cab and out; in Jim Jarmusch's 1991 ''Night on Earth,'' Winona Ryder, among others, helps take us for an engaging spin. Also on view is Martin Scorsese's 1976 masterpiece ''Taxi Driver,'' in which the director himself plays a virulently sexist and racist passenger whose rage seems to tap into a primordial element of the taxicab experience: ''Did you ever see what a .44 Magnum pistol can do to a woman's face?'' No, but I have seen what a New York cab can do to her nerves. Weekends through April 29, IFC Center, 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 924-7771, ifccenter.com.

I wish Ann Hulbert (April 1) had examined in greater detail the central dilemma of the intellectually daring citizens of the People's Republic of China. Those who would like to make a difference in today's China also know how dangerous free expression can be. How does one think outside the box when the simplest questions are dangerous?

SUSSMAN--Morris, on April 5. Entrepreneur and philanthropist. A leader in the cosmetic packaging industry founding two firms: Shore Plastics and Cadview Technologies. He was discreetly generous to both organized charities and his friends, while mentoring a large number of colleagues. Loving husband, father, and grandfather. He is sorely missed by those whose lives he touched, but remains a powerful influence on those who knew him.

THALER--Carole, died on April 13, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Devoted and loving mother of Jacqueline, Michael and Gabrielle. Cherished daughter of Eleanore Rosen and sister of Stanley, Betsi and Larry, and sister-in-law of Nancy. Dearest aunt of Jeffrey, Matthew, Jaime, David and Alek and great-aunt of Peyton. Carole was a vibrant loving soul with a sense of style whose love of her children, family and music will endure forever. Services Monday 1pm at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.
One influence in David Bradshaw's men's clothing design (notably the Thom Browne suits) (Style, April 1) that was surely overlooked is none other than Pee-wee Herman.

To the Editor: Your editorial about Greenport (''A Victory on Main Street,'' April 1) reported the happy resolution to a contested development plan, but did not mention the long journey and grass-roots activism that brought about this conclusion.

HIRSCH--Barry. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the untimely passing of their fellow member Mr. Barry Hirsch and offer their deepest sympathy to his loving companion, Karen Mansour, his children and the entire Hirsch Family. Alpine Country Club Robert Hershan, President
Or how to get a grip.

THE dance routines have lost some of their Hollywood gloss, and occasionally a hormone-hijacked voice threatens to derail a duet. But herds of young actors have been saying the same thing since last fall, when Disney's ''High School Musical'' started hurtling into school drama departments: The show is unstoppable. The TV movie that set off a million adolescent singalongs before its soundtrack went on to become the biggest-selling album of last year is currently rah-rah-ing its way across more than 1,300 school stages worldwide, according to Disney officials; more than 100 of them are in elementary, middle and high schools in the suburbs around New York.

Mayor Noam Bransom of New Rochelle outlined the steps last week that city officials and representatives of New Roc City Associates were taking in response to the melee that started Sunday at the New Roc City entertainment center.Hundreds of youths, many from New York City, had clashed with the police on city streets after being ejected from New Roc, and more than 200 police officers, including some from other Westchester departments, were called in. At least seven youths were arrested. Mr. Bramson, describing the violent clash as an ''anomaly,'' said the city would accelerate the start of its summer security and youth outreach programs, increase the overall police presence in downtown, and improve communication with Metro-North, so that local police officials would be informed whenever a large group boards a train at another location with New Rochelle as its destination.

An article in the pay report about exit packages for ousted chief executives misstated a salary equivalent of the average severance in 2006. That average, $9 million, was equivalent to about 170 weeks of salary for each year, not each week, at the helm.

Dirty is vastly underrated as a perfume aesthetic. There are, of course, several kinds of dirty. Exhibit A is Agent Provocateur, a lingerie concern that, like Victoria's Secret, professes to sell sex. But while Victoria's Secret is that great Middle American Walt Disney of sex, Agent is slightly grittier, dirtier. Or it professes to be; sex packaged by marketers tends to promise the real thing but is in fact so sterile you couldn't even catch the other person's cold. It's dirt without germs, an idea of intimacy without actually experiencing it. The surprise is that this turns out to be an excellent concept for a perfume. The brilliance of Agent Provocateur, the company's rather astonishing first perfume, is that it doesn't actually smell like unwashed panties. It's better than that: it just reminds you of them. It smells like crushed raspberries and black plums on hot skin. Expertly constructed by the perfumer Christian Provenzano, the juice lasts beautifully, diffuses perfectly and could raise the fertility rate in Manhattan without raising laundry bills. It's like a photo of a thong and cheeky ouverts. All image, no dirt.

To the Editor: Re ''Jolly Good Show Or Was It?'' [April 8]: Though I was unaware of Stephen Fry's comments concerning the lack of discernment we Americans seem to evince in evaluating British actors, this subject has long been a source of great mirth among my set.

AS Washington tussles over the fate of the nation's estimated 12 million undocumented immigrants, municipal governments are taking sides. Places like Morristown, N.J., and Danbury, Conn., are cracking down. Others, like New Haven and New York City, are embracing their undocumented workers. City councils can't change the federal government's failed immigration policies, but they can choose whether to offset or intensify the damage. According to the Migration Policy Institute at New York University, United States municipalities passed 34 laws last year tightening the screws on undocumented immigrants; 56 more such measures are pending.

Less Is More During Kobe Bryant's four-game streak of scoring 50 or more points, it seemed that he was proving the ''Wall Street'' antihero Gordon Gekko's theory that greed is good. The Lakers won all four games on the heels of a seven-game losing streak. Since then, the Lakers have lost both of the games in which Bryant scored 50 or more, including 50 in a loss to the Clippers on Thursday. Outside the streak, they are 2-3 when he reaches 50.

To the Editor: Re ''Packing for the Ineffable'' (Op-Ed, April 11): Valerie Seiling Jacobs's heart-rending reflection on the packing and departure of her stepson for a tour in Iraq was at once rich in the details of packing rites and expansive toward the human feelings implied by these actions.

To the Editor: Your support for a proposed beverage-container law allowing the state to seize unredeemed deposits held by wholesalers (''Don't Discard the Bottle Bill,'' editorial, April 8) shows an apparent misunderstanding of how the law works now.
Bronze-medal treatment.

INTERNATIONAL 3-16 Iran's Neighbors in Atomic Push Roughly a dozen states that neighbor Iran have recently turned to the International Atomic Energy Agency for help in starting nuclear programs. While they say they intend to use the programs for energy production, the United States government and private analysts say the activity is also intended to counter the threat of a nuclear Iran. 1 McCain Says 'No Plan B' for Iraq In a discussion of how he would handle Iraq if elected president, Senator John McCain said that the buildup of American forces in the country represents the only viable option to avoid failure in Iraq and that he had yet to identify an effective fallback if the current strategy failed. 1 A car bomber struck near a bus station in the holy city of Karbala, killing at least 36 people, including several children, according to security officials. 6 Marine Actions Criticized A report published by an Afghan human rights commission said American marines reacted to a bombing with excessive force in Afghanistan last month, hitting groups of bystanders and vehicles with machine-gun fire in a series of attacks that killed 12 civilians, including an infant. 1 A Possible Alliance in Darfur Representatives of the main rebel groups fighting the Sudanese government in Darfur are discussing a military alliance of Arab and non-Arab tribes in an effort either to negotiate a settlement to the crisis in Darfur or to mount a decisive offensive against the government. 1 North Korea Deadline Passes The first deadline for North Korea to shut down and seal its main facility for manufacturing nuclear weapons fuel expired with no apparent action by the North to fulfill its commitments, while China asked officials in the Bush administration to show patience. 10 NATIONAL 18-26 Battle for Student Loans In a fierce contest to control the student loan market, the nation's banks and lenders have for years waged a successful campaign to limit a federal program that was intended to make borrowing less costly by having the government provide loans directly to students. 1 Philadelphia Gun Violence Philadelphia is in the midst of an epidemic of gun violence that has left the police struggling to preserve public safety and government officials renewing efforts to tighten the state's gun control laws. Last year, there were 406 homicides, most by gunshot, the highest number in nine years. 18 Falling Away From Religion A new wave of research shows that increasing percentages of Hispanics are abandoning church, suggesting that along with assimilation comes a measure of secularization. 18 NEW YORK/REGION 29-34 Uncertainty After Corzine Crash Gov. Jon S. Corzine's doctor said it could take ''days or weeks'' before he was lucid enough to resume his duties after a car crash, and six months before he could walk again. The crash comes at a crucial moment in New Jersey state government and in the life of Mr. Corzine's young administration. 29 Chess 33 Weather 24 Obituaries 27

SAVER--Harry N., 77, of Scarsdale, NY and Palm Beach, FL died April 10. Graduate of Harvard College and Tufts Medical School, he practiced for many years as an internist in the NYC Hospital system, well-respected by colleagues and students and loved by patients. Devoted husband, father, grandfather, friend, and colleague, he leaves his beloved wife, Esther; his loving sons, daughters-in-law, and grandchildren, Jeffrey and wife Kay Young and their son Dashiell; Richard and wife Joan Krause and their daughter Mikaela. An extraordinarily warm, intelligent, and empathetic man, he was much loved and will be greatly missed. Funeral service Sunday, 1:00pm, Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale. Donations in his memory may be made to a medical charity of your choice.

Faced with what it said was an increase in gun crimes in the last year, the New Haven Police Department is considering installing a system of sensors to detect gunfire in certain areas of the city. On April 4, officials from ShotSpotter Inc., a company in Santa Clara, Calif., that builds such a system, toured the city to find sites for the sensors. Lt. Peter G. Reichard of the New Haven Police said the department was considering the system for the Newhallville and the Hill neighborhoods, where about 80 percent of the violent crime in the city took place. ''We found about 50 different sites,'' Lieutenant Reichard said, but would not disclose which were chosen.

An article on April 1 about the New York auto show misstated the source of emissions technology in new heavy-duty Dodge Ram pickups. The trucks' diesel engine was developed by Cummins; Mercedes-Benz was not involved.

There can be no secrets when an adolescent in a school shares with an adult that he or she is considering suicide (The Ethicist, April 1). School personnel are ethically obliged to report such communications to clinical and administrative parties. And, most important, parents must be informed.

FOR years I've coached my kids' teams -- my three sons' baseball and basketball teams, my daughter's softball team. I didn't do it because I was a great athlete; I didn't even play high school sports. I've coached because a lot of the coaching I saw when my oldest was starting out was very bad. I've found it hard to do well, and rarely do I feel I've achieved the right balance. It's fine to say winning doesn't matter, but try losing every game, as I did one year in our town basketball league. Kids lose interest. When you see the parents in town, you feel you owe them an explanation. (''That team we played last night was so stacked.'') The joy goes out of the game and the players do, too. In their overprogrammed lives, the 0-8 basketball team falls to the bottom of the list.

KELLNER--Zoe M. Beautiful Zoe, your sparkling smile and dancing Brown eyes will be forever in our hearts. Your spirit never to be forgotten. All our love forever, Vanessa, Peggy, Marc, Brian and Kelli
The Savage Detectives By Roberto Bolano. Translated by Natasha Wimmer. 577 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.
Deep thoughts? Marisa Meltzer pans for gold.
To the Editor: Re ''Unsettling History of That Joyous 'Hallelujah' '' [April 8]:

To the Editor: ''Bringing Back the Sunday Dinner'' (April 1) hit home. I should say the home I once knew. Sundays were family visiting days. Either our aunts, uncles, cousins and friends came to our house or we went to theirs. To this day, I get a bittersweet feeling on a Sunday afternoon when I long for those wonderful days of food, laughter and warmth.

A parade of Republican White House candidates appealed for support from over 1,000 Iowa Republicans on Saturday, with two of their leading candidates -- Senator John McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani -- assailing Democrats in Washington for pressing legislation that would set a timetable for bringing American troops back from Iraq. It was the first time that the major Republican candidates had appeared at the same event -- the annual Lincoln Day dinner, held in the sprawling ballroom of a downtown convention center here. For more than three hours, an audience of the state's most active Republicans listened attentively as candidates proclaimed their strong opposition to abortion rights, called for a crackdown against illegal immigrants and warned that a Democratic return to the White House would result in higher taxes.

To the Editor: David Brooks (''The Fatalist,'' column, April 12) tells us that John McCain believes that he has ''an obligation to seek victory'' in Iraq ''as long as there is any chance of it.'' But is there any chance of it? And is there anything -- anything at all -- that would persuade Senator McCain that victory is impossible? Certainly, it's hard to hold out much hope of winning when things look as terrible as they do now, and when we haven't even been given a consistent account of what would count as a ''win.''

To the Editor: Re ''It's Time to Pack Up Those Beanie Babies,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, April 8): Did anyone think to suggest donating these outgrown toys and childhood treasures? This is the spring season, when volunteers at church sales sort, price and prepare for the spring sales in communities all over the New York area. It is irresponsible to consume and then throw it all away. Recycle! All you have to do is bundle and take it to an open door at a church or Salvation Army. Just not to the landfill, please!

BENDEROTH--Steven C. A memorial service for Steven C. Benderoth, musician, singer, composer, New Yorker, will be held Saturday, April 28th at 3:30 pm at Saint Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Ave. (54th St) in NYC. Please join us to celebrate Steve's life. In lieu of flowers, contact TLJ55@aol.com

The residents of Middlefield have given the town the approval to buy the Powder Ridge Ski Resort, which is closed. But whether the purchase ever happens seems as unpredictable as snow itself. In a referendum last Tuesday, residents voted 1,097 to 151 to authorize the town to borrow $2.8 million to buy the open land at Powder Ridge and the development rights to that property. Jon A. Brayshaw, the first selectman of Middlefield, said the owner of Ski Sundown in New Hartford had agreed to pay the rest of the purchase price for the ski resort itself. Ken Leavitt, the owner of Powder Ridge, however, said the town had yet to offer a fair price. Neither side would disclose the offer, but both agreed it was less than the approximately $6 million the town had appraised the property and the business to be worth.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A First-Class Response to a Second-Class Put-Down,'' April 11: Selena Roberts misses a crucial point in her otherwise prescient analysis of sexism in sports. She cites examples in professional sports in which terms like ''queen'' and ''Mary'' have been used, yet these have as much to do with the denigration of gay men, to whom these terms often refer, as they do with women. Sadly, homophobia and sexism go hand in hand.
Favorite color: Mauve. Favorite Author: Umberto Eco. Favorite Food: Meyer Lemon Sorbetto. Favorite Magazine: T.

To the Editor: Regarding Gerry Wallman's letter about Myanmar (March 25): I have recently returned from a privately escorted nine-day tour of Myanmar. Although I agree with Ms. Wallman that the repressive military government of Myanmar violates human rights as we free people of the Western world know them -- and as I now personally know them from listening to my charming Burmese guide's firsthand accounts of life there -- Myanmar remains a very special place in the world. Where else could you see sites like the one-legged boat rowers on Inle Lake or the more than 4,000 temples in Bagan?

ELKINS--Robert Charles, 89, died April 11, 2007, in Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Lawrence, NY. Artist, poet and family man extraordinaire. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Geraldine, his loving daughter, Joanne Ranzer, and son-in-law David; and his cherished granddaughters, Cori and Karen. A memorial service is planned.

Q. The building next to ours erected a sidewalk shed that partly extends in front of our building. It would not bother us were it not for the fact that it has been up since 2004 and no work has been done since it went up. The owner has dutifully renewed the permit for the shed with the New York City Buildings Department every year. Is the permit renewable by right? Can we protest the next renewal? We think that the work for which the shed was erected should have been completed a long time ago. A. Kate Lindquist, a spokeswoman for the Buildings Department, said a property owner has the right to leave a sidewalk shed up for as long as the permit allows.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended March 31, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. SELECTED POEMS, by Derek Walcott. Edited by Edward Baugh. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) The Nobel Prize winner Walcott, who was born on St. Lucia, is a long-serving poet of exile, caught between two races and two worlds. SEIZURE, by Erica Wagner. (Norton, $23.95.) A troubled young Englishwoman inherits a seaside cottage and takes an unexpected lover. KNOTS, by Nuruddin Farah. (Riverhead, $25.95.) After 20 years, a Somali woman returns home to Mogadishu from Canada, intent on reclaiming a family house from a warlord. CHANGING LIGHT, by Nora Gallagher. (Pantheon, $22.) The Manhattan project inspired this novel of love and guilt in 1940s New Mexico. EVOLUTION FOR EVERYONE: How Darwin's Theory Can Change the Way We Think About Our Lives, by David Sloan Wilson. (Delacorte, $24.) An absorbing study of cooperative behavior. THE MISTRESS'S DAUGHTER, by A. M. Homes. (Viking, $24.95.) Homes's dark memoir tells the story of her birth parents' re-entry into her life. CULTURAL AMNESIA: Necessary Memories From History and the Arts, by Clive James. (Norton, $35.) Essays on 20th-century luminaries by one of Britain's leading public intellectuals. SICK: The Untold Story of America's Health Care Crisis -- and the People Who Pay the Price, by Jonathan Cohn. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) The crisis seen through the experiences of ordinary people. THE LONG EXILE: A Tale of Inuit Betrayal and Survival in the High Arctic, by Melanie McGrath. (Knopf, $24.95.) Canada's forced relocation of a group of Inuit in 1953 is now seen as one of the country's worst human rights violations. THE ROAD TO DISUNION: Volume Two. Secessionists Triumphant: 1854-1861, by William W. Freehling. (Oxford University, $35.) This history of the origins of the Civil War stresses the South's distinct cultural and economic divisions. INVENTING HUMAN RIGHTS: A History, by Lynn Hunt. (Norton, $25.95.) Modern attitudes are traced to the 18th-century Enlightenment. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Beauty that's fresh as a daisy.

To the Editor: Like Fred and Ellen Bishko, who described their Edward Albee-inspired trip in their recent letter to the editor (March 11), my husband and I also went to Easter Island after reading Mr. Albee's rave travelogue, ''The Dream at the End of the World'' (April 30, 2006). Never has a trip so exceeded expectations. The statues were awesome, exactly as Mr. Albee described them, but what he never mentioned was the ravishing beauty and the incredibly mellow vibe of Easter Island.

Kellie Kvern, 35, from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, exploring an old quarter of Beijing in the process of being demolished: ''I went back to Beijing for three weeks; I had lived there for three years as a student and as a teacher of English. I hadn't been back in 10 years, so this trip was just to see the city again. It's pretty common that these homes are going down to make way for new stuff. We met a family that was still living in that neighborhood, and they invited us into their house to have lunch. I can't imagine that they were thrilled about the demolition, but we didn't have any conversations about it. Everything just changes so fast there. I brought a friend of mine from New York who had never been, and she and I were in the same boat. Going back after 10 years was really like going to the city for the first time.'' As told to Austin Considine

The big attraction in New York this week is the public opening on Friday of the new GREEK AND ROMAN GALLERIES at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. With 30,000 square feet of space and more than 5,000 objects, it rounds out the story of ancient Western Classical culture in imperious style with a sweep through Hellenism and Augustan Rome to the coming of Christianity. Add the fascinations of Etruscan art, and you have a panoramic adventure to look forward to. Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. A day later the opening of ''GEGO, BETWEEN TRANSPARENCY AND THE INVISIBLE'' at the Drawing Center in SoHo takes us from the grand to the antimonumental. This survey of work by the German-born Venezuelan artist Gertrud Goldschmidt (1912-1994), who went by the name of Gego, includes ink drawings on paper and in meshlike weavings of stainless-steel wire. Little known outside Latin America until fairly recently, Gego, with her fragile but tensile linear art, is now recognized as one of the most memorable of the late 20th century. Through July 21, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166, drawingcenter.org. Finally there are two memorable exhibitions outside Manhattan. In Brooklyn a lively group show called ''POSTMILLENNIAL BLACK MADONNA,'' with new works by 23 young artists, is split between two enterprising institutions, the Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Arts in Fort Greene (through May 12, 80 Hanson Place, 718-230-0492, mocada.org) and the Skylight Gallery of the Restoration Plaza in Bedford-Stuyvesant (through May 5, 1368 Fulton Street, third floor, 718-636-6976, restorationplaza.org). I also recommend another ensemble effort, ''A JAMAICA, QUEENS THING,'' in which a bunch of smart young artists look back at the South Queens music scene of two decades ago. It's at the Jamaica Center for Arts & Learning, a classic example of a grass-roots alternative space. Through June 2, 161-04 Jamaica Avenue, (718) 658-7400, jcal.org.

To the Editor: I was a Clinton appointee to the Cultural Property Advisory Committee, that ''obscure'' State Department panel that was the subject of Jeremy Kahn's article ''Is the U.S. Protecting Foreign Artifacts? Don't Ask'' [April 8]. I fully endorse the arguments that the appointed membership of the panel is heavily skewed toward the archaeologists' perspective and that the committee's activities are inappropriately secretive. The public should be made aware of those who have been empowered to direct America's foreign cultural policy -- and hold them accountable.

LET'S start by addressing the obvious. There was no nepotism involved when Karen Lawrence was named the 10th president of Sarah Lawrence College. Despite what she describes as ''the karma and coincidence'' of sharing a name with the school, the match was professional, not personal. Dr. Lawrence, 58, who will assume her post in August, comes to Sarah Lawrence from the University of California, Irvine, where she began serving as dean of humanities in 1998. Even within that large research institute, Dr. Lawrence said, she tried to create the kind of intimacy and dialogue in which liberal arts colleges specialize.

CLAY--Marie M., 81, developmental scientist, distin guished literacy researcher, and founder of Reading Recovery, died Friday, April 13, 2007, in New Zealand. Internationally recognized for outstanding research on early literacy learning and credited with changing the face of primary school literacy instruction. Past president of the International Reading Association. First woman professor and first woman to head an academic department at the University of Auckland. Made a Dame Commander of the British Empire in 1987 and named ''New Zealander of the Year'' in 1994. Honors and awards include five honorary degrees and 2005 establishment of the Marie Clay Endowed Chair at The Ohio State University. Memorial Services April 19 at the University of Auckland.

A review on April 1 about ''Once Upon a Country: A Palestinian Life,'' by Sari Nusseibeh, referred incorrectly to the relationship between the prophet Muhammad and a woman Nusseibeh names as the progenitor of his own family. She was one of 14 tribal leaders who met the prophet on the outskirts of Medina and pledged early allegiance. She did not accompany him on a pilgrimage to Jerusalem. (Muhammad did not make an actual pilgrimage to Jerusalem; Nusseibeh uses the term in reference to the miraculous ''Night Journey.''

The Re:framing column last Sunday, about genetically engineered crops used in medicine, misstated the status of a proposal by Ventria Bioscience to plant its pharmaceutical rice in fields in Kansas. The Agriculture Department is evaluating comments before making a decision; it has not yet approved the permit.

To the Editor: Unfortunately, ''A New Proposal to Rescue Yonkers' Waterfront'' (April 8) did not show the actual building design proposed by the London-based architect Will Alsop. The building is described as ''color-spattered,'' and indeed it would be a lively touch against the bland office towers in London's Docklands complex.

How lasers work: In dermatology-speak, the word ''laser'' is a catchall for devises that use intense beams of focused bright light, those that use intense pulsed light (producing short, quick flashes) and ones that employ radio frequency or electromagnetic energy. To diminish wrinkles, some types of lasers, like Titan and Thermage, send energy deep into the dermis (the lower layers of skin) without damaging the epidermis (the upper layer). That energy creates heat and a slight injury, which sends the body into repair mode, encouraging existing collagen (a building block of skin) to contract and become tighter, and stimulating new collagen and elastin (another building block) to be produced. The result? Smoother, plumper, more youthful-looking skin. Other lasers, like Lyra, Affirm and V-Beam, have specific wavelengths that are attracted only to certain pigments, such as red or brown, and destroy anything within that color range, so they work well on blood vessels, spider veins, sunspots and hair. What a laser procedure is like: Most involve an application of topical anesthesia or a cooling gel, followed by a few passes of the device over the area to be treated. Patients usually experience slight warmth or a mild burning sensation, which dissipates quickly. Aftereffects can be similar to a sunburn -- including some redness, swelling or flaking for up to a few days. How to find the right person to perform the procedure: Since you do not need a license to operate a laser, it's best to look for a board-certified dermatologist (check the American Academy of Dermatology Web site at www.aad.org) who has lasers as a major part of his or her practice. Be sure to do your research: in the wrong hands, you could be burned or scarred. Adds Dennis Gross, M.D., a dermatologist and dermatological surgeon in New York (212-725-4555), ''A word-of-mouth recommendation never hurts.'' How to take care of post-laser skin: Use gentle products, don't scrub and slather on a nonirritating sunscreen -- like one with zinc oxide -- on a daily basis. Cost: It depends on the doctor, the size of the area to be treated and the strength of the laser.
MAIER--Stephanie, 82, lifelong New Yorker, retired from GMAC, died April 11, 2007. Widow of John J. Survived by sister Sophie Romance and many nieces and nephews.

GOLDMAN--Joseph B. (Jay) on April 12, 2007. Former New York State Acting Commissioner of Housing, retired Civil Court Judge and Assistant Corporation Counsel for the City of New York. Survived by loving daughters Amie Frances Goldman and Betsy Goldman Wallshein, adored granddaughter Samantha Wallshein and dear sister Betty Goldman Schlein. Remembered by his former wife Patti Hammer and longtime partner Carole Mitnick. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has appointed a new state ethics czar, John D. Feerick, a professor and the former longtime dean of the Fordham University School of Law. Mr. Feerick will immediately take over as chairman of the state Ethics Commission, and then as chairman of the new state Commission on Public Integrity when it comes into being in September.

Pedro Reinhard has rejected Dow Chemical's claim that he took part in unauthorized talks to sell the company, an alleged offense that prompted Dow last week to dismiss him as a senior adviser and to fire Romeo Kreinberg, an executive vice president. In a statement distributed Monday, Mr. Reinhard said "I categorically deny that I have been part of any secret effort to take over or acquire Dow Chemical" (an assertion that a stickler might say does not rule out the possibility that he was involved in non-secret efforts to sell the company).

As private equity firms consider an ever-widening array of industries for megabuyouts, an analyst at Bear Stearns suggests they might want to go shopping in a somewhat more conventional place: the retail sector. Christopher Horvers ticked off a list of reasons for buyout funds to look at "hardline" retailers, a category that includes appliance, furniture and electronics chains, and he names a few promising candidates such as Bed Bath & Beyond and Circuit City. The analyst said that many of these companies have qualities that would endear them to private equity buyers, including mature businesses, predictable cash flows, relatively little "merchandising risk" (as compared to apparel retailers, who face fickle fashion trends) and strong balance sheets.

Should you care if the companies you invest in have a dark side, if they make money in ways that might end conversations at cocktail parties or operate in the same slop bucket as the seamy underworld you'd rather not have your name associated with?
The Mets were rained out again, this time in Philadelphia. The game has been rescheduled as part of a day-night doubleheader on Friday, June 29.

Monday's news that Sallie Mae has accepted a $25 billion buyout lifted the stocks of other student lenders, in some cases by double-digit percentages. Sallie Mae's own stock jumped more than 17 percent to $54.99 by Monday afternoon. But shares of one company in the student-loan business moved firmly in the other direction.

When Jay Sidhu resigned as chief executive of Sovereign Bancorp last October amid pressure from investors over his deal-making, the Philadelphia-based bank said he was leaving for "family health reasons." Later, though, Sovereign disclosed in regulatory filings that Mr. Sidhu had faced "threatened termination by the company without cause."

Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli released his tax returns today, and they looked humble in comparison to the tax information disclosed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Attorney General Andrew Cuomo on Friday. On the other hand, it might be reassuring to some that there's a middle class voice in the top echelons of state government.

Monkey Island, a five-acre island with a 26-bedroom hotel in the middle of the Thames river, is for sale at 7.5 million pounds, or $15 million, Bloomberg News reports. The island, reachable only by walkway, boat or helicopter, is 30 miles west of London near the village of Bray. It has been owned since 1999 by the Al Habtoor Group from Dubai, which has owned and operated hotels in the Middle East for 25 years. The hotel was built as a fishing lodge about 280 years ago and has a Grade 1 heritage listing, which carries the greatest level of restrictions for owners wishing to renovate sites deemed to be historically significant. The hotel has been used as an inn since 1840 and includes a 90-seat restaurant.
