Which "W" should concern us the most? Weather or weapons? Mike Townsley of Greenpeace International suggests that question ahead of the first-ever debate on climate change at the UN Security Council on Tuesday. "Time is of the essence," Townsely wrote in a discussion paper he forwarded to me over the weekend. "The Council must live up to its mandate and address the threat of Weather of Mass Destruction with the same vigor as it is currently pursuing Weapons of Mass Destruction," he said in the paper, to be posted on the Greenpeace website on Tuesday. Townsley's point is that climate change will lead to increased geopolitical tension and conflict because of shifts in where food can grow and water can be accessed, and because of mass migrations from rising temperatures and sea levels. The looming challenges could mean a radical change in how nations cooperate and distribute aid money around the world. That's something the Security Council could help to address. But, as Townsley points out, the United Nations plans no resolution and ultimately the job of finding enough money to help curb climate change and adapt to its effects will fall to nation states. Instead of more talk, Townsely wants governments to walk the walk by starting to channel massive chunks of their military budgets -- including money to replace aging nuclear weapons -- into renewable energy projects and efficiency to slash global emissions dramatically by mid-century. Is Townsley right? Do we live in a world where turning swords into ploughshares -- or into biomass for making clean electricity -- is the highest priority? Or is Townsley being naÃ¯ve in a world still beset by terrorism and the threat of nuclear strikes from rogue states?

I do not hold the moldy piece of toast against London. It was served to me just after the long Easter weekend (and in Britain, the celebration lasts four days). The swank little North London cafe we were at for breakfast had perhaps found bread deliveries lacking during the break. And even though the bacon and tomato omelets were fine alternatives to the baked beans and bad bangers we had come across, apparently no one in the kitchen bothered to check the toast.

We left Beaufort feeling giddy, as if we had drunk a lot of Champagne (even though we had had nothing stronger than sweet tea and lemonade). We were ebullient because we had found our architect and we were on our way.

Siemens' board of management is examining letters of intent from buyout firms interested in buying the German conglomerate's automotive engineering unit, valued at up to 9 billion euros ($12 billion). Siemens shares traded up 2.1 percent at 87.44 euros by Monday morning, after the Financial Times Deutschland earlier reported Siemens could get a price of more than 10 billion euros.

Citigroup said Monday that first-quarter net income fell 11 percent, hurt by a charge related to its plans to eliminate 17,000 jobs and slash costs. But profit excluding special items topped analysts' forecasts, helped by surging trading gains, including 20 percent revenue gains from fixed-income capital markets and 26 percent from equity markets.

A large group of floor traders at the New York Board of Trade are furious with their new owners at the IntercontinentalExchange and are about to launch a publicity campaign meant to derail the exchange's offer for the Chicago Board of Trade, The New York Post reported Monday. The group, which includes nearly all traders on the N.Y.B.O.T. floor, is upset over a move by ICE to lift a fee on electronic trading of coffee, sugar, cocoa and other commodities that has helped to preserve floor trading.

As private equity has tackled sectors it once shied away from -- the offers for TXU and Sallie Mae testify to that -- the industry may now be setting its sights on mining companies. TheStreet.com points to Apollo Management's $1.15 billion plan earlier this month to acquire Xstrata's aluminum business as proof and says there may be more to come.

Portfolio, the new business magazine from Condé Nast, wants to bring some glamour to world of business magazines. The New York Times notes that in its debut issue readers will find business executives treated like celebrities and the kind of matching of writer and subject they might find in Vanity Fair: Tom Wolfe on hedge funds (with photographs by Annie Leibovitz); Betsey Morris on the Ford family; and Michael Lewis on "jock exchanges," which trade in athletes.

Quest Diagnostics, the biggest U.S. provider of medical tests, will buy AmeriPath in a deal worth about $2 billion to increase the ability to screen for cancer. The transaction includes the assumption of about $770 million in debt, the companies said Monday in a statement. AmeriPath, based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., is owned by Welsh, Carson, Anderson and Stowe, a venture capital firm. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter.

Several large private equity firms submitted first-round bids for Home Depot's HD Supply unit, but Home Depot may not be all that interested in selling the unit, according to The Deal.com. When the company said in February that it was considering strategic alternatives, HD Supply was seen as a distraction to Home Depot's core business. But with the housing market slowing dramatically in recent months, analysts now say the unit, which is less reliant on the residential housing market, could help the retailer weather the housing storm.

Is Microsoft's objection to Google's $3.1 billion deal for online advertising company DoubleClick just a case of sour grapes? Microsoft and AT&T, both veteran defendants of epic antitrust battles in the United States and Europe, is urging regulators to consider scuttling Google's plan to buy DoubleClick.

Citigroup's announcement Friday that it will buy hedge fund Old Lane Partners and bring its founder, former top Morgan Stanley banker Vikram S.Pandit, on board, unleashed a a wave of sport metaphors. The New York Times notes that Citigroup is paying a steep price -- estimated at between $600 million and $800 million to win Mr. Pandit to its alternative investments division.

A consortium led by investment bank Babcock & Brown said on Monday some shareholders in takeover target Alinta Ltd. would be able to choose an all-cash option under enhanced terms for its A$7.4 billion ($6.2 billion) offer. Babcock's cash and stock bid last month for Alinta, Australia's largest energy infrastructure group, beat a higher offer from a Macquarie Bank consortium which was rejected by Alinta's board.

The term "merger mania" may be more than a snappy description of the recent pace of corporate deal-making. It could be an astute diagnosis of a malady spreading through boardrooms and financial markets, Conrad de Aenlle writes in The New York Times.

Sallie Mae agreed late last night to be sold to J.P. Morgan Chase, Bank of America and two private equity firms for $25 billion. The deal, announced early Monday, would move the nation's largest education lender, officially known as the SLM Corporation, into private control amid increasing turmoil for the company.

Despite high office rents, New York City is emerging as the new home of the mega-rich hedge fund trader - stealing a bit of the thunder from Greenwich, Conn., The New York Post reports. Pointing to Trader Monthly's recent hedge-fund rankings review, the paper says that five of last year's 11 highest-earning hedge fund traders call the Big Apple home. Among the big names in the list are Cerberus Capital Management, D.E. Shaw and Atticus Capital.
Congressional Democrats will try this week to find some agreement among themselves on the Iraq spending bill as they press their disagreement with President Bush.

Despite continuing fallout from subprime loans and clouds over the U.S. economy, three banking giants are expected to report relatively strong first-quarter earnings this week, according to MarketWatch. On tap are J.P. Morgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup, which ast week unveiled a restructuring plan that would eliminate about 17,000 jobs worldwide and save the company an estimated $1.7 billion this year.

Lehman Brothers was sued by an shareholder who said the investment bank manipulated stock option grants from 1998 to 2001 to secure a "huge financial windfall" for Richard Fuld, its chief executive, and other top officials.

A federal judge has dismissed most of a shareholder complaint against CNet Networks in a decision that shows how difficult it may be for plaintiffs to succeed in numerous similar claims related to stock-option backdating, according to The Recorder.

China CITIC Bank, which is raising up to $5.4 billion in what is expected to be the world's biggest initial public offering so far this year, is getting a very warm reception from institutional investors. The overseas institutional tranche of the bank's I.P.O. has been more than 30 times covered before opening to retail investors Monday, Reuters reported.

Charles B. Wang, the founder and former chairman of Computer Associates, oversaw a decade-long accounting fraud at the software company, according to a report released Friday by the company's directors. Mr. Wang, who owns the New York Islanders and is among the most politically influential people on Long Island, masterminded accounting gimmicks that inflated his company's sales and profits for years, the report says. In 25 years running Computer Associates, Mr. Wang built a fortune of about $1 billion, including a bonus in 1998 of $670 million.

Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire activist investor, continued his campaign to gain a seat on Motorola's board, this time making his pitch directly to the cellphone maker's shareholders. In a letter to shareholders filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission Friday, Mr. Icahn said that the company' financial woes "reflect not only operational failures, but are also symptoms of a passive and reactive board."

A consortium of three banks that is threatening to gate-crash merger talks between Barclays and ABN Amro are considering an offer that would reportedly lead to the break-up of the Dutch bank's assets. The three bidders, the Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander Central Hispano and Fortis, which on Friday said that they have asked ABN Amro to enagage in exploratory talks, are proposing to carve up ABN Amro and give its shareholders a package of shares in each of their institutions, The Guardian reported.

More than 150 firefighters battled a five-alarm blaze at a lumber yard for nearly four hours last night before bringing it under control, officials said. Several buildings near the General Lumber Company, at Clinton Avenue and Second Street, were evacuated as a precaution, Mayor David Roberts of Hoboken said. The fire started about 5 p.m., and three firefighters suffered minor injuries, Mr. Roberts said. More than three dozen people were evacuated from their homes and taken to a municipal center. The Red Cross was assisting. Residents would probably be able to return home by this afternoon, Mr. Roberts said. The Fire Department asked Public Service Electric and Gas to shut off power in a four-block area around the scene, affecting 1,400 customers, according to a utility spokeswoman. The cause of the fire is still under investigation. “It’s been a very bad day here, between the flooding and this fire,” Mr. Roberts said. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey is still sedated, but his loved ones say they are encouraged.

A special master appointed by the United States Supreme Court ruled on Friday that Delaware has jurisdiction over the Delaware River and can regulate developments extending from the New Jersey shoreline. The master made the ruling regarding Delaware’s decision to deny a permit for the construction of a 2,000-foot pier to service a planned gas terminal on the New Jersey side of the river just north of Wilmington. New Jersey officials said they were reviewing the decision and would most likely appeal to the Supreme Court. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A permanent superintendent has been appointed at the Roslyn school district on Long Island, nearly three years after the former superintendent resigned amid a multimillion-dollar embezzlement scandal. The new superintendent, John Richman, currently the school superintendent in nearby Plainedge, will take over in Roslyn on July 1, Newsday reported on Saturday. Mr. Richman said he hoped to help the district move past the scandal, in which state auditors found that $11 million was embezzled between 1996 and 2004. Six people pleaded guilty in the scandal, including former school officials. Since 2004, the district has been led by interim superintendents.

The driver of a 2004 Acura was killed early yesterday after he lost control of his car, which went over a guardrail on the Bronx River Parkway and fell onto a parked truck, the police said. The police and the driver’s uncle identified the man as Rabindranath Ramjanack, 22, of Mount Vernon. A passenger, whose name was not released, crawled from the car and was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where he was in serious condition last evening, the police said. The police said that the roads were wet, but that they were unclear as to what caused the driver to lose control. The accident occurred about 1 a.m. on the parkway near East 233rd Street. The Acura went over a guardrail on the right shoulder, landing on a Metro-North truck, then rolling off to the ground.

A man was charged with vehicular manslaughter after a crash on the Henry Hudson Parkway that killed a woman early yesterday, the police said. The man, Joseph W. Harris, 29, of Harlem, was also charged with driving while intoxicated. He was treated for minor injuries at St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center and then taken into custody. The woman, Gretchen Patterson, 48, of Brooklyn, was pronounced dead at St. Luke’s, according to the police. The police said that Mr. Harris was speeding south on the parkway about 12:30 a.m. when he slammed into Ms. Patterson’s car near 74th Street, sending her vehicle into two other cars and over a wall. Ms. Patterson’s car landed 26 feet below, in Riverside Park. The drivers of the other two vehicles, men ages 19 and 24, were treated for minor injuries. Mr. Harris’s vehicle came to a halt upside down on the parkway. Mr. Harris refused a Breathalyzer test before his arrest, the police said. Two passengers, men ages 22 and 23, in Mr. Harris’s vehicle suffered minor injuries, the police said.

The police yesterday reviewed images caught on security cameras in an effort to find a robber who followed a family to their downtown hotel and stole jewelry and other possessions valued at thousands of dollars. The robbery occurred Friday night as the family, an 8-year-old girl and her parents visiting from Atlanta, returned to the Millenium Hilton Hotel on Church Street. The police said the group was joined in the elevator by the robber, who rode with them to the 40th floor. As they got off the elevator, he drew a silver pistol and forced his way into their room, where he handcuffed the adults and bound the girl with duct tape before stealing cash, an emerald ring, two laptops and other items. The girl freed herself a half-hour later and alerted security officers. The police did not identify the family.

Courtesy of Aaron Heilman, the first song that blared over the clubhouse speakers yesterday morning was ''The Long and Winding Road'' by the Beatles. If that selection was a tongue-in-cheek reminder of how early in the season it was, then the next Beatles number -- ''Come Together'' -- could have been a message of its own. Like many teams around the league, the Mets have been searching for an identity through the first 11 games. Since romping to four consecutive victories to begin the season, outscoring the Cardinals and the Braves, 31-3, the Mets are 3-4 and a game behind first-place Atlanta in the National League East.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about a report from the board of the computer company CA contending that its founder, Charles B. Wang, masterminded an accounting fraud rendered a word incorrectly in Mr. Wang's response. In a statement, he called the report ''fallacious'' -- not ''fictitious.''

As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton seeks to reassemble the Democratic money machine her husband built, some of its major fund-raisers have already signed on with Senator Barack Obama. Among the biggest fund-raisers for Mr. Obama's campaign are as many as a half-dozen former guests of the Clinton White House. At least two are close enough to the Clintons to have slept in the Lincoln bedroom.

RINEHART--George Henry Doran, of Annapolis, Maryland, died Tuesday, April 10, at age 78. He is survived by his beloved wife, Anne, whom he wed in 1985; his sisters, Mary R. Huvelle and Lady Benedicta Knox; his brother, Stanley M. Rinehart III; his daughter, Deborah Rinehart Fowler; his sons, Frederick R. Rinehart II and Stephen G. Rinehart; 25 grandchildren and 12 greatgrandchildren. He is also survived by his first wife, Sharon Caulfield. George was the grandson of Mary Roberts Rinehart, the mystery writer and correspondent; and son of Stanley Marshall Rinehart, Jr., founder of Holt, Rinehart & Winston. George attended Phillips Exeter Academy and Harvard College. He worked in the publishing and editing field throughout his life and was a certified Drug and Alcohol Abuse Counselor. A memorial service will be held in Annapolis, Maryland, on a date to be announced. Donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, 1-888392-0392 or www. doctorswithoutborders.com.

The clock in the visitors' clubhouse here read 4:42 p.m. when Jorge Posada answered his final question before boarding a bus to the airport on Sunday. The time was appropriate, because four Yankees had worn No. 42 -- including, of course, the great Mariano Rivera. But Rivera was not so great this time. He had just allowed a game-ending home run to the Oakland Athletics' Marco Scutaro, a sudden sucker punch of an ending to Jackie Robinson Day. Posada, who had called for a cutter that cut too much, was not yet ready to give a scouting report on Tuesday's emergency starter, the Class AA left-hander Chase Wright.

Chalk it up to spring fever. In recent weeks, the Capitol hallways have echoed with unlikely chatter about who might succeed Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, right, though Mr. Silver has shown no interest in voluntary retirement and little vulnerability to the forced kind. (He put down a coup once before, in 2000, led by Michael J. Bragman, now a former assemblyman.) Some published reports have Richard L. Brodsky, an outspoken and ambitious Westchester assemblyman who made a bid for the state comptroller's job this year, angling for Mr. Silver's post. Mr. Brodsky called the reports ''silliness of the highest order.''

BLUM--Claire. The UJA, Jersey City mourns the passing of Claire Blum. Claire was chairman of UJA of Jersey City over 20 years. Chair of the UJA, Jersey City's Russian Resettlement Board, she managed settlement of over 1000 Soviet, Iranian, Syrian, and Iraqi Jews in New Jersey: Member of governing board of Jewish Family and Counseling Service of Jersey City, and past President of Sisterhood of Temple Beth El. We extend deepest sympathies to her husband Melvin Blum, her children Dr. Jay and Sharon Blum, Dr. Jerald and Rochelle Blum, her grandchildren Drs. Yossef and Deena Blanchard Blum, Zvia, Ariana, Jordana, Samantha, Jamie and Brooke, and greatgrandson Nathan, sister Lorraine Weinstein and brother Leonard Crystal. Her devotion and compassion was unsurpassed. We will miss her forever. Hy Nutkis, Co-Chairman UJA of Jersey City $(6$)BLUM--Claire, (nee Crystal). We celebrate her beautiful life. The Weinstein Family: Sister Lorraine, Sy, Cliff, Ann, Andy, Julia, Jake, Chris and Daniel.
CHRYSTAL--Dorothy. Dotty, you are always in my heart. Tell Kurt Vonnegut hello. Love, Margot

LEFRAK--Samuel Jayson. Feb.12, 1918 to April 16, 2003. The vision to see. The faith to believe. The courage to do. You are forever in our hearts. Missing you and loving you more each day. Love, Denise and family

SCHILLER--Leona (nee Liebergall) on April 13, 2007 of Monroe, NJ formerly of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Louis R., cherished daughter of the late Sophie and Joseph Liebergall, devoted mother of Harlan M. and Barry S. Schiller, dear sister of the late Melvin and Harvey Libergall, loving grandmother of Louis, Jenifer, Joy, Lawrence, Matthew, Michael, Claudia, and Paul, great-grandmother of Kelly, Kaitlyn, Bryan, and Elijah. Service Wednesday, 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, 180 Piermont Road, Closter, NJ. For information, Gutterman Musicant, 800-522-0588.

MORE MIDDLE-CLASS AUDITS -- Since 2000, authorities at the Internal Revenue Service have nearly tripled audits of tax returns filed by people making $25,000 to $100,000 as part of a broad change in audit strategy. [Page C1.] SALLIE MAE UNDER SIEGE -- Sallie Mae, the nation's largest provider of student loans, is under siege on several fronts, political and financial. Its stock is sagging and at least two private equity buyers are in talks to acquire the company. [C1.] TAKING A MAGAZINE RISK -- Skepticism abounded when Condé Nast announced in September 2005 that it was starting a business magazine, Portfolio, at a time when many others were foundering. S. I. Newhouse, Condé Nast's chairman, said that Portfolio could be the company's last big investment in a new print publication, but as for any doubts, he said: ''Damn the torpedoes and full speed ahead.'' [C1.] HEALTH ON THE WEB -- Stephen M. Case, the America Online founder who oversaw an ill-fated merger with Time Warner before he left in 2003, says the time is ripe for a dominant health care brand -- one that could be as powerful as Starbucks in latte or Nike in fitness. [C1.] EASY E-MAIL BY PHONE -- Nicholas Fodor, a French computer programmer, will soon introduce Freedom Mail, a simple free service that he says will make it possible to view and respond by cellphone to messages sent to almost any e-mail account. [C9.] GOOGLE MAKES A RADIO DEAL Google will begin selling advertisements across all of the stations of Clear Channel Communications, the No. 1 radio station owner in the United States, at the end of June, the companies will announce today. [C4.] CBS'S STRUGGLE AGAINST IPOD -- Even with Don Imus off the air, profound problems face Dan Mason, CBS Radio's new chief executive. In an industry suffering from sluggish advertising sales, CBS and other broadcasters have been laboring to cling to listeners who are spending more time with their mobile phones, Internet radio and portable music players. [C6.] TED FOR THE MASSES -- With $6,000 and some high-level connections, you could attend an invitation-only TED conference (TED stands for Technology, Entertainment and Design) in Monterey, Calif. Alternatively, you could pay nothing and visit a new Web site that offers about 100 of its TED Talks. [C8.] AL JAZEERA ON YOUTUBE -- Starting today, YouTube will carry content from Al Jazeera English, the English-language version of the Qatar-based television news station, with guests like Yusuf Islam, above, formerly known as Cat Stevens. [C5.] SHOPPING BY TEXT MESSAGE -- A company called ShopText has introduced a system that lets people buy products instantly, using text messages, thus eliminating the need to go to a store or even visit a Web site. [C6.] CASUALTY COUNTS ONLINE -- The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan are the first with significant United States military casualties to take place in the Internet age. And while there have been debates over how much public attention to give members of the military who have been killed in combat, a string of Web sites has plunged ahead. [C4.] TECH ADVANCE AT INTEL -- At its Intel Developer Forum in Bejing this week -- the first to be held in China -- Intel is planning to announce several technology advances, including one that could lead to a new class of wireless hand-held computer. [C4.]

What's on the reading list of the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno? ''Spoiling for a Fight,'' the 2006 biography of Governor Spitzer written by Brooke A. Masters, now a reporter at The Financial Times.

LEINER--Lydia Bohmer, age 97, of Rego Park, NY, died April 11, 2007. She lived a remarkable life. She grew up in Vienna, Austria, and came to New York in 1939, saving her husband and mother, Fanny Fuerth, from the Nazis. Her beloved first husband, Willy Bohmer died in 1977. Lydia was a wonderful mother to her sons, Peter and Roger Bohmer, of Olympia, WA. In 1978 she married her loving husband, Irving Leiner. Also surviving are her dear grandchildren, Josina, Inti, Filemon and Antonio Bohmer-Tapia and many close friends. Lydia Bohmer Leiner touched everyone she met by her interest in them, her smile and wisdom. Funeral service will be Monday, April 16, 1pm, at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd.

TILLMAN--Harry, age 93, of Fort Lee, NJ and Aventura, FL. Distinguished Army Vet of WWII, Owner and Manager of Heritage L & M, NYC, A Founder of the New Synagogue of Fort Lee. Husband of Sylvia nee: Grossman and the late Sylvia nee: Resnikoff. Father of Loretta (Richard) Zenna, Alyce (William) Kravitz, Sylvia's children Susan (John) Orlove, and Stanley Terman. Brother of Hilda Rutkay. Grandfather of six. Religious Service Wednesday 10:30 AM at the New Synagogue of Fort Lee, corner of Whiteman and Center Ave. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Services by Eden (888) 700EDEN

RUSSELL--William T. In loving memory of a remarkable man whose integrity, keen intellect, dry wit, and unfailing kindness and grace continue to inspire us daily. March 24, 1915 -April 15, 1977. Mildred, Catherine, Margaret, and William T. Jr

A report in the Metropolitan Diary last Monday referred incorrectly to the location in Brooklyn where two street people were seen holding a sign that said ''Let's Do Lunch! You Buy!!!'' It was on Atlantic Avenue near Third Avenue, not Third Street. (Atlantic and Third Street do not intersect.)

La-Z-Boy, Monroe, Mich., chose RPA, Santa Monica, Calif., to handle its account, which had been at Doner, Southfield, Mich., since 1994. Spending was estimated at $35 million. Frito-Lay, Plano, Tex., part of PepsiCo, shifted the creative duties for Fritos and Tostitos snack chips to Element 79, Chicago, part of the Omnicom Group, from another Omnicom agency, GSD&M, Austin, Tex. Spending was estimated at $35 million. Element 79 creates campaigns for other PepsiCo brands like Gatorade.

Former Assemblyman Ryan S. Karben left the capital under a cloud last year, but he continues to serve as a fund-raiser for Governor Spitzer, above right. Mr. Karben, 32, was at a breakfast last week at which the governor discussed, among other things, his new federal political action committee, which he plans to use to support Congressional candidates.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Iraqi Town Becomes Haven For Seasoned Insurgents The Sunni guerrillas and extremists who now dominate Baquba, Iraq, demonstrate a sophistication and lethality born of years of confronting American military tactics. While the increase of American troops plays out in Baghdad, Baquba has emerged as a magnet for insurgents from around the country. A1 At least 34 people were killed in Baghdad in another day punctuated by car bombings and suicide vest attacks on civilian targets of the kind that the two-month-old American security crackdown has so far been unable to restrain. A8 Russia Lifts Bear Hunting Ban For the first time in more than five decades, the Russian government is preparing to allow hunters to kill polar bears, which are descending with greater regularity on coastal villages in parts of the far north as a result of shrinking sea ice generally attributed to a warming planet. A1 Wolfowitz Says He Won't Quit Senior policy makers at the World Bank delivered a public rebuke in a communiqué to the bank's president, Paul D. Wolfowitz, making it clear they expected him to resign. After learning of the rebuke, Mr. Wolfowitz adamantly made it known at a news conference that he intended to stay on the job. A1 U.S. Closes Morocco Consulate The United States Consulate in Morocco said it would close until further notice, a day after two brothers carried out puzzling suicide attacks near the consulate amid a spate of bombings in Morocco and Algeria. A10 Iran Seeks Bids on Atom Plants The deputy head of the nation's Atomic Energy Organization was quoted by the ISNA news agency as saying the country was seeking international bids for building two more nuclear power plants despite international pressure over its nuclear program. A3 Protests on Nigerian Elections Violent protests broke out in several of Nigeria's 36 states as partial results from contested state elections seemed to hand most of the victories to the governing People's Democratic Party. A3 NATIONAL A12-15 Donors Linked to Clintons Shift Support to Obama Aides to Senator Barack Obama released a list of top fund-raisers that showed how deep his presidential primary campaign has cut into the Democratic party establishment once presumed to back his rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. A15 Gonzales Has 'Nothing to Hide' Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales offered a measured apology for his mistakes in the dismissal of eight United States attorneys, but said in testimony prepared for a Senate hearing tomorrow that he had ''nothing to hide'' and insisted that none of the prosecutors were removed to influence the outcome of a case. A1 Georgia Prosecutor Unyielding When North Carolina's attorney general said an overreaching prosecutor lacked evidence to support charges of rape against three Duke University lacrosse players, some in Georgia hoped his pronouncement would help free a former star high school football player serving 10 years without parole for having consensual oral sex with a 15-year-old girl, even though he was 17 at the time. A12 Lobster Season in Distress Although spring is traditionally when lobster prices are highest, lobsters have rarely been as scarce or expensive as they have been in the last few weeks, thanks to a confluence of bad weather, extremely cold water and a lack of reserve supply. A14 Festival Honors Rural Legacy The celebration of Mule Day in Columbus, Tenn., marks the arrival of spring, but the event also acts as a window into the area's rural heritage and an homage to the humble beasts that turned the soil, gave a leg up to farmers, and cemented the county's reputation in the South for well-bred mules. A12 EDUCATION Student Loan Company Settles Education Finance Partners, a student loan company that investigators found had paid more than 60 colleges and universities across the country for steering students to its loans, has agreed to pay $2.5 million to resolve an investigation of its practices by the New York attorney general. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Increase in Tax Returns From Illegal Immigrants With the tax deadline approaching, illegal immigrants are sending in federal returns in what appear to be record numbers in hopes that filing a return will create a paper trail that could one day lead to citizenship. A1 Storm Sets Rainfall Records A rare spring northeaster roared up the coast and across the New York region and the Northeast, dumping record-setting rainfall that flooded coasts and rivers, disrupted airline travel at the three major airports, and cut power lines for thousands in New York and Connecticut. B1 Church Abuse Case to Trial While only a small fraction of sexual abuse complaints involving the Catholic Church have resulted in litigation or prosecutions, a trial involving a former youth minister is taking place in Nassau County, with jury selection giving a hint of what could come. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 More Middle-Class Audits Since 2000, authorities at the Internal Revenue Service have nearly tripled audits of tax returns filed by people making $25,000 to $100,000 as part of a broad change in audit strategy. C1 Deal for Sallie Mae Sallie Mae, the nation's largest provider of student loans, agreed to be sold to JP Morgan Chase and Bank of America and two private equity firms for $25 billion, people involved in the negotiations said. The deal would move the lender, which is facing increasing turmoil, into private control. A1 Google Makes Radio Deal Google has a deal to begin selling advertisements across all of the stations of Clear Channel Communications, the No. 1 radio station owner in the United States. C4 New Health Web Site Stephen M. Case, the America Online founder who oversaw an ill-fated merger with Time Warner before he left, has invested heavily in a new Web site on health issues, RevolutionHealth.com. C1 Business Digest C2 SPORTSMONDAY D1-8 The Rain and the Marathon More rain is expected for the Boston Marathon today, and winds could be 15 to 20 miles per hour. About 23,000 runners are expected to compete in the 111th edition of the sport's most historic race, which has never been postponed or canceled because of weather. D1 OBITUARIES B6 Pat Buckley A leading player in Manhattan's social circuit for decades and the wife of William F. Buckley Jr., the author, columnist and editor, she was 80. B6 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Cleaning up the alternative tax; China's signals on warming; time for Mr. Wolfowitz to go; Adam Cohen on a U.S. attorney who kept his job. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E6 Crossword E6 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E9 Weather A17

An article in some copies on Friday about an appearance by Richard P. Mills, the New York State education commissioner, at a community forum in Roosevelt to discuss the school district's finances misstated the frequency of his visits there. The visit on Thursday night was his sixth -- not his first -- since the state took control of the district in 2002.

GIESSER--Evelyn, 86, died on April 12th. Beloved wife and cherished mother and grandmother, she was devoted to her family. The respect for learning which she imparted to her children made possible their professional careers. She will be remembered for her strength of character, gracious spirit, and unfailing generosity even in times when she herself had little. She will be greatly missed by her friends and family.

PETO--Hanna, beloved wife of the late Dr. Andrew Peto, cherished mother of Agnes Jacobs, loved and adoring grandmother of Julie Menin and great-grandmother of Max, Mason and Lucas Menin. Also survived by devoted son-in-law, Dr. Robert Jacobs and grandson-in-law Bruce Menin. Hanna touched the lives of all who knew her. She was the epitome of strength and courage and will be deeply missed by her family and friends. Contributions to The Central Park Conservancy.

The WPP Group, London, will announce today the acquisition of an unspecified minority stake in VideoEgg, San Francisco, which operates an advertising network for social networking Web sites. Financial terms were not disclosed. The investment is the latest for WPP in companies outside traditional advertising. Other VideoEgg investors include venture capital firms like Maveron.

HIRSH--Barbara Vigdor. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Devoted mother of Steven and Alan. Devoted mother-inlaw of Alice. Sister of the late Burt. Loving grandmother to Jonathon, Becki, Jamie, Adam, Samantha, Bret, and Craig. Her love and caring will be missed. Her strength and grace will always be remembered.

When would you lead the king from king-doubleton in an unbid side suit against a trump contract? The White House Teams ran in Amsterdam Feb. 23 to 25. The junior team tournament took place March 19 to 23, with the victory going to Norway, represented by Ivar Berg, Erik Eide, Tor Ove Reistad and Fredrik Simonsen. Second was the Poland Under-20 team: Karol Galazka, Bartek Igla, Piotr Kruszewski and Artur Machno.

Even when the stakes were at their highest this season, and nothing was guaranteed, the Nets often had a difficult time kindling their inner fire. Now, with a postseason pass in hand, there was a question of how seriously the Nets would approach the one thing left to be had: the sixth seed in the Eastern Conference. Against the Indiana Pacers on Sunday, the Nets displayed the type of endgame execution that would serve them well in the playoffs. The Nets' 111-107 victory at Conseco Fieldhouse moved them to a game behind the Washington Wizards for the sixth seed. The Nets (39-41) play the Knicks on Monday night and finish the regular season Wednesday at home against the Chicago Bulls.

THALER--Carole, died on April 13, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Devoted and loving mother of Jacqueline, Michael and Gabrielle. Cherished daughter of Eleanore Rosen and sister of Stanley, Betsi and Larry, and sister-in-law of Nancy. Dearest aunt of Jeffrey, Matthew, Jaime, David and Alek and great-aunt of Peyton. Carole was a vibrant loving soul with a sense of style whose love of her children, family and music will endure forever. Services Monday 1pm at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

A memorial service for the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. will be held at 10:30 a.m. on April 23 in the Great Hall at Cooper Union, at Seventh Street and Third Avenue in Manhattan. The service is open to the public. Mr. Schlesinger, who wrote more than 20 books and won two Pulitzer Prizes, died on Feb. 28. Among those scheduled to speak are former President Bill Clinton; Senator Edward M. Kennedy; the author Norman Mailer; former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger; the author Theodore C. Sorensen, who, like Mr. Schlesinger, was an aide to President John F. Kennedy; the British historian Lord Hugh Thomas; William J. vanden Heuvel, a former American ambassador to the United Nations; and the historian Sean Wilentz.

People aiming to sell ''Prom Queen,'' the latest strange bird in the online-video aviary, invariably refer to the Web series as ''Michael Eisner's 'Prom Queen.' '' You can see why. The name of Mr. Eisner, the august former Disney chief, ought to confer legitimacy on the video project, which might otherwise seem unmoored and fly-by-night. And when Mr. Eisner stumps for ''Prom Queen,'' rhapsodizing about this high-school murder mystery as if it were ''The 400 Blows,'' he emphasizes that, even as he lights out into new media, his studio-honcho values are intact. ''Content is king,'' he likes to say.

Joy Lin joined R/GA, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as media director, a new post as the interactive agency adds media buying to its media planning services. Ms. Lin will manage the day-to-day online planning and buying, reporting to Ken O'Donnell, group media director. Ms. Lin had been media director of the New York office of Agency.com, part of the Omnicom Group. Brandon Berger joined the New York office of MDC Partners as director for digital innovation, a new post. He had held a similar post at Ogilvy North America, New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of the WPP Group.

Dear grandfather of Kim Trupp, Peter Kelly, Susan Smith, Anthony Kelly, Kate Spina, Alexander Spina, Daniel Hyman and Gail Hyman. Greatgrandfather of five. Brother of E. Daniel Spina and the late Rose Foley. Heartfelt thanks to his devoted caregivers, especially Christine Graham. Reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons, West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy. (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy.). Celebration of The Liturgy of Christian Burial, Thursday, 10:00 AM, at St. Patrick's RC Church, Bay Shore, LI. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery, Bay Shore, LI. Visiting Wednesday, 2-4:30 and 79:30 PM.
To the Editor: Re ''Films From the Weinsteins Falter, but the Brothers Stay Focused'' (Business Day, April 12):

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 5.07 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.95 percent.
To the Editor: Re ''Darfur Collides With Olympics, and China Yields'' (Diplomatic Memo, front page, April 13):

Imagine the boxing gloves Muhammad Ali wore when he knocked out Sonny Liston just steps away from a first edition of Phillis Wheatley's 1773 book of poetry, the first published by an African-American, around the corner from the cell door behind which the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. wrote ''Letter from a Birmingham Jail.'' That is the dream of an elite group of scholars and artists, including the novelist Toni Morrison and the Harvard scholar Henry Louis Gates Jr., who have been enlisted to help shape an ambitious traveling exhibition to showcase the black influence on life in this country.

GOLUB--Maurice P. Beloved father of Robert and Richard, father-in-law to Grace and Joan, loving grandfather to Rebecca, Brian, Grant, and Kaitie, passed on April 10, 2007. The nicest man on earth, he will be greatly missed.

In the volatile world of presidential election campaigns and half-day news cycles, the ups and downs of traffic to candidates' Web sites can be particularly volatile. From January to February, Barack Obama overtook Hillary Clinton for the lead in Web visitors, as they had their first big skirmish over remarks by David Geffen, a supporter of Mr. Obama's. Joe Biden had to answer for his own remarks about Mr. Obama, and John McCain pre-announced his candidacy on David Letterman's show. SHELLY FREIERMAN

A picture credit with an article on Thursday, about a visit to North Korea by Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico to retrieve the remains of six Americans killed in the Korean War, misstated the photographer's surname. The Associated Press picture, showing Governor Richardson and other officials with cases containing the remains, was by Foster Klug, not King.

Bob French ''Marsalis Music Honors Series'' (Marsalis Music) Bob French is the drummer and director for the Original Tuxedo Jazz Band of New Orleans, a dynastic institution dating back to 1910 that is known as one of the oldest jazz band in the world. But this isn't a Tuxedo band record. Produced by Branford Marsalis, it uses a few Tuxedo members who are mostly known in New Orleans -- the trumpeter Leon Brown, the bassist Chris Severin -- with Mr. Marsalis on saxophone, Harry Connick Jr. on piano and the young trombonist Troy Andrews, known around town as Trombone Shorty and lionized over the past 10 years by a forest of local press.

FELDER--Lawrence, on April 12, 2007. Beloved husband of Ruth (Kitain), devoted father of Brenda (Elkind) and Maxwell, father-in-law of Steven Elkind and Kate Ryan, adoring and adored ''Granpa'' of Erin, Sophie, Marissa and Lucie, brother of Louisa Solomon and the late Karl Felder and Rhoda Asher. First, foremost and forever Master Plumber and Proprietor of Mac Felder, Inc. on Manhattan's Upper West Side; Captain of his industry and active leader for The Association of Contracting Plumbers of the City of NY; former Temple President of Whitestone Hebrew Center, former Chairman of the Village of North Hills Planning Commission and former President of The Greens Condominium Association. A lion among men, he was generous and compassionate; and lived for his family, and his family loved him for his life. Services Tuesday, April 17, 2007, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

An article in the special Retirement section on Tuesday about a consulting company that helps executives change careers incorrectly described the job that Diane Capstaff, a retired insurance company executive, took as interim director of a historic preservation society in Boston. It was a paid position.
''I feel it's my responsibility to pay. And if it helps me get papers, fine.'' DIONICIO QUINDE LIMA, an illegal immigrant, waiting to pay United States taxes. [A1]

8 P.M. (CMT) 2007 CMT MUSIC AWARDS -- Jeff Foxworthy, left, who long ago proved that he's smarter than a fifth grader, is host of this country music awards show in which fans nominate and vote on the season's best videos in nine categories, including video of the year, which is chosen during the show. Nominees include ''A Little Too Late'' by Toby Keith, ''8th of November'' from Big & Rich, ''Not Ready to Make Nice'' by the Dixie Chicks and ''Before He Cheats'' by Carrie Underwood, whose director, Roman White, also got a nod. Kris Kristofferson will receive the Visionary Award, given, according to the people at CMT, ''to an artist who exemplifies what Johnny Cash perfected -- a vision.'' ''CMT Insider'' offers a pre-voting refresher course on the nominees at 4 p.m. ''CMT Music Awards Red Carpet'' gives the once-over to arrivals at the Curb Event Center at Belmont University in Nashville at 7. 8 P.M. (Travel) INSIDE GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK -- A look at the natural wonders of this Wyoming park, from its skyscraping peaks to its crystalline lakes, and some of the visitors who go there to chill and thrill. 8 P.M. (Fox) DRIVE -- The racers keep racking up the miles as Alex reconnects with an old friend after his arrest separates him from Corinna; Winston catches the eye of a dangerous beauty; John and Violet continue their deception; and Wendy tries to relinquish the wheel to a new partner. 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS -- Leeza Gibbons sweetly demanded a recount when she was axed from the competition last week for a dull paso doble. Tonight the remaining celebrities -- Billy Ray Cyrus, Clyde Drexler, Ian Ziering, Joey Fatone, Laila Ali, John Ratzenberger, Heather Mills and Apolo Anton Ohno -- get sultry in their choice of the samba or the rhumba. 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) DIVINE CANINE: WITH THE MONKS OF NEW SKETE -- Devotion, obedience and fulfillment are three of the things the Monks of New Skete, an Eastern Orthodox order, strive to achieve in their daily lives. They're also some of the traits the monks hope to instill in the dogs they raise and train as part of their religious education. This new series follows Brother Christopher, above, as he uses the resident German shepherd puppies at his 500-acre Cambridge, N.Y., monastery as examples to help troubled dogs become best friends to their owners once again. 9 P.M. (13, 49) WARRIORS -- This documentary is the second of 11 being shown on PBS this week in the series ''America at a Crossroads,'' which examines the challenges confronting the world in the aftermath of Sept. 11. This film checks in on American soldiers during 2005 in some of the most dangerous areas in and around Baghdad, and looks at who they are, what they do and why. 10 P.M. (FX) THE RICHES -- The deliciously devious Malloys (Minnie Driver as Dahlia and Eddie Izzard as Wayne) are forced to uphold their promise when Di Di's fiancé arrives at their door. Meanwhile Dale plots a power grab back at the Louisiana camp, and a lawsuit threatens the future of Panco. But is Wayne enough of a lawyer to deal with it? KATHRYN SHATTUCK

An article on Wednesday about a $400 million donation to Columbia University from John Werner Kluge, who made his fortune from the Metromedia Company, referred imprecisely to the status of Metromedia's television stations after Mr. Kluge sold them. They became the core of the Fox broadcast network, not of Fox News.

Bucky Covington (Lyric Street/Hollywood) Bucky Covington is 29, and he has been a sort of famous singer for about a year. But he already seems to miss the good old days, and his debut album, ''Bucky Covington,'' is full of nostalgia for a simpler time. In one song he evokes the days when ''there was nothin' else to do but think and toss a stone and watch it sink''; in another he remembers being ''raised on cornbread and Scripture''; in yet another he fondly recalls that ''our cribs were covered in lead-based paint.'' Of course nowadays you can't accidentally poison a baby without someone making a big fuss; it's no wonder cribs don't gleam as they used to.

Bill Carrothers ''Keep Your Sunny Side Up'' (Pirouet) Throughout the new album by the pianist Bill Carrothers, somber lyricism gives in to playful fizz. It happens on ''You and the Night and the Music,'' when Mr. Carrothers fixates on a trilling figure until it sounds delirious. It happens on ''Say It Isn't So,'' which he delivers as a frenzied tease. And it happens on ''I Can't Begin to Tell You,'' during a round of quote-riddled four-bar exchanges with his drummer, Ari Hoenig.

Avril Lavigne ''The Best Damn Thing'' (RCA) Just about every word and every note on Avril Lavigne's third album, ''The Best Damn Thing,'' is delivered as if it leads to an exclamation point. ''I hate you now! So go away! From me! You're gone!'' she sings in ''I Can Do Better,'' one of the album's many punk-pop kiss-offs.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer has taken some lumps in the press during his first 105 days in office, while Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has been riding a wave of positive publicity about his investigation into student loan practices. In a Quinnipiac University poll this month, Mr. Cuomo even surpassed the governor's still solid job approval numbers for the first time, a development that did not go unnoticed in the capital.

As the focus on presidential fundraising intensifies, it seems Barack Obama has taken the lead in one leg of the race. For the first quarter of the year, the Democratic senator from Illinois has taken on his more established New York rivals in hitting up Wall Street, Bloomberg News notes.

When I visited University of North Carolina recently, I ran into lots of students who were desperate to meet me to bolster their chances of winning the "win-a-trip" contest. But I also met one student, Loren Berlin, who didn't apply, and she gave me this thoughtful note explaining why. It's provocative, so let me share it in full:
With the horror of Virginia Tech, we see up close the horror that has been happening continually in Darfur for four years. One reader, David, wrote President Bush as follows (he copied me:

Here is how the world works. I am sitting at Stumptown coffee, my very first stop in Portland, when I check my Blackberry for news and see that my friend Lars Nilsson, formerly of Nina Ricci and Blass, has sent me an e-mail from Paris. Lars says that a friend of his, Patrick Long, is coming to one of my talks here and that we should get together-and by the way, I should try the coffee at Stumptown.

Since I am working on an article about Derek Jeter's defensive troubles for Wednesday's newspaper, I studied everything Jeter did before the Yankees played the Cleveland Indians. I took notes as Jeter fielded 71 of the 72 grounders slapped at him by Larry Bowa, the third base coach and a former terrific shortstop.

At the end of Joe Torre's pre-game news briefing before last night's game against the Cleveland Indians at Yankee Stadium, one of the reporters asked the Yankees' manager about the massacre at Virginia Tech on Monday, in which a student with two handguns killed 32 people and himself.

This is not a misprint: It's not raining. But a Mets game would not be complete without the requisite fun from Mother Nature: the flags high above center field at Citizens Bank Park have not stopped swirling since I got here five hours ago. From here in the mercifully enclosed press box, it seems as if the wind's blowing hard out to right, and any fly ball hit to left should be knocked down. We'll see how that affects all the left-handed sluggers -- Chase Utley, Ryan Howard, Carlos Beltran, Carlos Delgado -- who will be playing tonight.

A day after a student killed 32 people and himself at Virginia Tech university, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg refused to wag a finger at the Virginia gun dealers and lawmakers who have been among the most hostile to his national campaign to stop illegal gun sales.

This winter I was in a class called Romantic Comedy. Shakespeare, you might ask? Umm no. We're talking "You've Got Mail." I figured this had to be the Rocks for Jocks of the film department, but as it turned out, Rom-Com was no sunset stroll down the beach. We dragged our feet through Freudian readings of "Bringing Up Baby" and analyzed the shift from modernism to postmodernism by contrasting "The Apartment" with "Annie Hall." All I wanted to do was kick back with some popcorn and take a vacation from my not-so-"Moonstruck" freezing-cold Dartmouth winter, but unfortunately there would be an exam.
Ladies and gentlemen, let the drinking begin.

The state Assembly just posted its list of member items in the 2007/08 budget here. For the uninitiated, these are legislative pet projects -- pork would be another word -- that lawmakers dole out to constituents throughout the state.

We asked Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, what he thought of legislation being proposed over in the Senate that would impose term limits on the leadership positions in both houses of the Legislature.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer set out his agenda for the rest of the Legislative session, which runs through June 21, and campaign finance reform was at the top of the list. Slight problem: The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, detailed his own agenda for the rest of the session this week and campaign finance reform was nowhere on his list.
Given the events of this week, the controversy over Don Imus's racially charged remarks aimed at the Rutgers women's basketball team seem farther away than just a week or so ago.

After a much-anticipated hour and a half hearing that bristled with questions, comments and clarifications, the Landmarks Preservation Commission declined to rule today on the New-York Historical Society's controversial proposal to renovate the exterior of its landmark building at 170 Central Park West.

Assemblyman N. Nick Perry of Brooklyn was one of several lawmakers to speak today before the Transit Workers Union on the occasion of their "lobby day" in Albany. And he did not mince words when it came to Judge Theodore T. Jones, the Court of Appeals jurist who slapped the TWU with heavy fines -- and sent its leader, Roger Toussaint, to jail -- during last year's transit strike.
Before attending a convocation on the campus, members of the Virgina Tech community reflected on Monday's tragedy.

Formed in 2002, Reunion.com is already coming up on its fifth anniversary. But the company, which runs a Web site for former schoolmates to get in touch with each other, only just announced its first round of venture capital funding, a $25 million slug from Oak Investment Partners. Red Herring describes Reunion.com as a social networking site in the Web 2.0 camp, like the much more popular online hangouts MySpace or Facebook.
Jocelyne Couture-Nowak was a victim in Monday's shooting at Virginia Tech. Please share your memories and thoughts on Jocelyne Couture-Nowak here.

Many backlashes bring a counter-backlash, and that may be what is going on with corporate crime. It has become trendy in certain circles to say that the government is cracking down too hard on company executives. James Surowiecki of the New Yorker has noticed this trend as relates to Conrad Black, the former chief of Hollinger International who is now being tried on fraud charges. Mr. Black -- whose own defense lawyer has described him as egotistical and arrogant -- is "not an obviously sympathetic figure," as Mr. Surowiecki understates it. But even he is being defended by "journalists, legal commentators, and myriad bloggers," Mr. Surowiecki writes.

In its first annual report since going public, Fortress Investment Group revealed Tuesday just how profitable last year was for the firm, which posted strong returns fueled by rising investment profit and asset-management fees. The private equity and hedge fund manager, which went public in February in a landmark stock offering, reported revenue of $1.52 billion, a 46 percent jump from 2005.

Wall Street heaved a sigh of relief today because the Consumer Price Index was up less than expected, and that makes the Fed seem less likely to raise interest rates.

James P. King, who chairs the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, had kind words for John D. Feerick, the incoming head of a new ethics agency that in September will subsume the lobbying commission and a second watchdog agency, the state Ethics Commission.
Juan Ortiz was a victim in Monday's shooting at Virginia Tech. Please share your memories and thoughts on Juan Ortiz here.

Hellman & Friedman is having a busy week. Just a few days ago, the San Francisco private equity firm agreed to sell portfolio company DoubleClick to Google for $3.1 billion, well above the $1.1 billion that Hellman and JMI Equity paid for the advertising firm just two years ago. On Tuesday, Hellman & Friedman announced that it raised $8.4 billion for its latest private equity fund, giving it plenty of ammunition for more deals. The new fund, which is the firm's sixth, represents more than half of the $16 billion that Hellman & Friedman has raised since 1987.
