The comedian Jackie Mason came to the defense of his co-author Raoul Felder this morning and criticized the governor for calling on Mr. Felder to step down as chairman of a state commission overseeing judges because of remarks in their new book.

Mark DeCambre admits up front that Goldman Sachs "isn't considering a breakup right now." But that hasn't stopped Mr. DeCambre, who writes for TheStreet.com, from joining the others who have recently speculated about what such a hypothetical and unlikely breakup might mean for the hugely profitable securities giant. The main reason for all the what-iffing seems to be a fascination with Goldman's rather opaque collection of businesses and a desire to compare Goldman with financial companies such as Fortress Investment Group, a hedge fund and private equity firm with some Goldman-like features but a much higher valuation on Wall Street.

Breaking an earlier takeover agreement, Catalina Marketing said Tuesday it had accepted a higher $1.7 billion offer from the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman. The deal tops an earlier offer made by Catalina's largest investor, the activist hedge fund ValueAct Capital.
After acquiring J. Crew Group in 1997, Texas Pacific Group waited nearly nine years to take the clothing retailer public again. Will it see a much quicker turnaround on Neiman Marcus?

There is a nice story in today's Times by David Picker, who examines the concept of "fight money" in Japan, where managers sometimes reward players with cash for good performances. Our friend C.J. Nitkowski, a 10-year major league veteran, is quoted in the story.
At public gatherings and in quiet spots around campus, Virginia Tech students created memorials and consoled one another.
There was a time that conglomerates were all the rage. This is not such a time.
Senator Barack Obama has postponed a foreign policy address he intended to deliver today in Chicago.

Monday should have been a normal day for the campaigns. Of course, it wasn't. The New York Daily News rounds up what campaigns have been doing to acknowledge the shootings at Virginia Tech, such as shifting concerts to memorials and canceling fund-raisers and events.

Hedge funds and private equity firms have grown colossally over the past few years, often working in tandem to shake up underperforming companies. But as they continue to expand and the lines between the two blur, conflicts between the these investment pools may increase, attendees at the 2007 MARHedge conference in San Francisco told MarketWatch.

The New York Times editorial page says the massacre at Virginia Tech shows the need for "stronger controls over the lethal weapons that cause such wasteful carnage and such unbearable loss." The Washington Post editorial page says the incident poses many questions, including one that suggests that the Times has it backward: "Would the university have suffered the same tragedy if Virginia law did not prohibit the carrying of guns on campus?" The Los Angeles Times editorial page thinks everyone "should remember that there are times when silence is the best response." (Though the L.A. Times editorial also adds, "No newspaper is in a position to criticize anybody for capitalizing on tragedy or taking convenient positions.")

We turn once again to the New York City tradition of street co-naming. The City Council's Parks and Recreation Committee will consider an omnibus bill on Thursday that will add extra names to 53 streets, based on recommendations from Community Boards. The list includes the actor Jerry Orbach, whose widow has been waging a public campaign to get a Midtown corner renamed in his honor.
According to a New York Times/CBS News Poll, younger people are more supportive of the war and the president than any other age group.
The 0.6 percent increase was the largest in 11 months, although inflation was modest when energy is excluded.

BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, said Tuesday it was in discussions with a consortium of Canadian pension funds about a deal to take the company private. The consortium, led by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, the Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec, and Canada's Public Sector Pension Investment Board, also includes New York-based buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts as a minority partner, BCE said. Last week, The New York Times reported that the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, BCE's largest shareholder, was in early talks with other investors about mounting a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE in what would be the largest buyout in history. BCE said at the time it was "not in any current talks with any other parties."

The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the largest U.S. public pension fund, said it will vote against the $19 billion purchase of Clear Channel Communications, becoming the third big shareholder to oppose the takeover. The acquisition "is not in the shareowners' best interest," Calpers said on its Web site Monday . The fund owns 3.34 million shares of Clear Channel, or less than 1 percent of the largest U.S. radio broadcaster.

When Sallie Mae goes private in a $25 billion deal announced Monday, the company will be saddling itself with debt in an effort to generate even more lucrative returns. And some of the biggest winners in the debt-fiesta may be hedge fund traders.

General Electric is launching a $250 million equity fund to invest in media and technology companies, part of a broader push by traditional media companies to get into hot areas such as digital advertising or social networks.

A consortium led by London-based private equity firm Terra Firma Capital Partners has gained access to the books of British retailer Alliance Boots to begin due diligence, according to reports. "The group has the money, the books and advisers and just needs to decide if it wants to proceed [with a bid]," a source close to Terra Firma reportedly told The Deal.com.

Who says venture capitalists have no sense of humor? Well, if anyone was saying it, a recent venture by Sequoia Capital would put the kibosh on that notion. The investment firm which has backed YouTube, Google, Yahoo, Oracle and Apple, among others, has partnered up up with funny man Will Ferrell and writer-director-producer Adam Mckay to launch FunnyOrDie.com, a comedy video site that began its beta release Thursday.

A man claiming to be Edward Pastorini, the mystery man named in a dubious Bloomberg News report as the bidder for gold producer Gold Fields, has demanded apologies from the Financial Times's Alphaville blog and from a writer at The New York Post for doubting the veracity of his existence.
A transcript of President Bush’s remarks at the Virginia Tech Memorial Convocation.
Would you like to avoid paying much of your income tax for decade or so? Many hedge fund managers can.

A consortium led by Independent News and Media, the Irish newspaper publisher headed by Tony O'Reilly, raised its offer for APN News & Media, Australia's fourth largest media group. The group, which also includes buyout shops the Carlyle Group and Providence Equity, tabled a a new bid Tuesday worth 6.20 Australian dollars ($5.17) per share, compared to the previous offer of A$6.10 ($3.08).

The prospect of a bidding war for ABN Amro sent its shares soaring on Monday, making it more difficult for the company, the biggest Dutch bank, to seal a merger deal with its preferred partner, Barclays, and reject an unusual overture from a group of three European banks.

SoundBite Communications, a 7-year-old company that provides automated voicemail-message delivery, seeks to raise as much as $69 million in an initial public offering. SoundBite's investors include North Bridge Venture Partners and Mosaic Venture Partners, and Cowen and Company and Thomas Weisel Partners are among the offering's underwriters. According to SoundBite's preliminary prospectus, it plans to use proceeds from the stock sale to repay $3.5 million in debt as well as for general corporate purposes, including potential acquisitions.

AT&T on Monday withdrew its offer to buy a stake in the company that controls Telecom Italia, the largest Italian telecommunications company, for about two billion euros, or $2.7 billion. In a terse statement, AT&T did not give any reason for the decision to pull back its offer to buy a third of the controlling company, Olimpia. But The New York Times reports that AT&T became disenchanted with the idea following intense political pressure in Italy against a sale to a foreign company.

The chief executive of US Airways, W. Douglas Parker, who failed in his attempt last year to pull off a merger with a recalcitrant Delta Air Lines, received salary and bonuses of $5.4 million last year, chalked up gains of $9 million by exercising stock options and still holds options and other stock holdings that are currently valued at roughly $30 million.

Jurors went home Monday after a third day of deliberations in the $101 million insider trading trial of Joe Nacchio, the former head of Qwest Communications International. "You've put in another long day so I'm going to let you go home for the evening," the presiding Judge, Edward W. Nottingham, of United States District Court, said.

As more venture capitalists and entrepreneurs are choosing mergers and acquisitions rather than initial public offerings as their exit of choice, the trend has some in Silicon Valley worried, says The San Jose Mercury News. According to industry tracker VentureOne, 40 venture-backed Silicon Valley start-ups were acquired in the first quarter of this year, compared with 53 in all of 1997. Meanwhile,the region was home to 417 companies in 2000, compared with the 280 I.P.Os last year.

Wachovia said Monday that its first-quarter earnings rose 33 percent, helped by growth in lending income and the acquisition of Golden West Financial. The Charlotte, N.C., bank said it remained on track to meet its goals from its $24.2 billion acquisition of Golden West, which it acquired in October, though chief executive officer Ken Thompson said "it's a trying time to be a participant in the mortgage market."

Google's $3.1 billion acquisition of online advertising firm DoubleClick drove up shares of other Internet ad firms. What was behind the rise? Many investors were betting that Microsoft (which was reportedly also in the running for DoubleClick) and Yahoo would be driven to make deals of their own to keep up with Google.

Macquarie Bank, the acquisitive Australian financial institution that has been snapping up Canadian assets from roads to nursing homes, is now making a further foray into Canada's energy business. Macquarie Power & Infrastructure Income Fund has offered to buy Clean Power Income Fund, a Toronto-based trust that owns the 99-megawatt Erie Shores wind farm in Ontario along with several hydro and biomass plants across the country.

Semiconductor maker Atmel's largest individual shareholder and former chief executive, George Perlegos, said Monday he proposed the company bring in a new board, hire a new C.E.O. and buy back up to $1 billion in shares. Mr. Perlegos said in a statement that he filed a proxy urging shareholders to adopt the measures and has nominated five new members to the board of directors, stating they would in turn seek to bring in three additional directors.

Delta Air Lines said Monday that unofficial voting results show its reorganization plan has received enough creditor support to be approved. The Atlanta-based carrier, which successfully fended off a hostile takeover bid from US Airways while in Chapter 11 protection, will go to court April 25 to ask a judge to confirm the plan, paving the way for it to emerge from bankruptcy on April 30. The Atlanta-based airline said in a statement that the results show that more than 95 percent of ballots cast were in favor of the plan.

T. Boone Pickens of BP Capital is "one of the most complex characters in modern-day capitalism," Portfolio magazine writes in a profile of the self-made oil tycoon, whose son pleaded guilty last year to securities fraud. It describes the hedge fund manager, who earned about $1.5 billion in 2005, as a combination of King Lear, Lazarus, Robin Hood, and Amarillo Slim.

Data Domain has filed for an initial public offering of as much as $100 million in stock, despite a choppy market for tech I.P.O.'s. The 451 Group, an analyst firm, assesses the outlook for the venture-backed data deduplication specialist, which some have touted as the 'next Network Appliance.'

Intelsat, which runs the world's largest network of communications satellites, has been put up for sale by the private equity funds that own it, according to The New York Times. And they apparently have the Blackstone Group to thank for giving them the idea.

Carlyle Group, the giant Washington-based private equity fund, has reportedly suffered a new setback in China. The weekly business magazine Caijing reported that Chinese government regulators have rejected Carlyle's bid to take a 7.99 percent stake in Chongqing Commercial Bank, ostensibly because of a banking rule that prevents foreign investors with total assets of less than $10 billion from becoming a major shareholder in Chinese commercial banks. The rule, which is not consistently applied in China, would virtually disqualify all regional private-equity funds active in the Asia-Pacific area, Forbes.com reported.
Searching for Lauren McCain | 9:36 PM ET
WPP Group, the global advertising and marketing giant, said Monday it had invested $3.5 million for an undisclosed stake in VideoEgg, the online video platform and advertising network company.

Fremont General said Monday that it had found a buyer for most of its home loan business, suggesting that the struggling lender might have found a way out of the troubled subprime mortgage industry. Its stock surged more than 25 percent.
Audio clips of old and rerecorded versions of classic rock songs
As the timeline becomes clearer in the deadliest shooting rampage in American history, many questions remain.
Richard N. Perle, the former chairman of the Defense Policy Board, admits neither mistakes nor regrets on his support of the war, and nothing can shake him of his complacency.
PBS’s documentary is valuable because it shows viewers something of what American forces really face in trying to train an Iraqi army and police force.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Take a quick tour of quick snacks in New Delhi.
Alison Smale, managing editor of the International Herald Tribune, looks at the events occurring worldwide this week.
Tour a Spanish-style home on Florida's Atlantic coast,  an sprawling ranch in New Mexico and a contemporary house near Monterey, Calif.
Fueled by technology, the level of available information about the shooting has been contributing to both false hope and unnecessary anguish among those involved.
Although Mr. Cho’s motives  remained unclear, acquaintances remarked on his isolation from the world and barely concealed anger.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey was riding in the front passenger seat and was not wearing a seat belt.
He was a stranger in a crowd of 26,000. Cho Seung-Hui was even unknown to the young man who for nearly a year slept just feet away from him.
The defense secretary said that the replacement of six cabinet ministers could help to reduce sectarian tensions.
An unpublished report says the government of Sudan is flying arms and military equipment into Darfur.

Cho Seung-Hui, who was identified today as the gunman who killed at least 30 people at Virginia Tech before killing himself, was a 23-year-old South Korean who moved to the United States with his family in 1992.
An amiable senior, a world-class researcher and an avid dancer were among those killed in Virginia.
Cho Seung-Hui’s behavior had caused deep concern among some at Virginia Tech before he killed 32 people and himself.
With two Islanders defensemen serving penalties midway through the second period, Buffalo center Daniel Brière scored the winning goal.
Vincent Lecavalier collected a goal and an assist to help the Lightning take a 2- 1 lead in the best-of-seven series, which resumes Wednesday.

Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano released the recruit Reggie Dixon from a letter of intent yesterday. Rutgers did not explain the action, but ESPN reported that Dixon, a football and track star at Plainfield (N.J.) High School, had been found guilty in a juvenile court case last summer. Dixon’s father, Craig Venson, refused to allow his son to speak to a reporter, saying “All I can tell you is it’s in the hands of the Union County prosecutor and the case is under appeal.”.
Monday’s shooting at Virginia Tech was among the deadliest attacks at a school. A list of other notable rampages.

Tyler Hamilton, the former Olympic gold medalist who was suspended in 2004 for doping, was 56th yesterday after the first stage of the Tour de Georgia. Hamilton finished about a minute behind the stage winner, Daniele Contrini of Italy. Contrini finished the 97-mile ride from Peachtree City to Macon in 3 hours 24 minutes 26 seconds.
The company still beat Wall Street expectations with strong sales, despite a decline in demand for Barbie dolls in the United States.
IntelSat, which runs the world’s largest network of communications satellites, has been put up for sale by the private equity funds that own it.

A 16-year-old boy was fatally shot on a street in East New York yesterday afternoon, the police said. The teenager, identified by the police as Henry Talbert of Brooklyn, was shot once near his neck shortly before 4 p.m. in front of 290 Bradford Street. He was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival, the police said. Investigators were still searching for the gunman, who witnesses said fled on foot.
The plucky but guarded optimism behind their feminist songs of 1978 now sound poignant, even quaint.

An article on Saturday about the opening in San Antonio of the Museo Alameda, the nation’s largest Latino museum, misstated the amount of the largest donation for the museum and its source. It was $5.5 million, not $5 million, from the Ford Motor Company and the Ford Motor Company Fund — not from the company and the Ford Foundation. Also, a picture caption referred incorrectly to Henry R. Muñoz III, who raised much of the money for the museum. He is an executive of an architectural firm, not an architect.

An article on April 6 about a decision by Florida’s clemency board to let most felons easily regain their voting rights after prison misstated the proportion of blacks among the state’s disenfranchised ex-offenders. About 21 percent of the estimated 950,000 ex-offenders are black, according to the Sentencing Project, a liberal advocacy group in Washington — not “the vast majority.”.

The Media Equation column in Business Day yesterday, about Field & Stream magazine and its four nominations for National Magazine Awards, misstated the date the 2007 awards will be presented. It is May 1, not May 4.

A picture caption on Saturday with a front-page article about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s college years at Wellesley reversed the names of two of her classmates in some copies. Eleanor Dean Acheson, in glasses, was at right, and Cheryl Lynn Brierton was at left.

A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Chicago’s selection as the United States’ candidate for the 2016 Summer Olympics referred incorrectly to New York City’s failed bid for the 2012 Olympics. The city’s proposal included plans to build a stadium in Flushing in conjunction with the Mets; the bid was not submitted without plans for a stadium. (The NYC2012 group turned to the Flushing alternative late in the process, after plans fell apart for a West Side stadium in Manhattan.).

An article in Business Day on Saturday about Citigroup’s acquisition of a hedge fund and the hiring of its leader, Vikram S. Pandit, misstated Mr. Pandit’s educational background. He has a Ph.D. in finance, not in engineering.

A brief report yesterday about a memorial service scheduled for April 23 for the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. included erroneous information from participants about who may attend. It is not open to the public; it is by invitation only.

An article last Tuesday about the possible deployment of 13,000 National Guard members to Iraq gave an incorrect surname in some references for an Arkansas National Guardsman and father of five who was deployed to Iraq in 2004. He is Staff Sgt. Kelly W. Collier — not “Sergeant Kelly.”.

An article in Science Times last Tuesday about the benefits of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine referred incorrectly to one of the causes of ear infections. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a kind of bacteria, not a virus.

An article in Business Day on Friday about the return of Jeffrey A. Citron, founder of the Internet phone company Vonage, to be its chief executive misstated the company he was with in the late 1990s when he was accused of fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Citron was an executive at Datek Online Holdings, not the Tyco Corporation.

Because of an editing error, an article on March 12 about the latest New York Times Scholars misstated the profession of Ernest Abrahamson, who along with his wife, Kathleen, has donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to the scholarship program. (The error first appeared in an article on March 14, 2002, about that year’s Times Scholars.) Mr. Abrahamson is an entrepreneur and the chairman of a manufacturing company; he is not an engineer. Mr. Abrahamson pointed out the error last week.
Corrections
Federal officials today said that the gunman who killed 32 people and himself yesterday was Cho Seung-Hui, a student who lived in a dormitory on the Virginia Tech campus.
The temporary closing of Chumley’s in Greenwich Village triggered a mix of reactions from neighbors and patrons.

The United States women’s team will play Norway on July 14 in East Hartford, Conn., as part of a six-game send-off series before the Women’s World Cup in China, which begins Sept. 10. The game will be played at Rentschler Field and televised live on ESPN2. The team also would play host to China on June 16 in Cleveland and Brazil on June 23 in East Rutherford, N.J. Games also are scheduled for July 28, Aug. 12 and Aug. 25, but the cities have not been announced.
France’s antidoping laboratory began analyzing the B urine sample belonging to the 2006 Tour de France champion Floyd Landis yesterday.

The start of the Louis Vuitton Cup was postponed yesterday because of inconsistent wind off Valencia, Spain. They will try to race today, but yesterday’s 10 match races were rescheduled for Friday. Alinghi of Switzerland will defend the America’s Cup from June 23 to July 4 against the winning boat.
Cortez Hankton signed with the Minnesota Vikings yesterday, leaving Jacksonville after four seasons. Hankton had 34 catches for 310 yards and 2 touchdowns with Jacksonville.

Syracuse tailback Delone Carter, who led the Orange in rushing as a freshman last season, will probably miss next season as he recovers from a dislocated hip, Coach Greg Robinson said. Carter was hurt Saturday in a spring drill.

The University of Texas regents approved a $200,000 raise for Coach Rick Barnes yesterday to increase his salary to $2 million a year. Barnes has led the Longhorns to the N.C.A.A. tournament in each of his nine seasons. Texas went 25-10 last season behind the freshman Kevin Durant, who last week announced he would enter the N.B.A. draft.

Wladimir Klitschko, the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, will defend his title against Lamon Brewster in a rematch July 7 in Cologne, Germany. In a 2004 fight for the World Boxing Organization title, Brewster won with a fifth-round technical knockout. Last month, Klitschko (48-3 with 43 knockouts) needed only a few punches to stop Ray Austin in the second round. Brewster (33-3 with 29 knockouts) lost the W.B.O. title in April 2006 to Sergei Liakhovich in a unanimous decision.
The George Washington junior Maureece Rice made himself available for the N.B.A. draft, but he plans to retain his N.C.A.A. eligibility. Rice led the Colonials in scoring, averaging 15.8 points.

Australia, the defending champion, defeated Sri Lanka by seven wickets in Grenada yesterday in a match between teams that had already qualified for the World Cup semifinals. Ricky Ponting, the Australian captain, and Andrew Symonds then scored unbeaten half-centuries to steer their team to 232-3 with 7.2 overs to spare.
As the Knicks played their final game of the season at Madison Square Garden, the optimism belonged to the Rangers.
A police officer whose death was used as an example of medical problems affecting ground zero workers did not work in Lower Manhattan until December 2001, city records show.

The Defense Ministry said it was “completely unacceptable” for an army instructor to order a recruit during target practice to pretend he was facing hostile African-Americans in the Bronx. A video of the order, posted on the Internet, drew a protest from the Bronx borough president, Adolfo Carrión Jr., who demanded an apology. The mayor of Rendsburg, where the base is situated, invited Mr. Carrión to visit, saying that he could not excuse the two soldiers but that most of the troops there were “open-minded and tolerant.”.

Army-led security forces arrested Arafat Rahman, the younger son of former Prime Minister Khaleda Zia, in Dhaka, the capital, on corruption allegations. Last month, the authorities arrested Mrs. Zia’s other son, Tarique Rahman, also on corruption allegations. The army-backed caretaker government that declared emergency rule in January after national elections were indefinitely postponed has detained more than 160 suspects in an anti-graft drive, focusing on public officials and business figures from the two main political parties, the Bangladesh Nationalist Party of Mrs. Zia and the Awami League headed by her rival, former Prime Minister Sheik Hasina Wazed.

Nearly a third of the estimated 260,000 Holocaust survivors in Israel are living in poverty and struggling to get state medical services or sufficient pensions, according to a report by the Holocaust Survivors’ Welfare Fund. The report, timed to coincide with Holocaust Remembrance Day, was delivered to Parliament on Sunday. Hundreds of survivors, advocates and students marched outside the building in protest. “We keep being very critical of those who have not admitted guilt or deny that there was a Holocaust, but here we are ignoring the people who are living in dire poverty,” said Collette Avital, a member of Parliament who advocates for Holocaust survivors. Isaac Herzog, the social affairs minister, asked to take control of the care for Holocaust survivors, now under the Finance Ministry. “I feel deeply ashamed,” he said.

Draped in a lion skin, Mandla Mandela, the 32-year-old grandson of Nelson Mandela, was installed as chief of the Mvezo Traditional Council by Buyelekhaya Dalindyebo, the paramount king of the Thembu clans, at a ceremony in Eastern Cape Province. The title has traditionally been held by a member of the Mandela family, but in 1934 Nelson Mandela renounced his claim to become a lawyer and fight apartheid. “That my grandson has taken the chieftaincy I was supposed to have, that he is to rule here at Mvezo will make me sleep forever a happy man in my grave,” a beaming Mr. Mandela said at the ceremony. Last week, Mandla Mandela graduated from Rhodes University with a degree in political science. His father, Makgatho, Nelson Mandela’s last surviving son, died of AIDS in 2005.

The Yangtze, the third longest river in the world after the Nile and the Amazon, is seriously polluted and the damage is almost irreversible, the state-run China Daily reported, citing a report by the Nanjing Institute of Geography and Limnology, part of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. More than 370 miles of the 3,860-mile-long river, which accounts for 35 percent of China’s total fresh water resources, are in critical condition, and almost 30 percent of its major tributaries are seriously polluted, the report said. The pollution, along with damming and heavy use of boats, has caused a sharp decline in aquatic life along the Yangtze, it said, with the annual harvest in the 1990s falling to 100,000 tons, from more than 400,000 tons in the 1950s. The report said that even the huge reservoir created by the Three Gorges Dam, the world’s biggest hydropower project, was now seriously polluted.

Britain’s biggest journalists union, the 40,000-member National Union of Journalists, has voted in favor of a boycott of Israeli goods, citing what it called Israel’s “military adventures.” The measure, approved by a vote of 66 to 54 at the union’s annual delegates meeting on Friday, called for “a boycott of Israeli goods similar to those boycotts in the struggles against apartheid in South Africa.” The timing was particularly delicate because a BBC journalist, Alan Johnston, has been held for over a month in Gaza. A Palestinian group claimed on Sunday to have killed Mr. Johnston, but the BBC said it was treating the report as a rumor. The union’s Web site says that the delegates criticized Palestinian authorities for failing “to carry out their promises to do all they can to free Alan.” Last year, the largest British university teachers’ association voted to encourage individual academics in Britain to sever professional contact with their counterparts in Israel.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer has named Avi Schick the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is overseeing the rebuilding at ground zero, and has named David Emil the corporation’s president. Mr. Schick is president of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state’s economic development agency, and was a deputy attorney general under Mr. Spitzer. Mr. Emil owned Windows on the World, the restaurant on top of the World Trade Center. Mr. Schick, whose salary in the state job is $213,000, will not be further compensated; Mr. Emil’s annual salary will be $185,000.

City officials pledged at a City Council hearing yesterday to work with the state, the Signature Theater and the Joyce Theater to produce a feasibility study in eight weeks on cultural development at ground zero. The cultural affairs commissioner, Kate D. Levin, said she hoped to have a better sense of the artistic programming, construction costs and a timetable in the next two months. The Joyce, which presents dance, will be the sole occupant of a performing arts center at the ground zero site; the Signature Theater was supposed to share the center, but is considering a move into nearby Fiterman Hall because sharing seems too complicated.

The chess team from Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn won its fourth consecutive national championship on Sunday, tying with a high school from Arizona. It was the second time in three years that Murrow and Catalina Foothills High School of Tucson were named co-winners of the National High School Championship. Each school earned 22 points in the tournament, which was held in Kansas City, Mo. Alex Lenderman, a Murrow senior who earned 6.5 points for his team, was named national scholastic chess champion, the tournament’s top individual honor.
The Defense Department directed a private contractor to hire the companion of Paul D. Wolfowitz to study issues related to setting up a new government in Iraq.

Bayonne Medical Center has filed for bankruptcy protection but will continue operating normally while it reorganizes its finances, hospital officials said yesterday. The officials said in a brief statement that a voluntary petition had been filed to reorganize under Chapter 11. The medical center, which opened in 1888, has 278 beds. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Clarence Norman Jr., the former leader of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to one to three years in prison for extortion. The sentence, less than the minimum of two and one-third to seven years, will begin after two other consecutive sentences of one to three years that Mr. Norman received after other corruption trials. In four trials on separate corruption charges, Mr. Norman was convicted three times and acquitted once. In the most recent trial, prosecutors described a plan to shake down judicial candidates in exchange for party support. The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said in a statement, “This trial showed how Clarence Norman manipulated the judicial selection system and perverted the way judges are elected in this county.”.

Officers continued searching yesterday for the man who beat and raped a 23-year-old woman while holding her hostage for 17 hours, the police said. The woman, a student at Columbia’s Graduate School of Journalism, remained hospitalized yesterday and has been joined by her family, according to a statement by Lee C. Bollinger, the university’s president. The attack, in a building in Hamilton Heights, began at 11:30 p.m. Friday and ended on Saturday afternoon when the assailant set fire to a futon, and the woman fled.

A government witness testified in Federal District Court yesterday that the man charged with the 1992 killing of Thomas and Rose Marie Uva of Queens, a young couple who robbed Mafia social clubs, had previously said he planned to take revenge. The witness, Michael DiLeonardo, a Gambino captain, testified that the defendant, Dominick Pizzonia, made the statement to John A. Gotti outside a social club where patrons had been robbed. “He told John he was going to go after them,” Mr. DiLeonardo said. “He was going to kill them.”.
Retail sales rose slightly more than expected in March, but February sales were much higher than first estimated.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer called on Raoul Felder yesterday to step down as the chairman of a state commission that oversees state and local judges in the wake of a vote of no confidence by the other commissioners last week. Mr. Felder, left, a celebrity divorce lawyer appointed by George E. Pataki, is the chairman of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct. The other nine members of the commission cast their vote against him last week because they said a new book Mr. Felder wrote with the comedian Jackie Mason “repeatedly invokes racial, ethnic and religious invective.” Mr. Felder has disputed the characterization of the book and said he would fight any move to oust him before his term ends next March.
New York State spends $50 million a year on drug and alcohol treatment for the 500 most expensive patients.

A bookseller was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 13 years in prison for plotting to buy arms for Islamic fighters in Afghanistan. Prosecutors say that the bookseller, Abdulrahman Farhane, 53, met with an undercover federal informant in his bookstore in late 2001 to discuss ways to send money overseas to buy weapons for the fighters. Three other men, including a jazz musician and an emergency room doctor, have also pleaded guilty to terrorism charges in the case and are awaiting sentencing.

First: Colette Brooks, above, who connects consumers with biodiesel cars and fuel; Joel Woolf, who devised a two-tank engine system that runs on vegetable oil; and Jeff Simmons, a professional race car driver and ethanol advocate who shows off that fuel’s potential with a 220-mile-per-hour test run in preparation for the IndyCar Series.

MORE TRANS-ATLANTIC COMPETITION Zoom Airlines, based in Ottawa, plans to begin service between Kennedy International Airport and London Gatwick Airport on June 21, with round-trip coach fares starting at about $510, including taxes and fees. Zoom says it will offer both economy and premium- economy cabins with meals. EOS ADDS SERVICE Eos Airlines, the discount all- business-class carrier, expanded its schedule to add a third flight between Kennedy International Airport and Stansted Airport in London. The additional flight will leave from Kennedy on Sundays, Mondays and Fridays and from Gatwick on Sundays, Mondays and Fridays. AMERICAN AIRLINES PROTEST Flight attendants for American Airlines will be picketing at domestic airports today to protest $180 million in bonuses the carrier is preparing to pay to about 1,000 top managers, according to the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, which represents nearly 20,000 flight attendants at American. In 2003, the flight attendants at American agreed to significant cuts in pay as the airline and others in the industry faced serious financial strain.

A senior politician in the Labor Party of Prime Minister Tony Blair said Monday that the Bush administration's commonly used phrase ''war on terror'' strengthens extremists. ''In the U.K. we do not use the phrase 'war on terror' because we can't win by military means alone and because this isn't one organized enemy with a clear identity and a coherent set of objectives,'' the politician, Hilary Benn, said at Center on International Cooperation of New York University. The speech was released in London by Mr. Benn's parliamentary office.

Leaders in both parties voiced their sympathies, their outrage and their prayers in the aftermath of the shootings at Virginia Tech. Advocates of gun control laws said they hoped for something more: a reopening of the debate over gun regulations. Many advocates had expected that the shootings at Columbine High School in Colorado in 1999 would transform the politics of gun control. In May 2000, the Million Mom March rallied in the nation's capital with a message of ''enough is enough.'' But after the 2000 election, in which Vice President Al Gore's support for new gun regulations was widely thought to have hurt his candidacy, many Democrats showed little appetite for challenging the gun lobby.

A brief report yesterday about a memorial service scheduled for April 23 for the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. included erroneous information from participants about who may attend. It is not open to the public; it is by invitation only.

HOCH--Frank. Brown Brothers Harriman mourns the loss of our friend and Partner Frank W. Hoch. Frank joined the Firm in 1947 and became a Partner in 1960. He was importantly responsible for the growth of our international businesses. Frank combined his business acumen with his personal graciousness. We extend our condolences to his wife Lisina and his family. Michael W. McConnell for the Partners $(6$)HOCH--Frank W. Passed away peacefully Friday, April 13, at his home in Irvington New York at the age of 85. Partner of Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., he served on several corporate boards in the financial and pharmaceutical sectors. Beloved husband of Lisina and devoted father to Steven, Alix, Daphne and Roland and grandfather of eleven. Educated in Switzerland, he received his Doctor of Law from the University of Zurich (Switzerland) in 1947. During World War II he served as a Lieutenant of the Swiss Alpine Infantry. Passionate philanthropist and engaged community leader, he served on the boards of the Smithsonian Institution, Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Phelps Memorial Hospital, Exodus Transitional Community, Irvington Presbyterian Church, Polly Hill Arboretum, American-Swiss Association, American Council on Germany, and was an active member of the Council on Foreign Relations, the Explorer's Club of New York, and the US Council for International Business. A memorial service will be held at Irvington Presbyterian Church, Saturday, April 28 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Exodus Transitional Community, New York, Phelps Memorial Hospital, Sleepy Hollow, NY or Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, MA.
The Alzheimer's Association is seeking to educate the public about the disease in a campaign with the help of celebrities like Lea Thompson. Page C3.

LASSOFF--Martin, 76, of NYC, on April 15, 2007 after a long illness. Adored husband of Michelle, cherished father of Samantha, Andrea, Lisa, Eric, and Jan, and granddad of Sadie and Sean, beloved brother of Roz and Doris, and brothers-in-law Marvin and Harry. An esteemed litigator and steadfast Yankee fan, we will deeply miss his devotion, munificent spirit and humor.

To the Editor: Maryland indeed has shown great leadership in advancing the National Popular Vote plan to have elections where candidates must reach out to all Americans (''Maryland Takes the Lead,'' editorial, April 14). The current system does not benefit small-population states, however. While such states have fewer people per electoral vote than big states, there's a reason for the conventional wisdom that the 2004 election came down to winning two of the big battlegrounds of Pennsylvania, Ohio and Florida.

A picture caption on Saturday with a front-page article about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's college years at Wellesley reversed the names of two of her classmates in some copies. Eleanor Dean Acheson, in glasses, was at right, and Cheryl Lynn Brierton was at left.

Nigerian Court Faults Exclusion of Candidate Nigeria's highest court ruled that electoral officials had illegally excluded a top opposition candidate for president, Atiku Abubakar, from the ballot for the presidential election on Saturday. The ruling throws the already chaotic election season in Africa's most populous nation into deeper turmoil. PAGE A8 Donating Early and Often The American public has given about $160 million to the 2008 presidential candidates so far this year, more than five times the total contributed to campaigns in the same period four years ago. PAGE A24 Almost Human Scientists are seeing increasing evidence of similarities between chimpanzees and humans, and there is just a 1.23 percent difference in their genes. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F1 Sudan to Allow U.N. in Darfur Sudan has dropped its objections to large-scale United Nations assistance to the overwhelmed African Union peacekeeping force in Darfur, setting the stage for the possible assignment there of United Nations peacekeepers. PAGE A6 First, Not Fast, in Boston Robert K. Cheruiyot of Kenya and Lidiya Grigoryeva of Russia overcame the remnants of a northeaster to win the 111th running of the Boston Marathon. The winning times were the slowest in more than two decades. SPORTSTUESDAY, PAGE D1 Museum Makes Show of Itself In a new exhibition, the Guggenheim Museum puts the focus on its corroding facade. Officials spent the last year inspecting each crack and devising a repair plan. The show, ''Restoring a Masterpiece,'' examines that process. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 Routed by a Record Storm Jay Hernandez, right, of the Police Emergency Unit in Yonkers, guided a boat down a flooded street after evacuating a woman and her two grandsons. The northeaster of '07 was blamed for at least nine deaths in five states. Damage is expected to total in the hundreds of millions of dollars. PAGE B1 Pulitzers Are Awarded The Wall Street Journal won two Pulitzer Prizes, for public service and international reporting, and The New York Times won for feature writing. Special citations were announced for Ray Bradbury and John Coltrane. PAGE B8 Green Move at Home Depot Home Depot is taking steps to encourage sales of items that meet standards for being safe for the environment with a new label called Eco Options on about 3,000 of its products. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Student Lender to Be Bought Sallie Mae, the student loan provider, agreed to be taken over by two private equity companies and two banks for $25 billion. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

BUCKLEY--Pat. The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourns the loss of our long time Advisory Council Member, Pat Buckley. Over the years, The Society's events benefitted enormously from Pat's advice, humor and style. She will be greatly missed. Mrs. Bijan Safai, President The Society of MSKCC $(6$)BUCKLEY--Pat. On behalf of the Board of Directors and all the residents of 778 Park Avenue, we offer condolences to the family of Pat Buckley. Having served all who lived in the building as a member of the Board of Directors since 1991, her warmth, wit and spirit will be greatly missed by all. $(6$)BUCKLEY--Patricia. The Chaos Club extends its sincere condolences to our esteemed member, William F. Buckley, Jr; and to his family, on the passing of his beloved wife, Patricia. We mourn a remarkable woman whose devotion to her family and energetic work in the greater community remain an inspiration. The Executive Committee: Gerald Gold Steven Goldberg John McCormack Harvey Weiss $(6$)BUCKLEY--Patricia. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the loss of Pat Buckley, our treasured Honorary Trustee and friend. Pat chaired the annual Costume Institute Benefit for 17 years, from 1978 to 1995, working in tandem with exhibitions on the Ballets Russes, the Hapsburg era, India, and the Belle Epoque and raised vital funds that greatly enriched the Costume Institute's programs and exhibitions. She had a feisty wit and a warm heart and was passionately devoted to this institution. Her indomitable spirit and her dedicated, imaginative and charismatic leadership were not only inspiring -they left an indelible mark on the world of fashion as well. We will miss her deeply and extend our sincerest condolences to Bill, Chris and the entire family. James R. Houghton, Chrman Philippe de Montebello, Dir Emily K. Rafferty, President $(6$)BUCKLEY--Patricia. The Costume Institute of The Metropolitan Museum of Art and its Visiting Committee mourn the death of our dear friend, Pat Buckley. For almost two decades, she chaired with deftness, humor, and an extraordinary organizational precision, the departments annual benefit. In her advisory role as the Head of The Costume Institutes Visiting Committee, she was an enthusiastic advocate for an exhibition program and acquisitions that favored the unexpected and untested and celebrated the exceptional. We will deeply miss the pungency of her affectionate critiques that steered us straight, delivered with a dip of her chin, and her unbridled generosity masked by her chic, worldly, and ironic affect. $(6$)BUCKLEY--Patricia. The Saint Vincent Catholic Medical Centers family mourns the loss of our longtime friend and loyal benefactor, Patricia Buckley, whose efforts in supporting patients suffering from AIDS will never be forgotten. Patricia Buckley's spirit and generosity were a treasured part of St. Vincent's for many years. We extend our deepest sympathies to her husband, William F. Buckley, Jr. and her son, Christopher Buckley. Alfred E. Smith, IV, Chairman, and the Board of Trustees of Saint Vincent Catholic Medical Centers

Gov. Eliot Spitzer called on Raoul Felder yesterday to step down as the chairman of a state commission that oversees state and local judges in the wake of a vote of no confidence by the other commissioners last week. Mr. Felder, left, a celebrity divorce lawyer appointed by George E. Pataki, is the chairman of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct. The other nine members of the commission cast their vote against him last week because they said a new book Mr. Felder wrote with the comedian Jackie Mason ''repeatedly invokes racial, ethnic and religious invective.'' Mr. Felder has disputed the characterization of the book and said he would fight any move to oust him before his term ends next March. DANNY HAKIM

To the Editor: Re ''Loosening the Stem Cell Binds'' (editorial, April 13): I find it hypocritical that President Bush, citing respect for life, has such a moral objection to the use of human embryos (five-day-old blastocysts, or microscopic balls of cells) for scientific and medical research when he had no problem starting and supporting a war that has caused the deaths of thousands and did not voice any objection to the death penalty when 131 prisoners were executed while he was governor of Texas.

For those who crave a little substance -- impatient with the often who's-up, who's-down nature of the presidential campaign -- the time has come. These days, it is hard to take a step without bumping into a candidate delivering a major policy address and seeking to establish credentials on the big issues. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, talked yesterday in Memphis about his economic policies. A speech by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, on ''women and leadership'' at Rutgers was postponed because of the weather. Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, is speaking about foreign policy today in Chicago, and former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts will deliver what he bills as a major address tomorrow in Washington. His campaign is keeping the topic a secret. And if it's Thursday, it must be Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, talking about energy. ADAM NAGOURNEY

INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Iraqi Cleric Withdraws 6 Ministers From Cabinet Moktada al-Sadr, the Shiite cleric, withdrew his six ministers from the Iraqi cabinet after threatening to do so several times. It is in the first major shake-up of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki's government and the first time Mr. Sadr had followed through with a threat to cut some of his ties with the government. A1 Nigeria Court Backs Opposition Nigeria's highest court ruled that electoral officials had illegally excluded a top opposition candidate for president from the ballot. The decision also applies to candidates for governor who were barred from races for suspected corruption in half a dozen states. A8 Sudan Drops Objections to U.N. Sudan said that it had dropped its objections to large-scale United Nations assistance to the overwhelmed African Union peacekeeping force in Darfur, setting the stage for the possible assignment there of United Nations peacekeepers. A6 Afghan Bomb Kills 9 Policemen A suicide bomber struck a group of police officers in the normally peaceful north of Afghanistan, killing nine policemen and wounding 25, the governor of Kunduz Province said. A6 Congress Blocks Disclosure Bill The Bush administration's allies in Congress successfully blocked a bill that would require the White House to disclose the locations of secret prisons run by the Central Intelligence Agency and to reveal the amount spent annually by American intelligence agencies. A6 NATIONAL A12-25 32 Dead and Many Injured In Virginia Tech Shooting Thirty-two people were killed and at least 30 injured in two apparently related shooting incidents at Virginia Tech in the deadliest shooting rampage in American history. A1 Ex-Aide to Gonzales Speaks Out Alberto R. Gonzales's former top aide has told Congressional investigators that Mr. Gonzales was ''inaccurate'' in asserting that he had no role in the deliberations about individual United States attorneys who were later dismissed, a Democratic senator said. A21 Claims From Terror Suspect A Palestinian man who has been described by American officials as a top logistics chief for Osama bin Laden said at a closed hearing last month at Guantánamo Bay that he was not a member of Al Qaeda , according to a transcript. A12 Donations to Campaigns Rose The American public has donated about $160 million to the 2008 presidential candidates so far this year, more than five times the total contributed to campaigns in the same period four years ago. A16 AARP to Help With Medicare AARP, the lobby for older Americans, announced that it would become a major participant in the nation's health insurance market, offering a health maintenance organization to Medicare beneficiaries. A19 8 Dead as Car Flips in Utah Eight men died when an SUV packed with a driver and at least 14 illegal aliens rolled over on a remote desert highway in southeastern Utah. A21 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 New York Spends the Most On Detoxification Patients New York State spends far more than other states on drug and alcohol treatment, including more than $300 million a year on 30,000 detoxification patients. One reason is that $50 million is spent on the 500 most expensive patients, who check in and out of detox wards more than a dozen times a year. A1 Record Rains Pound Northeast A large storm continued its assault on the Northeast, forcing evacuations and leaving rising rivers, gouged beaches and power failures in its wake. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Hedge Officials Delay Taxes Many Americans invest retirement accounts like 401(k)s and I.R.A.'s; but hedge fund managers with large incomes are able to avoid immediately paying taxes on much of that income: they can postpone taxes for at least 10 years. A1 Home Crisis Hits Immigrants Some of the casualties of America's housing bust, like ''for sale'' signs up and down California's Central Valley, are easy to spot. But less visible are immigrant workers, mostly illegal, who find fewer jobs on building sites. A1 Sallie Mae Taken Private Sallie Mae, the student lender, agreed to be taken private for $25 billion amid calls to reduce federal subsidies for student loans. GRAND--Bessie, 95, died surrounded by loved ones at home in Manhattan on Saturday, April 14th. ''Bubbie'', as she was known, was adored and revered by her family, friends and caregivers. A painter, baker and world traveler, Bubbie will be remembered always for her wisdom, humor, impeccability and strength. A service in her memory will be held today at 1 pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY.

WILKIE--George Hamilton, 75, died on April 14, 2007, of cancer after a short illness. Husband of the late Suzannah Ryan Wilkie, he is survived by his children, Angus Wilkie of New York, NY, Austin Wilkie of New York, NY, and Serena Wilkie Gifford of Cambridge, MA, and by his grandchildren, Suzannah Gifford and Abbott Gifford. Born in Tamsui, Formosa, he was a graduate of Williams College, Harvard Medical School and New York Psychoanalytic Institute. He practiced psychoanalysis privately in Manhattan for over 40 years, while also serving as Associate Professor of Psychiatry on the faculty at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. In summer months, he was president of Lac a Gravel trout fishing club in Charlevoix, Quebec, and organist at Murray Bay Protestant Church. Work and family were his music; his concise judgments and succinct wit in all endeavors will be long-remembered. Contributions to: Friends of the Murray Bay Protestant Church, Box 216, Pointe-auPic, PQ G0T 1M0, Canada, or Suzannah Ryan Wilkie Memorial Scholarship Fund, St. Bernards School, 4 East 98th Street, New York, NY 10029.

As President Bush and Congress square off over the Iraq war, most Americans agree with Democrats that a timetable should be set to withdraw troops, and they approve measures to link financing with such a timetable, a CBS News poll finds. Fifty-seven percent of the respondents said a withdrawal timetable should be set for some time next year, and 38 percent disagreed. One-third said all the troops should be removed now, and 37 percent favored lowering troop levels.

HIDDEN LOSERS IN HOUSING SLUMP -- Among the lesser-known losers in the downturn in new home construction are immigrant workers -- most of them illegal -- who have ridden the building boom and now find jobs few and far between. [Page A1.] QUITE A TAX SHELTER -- Because of some structural differences in hedge funds, some managers of the lightly regulated private pools of money have discovered a way to avoid paying taxes on their huge fees for up to 10 years. [A1.] FOR SAFE ROAD TRAVEL ABROAD -- Rochelle Sobel founded the Association for Safe International Road Travel after her son died in a bus crash in Turkey two weeks before he was to graduate from medical school. ''It is important to not only know the laws, but the road culture before you go,'' she said. Traffic accidents are the leading cause of nonnatural death for Americans overseas, according to the State Department. [C7.] SALLIE MAE SOLD TO PRIVATE FIRMS -- Sallie Mae agreed to be sold for $25 billion to two private equity investors amid calls in Washington to cut federal subsidies for student loans. The deal has the potential not only to change Sallie Mae but also to shake up the entire lending industry. [C1.] HOME DEPOT'S GREEN LABEL -- Home Depot, the second-largest retailer in the United States, is introducing the largest green-labeling program -- for 3,000 products -- in retailing today in a move that could persuade its rivals to speed up their own plans. [C1.] TROUBLES FOR AMGEN -- Setbacks at Amgen, some unexpected and some perhaps self-inflicted, are posing new challenges in the company's previously charmed 27-year history. [C1.] A NEW SOURCE OF ETHANOL -- Because of the great worldwide demand for corn, an alternative method for producing ethanol -- using the cellulose waste from sugar cane -- has been sought by researchers, venture capitalists and government officials as a way to help end America's dependency on foreign oil. A new plant under construction in Louisiana could help in that effort. [C1.] AND DIESEL FUEL FROM WHAT? -- Tyson Foods and ConocoPhillips are forming an alliance to produce and market diesel fuel made from pork, poultry and beef fat. [C5.] A BANK DEAL IS THREATENED -- A possible bidding war has sent shares of the big Dutch bank ABN Amro soaring, which is threatening the company's takeover by its preferred suitor, Barclays. ABN Amro has also rejected an unusual takeover overture from a group of three European banks. [C1.] JUSTICES HEAR WORK-RULE CASE -- In 1975, the Labor Department exempted home care aides from federal minimum wage and overtime protections. Lawyers representing an aide from New York argued before the Supreme Court to get that regulation changed. [B2.] CLOUD OVER GUIDANT IS LIFTED -- The Food and Drug Administration erased the cloud it cast in a warning letter sent to the Guidant Corporation in December 2005, a change that should make it easier for its parent, Boston Scientific, to introduce improvements in the unit's heart-regulating implants. [C3.] WHAT WAS THAT DOMAIN NAME? -- The House is to vote on legislation that clarifies the law barring for-profit companies from using names that sound like official government agencies -- especially ones that use the letters I, R and S in a row. [C3.] AT&T ENDS BID FOR TELECOM ITALIA -- AT&T has withdrawn its offer to buy a stake in the company that controls Telecom Italia, -- perhaps dissuaded by intense political pressure in Italy against a sale to a foreign company. [C3.] YAHOO'S NEWSPAPER DEAL -- Yahoo announced a broad deal with publishers representing 264 newspapers to sell national advertising across their Web sites. [C2.] RETAIL SALES UP SLIGHTLY IN MARCH -- Retail sales rose a bit more than expected in March, but adjusted February sales were much higher than first estimated, the Commerce Department has said. [C4.] A GOOD SIGN FOR CITIGROUP? -- Citigroup's first-quarter earnings declined 11 percent because of a big charge for its recently announced corporate revamping. But the results showed progress in its expense management and strength in investment banking, and its shares rose 2.6 percent, which come at a critical time for Citigroup's chief executive. [C3.] WHAT FEMALE TRAVELERS WANT -- American Airlines has tried to tap into the female market with innovations like lie-flat business-class seats on its long-haul flights. But a new Web site for women travelers isn't sitting well. On the Road: Joe Sharkey. [C7.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. MICROSOFT IS PREPARING to introduce a suite of design software, called Expression Studio, that will go head to head with Adobe Systems' flagship tools, Photoshop and Illustrator. It also will include a tool for building multimedia programs to bring it in line with Adobe's Flash. (AP) MATTEL REPORTED a 60 percent decline in first-quarter profit but beat Wall Street revenue expectations with strong sales, despite a decline in demand for Barbie dolls in the United States. (AP)

Because of an editing error, an article on March 12 about the latest New York Times Scholars misstated the profession of Ernest Abrahamson, who along with his wife, Kathleen, has donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to the scholarship program. (The error first appeared in an article on March 14, 2002, about that year's Times Scholars.) Mr. Abrahamson is an entrepreneur and the chairman of a manufacturing company; he is not an engineer. Mr. Abrahamson pointed out the error last week.

To the Editor: Re ''McCain Sees 'No Plan B' for Iraq War; Says Troop Buildup Is the Only U.S. Option'' (''If Elected '' series, front page, April 15): What a terrible combination -- a party with no competence at finishing a war, and a party's candidate who claims there is no alternative but to continue it. Endless, incompetently run war, with no accountability, just blindly believe the ''leader.''

GOLDBERG--Rose, 96. Beloved wife of Jesse, devoted mother to Harriet and Stephen (Susan). Loving grandmother to Debi and greatgrandmother to Jessie. Her unconditional love, kindness and wisdom will always be remembered.

The Wall Street Journal won the Pulitzer Prize for public service yesterday for uncovering the unethical practices of business executives who had rewarded themselves millions of dollars by backdating stock options. The articles, by Charles Forelle, James Bandler, Mark Maremont and Steve Stecklow, have led to the federal investigation of more than 130 companies, and at least 70 top executives have lost their jobs. In awarding The Journal its highest journalistic honor, the Pulitzer Prize Board said the paper had brought about ''widespread change in corporate America.''

The Media Equation column in Business Day yesterday, about Field & Stream magazine and its four nominations for National Magazine Awards, misstated the date the 2007 awards will be presented. It is May 1, not May 4.

A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Chicago's selection as the United States' candidate for the 2016 Summer Olympics referred incorrectly to New York City's failed bid for the 2012 Olympics. The city's proposal included plans to build a stadium in Flushing in conjunction with the Mets; the bid was not submitted without plans for a stadium. (The NYC2012 group turned to the Flushing alternative late in the process, after plans fell apart for a West Side stadium in Manhattan.)

Q. Can animals have hiccups? A. The collective wisdom of veterinary practitioners is that hiccups do exist in animals, at least in puppies and kittens, but they are episodic, and the animals typically outgrow them, said William E. Hornbuckle, professor of veterinary medicine at the Cornell College of Veterinary Medicine.

To the Editor: Re ''Romantic Revulsion in the New Century: Flaw-O-Matic 2.0'' (Findings, April 10): The empirical basis for John Tierney's article presupposes that individuals who are ''permanently'' single have some flaw.

ABC posted a considerable lead in the ratings Sunday, significantly overshadowing Fox's two-hour premiere of ''Drive'' and winning every hour of the night in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' garnered the night's highest ratings, earning 16.1 million viewers at 9 p.m. It followed new episodes of ''America's Funniest Home Videos'' at 7 (8.6 million) and ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (10.2 million). During the 10 p.m. hour, ABC's ''Brothers & Sisters'' (11.5 million) remained on top among adults 18 to 49, but CBS's ''Without a Trace'' led the hour in total viewers (14.3 million). For the night, CBS actually had slightly more total viewers over all, despite ABC's advantage in the 18-to-49 demographic. Meanwhile, ''Drive'' drew just 6 million viewers from 8 to 10. Fox ranked third for the night in the 18-to-49 demographic, ahead of NBC. BENJAMIN TOFF

Thirty-two people were killed, along with a gunman, and at least 15 injured in two shooting attacks at Virginia Polytechnic Institute on Monday during three hours of horror and chaos on this sprawling campus. The police and witnesses said some victims were executed with handguns while other students were hurt jumping from upper-story windows of the classroom building where most of the killings occurred. After the second round of killings, the gunman killed himself, the police said.

To the Editor: Re ''He's Not My Grandpa. He's My Dad'' (Thursday Styles, April 12): My husband is 17 years my senior. We married when I was 20 and he was 37. Our first child was born one year later. When our sixth child was born, my husband was 56. He was a great Lamaze coach, and while I breast-fed, he still got up first, changed the baby and brought the baby to me. We are now the grandparents of 14.
