Ryan Clark was known as Stack here on the rolling campus of Virginia Tech, an amiable senior memorable for his ready smile and thoughtful ways. He was also among the first victims of the deadliest school rampage in the nation's history.

To the Editor: Re ''Pas de Deux of Sexuality is Written in the Genes '' (April 10): Nicholas Wade concludes that sex differences in the brain are responsible for the differing ways that women and men express their sexuality. In assuming that brain structure ''is written in the genes,'' Mr. Wade completely overlooks environmental influences on brain development. There is ample evidence from the field of neuroscience that patterns of neural connections, and therefore brain organization, change constantly with experience. Indeed, contrary to Mr. Wade's claim that distinct patterns in female and male brains exist ''despite the heavy influences of culture,'' culture may in fact be the cause of many of these differences. Mr. Wade's views notwithstanding, the nature/nurture controversy is far from being resolved. Alison Nash New Paltz, N.Y. To the Editor: Professor Anthony F. Bogaert speculates that ''the fraternal birth order effect'' in which ''each additional older brother increases the odds of same-sex attraction by 33 percent'' results from ''maternal immune response.'' Another possibility is fetal microchimerism. Mothers carry male fetal cells for decades. Male DNA has been detected in women 38 years after their last male birth. Fetal cells can even repair maternal brain damage. On evolutionary biology grounds, microchimerism seems more likely than maternal immune response. The article notes that ''male and female neurons behave somewhat differently when kept in laboratory glassware.'' Perhaps male cells have evolved to infiltrate Mom and turn future brothers gay? James Lavin Stamford, Conn.

YOFFIE--William ''Tod''. The Union for Reform Judaism mourns with deep sorrow the passing of William Yoffie, father of our president, Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, and a generous philanthropist and humanitarian. We extend deepest condolences to the entire Yoffie family. May Tod's memory be a blessing. Robert M. Heller, Chairman

FLANDER--Carl-Eric. Died on April 12, 2007, at the age of 94. He was raised and educated in Finland and was fluent in five languages. He received graduate degrees in Germany and was a technical expert in papermaking. Sometime before World War II, he came to the USA to represent the Finnish paper industry. He returned to Finland to fight in the Finnish Winter War and then subsequently returned again to the USA to represent the Finnish paper industry. He was the recipient of two of the highest awards given by the Finnish Government in recognition of his efforts on behalf of Finland and the Finnish paper industry. He also founded the Finnish American Chamber of Commerce which was formed to stimulate and promote economic development, trade and investment between the United States and Finland. He had close ties with leaders in the American and Canadian paper industry. His leisure time was spent skiing and hiking with his family in the White Mts. of New Hampshire and also managing his dairy farm. He is survived by Margareta, his wife of 69 years, his daughters, Christina F. Holbrook and Pia Streeter, four grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Dobbs Ferry Lutheran Church on Saturday April 21 at 11am.

An article in Science Times last Tuesday about the benefits of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine referred incorrectly to one of the causes of ear infections. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a kind of bacteria, not a virus.

CORCORAN--David, 45, of Maine, on April 6th, 2007. Beloved son of Peter and Faith, brother of Carole, Kathy, Beth, Alex and Chris and partner of Jane Schaller. Master wooden boat builder and owner of Bullhouse Boatworks. His artistry, passion, and loyal companionship will be missed by all. Donations can be made to The Louis T. Graves Memorial Public Library, Kennebunkport, ME.

To the Editor: Re ''Birds Do It. Bees Do It. People Seek the Keys to It.'' (April 10): You are right to highlight that genes do contribute to sexual desire and intelligence and even sexual identity. But readers need to see the whole picture.
DUNBAR--Gerry. You left us much too soon. You will be sorely missed. With love to Christine. Wendy Weller-Jones & Family

KLUFER--Robert E., 85, of Rye, NY and Palm Beach, FL died peacefully on April 14th after a long illness. Beloved husband of Alyse Joel, loving father of the late Laura Cave and Jane Shrage, Elisabeth Klufer and Nancy Greengrass, adoring grandfather of Damien, Michael, Max, Natalie, Ross and Reed. Funeral service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY at 1pm April 17th, 914-664-6800. Shiva April 17th after interment and April 18th, 19th after 2pm at 720 Milton Road, 1A North, Rye, NY. $(6$)KLUFER--Robert. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime devoted member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus Jonathan Blake, Rabbi Ellen Sunness, President

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature unveiled a bill on Monday that state officials said would make New York the first state to establish tough new restrictions on the relationship between colleges and the companies that make tuition loans to their students. The legislation would bar lenders from sharing revenue from student loans with colleges, a much criticized practice that has been at the heart of recent investigations by Mr. Cuomo and federal officials into the student-loan industry.

TOMPKINS--Rexford E. The governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of Rexford Tompkins, former REBNY governor from 1966 to 1975 and REBNY Chairman from 1970 to 1972. In the mid 1970s, Rex also served as REBNY's President. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire Tompkins family. Stephen M. Ross, Chairperson Steven Spinola, President

The Defense Ministry said it was ''completely unacceptable'' for an army instructor to order a recruit during target practice to pretend he was facing hostile African-Americans in the Bronx. A video of the order, posted on the Internet, drew a protest from the Bronx borough president, Adolfo Carrión Jr., who demanded an apology. The mayor of Rendsburg, where the base is situated, invited Mr. Carrión to visit, saying that he could not excuse the two soldiers but that most of the troops there were ''open-minded and tolerant.'' MARK LANDLER

An article last Tuesday about the possible deployment of 13,000 National Guard members to Iraq gave an incorrect surname in some references for an Arkansas National Guardsman and father of five who was deployed to Iraq in 2004. He is Staff Sgt. Kelly W. Collier -- not ''Sergeant Kelly.''

Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, raised $500 in the first quarter of the year, according to his Federal Election Commission filing. The sum is fueling speculation that the five-term senator, who celebrated his 80th birthday this year, may not seek re-election next year. Another Republican of Virginia, Representative Thomas M. Davis III, who has said he would consider running if Mr. Warner does not, raised $623,463 in the first quarter -- $150,000 more than he has ever raised in a three-month period, his office said. Mr. Warner said in an interview yesterday that he was hardly in the ''pauper's column,'' pointing out he has more than $667,000 in the bank. He declared himself at the ''top of my game'' but said he was evaluating what was best for his state. ''Is it John Warner or is it a younger person to come in and start to build up their seniority?'' he said. ''That is not a simple decision.'' Democratic strategists are trying to enlist former Gov. Mark R. Warner, who made an unsuccessful run against Senator Warner in 1996. They are not related. Through a spokesman, Mark Warner had no comment. MICHAEL LUO

A government witness testified in Federal District Court yesterday that the man charged with the 1992 killing of Thomas and Rose Marie Uva of Queens, a young couple who robbed Mafia social clubs, had previously said he planned to take revenge. The witness, Michael DiLeonardo, a Gambino captain, testified that the defendant, Dominick Pizzonia, made the statement to John A. Gotti outside a social club where patrons had been robbed. ''He told John he was going to go after them,'' Mr. DiLeonardo said. ''He was going to kill them.'' MICHAEL BRICK

An article in Business Day on Saturday about Citigroup's acquisition of a hedge fund and the hiring of its leader, Vikram S. Pandit, misstated Mr. Pandit's educational background. He has a Ph.D. in finance, not in engineering.

FREEDMAN--Heidi, cher ished daughter of Barney and Jill, beloved sister of Jay and Andrew. Sister-in-law of Sheryl, adoring aunt of Jennifer Blake, and dearest niece and cousin. Finally at peace. In lieu of flowers donations in Heidi's memory to N.A.M.I. 1562 Route 130, North Brunswick, New Jersey, 08902.

The sudden change in Vince Carter's demeanor -- from relaxed to intense -- said it all. About 30 minutes after recording the fourth triple-double of his career last night, Carter tightened his jaw and put on a pointed glare when told that Toronto's Chris Bosh had said the Raptors wanted to face Carter and the Nets in the playoffs.

To the Editor: ''Turkey and the U.N.'s Cover-Up'' (editorial, April 13) reflects only the Armenian version of the events of 1915. There is no explanation as to how and why these sad events took place in eastern Anatolia. There is also no reference to those Turks who were mass-murdered by Armenian bands during that time. Those tragic events took place in time of war, and both populations suffered extensively.

PYNE--Eben. The Mount Desert Festival of Chamber Music in Northeast Harbor, ME mourns the passing of our esteemed Board President Eben Pyne. His wisdom, charm and expertise will be sorely missed by everyone associated with the festival. His love and enthusiasm for music underscored a firm commitment and unflagging dedication that were hallmarks of his stewardship. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to his lovely wife and longtime board member and patron, Nancy, and to his family. Robert L. Shafer, President-Elect Natalie Raimondi, Executive Director Todd Crow, Music Director

GRANT--William R., 82, Venture capitalist, investment banker, and philanthropist passed away Sunday, April 15, 2007, following a year's illness from metastatic melanoma. He is survived by his beloved wife, Adele Grant, and is predeceased by his beloved wife of 43 years, Dorothy Annetta Grant, a son, Gregory Scott Grant, and a daughter, Melissa Grant Davis. Mr. Grant is survived by his daughters, Deborah S. Grant and Elise Grant Seeley Lauinger and his son, Byron A. Grant, and two grandchildren, Jeremy Deschapelles Seeley and Molly Hall Seeley. A Mass of Resurrection will be celebrated at 3pm on Thursday, April 19th, at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Avenue, New York City. Burial services will be private. In lieu of flowers, his family requests that donations be made to the Gregorian University Foundation, 106 West 56th Street, New York, NY 10019.

An article on April 6 about a decision by Florida's clemency board to let most felons easily regain their voting rights after prison misstated the proportion of blacks among the state's disenfranchised ex-offenders. About 21 percent of the estimated 950,000 ex-offenders are black, according to the Sentencing Project, a liberal advocacy group in Washington -- not ''the vast majority.''

An article on Saturday about the opening in San Antonio of the Museo Alameda, the nation's largest Latino museum, misstated the amount of the largest donation for the museum and its source. It was $5.5 million, not $5 million, from the Ford Motor Company and the Ford Motor Company Fund -- not from the company and the Ford Foundation. Also, a picture caption referred incorrectly to Henry R. Muñoz III, who raised much of the money for the museum. He is an executive of an architectural firm, not an architect.

An article in Business Day on Friday about the return of Jeffrey A. Citron, founder of the Internet phone company Vonage, to be its chief executive misstated the company he was with in the late 1990s when he was accused of fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Citron was an executive at Datek Online Holdings, not the Tyco Corporation.

Since the Guggenheim Museum opened in 1959, Frank Lloyd Wright's massive spiral facade has been showing signs of cracking, mainly from seasonal temperature fluctuations that cause the concrete walls, built without expansion joints, to contract and expand. While museum officials say the facade is structurally sound, they have spent the last year inspecting each crack to devise a repair plan. On Saturday the museum opened ''Restoring a Masterpiece,'' an exhibition (on view through July 8) that chronicles its process. The display includes a diagram that shows each crack on the building's west side. HAEYOUN PARK

ARGAMASO--Ravelo M.D., 81. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of Ravelo Argamaso M.D., an esteemed colleague for over 40 years and a founder of Montefiores Center for Craniofacial Surgery. Dr. Argamaso served as professor and attending surgeon in both the departments of Plastic Surgery and Neurosurgery and was the department of Plastic Surgery's first resident in 1959. Dr. Argamaso was known as a mentor to the many residents who passed through the surgery program over the many years he was at Montefiore. He specialized in pediatric congenital disorders, writing extensively on cleft lip and palate surgery. Our heart felt condolences go out to his wife Carol, his daughters Charlene, Susanne and Stephanie and their families. Spencer Foreman, M.D., President David A. Tanner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

Amanda Loulaki and her trio of dancers appear to be well into the aftershock stage when the lights rise on ''Delirium, or that taste in my mouth,'' which had its premiere on Thursday at Danspace Project. Torsos shudder and clench, legs splay; it's as if some great upset has occurred, and their bodies are only now registering its effects. This place is all too familiar to any half-sentient adult: psychological hurts acquire a physical dimension, and the stunned body curls into itself, creating a strange distance from the mind. It's a rich state for dance to evoke but a difficult one to sustain, even in a 55-minute show. ''Delirium'' is only partly successful in maintaining the wounded erotic tension it builds in the opening section, but its fiercest moments grab the jugular and squeeze.
The Times tasting panel tried 25 bottles of bock beer, a traditional Bavarian seasonal beverage.

Our friends at the Prague Stock Exchange would agree that common ownership of property has been proven to limit innovation. So should our airwaves be publicly owned or privately controlled? Bet I surprise you with my view!

Even in the easy, low-output blogging life we live here at Screens -- hammock, corncob pipe, video iPod -- there emerges now and then a special kind of blogging ... emergency. You try to ignore it, and then you can't.
A look at U.S. efforts to foster democracy in Indonesia. A Times documentary on Islam and Indonesia debuts April 19 on PBS.
Blogs are in overdrive about the Supreme Court's 5-4 decision today to uphold a nationwide ban on a procedure known by opponents as "partial birth" abortion.
Dear Mom,
Remember "secret holds?" A privilege of any given senator who wants to stall legislation for whatever reason. Democrats do it. Republicans do it.

A member of the New York's Public Service Commission -- basically, the body that regulates utilities -- says an aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer threatened to have her removed if she didn't back off efforts to investigate Consolidated Edison over last year's Queens blackout.

Christine Quinn, the City Council speaker, was one of the many politicians who issued a statement today about the Supreme Court decision upholding the 2003 Partial-Birth Abortion Act. She called it "a dark day for women's health." Her full statement is below:

The juvenile minke whale that spent Wednesday and today cruising around Gowanus Bay and frolicking around the mouth of the infamous canal (never venturing in) died in the water shortly after 5 p.m., according to Anthony Ramirez and Ann Farmer, who have been following the story.

A spokeswoman for Lieutenant Governor David A. Paterson made the rounds today, giving reporters an opportunity to review the tax returns Mr. Paterson filed jointly with his wife, Michelle Paige Paterson. We didn't have time to check out the city and state returns, but we took a gander at the federal ones.

Minal Panchal was a victim in Monday's shooting at Virginia Tech. Please share your memories and thoughts on Minal Panchal here.
Readers are provided with another reminder of the quirks of Red Sox outfielder Manny Ramirez in a profile in this week's New Yorker.
The nanny tendencies of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, which he spoofed this past weekend in a send-up of Mary Poppins, were on full display this afternoon in Jersey City.

Governor Corzine's job approval was apparently unaffected by his automobile accident last Thursday. Overall, 51 percent of the New Jersey voters surveyed by Quinnipiac University approve how Mr. Corzine is handling his job, and 36 percent disapprove.The voters interviewed Tuesday through Thursday had essentially the same view of Mr. Corzine's performance in office as did those interviewed Friday through Sunday.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's April 18 column, "Help Wanted."

On the market: two hot new developments in Thailand. Above is the first one, Banyan Tree Phuket, which offers 150 luxuriously appointed one- and two-bedroom villas just a 20-minute drive from Phuket International Airport. The resort facilities include an 18-hole golf course, a spa, fitness center, tennis courts, private chef, and library. The villas offer Wi-Fi access, surround-sound home theatre systems, infinity pools, jet pools, wading pools, steam rooms, and terraces. The properties -- priced from $2.25 million -- are being marketed by Oakhall Property Source www.oakhallpropertysource.com.
A dozen or so slices of cheese. Condiments for said cheese. One or two small slices of bread. Two glasses of a Spanish white.

Sometimes more turns out to be less. Just as soon as Clear Channel Communications announced Wednesday that its private equity suitors had raised their offer to $39 per share from $37.60 per share -- confirming a report in that morning's New York Times -- the company's stock started to fall. The shares were down more than 1 percent at $36.28 in the hour before the close of trading.

Yesterday, Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced the date of a special election to fill the seat of Manhattan Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, who the governor appointed to be commissioner of the Department of Environental Conservation.

After Diane Cardwell of The Times wrote about a National Rifle Association magazine's broadside aimed at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his gun proposals, a reader raised an issue about the image on the cover (at right), showing the Jewish mayor as an octopus.
Money, memories and a town fair link Mexican New Yorkers to the home they  left behind.

The State Commission on Judicial Conduct, stepping up its cold war with its chairman Raoul Felder, said today that Mr. Felder no longer speaks for the commission. He also will no longer sign commission orders or official letters of caution or dismissal sent to judges, according to resolutions passed by the commission at a meeting yesterday.

We never thought we would see the day when the Internet was buzzing about credit default swaps. But the parade of huge leveraged buyouts -- often accompanied by some, ahem, uncanny predeal trading activity -- has brought new attention to these once-exotic financial instruments, which serve as a kind of insurance for the holder of a bond or other kind of debt.

Several of the candidates have already put out statements regarding today's 5-4 Supreme Court decision upholding a nationwide ban on what opponents of the procedure call partial-birth abortion. Notice the differences between comments by Senator John McCain, a Republican who has said he opposes abortion except in cases of rape or incest, and Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican who has said he is personally anti-abortion but believes women should have the right to receive one. Mitt Romney, a Republican who has sought to persuade social conservatives that his abortion stance is genuine, also released a statement, as did some Democrats.

All the entrepreneurs out there dreaming about being acquired by Google should take note: The two founders of Dodgeball, a mobile social-networking service Google bought in 2005, have quit, saying the company "wasn't supporting Dodgeball the way we expected."
At public gatherings and in quiet spots around campus, Virginia Tech students created memorials and consoled one another.

As credit derivatives multiply, it is getting harder and harder to know who has taken on risks. And if you don't know that, it is impossible to know whether they could manage the risks in times of market stress or panic. Who has taken on the ultimate risk of defaults of subprime mortgages?

After The Wall Street Journal reported that Time Warner is considering selling off part of its cable holdings to invest more in the Internet, CNNMoney.com's Paul R. La Monica suggested that Carl Icahn, the billionaire financier who tried to break up the company, may deserve some credit if the company chooses this route. An analyst at Prudential Equity Group said she found Tuesday's report from the Journal hard to believe, however.
I was scanning the Detroit papers recently and catching up on my Chrysler buyout news when all of a sudden it struck me: Kirk Kerkorian is pushing 90.

Detroit is tied up in knots fretting about the future of the Chrysler Group, which has been put up for sale by its parent, DaimlerChrysler. Not to worry, says Toyota's top executive in North America, James E. Press.

Texas power company TXU said on Wednesday it would proceed with its planned buyout by private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group after failing to attract a superior offer. TXU, which agreed in February to be bought for $45 billion by the private equity firms and other investors, said that during a 50-day "go-shop" period, in which it had the right to solicit other bids, it received no offer that could reasonably be expected to result in a superior proposal.

Have a beef about Citigroup's stock price? Or did you find a strange charge on your bank account? Either way, you can take your idea straight to the top. Charles O. Prince III, Citi's chief executive, took investor relations to a bizarre extreme Tuesday when he gave out his e-mail address (princec@citigroup.com) and phone number (212-793-8854) at the bank's annual shareholder meeting. As The New York Times's Eric Dash reported, Citi's meeting ended up being a marathon session where myriad grievances were aired, including gripes about bank customer service or policies.

Give the Virginia Tech administration a break: "The overwhelming majority of murders that take place on campus (or anywhere else) are not a prelude to a mass killing," writes The Economist's Megan McArdle, who is guest-blogging at Andrew Sullivan's Daily Dish at The Atlantic Online. "Should we really act as if they were, because it might prevent the 0.001 percent that are?" She continues:

The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is announcing today that it will sponsor individual candidate forums for its members, beginning with one featuring Senator Chris Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, in Sacramento (corrected, it's not San Francisco) on April 29.
“Accomplice: New York” audiences meet characters at several Manhattan locales.

In my day job, running a small company, I have to deal with contracts fairly often. Our clients ask us to sign confidentiality agreements; there are frequently complex retainer agreements; and we're always managing equipment leases, vendor agreements and the other legal minutiae that come with being in business. (For example, when we moved into our offices six years ago, we signed a 10-year, multimillion-dollar lease.)

Research In Motion's BlackBerry service is an indispensable tool for many Wall Street workers, but it came up short this morning when many customers in North America were cut off from their e-mail. It was not immediately clear how many people were affected by the problems, which began late Tuesday, when certain users found themselves unable to receive messages on the devices.
Even a whale seems to know enough not to stray into the Gowanus Canal, although this one came close, frolicking near its mouth.

Dana Milbank of The Washington Post captures the tone here in the capital in response to the Virginia Tech shootings: "The nation's leaders wanted to act, but they had no obvious course of action." The White House canceled events; Congress canceled some hearings, including the testimony of Alberto Gonzales, the embattled attorney general. Some Democrats called for new gun restrictions, but responses were tepid from the party leadership and dismissive from newer, more moderate members.

In the most recent issue of Newsweek, the California Governor Arnold Schwarznegger talks about the fact that he now owns both biodiesel and hydrogen-powered Hummers, in order to limit CO2 emissions of these normally gas guzzling monsters. He recently appeared on a show where a '65 Chevy Impala's 800-horsepower engine was overhauled to run on biofuel. "That was the point of the show," he told Newsweek, "To show people that biofeul is not like some wimpy feminine car like a hybrid."

An American massacre, not a Korean one: Virginia Tech shooter Seung-hui Cho "came to the U.S. when he was 8 years old and, at the time of his death, was 23 and an English major at Virginia Tech," writes Edward Taehan Chang, a professor of ethnic studies at the Universit of California-Riverside, on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. "In other words, he probably spoke fluent English and was culturally Americanized." He also writes:
Coverage of Mr. Cho's Manifesto Continues Here
The scene on campus when, one day after the shooting, Virginia Tech students gathered for a candlelight vigil.

As Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone service provider, was admitting that its legal woes could lead to bankruptcy, industry watchers were debating the merits of a takeover of the company by Sprint-Nextel.

A hedge fund manager Farallon Capital Management said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the manufactured-home unit of Affordable Residential Communities for $1.8 billion. Farallon already owns 10 pecent of Affordable Residential, which owns and operates about 57,264 home sites in 275 communities in 23 states. Analysts said the deal could help Farallon benefit from the downturn in the subprime lending market.

Offering further proof that a real estate slowdown has not hampered property deal making, the Lightstone Group agreed on Tuesday to purchase Extended Stay Hotels from the Blackstone Group for $8 billion. The deal establishes Lightstone as the dominant company in a fast-growing market for travelers seeking long-term accommodations.

Nikki Giovanni is a noted poet, a popular professor at Virginia Tech and one of Oprah's 25 "living legends." She also may be the first at the university to express serious concerns about Cho Seung-Hui.

A well-known Greenwich hedge fund is getting into the subprime mortgage business in a big way. The New York Post reports that Ellington Capital Management is in the process of finalizing an agreement with Fremont General to buy $2.9 billion worth of loans and the distressed lender's real estate business, including its mortgage bond investments and loan origination platform.

Sweden's billionaire Wallenberg family is leading a group that may sell Gambro Healthcare, an owner of dialysis clinics in 15 countries, Bloomberg News reported. Bloomberg said the Gambro unit, which has 160 clinics that treat about 13,000 patients, might be worth $800 million. Goldman Sachs has reportedly been hired to review potential offers.

Lehman Brothers said it had appointed Kunho Cho as the firm's first Asia-based vice chairman. Mr. Cho, who has been with Lehman Brothers since 1989, previously led the company's investment-banking division in the Asia-Pacific region and has been involved in major financing transactions in South Korea, China and Japan.

Orica, a diversified manufacturer, rejected a takeover bid worth 9.95 billion Australian dollars ($8.3 billion) from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and the Blackstone Group as too low. The buyout firms offered 32 Australian dollars a share, 15 percent more than Orica's closing price Tuesday. Shares in the company, which is based in Melbourne, surged to a record on speculation the bidders might raise their price.

The steel manufacturer Steel Dynamics might have an interest in acquiring the Canadian steel pipe maker Ipsco. At least its chief executive, Keith Busse, did not rule it out when he had the opportunity on Tuesday.

The announcement Tuesday that BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, was in buyout discussions with three Canadian pension funds and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is the latest move in what could be the biggest takeover battle in Canadian history.

J.P. Morgan Chase said its profit jumped 55 percent from a year ago to $4.8 billion in the first quarter, a record for the firm. It also raised its stock dividend by 12 percent, marking the firm's first dividend increase in six years.

Mandriva, a struggling French seller of the Linux operating system, is in the process of raising "a minimum of 3 million euros," or $4.1 million, the company said Monday. The funds will be used to exit bankruptcy protection and to complete the acquisition of a server software company, Linbox.

Adding more fuel to the fire of speculation that the Carlyle Group may take itself public in the near future, the private equity firm's co-founder, Daniel D'Aniello, said Tuesday that the buyout shop has been considering an initial public offering for some time.

As DealBook noted earlier this week, news that Sallie Mae has accepted a $25 billion buyout spelled trouble for student-loan business First Marblehead. It also may cause some serious problems for a hedge fund, Second Curve Capital.

Are Terry Semel's days numbered? As Yahoo delivered a disappointing set of first quarter results and the good news that investors expected from company's Panama project -- the nickname for the firm's major overhaul of its search advertising system -- was not yet a reality, some industry watchers speculated that it may be curtains for the chief executive.

The Italian government, fresh from having dissuaded AT&T from investing about 2 billion euros to buy a 6 percent stake in Telecom Italia, made a call on Tuesday for Italian companies to band together to buy the troubled telecommunications company from the controlling shareholder, Pirelli.

The market cheered the withdrawal of the Carlyle Group's $5.5 billion bid for the world's largest computer-chip tester, Advanced Semiconductor Engineering. The announcement late Tuesday night that the buyout shop had abandoned its bid sent Advanced Semiconductor's shares up 7 percent.
Vivendi's Universal Music Group is closer to winning European Union approval to buy BMG Music Publishing from Bertelsmann after EU antitrust officials backed the deal, Bloomberg News reported.

The biopharmaceutical firm NeurogesX is seeking to raise $60 million in its initial public offering on the Nasdaq. The company said Tuesday it expects to sell 4 million shares priced at $13 to $15 a share. Morgan Stanley, Pacific Growth Equities, Lazard Capital Markets and Susquehanna Financial Group are underwriting the I.P.O.
On the Upper East Side, a shiny disco ball of a show house.

Companies are increasingly being urged to listen more closely to shareholders. There could be such a thing as too much. In sharp contrast to the Home Depot annual meeting last May that investors decried as unresponsive, Citigroup's session yesterday dragged on, writes The New York Times' Eric Dash. And on. And on.

In an effort to keep a rival consortium at bay, ABN Amro and Barclays have extended the period of their exclusive takeover discussions until the end of Friday. The banks said Tuesday that they were continuing their exclusive talks, which were initially scheduled to end Wednesday after 30 days, and were working on a combination agreement. They added that there was still "no certainty" that the discussions would lead to a transaction.

A co-defendant of the former media mogul Conrad M. Black was so determined to follow securities law that he "spent a lot of money" to seek a second opinion on whether certain payments at the heart of the trial had to be publicly disclosed, a defense lawyer said on Tuesday.

A top lawmaker said Tuesday that the House Judiciary Committee is working on legislation to rein in compensation and bonuses paid to executives of bankrupt companies. Rules for bonuses to such executives were revamped in 2005, but many companies have found ways around the restrictions in the revised bankruptcy code, lawyers say.

Facing mounting opposition, two private equity firms raised their offer for Clear Channel Communications by more than $1.5 billion Tuesday, to about $27.6 billion, The New York Times reported. The sweetened bid from Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners came 24 hours ahead of a crucial vote by shareholders, who were expected to reject the offer.
Seung-Hui Cho, the gunman responsible for the shootings at Virginia Tech, mailed photographs, video and writings to NBC News.
Visions of nature wrought in meta find a habitat in Chelsea, well-seasoned works to place among the blooms and more.
Ideas from the show house to take home.
Heather Gollnick, Ironman winner, test sunscreens.
Students are mourning their friends and teachers who were killed, and many of them have left the Virginia Tech campus to stay elsewhere.
The seventh entry in PBS’s series about the post-9/11 world makes a rather dull documentary out of the complex warp of Islamic life in the U.S.

“Head Case,” which features Alexandra Wentworth as a shrink for the known but barely employed, reminds us that celebrities whose fortunes have dwindled seem to have an endless capacity to make fun of themselves.
It was the deadliest day in Baghdad since the U.S.-led security plan for the city took effect two months ago.
At these restaurants, it is possible to eat well in London without spending a week's salary.
Weekend visitors to Dublin can indulge in the offerings of an ancient city with a cosmopolitan face-lift.

Lauren Ashley McCain was a victim in Monday's shooting at Virginia Tech. Please share your memories and thoughts here.

Even if Billy Wagner will be remembered for being a small guy with a huge fastball, he is doing his best to change his legacy. In Wagner's five appearances, he has struck out two batters (Ryan Howard and Pat Burrell) ­and that was in the same game, April 9 against the Phillies. The strikeouts are not the only numbers that are down; so are his walks (none) and earned run average (0.00), and Wagner said that was hardly a coincidence.
“Tie Xi Qu: West of Tracks” is an astonishingly intimate record of China’s painful transition from state-run industry to a free market.
Alejandro Jodorowsky’s  “Holy Mountain” is a dazzling, rambling, often incoherent satire on consumerism, militarism and exploitation.
The jury convicted Joseph P. Nacchio on 19 of 42 insider trading counts related to his sale of Qwest stock in 2001.
Breast cancer rates fell sharply in 2003, and then held steady at the lower rate in 2004, researchers are reporting.
Kitty Carlisle Hart began her career in the theater in a 1932 musical comedy revue on Broadway and acted in films.
The trooper has been involved in four other vehicle accidents, two while on duty, according to records of the State Police.
Koreans were stunned and ashamed to learn that the gunman responsible for the shooting was a South Korean.
The increase, which will take effect on June 1, is the third since 2002 and brings rates on New Jersey Transit trains closer to the higher fares charged by Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road.
The 5 to 4 ruling that a ban on a controversial abortion procedure does not violate the Constitution was a major victory for the anti-abortion movement.
Republicans in the Senate argued that private insurers were already negotiating large discounts for Medicare beneficiaries.
A flurry of insurgent attacks included car bombs that tore through predominantly Shiite crowds at a bus hub.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates called today for Iraq to make “faster progress” on Sunni-Shia reconciliation.

NAGASAKI, Japan, April 18 — The mayor of the southern Japanese city of Nagasaki died on Wednesday after being gunned down in what appeared to be a murky gang-related killing, shocking a nation where crime rates are low and shootings extremely rare.
The juvenile minke whale appeared to be in good health and had moved away from the canal entrance today.
The board chose Mark Everson, the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, as its new chief executive.
A body believed to be that of an American Peace Corps volunteer was found today in a mountainous province in the north of the Philippines, officials said.
Cho Seung-Hui apparently mailed the materials between the two attacks at Virginia Tech that killed 33 people.
Philippine authorities found the body of a missing American Peace Corps volunteer in a northern mountain town where she disappeared.
Daisuke Matsuzaka struck out 10 over six innings but forced in the go-ahead run with a bases-loaded walk to Gregg Zaun in the fourth inning.
Tom Glavine allowed just six hits in six innings, as the Mets took advantage of the Phillies’ mistakes all night.
Chase Wright’s teammates scored eight runs in the first two innings, as the Yankees beat the Cleveland Indians Tuesday, 10-3.
The Internet phone service provider said its recent legal woes over patents could lead to bankruptcy.
A former vice president of Hollinger International asked a law firm for advice on whether the company needed to publicly disclose payments.
Big names turned out to remember Ahmet Ertegun — the diplomat’s son, record-business mogul, jazz fan and prime mover in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
The continued introduction of Coke Zero helped bolster sales in many countries, allaying investors’ concerns that the soft drink business was stagnant.
After a commanding victory behind Michael Nylander’s hat trick, the Rangers can sweep the Thrashers in their first-round series with another win Wednesday night.
Two private equity firms raised their offer for Clear Channel by more than $1.5 billion, to about $27.6 billion.

New York State has settled a lawsuit over its treatment of mentally ill prisoners, agreeing to end 23-hour-a-day solitary confinement and limiting the use of a bread-and-cabbage diet and other punishments. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan in 2002 by several prisoners’ rights groups against the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki, claimed that the state had failed to provide the treatment the prisoners needed and that solitary confinement had led to severe psychiatric deterioration, self-mutilation and suicide. The agreement with the administration of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, which still requires court approval, means that the mentally ill who are confined to special housing units will get at least two hours of treatment outside their cells each day and as many as four hours’ additional recreation time. As attorney general, Mr. Spitzer represented the Pataki administration in the case, but he said last year that he would not hesitate to change course as governor.

The driver of a sport utility vehicle crammed with suspected illegal immigrants was groping a woman when he lost control and crashed, killing eight men, the authorities said. That contradicts the driver’s claim that he was trying to avoid an animal when his Chevy Suburban rolled. “The passengers say no, he wasn’t swerving to miss a horse, that he was fondling a female passenger in the front seat of the vehicle,” Sgt. Rick Eldredge of the Utah Highway Patrol told The Salt Lake Tribune in an article posted on its Web site. The driver was charged with one count of transporting illegal immigrants resulting in death.
A House panel is considering granting limited immunity from prosecution to force testimony by a former aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales about the dismissals of eight United States attorne
A state appeals court upheld a lower court ruling that a law designed to give Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa of Los Angeles partial authority over schools is unconstitutional.
Two Secret Service officers were injured on the White House grounds after a gun accidentally fired, said a spokesman for the service, Darrin Blackford.

An article in Business Day on Monday about a new health information Web site, RevolutionHealth.com, misstated the contribution of various investors in Revolution Health Group, which operates the site. The business’s founder and chairman, Stephen M. Case, has put $100 million of his own money into Revolution Health Group, and his other board members have invested about $30 million. Mr. Case and the investors have not contributed $500 million to Revolution Health Group. (Mr. Case has put about $500 million of his own money into the various business ventures, including the health group, that operate under his holding company Revolution L.L.C.).

An article in Business Day on Saturday about a medical procedure known as hip resurfacing, an alternative to a standard hip replacement, misstated the duration of hip replacement surgery. It generally requires an hour to 90 minutes — not three to four hours, which would include the time spent in the recovery room. Because of an editing error, the article also misspelled the name of a hospital affiliated with the New York University Medical Center. It is Tisch Hospital, not Ticsch.

The Sports of The Times column on Sunday, about Jessica Long, a 15-year-old swimmer who became the first Paralympic athlete to win the Sullivan Award, given by the Amateur Athletic Union, misidentified her primary coach and misstated the age of her brother Joshua. Her coach is Andrew Barranco — not Stephanie Weisenborn, who used to coach her. Joshua is 17, not 14.

An article in The Arts on Monday about the final night of the Lower East Side club Tonic misidentified the radio station where Daniel Blumin, who spoke about his experiences at the club, was once host of a show. It was WNYU, not WNYC.

A film review in Weekend on Friday about “Lonely Hearts” referred incorrectly to the suicide of the wife of the central character, the detective Elmer Robinson. She shoots herself; she does not slash her wrists.
Corrections
An obituary on Saturday about Reginald H. Fuller, a biblical scholar, misidentified the Cambridge college from which he earned his undergraduate degree. It is Peterhouse, not Queens’ College.

An article on April 9 about the growing pains experienced by Washington Township, N.J., home to a “smart growth” planned development, referred imprecisely to taxes in the township relative to those in Alpine, N.J. The average tax bill is higher in Alpine, but Alpine’s tax rate — the amount per $100 of assessed value — is in fact lower than Washington’s, not higher.

An article on Saturday about a lottery by immigration authorities to select applicants for 65,000 visas for highly skilled foreign workers misstated the requirements employers must meet in order to sponsor the visas, known as H-1B. For most of these visas, employers must affirm to the Labor Department that they will pay the immigrant at least the prevailing wage for the job and that hiring the immigrant would not negatively affect the labor conditions of United States workers in similar jobs. Employers do not have to show that no American workers were available for the job.
Virginia Tech officials were pursuing what appears to have been a fruitless lead after the first shooting when the second began.
The Lightstone Group agreed to purchase Extended Stay Hotels from a private equity giant, the Blackstone Group.
Anton Volchenkov’s slap shot from the slot midway through the third period last night helped the Ottawa Senators to a 2-1 victory over the Penguins in Pittsburgh.
Cho Seung-Hui rarely spoke to his own roommate and teachers were disturbed by his violent writings.
Remembering some of the students and faculty members killed in the Virginia Tech shootings, in these biographical sketches.
The legal purchase of the guns used in the shooting at Virginia Tech is drawing attention to the state’s gun laws.

A disregard for safety in the interest of profit very likely caused the explosion in a Siberian mine last month that killed 108 people, the biggest mine disaster in Russia’s recent history, officials said. They said that the mine’s management deliberately disabled a methane detector, among other safety violations. A buildup of methane, sparked by a short circuit, caused the blast. The governor of the Kemerovo region, Aman-Geldi M. Tuleyev, said the managers defied safety regulations to increase production.

The German Army dismissed an instructor who was filmed in a training exercise telling a recruit to imagine he was firing his machine gun at African-Americans in the Bronx. The Defense Ministry said the instructor, a lance corporal, had been stripped of his rank and pay. The soldier who filmed the scenes with his camera phone is still under investigation.

Israeli forces shot and killed a militant belonging to the radical Islamic Jihad group south of Jenin in the West Bank, Israeli security officials said. An army spokesman said troops identified Ashraf Haneisheh, who was wanted by Israel, and shot him after he drew his handgun. Palestinian news reports identified Mr. Haneisheh as a member of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades and said he had been “executed” by an Israeli undercover special unit. Earlier in the day, Palestinian militants slightly wounded four Israelis in a drive-by shooting near the Jewish settlement of Modi’in Ilit. Al Aksa Martyrs claimed responsibility for the attack.

Specialist Mario Lozano, the American Army soldier who fired on a car carrying Nicola Calipari, left, the deputy chief of Italian military intelligence, and Giuliana Sgrena, an Italian journalist rescued earlier after a month as an insurgent hostage in Iraq in 2005, went on trial in absentia in Rome. The trial was immediately adjourned until May 14 for technical reasons. Specialist Lozano, 37, is charged with voluntary homicide in the death of Mr. Calipari, who shielded the journalist during the shooting and is regarded as a hero, and with intent to kill in the wounding of Ms. Sgrena and another Italian agent. In interviews, Specialist Lozano has said the car was traveling too fast as it approached a roadblock on the way to Baghdad airport and did not respond to warning shots. In a report, the United States military cleared American soldiers of any responsibility.

The government appeared to revoke the legal basis for all nongovernmental organizations to operate inside the country, arguing that some of the groups have provided cover for Western governments seeking to overthrow Robert G. Mugabe, the nation’s autocratic president. The state-run broadcaster Zimbabwe Television said the revocations would give officials time to “screen out agents of imperialism from genuine organizations working to uplift the well-being of the poor.” Mr. Mugabe has often accused private nongovernmental organizations of secretly channeling aid to the Movement for Democratic Change, the lone opposition party of note inside the country.

Two separate coal mine accidents have trapped 45 workers underground, the official Xinhua news agency said, chronicling the latest tragedies to hit the world’s deadliest coal mining industry. Nine of 42 miners escaped after an explosion late Monday at the private Wangzhuang colliery in Henan Province, the report said. The condition of the remaining 33 was “unclear,” it said. The mine owner fled after the accident, making it difficult for experts to map out rescue plans. Also on Monday, a pit flooded in Zhuzhou, in Hunan Province, trapping 12 coal miners, Xinhua said. It said rainy weather had hampered water-pumping efforts. Last year, 4,746 coal miners were killed in thousands of accidents.

Former Prime Minister Khaleda Zia, left, agreed to go into self-exile in Saudi Arabia after the military-backed interim government released her younger son from police custody. Senior government officials were widely quoted in press reports as saying Mrs. Zia would leave in the coming days as part of a deal in return for leniency for her two sons, both of whom are facing corruption charges. Her elder son, arrested last month, remains in custody. Mrs. Zia, herself under virtual house arrest since last week, was prime minister until her five-year term ended in October. She and her political archrival, former Prime Minister Sheik Hasina Wazed, have been blamed for steering the country into political chaos. Last week, while on a visit to the United States, Sheik Hasina was charged with murder and extortion. The authorities warned that she faced arrest if she dared to return home.
A new analysis claims the benefits of antidepressants in children and teenagers trump a small risk that they will experience increased suicidal thoughts and behavior.
A German class at Virginia Tech appears to be where the gunman exacted his greatest toll.
Officials were concerned that marketers were improperly obtaining private information on potential borrowers.

SAN JOSE, Calif., April 17 (AP) — Most of the Nashville Predators did not participate in an optional team skate Tuesday. Instead, they attended meetings and rested in their hotel after a tough night at the Shark Tank.
Since Madison Square Garden chairman James L. Dolan announced a contract extension for Isiah Thomas, the Knicks’ coach and president, the team has lost 15 of 18 games.
Five years after he was convicted of killing his neighbor, Martha Moxley, as a teenager in Greenwich, Conn., in 1975, Michael C. Skakel is seeking a new trial.
New health statistics from the World Health Organization quantifies just how desperate the situation has become for Iraqis.
After years as a symbol of government sloth, the levee board is pushing the Army Corps of Engineers to fortify the city.
Several experts said that the nearly three-hour delay between shootings  on the Virginia Tech campus may have been a matter of nerves, or practical necessity.
Despite their differences, a father and son from a high-profile political family in the Bronx are extremely close.
Dozens of correction officials and experts converged yesterday on the first and only public hearing to debate a plan to revise the standards that govern New York City’s jails.
The economy remains on an even keel, with inflation showing signs of easing and growth not slipping too far.
The marine was one of the four charged with murder in the killings of 24 Iraqi civilians in Haditha, Iraq, in 2005.

Rich Little, who will headline at the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner this weekend, has said he will avoid delivering the type of stinging performance Stephen Colbert delivered last year.
Analysts say the flurry of diplomatic attention signals the beginning of the countdown to independence for Kosovo.
Derek Jeter has committed six errors in the first 12 games. Yet he stressed that his pregame preparation was unrelated to the problems he has endured at shortstop.
Chinese companies are finding their fastest growth in the world’s rapidly growing economies, not the United States.

Larry Hughes scored 22 points and LeBron James had 18 to lead Cleveland to a 98-92 victory over the host Philadelphia 76ers last night, keeping the Cavaliers alive for the second seed in the Eastern Conference playoffs.
It was the first time that a senior U.S. official had asserted that Iranian weapons were being supplied to the Taliban.
The trooper driving Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey said he didn’t know how fast he was going.
Efficiency and economy are likely to be the first casualties in the Army budget standoff between the White House and Congress.
Earnings appeared to reassure investors that the company’s profit margins were finally starting to improve.
Mardy Collins’s recent emergence as a shooter has been a rare bright spot for the Knicks. Yet Renaldo Balkman and David Lee still lack an outside shot that opponents respect.
The Lightning, led by its superlative center, Vincent Lecavalier, has put three pucks past Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur in each game of this series, taking a 2-1 lead.
Two classmates from Westfield High School in Virginia died in the Virginia Tech shootings. Their killer, Cho Seung-Hui, was also a graduate.
The Texans were second-guessed and publicly criticized for their 2006 draft choice.  Now with a new front office in place, there will be less pressure when the Texans pick 10th.
GoodWorks International has become a lightning rod in Nigeria as the country prepares to elect a new president.
A U.N. report says the military equipment is being flown into Darfur in violation of Security Council resolutions.
China faced off with Britain in the first Security Council debate on climate change, saying the 15-member body had no competence to deal with it.
Higher revenue from its Web businesses helped offset a 1.8 percent decline in ad revenue at The Wall Street Journal in the United States.
An anticipated spring offensive by insurgents has not materialized on a large scale, a NATO commander said.
ALBANY, April 17 — Campaign-finance reform tops Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s agenda for the rest of the legislative session, which has two more months to run.

New York State is failing to harvest as many trees from its state forests as it could each year and is losing almost $5 million annually in possible income as a result, State Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli said yesterday. The program, which involves about 762,000 acres of state forest, is intended to keep the forest healthy while producing income for the state. Mr. DiNapoli said the state should consider hiring more foresters. State environmental officials agreed with the comptroller’s recommendations, but said the amount of cutting should be viewed as a limit and not as a harvesting goal.

The head of the agency coordinating more than 60 construction projects around the World Trade Center site resigned yesterday after two years in office. The chief, Charles J. Maikish, executive director of the Lower Manhattan Construction Command Center, said he had agreed to stay for two years, and wanted to return to the private sector. Mr. Maikish, previously with JPMorgan Chase and Columbia University, said he would stay until July. Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, praised Mr. Maikish’s hard work and dedication.

A man halted the opening of his murder trial yesterday by admitting that he fatally shot his pregnant sister-in-law on Feb. 21, 2005, and hid her body in the trunk of her car in Jamaica, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Schiovone, 37, of Levittown, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to first-degree manslaughter, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Schiovone admitted that he shot Susan Ambrosino, 26, of Franklin Square, as they sat in her car. Prosecutors say he shot Ms. Ambrosino because she planned to tell her ex-husband, Mr. Schiovone’s brother, that Mr. Schiovone was the father of her unborn child. Mr. Schiovone is expected to be sentenced to 30 years in prison.

Seventeen people said to be members of a Plainfield street gang have been arrested and charged with offenses including racketeering, weapons possession and drug charges, Union County officials said yesterday. Early Monday morning, agents with the Union County prosecutor’s office and state troopers raided 19 sites in Plainfield, Piscataway and Scotch Plains, the prosecutor, Theodore J. Romankow, said. The gang, known as the Clinton Avenue Posse, was responsible for street violence and drug dealing in the Plainfield area, Mr. Romankow said. Officials said that the police seized nine guns along with heroin and cocaine during the raids.

Federal prosecutors are seeking a 10-year prison term for a former officer in the Philippine National Police who pleaded guilty to possessing secret United States government documents. as part of an effort to undermine political opponents in the Philippines. In a 97-page memo filed on Monday in Federal District Court, prosecutors said the former officer, Michael Ray Aquino, caused serious disruption to the United States government. Mr. Aquino, 41, a native Filipino, admitted accepting documents from a civilian F.B.I. employee, Leandro Aragoncillo, as part of an effort to undermine political opponents in the Philippines. Mr. Aragoncillo has also pleaded guilty, admitting that he passed the documents to Mr. Aquino and to opposition politicians in the Philippines.

The World Trade Center Memorial Foundation has raised more than $300 million toward its $350 million goal, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday, with more than $165 million raised since he took over as chairman of the foundation roughly six months ago. The money, which includes gifts from across the country and overseas, is to pay capital and planning costs as well as an endowment to operate the memorial and museum. Officials announced yesterday that the foundation board had selected Thinc Design as the lead exhibition design firm.

A pilot who took off from Westchester County Airport in White Plains on April 4 reported lightning and an unspecified problem before his plane crashed in Maryland this month while he was flying to North Carolina on a golf trip, federal investigators say. The pilot, Gregory Doppke of Greenwich, Conn., reported lightning to air traffic controllers, according to a report from the National Transportation Safety Board. “We just, uh, we got a problem. Looks like we just lost ... we lost altitude,” Mr. Doppke said in his last radio transmission, according to the report. Mr. Doppke, Richard Lomas of Stamford, Conn., and Andrew Young of Mahopac, N.Y., died in the crash.

Marine biologists were checking reports yesterday that a whale was swimming off the Brooklyn shore of New York Harbor, although it was not known whether the animal was in distress. The police said a police boat was standing by. The whale was reported to be swimming near Pier 22 in Sunset Park. WCBS reported that its helicopter had spotted the 15-foot minke whale and had taped it jumping out of the water several times.
Yankees Manager Joe Torre hinted strongly that Jeff Karstens would pitch Saturday afternoon against the Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park.

A man found lying on the side of the road on Sunday after being dragged by a sport utility vehicle for about three-quarters of a mile was in stable condition at Stony Brook University Medical Center yesterday. The state police said that the man, Anselmo Chin-Sabam, 22, of Flanders, was hit in a parking lot behind Crystal’s Bar in Riverhead early Sunday morning. The driver, Alejandro Xuya-Sian, 27, who was charged with drunken driving, told the police he had not realized that he struck anyone, although he heard a rubbing noise from under the vehicle, the police said. He pleaded not guilty.

The actor Rip Torn pleaded guilty on Monday night to driving while his ability was impaired, and agreed to pay $380 and surrender his license for 90 days, said Trish Rubino, a clerk at North Salem Town Court. Mr. Torn, 76, who won an Emmy Award for playing a producer on “The Larry Sanders Show,” was arrested in December after his car hit a tractor-trailer on Hardscrabble Road in North Salem. He was charged with driving while intoxicated and was to go on trial in June.
Universities responded to security threats even as officials said that it was almost impossible to prevent a shooting by a deranged student.
With one devastating act, 32 people from places as far apart as Romania, Peru and Nova Scotia were united in a horrifying fate.
Companies are increasingly being urged to listen more closely to shareholders. There could be such a thing as too much.
If statements from FIFA headquarters in Zurich are credible, Brazil will be awarded the 2014 World Cup later this year — probably.
J. Christopher Flowers, the architect of the $25 billion deal to take Sallie Mae private, has had a history of daring financial challenges.
Gerald P. Garson, a former State Supreme Court justice, is accused of taking cash and gifts to manipulate divorce cases.
G.M.’s chief executive hailed India’s growing car market and said the company would increase purchasing and production in the country.
The company’s strategic shift toward higher-margin software and services is making gradual progress.
The protest to force the governor of Basra to step down could throw the already unsettled southern city into turmoil.
Just when it looked as if the Iraqi government had sunk as low as it could go, it sank still further, following a brazen power play by Moktada al-Sadr.

The House is right to confront the gross injustice that keeps the citizenry of the District of Columbia locked into that definitive grievance of the American revolution: taxation without representation.
The New York City region took stock and mopped up on Tuesday from the rainiest April storm on record.
Congress should make it a federal crime for lenders to offer college officials anything of value in exchange for the right to do business at a given school.

I have been taking lessons for the past couple of months because tennis is so Californian, because the world will soon be nothing but asphalt, and because I have not spent enough of my life using the hand-eye reflexes that are such a pleasure to use.
A big charge for a recent acquisition offset record sales driven by last year’s purchase of a stable of top consumer health products.
Problems with subprime mortgages weighed on earnings at regional banks that reported their first-quarter results.
Sammy Sosa tuned out the boos and showed Chicago what it has been missing the last few years.
Goodby, Silverstein.
A surprise increase in Britain’s inflation rate spurred expectations the Bank of England would raise interest rates at least once more this year.

ALBANY, April 17 — Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver directed $7.3 million in grants to community organizations for the current fiscal year, according to an analysis of documents released by his office on Tuesday.
Billy Wagner has learned to value efficiency more than showmanship and is more than happy to sacrifice strikeouts if that means keeping his pitch count down.
The experiences of a pair of New Yorkers illustrate the frustrations of adult illiteracy and also the relief that properly run adult education programs can bring.
A program has grown from a neighborhood project into one of the largest mentoring programs for Asian-Americans in New York City.
Mr. Spizz was a tough-talking, cigar-chewing artisan of smoked fish whose work was enshrined behind glass at some of New York’s best-known food shops.
Hans Koning’s outpouring of more than 40 fiction and nonfiction books ranged from exotic travel to erotic trauma to a withering indictment of Christopher Columbus.
Many of the dwindling number of mobile home parks in the New York suburbs are being snapped up by developers.
Dick Allen was a jazz historian whose scholarly command of the traditional New Orleans sound was matched only by his role as a French Quarter character.
The arrest was the second case of accusations of Israeli espionage announced by the Egyptian authorities this year.
The mortgage lending subsidiaries of national banks are immune from state regulation, the Supreme Court ruled.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the reopening of the Staten Island Railroad yesterday, an important step in his plan to transform the way the city disposes of the thousands of tons of garbage it collects daily.
Roy Moyer was a painter who helped bring works by other artists to museums across the United States.

An article on March 24 reported on a decision at a high school in Wilton, Conn., to cancel a play about the war in Iraq. It also discussed the involvement of Gabby Alessi-Friedlander, a junior, whose brother is serving in Iraq.
The Coast Guard announced that it was curtailing the role of two military contractors in its $24 billion fleet modernization project.
Now, for the first time, the Parks Department can actually translate the value of the city’s trees into real dollars and cents.
Brant Parker was a co-creator of “The Wizard of Id,” an award-winning comic strip that is set in medieval times and has poked fun at politics and cultural follies for more than 40 years.
Kmart is teaming up with Draft FCB, the agency that won — then lost — the creative account of its major competitor, Wal-Mart Stores.
A U.S. proposal to plant antimissile missiles in Poland is prompting European queasiness about American influence on the Continent.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,302 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
The activist, Cynthia Greenberg, had planned to offer as evidence a videotape of the encounter, which appears to show her being kneed in the head by a former police official.
About two million people in the world are receiving drugs for AIDS, an increase of 700,000 in the last year.
The approval by the F.D.A. means the vaccine is no longer considered experimental and therefore could be dispensed more quickly during a pandemic.
The Environmental Protection Agency will consider the environmental policies of hotels and convention centers when it considers places to stay.
How will the United States help those Iraqis whose belief in us cost them their country?
The last-minute maneuvering came amid a turbulent election season already marked by violence and fraud charges.
The group’s public rebuttal was a rare protest in a country where the prime minister’s remarks had stirred little outcry.
By re-recording decades-old hits, artists are keeping a much bigger share of licensing proceeds.
David Mamet sells “junk” to University of Texas, the Tucker Foundation and Met Opera mend split and more culture news.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
A $2.05 billion mixed-use project designed by Frank O. Gehry may provide the city with a vibrant focal point.
Revenue and income were below expectations, suggesting that an overhaul of the search advertising system has yet to deliver.
Farmers are raising veal more humanely these days, leading more chefs to include it on their menus — and giving the meat new character and flavor.
Olga Garay, former director of the arts program for the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation, has been nominated for the city’s top public arts post.
Over the last several years, architect Kevin Roche has been busy transforming the Met’s southernmost wing, which will officially open on Friday.
The early economic advisers to presidential candidates can leave a big imprint if their candidate prevails.
The Colombian forward, released from his contract with Aston Villa of the English Premier League, will be one of two Red Bulls players whose contract won’t count against the M.L.S. salary cap.
With the government cracking down on sidewalk cookery, and high-end restaurants serving snacks usually found only by the roadside, Indian street food is under threat.
“Trophy Wife,” a musical that opened Sunday at La MaMa E.T.C., is a bright, perky little piece based on Anton Chekhov’s “Anna on the Neck.”
In the hangarlike spaces of Earls Court One in west London, thousands of book editors, agents and scouts are able to indulge in their favorite pastime.

Hyundai Motor America today chose as its new creative advertising agency a shop with automotive experience for brands like Porsche, Saturn and Isuzu. Hyundai spends about $600 million a year on ads in major media.
The announcement marked the fourth time that Alfred A. Knopf has achieved a Pulitzer trifecta.
Julie Christie, who has grown disillusioned with the movies, makes a rare starring appearance in “Away From Her.”
Les Ballets Grandiva offered a program of parodies, including “Pas de Quatre,” “Spartacus” and Allen Dennis’s version of “Dying Swan.”
Jack Beatty’s “Age of Betrayal,” is an indignant history of the decades after the Civil War, a long nightmare of repression and racism from which the country, in his view, has never awakened.

One of the N.B.A.’s top referees was indefinitely suspended
for inappropriate behavior toward Tim Duncan.
Cherry Blossom Time.
Draft FCB will create advertising campaigns for television, radio and magazines.
A two-part series of short plays from the Naked Angels theater company tackles the war and its ripple effects on the culture.
On Monday at Merkin Concert Hall, the new-music ensemble Sequitur moved toward more accessible styles of composition, alternating melancholy with zest.

10 P.M. (AMC) HUSTLE California, here they come. Albert, the veteran grifter played by Robert Vaughn, above far right, and his London crew (played by, from left, Robert Glenister, Jaime Murray, Marc Warren and the newcomer Ashley Walters, not shown) cross the pond to begin a new season of scamming in Los Angeles and Las Vegas. Tonight the con artists try to convince a movie memorabilia fanatic (Robert Wagner, in a guest role) that the Hollywood sign is coming up for sale. Yeah, right.
The banks said that they are continuing their exclusive takeover talks until the end of Friday. A rival bid looms.
Adding to the Novice’s Wine List.
Charles Wuorinen’s Percussion Symphony brought an ebullient ebb and flow of texture and dynamic angular melodies to Alice Tully Hall.
News about two TriBeCa restaurants: 66 is transitioning into Matsu Gen, a japanese noodle spot, and Landmarc is opening an uptown branch in the Time Warner Center.
At Cafe Gratitude, a raw-food restaurant in San Francisco, every order is a self-affirmation.
The new film, “Waitress,” is an ode to pie — a love letter to the loft of a filling, the flake of a crust and the waves of a fluted rim.

A restaurant review last Wednesday of E.U., in the East Village, referred incorrectly to the beers served there. No beer from Denmark is available. The restaurant serves beer from the Czech Republic, not Czechoslovakia, which divided in 1993 to create the Czech Republic and Slovakia.
Hadaka in Los Angeles offers “body sushi,” meals served on scantily-clad models.
But gains excluding food and energy, which the Federal Reserve carefully monitors, slowed.

Order coffee at the Roasting Plant, 81 Orchard Street (Broome Street), and instead of a barista pulling levers to fill your cup, a clerk will touch a computer screen. The correct amount of whole coffee beans, roasted on the premises, right, will then whiz and clatter through a network of transparent plastic pipes overhead and drop into a compact countertop machine to be ground according to the type of coffee ordered. The beans are then brewed, in one seamless operation.

The government appeared to revoke the legal basis for all nongovernmental organizations to operate inside the country, arguing that some of the groups have provided cover for Western governments seeking to overthrow Robert G. Mugabe, the nation's autocratic president. The state-run broadcaster Zimbabwe Television said the revocations would give officials time to ''screen out agents of imperialism from genuine organizations working to uplift the well-being of the poor.'' Mr. Mugabe has often accused private nongovernmental organizations of secretly channeling aid to the Movement for Democratic Change, the lone opposition party of note inside the country. MICHAEL WINES

Who: David Mamet. What: scrawlings from a 1975 journal. ''David, you absolutely must complete a draft of Buffalo by 1 June. June. You want to be a pauper all your life?'' That and other intimate glimpses into the creative processes of Mr. Mamet, one of the nation's most acclaimed and prolific playwrights, is to be found in more than 100 boxes of diaries, manuscripts, drafts and production files just acquired from the author for an undisclosed sum by the Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center at the University of Texas in Austin. ''Why, I wondered, had I collected this mass of junk, none of which I ever wanted to see again?'' said Mr. Mamet, 59, famous for his brawny, clipped dialogue in scripts and screenplays including ''American Buffalo,'' ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' ''The Untouchables,'' ''The Spanish Prisoner'' and ''Wag the Dog.'' ''I dunno.'' But he said in a statement that he was flattered. ''Anybody who is interested in my work is 'O.K. with me.' '' RALPH BLUMENTHAL

Groups representing Michigan's public museums, theaters, music halls and other cultural institutions plan to rally at the state capital in Lansing today in hopes of lifting a freeze on state spending for the arts. The moratorium was ordered last month by the state's governor, Jennifer M. Granholm, as part of efforts to head off a $686 million budget deficit. State law requires that any deficit must be wiped out by the end of the state's fiscal year on Sept. 30. The governor's action affects about $7.5 million of $10 million in state aid that was to be paid to cultural institutions this year. Many institutions say they have already planned their budgets in the expectation of state funding, and the spending freeze is forcing some to cut programs and consider job reductions. In an e-mail message to contributors, the Michigan Theater in Ann Arbor, which has lost $42,000 in state funding, said it was eliminating its Cinema Slam, a monthly showcase for short films. But some Michigan legislators already are proposing cuts in state arts spending for the next fiscal year, when the state's budget crisis is likely to deepen. MICHELINE MAYNARD

WILKIE--George Hamilton, 75, died on April 14, 2007, of cancer after a short illness. Husband of the late Suzannah Ryan Wilkie, he is survived by his children, Angus Wilkie of New York, NY, Austin Wilkie of New York, NY, and Serena Wilkie Gifford of Cambridge, MA, and by his grandchildren, Suzannah Gifford and Abbott Gifford. Born in Tamsui, Formosa, he was a graduate of Williams College, Harvard Medical School and New York Psychoanalytic Institute. He practiced psychoanalysis privately in Manhattan for over 40 years, while also serving as Associate Professor of Psychiatry on the faculty at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. In summer months, he was president of Lac a Gravel trout fishing club in Charlevoix, Quebec, and organist at Murray Bay Protestant Church. Work and family were his music; his concise judgments and succinct wit in all endeavors will be long-remembered. Contributions to: Friends of the Murray Bay Protestant Church, Box 216, Pointe-auPic, PQ G0T 1M0, Canada, or Suzannah Ryan Wilkie Memorial Scholarship Fund, St. Bernards School, 4 East 98th Street, New York, NY 10029.

Seventeen people said to be members of a Plainfield street gang have been arrested and charged with offenses including racketeering, weapons possession and drug charges, Union County officials said yesterday. Early Monday morning, agents with the Union County prosecutor's office and state troopers raided 19 sites in Plainfield, Piscataway and Scotch Plains, the prosecutor, Theodore J. Romankow, said. The gang, known as the Clinton Avenue Posse, was responsible for street violence and drug dealing in the Plainfield area, Mr. Romankow said. Officials said that the police seized nine guns along with heroin and cocaine during the raids. JOHN HOLL

LEWITT--Sol. The New School and the Board of Trustees mourn the passing of our friend Sol LeWitt. Mr. LeWitt's generous gifts to the University's Art Collection enhance our tradition of the importance of contemporary art in the life of an educated citizenry. His well-known support of younger artists also is a wonderful testament for the new generation of artists and designers studying at the university. We are privileged to be able to benefit from this legacy and live with his vital works of art. Bob Kerrey, President, The New School Philip Scaturro, Chair, Board of Trustees

An article on Saturday about a lottery by immigration authorities to select applicants for 65,000 visas for highly skilled foreign workers misstated the requirements employers must meet in order to sponsor the visas, known as H-1B. For most of these visas, employers must affirm to the Labor Department that they will pay the immigrant at least the prevailing wage for the job and that hiring the immigrant would not negatively affect the labor conditions of United States workers in similar jobs. Employers do not have to show that no American workers were available for the job.

THE most successful animal rights boycott in the United States started more than 20 years ago and had nothing to do with foie gras. When photographs of formula-fed veal calves tethered in crates where they could not turn around appeared across the country, sales of veal plummeted. They have never recovered. In the 1950s and 1960s Americans ate four pounds of veal a year on average. Today per capital consumption is around half a pound a year.
