An article on April 9 about the growing pains experienced by Washington Township, N.J., home to a ''smart growth'' planned development, referred imprecisely to taxes in the township relative to those in Alpine, N.J. The average tax bill is higher in Alpine, but Alpine's tax rate -- the amount per $100 of assessed value -- is in fact lower than Washington's, not higher.

Pistahan, 229 First Avenue (14th Street), is a friendly newcomer to a part of town that already has a few examples of its Filipino cuisine, a blend of Latino and Southeast Asian. This spot, whose name means festival, has a counter crammed with dishes like kalderetang, beef stewed in brown sauce, and binagoongan, vegetables in a thick sauce. All are sold to go, around $5 a pint, or to eat at a few cafe tables. The owners, including Rodil Santos, will patiently explain the dishes, but some need no introduction, like lechón, roast pork with a tangy sauce. A separate counter is filled with desserts like flan and cassava cake: (212) 228-9000.

A Cuddle Party in an East Village apartment. The concept involves a workshop that provides a drug- and alcohol-free environment where people meet to explore communication, boundaries, intimacy and nonsexual touch and expressions of affection. The promoters maintain that such an atmosphere might just help restore a participant's faith in humanity, or at least provide a relaxing, enjoyable experience.

When Kim Melrose looked out at the backyard of his vacation home in Rancho Mirage, Calif., he envisioned more than a swimming pool, a grill and a couple of lounge chairs on the patio. He saw the yard as the hub for entertaining -- and living. So he added an outdoor kitchen with a double sink, a dishwasher, a built-in grill, a full-size refrigerator, a bar with seven stools, and a sheltered outdoor living room complete with a wood-burning fireplace, a television and plush seating covered with a waterproof and fade-resistant version of a chenille-like fabric. The project took a year and a half.

Is it worth $9.99 to have someone buy and cook short ribs, shred them, season them with chipotle, arbol and pasilla chilies, mix them with slices of nopales (cactus paddles), fill two soft tortillas with the mixture and slather them with a rich sauce so you can have beef short rib enchiladas with salsa mestiza and cactus for dinner? That is one of eight prepared, ready-to-microwave main dishes devised by Roberto Santibañez, the culinary director of the Rosa Mexicano chain, and available online from FreshDirect. The enchiladas are excellent. Moist turbot and rice in a lusty Vera Cruz-style sauce ($9.99) comes close, but for its undercooked asparagus and chayote. In addition to the choice of prepared dishes ($8.99 to $13.99) are preseasoned meats and seafood ($2.99 to $11.99 a pound), including lush Berkshire pork chops with a rich guajillo chili marinade, ready to bake, broil or grill, $4.49 a pound; freshdirect.com.

STATE REGULATION OF BANKS -- The mortgage-lending subsidiaries of national banks are immune from state regulation, the Supreme Court ruled in a decision that upheld a controversial regulation issued six years ago by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the chief federal bank regulator. [Page C1.] A U.S.-NIGERIA GO-BETWEEN -- What, exactly, is Andrew Young, the civil rights leader, and his company GoodWorks International doing in Nigeria? His lobbying and consulting firm has become a lightning rod as Nigerians prepare to elect a president on Saturday. [A1.] YAHOO SHARES FALL -- Yahoo's quarterly earnings were in line with the company's own forecasts, but fell short of analysts' expectations and disappointed investors, who sent Yahoo shares tumbling about 8 percent in after-hours trading. [C1.] CHINA NOT RELYING ON U.S. MARKET -- Chinese manufacturers say their fastest growth these days lies in Europe, Africa, the Middle East, South America and elsewhere in Asia. In other words, practically anywhere other than the United States. [C1.] POUNDS REACH $2 EACH -- The British pound rose above the $2 mark for the first time in 15 years after a surprise increase in Britain's inflation rate spurred expectations the Bank of England would raise interest rates at least once more this year. On Monday, the dollar approached its record low of $1.3666 against the euro. [C8.] REASSURING DATA -- New government data suggested the economy remains on an even keel, with underlying inflation showing signs of easing and growth not slipping too far. [C1.] BCE MAY TAKE ITSELF PRIVATE -- BCE, the largest telecommunications company in Canada, said that it was talking about going private with three Canadian pension funds and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity group. [C8.] G.M. SEES ITS FUTURE IN INDIA -- General Motors' chief executive, Rick Wagoner, came to New Delhi and hailed the country's thrifty manufacturing culture and growing car market and said the company would significantly increase purchasing and production here. [C3.] ABN AND BARCLAYS EXTEND TALKS -- ABN Amro and Barclays said that they had extended the period of their exclusive takeover discussions until the end of Friday. [C8.] I.B.M.'S SOLID GAINS -- I.B.M. reported solid gains in quarterly profits and modest growth in revenue its strategic shift toward higher-margin software and services makes gradual progress. The results paint a picture of dynamic markets in the Asia-Pacific region, a rebound in Europe, and sluggishness in the United States. [C2.] INVESTORS GREET INTEL'S EARNINGS -- Intel reported first quarter earnings up 19 percent, appearing to reassure investors that the company's profit margins were finally starting to improve following a period of price cutting and heavy spending. TO FAVOR GREEN BUSINESSES -- The Environmental Protection Agency will consider the environmental policies of hotels and convention centers when it considers places to stay. [C3.] NEW LOS ANGELES FOCAL POINT -- Work is expected to begin later this year on a $2.05 billion mixed-use project in the Bunker Hill section of Los Angeles, a project designed by Frank Gehry that may provide the city with a vibrant focal point. [C6.] THE DISAPPEARING TRAILER PARKS --Trailer parks in the New York suburbs, which provide quiet pockets of affordability in expensive enclaves, are being snapped up by developers who inevitably replace them with much more costly housing. [B1.] CREDIT PROBLEMS TAKE TOLL -- Problems with consumer credit, particularly in subprime mortgages, weighed on earnings at regional banks, including Wells Fargo & Company, U.S. Bancorp and Washington Mutual. Knopf emerged with three of the five book prizes. [E1.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. A CO-DEFENDANT of the former media mogul Conrad M. In the late 1990s, a small team of economists began traveling down to Austin, Tex., for occasional visits with Gov. George W. Bush, then an unannounced candidate for president. The economists were mostly old Republican policy hands. The youngest member of the group -- the only one who hadn't worked for Ronald Reagan or Gerald Ford -- was Glenn Hubbard, a Columbia professor in his early 40s. After Mr. Bush won, Mr. Hubbard went on to become the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers and an architect of the tax cuts that -- love them or hate them -- have undeniably been the centerpiece of Mr. Bush's domestic policy. Mr. Hubbard was later responsible for bringing Ben Bernanke, then a professor at Princeton, into the Bush orbit.

COLLEGES COACHES MAY FACE TEXT MESSAGING BAN -- The N.C.A.A.'s Division I Management Council voted yesterday to eliminate the use of text messaging by coaches to prospects. The legislation needs approval of the N.C.A.A.'s board, which meets next week, and then its executive committee.

FIELD--Howard O. Writer extraordinaire passed from his dear family and friends. He played his trump card on April 13, 2007 in Palm Springs, CA. He is survived by his loving life partner of 50 years, Jack Kellogg, his sister Elayne, his nieces and nephews Alex and Syd, Doug and Janis, Liz and Michael, and Nick and Cynthia, and so many wonderful and loving cousins and friends who will also share deeply the loss of this funny and engaging man. Howard loved Hollywood and after graduating USC he was signed as the youngest contract writer at MGM Studios. He was one of the first writers of plays for television but the Big Apple beckoned and he went off to write for Young & Rubicam, Grey and Compton Advertising Agencies. Howard served his country in the Navy in WWII and it is there that he forged a friendship with Joe Papp, as they worked to entertain the fellow troops. Their friendship fostered Howard's love of Broadway Theater. He was a Broadway Angel to help support Theater. California called again and Howard and Jack moved out to be closer to family. He continued with advertising at Irwin Wasey and settled in the west coast style, choosing to retire in Palm Springs. We will miss him. Everyone who ever met him, never forgot him. He will always be our Star. Funeral Services will be at Hollywood Forever Cemetery, Beth Olam at 11:00am, Sunday April 22nd, 2007, 6000 Santa Monica Blvd, Hollywood. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to charity of your choice. A celebration of his life is planned for the near future in Palm Springs.
To the Editor: Re Eric Asimov's column ''To Study Wine, Buy and Drink'' (April 11):

FINLAY--John R., M.D. The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary deeply mourns the passing of an esteemed physician and colleague for more than 55 years. Dr. Finlay completed his Ophthalmology residency at the Infirmary and later became a surgeon director. He was an early investigator of intraocular lenses and an ophthalmic pathologist, as well as teacher and mentor to many. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Peter Frelinghuysen, Chairman, Board of Directors Joseph B. Walsh, M.D., Chairman, Department of Ophthalmology J. Robert Rosenthal, M.D., Vice President, Medical Affairs Joseph P. Corcoran, President & CEO $(6$)FINLAY--John R, M.D., Dr. John R. Finlay, a pilot, explorer, and Ophthalmologist, died at his home in North Salem, NY, on April 14 at age 86. Dr. Finlay, a New York native, earned his undergraduate degree from City College of New York and his medical degree from Hahnemann Medical College in Philadelphia. He met his wife Vera, also a physician, at Hahnemann. She was a Greenwich Hospital Pathologist for many years and died in 1994. Dr. Finlay completed his Ophthalmology residency at New York Eye and Ear Infirmary and later became a Surgeon Director there. He was published as an early investigator of Intraocular Lenses and was a founding member of the New York Intraocular Lens Society. He was also a Professor at NYU School of Medicine where he taught courses in Ophthalmic Pathology. Dr. Finlay obtained his pilot license with instrument rating and flew his Beachcraft Baron to destinations as far as Alaska and Brazil. He is a past President of the Flying Physicians Association. He was a member of the Explorers Club of Manhattan and the International Order of Characters, a group of experimental aviators. Dr. Finlay traveled extensively, often to remote areas of the world, and taught surgical techniques to Ophthalmologists in the Philippines, Tunisia, China, Brazil, Russia and Sri Lanka. He volunteered with the ship Hope and with Orbis, an airplane-based eye hospital. Dr. Finlay was also an avid windsurfer and sailor at his home of 40 years in Byram, CT. He won the President's Cup in his Flying Scott in 1962. He also loved to ride at his current home in North Salem, NY, and to ski near his farm in Vermont. He is survived by his son John R. Finlay, Esq., and daughter-in-law Rita St. Germaine, their son Alexander S. Finlay, his daughter Dr. Alexis Finlay and son-in-law Matthew Eliott DVM, his granddaughter Fiona Finlay-Hunt, and his close companion Gisela Kara. A memorial service is planned for June in New York City. In lieu of flowers please send donations to: The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, 310 E. 14th St., NY, NY 10013.

To the Editor: Re ''32 Shot Dead in Virginia'' (front page, April 17): Virginia Polytechnic Institute's students and faculty will forever be changed after the massacre on April 16, 2007. College students around the country are shocked and horrified. In 2002, a man shot four people, including two professors, at my school, the University of Arizona. Although the attack in Virginia was more a massacre than a shooting, students experience a similar gut-wrenching feeling as they realize that their college campus is a vulnerable environment.

Services will be held Wednesday, April 18, 11am, at the Temple Israel of New Rochelle.

An article in Business Day on Monday about a new health information Web site, RevolutionHealth.com, misstated the contribution of various investors in Revolution Health Group, which operates the site. The business's founder and chairman, Stephen M. Case, has put $100 million of his own money into Revolution Health Group, and his other board members have invested about $30 million. Mr. Case and the investors have not contributed $500 million to Revolution Health Group. (Mr. Case has put about $500 million of his own money into the various business ventures, including the health group, that operate under his holding company Revolution L.L.C.)

Five weeks ago, a Virginia Tech student walked into a nondescript gun store next to a pawn shop in Roanoke, Va., and paid $571 for a Glock 9-millimeter handgun and a box of ammunition. On Monday, the student, Cho Seung-Hui, made a horrible kind of history by using that gun and another pistol to go on a murderous rampage at the university, in Blacksburg, Va., before taking his own life.

Specialist Mario Lozano, the American Army soldier who fired on a car carrying Nicola Calipari, left, the deputy chief of Italian military intelligence, and Giuliana Sgrena, an Italian journalist rescued earlier after a month as an insurgent hostage in Iraq in 2005, went on trial in absentia in Rome. The trial was immediately adjourned until May 14 for technical reasons. Specialist Lozano, 37, is charged with voluntary homicide in the death of Mr. Calipari, who shielded the journalist during the shooting and is regarded as a hero, and with intent to kill in the wounding of Ms. Sgrena and another Italian agent. In interviews, Specialist Lozano has said the car was traveling too fast as it approached a roadblock on the way to Baghdad airport and did not respond to warning shots. In a report, the United States military cleared American soldiers of any responsibility. PETER KIEFER

GRANT--William R., 82, Venture capitalist, investment banker, and philanthropist passed away Sunday, April 15, 2007, following a year's illness from metastatic melanoma. He is survived by his beloved wife, Adele Grant, and is predeceased by his beloved wife of 43 years, Dorothy Annetta Grant, a son, Gregory Scott Grant, and a daughter, Melissa Grant Davis. Mr. Grant is survived by his daughters, Deborah S. Grant and Elise Grant Seeley Lauinger and his son, Byron A. Grant, and two grandchildren, Jeremy Deschapelles Seeley and Molly Hall Seeley. A Mass of Resurrection will be celebrated at 3pm on Thursday, April 19th, at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Avenue, New York City. Burial services will be private. In lieu of flowers, his family requests that donations be made to the Gregorian University Foundation, 106 West 56th Street, New York, NY 10019. $(6$)GRANT--William R. Bill, you were an inspiration to us in every aspect of life from family, philanthropy, business, and spiritually. You were a mentor, a trusted friend, confidant, and running coach. Our thoughts, prayers, and love are with your family, wife Adele, daughters Debbie and Elise, and son Sandy. We will miss you terribly. Jill and Barry Lafer $(6$)GRANT--William R. The Gregorian Consortium in Rome--the Pontifical Gregorian University, the Pontifical Biblical Institute and the Pontifical Oriental Institute-joins the Gregorian University Foundation in the United States as it mourns the loss of its longtime Vice Chairman, William R. Grant. For 18 years his creative and challenging leadership, his exceptional dedication and remarkable generosity, his insightful and inspiring advice and wise counsel and his affectionate and caring friendship endeared him to his fellow trustees and to administrators, faculty and students in Rome. We will surely miss this loving and loved exemplary human being. We extend our deepest sympathy and affectionate concern to his beloved wife Adele and to his loving children, Byron (Cynthia), Deborah and Elise (Joseph) Lauinger; and to his grandchildren, Jeremy D. Seeley and Molly Hall Seeley. Peter P. Mullen, Chairman Ellen Shafer, Vice Chairperson Rev. Robert F. O'Toole, S.J., President Rev. Prof. Gianfranco Ghirlanda, S.J., Rector, Gregorian University Rev. Prof. Stephen F. Pisano, S.J., Rector, Biblical Institute Rev. Prof. Hector Vall, Rector, S.J., Oriental Institute $(6$)GRANT--William R. The trustees, administration, faculty and staff, students, parents, and alumnae of Convent of the Sacred Heart, New York City, deeply mourn the passing of a dear friend. The Sacred Heart community will cherish the memory of Bill's generous spirit and remember his wife, Adele, and his entire family in perpetual prayer.

''I could never keep up with him,'' Mick Jagger said at the tribute to Ahmet Ertegun -- the diplomat's son, record-business mogul, jazz fan, prime mover in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, dapper dresser and notorious bon vivant -- last night at Jazz at Lincoln Center's Rose Theater. Mr. Ertegun, the chairman of Atlantic Records, who died on Dec. 14 at 83, was remembered by what Mr. Jagger teasingly called ''a diverse and fascinating group of people such as ourselves.'' There were musicians at ''Ahmet Ertegun: A Celebration'' who recorded for Atlantic: Eric Clapton, Stevie Nicks, Solomon Burke, Kid Rock and Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young, among them. And then there were big names from the other realms Mr. Ertegun traveled in: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, fashion designer Oscar de la Renta, movie director Taylor Hackford, fellow entertainment mogul David Geffen and Henry Kissinger, who admitted: ''I found his political views, shall we say, not exactly convergent with mine. It did not matter.''

Hyundai Motor America in Fountain Valley, Calif., said yesterday that it would award its creative account to Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group. The assignment, with spending estimated at $600 million a year, had been handled since 2002 by the Richards Group in Dallas. Hyundai, part of Hyundai Motor of South Korea, selected Goodby, Silverstein after a review that began in late February. Richards did not take part, citing company policy.

To the Editor: That the state of poverty in America is far bleaker than official reports have indicated (''Counting the Poor,'' editorial, April 17) should be a wake-up call for all. Those who work every day to fight poverty know that when government, nonprofit, corporate and philanthropic sectors join forces, dramatic change happens.

While balancing on her prosthetic leg at the end of her samba routine, Heather Mills, below, fell during Monday's edition of ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars,'' which remained the night's leader in the ratings. According to Nielsen's estimates, this 90-minute variety show averaged 18.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., putting ABC on top over all, even as ''The Bachelor,'' which followed, drew 9.3 million viewers from 9:30 to 11. CBS, which ranked second for the night, led during that portion of prime time with ''The King of Queens'' at 9:30 (12.3 million) and ''CSI: Miami'' at 10 (15.2 million). Fox's new drama ''Drive'' garnered a last-place 5.7 million viewers in its official time-period debut at 8, but the serial drama ''24'' at 9 (11.1 million) helped Fox finish third for the night. NBC was fourth; neither its improv comedy ''Thank God You're Here'' at 9 (6.9 million) nor its ''Dateline'' special on the Virginia Tech shootings at 10 (6.4 million), fared better than last place. BENJAMIN TOFF

It is the time of year to contemplate National Hockey League viewership. It is time to wonder why Versus, in Year 2 of its N.H.L. deal, watched its viewership swell 31 percent over the 2005-6 regular season but has lost 6 percent of its postseason audience, reaching an average of 267,720 a game.

A disregard for safety in the interest of profit very likely caused the explosion in a Siberian mine last month that killed 108 people, the biggest mine disaster in Russia's recent history, officials said. They said that the mine's management deliberately disabled a methane detector, among other safety violations. A buildup of methane, sparked by a short circuit, caused the blast. The governor of the Kemerovo region, Aman-Geldi M. Tuleyev, said the managers defied safety regulations to increase production. MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

The Richard Tucker Music Foundation and the Metropolitan Opera have made up. After several years of banning its contracted singers from appearing at foundation concerts, the Met is allowing them to perform. And the foundation has agreed to resume a $25,000 yearly donation to the opera, said Peter Carwell, its executive director. Met singers will take the stage for the first time in four years at a free community concert put on by the foundation on Tuesday at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan. They also appeared at a foundation fund-raiser in November. Mr. Carwell said the ban, imposed to protect the Met's own fund-raising and ticket sales, was lifted by the new general manager, Peter Gelb. ''Peter gets it,'' he said. ''He understands what we are trying to do.'' The roster for the Tuesday concert includes Maria Guleghina, Barbara Frittoli, Stephanie Blythe, Joyce DiDonato, Massimo Giordano, Salvatore Licitra, Oren Gradus and Samuel Ramey. The foundation, which supports young singers and is named for a legendary Met tenor, announced last week that Brandon Jovanovich, a 36-year-old tenor, had won its $30,000 Richard Tucker Award. DANIEL J. WAKIN

OLINER--Seymour David, beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Elizabeth and Benjamin. Dear sister Carol and Mitchell Fischman. Services were held on Tuesday at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Five weeks ago, a student walked into a gun store, above, in Roanoke, Va., and paid $571 for a Glock handgun and bullets. On Monday, he used it and another pistol to kill 32 people. BY LESLIE EATON AND MICHAEL LUO, PAGE A20

An article in Business Day on Saturday about a medical procedure known as hip resurfacing, an alternative to a standard hip replacement, misstated the duration of hip replacement surgery. It generally requires an hour to 90 minutes -- not three to four hours, which would include the time spent in the recovery room. Because of an editing error, the article also misspelled the name of a hospital affiliated with the New York University Medical Center. It is Tisch Hospital, not Ticsch.

FOR cooks of a lemon-loving persuasion, a puckery citrus curd is the culinary analogue of a chocolate fanatic's fudgy ganache. A cousin of lemon custard but without the milk or cream, lemon curd is a go-to topping, filling, sauce and eat-off-the-spoon treat. It's a mainstay of the pastry cook's repertory, yet subject to countless variations. And so it was one afternoon that in front of me on the counter sat three bowls of curd in glossy pastels: yolk-yellow lemon; pale, coral-tinged blood orange; and a grass-green-speckled lime, showered with zest. My aim was to dollop them into miniature butter-crusted tart shells and arrange them on a platter in a gorgeous springtime mosaic.

Alejandro Jodorowsky's 1973 film ''Holy Mountain'' starts in a mysterious room where a shaman figure known as the Alchemist undresses blond female twins, removes their false fingernails and jewelry and shaves their heads. From there, the movie gets really outré. A scandal when first released, Mr. Jodorowsky's movie is a dazzling, rambling, often incoherent satire on consumerism, militarism and the exploitation of third world cultures by the West. It unfurls like a hallucinogenic daydream, which is to be expected, considering that it's the follow-up to Mr. Jodorowsky's midnight movie ''El Topo.''

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Sudan Sending Arms Into Darfur, U.N. Says A confidential United Nations report says the government of Sudan is flying weapons and military equipment into Darfur in violation of Security Council resolutions and disguising military planes as United Nations or African Union aircraft. A1 Iran Weapons Linked to Taliban A shipment of Iranian-made weapons bound for the Taliban was recently captured by allied forces in Afghanistan, said Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He said it was not clear if the Iranian government had authorized the shipment. A10 Mixed News on AIDS Drugs About two million people worldwide are receiving drugs for AIDS, an increase of 700,000 in the last year, the United Nations reported. But the total represents only 28 percent of the people with advanced AIDS who need such therapy in poor and middle-income countries. A7 Calls for a Resignation in Basra In the latest sign of worsening tensions among Shiite factions, several hundred people began a protest to force the governor of Basra, Iraq, to step down, a move that could throw the city into further turmoil. A10 Confusion in Nigeria Election Election officials in Nigeria said a leading opposition candidate for president would appear on the ballot, even though a court ruling reversing his exclusion came just days before the vote. The Nigerian Supreme Court ruling threw an already chaotic election into further confusion. A3 NATIONAL A14-21 Police Have Identified Virginia Tech Gunman The police identified Cho Seung-Hui, 23, as the killer of 32 people in the shooting rampage at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute, releasing new details into the troubled mind of a student whom few people on campus really knew. A1 Mr. Cho's gun purchase is drawing attention to Virginia's gun purchase laws, which some gun-control advocates described as lax, and it has prompted calls from several Democrats and at least one leading presidential candidate, John Edwards, for measures to restrict gun sales. A20 Student Database Is Restricted The Education Department cut off outside access to a government database that contains the personal financial information of millions of student aid applicants. The department acted after increased usage raised concerns that loan companies or other marketers were improperly obtaining private information on potential borrowers. A1 Coast Guard Seizes Control After months of criticism and setbacks, the Coast Guard announced that it was taking over the management of its $24 billion fleet modernization project, curtailing the role of two military contractors that had been hired to run the job. A14 SCIENCE/HEALTH F.D.A. Approves Flu Vaccine The first vaccine against avian flu won government approval, even as officials conceded its usefulness in a flu pandemic might be limited. Corzine of New Jersey on the Garden State Parkway shows that it was traveling 91 miles per hour, 26 miles over the posted speed limit, when it collided with a truck and then slammed into a guardrail, leaving the governor critically injured. More than 900 residents of Bound Brook, N.J., were still staying in shelters, and about 3,000 people were still without electricity, said acting Gov. Richard J. Codey. But the question of what exactly GoodWorks is doing has turned Mr. Young and his firm into a lightning rod, as Nigerians prepare to elect a successor to the country's president, whom Mr. Young has known for 30 years. Israeli forces shot and killed a militant belonging to the radical Islamic Jihad group south of Jenin in the West Bank, Israeli security officials said. An army spokesman said troops identified Ashraf Haneisheh, who was wanted by Israel, and shot him after he drew his handgun. Palestinian news reports identified Mr. Haneisheh as a member of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades and said he had been ''executed'' by an Israeli undercover special unit. Earlier in the day, Palestinian militants slightly wounded four Israelis in a drive-by shooting near the Jewish settlement of Modi'in Ilit. Al Aksa Martyrs claimed responsibility for the attack. ISABEL KERSHNER

A restaurant review last Wednesday of E.U., in the East Village, referred incorrectly to the beers served there. No beer from Denmark is available. The restaurant serves beer from the Czech Republic, not Czechoslovakia, which divided in 1993 to create the Czech Republic and Slovakia. The review also referred incorrectly to the main ingredient in a potpie. It is vegetables, not chicken.

To the Editor: Re ''A Catholic Debate Mounts on the Meaning of 'Just War,' '' by Peter Steinfels (Beliefs column, April 14): I would include among the criteria for a just war a response to a serious, imminent threat; just wars are normally defensive, although there are provisions for pre-emptive strikes.

Ever since his films began to attract admiring attention from the international film festival crowd, the Thai director Apichatpong Weerasethakul has encouraged his tongue-tied Western fans to call him Joe. That friendly, disarming gesture reflects the sensibility behind the movies, which are at once stubbornly difficult -- resistant to summary, at times even to understanding -- and surprisingly warm and gentle. Unabashed art films that demand patience and close, quizzical attention, they are also generous, unpretentious and funny, posing thorny formal questions in a relaxed, democratic spirit. It is possible to feel, watching his earlier movies ''Blissfully Yours'' or ''Tropical Malady,'' that you just don't get, on a conscious, cerebral level, what Mr. Weerasethakul is trying to do. Yet at the same time you find yourself moved, even enchanted, by the beautiful, oblique stories unfolding before your eyes. It thus may or may not be helpful to know that the situations in his new film, ''Syndromes and a Century,'' were suggested by events in the lives of the director's parents before they became a couple. This information does not provide any clues about the plot, but it can help ground some of the film's fugitive moods of nostalgia and romantic longing, the feelings that attend a child's contemplation of the endless mystery of his own origins.

STONE--Robert G., Jr. In memory of our beloved Bob. You are dearly missed and our thoughts and prayers are always with you. Your loving memory gives us great strength and inspiration and you will forever be in our hearts. We miss you LoveBug! Withlove always, Nancy

The father is a decidedly conservative Pentecostal minister who opposes abortion and same-sex marriage and often endorses Republicans. The son is an unabashed liberal who favors abortion rights and frequently aligns himself with the Rev. Al Sharpton. When they appear together on radio programs, they spar like combatants on CNN's ''Crossfire.'' Even in New York, where political families are anything but uncommon, State Senator Rubén Díaz Sr. and his son, Assemblyman Rubén Díaz Jr., stand out. They are among the best-known legislators in the Bronx, where they have built a formidable political organization that has won them election after election.

A man halted the opening of his murder trial yesterday by admitting that he fatally shot his pregnant sister-in-law on Feb. 21, 2005, and hid her body in the trunk of her car in Jamaica, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Schiovone, 37, of Levittown, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to first-degree manslaughter, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Schiovone admitted that he shot Susan Ambrosino, 26, of Franklin Square, as they sat in her car. Prosecutors say he shot Ms. Ambrosino because she planned to tell her ex-husband, Mr. Schiovone's brother, that Mr. Schiovone was the father of her unborn child. Mr. Schiovone is expected to be sentenced to 30 years in prison.

The victims lived in Blacksburg, Va., but came from places as far apart as Romania, Peru and Canada. Among them was Reema Samaha, above, who went to the same Virginia high school as the killer. BY PAM BELLUCK, PAGE A19

To the Editor: ''Stalking Strangers' DNA'' (''The DNA Age'' series, front page, April 2) states that the law views DNA from discarded cigarettes, drinking cups and so on to be abandoned property. In fact, the courts have not reached a clear decision on whether people have an expectation of privacy over their DNA, which they are continuously but not intentionally shedding.
ALEXANDRE--John Clement, (94), Died peacefully on April 14, 2007. Resident of Tarrytown, New York.

The German Army dismissed an instructor who was filmed in a training exercise telling a recruit to imagine he was firing his machine gun at African-Americans in the Bronx. The Defense Ministry said the instructor, a lance corporal, had been stripped of his rank and pay. The soldier who filmed the scenes with his camera phone is still under investigation. VICTOR HOMOLA

The World Trade Center Memorial Foundation has raised more than $300 million toward its $350 million goal, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday, with more than $165 million raised since he took over as chairman of the foundation roughly six months ago. The money, which includes gifts from across the country and overseas, is to pay capital and planning costs as well as an endowment to operate the memorial and museum. Officials announced yesterday that the foundation board had selected Thinc Design as the lead exhibition design firm. DIANE CARDWELL

The Sports of The Times column on Sunday, about Jessica Long, a 15-year-old swimmer who became the first Paralympic athlete to win the Sullivan Award, given by the Amateur Athletic Union, misidentified her primary coach and misstated the age of her brother Joshua. Her coach is Andrew Barranco -- not Stephanie Weisenborn, who used to coach her. Joshua is 17, not 14.
FELDER--Larry. Rudin Management Company express their deepest condolences to the Felder family on the passing of Larry. We will miss his contribution to our organization. Jack Rudin, Chairman.

Universities in Oklahoma, Tennessee and Texas canceled classes yesterday, searched campuses or evacuated buildings in response to threats, and a Louisiana public school district locked down its middle school and high school. After the shootings at Virginia Tech on Monday, nerves were on edge at universities nationwide, as security officials worried about copycat incidents, even as they acknowledged it was almost impossible to prevent shootings by a deranged student. Universities also reviewed their emergency preparedness plans, considering new technologies to reach students and faculty members in case of danger.

Cho Seung-Hui rarely spoke to his own dormitory roommate. His teachers were so disturbed by some of his writing that they referred him to counseling. And when Mr. Cho finally and horrifyingly came to the world's attention on Monday, he did so after writing a note that bitterly lashed out at his fellow students for what he deemed their moral decay. Mr. Cho's eruption of violence, in which 32 victims and himself were killed on the Virginia Tech campus here in a rampage of gunfire, was never directly signaled by his actions or words, several of his acquaintances said Tuesday. But those acquaintances were frequently disturbed by his isolation from the world and his barely concealed anger.

THERE are places in the world where anchovies are revered, the Mediterranean chief among them. The little fish, usually salted and preserved in oil, is enormously popular on every continent except our own. There are two reasons so many Americans aren't wild about anchovies. One is that we typically buy those of inferior quality. The other is that anchovies are strong flavored and undeniably fishy.

Orange Broadband Shortlist Announced ''Digging to America'' (Alfred A. Knopf), the novel by Anne Tyler of the United States about two Baltimore families who adopt baby girls from Korea, has been named to the shortlist for the Orange Broadband Prize for Fiction, an annual British award for works by women, the BBC reported. Ms. Tyler's book will compete for the $60,000 prize against ''The Inheritance of Loss'' by Kiran Desai from India, winner of last year's Booker Prize; ''Half of a Yellow Sun'' by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie from Nigeria; ''Arlington Park'' by Rachel Cusk from Britain; ''The Observations'' by the Belfast-born Jane Harris; and ''A Concise Chinese-English Dictionary for Lovers,'' by Xiaolu Guo from China. The winner of the prize, for ''excellence, originality and accessibility in women's writing'' by an author writing in English, will be announced in London on June 6. Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra Moves to Symphony Space Arturo O'Farrill and his Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra will take up residence at Symphony Space in the 2007-8 season after performing since 2002 at Jazz at Lincoln Center. Cynthia Elliott, executive director of Symphony Space, said, ''The A.L.J.O.'s inaugural season is also Symphony Space's 30th-anniversary season, and it will be part of our new, expanded roster of music series and outstanding musicians, including Jon Faddis, Ursula Oppens, Meredith Monk and Mark O'Connor.'' Country Music Awards ''Before He Cheats,'' a hit video in which Carrie Underwood, above left, takes a baseball bat to an unfaithful boyfriend's ''pretty little souped-up 4-wheel drive,'' won prizes for video of the year, best female video and best video director on Monday night in Nashville after fan votes were tallied for the CMT Music Awards, The Associated Press reported. Kenny Chesney, above right, won the male video prize for ''You Save Me.'' (He is to appear on July 26 at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., and on Aug. 30 at Madison Square Garden.) Kris Kristofferson, who wrote the country classics ''Sunday Morning Coming Down'' and ''Help Me Make It Through the Night,'' received the Johnny Cash Visionary Award. Footnotes A court-ordered auction of the rights to the O. J. Simpson book ''If I Did It'' yesterday was canceled because his surrogate company, Lorraine Brooke Associates, established to collect the reported $1 million advance, has declared bankruptcy, The Associated Press reported. The news agency attributed its report to David Cook, a lawyer for Fred Goldman, who is seeking to collect a $33.5 million judgment in a civil suit stemming from the slaying of his son in the case the book addresses.

WICKERI--Randy Dwight, 55, died peacefully on April 13, 2007, in Morristown, NJ. Beloved brother, brother-in-law and uncle. He was born in Finland, grew up in Pelham Manor, NY, and lived for many years near Lake Hopatcong, NJ. Deeply missed for his independent spirit and generous nature.

HERZ--Wolfgang A., passed away peacefully at home on April 16th, 2007, at age 77 after a short and sudden illness. He is survived by Heide, his beloved wife of 44 years, and his loving daughters Anya and Audrey. Wolfgang was a collector of art and rare books, a philanthropist, and an entrepreneur. As a founder and president of American Contex Corporation, he was instrumental in the development of specialty motors for the car shredder industry. Wolfgang was the consummate husband, father and friend and the personification of dignity and elegance. We will miss his presence in our lives, his love and devotion to his family, his generosity of spirit, sense of humor and passion for life. Funeral service: Friday, April 20, 11am, St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Account 205568

A German classroom in Norris Hall, above, appears to be where the gunman exacted his greatest toll: as many as a dozen people. Terrified students tried to escape out windows or cowered under desks. BY RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, PAGE A19

Well, it seems like the federal corruption investigations team has moved into a more aggressive phase. This news is on top of Congressman John Doolittle's decision to step off the Appropriations Committee after investigators raided his house.
In his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales struggled to hold on to his job.

In H Block at Bletchley Park, the historic code-breaking facility 50 miles from London, visitors can view a rebuilt working model of a Colossus, one of the first electronic digital computers, built during World War II to decrypt Nazi codes. If only they hadn't waited 60 years to put it back together - there might still be a British Empire. And Silicon Valley might be in some bog outside of Bletchley Park.

In recent weeks, few topics have galvanized some of the more prominent lib-blogs than the firings of federal prosecutors -- led by Joshua Marshall at TalkingPointsMemo.com -- at the hands of Attorney General Alberto Gonzales. His much-anticipated appearance before the Judiciary Committee today was blogged and dissected nearly moment by moment, answer by answer. (Senators on both sides of the aisle did nearly as much dissection as the writers.) The chorus from several wings of the blogosphere was practically in unison -- that this hearing was Mr. Gonzales' last chance to save his job. And his performance did not go over well, at least in this arena.
The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Syndromes and a Century," an unusual Thai film about mood and memory.
With $500 in his pocket, Matt Gross, a.k.a. The Frugal Traveler, sets out to find a 5-star weekend in San Juan, Puerto Rico.
Michael Kimmelman tours the Greek and Roman court at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which is opening after 15 years of renovations.

I did not grow up rooting for -- or against -- the Yankees. As a kid in a National League town in the 1980s, the Yankees were somewhat irrelevant. A good team, usually, with some star players, but they never made the playoffs in the 13 years after I started following the game.

At 28 years old Shelley Duncan is far from the gem of the Yankees farm system. He is not considered one of their top 10 prospects and did not receive an invitation to the team's major league spring training this year.

On July 13, the first 25,000 fans to the Mets-Reds game will receive a bobblehead doll of one of Endy Chavez making his remarkable catch in Game 7 of last year's NLCS. Chavez hasn't seen a copy yet, but he was able to see the catch from all angles yesterday afternoon, when he walked into the clubhouse carrying a matted poster of four photographs of his over-the-fence grab of Scott Rolen's deep fly. The photos were taken by Times photographers.

Let us pray for a slow news day. I sit here at the keyboard with the time almost past for submitting my column. About all I am sure I can produce here is a kind of cop-out apology to you, dear reader.

There's an absolutely horrifying article in the current issue of Child Magazine about the food fight now raging between parents of children with life-threatening food allergies and parents of the allergy-free. The latter, apparently, have started to push back against "peanut-free" school regulations to assert their children's natural right to eat whatever they darn well please.

Most details of my high school graduation are hazy in my memory, but I distinctly remember one speech given by a member of the school board. He turned his back to us seniors onstage and faced our parents in the audience.
