Americans remain sharply divided over the issue of abortion, but a plurality would like to see stricter limits placed on abortions in the United States, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted last month. Democrats and women are more likely to prefer keeping abortion generally available to those who want it.

Among Web 2.0 startups, few are more closely watched than Facebook, a social-networking Web site that was originally restricted to college students but has since opened the gates to many others as well. Much of the fascination comes from the decision by Mark Zuckerberg, the company's young founder, not to accept offers to acquire Facebook, including a bid from Yahoo that The New York Times said was worth $900 million. (Others have rounded it up to an even $1 billion.) In a long profile of the oft-profiled Mr. Zuckerberg, Fast Company's Ellen McGirt spends some time pondering how Facebook's founders and its investors -- who include PayPal founder Peter Thiel -- might eventually cash out their stakes.

I get a lot of unsolicited correspondence from readers, most of whom want to make sure I know how bad Restaurant X's service is, how good Restaurant Y's veal chop is, how impossible it is to get a human being on the phone at Restaurant Z or what an overlooked dining Mecca some six-square-block area in a far corner of the Bronx is.

Did anyone notice fewer photos of the winning team in the press after Ferrari won the Bahrain Grand Prix last Sunday? I did. But it's no surprise. The job of photographer and photo editor has become exponentially more difficult this season as all of the teams except Ferrari have ceased to use tobacco sponsorship. Bahrain was the first race of the season at which Ferrari chose to display the name of its tobacco sponsor. It is not only the tobacco companies and the teams - except Ferrari and its sponsor - who have decided to fall in line with legislation that is quickly expanding worldwide against tobacco sponsorship, it is also much of the print media - although not so much television. So it is that many newspapers and magazines no longer use images of cars with tobacco sponsors. Moreover, it is clear to me that Ferrari's very occasional use of its tobacco sponsor's name and logo this year is actually going to seriously backfire against Ferrari, its tobacco sponsor and Formula One in general. It has already started.
A birth control pill designed to eliminate the monthly period may hit the market soon.

The Times of London takes a look at what it calls the "vicious feud" between London brokerage firm Tullett Prebon and Cantor Fitzgerald, the New York-based firm that rejected Tullett's bid for eSpeed, its electronic bond-trading subsidiary. The account describes a "deep and vituperative" divide between the companies' chief executives and even offers a timeline and a list of players in the trans-Atlantic contretemps. But somehow the article fails to mention one of the most colorful figures in the affair: The hedge fund manager Robert Chapman of Chapman Capital, who has been pushing for a sale of eSpeed.

The Yankees will use Jorge Posada for all three games in Boston this weekend, so today it's Wil Nieves behind the plate at Yankee Stadium. Nieves won the backup catcher's job during spring training, beating out veterans Todd Pratt and Raul Chavez. Pitchers love throwing to him, according to GM Brian Cashman.
We're now in an accelerated campaign season, one that is propelling candidates to raise huge amounts of money and to outline positions far ahead of the usual schedule.

The beleaguered recorded-music business has to do something to pull itself out of its current predicament, which stems partly from outside forces it cannot control (the Internet) but also from its own clumsy or outdated strategies. According to Fortune magazine's Tim Arango, Warner Music Group's rumored deal to buy Front Line Management -- the nation's largest artist-management firm, with a roster of big-name clients including Christina Aguilera and Aerosmith -- may offer "a new economic model for the major record companies." He compares this model to venture capital investing, but with the record labels nurturing new talent instead of new technologies.

Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. -- If an expert puts out a book saying a trend will last for a decade, and it then promptly ends, can you depend on his next book to be a similarly excellent contrary indicator?
That's how much time Gov. Eliot Spitzer has left to carry out the remainder of his agenda, as the governor himself noted today.

Ever since Sallie Mae announced on Monday a $25 billion buyout offer by two private equity firms and two banks, one of the questions deal-makers have been asking is this: How did Friedman, Fleischer & Lowe, a relatively small buyout firm, get a cut of one of the biggest financial-services buyouts ever?
Despite wearing chest protectors, shin guards, face mask, knee savers and a few other pieces of armor, catchers every so often leave one area of the body exposed.
Hedge funds that dabble in distressed assets are celebrating a decision in an obscure Texas bankruptcy case.
New shows in New York include Broadway revivals of "Inherit the Wind" and "A Moon for the Misbegotten."

As she campaigns for president, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton often talks about growing up in Chicago, but she has yet to try capitalizing on her hometown roots, at least as far as fundraising is concerned.

Mark Buehrle's no-hitter for the White Sox on Wednesday night was the first of the 2007 season and the 16th in team history. He was nearly perfect against the Rangers in Chicago's 13th game of the season, his first win in three appearances. According to The Associated Press, there have been 32 no-hitters thrown in the month of April since 1898.
Blogtalk Wrap Up | 6:06 PM ET

The Los Angeles Times editorial on the Supreme Court decision upholding the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act includes a sentence that suggests Gonzales v. Carhart ultimately doesn't mean very much for either side of the abortion debate: "This muddled decision doesn't attack the basic holding of Roe v. Wade, and it will have no effect on the vast majority of abortions performed in this country."

Confirming earlier reports, Delphi said on Thursday that Cerberus Capital Management is dropping out of a group planning a $3.4 billion investment in the bankrupt car parts maker. Reuters reported that Cerberus may still participate in the reorganization as part of the company's exit financing package, and the other investors in the plan, including Appaloosa Management, are staying in.

Dozens of Republican House members looking for a promising presidential hopeful flocked to the nearby Capitol Hill Club, seeking a sermon on the Hill from Fred D. Thompson, the "Law & Order" actor and former Tennessee senator. Little insight about Mr. Thompson's decision-making came out of the meeting-or into whether he would ultimately be a viable candidate-or into where he stands on the issues. From The Washington Post's Dana Milbank:

Could private equity try to board Southwest Airlines? One credit analyst says the carrier, known for its quirky, no-frills style, could be a tempting buyout candidate. But Southwest's chief executive, Gary Kelly, sounds skeptical.

Compared with other beaches lining the South Florida coast, Hollywood Beach is often referred to as an "ugly duckling" with condos that mostly resemble military barracks. But that's about to change -- thanks to gazillionaire Donald Trump.

Paul O'Neill, the former Yankee, retired at the end of the 2001 season and is now an analyst with the YES Network. But, as O'Neill hung around by the batting cage before the Yankees played the Cleveland Indians on Wednesday night, he acted more like a player than a broadcaster.
“A Dios Momo,” directed by Leonardo Ricagni, is to melodrama as corn syrup is to sweeteners: efficient but crude.
“Downtown: A Street Tale” is a hackneyed melodrama partly redeemed by a cast convinced that it’s performing Tennessee Williams.
This banal horror retread involves a couple of critters flailing inside a sticky trap for what is, in effect, the big-screen equivalent of a roach motel.

Tensions between the management of Motorola, the cell phone maker, and the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn heated up after Motorola reported a loss for the first quarter and issued a disappointing forecast for the second, leading some analysts to question whether it would be able to return to profitability this year.
After the news media spent days dealing with unconfirmed reports, the playing field was suddenly leveled with NBC News's release of much of Cho Seung-Hui's "multimedia manifesto."

Merrill Lynch said Thursday that first-quarter profit rose 31 percent, to $2.16 billion, lifted by record investment-banking fees and trading revenue. Merrill's chief executive, Stan O'Neal, called it a "terrific quarter" despite a sometimes volatile environment. Including Merrill's latest figures, Bloomberg News reported that first-quarter profit at the five biggest securities firms in the nation totaled $9.7 billion, an all-time high. Separately, Bank of America said Thursday that first-quarter profit increased 5 percent to $5.26 billion, helped by growth in fee income.

ALEXANDRIA, Va. -- His retrial in federal court here isn't over yet, but Dr. William E. Hurwitz is already doing much better than he did the first time. Judge Leonie M. Brinkema has dismissed the most serious charges against him.

MetroPCS Communications, a mobile-phone company that sells flat-rate calling plans in metropolitan areas, raised $1.15 billion in the biggest initial stock sale of 2007, Bloomberg News reported. The company, based in Dallas, sold 50 million shares for $23 each. The price was more than the $19 to $21 range it had predicted.

Experian, the credit information company, announced plans to buy an Internet marketing group, Hitwise, for $240 million, the Telegraph reported Thursday. Hitwise helps clients monitor the performance of their Web sites and target their online advertising spending more effectively. Experian's core business is its credit checking service, but the group hopes the acquisition will strengthen its marketing solutions division.

Stock in the Jefferies Group, the investment bank, rose more than 5 percent and call options surged on Wednesday, fueled by speculation the company is a takeover target, Reuters reported citing options market participants and a stock analyst. Jefferies, a merger adviser and underwriter to mid-sized companies, declined to comment on the chatter. Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance, known as MassMutual, was touted as a possible suitor by one options analyst.

Carl C. Icahn turned up the heat on Wednesday in his campaign to take over the board of the troubled developer WCI Communities, a builder of posh retirement communities, mostly in Florida, the New York Post reported. In a regulatory filing, Mr. Icahn urged shareholders to vote for his slate of 10 new directors, who back his buyout offer of $956 million, or $22 a share.

Seven years after the Internet bubble burst, investors say it's time to recoup their Silicon Valley losses. Technology firms backed by venture capitalists raised $701 million in seven initial public offerings last quarter, equaling the third period of 2004 as the busiest since 2000, according to Dow Jones VentureOne, which does research on the industry.

A fight is brewing over a bill that would allow shareholders to have the right to a nonbinding vote on the pay packages of senior executives of public companies. The measure, which the House began debating Wednesday, would also give shareholders the right to vote on any "golden parachute" compensation plans that are awarded to executives while they are negotiating the purchase or sale of a company.

The recent outage that left five million BlackBerry users without their cherished wireless e-mail triggered some major withdrawal symptoms. People across the country frantically switched the devices on and off and made desperate calls to their help desks in an attempt to figure out what was wrong. "I quit smoking 28 years ago," an executive at an insurance company told The New York Times, "and that was easier than being without my BlackBerry."

A Citigroup executive, Dean S. Barr, resigned Wednesday as head of the bank's hedge funds less than a week after the bank agreed to buy a hedge fund, Old Lane Partners, and name its co-founder, Vikram S. Pandit, to oversee alternative investments including private equity. Mr. Barr also resigned as chief executive of the bank's Tribeca global management unit, Citigroup said Wednesday in a memorandum to employees.

What are those crazy venture capitalists in Silicon valley up to these days when they are not listening to pitches and signing deals? Kiteboarding, apparently. Bloomberg News takes a look at the sport, which has seduced the likes of Google co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page, as well as a slew of venture capitalists, private equity pros and investment bankers.

Ford Motor said Wednesday it reached a tentative deal to sell the glass-making operations it took back from its former subsidiary, Visteon. Ford said it had agreed to sell the glass-making unit, which employs about 1,600 workers, to Glass Products, a company formed by an investor, Robert Price. Terms were not disclosed.

TD Banknorth shareholders have approved a plan by Toronto-Dominion Bank, which already owns nearly 60 percent of the Bank, to acquire the rest of the shares for $3.6 billion. The transaction is expected to close April 20, at which time TD Banknorth's shares will be delisted from the New York Stock Exchange, the company said Wednesday. TD Banknorth, which is based in Portland, Maine, will then become a subsidiary of Toronto-dominion Bank, which is based in Toronto.

Splashed across the headlines recently: A report from Savills, the real estate agency, showing that the price of trophy houses in London costing $10 million-plus had soared by up to 50 percent in the past year. These kinds of figures seem to indicate that booming London is set to keep, well, booming. But, according to "The Sunday Times," there are signs that soaraway house prices are set for a crash landing. The newspaper reports several reasons to be cautious. First, a series of interest-rate rises has hit affordability, helping push up repossessions. Second, developers are overpayinhg for land in the expectation of continuing price rises. Third, the market in other parts of England is already slowing. In the end, what goes up ...

A hedge fund, Highland Capital Management, is interested in making another run at the auto parts maker Delphi, the Wall Street Journal reported. In January Delphi signed a $3.4 billion deal with a group of private equity investors, despite a $4.7 billion rival bid from Highland.

The independent power company Mirant said on Wednesday it had agreed to sell its Caribbean business to Marubeni of Japan for about $732 million. Mirant, which emerged from bankruptcy early last year, is also in the process of selling its Philippines assets to Marubeni and Tokyo Electric Power.

Some board members and shareholders of Topps, the baseball card maker, are furious with the company after it shunned a higher bid from its rival Upper Deck in favor of a $385 million deal with Disney's former boss Michael D. Eisner, The New York Post reported.

Some hedge funds apparently are making it hard for a private equity consortium to seal its $11.1 billion deal for the Australian airline Qantas. With just more than two weeks to go until their tender offer expires, the bidders, who include the Macquarie Bank and the Texas Pacific Group, are having trouble winning over shareholders, with the number of shares committed to the deal actually dropping since last week, according to Finance Asia.

Japan Tobacco has completed its $15 billion acquisition of the Gallaher Group, both sides said Wednesday, in what was the biggest Japanese overseas acquisition ever. Japan Tobacco, the overseas distributor for Winston, Camel and Salem cigarettes, and Gallaher Group, the British-based maker of Silk Cut and Benson & Hedges cigarettes, announced the deal last December.

Gazprom, the Russian state-run gas company, on Wednesday completed the purchase of its controlling share in the Sakhalin-2 oil and gas project, buying half the stakes owned by Royal Dutch Shell, Mitsui and Mitsubishi for $7.45 billion.

Telefonica, the Spanish phone operator, has agreed to sell its Airwave O2 unit, Britain's police and emergency services radio network, to the Macquarie Bank of Australia for 1.9 billion pounds ($3.8 billion). The Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group and Macquarie European Infrastructure Fund II, both managed by the bank, which is based in Sydney, will each own 50 percent of Airwave, they said.
Ebay is in talks to buy StumbleUpon, a Web site rating system that has been the subject of deal speculation for some time, according to the blog TechCrunch.

The president of the United Auto Workers said Wednesday he hopes to persuade DaimlerChrysler not to sell the Chrysler Group, even as a German magazine reported that Daimler could make a decision on a buyer in the next four weeks. Ron Gettelfinger, the union head who was speaking to reporters at Chrysler's headquarters, said the union believed that it was still an option for Daimler to keep Chrysler, which reported an operating loss of $1.5 billion last year. "There is a lot of value in keeping it there right now because of the synergy, even though you don't hear a lot about that," he said. "It has worked well."
Inside the Metropolitan Museum's galleries for Greek and Roman art.
The work of Merce Cunningham over the years, in pictures.
U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates landed in Baghdad on Thursday to deliver a sharp message to Iraqi political leaders: The U.S. military’s commitment to the war is not open-ended.
First-quarter results beat projections, but the brokerage firm warned that recent market turbulence would dent earnings for the year.
This sweeping documentary, a production of New York Times Television, has gathered the views of an amazing assortment of Indonesians.
Luis Posada Carriles is an aging ex-C.I.A. operative suspected in a decades-old airliner bombing.
Atlanta played much tougher in Game 4, twice taking a lead before the Rangers stormed back to win and advance to the second round of the playoffs for the first time in a decade.
Alex Rodriguez is having an April for the ages. The Yankees slugger hit a three-run, two-out homer that capped a ninth inning Yankees comeback Thursday.
The former judge could face as many as 15 years in prison if he is sentenced consecutively on the bribery verdict and two lesser charges of which he was also found guilty.
The mayor of Yonkers, Philip A. Amicone, and Herman Keith, a former president of the NAACP, celebrated the settlement of a decades-old lawsuit over housing segregation.
The surge in growth is almost certain to force Beijing to step up its efforts to cool down the economy and prevent it from overheating.
By permitting a relatively open round of political discussion, President Hu Jintao and other top leaders have sought to cast themselves publicly as progressives.
A judge in Manhattan sentenced a private school principal to up to 14 years in prison for having a sexual relationship with a student.
Karcher, the company’s brand name is becoming a French political verb, to Karcher. And the context is explosive.
Doctors say they may soon be able to remove the tube that has helped him breathe since last Thursday.
Officials also said they did not receive any reports after late 2005 that Cho Seung-Hui was dangerous.
Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales encountered skepticism from senators today as he insisted that he had nothing to hide in the dismissals of eight United States attorneys.
The defense secretary said today that arms sales to Persian Gulf countries would not threaten Israeli security.
With an 11.1 percent annualized growth rate in the first quarter, China may step up efforts to slow the economy.

A front-page article on April 4 about Arnold Blume, an 81-year-old substitute teacher on Long Island who shares his firsthand knowledge of historical events in class, included an erroneous reference from Mr. Blume to the day in 1945 when he and fellow members of the Army Air Corps assembled for a memorial service for President Franklin D. Roosevelt. The men were in their green dress uniform, not dress blues. (A spokesman for the Air Force, which succeeded the Air Corps, said the dress blues uniform was not introduced to the Air Force until 1949.).
Mets’ starting pitcher John Maine carried a no-hitter into the seventh inning while David Wright set a franchise record by notching a hit in his 25th consecutive game.
Scott Gomez scored his first goal of the N.H.L. postseason in the eighth minute of the first overtime to lead the Devils past the Lightning on Wednesday night.
Chris Drury scored two goals, including the winner 39 seconds into the third period, to help the Sabres take a 3-1 lead over the Islanders in the best-of-seven series.
By pitching six innings Wednesday night, Kei Igawa became the second Yankees rookie starter in two nights to gain his first major league victory.

A homeless man died in his jail cell while in police custody on Monday, the police said yesterday. The man, Dennis Cafila, 55, had been arrested on Saturday at the corner of Seneca Avenue and Faile Street for criminal possession of a controlled substance. He was found dead in his cell at the central booking facility in Morris Heights, and his death did not immediately appear suspicious, the police said. The medical examiner is expected to conduct an autopsy to determine the cause of death.

Peter Braunstein, the writer accused of pretending to be a firefighter and sexually abusing a woman in Chelsea in 2005, was found medically fit yesterday despite suffering skull fractures, and his case was transferred to another judge. Justice Thomas Farber of State Supreme Court got the case from Justice James Yates after Justice Yates read a report that found Mr. Braunstein medically and mentally fit for trial. Mr. Braunstein’s lawyers had sought delays to give their client’s three skull fractures and five brain hematomas a chance to heal and for headaches to ease. Lawyers on both sides had already agreed that Mr. Braunstein was mentally fit for trial, but Justice Yates had wanted to know if the skull injuries had left the defendant physically unable to participate. Justice Farber ordered pretrial hearings to begin this afternoon.
In his new book, “The New American Story,” Bill Bradley presents his detailed solutions for improving the United States. Regarding the Knicks, he already sees progress toward a better future.
With Wednesday night’s victory, the Knicks completed their sixth straight losing season and their fourth since Isiah Thomas became team president.
Street Tree Care.

A film series entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday, about the three-part Chinese documentary “West of Tracks” at Anthology Film Archives, misstated the opening dates for the first two parts, “Rust” and “Remnants.” “Rust” opened yesterday and “Remnants” opens today; they did not open last Friday and Saturday. (As the article noted, part three, “Rails,” opens tomorrow.).

An article in Business Day yesterday about a Supreme Court decision limiting state control of big banks misstated a word in a quotation from Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, who criticized the ruling, which upheld a regulation issued by the office of the comptroller of the currency. Mr. Frank, who heads the House Financial Services Committee, said, “The controller has eliminated a whole bunch of state consumer laws with nothing to put in their place.” He did not say the court had eliminated the laws.

An article yesterday about Pulitzer Prizes awarded this year to books published by Alfred A. Knopf misstated the title of a Knopf winner from last year. It was “American Prometheus: The Triumph and Tragedy of J. Robert Oppenheimer” — not “Robert J. Oppenheimer.”.

A sports article on Sunday about the challenges facing Nascar after years of growth referred incorrectly to the finances of International Speedway Corporation, which owns many tracks where top races are run. The company’s first-quarter revenue fell 4.5 percent compared with the same quarter a year ago — not 19 percent, which was the decline in first-quarter earnings compared with the same period. The article also referred incompletely to the company’s explanation for these declines. Aside from lower attendance and a drop in concessions sales, the company also cited higher expenses.

An article on Tuesday about the struggles of St. Louis in the wake of a population decline misspelled the surname of an assistant professor at Washington University who has been involved in municipal planning projects. He is John Hoal, not Haul.

A front-page article on April 4 about Arnold Blume, an 81-year-old substitute teacher on Long Island who shares his firsthand knowledge of historical events in class, included an erroneous reference from Mr. Blume to the day in 1945 when he and fellow members of the Army Air Corps assembled for a memorial service for President Franklin D. Roosevelt. The men were in their green dress uniform, not dress blues. (A spokesman for the Air Force, which succeeded the Air Corps, said the dress blues uniform was not introduced to the Air Force until 1949.).
The Critics’ Choice column on Monday about new CDs misstated the nationality of Dr. Luke, who produced some of the songs on the Avril Lavigne album “The Best Damn Thing.” He is American, not Swedish.
Corrections
Freddie Mac said it would buy as much as $20 billion in subprime mortgages and Washington Mutual offered to refinance $2 billion in loans.

Europe’s trade chief said that he could start more litigation against China as part of a new push to bring down barriers around the world to European exports and investments. The trade chief, Peter Mandelson, left, said if Chinese authorities failed to bend on intellectual property rights and other market issues, “Europe’s patience could wear thin.” European companies have complained in the past that the European Commission is not as aggressive as the United States in tackling obstacles to exports or investment in countries, including China. Although China has made some progress, protection of intellectual property rights remains “patchy and uneven,” Mr. Mandelson said, adding that the European Union companies lose an estimated 20 billion euros ($27.18 billion) a year because of Chinese trade barriers.

Telefónica, the Spanish phone operator, has agreed to sell its Airwave O2 unit, Britain’s police and emergency services radio network, to Macquarie Bank of Australia for £1.9 billion ($3.8 billion). The Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group and Macquarie European Infrastructure Fund II, both managed by the bank, which is based in Sydney, will each own 50 percent of Airwave, they said in a statement. Marquarie is the world’s largest manager of infrastructure. Telefónica, based in Madrid, which has more debt than any other major European phone operator, is selling Airwave after shedding its phone directory business last year.

The Canadian National Railway lifted a lockout against striking workers in five cities after a special labor law, passed Tuesday by the House of Commons through a special accelerated process, was approved by the Senate and swiftly signed into law by Governor-General Michaëlle Jean, the formal head of state. An arbitrator will now impose a settlement. The United Transportation Union began rotating strikes against Canadian National last week after its workers overwhelmingly rejected a tentative contract. That proposed contract had ended a 15-day general strike in February that had caused industrial disruption in Canada and shipping delays to the United States. The dispute focuses on work rules, particularly those concerning older employees.

A petrochemical complex in Libya will be expanded and operated by a joint venture formed by the Dow Chemical Company and Libya’s state-owned National Oil Corporation, the two companies said. Dow Chemical said it was the first global chemical company to take part in the economic development of the petrochemical industry in Libya since the North African nation recently embarked on a policy of attracting foreign expertise and investment to help diversify its domestic economy. Enhancements at the petrochemical complex, which was built in the 1980s in the Mediterranean coastal port of Ras Lanuf, will position the joint venture for growth as a world-class supplier of polyethylene and polypropylene, Dow said. The plastics are used in the manufacture of a wide array of products including packaging materials, plastic bottles and automobile interiors.
The Virginia Tech gunman’s behavior had resulted in an effort to have him committed to a mental institution.
football.
Two wildfires forced more than 1,000 people from their homes in southeastern Georgia and threatened the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge, officials said.
The national coalition Mayors Against Illegal Guns unveiled a 30-second television advertisement intended to pressure Congress to rescind the so-called Tiahrt amendment.
Airport workers will be given more security checks, the Transportation Security Administration said.
The Most Rev. Rowan Williams, archbishop of Canterbury, left, has announced he will visit the United States in September to meet with bishops of the Episcopal Church.
The arrival of a package from Cho Seung-Hui set in motion intense decision making at NBC.
With the playoff stakes high for both teams, the Nets came away with a victory to vault themselves into the sixth seed in the Eastern Conference and a first-round matchup against Toronto.
For the most part, universities cannot tell parents about their children’s problems without the student’s consent.

Russia unveiled a plan to build a tunnel between Siberia and Alaska under the Bering Strait, saying the $65 billion project could be used to export Russian oil, natural gas and electricity to the United States. At 64 miles, it would be twice the length of the Channel Tunnel between Britain and the Continent. While two Ministry of Economy officials endorsed the idea, they made it clear that the Russian government had not signed off on it.

At least 32 workers were killed when they were engulfed in white-hot molten steel at a metal factory in Liaoning Province, the government said. The accident occurred when a 30-ton-capacity ladle sheared off, throwing the 2,700-degree liquid metal into an adjacent room and engulfing workers gathered there for a shift change, the State Work Safety Administration said.

Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, the chief justice suspended by President Pervez Musharraf last month, appeared before the Supreme Judicial Council to defend himself on charges of misuse of power. He has filed a petition in the Supreme Court, the court he once headed, challenging the constitutional authority of the five-judge council, said his lawyer, Chaudhry Aitzaz Ahsan. The council adjourned the hearing until Tuesday.

The Antwerp Zoo has posted a sign asking visitors not to stare at the apes. The zoo wants visitors not to form a bond with a male chimp named Cheetah. He was raised by humans but is now bonding with the other apes, and continued interaction with humans has been “delaying the social integration.”.

Thailand unveiled a draft constitution that eliminates direct elections for the Senate while bolstering the power of the unelected judiciary. The document, posted on Parliament’s Web site, was drafted by a 35-member committee selected by the junta and will be presented at public forums beginning next week, and then to a national referendum in September. While the 1997 Constitution rescinded by the coup leaders sought to consolidate Thai politics and avoid the fractured coalitions of the 1990s, its proposed replacement seeks to decentralize power by buttressing the power of judges and bureaucrats.

Officials said the body of a woman found buried in mud in the mountainous northern province of Ifugao was that of a missing Peace Corps volunteer, Julia Campbell. They said she had apparently been murdered. “Work continues at the site to determine the circumstances,” said a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Manila, Matthew Lussenhop. A regional police commander, Chief Superintendent Raul Gonzales, told The Associated Press, “There is a probability that there was foul play.” Ms. Campbell, 40, a former freelance reporter in New York who contributed to The New York Times in the 1990s and joined the Corps in 2005, was last seen on April 8 as she set off for a hike in the village of Batad, which offers a magnificent view of the centuries-old rice terraces, one of the country’s tourist attractions. Ms. Campbell, from Fairfax, Va., was one of 137 Peace Corps volunteers in the Philippines. Colleagues said that her service was wrapping up and that she was excited about returning to New York.

A bomb planted in the road exploded under a United Nations car in the southern city of Kandahar on Tuesday, killing four security guards from Nepal and their Afghan driver. The five men were contractors working for the United Nations Office of Project Services, a support agency that has worked on large projects in Afghanistan, including running elections. The explosion tore apart the vehicle and burned the men inside.

About 8,000 demonstrators gathered near President Kurmanbek Bakiev’s office in Bishkek, the capital, for an eighth day of protests against him, and added a call for new parliamentary elections to their list of demands for sweeping government reforms. They have already demanded new presidential elections. Mr. Bakiev has initiated a number of compromises with the opposition in recent weeks, including appointing a critic as prime minister. Protest leaders are calling for larger demonstrations over the weekend.
The Rev. Alexander W. Evans has listened and spoken to those closest to the killings of the 32 Virginia Tech students and faculty members.

GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 18 — Justice R. Bruce Cozzens Jr. discreetly handed tissues to the witness on the stand Wednesday. She tried to stifle sobs and wiped away tears while she told of being sexually abused as a teenager by a Catholic youth ministry leader in the early 1990s.
Jessica Mayo-Swimeley said a McDonald House manager had admonished her for nursing her son in a lounge.
Revelations about Seung-Hui Cho’s stay in a psychiatric center have raised questions about whether background checks adequately scrutinize the mental health history of potential gun buyers.
The reaction from the presidential candidates to the Supreme Court’s decision was quick and along party lines.
Whether you’re an ordinary citizen or the chief executive of a state, traffic laws cannot be considered optional — for your own safety and the safety of all those traveling around you.
President Bush warned that the U.S. would impose stiff economic sanctions if Sudan does not end the violence in Darfur.
Koreans around the country have watched the events in Virginia unfold with particular unease.
Dell’s personal computer sales continued to decline in the first quarter in the United States and across the world.
The results led some analysts to question whether the wireless phone maker would be able to return to profitability this year.
A suicide bomber killed 10 people in a religiously mixed neighborhood today, the day after attacks killed 171.
First-quarter profit dropped 19 percent but results exceeded estimates because of the company’s fast-growing drug business.
The wife of Representative John T. Doolittle is being investigated in connection with her ties to the convicted lobbyist Jack Abramoff, her lawyer said.
Politicians should have the guts to tell the nation that retrogression is the state of gun control in America.

A picture on the front page of The Metro Section on Tuesday with an article about flooding caused by the recent northeaster showed an antiques shop in Ridgefield, Conn., being washed away. The wood siding at the far left of the pink building was out of alignment because the picture was retouched by a Times staff member who took the picture, but who is not a staff photographer. He altered it because a flash created a white spot on the picture when he shot it through the window of a train. Also, the retouching tool left a round circle on the building’s window at right.

The Supreme Court has handed the Bush administration and other opponents of women’s reproductive rights the big political victory they were hoping to get from the conservative judges President Bush has added to the bench.
Prosecutors are relying on computer evidence in their case against a well-known figure in graffiti culture, Alan Ket, whose graffiti work has been shown in galleries.
The dismissal of the U.S. attorney from New Mexico demonstrates the interaction of the Republican Party, the White House and Alberto R. Gonzales that led up to the firings of several attorneys.
Investment gains offset a decline in revenue from property-liability insurance premiums.
Pokey Chatman’s resignation from L.S.U. following charges of inappropriate sexual relationships between her and former players is renewing worries about inflaming homophobia in sports.
Sharp Electronics has embarked on a six-month campaign to teach homeowners how solar energy works.

TXU will go ahead with a $32 billion sale to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Texas Pacific Group after no better offers surfaced this week.

The Cleveland Cavaliers handed out more than $500,000 in free goodies to thank their fans, then flirted with giving away a crucial game. LeBron James scored 24 points and capped a decisive run to open the fourth quarter with one of his powerhouse dunks as Cleveland defeated the visiting Milwaukee Bucks, 109-96, in its regular-season finale last night.
The parent of American Airlines swung to an $81 million profit from a loss a year ago as it filled more seats, charged higher fares and paid less for fuel.
The Dow recovered from Wall Street’s steep decline in February as investors rewarded companies that showed strong earnings.

A special election to fill an Assembly seat in the 65th District, on the Upper East Side, has been rescheduled because of a conflict with a holiday, state officials said yesterday. The seat was vacated after the incumbent, Pete Grannis, above, resigned to become the state environmental commissioner. The election has been rescheduled to June 5 from May 22 because some polling places will close early for Shavuot, officials said. Mr. Grannis, a Democrat, had served in the Assembly since 1974.

Federal railroad officials said they had found 79 problems with tracks of CSX Corporation across New York State during a study prompted by recent derailments of freight trains. Only one problem was called a violation, a more serious lapse for which the regulators recommended a fine. “CSX tracks generally are in compliance with federal track safety standards,” said Joseph Boardman, administrator of the Federal Railroad Administration. The agency checked 1,085 miles of track. Mr. Boardman said CSX was working to fix the problems.

A federal judge has denied a motion by bicycling groups seeking a preliminary injunction barring the city from enforcing regulations on large-scale bicycle rides, city officials said yesterday. The bicyclists, who have sued to overturn city rules that say groups of 50 or more riders must obtain parade permits, claim that the regulations violate their right to free assembly; city officials have argued that the police have the right to enforce regulations to maintain public order and safety. In a decision on Tuesday, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court said he was not convinced that an order barring enforcement was justified before a trial on the lawsuit.

City officials yesterday opened the refurbished reptile wing at the Staten Island Zoo. The city invested $18.8 million in the 16,600-square-foot wing, which has a two-level alligator pool and 120 species of reptiles. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the zoo was home to one of the largest collections of venomous reptiles in the country. The mayor also said that the renovation incorporated energy-efficient features to allow the zoo to cut energy consumption by 20 percent.

The state commission overseeing judges said yesterday that its chairman, Raoul Felder, no longer speaks for the panel. Last week, Mr. Felder received a unanimous vote of no confidence from the nine other members of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct after they accused him of invoking “racial, ethnic and religious invective” in a book that he wrote with Jackie Mason. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has also called for Mr. Felder to step down, but he has refused to do so and has disputed characterizations about his book. The commission said yesterday that the staff administrator would speak for the commission, and that the clerk would sign the panel’s orders. Mr. Felder said he did not oppose any of the steps being taken.

New Jersey voters approved all but about 20 percent of school budgets in elections held Tuesday, a change from last year, when just over half of the budgets were approved, the New Jersey School Boards Association said yesterday. Edwina M. Lee, the association’s executive director, said voters were responding to the state government’s efforts to provide relief for property taxes. The association said budgets were approved in 78 percent of the districts.

The pilot of a small plane was killed yesterday when it crashed shortly after taking off from an Adirondack airport, officials said. The pilot, who was alone, was not named by officials. The twin-engine plane, a six-seat Beech 95-B55, went down in the woods beyond the runway of Adirondack Regional Airport almost immediately after taking off around 1:30 p.m., according to state officials and the Federal Aviation Administration. The cause of the crash, about 45 miles south of the Canadian border, was not known yesterday.

A member of the Public Service Commission, which regulates public utilities in New York State, charged yesterday that an aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer threatened to have her removed if she did not back away from efforts to investigate Consolidated Edison over last year’s blackout in Queens. The member, Cheryl Buley, a commissioner appointed last year by Gov. George E. Pataki, made the accusation against Steve A. Mitnick, an assistant secretary to Mr. Spitzer, as the commission voted unanimously yesterday to proceed with the investigation. The investigation, which was opposed by the utility and by New York City officials, allows the commission to determine whether the company can charge customers some of the costs associated with the blackout. Christine Anderson, a spokeswoman for Mr. Spitzer, said no one from the administration told Ms. Buley to vote against the investigation, which she said the governor supports.

About one in four men in New York City reported binge drinking in a survey that was released yesterday by the city health department. The survey, which gathered information from 10,000 New Yorkers by telephone, was based on 2005 data, the most recent that was available, city officials said. They said the rate of binge drinking — defined as having five or more drinks on one occasion in the past month — was unchanged since 2002. Over all, 14 percent of adult city residents reported binge drinking, lower than the national rate of 24 percent of adults, city officials said. The survey showed that men reported binge drinking three times more frequently than women.

A former East Haven police officer who left the Police Department to train Iraqi security officers has won a court battle to get his job back. A State Superior Court judge ruled earlier this week that the town must rehire the officer, Robert Nappe. Mr. Nappe, a 19-year veteran, retired three years ago after the town’s Board of Police Commissioners denied his request for a leave of absence to volunteer for a one-year job in Iraq. Pasquale Romano, the chairman of the Board of Police Commissioners, told The New Haven Register that the board needed to review the decision and discuss it with its lawyer before acting.

(22, 26) FAITH WITHOUT FEAR This “America at a Crossroads” documentary follows the journey of the Muslim dissident Irshad Manji, left, as she travels through Yemen, Europe and North America on what she sees as a quest to restore humanity and reason to Islam. “How,” she asks, “has a religion of justice become mired in fear?” At 10 “Struggle for the Soul of Islam: Inside Indonesia” explores the country’s long history of moderation in its practice of Islam, and how its Muslim majority is struggling to control the rise of Islamic extremism, which has made Indonesia a flash point in global terror.

RUBIN--Elliott, died on April 17. Beloved husband of Nancy Brown Rubin, adored father of Sally Ann Ball (Ronald) and David I. Rubin, proud grandfather of Michael Andrew Ball and Jacquelyn Dana Ball, brother of Cyrus Rubin (Mary Ellen) and Deborah Ploss (Dr. Lester). Interment private, in lieu of flowers, contribution to charity of your choice.

POSNER--Marilyn, 80 years old, died Monday from complications due to pulmonary disease. A civil rights activist, she served the NYC Board of Education for 30 years, she was also an actress and proud SAG member. She was married to the late Assemblyman Sy Posner, and is survived by her twin sister Eleanor Reben, her daughter Naomi Stein and grandson Evan. Services will be held 11am Sunday, April 22 at Krtil Funeral Home 1297 First Ave. (70th St.)

Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, the chief justice suspended by President Pervez Musharraf last month, appeared before the Supreme Judicial Council to defend himself on charges of misuse of power. He has filed a petition in the Supreme Court, the court he once headed, challenging the constitutional authority of the five-judge council, said his lawyer, Chaudhry Aitzaz Ahsan. The council adjourned the hearing until Tuesday. SALMAN MASOOD

An article in Business Day yesterday about a Supreme Court decision limiting state control of big banks misstated a word in a quotation from Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, who criticized the ruling, which upheld a regulation issued by the office of the comptroller of the currency. Mr. Frank, who heads the House Financial Services Committee, said, ''The controller has eliminated a whole bunch of state consumer laws with nothing to put in their place.'' He did not say the court had eliminated the laws.

BILLIK--Marilyn, of Livingston, New Jersey and Boca Raton, Florida, died on April 18 of lung cancer at home surrounded by family. Stylish and radiant, possessing of a joyous sense of humor, treasured by family and friends, she was raised in Millburn, New Jersey, went to Kent Place School and then attended Pembroke College of Brown University. Marilyn is survived by Gene, her husband of 56 years, her children, Buzz (Beth) Billik and Nancy (Ken) Weinrib, her brother Mal (Mickey) Poland and her grandchildren, Britton, Cameron and Cole Billik and Craig, Doug and Miles Weinrib. Graveside service will be held on Friday, April 20, 11:30am at Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, New Jersey. Visitation following the service at the family home in New Jersey, 3-7pm. Donations may be made to Saint Barnabas Hospice, West Orange, New Jersey 07052.

TOMPKINS--Rexford E. NADAP marks with great sadness the passing of one of its founders, Rexford E. Tompkins, age 90. NADAP's success is built upon the founders' foresight that education and employment play significant roles in reducing addiction and reviving the lives of individuals, families and communities. Mr. Tompkins also served as chairman of NADAP (formerly known as The National Association on Drug Abuse Problems, Inc.) from 1972 to 1978 and as interim president and CEO from 1996 to 1997. During this period, Mr. Tompkins volunteered his time and energies towards keeping NADAP viable and functional as it began transitioning into a new decade of services, under new leadership. In these roles he supported the agency through some of its most challenging and exciting periods of growth. Mr. Tompkins was dedicated to bringing economic opportunity to those in need with effective services and remained a dedicated and staunch supporter of NADAP and its mission of helping recovering substance abusers become selfsufficient and employed. His longtime commitment and leadership as a founder, former chairman and former president continued after his retirement and relocation to Florida. He will be greatly missed. John A. Darin President& CEO NADAP, Inc.

About 8,000 demonstrators gathered near President Kurmanbek Bakiev's office in Bishkek, the capital, for an eighth day of protests against him, and added a call for new parliamentary elections to their list of demands for sweeping government reforms. They have already demanded new presidential elections. Mr. Bakiev has initiated a number of compromises with the opposition in recent weeks, including appointing a critic as prime minister. Protest leaders are calling for larger demonstrations over the weekend. ILAN GREENBERG

ROSSEN--Stephen M., died April 17th, at the age of 67. A wonderful husband to Susan Ko, adored father of Benjamin, Daniel, and Dan Ko. Devoted son to Sue and the late Robert Rossen. Extraordinary brother and uncle to Ellen, Carol, and Eve Holbrook. He was smart, funny, and loving. He will be deeply missed. Contributions to the Jay Monahan Center for G.I. Health, 1315 York Ave, New York 10021. Services at 1pm, Thursday, April 19th, at the Plaza Community Funeral Home, 91st and Amsterdam.

Russia unveiled a plan to build a tunnel between Siberia and Alaska under the Bering Strait, saying the $65 billion project could be used to export Russian oil, natural gas and electricity to the United States. At 64 miles, it would be twice the length of the Channel Tunnel between Britain and the Continent. While two Ministry of Economy officials endorsed the idea, they made it clear that the Russian government had not signed off on it. ANDREW E. KRAMER

WALDMAN--Marvin, on April 18, 2007, of Bronx, NY. Beloved husband of Elenor. Devoted father of Gloria, Susan and Barbara. Dear brother of Eleanore Licht and the late Alex and Arnold. Also survived by two grandchildren, Jennifer and Samantha. Funeral service will be held at Wienstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY, Friday, 1pm. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. Donations may be made to St. Jude's Children's Hospital.

Thailand unveiled a draft constitution that eliminates direct elections for the Senate while bolstering the power of the unelected judiciary. The document, posted on Parliament's Web site, was drafted by a 35-member committee selected by the junta and will be presented at public forums beginning next week, and then to a national referendum in September. While the 1997 Constitution rescinded by the coup leaders sought to consolidate Thai politics and avoid the fractured coalitions of the 1990s, its proposed replacement seeks to decentralize power by buttressing the power of judges and bureaucrats. THOMAS FULLER

In his new book, ''The New American Story,'' Bill Bradley presents his detailed solutions for improving the United States. Regarding his former team, the Knicks, he already sees progress toward a better future. ''I think they're better than last year,'' Bradley said in Manhattan recently at the Volvo for Life Awards, which honor people who perform heroic acts.

PENDIAS--Stephen P., on April 16th, 2007, of Garden City. Beloved husband of Sophie. Devoted father of Joan Pendias and Calli Checki. Loving grandfather of Matthew. Services Thursday, 10 am, at St Paul's Greek Orthodox Cathedral, West Hempstead, NY. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

There are 100 product and furniture designers in ''& Fork,'' out from Phaidon Press next month ($69.95), chosen by 10 curators and arranged alphabetically to make a contemporary and global encyclopedia of what happens when wit, whimsy and rigor are brought to bear on ordinary items. Three highlights: the deliriously functional polypropylene underwear dryers by Manuel Bandeira, a Brazilian designer, which are shaped like bikini briefs and attach to a shower wall with suction cups, right; the purple lacquer wood console by Jaime Hayon, from Barcelona, with its 12 cartoonishly turned legs; and the reductively functional mangastrap by ixi, the design team of Xavier Moulin and Izumi Kohama, based in Okinawa, which was designed for manga (comics) readers on crowded subways, hence the name. The strap is actually a kind of vest that is padded at the upper back and fitted with vertical straps in front where your wrists can rest comfortably, supporting your whole arm and nicely turning your body into a piece of furniture. PENELOPE GREEN

A front-page article on April 4 about Arnold Blume, an 81-year-old substitute teacher on Long Island who shares his firsthand knowledge of historical events in class, included an erroneous reference from Mr. Blume to the day in 1945 when he and fellow members of the Army Air Corps assembled for a memorial service for President Franklin D. Roosevelt. The men were in their green dress uniform, not dress blues. (A spokesman for the Air Force, which succeeded the Air Corps, said the dress blues uniform was not introduced to the Air Force until 1949.)

For a decade, those April voices had lost their decibels. Wild roars for the Rangers from the slopes of Madison Square Garden simply didn't exist. In seven of those years, the Rangers, who preceded the Knicks as dollar for dollar the worst franchise in sports history, had not even qualified for the playoffs. Two years ago, because of the season-long lockout, there were no playoffs at all. When the Rangers finally squeezed into the playoffs a year ago, they were dispatched by the Devils in four straight games.

About one in four men in New York City reported binge drinking in a survey that was released yesterday by the city health department. The survey, which gathered information from 10,000 New Yorkers by telephone, was based on 2005 data, the most recent that was available, city officials said. They said the rate of binge drinking -- defined as having five or more drinks on one occasion in the past month -- was unchanged since 2002. Over all, 14 percent of adult city residents reported binge drinking, lower than the national rate of 24 percent of adults, city officials said. The survey showed that men reported binge drinking three times more frequently than women.

Remembering some of the students killed at Virginia Tech, in these biographical sketches. Rachael E. Hill, 18 A freshman, she graduated in 2006 from the Grove Avenue Christian School in Henrico County, Va. She was studying biology. Clay Fogler, school administrator for Grove Avenue, said she had a penchant for shoes and was competitive on the volleyball court. He said Ms. Hill's senior yearbook quotation from C. S. Lewis summed up what school officials believe she would say at this time: ''God, who foresaw your tribulation, has specially armed you to go through it, not without pain but without stain.'' Jarrett Lane, 22 A senior and recipient of a special scholarship for engineering students, he was in G. V. Loganathan's classroom when he was killed. He came from Narrows, Va., and was valedictorian of his class at Narrows High School in 2003. His former teachers spoke of him as a four-sport athlete, remembered for his humility and work ethic. Partahi Mamora Lumbantoruan, 34 A doctoral student in civil engineering, he was one of 16 Indonesians at Virginia Tech. He arrived three years ago from Parahyangan University in the West Java capital of Bandung. His father, a retired Army officer, said he had sold off property and cars to finance his son's tuition. Rhondy Rahardja, president of the Indonesian Students Organization, said Mr. Lumbantoruan was ''superdisciplined,'' and always wore a polo shirt tucked neatly into his pants. The Indonesian student association offered to clean up his apartment. That's where they learned his secret passion: ''He had 30 films, all about war,'' Mr. Rahardja said, from ''The Thin Red Line'' to ''The Alamo.'' Daniel P. O'Neil, 22 He was pursuing a master's in environmental engineering and also served as a teaching assistant at Virginia Tech. From Lincoln, R.I., he was an avid runner, a prolific musician and a big fan of the Beatles, friends said. Mr. O'Neil earned his bachelor's degree at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., where he studied the effects of urban development on regional watersheds. But his passion was writing music, which he posted to his Web site www.residenthippy.com. Minal Panchal, 26 An architecture student from Mumbai, India, she graduated from high school in Mumbai and the Rizvi College of Architecture. Ms. Panchal's Orkut site -- a MySpace for young Indians -- listed her passions as buildings and nature. Among her favorite books were the ''Harry Potter'' series, ''Little Women'' and ''To Kill a Mockingbird.'' Waleed Shaalan, 32 He came to the United States in 2006 from Zagazig, Egypt, leaving behind his wife and 1-year-old son, to follow in his father's footsteps studying civil engineering. He was a member of the Muslim Student Association. On the day he died he told Fahad Pasha, a roommate, that he planned to bring his family to the United States this summer. Randy Dymond, a civil engineering professor at Virginia Tech, said Mr. Shaalan saved the life of a fellow graduate student. Mr. Dymond said the student recounted to him how he and Mr. Shaalan were both in the first classroom the gunman entered. He shot Dr. Loganathan and several students. Mr. Shaalan was badly wounded and lay beside the student, who was not shot but played dead, as the gunman returned two times. Just as the gunman noticed the student, Mr. Shaalan made a move to distract him, at which point he was shot a second time and died. The student believed that Mr. Shaalan purposely distracted the gunman to save him, Mr. Dymond said. Nicole White, 20 In her junior year, she grew up in Isle of Wight County, Va., loving horses and the water. A friend, Chance Hellmann, who graduated from Smithfield High School with Ms. White in 2004, said she intended to follow a veterinary track at Virginia Tech but she was ultimately drawn to a double major, in international studies and German.

The Nets' chance to make amends for a disappointing regular season will begin in earnest this weekend, but they got an early start on their postseason push Wednesday night against the Chicago Bulls. With the playoff stakes high for both teams, the Nets came away with a 106-97 victory to vault into the sixth seed in the Eastern Conference and a first-round matchup against the Toronto Raptors. The victory allowed the Nets (41-41) to avoid a losing record and capped a late-season push.

An article on Tuesday about this year's Pulitzer Prize winners included outdated information from the Pulitzer board in some copies about the prize for editorial writing. After awarding it to the editorial board of The Daily News in New York, the Pulitzer board updated its Web site to note that it was won by only three writers from the paper: Arthur Browne, Heidi Evans and Beverly Weintraub. The article also referred incompletely in some copies to the reporters for The Wall Street Journal who contributed to the newspaper's prize for public service. In addition to Charles Forelle, James Bandler and Mark Maremont, Steve Stecklow worked on the project about the unethical practices of business executives.

The Canadian National Railway lifted a lockout against striking workers in five cities after a special labor law, passed Tuesday by the House of Commons through a special accelerated process, was approved by the Senate and swiftly signed into law by Governor-General Michaëlle Jean, the formal head of state. An arbitrator will now impose a settlement. The United Transportation Union began rotating strikes against Canadian National last week after its workers overwhelmingly rejected a tentative contract. That proposed contract had ended a 15-day general strike in February that had caused industrial disruption in Canada and shipping delays to the United States. The dispute focuses on work rules, particularly those concerning older employees. IAN AUSTEN

An article yesterday about Pulitzer Prizes awarded this year to books published by Alfred A. Knopf misstated the title of a Knopf winner from last year. It was ''American Prometheus: The Triumph and Tragedy of J. Robert Oppenheimer'' -- not ''Robert J. Oppenheimer.''

POPE--Leavitt J., of Scarsdale, NY, on April 18, 2007. Husband of Martha Pope. Father of Joseph, Daniel, Patricia, Elizabeth, Nancy, Maria, Joan, Christopher, Virginia, Matthew and Charles. Grandfather of 24. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Sons, Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm, Friday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Pius X Church Scarsdale, on Saturday, April 21, at 11am. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. Pius X Church, Secor Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

Despite big drops in sales, the top two albums on last week's Billboard chart retained their positions this week. The pop compilation ''Now That's What I Call Music!'' Vol. 24 holds at No. 1 with 89,000 copies sold in its third week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan -- 58 percent less than it sold last week -- and ''Let It Go'' (Curb) by Tim McGraw, above left, sold 66,000, down 66 percent. Akon's ''Konvicted'' (Universal) sold 60,000, which was 20 percent less than last week. But in the peculiar calculus of this year's music slump, that was enough to send the album up six spots to No. 3. Bright Eyes, led by the Nebraska indie-rock darling Conor Oberst, above right, had its best sales and chart week ever, with ''Cassadaga'' (Saddle Creek) selling 58,000 copies to reach No. 4. HellYeah, a metal supergroup featuring members of Pantera, Mudvayne and Nothingface, opened at No. 9 with 45,000 sales of its self-titled debut album on Epic, and ''A Hundred Miles or More: A Collection'' (Rounder) by the bluegrass fiddler and singer Alison Krauss, held at No. 10. BEN SISARIO

RAEBURN--Robert A., 77, former president N. S. Meyer, Inc., died April 17, 2007, at NY Presbyterian Hospital following a long battle with cancer. Mr. Raeburn graduated from the Virginia Military Institute. He distinguished himself as a member of the Institute's swim team, setting southern conference records. He was a very active supporter of the Regiment of Graduates, serving as class agent for the class of 1951 until this past year. Following the sale of N. S. Meyer, Inc. in 2000, Mr. Raeburn donated to the Virginia Military Institute Museum his entire collection of original Civil War Paintings including the well known ''Drummer Boy''. Mr. Raeburn was a member of the Board of Trustees of the NY Military Academy. He was a great supporter of the ''Puppies Behind Bars''. Mr. Raeburn was predeceased by his first wife, Joann, who passed away in 1992. He is survived by his widow Donna, a daughter, Victoria Benton (Leigh), a son Robert (Karen), four grandchildren, Christopher, P.J., Kyle, and Lauren, and three great - grandsons. Friends may call Friday, April 20th, 25 and 7-9 pm with the service at Frank E. Campbell, Saturday, 11:30 am. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to the Virginia Military Institute or Puppies Behind Bars.

A homeless man died in his jail cell while in police custody on Monday, the police said yesterday. The man, Dennis Cafila, 55, had been arrested on Saturday at the corner of Seneca Avenue and Faile Street for criminal possession of a controlled substance. He was found dead in his cell at the central booking facility in Morris Heights, and his death did not immediately appear suspicious, the police said. The medical examiner is expected to conduct an autopsy to determine the cause of death. JENNIFER 8. LEE

In an awkward night of television, as network news specials about the shootings at Virginia Polytechnic Institute bumped up against country music performances on ''American Idol,'' Fox eclipsed all its rivals in the ratings Tuesday. According to Nielsen estimates, 25.9 million viewers tuned in for the music competition at 8 p.m. NBC's ''Dateline,'' with Stone Phillips reporting from Blacksburg, Va., ranked fourth in the same hour with 5.1 million viewers. ABC and CBS fared better with their specials at 10. ABC's ''Primetime,'' with Diane Sawyer, led the hour over all with 11.3 million viewers, while CBS's ''48 Hours,'' which featured Katie Couric as anchor, finished third (6.5 million) behind a repeat of NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (8.3 million). ABC posted a solid second place for the night with a ''Dancing With the Stars'' recap show at 8 (6.9 million) followed by results show at 9 (16.2 million). Fox's ''House,'' however, remained No. 1 in the 9 p.m. hour (22.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

Both sides in the abortion struggle predicted that the Supreme Court's decision on Wednesday would escalate the drive for new abortion restrictions in state legislatures and push the issue of abortion rights -- and the Supreme Court -- squarely into the 2008 presidential election. The decision was a major victory for social conservatives, a validation of their decade-long strategy of pushing for step-by-step restrictions on abortion while working to change the composition of the Supreme Court.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 171 Killed in Deadliest Day Of Baghdad Security Plan Bombs ravaged Baghdad in five explosions aimed mainly at Shiite crowds, killing at least 171 people in the deadliest day in the capital since the American-led security plan for the city took effect. A1 After weeks of sparring over financing the next phase of the war in Iraq, President Bush and Congressional leaders softened their tone but failed to resolve their differences over a timeline for the withdrawal of American troops. A10 Anger in Iran After Court Ruling The Iranian Supreme Court has overturned the murder convictions of six members of a prestigious state militia who killed five people they considered ''morally corrupt.'' The reversal has produced anger and controversy across Iran. A1 Aid for Endangered Crops Repositories of endangered crops that underpin the global food supply are eroding with regularity, experts say, as war, storms or bad management cause seed stores to deteriorate. Now, the first international effort to restore the repositories will receive an infusion of funds. A8 Bush Presses Sudan on Darfur President Bush warned Sudan that the United States would impose stiff economic sanctions if it did not bring an end to the violence in Darfur. A12 3 Evangelicals Slain in Turkey Three people were found with their throats slit in a publishing house in eastern Turkey that printed Bibles and other Christian literature, the authorities said. A11 NATIONAL A14-25 Justices Uphold a Ban On Late-Term Abortion The Supreme Court reversed course on abortion, upholding the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act in a 5-to-4 decision that promises to reframe the abortion debate and define the young Roberts court. A19 Senate Blocks Medicare Plan A pillar of the Democrats' program tumbled when the Senate blocked a proposal to let Medicare negotiate lower drug prices for millions of older Americans, a practice now forbidden by law. A20 Red Cross Names New Chief The American Red Cross named Mark W. Everson, the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, as its president and chief executive. He is expected to take over in May. Jon S. Corzine's sport utility vehicle crashed on a highway, critically injuring him. HAUGEN--John C. The directors and staff of the American Parkinson Disease Association mourn the loss of our friend and treasurer of seven years. John was a quiet man of charity, compassion and faith, who served with fervor yet without flourish. We will miss him deeply, as will the many people whose lives he touched, and extend our sincerest condolences to Sophia, John Jr., Katryn, Mary Virginia and his entire family including Mattingly. Vincent N. Gattullo, President Joel Gerstel, Executive Director

MICROSOFT WINDOWS FOR $3 Microsoft plans to offer a stripped-down version of Windows, Office and other software for $3 to people in developing nations. The program is to be announced in Beijing by Bill Gates. [Page C1.] A CHECK ON EXORBITANT PAY The House has begun debating a bill that would give shareholders the right to a nonbinding vote on the pay packages of senior executives of public companies. [C2.] 10 HOURS WITHOUT A BLACKBERRY Where were you when the BlackBerrys went out? On Tuesday night technical problems cut off more than five million American BlackBerry users from their cherished wireless e-mail. Service was restored 10 long, data-starved hours later. [C1.] OUTSOURCING'S NEW LOCALE Cities in Central and Eastern Europe are turning into centers for outsourced white-collar jobs for multinational corporations. The countries offer a highly educated, multilingual pool of talent in an increasingly affluent consumer market -- all barely a stone's throw from prime clients. [C1.] JOURNAL NAMES TOP EDITOR The competition for the most powerful position in business journalism ended as Marcus W. Brauchli was named managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, succeeding Paul E. Steiger, who has held the top job in the newsroom since 1991. [C1.] $81 MILLION PROFIT AT AMR The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, swung to an $81 million profit from a loss a year ago as it filled more seats, charged higher fares and paid less for fuel. AMR is the first major United States airline to report first-quarter results. Its profit may set the tone for the industry, which endured several weather-related cancellations in the first three months of the year. [C2.] 2 NEW PLANTS FOR CHRYSLER The Chrysler Group will spend $1.43 billion to build two plants in Michigan that will make parts for Chrysler and Mercedes vehicles, even as the American and German companies prepare for a possible divorce. [C3.] PROFIT SURGE AT JPMORGAN CHASE JPMorgan Chase, the nation's third-largest bank, reported a 55 percent surge in first-quarter profit, reflecting strength across most of its primary businesses. Still, the report showed some softness in the retail banking and credit card divisions. [C2.] U.S.-BRITISH LABOR MERGER The United Steelworkers announced that it would seek to merge with two large British unions in a move that would create the first trans-Atlantic labor group. [C2.] EBAY ENHANCED BY NEW UNITS EBay posted better-than-expected profit in the first quarter as several of its newer businesses compensated for disappointing results in its mainstay auction service. The faster-growing units include shopping.com, a price comparison site; some classified listing sites; and Skype, the online voice chat service. ''We are on track with our well-crafted portfolio,'' said Meg Whitman, above, eBay's chief executive. [C3.] YAHOO SUED IN TORTURE CASE A Chinese political prisoner and his wife sued Yahoo in federal court in San Francisco, accusing the company of abetting the commission of torture by helping Chinese authorities identify political dissidents who were later beaten and imprisoned. [C4.] DELL STILL SLIPPING Dell's personal computer sales continued to decline in the first quarter, and Dell continued to lose market share, according to analyses of PC sales. [C4.] LIFE AFTER HARVARD Lawrence H. Summers, who was forced to step down as president of Harvard amid controversy and criticism, is facing a much friendlier audience in Asia, where his views on global economics draw overflow crowds. [C5.] MOTOROLA'S PROSPECTS DIM Motorola, the wireless phone maker, reported a loss for the first quarter and issued a disappointing forecast for the second, leading some analysts to question whether it would be able to return to profitability this year. [C4.] TEACH FIRST, THEN SELL Sharp Electronics, which makes rooftop solar panels, has embarked on a six-month campaign to teach homeowners how solar energy works. Advertising. [C10.] A RECORD FOR THE DOW The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 12,800 for the first time, a recovery from Wall Street's steep decline in February. [C10.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. ABBOTT LABORATORIES, the pharmaceutical and medical products maker, reported a 19 percent drop in first-quarter profit Wednesday as a result of acquisition costs, but exceeded Wall Street estimates because of its fast-growing drug business. (AP) E*TRADE FINANCIAL, the brokerage firm, reported first-quarter results that beat Wall Street projections, but it warned that recent market turbulence would dent earnings for the year. (AP) ALLSTATE SAID THAT its first-quarter profit rose 5 percent as investment gains offset a decline in revenue from property-liability insurance premiums. (AP) KRAFT FOODS, reporting results for the first time as an independent company, posted a 30 percent decline in first-quarter earnings. (AP)

A member of the Public Service Commission, which regulates public utilities in New York State, charged yesterday that an aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer threatened to have her removed if she did not back away from efforts to investigate Consolidated Edison over last year's blackout in Queens. The member, Cheryl Buley, a commissioner appointed last year by Gov. George E. Pataki, made the accusation against Steve A. Mitnick, an assistant secretary to Mr. Spitzer, as the commission voted unanimously yesterday to proceed with the investigation. The investigation, which was opposed by the utility and by New York City officials, allows the commission to determine whether the company can charge customers some of the costs associated with the blackout. Christine Anderson, a spokeswoman for Mr. Spitzer, said no one from the administration told Ms. Buley to vote against the investigation, which she said the governor supports. NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

The Critics' Choice column on Monday about new CDs misstated the nationality of Dr. Luke, who produced some of the songs on the Avril Lavigne album ''The Best Damn Thing.'' He is American, not Swedish.

ATHLETES come up with all manner of excuses not to wear sunscreen: sticky hands, stinging eyes, feeling like a grease monkey, to name a few. But active people in particular should take precautions, said Dr. Brian Adams, a dermatology professor at the University of Cincinnati. ''Skin cancer is one of the few things for which participation in sports actually increases risk,'' said Dr. Adams, author of ''Sports Dermatology.'' Athletes spend extended periods of time in the sun, and often ''at the worst times, between 11 and 4, when you have practices.'' Sweating also increases your chance of getting burned, he added.

When Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales takes the witness chair on Thursday before the Senate Judiciary Committee, the dismissal of the United States attorney from New Mexico will be a topic of particular scrutiny, committee members and their staff said. That case, perhaps more than any of the other ousters, demonstrates the interaction of the Republican Party, the White House, a prominent Republican senator and Mr. Gonzales that led up to the firings.

A sports article on Sunday about the challenges facing Nascar after years of growth referred incorrectly to the finances of International Speedway Corporation, which owns many tracks where top races are run. The company's first-quarter revenue fell 4.5 percent compared with the same quarter a year ago -- not 19 percent, which was the decline in first-quarter earnings compared with the same period. The article also referred incompletely to the company's explanation for these declines. Aside from lower attendance and a drop in concessions sales, the company also cited higher expenses.

Mayer, Trustee, and Day School Board Member and Ninette are respected leaders and benefactors. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Arthur Schneier

A federal judge has denied a motion by bicycling groups seeking a preliminary injunction barring the city from enforcing regulations on large-scale bicycle rides, city officials said yesterday. The bicyclists, who have sued to overturn city rules that say groups of 50 or more riders must obtain parade permits, claim that the regulations violate their right to free assembly; city officials have argued that the police have the right to enforce regulations to maintain public order and safety. In a decision on Tuesday, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court said he was not convinced that an order barring enforcement was justified before a trial on the lawsuit.
HOLLANDER--Selma. 4/18/94. We love you forever. Alex, Jane, Beth, Wendy, and Herb

A memorial service for the stage and screen actor Roscoe Lee Browne is scheduled for 6 p.m. Sunday at the Church of St. Charles Borromeo, 211 West 141st Street, in Harlem. Mr. Browne, 81, died on April 11.

With Attorney General Alberto Gonzales testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee today, the Op-Ed page asked four legal experts to step into a senator's shoes and list three questions they would ask Mr. Gonzales. 1. Can politics truly be kept out of the investigations into the recent dismissal of several United States attorneys if such oversight is being led by a senator who is himself responsible for the election of Democratic senatorial candidates in 2008?

A bomb planted in the road exploded under a United Nations car in the southern city of Kandahar on Tuesday, killing four security guards from Nepal and their Afghan driver. The five men were contractors working for the United Nations Office of Project Services, a support agency that has worked on large projects in Afghanistan, including running elections. The explosion tore apart the vehicle and burned the men inside. CARLOTTA GALL

''Destination: Berlin,'' a collection of new products by German designers at MoMA Design Stores starting May 10, offers practical solutions to vexing everyday problems. The Four-Hole Aliacta Vase ($110), above, comes with a removable steel shell with small openings. ''If you buy a lot of flowers, some of them are not looking good after two or three days,'' said one of its designers, Jörg Adam of the Adam & Harborth Designbüro, ''and you need a smaller vase.'' The Lined Glasses ($70 for six), below, by Chul Cheong, Christine Nogtev and Jork Andre Dieter, are etched with one to six bands, to help you find your glass at any dinner party with half a dozen guests, tops. MoMA Design Stores, 81 Spring Street and 44 West 53rd Street, or momastore.org. ELAINE LOUIE
