BROWN--Jack M. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of the Jewish Home & Hospital mourn the passing of Life Trustee and former president Jack M. Brown. Jack was a wonderful man, a dedicated leader and generous benefactor. He was proud to have been involved with ''so fine an institution that helps people through the hard parts of life''. He served as president from 1967-1972 and was part of the team that acquired the Kaufman building for the Home. Those who had the pleasure of knowing and working with him will fondly remember Jack. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Dorothy, sister Madelyn Brown Harris, and nephews Jack and Steven Brown Harris. Gene D. Resnick, M.D. Chairman of the Board Audrey S. Weiner, D.S.W. President/CEO

The New York Red Bulls are close to completing a deal to trade the second-year defender Marvell Wynne to Toronto F.C. for a draft pick and other considerations. The Red Bulls last year made a trade to secure the top pick in the league draft and took Wynne No. 1 over all out of U.C.L.A. Mo Johnston was the team's coach at the time; he is now the coach of the Canadian expansion team. The Red Bulls on Tuesday acquired striker Juan Pablo Ángel from Aston Villa of the English Premier League and need to free a spot on their 18-man roster. JACK BELL

Due to a fact-checking error, in some editions of Wednesday's Times, Maureen Dowd's column cited the wrong former Iraqi official as critical of the U.S. invasion of Iraq. He was Ali Allawi, the former finance minister, not Ayad Allawi, the former prime minister.

To the Editor: Re ''In Words and Silence, Hints of Anger and Isolation'' (front page, April 18):

FOR most people, a decorator show house is more a place of fantasy than reality. The furniture and the artwork are often expensive, the rooms larger than life. But there are always professionally executed details that one can learn from and ideas for do-it-yourselfers to try at home. This year the Kips Bay Decorator Show House, a six-floor town house at 14 East 82nd Street, is filled with unusual wall treatments that can be adapted for use in real homes with a little modification. A number of new products on display are available to the public. Of course, the decorators who created these rooms are available for hire, but sometimes it is more fun to try your own hand at designing your living space. 1. In the dining area, L'Olivier, a New York florist, submerged pincushion blossoms in cylinders of water instead of filling vases the usual way, and Eric Cohler walled off the space with Definition resin panels by Armstrong. The two-by-six-foot panels come in 16 colors and textures, and attach to the floor and ceiling with wires. Each panel is $699; (877) 276-7876 or armstrong.com. 2. Using a simple spray mount, Randall Beale and Carl Lana glued aluminum foil to the wainscoting along the staircase between the entrance foyer and the first floor. ''Our inspiration was Andy Warhol's Silver Factory,'' Mr. Beale said. ''After all, isn't a show house about experimentation?'' He added: ''The foil nicks, but it acquires a patina, and it is easy to repair. If I was doing this in a real house I would coat the foil with clear polyurethane.'' 3. Noel Jeffrey cut grass cloth wallcovering into squares and applied them to the walls, creating a checkerboard pattern. Grass cloth comes in many colors and can be bought in rolls like regular wallpaper. Mr. Jeffrey used all one color, but a multicolor pattern would also work. 4. On the second-floor landing, Ed Ku and Etienne Coffinier hammered big nailheads into the wall to create a swirling pattern to give the effect of molding or wallpaper. 5. Jamie Drake used fabrics from his new F. Schumacher collection, which was ''inspired by all the French fashion stuff I love,'' he said. The chairs are covered in a silk-and-cotton blend called Babe's Tweed ($93 a yard) and the shades are made of a sheer called Bubble Lounge ($141 a yard); to the trade, from F. Schumacher, (800) 332-3384 or fschumacher.com for showrooms. 6. Wayne Nathan and Carol Egan's installation is a novel and inexpensive way to cover a wall: cut pieces of packing tape printed with words like fragile, then plaster them on the wall to create texture and pattern. Mr. Nathan and Ms. Egan had their tape printed in silver and white, but red and white from the hardware store would work just as well. 7. Eva Lee, a decorative arts painter and a partner in Christianson Lee Studios, used a decoupage technique on the stairwell between the fourth and fifth floors. Handpainted faux bois paper was applied to the wall, pieces of digitally cut leaf-shaped paper were layered on top, and the wall was varnished, replicating the appearance of inlaid wood. To create a similar effect, attach pieces of paper to the wall with wallpaper paste, then varnish the whole thing. Wrinkles in the paper will add texture.

A pillar of the Democrats' program tumbled on Wednesday when the Senate blocked a proposal to let Medicare negotiate lower drug prices for millions of older Americans, a practice now forbidden by law. Democrats could not muster the 60 votes needed to take up the measure in the face of staunch opposition from Republicans. The opponents said private insurers and their agents, known as pharmacy benefit managers, were already negotiating large discounts for Medicare beneficiaries.

A film series entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday, about the three-part Chinese documentary ''West of Tracks'' at Anthology Film Archives, misstated the opening dates for the first two parts, ''Rust'' and ''Remnants.'' ''Rust'' opened yesterday and ''Remnants'' opens today; they did not open last Friday and Saturday. (As the article noted, part three, ''Rails,'' opens tomorrow.)

Along with the usual exhibitors at the 15th annual Antique Garden Furniture Show and Sale, opening April 27 at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, will be several showing more exotic garden follies. Ana Thompson, owner of the Thompson Studio in Berwyn, Pa., will sell 17th- and 18th-century Chinese limestone garden seats from Shanxi province ($8,500 to $15,000). Barbara Israel, from Katonah, N.Y., whose booth will resemble a shop in southwest France, will sell mostly French items, with a few exceptions, among them the bronze ''Baby Bacchus'' ($25,000), above, by Beatrice Fenton, a Philadelphia sculptor (1887-1983). Through April 29; nybg.org. ELAINE LOUIE

After 18 years of making nature-inspired tabletop objects in metals like bronze, copper and stainless steel, Michael Aram has opened his first store, in Chelsea, above. Mr. Aram, far left, said he has made more than 2,000 pieces and wanted a ''handmade'' space -- ''like my work'' -- where he could show them off. The designer, an American now based in New Delhi, collaborated on the plan with James Harb, a New York architect. The store has hand-finished black-plaster walls, gold-leaf panels and tiles that Mr. Aram made himself. Items for sale include the Leaf series of trays in polished aluminum ($27.50 to $95), top left, and the Pod Round Platter ($210), left. Michael Aram Flagship Store, 136 West 18th Street, (212) 461-6903. TIM McKEOUGH

The Supreme Court reversed course on abortion on Wednesday, upholding the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act in a 5-to-4 decision that promises to reframe the abortion debate and define the young Roberts court. The most important vote was that of the newest justice, Samuel A. Alito Jr. In another 5-to-4 decision seven years ago, his predecessor, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, voted to strike down a similar state law. Justice Alito's vote to uphold the federal law made the difference in the outcome announced Wednesday.

Officials said the body of a woman found buried in mud in the mountainous northern province of Ifugao was that of a missing Peace Corps volunteer, Julia Campbell. They said she had apparently been murdered. ''Work continues at the site to determine the circumstances,'' said a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Manila, Matthew Lussenhop. A regional police commander, Chief Superintendent Raul Gonzales, told The Associated Press, ''There is a probability that there was foul play.'' Ms. Campbell, 40, a former freelance reporter in New York who contributed to The New York Times in the 1990s and joined the Corps in 2005, was last seen on April 8 as she set off for a hike in the village of Batad, which offers a magnificent view of the centuries-old rice terraces, one of the country's tourist attractions. Ms. Campbell, from Fairfax, Va., was one of 137 Peace Corps volunteers in the Philippines. Colleagues said that her service was wrapping up and that she was excited about returning to New York. CARLOS H. CONDE

We will miss his presence in our lives, his love and devotion to his family, his generosity of spirit, sense of humor and passion for life. Funeral service: Friday, April 20, 11am, St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. HART--Kitty Carlisle. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Kitty Carlisle Hart, our irrepressible, multi-talanted, and much loved Honorary Trustee, colleague, and friend. Always a celebrated champion of the arts in New York, she turned her personal and professional spotlight on the cultural life of this city and state, first as an artist and later as chair of the New York State Council on the Arts for two decades. She was part of this museum in so many ways--as performer, lecturer, co-chair of our musical instruments visiting committee, advisor, audience member--always gracious, helpful, and wise. We will miss her elegance, vivacity, and wit, and will hold a song in our hearts for this outstanding woman whose zest for life and art did so much to enrich us all. We'll be loving her always. James R. Houghton, Chrman. Philippe de Montebello, Dir. Emily K. Rafferty, President. $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. Breast cancer rates fell sharply in 2003, and the lower rate remained in 2004, researchers are reporting today. The finding, they say, fits with a hypothesis they advanced last December when they had data only from 2003. At that time, national data showed that breast cancer rates fell by nearly 15 percent in the 18 months from July 2002 through December 2003.

Schedules have been announced for the 2007 JVC Jazz Festival-New York, from June 17 to 30. Highlights include the Keith Jarrett-Jack DeJohnette-Gary Peacock trio (June 21, Carnegie Hall); a concert celebrating the bassist Ron Carter, including Mr. Carter with Herbie Hancock, Wayne Shorter, Jim Hall, Mulgrew Miller and others (June 27, Carnegie Hall); Nancy Wilson (June 29, Carnegie Hall); a double bill of Branford Marsalis's quartet and Joshua Redman's new trio (June 20, Town Hall); a concert with the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, including Allen Toussaint and New York-based guests including Jenny Scheinman and Steve Wilson (June 19, Town Hall); double bills with the singers India.Arie and Lizz Wright (June 22, Carnegie Hall), and Patti LaBelle with Lou Donaldson's quartet (June 23, Carnegie Hall). Three shows at Zankel Hall include Lee Konitz playing with four different ensembles (June 24). The festival also encompasses a week of world-jazz shows at the Jazz Standard, as well as concerts at the Rubin Museum of Art, Hunter College's Kaye Playhouse, and the Prospect Park Band Shell. Tickets went on sale yesterday at the concerts' respective box offices. Information: festivalproductions.net. BEN RATLIFF

To the Editor: Re ''China's Signals on Warming'' (editorial, April 16):

Stones' Mild Horses Plan Troubles Animal Lovers A plan to sedate more than 300 horses at a Belgrade race track where a Rolling Stones concert on July 14 is expected to draw more than 100,000 people has ignited rage among Serbian animal lovers, Reuters reported yesterday. O.R.C.A., the country's largest animal protection society, said that the noise and vibrations of the concert would be extremely harmful to the animals and added that sedating them is not the answer. The society said that if it failed to persuade the organizers to move the concert from the Hippodrome, Belgrade's largest fenced space, it would appeal directly to the Stones -- including Mick Jagger, above -- who have never performed in Serbia. ''I believe we'll succeed, since such a reputable band will not allow such a stain on its record,'' said Elvir Burazerovic, the president of O.R.C.A. A Book Club of One The Canadian author Yann Martel, below, who wrote the best-selling novel ''Life of Pi,'' wants the country's prime minister, Stephen Harper, to pay more attention to the arts. So Mr. Martel is sending him some reading. Mr. Martel said he was upset that Mr. Harper had appeared to pay no attention during a recent ceremony honoring Canadian artists, Reuters reported. ''But he must have moments of stillness,'' Mr. Martel said. ''For as long as Stephen Harper is prime minister of Canada, I vow to send him every two weeks, mailed on a Monday, a book that has been known to expand stillness.'' First up: ''The Death of Ivan Ilyich'' by Leo Tolstoy. There was no immediate comment from Mr. Harper's office. Mr. Martel said he would post all selections and other developments on the Internet at whatisstephenharperreading.ca. 'Survivor' Heads for China China will be the location of the 14th edition of the CBS reality show ''Survivor,'' Variety.com reported. American productions on the mainland have been rare, but China has become more open. The CBS series will be the first American network show to be filmed there, Variety said. Kirov Ballet Plans A City Center Visit The Kirov Ballet and Orchestra will perform at New York City Center for the first time when it appears there next year, from April 1 to 20. Under the artistic direction of Valery Gergiev and the director of the ballet Makhar Vaziev, the company from St. Petersburg, Russia, will dance repertory classics including Petipa's ''Kingdom of Shadows'' from ''La Bayadère''; Fokine's ''Scheherazade'' and ''Chopiniana''; Gorsky's ''Grand Pas de Deux'' from ''Don Quixote''; Balanchine's ''Jewels'' and ''Ballet Imperial'' and Forsythe's ''Septet.'' Tickets go on sale on Friday. Tickets for the 75th Radio City Christmas Spectacular go on sale at 9 a.m. Sunday. The show, featuring new scenes and Rockette performance numbers and new Rockette costumes, will run from Nov. 9 through Dec. 30 at Radio City Music Hall. Gere's Kisses Reach Court India's overburdened judicial system has two new cases after three lawyers filed complaints against Richard Gere, 57, for kissing the actress Shilpa Shetty, below, 31, at an AIDS awareness rally in New Delhi, The Associated Press reported. Public displays of affection are largely taboo in India. In one complaint a lawyer accused the actors of committing ''an obscene act,'' the Press Trust of India reported. Two other lawyers filed another complaint in Ghaziabad, a town on the outskirts of New Delhi, naming Ms. Shetty and private television channels for showing videos of the incident. Ms. Shetty said the hug and kisses were not obscene and that the public was overreacting. Yesterday, her representative, Dale Bhagwagar, declined comment on the court complaints but said, ''The media should concentrate on the cause of AIDS awareness rather than making an issue out of kisses.''

Please post your comments on my India column about sex trafficking, or about the related video. I particularly welcome ideas about what we should do about the problem, or experiences related to it. Just hit the comment button.

Doug Mientkiewicz said he noticed only one obscene gesture directed at him Friday night, which he considers a victory as a former Red Sox player now with the Yankees. Actually, Mientkiewicz mused, they probably should cheer for him, since he's batting .139.

Remember the swanky bachelor pad in which Daniel Cleaver discovers that Bridget Jones wears big white tummy control knickers? It's on the market for £3.2 million -- or about $6.4 million. Owner Antoine Blondeau is selling the 3,900-square-foot three-bedroom duplex overlooking the Thames that's located near London's Borough market through Savills real estate agency at www.savills.com. The property featured in several scenes in the 2001 comedy starring Hugh Grant and Renee Zellweger.

Daisuke Matsuzaka will be introduced to the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry when he starts for Boston on Sunday night at Fenway Park. Matsuzaka, who is 1-2 with a 2.70 earned run average, has already shown that he is poised and is unlikely to be bothered by the extra attention.

As writers, we, of course, do not root for particular players or teams. We root for good things to write about, and as John Maine dismantled the Marlins through six innings on Thursday night, I started wondering whether I would finally get to see a no-hitter. Out of all the potentially superlative individual performances (A-Rod included), I would much prefer watching a pitcher on top of his game. In every no-hitter, there seems to be a little bit of luck involved, the one close play at a base or a great catch by an outfielder. But for the most part, you cannot hold another team without a hit if you're looking like today's starter, Oliver Perez, did in his ugly outing on April 11 against the Phillies.

From the 2008 campaign contenders, to the killings at Virginia Tech to Attorney General Alberto Gonzales' testimony, the past week's news should keep guests on the news shows busy.
The Chicago Tribune has a major profile today of Michelle Obama, Senator Barack Obama's wife, capturing not only her personality but also her strategic role in his campaign.
Beatings of suspects by Iraqi soldiers, which appear to be widespread, are a largely undiscussed dilemma.
Photographs by James Hill of the people who live in Chukotka, a blistering cold region in the Russian Arctic.
This is why we're supposed to be cynical in this business.
Calvin Sims and Elaine Sciolino discuss France’s elections.
The Red Sox rallied for five runs in the bottom of the eighth inning, overcoming a four-run deficit to upend Mariano Rivera and the Yankees Friday night.
Tim Hudson overwhelmed the previously scorching Mets, shutting them out through eight innings before they scored three times in the ninth off Rafael Soriano.

A building inspector found a man’s body yesterday in the basement of 542 Bainbridge Street in Ocean Hill, the police said. The victim, identified as Donell Johnson, 22, a tenant of the apartment building, was found face down with a gunshot wound to his head, the police said. Investigators he said that Mr. Johnson was probably murdered because no weapon was found near his body. It was unclear last night how long the body had been in the basement.

A State Supreme Court justice declined yesterday to issue a restraining order temporarily halting the demolition of nine vacant buildings to make way for the Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn. The restraining order had been requested by Develop Don’t Destroy Brooklyn, which opposes the scale of the 22-acre project that is to encompass housing, office and retail space and a basketball arena. The group had argued that the developer, Forest City Ratner, should not be allowed to begin demolishing buildings before May 3, the date of a hearing on a lawsuit challenging the state’s environmental review and approval of the project. Justice Joan Madden said that the plaintiffs had failed to substantiate their argument that the demolition would “irrevocably harm the neighborhood,” but that she was not judging the suit’s merits.
Vermont senators voted to call for the impeachment of President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney, saying their actions have raised “serious questions of constitutionality.”

Workers found the bodies of two miners trapped when a wall section collapsed in an open-pit coal mine in western Maryland, a federal mine official said. The official, Bob Cornett, acting regional director for the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration, said the men, one of whom was found in a backhoe, and the other, found in a bulldozer, appeared to have died instantly. The cause of the collapse was under investigation. Mr. Cornett said heavy rain and the ground’s freezing and thawing could be a factor. The mine, about 150 miles west of Baltimore, has had no fatal injuries since at least 1995 and was not cited for violations in its most recent inspection, which began March 5, according the federal mine agency.
Democratic efforts to raise the minimum wage to $7.25 an hour from $5.15 got a boost as House and Senate negotiators reached a deal on business-tax incentives to accompanying the increase.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit said it would not step down from the latest appeal by Mumia Abu-Jamal, who is on death row for killing a police officer in 1981
A federal appeals court rejected an effort to halt carrying out Arizona’s requirement that residents prove they are American citizens when they register to vote.
After pulling within a goal with seven minutes left, the Islanders pressed their attack, but they could not get the puck past Sabres goalkeeper Ryan Miller, who finished with 30 saves.
One of the most delicate tasks in the inquiry will be to determine New Jersey Gov. Jon S. Corzine's role in his caravan’s violation of traffic laws.
Goaltender Martin Brodeur stopped everything, and often spectacularly, leading the Devils to a victory and a 3-2 lead in the best-of-seven series.

The netherworld of limbo, long speculated in Roman Catholic teaching as the destination of babies who die unbaptized, has been replaced with the “prayerful hope” that they reach heaven. Pope Benedict XVI signed a theological report, years in the making, that effectively demoted limbo, a place neither in heaven nor in hell, where unbaptized babies would not be in communion with God but would nonetheless enjoy eternal happiness. Many in the church felt the idea, never formally a part of church doctrine, was outdated and caused undue worry for parents.

President Rafael Correa’s proposal to rewrite Ecuador’s Constitution won 81.7 percent of the votes in a national referendum last Sunday, according to final results. More than 70 percent of Ecuador’s 9.2 million voters participated. Mr. Correa, an economist who has allied himself with President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, wants a new constitution to wrest power from political elites and the country’s unpopular Congress.

The American Embassy in Berlin said it would tighten security measures at diplomatic and consular facilities in Germany because of a “heightened security threat.” It also urged Americans in Germany to be more vigilant about their safety. An embassy spokesman, Robert A. Wood, declined to give specifics, but said American officials were responding to recent warnings by German authorities that the country faced “an increased threat from terrorism.”.

Construction workers in Beijing using pick axes started demolishing a complex of three single-story homes, including one belonging to a family that has fought eviction for more than five years while two people were still inside. Li Xiuyun said her 80-year-old husband and 20-year-old mentally impaired son were inside the building on the northern edge. The workers tore down the southern building before stopping for the day, people at the site said. The standoff drew large crowds of angry neighbors who shouted at security guards. Similar scenes have played out across the capital as part of a building boom ahead of the Beijing 2008 Olympic Games.

The government is intensifying efforts to combat Japanese encephalitis, an untreatable viral disease spread by mosquitoes that kills one in three children who contract it. India said it would finance the immunization of 20 million children in nine states before July, when the monsoon season brings rains that increase infection rates. It obtained the vaccine, which costs about 25 cents per dose, from the Chengdu Institute of Biological Products, a part of the China National Biotec Corp. PATH, an international nonprofit group, negotiated the lower price on behalf of developing countries.

North Korea reiterated that it would allow international nuclear inspectors into the country as soon as it could confirm that funds frozen in a Macao bank had been released. According to the official Korean Central News Agency, Ri Je-son, the director general of North Korea’s Atomic Energy Department, delivered that message in a response to a request by the International Atomic Energy Agency to send inspectors. North Korea repeated that it remained committed to a Feb. 13 agreement under which it would allow inspectors in and shut down its Yongbyon nuclear plant in return for energy aid.

’ A “coalition of the willing” may be needed to enforce peace in Somalia, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said in a report to the United Nations Security Council. He said a United Nations force might work if fighting stopped and armed groups allowed for outside monitoring. But if the political process fails and violence gets worse, “an operation, mandated by the United Nations, mounted by and composed of a coalition of the willing with the appropriate capabilities to deal with the high paramilitary threat, would be better suited.” His report, to be discussed by the Council next week, came as the Elman Peace and Human Rights Organization in Mogadishu said three days of battles in the city pitting Ethiopian and Somali troops against Islamist insurgents had killed 113 people and the United Nations’ refugee agency said 321,000 people had fled Mogadishu since February.

An article on Thursday about questions surrounding the adequacy of background checks for gun buyers in the wake of the massacre at Virginia Polytechnic Institute incorrectly described the meaning of Virginia’s being a “shall issue” state. The term refers to the qualifications for obtaining a permit to carry a concealed weapon, not for obtaining a weapon.

A picture of Representative John T. Doolittle on Thursday with an article about a search of his home by the F.B.I. carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Pablo Martinez Monsivais/Associated Press, not Max Whittaker for The New York Times.

A front-page article yesterday about the angry writings of Seung-Hui Cho, who went on a shooting rampage at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, misspelled the surname of a novelist whose books were among those he studied in a class on contemporary horror films and literature. She is Patricia Cornwell, not Cornwall.

An article in The Arts last Saturday about the architect Jean Nouvel’s design for the new Philharmonie de Paris concert hall misstated the year in which his concert hall in Lucerne, Switzerland, opened. It was 1998, not 2000.

A news analysis article yesterday about the testimony of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales before the Senate Judiciary Committee referred incorrectly to the power of Congress to remove an attorney general from office. Under the Constitution, civil officers of the United States government may be removed upon impeachment by the House of Representatives and trial in the Senate. Congress is not powerless to remove the attorney general.

An article on Wednesday about closing arguments in a corruption case against Gerald P. Garson, a former State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn, misstated the name of his wife, a Brooklyn Civil Court judge who was in the courtroom. She is Robin Garson, not Rachel.
Corrections

An article in The Arts on Monday about plans for a traveling exhibition of African-American history misstated the academic affiliation of Quintard Taylor Jr., a member of the exhibition’s advisory panel. He is a professor of history at the University of Washington in Seattle — not at Washington University in St. Louis.

A front-page article on Thursday about universities’ limited options in dealing with mentally ill students misidentified a university that requires four counseling sessions after suicide attempts. It is the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, not the University of Missouri.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the struggles of St. Louis in the wake of a population decline misstated the name of a neighborhood that is thriving. It is Lafayette Square, not Lafayette Park.
A biographical sketch on Wednesday of Michael S. Pohle Jr., one of the victims at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, misspelled the name of the restaurant where he worked. It is Nerv, not Nerve.

An article by The Associated Press in some copies last Saturday about the discovery of a man’s body under a pile of debris in a home in Woodmere, N.Y., included a quotation about the incident from a man who identified himself as Erik Kinney, a volunteer firefighter. Mr. Kinney has told The A.P. that he never spoke to a reporter, and the news agency says it does not know who at the fire station identified himself as Mr. Kinney.

A front-page article yesterday about China’s talk of democracy misstated the name of the organization with which Bonnie G. Glaser, who commented about the issue, is affiliated. She is a China expert with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, not the Center for Security and International Studies.
After winning a bribery conviction, Brooklyn district attorney Charles J. Hynes vowed to finish out his investigation.
Under federal law, the Virginia Tech gunman should have been prohibited from buying a gun after he was declared to be a danger to himself.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., April 20 (AP) — Parker Dalton studied the faces in the crowded room and nearly burst into tears.
Richard Robinson, chief executive of Scholastic, spoke about the success of the Harry Potter and the prospect of another best-selling series to come.
More than 1,000 restaurant customers on the East Coast have had their credit card information stolen, the Manhattan district attorney said yesterday.
The victims of the shooting rampage at Virginia Tech were remembered at memorial services and the family of their killer issued an apology.
Profit was hurt by one-time charges and disappointing sales of its diabetes drug Exubera.
Leading candidates say they would raise taxes on the affluent but extend President Bush’s tax cuts for others.
Nelnet, a major student loan company, offered a broad accounting of many often unpublicized relationships it has established with universities and their senior officials.
A restaurant owner cannot bring himself to reopen Brasserie LCB, which city officials had temporarily closed.
Several pending trade pacts have dissolved in a burst of charges and countercharges over the issue of labor rights.
The move by broadcast networks follow fierce criticism of the news media, newspapers as well as television, by students, victims’ family members and others.
Wal-Mart’s chief took the unusual step of releasing portions of a former employee’s sworn testimony that denied surveillance on shareholders and employees.
President Bush’s loyalty is now facing a serious test as he confronts what to do about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and Paul D. Wolfowitz, the president of the World Bank.
pro football.
This huge nation, which is losing population, needs to find a way to welcome ambitious newcomers instead of excluding them.
A glitch in the BlackBerry system accomplished temporarily what some had, in their darkest moments, considered effecting with a hammer.
The Education Department’s inspector general has issued a half-dozen reports finding conflicts of interest, cronyism and bias in the operation of Reading First.
The trouble with modernity is how efficiently it obliterates the troves of age-old knowledge otherwise known as wisdom.
The Transportation Department said it was investigating several domestic airlines for publishing unrealistic flight schedules.
For the 10th day, gusting winds whipped flames through drought-stricken pine forests and fields near the Georgia-Florida border.
A new bill gives shareholders the right to cast nonbinding votes on the pay of top company executives.
The company will sell the Option One Mortgage Corporation to the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management.
The move comes even as the company has begun building Camry sedans at a Subaru plant in Indiana to replace those built in Japan.
Coco Crisp has disappointed the Red Sox while trying to replace Johnny Damon. But he played a key role Friday night in Boston’s comeback victory.

Representative Rick Renzi of Arizona stepped down from the House Intelligence Committee, saying he was doing so because he was under federal investigation dealing with a series of financial transactions.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey was still in critical but stable condition, and doctors cautioned that a breathing tube could again be used for the governor.
John Edwards told reporters in Iowa that he was “embarrassed” over the disclosure that he had paid $800 for two haircuts.
Fort Wayne, Ind., a city of 248,000 people and 606 Christian churches, is in the midst of a Buddhist temple boom.
The radical new strategy will build a wall separating a historic Sunni enclave from Shiite neighborhoods.
Even under the most optimistic conditions, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's congestion pricing is likely to be years away.
Some universities use lenders to conduct workshops required by law for many students taking out loans.
At Rutgers University and then before the Rev. Al Sharpton’s political organization, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton criticized President Bush over Hurricane Katrina recovery efforts and Iraq.
Xerox has been sharply cutting prices for its machines to focus on the sales of toners, inks and services.
David Hayden, a dot-com entrepreneur, put his faith in investment bankers who have now gone after him for all he’s worth — and more.
The paper is doubling its street sale price to 50 cents to help stem losses, estimated to be about $70 million a year.
Craig Biggio hit his first grand slam in 13 years with one out in the ninth last night and the Houston Astros defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 6-5, to extend their winning streak to five games.

A New York City correction officer was arrested yesterday and accused of supplying heroin to the Shinnecock Indian Reservation near Southampton, the police said. The arrest of the officer, Gary Morton, 25, of Jamaica, Queens, who New York officials said has worked on Rikers Island since November, came a day after the police seized more than a dozen people in raids on the reservation and elsewhere, breaking up what they termed a major narcotics distribution network.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer asked the state’s inspector general yesterday to investigate allegations that a top gubernatorial aide threatened a Republican member of the Public Service Commission. The governor’s move came two days after the commissioner, Cheryl Buley, charged during a meeting of the Public Service Commission, which regulates the state’s utilities, that Steven Mitnick, an assistant secretary to Mr. Spitzer, had threatened her to get her to back off efforts to investigate Consolidated Edison over last summer’s blackout in Queens. On Wednesday, the Public Service Commission ordered the Con Ed investigation to move forward. Darren Dopp, a spokesman for Mr. Spitzer, said, “It appears to be a misunderstanding between two people.”.
Kimberly Bartosik and Jennifer Allen, two choreographers with seemingly little in common, shared an evening of work on Thursday at the Kitchen.

An East Hartford man has been charged with taking a pellet gun to the mayor’s office and making a threatening phone call to Gov. M. Jodi Rell’s office, the police said yesterday. The man, Lawrence James Palumbo Jr., 58, was arrested yesterday on charges of threatening, disorderly conduct and harassment in connection with the phone call on Wednesday, the police said. Christopher Cooper, a spokesman for Mrs. Rell, said a man phoned about 8:30 a.m. on Wednesday and indicated that he had a BB gun. The police say that Mr. Palumbo was arrested less than an hour later in East Hartford after entering Mayor Melody A. Currey’s office bearing flowers, then showing a pellet gun in the waistband of his pants and telling a secretary, “College campus, here we go.” His words are thought to allude to the killings at Virginia Polytechnic Institute on Monday. Compiled by Karin Roberts.

A longtime celebrity gossip columnist was sentenced yesterday to six years in federal prison for soliciting sex over the Internet from an undercover F.B.I. agent posing as a 13-year-old girl. The columnist, Timothy McDarrah, 45, who once edited the “Page Six” feature in The New York Post and last worked as editor of the “Hot Stuff” column at Us Weekly magazine, held back tears during his appearance before Judge Paul Crotty in Federal District Court. Mr. McDarrah was convicted of attempted child enticement in December after an eight-day trial. He was caught in the F.B.I.’s sting operation after he responded to a classified ad in craigslist.com offering introductions to the “freshest, youngest” girls in New York. The F.B.I. had posted the ad to lure pedophiles.

An appeals court ruled this week that Environmental Protection Agency officials are not liable for making rosy declarations about air quality in the days after the World Trade Center’s destruction on 9/11. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit issued its ruling on Thursday in a lawsuit brought by five government employees who did rescue and cleanup work at ground zero. The opinion said that putting agency workers at risk of lawsuits for giving out bad information during a crisis could have catastrophic effects.

The officer in immediate command of three marines accused of killing civilians in Haditha in 2005 has 
agreed to answer all questions relating to the case.

The number of applications from same-sex couples seeking licenses for civil unions increased in the second month that they were available, the state reported yesterday. According to figures released by the state health department, 373 couples applied in the period from March 20 to April 20, up from 229 in the first month after the civil union law went into effect on Feb. 19. Despite the increase, the number of applicants still lags behind the number of same-sex couples who applied for domestic partnerships in 2004, when that option became available and 1,700 couples signed up in the first month alone. Of the 373 same-sex couples who applied in the last month, 17 said that they had equivalent partnerships in other states or Canada. Compiled by Karin Roberts.

Ronald O. Ross has resigned as superintendent of the troubled Roosevelt Union Free School District, state education officials announced yesterday. Mr. Ross, who was appointed in 2004 by Richard P. Mills, the education commissioner, will step down on June 30, the end of the current school year. In recent weeks, Mr. Ross has come under increasing criticism from local residents as the 2,800-student district, the only one under state oversight, has run up a budget deficit of as much as $12.3 million, according to a state audit. Mr. Ross, who earned $200,000 a year, could not be reached for comment.
The Toronto Raptors hope to use the postseason as a steppingstone to something more. But first, they must prove they are over the Vince Carter era.
The virus is devastating to the ecosystem and so unfamiliar, experts said, that its full biological impact might not be clear for years.
Nascar’s Car of Tomorrow has been billed as a safety upgrade that will lower costs and make races more competitive. But crews are questioning some of those very issues.
At stake in Friday's multihued predawn face-off was a $5 million contract to bring 21st-century illumination to Manhattan’s tallest skyscraper.
China unveiled an array of prototypes for fuel-cell cars, hybrids and electric battery cars at the Shanghai auto show.
A private equity firm and a medical charity raised their joint bids for Alliance Boots, hours after the board had accepted a rival offer.
The Heat played to the mediocrity of its conference opponents during the regular season. Now Miami will try to become the lowest-seeded team to repeat as champion since 1995.
Indian officials are arguing whether the limitations of a nuclear accord with the U.S. offend the country’s sense of sovereignty.
The Dow Jones industrial average approached 13,000 after a week of surprisingly strong earnings reports.
A contract worker brandishing a revolver killed a hostage and then himself after a standoff with the police at a Johnson Space Center building in Houston.
Country Garden’s public offering is just the latest symbol of China’s meteoric rise, and the country’s continuing stock market fever.
Patrick Marleau scored his second goal with 4 minutes 21 seconds left, and the Sharks grabbed a berth in their third consecutive Western Conference semifinals, beating Nashville, 3-2, Friday night.
A former youth minister who confessed to the statutory rape of four teenagers was said to have had sex with a 16-year-old, his relative testified.
The board of directors said their inquiry into Paul D. Wolfowitz’s leadership would extend beyond allegations of favoritism.
With three starters on the disabled list, the Yankees will start Jeff Karstens on Saturday and Chase Wright on Sunday.
The Social Security numbers of tens of thousands of people were disclosed for years in a publicly available database.
Carlo Maria Badini was a former superintendent of the Teatro alla Scala in Milan who brought the opera house into the age of television and corporate sponsorship.
On the larger steelhead rivers of the Pacific Northwest — the Skagit and Bulkley, among others — hooking a steelhead trout on a fly may require a thousand very long casts.
A Harvard economics professor has argued that tall people should pay more in taxes than short people.
Jean-Pierre Cassel shot to fame as the star of film comedies by the director Philippe de Broca in the 1960s.
Frank H. Westheimer was a Harvard chemist whose work in understanding how the body metabolizes alcohol became a model for similar studies in the growing field of biochemistry.
The Mets’ Jackie Robinson Day festivities, postponed because of rain, were rescheduled for Friday night, and Willie Randolph finally wore No. 42.
Andrew Hill was a pianist and composer of highly original and sometimes opaquely inner-dwelling jazz whose work only recently found a wide audience.
History sometimes has a tangled sense of humor.
The New York City Council is considering a bill to shed light on the process of applying to buy a co-op apartment.
The Supreme Court decision to uphold a ban on a type of abortion, has huge political implications but, as a practical matter, is unlikely to have much of an effect.
Army investigative documents reviewed by The Associated Press describe how the military tried to seal off information about  Cpl. Pat Tillman’s death.
The White House is trying to persuade Americans — and, more importantly, Democrats in Congress — to give President Bush’s troop buildup a chance.
Greg Oden said Friday that he was leaving college to enter the N.B.A. draft, where he is expected to be one of the top two picks.
A tax break that was part of a relief package to aid victims of Hurricane Katrina could cost the government more than $3 billion in lost tax revenue.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) — Mark Buehrle went home after he made baseball history by throwing a no-hitter and had a pizza party with his wife.
The U.S. is offering Russia a new package of incentives to drop its opposition to U.S. missile defense sites in Poland and the Czech Republic.
The America’s Cup lifted itself out of the doldrums Friday as some of the world’s fastest yachts finally began racing after four days of delays because of a lack of wind.
Harry Hurt marches into battle with a mask and saber in hand, trying to summon the spirit of Zorro.
Blackberry users’ thumbs were idle; private equity investors got a thumbs up from Sallie Mae; and a jury turned thumbs down on Joseph P. Nacchio.
Helen Robson Walton’s husband, Sam Walton, founded Wal-Mart Stores and relied on her for advice.
The main hurdle is learning how to talk about your finances about a year into a marriage.
George Webster was a two-time all-American at Michigan State and an All-Pro linebacker whose attempt to have his disability pension increased reached the Supreme Court.
If the greatness of artist Sol LeWitt has so far escaped you, make haste to Beacon, N.Y., a quiet Hudson River town, to see hulking displays of his minimal art.
Weysan Dun, a 25-year borough veteran, said that one of his first tasks would be to deal with trauma from the killing of Agent Barry Lee Bush.

Richard Robinson, the chief executive of Scholastic, spoke about the success of the Harry Potter books and intimated that there could be another best-selling series to come — from the same author.
Bansky be gone, Ardant onstage, Kevin Spacey gives a master class, an opening and a protest, keys to the eternal city and more culture news.

An Op-Ed article last Saturday about Jackie Robinson misidentified the birthplace of a teammate, Eddie Stanky. He was born in Philadelphia, not Alabama. The article also misspelled the surname of a Boston Brave. He was Earl Torgeson, not Torgenson.
Manhattan borough president Scott Stringer wants the city to use tax policy to encourage development.
If a fan doesn’t root for his team to win, who is he, exactly?

Sure, win a Rhodes scholarship, become a United States senator and run for president. Congratulations. Now, want a real challenge? Try producing.

In a sharp suit, black fedora and sunglasses, Chuck Brown, 72, was the image of a classic bluesman leading his band at Joe’s Pub on Thursday night.

With the Museo Alameda, a half-century of intense cultural preoccupation with hyphenated American identity has given birth to the hyphenated American museum.

To the Editor:.
Patty Griffin cheerfully admitted during her set at the Beacon Theater on Thursday night that she doesn’t write many happy songs. Hardly any, in fact.

Some years ago I asked Edgar Kaplan whom he rated as the best bridge player of all time. He replied that the most talented was Alvin Roth, who died on Wednesday at 92.

10 P.M. (BBC America) WILD AT HEART Goodbye, city life! When Danny Trevanion (Stephen Tompkinson), an English veterinarian, saves the life of a monkey smuggled illegally into Britain, his new wife, Sarah (Amanda Holden), decides that they and their children — his teenage daughter, Rosie (Lucy-Jo Hudson), and Sarah’s 8-year-old daughter, Olivia (Rafaella Hutchinson), and 13-year-old son, Evan (Luke Ward-Wilkinson) — should travel to South Africa to return the monkey to its natural habitat, and, with luck, bond as a family along the way. (Above, from left, Ms. Holden, Ms. Hutchinson and Ms. Hudson.) But that charmingly decrepit game reserve is just too tempting to leave behind. The six-episode first season of this new series follows the Trevanions as they rumble in the jungle.
To the Editor:.
The Riverside Symphony’s performance at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening showed yet again how superb New York’s pool of freelance musicians can be.

A front-page article on Thursday about universities' limited options in dealing with mentally ill students misidentified a university that requires four counseling sessions after suicide attempts. It is the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, not the University of Missouri.

The American Embassy in Berlin said it would tighten security measures at diplomatic and consular facilities in Germany because of a ''heightened security threat.'' A Pakistani Taliban leader who has been waging a government-backed campaign to evict Central Asian militants from Pakistan's tribal regions said Friday that he would give Osama bin Laden protection in his area if he sought it. ''Bin Laden has never come to this area, but if he comes here and seeks our protection, then according to tribal laws and customs we will protect him,'' the Taliban commander, Mullah Muhammad Nazir, 32, said at a rare news conference in the city of Wana in the tribal region of South Waziristan.

Over the first four games, Martin Brodeur had not been what he is: hockey's best goaltender. His goals against average was 2.87, in contrast to 1.89 in his previous 153 Stanley Cup playoff games. And his save average against the Tampa Bay Lightning had been a shaky .897. But in last night's 3-0 victory that lifted the Devils into a 3-2 lead in their Eastern Conference quarterfinal series going into tomorrow's rematch in Tampa Bay, Brodeur again was what he is: hockey's best goaltender.

An article in The Arts on Monday about plans for a traveling exhibition of African-American history misstated the academic affiliation of Quintard Taylor Jr., a member of the exhibition's advisory panel. He is a professor of history at the University of Washington in Seattle -- not at Washington University in St. Louis.

A picture of Representative John T. Doolittle on Thursday with an article about a search of his home by the F.B.I. carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Pablo Martinez Monsivais/Associated Press, not Max Whittaker for The New York Times.

U.S. Erects Baghdad Wall To Separate Rival Sects American military commanders in Baghdad are trying a radical new strategy to quell sectarian violence by building a 12-foot-high, three-mile-long wall to separate a historic Sunni enclave from Shiite neighborhoods. But Sunni Arab residents say it will only increase tensions. An article in The Arts last Saturday about the architect Jean Nouvel's design for the new Philharmonie de Paris concert hall misstated the year in which his concert hall in Lucerne, Switzerland, opened. It was 1998, not 2000.

HART--Kitty Carlisle. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the death of Kitty Carlisle Hart. Kitty was an Honorary Member of the Museum's Board of Trustees since 1996 and a member of MoMA's Education and Special Events committees. This gifted actress and entertainer was a great friend of the Museum. We will remember Kitty for her grace, charm, fearless advocacy of the arts, and for her very special performance as the honoree of the Museum's Party in the Garden in 1999. We extend our deepest sympathy to her daughter Catherine, her son Christopher, and three grandchildren. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Robert B. Menschel, Chairman Marie-Josee Kravis, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. What a dear friend you have been over the decades -such grace and charm. Your steadfast support of rehabilitation medicine and our programs at the United Nations added dignity to our concept of ''Rusk Without Walls''. The Rusk Institute acknowledges your vibrant advocacy of its endeavor to recognize music as an international language and music as an integral component of rehabilitation therapy. To your family we share their loss and grateful that you touched our lives. Mathew Lee, M.D. Howard A. Rusk, Professor of Rehabilitation Medicine NYU School of Medicine Medical Director Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of its loyal friend and tireless champion, Kitty Carlisle Hart. She sang 15 performances as Orlofsky in ''Die Fledermaus'' with our company in 1967, but it was as an ever present advocate for the Met and all of the arts that we owe her our greatest debt of gratitude. Her charm, glamour, warmth, and wit will not soon be forgotten. We offer our sincerest condolences to her family and friends. Peter Gleb General Manager James Levine, Music Director $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. Two miserable kids in a Swiss boarding school: Kitty and me -weeping daily -as I do now for the loss of my oldest friend. Lora Hays $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. The Members and Staff of the New York State Council on the Arts express their deep sadness at the passing of their beloved former Chairman, Kitty Carlisle Hart. Affectionately known to us as Kitty, she was a vital mainstay of our agency for more than three decades, dispensing wisdom and charm wherever she went. She was a vibrant and tireless advocate for the arts and she will be missed by the entire arts community. Kitty will always be remembered by us as a colleague and a good friend. She was one of a kind and remains irreplaceable. $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. Champion of the arts for New York State, she led us with grace, a commitment to artists and free expression, and a passion for ensuring art in the daily lives of all. She charmed all with her ''Governor Darling'' requests. We celebrate a life that requires us to speak for the potential of the human spirit. New York City Arts Coalition

MARKS--Charles Emmanuel Sr., an artist, died on April 17th. He was Born October 25th, 1917 to Alma and Clarence Marks of Philadelphia. He served as an aviator pilot in the Navy during World War II. Mr. Marks graduated from the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, and lived most of his life in Paris, France, where he exhibited his paintings frequently. Predeceased by first wife Caroline French Cummin and son Charles E. Marks Jr. Survived by wife Yannick Rigourd Marks, daughter Suzanne Squires (David); and one granddaughter, Caroline Squires. A memorial is planned at a later date in Paris, France. Inquiries can be made to Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 212-288-3500.

Residents of the mountain town of Monteleone di Spoleto held a noisy protest in front of the Italian Culture Ministry in Rome yesterday, calling for the return of an Etruscan chariot that's a centerpiece of the newly opened Greek and Roman galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The 2,600-year-old chariot was discovered in Monteleone in 1902 and sold to the Met the next year. Monteleone officials now say it was illegally whisked out of the country. Some 200 people -- about a third of the town's population -- blew whistles and waved placards demanding that the Italian state, which does not support their claim, join their cause. The Met says that because the chariot (detail, right) was bought more than a century ago, the statute of limitations has expired. Nando Durastanti, Monteleone's mayor, who led the delegation, said the Met had ''closed itself off'' to requests to negotiate the artifact's return. ''Mind you, they've been very busy with the opening of the galleries,'' he said by telephone. ''They probably have other things on their minds than our chariot.'' ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

WING--Earl, 85 years of age died at his Jersey City residence on Wednesday, April 18, 2007. Son of the late Alfred E. Wing, and Cornelia DeGraw. Born in Ontario, California he resided in New York City from 1944. He was employed at Walgreen's Soda Fountain on 42nd Street, before joining the McGraw-Hill Company in 1961 where he worked as a project manager until his retirement in 1999. He is survived by his son Willie Melia, and many dear friends. He had a passion for cooking, sense of humor, and generous spirit for life. Visitation Saturday evening 7-9pm, and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm, at the Introcaso-Angelo Funeral Home, 143 Brunswick Street, Jersey City, NJ 07302 (201653-2494). Private cremation to follow.

Real competition appears to be breaking out in the race to bring very-low-cost computers to people in developing nations. Microsoft said this week that it would sell a stripped-down version of Windows and Office for $3 in developing nations. Analysts say basic PC's running the Microsoft programs could sell for $300 or less.

North Korea reiterated that it would allow international nuclear inspectors into the country as soon as it could confirm that funds frozen in a Macao bank had been released. According to the official Korean Central News Agency, Ri Je-son, the director general of North Korea's Atomic Energy Department, delivered that message in a response to a request by the International Atomic Energy Agency to send inspectors. North Korea repeated that it remained committed to a Feb. 13 agreement under which it would allow inspectors in and shut down its Yongbyon nuclear plant in return for energy aid. NORIMITSU ONISHI

History sometimes has a tangled sense of humor. Don Nelson, the Golden State Warriors' coach, was the last person to get the Warriors to the playoffs, in 1994, a year before he left Golden State to coach the Knicks. His point guard in 1994 was Avery Johnson, who replaced Nelson as the coach of the Dallas Mavericks in 2005. Nelson's son, Donnie, was an assistant in Dallas and is now the Mavericks' president. Now everyone will face one another in the first round of the N.B.A. playoffs.

The government is intensifying efforts to combat Japanese encephalitis, an untreatable viral disease spread by mosquitoes that kills one in three children who contract it. India said it would finance the immunization of 20 million children in nine states before July, when the monsoon season brings rains that increase infection rates. It obtained the vaccine, which costs about 25 cents per dose, from the Chengdu Institute of Biological Products, a part of the China National Biotec Corp. PATH, an international nonprofit group, negotiated the lower price on behalf of developing countries. CELIA W. DUGGER

An Op-Ed article last Saturday about Jackie Robinson misidentified the birthplace of a teammate, Eddie Stanky. He was born in Philadelphia, not Alabama. The article also misspelled the surname of a Boston Brave. He was Earl Torgeson, not Torgenson.

A news analysis article yesterday about the testimony of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales before the Senate Judiciary Committee referred incorrectly to the power of Congress to remove an attorney general from office. Under the Constitution, civil officers of the United States government may be removed upon impeachment by the House of Representatives and trial in the Senate. Congress is not powerless to remove the attorney general.

GOLDSMITH--Frieda Kittay. Cherished wife of the late A. Philip Goldsmith and the late Sol Kittay. An elegant woman and role model of femininity, she brought grace and beauty to all she knew. Fluent in many languages and very much involved in the world of the arts, in particular French history and culture. Her wit sparkled like a jewel and she brought laughter and wisdom through her extraordinary ability as a supreme hostess and raconteur. The world is a lesser place without her. Beloved mother of Jeffrey Kittay and his wife Eva, Arlyn Imberman, and Linda Strulovic; adored grandmother of Sesha and Leo (Kim) Kittay, Thomas and Alberto Strulovic, and Deborah and Liane Radel; dear great grandmother of Micah and Asa Kittay; loving aunt to her nieces and nephews, and special cousin to Eleanor and Robert Sorin. Services 1:00PM Sunday April 22, 2007 at Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Kittay House, 2550 Webb Ave., Bronx, NY 10468.

Seeking black and female votes yesterday, first at Rutgers University and then before the Rev. Al Sharpton's political organization, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton used housecleaning imagery to swipe at President Bush and praised the Rutgers women's basketball team as teaching her and others a lesson. Mrs. Clinton, Democrat of New York, criticized President Bush at several points, particularly over Hurricane Katrina recovery efforts and Iraq, which she called ''this war that he deliberately started.'' But for the most part she used personal examples and metaphors to advocate for blacks, women, gay men and women, the poor, the old and the young.

The netherworld of limbo, long speculated in Roman Catholic teaching as the destination of babies who die unbaptized, has been replaced with the ''prayerful hope'' that they reach heaven. Pope Benedict XVI signed a theological report, years in the making, that effectively demoted limbo, a place neither in heaven nor in hell, where unbaptized babies would not be in communion with God but would nonetheless enjoy eternal happiness. Many in the church felt the idea, never formally a part of church doctrine, was outdated and caused undue worry for parents. IAN FISHER

In the breezy days of spring training, the plan seemed so logical to Yankees Manager Joe Torre. His indispensable closer, Mariano Rivera, would be restricted to one inning in 2007. It was better, Torre reasoned, to be careful with an elbow that was fragile last September. Only 15 games into the season, with a rally bubbling in the caldron of Fenway Park, Torre changed his mind. The Yankees needed five outs to secure a three-run lead, and Torre bypassed five other relievers to call for his old reliable.

Early on in the Don Imus firing controversy I took an abstinence pledge, vowing never to write anything about it. I now go back on that pledge, not because I have anything to say, but because there isn't anything to say, although almost everybody in the world has been saying a great deal. What I mean is that there are no serious issues that might be appropriately - as opposed to opportunistically - attached to this incident. The story should not be filed under "free speech" or "racist speech" or "the culture of indecency" or "double standards"; it should be filed under "blunders with unexpected consequences," the subject of an earlier column about men and women who say or do something apparently small and even casual and find, sometimes within minutes, that their public lives are over.In Mr. Imus's case, what followed his disparaging of the Rutgers women basketball players was unanticipated not because he had intended no insult, but because intending insults has always been his line of work, and he had no reason to believe that this five-second instance of his ordinary practice would bring everything crashing down. Many commentators have said that Imus should have distinguished between his usual targets - Hollywood celebrities, politicians, sports icons - and 10 innocent and vulnerable young women. But this criticism assumes that behind what Imus said over the years was some kind of social or moral or philosophical calculation. There was nothing at all behind his daily performances; he was just occupying a professional niche - Don Rickles with a network - and doing exactly what he was paid to do.

The Checking In column last Sunday, about increased hotel development in Lower Manhattan, referred incorrectly to four hotels being developed by the McSam Hotel Group. At 20 Maiden Lane, the hotel will be a Wyndham, not a Holiday Inn Express, and it will have 113 rooms, not 101. At 99 Washington Street, the hotel will be a Holiday Inn with 370 rooms, not 371; it is not unnamed. At 8 Stone Street, a hotel yet to be named will have 400 rooms, not 192; it is not a Doubletree. And at 33 Beekman Street, a hotel yet to be named will have 350 rooms, not 288; it is not a Westin.

But with the hotel’s owners having won three court decisions, the town has come up with a different tactic: to declare the hotel and surrounding area blighted and seize it through condemnation.

The Brady Bunch reunites to receive the Pop Culture Award — and to mix it up in a song-and-dance routine with Kelly Ripa, second from right above, the ceremony’s host — at this fifth annual tribute billed as “the ultimate celebration for the TV generation.” Other nods go to Lucille Ball (the Legacy of Laughter award, accepted posthumously by her children, Lucie and Desi Arnaz Jr.), “Hee Haw,” “Taxi,” “Heroes” (the Future Classic award) and “Roots,” in honor of its 30th anniversary. An article last Sunday about potential candidates for music director of the New York Philharmonic misspelled the surname of a guest conductor who has impressed the orchestra’s musicians. He is Ludovic Morlot, not Merlot. The article also misidentified the work that Gustavo Dudamel, who will take over as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic in 2009, conducted in his debut with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. It was Mahler’s First Symphony, not his Fifth Symphony. The article also gave an incorrect surname in some references for a conductor who will lead the Dallas Symphony Orchestra. He is Jaap van Zweden, not von Zweden.
An article last Sunday about the forthcoming Nickelodeon television series “Ni Hao, Kai-lan!” misspelled the surname of the show’s creator. She is Karen Chau, not Chao.

Virginia Comer Ireland was married yesterday to Robert Brandon Aebersold. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Thomas Church in New York. The bride, 28, and bridegroom, 30, received law degrees from the University of Virginia, where they met.

To the Editor: As a retired music theater educator, I read ''Calling All Jocks and Brainiacs Onstage'' (April 15), about ''High School Musical,'' with encouragement and a little dismay. Getting students involved in music theater yields many secondary benefits such as building self-esteem, being part of a group enterprise and even some improvement of study skills and grades. But it should also be meeting some primary artistic and educational goals as well.

To The Editor: In her intelligent review of Jonathan Cohn's ''Sick'' (April 8), Sally Satel refers to ''our ailing health care system.'' The United States has in fact never had a health care system: what we have is neither a system nor on the whole a promoter of health. Sadly, ''nonsystematic illness intervention'' more accurately desribes the state of American medicine.

Dara Blake Gilwit, the daughter of Randie and Mark Gilwit of Coral Springs, Fla., was married last evening to David Andrew Hammerman, a son of Barbara and Michael Hammerman of Jericho, N.Y. Rabbi Lawrence M. Schuval officiated at the Biltmore Hotel in Coral Gables. Mrs. Hammerman, 29, is a litigation associate at Hughes Hubbard & Reed, the New York law firm. She graduated magna cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and received her law degree from Washington University in St. Louis.

Young Americans defy easy political labels. Findings of a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll suggest that the presidential candidates will face challenges as they seek support from these voters, ages 18 to 29, who accounted for 17 percent of the ballots cast in the 2004 presidential race.

To the Sports Editor: I would have been much more impressed with major leaguers if, instead of wearing Jackie Robinson's No. 42 on the 60th anniversary of his breaking baseball's color barrier in baseball, they had each contributed $42,000 to a scholarship fund for disadvantaged youth of all races. Or perhaps donated 42 hours of their time to volunteering in the public schools.

The hot swimsuit for summer is one that mothers will actually enjoy shopping for: the new skull-and-bones boys' swim trunks by J. McLaughlin for Best & Co. In March, the company introduced the line of embroidered swim shorts for boys age 2 to 12 in three patterns: lobsters, sailing knots and skulls. The first four shipments sold out immediately, with the skulls pattern being the clear front-runner. Last week, yet another shipment arrived at the stores -- $55 at Best & Co. in Greenwich, Conn., (203) 629-1743, and through bestandcompany.com.

Shostakovich: Violin Concertos Nos. 1, 2 Sergey Khachatryan, violinist; Orchestre National de France, conducted by Kurt Masur. Naïve V 5025; CD. WHILE not yet staples, the two violin concertos by Shostakovich are steadily claiming places in the repertory. There are many fine recordings, including those by the great violinist for whom they were written, David Oistrakh.

The Old State House in Hartford has been given a reprieve by the governor -- for now. Gov. M. Jodi Rell announced on April 11 that she would ask legislators for the money to keep the Old State House open for the rest of the year, while a long-term financial plan is being worked out. In March, she said the state would make $600,000 available to repair the roof.

Learning to plan for your financial future needn't be a boring indoor exercise, according to the television personality Suze Orman, who will share her financial expertise on a seven-day Caribbean cruise this December. Between their stops at San Juan, St. Maarten, Tortola and Nassau (not to mention trips to the ship's 11 bars, four restaurants, theater, three swimming pools, gym and disco), participants can hear Ms. Orman discuss topics like retirement planning, estate planning and investment.

The lineage of dogs can be traced to wolves; we know that. But according to the novel work of the Swedish geneticist Peter Savolainen, who analyzed DNA from breeds around the world, dogs can be traced to a point of single origin in East Asia thousands of years ago. In a two-part PBS series beginning on Sunday (and continuing next Sunday) ''Nature'' presents ''DOGS THAT CHANGED THE WORLD,'' a look at the species, from its evolutionary history to the impact it is making on 21st-century medical care. Dogs, dogs and more dogs. A golden retriever puppy named Thomas takes center stage in the BBC America movie ''AFTER THOMAS,'' which makes its debut on Sunday at 8 p.m. The film, based on a true story, deals with a young couple struggling to raise an autistic son. The father would like to place the boy in a good boarding school to help him. The mother resists. The marriage is strained. But things begin to improve immeasurably for the child with the arrival of Thomas, who can reach the boy in a way that no mere human can. A telepathic person, a brilliant person, a stripper, a man who can stop time -- these are a few of the strangely connected characters who have made the NBC drama ''HEROES'' so compelling. The fate of the world confronts them when the series returns on Monday at 9 p.m.

There you are, curly head, admiring your new do in the mirror at one of Manhattan's curlcentric Devachan salons, when what should come up behind you but the Claw? Looking like something out of a horror movie, the thing is actually called the DevaSun Dryer DevaFuser ($185 at Devachansalon.com). Lorraine Massey, an owner of the SoHo salons, says the hand-held device is designed to dry hair from the inside out. Place it among your tresses; its gentle heat won't roast your ringlets the way conventional dryers do. (''You can cook a turkey with most dryers,'' she said. ''No wonder you see fried hair all over the place.'') The dryer also quells frizz, a word Ms. Massey disdains as follicly incorrect: Call it a halo, please. SUSAN GUERRERO

Lately it seems as if black-and-white photography is being discovered for the first time. More than a few galleries have been showing early work from the 1970s by well-known photographers. Whether the interest in this period is nostalgic, with pictures that appear elegiac, or just the next trend, black and white is clearly having a moment. In contrast to the wall-size, super-saturated color photography dominating the market in recent years, the smaller black-and-white images from the 1970s take on the quality of rare, quaint handmade objects. On view at PACE MacGILL is a show of work by TOD PAPAGEORGE called ''Passing Through Eden -- Photographs of Central Park.'' From the clothing and hairstyles, the people in these pictures are typical of that era, and they sit on benches, lie on the grass, have picnics, or linger. Most are unaware of the camera, un-self-consciously being who they are. Mr. Papageorge, director of Yale's graduate program in photography since 1979, used to go ''shooting'' on the streets of New York a couple of times a week with Garry Winogrand and Joel Meyerowitz in the 1960s. That kind of street photography defined what later came to be called the snapshot aesthetic. Here Mr. Papageorge captured authentic moments on his photography walks through Central Park in the 1970s. Composed with keen observation and not a little wit, his black-and-white pictures seem chiseled from the light, every detail precision-cut; the prints glow as if illuminated from within by the silver of the paper itself. Nostalgia or novelty notwithstanding, they are as pure as photography gets. 32 East 57th Street, Midtown.

Ashley Lynn Bell and Shamina Singh affirmed their partnership last evening. Mata Mandir K. Khalsa led a commitment ceremony incorporating Sikh traditions at the Houghton House, an event space at the Aspen Wye River Conference Centers in Queenstown, Md. Ms. Bell (above, left) is 38 and an associate producer of ''Blackout,'' a feature film that is to be shown this week at the Tribeca Film Festival. In 2005 and 2006, she was a logistics consultant for the Clinton Global Initiative conferences, a series of events in New York that bring together influential individuals to devise and implement innovative solutions to pressing world problems. From 1993 to 2000, she had various roles in the Advance Office of the Clinton White House. She graduated from the University of Tulsa.

INTERNATIONAL 3-18 Making Detainees Talk in Iraq In the joint American and Iraqi operation to clear insurgents from dangerous neighborhoods, American troops are confronted with a problem: how to deal with their Iraqi counterparts' aggressive interrogation techniques, including beatings. 1 A military investigation has found that the Marine Corps chain of command in Iraq showed a routine and blatant disregard for the lives of Iraqi civilians that contributed to its ''willful'' failure to investigate an attack by marines that killed 24 unarmed Iraqis. 18 Kremlin Tightens Grip on Radio Radio news in Russia has been a rare bright spot in a darkening media landscape. But new rules imposed on Russia's largest independent radio news network leave an increasingly small number of news outlets not managed by the government. 1 New Defiance in Israeli Settlers Jewish settlers evacuated from Gaza by the Israeli government 20 months ago are showing greater assertiveness in protesting the moves. They are taking advantage of the weakened position of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, who, after the rise to power of Hamas and Israel's war with Hezbollah in Lebanon last summer, is in no position to challenge the settlers. 1 About a dozen masked Palestinians bombed and set fire to the American International School in Beit Lahiya, north of Gaza City, school officials and Palestinian security officials said, causing extensive damage, but no injuries. 10 Nigeria Vote Begins in Chaos Nigeria's presidential election began amid chaos, with a botched attempt to smash a truck bomb into the headquarters of the electoral commission in the nation's capital and with ballots arriving late to polling places and lacking vital information to identify candidates and prevent fraud. 3 NATIONAL 20-27 Infant Death Rate Up in South For decades, Mississippi and neighboring states with large black populations and expanses of enduring poverty made steady progress in reducing infant death. But progress has stalled, and in recent years the death rate has risen in Mississippi and several other states. 1 Gunman's Silence and Rage From the beginning, Seung-Hui Cho did not talk, and his mother agonized over his brooding behavior. Interviews with investigators, relatives, classmates and teachers show how Mr. Cho progressed from silence to murderous rage, and how he meticulously prepared for his final hours. 1 Giuliani's Immigration Stance A decade ago, as mayor of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani often defended illegal immigrants. But now he is running for president, and the politics of immigration in the post-9/11 world is vastly different. 1 NEW YORK/REGION 29-34 More Men Living Downtown Men now outnumber women in Lower Manhattan by a ratio of 126 to 100, a disparity usually seen only in towns with prisons or military bases. 29 Chess 34 Weather 24

WADLER--Sylvia on April 18, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Harry Gillers and Samuel Wadler. Loving mother of Debra Gillers and Stephen Gillers. Devoted mother-inlaw of Barbara Gillers and Robert Reiss. Dear sister of Florence Halpern. Adoring grandmother of Heather and Gillian Gillers.
The Bites column on April 8 about paella at L'Alter in Picassent, Spain, misstated an ingredient in the paella. It is sweet pimentón (paprika), not pimento.

Okay, Governor Spitzer and New York lawmakers. You finished the budget, only a few hours late, but it's done. You took your spring vacation. Now it is time to tackle one of the truly terrible, disgraceful things about New York's political scene -- the ossified, uncompetitive, self-serving system that virtually guarantees legislators jobs for life. There is more job security in Albany than there once was in Albania. There is less turnover than in the last outposts of tenured academia, a better chance of a lifelong job than in the strongest of union strongholds.

Loving uncle of many nieces, nephews and great-nieces and nephews. Life-long parishioner of St. Benedict's Church.
