Tremont Ave, Bronx on Monday April 23rd, 2007 at 9:00 AM. Mass of Christian burial at St. Benedict RC Church at 9:30 AM. Interment St. Raymond Cemetery.
To the Editor: With regard to Mimi Sheraton's ''Cook's Tour of Milan'' (April 1): If only I had known sooner about the culinary delights of that city.

As a licensed funeral director and founder and chairman of Service Corporation International, the mortuary operator, R. L. Waltrip knows something about untimely passings. And this year, Mr. Waltrip faces the sad prospect of watching 2.8 million stock options he holds expire worthless. The company, based in Houston, is still on the mend from an expansion binge that mostly ended in 1999. Its stock has not risen above $12.33 in the past year. Thus, 400,000 options with an exercise price of $14.81 would have expired worthless on March 10, according to Service Corporation's recently filed proxy statement. And 800,000, exercisable at $19.47 a share, expire May 12.

An article last Sunday about potential candidates for music director of the New York Philharmonic misspelled the surname of a guest conductor who has impressed the orchestra's musicians. He is Ludovic Morlot, not Merlot. The article also misidentified the work that Gustavo Dudamel, who will take over as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic in 2009, conducted in his debut with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. It was Mahler's First Symphony, not his Fifth Symphony. The article also gave an incorrect surname in some references for a conductor who will lead the Dallas Symphony Orchestra. He is Jaap van Zweden, not von Zweden.

A table on April 8 with a report on executive pay included an incorrect figure from Equilar Inc., an executive compensation research firm, for the value of equity holdings of Glenn A. Britt, chief executive of Time Warner Cable. And a correction in this space last Sunday gave another incorrect figure from the firm for those equity holdings. The value was $10.8 million -- not $25.8 million or $10.5 million.

THE NOISETTES, an English band that comes to the Mercury Lounge on Monday night, represent the latest volley in a long trans-Atlantic interchange. The Noisettes are a trio with a volatile female lead singer, Shingai Shoniwa (who also plays bass); she can be frantic, flirtatious, playful and pensive, in songs that leap from punk to hard rock to math-rock to something like swing. So the Noisettes are a rejoinder to the Yeah Yeah Yeahs from New York City. But the Yeah Yeah Yeahs owe a lot to English bands like X-Ray Spex and Siouxsie and the Banshees, who in turn were inspired by Patti Smith, who Anyway, the Noisettes have their own flair. The songs on their new album, ''What's the Time Mr. Wolf?'' (Universal Motown), are sinewy and full of surprises, like irregular meters and sudden stylistic mutations. Ms. Shoniwa belts advice -- ''Scratch your name into the fabric of this world before you go'' -- and feisty declarations: ''We complement each other just like Satan and Christ.'' They're on a quadruple bill that also includes LOOKER, a New York City band drawing on girl groups and punk; one song exults in being ''hopped up on pheromones.'' 9 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side; (212) 260-4700; $12. Speaking of PATTI SMITH -- rocker, poet, three-chord shaman -- she's playing three New York City shows this week, all on one night: Tuesday. ''The Bowery Sesssions'' marks the release of her new album, ''Twelve,'' which is a collection of songs by others, including Jimi Hendrix, Tears for Fears and Nirvana. After more than three decades of writing and performing Ms. Smith has more than enough of her own material to fill three sets without repeating a song, should she choose. 6, 8:30 and 10:30, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111; $17; sold out.

Rebecca Merrill Schatzkin, the daughter of Dr. Tamara Harris and Dr. Arthur Schatzkin of Chevy Chase, Md., was married last evening to Gregory Lawrence Vincent, a son of Margaret Vincent and Fred Vincent of Philadelphia. Justice Karla Moskowitz of the New York State Supreme Court officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in New York. The bride, 26, and the bridegroom, 30, met while working at the New Teacher Project, a nonprofit educational consulting organization in New York that helps educational agencies recruit, train and place teachers. Ms. Schatzkin is the director of placement for New York City Teaching Fellows, and Mr. Vincent is an adviser for more than 15 school districts across the country.

HOLT--Carol, 70, of Stratford, CT, on April 11, 2007. Psychiatric social worker, clinical faculty at Yale University. Mother of Elizabeth and Stephen, mother-in-law of Laura, devoted grandmother of Philetus and Tattnall. Graduate of Barnard College, Fulbright Scholar in Economics at the University of Copenhagen, MAT from Yale, MSW from University of Connecticut, Ph.D. in Social Work from New York University. Enthusiast of art, film, books and political discussion, her intellect and sense of humor will be missed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Stratford Library Association, 2203 Main Street, Stratford, CT 06615. Private burial at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, is planned.

THE MARKET The News -- The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished at record highs for three consecutive sessions, topping out at 12,961.98 on Friday following encouraging earnings reports. Behind the News -- The rise of the Dow came just two months after its biggest fall in percentage terms since March 2003, when it closed down 416.02 points, or 3.29 percent on Feb. 27. That drop followed a global wave of selling set off by a plunge in China's stock market. This time, the American market appeared to shrug off news that China may raise interest rates to cool down its economy, which grew 11.1 percent in the first quarter. The broader market struggled on the first two record days, with losing stocks outnumbering advancers, but by Friday, winners far outpaced losers. THE DIAMOND The News -- Alex Rodriguez, the Yankees' third baseman, set an American League record by hitting 12 home runs in the first 15 games of the season. Behind the News -- As baseball's highest-paid player ($252 million over 10 years) he was leading the American and National Leagues not only in home runs as of Friday night, but in runs batted in, with 30, and was batting ..371. He has come through dramatically in the clutch, as well, twice hitting game-winning home runs to center field with two outs in the ninth inning.Though the season is in its infancy, there is already concern in the Yankee organization that Rodriquez might opt out of his contract at the end of the season and become a free agent. How to describe his performance so far? ''Scary,'' said his manager, Joe Torre. THE POUND The News -- The British pound rose above $2, its highest level against the dollar since 1981. Behind the News -- This may not be the summer for Americans to hop across the pond for a visit. But for the British, it's another story. Travel agents in Britain have reported a 30 percent increase in bookings for American vacations in recent weeks as the pound edged upward, according to The Times of London. Europeans may be joining them, as the dollar has also been declining against the euro. The pound's rise came after a surge in British inflation led to expectations that the Bank of England would raise interest rates, increasing demand for the pound as investors look for bigger returns there. Some analysts expect the pound to remain above $2 for a while. THE INVESTOR The News -- Mutual funds distributed a record $418.5 billion to investors in 2006, surpassing the previous high set in 2000 by nearly $42 billion, according to estimates by Lipper, a fund research company. Behind the News -- It was also a good year for Uncle Sam. Those investors paid at least $23.8 billion in taxes on their capital gains, dividend and interest income, according to Lipper. Still, the tax bite was $7.5 billion less than in 2000, because of reductions in the tax rates. But Lipper warned that ''the tax holiday of sorts is over'' because mutual funds can no longer carry forward losses from the bear market of 2000 to 2002 to offset future gains. Over all, investors in mutual funds experienced what Lipper called ''another banner year'' with stock funds returning an average 14.78 percent. THE HAIRCUT The News -- John Edwards, one of the Democratic presidential candidates, spent $400 for a haircut in Los Angeles, his campaign said. Behind the News -- Actually, it was $800, for two haircuts in recent months, both by the Beverly Hills hairstylist Joseph Torrenueva. He usually charges $175, but upped the fee to $400 because he went to Mr. Edwards rather than seeing him at his salon. The last political haircut to make big headlines was in 1993, when former President Bill Clinton paid $200 for a trim by Christophe, another Beverly Hills stylist, as Air Force One sat at Los Angeles International Airport. Mr. Clinton was skewered then, as Mr. Edwards was last week. ''John Edwards has a new campaign slogan,'' joked Jay Leno. ''Shampoo, rinse, repeat.''

To the Editor: I am so glad that The Times has identified and not forgotten that former Gov. Christie Whitman was the original source of the pension mess in New Jersey. Your April 15 editorial ''History's Painful Fallout'' is a rare effort to assign responsibility for the current state of budgetary affairs here. I am familiar with the debacle because my wife was and is a pension participant. What soured my insides more than anything else about the mess was the indifference of the Democrats at the time to the very obvious fiscal gimmickry, and the boastful pride the Republicans exhibited at the deliberate decision to not fund the pension because, at the time, it was fully funded and well reserved.

STONE--Robert G., Jr. In memory of our beloved Bob. You are dearly missed and our thoughts and prayers are always with you. Your loving memory gives us great strength and inspiration and you will forever be in our hearts. We miss you LoveBug! With love always, Nancy

Overload refers to adjusting the amount of exercise to a person's present capacity; progression refers to gradually increasing exercise over time to improve fitness. 2. b. Basketball was developed at a YMCA in Massachusetts as an indoor winter activity. 3. a. The primary role was played by physicians interested in anthropometry and other medically related subjects. 4. a. 5. c. 6. b. Skipping is a combination of a step and a hop. Combining these is difficult at earlier stages of development. 7. b. For young children, such training could damage the growth plates or growth areas in the bone, typically through epiphyseal separations. 8. a. Children at this age are concerned with their own needs. 9. b. Children become increasingly aware of their environment and the individuals who infuence their surroundings. 10. b. At these ages the most profound gender differences are in positioning the arm and trunk, plus leg mechanics. 11. c. 12. b. The common strategy is to get off to a fast start and finish with the fastest runner. 13. a. Contacting the ball with the heel of a cupped or open hand provides for surface coverage of the ball and control over the ball. 14. d. Although most players, even at fairly advanced levels, will have better control with the dominant foot than with the nondominant foot, it is still essential that practice in dribbling at every level emphasize use of both feet. 15. c. All three activities require a compact arrangement of the body so that it can move smoothly through the medium (air or water). The failure to observe this would hinder movement by creating turbulence. 16. d. After skiing, walking expends the most energy, followed by bowling and volleyball. 17. b. 18. c. With age, ever-greater percentages of body cells become less metabolically active, generally causing more body fat to accumulate over time. 19. b. Lower back pain may result from muscular damage, dislocation, fracture or other problems with spinal vertebrae or discs. 20. a.

To the Editor: ''Familiar Faces in the Crowd, and Why They're Rare,'' by David Margolick (New York Observed, April 15), was absurd. For one thing, he asserts that ''much of New York is out of town'' June through August. Not to denigrate the migratory patterns of the super-rich, but most of New York stays right here in the summer.

Miguel Moshán Méndez's troubles have piled up over the past two years. Like other coffee growers here in the impoverished state of Chiapas, he suffered devastating losses when Hurricane Stan passed through 18 months ago, tearing coffee trees from hillsides. He lost half his trees, then borrowed money to get by. Now, he must find extra work as a laborer to pay his debt, which will make it harder to maintain his tiny farm.

MEADE--Thomas A., Sarasota, FL, formerly of Lloyd Harbor, NY, and Manchester, VT, October 18, 1914 -April 13, 2007. He served as a Captain in the US Army during World War II, in the Pacific. He was corporate Vice President and Group Executive for AMF Bowling Products Group, retiring in 1980. Survivors include wife Frances, daughter Mary Ruggles, two granddaughters and five greatgrandchildren.

To the Editor: The photo of the very suburban street in Los Alamos, N.M., above the review of Nora Gallagher's ''Changing Light'' (April 8) stopped me cold. I think I am the kid on the bike; my brother, Marshall Wilder, and his friend Bob Howes are playing leap frog in our yard. It must be 1947, after the Manhattan Project years. We are playing in the big yards of new houses in the Western Area.

The British composer Nicholas Maw, born in 1935, is generally described as a Neo-Romantic. But that does not tell it all. His elegant works are also filled with striking modern touches that make them elusive and fresh. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presents the premiere of Mr. Maw's String Sextet. Preceding it are pieces by composers Mr. Maw cites as strong influences: Haydn, Schumann, Bruckner, Strauss and Britten. Friday at 8 p.m., next Sunday at 5 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org; $28 to $50. Speaking of the Chamber Music Society, the players of the Vermeer Quartet, founded in 1969 at the Marlboro Music Festival, come from Israel, Germany, Nebraska and New York. This eminent string quartet has announced that its current tour will be its last. The final New York concert includes works by Schubert, Britten and Dvorak. Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Alice Tully Hall; $30 to $52. Then there is the program by the Metropolitan Museum Artists in Concert, the museum's house ensemble, which boasts a roster of strong and noted players. This unusual program offers two early Schoenberg works: the audacious String Quartet No. 2 and his surprisingly effective cabaret songs, ''Brettl-Lieder.'' Works by Schubert and Brahms complete the program. Friday at 8 p.m., Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art, (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $30. Enough with chamber music. Those who attend the American Composers Orchestra's concert may some day brag that they heard John Adams conduct three of his own works, major scores all: ''My Father Knew Charles Ives''; the Violin Concerto, with the dynamic Leila Josefowicz as soloist; and ''The Wound-Dresser,'' a profound setting of Walt Whitman's poem about his experience tending to injured Civil War soldiers. The bass-baritone Eric Owens is soloist in this vocally and emotionally challenging work. Friday at 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $16 to $43.

The Taliban demanded Saturday that France withdraw its troops from Afghanistan and that the Afghan government release all Taliban prisoners as conditions for the release of two French aid workers and three Afghan colleagues being held hostage. The aid workers were working for Terre d'Enfance, a nongovernmental organization. They were kidnapped in southwestern Afghanistan on April 3. A spokesman, Qari Yousuf Ahmadi, telephoned The New York Times's bureau in Kabul on Saturday to announce the Taliban's conditions for the aid workers' release.

McDOUGALD--Mildred Holloway, died on March 16, 2007, in Somers, NY, at the age of 97. Born in Charleston, SC, she was a long-time New Yorker, teaching in the New York City Public School system from which she retired as an assistant principal. She will be missed by many. Widow of Cornelius McDougald, a New York City attorney, loving mother of Connie, Cornelius Travis, and of Mary Kohn who predeceased her, adoring grandmother of Sarah and Jeremy Kohn. A Memorial service in her honor will be held at 3 o'clock on Saturday, April 28th, at the Community Church of New York, 40 E. 35th St., NY, NY.

When it comes to food, Paris has long been the capital of nostalgia -- a grand lover of itself and its storied culinary ways, but no lover of fads or progress for progress's sake. More than anything, the city has rewarded memory and its tastes: a delicious contract that there will always be a certain amount of butter, cream and wine and a right way of doing things.

Amanda Katherine Cody, a daughter of Joy and Matthew Cody of Garden City, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Avon Phillip Donohue, a son of Phillip and Ann Donohue of Brooklyn, N.Y. John J. McKenna, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated at St. Joseph Church in Garden City. The bride, 27, is a manager in the technology and security risk services group at Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, in Manhattan. She graduated from Loyola College in Maryland. The bride's father is a senior marketing officer at Vanderbilt Capital Advisors in Manhattan. The bride's mother retired as a health and physical education teacher at Richmond Hill High School in Queens.

POPE--Leavitt J. Hartford friends mourn the passing of a wise leader who sparked the effort to renew the park donated by his great-grandfather Col. Albert Pope. Our condolences to his family. Nancy Macy, President Pope Hartford Fund Steve Mirsky, President Friends of Pope Park

MARKS--Charles Emmanuel Sr., an artist, died on April 17th. He was Born October 25th, 1917 to Alma and Clarence Marks of Philadelphia. He served as an aviator pilot in the Navy during World War II. Mr. Marks graduated from the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, and lived most of his life in Paris, France, where he exhibited his paintings frequently. Predeceased by first wife Caroline French Cummin and son Charles E. Marks Jr. Survived by wife Yannick Rigourd Marks, daughter Suzanne Squires (David); and one granddaughter, Caroline Squires. A memorial is planned at a later date in Paris, France. Inquiries can be made to Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 212-288-3500.

Romance de Amor Xue Fei Yang, guitarist. EMI Classics 3 70714 2; CD. ONE of the most heartening stories in the classical music industry is the genre's fast-growing popularity in China. Xue Fei Yang, a gifted 30-year-old guitarist born in Beijing, was the first guitar major at the Central Conservatory of Music there and graduated with the school's first bachelor's degree in classical guitar performance in 2000.
BAUM--Michael, 10/7/35-4/22/ 06, Remembered with love. Always in our hearts. Always in our thoughts. Missed by family and friends. Myra , Robert, Richard and Linda, Ally, Matthew

Grandmother of Schuyler, Blair, Alexis, Ashley and Graham. Sister of Phyllis Riker and Elaine Ryan. Service at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville on Monday April 23 at 10:30am.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended April 7, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. THE SAVAGE DETECTIVES, by Roberto BolaÃ$(1$)o. Translated by Natasha Wimmer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) A craftily autobiographical novel about a band of literary guerrillas. SEIZURE, by Erica Wagner. (Norton, $23.95.) A troubled young Englishwoman inherits a seaside cottage and takes an unexpected lover. ALL WHOM I HAVE LOVED, by Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Aloma Halter. (Schocken, $23.) Family turmoil preoccupies a young Romanian Jewish boy on the eve of the Holocaust. DELIRIUM, by Laura Restrepo. Translated by Natasha Wimmer. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $23.95.) In the '80s, a Colombian grapples with his wife's, and his country's, loss of memory. THE MISTRESS'S DAUGHTER, by A. M. Homes. (Viking, $24.95.) Homes's dark memoir tells the story of her birth parents' re-entry into her life. CULTURAL AMNESIA: Necessary Memories From History and the Arts, by Clive James. (Norton, $35.) Essays on 20th-century luminaries by one of Britain's funniest intellectuals. KNOTS, by Nuruddin Farah. (Riverhead, $25.95.) After 20 years, a Somali woman returns to Mogadishu from Canada, intent on reclaiming a family house from a warlord. SICK: The Untold Story of America's Health Care Crisis -- and the People Who Pay the Price, by Jonathan Cohn. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) The crisis through the experiences of ordinary people. THE LONG EXILE: A Tale of Inuit Betrayal and Survival in the High Arctic, by Melanie McGrath. (Knopf, $24.95.) Canada's forced relocation of a group of Inuit in 1953 is now seen as one of the country's worst human rights violations. PAPER TIGER, by Olivier Rolin. Translated by William Cloonan. (University of Nebraska; cloth, $40; paper, $17.95.) A French radical from the '60s explains ''the Cause'' to a dead friend's daughter. THE STORY OF THE CANNIBAL WOMAN, by Maryse Condé. Translated by Richard Philcox. (Atria, $24.) A fictional portrait of a woman's grief after her longtime partner is murdered. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

TOMORROW is the first day of TV-Turnoff Week, and I'm conflicted. On the one hand, I want to comply. It's a cause that has my sympathy. On the other hand, television is one of the few places where my 15-year-old son, Asher, and I can hang out together. That might sound blighted, and the penurious nature of our present relations might be all my fault, but it is what it is. Some people have Paris. We have ''Animal Cops: Houston.'' Accepting this hasn't come easily. When Asher was little and controllable, it was possible to stick to my resolve of raising him with a minimum of television in his life. I wasn't allowed to watch more than half an hour a week when I was growing up, and my mother's claims that it was a waste of time, a destroyer of brain cells, a purveyor of unhealthy food and unnecessary material items, which seemed like a paranoid rant at the time, came to make sense to me as an adult.
A list last Sunday of performances of Disney's ''High School Musical'' included an incorrect date for the Ventnor Middle School. The school will present the show on May 17 but not on May 16.

Candyce Renée Major, 24, a registered nurse from Sydney, Australia (pictured with her boyfriend, James Clinch, 23): ''We were traveling in Cologne for the Christmas markets -- we were excited to see these markets and the Cologne Cathedral. However, we were also sad that we were away from home and away from our families for these Christmas festivities. The whole weekend we were thinking of our parents. It was Christmastime: The shopping was something for us, something for them, something for us, something for them. In this photo, the people walking past are a blur, so the focus is on us. That's the way we think of our holidays: We take it easy and at our pace, but so many people still live everyday lives and still have to do everyday things. So we can pause and stop time for as long as we like, yet people still move on.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

To the Editor: According to ''The Warriors' Second Front at Home'' (editorial, April 13), military hospitals are failing to adequately treat thousands of soldiers afflicted with brain damage and post-traumatic stress disorder.

Nathan Englander's coolness in the face of questioning about why he hasn't published a book in eight years was refreshing (Deborah Solomon, April 8). If more editors and more writers agreed that it's healthy to take time between books, the shelves at bookstores would be stocked with fewer, but undoubtedly better, books.

A NEW WORLD: England's First View of America, by Kim Sloan. (University of North Carolina, cloth, $60; paper, $29.95.) In 1585 the British artist John White accompanied a group of colonists to the North Carolina coast with instructions to ''drawe to liefe all strange birdes, beastes, fishes, plantes.'' The resulting images, collected here, are like a slide show of the wonders they found: flying fish, colorful butterflies and a variety of Native American tribes. White probably saw the flamingo when he passed through the Bahamas or the West Indies.

To the Editor: I was very interested in your article about the statues formerly on the facade of the Exchange Court building (Streetscapes, April 1). In the mid- or late 1950s, my father came home one day and announced, ''I have found General Wolfe.'' He packed us in the car and took us to a junkyard in Brownsville.

HOCH--Frank W. The Phelps Memorial Hospital Center community mourns the passing of long-time friend, Frank W. Hoch, who was associated with the Hospital since 1968. He served on The Phelps Board of Directors for 15 years, including a term as Chairman. He was instrumental in the planning and funding of the expanded Emergency Training Center, which will be located in Phelps' new Medical Services Building. The Emergency Training Center will carry the Hoch name, serving as a reminder of Frank and Lisina Hoch's extraordinary support over many decades. We extend our deepest condolences to Frank's devoted wife Lisina, his children Steven, Alix, Daphne, and Roland, and the entire Hoch family. C. Edward Midgley, Chairman, Bd of Dir; Keith F. Safian, President and CEO; Elio Ippolito, M.D., President of the Medical Staff.

NEMSER--Stanley, The Dannenberg Family mourns the passing of our dear friend Stanley. We will always remember our cruises together, the dances, parties and dining. We loved hearing your wonderful stories about growing up in New York City and your service during World War II. Our hearts go out to Barbara, your wife of many years and your extended family. The Dannenberg Family, Barbara and Richard B. Sudi, Catherine, David and their Families

LEEDS--Henry H. April 12, 2007. Cherished husband, father and grandfather. We will never forget you. Love, Sylvia, Blair, Kirby, Jennifer and Bobby

Barbara J. Brush and Robert Murillo are to be married this afternoon at the Lauderdale Yacht Club in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Bishop Terry G. Villaire of the Catholic Church in America will officiate. The bride, 44, is a Palm Beach County assistant public defender in West Palm Beach, Fla. She is on the board of the Humane Society of Broward County. She graduated from Queens College and received her law degree from Nova University (now known as Nova Southeastern University) in Fort Lauderdale.

As the state bailed out, dried out and put things back where they belonged after last week's northeaster, it was clear that location was everything in determining how communities fared. ''I would call it a tale of two storms,'' said Wayne Sandford, the deputy commissioner of the State Department of Emergency Management and Homeland Security, who helped coordinate storm response from the Hartford Armory. ''In western Connecticut it's a flooding issue, and in eastern Connecticut it's a wind issue.''

Steven P. Jobs, chief executive of Apple Inc., is not known for giving up without a fight. And that certainly applies to the 17,000-square-foot Spanish colonial revival house he bought more than 20 years ago in Woodside, Calif. Mr. Jobs has been trying to have the house demolished and replaced with a smaller one. But a local preservation group known as Uphold Our Heritage has been fighting to save the house, built in the 1920s and known as the Jackling House after its original owner, the copper mogul Daniel Jackling.

ROBERTS--Joseph L., Jr., age 87, of Sewickley, PA, died on April 15, 2007, of pancreatic cancer. Survived by his wife, Helen Shaw Roberts: daughters Melinda R. O'Rourke and her husband Terrence, of Sewickley Heights, PA, and New York City, Jean S. Roberts of North Carolina, and the Rev. Kyoki Roberts of Sewickley, PA. A grandson and two great-grandsons, Joseph, David and Tristan Eliason of Omaha, NE. Memorial service, Saturday, 1 pm, April 21, 2007 at St. Stephen's Church, Sewickley, PA. Contributions may be made to Hillman Cancer Center, 5150 Centre Ave., Pittsburgh, PA 15232

On June 25, 1980 (a date he would remember), a good-natured Filipino pool-maintenance man gathered his wife and five children for an upsetting ride to the Manila airport. At 36, Emmet Comodas had lived a hard life without growing hardened, which was a mixed blessing given the indignities of his poverty. Orphaned at 8, raised on the Manila streets where he hawked cigarettes, he had hustled a job at a government sports complex and held it for nearly two decades. On the spectrum of Filipino poverty, that alone marked him as a man of modest fortune. But a monthly salary of $50 did not keep his family fed.

SCHLYEN--Samuel, M.D., 84, on April 18, after a four year battle with multiple myeloma, which he bore with strength and dignity. Survived by Maxine, his devoted wife of 41 years, loving children James, Peter (Renee), Elisabeth Ashbes, Alison, Jenifer Salzberg (Mark), granddaughters Emilie and Eliana, and sisters Edith Berman and Janet Verner. Predeceased by his first wife, Muriel, his grandson Adrian Ashbes and his brother Henry. Born in Passaic, NJ, an Eagle Scout, enlisted in the Army in 1942. Through Army Specialized Training Program and the G.I. Bill, attended Princeton and received his medical degree from Cornell Medical College (1949). Recalled during the Korean War, served at the National Cancer Institute, completed his fellowship at Memorial Sloan Kettering, where he became an adjunct professor. Private Practice in Rutherford, NJ, until his retirement to Boynton Beach, FL, in 2003 at the age of 80. Patriot, scholar, gentleman, devoted to and loved by his family, friends, colleagues and patients.
To the Editor: I have no sympathy for Joe Greco or Jim Isaacs or their families (''Alternative Tax Hits Home the Hardest,'' April 15).

Tough to Hit Mark Buehrle of the White Sox, who no-hit Texas in his last start, is scheduled to start tomorrow against Kansas City. Johnny Vander Meer, with the Reds in 1938, is the only pitcher to throw no-hitters in consecutive starts. Vander Meer no-hit the Boston Bees, 3-0, on June 11, then no-hit the Dodgers, 6-0, on June 15. Vander Meer pitched 21 consecutive hitless innings that season. A Baseball Hat Trick Last Monday, first baseman Aubrey Huff of the Orioles could not handle a spinning grounder hit by B. J. Upton of the Devil Rays, then overthrew first base on the same play. Baltimore catcher Paul Bako, who was backing up first, grabbed the wild throw and threw wildly as Upton advanced to third. The last time a team made three errors on a single play was on May 23, 1998, when the Astros did it against the Padres. It Could Be Worse Players off to slow starts at the plate should take solace. Richie Scheinblum, with the 1969 Indians, went 0 for 30 in April. Watch List Toronto's Aaron Hill is having a good year in average (.306) and runs batted in (11). While Hill improved his average by 17 points with nearly 200 more at-bats in his second season last year, he does not figure to compete for a batting title any time soon. He will not face the Royals' pitching staff again for a while, either. After going 7 for 11 in three games against Kansas City, he was 5 for his last 27 and on his way back to earth. The Cubs' Rich Hill is 3-0 with a 0.41 earned run average. The left-handed Hill, 27, has used a dominant curveball to strike out 18 in 22 innings. In his first 14 big-league appearances in 2005 and 2006, he had a 9.20 E.R.A. But his current results correspond with his minor league numbers, when he averaged more than 12 strikeouts per nine innings. Long labeled a top prospect, Wilson Betemit survived the Dodgers' experiment with Julio Lugo last year and is their starting third baseman. How has he responded? By getting 5 hits in his first 38 at-bats. If Betemit cannot find his stroke, the Dodgers could give up on their plans of switching the top prospect of the moment, Andy LaRoche, to the outfield. (Sources MLB.com, STATS LLC)

Bettina Edelstein and William Scott were married yesterday afternoon at the Spire Bar & Lounge of the Hotel in Miami Beach. Gary Eisenberg, a friend of the couple and a Florida notary public, officiated. Ms. Edelstein, 47, is keeping her name. She is an assistant to the editor of the news technology department at The New York Times. She graduated cum laude from Yale. She is the daughter of Ellia Edelstein of Aventura, Fla., and the late Benny Edelstein.

HILL--Andrew. The Board and staff of The Joyce Theater mourn the passing of Andrew Hill, jazz pianist, composer and beloved husband of Joanne. We are all the fortunate recipients of the great gifts of his music and spirit.

HOW do you survive a child's death? On Sept. 27, 2005, at Little League practice, Robbie Levine was running the bases during a relay race. As he rounded first, his dad, Craig, the coach, remembers thinking his son had never run so fast. Robbie was a fine little athlete, that blessed 9-year-old who could catch a grounder and make the throw to first, a smart, focused boy you could put at shortstop to hold your infield together.

Long Beach Condo $879,000 NASSAU: 260 West Broadway A two-bedroom, two-bath condo on the fifth floor of the Meridian, a new oceanfront building with 24-hour concierge service and a pool. Two indoor parking spaces and a one-year membership at a nearby gym are included. Barbara Ruotolo, Topper Realty (516) 286-9527; www.topperrealestate.com COMMON CHARGE: $384 a month; taxes: $12,000 a year PROS: The building is next to the boardwalk and the beach, and within walking distance of the train station. CONS: The terrace is on the side of the building, so the ocean view comes with a parking lot in the foreground. Arts and Crafts Bungalow $1,199,000 BROOKLYN: 678 East 22nd Street (near Farragut Road) A detached house near Brooklyn College with five bedrooms, one full and two half baths, a garden, a deck, a garage and a porch. Brooklyn Properties (718) 788-3888; www.Brooklynproperties.com. Open house, Saturday and Sunday, 12 to 2 p.m. TAXES: $2,942 a year PROS: Meticulously restored inside and out, this perfectly proportioned house has the original center staircase, leaded glass windows, beamed ceilings, a decorative mantel and a butler's pantry as well as an updated eat-in kitchen. CONS: There is only one full bath. Upper East Side Condo $925,000 MANHATTAN: 225 East 86th Street (between Second and Third Avenues), #1203 A one-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath unit with a washer/dryer in a doorman building. Lauren Zidel (212) 585-4558, Iris Klatsky (212) 452-4407, Stribling & Associates; www.stribling.com COMMON CHARGE: $1,156 a month; taxes: $825 a month PROS: The apartment has open city views, which can best be appreciated from the spacious terrace, and a dining solarium. A walk-in closet and additional built-ins provide plenty of storage. CONS: Some buyers might find the layout, which is spread out over four levels, a bit too quirky. Waterfront Contemporary $2,295,000 CONNECTICUT: 274 Pine Creek Avenue, Fairfield A five-year-old cypress-clad contemporary designed by Roger Ferris & Partners with two large bedrooms, two and a half baths, floor-to-ceiling built-ins, gas fireplace and radiant-heat floors. Charles Zylstra, Nicholas H. Fingelly Real Estate (203) 257-5727, www.fingelly.com TAXES: $19,180 a year PROS: The angled spaces make this house visually arresting. Horizontal cypress louvers and remote-controlled shades afford privacy. CONS: The house would not lend itself to a third bedroom. Although the garage holds two cars, it is of older construction and is across the street. Garment District Loft $1,795,000 MANHATTAN: 28 West 38th Street (between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas), #3W A two-bedroom, two-bath floor-through co-op with a washer and dryer for sale by the owner, a broker. Jim Gricar, Brown Harris Stevens (212) 588-5660; www.brownharrisstevens.com MAINTENANCE: $1,943 a month PROS: This airy loft is made for entertaining. The living room has a built-in media system that includes a 72-inch flat-screen digital television. The open kitchen comes with Viking appliances, a walk-in pantry and two-inch-thick marble counters. In addition to the dining area, there is a lounge area that could be converted to a small third bedroom. The bathrooms have been sleekly renovated with limestone and bluestone tile. CONS: The bedrooms face south onto a construction site, where a 10-story office building is being built.
The nonfiction best-seller list on Page 30 of the Book Review today gives an erroneous ranking for ''Blackwater,'' by Jeremy Scahill. It is No. 15. (There is no No. 16 on this week's list.)

A 40-year-old Bronx man was arrested at Shea Stadium on Friday night during the Mets' game after being accused of trying to blind Atlanta Braves players with a high-power flashlight, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. Frank Martinez, who was sitting behind home plate, was accused of shining the flashlight at pitcher Tim Hudson and shortstop Édgar Rentería before Hudson pitched to the Mets' Endy Chávez in the eighth inning. The second-base umpire, Paul Emmel, who was also affected, alerted security officials, and the game was stopped while Martinez was taken to Shea's security office.

IT is 11:15 a.m. The kids have the day off from school and I'm mall crawling The Westchester in White Plains, with my posse: my 11-year-old daughter, Lake, and two of her friends, Annabelle Kirk, 11, and Eve Wulf, 12. They are identically (though they would say individually) decked out in the suburban tween girl uniform, almost head-to-toe Abercrombie: skin-tight jeans and layered T-shirts, as well as ballet flats, Uggs, or Michael Kors boots. Eve wears a Juicy Couture bracelet with a $60 charm that her mother bought for her for Valentine's Day, which the others fawn over longingly.

To the Editor: As a retired music theater educator, I read ''Calling All Jocks and Brainiacs Onstage'' (April 15), about ''High School Musical,'' with encouragement and a little dismay. Getting students involved in music theater yields many secondary benefits such as building self-esteem, being part of a group enterprise and even some improvement of study skills and grades. But it should also be meeting some primary artistic and educational goals as well.

In our ever-recyclable culture things don't get old; they become ''vintage.'' This week is a particularly interesting one for vintage theater. ''Biography,'' a comedy by a largely forgotten American playwright, S. N. Behrman, is resurrected by the Pearl Theater. And a whole company, the legendary Living Theater, springs back onto the scene with a new home and a new version of one of its most controversial works. The big event is the return of the LIVING THEATER, the celebrated avant-garde company founded by Judith Malina and Julian Beck. This unabashedly radical troupe hit its stride in the early 1960s, winning its third Obie award in 1963 for ''The Brig,'' the autobiographical play by Kenneth H. Brown about the brutality of a Marine Corps prison. Itinerant for many years, the company now has a permanent space to play in, and Ms. Malina, still very much in charge (Mr. Beck died in 1985), will direct the new production. ''The Brig'' opens Thursday at the Living Theater, 21 Clinton Street, Lower East Side, (212) 352-3101, livingtheatre.org; $20 to $30. The experimental theatrics of the Living Theater seem remote from today's scene, but the high comedy exemplified by the work of Mr. Behrman is probably a further stretch. ''BIOGRAPHY,'' produced on Broadway in 1932, is the story of a painter setting out to write her memoirs. Trouble arises when a key player in her past, now a prominent political figure, registers an objection. The third major character is the radical publisher, intent on getting his author to tell all. J. R. Sullivan directs. ''Biography'' opens Sunday at the Pearl Theater, 80 St. Marks Place, East Village, (212) 598-9802, pearltheatre.org; $40 to $70.

THE federal government helped create the mortgage industry in 1934 by insuring long-term housing loans, but it has largely disappeared from the market in recent years as private lenders have led the mortgage boom. Now government loans may once again be finding a spot on the borrower's short list. Mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration are starting to make a comeback as banks and regulators tighten lending standards throughout the nation and turn away many low- and moderate-income homeowners. According to mortgage industry analysts and executives, such loans include important benefits not common in the current pool of conventional mortgages.

FEINBERG--Sidney, New York entertainment attorney died on April 20th. Mr. Feinberg was a graduate of Harvard Law School and a prominent attorney in the field of entertainment, representing many Broadway shows, as well as stars of stage, film, and TV. He will be mourned by family and his many friends. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. Donations in his memory may be made to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. $(6$)FEINBERG--Sidney. The Dorothy Loudon Foundation deeply mourns the loss of their friend Sidney Feinberg, whose wise counsel, knowledge of the theatre and brilliant wit was unmatched. A loyal man, devoted to his friends and clients, and as a mentor to many young lawyers, he was patient and gave of his time tirelessly. We extend to his family, our deepest sympathy and condolences. Lionel Larner, Executive Director $(6$)FEINBERG--Sidney. The former partners of Leavy Rosensweig and Hyman note with sorrow the passing on April 20th of Sidney Feinberg, a founding member of the firm and a beloved friend. Sidney was a leading member of the entertainment bar and extraordinary practitioner who served clients with both devotion and consummate skill. Most of all we miss his contagious smile, his warmth, his wry humor and his just being there. $(6$)FEINBERG--Sidney. My dear friend and attorney for over 40 years. I wouldn't have had a career if it weren't for Sidney. On behalf of the entire Keach family, our thoughts and prayers are with him, his family, and his many friends. He was a bright and shining star in my life. We shall miss him terribly. Stacy Keach

A table on April 8 with a report on executive pay included an incorrect figure from Equilar Inc., an executive compensation research firm, for the value of equity holdings of Glenn A. Britt, chief executive of Time Warner Cable. And a correction in this space last Sunday gave another incorrect figure from the firm for those equity holdings. The value was $10.8 million -- not $25.8 million or $10.5 million.

To the Editor: Mimi Sells reminds us, in ''Packing on the Pollution'' (Op-Ed, April 15), that we should be more aware of the environmental impact of our online purchases. She's certainly right that the ease of online purchasing and returns can lead to greater pollution, as our boxes wing their ways across our skies day and night.

HART--Kitty Carlisle. You taught us all how to discover our voice and our spirit, to find our light, and to shine like the glow of your glorious smile. I will always remember and love you. Ted Berger $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. The Musical Instruments Department of The Metropolitan Museum of Art is deeply saddened by the death of our Leading Lady Kitty Carlisle Hart, Co-Chair of our Visiting Committee. She enlivened our events, our meetings, our galleries, our lives. She will always be ''Something wonderful'' to us. J. Kenneth Moore, Frederick P. Rose Curator in Charge, Musical Instruments Department Mrs. Thatcher M. Brown, Co - Chair, Musical In struments Visiting Committee $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. The Board of Directors of the Parkinson's Disease Foundation mourn the loss of our dear friend and cultural leader. Her elegant presence will be missed at our annual galla. Page Morton Black, Chairman $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. Unparalleled style, elegance, and intelligence, all uniquely yours. How blessed I am with so many memories to hold Hart to heart. You truly were Something Wonderful. Dean Williamson $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. The Members and Staff of the New York State Council on the Arts express their deep sadness at the passing of their beloved former Chairman, Kitty Carlisle Hart. Affectionately known to us as Kitty, she was a vital mainstay of our agency for more than three decades, dispensing wisdom and charm wherever she went. She was a vibrant and tireless advocate for the arts and she will be missed by the entire arts community. Kitty will always be remembered by us as a colleague and a good friend. She was one of a kind and remains irreplaceable. $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. The daughters of Irving Berlin mourn the death of Kitty Carlisle Hart. She was a dear friend to our parents and to us. We $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle, The Board and Staff of Americans for the Arts, Arts & Business Council of Americans for the Arts, and Arts & Business Council of New York celebrate the life of Kitty Carlisle Hart. She was a beacon for all of the arts and a tireless advocate for public funding for the arts in New York and across the country. We were proud to have honored Ms. Hart last year at the Americans for the Arts' National Arts Awards with an award that has since 1997 borne her name, which celebrates those who lead as artists and advocates. Her legacy and spirit continues. $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. The Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization, and the Rodgers and Hammerstein families, note with sadness the passing of our dear friend Kitty Hart. From her performance in the revival of ''On Your Toes'' to her enlightened encouragement of the work of Moss Hart, her enthusiasm and passion for the arts was without equal. We will miss her, but feel blessed to have known her throughout her long and extraordinary life. We send our condolences to Cathy, Chris and their families. $(6$)HART--Kitty Carlisle. The directors, board members and staff of The Menninger Clinic in Houston, Texas mourn the passing of our friend and mentor, who has been affiliated with Menninger since 1982, and was the perfect hostess at a relatively recent gettogether on Menninger's behalf at her apartment. Everyone attending came away with a wonderful memory and the impression they had been in the presence of someone very, very special. Ian Aitken President and CEO, The Menninger Clinic

I am a musician who would like to visit Paris and sing. Any suggestions? -- Catherine O'Brien, St. Pauls, New South Wales, Australia There are many options for you, depending on what kind of singing you want to do in Paris. Busking on the Pont St. Louis near Notre-Dame is popular with young musicians from all over.

To the Editor: Thank you for your continued support of New Orleans (''Broken Promises to a Broken Gulf,'' editorial, April 17). The $110 billion that was initially committed after Katrina was divided up over the five states that were hit, and much of it went to cleanup work that was contracted out by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Amazingly, there were so many layers of management involved that a great deal of money was wasted.

Student photographers roving their campuses for The New York Times: Katharine Sidelnik (Rochester Institute of Technology) and Clara Rice (Northeastern). Text by Jamie Wallis DANCE PAD -- With clubs from U.C.L.A. to Cornell devoted to it, and almost 400 Facebook groups on the subject, Dance Dance Revolution is firmly entrenched as a college craze. Born as an arcade game and played with an Xbox or PlayStation 2, D.D.R. demands fast reflexes to keep up with furious on-screen directions. At a party at Northeastern University in Boston, Jenna Short and Dave Landry, far right, competed for dance dominance; then Marybeth Miller took a solo turn. Ms. Miller confesses to playing alone in her room -- ''a lot.'' GEEK ART -- A computer is a canvas at the Rochester Institute of Technology. Philipp Batta, far left, arranged sticker-sheet remnants to make his apple appear to move. ''They represent progress,'' he says. Sally Safadi's babysitting charges affixed their sticker collection, center. Computer makers, too, are rethinking the skin. The two assemblages at left come from Dell.

RAEBURN--Robert A. The employees of Vanguard Industries wish to pay tribute to Robert A. Raeburn, who passed away on April 17, 2007 in New York. Mr. Raeburn was a friend, competitor, and business associate for over 50 years. He will be missed by all who knew him. He was a man of integrity, honesty, and character. He taught us all that ''his word was his bond.'' Bill and Debra Gershen, Michael Harrison, and Mr. Herbert P. Sydney

Stephen Petronio has always had a talent for choosing interesting musical partners. Last year he enlisted the singer-songwriter Rufus Wainwright for the lyrical ''Bud Suite,'' a work that will be shown again when the STEPHEN PETRONIO COMPANY opens this week at the Joyce. For his most recent piece Mr. Petronio has chosen a song by the avant-garde vocalist Antony, whose ''For Today I Am a Boy'' will be used for a new solo for Davalois Fearon, one of the company's most expressive and appealing dancers. The program also includes ''The Ship Song,'' an extract from Mr. Petronio's recent work for the Sydney Dance Company, and a revival of his 1997 ''ReBourne,'' to music by those avatars of punk-influenced hip-hop, the Beastie Boys. Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday through Saturday at 8 p.m., next Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $40. The NEW YORK CITY BALLET'S spring season opens Tuesday with a week of 10 all-Balanchine masterworks -- a tribute to its co-founder, Lincoln Kirstein, whose birthday centenary is being celebrated throught the season. After trying out a schedule of fixed programs during the winter, the company appears to have reverted to the model of different combinations of ballets on each night, a relief to those who liked to deliberate over whether to see, say, ''Concerto Barocco,'' ''Duo Concertant'' and ''Symphony in Three Movements'' with ''Square Dance'' (Wednesday night) or with ''The Four Temperaments'' (Thursday). Take note of Kyra Nichols -- the company's reigning ballerina, due to retire at the end of the season -- in ''Pavane'' on Tuesday and Friday nights. And the wonderful Nikolaj Hübbe, recently appointed as the next director of the Royal Danish Ballet, appears in ''Apollo'' (Saturday matinee) and ''Square Dance'' (Wednesday and Friday nights). Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday through Saturday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 2 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570, nycballet.com; $30 to $86. On Saturday night Symphony Space will play host to some 15 contemporary dance, tap, and ballet companies in ''DANCE SAMPLER: FROM TAP TO TOE.'' As ''Fall for Dance'' has proven, mixed bills like this are an enjoyable way to introduce audiences to the kinds of work that may not have been seen before, and to suggest something about the state of the art. For $15 this program, which includes Christopher Williams, Chamber Dance, Hilary Easton and Company and Rumba Tap, is a great deal. 7 p.m., 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org.

TO lease or not to lease. That is a question that landlords and tenants must answer whenever a market-rate apartment is being rented. And while the landlord's preference will usually prevail, real estate lawyers say that it is not uncommon for both landlords and tenants to be wary of signing a lease, particularly for rentals in buildings outside Manhattan. The choice can have legal ramifications.

When James F. Davis bought New Balance, the athletic shoe company, he paid $100,000 for it. Now, 35 years later, Mr. Davis is stepping down as chief executive of the company, which had $1.55 billion in revenue last year. Mr. Davis, 62, said that it was ''time to introduce younger and more progressive management'' to New Balance, known for offering several widths in its running shoes, and for manufacturing them in the United States, at five sites in Maine and Massachusetts; the company is based in Boston.

BERGSTEIN--Leonard. Loving husband, father, and grandfather. Survived by his wife Marilyn, three daughters, seven grandchildren, and all of those who had the good fortune of knowing him. He will be missed. Memorial Service at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, 2pm, April 23, 2007.

Truman and Minhee Cho, the founders of Paper + Cup, a graphic design firm in Brooklyn known for its hip, whimsical stationery, see eye-to-eye at work. ''Everything we make, we think of together,'' Ms. Cho said. ''I'm always looking for mundane objects on the sidewalk that I can translate onto paper.'' Her husband, Truman, who also works as a technological engineer at EMI Records, agreed. ''We make napkin drawings at breakfast and dinner,'' he said. ''Minhee comes up with the designs on the computer, and then I pull back the reins because she goes so far out there.'' Simply put, Ms. Cho said, ''He edits me.'' In terms of wardrobe, it is her husband who could use some editing. ''He owns more than double the clothing that I do,'' said Ms. Cho, 32. ''I usually just wear jeans and a comfortable shirt.'' Here, she wears a Tracy Reese cotton eyelet top, Paige jeans and Chie Mahara shoes. Mr. Cho, also 32, wears an Etro jacket over a Thom Browne shirt and a Dries Van Noten sweater. His jeans are by John Varvatos, and his sneakers are Jack Purcells by John Varvatos. ''Clothes are functional art pieces,'' he said.

Florida residents will get another chance to vote for Jeb Bush, provided that they own shares of the Tenet Healthcare Corporation. Tenet, the hospital operator based in Dallas, appointed Mr. Bush, who served two terms as governor of Florida, to its board this month.

FORD--Emory, (Emory M. Ford, Jr.) died April 15, at age 63. Beloved husband of Anne Fisher Ford of Grosse Pointe Farms, Michigan; stepfather of Christopher and Brooke Benkert; sister of Laura Ford. Funeral was held April 19 at Christ Church Grosse Pointe. Memorial contributions may be made to the Emory M. Ford, Jr., Endowment Fund at the Community Foundation for Southeast Michigan, 333 West Fort Street, Suite 2010, Detroit, MI 48226-3134.

DRINKING fountains are becoming a thing of the past. They are disappearing from public buildings and public places, while the ones that remain are broken or poorly maintained. And it's not just water fountains. Plain old water from the faucet is increasingly ignored. Waiters look askance when diners request tap water instead of bottled. Conference tables and lecterns at public hearings no longer have the familiar pitcher of water with a supply of glasses for the participants and speakers. Instead more and more people are buying and carrying plastic water bottles; sponsors for public forums often provide them for each speaker. What is going on?

GOLDSMITH--Frieda Kittay. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of the Jewish Home & Hospital mourn the passing of a generous benefactor, Frieda Kittay Goldsmith. For over 37 years, Mrs. Goldsmith has supported Kittay House, named in honor of herself and her first husband, Sol Kittay. Since 1970, Kittay House has provided affordable independent living with support services for seniors. Mrs. Goldsmith's thoughtfulness and generosity has enabled Jewish Home to provide the amenities that make a significant difference in the lives of Kittay tenants. She will be warmly remembered by all who had the privilege to know her. We're extremely grateful to Mrs. Goldsmith and send our heartfelt condolences to her son Jeffrey Kittay, her daughter Arlyn Imberman and the entire family. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Kittay House, 2550 Webb Avenue, Bronx, NY 10468. Gene D. Resnick, M.D. Chairman of the Board Audrey S. Weiner, DSW President/CEO $(6$)GOLDSMITH--Frieda Kittay. Cherished wife of the late A. Philip Goldsmith and the late Sol Kittay. An elegant woman and role model of femininity, she brought grace and beauty to all she knew. Fluent in many languages and very much involved in the world of the arts, in particular French history and culture. Her wit sparkled like a jewel and she brought laughter and wisdom through her extraordinary ability as a supreme hostess and raconteur. The world is a lesser place without her. Beloved mother of Jeffrey Kittay and his wife Eva, Arlyn Imberman, and Linda Strulovic; adored grandmother of Sesha and Leo (Kim) Kittay, Thomas and Alberto Strulovic, and Deborah and Liane Radel; dear great grandmother of Micah and Asa Kittay; loving aunt to her nieces and nephews, and special cousin to Eleanor and Robert Sorin. Services 1:00PM Sunday April 22, 2007 at Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Kittay House, 2550 Webb Ave., Bronx, NY 10468.

TOMORROW is the first day of TV-Turnoff Week, and I'm conflicted. On the one hand, I want to comply. It's a cause that has my sympathy. On the other hand, television is one of the few places where my 15-year-old son, Asher, and I can hang out together. That might sound blighted, and the penurious nature of our present relations might be all my fault, but it is what it is. Some people have Paris. We have ''Animal Cops: Houston.'' Accepting this hasn't come easily. When Asher was little and controllable, it was possible to stick to my resolve of raising him with a minimum of television in his life. I wasn't allowed to watch more than half an hour a week when I was growing up, and my mother's claims that it was a waste of time, a destroyer of brain cells, a purveyor of unhealthy food and unnecessary material items, which seemed like a paranoid rant at the time, came to make sense to me as an adult.

To the Editor: My mouth is watering for cheap West Indian takeout after David McAninch's richly rendered stroll down Jamaica Avenue in Brooklyn and Queens (April 15). But I am amused at the unapologetic ethnocentrism of calling it ''A Road Not Taken, Much.'' The article describes the commercial blocks of Jamaica Avenue as a pulsing ''Main Street, U.S.A.,'' teeming with businesses and shoppers ''conveyed from far and wide.'' Yet the headline and the whole premise is that this is undiscovered territory, one of ''a city's less-traveled wards.''

IT is 11:15 a.m. The kids have the day off from school and I'm mall crawling The Westchester in White Plains, with my posse: my 11-year-old daughter, Lake, and two of her friends, Annabelle Kirk, 11, and Eve Wulf, 12. They are identically (though they would say individually) decked out in the suburban tween girl uniform, almost head-to-toe Abercrombie: skin-tight jeans and layered T-shirts, as well as ballet flats, Uggs, or Michael Kors boots. Eve wears a Juicy Couture bracelet with a $60 charm that her mother bought for her for Valentine's Day, which the others fawn over longingly.

To the Editor: The writer of ''The Crime Rate and Birth Control'' (letter, April 15) implies that the poor bear children who become criminals, so it is consequently good to give them birth control or abortions. Her comments are pro-eugenics thinking, and she is misinformed as well.

In Katonah, a community group and a local business owner have formally filed their opposition to an attempt by Martha Stewart's company to trademark the wealthy hamlet's name for a line of furnishings and other home décor merchandise. The Katonah Village Improvement Society and Andrew Hall Baren, the owner of Katonah Architectural Hardware and Katonah Paint and Hardware, filed their objection with the Patent and Trademark Office on April 11.

Q. We live in a co-op in a 100-year-old brownstone with several apartments on four floors. The fireplace in the apartment on the first floor appears to have a leak in the chimney so that fumes escape into the adjacent apartment and the common area. The owner has agreed to stop using the fireplace until it is fixed. Who should pay for this repair? A. ''The first step in solving this problem is to determine what is wrong and how it can be fixed,'' said Howard Schechter, a Manhattan co-op lawyer. He said that under most proprietary leases, anything visible in the apartment (other than standard heating equipment like radiators) is the shareholder's responsibility and anything behind the walls, floor or ceiling (with the exception of electrical wiring and certain plumbing connections) is the co-op corporation's.

To the Editor: Re ''The Pilotless Plane that Only Looks Like Child's Play'' (April 15), about unmanned aerial vehicles used by the military: The Air Force is not desiring to ''control the deployment of unmanned airplanes,'' as the article said, but is recommending that it be designated the Department of Defense executive agent to oversee the purchasing process for medium- and high-altitude U.A.V.'s. The associated authority would let the Air Force standardize and streamline U.A.V. purchasing to produce substantial cost savings benefiting all the military services.
The 36 Hours column last Sunday about spending a weekend in Portland, Ore., gave an incorrect Internet address for Sip & Kranz, a coffee bar. It is www.sipandkranz.com.

The Checking In column last Sunday, about increased hotel development in Lower Manhattan, referred incorrectly to four hotels being developed by the McSam Hotel Group. At 20 Maiden Lane, the hotel will be a Wyndham, not a Holiday Inn Express, and it will have 113 rooms, not 101. At 99 Washington Street, the hotel will be a Holiday Inn with 370 rooms, not 371; it is not unnamed. At 8 Stone Street, a hotel yet to be named will have 400 rooms, not 192; it is not a Doubletree. And at 33 Beekman Street, a hotel yet to be named will have 350 rooms, not 288; it is not a Westin.

To the Editor: After seeing Eve Fairbanks's take on my book, ''Framing the Debate'' (April 8) -- wherein she lampoons me as an ''unjust,'' ''profoundly undemocratic'' and ''terrifying'' villain on par with Brutus in Shakespeare's ''Julius Caesar'' -- readers may have wondered why Fairbanks stopped short of blaming me for the Iraq war, the Kennedy assassination and the Lindbergh baby kidnapping. Et tu, Feldman?
HAGAI--Shlomo, Beloved husband of Victoria. Died April 7, 2007 at the age of 88.

IT is 11:15 a.m. The kids have the day off from school and I'm mall crawling The Westchester in White Plains, with my posse: my 11-year-old daughter, Lake, and two of her friends, Annabelle Kirk, 11, and Eve Wulf, 12. They are identically (though they would say individually) decked out in the suburban tween girl uniform, almost head-to-toe Abercrombie: skin-tight jeans and layered T-shirts, as well as ballet flats, Uggs, or Michael Kors boots. Eve wears a Juicy Couture bracelet with a $60 charm that her mother bought for her for Valentine's Day, which the others fawn over longingly.

HARTMAN--John Wheeler. Management, Innovator, Author, Philanthropist. John Wheeler Hartman of Ocean Reef, Key Largo, Florida, died on April 5th, 2007 at the age of 84. He was predeceased by his wife of 56 years, Esther Kelly Bill Hartman. In 1946. Mr. Hartman was one of the founders of Bacon, Hartman and Vollbrecht, a St. Augustine and Jacksonville, Florida advertising agency. After joining the sales department of Bill Communications, Inc., a New York city-based magazine publisher, he became its Chief Executive Officer in 1957, and later Chairman of the Board. In 1975, Mr. Hartman introduced the publishing industry's first decentralized participatory management plan and Employee Stock Ownership Trust. Bill employees at all levels were encouraged to make management contributions and decisions. Several of Mr. Hartman's unconventional innovations, such as his ''Bottoms Up Management'' theory, remain to this day as case studies at Harvard's Business School. Mr. Hartman's witty writings appeared in a column he titled Second Thoughts, which was originally published in Sales & Marketing Management magazine. He has authored nine books including More Second Thoughts and Maverick Management. He later became a contributing columnist to other publications, such as Advertising Age, Business Marketing, and the Ocean Reef Free Press. Mr. Hartman, and his wife Kelly's philanthropy established the Hartman Center for MidSized Company Education and Research at the Fuqua Graduate School of Business and the Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising and Marketing History at the college library. The Hartman's also donated 300 acres to the Town of Lyme, CT., to create the Hartman Park. Mr. Hartman was born in Detroit, Michigan, and attended Colgate University before receiving his Bachelor's degree from Duke University. He served as a Lieutenant JG in the U.S. Navy during World War II and participated in the D-Day invasion of Normandy on June 6th, 1944. He wrote for the U.S. Navy's newspaper, The Inlander from 194546, and was a correspondent in Florida for United Press International. In 1963, he was elected international president of the Young Presidents Organization, serving as board member and Forum Chairman of the Chief Executives Organization. He founded the Executive Council of the Conference Board and was a member of the World Presidents' Organization. Mr. Hartman is survived by daughter, Kelly H. Sherwood, of Woolwich, Maine; son Raymond Hartman, of Mooresville, NC; grandchildren, Katerina Sterghiou, of Brooklyn, NY, and Nicola Hartman, of San Carlos, CA; a brother, Robert E. Hartman, of Albuquerque, NM; and a sister, Ann Carter, of Darien, CT. $(6$)HARTMANN--Charolotte Sigrid, age 86, February 26, 1921-April 16, 2007. Visiting hours on Tuesday April 24, 2007, 4-8pm. Morehead-McKim-Gallaher, 424 West 51st Street (between 9th and 10th Ave). Funeral Service Wednesday April 25, 2007, 2:30 pm. Church of Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner) 1 E. 29th Street.

MATTERS were simpler 100 years ago, when junior colleges were created to prepare deserving students for the final two years of a university. In fact, the very first public junior college, in Joliet, Ill., was set up in a high school, as the equivalent of grades 13 and 14. Community colleges today do far more than offer a ladder to the final years. They train the people who repair your furnace, install your plumbing, take your pulse. They prepare retiring baby boomers for second or third careers, and provide opportunities for a growing number of college-age students turning away from the high cost and competition at universities. And charged with doing the heavy remedial lifting, community colleges are now as much 10th and 11th grade as 13th and 14th.

A photograph with an article last Sunday about the impending closing of the Barnes & Noble bookstore at Astor Place was published in error. It showed the Barnes & Noble store at Union Square, not the store at Astor Place.

To a first-timer, the letters that arrive in spring from financial aid offices can be a head-scratcher: no two packages are alike. Private institutions, especially, interpret family finances in different ways; some have deeper pockets; some fail to meet ''demonstrated need'' (the difference between the cost of attending and the amount a family is deemed able to pay, according to a need analysis formula). According to an annual College Board survey, the private colleges below provide aid packages that meet the highest percentage of need. In reviewing offers, remember: loans have to be paid back, grants do not. KEY: COST: Tuition, fees, room and board AVERAGE AID PACKAGE: Given freshmen with need SELF-HELP: Work-study and need-based loans NON-NEED: Grants and scholarships, excluding athletic awards PERCENTAGES: % of applicants getting this aid (non-need: % of class) ALL DOLLAR FIGURES IN THOUSANDS (for freshman class, 2005)

PYNE--Eben W., 89, died April 11, 2007, at his home in Hobe Sound, Florida. A Service will be held on May 12 at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 182 Main St., Gladstone, NJ at 10:30 am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Brooklyn Museum, Fort Ticonderoga, Juilliard School of Music and the Wildlife Conservation Society.

Okay, Governor Spitzer and New York lawmakers. You finished the budget, only a few hours late, but it's done. You took your spring vacation. Now it is time to tackle one of the truly terrible, disgraceful things about New York's political scene -- the ossified, uncompetitive, self-serving system that virtually guarantees legislators jobs for life. There is more job security in Albany than there once was in Albania, less turnover than in the last outposts of tenured academia, a better chance of a lifelong job than in the strongest of union strongholds. All those years in office do not guarantee more wisdom. They mostly mean more paralysis, more petrifaction. With no fresh ideas, no fresh air, the place gets downright moldy.

At their first meeting with journalists since taking over Russia's largest independent radio news network, the managers had startling news of their own: from now on, they said, at least 50 percent of the reports about Russia must be ''positive.'' In addition, opposition leaders could not be mentioned on the air and the United States was to be portrayed as an enemy, journalists employed by the network, Russian News Service, say they were told by the new managers, who are allies of the Kremlin.

Less gym, more pounds. A coincidence? Judith Rink, a phys ed expert at the University of South Carolina, thinks not, and predicts a new respect for P.E. ''There has been so much public attention to the obesity issue,'' she says, ''decreasing P.E. time is probably not politically correct for schools to do anymore.'' She cites some legislative ''bright lights'': South Carolina has mandated at least 150 minutes of physical activity a week in elementary schools; California has announced incentive grants to hire about 1,100 new gym teachers. Two dozen states use the Praxis exam to certify phys ed teachers. The questions below, from the Educational Testing Service's practice exams, show what it takes. Answers are on Page 32. 1. It is reputed that Milo of Greece lifted a newborn bull onto his shoulders each day until the bull became fully mature. Milo followed what two principles of modern muscle strength and endurance conditioning? a. progression and overload b. variable resistance and overload c. frequency and progression d. intensity and retention 2. Which of the following sports is considered to have originated in the United States and not been adapted from similar games from other countries? a. baseball b. basketball c. football d. golf 3. In the late 1800s, the greatest influence on the direction of physical education came from individuals with a background in which of the following? a. medicine b. professional sport c. intercollegiate sport d. the military 4. Which of the following best describes the effect of sports participation on personality? a. Players are not affected in a predictable way. b. Players who pursue individual sports become more introverted. c. Players who participate in team sports become more extroverted. d. Players tend to become more individualistic. 5. Which of the following lists the usual developmental order of play stages through which children progress in United States society? a. competitive, cooperative, introspective, parallel b. cooperative, competitive, parallel, introspective c. introspective, parallel, cooperative, competitive d. parallel, cooperative, competitive, introspective 6. In its most rudimentary form, which of the following locomotor skills generally appears last in a young child's repertory of movements? a. galloping b. skipping c. hopping d. jumping 7. Heavy resistive training, such as strenuous weight training, should be avoided in early childhood because of the potential development of: a. inflexible joints b. epiphyseal separations c. elongated ligaments d. calcium deposits 8. Which of the following statements best characterizes most children between ages 5 and 8? a. They are in the egocentric stage. b. They choose leaders spontaneously from among themselves. c. They are primarily concerned with following the rules. d. They begin to create strategies and mentally test their abilities. 9. Which of the following statements best characterizes most children between ages 8 and 11? a. They have lost their strong egocentric tendencies. b. They have a strong social need, especially at the higher age range. c. They have a desire to participate in parallel play. d. They feel more comfortable as part of a large group than a small group. 10. In children age 5 through 9, the largest gender difference is generally evident in which of the following? a. standing height (or stature) b. overarm throwing velocity and distance c. standing long-jump distance d. sprint running speed and duration 11. Using various body parts to volley a balloon or a lightweight ball will best enhance skill for which of the following sports? a. basketball and soccer b. basketball and tennis c. volleyball and soccer d. volleyball and tennis 12. Based on the speed of the runners, which of the following is the generally accepted strategy used in setting up a pursuit relay team? a. fastest, second fastest, third fastest, slowest b. second fastest, third fastest, slowest, fastest c. third fastest, slowest, fastest, second fastest d. slowest, fastest, second fastest, third fastest 13. When performing an overhand serve in volleyball, the player should: a. contact the ball with a cupped or open hand b. contact the ball with the arm bent c. serve the ball off a bounce d. shift weight to the back foot as the ball is contacted 14. When dribbling a soccer ball in a restricted space, the player should attempt to do all of the following except: a. keep the ball close to the feet b. stay in a slightly crouched position c. use body feints and changes of speed d. use only the dominant foot for better control 15. The correct racing posture of a swimmer, cyclist or downhill skier minimizes the effect of: a. lift b. propulsion c. turbulence d. gravity 16. Which of the following activities is most aerobically demanding in relation to kilocalories burned per hour? a. bowling b. volleyball c. walking d. cross-country skiing 17. To lose one pound of fat a week, a person would theoretically need a weekly caloric deficit of approximately: a. 1,500 calories b. 3,500 calories c. 5,500 calories d. 7,500 calories 18. After maturity, which of the following generally increases due to the aging process? a. maximum heart rate b. vital capacity c. body fat d. body height 19. Eighty percent of Americans will suffer from lower back pain. The primary cause of this condition is: a. car accidents b. muscular imbalance of the trunk c. falls d. osteoporosis 20. The primary reason for including protein in the human diet is to provide: a. material for building and repairing body tissue b. an energy reserve in the body c. vitamins and minerals for growth d. readily available energy for bodily functions

To the Editor: Re ''The Morality Line'' (column, April 19): David Brooks makes the point about choice and responsibility: The killings at Virginia Tech happened at a moment ''when background forces stop and individual choice'' begins.

ARGAMASO--Ravelo. The Department of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Montefiore Medical Center and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine is deeply saddened with the passing of their senior colleague and devoted faculty member. He was born in the Philippines in 1926 and received his M.D. degree at the University of Santo-Tomas in 1953. After general surgery training in Portland, Oregon he came to Montefiore Hospital as the first resident in Plastic Surgery from 1959-1961. He returned to the full time faculty at Montefiore in 1966 and achieved the rank of full professor in Plastic Surgery in 1982 and in Neurosurgery in 1989 at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He was an extremely innovative surgeon, artistic and skilled. His main interests were in the area of Cleft Lip and Palate surgery and congenital ear reconstruction. His surgical talents created major improvements in the quality of life for these children. He was recognized by his peers with membership in many scientific organizations among which were the Association of Plastic Surgeons and the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons. Our sympathies go out to his wife Carol, his children Sharlene, Susanne and Stephanie as well as to his three grandchildren, Maggie, Ella and Aidan. The family has planned a memorial service for Friday April 27, 2007 at 11:30 a.m. at the First Baptist Church 407 New Rochelle Rd. Bronxville, New York . Berish Strauch, M.D. Professor and Chairman Dept. of Plastic Surgery, Montefoire Medical Center and The Albert Eistein College of Medicine
