LEYNSE--Judith L. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Judith L. Leynse. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, Pres. George Asch, Sec'y $(6$)LEYNSE--Judith Light, 68, beloved mother, grandmother and wife, died in her sleep on April 15th at her home in New York. Her remarkable career included work in newspaper journalism, the U.S. Foreign Service, documentary film, teaching, and public information and media relations. She was also a dedicated volunteer, active in her community. As a tireless theatre supporter, an opera enthusiast, a world traveler and Francophile, she enjoyed varied pursuits. Her life was full of hope, love and purpose, and she will be greatly missed by all who knew her. She is survived by her sons, James and Andrew Leynse; their loving wives, Wendy Leynse and Mary Bacon; and two grandchildren, whom she adored. Services Monday, April 30th, 2pm, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

DANTZKER--Morris ''Dan'' Dan Dantzker died on April 12, 2007. A resident of San Francisco since 1986, Dan's roots remained in Washington, D.C. and New York City, where he was born 92 years ago. He was the only one of four children of immigrant parents from Luboml, Ukraine born in the United States. Dan survived his wife Mary by six years and is survived by three children and five grandchildren. With a lifelong commitment to education and learning, Dan graduated from the College of the City of New York with a B.S. in Chemistry in 1934. A course in logic at CCNY significantly influenced Dans thinking and work throughout his professional life. Grateful to CCNY for providing an outstanding, free education, Dan supported the College throughout his life. With the support of the U.S. Army, Dan obtained an M.B.A. from Ohio State University in 1955. He also attended the US Army Command and General Staff College in 1959 and the Industrial College of the Armed Forces in 1963. Dan was inducted into the U.S. Army in 1941 and commissioned a second lieutenant in the Adjutant General Corps in 1942. During World War II, he served in Manila and Korea, and de-mobilized in 1946. He re-joined the Regular Army in 1947. In a 25-year military career, primarily in computer technology, he was awarded the Legion of Merit, the Bronze Star, the Korea Defense Service Medal and the Commendation Medal. In his last tour, Dan was Special Assistant to the Army Chief of Staff for Army Information and Data Systems before retiring as a Colonel in 1967. Dan's background in logic and information systems led him in 1969 to a second career with Con Edison of New York, where he eventually became Executive Vice President. He was part of a new management team brought in to assist the company refocus on customer service and system reliability. He led a team in the successful development and deployment of one of the country's first computer data base customer information retrieval systems, which would allow a service representative to see a customer's records on a computer screen while talking to the customer. Commonplace now, such systems were at the outer edge of information technology at the time. Dan's focus on customer service operations and the reliability of power distribution systems led to a substantial reduction in complaints and to system wide improvements that helped all employees deliver better service to the ratepayers. He remained committed his entire life to a company that he knew affected the lives of millions of residents every day and that was critical to the economic sustainability of the city he loved. Dan retired from Con Edison in 1980 and became President of the Economic Development Council of New York City, Inc. where he coordinated efforts of business, labor and government to improve the economic development environment of New York City. He then went on to consulting career for utilities nationwide, before finally retiring in 1990. A life long student of space, astronomy and the physical world, Dan was a voracious reader. At age 90 he read On The Origin of Species, taking notes as he went. He was a supporter of smaller or less is better long before environmental impacts would be widely understood. For Dan, education never ended and he supported his children and grandchildren generously in their own schooling. He also completed the New York Times crossword puzzle every day for the last 30 years. His family deeply mourns his passing, and will keep his adage that it is always better to share close to our hearts. A service and burial will take place in Arlington National Cemetery on June 13, 2007 at 9:00 am.
An article last Sunday about the forthcoming Nickelodeon television series ''Ni Hao, Kai-lan!'' misspelled the surname of the show's creator. She is Karen Chau, not Chao.

Among the list of contentious proposals that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to announce today in his ambitious effort to steer the city toward a greener future, here's one that is likely to receive little argument: more trees. The city intends to plant a million trees during the next 10 years, filling every sidewalk vacancy with one and adding thousands to parks and public spaces.

A memorial service will be held at First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and 11th Street, Saturday April 28, 2007 at 2 PM. Memorial gifts may be made to PCUSA Hostetter Fund at the Presbyterian Foundation, PO Box 406863, Atlanta, GA 30384-6863.

Dave Soldier: Chamber Works Various instrumentalists; Dave Soldier, guitarist, harmonica player. Mulatta MUL014; two CDs. ONE thing about having an approach as idiosyncratic as Dave Soldier's is that once listeners know your work at all, they realize that coming to new works with any expectations about style, form or language is fruitless. As this expertly played sampler of his chamber music shows, Mr. Soldier is all over the musical map, and this is only part of the picture. Absent are his music for elephant orchestra, his quasi-operatic dramas and his unalloyed rock music.

HOW do you survive a child's death? On Sept. 27, 2005, at Little League practice, Robbie Levine was running the bases during a relay race. As he rounded first, his dad, Craig, the coach, remembers thinking his son had never run so fast. Robbie was a fine little athlete, that blessed 9-year-old who could catch a grounder and make the throw to first, a smart, focused boy you could put at shortstop to hold your infield together.

Dr. Sarah Bland Smith and James Frederick Butterworth were married in Boulder, Colo., yesterday afternoon. They married themselves under Colorado law. David Secunda and Carmela Weber, friends of the couple, led the ceremony at the Sunrise Amphitheater, an outdoor event space. Dr. Smith, 39, is known as Sallie. She is a neurologist in Denver and a clinical instructor in neurology at the University of Colorado School of Medicine. She also has a hypnotherapy practice in Boulder. She graduated from the University of North Carolina and received a medical degree from Columbia.

To the Editor: A 59-year-old and his girlfriend (The Hunt, April 8) buy a fourth-floor walk-up to live out their New York City fantasies? That's all fine and good right now, but even a small inevitable surgery or twisted ankle leaves them unable to use it. Do people have no sense? Susan Frierson Upper West Side

HOLLIS--Zachary. August 22, 1990-April 19, 2007. It is with deepest sorrow that the Board of Directors, Staff and Members of the Tourette Syndrome Association (TSA) mourn the passing of Zachary Hollis, who died tragically and suddenly in an automobile accident in Albuquerque, NM. A kind, cheerful and gentle young man, in his all too brief 16 years, undeniably he touched the lives of everyone who knew him with his positive outlook, exceptional warmth, contagious smile and quick wit. His indomitable spirit and irrepressible sense of humor will be missed by family, friends and all who knew him. He had a passion for research and geology and loved school. He was very active in Boy Scouts and was close to making Eagle Scout, a rank he is being awarded posthumously. Zak also collected old Volkswagen models, enjoyed playing tennis and swimming, and was an avid animal lover, faithfully nurturing his dozens of pets. He wanted to become a neurologist and study the brain. Diagnosed with Tourette Syndrome at the age of eight, he always sought opportunities to raise awareness about this neurological disorder. Zak volunteered his time to the TSA selflessly. He served as an editor of the TSA Children's Newsletter and each year, eagerly looked forward to traveling to Washington D.C. to meet personally with his elected officials to educate them and put a real face on what it meant to have Tourette Syndrome. Zak will be receiving the TSA National Youth Recognition Award posthumously, and the award will be renamed The Zak Hollis National Youth Recognition Award in his honor. Our deepest sympathies and prayers go to his parents, Sandra and Michael, and his siblings, Joshua, Christopher, Jennifer and Rosanna. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Tourette Syndrome Association, Inc., 42-40 Bell Boulevard, Bayside, NY 11361. He will be missed dearly and always remembered with a smile by the many, many people whose lives he touched.

A review on April 1 about ''Chance and Circumstance: Twenty Years With Cage and Cunningham,'' by Carolyn Brown, misstated the composer of the music for ''Suite by Chance,'' a 1953 Merce Cunningham Dance Company piece. It was Christian Wolff, not John Cage.

AS the renters of Hamptons summer shares are making their final plans for the coming season, the five members of our house will be getting ready to say goodbye. We didn't sip piña coladas on the deck; we nursed glasses of port and fed the fireplace. Instead of packing bathing suits, we brought thick sweaters and woolly caps. Renting a cottage off-season, from September through May, was my friend's idea; I said yes without giving it much thought. Though I had lived in New York for several years, I had never been to the Hamptons in the summer. Mostly, I was convinced it was not worth the money or the headache to get out there in July. This, my friend informed me, would be the perfect solution: I would satisfy my California-native craving for sand and sea and avoid the madness.

Joanne Jane Wang, the daughter of Julia and Dong-Ping Wang of Stony Brook, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Warner Golann, a son of Jan F. Golann and Steven W. Golann of New York. The Rev. Dr. Paul Sorrentino, a minister of the Conservative Congregational Christian Conference, performed the ceremony at Three Village Church in East Setauket, N.Y. The bride and bridegroom, both 24, met at Amherst, from which they graduated.

After some neighborhoods in Mamaroneck flooded in a heavy rain on March 2, village officials and residents met with the Army Corps of Engineers to discuss ways to prevent a repeat. ''Then we got zonked again,'' Mayor Philip Trifiletti said Tuesday after more than seven inches of rain fell in the village in last week's northeaster, flooding basements, closing roads and leaving merchants lamenting their lack of flood insurance.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Nascar at Crossroads After Years of Growth,'' April 15: Perhaps Nascar's popularity is not growing so fast because people realize that it is a monopoly and that there are forces at work to manipulate the outcomes of races. What was once a sport has become the equivalent of professional wrestling. Ted Stryker Charlotte, N.C.

To the Editor: ''Egypt: On the Red Sea, As Hotels Go Up, Divers Head Down'' (Explorer, April 8) looked like one of those ''What Went Wrong'' post-mortems used for education in diver magazines. The reporter acknowledged his limited diving experience and then broke three cardinal rules of dive safety.

Every time Alex Rodriguez walks to the plate at Yankee Stadium, the smooth voice of Mims, a rapper from Washington Heights, serenades him for each step and for each practice swing. ''This is why I'm hot,'' raps Mims, a line that becomes infectious almost instantly. ''This is why I'm hot. This is why, this is why, this is why I'm hot.''

RICHLAND--Irwin S., 96, Formerly of Riverdale, NY, Fort Lauderdale and Tamarac, FL, died peacefully in his sleep on Friday, April 20, in Weston, MA. After a 45 year advertising career with Richland Advertising in NYC serving the fashion industry, he continued in his beloved career in Florida until his early 90's. An avid athlete himself, he wrote exercise is life! A graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School he entered NYU where he discovered his passion for advertising. He was always the most gracious gentleman who enjoyed sharing his enthusiasm and vigor for life. He lived with the philosophy that the world operates on the essence of goodness. He was predeceased by his beloved wives, Ethel Gips and Edith Kurtz and beloved brother Sidney. He will be missed by his loving family. A graveside service will be held at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, April 24, 11 am.

To the Editor: Re ''Is the U.S. Protecting Foreign Artifacts? Don't Ask'' by Jeremy Kahn [April 8]: Ancient artifacts may be plentiful, but that does not excuse the method used to extract them. One of the most popular items sought by looters of ancient sites in Cambodia are beads. There is a very real possibility that we will lose any chance to understand the rise of the Angkorian civilization.

The Department of Defense has identified 3,305 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday: MORALES, Jason M., 20, Pfc., Army; La Puente, Calif.; First Infantry Division.
To the Editor: Re ''Corzine's Speed Put at 91 M.P.H. Near Crash Site'' (front page, April 18):

An article on Page 17 of the special Education Life section today about new scrutiny of college applications for discipline violations and criminal convictions went to press before the shootings at Virginia Tech on Monday. An updated version of the article that reflects that event can be found at: nytimes.com/edlife.

As a single event, the shootings last week at Virginia Tech were horrific in scale. But every day in the United States, dozens of people die from gunfire. In 2004, the most recent year for which figures are available, an average of about 81 people died everyday from gunfire in the United States. To the Editor: I was very interested to read ''Calling All Jocks and Brainiacs Onstage'' (April 15). I, too, recently had the privilege of directing a production of Disney's ''High School Musical,'' at Somerville School in Ridgewood, N.J., on March 23 and 24. Our production had a total of 96 fourth and fifth graders, who we broke down into two casts. Imagine two Troys, two Gabriellas, two Mrs. Darbuses!

WEISS--Carol, age 80, peacefully on April 19 at her home in East Williston after battling Alzheimers. Beloved wife of Robert Weiss. Carol graduated NYU School of Commerce in 1947. A skilled accountant and leader, she passionately loved and served her family. She is also survived by her loving children Larry (Wendy), and Susan (Ken). Brother Lewis Kaufman, and her adoring grandchildren Shennan, Sascha, Emily, and Daniel. She sought and found the good and beauty in everything she encountered.

Many consider CARLOS SAURA, the left-wing Spanish director who challenged the restrictions of the Franco regime, to be the father of modern Spanish cinema. A leader of the movement labeled the New Spanish Cinema in the 1960s, Mr. Saura established his international reputation with sociopolitical allegories like ''Peppermint Frappé'' (1967), ''Garden of Delights'' (1970) and ''Cría Cuervos'' (1976). An international hit, ''Cría'' told the story of a precocious 9-year-old girl using the notion of arrested childhood (a recurrent theme in his work) as a metaphor for growing up under fascism. The movie, filmed while Franco was dying, was released only after his death. These are among the two dozen films directed by Mr. Saura in ''COMMITMENT AND GRACE,'' a comprehensive anthology presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. After Spain's transition to democracy, Mr. Saura largely retreated from politics to explore Spanish culture, spectacularly in three dance films: ''Blood Wedding,'' a flamenco interpretation of García Lorca's masterpiece; ''Carmen'' (1983), which was nominated for an Academy Award for best foreign film; and ''Flamenco'' (1995), an elegant, fiery documentary study of flamenco styles photographed by Vittorio Storaro. ''Goya in Bordeaux'' (1999), which follows the 82-year-old painter through the streets of that French city as he reflects on his life and work, is a magnificent fusion of biography and art. Another high point is the satire ''¡Ay, Carmela!'' (1990), in which Mr. Saura returned to the Spanish Civil War as a subject. Starring Carmen Maura, it tells the story of a troupe of performers with Republican sympathies arrested by Nationalists in 1938 who, to save themselves, must suddenly adjust their act. Through May 3, Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5600, filmlinc.org.

Next weekend will lack the sizzle of the 2006 draft, which featured two Heisman Trophy winners (Reggie Bush and Matt Leinart) and leading players from two national championship teams (Bush, Leinart and Vince Young). But teams that need a wideout are in luck. This is a deep group of receivers and contains the best player in the draft, Georgia Tech's Calvin Johnson. He is so good that the Raiders will consider taking him with the first overall pick. But they, like a lot of teams near the top of the draft, need a quarterback. That could be a problem because there are not many top quarterbacks in the draft beyond Louisiana State's JaMarcus Russell and Notre Dame's Brady Quinn. Quinn's stock has fluctuated in the past year and his fate, like Leinart's last year, will be one of the intriguing stories Saturday. The top priority for every team, though, is clear: to avoid players with significant character issues. The new personal conduct policy allows the commissioner to discipline teams that consistently have players in trouble. Below, a look at each team's needs. By JUDY BATTISTA 1. OAKLAND -- Needs plenty on offense, but quarterback remains a top priority on a team that has Randy Moss and Jerry Porter. The Raiders have never traded down in the first round. 2. DETROIT -- Could consider a quarterback, but really needs help on defense, especially defensive end and cornerback. Will listen to plenty of trade offers to move down. 3. CLEVELAND -- Lots of offensive needs, including quarterback and running back. 4. TAMPA BAY -- Desperate for Calvin Johnson, it could try to move up if he is available. 5. ARIZONA -- An offensive tackle who could start immediately. 6. WASHINGTON -- A pass-rushing defensive end; the team had just 19 sacks in 2006. 7. MINNESOTA -- Could use a quarterback, with Tarvaris Jackson penciled in at starter, but also needs playmakers on offense to help whoever the quarterback is. 8. ATLANTA (from Houston) -- Offensive line, safety, receiver, defensive end. 9. MIAMI -- The need for a quarterback is overwhelming, with Daunte Culpepper's health still in question. Also needs lots of bodies on offensive line. 10. HOUSTON (from Atlanta) -- Needs a second receiver to pair with Andre Johnson and give new quarterback Matt Schaub more weapons. It could also use a starting-caliber cornerback. 11. SAN FRANCISCO -- Improved defense with free agency spending spree, but still needs help just about everywhere, especially on the defensive line and the back end of the secondary. 12. BUFFALO -- Willis McGahee is gone, so the Bills need a running back. Also needs linebackers. 13. ST. LOUIS -- Improving the run defense is critical. 14. CAROLINA -- Safety and tight end are its most urgent needs, but linebacker could use an infusion of help, too. 15. PITTSBURGH -- Linebacker and cornerback for a defense that will still be a 3-4, but will likely become a 4-3 under the new coach, Mike Tomlin. 16. GREEN BAY -- A running back and a wide receiver would give Brett Favre more weapons in the West Coast offense. 17. JACKSONVILLE -- Safety is only hole in an otherwise stellar defense. A top-flight receiver would help Byron Leftwich. 18. CINCINNATI -- Needs a big defensive tackle to shore up run defense. Also could use linebacker help. Biggest need: spotless character players. 19. TENNESSEE -- Suspension of Pacman Jones makes cornerback a need, but first priority should be receiver. 20. GIANTS -- Linebacker, cornerback and left offensive tackle. 21. DENVER -- Receiver, pass-rushing end and depth at safety for a team that barely missed the playoffs. 22. DALLAS -- Needs help across the board on defense, particularly at cornerback. 23. KANSAS CITY -- Aging team needs youth everywhere, but especially at wide receiver, offensive line and cornerback. 24. NEW ENGLAND (from Seattle) -- First of two first-round picks for team that was extremely active in free agency; will try to get younger at linebacker and get help in secondary. 25. JETS -- Cornerback is an overwhelming need. 26. PHILADELPHIA -- Linebacker and depth in secondary. 27. NEW ORLEANS -- Cornerback and depth at linebacker and on the defensive line. 28. NEW ENGLAND -- See No. 24. 29. BALTIMORE -- Needs cornerback to replace the aging Samari Rolle, in addition to a linebacker and offensive tackle. 30. SAN DIEGO -- Most talented team in N.F.L. doesn't need much beyond a No. 1 receiver. 31. CHICAGO -- Uncertainty over the futures of linebacker Lance Briggs (seeking trade) and defensive tackle Tank Johnson (could face suspension) make their positions a need. But the team's weakness is offense. 32. INDIANAPOLIS -- Defense was picked over in free agency; needs tackle, linebacker and cornerback.

Noah Feldman (April 8) has it right: With no desirable option apparent for Iraq, leaders of both parties are in the dysfunctional mode of avoiding blame. But his ''solution'' -- re-branding the conflict as a fight with Al Qaeda while endorsing no change in strategy -- is a recipe for more of the same.
To the Editor: The Los Angeles Philharmonic's choice for music director, Gustavo Dudamel, is remarkable for his youth, but one wonders why it is necessary to go abroad to find a leader.

Some people refer to Long Island Sound as the Urban Sea, which by itself is enough to make you nervous. Since colonial days, humans in great numbers have gravitated to its coastal habitats, bringing housing, commerce, recreation and, inevitably, pollution. An estimated 20 million people live within a 50 mile drive of its shores, and 400 years after the first European explorers came to trade with the Indians, people are still moving to the coast, eating up open space, trampling wildlife habitats and paving over land in ways that reduce nature's capacity to filter and clean contaminated runoff. The remarkable thing is that the Sound is doing as well as it is; though hemmed in by the densest population area in America, this 110-mile-long body of water has, against all odds, remained one of America's great estuaries, still very much at risk but by no means gasping for life the way Chesapeake Bay is. Water quality has improved, osprey and striped bass, among other species, have made dramatic recoveries, rivers have been opened to provide fish passage and there have even been tiny improvements in restoring wetlands. Credit belongs to governments at all levels, advocacy groups and private citizens; indeed, the entire enterprise is as good an example of regional cooperation as one is likely to find.

AS the renters of Hamptons summer shares are making their final plans for the coming season, the five members of our house will be getting ready to say goodbye. We didn't sip piña coladas on the deck; we nursed glasses of port and fed the fireplace. Instead of packing bathing suits, we brought thick sweaters and woolly caps. Renting a cottage off-season, from September through May, was my friend's idea; I said yes without giving it much thought. Though I had lived in New York for several years, I had never been to the Hamptons in the summer. Mostly, I was convinced it was not worth the money or the headache to get out there in July. This, my friend informed me, would be the perfect solution: I would satisfy my California-native craving for sand and sea and avoid the madness.

RADWELL--Jeanne, 86, died at home peacefully on April 16, 2007, surrounded by loved ones. She was adored, admired and respected by a large, loving extended family, by friends, old and new, and by most gracious caretakers. Her loss will be felt by her daughters Laura and Amy and son-in-law Chick, her grandsons Zachary, Luke and Dylan, Jason and his wife Christine, her great-granddaughter Zarah-Louise, sister Shoy and brother-in-law Norman and sister-in-law and brother-in-law Shirley and Sam. Blessed by a 50 year marriage to the late Louis Radwell, she lived her life with grace, compassion, and a genuine interest in those around her. She elegantly endured life's travails with a strong spirit and sense of joy. We mourn an accomplished, inspirational woman of unfailing warmth and wit. Donations can be made to Comprehensive Community Hospice, 1 Delaware Drive, Lake Success, NY 11042.

Atlantic City last week joined a growing list of cities and states to ban or restrict smoking indoors, limiting smoking to no more than 25 percent of a casino's wagering area. The benefits of restrictions seem obvious. A report by the United States surgeon general last year said smoke inhaled by adult nonsmokers increases their risk of heart disease by 25 to 30 percent and lung cancer by 20 to 30 percent.

Senator Barack Obama of Illinois told several hundred black political organizers yesterday in Manhattan that African-Americans had been ''complicit in diminishing ourselves'' by talking about blacks in the same sort of degrading terms that the radio host Don Imus recently used about the Rutgers women's basketball team. ''I've heard those words around the kitchen tables,'' Mr. Obama said, speaking to members of the Rev. Al Sharpton's group, the National Action Network at its ninth convention. ''All of us have been complicit in diminishing ourselves, and engaging in the kind of self hatred that keeps our young men and young women down. That's something we have to talk about in this election.''

Charles Siebert's article (April 8) provided good insight into the experiences of people like us looking to adopt a shelter dog. When we started on the quest, we were taken aback by the psychological grilling associated with the adoption process. The shelter even insisted on conducting home visits to ''check us out.'' Had we not read the article, we would have continued in our assumption that the rescue folks were well intentioned but way over the top in their desire to get the adoption process to stick.

When Angelina Jolie wore Rag & Bone's mushroom-hued Mac Herring raincoat in a fashion spread for Vogue earlier this year, she loved it so much, she got one for herself. The coat's ensuing popularity was such that the company was moved to recut another batch in the more summery, lighter-colored fabric for warmer months. Now, shoppers can buy from a final shipment of the lighter Mac Herring. For the truly good planners, Rag & Bone has responded to high customer demand by reissuing the Mac in navy, olive and plaid for fall ($510 in natural, $550 in navy, olive or plaid for pre-order), all at Barneys New York in Manhattan, (212) 826-8900.

To the Editor: Thank you for your editorial ''A Tax to Clear the Air'' (April 15), in support of the laudable initiative by Thomas Suozzi, the Nassau executive, to effectively combat a major killer in our midst: tobacco smoking.

There are about 40 million people between the ages of 10 and 19 in the United States, so adolescent medicine might be expected to be booming, Jan Hoffman writes in an article in Science Times. But a decade after adolescent medicine became board certified as a subspecialty, the availability of doctors and nurse practioners dedicated exclusively to treating adolescents is still the exception.
In recent years, teams holding the No. 1 pick in the National Football League draft have rarely passed on taking a quarterback.
As heard on TV one morning while shaving:

I hope the jurors now deliberating the fate of Dr. William Hurwitz take a look at one of the exhibits in the case, a rumination he posted in a chat room in December of 2001. He was wrestling with the same question now facing the jury: What should a doctor who treats pain do when he discovers he's got a problem patient?
Which country is going to be on top in 2100? Nicholas D. Kristof visits India in search of an answer.

It's not a Gore '08 strategy session (at least not officially), but about 20 former fund-raisers and supporters of former Vice President Al Gore will gather in Washington next month to talk about politics, memories and Mr. Gore's future at a dinner being organized by Peter Knight, his close friend and political ally.

Here's your chance to place bets based on Tuesday's column and video. Which country do do you think will be the dominant nation in 2100? For now, I'm voting for China. I know a lot of other people like India's chances. Maybe you have an affinity for Russia or Brazil. Or perhaps it's best to go with the safe bet of the United States or Europe.
A leading voice of hip-hop called on music executives and radio stations today to eliminate three words that are as common in lyrics as they are controversial. The news release has the details.

I guess this should become a season-opening ritual. Last year I mentioned the great season start for Sebastien Bourdais, in what would become his record-equaling three-straight championship titles. This year, Sebastien got off to a rough start in the first race, but he went on to win the next two, last night taking the Houston title for the second time. He again leads the series.
Alison Smale, managing editor of The International Herald Tribune, discusses the first round of the French presidential elections.
Most Americans are in favor of stricter gun control, but few say it would have done a lot to prevent the shootings last week at Virginia Tech, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

Appearing in the Capitol just a few hours after campaign finance negotiations with the Senate Republicans collapsed, Gov. Eliot Spitzer seemed to be taking the news with his usual restraint and forebearance.

There's a disease that takes over college and even high school seniors every year. It's not proven to be deadly. In some instances it's not even harmful - but, see, the trouble is that it can be. What is it, you ask? Senioritis.

In a perfect world, GM Brian Cashman said, the Yankees would have let Phil Hughes pitch the entire season at Class AAA Scranton. But things have been far from perfect for the Yankees' pitching staff this season.
CHICAGO - Earlier today, Senator Barack Obama delivered a foreign policy address to the Chicago Council of Global Affairs. The title of the speech? The American Moment.

A coalition of more than 70 organizations and individuals, calling themselves the Campaign for New York's Future, has issued a statement of support for Mayor Bloomberg's PlaNYC proposal to make New York City environmentally sustainable.
A group of City Council members introduced a resolution today to formally apologize for the city's "role in sustaining and benefiting from the slave trade."
Does Richard Scrushy really think he could run a public company again?
Movie trailers, which are not made by filmmakers but by shops like this one, are typically black holes for all kinds of cheap tricks, gratuitous slow-mo and editing-room Barnumism.

Senator John McCain has long been one of the few presidential aspirants willing to speak out against subsidies for ethanol - a stance which politically potent corn growers in Iowa think is akin to a candidate campaigning against moms and apple pies. It is one of the main reasons that Senator McCain essentially wrote off the Iowa caucuses in 2000.
Readers respond to Frank Rich's Apr. 1 column, "Elizabeth Edwards for President."
Readers respond to Frank Rich's Apr. 8 column, "Sunday in the Market With McCain."
Readers respond to Frank Rich's Apr. 15 column, "Everybody Hates Don Imus."
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's Apr. 23 column, "Words as Weapons."
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his Apr. 23 column, "A Hostage Situation."

HealthSouth's founder, Richard Scrushy, will settle a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit for $81 million, closing the book on an investigation of the former executive's role in a $2.7 billion accounting fraud. The settlement marks another step toward the end of the accounting fraud at HealthSouth, one of many that cropped up in the wake of Enron in the early 2000's. The scandal nearly forced the healthcare giant into bankruptcy.

The "Great Wall of Adhamiya" project has evidently been shut down after a furious public response endorsed by the Iraqi prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who said on Sunday that he wanted the work stopped. But the status of other walls reportedly planned for Baghdad remain an open question.

John Edwards, one of the Democratic contenders for the presidency in 2008, has long expressed support for legislation to plug tax loopholes for United States companies with offshore headquarters. But The Washington Post suggests that his time as a consultant for Fortress Investment Group, which houses many of its funds in the Cayman Islands, could make it tougher for him to maintain his image as a champion of the poor -- especially now that Mr. Edwards (who is already trying to live down a pair of $400 Beverly Hills haircuts) has scooped up a pile of campaign cash from Fortress employees.

Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat whose district is in Lower Manhattan, sounded somewhat cool to the idea of an extra fee for commuters today. He was asked about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal after a speech today and had this to say:Q. Mr. Speaker, how do you feel about congestion pricing?

Aid groups in Darfur are in an awful position. If they stay, they risk losing more of their own staff to attacks. If they leave, then thousands of local people will die, and the lack of witnesses will probably lead to a surge in the death toll. The latest on that front in a dispatch from Reuters:
For the titans of private equity, there is a new number to beat.

It was a year ago that some enterprising students from Columbia Business School created a small-scale sensation online with their spoof of the classic Police song "Every Breath You Take." In the video, part of the business school's annual Spring Follies, a student actor portrayed R. Glenn Hubbard, the school's dean, as creepily obsessed with the new chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben Bernanke.

Apple's former general counsel, Nancy Heinen, may be sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission this week for backdating two stock option grants, including one made to the company's chief executive, Steve Jobs, her lawyers told Bloomberg News.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

A host of organizations and individuals have released statements concerning Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's major announcement on Sunday of a 127-point plan to make New York City environmentally sustainable. Here is a sampling of the reaction.

In a deal that seems to have won only praise from analysts, Business Objects, a French-American software company, said it would acquire Cartesis for about $300 million in cash, bolstering its presence in financial enterprise software. Business Objects, which makes so-called business intelligence software, has felt pressure to cut a deal since Oracle bought a rival, Hyperion Solutions, for $3.3 billion last month.

The Texas Pacific Group is already working on one big deal in Spain, and there is likely to be mas where that came from. The United States-based private equity firm, which offered $4.5 billion for the Spanish airline Iberia late last month, said Monday it had named a senior adviser in Spain whose prime objective is "identifying possible investment opportunities." The firm, also known as TPG, said Alfonso Cortina would be based in Madrid and serve as its main represenative in the Spanish market. Mr. Cortina, who was chairman of the Spanish-Argentinean oil company Repsol YPF until 2004, is also a European adviser to Rothschild, the investment bank.
Boris N. Yeltsin, the first freely elected leader of Russia, left a contradictory legacy.

With the budget battles now a few weeks in the past, Gov. Eliot Spitzer's favorability and job approval ratings have bounced back up in the latest Siena poll. Two-thirds of New Yorkers view Mr. Spitzer favorably, and 55 percent say he is doing an excellent or good job as governor. The bad news? 62 percent of the respondents said this year's budget shows that nothing has really changed in Albany.
Voters in the tiny Buddhist nation chose among “dummy” parties in a rehearsal for multiparty elections next year.
Boris N. Yeltsin, the first elected leader of the Russian Federation whose death was announced today, always gave historians fits.
Night shining clouds, which reside in the upper reaches of earth's atmosphere, are appearing more often over more parts of the world.

Dutch unions would rather see Barclays succeed in its bid to buy the Dutch bank ABN AMRO as fewer job cuts are expected compared to those expected under a rival's bid, Dutch union groups said on Monday.

Chalk up another deal for Carl C. Icahn. American Real Estate Properties, a unit of Mr. Icahn's American Real Estate Partners, said Monday it was selling its Nevada gaming operations to Whitehall Street Real Estate Funds, an affiliate of Goldman Sachs for $1.3 billion.

Haircut's never over: Maureen Dowd's mockery of John Edwards as an aspiring "metrosexual in chief" for his $400 haircuts (a $400 haircutter's house call, to be precise) has prompted a blogburst of reactions. The Washington Monthly's Kevin Drum breaks down the " four different schools of thought about this in the liberal blogosphere."
The current construction craze along Las Vegas strip is driven by a 95 percent weekend occupancy rate.
Candidates in the 2008 field this week have a fairly busy schedule, and some of them -- those who are sitting senators -- have a separate, full week of work, too.
Most of the players may be in Europe, but a bank in Chicago was stealing much of the focus Monday as ABN Amro agreed to a $91 billion merger with Barclays.

It will be referred to simply as "the Club" -- an exclusive enclave of luxury residences in one of the most painted, photographed, and recognizable buildings in the golf world. Indeed St. Andrews Grand will be a private, luxury residence and golf and sporting club when opened in 2009. The building is adjacent to the clubhouse of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews in Scotland and it overlooks the first tee and final hole of the fabled Old Course.

The group staging a management buyout of Affiliated Computer Services, the technology services provider, raised their bid on Monday to $62 from $59.25 a share, saying that the company's board had rejected an earlier proposal.

No more classes, no more books, no more subsidization of private student-loan lenders: "Why continue to subsidize these firms?" asks a Washington Post editorial. "Currently, universities can participate in the public-private program, in which private lenders pony up the principal and collect low-interest payments from students while receiving a government subsidy that, in effect, increases the interest these companies receive. Or universities can choose to have their students borrow money directly from the government. Either way, Congress sets the general interest rates students pay on most loans. And the Congressional Budget Office and the Office of Management and Budget have both concluded that the government's direct lending program is significantly cheaper for taxpayers." The editorial continues:

ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by Barclays of Britain in a $91 billion deal that would be the largest financial-services merger in history. To fend off a rival group of bidders seeking to break up the 183-year-old bank, ABN Amro and Barclays struck a separate agreement Sunday to sell the LaSalle Bank of Chicago, a unit of ABN, to the Bank of America for more than $21 billion.

Seeking to explain some prominent recent lapses in the government's food safety operation, The Washington Post finds no failures of imagination, no series of missed signals or any of the other usual explanations.
Mr. Halberstam came into his own as a journalist in the 1960s covering the Vietnam War.
Building a dream house is not for those who buy their morning coffee at Dunkin' Donuts because Starbucks takes too long.
It's not often that Congress devotes so much time and energy to legislation that is doomed.

Rampant deal speculation surrounding Foot Locker came true Friday, but not necessarily in the way that many had expected. The sneaker retailer, which has long been rumored to be a takeover target, made an unsolicited $1.2 billion bid for Genesco, a company that owns the teenager-focused Journeys sneaker chain and the Johnston & Murphy brand of dress shoes.

AstraZeneca, the British drugmaker, agreed Monday to buy MedImmune, an American biotechnology company, for $15.2 billion to gain flu vaccines and an antiviral treatment for babies. Shareholders in MedImmune, which makes the flu vaccine FluMist, will receive $58 a share, a 21 percent premium over the closing price on Friday of $48.01 a share.

With the surging market for initial public offerings expected to pick up even more momentum this year, stock exchanges in the United States are campaigning to win the new listings, The Associated Press reports. The Nasdaq Stock Market and the New York Stock Exchange said the first quarter turned out to be one of the best on record for public offerings since the dot-com boom that ended in 2000. There were 64 offerings that raised $12.1 billion during the period.

Tribune, which has agreed to be taken private in an $8.2 billion deal, is expected to announce staffing reductions as early as Monday at its flagship Chicago Tribune as well as its largest-circulation newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, as revenue in the newspaper industry declines.

A consumer group asked the Federal Trade Commission on Friday to investigate and block Google's proposed $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising company DoubleClick unless the companies improve consumer privacy protections.

A group of Chrysler workers that has proposed an employee-led buyout of the company is apparently looking to hook up with one of the possible bidders for DaimlerChrysler's United States unit. The Los Angeles Times reported that billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, who has thus far been shut out by DaimlerChrysler's board, is planning to meet with the group, which calls itself the Employee Buyout Committee.

Stephen Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, who predicts China will overtake the United States as the world's dominant economy within two decades, will become the firm's Asia chairman, leading a push to arrange more takeovers and stock sales in the region. Mr. Roach, 61, will take up his post in June and move to Hong Kong in September, Morgan Stanley said in an e-mailed statement. He replaces Alasdair Morrison, who retired this month.

British Airways is considering a bid for Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana of Spain along with a group of private equity investors to protect its interest in the carrier. British Airways said it had approached "a number of private equity companies." The airline has not made a final decision on the future of its 10 percent Iberia stake and may sell the holding, the company said.

Speculation last week that Intelsat's owners are seeking a sale to private equity firms has raised concerns among industry watchers about the future of the satellite services operator, The Deal.com says.

After more than two decades of spectacular economic growth, China has a rising number of entrepreneurs who are forming private companies, going public and getting extremely rich. But the family of Yang Guoqiang, a dirt-under-the-fingers property tycoon, may be the richest yet.

Southern California is starting to muscle out New England for second place behind Silicon Valley as a magnet for venture capital. A report scheduled to be released Monday by the research and consulting firms Ernst & Young and Dow Jones VentureOne underscores Southern California's attractiveness, especially to financiers of the healthcare and biotechnology industries in San Diego County and information technology firms in Los Angeles.
When it comes to throwing brickbats, DealBook doesn't discriminate.

Shares of a Chinese drugmaker, the Simcere Pharmaceutical Group rose as much as 11 percent in its stock market opening in the United States on Friday, a day after pricing at the top of the forecast range. The American depositary shares opened at $15 and climbed as high as $16.05 in morning trade on the New York Stock Exchange. Simcere's results break a recent string of disappointing initial public offering results from China triggered by a sell-off in February.

H&R Block said Friday it would sell its subprime lender, Option One Mortgage, to a private equity firm, Cerberus Capital Management, sending the tax preparer's shares up as much as 8.2 percent. The sale price depends on the value of the mortgage assets when the sale closes, but will likely be below $1 billion and perhaps as low as $700 million or $800 million, one analyst told Reuters.

UniCredit, Italy's biggest bank, said Friday it was talking with France's Societe Generale about "growth opportunities," but denied rumors the banks were discussing a merger. Market rumors about the banks intensified throughout the day, sending the shares of both surging, and set off a chain reaction that lifted other bank stocks.

Terra Firma, the British private equity group trying to trump the 10.6 billion pound ($21.2 billion) takeover bid accepted by the directors of the British drugstore chain Alliance Boots, is also bidding to buy Bupa's hospitals, The Guardian said.

Caldwell Investment Management, one of Canada's best known investors in stock and commodity exchanges around the world, is buying a small stake in the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, possibly as a prelude to going after more of the privately owned bourse.

the Fortress Investment Group, the private equity and hedge fund manager that went public in February, has agreed to buy Interpool for $2.4 billion. Through several of its private equity funds, Fortress is bidding $27.50 in stock and debt for Interpool, a transportation equipment and services company based in Princeton, N.J. Interpool said that the deal represents a 6 percent premium over its closing price on Friday of $25.59.

In an echo of Nick Carraway in F. Scott Fitzgerald's "The Great Gatsby," The New York Times asks: When it comes to hedge funds, do the extremely rich know more than the rest of us? The Times refers to a report from Bloomberg Markets that says that while institutions are increasing their holdings in hedge funds - and some of the largest hedge funds are planning to sell shares to an eagerly awaiting public - the wealthiest Americans have been bailing out.

McDonald's said Friday it had agreed to sell virtually all of its 1,600 restaurants in Latin America and the Caribbean to an Argentine businessman who has run McDonald's outlets in Argentina for 20 years.

Calpine, the bankrupt power generator, said it had reached a preliminary settlement with a group of bondholders that would eliminate a large group of duplicate claims filed in its bankruptcy case. The settlement, which requires United States bankruptcy court approval, will reduce $12 billion in claims tied to bonds in a Calpine unit to a single claim of $3.5 billion, the company said. Calpine, based in San Jose, Calif., also said it would seek approval from HSBC Bank, the indenture trustee on the bonds.

China Citic Bank sold $5.4 billion of stock in the world's biggest offering this year, according to Bloomberg News. The bank, one of the 10 largest in China, sold shares in Shanghai and Hong Kong on Friday, raising the maximum it targeted,the report said, adding that the sale values the state-owned company at $28.9 billion.
Time was that former media executives were offered consulting contracts, partnerships at private equity firms or book deals. Now, they are being offered a blank check.

When investors gather in Omaha, Neb., in two weeks for the Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, the chairman, Warren E. Buffett, will face what has become the annual question: who might someday succeed him in each of the two roles he plays - chief executive and chief investment officer?

The private-equity consortium that is struggling to complete a takeover of Qantas Airways in Australia said Sunday that its bid would not be extended beyond May 4. The consortium, whose bid of 10.82 billion Australian dollars ($9.06 billion) has been opposed by two major investors, also announced a range of incentives aimed at achieving the revised 70 percent minimum share target it unveiled on April 12 when it extended the bid two weeks.

One UBS media banker has gotten a crash course on what it's like being on the other side of the business. Aryeh Bourkoff, who on May 1 officially moves from the analyst side to his new position as vice chairman of technology, media and telecommunications investment banking at the bank, has scored a producer credit on a film directed by his mother that will show at the TriBeca Film Festival this week.
One of the auto industry's most powerful leaders found inspiration in a competitor's backyard during a visit to Detroit this week.
The prize-winning London adaptation of the 1935 Alfred Hitchcock thriller “The 39 Steps” is bound for Broadway.
Richard Scrushy admitted no wrongdoing but agreed to give up money the government said he made from an accounting scheme.
One crashed wedding can be entertaining, but a steady stream could wear thin.
Classes resumed after a moment of silence and the tolling of bells in memory of the victims of the massacre.

As part of his plan to create what he called "the first environmentally sustainable 21st-century city," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed charging drivers who travel below 86th Street in Manhattan. A similar system is in place in congested parts of London and Singapore.
Alex Rodriguez’s historic start to the season can be attributed to changes in his swing thanks to the Yankees’ new hitting coach, Kevin Long.
The Department of Veterans Affairs has agreed to add the Wiccan pentacle to a list of approved religious symbols that it will engrave on veterans’ headstones.
The campaign entered a new phase today, as the winners of the first round began a battle for the 6.8 million voters who chose the path down the middle.
Hani al-Qawasmi was persuaded to stay on by the prime minister, Palestinian government officials said.
The deal would increase pay by 23 percent over nearly seven years, with bonuses of up to $25,000 a year to top-rated principals.
The senator said that  America must repair its standing in the world and resist the temptation to turn inward.
The war spending bill would order the administration to begin pulling troops out of Iraq by Oct. 1.
The defense secretary today urged Russia to drop its opposition, but the Russians refused to budge.
President Bush said that the attorney general’s testimony last week had increased his confidence in him.
Partial results from Saturday’s election, which was marred by widespread fraud, showed a landslide victory for the governing party’s candidate.
Classes resumed today after a moment of silence and the tolling of bells in memory of the victims of the massacre.
Large crowds marched through Baghdad to protest the plan to build a wall around a mostly Sunni neighborhood.
Boris N. Yeltsin, who presided over the dissolution of the Soviet Union to become the first freely elected leader of Russia, has died at 76, the Kremlin said today.
Stephen S. Roach, the bank’s chief economist, will become the chairman of Asia operations.
Chase Wright of the Yankees became only the second pitcher to surrender four consecutive homers. The first was Paul Foytack.
Mike Lowell hit his second home run of the night with no outs in the seventh inning, as the Red Sox beat the Yankees 7-6.
Stephen S. Roach, the bank’s chief economist, will become the chairman of Asia operations.
The Santa Barbara News-Press published a story suggesting that the paper’s former editor had kept child pornography on his work computer.
The Nets’ body of work with Richard Jefferson in the lineup paints a telling picture of how much they value their third star.
For most of the last decade, older suburban neighborhoods have undergone a building boom that has divided communities.
SOCCER.
An unlucky 13 miles has claimed 25 lives in the past decade, the last three in March, yet state troopers cannot seem to find anything wrong with the roadway.

Two people were killed when a small plane crashed yesterday afternoon onto Route 6 in eastern Connecticut, a Federal Aviation Administration official said. The identities of the victims were not released yesterday evening. The plane crashed near Windham Airport just before 4 p.m. and caught fire, said Holly Baker, an F.A.A. spokeswoman. The airport is three miles north of Windham. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A man who died on Saturday afternoon after falling from a boat into Jamaica Bay was identified by the police yesterday as Charles Rosenberg, 37, of Hewlett. Mr. Rosenberg fell from a boat about 400 yards from the Canarsie Pier, the police said. Mr. Rosenberg and another man, who was not named by the police, fell into the water about 4 p.m., the police said. The other man was rescued by another boat and was taken to Peninsula Hospital Center, where he was in stable condition on Saturday. Police rescuers pulled Mr. Rosenberg from the water, and he was later pronounced dead at Staten Island University Hospital, the police said.

Two police supervisors are being investigated after officers accused them of referring to them as “hos” or a “nappy-headed ho,” the police said. One instance took place in the 70th Precinct in Brooklyn on April 15. The supervisor in that case has been transferred and stripped of supervisory duties, said Chief Michael Collins, a police spokesman. Chief Collins said the supervisor was accused of having addressed a group of officers jokingly as “hos.” The supervisor was identified by Bonita Zelman, a lawyer for the accusers, as Sgt. Carlos Mateo. In the second case, a Queens narcotics detective, Aretha Williams, said yesterday at a news conference that a sergeant recently told her, “Don’t give me no lip, or I’ll have to call you a nappy-headed ho.” The police, who did not release the sergeant’s name, said that case would be reviewed this week. The radio host Don Imus was fired recently by CBS Radio for his on-air description of members of the Rutgers University women’s basketball team as “nappy-headed hos.” Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said in a statement yesterday, “This language is unacceptable under any circumstances and even more egregious when it comes from individuals in a position of authority.” A representative of the Sergeants Benevolent Association contacted last night said he knew nothing about the accusations and declined to comment.

Two men were killed in shootings in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday morning, the police said. In Queens, a 22-year-old man was shot once in the chest at Martense Avenue and 104th Street shortly before 1:30 a.m., the police said. There were no arrests yesterday, and the victim’s name was not released. In Brooklyn, a fight that began in Nostrand Donut Shop spilled outside, and a 20-year-old man, whose name was not released, was fatally shot in the chest, the police and witnesses said. The shooting occurred at Church Street and Nostrand Avenue shortly before 6 a.m. “I heard an argument, fighting in the doughnut shop, and then it went outside,” said Khaled Saleh, 38. “I heard the shot, like a small gun, one shot. One shot, that’s his life.”.

Almost three years after a pine-tree killing wasp was found in upstate New York, scientists have caught others in traps from western New York to the Adirondacks. The Sirex woodwasp kills pines and sometimes other conifers by introducing a toxic mucus and fungus when the female lays her eggs through the bark and into the sapwood. Monitoring shows the wasp has moved into 25 counties in New York since it was discovered in Oswego County in September 2004.

Two members of Congress representing New York said yesterday that they would introduce federal legislation to tighten background checks for gun buyers in the wake of last week’s fatal shootings at Virginia Tech. Senator Charles E. Schumer and Representative Carolyn McCarthy, both Democrats, said the legislation would provide financing and incentives for states and local governments to close loopholes in laws concerning delivery of mental health data for federal gun background checks.

A barge that once served as a floating hospital in New York City is for sale. The five-deck, 180-foot-long barge was launched in 1973 to serve the city’s poor and homeless, but it lost its Manhattan berth after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. The barge, part of a line of floating hospitals dating to the 19th century, was kicked out of its berth to make way for emergency Manhattan ferries after the terrorist attack. It was sold in 2004 to an entrepreneur who hauled it 50 miles up the Hudson River to Newburgh, where he is offering it for sale.
As Korean-Americans gathered at churches near the campus of Virginia Tech, they embraced a time for reflection and spiritual solace.
The presidential election is now a classic battle between two candidates with competing visions for France.
Aides to the major candidates have concluded that the large number of debates has become a hindrance.
Authorities in Kazakhstan have accused an American telecommunications executive of embezzling funds from his own Kazakh company, a charge he denies.
Gary Sheffield, a nine-time All-Star, has hit only .119 in 17 games this season, his first in Detroit, and is hitless in his past 12 at-bats.
The merger is reportedly worth more than $90 billion, one of the largest European bank deals ever.
Early next month, the PGA Tour will unveil its high-tech scoreboards, which are designed to be placed strategically on courses where Tour tournaments are played.
Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s plan for what he calls “a greener, greater New York” is a broad, complicated and exciting blueprint.
Analysts said the Nigerian vote showed that many African voters are steadily losing confidence in their democracies.
The State of New York took a step toward basic human decency when it agreed to settle a lawsuit brought on behalf of mentally ill prisoners.
Hydroelectric dams in Oregon have raised the question of whether righting one environmental wrong can lead to another.
The Yankees have the highest payroll in the major leagues, but they have been unable to disguise the pitching problems that injuries have helped create.
A white-haired prince of the Roman Catholic Church remains something of a riddle.
“Inherit the Wind,” the half-century-old melodrama about populist attacks on evolution, might itself be consigned fossil status but for the current events of 2007.
The inquiry involves suspicions that Israel’s finance minister embezzled funds before he joined the government, the police said.
Recriminations and finger-pointing continued the day after an argument over global warming between Sheryl Crow and Karl Rove.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine showed signs of improvement on Sunday, eating for the first time since his accident and watching part of a New Jersey Devils game.
With four championships in a career that few can rival, Jeff Gordon as only history left to chase as he secures his standing among the series’ greats.
The plan is intended to foster population growth and to reduce greenhouse gases.
Martin Brodeur stopped 32 shots and Brian Gionta scored two goals to lead the Atlantic Division champions to a victory over Tampa Bay.

Almost half of French voters over age 70 cast their ballots for the conservative candidate for president, Nicolas Sarkozy. Almost 30 percent of those ages 18 to 24 favored Ségolène Royal of the Socialist Party.
Some experts say America might have been able to discourage China from launching the antisatellite missile.
Robert Smith, the former head of the Republican Party in Onondaga County, says a Senate Republican official threatened a candidate's job security.
Roger Federer seems no closer to figuring out how to beat Rafael Nadal on clay. Yet he still hopes to win the French Open.
Senator John McCain of Arizona is renewing his call for a cap on emissions of greenhouse gases.
Lacking big-name stars and oversized personalities, the Chicago Bulls relied on a gutsy group effort for a 96-91 victory over the Miami Heat.
Hopeful fans of the superstar defensive end Michael Strahan arrived at his ex-wife's garage sale in search of memorabilia, but they left disappointed.
A fire in a downtown orphanage in Sarajevo, Bosnia’s capital, killed five babies and injured 19 others on Sunday.
Virginia Tech was quiet, sunny, sad and playful over the weekend, as the campus tried to move forward.
The American entry BMW Oracle Racing posted its third consecutive victory as the Louis Vuitton Cup racing series resumed Sunday.
Dr. Hoffleit was an astronomer who studied the features of stars visible to the naked eye.
President Bush is taking every opportunity to rail against the troop withdrawal deadlines in the war-spending bills that Congress is readying for passage.
The move would propel New York to the forefront of one of the most contentious issues in politics.
The National Hockey League came down hard yesterday on the Calgary Flames for actions late in Game 5 of the team’s first-round series against the Detroit Red Wings.

Barry Bonds hit his 740th home run yesterday, connecting for the second consecutive game and helping Matt Cain earn his first victory of the season in the San Francisco Giants’ 2-1 victory against the visiting Arizona Diamondbacks.
The lethargic pace of campaigning in the streets reflects recent uncertainty over who would ultimately be on the ballot.
In a famous collaboration of more than three decades, Mr. Natzler and his wife Gertrud Natzler produced wafer-thin pots with bold, violent glazes.

Nick Markakis and Miguel Tejada each had three runs batted in yesterday and the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 7-3, to complete their first three-game home sweep of the Blue Jays in 13 years.
Senator Arlen Specter’s comments reflect a lack of support for Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales among key Republicans.
Mr. O’Brien won three Olympic medals (two gold) and became the first man to reach 59, 60, 61, 62 and 63 feet.
Don Nelson’s wacky ways still win playoff games in Dallas — even though he is now coaching the Golden State Warriors.
The wall, which would have isolated a Sunni neighborhood, came under criticism from both Sunni Arab and Shiite parties.
Mr. McDougald, a retired journalism professor at the University of Georgia, directed the Peabody Awards for almost 30 years.
Government forces and insurgents blasted each other for a fifth straight day on Sunday, killing scores of civilians and plunging the country deeper into chaos.
Many Canadians say that it may be time for other NATO countries to assume greater responsibilities in the conflict.
A man was arrested at the scene of one of the crashes and charged with driving while intoxicated and vehicular manslaughter, the police said.
Ms. Millender-McDonald was in her sixth full term representing the heavily Democratic 37th District in Southern California.
Two bombings, one of them a suicide attack, rocked the eastern town of Khost on Sunday, killing nine people and wounding more than 40, officials said.
The military-backed interim government barred Sheik Hasina Wazed from returning and asked airlines not to allow her on any flight to the country.
For South Africa, hosting the World Cup of soccer in 2010 is a chance to erase a whole host of stereotypes about Africa and its people.
A passer-by clarifies for a bus rider the meaning of a sign that says "No standing."
At The Philadelphia Inquirer, a joint venture with an advertiser that in other times might have raised questions is being rethought.

A prominent Columbia University cardiologist has been censured for breaking an embargo on the results of a major heart study.
Rich Little was hired for this year’s White House Correspondents’ dinner to help the audience forget last year when Stephen Colbert opened both barrels on all parties.
Clear Channel is trying something radically different at a commercial radio station in Texas: getting rid of the commercials.
“Disturbia” rules the weekend movie box office, the Princess of Wales inspires a ballet and more culture news.
A panel discussion on anti-Semitism in Handel’s “Messiah” was relatively restrained.
Warren E. Buffett’s successor will probably be a lot like Louis Simpson, who has overseen the investment portfolio of Geico.

Peter Boal, the company’s artistic director since 2005, made more local connections than one would have imagined possible in the “Celebrate Seattle!” festival.
Ryan Hall, an American upstart making his marathon debut, held his own but yielded down the stretech to a more predictable winner, Martin Lel of Kenya.
The much-anticipated showdown between Tom Glavine and John Smoltz fizzled as neither pitcher lasted more than six innings.
Several start-up companies are pursuing the idea of advertising-supported music on peer-to-peer file-sharing networks.
Reports in both newspapers said job cuts were imminent and would be carried out mostly through voluntary buyout packages.
Online publishers are increasing their offerings of “green” content, hoping to attract more readers and advertising revenue.

This year’s world bridge championships are in Shanghai beginning Sept. 29.

Ms. McKennitt’s game is conjuring pleasant pop from popular thoughts about ancient cultures.

QUARTERLY REPORTS A decline in oil and gas prices is expected to translate into lower profits for the big oil companies. Bill Callahan ''Woke on a Whaleheart'' (Drag City) A few years ago the Italian-Icelandic singer Emiliana Torrini recorded an exquisite song called ''Honeymoon Child.'' Accompanied by nothing besides a flickering guitar she murmured, ''You are a true honeymoon child, conceived on an island in the sun/Heels dug in the white sand, loved and adored by everyone.''

To the Editor: ''Equality Elusive Under New Jersey Civil Union Law'' (news article, April 13) shows the confusion and lack of recognition and benefits that couples in civil unions face versus their straight-couple counterparts.

Two men were killed in shootings in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday morning, the police said. In Queens, a 22-year-old man was shot once in the chest at Martense Avenue and 104th Street shortly before 1:30 a.m., the police said. There were no arrests yesterday, and the victim's name was not released. In Brooklyn, a fight that began in Nostrand Donut Shop spilled outside, and a 20-year-old man, whose name was not released, was fatally shot in the chest, the police and witnesses said. The shooting occurred at Church Street and Nostrand Avenue shortly before 6 a.m. ''I heard an argument, fighting in the doughnut shop, and then it went outside,'' said Khaled Saleh, 38. ''I heard the shot, like a small gun, one shot. One shot, that's his life.'' MICHAEL WILSON

The governor unveiled his priorities for the rest of the legislative session this week, but lawmakers offered up their own wish list items. Among the more notable was one by Senator Dean G. Skelos, left, a Long Island Republican and the deputy majority leader, who said he would introduce legislation to bring back tax incentives for hybrid electric vehicles. On another front, Assemblymen Keith L. T. Wright of Harlem and Hakeem Jeffries of Brooklyn said they would be introducing legislation ''aimed at acknowledging and making an official apology for the role of New York State in the transatlantic and domestic slave trade.''

John R. Drexel III, scion of a powerful Philadelphia banking family and a prominent socialite in an era when the charity galas and debutante balls of the affluent dominated society-page headlines, died April 13 at his estate in Newport, R.I. He was 87. The cause was heart failure, his daughter Noreen Drexel O'Farrell said.

Daisuke Matsuzaka was all theirs. Red Sox devotees entered Fenway Park last night with martial arts headbands and Dice-K T-shirts and red K's on poster board as if to advertise they had something the Yankees did not: a secret weapon, a mystical man and the catch of the off-season. His debut against the Yankees wasn't fable material. ''Part of it is facing that lineup,'' Red Sox Manager Terry Francona said.

HEARN--Thomas Michael Jr., of Hobe Sound, FL, and Upper Largo, Fife, Scotland, died on April 21, 2007, at the age of 82. He is survived by his wife, Helen; children, Thomas, Peter, David, Gail, and Edward; and six grandchildren. Following Naval service in the Pacific in World War II he returned to Yale and graduated in the Class of 1948. He was President of G.L. Hodson & Son, Inc., Reinsurance Intermediaries, from 1977 until his retirement in 1986 and served as a director of R.K. Carvill (Int'l Holdings) Ltd., Hamilton, Bermuda from 1990-2000. There will be a Memorial Mass at 10:30 AM, Tuesday, April 24, 2007 at St. Christopher Catholic Church, Hobe Sound, FL. Contributions may be made to: Jupiter Medical Center Foundation, 1210 South Old Dixie 01Highway, Jupiter, FL 33458.

Governor Eliot Spitzer, below, used his veto pen for the first time last week on a bill that would have made police disciplinary procedures across the state the subject of collective bargaining with the police unions. Police discipline is already subject to negotiation in most of the state -- but not for the New York Police Department, the state police, or for departments in Westchester and Rockland Counties.

FEINBERG--Sidney. The law firm of Lazarus & Harris mourns the passing of our dear friend, mentor and partner, Sidney Feinberg. Sidney was an extraordinary entertainment lawyer, adored by his clients. He was truly one of a kind -razor sharp, a witty raconteur, elegant and a complete class act. Most of all, Sidney was extremely generous, kind and loyal to his friends and colleagues. Sidney is irreplaceable and will be terribly missed.

Paul Foytack was watching the N.B.A. playoffs Sunday night, but he switched to the Yankees-Red Sox game during a commercial. He saw Manny Ramírez hit a home run before shifting back to the basketball game. That is how Foytack missed history. History that he was a part of. By the time Foytack went back to watching baseball, Chase Wright of the Yankees had allowed three more home runs to become only the second pitcher to surrender four consecutive homers. The first was Foytack.

Robert Smith, the former head of the Republican Party in Onondaga County, says a top Senate Republican official repeatedly threatened the job security of a candidate seeking an upstate Senate seat. Mr. Smith's comments raised questions about what role, if any, Senate Republicans played in the subsequent firing of the candidate, Thomas V. Dadey Jr., from his job at a large state contractor.

HART--Kitty Carlisle. The Members and Staff of the New York State Council on the Arts express their deep sadness at the passing of their beloved former Chairman, Kitty Carlisle Hart. Affectionately known to us as Kitty, she was a vital mainstay of our agency for more than three decades, dispensing wisdom and charm wherever she went. She was a vibrant and tireless advocate for the arts and she will be missed by the entire arts community. Kitty will always be remembered by us as a colleague and a good friend. Calle 13 ''Residente o Visitante'' (Norte) The debut album by Calle 13, released in 2005, established this Puerto Rican duo of Residente (René Pérez), a rapper, and Visitante (Eduardo Cabra), a composer and producer, as one of the smartest raunchiest, funniest and most ambitious acts in reggaetón. It also won Calle 13 (which means ''13th Street'') the Latin Grammy as best new artist. Calle 13's second album, ''Residente o Visitante'' (''Resident or Visitor'') goes further.
