He is the son of the late Mary McVey Jollon and the late Alfred Jollon, a lawyer and longtime trustee of St. John's University. He is survived by his children: Alfredo (Soraya), Jeffrey, Laurence and Katherine and by his wife, Katherine Ryan Jollon. A memorial service is planned for Tuesday, April 24, at 2:00pm at St. Stephen of Hungary Church, 414 East 82nd St., NY. The family requests donations, in lieu of flowers, be made in his memory to ''The Trustees of Phillips Academy'' for the ''Katherine Ryan Jollon Scholarship Fund'', 180 Main St., Andover, MA 01810.

To the Editor: ''City Reopens Old Rail Line for Staten Island Trash and Freight'' (news article, April 18) should be heard as a clarion call to reopen the Amtrak line along Manhattan's West Side for the export of trash from that borough.

The tale of John Edwards' $400 haircuts may have ended or at least his campaign hopes it ended when Mr. Edwards told Iowans on Friday that he was embarrassed by the episode. It arguably began four years ago this weekend with a story in The New York Times about the White House's strategy for dealing with prospective Democratic challengers to President Bush. In the last paragraph of that story, which I wrote with a colleague, Richard W. Stevenson, an unnamed ''Bush associate'' was quoted as referring to Mr. Edwards as ''the Breck Girl of politics.'' Another Bush adviser, again unnamed, was quoted as saying of Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, ''he looks French.''

Most first-season top sellers are fairly recent shows. The first season of ''The Odd Couple'' is being released tomorrow. The ultimate buddy comedy starred Tony Randall (above, left, in a scene from 1972) and Jack Klugman as mismatched roommates. ''The Odd Couple'' had a five-year run starting in 1970, and many more in syndication. It has attained classic sitcom status, in spite of its one-joke premise, alongside more socially nuanced hits like ''All in the Family'' (on the air from 1971-79) and ''M*A*S*H'' (1972-83). SHELLY FREIERMAN
LANDI--Ruth, April 23, 1905. Happy Birthday in Heaven, Dearest Mama. We will love and miss you forever. Always, Googie and Iona
To the Editor: Re ''Revolving Door for Addicts Adds to Medicaid Cost'' (front page, April 17):

Arctic Monkeys ''Favourite Worst Nightmare'' (Domino) The cynicism is as barbed as the guitar riffs on Arctic Monkeys' second album, ''Favourite Worst Nightmare,'' and the guitar riffs bristle. Their 2006 debut album, ''Whatever People Say I Am, That's What I'm Not,'' rode an Internet buzz fueled by the band's giving away its songs before release, but the momentum came from the songs themselves. Arctic Monkeys arrived amid a wave of English bands that were rediscovering the terse melodies and hurtling, hard-nosed narratives of new-wave rock. They weren't the first, but they were among the most musically gifted, with two guitarists (Alex Turner and Jamie Cook) who spar and mesh with constant tension and a rhythm section (Andy Nicholson on bass and Matt Helders on drums) that swings as it drives the music.

A fire in a downtown orphanage in Sarajevo, Bosnia's capital, killed five babies and injured 19 others on Sunday, the chief prosecutor's office said. The fire broke out in a third floor room of the Ljubica Izevic children's home shortly before 6 a.m., said Dubravko Champara of the prosecutor's office. While fire crews were able to put out the blaze rapidly, he said, three boys and two girls died from the effects of smoke inhalation.

ULTAN--Dr. Leslie Barry was born on November 12, 1934 in New York City as the second child and son to late parents Carl and Blanche. Dr. Ultan grew up in Bayside, New York with his parents and older brother, Lloyd, where he attended Bayside High School. After graduating with the Class of 1951, he attended Yale University, where he earned his Bachelor's degree in Economics and Political Science. While at Yale and on a visit home, Dr. Ultan met Susan Drezner at a sweet sixteen party for a mutual friend, and she became his beloved life partner. Following his college graduation in 1955, Dr. Ultan attended N.Y.U. School of Medicine, and he and Susan were married. After earning his medical degree in 1959, he did his internship at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester, New York and then a residency in internal medicine at Hartford Hospital in Connecticut. Between these trainings he served his country and the U.S. Public Health Service as Heart Disease Control Officer in San Juan, Puerto Rico. He continued to pursue his life's vocation as a heart doctor with a fellowship in cardiology at Hahnemann Medical College in Philadelphia. Dr. Ultan established his private practice in Trenton and at Helene Fuld Medical Center, where he became Chief of Cardiology, Chairman of the Coronary Care Unit and Coronary Care Committee, Director of the Non-Invasive Cardiovascular Laboratory and Trustee. A Fellow of the American College of Cardiology and Diplomate to the American Board of Internal Medicine and American Board of Cardiovascular Diseases, Dr. Ultan taught at Hahnemann and Rutgers Medical School, published medical journal articles and especially enjoyed mentoring and training paramedics and nurses in pre-hospital care of cardiac patients. Throughout his career, he was an active member of the Mercer County Heart Association, serving as President and Trustee. Frustrated with the number of heart attack patients who were dying while being transported by ambulance to the hospital, Dr. Ultan worked with others to establish in Mercer County one of the nation's first community-sponsored all-volunteer mobile intensive care unit programs. The result of their efforts was the Mercer County Lifemobile Program, which he served as founding Project Director. It has since evolved into the Capital Health System Mobile Intensive Care Unit (M.I.C.U.) and continues to bring the highest level of cardiac care equipment and paramedics and nurses trained to use it directly to patients wherever they need it. This program has saved numerous lives since its inception in 1977. Dr. Ultan was awarded a Mercer County Special Recognition Plaque in 1977 for his work helping found the Lifemobile M.I.C.U. Program and made Chairman of the New Jersey Department of Health's Advisory Committee for Mobile Intensive Care Units. He was also the recipient of Helene Fuld Medical Center's first ever Doctor of the Year Award in 1979 and their Superior Clinical Teaching Award in 1981. In 1984, he was presented with the American Heart Association's Golden Heart Award for his career work in cardiac care. Beloved by his patients and colleagues for his dedication, intelligence, wit, charm and wonderful sense of humor, Dr. Ultan had the ability to make any patient feel better just by his presence. He loved to discuss politics, sports, international relations and current events and was a lifelong New York Yankees fan (converting Susan, who wore Brooklyn Dodger blue when he met her.) He will be sorely missed by his family who survive him: wife of 511/2 years Susan, daughter Robyn, sons Robert and William, daughters-in-law Jill and Lisa and grandchildren Matthew, Emily and Sophia. Condolences can be shared with family members, who will be sitting Shiva in his memory at the family home on the evenings of Monday, April 23, 2007, and Wednesday, April 25, 2007. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be given, in the name of Dr. Leslie Barry Ultan, to Capital Health System Foundation's M.I.C.U. Fund, 408 Bellevue Ave., Trenton, NJ 08618, so that such gifts will continue Dr. Ultan's lifelong pursuit of saving and improving lives. Patients, colleagues, community members and all who want to pay their respects are invited to attend a memorial service to celebrate his life, to be held at 11:00 am Thursday, April 26, 2007 at Adath Israel Congregation, 1958 Lawrenceville Road, Lawrenceville, NJ.

At 76 years old, George Steinbrenner does not roar the way he used to. But as the Yankees stagger into Steinbrenner's territory for a series with the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, the principal owner cannot be pleased. The Boston Red Sox completed a three-game sweep of the Yankees, using five home runs to take the series finale on Sunday, 7-6, at Fenway Park. The rookie Chase Wright became the second pitcher in baseball history to allow four consecutive homers, but the Yankees actually led after he was finally removed. The fifth home run did them in.

Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, the ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said Sunday that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales's failure to step down was ''no doubt, bad for the Justice Department.'' Mr. Specter's comments, made on the television program ''Fox News Sunday,'' reflected a growing lack of support for Mr. Gonzales among key Republicans on Capitol Hill as he faces accusations that the dismissals of eight United States attorneys were politically motivated.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Sarkozy Leads French Poll; Socialist in Second Place Nicolas Sarkozy, the conservative, and Ségolène Royal, the Socialist, took the top spots in the first round of the presidential election. With more than 95 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Sarkozy was leading with about 30.7 percent of the vote, while Ms. Royal had about 25.2 percent. A1 Almost half of French voters over age 70 voted for the conservative candidate, Mr. Sarkozy. Almost 30 percent of those 18 to 24 favored the Socialist Party. Women supported Mr. Sarkozy and Ms. Royal equally; men were twice as likely to vote for the far-right candidate, Jean-Marie Le Pen, according to a telephone poll of registered voters. A10 U.S. Knew of China Missile Test After a Chinese interceptor smashed into a target satellite in January, Bush administration officials criticized the test. What they did not say is that as the Chinese were preparing to launch their antisatellite weapon, American intelligence agencies had issued reports about the preparations being made at the test facility in southern China. A1 Iraq Puts Stop to Work on Wall Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said he was ordering a halt to construction of a controversial wall that would block a Sunni neighborhood in Baghdad from other areas. The announcement appeared designed to allay mounting criticism from both Sunni Arab and Shiite parties. A6 Israeli Minister Investigated Israel's finance minister, Abraham Hirchson, said he was leaving office pending the outcome of a police investigation against him. The investigation involves suspicions that he embezzled funds before he joined the government, an Israeli police spokesman said. A10 9 Dead, 40 Hurt in Afghanistan Two bombings, one of them a suicide attack, rocked Khost, Afghanistan, killing 9 people and wounding more than 40, officials said. The suicide blast killed eight people and wounded at least 40, including several children, according to officials. The second bomb detonated in a video store, killing the owner and wounding seven. A3 Somalian Plight Grows Worse Government forces and insurgents in Somalia fought for a fifth straight day, killing scores of civilians and plunging the country deeper into chaos. United Nations officials say Somalia is headed toward its worst crisis ever. Estimates, at their most conservative, put the death toll from the past month near 1,000, with 200 people killed in the past week. A4 Bangladeshi Kept From Return Bangladesh's former prime minister, Sheik Hasina Wazed,was blocked from boarding a flight home from London after her country's military-backed interim government barred her from returning. A9 NATIONAL A12-16 Debate Invitations Besiege Presidential Candidates A flood of debate invitations is besieging Republican and Democratic candidates, thrusting them into a complicated political vortex as they struggle to balance their own needs with the demands of sensitive and powerful debate sponsors who candidates are eager not to offend. A1 Classes to Resume in Virginia Classes are scheduled to resume at Virginia Tech today, and as the campus tries to regain a sense of normalcy, professors struggle to find a sensitive way to shift the discussion back toward course work. Meanwhile, investigators are trying to solve the mystery of the motive of the gunman, Seung-Hui Cho. A14 As Korean-Americans in Centreville, Va., gathered at local churches, they embraced a time for reflection and spiritual solace after the week's jolting news that Seung-Hui Cho, who hailed from their community, had killed 32 people, and then himself, at Virginia Tech. A14 Ecological Conflict Over Dams In Klamath Falls, Ore., a conflict has arisen between PacifiCorp, a power company that owns energy producing hydroelectric dams on the Klamath River. Indian tribes, fishermen, and environmentalists who want the dams removed because they say the dams block endangered salmon from migrating. A12 McCain's Emissions Proposal John McCain is expected to call for America to be weaned from its reliance on foreign oil and for a cap on emissions of greenhouse gases as a way to fight global warming. He called global warming ''a serious and urgent economic, environmental and national security challenge.'' A14 Specter Critical of Gonzales Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, the ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales's failure to step down was ''no doubt, bad for the Justice Department.'' Mr. Specter's comments reflected a continued lack of support for Mr. Gonzales among key Republicans on Capitol Hill as he faces accusations that the dismissals of eight United States attorneys were politically motivated. A15 Run-In Over Climate Change An argument broke out at the White House Correspondents' Association Dinner between Karl Rove, the president's deputy chief of staff, and the singer Sheryl Crow and Laurie David, a top Democratic donor and a producer of the global warming documentary featuring Al Gore, ''An Inconvenient Truth.'' A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 In the Face of Retirement, A Cardinal Is Evaluated In the dusk of his half-century-long career, Cardinal Edward M. Egan, 75, remains something of a riddle. As he faces possible retirement, in accordance with church law he has submitted his resignation to the Vatican, the challenges facing the second largest archdiocese in the nation extend well beyond uncertain finances. A1 Plan for a Greener New York In a plan to create what he called ''the first environmentally sustainable 21st-century city,'' Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed a sweeping vision of 127 projects, regulations and innovations for the city and surrounding region. The plan would put in place a host of environmentally sensitive measures that would reduce greenhouse gases and foster steady population growth. B1 Same-Sex Marriage Bill Gov. Eliot Spitzer will introduce a bill to legalize same-sex marriage in New York, a move that would propel the state to the forefront of one of the most contentious issues in politics. B1 SPORTSMONDAY D1-8 Coach Fuels Yankee's Hot Start In the weeks after the Yankees' swift elimination from the playoffs last year, the first significant change the team made was to hire a new hitting coach, Kevin Long. Third baseman Alex Rodriguez met with Long for five days in the offseason, and armed with a better frame of mind and a sleeker physique, is off to perhaps the hottest start in baseball history. ARTS E1-8 Having Words Over Handel A panel discussion at the American Handel Festival 2007 at Princeton centered around an explosive issue: Michael Marissen's thesis that ''Messiah'' and more specifically the ''Hallelujah'' chorus -- perhaps the most sacrosanct and beloved totem in Western music -- conveys malice toward Judaism. E3 OBITUARIES A17 E. Dorrit Hoffleit An astronomer who studied the features of stars visible to the naked eye and was probably the oldest- working scientist in her field, she was 100. A17 Parry O'Brien An athlete who revolutionized shot-put technique and won two Olympic gold medals, he was 75. A17 Juanita Millender-McDonald A six-term Democratic Congresswoman from California's 37th District, she was 68. A17 Otto Natzler A ceramicist best known for inventing glazes resembling geologic textures and colors that he applied to forms created by his wife in a famous collaboration, he was 99. A17 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 The Return of PC Games PC games were once the mainstay of video gaming, but sales have slumped in recent years, overshadowed by a new generation of game consoles. Now they are showing signs of a making a comeback. C1 Alternative to Private Equity New shell companies led by former senior executives of companies like Time Warner, ABC and DirecTV have raised hundreds of millions of dollars on the stock market in low-profile deals using an obscure but growing financing technique. C1 Commercial Radio, Sans Ads Facing increasing competition from satellite radio and iPods, Clear Channel Communications is trying something radically different at a commercial radio station in Texas: getting rid of the commercials. C2 Layoffs at Tribune The Tribune Company is expected to announce staffing reductions soon at its flagship newspaper, The Chicago Tribune, as well as its largest circulation newspaper, The Los Angeles Times. C6 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Deadlines, war money and pork; the mayor's ode to Earth Day; prison horrors for the mentally ill; Francis X. Clines on evolution, on and off Broadway. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E2 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E8 Weather B8

ALFIN--Irwin (10/6/1929-4/19/ 2007). Irwin Alfin of Manhasset, NY, on April 19, 2007, at 77 years of age. Loving husband of Betsy. Cherished father of David and Susan. Devoted grandfather of David, Daniel, Dennis, Deborah, Emily and Kate. Irwin Alfin, a retired cosmetics and fragrance industry executive died Thursday, April 19, in New York City. In 1992 he retired as President and CEO of Alfin Fragrances, Inc., which he founded in 1976. The company went public in 1983 and distributed fine fragrances including Ombre Rose, Bal a Versailles, Joy, Fracas, Cabochard and Gianfranco Ferre. Prior to forming his company, Mr. Alfin served as President of Max Factor, Halston Fragrances and Chanel, Inc., USA. He started his career at Revlon, Inc. In 1985, Mr. Alfin served as president of the Fragrance Foundation and in 1999 was recognized for his contribution to the industry. Mr. Alfin served as a First Lieutenant in the U.S. Army in Korea following his graduation from OCS and Rutgers University in 1951. Funeral Home: Fairchild Funeral Home, Garden City, N.Y.
To the Editor: We applaud you for urging the Census Bureau to adopt a more realistic measure of poverty in ''Counting the Poor'' (editorial, April 17).

Two police supervisors are being investigated after officers accused them of referring to them as ''hos'' or a ''nappy-headed ho,'' the police said. One instance took place in the 70th Precinct in Brooklyn on April 15. The supervisor in that case has been transferred and stripped of supervisory duties, said Chief Michael Collins, a police spokesman. Chief Collins said the supervisor was accused of having addressed a group of officers jokingly as ''hos.'' The supervisor was identified by Bonita Zelman, a lawyer for the accusers, as Sgt. Carlos Mateo. In the second case, a Queens narcotics detective, Aretha Williams, said yesterday at a news conference that a sergeant recently told her, ''Don't give me no lip, or I'll have to call you a nappy-headed ho.'' The police, who did not release the sergeant's name, said that case would be reviewed this week. The radio host Don Imus was fired recently by CBS Radio for his on-air description of members of the Rutgers University women's basketball team as ''nappy-headed hos.'' Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said in a statement yesterday, ''This language is unacceptable under any circumstances and even more egregious when it comes from individuals in a position of authority.'' A representative of the Sergeants Benevolent Association contacted last night said he knew nothing about the accusations and declined to comment. MICHAEL WILSON

ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank, was near a deal Sunday night to be acquired by Barclays of Britain for more than $80 billion, in what would be one of the largest European banking deals ever. The deal is expected to be announced on Monday, according to people briefed on the negotiations. To fend off a rival group of bidders seeking to break up the 183-year-old bank, ABN Amro and Barclays struck a separate deal on Sunday to sell LaSalle Bank, a unit of ABN, to Bank of America for more than $21 billion. That deal requires shareholder approval, so it is possible that the rival bidders, led by the Royal Bank of Scotland, may still try to woo ABN. That group is scheduled to meet with ABN on Monday.

With all the hype and analysis surrounding presidential candidates’ quarterly fund-raising reports, Slate’s Dan Gross has decided to cut to the chase and start matching the contenders with the actual corporations he thinks they resemble most. Try to figure out which candidates are the steady but staid juggernauts, the rock-star upstarts and, well, Halliburton.
The latest ranking of the top-paid hedge fund managers has reignited a debate about just what these guys (and on this list, they are all guys) are doing, and whether it is worth all that money.

The crude language some rappers use has become a topic of national discussion in the last few weeks, with Oprah Winfrey taking up the subject and Russell Simmons, the hip-hop impresario, going as far as to call for the censoring of misogynistic words in song lyrics.

Alex Rodriguez doesn't speak much to the news media before games anymore. It seems to be part of another new strategy for dealing with reporters. As hot as he is these days, I'm sure he's sticking to whatever works.

Unrest at a prison in Indiana sparked headlines when the governor announced a "full-scale riot," but it was quelled soon after. Remaining were two injured employees, fire damage and a very interesting issue to examine.

After months of controversy, how many minutes did it take today for the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission to announce its unanimous ruling that the New-York Historical Society can renovate the exterior of its 1908 building?

On the eve of his official announcement tour to declare his candidacy for president, Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, has replaced his finance director. Carla Eudy, a long-time adviser, is out and Mary Kate Johnson, a former Bush fund-raiser, is in.

In a spirited town hall meeting with voters in Henniker, N.H., today, Rudolph W. Giuliani was challenged on his Republican credentials and pushed to be more specific in what it means to be on the "offense" in the war on terror.

But though Apple itself was not charged, its highly visible chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, may face separate charges -- a prospect raised by the claims of the company's former chief financial officer.

What raised our eyebrows, and apparently those of many commenters on the Gawker Web site, are some of his claims.

He was observing a program known as Oportunidades, an antipoverty program that provides cash incentives to poor families who agree to take certain steps to improve the health and education of their children.

Doug Lowenstein ran the Entertainment Software Association, which represented the videogame business, for more than a dozen years. Now he is the head of the new Private Equity Council, a lobbying group charged with improving the image of buyout firms. What could one job possibly have to do with the other? Mr. Lowenstein says there are indeed parallels between the two industries. His explained the common threads in a keynote speech at this week's Private Capital Symposium in New York, sponsored by The Deal.

Oracle is still hungry. The database software giant, which has been making a steady stream of acquisitions as its organic growth has stalled, said Tuesday it would buy Lodestar, which makes software applications used by energy companies. Terms were not disclosed.

A number of you have commented on my blog that the way to address prostitution is to legalize it and encourage unions of sex workers, thus empowering prostitutes and enabling sensible regulation and health outreach programs. In the context of countries like India and Cambodia where I've written about sex trafficking, that would be a bad mistake. Let me explain why.

Shareholders in The New York Times Company, led by a Morgan Stanley fund, withheld 42 percent of their votes from directors at Tuesday's annual meeting. Though largely symbolic, the show of protest over the company's dual-class stock structure was even greater than last year, when 30 percent of shareholders withheld their votes.

The gathering, held by the Milken Institute, a think-tank founded by the former junk-bond king, Michael Milken, features more than 100 sessions and 300 speakers.

When you're a fugitive executive awaiting extradition from Namibia on charges of fraud, how do you curry favor with the locals? If you're Jacob "Kobi" Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technology, who is accused of profiting from backdated stock options, you set up a local scholarship fund.

Rival suitors for Alliance Boots have thrown up their hands and ceded Britain's largest drugstore chain to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Stefano Pessina, the company's deputy chairman. Still, Terra Firma Capital Partners, a private equity firm led by Guy Hands, Wellcome Trust and HBOS managed to force the winners into raising their bid to 11.1 billion pounds ($22.2 billion).

They're justices, not popes: Jan Crawford Greenburg, ABC News's legal correspondent and the author of "Supreme Conflict: The Inside Story of the Struggle for Control of the United States Supreme Court," objects to those who have attributed the majority decision in Gonzales vs. Carhart to religious belief, rather than legal analysis. She notes that Geoffrey Stone, former law school dean and provost at the University of Chicago (where Greenburg attended law school), wrote on the University of Chicago law school faculty blog: "All five justices in the majority in Gonzales are Catholic. The four justices who either are Protestant or Jewish all voted in accord with settled precedent. It is mortifying to have to point this out. But it is too obvious, and too telling to ignore." Greenburg responds on Legalities, her ABC News blog:
A few stories that struck us in our travels around the Web:

Evercore Partners' employees, including senior managers, will sell about $82 million of stock in the investment banking boutique, whose shares have risen more than 50 percent since it went public eight months ago. Financial News, citing regulatory filings, reported that Evercore's chairman, Roger Altman, plans to sell as much as $20 million in stock and the co-chief executive, Austin Beutner, is selling $14 million of shares.

The New York Times Company annual shareholder meeting traditionally has been a tame affair, where the Sulzberger family, which owns a controlling interest in the company, applauds the achievements of its journalists and, in turn, basks in the applause of investors.

An initial public offering from the movie theater operator Cinemark Holdings raised $532 million Monday, at the top of the range the company expected. That might set a good tone for Cinemark's rival, AMC Entertainment, which hopes to raise $800 million in a stock sale next month.
The rival group considering a bid for ABN Amro may be down, but analysts say it's not out.
The market pundit Jim Cramer apparently wants to help the little guy get into the private equity action.

A deal to sell the Chrysler Group likely will get tied up in the upcoming contract negotiations between Detroit automakers and the United Auto Workers, according to the Detroit Free Press. That means a final deal to sell Chrysler is unlikely to be made before Sept. 14, the day the labor contract expires, complicating both the talks for a new labor agreement and negotiations with DaimlerChrysler to sell its United States operations.

Private equity's clout has never been greater, but the industry is still poorly understood by most people in Europe's five biggest economies, according to a poll conducted as part of The Financial Times's special report on private equity. About 62 per cent of those surveyed said they are "not at all familiar" with private equity.

Following a prickly letter from Affiliated Computer Services' founder and chairman about the lack of progress on his talks for a management buyout of the technology services provider, the board had a barbed response of its own.

Marc Benioff, the chief executive of Salesforce.com, a provider of online customer management software, is opening the company's first incubator for start-ups that are developing online software that complements that of Salesforce, BusinessWeek reports.

The British drugstore chain Alliance Boots said Tuesday it was recommending an improved offer from the buyout shop Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Stefano Pessina, after the group raised its bid to 11.1 billion pounds ($22.2 billion), topping a rival offer from the financier Guy Hands.

Apple's former chief financial officer, Fred D. Anderson, is preparing to settle with the Securities and Exchange Commission over the dating of an option grant to senior officials in January 2001, The New York Times reported Tuesday.

In the introduction to the 25th anniversary edition of his Pulitzer-winning book on Vietnam, "The Best and the Brightest," David Halberstam mused about one thing that always worries journalists: "If my byline disappears, have I disappeared as well?"

Brocade claims its post-merger integration with former rival McData is well under way. The analyst firm The 451 Group looks at whether the bulked-up storage-area network vendor can hold off Cisco Systems as it attempts to broaden its product base. The report concludes that Brocade, which has a market capitalization of about $4 billion, "will make further acquisitions in the Ethernet market to ensure it can be competitive with Cisco in this space."

Two of my greatest passions are road trips and Broadway musicals. Even though I grew up as an airline child, I would far rather drive than fly when the time allows, and I much prefer to take back roads if they can get me there fast enough. Last week, on the way back from the start of Toyota production at Subaru's plant in Lafayette, Ind., my two passions collided when I saw the road sign for Peru on Route 24.

The technology investment firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is opening offices in Shanghai and Beijing and plans to invest a $360 million fund in Chinese Internet, energy, media and communications start-ups, The New York Times reported.

A dispute between two top figures in the corporate media establishment spilled into public view Monday when Richard Snyder, the former chairman of Simon & Schuster, sued Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chairman of the Warner Music Group, saying he had not compensated him for his role in Mr. Bronfman's $2.6 billion acquisition of the music company three years ago.

In a victory for a small wi-fi start-up called Fon, Time Warner will let its home broadband customers turn their connections into public wireless access spots, a practice shunned by most Internet service providers in the United States.

Carl Icahn and the other investors who pressed MedImmune for a sale are probably quite happy with the result: a $15.2 billion bid from the British drug giant AstraZeneca. At $58 a share, AstraZeneca's offer is 53 percent above where MedImmune's stock was trading when the company put itself on the block, according to Jason Zhang, an analyst at Prudential. The bid was far higher than many on Wall Street had expected. Shares of MedImmune, which already announced that it had hired Goldman Sachs to look for potential buyers, surged 18 percent Monday in heavy trading.

A Brazilian iron and steel company, MMX Mineração e Metálicos, plans to sell a large stake in one of its mining projects to the British mining company Anglo American, according to a regulatory filing. According to the preliminary agreement between the two companies, Anglo American will acquire 49 percent of the MMX unit Sistema Minas-Rio for $1.15 billion. Sistema Minas-Rio is the company's most ambitious mining project, with total investments of more than $2.4 billion.

Eiffage, a French construction company, said its board had rejected a takeover bid of 6.6 billion euros ($9 billion) from a Spanish rival, Sacyr Vallehermoso, for the two-thirds of Eiffage it does not already own. Eiffage, which is based near Paris, challenged the strategic sense of the approach and accused Sacyr of violating merger rules by collaborating with other investors in making its bid.

Atacadão operates 34 discount hypermarkets in Brazil, 17 of which are located in São Paulo state. Atacadão's property portfolio consists of 2.3 million square feet.

After the object of its desire rejected its $1.2 billion bid, the sneaker maker Foot Locker said it was not ruling out the possibility of raising the price. Foot Locker's target, Genesco, which makes footwear and accessories, rejected the $46 a share bid Monday saying that it undervalued the company.

The Spanish property market is going through a tough time right now. Residential property inflation has slowed to 7.2 percent -- down from 9.1 percent -- with prices stagnant or falling in many parts of the country.

One cannot help regarding Robert Dallek's account of the Nixon-Kissinger White House and its handling of the Vietnam War as a kind of parable about the presidency of George W. Bush and its determination to stay the course in Iraq.

Bryan Curtis looks at the draft and the falling fortunes of last season’s Heisman Trophy winner, Troy Smith. Also, if the only horse race you bet on all year is the Kentucky Derby, Joe Drape tells you how to maximize your investment.

WARSAW, April 24 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates was told by his Polish counterpart today that Poland supports proposals to base 10 American missile interceptors on its soil — but only so long as Poland’s security is enhanced by the move, along with that of Western Europe.

TOKYO, April 24 — When the fund set up by Japan a dozen years ago to compensate the aging victims of its wartime sexual slavery closed down on schedule last month, it left much of its mission of redress and reconciliation unfulfilled, because many of the victims refused to accept its money.

The first-quarter results mark another milestone in America’s long decline from industrial pre-eminence.
Yankees starter Kei Igawa allowed seven runs over four and a third innings while Alex Rodriguez homered twice, making him the first player to hit 14 in the first 18 games of a season.
Nissan will offer buyouts to workers in Japan after slumping domestic sales forced it to cut earnings and sales goals.
John Maine baffled the Rockies for seven and two-thirds innings, scattering seven hits and allowing one run as the Mets cruised to a victory Monday night.

British Airways said it was in discussions with several private equity investors about entering a joint bid for Iberia Líneas Aéreas de España, increasing the chances of a bidding war for the Spanish carrier. The Texas Pacific Group, the American buyout firm, made a $4.6 billion approach for Iberia last month. One person with knowledge of the negotiations, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said British Airways, which already owns a 10 percent stake in Iberia, was considering either joining the Texas Pacific bid or backing a bid from one of two other private equity firms, which were not named. British Airways, which has ruled out a bid on its own, said in a statement that any bidding group in which it was involved would probably “include one or more Spanish partners.”.

Eiffage, a French construction company, said its board had rejected a takeover bid of 6.6 billion euros ($9 billion) from a Spanish rival, Sacyr Vallehermoso, for the two-thirds of Eiffage it does not already own. Eiffage, which is based near Paris, challenged the strategic sense of the approach and accused Sacyr of violating merger rules by collaborating with other investors in making its bid. Sacyr, based in Madrid, made the hostile bid for Eiffage, the company that built the Eiffel Tower, after Eiffage blocked Sacyr, its largest shareholder, from taking a board seat. Eiffage decided not to cooperate with Sacyr after the pair held 14 rounds of talks. Eiffage said. “None of the meetings allowed the companies to identify a common strategy, synergies or even a road map for future joint projects,” Eiffage said in a statement.

A Brazilian iron and steel company, MMX Mineração e Metálicos, plans to sell a large stake in one of its mining projects to the British mining company Anglo American, according to a regulatory filing. According to the preliminary agreement between the two companies, Anglo American will acquire 49 percent of the MMX unit Sistema Minas-Rio for $1.15 billion. Sistema Minas-Rio is the company’s most ambitious mining project, with total investments of more than $2.4 billion. The investments include development of the Minas mine in Minas Gerais state, and a slurry pipeline and, port facilities. Anglo American will pay $704 million for the 30 percent stake in Sistema Minas-Rio held by an MMX affiliate, Centennial Asset Mining Fund.

Carrefour, the French retailer, said it had agreed to buy a Brazilian discounter, Atacadão, for about $1.09 billion in a deal that would make it the largest food retailer in Brazil. Atacadão operates 34 discount hypermarkets in Brazil, 17 of which are located in São Paulo state. Atacadão’s property portfolio consists of 2.3 million square feet. The company posted net sales in 2006 of about $2 billion, representing a 4 percent market share. Carrefour’s operations in Brazil consist of 109 hypermarkets, 34 Carrefour Bairro and 258 Dia hard discount stores with total net sales in 2006 of $5.16 billion.
Phil Mickelson dropped his swing instructor, Rick Smith, and hired Butch Harmon, who helped Tiger Woods and Greg Norman become the world’s No. 1 golfers.
Several experts presented evidence that they had gathered in recent years of increased asthma rates and widespread home contamination in Brooklyn.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about “Il Barbiere di Siviglia,” at the Metropolitan Opera, misidentified the nationality of the baritone Russell Braun, who sings Figaro. Although he was born in Germany, he is Canadian.

Picture captions on April 18 with an article about the London Book Fair and the importance to the publishing industry of the fair’s International Rights Center misidentified the section of the fair shown in two photographs. It was the exhibitors’ area, not the International Rights Center.
An obituary on Wednesday about the writer Hans Koning misspelled the surname of the star of a movie made from his novel “A Walk With Love and Death.” She is Anjelica Huston, not Houston.

A front-page article on Sunday about the troubled life of Seung-Hui Cho, the gunman in the Virginia Tech massacre, misspelled the given name of the roommate of Emily Hilscher, who was shot to death in a campus dormitory. She is Heather Haugh, not Haughn.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the challenges facing Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York who turned 75 this month, referred incorrectly to the resignation he has submitted to the Vatican, in accordance with church law. He offered to resign as archbishop — not cardinal, a lifetime position. The article also misspelled the given name and surname of the president of the College of New Rochelle, who praised the cardinal’s dedication to education. He is Stephen Sweeny, not Steven Sweeney.

An article on April 12 about the $500 million asking price for the building at 229 W. 43rd Street that houses the headquarters of The New York Times — nearly three times the amount a developer paid for it in November 2004 — included an outdated reference to an Upper East Side mansion with a high price tag. The 25-room building, which is listed at $59 million, is no longer owned by Robert C. Guccione, the founder of Penthouse magazine.

A sports picture caption in some copies yesterday about Boston’s 7-6 victory over the Yankees referred incorrectly to a home run by Mike Lowell of the Red Sox. The photograph showed the celebration after his three-run homer that put Boston ahead in the seventh inning — not after his third-inning home run, which tied the score at 3-3.

An article on Sunday about a military report that found that senior Marine Corps commanders had contributed to a “willful” failure to investigate the killing of 24 unarmed Iraqis by marines in the town of Haditha in 2005 misstated a word in a quotation from Brian J. Rooney, a lawyer for an officer punished in the Haditha matter. Mr. Rooney said his client, Lt. Col. Jeffrey R. Chessani, had promptly reported what he knew about the killings and “I don’t know how that’s untimely, inaccurate and incomplete.” He did not say “untimely, accurate and incomplete.”.

A television review last Tuesday of the documentary “Gangs of Iraq” on PBS omitted a word in a quotation from a motivational speaker shown addressing Iraqi police trainees. He said, “‘I am not here to impose my American will upon you” — not “I am here.” A listing of credits with the review carried outdated information from PBS about the program’s producer and erroneously credited another executive. The producer is Marcela Gaviria — not Martin Smith, who was correctly identified in the article as the PBS correspondent. Sherry Jones is a senior producer — not an executive producer, the position held by David Fanning.

An article on Sunday about a military report that found that senior Marine Corps commanders had contributed to a “willful” failure to investigate the killing of 24 unarmed Iraqis by marines in the town of Haditha in 2005 misstated a word in a quotation from Brian J. Rooney, a lawyer for an officer punished in the Haditha matter. Mr. Rooney said his client, Lt. Col. Jeffrey R. Chessani, had promptly reported what he knew about the killings and “I don’t know how that’s untimely, inaccurate and incomplete.” He did not say “untimely, accurate and incomplete.”.
An obituary on Saturday about Carlo Maria Badini, a former superintendent of La Scala opera house, who died last week at the age of 81, misstated the year he was born. It was 1925, not 1915.

Because of an editing error, a brief article yesterday about a deadly orphanage fire in the Bosnian capital of Sarajevo referred incorrectly in some copies to the location of Ljubljana, the city in the dateline, where the article was reported and written. It is in Slovenia, not Slovakia.
This season, David Wright has a modest average (.261), less than a handful of runs batted in (four) and no home runs.
Matthew Maiello, who has served time for statutory rape, singled her out for special attention and told her that it was “God’s plan” that they have sex, she testified in court.
yacht racing.
An insurgent group today claimed responsibility for yesterday’s suicide bombing, which was one of the most lethal attacks on U.S. troops in Iraq.
The city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission is expected to designate a long swath of 472 buildings in Crown Heights.
Ever since 200 police officers were called in to break up a group of violent teenagers earlier this month, city officials have cast the episode as an anomaly.
Boris N. Yeltsin, Russia’s first freely elected leader, presided over the end of the Soviet Union and the Communist Party.

Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio, a Democratic presidential candidate who is a vocal critic of the war in Iraq, plans to introduce articles of impeachment against Vice President Dick Cheney today. Mr. Kucinich’s articles would be reviewed by the House Judiciary Committee, which would decide whether to conduct an inquiry and would then need to seek authority from the entire House. Megan McGinn, a spokeswoman for Mr. Cheney, responded to Mr. Kucinich’s announcement by saying the vice president had served the nation honorably for almost 40 years and “is focused on the serious issues facing our nation.”.

A former state legislator who disappeared overnight after a family boating trip was found alive on a small island. The former lawmaker, Bruce Weyhrauch, was hypothermic but conscious when he was found at 11:15 a.m. by a dog-search team on Coghlan Island at the mouth of Auke Bay in Juneau. Mr. Weyhrauch, 54, was reported missing Sunday evening after his 15-foot Boston Whaler was found drifting with no one on board.

The State Senate approved a bill that would bar state health officials from following Gov. Rick Perry’s order requiring schoolgirls to be vaccinated against a cancer-causing sexually transmitted disease. The bill was overwhelmingly approved by the House last month. The chambers must now work out the differences between the two versions and can then send it to the governor, who is expected to veto the legislation.

Gov. Christine Gregoire, a Democrat, is expected to sign a measure that would make Washington the second state, after California, to grant paid leave to workers after the birth of a child. The bill, passed by the Democratic-controlled Legislature on Sunday, would provide up to $250 a week to new parents starting in October 2009. Parents of adopted children could also receive benefits. The bill was amended to remove a section that would have extended the benefits to people caring for a seriously ill relative. The program is expected to cost $19.7 million in 2010 and $21.4 million in 2011, legislative staff members said. The bill did not designate a financing source but instead created a task force to make recommendations by January 2008. California’s paid family leave program, which started in 2004, provides up to $882 per week for a total of six weeks and offers benefits for those caring for an ill relative.

A wildfire in southeast Georgia was about 45 percent contained after burning about 55,600 acres, officials said. The fire started April 16 when a fallen power line ignited tinder-dry trees near the sprawling Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge. Eighteen homes have been destroyed, officials said. No more evacuations had been ordered since about 1,000 people near Waycross were told to leave their homes last week.

A former Congressional staff member, Mark Zachares, will plead guilty today to accepting $40,000 in money and tickets to sporting events and concerts in exchange for helping the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, Mr. Zachares’s lawyer said. Mr. Abramoff and his lobbying team supplied Mr. Zachares with tickets on about 40 occasions from August 2002 to February 2004, says a 10-page document filed in the case. The document also said Mr. Zachares received $10,000 in wire transfers from Mr. Abramoff in January and February 2002 through a nonprofit foundation the lobbyist controlled.

The Agriculture Department has again lowered the number of people whose Social Security numbers were disclosed in a public database posted on the Census Bureau’s Web site. The department, which was alerted to the problem two weeks ago, now says about 37,800 numbers were exposed. Initially, it had said 100,000 to 150,000 people were affected, before lowering the number to 63,000. It says the current number reflects a complete review of all records posted in the database. The department will provide credit monitoring for one year for the people whose Social Security numbers were exposed.

The Coast Guard unloaded about 20 tons of cocaine with a street value of $600 million into port in Alameda after what it called the largest drug seizure ever at sea. The cutter Sherman stopped the Panamanian cargo ship Gatun about 20 miles off a Panamanian island on March 17. The cargo ship’s 14 crew members were Panamanians and Mexicans; they were not armed and offered no resistance when stopped, Coast Guard officials present during the inspection said.

Police officers and other city employees will not help federal immigration authorities seeking to round up and deport illegal immigrant workers in San Francisco, Mayor Gavin Newsom said Sunday. The mayor told a predominantly Hispanic audience at St. Peter’s Church that while city and state officials could not stop Immigration and Customs Enforcement from conducting sweeps in the city, he would do everything within his power to discourage them. “We are a sanctuary city, make no mistake about it,” Mr. Newsom said.
Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey said that New Jersey had suffered $180 million in damage in what he called the second-worst rainstorm in the state’s history.
President Bush has vowed to veto the Democratic war spending bill, which would order the administration to begin withdrawing troops by Oct. 1.
A ranking of the top 25 earners shows that for the hedge fund elite, the rich are getting much richer in a hurry.
Texas Instruments struggled with a glut of inventory and shifting demand toward lower-end phones with less expensive chips.

Jorge Luis García Pérez, a dissident leader widely known by the nickname Antúnez, was freed from prison on Sunday after serving his entire 17-year sentence on charges of engaging in enemy propaganda, rights groups reported. At the same time, they reported the case of a dissident lawyer, Rolando Jiménez Posada, sentenced after a secret trial over the weekend to 12 years in prison for painting graffiti and distributing pamphlets with an anti-government message. He has been jailed since his arrest in early 2003. According to Elizardo Sánchez, a leading dissident and a spokesman for the independent Cuban Commission for Human Rights and Reconciliation, relatives of Mr. Jiménez Posada say that the authorities denied his request to represent himself in court and that when he protested, he was not allowed to attend his own trial. “The biggest worry for the commission is that in two weeks, we have seen two similar secret trials behind closed doors, without relatives or defense attorneys present,” Mr. Sánchez said.

It was Zalmay Khalilzad’s first day on the job as the American permanent representative to the United Nations. Mr. Khalilzad, the former ambassador to Iraq who replaced John R. Bolton after he resigned the United Nations post in December when he failed to obtain Senate confirmation, will travel immediately, joining a Security Council mission departing New York today for Serbia and Kosovo. The United States supports a United Nations plan for granting near-independence to Kosovo, but Russia, a veto-bearing member of the Council, is seeking to renegotiate it and called for the trip so ambassadors could see conditions on the ground. Mr. Khalilzad will become head of the Council for May, when the United States occupies the rotating presidency of the 15-member body. Richard A. Grenell, the spokesman for the American mission, quoted Mr. Khalilzad as saying his priorities would be Iran, Iraq, Lebanon, Sudan and United Nations reform.

A bomb ripped through a bus traveling near the northern town of Vavuniya, killing at least three passengers and wounding 35 in the third bombing of a civilian bus this month, the Defense Ministry said. At the same time, there was rising speculation that after weeks of near daily airstrikes and artillery attacks by its forces, the government was preparing to open a large military offensive in the north, where the Tamil Tiger rebels run a ministate complete with border guards, schools and traffic police. Earlier in the day, officials ordered Norway’s ambassador, who is trying to mediate a resumption of peace negotiations, to cancel a trip to the rebels’ northern strongholds for security reasons.

India successfully placed an Italian astronomical satellite in orbit and became one of just a handful of countries conducting commercial space launchings. The 775-pound satellite blasted off from southern Sriharikota atop a domestic PSLV-C8 rocket. India is planning to use the rocket for the launching of a spacecraft to the moon next year.

South Korea, facing criticism after it agreed Sunday to send 400,000 tons of rice to North Korea despite the North’s prevarication on a Feb 13 international agreement to shut down its main nuclear reactor, warned that North Korea might not get all the aid if it continued to refuse to live up to its commitment. “We emphasized that the speed and timing of the aid shipments could be changed depending on the North’s sincere implementation of the Feb. 13 agreement,” Lee Jae-Joung, the unification minister, said in a statement. The agreement signed Sunday contained no such preconditions. South Korea is to send the first shipment of rice in late May. Critics from the political opposition and conservative civic groups in Seoul had urged the government not to promise any aid until after the North had made a move to shut down the nuclear reactor.
Two former executives expect to be sued this week by the S.E.C. over the company’s backdating of employee stock options.
The Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist wrote books on topics as varied as the Vietnam War and basketball.
For 30 years, Sondra Fortunato has used her physique and a skill for self-promotion to achieve a level of tabloid fame a few notches below Paris Hilton’s.
It is in the nature of men who lead revolutions that they rarely prove to be effective leaders of governments. So it was with Boris Yeltsin.
The news that Gov. Eliot Spitzer will soon introduce a bill to legalize same-sex marriage is welcome and could give new national momentum to this important cause.
A new service by Philips Electronics lets people send text messages to seek information about popular destinations in major cities.
A number of New York’s black elected officials say they are undecided in the Democratic presidential race.
President Bush said that the attorney general’s testimony last week had increased his confidence in him.
A police official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said that detectives thought the girl had accidentally become tangled in the rope.
Rising medical costs and the retirement of baby boomers are set to overwhelm the Medicare program by 2019, the Bush administration reported.
The drug maker posted an 11 percent increase in first-quarter earnings, led by strong sales of its hypertension and cancer treatments.
Congress is to be commended for making the minimum wage bill a priority. But lawmakers will have to temper their enthusiasm for never-ending tax cuts.
Attorneys general around the country are stepping up their scrutiny of college lending practices in the absence of federal enforcement.
The president of the Italian American Museum is leading a campaign to move the museum from its quarters in an office building on West 44th Street.
Robert S. Bennett, the lawyer who once defended President Bill Clinton, will help the World Bank president make his case that he should not be ousted.
American commanders consider Kurdish soldiers to be a critical part of the new Baghdad security plan because of their fighting prowess.
The time  between the N.F.L. scouting combine  and the draft is critical for teams hoping to screen prospective draft choices, and for players hoping to sell themselves to potential employers.
With The New York Times Company’s stock performance lagging, the Sulzberger family is bracing for a contentious meeting today.
The outcry about the construction of a wall around a Sunni neighborhood has revealed deep Iraqi frustration.
A study released by the state excluded victims of child abuse that did not involve a commercial purpose.
The four-year contract fight with the union representing New York City school principals was unusually bitter even by the standards of city labor relations.
Microsoft filed documents defending its demand to be paid royalties for releasing some software code to competitors.
The phrase, intended to signal that the country was involved in a lengthy struggle, has been retired at Central Command.
Tests on seven backup urine samples taken from Floyd Landis at the 2006 Tour de France have revealed traces of synthetic testosterone, according to a report Monday by a French newspaper.
Raptors Coach Sam Mitchell’s smile and his moxie have helped him orchestrate the biggest turnaround in the N.B.A.
China has given U.S. regulators permission to investigate whether suppliers exported contaminated pet food ingredients to the U.S.
Classes resumed Monday after a moment of silence and the tolling of bells in memory of the victims of the massacre.
Phil Hughes, the 20-year-old right-hander who may be the best pitching prospect in all of minor league baseball, will make his Yankees debut on Thursday.
The Department of Veterans Affairs will add the Wiccan pentacle to a list of approved religious symbols.
First-quarter profit fell 64 percent because of declining sales of medical devices used in cardiac patients.
The technology investment firm is opening offices in Shanghai and Beijing and plans to invest a $360 million fund in Chinese start-ups.
A.M.D. posted a $611 million quarterly loss, hurt by a price war with Intel, and said it would explore ways to raise new capital.
Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. was remembered at a memorial service in Manhattan as a pre-eminent historian, a lifelong liberal and a devoted father.
A New Zealand company said it secured financing to produce ethanol from an untapped source — carbon monoxide gas.
Strong sales of its anemia-fighting drugs boosted profit but its revenue for the quarter failed to meet expectations.
Stocks retreated as concern about rising oil prices outweighed strong earnings reports and new takeover activity.
Since Donovan McNabb has had a season-ending injury in each of the last two seasons, some believe that the Philadelphia Eagles should select a quarterback in this weekend’s N.F.L. draft.
New discoveries should remind us how steadily our knowledge of the ancient saurian world has deepened as research has shifted from the macroscopic to the molecular.
The $15.6 billion deal to acquire MedImmune is perhaps the most emphatic sign yet of the push by big drug makers into biotechnology.
Time Warner will let its home broadband customers turn their connections into public wireless access spots.
Chicago’s Thabo Sefolosha, a rookie guard and the first player from Switzerland to play in the N.B.A., gamely guarded Miami’s Dwyane Wade during their first-round game.
The former chairman of Simon & Schuster alleged he was not compensated for his role in the $2.6 billion acquisition of the music company three years ago.
An agent who shot and killed a Mexican immigrant along the Arizona-Mexico border in January was charged Monday with first-degree murder.
The deal with Barclays reduces, but does not eliminate, the chance of another suitor coming in with a higher bid.

A 25-year-old woman was being questioned by the Camden police yesterday afternoon after she told investigators that her daughter had been abducted, leading to a statewide Amber Alert, the police said. Around 11:30 a.m., the woman, Lakeesha White of Camden, told the police that she had stopped her car to help an older person cross the street and that a man jumped into the car and sped off with her 7-year-old daughter in the back seat, said Teresa Sicard Achambeault, a police spokeswoman. Detectives issued the alert and found Ms. White’s car several blocks away about 1 p.m. The police later discovered that the girl had been in school all morning, Ms. Sicard Achambeault said.

A State Superior Court jury convicted a Woodbridge woman yesterday of killing her husband, dismembering him, then stuffing the body parts into three suitcases and throwing them into Chesapeake Bay. The woman, Melanie McGuire, 34, was convicted of murder, desecration of a corpse and perjury in the death of her husband, William McGuire, 39, a computer programmer. Prosecutors said that Ms. McGuire, a nurse, killed her husband so she could begin a new life with her companion, her boss at a fertility clinic.
Delta Air Lines reported that it narrowed its loss in the first quarter on an 11.4 percent increase in sales.
The consumer products maker also stood by its full-year profit view despite topping Wall Street’s expectations.

The son of Bud Harrelson, a former New York Mets star, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years’ probation and 420 hours of community service for hindering the prosecution in the samurai sword slaying of his best friend’s stepfather, a retired New York City police officer. Mr. Harrelson’s son, Troy, 19, was the key witness in the trial of the friend, Zachary Gibian. Mr. Gibian was on trial in the 2005 murder of his stepfather, Scott Nager, at their home in Hauppauge. In a plea agreement, Mr. Harrelson admitted that he had helped dispose of evidence. Mr. Gibian, 20, was sentenced in January to 25 years to life in prison after he was convicted of second-degree murder.

City officials announced the start of construction yesterday on the city’s second Family Justice Center, which provides services to victims of domestic violence and their children. The center, in Kew Gardens, will provide multilingual services including assistance with police reports, emergency shelter and lawyers.

The Claremont Riding Academy on the Upper West Side will shut down at 5 p.m. on Sunday, the owner, Paul Novograd, said yesterday. The academy, which opened as a livery stable in 1892, has been a riding academy since the 1920s, Mr. Novograd said. He said the increased popularity of the park’s bridle path among pedestrians had made it very difficult for riders. The closing of the academy, which is on West 89th Street, was first reported in The New York Post. Homes will be found for the approximately 45 horses that are stabled there, Mr. Novograd said.

The vacancy rate for rental apartments in nearly every Manhattan neighborhood remained below 1 percent for all of 2006, according to data released yesterday by the rental brokerage firm Citi Habitats Inc. Last year was the first time in the five years that Citi Habitats has been collecting this data that the vacancy rate was below 1 percent throughout the whole year. In the West Village, the vacancy rate shrank as low as 0.49 percent. Prices for studio, one-bedroom and two-bedroom apartments throughout Manhattan jumped by about 9 percent from the previous year, and prices for three-bedroom apartments rose by nearly 14 percent. Citi Habitats surveyed 60,000 units for its report.

One man was killed and another wounded yesterday when they were shot in a sport utility vehicle in Bedford-Stuyvesant by gunmen who pulled up alongside them and began firing, the police said. The driver, Isaiah E. Jacob, 21, of Brooklyn, was shot once in the torso and killed, and his passenger, who was not identified, was in stable condition late yesterday at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center with two gunshot wounds, the police said. They said two gunmen in a sedan pulled up beside the S.U.V. around 12:20 p.m. at Marcy and Lafayette Avenues. There were no arrests yesterday.

Army authorities are investigating the death of a 21-year-old soldier who was found unresponsive in a Fort Drum residence on Friday. The Army identified the soldier yesterday as Pvt. Richard Therrien of Howell Township, N.J. Private Therrien was pronounced dead after being taken to Samaritan Medical Center in Watertown. He was an infantryman assigned to the First Battalion, 87th Infantry.

The site of the Navy brig, a former naval prison next to the Brooklyn Navy Yard in Fort Greene, will be turned into a mixed-income housing complex with town houses, co-op apartments, rental apartments, supportive housing, a day care center and perhaps even an environmentally friendly dry cleaner, city officials said yesterday. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development announced that a partnership between the Dunn Development Corporation and L&M Equity Participants Ltd., two development companies specializing in low-priced housing, would redevelop the 103,000-square-foot site between Flushing and Park Avenues with 434 housing units.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission fined the owner of the Indian Point nuclear plant $130,000 yesterday for failing to meet a deadline last week for a new emergency siren plan. The plant’s 150 sirens are meant to alert residents within 10 miles to an emergency at the plant. Despite extensive testing by the owner, Entergy, the sirens failed their final test on April 13. Yesterday, the commission gave the company 30 days to come up with a plan to get the new sirens working. Entergy said it would meet the requirement.
Fear, uncertainty and cultural taboos make it hard for victims of human trafficking to speak out.
The network equipment maker reported a decline in quarterly profit as expenses rose despite higher sales.
Strong sales of Spider-Man toys and its Littlest Pet Shop and Playskool brands sent its shares up sharply.
Voters in the tiny Buddhist nation chose among “dummy” parties in a rehearsal for multiparty elections next year.
The Council also voted to ban metal bats in high school baseball games when it overrode a second mayoral veto.
Many of the prospective jurors questioned have expressed some knowledge of the case against Jose Padilla and two other defendants.
Volvo Taps Two Agencies.
Lawmakers began weighing ways to prevent more tragedies on college campuses in a hastily convened hearing a week after the shootings in Virginia.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey will remain in the hospital for at least a week.
Despite American pressure, the Kremlin remains opposed to a new plan for cooperating on missile defense in Europe to defend against a potential Iranian attack.
The former chief executive of HealthSouth agreed to pay more than $81 million to settle a case over accounting fraud.
Senate Republicans suggested that Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s proposals were undemocratic and would be advantageous to wealthy candidates — like the governor.
The senator said that  America must repair its standing in the world and resist the temptation to turn inward.
For the 30 people who live in the Kaisertal, Austria, there has always been only one way in and one way out: on foot. Yet next March, that isolation will come to an end.
A bizarre gap in the N.H.L. schedule has created an Eastern Conference semifinal series between strangers. The Rangers play the Sabres in Game 1 on Wednesday night.
The question of whether a reasonable passenger would feel free to leave a car that has been stopped by a police officer was a key issue in a case heard by the Supreme Court.
Richard Hamilton scored 22 points, one of four Pistons with at least 17 last night, to lead Detroit to a 98-90 victory against the Orlando Magic and a 2-0 lead in their first-round series.

Awaiting the imminent birth of his first child, Dontrelle Willis went about his business last night by pitching six and two-thirds innings and hitting a standup triple to help the Florida Marlins defeat the visiting Atlanta Braves, 8-7.
Ford Motor’s chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, appointed Susan M. Cischke to create a long-range strategy on sustainability matters.
The unsolicited offer for the company was raised 4.6 percent, valuing it at about $6.1 billion.
A man who was facing eviction from a fashionable apartment complex killed the manager of the complex and then himself.
Nicolas Sarkozy and Ségolène Royal are battling for France’s political center in the second round of the country’s presidential elections.
The F.D.A. said regulators had approved generic versions of Ambien, a blockbuster sleeping pill from Sanofi-Aventis.
Hani al-Qawasmi submitted his resignation on Monday, but was persuaded to stay on by the Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya of Hamas.
To truly understand Mr. Yeltsin — and the events he set in motion — it helps to look back to that period just before he burst onto the global political scene.

Climate stress may well represent a challenge to international security just as dangerous — and more intractable — than the arms race between the United States and the Soviet Union during the cold war.
In the latest effort to force Iran to curb its uranium enrichment activities, the European Union approved a second phase of United Nations sanctions on Monday.
A Chicago man was cleared of a criminal conviction because of D.N.A. evidence in what an advocacy group said was the 200th such case.
Many government workers who drive to work sell the transit passes provided by the government, according to a report from the Government Accountability Office.
Some prisoners executed by lethal injection may die of suffocation while they are still conscious and in pain, University of Miami researchers said Monday.
Foot Locker said it was not ruling out the possibility of raising its $1.2 billion bid for the footwear and accessories maker.
Overseas, high-speed rail service with amenities like Wi-Fi is luring business travelers away from airports.
How to confront a fear of flying, deal with it and get on with business.

AIRLINE EMPLOYMENT The number of employees working for domestic airlines in February rose 0.2 percent over February 2006, according to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics. But the increase was not because of hiring by the major carriers. Despite record passenger demand, the network carriers had 2.2 percent fewer workers than the previous February. Instead, regional carriers are adding employees (up 5.9 percent over February 2006) as are low-cost carriers (up 5 percent). Compared with February 2003, the number of employees at the big network carriers declined 23.3 percent, to 262,400, from 342,300. Meanwhile, employment at low-cost carriers rose 8.3 percent, to 71,400, from 65,900, and employment at regional carriers rose 22.4 percent, to 599,000, from 489,000 in 2004. That was the first year regional carriers reported unified employee statistics.
In a surprise facet of the deal, ABN Amro said that it had arranged to sell LaSalle Bank to Bank of America.
The suspension came after complaints about the broadcast of a prank phone call to a Chinese restaurant that was peppered with ethnic and sexual slurs.
A film trains a lens on the photography collector Sam Wagstaff.

World Voices Festival of International Literature, sponsored by the PEN American Center, will run from today through April 29 at 29 locations. Here are some highlights:.
A festival created in the aftermath of Sept. 11 gives authors a forum to address political issues.
Peter Sagal’s play is an engrossing legal drama that examines the moral and ethical dilemmas inherent in the First Amendment.
Prison sentences in Munch thefts imposed, Carl Bernstein’s Hillary Clinton book is due in June, a new Gershwin prize given to Paul Simon and more culture news.

To the Editor:.
The orchestra’s Saturday evening concert had a theatrical theme, with works by Vaughan Williams, Julia Wolfe and Holst.
Four out of five studies on chocolate found reduced blood pressure after eating, a report says.
Arnold Worldwide and Nitro will share an assignment with spending at around $150 million to $200 million.
William E. Hurwitz spent more than two days on the witness stand telling a jury why he had prescribed painkillers to patients who turned out to be drug dealers and addicts.
The double dose of environmental programming offered on PBS’s “Nova” and “Frontline” on Tuesday feels too timid for the task at hand.
The chemistry behind that new car smell, an asteroid Itokawa and the Gilboa tree.
Apparently, it is never too soon to think about the risk of cardiac disease.
Mr. Meyer’s eclectic program included works by Bach, Haydn, Bright Sheng and Saint-Saëns at Zankel Hall on Friday.
Helicobacter pylori might have a beneficial effect in reducing the risk of asthma and allergies, a new  study suggests.
Noctilucent, or “night shining,” clouds are increasing rapidly and reflecting more light.
Readers respond to articles in Science Times with thoughts on chimps, computer science, hospitals and more.
Swedish children, like their American counterparts, are growing fatter, researchers say.
There were no cutting-edge eruptions, just the quiet pleasure of well-made art, in four dances performed by Kun-Yang Lin/Dancers on Friday at Queens Theater in the Park.
Erika Sunnegardh, a Swedish soprano, was presentable, agile and reasonably regal in her performance of “Turandot” on Saturday.
At the Joyce SoHo on Friday, the troupe presented three well-made new works, and while none of them are likely to change the face of the art, they constituted an enjoyable evening.
A mistake in the way the body’s cells repair their DNA may lead to the onset of the incurable hereditary brain disorder Huntington’s disease, researchers say.
A popular old wives’ tale holds that for every baby a woman has, she is bound to lose a tooth. Is it true?

8 P.M. (13, 49) SAVED BY THE SUN Gas prices are through the roof, oil supplies are dwindling, and global warming is on everyone’s radar. Could solar energy be a cleaner solution? In this “Nova” special, above, scientists explain advances in technology that may make this once-futuristic energy source viable. Proponents and critics discuss the possibilities.
Orson Welles dominates the 1944 version of “Jane Eyre” and a low-priced, high-quality Jean Renoir collection brings the director’s lesser-known work to the forefront.
A newly discovered feature of dog body language may surprise attentive pet owners and experts in canine behavior.
Five far-flung composers at Alice Tully Hall on Friday performed contemporary works that all seemed to be exercises in instrumental hedonism.
Ms. Mahler’s latest evening of work, as seen at Danspace Project on Friday, focused on juxtaposing stillness and the energetic impulses that propel movement into action.
A new book provides an analysis of the often invisible ties that bind drug makers and doctors.

Boeing is using new technology not only to build its 787 Dreamliner aircraft but also to promote it: The company has commissioned a series of large-format videos running on the aircraft’s Web site to promote the 787 to potential passengers and airline customers, aviation enthusiasts and others.
Keith Aronowitz first noticed the crater on his elbow after returning from Bolivia. For a week or two, he simply ignored it. Then his friends began to worry.
Susan L. Lindquist performs imaginative research into how proteins function that reveals clues to how diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's develop.
The study tracked women prospectively to see if those who reported having abortions were more likely to develop breast cancer in the future and found that they were not.
How do engineers decide how many blades to have on a plane?
Millions of people throw away good money and, sometimes, their good health, using over-the-counter weight-loss remedies that don’t work.
Cues that a family medicine or pediatric practice is welcoming to adolescents can be discerned well before the first visit.
DayJet plans to begin flying the nation’s first on-demand, per seat air taxi service in June.
First and foremost, Willis Reed, still the most important catch the Knicks ever made, was always a gentleman. He is retiring as the Hornets’ vice president in June.
ESPN became a masseuse of history Sunday night when its goal was to straightforwardly chronicle the four consecutive home runs that Red Sox batters swatted.
The Yankees have an advantage in that it’s early, and they have a lot of time to correct their pitching problems. But they also have a lot time to intensify their problems.
The restaurant of Vanity Fair editor Graydon Carter was cited for nine different violations, including “mouse activity.”
To pursue the future, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had to return to the past. Consciously or not, he went as far back as the first century.
Even if neocons weren’t bent on spreading democracy, their chronic inflammation of world opinion would be unhealthy.
William Gross, manager of the bond powerhouse Pimco, will donate the proceeds from an auction of his rare stamp collection to Doctors Without Borders.
Umaru Yar’Adua easily won the presidential election in Nigeria, but international observers said the voting was not credible.

With “Ratatouille,” Disney and Pixar have staked their fortunes on a summer movie that is completely original in concept at a time when ticket buyers have shown a growing preference for repeat performances.
Adolescent medicine is in little demand by doctors seeking to advance their careers.
Edward Albee joined a who’s who roster of artists for last weekend’s YoungArts program, which offered mentoring sessions to creatively inclined students from around the country.
More than a quarter of the country’s bee colonies have been lost, and no one can say what is to blame.
The current construction craze along the Las Vegas Strip is driven by a 95 percent weekend occupancy rate.
Until India’s economic boom becomes much more broadly based, the country won’t achieve a fraction of what it should.
