Gov. Christine Gregoire, a Democrat, is expected to sign a measure that would make Washington the second state, after California, to grant paid leave to workers after the birth of a child. The bill, passed by the Democratic-controlled Legislature on Sunday, would provide up to $250 a week to new parents starting in October 2009. Parents of adopted children could also receive benefits. The bill was amended to remove a section that would have extended the benefits to people caring for a seriously ill relative. The program is expected to cost $19.7 million in 2010 and $21.4 million in 2011, legislative staff members said. The bill did not designate a financing source but instead created a task force to make recommendations by January 2008. California's paid family leave program, which started in 2004, provides up to $882 per week for a total of six weeks and offers benefits for those caring for an ill relative. WILLIAM YARDLEY

It's not a Gore '08 strategy session (at least not officially), but about 20 former fund-raisers and supporters of Al Gore will gather in Washington next month to talk about politics, memories and Mr. Gore's future at a dinner being organized by Peter Knight, his close friend and political ally. The dinner comes as speculation has intensified about whether Mr. Gore will be a late entry into the Democratic presidential race. Two people who plan to attend said that a possible presidential run by Mr. Gore in 2008 would inevitably be a topic, given the Oscar victory for ''An Inconvenient Truth,'' the buzz about his Congressional testimony on global warming, his new book that will be out two weeks after the May 8 dinner, and his global ''Live Earth'' concerts in July.

The Agriculture Department has again lowered the number of people whose Social Security numbers were disclosed in a public database posted on the Census Bureau's Web site. The department, which was alerted to the problem two weeks ago, now says about 37,800 numbers were exposed. Initially, it had said 100,000 to 150,000 people were affected, before lowering the number to 63,000. It says the current number reflects a complete review of all records posted in the database. The department will provide credit monitoring for one year for the people whose Social Security numbers were exposed. RON NIXON

HIRSCH--Rev. A. Asher. With profound sorrow the worldwide Shaare Zedek family mourns the loss of this righteous individual and true ''eved Hashem''. A man of great emunah and Torah wisdom who inspired us all, he over came personal heartbreak and loss to devote his life to alleviating the spiritual burdens and physical ailments of countless thousands, both in New York and in Jerusalem. For the past fifty years, he served the Hospital with unparalleled devotion, un matched distinction and unwavering commitment to Halacha, first as the American Committee's founding Executive Director, and then, following his aliyah to Eretz Yis rael in 1979 with his dear wife Henrietta, as Director of the Hospital's Religious Services Unit. We will always cherish his leadership and be eternal ly grateful for his five decades of tireless efforts that continue to play such a vital role in the growth and development of the American Committee and the Medical Center itself. Heartfelt condolences to his beloved Henrietta, brother Benjamin, children Miriam and Noftoli, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Emeritus Sidney G. Adler, Treasurer Emeritus Michael G. Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Vice Chair Jack C. Bendheim, President Prof. Jonathan Halevy, Director-General Lee Weinbach, President, National Women's Division Michael S. Strauss, Board of Governors Paul S. Glasser, Nat'l Director Morrie Libman, Regional Director

The 2008 presidential campaign is having something of a spring awakening this week. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, is formally announcing his candidacy for the White House with a trip that begins tomorrow in New Hampshire; it is part of something of a do-over for Mr. McCain after a particularly rough couple of months.

To the Editor: Re ''Postures in Public, Facts in the Womb'' (column, April 22): David Brooks writes, ''In the beginning there is the womb and the creature inside.'' Sounds as if ''the womb'' is sitting over there in the corner, minding its own business, unattached to a person!

India successfully placed an Italian astronomical satellite in orbit and became one of just a handful of countries conducting commercial space launchings. The 775-pound satellite blasted off from southern Sriharikota atop a domestic PSLV-C8 rocket. India is planning to use the rocket for the launching of a spacecraft to the moon next year. HARI KUMAR

INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Democrats to Send Iraq Bill With Withdrawal Deadline Congressional Democrats agreed to ignore President Bush's veto threat and send him a $124 billion war spending bill that orders the administration to begin pulling troops out of Iraq by Oct. 1. The House and Senate are to vote on the agreement and send it to the White House by the end of the week. A sports picture caption in some copies yesterday about Boston's 7-6 victory over the Yankees referred incorrectly to a home run by Mike Lowell of the Red Sox. The photograph showed the celebration after his three-run homer that put Boston ahead in the seventh inning -- not after his third-inning home run, which tied the score at 3-3.

A devastating suicide car bombing on Monday killed nine American soldiers near a patrol base in Diyala Province, the military announced early Tuesday morning. It was one of the most lethal suicide bomb attacks on American troops in Iraq. Another occurred on Dec. 21, 2004, when a suicide bomber wearing an explosive vest walked into a mess tent on an American base in Mosul and detonated his charge, killing 14 United States soldiers.

When the Bush administration has sought to explain its strategy for fighting terrorism, it has often said the United States is involved in a ''long war'' against Islamic extremists. The phrase was coined by Gen. John P. Abizaid before he retired as head of the Central Command. It was intended to signal to the American public that the country was involved in a lengthy struggle that went well beyond the war in Iraq and was political as well as military.

An article on April 12 about the $500 million asking price for the building at 229 W. 43rd Street that houses the headquarters of The New York Times -- nearly three times the amount a developer paid for it in November 2004 -- included an outdated reference to an Upper East Side mansion with a high price tag. The 25-room building, which is listed at $59 million, is no longer owned by Robert C. Guccione, the founder of Penthouse magazine.
Paul D. Wolfowitz, who is fighting to stay on at the World Bank, has enlisted the help of Robert S. Bennett, a lawyer who once represented President Bill Clinton. Page A10.

To the Editor: I could not agree more with Frank Rich (''Iraq Is the Ultimate Aphrodisiac,'' column, April 22) about the president's rushing to Blacksburg, Va., to be the nation's mourner in chief. The president said ''our nation is shocked and saddened'' by the violence at Virginia Tech and that he and Laura Bush had come to Blacksburg ''with hearts full of sorrow.'' Yet what happened at Blacksburg is a daily occurrence in Iraq precipitated by an ill-considered invasion and a bungled occupation.

Q. I have heard of planes with five-bladed propellers. How do engineers decide how many blades to have? A. The number of blades is but one choice an engineer designing propellers must make, and the others may be just as important or even more so, said Alan J. Friedman, consulting senior scientist for the New York Hall of Science in Queens.

British Airways said it was in discussions with several private equity investors about entering a joint bid for Iberia Líneas Aéreas de España, increasing the chances of a bidding war for the Spanish carrier. The Texas Pacific Group, the American buyout firm, made a $4.6 billion approach for Iberia last month. One person with knowledge of the negotiations, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said British Airways, which already owns a 10 percent stake in Iberia, was considering either joining the Texas Pacific bid or backing a bid from one of two other private equity firms, which were not named. British Airways, which has ruled out a bid on its own, said in a statement that any bidding group in which it was involved would probably ''include one or more Spanish partners.'' NICOLA CLARK

Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. was remembered yesterday as a pre-eminent historian, a lifelong liberal and a father who danced with his daughter and watched Sergeant Bilko with a son. At a memorial service in the Great Hall at Cooper Union, in Lower Manhattan, historians, diplomats and a former president mingled with surviving New Frontiersmen of the Kennedy White House to recall the lasting contributions of Mr. Schlesinger, who died on Feb. 28 at the age of 89. The event filled the 900-seat Great Hall, where, as several speakers noted, Abraham Lincoln defined his presidential candidacy in 1860.

Prison Sentences in Munch Thefts Sentences from five and a half to nine and a half years were imposed yesterday by an appeals court in Oslo on the gunman, the mastermind and the getaway driver in the theft of the Edvard Munch masterpieces ''The Scream,'' above left, and ''Madonna,'' right, The Associated Press reported. Petter Tharaldsen, 35, the getaway driver, was given nine years and six months for grand theft in the Munch case and an unrelated robbery. Bjoern Hoen, 39, the mastermind, was sentenced to nine years for grand theft, and Stian Skjold, 31, one of the gunmen, to five and a half years. They were also ordered to pay a total of $263,000 in compensation to the city of Oslo, owner of the paintings, which were stolen in a daring daylight robbery at the Munch Museum in 2004. The paintings were recovered in August, but both were damaged. New Gershwin Prize Given to Paul Simon Paul Simon has been chosen to be the first recipient of the Library of Congress Gershwin Prize for Popular Song. Named for George and Ira Gershwin, the new award is to be given annually to a composer or performer whose lifetime contributions exemplify the excellence associated with the Gershwins. ''Few songwriters have had a broader influence or contributed to more song genres than Paul Simon,'' said James H. Billington, librarian of Congress. ''Because of the depth, range and sheer beauty of his music, as well as its ability to bridge peoples and cultures, he is the perfect first recipient of this prestigious award.'' Mr. Simon, above, is to the receive the honor in ceremonies on May 23 at the Warner Theater in Washington, where the performers will include Marc Anthony, Art Garfunkel, Philip Glass, Alison Krauss, Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Lyle Lovett, James Taylor and Buckwheat Zydeco. PBS will televise the event nationally on June 27. Festival Prize for Work By Slain Filmmaker ''The Waitress,'' a romantic comedy written and directed by Adrienne Shelly, who was murdered in Greenwich Village on Nov. 1, won the narrative feature competition on Saturday at the ninth annual Sarasota Film Festival in Florida, Reuters reported. The award carries a $5,000 prize. Sienna Miller Takes On Dylan Thomas Film Exit Lindsay Lohan and enter Sienna Miller in a film about the life of Dylan Thomas that is scheduled to go before the cameras next month in Wales, Variety.com reported. Ms. Lohan had been expected to play the role of Thomas's wife, Caitlin MacNamara, in ''The Best Time of Our Lives,'' but when she and the backers could not agree on a deal, she dropped out and Ms. Miller, above, stepped in. Keira Knightley will play Thomas's childhood friend Vera Phillips in the story of the rivalry between the two women over the Welsh poet, to be played by Matthew Rhys. The script was written by the playwright Sharman Macdonald, Ms. Knightley's mother, and is to be directed by John Maybury.

STRINGER--Ronald E. of New York City and Coconut Creek, FL, died on April 20, 2007. He is survived by his wife Sandra, sons David and Scott Stringer, stepdaughters Cynthia Zucker, Amy Gold and seven grandchildren. Counsel to New York City's Mayor, Abe Beam during the 1970's fiscal crisis, Professor of Constitutional Law at John Jay College and The Police Academy of San Juan Puerto Rico. A graduate of Bronx Science High School, City College and Brooklyn Law School, he was a fervent defender of the law. He changed the quality of people's lives through the giving effort of his pro-bono representation, as well as by serving as night court arbitrator for many years. Cherished by his students, he instilled the importance and power of a good education. He and Sandy shared their passion for travel, the environment and wildlife preservation. We will all miss his compassion, positive outlook, sense of humor and the sparkle in his eye. Memorial Contributions may be made to John Jay College Library, 899 10th Avenue, NY, NY 10019.

To the Editor: Re ''Computer Science Takes Steps to Bring Women to the Fold '' (April 17): Women's avoidance of computer science may reflect a practical understanding of economic reality not available to the rarefied world of academia, which wants to see computer science as ''fun and interesting.'' Most computer opportunities exist in the world of business, where the main preoccupation is technical troubleshooting and the busywork associated with our national mania for mergers and acquisitions. This activity is akin to appliance repair or the assembly line, not what computer professionals originally have in mind for a career.

Senator John McCain was once one of those relatively few politicians willing to speak out against subsidies for ethanol, a stance that in Iowa is akin to campaigning against apple pie. His position was one of the main reasons Mr. McCain essentially wrote off the Iowa caucuses when he ran for president in 2000. But this time around, with demand for alternative fuels increasing, Mr. McCain, an Arizona Republican who has been actively campaigning in Iowa, has cautiously embraced the use of ethanol.

GILL--Captain Frank, 64, a native of Long Beach, N.Y., and a son of the late Arthur and Ruth Gill, on April 21, 2007, after a courageous battle with cancer. A Vietnam veteran who loved the sea, Frank was a great fisherman and pioneered surfing in Long Beach. He is survived by his sons Blake and Alex; daughter Erin; sisters Nancy McShea (Jerry), Kit Gill and Jane Gill; brother Roger Gill (Susan); nieces Colette, Susan, Marisa and Grace; nephews Justin, Jeremy and Robert; grandnephew and niece Quinn and Tatum; and his beloved Bichon, Lily. A memorial mass will be held at St. Ignatius Martyr Church in Long Beach.

To the Editor: Dr. Elissa Ely's thoughtful commentary on exploring her former patient's MySpace site after his suicide (Cases, April 17) is marred by her observation that the messages there ''were not written to a haunted self, or someone who had failed trials of antipsychotic drugs.'' Those suffering from brain illnesses have enough burdens without being labeled failures. It was surely the antipsychotic drugs that failed, not the patient. Suzanne M. Parson St. Ignatius, Mont.

THE CLAIM Gain a child, lose a tooth. THE FACTS A popular old wives' tale holds that for every baby a woman has, she is bound to lose a tooth, supposedly because the pregnancy interferes with calcium absorption and increases hormones that affect oral health.

Apparently, it is never too soon to think about the risk of cardiac disease. A study published today has found that mildly elevated levels of cholesterol or slightly above normal blood pressure from ages 18 to 30 are strong predictors of having coronary artery calcium at ages 30 to 35. Coronary artery calcium, a form of arterial plaque, is a predictor of later heart disease. Researchers recruited 5,115 people from 18 to 30 in 1985 and 1986 and followed them with physical examinations 2, 5, 7, 10 and 15 years later. The scientists tested blood pressure, cholesterol and serum glucose levels and recorded body mass index. The study appears in The Journal of the American College of Cardiology.

To the Editor: Re ''Bloomberg Draws a 25-Year Blueprint for a Greener City'' (news article, April 23): I applaud and admire Mayor Michael R. It was Zalmay Khalilzad's first day on the job as the American permanent representative to the United Nations. Mr. Khalilzad, the former ambassador to Iraq who replaced John R. Bolton after he resigned the United Nations post in December when he failed to obtain Senate confirmation, will travel immediately, joining a Security Council mission departing New York today for Serbia and Kosovo. The United States supports a United Nations plan for granting near-independence to Kosovo, but Russia, a veto-bearing member of the Council, is seeking to renegotiate it and called for the trip so ambassadors could see conditions on the ground. Mr. Khalilzad will become head of the Council for May, when the United States occupies the rotating presidency of the 15-member body. Richard A. Grenell, the spokesman for the American mission, quoted Mr. Khalilzad as saying his priorities would be Iran, Iraq, Lebanon, Sudan and United Nations reform. WARREN HOGE

South Korea, facing criticism after it agreed Sunday to send 400,000 tons of rice to North Korea despite the North's prevarication on a Feb 13 international agreement to shut down its main nuclear reactor, warned that North Korea might not get all the aid if it continued to refuse to live up to its commitment. ''We emphasized that the speed and timing of the aid shipments could be changed depending on the North's sincere implementation of the Feb. 13 agreement,'' Lee Jae-Joung, the unification minister, said in a statement. The agreement signed Sunday contained no such preconditions. South Korea is to send the first shipment of rice in late May. Critics from the political opposition and conservative civic groups in Seoul had urged the government not to promise any aid until after the North had made a move to shut down the nuclear reactor. CHOE SANG-HUN

A television review last Tuesday of the documentary ''Gangs of Iraq'' on PBS omitted a word in a quotation from a motivational speaker shown addressing Iraqi police trainees. He said, '''I am not here to impose my American will upon you'' -- not ''I am here.'' A listing of credits with the review carried outdated information from PBS about the program's producer and erroneously credited another executive. The producer is Marcela Gaviria -- not Martin Smith, who was correctly identified in the article as the PBS correspondent. Sherry Jones is a senior producer -- not an executive producer, the position held by David Fanning.

CORNELL--Richard D. Loving husband, father and friend, dedicated to his dental profession, Dr. Richard Cornell passed away Friday evening the 20th of April in peaceful surroundings in Palm Beach County, Florida. Born in Brooklyn October 8th, 1924, he attended the College of William & Mary, Chapel Hill, and New York University College of Dentistry in an accelerated Armed Forces program. He served honorably in both the United States Army and Navy and upon return from Germany settled in the NY Rivertown village of Dobbs Ferry where he established his dental practice. An avid golfer, photographer, and lover of life, always dedicated to his patients, family, and friends, he now rests in peace. He is predeceased by his eldest son, Jonathan Cornell. Dick Cornell is survived by his wife of 56 years, Betty Cornell, his brother Robert Cornell, sister-in-law Mari Cornell, his two sons Ivan and David, his daughter-in-law Valerie Gutterman, and two grandchildren Elizabeth and Julianne Cornell. Rest in peace now father. We know in our hearts your infectious smile will always be looking over us. Shalom. Funeral services will be held Tuesday April 24th, 2007, 9:30 am at Temple Beth Abraham, 25 Leroy Avenue, Tarrytown, NY with interment at Montefiore Cemetery, 121 - 83 Springfield Blvd., Springfield Gardens, Queens, NY.

FRIEDMAN--Irving. Kind, respected, visionary, mentor and patriarch. Devoted father of Bob and Micki, Bernie and Leslie. Loving grandfather of Deborah, Matthew, Teri, Michael, Monica, David and Rachel. We extend our heartfelt sympathy. Richie, Jeffrey and Scott $(6$)FRIEDMAN--Irving Our family mourns with you in the loss of your Dad, a man of great honor and charm. He was a wonderfully devoted husband to Clara, and a guiding light for his sons, Bernie and Bob and their families. He will be greatly missed by all those who knew him. We are here for you. Patti and Marty Goodstein and our Family $(6$)FRIEDMAN--Irving. It is difficult for me to express the feelings of sorrow I felt when Bernard and later Robert Friedman called me to tell me that their father Irving had passed away. It will be hard to comprehend that he is no longer with us. I first met Irving Friedman thirty years ago when as vice president of Morse Diesel, I was in charge of building the addition to the Park Avenue Synagogue of which Irving, a successful owner/builder was Chairman of the Building Committee. As such he oversaw construction issues and was my liaison with the Synagogue. What became obvious through the construction process, was not only his dedication in insuring a successful project but the depth of his knowledge and wise counsel on matters relating to the process. Irving was ''hands on'' practical and showed tremendous foresight in solving problems before they occurred. He was instrumental in the success of the project. Through the years in working with Irving on numerous development projects, his energy and tenacity never waned. He was at work every day until very recently and his door was always open to discuss project details both from a technical and financial prospective. He knew where every dollar went and never sacrificed quality for expediency. His name and reputation for building a project that would last the test of time was very important to him. Many times when faced with difficult construction decisions, I would ask myself, ''What would Irving do?'' What Irving would do was usually the right decision. Our industry and I personally share a tremendous loss with the passing of this industry leader and mentor. On behalf of myself and my family I wish to express my sincerest and deepest condolences to his sons, Bernard and Robert Friedman and their families and extended families. Lou Katsos President Jekmar Associates $(6$)FRIEDMAN--Irving. Beloved husband to the late Clara. Devoted father of Bernard and Leslie, Robert and Micki. Loving grandfather of Teri, Michael and Monica, David and Rachel, Deborah and Matthew. Proud great-grandfather of Kieran, Jane, Stephanie and Emily. Service Tuesday, 10:30am, Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th St. and Madison. He was the patriarch of the family and will be missed. Contributions, if you desire, to Park Avenue Synagogue, would be appreciated. $(6$)FRIEDMAN--Irving. The Em ployees of Friedman Management have lost our founder & dear friend. Our hearts are heavy. He was a gentleman among men and he will truly be missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Friedman Family. $(6$)FRIEDMAN--Irving. The partners and employees of Cooley Godward Kronish LLP wish to express their sorrow at the loss of Irving Friedman. He and his late wife, Clara, were individuals of exceptional decency, integrity and warmth. We extend our sincerest condolences to their sons, Bernard and Robert, and to their families.

The article also misspelled the given name and surname of the president of the College of New Rochelle, who praised the cardinal's dedication to education. He is Stephen Sweeny, not Steven Sweeney.

Helicobacter pylori, the main cause of peptic ulcer disease, might have a beneficial effect in reducing the risk of asthma and allergies, a study published yesterday suggests. Researchers questioned 7,663 men and women about their history of asthma, allergic rhinitis and allergy symptoms, and tested them for antibodies to H. pylori. They also administered skin tests using 10 standardized allergens.

Because of an editing error, a brief article yesterday about a deadly orphanage fire in the Bosnian capital of Sarajevo referred incorrectly in some copies to the location of Ljubljana, the city in the dateline, where the article was reported and written. It is in Slovenia, not Slovakia.

Most Americans favor stricter handgun control, but few say it would have done a lot to prevent the shootings last week at Virginia Tech, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Two-thirds of the adults surveyed Friday through Sunday said the laws covering the sale of handguns should be stricter, and 27 percent said the laws should be kept as they are now.

To the Editor: I disagree with Kirk W. Johnson's characterization, in ''Hounded by Insurgents, Abandoned by Us'' (Op-Ed, April 18), of my objection to a recent legislative proposal that would revise the immigration code's prohibition on allowing individuals tied to terrorist activity or groups to enter the United States. I support the original purpose of the legislation, which is to permit groups like the Hmong in Southeast Asia and Iraqis who have helped the United States in their country and do not pose a threat to our security to enter the United States.

From a boardroom set at a rainy Hollywood Bowl, Donald Trump hired Stefani Schaeffer, a 32-year-old lawyer, as the sixth season of NBC's ''Apprentice'' came to a close on Sunday, drawing marginally improved ratings. Mr. Trump chose Ms. Schaeffer despite his concerns that she advanced largely ''under the radar'' during the 14 weeks of competition. According to Nielsen's estimates, the live finale attracted 7.9 million viewers, leading the 10 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49 and delivering the show's largest audience in nearly three months. Average ratings for ''The Apprentice'' have fallen precipitously every season since its debut in January 2004. Compared with the 21 million viewers averaged that first season, this year's edition, the only one set in Los Angeles, drew just 7 million on average. NBC has yet to announce whether the reality show will be renewed. For the night, the network finished third in total viewers and fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic, just behind CBS. ABC led the night over all. BENJAMIN TOFF

To the Editor: Re ''Almost Human, and Sometimes Smarter'' (April 17), about new findings on chimpanzees: Humans routinely disregard not only the feelings and wishes of other species, but that they are capable of feelings and wishes at all. The new studies show an increasing awareness that our failure to recognize emotions and morality in other species is exactly that -- our failure. We routinely abuse other species in labs, circuses and slaughterhouses not because we have the moral authority, but simply because we can. Dan Piraro Brooklyn To the Editor: In ''Almost Human,'' Tetsuro Matsuzawa, a Tokyo primatologist, notes that chimpanzees perform better than humans on certain computer memory tests and suggests what he calls a trade-off theory: that early human species ''lost the immediate memory and, in return, learned symbolization, the language skills.''

GARDNER--Milton M., M.D., a well-known obstetrician and gynecologist on Long Island, distinguished by his personal warmth, grace and elegance, died of natural causes at age 93 on April 22 in Glen Cove, NY. One of four children of Samuel and Bella Gardner, he was born on March 17, 1914 in New York's Lower East Side. His family soon moved to Brooklyn where he attended Erasmus High School. He began his undergraduate studies at Brooklyn College and then matriculated at Arkansas University, where he completed his B.S. and M.D. degrees. He joined the US Public Health Service and, at the start of WWII, was assigned to the US Coast Guard, serving on the USS Charlotte, a destroyer escort in the North Atlantic, as ship's doctor with the rank of Lieutenant. After the war, he completed his residency in obsterics and gynecology in Boston, MA and moved back to NYC. In 1948 he married Madeleine Murphy, whom he met in Buffalo, NY when both were in uniform during the war. (She was a Major in the WACS). After living in NYC, they moved to Levittown, NY where he established one of the first OB/GYN practices in this booming post-war community. Eventually, he established a second office in Merrick, with professional associations at Hempstead General Hospital and Memorial Hospital, and he was named Chief of Obsterics and Gynecology at South Nassau Hospital in Oceanside, NY. The Gardner's also lived in Merricak, where they raised their five children: Leslie Gardner Pantucci, Deborah GardnerGray, Cecilia L. Gardner, Samuel Gardner and Mara Gardner. A devoted husband, father and grandfather, adored brother and uncle, he was a dedicated community member and medical professional whose great passion was modern art. As an arts enthusiast, he had a passionate interest in the burgeoning post-war NYC and Long Island art scene and a keen eye as a collector. He was generous with his knowledge and his collection, leading the establishment of the Friends of the Emily Lowe Gallery at Hofstra University and donating many works of art to Hofstra University (where he was also a trustee), Smith College and the Brooklyn, Parrish and Heckscher Museums. A longtime resident of Water Mill, NY, he was truly and ardent ''gardener,'' who delighted in cultivating his beautiful Japanese garden at the waterfront home on Mecox Bay that he built with Madeleine. Madeleine Gardner died in 1983. He later married Mayda Lannick, who survives him along with his five children, daughter-and-sons-in-law and nine grandchildren, all of whom loved him dearly and are thankful for his long, full and very happy life. The funeral service will take place Tuesday, April 24th at 10am at the Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza in Great Neck, NY. Contributions may be made to the Milton M. Gardner Endowed Scholarship Fund at Hofstra University.
SORELL--Michael, M.D., 59, on April 20, 2007. Funeral April 24, 2007 at 3pm, St. John's Episcopal Church, Washington, CT. Hufcut Funeral Home 845-877-1400.

Carl Bernstein, right, the journalist who, with Bob Woodward, uncovered the Watergate scandal for The Washington Post more than three decades ago, has finished a biography of Hillary Rodham Clinton, below, to be published by Alfred A. Knopf in June. ''A Woman in Charge: The Life of Hillary Rodham Clinton,'' which will weigh in at 640 pages, covers her life up through her decision to run for president, according to a press release issued yesterday. Paul Bogaards, a Knopf spokesman, said that Mr. Bernstein ''reaches conclusions that stand in opposition to what Hillary Clinton has said and written about herself.'' Mr. Bernstein's book is one of at least two biographies about Mrs. Clinton scheduled to come out this summer. ''Her Way: The Hopes and Ambitions of Hillary Rodham Clinton,'' by Jeff Gerth and Don Van Natta Jr., reporters for The New York Times, is to be published by Little, Brown & Company on Aug. 28, according to Michael Pietsch, Little, Brown's publisher. Mr. Pietsch said the company was ''presently reviewing our publication schedule.'' Mr. Bernstein has been working on his book, which was done without Mrs. Clinton's official cooperation, for eight years. Knopf decided to advance publication, tentatively planned for this fall, as soon as it received the final chapter last Thursday, Mr. Bogaards said. The book has been simultaneously translated so that it can be published in Germany and the Netherlands at the same time as in the United States. Knopf is planning an initial print run of 350,000 copies in the United States. MOTOKO RICH

The union, which has been raising questions about the benefits of private equity deals to workers and investors, wrote that Warner Music's new owners "hollowed out a once-proud music company, harming its image in the music industry and potentially reducing its long-term value."

The fatal shooting of a New York state trooper this morning has prompted a variety of reactions in Albany.

It was a press conference where the topic was the opening of the Tribeca Film Festival. But presidential politics could never be far from the surface at any event that includes both former Vice President Al Gore and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

On Tuesday, speakers along a section of the Detroit riverfront promenade near the General Motors headquarters broadcast an XM Satellite Radio channel playing No. 1 songs from the 1960s and 1970s -- the same day Toyota announced first-quarter production figures showing that it had overtaken G.M. to become the world's largest automaker.

Life is tough if you're one of the Democrats in the State Senate. Since Republicans run the chamber -- as Democrats do the Assembly -- the Senate's minority party don't get many chances to move legislation of their own.

Seung-Hui Cho's shooting rampage at Norris Hall lasted nine minutes, Virginia Tech's police chief, W.R. Flinchum, said today. During that time, he fired more than 170 rounds, killing 30 people and himself, the official said. Twenty four were injured, according to earlier reports.
Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, prepares a spectacular chili paste with dried chilies and garlic.

If Lee Iacocca, the legendary former chief of Chrysler, has a guess about which bidder will win his old company, he's keeping it to himself. "Who knows?" was his diplomatic response to Fortune when asked about the auction for the automaker. But he couldn't resist editorializing a bit on the process: "Private equity funds scare me," Mr. Iacocca said. "Do they really understand the car business?"

Gov. Eliot Spitzer cut short his schedule today in the New York City area -- including canceling his appearance at a NARAL lunch -- to fly back to Albany after two state troopers were shot in the Catskills. One of the troopers is reported to have died.

The two most prominent Democratic presidential contenders struck back today at Rudolph W. Giuliani's comments in New Hampshire on Tuesday night, when he warned that America would be more vulnerable to another terrorist attack if a Democrat takes the White House.

Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly "to maximize value," he told Fortune magazine's Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta's creditors' committee in January. "But it's also kind of fun, too."
Breaking ground this spring is French Leave, a new resort with ownership opportunities located in Governor's Harbor, the capital of Eleuthera and the oldest settlement in the Bahamas.
At first I wasn't sure what I was seeing.
Back when I had a real job, I used to tie my business trips to places I wanted to visit so that the boss would pick up some of my travel costs.

An interesting and diverse assortment of high-profile Internet voices, led by Larry Lessig, prominent bloggers on the left and right and activists like those with MoveOn.org, have written letters to the chairmen of the Republican and Democratic parties in an effort to make televised footage of any presidential debates widely accessible on the Internet for any purpose.
Jack Valenti was a confidant of President Lyndon B. Johnson and then a Hollywood institution.

Carl Icahn is on a roll. Building on a string of successful efforts to push for change at various companies, the billionaire financier has won the endorsement of an influential advisory firm in his face-off with Motorola. Institutional Shareholder Services, which gives voting recommendations to institutional investors, on Wednesday urged the cellphone company's shareholders to elect Mr. Icahn as a director -- despite Motorola's ardent desire to keep him out of the boardroom.
A glimpse of the aircraft carrier Intrepid, which is in dry dock for major repairs.

Virginia Tech Update Law enforcement authorities are still looking for the gunman's motive. Also, there's a gripping account of the scene in one of the classrooms, with a graphic showing his footsteps.

In her Web-only column today, Robin Toner takes a look at the debate taking place over the religion of the five Supreme Court Justices who voted to uphold the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act last week:

PORTSMOUTH, N.H. -- Senator John McCain of Arizona is about to reveal the not-so-secret news that he is running for president of the United States. A stage for the official announcement at noon has been set up here overlooking the Portsmouth Naval shipyard.

Let's go back to last spring training, before Endy Chavez's first season with the Mets. Willie Randolph raved and raved and raved about Chavez - his speed, his defense, his compact swing - but would mistakenly refer to him as Sanchez and, when referring to Duaner Sanchez, would call him Chavez.

As the Blackstone Group prepares to go public, its rivals are continuing to evaluate the possibility of initial public offerings. The heads of three buyout firms shared their thoughts at the Milken Global Conference in Los Angeles by evaluating the pros and cons of initial public offerings, according to The Financial Times.

In what The Times's Alan Cowell described as a "rare overview of the development of terrorism threats and of police and secret intelligence service counter-measures since Sept. 11, 2001," a top British official said today that Al Qaeda was alive and well despite major efforts to destroy it.
To paraphrase William Carlos Williams, so much depends upon a Chicago bank.

Today's the big day for Senator John McCain. He's set to officially announce his candidacy in New Hampshire, the state that handed him a victory over then-Gov. George W. Bush in the 2000 G.O.P. primary. Since that time, he's gone from presumed Republican heir to, as The Washington Post's Dan Balz puts it, the candidate with "the most to prove." But Mr. McCain is finding the silver lining in his diminished fortunes, writes Dan Nowicki of The Arizona Republic. Now he gets to run as the underdog again.

The Wall Street Journal editorial page says this month's F.B.I. raids of the home of Rep. John Doolittle of California and the family business of Arizona Rep. Rick Renzi, both Republicans, are "the residue of the G.O.P.'s lost, arrogant Congressional majority [$], which allowed its principles to atrophy. If the Republicans hope to retake Congress in 2008, they'd do well to eliminate the habits that created these scandals in the first place."
By a "statistical hair," Google passed Microsoft as the world's most visited family of sites last month, according to data from comScore.
Stash those guests, and then stash away the extra beds.
Orders for American-made durable goods rose by 3.4 percent, and businesses continued to invest in expansion.
Modernism to go, Ikea for the post-collegiate crowd, a sale on woven cotton rugs in classic American patterns and more.

Goldman Sachs is in talks to buy a South Korean asset management firm whose biggest owner is Australia's Macquarie Bank, Reuters reported Wednesday citing sources it did not identify. Goldman wants to buy Macquarie-IMM Investment Management, in which the Australian investment bank controls 65 percent, with the Korean investment firm IMM owning the remainder.

Merrill Lynch will invest $3 billion in Resona, providing the Japanese bank with additional cash to repay debt from a previous state bailout. The investment will be in the form of preferred shares of Resona convertible into common stock.

Locked in a proxy fight with its biggest shareholder, a French car parts maker, Valeo said it was open to offers by several private equity firms, Reuters reported. Valeo said a request for eight board seats from Pardus Capital Management, an investment company in New York, was "excessive," but the company's executive chairman, Thierry Morin, said the firm will continue talks with the company.

Shares of J Sainsbury, one of Britain's largest supermarket companies, jumped after a 1.4 billion pound ($2.8 billion) block of stock was acquired, spurring speculation an investor is targeting the company or its real estate, Bloomberg News reported.

If ABN Amro and Barclays seal their $91 billion merger pact, the newly formed behemoth will be making a big push into Asia, following a stream of Wall Street investment banks which have headed aggressively into India and into smaller Asian markets like Vietnam while bolstering their operations in China.

Photobucket, an online photo and media sharing web site that is reportedly exploring a sale of itself, has apparently ended a spat with the News Corporation's social networking site MySpace. And the maneuver may drive up the company's price-tag.

An Internet ad firm 24/7 Real Media is on the auction block and has already been talking to Martin Sorrell's WPP Group, the world's second-largest ad company, among other potential suitors, The New York Post reported.

Wealthy investors say they are no better than anyone else at finding the world's best hedge funds, those loosely regulated portfolios that can enrich the people who run them and those who invest in them. Three out of four wealthy investors polled by U.S. Trust, a company that has served high net-worth families for more than 150 years, said hedge funds are difficult to investigate and that it is difficult to find a good fund.
Business Wi-Fi startup Meru Networks will test Wall Street's recent finicky appetite for telecom stock when it files for an initial public offering perhaps later this year, the Red Herring reports.

CastTV, a Web video search start-up backed by the Netscape co-founder Marc Andreessen, has scored a $3.1 million round of funding led by Draper Fisher Jurvetson. CastTV, which has not started its service yet, also said it had signed a two-year deal with a "major media" company it did not name to power its online search.

Cinemark Holdings, the theater chain, failed to wow the critics in its first day of trading Tuesday following its $532 million initial public offering. The company, backed by the buyout shop Madison Dearborn Partners, sold 28 million shares at $19 a share, the top end of its expected price range. But the stock drifted after the debut, trading down as much as 6 percent during the day, to close flat at $18.91.

Goldman Sachs's private equity arm, Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, agreed to buy a polymer products maker, Myers Industries for about $1.07 billion, including debt, Myers said Tuesday. Goldman is paying $22.50 per Myers share, a 5 percent premium over Myers' closing price Monday, valuing the company at about $790 million. The deal also includes about $276 million in debt.

Nine months after canceling a proposed public offering, a radio frequency identification systems developer, Alien Technology, has returned to its existing stakeholders for a new $33 million round of venture funding.

Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, which is trying to outmaneuver a rival to buy the Chicago Board of Trade, said first-quarter earnings climbed 42 percent, as trading volume at the futures exchange continued to set records. Net income was $130 million, or $3.69 a share, up from $91.4 million, or $2.61 a share.

The student loan provider Sallie Mae, which last week agreed to a $25 billion buyout, said Tuesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating trading in its stock by at least two members of its board of directors.

OceanFreight, a Greek shipping company, raised about $200 million in its initial public offering on the Nasdaq. It said part of the proceeeds would go toward the acquisition of seven drybulk carriers.

Federal securities regulators said Tuesday that they would bring no civil charges against Apple over the backdating of executive stock options. But they stopped short of removing the cloud that for nearly a year has hung over the company's chief executive, Steven P. Jobs.

The showdown between the Democratic-controlled Congress and the Bush administration over the emergency war spending bill is front and center again, as top-ranking Republicans like Vice President Dick Cheney seized the moment to denounce Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, and he replied in kind.

In a deal that tosses sports equipment into its bulging locker of products, Jarden will acquire K2, the maker of K2 skis and Rawlings baseball gloves and bats, for about $1.2 billion in cash and stock, the two companies announced Wednesday.

JPMorgan Chase is threatening to move thousands of employees from Midtown to Stamford, Conn., if New York officials do not give it a larger subsidy package to build a 50-story skyscraper near ground zero, The New York Times reported.

Ocean Power Technologies, which develops systems that generate electricity through the energy of ocean waves, raised about $100 million in its first stock listing in the United States. The New Jersey-based company said Wednesday it sold 5 million shares, to be listed on the Nasdaq, at $20 each. Shares of Ocean Power already traded on the AIM market of the London Stock Exchange.

ABN Amro, the Dutch financial services group, was at the center of one of the priciest bidding wars in history Wednesday, when a group including the Royal Bank of Scotland offered 72.3 billion euros ($98.1 billion) for the bank, in hopes of trumping a bid from Barclays of Britain.

Klaus Kleinfeld's future as the chief executive of Siemens, the scandal-ridden engineering giant, was left hanging Tuesday as the company's supervisory board wavered over the extension of his contract.

For years, sex discrimination lawsuits against Wall Street firms were almost guaranteed to include details of crude antics, pornography and strip clubs. A bias settlement announced yesterday had no such lurid accusations, but sought to tackle a subtler, if arguably systemic, form of discrimination that has long troubled Wall Street.
Council Election in Brooklyn: "We have made history today. The road we have traveled has not been an easy one. But we never quit." -- Dr. Mathieu Eugene, after winning his second special election.
The new design element of the season? It's the antler, naturally.
Inside the new exhibition space at the Skirball Cultural Center in Los Angeles, which is really a children’s museum that takes the form of Noah’s Ark.
The United States plans to spend $3.4 billion this fiscal year on army and police units in Afghanistan, but questions about their readiness linger.
For decades, women have crisscrossed grassy fields in Hobbit-size versions of men’s shoes. No more.
Stripes: a little uptown prep, a little downtown slacker.
A weekend in search of the tranquil, laid-back Key West of yesterday.
For design-conscious Manhattanites who couldn’t make it to Milan for the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the contemporary furniture fair, there is always Manhattan.

Keyshawn Johnson will be at the National Football League draft Saturday as a television analyst, but he may be able to offer some historical perspective as well. Johnson, the Carolina Panthers receiver, was the last receiver to be selected with the first pick over all, by the Jets in 1996. He and Irving Fryar were the only receivers drafted first over all since 1970.

With their eyes on green-minded voters, European politicians are among the people clamoring the loudest for efforts to combat global warming. That makes it all the more surprising that the European Parliament might be one of the world's most polluting elected bodies.
“Zoo” is, to a large extent, about the rhetorical uses of beauty.  It is, rather more coyly, also about a man who died after having sex with a stallion.
The surfaces gleam as luxuriously in Johnnie To’s exemplary gangster thriller “Triad Election” as those in a similarly slicked-up Hollywood film, but the blood on the floor here seems stickier.
“Election,” the first installment in Johnnie To’s two-film Hong Kong gangland serial, is a densely plotted, pulpy procedural.
“The Collector,” a documentary about influential New York art gallery owner Allan Stone, is fascinating for its nonstop parade of significant 20th-century art.
Green has not yet replaced red or white as the most important color in deciding which wines to buy, but people have started to think about it.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer plans to introduce legislation shoring up a woman’s right to an abortion in New York State.
New York State’s attorney general said that criminal charges might result from his months-long investigation of ties between universities and the student loan industry.
The police surrounded a house in the Catskill Mountains in search of a man suspected of killing a state trooper.
François Bayrou then appeared to give an opportunity to Ségolène Royal, the Socialist candidate, to win his support.
There was no indication of why Seung Hui Cho went on what is the worst shooting massacre in American history.
The influx of Hispanic immigrants to the U.S. is transforming the nation’s religious landscape, study finds.
The Republican candidate stressed his experience as he sought to revive his struggling ’08 campaign.
Severe thunderstorms continued to move across the nation’s southern midsection today after an apparent tornado killed seven people on Tuesday evening along Texas-Mexico border.
Democrats on Capitol Hill issued a flurry of  subpoenas to fuel a series of investigations of the Bush administration.
The approval of the measure would set the stage for the first veto fight between President Bush and majority Democrats.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine could be released from Cooper University Hospital in Camden as soon as Monday.
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe wants to limit his exposure to uncomfortable questions about his views on Japan’s conduct during World War II.
ABC News announced today that it had failed to reach a contract extension with Rosie O’Donnell.
The rush hour turned nasty this morning for tens of thousands of commuters in Connecticut.
The somber funeral service was attended by Russia’s political elite and current and former world leaders.
North Korea celebrated the 75th birthday of its People’s Army today in the shadow of its nuclear standoff with the U.S.
Britain’s top counterterrorism official, Peter Clarke, said today that Al Qaeda has survived and is planning attacks.
Royal Bank of Scotland and two other European lenders today trumped a recommended offer made by Barclays.

A transit worker was accidentally killed by a train in the Columbus Circle station in Manhattan late last night, the police said. The worker, whose identity had not been released, was hit around 11:25 p.m. and declared dead at the scene. Trains were stopped for at least half an hour while investigators were at the scene. It was not immediately clear why the worker was on the track, the police said.
Luol Deng scored 14 of his 26 points in the final quarter, lifting Chicago to a thunderous victory to seize a 2-0 lead in the best-of-seven games series.
In a highly unusual second special election Tuesday to fill a vacant City Council seat in central Brooklyn, Mathieu Eugene was once again the winner.
Endy Chávez’s bunt single scored Shawn Green with the winning run in the 12th inning as the Mets defeated the Colorado Rockies Tuesday night.
On Tuesday night’s Charlie Rose show, President Bush spoke forcefully and at length about Iraq.
Chien-Ming Wang pitched well in his return, but Alex Rodriguez ended his hitting streak and Derek Jeter left the game after being hit with a pitch as the Yankees fell to last place in the division.
Japan’s trade surplus rose more than expected in March from a year earlier as exports climbed despite a slowdown in the U.S. economy.
In front of a raucous home crowd, the third-seeded Raptors showed more poise than the veteran-laden Nets when the game was on the line.

A sports article in some copies on Monday about Boston’s 7-6 victory over the Yankees referred incorrectly to Derek Jeter’s hitting, and referred imprecisely to a home run by Manny Ramírez as part of a third-inning string of four consecutive homers by Red Sox batters. Jeter’s fifth-inning home run gave him at least one hit in 52 of his last 54 regular-season games in which he had an official at-bat — not 53 of 55 games. And the home run by Ramírez went out of Fenway Park, not high into the Green Monster seats.

A front-page article on Monday about an increase in debate requests for presidential candidates referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing of a debate promoted by advocates for the homeless. The debate has been proposed for January 2008 during the 11th Annual Homelessness Marathon, a nationwide radio broadcast originating in San Francisco. The advocates did not propose it for this past February in Fresno, Calif., during the 10th marathon broadcast.

A picture caption last Wednesday with a music review of Sequitur, at Merkin Concert Hall, included outdated program information about the violinist shown. She was Miranda Cuckson — not Andrea Schultz, another Sequitur violinist.
Corrections: For the Record

An article in The Arts yesterday about a new documentary on the photography collector Sam Wagstaff misstated the name of the museum that was charged with obscenity in 1990 when it showed work by Robert Mapplethorpe, Mr. Wagstaff’s protégé and lover. It was the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati — not the Cincinnati Museum of Art.

The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday, about a campaign by Sharp Electronics to teach homeowners about solar energy, referred imprecisely to the company’s agreement with the Google search engine. Sharp pays to appear high on the list of advertisements on Google search pages, not at the top of the search results.

An obituary yesterday about Boris N. Yeltsin, the former Russian leader, referred incorrectly to Anatoly B. Chubais, who along with Mr. Yeltsin’s daughter Tatiana had persuaded Mr. Yeltsin not to outlaw the Communist Party, as Mr. Yeltsin later revealed in his memoir “Midnight Diaries.” Mr. Chubais was a former deputy prime minister, not a former prime minister.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the New England Journal of Medicine’s response to a possible breach of confidentiality by a medical researcher, Dr. Martin B. Leon, misidentified the online news wire that first reported the matter. It was heartwire (www.theheart.org), not heartline. The article also included incorrect information from theheart.org about the role of Dr. Leon in its report. While Dr. Leon was initially cited as the report’s only source for the Journal’s action, heartwire said Monday that an unidentified individual had provided details that were later confirmed by Dr. Leon.

A sports article in some copies on Monday about Manager Terry Francona’s power of suggestion in helping the Red Sox batters succeed in Sunday night’s game against the Yankees, referred imprecisely to a home run hit by Mike Lowell in the third-inning. The ball left Fenway Park; it did not land in the Green Monster seats.

An article on Friday about the massacre at Virginia Tech included erroneous information from a law enforcement official about the origin of chains the gunman, Seung-Hui Cho, used to secure doors in a classroom building where most of the killings took place. (The error was repeated in a front-page article on Sunday about Mr. Cho’s life.) Although officials now say the chains were not bought at Home Depot, they have declined to say where the chains were obtained.

An article in The Arts on Monday about the success Ashton Kutcher and Jason Goldberg have had with their Katalyst Films production company referred incorrectly to the assets of Merv Griffin, another successful producer to whom Mr. Kutcher was compared in the article. Although Mr. Griffin did indeed once own the Beverly Hilton hotel, he sold it in 2003.

A front-page article on Sunday about an increase in the infant death rate in some Southern states misstated the given name of an obstetrician at the Mississippi Department of Health who said officials could not yet explain the rise in the rate in that state. He is Dr. LeDon Langston, not William.
The tale of the outdoor art installation “The Wall” spans more than a third of a century, 10 years of it in litigation.

NEWARK, April 24 — The girl, identified in a lawsuit as S. A., is 8 now, with a loving adoptive mother. But throughout most of her life, the people who were supposed to protect her failed to do so, according to the suit filed on Tuesday against New Jersey’s child welfare agency.

TROY, N.Y., April 24 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer traveled Tuesday to the district of the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, on the first stop of a statewide tour to blast Senate Republicans for scuttling his plan to overhaul campaign finance regulations.
The conclusions by the Justice Department are the latest round of criticism about diversity issues in the New York City Fire Department, which is about 90 percent white and 99 percent male.
The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission ruled unanimously Tuesday that the New-York Historical Society can renovate the exterior of its landmark building.
Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $46 million to settle a suit by female brokers who said they were discriminated against in how they were trained, promoted and paid.
Regulators said they would bring no civil charges against Apple over the backdating of executive stock options.

GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 24 — A former church youth director who confessed in 2003 to the statutory rape of four teenagers took the witness stand on Tuesday in a civil trial, but the two victims who are suing him were not present. They had left the courtroom here earlier, saying they could not bear to see him again.
Warren E. Avis was a Michigan car dealership owner who founded a chain of car rental agencies and turned it into the nation’s second biggest.
The president and vice president accused Democrats of political opportunism in pushing a timetable for leaving Iraq.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission proposed that designers be required to analyze how their reactors can be built to mitigate the effects of a suicide attacks by big airplanes rather than withstand them.
Eli Broad and Bill Gates are joining forces for a $60 million foray into politics in an effort to vault education high onto the agenda of the 2008 presidential race.
Sara Martinez Tucker, the under secretary of education, worked for student lenders before she worked for the department of education.
A top manager at the World Bank said the furor over Paul D. Wolfowitz was the biggest crisis in the bank’s history.
The news that Toyota is now the world’s largest carmaker was met in Detroit with anger and a sense of resignation.
Opportunists who profit from chaos are trying to help bring down the transitional government.
Walter Thomas is a 370-pound defensive tackle with surprising athleticism and his own hip-hop group, but a questionable past.
JPMorgan Chase is threatening to move thousands of employees from Midtown to Connecticut if New York officials do not give it a larger subsidy package to build near ground zero.
cycling.
A Justice Department agency will investigate whether the White House has improperly tried to use government agencies for political purposes, its spokesman said.
The vote sets the stage for court battles and social clashes between Mexico’s religious conservatives and liberals.
Harold Max Mayer was the former chairman of Oscar Mayer who helped oversee the company’s sale in 1981.
The Mets addressed last season’s woes against left-handers by signing Moises Alou to balance the lineup. Alou has done his part, but his success is only a small part of the team’s improvement.

A Manhattan judge ruled yesterday that three days of statements made by Peter Braunstein, a fashion writer accused of sexually molesting a former colleague at a fashion publication, should be excluded from his criminal trial.
Turkey’s ruling party chose a presidential candidate with an Islamic background, focusing secular Turks’ worries.

The Supreme Judicial Council, the five judges conducting an inquiry into misconduct allegations against Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, the chief justice suspended by President Pervez Musharraf last month, again put off a hearing on the case, this time until Monday. Earlier, the Supreme Court adjourned a hearing on Mr. Chaudhry’s complaint of bias on the part of some of the council judges. Mr. Chaudhry wants his old court to hear the case against him, but the justice handling the petition said he could not decide on it because he had supported Mr. Chaudhry’s suspension. He called for a broader panel.
For the past two seasons, Tom Renney has tackled the job of coaching the Rangers with earnestness, dogged preparation and a great deal of composure.

An air raid by Tamil separatist rebels on a government military base on the northern Jaffna peninsula killed at least six soldiers and wounded 13 others. The military said it averted a larger attack on the base, at Palaly, by firing at the oncoming aircraft. The rebels unveiled their aerial capacity for the first time last month, when they bombed a military base outside the capital, Colombo, and killed three soldiers.

Lady Butler-Sloss, left, the judge presiding over the long-delayed inquest into the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, said she would withdraw in June because “I do not have the degree of experience of jury cases that I feel is necessary.” Last month, the High Court ruled that a regular jury of 12 members of the public would hear the inquest to determine the exact cause of death of Diana and her companion, Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, known as Dodi. Lady Butler-Sloss wanted to handle it on her own. She will be replaced by one of Britain’s most senior judges, Lord Justice Scott Baker. He will have to wade through thousands of pages of documentation to familiarize himself with the case and will take up the job in June, three months before the 10th anniversary of Diana’s death.

The suspect in the killing of Julia Campbell, the Peace Corps volunteer found buried in a shallow grave a week ago in northern Ifugao Province, has continued to evade the authorities, the police said. They identified him as Juan Dontugan, 25, a woodcarver whose wife is the owner of a store where Ms. Campbell was last seen alive. Ms. Campbell, 40, a former freelance reporter in New York who contributed to The New York Times in the 1990s and joined the Corps in 2005, disappeared on April 8 while hiking alone. The police said over the weekend that she had been beaten to death and that robbery was the most likely motive.

The State House and Senate approved resolutions apologizing for slavery. The House passed its resolution on an unrecorded voice vote, and the Senate vote was 22 to 7. The House earlier voted 46 to 41 to table an amendment that sought to change the apology to an expression of regret. Gov. Bob Riley, a Republican, is expected to sign one of the resolutions. Legislatures in Virginia, Maryland and North Carolina have approved similar slavery apologies this year.
An elementary school in Southlake was evacuated for more than an hour after a fourth grader showed up with a hand grenade, the authorities said.
A legislative task force has decided to leave two controversial mural panels on display in a historic county courthouse that is scheduled to play host to the 2008 Legislature.
The administrator of the E.P.A. refused to tell a Senate committee how soon he would comply with a Supreme Court ruling on the regulation of carbon dioxide emissions from motor vehicles.
Representative Rick Renzi, Republican of Arizona, temporarily stepped down from two more House committees in the wake of the F.B.I.’s raid on his wife’s insurance business.
The State House approved a measure that would require voters to show more proof of identification at the polls.
Vice President Dick Cheney returned to work after an ultrasound exam showed that a blood clot in his leg was gradually improving, his office said.
The police arrested a man in Tampa who had picked up a dead alligator and tried to butcher it on his front lawn on Sunday.
A Canadian detained in Afghanistan and held at Guantánamo Bay since 2002 was charged with murder.
The Supreme Court hears arguments Wednesday in a case that could determine whether a major new leak opens up in the campaign finance system.
Many Rangers fans will not be able to watch Game 1 against the Buffalo Sabres because it will be seen only on Versus, which has far fewer homes in the New York market compared with MSG.
In the drought that began in 2000 across much of the West, 2007 is promising no relief: better than some years, but with no clear turning of the corner, either.
Officials said the riot began after a group of prisoners took off their shirts in the recreation area to show staff that they would not comply with orders to keep them on.
New York State would more closely scrutinize its use of solitary confinement for mentally ill prison inmates under the proposed terms of a legal agreement.
The shake-up at the top of his financial apparatus follows the disclosure that Senator John McCain has raised less money for his presidential campaign than the party’s two other leading candidates.
Michigan’s largest commercial landlord is offering free space as an incentive to attract business into the economically challenged state.
The antipoverty strategy, which would cost the government $90 billion a year, would cut the number of people living in poverty in half within a decade, a liberal research group says.
Known for their speed on the ice, the Buffalo Sabres have chosen to take a more cautious approach off it in a budding war of words with the Rangers.
First-quarter earnings rose 17 percent because of higher sales at its technology unit and one-time gains.
Phil Hughes threw a bullpen session in Scranton on Tuesday and will be in New York on Wednesday to prepare for his first Yankees’ start Thursday night.
An antipoverty program in Mexico is the model for one that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wants to start in New York City.
President Bush traveled to Harlem to seek common cause with the rival party, on its home turf, on his signature education initiative, “No Child Left Behind.”
The severity of the attack seemed to unnerve Ethiopian officials, who usually minimize threats to their control.
A $110 million settlement between Warner Music and Bertelsmann resolves claims that Bertelsmann had contributed to widespread copyright infringement.
House Democrats burrowed into the histories of Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch and Cpl. Pat Tillman in a hearing, holding up the episodes as egregious examples of officials twisting the truth.
The earnings show the potential for growth but also the steep challenges facing AT&T and other telephone companies.
Job cuts in Europe and the U.S. may be offset by growth in Asia if Barclays and ABN Amro complete their nearly $91 billion deal.
China announced new regulations to grant citizens greater access to official information, but questions about government openness remain.
Skybus Airlines, a start-up based in Columbus, Ohio, that promises some $10 seats on every flight, will begin service on May 22.
The Jarden Corporation will acquire K2, the maker of K2 skis and Rawlings baseball gloves and bats, for about $1.2 billion.
The Pepsi Bottling Group said that quarterly profit fell nearly 15 percent on higher raw material costs.
Amnesty International has taken up the issue of sexual assault cases involving Indians, calling on Congress to extend tribal authority to all offenders on Indian land.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and an Italian billionaire won the takeover battle in Europe’s biggest private equity buyout.

TRENTON, April 24 — With 24 years on the job as chief of police in Clayton, N.J., Norman Frank Winters was already the stuff of local legend with his work promoting drug education and planning alcohol-free after-prom and after-graduation events for schools.

The Newark Municipal Council yesterday unanimously approved a $720 million budget for 2007, making it one of the first in two decades to be passed on time and without a tax increase. Although the city is facing a $180 million shortfall next year, Mayor Cory A. Booker said he did not want to increase property taxes, which rose 8.3 percent last year, or about $322 for the average homeowner. The city actually cut the municipal tax levy this year by 7.8 percent to offset an increase in county and school taxes. To plug the looming deficit in 2008, Mr. Booker has been warning residents that he may have to cut services, reduce the municipal payroll and raise property taxes.
Rutgers University officials said they would attempt to register the mobile phone numbers of their student and faculty so they can receive alert messages during an emergency.

Officials and city residents yesterday criticized a proposed 11.5 percent increase in city water and sewer bills. In the first of five public hearings scheduled to take place over three days, speakers told the New York City Water Board, which sets the rates for the city, that the increase would hurt working families, especially those on fixed incomes. “The senior citizens are going to be in trouble,” Nancy DiCroce, 76, of Howard Beach, said at the meeting, which was held at the city’s Department of Environmental Protection office in Flushing. The increase, which would go into effect in July, would add $72 to the average annual water and sewer bill for a single-family home in the city, bringing the average bill to $699. The department’s deputy commissioner, Anne Canty, said she hoped that the increase would not be too much of a burden but was “what the system really needs right now.”.

The death of a 5-year-old girl who was found hanged on Sunday in her Eastchester apartment has been ruled accidental by the city medical examiner, a spokeswoman said yesterday. The spokeswoman, Ellen Borakove, said the girl, Monet Fulgham, had accidentally hanged herself with a jump-rope. Ms. Borakove said the investigation showed that Monet “was playing with a jump-rope that was attached to a closet door.”.

Environmentalists are praising a package of measures announced by the State Department of Environmental Protection that would restrict development near hundreds of miles of rivers and streams in a move to protect water quality. The measures, announced on Monday by Lisa P. Jackson, the state environmental commissioner, would limit development within a 300-foot area along 15 major waterways in New Jersey. Those slated for protection include the Toms River in Ocean County, the Pompeston Creek in Burlington County, the Wallkill River in Sussex County, and the Salem River in Salem County.
Tonya Antonucci, an executive at Yahoo, has worked, with financial support from U.S. Soccer and the United States Soccer Foundation, to start a women’s professional league.

The state filed a lawsuit yesterday against contractors involved in the widening of Interstate 84 in the Waterbury area, saying the job was botched. The lawsuit, filed in State Superior Court, names L. G. DeFelice Inc., a New Haven construction contractor; Maguire Group of New Britain, hired to oversee the project; individual Maguire inspectors; and officials from both firms. DeFelice went out of business after last year’s construction season, citing financial problems. The Maguire Group did not respond yesterday to a message seeking comment. Last month, the insurance company that guaranteed DeFelice’s work on the widening project agreed to pay the state $17.5 million. The payment from the insurer will allow the state to begin repairing hundreds of storm drains along a three-mile stretch of highway between Cheshire and Waterbury. Many of the drains lead nowhere, some are clogged with debris and others were apparently connected with cracked and leaking pipes. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Lynne F. Stewart, left, the lawyer who was convicted on federal charges of helping an imprisoned terrorist leader communicate with his disciples, was disbarred yesterday in New York State. The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, which acts on recommendations of its disciplinary committee, said Ms. Stewart became subject to losing her law license immediately upon being convicted of a felony in Federal District Court on Feb. 10, 2005. Ms. Stewart, who was convicted of conspiracy to defraud the government and making false statements, was sentenced in October to 28 months in prison. She has appealed her conviction.

Justice Marilyn Shafer of State Supreme Court yesterday struck down the Tenant Empowerment Act, a 2005 New York City law giving tenants in subsidized rental buildings the right of first refusal to buy their buildings if the owners decide to sell or quit rental assistance programs like Mitchell-Lama. Justice Shafer said she “reluctantly” concluded that the city cannot limit rights granted to building owners by the State Legislature in allowing them to withdraw from Mitchell-Lama. The Legislature itself could choose to protect middle- and low-income tenants in those buildings, she pointed out. “In failing to do so, or to permit the City of New York to do so, the State Legislature has failed the residents of the City of New York,” she wrote in her opinion.

(Fox) AMERICAN IDOL When the six finalists return to hear their fates after last night’s vote, they will be surrounded by some established winners — of Oscars, Golden Globes, Emmys and Grammys, no less — in a two-hour “Idol” that concludes a two-night charity drive. A sports article in some copies on Monday about Boston's 7-6 victory over the Yankees referred incorrectly to Derek Jeter's hitting, and referred imprecisely to a home run by Manny Ramírez as part of a third-inning string of four consecutive homers by Red Sox batters. Jeter's fifth-inning home run gave him at least one hit in 52 of his last 54 regular-season games in which he had an official at-bat -- not 53 of 55 games. And the home run by Ramírez went out of Fenway Park, not high into the Green Monster seats.

NBC's receipt of the so-called multimedia manifesto from the suspect in the Virginia Tech shootings helped make ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' the most-watched of the three network evening newscasts last week, according to figures released yesterday by Nielsen Media Research. Mr. Williams's broadcast was watched by an estimated 8.57 million viewers each night last week, according to Nielsen, about 90,000 more than watched ''World News With Charles Gibson'' on ABC and about two million more than tuned in the ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric.'' JACQUES STEINBERG

The Newark Municipal Council yesterday unanimously approved a $720 million budget for 2007, making it one of the first in two decades to be passed on time and without a tax increase. Although the city is facing a $180 million shortfall next year, Mayor Cory A. Booker said he did not want to increase property taxes, which rose 8.3 percent last year, or about $322 for the average homeowner. The city actually cut the municipal tax levy this year by 7.8 percent to offset an increase in county and school taxes. To plug the looming deficit in 2008, Mr. Booker has been warning residents that he may have to cut services, reduce the municipal payroll and raise property taxes. ANDREW JACOBS

An article in The Arts yesterday about a new documentary on the photography collector Sam Wagstaff misstated the name of the museum that was charged with obscenity in 1990 when it showed work by Robert Mapplethorpe, Mr. Wagstaff's protégé and lover. It was the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati -- not the Cincinnati Museum of Art.

BUTKIN--Bernice The Sepkowitz family notes with profound sadness the recent death of our friend and touchstone, Bernice Butkin, a closet New Yorker for almost 80 years. She was sanity personified for us and countless other stragglers who sought her counsel across the many decades. To sit on the leather couch in her air conditioned Oklahoma City living room was to see adulthood as a worthy destination and one that might even be fun. She was equal parts Sigmund Freud and Dinah Shore and gently nosy neighbor. Gossip was never and will never again feel so vital and pleasantly mischievous. Her single-minded dedication to her family and to the idea of family will continue to guide us all. Ah, Bernice, thank you so much and please do rest in peace. Julie, Doug, Kent, Warren Sepkowitz and families

To the Editor: Re ''Word by Word, the World Becomes a Little Less Mystifying for Illiterate Adults,'' by Joseph Berger (On Education column, April 18): The reasons for the dramatic growth in the number of students in special education classes are more complex than they appear. Failure to understand the causes undermines taxpayer support for neighborhood public schools at voting time.

HALBERSTAM--David. All of his neighbors and the staff at 27 W 67th St. are saddened by the untimely loss of our dear friend, David Halberstam. We will miss his grand presence, his unique personality, his cleverness, wit and intelligence. Our hearts, love and prayers go to Jean and Julia. Board of Directors, Neighbors and Staff, 27 West 67th St.
