Job cuts in Europe and the United States may be offset by growth in Asia if Barclays and ABN Amro complete their nearly $91 billion deal. The two banks plan to expand in Asia while moving or eliminating more than 23,000 jobs -- many in Europe and the United States -- and selling the LaSalle Bank, based in Chicago, to Bank of America. About half of those 23,000 jobs will be relocated, thousands of them to India.

To the Editor: Re ''Democrats Back Date for Start of Iraq Pullout'' (front page, April 24): President Bush argues: ''An artificial timetable of withdrawal would say to an enemy, 'Just wait them out.' It would say to the Iraqis, 'Don't do hard things necessary to achieve our objectives,' and it would be discouraging for our troops.''

Lincoln Center named a new executive director of its development project yesterday. Beginning May 8, Ron Austin, a construction management specialist, will oversee the transformation of the campus, currently under way. Mr. Austin replaces Jerry Hastings, who resigned last month after less than a year in the job. As president of Vital Management Solutions, Mr. Austin has handled projects including the completion of construction on the Carnival Center for the Performing Arts in Miami. ROBIN POGREBIN
Correction from my last column: H.I.V.-AIDS kills more people in Africa than malaria.

Many Rangers fans will not be able to watch Game 1 of the Eastern Conference semifinals against the Buffalo Sabres tonight because it will be seen only on Versus, which is available in far fewer homes in the New York market than MSG is. About 3 million local cable households receive Versus compared with 5.5 million who get MSG, according to both networks. The figures exclude each networks' satellite availability on DirecTV and Dish.

KATZ--Jerome. On April 24, 2007. Beloved husband of the late Florence, cherished father of Alan and Joyce and Susan and Seth Truwit. Adored ''Pops'' of Marjorie, Brittany, Alison, Elana, Noah, and Jillian. His kindness, wisdom and wit will always be remembered. ''The Room would be quiet and Jerry would be a riot''. Graveside services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, on Wednesday, April 25, 2007, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

A front-page article on Monday about an increase in debate requests for presidential candidates referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing of a debate promoted by advocates for the homeless. The debate has been proposed for January 2008 during the 11th Annual Homelessness Marathon, a nationwide radio broadcast originating in San Francisco. The advocates did not propose it for this past February in Fresno, Calif., during the 10th marathon broadcast.

An air raid by Tamil separatist rebels on a government military base on the northern Jaffna peninsula killed at least six soldiers and wounded 13 others. The military said it averted a larger attack on the base, at Palaly, by firing at the oncoming aircraft. The rebels unveiled their aerial capacity for the first time last month, when they bombed a military base outside the capital, Colombo, and killed three soldiers. ANTHONY DAVID

The place: Grand Hyatt Hotel, East 42nd Street. The time: nearing the deadline for first-quarter political fund-raising. The reason: Senator Barack Obama. A crowd gathered early for a $100-a-person chance to see Mr. Obama and hear him talk about his presidential campaign. More than 2,000 people ultimately bought tickets for this, his second fund-raising event of the night, and it quickly sold out, forcing some potential supporters to turn to Craigslist.

An obituary yesterday about Boris N. Yeltsin, the former Russian leader, referred incorrectly to Anatoly B. Chubais, who along with Mr. Yeltsin's daughter Tatiana had persuaded Mr. Yeltsin not to outlaw the Communist Party, as Mr. Yeltsin later revealed in his memoir ''Midnight Diaries.'' Mr. Chubais was a former deputy prime minister, not a former prime minister.

American history seen through a beer mug is the subject of a new film, ''The American Brew,'' produced by Florentine Films-Sherman Pictures. It begins in colonial days, when beer was safer to drink than water. It highlights the heyday of German immigration 100 or so years ago and the subsequent rise of industrialized beer plants in Milwaukee and other cities, and continues to the current craft-brewing movement. The film is enlivened by old advertising images like those above, below and left.

ACKERMAN--Dr. Martin P. The Board of Governors, Members and Staff of Elmwood Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member and friend, Dr. Martin P. Ackerman. We wish to express our deepest sympathies to his family.

Sheila Lukins and Julee Rosso, the founders of Silver Palate, collaborated on a groundbreaking, bestselling cookbook in 1982. A few years later they had a falling out, the reasons for which have faded. In the intervening years, Ms. Lukins, right below, wrote other cookbooks and Ms. Rosso, left below, moved to Michigan and opened an inn. Now, they are celebrating the 25th anniversary of ''The Silver Palate Cookbook,'' and the 30th anniversary of the opening of their little store on Columbus Avenue. (Disclosure: the name of the store and the company it spawned was coined by this writer on the spur of the moment and without any monetary compensation.)

Family will receive friends on Wednesday, 79pm, and Thursday, 2-5 and 79 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10am, at St. John the Evangelist R.C. Church, First Ave at 55 St. Interment to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York.

Justice Shafer said she ''reluctantly'' concluded that the city cannot limit rights granted to building owners by the State Legislature in allowing them to withdraw from Mitchell-Lama. The Legislature itself could choose to protect middle- and low-income tenants in those buildings, she pointed out. ''In failing to do so, or to permit the City of New York to do so, the State Legislature has failed the residents of the City of New York,'' she wrote in her opinion. JANNY SCOTT

Joe Mizrahi has cooked pulled pork, brisket and barbecued chicken at his Staten Island catering company, Smokin' Joe's True-Blue Texas Barbecue, for several years (smokinjoesbbq.com). Now he is taking his food to the Tribeca Tavern, 247 West Broadway (Walker Street), where sandwiches ($7 to $8) and platters ($9 to $10) with potato salad, coleslaw and plenty of sass, will be served at lunchtime on Fridays and Saturdays during the TriBeCa Film Festival, which starts today and runs until May 6. Mr. Mizrahi said the Friday barbecue lunches and perhaps the Saturday ones will be available all summer.
FEINBERG--Sidney. Steadfast and loyal, always there for his friends. We miss him so and will never forget. Barbara Wainscott

When the Yankees called Phil Hughes on Monday to tell him he was going to the major leagues, Hughes was in a mall eating lunch with his teammates. He did not feel his cellphone vibrate. So Dave Eiland, the pitching coach for Class AAA Scranton-Wilkes-Barre, called Hughes's friend Tyler Clippard, a pitcher who was eating with Hughes, and Clippard handed him the phone. That was how Hughes got the only call to the big leagues he expects to receive.

Mother of Otile E. McManus of Milton, MA, the late Carol E. McManus, and Julie M. O'Rourke of Pelham, NY. Grandmother of Julia, Maggie, Aidan, Nell and Desmond. Mother - in - law of Robert L. Turner of Milton, and the late Thomas A. O'Rourke. Sister of the late Julia K. Hickey. Funeral Thursday in Boston. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY, Saturday, April 28. Meet at office at 11:45am. Donations may be sent to The Miriam Boyd Parlin Residence, Wayside Hospice, 266 Cochituate Rd., Wayland, MA 01778. Visit: www.ccgfuneralhome.com for complete obituary.
Re ''With Button Ignition, Car Keys Could Go the Way of Tail Fins'' (front page, April 14): The other day, the remote control door opener to my 2000 model car failed.

President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney aggressively challenged the motives of Congressional Democrats on Tuesday, as the House and Senate prepared to consider a war spending bill that would order troops to be withdrawn from Iraq beginning later this year. In separate appearances that served as a prelude to an inevitable veto showdown, Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney accused Democrats of political opportunism in forging ahead with a $124 billion measure that sets a timetable for leaving Iraq.

The Supreme Judicial Council, the five judges conducting an inquiry into misconduct allegations against Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, the chief justice suspended by President Pervez Musharraf last month, again put off a hearing on the case, this time until Monday. Earlier, the Supreme Court adjourned a hearing on Mr. Chaudhry's complaint of bias on the part of some of the council judges. Mr. Chaudhry wants his old court to hear the case against him, but the justice handling the petition said he could not decide on it because he had supported Mr. Chaudhry's suspension. He called for a broader panel. SALMAN MASOOD

GOODWIN--Francis X. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our cousin Frank, a treasured member of our family. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his brothers, Bob, Dick, and their families. The Kissane Family

Ethiopian Rebels Hit Oil Site Separatist rebels stormed a Chinese-run oil field in eastern Ethiopia, killing more than 70 people, including nine Chinese workers, in one of Ethiopia's worst rebel attacks in years. After a fierce hourlong battle, the attackers rushed away, taking at least six Chinese hostages with them. To the Editor: Re ''Obama, in Foreign Policy Speech, Urges U.S. Leadership'' (news article, April 24): In his foreign policy speech in Chicago on Monday, Senator Barack Obama clearly outlined his strategy for dealing with nuclear terrorism, which included a bold commitment to completely secure vulnerable nuclear material in the former Soviet Union within four years and a verifiable global ban on new fissile material.

A sports article in some copies on Monday about Manager Terry Francona's power of suggestion in helping the Red Sox batters succeed in Sunday night's game against the Yankees, referred imprecisely to a home run hit by Mike Lowell in the third-inning. The ball left Fenway Park; it did not land in the Green Monster seats.

LAURITA--Richard A. The members and employees of Geller Group, LLC, a member of Focus Financial Partners, wish to express their sorrow at the loss of Rich Laurita. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Rich, a giving, caring and fun loving colleague. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Krista, to his sister, Monica, and to his parents, Sharon and Tony.

An article in The Arts on Monday about the success Ashton Kutcher and Jason Goldberg have had with their Katalyst Films production company referred incorrectly to the assets of Merv Griffin, another successful producer to whom Mr. Kutcher was compared in the article. Although Mr. Griffin did indeed once own the Beverly Hilton hotel, he sold it in 2003.

A transit worker was accidentally killed by a train in the Columbus Circle station in Manhattan late last night, the police said. The worker, whose identity had not been released, was hit around 11:25 p.m. and declared dead at the scene. Trains were stopped for at least half an hour while investigators were at the scene. It was not immediately clear why the worker was on the track, the police said. JENNIFER 8. LEE

To the Editor: Re ''Gonzales's Testimony Satisfied at Least One Person, His Boss'' (front page, April 24): President Bush's reaction to Alberto R. Gonzales's Congressional testimony is yet another appalling and unfathomable position of this president.

Officials and city residents yesterday criticized a proposed 11.5 percent increase in city water and sewer bills. In the first of five public hearings scheduled to take place over three days, speakers told the New York City Water Board, which sets the rates for the city, that the increase would hurt working families, especially those on fixed incomes. ''The senior citizens are going to be in trouble,'' Nancy DiCroce, 76, of Howard Beach, said at the meeting, which was held at the city's Department of Environmental Protection office in Flushing. The increase, which would go into effect in July, would add $72 to the average annual water and sewer bill for a single-family home in the city, bringing the average bill to $699. The department's deputy commissioner, Anne Canty, said she hoped that the increase would not be too much of a burden but was ''what the system really needs right now.'' DARYL KHAN

CANTER--Lenore Engel, 70, died Sunday morning, April 22, 2007. Beloved mother of Sheryl Canter, Neil Canter, and Nina Canter Fresco, and adored grandmother of Maia, Chloe and Melina Canter, and David and Eli Fresco. Lenore was an extraordinary, gifted woman. She loved the theater and her native New York City, and touched hundreds of lives through her love, friendship, and work as an astrologer. She will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society. A memorial service will be held at The Village Temple, 33 East 12th St., New York City, on Sunday, May 20 at 11 am.

An article on Friday about the massacre at Virginia Tech included erroneous information from a law enforcement official about the origin of chains the gunman, Seung-Hui Cho, used to secure doors in a classroom building where most of the killings took place. (The error was repeated in a front-page article on Sunday about Mr. Cho's life.) Although officials now say the chains were not bought at Home Depot, they have declined to say where the chains were obtained.
SCHIFF--Charles. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Caroline on the passing of our friend, neighbor and longtime Board Member. The Tenants/Shareholders and Staff of 565 Park Avenue

KLAUS KLEINFELD'S FUTURE as the chief executive of Siemens, the scandal-ridden engineering giant, has been left hanging as the company's supervisory board wavers over the extension of his contract. G. THOMAS SIMS and MARK LANDLER

NOLL--S. Darwin, 86, passed away peacefully at his home in Palm Beach, FL, on April 23rd, 2007, after a long illness. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Evelyn, in 1992, and is survived by his devoted and cherished companion, Hazel Leichter Scott, a son, Ronald Noll, a daughter, Lauren Brenckle, five grandchildren, and his devoted cousin, Fred Mervis. A Cleveland industrialist and CEO of Cardinal American Corp, he was also founder of Production Experts, Inc., and numerous other successful companies, primarily in the steel industry; having built and operated steel mills in the United States, Europe and Japan. He was extremely charitable, and was awarded an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from John Carroll University of Cleveland where he sponsored and aided many, many students. Donations, in lieu of flowers, will be appreciated to the Darwin Noll Fund for Childrens Education at Temple-Tifereth Israel, 26000 Shaker Boulevard, Beachwood, Ohio 44122. Services for Mr. Noll will be private.

HITCHCOCK--Mari Watts, 97, prolific painter and muralist showed in London and America and had a retrospective of her work at the New Jersey State Museum. She left the earth from her home, on April 17, where she was surrounded by her three children. She was looking forward to her next adventure. Mother, grandmother, great grandmother and friend, Mari loved life with a passion and inspired people of all ages to live their dream. She was dearly loved by all who knew her. There will be a celebration of her life in October of 2007.
To the Editor: In '' 'Patient' Capital for an Africa That Can't Wait''(column, April 20), Thomas L. Friedman is spot-on in his diagnosis of Africa's poverty as rooted in a lack of capitalism.

A picture caption last Wednesday with a music review of Sequitur, at Merkin Concert Hall, included outdated program information about the violinist shown. She was Miranda Cuckson -- not Andrea Schultz, another Sequitur violinist.

An article on Friday about the massacre at Virginia Tech included erroneous information from a law enforcement official about the origin of chains the gunman, Seung-Hui Cho, used to secure doors in a classroom building where most of the killings took place. (The error was repeated in a front-page article on Sunday about Mr. Cho's life.) Although officials now say the chains were not bought at Home Depot, they have declined to say where the chains were obtained.

FRIEDSON--Dr. Bernard, 89, of Jerusalem, formerly of Saratoga Springs, NY, and Delray Beach, FL, passed away on April 24, 2007. A decorated veteran of WWII, he participated in the liberation of Dachau. Upon his return, he married the love of his life, Ruth Kopolsky. In addition to practicing medicine, he served on the Saratoga Board of Education and was an active philanthropist for Jewish causes. Dr. Friedson is survived by his beloved wife and his children, Arlene Saslow of Jerusalem; Michael (Felice) Friedson of Jerusalem; and Arthur S. Friedson of Chicago. The family can be contacted through friedsonfamily@yahoo.com.

To the Editor: Re ''Veal to Love, Without the Guilt'' (April 18): This article's claims of livestock reform are admirable, but I think we could be missing the point here. Even the headline suggests that we feel guilty only about the way these animals are raised, turning a blind eye to another very real horror: the killing and processing that follows.

Kryptonite, the one mineral that is deadly to Superman, the Man of Steel, was discovered, really, by a group of researchers in Serbia, according to a report by the BBC. In comic books, kryptonite comes in an assortment of colors and with different side effects. Overexposure to the green variety would kill Superman, whereas the gold kind would permanently strip him of his powers. The real-world researchers turned to Chris Stanley, a mineralogist at the Natural History Museum in London, for help in identifying a substance they found. Dr. Stanley's Web search found that the new mineral's chemistry matched the description of kryptonite's composition in last year's film ''Superman Returns.'' ''The universe is full of mysteries, and some have been foreshadowed by comics,'' said Paul Levitz, president and publisher of DC Comics, longtime home of Superman. ''We look forward to scientists figuring this one out.'' Coincidently, the first storyline of a new series, ''Superman Confidential,'' deals with Superman's first encounter with the deadly substance. It is written by Darwyn Cooke and illustrated by Tim Sale, whose work is featured on NBC's ''Heroes.'' The next part of the story will be published June 20. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

After months of controversy, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission ruled unanimously yesterday that the New-York Historical Society can renovate the exterior of its landmark building at 170 Central Park West. The 6-0 vote, believed to be the project's final regulatory hurdle, will permit the society to create a glass entrance vestibule, extend the main staircase, install free-standing kiosks and enlarge windows at the West 77th Street entrance of the building, which stretches to West 76th Street.

PRETSFELDER--Ernest. The Pretsfelder family mourns the death of its beloved husband, father, and grandfather Ernest Pretsfelder. A loving family man of principle and honor who will be deeply missed, his indomitable spirit and integrity are an inspiration to those who knew and loved him, and will live on in all of us. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice.

IT has a reputation for being one of the mysteries of international cuisine, but chili paste is really about as easy to make as applesauce. Take dried chilies, soak them until they are soft, combine them with a spice or two (or not) and purée. You can make it more complex, of course, but with a variety of dried chilies -- some mild, some hot -- you won't go far wrong. For the best flavor, toast the chilies before soaking, turning them in a dry skillet or over an open flame just until they darken and become fragrant.

Eli Broad and Bill Gates, two of the most important philanthropists in American public education, have pumped more than $2 billion into improving schools. But now, dissatisfied with the pace of change, they are joining forces for a $60 million foray into politics in an effort to vault education high onto the agenda of the 2008 presidential race. Experts on campaign spending said the project would rank as one of the most expensive single-issue initiatives ever in a presidential race, dwarfing, for example, the $22.4 million that the Swift Vets and P.O.W.s for Truth group spent against Senator John Kerry in 2004, and the $7.8 million spent on advocacy that year by AARP, the lobby for older Americans.

Nike is expanding its agency roster by shifting several important creative assignments to Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, part of MDC Partners. The shift of the assignments had been expected since last month, when Nike said it wanted to look beyond its primary creative agency, Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. Nike spends about $220 million a year on ads in major media.

Cirque du Soleil's 'Wintuk' Is Garden's Holiday Show ''Wintuk'' is the title of the Cirque du Soleil holiday show that will occupy the Theater at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 1 through Jan. 6, in its world premiere engagement. Created for a family audience, the plot deals with a boy named Wintuk and his quest for snow and adventure, which takes him and three companions from a city where he encounters acrobats, dancers and talking marionettes to an imaginary Arctic where they meet gigantic ice characters before returning home on the wings of a giant crane. ''We look forward to entertaining audiences with 'Wintuk' through the holidays for the next several years,'' said Jay Marciano, president of MSG Entertainment. Tickets go on sale on Sunday. China to Knock Down 17th-Century Opera House The 17th-century Guanghe Theater, billed as the oldest opera house in Beijing, is to be demolished in favor of a state-of-the-art theater, CBC Arts reported. ''We intend to build a modern, professional venue like those on Broadway in the United States, where regular shows are offered all year round and high-end performances can also take place,'' Ma Dekai, director of cultural facility construction in the Beijing Municipal Bureau of Culture, told the Xinhua news agency. No details of the design or the opening date of the new theater were given. The Guanghe, constructed in the final years of the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644), is one of a handful of opera houses remaining from about 40 that the city once had. In 2000, government officials declared the Guanghe unsafe. Mystery Writer Turns Opera Librettist Ian Rankin, the novelist acclaimed for mysteries featuring Detective Inspector John Rebus, the lone-wolf Scottish police official, is turning his hand to opera. He is one of five authors commissioned by the Scottish Opera to write a libretto as part of its campaign to garner more interest in the arts, The Times of London reported. Mr. Rankin, left, who has been at work on his final Inspector Rebus novel, said he was being allowed to devote the libretto to anything he wanted, although he would not discuss his choice. He will be collaborating with the film composer Craig Armstrong, whose credits include ''World Trade Center,'' ''Must Love Dogs,'' ''Fever Pitch,'' ''Ray'' and ''Moulin Rouge.'' The five short operas are to be performed in February in Glasgow and Edinburgh. Go South, Young Man? Is Harry Potter bound for the leisure life in Florida? Universal Studios is working on a deal with Harry's creator, J. K. Rowling, to build a $500 million Harry Potter theme park in Florida, the newspaper Scotland on Sunday reported. The new attraction is likely to become part of Universal's Islands of Adventure in Orlando, which includes Marvel Super Hero Island and Jurassic Park. Peter Alexander, a former vice president of University Studios who founded a theme park design consultancy, said Ms. Rowling stands to make about $18 million a year if the park deal comes to fruition. If details are ironed out, the Potter playground could be open in 18 months. Universal and Ms. Rowling declined to comment. Potter fans online were already proposing rides with names including Fred and George Weasley's Laser Fun House, Azkaban Prison, the Gringotts Bank Ghost Train and Crazy Quidditch. ''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix,'' starring Daniel Radcliffe, above, opens in theaters July 13. Pirates Capture Spider-Man China's pirates have struck again. Nearly two weeks before its American premiere, ''Spider-Man 3,'' starring Tobey Maguire and Kirsten Dunst, is on sale on the streets of Beijing, Reuters reported. Priced at $1 each, the pirated DVDs look like the real thing, complete with a picture of the hero in his new black spider costume and even bearing a warning in Chinese against pirating the product. A copy bought yesterday and put in a player, however, did not work. The problem is common. Many Chinese DVDs are made with poor equipment in dingy backrooms. Jail Term for Founder Of 'Girls Gone Wild' Blowing his nose and wiping away his tears, Joe Francis, below, 34, the multimillionaire founder of the ''Girls Gone Wild'' empire of breast-baring videos, pleaded guilty to contempt of court on Monday in Panama City, Fla., and was sentenced to 35 days in jail, The Associated Press reported. He apologized to United States District Judge Richard Smoak for yelling during negotiations to settle a lawsuit brought by seven women who were minors when they were filmed at Panama City Beach in 2003. He said the women lied about their ages. He has reached a settlement for an undisclosed amount.

THEY'RE NO. 1 Toyota Motor Company officially took over bragging rights from General Motors as the world's largest automaker, prompting a round of finger pointing in Detroit over what went wrong, and what G.M. should do to regain its global leadership. But they stopped short of removing the cloud that for nearly a year has hung over Steven P. Jobs. [C1.] F.D.A. QUESTIONS LILLY DATA The Food and Drug Administration is examining whether Eli Lilly & Company provided it with accurate data about the side effects of the antipsychotic drug Zyprexa. [C1.] A BIAS SUIT IS SETTLED Morgan Stanley will pay at least $46 million to settle a suit filed by current and former female brokers who said that they were discriminated against in how they were trained, promoted and paid. The settlement aims to overhaul the way accounts are distributed in the firm's retail branches. [C1.] PAY TO BURN Gazprom, the Russian energy giant that sells natural gas to Europe, has begun selling carbon dioxide emissions credits that companies in the European Union need to burn Gazprom's fuel. [C4.] SALES OF EXISTING HOMES PLUNGE Sales of previously owned homes took their biggest tumble in nearly two decades last month, dashing hopes that the housing market had stabilized. [C2.] VONAGE CAN SIGN NEW CUSTOMERS Vonage, the Internet phone company embroiled in a bitter patent suit with Verizon, can continue signing up new customers, a federal appeals court in Washington ruled. ''It's business as usual for us,'' said Jeffrey A. Citron, above, Vonage's chairman and interim chief executive. [C4.] BETTING ON CHEAP FARES Skybus Airlines, a well-financed start-up based in Columbus, Ohio, that promises some $10 seats on every flight, will begin service on May 22, returning the extremely low-fare airline to the United States. [C12.] VIRGIN ATLANTIC ORDERS PLANES Virgin Atlantic Airways ordered 15 fuel-efficient Boeing 787 planes as part of an environmental partnership with the company that includes joint research into biofuels for use in jet engines. [C12.] A WARNING FROM ALCATEL-LUCENT Alcatel-Lucent warned investors of continued losses and weak sales, casting doubt about the long-term outlook for the company four months after completing a trans-Atlantic merger. Share prices dropped after the announcement, but later made a strong recovery. [C18.] OSHA'S RULES HAVE BEEN LOOSENED Since George W. Bush became president, appointees to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration have eased regulations or weakened enforcement of rules on issues like driving hours for truckers, logging in forests and corporate mergers, while issuing the fewest significant standards in its history, public health experts say. [A1.] DELIVER CUSTOMERS, OR ELSE The frenetic competition in the automotive industry is taking its toll on the advertising industry. In recent months the makers of six auto brands decided to re-evaluate the relationships with the agencies that worked for them. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] SHAREHOLDERS WITHHOLD VOTES Shareholders of The New York Times Company gave voice to their displeasure with the company's management and financial performance by withholding votes representing 42 percent of the Class A shares at the annual meeting. [C5.] MIXED NEWS FOR MARKETS Wall Street closed mixed, but the Dow briefly reached a new trading high as investors weighed disappointing data on housing sales and consumer confidence against stronger-than-expected quarterly earnings. [C14.] ACQUITTAL IN INDONESIA An Indonesian court acquitted Newmont Mining Corporation, the American mining giant, and one of its executives on charges of polluting a bay here with toxic waste from a now defunct gold mine, in a case that became a litmus test of foreign investor confidence in Indonesia. [A8.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. THE CHEMICAL MAKER DUPONT reported a 16 percent increase in first-quarter earnings as strong performance in its agricultural unit helped offset sluggish demand for products in the domestic housing and automotive markets. (AP) SHARES IN WHIRLPOOL, which makes home appliances, soared past $100 for the first time as the company said it would resume share buybacks that it had suspended while it digested its purchase of rival Maytag. (AP) UNITED STATES STEEL reported that first-quarter profit rose 6.6 percent on strong growth in European operations. (AP) THE PEPSI BOTTLING GROUP said that quarterly profit fell nearly 15 percent on higher raw material costs, but the results beat Wall Street's consensus because of tight expense controls. (REUTERS)
WAGGER--Harold. The loss of our friend and partner will sorely be missed. He was one of the good guys. Our heartfelt love and sympathy to his family. Phyllis and Gerry Lakow

MEGROZ--Barbara Huntington, of Mamaroneck, died April 22nd, 2007, at age 83. Barbara was born February 15th, 1924, to Majorie and Kenneth Huntington in New Rochelle, NY, a city founded by her French ancestors, the Hugenots. She was also a direct descendant of John and Priscilla Alden, members of the Mayflower Company, on her mother's side. She was educated in New Rochelle and graduated from Colby Junior College. She was a member of the American Yacht Club and had a long involvement with the New Rochelle League for Service. Most recently she was a very active member of the United Methodist Church in Mamaroneck. She loved to garden and was a very talented artist. As an avid sports enthusiast, she was an accomplished ice skater. Bobbie, as she was known to her friends and family, is survived by her husband, Jacques, retired from Time, Inc., three sons, Andy, Chris and Roger, and her daughter Shelley. In addition she also leaves behind five grandchildren. Funeral service will be held today, 1:30pm, Mamaroneck United Methodist Church, on Boston Post Road in Mamaroneck. Contributions can be sent to the American Cancer Society. For information, Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home in Mamaroneck: 914-698-5968.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the New England Journal of Medicine's response to a possible breach of confidentiality by a medical researcher, Dr. Martin B. Leon, misidentified the online news wire that first reported the matter. It was heartwire (www.theheart.org), not heartline. The article also included incorrect information from theheart.org about the role of Dr. Leon in its report. While Dr. Leon was initially cited as the report's only source for the Journal's action, heartwire said Monday that an unidentified individual had provided details that were later confirmed by Dr. Leon.

BLAKE--Ethel. Maxwell Shmerler & Co. CPAs records with great sorrow the passing of Ethel Blake, our esteemed colleague for over 50 years. Ethel will be greatly missed by all who had the pleasure of working with her. Our condolences to her family.

The death of a 5-year-old girl who was found hanged on Sunday in her Eastchester apartment has been ruled accidental by the city medical examiner, a spokeswoman said yesterday. The spokeswoman, Ellen Borakove, said the girl, Monet Fulgham, had accidentally hanged herself with a jump-rope. Ms. Borakove said the investigation showed that Monet ''was playing with a jump-rope that was attached to a closet door.'' THOMAS J. LUECK
SAMEK--Michael J. Died on April 21, 2007. Family and friends will gather for a Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, on Thursday, April 26, 2007, at 3pm.

CHILEWICH--Simon, long time resident of New York City passed away April 24th, 2007 at age 88. Simon was born in Poland, but soon after immigrating to his new country in 1939, he served in World War II as an army intelligence officer in the United States Army. Thereafter, he rejoined the family business, Chilewich Sons and Company, which became a prominent, international, commodity trading firm based in New York. Simon was very instrumental in forging strong commercial ties with the former Soviet Union during much of the Cold War years. He strongly believed at the time that commercial ties were necessary in order to build a meaningful foundation for the development of peaceful relationships between the two nations. He opened the first official American trading offices in Moscow in 1972, from which he could represent many western firms also dedicated to developing business connections with the Soviets. After the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, he continued to help with the establishment of several new commercial organizations emerging from the old system. He has been a civic leader in New Rochelle and Westchester County for many years where he was active in local politics with his former wife, Norma. Like his father Aaron before him, Simon was involved in many philanthropic efforts, especially in regards to the support of several universities here and in the State of Israel. He also followed in the footsteps of his father with an active support of the American Friends of Ben Gurian University of the Negev, in Israel, and the United Jewish Appeal, where he chaired the Hide and Leather Division on several occasions. With his support, the Chilewich Family also helped with the formation of a number of small businesses in the young Jewish nation. His numerous activities of helping small minority-owned businesses and others became known as Simon's ''Better World Department''. Simon Chilewich graduated from the London School of Economics before the War and had a true love of the Arts. He spent much of his life supporting and encouraging a number of artists in the music and art fields, some born here and others whom he assisted in immigrating to this country where they could pursue artistic freedom. He was later joined in this passion for the arts by his beloved late wife, Virginia Kaye Chilewich, a well-known former actress in her own right. Simon Chilewich is survived by sons, Melvin Chilewich of Cherry Hill, New Jersey, and Martin David Chilewich of Los Angeles, California, and his daughter, Sandra Chilewich Sultan, of New York City. He is also survived by seven grandchildren, seven greatgrandchildren, two step-sons, and five step-grandchildren, for which he was truly blessed and for all of whom he showed immense love. He will be warmly missed and remembered by the many people he touched around the globe. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY. Close friends and family are invited to attend services which will commence at 12:30 pm, on Wednesday, April 25, 2007.

GIGES--Shirley A. Loving wife, mother, grandmother and great - grandmother passed away early Tuesday morning, the 24th of April. Born in Valdosta, GA, January 22, 1922, she moved to White Plains in 1955 with her husband, Melvin, and three children. She devoted her life to her family and was active in a variety of community organizations. The first female vice president of the Temple Israel Center, White Plains. She was especially proud of her role as membership chairman. Education and learning were important to her, and she completed her college education by earning a bachelors degree in 1976 at the College of New Rochelle. She is survived by two sisters, Jackie Wahnish of Orlando, FL, Gloria Kulbersh of Tifton, GA; three children, Marc Giges of White Plains, Carole Moskovitz of Marina del Rey, CA, Elissa Giges of Culver City, CA; daughter-in-law Nancy Giges of White Plains; five grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Temple Israel Center in White Plains at 10am, Thursday, with burial following at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY.

WILLIAMS--Thomas H., Jr., after a brief illness on April 23rd. He is survived by his loving sister Claudia and cherished niece Barbara. Visiting Friday, 2-4 and 7-9, at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, NY. Service Saturday, 11:00am, at Funeral Home.

The Iraq emergency war spending bill, passed today by the Senate (yesterday by the House) and headed for President Bush's veto pen, includes a mandate to begin troop withdrawal by Oct. 1. But candidates and political committees are more concerned about its ramifications for Nov. 4, 2008.

A trio of banks seeking to buy ABN AMRO said on Thursday the Dutch bank was setting unreasonable conditions on opening its books, increasing the chance they could launch a hostile bid, Reuters reported. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is speaking about his executive budget proposal right now, and nyc.gov is streaming it live on the Web. Details released yesterday show that New York City's revenues are running $1.3 billion ahead of projections for this fiscal year, bringing the current budget surplus to $4.4 billion. Richard Breeden, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, recently called Applebee's International a "study in stagnation." But life at the restaurant chain is bound to get livelier now that Mr. Breeden, who is head of activist investment firm Breeden Capital Management, and one of his allies have been named to the Applebee's board. The appointments, announced Thursday, settle a proxy fight that was brewing ahead of the company's annual shareholder meeting on May 25.

Throughout the day on Wednesday, as he rolled through New Hampshire on the formal kickoff of his presidential campaign, Senator John McCain of Arizona was asked if he believes that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales should step down. He was asked twice as he held forth in his bus, the "Straight Talk Express,'' and at a brief news conference in Manchester, N.H. Each time he told reporters "Ask me tomorrow," broadly hinting that he might make news on the subject.

Bristol-Myers Squibb, the giant pharmaceutical company that has long been the subject of takeover chatter, said Thursday it named James Cornelius to be its chief executive officer until 2009. Mr. Cornelius has been serving as Bristol-Myers's interim chief executive since September, when his predecessor was pushed out in what was widely seen as a tacit admission that the drugmaker was on the block. The company's decision to make Mr. Cornelius its long-term chief could quell rumors that Bristol-Myers is heading for a sale, although some analysts were doubtful on that front on Thursday. "I don't think this is going to end speculation about the company's independence," one analyst told Bloomberg News.

Rumors of a rift between Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Goldman Sachs seemed to have been greatly exaggerated. The two firms announced Thursday that they are teaming up on an $8 billion deal to take Harman International Industries private, an alliance that would seem to undercut the notion, making the rounds on some Web sites of late, that Kohlberg felt threatened by Goldman's well-funded private equity arm.

Bush tries to kill all the Gitmo lawyers: "We should not forget this central point: The Justice Department is trying to do everything possible to prevent Guantanamo detainees from having any rights at all," writes Yale law professor Jack Balkin at the group legal blog Balkinization. "It wants to get as close as it can to what it the Bush Administration sought before [the Supreme Court decisions in] Rasul and Hamdan - a law-free zone. But the more the Justice Department tries to eliminate procedural protections and basic elements of fairness for the detainees, the more it undermines its argument that the detainees have a remedy that is just as good as habeas." ABN Amro and Barclays are likely to face pointed questions from shareholders on Thursday at their general annual meetings, which come as the two banks' proposed merger has been challenged by a $98.5 billion offer from a group including the Royal Bank of Scotland. The Children's Investment Fund, an activist hedge fund whose agitations prompted the start of ABN's takeover talks with Barclays, called the competing offer for ABN "compelling" on Wednesday. NYSE Euronext's chief executive, John Thain, disputed claims by a Goldman Sachs analyst that new regulations in the United States might erode market share at his trans-Atlantic stock ex­change and benefit its rival, the Nasdaq. In an interview with The Financial Times, Mr. Thain said some of the new rules, known as Regulation Nat­ional Market System, would actually help NYSE Euronext.

Citigroup wrapped up its bid to take over the scandal-tainted broker Nikko Cordial on Thursday in a buyout valued at up to $13.35 billion, which would make it the biggest foreign takeover of a Japanese company.

A federal bankruptcy judge gave his final approval Wednesday to Delta Air Lines' plan to emerge from bankruptcy, clearing the way for the company to resume trading next month on the New York Stock Exchange.

A man from Princeton, N.J., was arrested and charged with driving without a license after his vehicle killed a motorcyclist in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said. Shiraz Sanjana, 47, was driving north on Ocean Avenue near Avenue R shortly after 2 p.m. when he suddenly made a U-turn and hit Syed Adil Zaidi, 21, of Brooklyn, who was going south on his motorcycle, the authorities said. Mr. Zaidi was was declared dead on arrival at a local hospital. Mr. Sanjana was charged with aggravated unlicensed operation of a motor vehicle and driving without a license.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that he hoped former Vice President Al Gore would run for president in 2008, saying “I think it would be good for the country.”

New York City’s revenues are running $1.3 billion ahead of projections for this fiscal year, bringing the current budget surplus to $4.4 billion, according to new figures released yesterday in advance of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s executive budget announcement today.

The Saturday Profile, about Saifa Benaouda, a Swedish Muslim who went to Somalia last December as the country was becoming a magnet for Islamic extremists, referred incorrectly to Daniel Maldonado, an American Muslim convert in Somalia arrested on the Kenya border and deported to the United States in February on terrorism-related charges. Mr. Maldonado pleaded guilty in Houston federal court last Thursday to receiving training from a foreign terrorist organization. He is not “currently on trial.”.

An obituary on Monday about Parry O’Brien, the shot-putting champion, misstated the year he last broke the world record, and the distance. It was 1959, not 1966, and the record distance was 63 feet 4 inches, not 63-3.

The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday, about weight-loss products, included an outdated reference to the drug Alli, known clinically as orlistat. The Food and Drug Administration approved it on Feb. 7 for over-the-counter sale; its approval is no longer conditional.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about efforts to solve the mystery of collapsing honeybee populations misstated the institution where a project to sequence honeybee genes was completed late last year. It is Baylor College of Medicine, not Baylor University. (The two became separate institutions in 1969.) And a map with the article, showing the extent of the problem in the United States, reversed the labels for Kansas and Nebraska, two states where collapsing populations have not been reported.

A sports picture caption yesterday about Toronto’s 89-83 playoff victory against the Nets referred imprecisely in some copies to the Raptors’ postseason history. It was the team’s first playoff victory in five years — not the first ever. (The first was in 2001, against the Knicks.).

The Saturday Profile, about Saifa Benaouda, a Swedish Muslim who went to Somalia last December as the country was becoming a magnet for Islamic extremists, referred incorrectly to Daniel Maldonado, an American Muslim convert in Somalia arrested on the Kenya border and deported to the United States in February on terrorism-related charges. Mr. Maldonado pleaded guilty in Houston federal court last Thursday to receiving training from a foreign terrorist organization. He is not “currently on trial.”.
Buffalo goaltender Ryan Miller stopped the Rangers’ first 29 shots and the Sabres took control of Game 1 with a three-goal outburst in the second period.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Toyota passing General Motors as the No. 1 automaker misstated an earlier period when G.M. lost the top spot because of a strike. It was overtaken by Ford in the late 1990s, not the 1980s. (G.M. also faltered because of a strike in the 1970s, and Ford claimed the top spot.).

An architect’s rendering yesterday of planned renovations for the exterior of the landmark New-York Historical Society building was published in error. A rendering of the design approved by the Landmarks Preservation Commission appears today on Page B6.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about the London Marathon referred incorrectly to the performance of Ryan Hall, an American making his marathon debut. He led the race near Mile 22; he was not the leader for almost 22 miles.

A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on April 6, about performances and discussions at the Flea Theater in Lower Manhattan, misidentified the curator who chose the works performed. She was Nina Winthrop — not Yasuko Yokoshi, who had been scheduled to be the moderator, but who was repalced by Ms Winthrop.

A music review on Monday about the UBS Verbier Festival Chamber Orchestra, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the name of another training orchestra that recently played there. It is the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, not the East-West Divan Orchestra.
The rise lends support to the views of bullish investors that the company’s spending and its emphasis on increasing sales over profit would eventually pay off.

The subway train that struck and killed a track worker near the Columbus Circle station on Tuesday night had been diverted to the express track, where the accident occurred, because a stalled train was blocking a local track, according to two people briefed on the investigation.

GlaxoSmithKline said first-quarter profit was flat as it faced greater competition from generic versions of its drugs in the United States. Glaxo said earnings, which were slightly better than analysts had forecast, were also hurt by currency exchange rates because of the dollar. The company said that it earned £1.51 billion ($3.01 billion) in the period, compared with £1.50 billion a year earlier. Sales rose 3 percent, to £4.8 billion.

Canada will ban inefficient light bulbs within five years, the natural resources minister, Gary Lunn, said. The decision follows a similar move by Australia and by Canada’s most populous province, Ontario. Regulations for the ban, which will not be available until later this year, will require bulbs to meet minimum efficiency standards. While that will remove traditional incandescent bulbs from store shelves, it may also affect other technologies, like bulbs filled with halogen gas.

Honda Motor reported a seventh consecutive year of record sales, but profit dropped 20 percent in the first quarter because of a special gain in the previous year. Profit for the fourth quarter was 176 billion yen ($1.5 billion), down from 219.5 billion yen in the period the previous year. Quarterly sales rose 9 percent, to 3.1 trillion yen, on strong demand for Honda’s models, which have a reputation for good fuel efficiency.

Endorsing a set of common criminal penalties across the European Union for the first time, the European Parliament approved legislation that would impose jail sentences and fines on counterfeiters of drugs, toys and other goods in the 27-country bloc. The legislation, which still must be approved by national governments, aims to protect consumers from unsafe products like fake Viagra pills or imitation condoms, while preventing the infringement of intellectual property in the music and film industry. .

Hynix Semiconductor, the maker of memory chips, reported a 45 percent increase in first-quarter profit, but the gain was less than some analysts expected after a glut drove down chip prices. Net income rose to 418 billion won ($451 million), from 289 billion won a year earlier, missing analysts’ estimates by more than 20 percent. Hynix joins Samsung Electronics, Micron Technology and Nanya Technology in reporting lower-than-expected results for the latest quarter because prices for computer memory chips have tumbled more than 60 percent.
The state dropped 36 counts of cruelty to the infirm against the owners of a nursing home where 35 people died in the flooding of Hurricane Katrina.

California will sue the Environmental Protection Agency if it does not act soon on the state’s request for permission to regulate automobile emissions, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said. The state applied in 2005 for a waiver that would exempt California from the federal Clean Air Act, allowing it more aggressive regulation of heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide as air pollutants. Mr. Schwarzenegger said he called the E.P.A. administrator, Stephen Johnson, and told him that his agency was moving too slowly. A letter announcing the intent to sue, a procedural step required six months before a lawsuit would be filed, was being sent yesterday, said a Schwarzenegger spokesman, Aaron McLear.

Nearly 100 residents of Spencer were taken to hospitals with burns or rashes after the town’s water supply was accidentally treated with too much corrosive lye, officials said. No serious injuries were reported. People were advised not to use or touch the water, said Ed Coletta, a spokesman for the State Department of Environmental Protection. Officials determined that a malfunction at the town’s water treatment plant had released too much sodium hydroxide into the water supply. Sodium hydroxide, also known as lye, is routinely put into water to reduce acidity and limit pipe corrosion, Mr. Coletta said. The town of 12,000 is about 50 miles west of Boston.
The University of Virginia’s board marked the birthday of Thomas Jefferson, its founder, with an apology for its use of slave labor from 1819 to 1865.
Indiana authorities have transferred more than 200 inmates accused of helping instigate a two-hour riot at a state prison in New Castle run by a private company, officials said.
Phil Hughes, considered one of the top pitching prospects in baseball, will take the mound tonight against the Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium.
Trees that were felled in Buffalo during last October’s freakish snowstorm become art with one man’s chain saw.
Junk foods like potato chips, doughnuts, chocolate-covered ice cream and sugary drinks should be banned from schools, according to a report by the Institute of Medicine.
The narrow approval of the measure sets the stage for the first veto fight with President Bush.
The Catskill farmhouse where the suspect was believed to be hiding erupted in flames as the police were besieging it.

After executing 19 search warrants early yesterday in the Cypress Hills Houses in East New York, the police said they had arrested 53 people, including 23 women, on charges of selling crack cocaine or heroin. The sweep was conducted at a public housing project that has long been plagued by illegal drugs. Eighty people were arrested there on similar charges in 2002. Inspector Steven Powers said that the arrests yesterday followed more than 100 drug purchases by undercover agents, and that some of the dealers had been paying tenants’ rent in exchange for using their apartments for drug sales. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that “crime had spiked” in the Cypress Hills Houses, but that the arrests would provide residents with “better, safer lives.”.

A West New York man who impregnated his teenage daughter twice and ordered her to throw both newborns down an air shaft — which she did, killing one — was sentenced yesterday in State Superior Court to 35 years in prison. The man, Jose Julio Ventura, 46, pleaded guilty in December to aggravated manslaughter, aggravated assault and two counts of aggravated sexual assault. Prosecutors say he started having sex with his daughter, Lucila Ventura, when she was 14. When a boy was thrown out in September 2005, the mummified body of his sister, who had lain in a heap of garbage for a year, was discovered. The boy survived. Ms. Ventura, now 19, has pleaded guilty to reckless manslaughter and aggravated assault and is to be sentenced next month.

A high school senior has been arrested on charges of writing a threatening letter about his prom, prosecutors said yesterday. The student, Michael DiGiovanni, 17, wrote a letter last Thursday warning students and teachers at the Middle College High School in Long Island City that those attending the prom would share a fate similar to the 32 students and faculty members at Virginia Tech who were shot to death on April 16, prosecutors said. They said Mr. DiGiovanni told them that the letter was meant as a joke. He was arraigned yesterday on charges of falsely reporting an incident and aggravated harassment.

New Jersey officials asked a federal appeals court yesterday to overturn a decision by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that the possibility of a terrorist attack on the Oyster Creek nuclear plant should not be a consideration in deciding whether to extend its license. Oyster Creek, the country’s oldest operating plant, is seeking to extend its license for 20 years beyond its 2009 expiration date. In reviewing the potential environmental impact of continued operation, the N.R.C. did not take terrorism into account, and state officials claim that the commission erred. They have appealed the decision in the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

Ten men were charged yesterday with defrauding more than a dozen mortgage lenders in a scheme involving false identities and credit ratings, federal prosecutors said. Some of the men received loans through a mortgage brokerage firm they ran and then used false identities and credit ratings for others who bought and resold the properties, prosecutors said. The prosecutors, with the United States attorney’s office in Brooklyn, said the goal was to obtain mortgages without repaying the money. The men stole an estimated $7 million, said James Margolin, an F.B.I. spokesman.

A Queens man was charged yesterday with providing support to a terrorist organization operating in Sri Lanka, federal prosecutors said. The man, Karunakaran Kandasamy, is charged with aiding an organization called the Tamil Tigers, said Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn. The organization, which is fighting to establish an independent state in Sri Lanka, has been designated a terrorist organization by the federal government, prosecutors said. They say Mr. Kandasamy is director of the American branch of the organization, based in Queens.

A state appeals court yesterday overturned the conviction of a woman accused of ordering the theft of human remains from Newark graves so she could use them in rituals she conducted as a high priestess in a religious cult. In a 3-to-0 decision, an appellate panel of State Superior Court ordered a new trial for the woman, Miriam Miraballes, 61, who was convicted of conspiracy to commit theft and burglary after prosecutors said she ordered the theft of the remains of three people in 2001 and 2002. The panel said the trial had been tainted by the testimony of an expert in nontraditional religions, which they found violated a rule about a witness voicing an opinion about the credibility of another. Prosecutors said they would appeal the decision.

A state assemblyman from Brooklyn was charged yesterday with driving while intoxicated and speeding after he was stopped by the police on an Albany street, according to P. David Soares, the Albany County district attorney. The assemblyman, the Rev. Karim Camara, above, a Democrat from Crown Heights, appeared intoxicated and refused to take a breath test before he was arrested, the police said. He was released on his own recognizance and is expected back in court on May 9. Mr. Camara, 35, who represents the 43rd Assembly District, was elected in 2005 to fill the seat left vacant when Clarence Norman Jr. was forced to resign after his conviction in a corruption scandal.

The former head of the New Haven Police Department’s narcotics division was indicted yesterday on charges including theft, bribery and fraud, federal prosecutors said. The former lieutenant, William B. White, 63, and three bail bondsmen were arrested last month in a federal sting operation. Prosecutors said Mr. White routinely received money from the three men: Robert Jacobs, 79, who runs a local bail bonds service, and his two sons, Paul, 48, and Philip, 47. According to prosecutors, the bondsmen would bribe Mr. White to track down criminals who had posted bail bonds but failed to appear; their failure to appear would have caused the bondsmen to lose money. Compiled by John Sullivan.
A former Apple board member kept suspicions about Apple’s options-backdating policies swirling around Steven P. Jobs.
The patches of the New York Fire Department are slowly being refashioned after two incidents prompted a department review.
Senator John McCain pledged that he would restore competence to foreign and domestic policy and welcome compromise with Democrats.
Proposed regulations would restrict violent programs to late evening, when most children would not be watching.
New York’s attorney general accused the federal Education Department of being lax in regulating the student loan industry.
The plan could take on broad significance if the Supreme Court ever returns abortion law to states’ discretion.
There was no discussion of alternative postseason models during the annual Bowl Championship Series meetings, which ended Wednesday with little significant action.
The company surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts on strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod music players.

The N.C.A.A. announced that it will no longer accept academic records from God’s Academy Prep, a secondary school in Dallas that opened last year in a recreation center. An N.C.A.A. review of the school found a “lack of formal instruction or organized curriculum structure,” according to a news release. The school was opened in August 2005 in Irving, Tex., by a summer basketball coach and quickly blossomed to 40 students, all of whom were basketball players. The school sent two players to Division I schools last year: Jeremy Mayfield to Alabama-Birmingham and Tommy Moffitt to the University of Texas-Arlington. Two players from the school signed letters of intent to Division I schools this year, Marcus Brister to Iowa State and T. J. Clark to Morehead State. Their status will be reviewed.
pro football.
Since winning the fifth starter’s job in spring training, Mike Pelfrey has pitched progressively worse. The struggles continued in Wednesday’s loss to the Colorado Rockies.
An Amalgamated Bank branch opened Wednesday in Long Island City, part of an effort to wean many residents off an all-cash economy.
Lakers officials are quietly speaking of the shrinking window for returning to contender status before Kobe Bryant begins to decline.
The companies plan to introduce specialized high-end server systems that provide fresh evidence of a new era in computing.
The American military said a senior commander at Camp Cropper, its main detention center in Baghdad, was being held in Kuwait for the military equivalent of a grand jury investigation.
A fierce tornado southwest of San Antonio killed at least 10 people on both sides of the Mexican border Tuesday night, injured many others and destroyed or damaged hundreds of homes
Because all three decisions dealt with a provision of the Texas death penalty law that is no longer in effect, their practical significance may be limited.
Rudolph W. Giuliani said that Democrats “do not understand the full nature and scope of the terrorist war against us.”
Federal authorities charged 22 people with being part of one of the nation’s largest operations to produce counterfeit identification documents.
Calvin Johnson, the best wide receiver and perhaps the best player in this weekend’s N.F.L. draft, has created a few local legends, but no legendary outbursts.
Dr. Paczynski was a leading astrophysicist whose unconventional ideas led to new methods of studying distant stars and hidden planets.
The UAL Corporation posted a bigger-than-expected $152 million loss for the first quarter, pressured by reduced domestic passenger demand.
In a vivid display of their new power, Democrats across Capitol Hill approved a flurry of subpoenas to fuel a series of investigations of the Bush administration.
The U.N. accused the Iraqi government  of failing to “seriously address” problems of detainee abuse, including torture, and to ensure the timely and fair prosecution of detainees.
Another run to the Stanley Cup arrived for the Devils this season, but none of the three first-round home games against the Tampa Bay Lightning were sold out.
Recently the government has cracked down on advocates of change and scrapped some long-promised initiatives.

British bookmakers slashed the odds on discovering extraterrestrial intelligence after astronomers announced Tuesday that that they had found an Earth-like planet 20 light-years away. Deciding to take less risk, William Hill cut its odds on proving the existence of extraterrestrial life from 1,000-to-1 to 100-to-1. For William Hill to pay out on an aliens bet, the prime minister has to confirm officially the existence of intelligent extra-terrestrial life and it has to be done within a year of the bet being placed. “We have come a cropper before, when, in the early 1960s we offered 1000-to-1 about man walking on the moon before 1970,” a spokesman said.
New data on durable goods orders raised expectations that decent economic growth can continue.

The army-backed government said it was no longer barring Sheik Hasina Wazed, a former prime minister, from returning to the country or pressing another former prime minister, Khaleda Zia, to go into exile. The interim government says it hopes to hold general elections before the end of next year. News reports have said the government wanted to remove Sheik Hasina and her longtime rival, Mrs. Zia, to ease tensions before the vote. A bitter feud between the women and their political parties before elections that had been set for January led to violent street protests, which brought the suspension of the elections and the declaration of a state of emergency. It is not clear if Mrs. Zia and Sheik Hasina will be allowed to resume their political careers.

The United States and the Global Business Coalition on H.I.V./AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria have jointly donated $2.9 million to distribute more than 500,000 insecticide-treated mosquito nets in Zambia. The nets will help protect those who sleep under them from contracting malaria, which kills up to 50,000 Zambians a year, mostly children. The nets, enough for a tenth of the country’s population, will be handed out before November, the beginning of the malaria season.

President Viktor A. Yushchenko, left, battling to outmaneuver his rival, Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, said in a late-night television address that he was delaying new elections ordered for May 27 until June 24. Mr. Yanukovich has challenged the legality of the decree setting the earlier date in the Constitutional Court, and government ministries controlled by him had refused to provide money to finance the May 27 vote. Mr. Yanukovich was visiting Uzbekistan when the president’s new decree was issued. A spokesman, quoted by the Interfax news agency, said he was cutting short his visit and returning home. Mr. Yushchenko’s address took politicians by surprise. “Today let me say very firmly that there will be an early parliamentary election in Ukraine,” he told viewers. The election, he said, would take place “in calm, honest and democratic fashion, as befits a European state.”.

Iran met with the European Union over its uranium enrichment program, the first face-to-face talks between the top negotiators for the sides since the United Nations Security Council expanded sanctions on Iran in March. The talks, in Ankara, Turkey, continued late into the evening. At their conclusion, after five hours, Iran’s nuclear negotiator, Ali Larijani, said, “There are ideas on the table, still in discussion,” the Anatolian news agency reported. “We have time to continue also tomorrow. Within two weeks, we will have more meetings.” Javier Solana, the European Union’s foreign policy chief who is negotiating on behalf of the permanent members of the Security Council, called the talks “productive.” A press conference is scheduled for today.
Major League Baseball officials are quietly preparing to re-establish a relationship with Cuba if the United States lifts its trade embargo.
The increase came on lower corporate expenses, a lower tax rate and strong international sales of snacks and beverages.
Miguel Olivo scored on a passed ball to cap a four-run rally in the ninth inning against Tim Hudson and Bob Wickman, and the host Florida Marlins defeated the Atlanta Braves, 4-3, last night.
Changes for the city’s 29,000-acre park system are even more ambitious than initially detailed by the mayor in his 25-year plan for a greener New York.

GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 25 — The witness recalled his troubles as a shy teenager with an alcoholic father and few friends, who cut classes and drank. Then a church youth director, Matthew Maiello, came into his life and steered him on a righteous path, he testified, transforming him with a sense of purpose, achievement and self-worth.
Coming off their sixth consecutive losing season, the Detroit Lions find themselves in a familiar position as they prepare for this weekend’s N.F.L. draft.
The world’s largest aluminum company said it might put its packaging and consumer businesses up for sale to focus on metal production.
First-quarter profit rose 7.7 percent as income from asset sales helped offset lower commodity prices and higher operating costs.
First-quarter earnings climbed 27 percent, mostly as a result of robust orders for commercial airplanes and strong military business.
Federal authorities arrested a man suspected of mailing pipe bombs and threatening letters to two mutual fund companies.
Wendy’s said it had formed a special committee to review options that could include a possible sale, merger or other business combination.
Dr. Richards was a prominent veterinarian who was a recognized authority on cat care.
Paul D. Wolfowitz, president of the World Bank, appealed for more time to defend himself against allegations of favoritism and other matters.
The Virginia police said that they were no closer to determining a motive for Seung-Hui Cho’s shooting rampage last week at Virginia Tech.

Tens of thousands of rail commuters in Connecticut were stranded yesterday morning after the overhead wires that provide power to Metro-North trains were damaged, disrupting service for about five hours.
General Dynamics and Raytheon were reluctant to raise their profit outlooks for the full year, citing unusually high uncertainty over future Pentagon funding.
Half of New York City’s high school students graduated on time in June 2006, up from 47 percent the year before.
It seems that for the National Rifle Association and the gun lobby, the only solution to a gun in the wrong hands is a gun in the hands of everyone.

In order to put the system on a sounder financial footing, the administration and Congress will have to propose solutions under rules that are perversely skewed to rule out the most progressive financing.
Alan Ball was a crafty 5-foot-6 soccer midfielder who at 21 was the youngest member of the team that won England its only World Cup in 1966.
Jeffrey R. Immelt said he found the lagging performance of the company’s shares “frustrating.”
Qualcomm also raised its annual revenue and profit forecasts.
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe wants to limit his exposure to uncomfortable questions about his views on Japan’s conduct during World War II.
More than 400 North Korean refugees have gone on a hunger strike to protest poor sanitary conditions and delays in their resettlement in South Korea.
First-quarter profit rose 50 percent, driven by sales of new products and growth in all geographic regions.
Manufacturing companies have formed an unusual alliance with the United Steelworkers, aiming to preserve and promote manufacturing in the U.S.
United Parcel Service reported lower quarterly profit as a result of a charge related to aging aircraft and expenses for a voluntary layoff program.
The case of Paul Charlton, a United States attorney in Arizona and one of the eight prosecutors purged by the White House and the Justice Department,  adds a disturbing new chapter to the scandal.
Lawyers for Jacob Alexander won a delay against attempts to extradite him to face charges of options fraud in the U.S.
The enticing possibility that Curlin will emerge as racing’s next super horse will be among the themes of this year’s Kentucky Derby.
Joost, the Internet television service, has lined up several blue-chip advertisers as it prepares for its introduction.
The nation’s largest brewer reported a 3.7 percent increase in first-quarter earnings.
Quarterly profit rose 27 percent on better-than-expected demand for telecommunications products.
François Bayrou, the defeated “third man” in the race for the French presidency, is signaling that he intends to retain some influence in the contest.
Singapore is trying to carve out a new niche for itself in the global economy by bolstering banking secrecy laws and offering generous tax incentives.
A proxy fight between investor Carl C. Icahn and Motorola heated up when two proxy advisory firms lined up in opposing camps.
Arguments today suggested that the court could soon open a significant loophole in the McCain-Feingold law.
Britain’s top counterterrorism police officer said that Al Qaeda’s supporters had established “an inexorable trend towards more ambitious and more destructive attack planning.”
Anne Pitoniak began her stage career in late middle age, but received a Tony nomination for her Broadway debut, in “ ’night, Mother,” and had an enduring career playing strong-willed older women.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,317 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
The influx of Hispanic immigrants to the U.S. is transforming the nation’s religious landscape,  according to a study.
The authorities said the bombs, sent in an effort to drive up stock prices in two companies, would have been live if a wire had been connected and came with letters signed “the Bishop.”
Boris N. Yeltsin, Russia’s first democratically elected president, was buried Wednesday after a somber, symbolic funeral service.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey is still receiving pain medication, and antibiotics to prevent any infection in his left leg, which was fractured in two places.
BMW Oracle Racing and Emirates Team New Zealand, both undefeated, showed why they are the favorites for the Louis Vuitton Cup with impressive victories Wednesday.
Even in new, egalitarian Britain, everyone seems ready to believe in the return of the class war that had supposedly ended in a truce years ago.
A report states that  Ehud Olmert improperly helped an associate during his term as minister of trade and industry in a previous government.
Web sites are selling professional retouching services to provide age progression, beauty enhancing or simple fixes.
The Elder Scrolls IV: Shivering Isles adds a single mysterious door in the middle of the original game’s world.

Hot dogs? Check. Sun hat? Check. Robotic pool cleaner with built-in filter that takes about 90 minutes to pick up leaves, hair and sand? Check.

Klaus Kleinfeld is the latest casualty in the German engineering company’s widening corruption scandal.
Obtaining any new funding — or significant support from Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s administration — has been difficult of late for the much-criticized schools construction agency.

The Epson PowerLite Home Cinema 1080 costs about as much as a large-screen TV and lets you project a 100-inch HD picture on any wall.

Fastmac recently released an internal slot-loading Blu-ray drive that replaces the DVD drive.
For design-conscious Manhattanites who couldn’t make it to Milan for the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the contemporary furniture fair that ended on Monday, there is always Manhattan.

The poster in front of the Joyce Theater, where the company performs this week, reveals much about the choreographer’s desire to attract younger audiences: the names of musicians appear above the dancers’.
The company starts its spring season with one all-Balanchine week: 10 ballets created from 1928 (“Apollo”) to 1975 (“Pavane”).
The 2007 season of show houses and house and garden tours runs through fall, with several events every weekend. Here are all manner of house tours, show houses and garden tours.

Summer is biking season in Europe, and not just for the desperate 200 or so who form the Tour de France peloton. Anybody with a bike and a good pair of padded shorts can see the Continent from the comfort of a tiny leather perch. The U.K.’s Graham Baxter is one of just seven operators of official Tour de France trips, and the “Live the Dream” packages allow riders to bike the Alpine stages the same day as the pros. Ciclismo Classico offers up Italy immodestly. The cycling tour outfit is featuring its “Trips No One Else Has,” which includes, among its many offerings, bike trips alongside celebrity chefs, and one eight-day trip that follows the world’s second-biggest bike race, the Giro d’Italia, beloved among cycling fans, and this year known as the “Giro of Climbs” for its grueling mountain stages. Graham Baxter tours.

The first step in preparing for a bike tour isn’t, as you might expect, to get fit, but to get fitted. “If your bike doesn’t fit properly, you’ll have all kinds of problems,” says Gabe Mullens, a program manager for Specialized Bicycle Components and a veteran of many tours. Problems range from debilitating knee injuries to shooting leg pains, sore backs, numb groins, fatigue (from inefficient pedal strokes), and generalized whininess. Most bike shops have computerized fitting systems. Or if you’re persnickety and adept with a yardstick, you can fit yourself. Coloradocyclist.com has instructions and downloadable worksheets.

As Barry Bonds moves ever closer to Sadaharu Oh’s all-time home run record — if you factor in age and injures, Bonds, 42, may not get to the magic number of 868 until some time around his 50th birthday — the riddle of just how many of his long flies may have made it over the wall thanks to the Clear and other substances remains unsolved. Michael Lewis, a PLAY Magazine contributor and the author of the best-selling “Moneyball,” tells us that he does not expect that question to remain unanswered for long.

Q. March in Missouri was unseasonably warm; then we had several nights at 20 degrees or lower. The leaves on my Nikko Blue hydrangeas died, and I’m sure the flower buds died too, but will I lose the plants themselves? And will the crab apple tree, its flowers now brown, produce any fruit this year?
The increase in reality programming is more about a shrinking potential market that gives networks less incentive to spend money.
