Phil Hughes is being asked to do his part in making the Yankees a team that Roger Clemens could be proud of and want to pitch for.
Priscilla of Boston has added new lines and new designers, and it will open its first salon in Manhattan on Thursday.
The 2007 season of show houses and house and garden tours runs through fall, with several events every weekend. Here’s a list of tours throughout the country.

This was supposed to be the year in which Travis D. Trim worked his life out. He told his probation officer and his grandmother that he was returning to college at SUNY Canton, not far from his hometown in northern New York.
Alec Baldwin, who plays a lead role in NBC’s new comedy “30 Rock,” asked Wednesday to be let out of his contract on the show.

Collectively, patches worn by New York City firefighters form a quilt, a tapestry intertwining the history of the city and that of the Fire Department, an institution with century-old standing in some of the city’s oldest neighborhoods, the affluent and the afflicted alike.
The New Jersey governor’s office of late has seemed to be laboring under some bizarre curse.
The arguments suggested that the Supreme Court could soon open a major loophole in the McCain-Feingold law.
A Justice Department filing proposes limits on lawyers’ contact with their clients and access to secret evidence.
The ABN Amro takeover battle, the biggest in banking’s history, is the latest sign of the deal frenzy in Europe.

Phil Spector, the mastermind behind hit songs like “Da Doo Ron Ron,” “The Long and Winding Road” and “You’ve Lost That Lovin’ Feelin’,” went on trial on Wednesday on charges that he shot to death a struggling actress.
The sooner President Bush and his allies drop the pretense that military victory is still possible in Iraq, the closer the nation will be to rescuing what can still be rescued from the debacle.
A revolt by lawmakers has blocked Gov. Rick Perry’s effort to make Texas the first state to require sixth-grade girls to be vaccinated against the sexually transmitted H.P.V. virus.
Only a lunatic could seriously believe that more guns in more homes is good for America’s children.

WHEN the newly married Charles and Ray Eames set up house in Los Angeles in 1941, they turned the bathroom in their cramped apartment into a plywood laboratory. They continued their experiments for the next few years, opening an office nearby, and in 1945, the same year they introduced their famous LCW molded plywood chair, they designed a collection of plywood animals — a bear, a frog, a seal and an elephant.
Among the thousands of new products unveiled at the 46th International Furniture Fair outside Milan last week, almost all of the standouts belonged to one of two camps.

ONE room was dominated by a giant Pinocchio figure, clad in black, white and gold mosaic, lampshades dangling from his nose. Next door was a Lewis Carroll scene of neo-Classical-style plinths bearing gargantuan white gold mosaic replicas of a tea tray, cake plate, dish and teapot.

AT first glance there was nothing special about the steel dishes, ceramic bowls, paper clips, scissors or any of the other objects in “Super Normal,” an exhibition on view last week at Milan’s Triennale museum. And that’s the point.
With the box office dominated by action and horror films, it is harder than ever to win a green light for movies that appeal to women.

ON a recent afternoon, in the dental office of Dr. Jeff Golub-Evans on the Upper East Side, Anne Keane, a 26-year-old executive assistant from Little Silver, N.J., donned a pair of orange sunglasses, revved up the office’s loaner iPod, and lay back to get her teeth buffed with a paste made from 2 milliliters of pulverized diamonds.
Diamonds and other gems have a new engagement, as an ingredient in cosmetics.
The goods at the newer MoMA Design Store are savvy just like the customers.

NEW BID FOR ABN AMRO Royal Bank of Scotland and two other lenders started the biggest takeover battle in banking industry by offering 72.2 billion euros, or $98.5 billion, for the Dutch bank ABN Amro. The offer trumps a bid by Barclays for the bank. [Page C1.] EUROPE IS IN A BUYING FRENZY The takeover battle for ABN Amro is just the latest sign of Europe's growing deal frenzy. [C12.] SIEMENS CHIEF TO STEP DOWN The embattled chief executive of Siemens, Klaus Kleinfeld, said that he would step down when his contract expired in September, becoming the latest casualty in a widening corruption scandal that has shaken corporate Germany. ''In times like these,'' Mr. Kleinfeld, above, said, ''the company needs clarity about its leadership. I have therefore decided not to make myself available for an extension of my contract.'' [C1.] DOW SOARS PAST 13,000 The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 13,000 for the first time and is up 6 percent for the month, its best performance in a single month since December 2003. The rally has defied skeptics who thought stocks were due for a slide. [C1.] ASIA'S ANSWER TO SWITZERLAND Singapore is trying to carve out a new niche for itself in the global economy -- as a sanctuary for the world's wealthy and their money -- by bolstering banking secrecy laws and offering generous tax incentives. [C1.] RULES ON TV VIOLENCE The Federal Communications Commission urged lawmakers to consider regulations that would restrict violent programs to late evening, when most children would not be watching. [C1.] HOUSING ASIDE, HOPEFUL SIGNS New data on durable goods orders has allayed fears that business investment was about to falter, raising expectations that decent economic growth can continue while the pullback in residential real estate runs its course. [C4.] PROMOTING U.S. MANUFACTURING United States Steel, Alcoa, Goodyear and other manufacturing companies have formed an unusual alliance with the United Steelworkers, aiming to preserve and promote manufacturing in the United States. [C2.] DELAY FOR EX-COMVERSE CHIEF Lawyers for Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technologies who faces charges of options fraud and is regarded as a fugitive, won a fresh delay of attempts to extradite him from Namibia to the United States.[C2.] SERVERS OF THE FUTURE Sun Microsystems and I.B.M. plan to introduce specialized high-end server systems, providing fresh evidence of a new era in computing. [C12.] APPLE'S QUARTERLY PROFIT UP 88% Apple Inc. surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts for its usually tepid second quarter, delivering an 88 percent increase in profit on strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod music players. The company said that its profit rose to $770 million, from $410 million in the comparable quarter last year. Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, called the quarter a ''blowout.'' [C3.] NOT GOING QUIETLY Fred D. Anderson, the former Apple board member who appeared to be a fall guy in the federal investigation of Apple's options-backdating policies, has instead made a statement that keeps suspicions swirling around the company's chief, Steven P. Jobs. [C3.] GETTING ON BOARD WITH JOOST Joost, the Internet television service being developed by the founders of Skype, has lined up several blue-chip advertisers as it prepares for its introduction. Advertising. [C13.] A WANING INFLUENCE IN HOLLYWOOD As Hollywood's most visible female power brokers have left their jobs and been replaced with men, there is a growing sense that ''women's pictures'' are being pushed aside in favor of action-adventure films like ''300.'' [E1.] UNCOVERING TALENT IN THE MINORS A business professor and a consultant are using baseball's minor leagues as a model for building networks in underserved and overlooked regions of the country for identifying, recruiting and developing entrepreneurs. CHILEWICH--Simon. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Simon Chilewich, a prominent figure of the Jewish community whose commitment and generosity profoundly impacted the most vulnerable, and strengthened Jewish life and learning in New York, in Israel, and worldwide. We extend our deepest sympathies to Simon's children; Melvin, Martin, and Sandra; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

The House on Wednesday narrowly approved a $124 billion war spending bill that would require American troops to begin withdrawing from Iraq by Oct. 1, setting the stage for the first veto fight between President Bush and majority Democrats. Only hours after Gen. David H. Petraeus, the commander in Iraq, told lawmakers he needed more time to gauge the effectiveness of a troop buildup there, the House voted 218 to 208 to pass a measure that sought the removal of most combat forces by next spring. Mr. Bush has said unequivocally and repeatedly that he will veto it.

VARET--Frances Goldberg. Died peacefully at home on April 24th age 91. Beloved wife of the late Guster V. Varet and adored mother of Ellen Bock and Michael A. Varet. Also survived by her devoted grandchildren, Lauren Schwartz and her husband Adam, Joseph Varet, Sarah Varet and David Varet, her darling great-granddaughter, Alexandra Schwartz, her daughter - in - law Elizabeth Varet and son-in-law Charles Bock. Graduate of the Class of 1935 at Long Island University and for many years a much admired teacher of English at Midwood High School where she especially enjoyed her work with students who needed to improve their reading skills. Funeral will be private. The family will observe Shiva at the home of Elizabeth and Michael Varet on Thursday from 5pm until 8pm, Friday afternoon from 2pm until 5pm, Sunday from 2pm until 8pm, and Monday and Tuesday from 6:30pm until 9pm. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate contributions to the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, 475 West 250th Street, Riverdale, NY 10471, or to the UJA-Federation of Greater New York, 130 East 59th Street, New York, NY 10022. $(6$)VARET--Frances Goldberg. The Board of Directors of Plaza Jewish Community Chapel extends its deepest sympathy to Board Member Michael Varet and his family on the loss of his mother, Frances Varet. May her memory be a blessing for all who mourn. Al Engleberg, President Andrew Fier, Executive Director $(6$)VARET--Frances. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Frances Varet, beloved mother of Michael Varet and mother-in-law of Elizabeth Varet. Elizabeth and Michael's dedication, expressed through their leadership and boundless generosity, sets an example of philanthropic leadership imbued with compassionate generosity and the spirit of klal Yisrael, which profoundly impacts our community and enriches the lives of millions in New York, in Israel, and around the globe. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Elizabeth and Michael; to their children, Joseph, Sarah, and David; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.
''Even if the Supreme Court does not understand the law, we do.'' GOV. ELIOT SPITZER, on his legislative proposal to buttress abortion rights in New York. [B4]

Canada will ban inefficient light bulbs within five years, the natural resources minister, Gary Lunn, said. The decision follows a similar move by Australia and by Canada's most populous province, Ontario. Regulations for the ban, which will not be available until later this year, will require bulbs to meet minimum efficiency standards. While that will remove traditional incandescent bulbs from store shelves, it may also affect other technologies, like bulbs filled with halogen gas. IAN AUSTEN
To the Editor: Re ''No Spitting on the Road to Olympic Glory, Beijing Says'' (news article, April 17):

Beginning on Monday, woven cotton rugs by Woodard Weave in discontinued patterns will be on sale at 40 to 75 percent off retail prices. Ends of rolls and one-of-a-kind samples will also be offered. Area rugs -- some of them as large as room-size -- and 27-inch-wide runners will be $4.24 to $8.48 a square foot (reduced from $18.50 a square foot). For an additional $20, the rugs can be finished with fringe; free fringing lessons will be offered as well. On the first three days, a free round-trip bus will leave at 10 a.m. from the northwest corner of 55th Street and 3rd Avenue and return by noon. Through May 10 at the Woodard Weave Workroom, 37-24 24th Street (38th Avenue), Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-5307. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, formally began his second bid for the White House on Wednesday with a thinly veiled critique of the Bush administration, pledging that he would restore competence to foreign and domestic policy and welcome compromise with Democrats. Mr. McCain lamented the ''many mistakes'' in Iraq, alluded to Hurricane Katrina and the government's failure to ''rescue the infirm from a hospital with no electricity,'' criticized ''substandard care and indifference for our wounded veterans'' and called for reining in what he termed wasteful federal spending over six years of Republican rule.

Iran met with the European Union over its uranium enrichment program, the first face-to-face talks between the top negotiators for the sides since the United Nations Security Council expanded sanctions on Iran in March. The talks, in Ankara, Turkey, continued late into the evening. At their conclusion, after five hours, Iran's nuclear negotiator, Ali Larijani, said, ''There are ideas on the table, still in discussion,'' the Anatolian news agency reported. ''We have time to continue also tomorrow. Within two weeks, we will have more meetings.'' Javier Solana, the European Union's foreign policy chief who is negotiating on behalf of the permanent members of the Security Council, called the talks ''productive.'' A press conference is scheduled for today. SABRINA TAVERNISE
SAMEK--Michael J. Died on April 21, 2007. Family and friends will gather for a Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, on Thursday, April 26, 2007, at 3pm.

An article in some copies on Sunday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to plant a million trees in New York City over the next 10 years misstated the role of carbon dioxide, which trees absorb, in ozone layer depletion. In fact, it has no effect.

A Rome court ruled this week that Italy must return a second-century statue of Venus to Libya. In a statement, the Italian culture ministry said it was satisfied with the decision, which it described as an ''important legal precedent'' and ''coherent'' with Italy's own efforts to recover illegally exported artifacts from foreign museums and collectors. The legal battle over the statue, above, began nearly five years ago when then Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi ceded to Libyan demands to return the statue, which had been found by an Italian archaeological expedition in 1913 at Cyrene, an ancient Greek colony, later Romanized, that is now a Unesco World Heritage site. Italia Nostra, a conservation group, had challenged the restitution, arguing that the headless statue was part of Italy's cultural heritage, but on Monday an administrative court dismissed the challenge. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

FALK--Paul, born July 21, 1922, passed away at Woodside Hospice, Pinellas Park, FL, on Wednesday, April 25, 2007 at the age of 84. The adored husband of June, celebrating their 60th anniversary on Thanksgiving Day 2006. He was the cherished son of the late David and Ray Falk; beloved brother of Norma Landsman, Pearl Forman, and the late Henry Falk; and unforgettable uncle to numerous nieces and nephews, grand and great. Paul was for many years a vocational rehabilitation counselor and chief vocational guidance counselor. After retirement he volunteered for the Metropolitan Museum until 2006. A creative and sensitive individual, poet, potter, and photographer, Paul will always be remembered as a warm, comforting, kind person by all who loved him.

On the strength of her cheerleader-rock smash ''Girlfriend'' (''Hey, hey!/You, you!/I don't like your girlfriend!''), Avril Lavigne opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, with 381,000 sales of her album ''The Best Damn Thing'' (RCA), according to Nielsen SoundScan. Ms. Lavigne, left, made numerous television appearances last week, and the video for ''Girlfriend'' has been a hit on MTV and online, with more than 16 million views on YouTube. Nine Inch Nails promoted ''Year Zero'' (Interscope) in a much less conventional way, with hidden messages scattered across the Web. But the album still reached No. 2 in its first week, with 187,000 copies sold. After two weeks at No. 1, ''Now That's What I Call Music! Vol. 24'' fell to No. 3, and the ''American Idol'' contestant Bucky Covington opened at No. 4, moving 61,000 copies of his self-titled album on Lyric Street. BEN SISARIO

Biden Jr., Hillary Rodham Clinton, Christopher J. Dodd and Barack Obama; former Senators John Edwards and Mike Gravel; Representative Dennis Kucinich; and Gov. Bill Richardson are confirmed to participate. Chris Matthews, Keith Olbermann and Tom Brokaw will provide predebate coverage at 6. Post-debate analysis will begin at 8:30. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) ALCATRAZ: LIVING HELL -- Al Capone spent time there. So did Machine Gun Kelly and Robert Stroud, a k a the Birdman. This documentary examines the country's first maximum security prison and the inmates who tried time and again to conquer the Rock. 8 P.M. (HBO) THE TRIALS OF DARRYL HUNT -- In 1984 Deborah Sykes, a young white newspaper reporter, was raped, sodomized and stabbed to death near her office in Winston-Salem, N.C. Though no physical evidence implicated him, Darryl Hunt, a 19-year-old black man, was identified as the perpetrator by a former Ku Klux Klan member, convicted of the crime by a jury of 11 whites and one black and sentenced to life in prison. Ten years later, DNA proved that Mr. Hunt did not rape Ms. Sykes and cast credible doubt on his role in the murder, but he spent another 10 years behind bars nonetheless. This documentary, a decade in the making, looks at the investigation by Phoebe Zerwick, a Winston-Salem journalist, that finally exonerated Mr. Hunt (above center, upon his release) and follows the lawyers and supporters who fought for him. 10:30 P.M. (Showtime) THIS AMERICAN LIFE -- Subtitle this one ''Pandora's Box.'' Ira Glass examines overzealous scientists, including some who erased minds, others who unwittingly botched their porcine research and a couple of hot dog stand owners (are they scientists?) whose better business practices unleashed some unsavory human emotions. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- It's practically a war zone: Steve Martin, Tony Trischka and Béla Fleck play dueling banjos. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Toyota passing General Motors as the No. 1 automaker misstated an earlier period when G.M. lost the top spot because of a strike. It was overtaken by Ford in the late 1990s, not the 1980s. (G.M. also faltered because of a strike in the 1970s, and Ford claimed the top spot.)

Ikea, the company known for its low-priced, flat-packed furniture, has introduced a new 82-piece collection called Stockholm -- furniture that is slightly more expensive because it is made of higher-quality materials, according to Ikea, and requires less assembly than the company's other lines. Each of the pieces is associated with a particular Swedish designer. The extra wide armchair, above, is covered in red or beige velvet and costs $699. A sofa that seats three or more, which comes with a removable fabric cover or in dark brown leather, is $1,399; a swivel footstool in pony skin or velvet is $299; and the oak-veneer cupboard, right, is $399. There are lamps, fabrics, rugs and vases as well; at Ikea stores, (800) 434-4532 or ikea.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

The Smithsonian Institution plans to charge admission for part of a new permanent exhibition at the National Museum of Natural History called ''Butterflies and Plants: Partners in Evolution,'' the museum confirmed yesterday. Admission to the Smithsonian's Washington museums has historically been free; the institution receives 70 percent of its financing from the government. Some members of Congress have recently urged the institution to find ways to raise more of its own money. The exhibition, scheduled to open in November, will include a climate-controlled space full of butterflies that requires admission of about $5. The rest of the show, which focuses on plants and butterflies, will be free. The Washington Post reported yesterday that the fee was planned. The decision was made by the Smithsonian Board of Regents, The Post said, citing minutes it obtained of the board's January meeting. Fees would be waived one day a week. ROBIN POGREBIN

In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society. A memorial service will be held at The Village Temple, 33 East 12th St., New York City, on Sunday, May 20 at 11 am.
To the Editor: Re ''Imams at the Airport'' (letter, April 23):

The Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned death sentences in three cases from Texas, all by votes of 5 to 4 and all with Justice Anthony M. Kennedy providing the margin of victory to his four more liberal colleagues. Because all three decisions dealt with an idiosyncratic provision of the Texas death penalty law that is no longer in effect, their practical significance may be limited to requiring the resentencing of several dozen inmates on that state's death row.

A man from Princeton, N.J., was arrested and charged with driving without a license after his vehicle killed a motorcyclist in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said. Shiraz Sanjana, 47, was driving north on Ocean Avenue near Avenue R shortly after 2 p.m. when he suddenly made a U-turn and hit Syed Adil Zaidi, 21, of Brooklyn, who was going south on his motorcycle, the authorities said. Mr. Zaidi was was declared dead on arrival at a local hospital. Mr. Sanjana was charged with aggravated unlicensed operation of a motor vehicle and driving without a license. JENNIFER 8. LEE
KOSROVANI--Bahman. Beloved son and brother. Adoring father of Cyrus and Darius. Died April 26th, 2006. We miss you every day, always in our hearts.

In a vivid display of their new power, Democrats across Capitol Hill on Wednesday approved a flurry of subpoenas to fuel a series of investigations of the Bush administration. The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform issued three subpoenas in quick order. One was to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice to answer questions about the administration's prewar claims about Iraq's weapons programs and two were to the Republican National Committee and its chairman to be questioned about whether the party's e-mail system was used by Bush officials to conceal some of their actions.

BAREISS--Walter, was not only a passionate collector with a remarkable eye for art, he was also an exceptional human being with an eye for people he could help along the way. With his unceasingly gracious and caring wife, the late Molly Stimson Bareiss, he touched and transformed the lives of a small army of people -many artists, many not -both here and abroad. Consequently, this passionate collector of art became an inadvertent, compassionate collector of friends who remain a living monument to his guidance, support, and caring. He will be greatly missed. Caryl Avery Les Zuke Joan FitzGerald

Design Within Reach, the furniture retailer, is collaborating with Airstream to develop a trailer for the mobile young modernist --''rock climbers, surfers, dot-com guys,'' said Christopher Deam, the San Francisco architect in charge of the project, ''who want to work anywhere with cellphones and wi-fi connections.'' The trailer has kitchen cabinets lined with green plastic laminate, far right, a Nelson Ball Clock and a dinette with cushions upholstered in striped fabric by Paul Smith, the fashion designer, which doubles as a bed (the table slides down to align with the seats and the cushions serve as a mattress). It also has a separate bedroom, right, a flat-screen TV, an antenna and phone jacks. ''At some campgrounds, you can pull in and plug all that stuff in, and wire it like an extension of your house,'' Mr. Deam said. The 16-foot trailer will be $49,066, in early June, through dwr.com or Airstream dealers: (877) 596-6111. ELAINE LOUIE

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about the London Marathon referred incorrectly to the performance of Ryan Hall, an American making his marathon debut. He led the race near Mile 22; he was not the leader for almost 22 miles.

After executing 19 search warrants early yesterday in the Cypress Hills Houses in East New York, the police said they had arrested 53 people, including 23 women, on charges of selling crack cocaine or heroin. The sweep was conducted at a public housing project that has long been plagued by illegal drugs. Eighty people were arrested there on similar charges in 2002. Inspector Steven Powers said that the arrests yesterday followed more than 100 drug purchases by undercover agents, and that some of the dealers had been paying tenants' rent in exchange for using their apartments for drug sales. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that ''crime had spiked'' in the Cypress Hills Houses, but that the arrests would provide residents with ''better, safer lives.'' THOMAS J. LUECK

WEINBERGER--Geri, on April 23, age 64, at home. Geri died of complications from leukemia. Per her request, no service will be held. Respects may be paid at the home of her son, Mitchel Weinberger, 300 Iroquois Lane, Franklin Lakes, NJ, on April 29th through May 1st.

THE battle lines were drawn. Among the thousands of new products unveiled at the 46th International Furniture Fair outside Milan last week, almost all of the standouts belonged to one of two camps: a cadre of neo-Surrealist designers whose sensational, impractical, often supersize work is more than anything a form of self-expression, and a more serious group of neo-rationalists, who hark back to old-school Modernists in their desire to make better products for everyday use. ''No one's going to win,'' said Murray Moss, the New York design impresario, of the war of ideas brewing at the Rho-Pero fairgrounds and at the fringe shows around the city. He seemed upbeat about his prediction, reflecting a mood that had taken hold across Milan: Finally, people seemed to feel, the furniture industry is healthy enough to support a little competition.

HART--Kitty Carlisle. The Board and Staff of the New York Foundation for the Arts gratefully acknowledge her lifelong contributions to the arts and to artists. She was our true champion and will be missed by all. Kathleen O'Grady, President Michael L. Royce, Executive Director

Tuesday's first-ever charity telethon edition of ''American Idol,'' which Fox called ''Idol Gives Back,'' held up well in the ratings, drawing 25.7 million viewers, just shy of the 26.6 million who tuned in a week ago. according to Nielsen's estimates. The first hour of the two-day special, which hopes to raise money and awareness in the fight against global poverty, featured what Fox was calling ''life anthem'' performances by the six remaining contestants. Fox easily won the night's ratings over all, dominating the 9 p.m. hour after ''Idol'' with ''House'' (21.3 million). ABC and CBS were about even in second place. ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show fared solidly at 9 (16.4 million), while CBS posted up well opposite ''Idol'' at 8 with ''NCIS'' (14.1 million). The CW tied NBC, which broadcast mostly repeats, for fourth place for the night among adults 18 to 49. The CW's ''Gilmore Girls'' at 8 drew 3.7 million viewers, followed by the finale of ''Pussycat Dolls Presents: The Search for the Next Doll'' at 9 (3.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

FORTE--Michael J., 56, of New Canaan, died Thursday, April 19, 2007, peacefully, with his loving wife at his side, at the Richard Rosenthal Hospice Residence in Stamford. He was born on May 28, 1950, in St. Louis, MO, the son of Joseph and Dorothy Graham Forte of Ellsworth, PA. Mike received his B.A. from the Pennsylvania State University School of Journalism in 1972. In 1982 he received his MBA through The Executive Development Program at the Simon Graduate School of Business in Rochester, New York. For 15 years he had a distinguished marketing career at Eastman Kodak Company. Mike started Soccer USA Partners in early 1990, a marketing organization to promote the U.S. National Soccer. Through aggressive marketing and national broadcast exposure for U.S. soccer, blue-chip corporations began to rally behind the world's sport and made it very American. The corporate funding paved the way to an immeasurably better platform for U.S. soccer, leading to a very strong showing for the men's team in the 1994 World Cup. In 1996, Mike joined Spectacolor Communications as President and CEO and helped build Spectacolor into what became the dominant billboard company in Times Square, NYC. Under Michael's unique ''visionary'' status, the company built the most fabulous signs in the heart of Manhattan. Mike joined ClearChannel Outdoor (then Eller Media Company) in April 2000, when ClearChannel Outdoor acquired Spectacolor, which was renamed ClearChannel Spectacolor. Michael remained CEO and guided the successful expansion of that company. He soon became a key member of ClearChannel Outdoors senior management team, leading other ClearChannel businesses. His entrepreneurial drive and creativity lead to the creation of what is now known as the company's Branded Cities division, a unique integration of signage and sponsorship of major mixed-use commercial, retail and residential developments. Mike was the consummate professional at the highest of levels. As accomplished as he was, what mattered most to Mike was his family. He is survived by his wife, Jane Forte of New Canaan, his two sons, Max and Cameron Forte of New Canaan, his three daughters, Beth Forte of Rochester, NY, Allegra & Michaela Forte of Old Saybrook, CT, brother, Thomas Forte of Longwood, FL, and his sister Jane Guaetta of Hummelstown, PA. Three nieces and one nephew also survive. He was a member of The Core Club in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Michael J. Forte Trust for the benefit of his sons, Max Forte and Cameron Forte. Donations may be mailed to The Michael J. Forte Trust, P.O. Box 937, New Canaan, CT 06840. A funeral service will be held on Friday, April 27, 2007, at the Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main St., New Canaan, at 11:00am. Floral services can be made through Springdale Florists at (203) 329-8857. Interment will be private.

The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday, about weight-loss products, included an outdated reference to the drug Alli, known clinically as orlistat. The Food and Drug Administration approved it on Feb. 7 for over-the-counter sale; its approval is no longer conditional.

SCHINDLER--Mark. When you came into our mother's life, you also brought us so much joy. You were a man respected by all who knew you. We cherished the moments we spent together both individually and as a family. We trusted your opinions and loved your terrific sense of humor. You will be greatly missed and never forgotten. Our heartfelt condolences to your children, Steve and Suzie; sisters Lilian (Sy) and Ruth; and to your sweetheart Barbara Serota. We will love you always, Billy, Gail, Scott, Spencer and Julie

Endorsing a set of common criminal penalties across the European Union for the first time, the European Parliament approved legislation that would impose jail sentences and fines on counterfeiters of drugs, toys and other goods in the 27-country bloc. The legislation, which still must be approved by national governments, aims to protect consumers from unsafe products like fake Viagra pills or imitation condoms, while preventing the infringement of intellectual property in the music and film industry. . DAN BILEFSKY

HGTV is billing its new reality series, ''Bought & Sold,'' as a ''Dynasty''-style drama, full of calculation and competition, but its pleasures, such as they are, are of a gentler sort. Its characters are real estate brokers at Remax offices in Northern New Jersey, and they seem to be a kindly group, not much given to backstabbing each other or pulling the wool over their clients' eyes. This Sunday, the first episode, is a day with Vanessa Pollock and Sam Joseph. She is a model/actress-turned-broker; he is a former window display artist, most recently the creative director of Macy's Herald Square. She has two young couples who want the same Dutch Colonial-style house, and she really, really likes them both; he stumbles a bit, but not too terribly, in his trial tour with the owners of a historic estate, to whom he is pitching himself. As characters, they are mildly appealing; so too is the placid, passive fun of watching a video ramble through a few houses. But it all seems so easy, if your prism is the dark and desperate Manhattan market (or if you have any awareness of the subprime mortgage crisis). Presumably HGTV's market is nonurban, and the suburbs of New Jersey are comparable to viewers' own habitats. But what a show they might have made with Manhattan brokers. ''Dynasty,'' indeed. PENELOPE GREEN

A sports picture caption yesterday about Toronto's 89-83 playoff victory against the Nets referred imprecisely in some copies to the Raptors' postseason history. It was the team's first playoff victory in five years -- not the first ever. (The first was in 2001, against the Knicks.)

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he hoped former Vice President Al Gore would run for president in 2008, saying ''I think it would be good for the country.'' The mayor made the comments to reporters after a news conference kicking off the Tribeca Film Festival, as the two men took the stage and teased each other over speculation about their respective presidential ambitions.

HALBERSTAM--David. The International Center of Photography Staff and Board mourn the death of David Halberstam and extend our sincere condolences to his family. His impact on our world was substantial and for all our benefit. Willis E. Hartshorn, Director Cornell Capa, Founding Director Emeritus
BROOKS--Patricia, died April 14. Her service will be Sunday May 6th at 3pm. Riverdale Presbyterian Church, 4763 H. Hudson Pkwy., Bronx, NY.
To the Editor: Re ''Bush and Cheney Chide Democrats on Iraq Deadline'' (front page, April 25):

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about efforts to solve the mystery of collapsing honeybee populations misstated the institution where a project to sequence honeybee genes was completed late last year. It is Baylor College of Medicine, not Baylor University. (The two became separate institutions in 1969.) And a map with the article, showing the extent of the problem in the United States, reversed the labels for Kansas and Nebraska, two states where collapsing populations have not been reported.

''Tord Boontje,'' by Martina Margetts, editor of Crafts magazine in London, is Rizzoli's blowout monograph of the Dutch designer's work ($75). Some pages are die-cut in a Boontje design, like a wood-cut from a Grimm's fairy tale, making the book itself a beautiful object, much like ''Until Dawn,'' left, Mr. Boontje's lacy curtain panel made from Tyvek, the polyethylene paper used in house framing ($96 at unicahome.com). Mr. Boontje, who brought an artisanal sensibility into contemporary product design, may be the closest thing industrial design has to a celebrity -- he's at the Tate and, since late last year, at Target. It's not hard to see why: using synthetic materials, he makes heartbreakingly delicate objects that look handcrafted but come off a production line. ''A complex evocation of delicate fantasy, fairy tale and myth imagery drives everything he does,'' said Franklin Getchell, the president of the design store Moss. ''It's impossible to resist.'' PENELOPE GREEN

The Supreme Court put defenders of the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law on the defensive on Wednesday in a spirited argument that suggested the court could soon open a significant loophole in the measure. At issue is a major provision of the five-year-old law that bars corporations and labor unions from paying for advertisements that mention the name of a candidate for federal office and that are broadcast 60 days before an election or 30 days before a primary. By a 5-to-4 vote in December 2003, the court held that the provision, on its face, passed First Amendment muster.

KATZ--Ken, passed away at home in Jamaica Estates, NY on April 18, 2007 at age 61 after a noble and courageous battle with cancer. Son of Belle and the late Joseph Katz, Ken was a devoted school psychologist at West Hempstead High School, where he worked with Special Education students. A passionate traveler and humanitarian, he leaves friends in Cambodia, Tibet, Thailand and throughout the world. He is survived by his loving wife Ellen; mother Belle and brother Ronald of Santa Monica, CA; nephew Richard of Torrance, CA; nieces Laura Huntington of Canby, OR and Margaret Katz of Livonia, MI; sister-in-law Karen Fink of Brooklyn, NY; cherished friends Susan Horsey, Art Sherin and Joan Flum; and by Inle and Miwa. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions may be made to the HALO Trust, c/o HALO USA, 850 7th Avenue, Suite 506, New York, NY 10019.

The deal-making frenzy has taken over Europe, pushing ahead of the United States. So far this year, the value of mergers and acquisitions announced in Europe is $656.4 billion, compared with $601.4 billion in the United States, according to Thomson Financial. The activity is prompting changes in corporate behavior. European companies are scrambling to put themselves in play, or fend off unwanted bids, much as American companies did in the 1980s. By Mark Landler, Page C12

Heartfelt condolences are extended to her husband, David, their sons, Jacob and Adam, and their loved ones. May her memory be for blessing and may her loved ones be comforted amidst the mourners of our people for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Lois S. Nyren, President

The former head of the New Haven Police Department's narcotics division was indicted yesterday on charges including theft, bribery and fraud, federal prosecutors said. The former lieutenant, William B. White, 63, and three bail bondsmen were arrested last month in a federal sting operation. Prosecutors said Mr. White routinely received money from the three men: Robert Jacobs, 79, who runs a local bail bonds service, and his two sons, Paul, 48, and Philip, 47. According to prosecutors, the bondsmen would bribe Mr. White to track down criminals who had posted bail bonds but failed to appear; their failure to appear would have caused the bondsmen to lose money. JENNIFER MEDINA

An obituary on Monday about Parry O'Brien, the shot-putting champion, misstated the year he last broke the world record, and the distance. It was 1959, not 1966, and the record distance was 63 feet 4 inches, not 63-3.

SCHACTER--Herbert. The Partners and members of the firm of Needleman & Schacter, LLP mourn the loss of their partner. He was an inspiration to all the members of the firm and always offered thoughtful advice to the clients. We want to express our deep regrets to his wife Barbara, sons Ira, Howie, Alan and his grandchildren.

A music review on Monday about the UBS Verbier Festival Chamber Orchestra, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the name of another training orchestra that recently played there. It is the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, not the East-West Divan Orchestra.

A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on April 6, about performances and discussions at the Flea Theater in Lower Manhattan, misidentified the curator who chose the works performed. She was Nina Winthrop -- not Yasuko Yokoshi, who had been scheduled to be the moderator, but who was repalced by Ms Winthrop.

New Jersey officials asked a federal appeals court yesterday to overturn a decision by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that the possibility of a terrorist attack on the Oyster Creek nuclear plant should not be a consideration in deciding whether to extend its license. Oyster Creek, the country's oldest operating plant, is seeking to extend its license for 20 years beyond its 2009 expiration date. In reviewing the potential environmental impact of continued operation, the N.R.C. did not take terrorism into account, and state officials claim that the commission erred. They have appealed the decision in the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

An article on April 18 about a program that allows the city to calculate the dollar value of its trees referred imprecisely to one of the environmental benefits. Trees absorb carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas that is a primary contributor to global warming, but that process has no effect on the cleanliness of the air.

The Saturday Profile, about Saifa Benaouda, a Swedish Muslim who went to Somalia last December as the country was becoming a magnet for Islamic extremists, referred incorrectly to Daniel Maldonado, an American Muslim convert in Somalia arrested on the Kenya border and deported to the United States in February on terrorism-related charges. Mr. Maldonado pleaded guilty in Houston federal court last Thursday to receiving training from a foreign terrorist organization. He is not ''currently on trial.''

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 House Passes Bill Requiring Troop Withdrawal from Iraq The House narrowly approved a $124 billion war spending bill that would require American troops to begin withdrawing from Iraq by Oct. 1, setting the stage for the first veto fight between President Bush and the Democratic majority. A12 The United Nations released a report accusing the Iraqi government of failing to ''seriously address'' problems of detainee abuse, including torture, and to ensure the timely and fair prosecution of detainees. A11 French Also-Ran Slams Rivals François Bayrou, who won 18 percent of the first-round vote for the French presidency, criticized the two candidates who go on to the runoff, a Socialist and a conservative, and refused to endorse either. A8 Israeli's Conduct in Question Israel's state comptroller released a report accusing the prime minister, Ehud Olmert, of improperly helping an associate during his term as minister of trade and industry. The attorney general will decide whether to begin an investigation, a spokeswoman said. A3 Yeltsin Buried in Moscow Boris N. Yeltsin, Russia's first democratically elected president, was buried after a somber, symbolic funeral service attended by Russia's political elite, current and former world leaders, family and close friends. A6 NATIONAL A16-23 Court Asked to Limit Lawyers at Guantánamo The Justice Department has asked a federal appeals court to impose tight new restrictions on the hundreds of lawyers who represent detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and the request has become a central issue in a new legal battle over the administration's detention policies. A1 Vaccination Efforts Blocked A revolt by lawmakers has blocked Gov. Rick Perry's effort for Texas to become the first state to require sixth-grade girls to be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer. A16 10 Killed by Tornado in Texas A fierce tornado killed at least 10 people on both sides of the Texas-Mexico border and more than 500 rescue workers searched through the rubble of Eagle Pass, southwest of San Antonio. A16 Hispanics Alter Catholicism The influx of Hispanic immigrants to the United States is transforming the Roman Catholic Church as well as the nation's religious landscape, according to a study. A18 EDUCATION Loan Companies Criticized New York's attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, accused the federal Education Department of being lax in regulating the student loan industry and said criminal charges might result from his months-long investigation into ties between universities and lenders. A23 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 New York Trooper Killed During Catskills Manhunt A New York State trooper was killed and another wounded in a Catskill Mountains village as they tracked down a man suspected of shooting and wounding another trooper on Tuesday, the authorities said. A body was found in the farmhouse where the man, Travis D. Trim, was believed to be hiding. A1 A New Look at Abortion Law Governor Spitzer said he planned to introduce legislation to overhaul New York's abortion law, one that predates the Roe v. Wade decision by three years but is considered out of date by abortion rights advocates. A1 ARTS E1-10 Rosie to Leave 'The View' Rosie O'Donnell, who raised both the profile and the ratings of ''The View'' this season by commandeering it as a bully pulpitfor her opinions on the Iraq war, Donald Trump, Oprah Winfrey and even her own cast mates, will leave the show in June after failing to reach a contract extension, she announced on the program. To the Editor: Re ''France Looks Ahead, and It Doesn't Look Good,'' by Tony Judt (Op-Ed, April 22):

The United States and the Global Business Coalition on H.I.V./AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria have jointly donated $2.9 million to distribute more than 500,000 insecticide-treated mosquito nets in Zambia. The nets will help protect those who sleep under them from contracting malaria, which kills up to 50,000 Zambians a year, mostly children. The nets, enough for a tenth of the country's population, will be handed out before November, the beginning of the malaria season. CELIA W. DUGGER

We are deeply saddened by the passing of Rich, a giving, caring and fun loving colleague. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Krista, to his sister, Monica, and to his parents, Sharon and Tony.

Surpassing even the most optimistic forecasts, Apple delivered an 88 percent increase in profit in its second quarter, sending its shares over $100 for the first time in after-hours trading. But while investors were rewarding the chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, Silicon Valley was talking about a former chief financial officer's assertion that he cautioned Mr. Jobs in 2001 about the handling of stock options at Apple. Articles, Page C3.

WITH summer guests on the way, it is time to prepare extra beds. Many of those shown open to accommodate two people, while others sleep one. And some can be stacked, in multiples, when not in use. 1. Duo is a 26-by-26-inch ottoman that can be used as a coffee table during the day with a tray on top. Unfolded, it becomes a 76-by-25-inch sleeping mattress for one. Made in Denmark, it is $298 (plus $48 for the tray) from Apt, 61 Greene Street (Spring Street), (800) 694-9164 or apt-ny.com. 2. One2 opens to a queen-size bed. Designed by two architects, Flemming Busk and Stephan Hertzog, and made in Denmark, it is available in various colors; $998 from Apt (see No. 1 for contact information). 3. The Lubi Daybed could be used as a psychiatrist's couch or a bed for one; unfolded, it accommodates two. The foam-rubber cushions have a removable khaki-color cover made of a polyester, cotton and linen blend fabric, and the daybed measures 79 by 32 1/2 inches; $749 from CB2, (800) 606-6252 or cb2.com. 4. City is a sofa that opens into a 59-by-82-inch double bed. It has two individually adjustable backrests, so one person can sit while another is lying down. Created by Stine Engelbrechtsen, a Danish designer, it is available in 13 colors; $1,498 from Apt (see No. 1 for contact information). 5. Duo, designed by Pascal Mourgue, can be purchased as a single lounge-daybed ($3,210) or, as shown, as a sofa bed ($6,290); from Ligne Roset, ligne-roset-usa.com (for stores nationally) or (800) 297-6738. 6. The simplest kind of extra bedding is a floor cushion that folds in half for storage (and can be stacked in anticipation of a crowd). This 74-by-33-inch version is covered in taupe velvet; $100 from Urban Outfitters, urbanoutfitters.com or (800) 282-2200. 7. Flip Flap, by Ana Mir, a designer in Barcelona, is a 72-by-28 1/2-inch daybed made of foam rubber on a wood frame with stainless steel legs. Covered in wool felt, as shown, it is $3,815 (although other fabrics are available or you can supply your own); at Dune, 88 Franklin Street (Church Street), (212) 925-6171 or dune-ny.com.

PARKER--Edward H., 91, of Wantagh, NY died peacefully on April 22, 2007. He was born on January 28, 1916 in NYC to the late Augusta Nichols and Edward Parker. In September 1938 he married Lillian McCleery at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. She predeceased him in 1996. He married Margaret Cray in 1997. Mr. Parker attended high school in NYC and attended Columbia University. Mr. Parker proudly served with the 881st Field Artillary Battalion from April 1943 to the conclusion of the war in 1945. After the war he rejoined Union Carbide Corporation and served as Assistant Treasurer until his retirement in 1982. He is survived by his wife Margaret, sons Bruce and his wife Ellen, Roger and his wife Meta and stepdaughter Priscilla Gray and grandchildren Andrew Parker and Natalie Rebecca Gray. Mr. Parker was a very active and devoted member of The First Presbyterian Church of Levittown for over sixty years. He provided strength and support to many church members and friends. A memorial service will be celebrated on Sunday, April 29, at 2:00pm, at the First Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, donations in his honor may be made to The INN (Interfaith Nutritional Network) at 211 Fulton Avenue, Hempstead, New York, 11550 or the First Presbyterian Church of Levittown at 474 Wantagh Avenue, Levittown, New York 11756. Funeral Arrangements entrusted to Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Avenue, Wantagh, NY.

Artist's Garbage Fetches Millions Francis Bacon's trash has sold for $2.26 million at auction. The 45 lots consisted of paintings and other items that the incensed Irish-born British artist (1909-92) sought to discard in 1978 after they were disturbed by workmen at his chaotic studio in London, the BBC reported. Mac Robertson, an electrical contractor who had become a Bacon friend and drinking companion, rescued them and stored them in an attic. The lots on sale at the Ewbank auction rooms in Woking, England, had been valued at $100,000. But a painting of a dog that was expected to sell for $6,000 sold for $610,000, and four portraits mutilated by Bacon, who would cut out parts he didn't like, sold for a total of $240,000. No Jail for Willie Nelson Willie Nelson, below, and his tour manager, David Anderson, were spared jail sentences when they pleaded guilty on Tuesday in St. Martinville, La., to a misdemeanor count of marijuana possession, The Associated Press reported. State District Judge Paul deMahy fined the men $1,024 each and put them on probation for six months. Mr. Nelson; Mr. Anderson; Mr. Nelson's sister, Bobbie Nelson; and two drivers were issued citations on Sept. 18 after state troopers said they found marijuana and hallucinogenic mushrooms on their tour bus during a commercial-vehicle inspection on Interstate 10. As part of the plea deal, the citation against Ms. Nelson was dismissed. The citations against the drivers were also dismissed. St. Martin Parish Assistant District Attorney Chester Cedars said there was no indication they ''had anything to do with the contraband.'' Public Library Acquires Gay and Lesbian Archive A major archive of letters, photographs, handbills, manuscripts, publications and other materials gathered by two pioneers in the campaign for gay and lesbian rights has been acquired by the New York Public Library. The materials were donated by Barbara Gittings, an activist, editor and writer who died in February, and by her partner, the photojournalist and author Kay Tobin Lahusen. The Barbara Gittings and Kay Tobin Lahusen Gay History Papers and Photographs will be housed at the Humanities and Social Sciences Library's manuscripts and archives division on Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street. Footnotes HBO has given the go-ahead to ''The Pacific,'' a 10-hour World War II mini-series with Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg as the executive producers, Reuters reported. A companion piece to their Emmy-winning 2001 HBO mini-series, ''Band of Brothers,'' the new venture will follow three marines -- Robert Leckie, John Basilone and Eugene Sledge -- from the Battle of Guadalcanal to their triumphant return home after V-J Day. A memoir by Scott McClellan, who departed as President Bush's chief spokesman in 2006, is to be published next spring by PublicAffairs, The Associated Press reported. The mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato has been named the recipient of the second annual Beverly Sills Artist Award for young singers at the Metropolitan Opera. The $50,000 prize, described by the Met as the largest of its kind in the United States, goes to singers between 25 and 40 year old who have appeared in featured solo roles with the company. Ms. DiDonato is starring in the Met's new production of Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia.''

A revolt by lawmakers has blocked Gov. Rick Perry's effort to make Texas the first state to require sixth-grade girls to be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer. In a 135-to-2 vote that appeared veto-proof, the Texas House gave final passage on Wednesday to a Senate bill that bars the state from ordering the shots until at least 2011. Even many supporters of the governor resented Mr. Perry's proposal as an abuse of executive authority.

LEVERE--Dr. Richard D., age 75, of Marietta, died of heart failure April 23, 2007. Born in Brooklyn, he graduated SUNY Downstate Medical School in 1956 and completed his internship and residency at Bellevue and Kings County Hospitals. After serving his country in the armed services, Dr. Levere had a distinguished medical career that included appointment as Chief of Hematology at Downstate Medical Center, Professor and Chairman of Medicine at New York Medical College, Chief of Medicine at Westchester County Medical Center, Vice President of Medical Affairs at Westchester County Medical Center, St. Agnes Hospital and the Brooklyn Hospital Center. He held professorships at New York Medical College, Rockefeller University, New York University, and the Weill Cornell School of Medicine. He served as Vice Dean at New York Medical College and Associate Dean at New York University Medical School. He was President of Cantigny Research Foundation and Director of the Lang Research Center. He served in leadership positions in many organizations, including the Wellness Community of Atlanta, Resurgens Charitable Foundation, Leukemia Society of America, and the American Heart Association. Dr. Levere was the recipient of numerous awards, including the William Dock Teaching Award, membership in the Alpha Omega Alpha Medical Honor Society, and the Tinsley Harrison Research Award. He was Governor of the New York Chapter of the American College of Physicians, a Fellow of the New York Academy of Medicine, and an active member of many medical societies. Apart from all of his academic and administrative accomplishments, fundamentally, Dr. Richard D. Levere was a teacher of physicians. He taught literally thousands of medical students, internal medicine residents and faculty, thereby favorably and profoundly affecting their professional lives. He served as their role model at the bedside, teaching both clinical reasoning and a respectful, compassionate approach toward patients. He was recognized as a Master of the American College of Physicians, a designation reserved for very few accomplished physicians. Dr. Levere is survived by his wife, Diane; son, Dr. Scott M. Levere, Atlanta; daughters, Elyssa C. Levere, Esq., Marietta and Corinne G. Levere-Latter and her husband Daniel F. Latter, Esq., Los Angeles, CA; brothers and sisters-in-law, Herbert and his wife, Barbara Levere, Vero Beach, FL, and Julius and his wife Ann Levere, Roslyn, NY; and grandchildren, Isabella Mae Levere, Jenna Claire Latter, and Samuel Kolmo Levere. He was preceded in death by his brother, Dr. Arthur Levere. Graveside services will be held on Friday, April 27 at 11:00am at Arlington Memorial Park (Atlanta) with Rabbi Scott Saulson officiating. Following the funeral, guests are welcome to the Levere home, beginning at 1:00pm. Please sign on-line guest book: www.edressler.com. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial contributions to The Wellness Community, 5780 Peachtree Dunwoody Road, Atlanta, GA 30342; or Resurgens Charitable Foundation, 5671 Peachtree Dunwoody Road, Suite 700, Atlanta, GA 30342. Services by Dressler's Jewish Funeral Care, Atlanta, 770-451-4999. $(6$)LEVERE--Richard D. New York Medical College is saddened by the loss of our esteemed colleague, Richard D. Levere, M.D., former professor of medicine, who served as chairman of the department from 1977 to 1993. We extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Ronald F. Poe, Chairman Board of Trustees Karl P. Adler, M.D. President and CEO Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D. Provost and Dean School of Medicine

The N.C.A.A. announced that it will no longer accept academic records from God's Academy Prep, a secondary school in Dallas that opened last year in a recreation center. An N.C.A.A. review of the school found a ''lack of formal instruction or organized curriculum structure,'' according to a news release. The school was opened in August 2005 in Irving, Tex., by a summer basketball coach and quickly blossomed to 40 students, all of whom were basketball players. The school sent two players to Division I schools last year: Jeremy Mayfield to Alabama-Birmingham and Tommy Moffitt to the University of Texas-Arlington. Two players from the school signed letters of intent to Division I schools this year, Marcus Brister to Iowa State and T. J. Clark to Morehead State. Their status will be reviewed. PETE THAMEL

GURIAN--Elias on April 25, 2007 in his 91st year. Devoted and beloved husband and friend of Lil (Leah) for 65 years. Father of Stephen, Bonny and Marvin Rosen, Donald and Karen Gurian. Grandfather of Alyson and Steven Justman, Melanie and Robert Gallucci, Justin Gurian, Ariel Gurian. Greatgrandfather to Jordyn, Alexa and Tyler. Founder of Gurian Fabrics, Inc. Inventor of the Fabrak. Served with the US Air Force during WWII. He was a member of The American Arbitration Association and was active in many Philanthropies including UJA/ Federation, Lubavitch Youth, State of Israel Bonds. Former Chairman of the Board of Congregation Beth Shalom. Long time resident of Lawrence, NY, and then Boca Raton, FL. He will be missed by the numerous people whose lives he enhanced by virtue of his great sense of humor, his kindness and his loving generosity. Graveside service at Old Montefiore Cemetery in Springfield Gardens, Queens, at 2pm on Friday, April 27. He wanted to be remembered, not mourned, since he had a most satisfying life.

STARR--Adele Louise Landau, 90, died peacefully on April 24, 2007. Survived by Lee, her loving husband of 64 years, brother Alfred, his wife Bobbie, and brother-in-law, Bill Teel. Beloved mother of Jonathan and Frederick, adored mother-in-law of Kelly Starr and Kitty Kiefer and loving granddaughter, Hazel Kiefer. Attended Radcliffe College. Community activist, elegant lady and Proust lover. Funeral private. Family will receive at home on April 26, from 3 to 6pm, and 7:30 to 9:30pm. In lieu of flowers, send contributions to Mamaroneck Library Building Fund, 136 Prospect St., Mamaroneck, NY 10543, care of Mary Soto.

Communities across the New York region are debating whether their local police should be involved in immigration issues. For example, in Morristown, N.J., the mayor has proposed to enroll the police in a small but growing federal program that trains local officers to help enforce federal immigration laws. The program is known as 287(g), for a section of the 1996 Immigration and Nationality Act that allows local officers, after being trained, to "identify, process, and when appropriate, detain immigration offenders they encounter during their regular, daily law-enforcement activity."

ALEXANDRIA, Va. - After deliberating for seven days in federal court here, a jury late this afternoon found Dr. William Hurwitz guilty on 16 counts of drug trafficking. Dr. Hurwitz, whose legal battles over his opioid prescriptions made him a hero to some chronic-pain patients, was not convicted on the other 29 counts against him.

It looks like Lastings Milledge is going to be out longer than anticipated. Milledge, diagnosed with sprained ligaments in his right foot during a recent trip to New York, will be out four to six weeks, Omar Minaya said tonight. This doesn't hurt the Mets much now, but if something were to happen to Moises Alou or Shawn Green, the team's options are slim. Ben Johnson, next in line after Milledge for a promotion, is out with a sprained shoulder. After him, it's Ricky Ledee or, if the Mets are feeling extra bold, the prospect Carlos Gomez.

Last October, I bought a ticket from American Airlines to travel from Los Angeles to Hong Kong. I tried to upgrade to business class using American AAdvantage miles, but was told that this was not possible because I was on a code-share flight operated by Cathay Pacific, a partner in the Oneworld Alliance. I now wonder, what is the "alliance" in Oneworld? It seems that airlines are making it more and more difficult for frequent fliers to take advantage of the loyalty we show them.
The decline in housing values is supposed to make Americans less willing to spend. But so far it has not.

The Eater web site today calls into question the poetry and catchiness of FR.OG as a name for a restaurant, and the Eater folks have a pretty good point, even if you delete the odd mid-word punctuation mark, which signals that the all-capitalized syllable is a sort-of-quasi-acronym for FRench OriGine.

While not quite Harry Potter, former C.I.A. director George Tenet's new book has generated lots of buzz, three days before its scheduled release. Mr. Tenet's contention that the White House ignored any evidence countering its view that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction leading up to the Iraq War provided liberal bloggers lots of new talking points on an old subject. For the most part, conservative blogs ignored the issue today.
Yang Jianli, a democracy activist and Boston resident, was released from a Chinese prison after serving a five-year sentence.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa - The presidential campaign of Senator John McCain of Arizona took on a decidedly military cast today, from more discussion of the war in Iraq to vivid memories of the war in Vietnam.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, speaking in forceful and personal terms, went this afternoon to a neighborhood plagued by high asthma rates to argue for his plan to reduce the city's air pollution. The proposal includes a surcharge for vehicles entering congested sections of Manhattan.
Some people have been waiting around, wondering if a letter would drop today following a report that Representative Rick Renzi, an Arizona Republican, could resign "as soon as Friday ."

Preston L. Felton, the acting New York State Police Superintendent, said during a news conference this afternoon that Trooper David C. Brinkerhoff was apparently killed by friendly fire during a gunfight on Wednesday between state troopers and a suspect holed up in an unoccupied farmhouse.
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his Apr. 27 column, "Gilded Once More."
Seventy years after the Hindenberg disaster, hydrogen has come a long way. The Times recently tested hydrogen vehicles from three manufacturers.
Governor Bill Richardson sat down with The New York Times and reflected on his performance during Thursday's debate.

"Obviously what we make is absolutely obscene," said Marc Lasry, founder and managing partner of Avenue Capital Group, speaking about his fellow hedge fund managers a recent panel sponsored by the Milken Institute. "I'm not saying it's wrong, trust me, but it's still obscene," he said, according to the Associated Press. And the eye-popping sums earned by hedge fund managers could work against the industry as it tries to burnish its image and avoid greater regulation from Washington.

Edward E. Whitacre Jr., who led an aggressive acquisition strategy that built AT&T into the world's largest telephone company, said Friday he will retire as AT&T's chairman and chief executive on June 3. The announcement comes just a few months after AT&T completed its $86 billion purchase of BellSouth, which was the largest deal of 2006. Mr. Whitacre will be succeeded by Randall L. Stephenson, currently the company's chief operating officer, who is expected to focus on execution and integration at the company, The New York Times's Matt Richtel reported. Investors and analysts said they were not surprised by the change in command.

J.P. Morgan Chase's investment banking arm has hired Margaret Whelan, a former research analyst from UBS, as a managing director. Ms. Whelan will be a senior partner in the group that works with homebuilding companies, J.P. Morgan said in an internal memo. At UBS, Ms. Whelan had been global head of homebuilding equity research.

Last week, BlackBerry addicts across the country suffered through (or secretly enjoyed) a mobile e-mail blackout. This week, the ValleyWag blog highlighted the opposite problem: People who get so much electronic correspondence that they declare "e-mail bankruptcy." It seems to be especially common among the Silicon Valley and venture capital set. ValleyWag identifies several entrepreneurs and tech luminaries who have found that their inboxes were so hopelessly overstocked that they needed to wipe the slate clean. Copyright lawyer and Stanfard Law School professor Lawrence Lessig, a frequent writer about technology issues, famously did it in 2004. And on Monday, Fred Wilson, a partner at Union Square Ventures, did much the same on his blog, A VC.

When dealing with neighborhood restaurants beloved by the people who live nearby, a restaurant critic often hears pleas like these: "Don't go! Please don't go! You're going to like it, and then I'll never get a reservation at 8 p.m. on a Friday night. How can I persuade you not to go? Do you like cashmere? Have I mentioned my lovely new villa in Umbria?"

Updated. As expected, Gov. Eliot Spitzer introduced a bill today to legalize same-sex marriage in New York. (Gay City News had the early word this morning.) Mr. Spitzer's staff had been trying to put the legislation together in time for Monday's Tuesday's lobby day by gay-rights groups. And it looks like they succeeded.

Now that the first-quarter campaign reports of the 2008 presidential candidates have been filed and made public, we asked Robert Lenhard, the chairman of the Federal Election Commission, to take part in a question-and-answer session with us, and with you, Caucus readers.

Reacting to The New York Times article today about George Tenet's new book, Jason Zengerle of The New Republic has a theory about why the book portrays President Bush "in a largely positive light" while several other senior officials come in for a trashing.

A few blogs ago, I ridiculed the 15-screen installation process for a simple Netgear driver. Above all, I expressed derision for the stupid legalese-the license agreement-that everybody has to click past, every time they install any software, whether or not it makes any sense. (For example, Netgear's driver works only with Netgear's network adapter, so why is the company so worried that it will be pirated?)

At more than 7,000 words, Tom Wolfe's recent epic in Portfolio magazine might have served as the coda to the media's recent obsession with writing about hedge funds. But it didn't. The Financial Times on Friday produced its own treatise on hedge funds in the form of a special package of articles that, to be fair, was likely planned long before the publication of Mr. Wolfe's voluminous word portrait and another package on hedge funds that was recently played off the cover of New York magazine.

If you were hoping to share an address with Goldman Sachs chief executive Lloyd Blankfein and hedge fund manager Daniel Loeb, it may be too late (at least for awhile). Curbed is reporting that all the units at 15 Central Park West, the new luxury condominium where both Mr. Blankfein and Mr. Loeb have bought penthouses, have sold out, "as of yesterday." The development's Web site also indicates that all the one-, two-, three- and four-bedroom units have been sold.

Last year, when the Mets rolled to a hot start on their way to wrapping up the division by July, they were 13-7 through their first 20 games. Perhaps you've noticed, but that's what the 2007 Mets are at the same point, and they should be 16-7 after this weekend's series in Washington.

Slam Dunked George Tenet, the former C.I.A. chief, said that his famous "slam dunk" remark about Iraq's W.M.D.'s was made after President Bush urged his team to "add punch" to the public presentation. "I told the president that strengthening the public presentation was a 'slam dunk,' a phrase that was later taken completely out of context," Mr. Tenet writes.

Los Angeles Times columnist Rosa Brooks advances an argument that is usually verboten among mainstream opinion-slingers: International terrorism does not represent an existential threat to the United States. "The 9/11 attacks were appalling and tragic, but they did not threaten the survival of the nation," Brooks writes. "The year 2001 aside, total deaths (not just of Americans) caused by international terrorism worldwide have never exceeded - or even approached - 2,000 a year. Sept. 11 was an outlier: On 9/11, a group of brutal, extremist Islamic thugs got very lucky." She continues:

At the end of a week of mourning for Boris Yeltsin, the man who tried to sweep away remnants of the Soviet Union, including its anthem, the former Soviet republic of Estonia took another step in that direction today.

The morning after the first Democratic presidential debate in Orangeburg, S.C., the reviews are in - especially from the candidates themselves. Releases from John Edwards, who has sought to beat the other candidates to the policy punch by offering several broad proposals, highlighted reviews from analysts about the substance and detail of his responses.

Spitzer and the Raises: "The governor's agenda is to hold up legislative raises in order to use that as a chip for something else." -- Senator John A. DeFrancisco, the Republican judiciary committee chairman, on a judicial reform bill that would give raises to state judges.

Boutique investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners may be just a year and a half old, but it is already acting - and spending - like a member of the Wall Street establishment. Joseph R. Perella's outfit has raised $1.1 billion, hired more than 22 brand-name bankers as partners and set up shop in the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

The Premises, one of London's leading recording studios, has opened a fully solar powered recording studio. It is the first of its kind in Europe and the owners are hoping that it will be a draw for musicians and bands who want to reduce their carbon footprint. After all, the way rock stars fly around, it makes sense to save carbon whenever they can.
“Sing Now or Forever Hold Your Peace,” a “Big Chill” for today’s 36-year-olds, aims to put wisdom and unrelenting quippery in a seaside light.
Some Citigroup analysts have big plans for General Electric, the world's second-largest company by market capitalization after ExxonMobil.

The chief executive of Dow Chemical, which has been rocked by revelations of a secret plan to take it private, on Thursday launched an impassioned defense of his strategy, saying he had "earned the right" to run the company.

Cott, whose stock is fizzing up because of rumors of a merger with Cadbury Schweppes' drinks division, said Wednesday that its board has approved a shareholder rights plan to discourage a hostile takeover.
Sobeys, Canada's second- biggest grocery chain, said its founding family agreed to take the company private by paying C$1.06 billion ($950 million) for the 28 percent stake it doesn't already own.

Billionaire Carlos Slim's Impulsora del Desarrollo y el Empleo en America Latina and Macquarie Infrastructure Group teamed up to bid for a package of four Mexican toll roads worth at least $2.3 billion.
Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest, hired eight investment bankers and equity market specialists in Asia after slipping in advising on mergers in the region.

Storage technology maker EMC plans to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering of stock in VMWare, the fast-growing maker of virtualization technology that it acquired 2004 for $635 million.
Statoil, Norway's largest oil and gas company, on Friday made a $2 billion cash offer to acquire North American Oil Sands, its third significant acquisition in the Americas in less than a year.

Hedge fund firm Schultze Asset Management has increased its stake in Mair Holdings to 5.9 percent and asked the Minneapolis-based company to hold off on future acquisitions until its value can be correctly determined.
A group led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group said on Friday it will make an unsolicited offer for ABN Amro Holding, escalating the fight with Barclays for control of the biggest Dutch bank.

The investment banks that handled the recent auction of Tribune are set to collect nearly $150 million in advisory and financing fees, or a quarter of the total $590 million it will cost real estate magnate Samuel Zell to purchase the 40 percent of the media company.

Technitrol on Thursday withdrew its offer to buy rival electronics-parts-maker Bel Fuse, after its target refused to discuss the offer.

Hedge fund managers on the run from angry investors, beware. An Australian hedge fund manager who went on the lam after being accused of leaving investors out of pocket for as much as $20 million, was tracked down in Canada by group of what The Australian calls "vigilante" investors.

The Sun-Times Media Group said late Thursday that it reached agreement with Canadian authorities on an accord that will remove a significant portion of the company's massive potential tax liabilities related assets sales under Conrad Black.
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is bringing MySpace.com to China, a latecomer that is betting it can overcome that handicap by competing unconventionally as a start-up.

With a bribery scandal widening and its two top executives leaving, Siemens struggled on Thursday to maintain an air of somewhat normal operations, laying out ambitious growth and profit goals, even as the German engineering firm's credit rating was put on watch and regulators in Washington expanded their investigation.
Shares in the China Citic Bank rose 21 percent in their Hong Kong debut and surged more than 59 percent in Shanghai on Friday during its $5.4 billion offering, the world's largest this year.

A Wall Street analyst has raised eyebrows among competitors and customers because he did not speak to the senior management he wrote about prior to launching coverage of seven well-known pharmaceutical companies, The New York Post reported Friday.

Citigroup said on Friday that its takeover bid for Nikko Cordial succeeded after Nikko shareholders tendered a majority of the brokerage firm's stock. The result came after the close of a contentious tender offer for the Japanese company. Some big Nikko shareholders wanted Citigroup to offer more for the firm.

TheStreet.com has acquired the half of Stockpickr, a social network and stock-recommendation site, that it didn't already own. In announcing the deal, TheStreet.com characterized Stockpickr as "a forum where people who want to learn how the rich get richer meet to compare and exchange investment strategies and techniques."

Among the details of Thursday's $8 billion deal for Harman International Industries, one leaped out: Shareholders in Harman, which makes speakers and radios, could end up with an exceptionally large stake in the company once it goes private. Such a provision, known as stub equity, is relatively rare in dealmaking in the United States. But if buyouts keep getting bigger and public shareholders grow more resistant to approaches from private equity funds, it would not be surprising to see stub equity crop up more often.

Senator Barack Obama and Senator Hillary Clinton avoided clashing, and long-shot Senator Mike Gravel left many audience members rolling in the aisles. (Read a recap of the debate.)

BEIJING, April 27 — China appointed Yang Jiechi, a former ambassador to Washington, as its foreign minister, state media reported today, at a time when managing complex relations with the United States over issues like trade, Taiwan and North Korea’s nuclear weapons remains a top priority for the governing Communist Party.
