Despite declaring for the N.B.A. draft and not having played football in four years, the L.S.U basketball player Glen Davis, who is known as Big Baby, could be a late-round pick in the N.F.L. draft.
Despite a full running, gunning, catch-us-if-you-can start by the Suns, Kobe Bryant led the Los Angeles Lakers back and made the first-round playoff series a bit more interesting.  The Suns lead 2-1.
The Russian military helicopter was shot down today by Chechen rebels, the RIA news agency said.
Mr. Rostropovich was renowned as a great musician and also as a champion of freedom in the Soviet Union.
China named Yang Jiechi a former ambassador to the United States, as its foreign minister.
The Yankees increased their troubling losing streak to six games, as the Blue Jays spoiled the major-league debut of pitcher Phil Hughes.

A police chase on Staten Island yesterday afternoon ended with five crashed vehicles — including three police cars — and a fight between an officer and an occupant of the car being chased, the police said. Both suffered minor injuries in the fight.
A 41-year-old Queens man died early yesterday morning after police officers and medical workers responded to a 911 call that he was emotionally disturbed and acting irrationally, the police said.
New Orleans reached an agreement with defensive end Charles Grant on a seven-year extension that would be worth up to $63 million.
Shares in the China Citic Bank rose 21 percent in their Hong Kong debut and surged more than 59 percent in Shanghai.

Four of the state’s eight death row inmates continued a hunger strike yesterday to protest conditions at the Northern Correctional Institution in Somers, state correction officials said. One of the original five participants in the strike, which started on April 16, has started accepting meals again, a Department of Correction spokesman said. The inmates said in a statement released through an anti-death penalty group that they want to participate in recreation in a group, rather than alone. Death row inmates spend 23 hours a day in their cells and have one hour of solitary recreation.
The Ottawa Senators scored four goals on their first eight shots, then held off a New Jersey rally for a victory in the opener of their Eastern Conference semifinal series.

Three activists filed a federal lawsuit against the Police Department, charging that officers arrested them after they tried to videotape arrests in progress. The plaintiffs — Lumumba Bandele, Djibril Toure and David Floyd — say they were arrested while videotaping two arrests in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, on Feb. 9, 2005. “In trying to stop the police from violating the rights of others, they had their rights violated,” said Kamau Franklin, a lawyer with the Center for Constitutional Rights, a nonprofit legal organization that represents the activists. A Police Department spokesman, Paul J. Browne, said yesterday that the three “were arrested for interfering with police officers engaged in the performance of their duties.” He declined to comment further.

A 41-year-old St. Albans man died early yesterday morning after he was strapped to a board by emergency workers, the police said. Police officers and emergency medical workers arrived at the home of Patrick Ryan, at 104-36 204th Street, shortly after a caller phoned 911 at 4:20 a.m. and said that Mr. Ryan was emotionally disturbed and acting irrationally, the police said. They said he was strapped to a backboard and transported to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at 6:13 a.m. The police said that they did not know the cause of death and that the medical examiner would perform an autopsy.

A man and woman from Whitestone were arrested Wednesday after police officers seized 30 handguns and an assault rifle from their home, the police said yesterday. Keith Boyer, 45, and Roberta Boyer, 39, both of 148th Street, were charged with criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. Mr. Boyer was also charged with reckless endangerment. The police said they also recovered three silencers and 5,000 rounds of ammunition. Officers searched the home after receiving a 911 call reporting a man with a gun at the location, the police said.

Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has joined the board of a holding company that owns a troubled commercial college in New York City, and will head a new educational oversight committee, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Kennedy, above, an environmental lawyer, is a director of the EVCI Career Colleges Holding Corporation, which owns Interboro Institute, a two-year business college that has come under scrutiny for improprieties involving student financial aid. In 2005, state education officials directed Interboro to reduce its size so it could better deal with the issue. The company said the problems were isolated, but its stock plummeted and it was sued by investors. Mr. Kennedy said visits to the college convinced him that it was an “extraordinary” school that outperformed “virtually every school in the nation” in helping disadvantaged minority students. EVCI also announced an agreement for a $17 million financial package with a private equity firm.

City health officials warned yesterday that some brands of imported eye makeup contain high levels of lead and could pose a health hazard to users. The products, which are called kohl, kajal and surma, often do not have a list of ingredients on the package, officials said. Sara Markt, a health department spokeswoman, said consumers should not buy products if they are uncertain about the content. Among the products the city found to contain lead are Hashmi Surma Special, Hashmi Kajal and Hashmi Kohl Aswad, all made in Pakistan, and Pure Kohl From the Waters of ZamZam. “You should be looking for some sign that the product is approved, or there are listed ingredients,” she said. Officials issued the warning after investigating several recent cases of children and pregnant women reporting lead poisoning, she said.

Three researchers whose discoveries about cellular operations paved the way for a new generation of drugs that treat a variety of illnesses, including cancer and schizophrenia, won the nation’s largest prize for medicine and biomedical research yesterday. The researchers — Robert J. Lefkowitz of Duke University Medical Center, Solomon H. Snyder of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine and Ronald M. Evans of the Salk Institute for Biological Studies — will share the $500,000 Albany Medical Center Prize. The researchers made independent discoveries about the operations of receptors, proteins that act as docking ports for cells.

A woman convicted as an accomplice to a robbery that ended in the fatal shooting of an aspiring actress and playwright was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to six years in prison. The woman, Ashley Evans, 18, was sentenced by Justice Daniel P. FitzGerald as part of a deal in which she pleaded guilty to first-degree robbery. Ms. Evans’s boyfriend, Rudy Fleming, was sentenced to life in prison last year for first-degree murder in the killing of Nicole duFresne, 28, of Brooklyn, as she and three friends strolled in Lower Manhattan on Jan. 27, 2005. Before the sentencing, Ms. duFresne’s mother, Linda, said, “Ours is a sentence of life without Nicole.” Ms. Evans then apologized to Ms. duFresne’s family and her fiancé, Jeffrey Sparks, who were sitting in the courtroom.

A Yale University student received 50 hours of community service and a special form of probation yesterday for burning an American flag in New Haven, his lawyer said. Charges including arson and reckless endangerment against two other students, Nikolaos Angelopoulos, 19, and Farhad Anklesaria, 19, were dismissed. The student who received probation, Hyder Akbar, 23, was accepted for an accelerated rehabilitation program, which means that the incident will be erased from his record if he stays out of trouble. Mr. Akbar worked as an informal translator for American forces in Afghanistan. The three students were arrested last month after police officers spotted the flag in flames on a pole attached to a house. Mr. Akbar’s lawyer, William Dow, called the flag burning a “foolish college prank.”.
The Yankees want Phil Hughes to be a cornerstone of the future. On Thursday, however,  he lasted just four and a third innings, allowing four earned runs on seven hits.
Industrial output showed a surprise fall, raising the hurdle for the central bank to raise interest rates.
Citigroup said its takeover bid for Nikko Cordial succeeded after Nikko shareholders tendered a majority of the brokerage firm’s stock.

The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about the start-up of Joost, the Internet television service, misidentified Nick Loria, a Joost executive who explained the company’s advertising formats. He is senior vice president for global advertising, not general manager of North American sales and operations.

A front-page article on Wednesday about the Bush administration’s criticism of Congressional Democrats over their war spending bill misstated the rank of David H. Petraeus, the top American commander in Iraq, in some copies. He is a general, not a lieutenant general.

A headline in Business Day on Wednesday about the drop in sales of existing homes in March to 6.12 million units, on a seasonally adjusted annual basis, misstated the historical context of those sales. While the drop of 8.4 percent was indeed the steepest monthly decline since January 1989, when sales fell by 12.6 percent; the sales did not fall to the 1989 level. (The sales rate for 1989 was 3.29 million units.).

An article on Oct. 19 about the collapse of the actor Richard Easton during a performance of “The Coast of Utopia” at Lincoln Center misidentified his final line before he collapsed, and also misidentified an actor onstage at the time. The line was “That is my last word,” not “You can’t go to Berlin!” One of the actors onstage was Martha Plimpton, not Amy Irving. The errors were discovered last week during the editing of an article about distractions actors encounter during performances.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday, about the weekly Billboard album chart, misstated the number of copies that Avril Lavigne’s new album, “The Best Damn Thing,” sold in its first week of release to open at No. 1 on the chart. It was 286,000, not 381,000.

An article on April 18 about Westfield High School in Chantilly, Va., from which the killer in the Virginia Tech massacre and two of his victims graduated, referred incorrectly to the academic background of Steve Webb, who visited friends at the high school a day after the killings. He transferred to an alternative educational program in the district; he did not drop out of school.

A front-page article on Wednesday about the Bush administration’s criticism of Congressional Democrats over their war spending bill misstated the rank of David H. Petraeus, the top American commander in Iraq, in some copies. He is a general, not a lieutenant general.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about “The Pacific,” a World War II mini-series that will be shown on HBO, referred incorrectly to one of the three marines the series will feature. John Basilone was killed on Iwo Jima in February 1945; he did not return home after V-J Day.

An article on Wednesday about an investigation into the propriety of political briefings at federal agencies incorrectly described the Office of Special Counsel, the agency conducting the inquiry. The office, which investigates allegations of improper influence in the civil service, is an independent agency headed by a presidential appointee. It is not part of the Justice Department.
After the collapse in Brooklyn, about 350 people had to leave an adjacent homeless shelter.

Iranian and European officials said progress had been made in talks on Iran’s nuclear program but said they had fallen short of the breakthrough needed to restart formal negotiations. “We have not made miracles, but we have tried to move the dossier forward a little bit,” Javier Solana, left, the foreign policy chief for the European Union, said in Ankara, Turkey, at the end of two days of talks with Iran’s negotiator, Ali Larijani. “The fact that we are again together, I think it’s in itself a very important development.” Mr. Larijani had hinted that the Europeans seemed to be offering a new formula for conditions for talks to resume, but a spokeswoman for Mr. Solana said no new offers were on the table. On CNN Turk, Mr. Larijani said: “There were new ideas rising up. These ideas need time to grow and develop. But you can say this was a good first step.” The two agreed to meet again in two weeks.

The police found the bodies of a 25-year-old Sunni man and a 12-year-old Sunni boy whose abduction on Monday had already prompted concerns of rising sectarian tensions. The bodies were found in a field southeast of Beirut after an anonymous call to a television station. Their families are members of the pro-government party of the Druse leader Walid Jumblatt, an opponent of Hezbollah, the militant Shiite organization. Local reports said the two were kidnapped by members of a Shiite clan to avenge the killing of a relative in January. Mr. Jumblatt appealed for calm.

The army said it was reviewing its decision to allow Prince Harry, the younger son of Prince Charles and the third in line for the throne, to serve with his army unit in Iraq. “Prince Harry’s deployment to Iraq is, as we’ve always said, under constant consideration,” a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Defense said. But, she added, “it is still our intent that Harry will deploy as a troop leader.” British news outlets have reported that the Defense Ministry has grown increasingly nervous about the security implications of such a move. Eleven British soldiers have been killed in Iraq in the past month, including two whose armored reconnaissance vehicle — the same kind Harry would be using — was hit by a roadside bomb.

Two of the world’s most repressive nations, Myanmar and North Korea, restored diplomatic relations after more than two decades of estrangement. The agreement was signed without fanfare during a three-day visit to Myanmar, formerly Burma, by Deputy Foreign Minister Kim Yong-il of North Korea. Myanmar’s deputy foreign minister, Kyaw Thu, said it would be up to the North Koreans to decide whether to open a diplomatic mission in the remote new capital, Naypyidaw, 200 miles north of Yangon, the largest city and former capital. Relations between the nations have been quietly warming over recent years as both sought allies under pressure from the West.

A blackout hit much of Colombia, trapping commuters in subways and traffic jams and temporarily halting commerce in some of the largest cities. Internet and cellphone services were also interrupted before electricity was partly restored in some regions by late afternoon. Senior government officials quickly ruled out the possibility of an attack on the electrical grid by guerrilla groups, contending that the power collapse was caused by a glitch at a substation in Bogotá.

Estonia began excavating the earth surrounding a Soviet-era war memorial in the capital, Tallinn, a step toward relocating it to a military cemetery. The monument, the Bronze Soldier, commemorates the victory over Nazi Germany but is viewed by many Estonians as a symbol of the Soviet occupation that followed. Proposals to remove the monument have brought strong reactions from ethnic Russians in Estonia and from the Russian government.

College coaches will have to recruit the old-fashioned way next year. The N.C.A.A.’s board approved a ban yesterday on text messages from coaches to recruits beginning in August, but could revisit that legislation as early as 2008. The move comes a week after the N.C.A.A.’s management council recommended the ban.

Sean O’Hair shot a season-best five-under-par 65 yesterday at the Byron Nelson Championship in Irving, Tex., for a one-shot lead against the defending champion Brett Wetterich and Anders Hansen after the tournament’s first round without its namesake. Nelson, the champion golfer who in 1968 was the first person to have a PGA event named after him, died Sept. 26 at 94.

BMW Oracle Racing opened up a 3-point lead at the top of the Louis Vuitton Cup standings by beating Mascalzone Latino of Italy yesterday in Valencia, Spain. The undefeated Americans took the lead for good from the first wind marker after the Italians received a penalty.

The Penn Relays, the oldest and largest track and field carnival of its kind, began at Franklin Field in Philadelphia yesterday with 19,000 athletes from 260 colleges, 975 high schools and 100 clubs competing. With a crowd of 23,996 watching on a chilly day, the distance medleys were won by Tennessee among college women (11 minutes 9.16 seconds) and Southern Regional of Manahawkin, N.J., among high school girls (11:45.54).

Lorena Ochoa of Mexico shot a five-under 68 in her first round as the No. 1-ranked player in the world, leaving her a stroke behind the leader, Stacy Prammanasudh, at the Corona Morelia Championship in Morelia, Mexico.

Commissioner Bud Selig said yesterday that he believed that Marvin Miller deserved to be in the Baseball Hall of Fame, a surprising endorsement considering that Miller created the Players Association that was in protracted conflict with the owners for many years.Selig put in a word for the retired Miller as he spoke of the need for “adjustments” in the Hall’s reconstituted veterans committee. Every two years, the committee votes on players who were not elected over a 15-year period by the Baseball Writers Association of America. Every four years, the committee considers executives, umpires and managers.However, in five ballots dating to 2003, the committee has failed to elect a single person. In the most recent results, Miller received 63 percent of the votes; 75 percent is needed. The veterans committee is controlled by the Hall of Fame, not Major League Baseball, but Selig has input as a member of the Hall’s board of directors. Selig made his remarks at a meeting of the Associated Press Sports Editors in New York.

Michelle Wie, 17, who vowed to try again this year after failing to qualify for the 2006 United States Open, was not among the 8,544 golfers to submit qualifying applications for this year’s tournament, according to the United States Golf Association.
ALBANY, April 26 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer continued to antagonize lawmakers on Thursday by proposing to give judges, but not legislators, a pay raise, and to overhaul the way district lines are drawn.
Despite the strong results, the company, which is considered a bellwether for the economy, did not raise its full-year outlook.
The health insurer reported an 8 percent increase in first-quarter profits pointing to membership growth as proof that consumer marketing applied to health insurance is working.
Profit edged up 2 percent in the first quarter on modest revenue growth and the company repeated its forecast for a profitable year.
The publisher of The Dallas Morning News reported a drop in quarterly profit and revenue because of decreasing sales of classified and other advertising.
Despite the drop, earnings beat expectations, helped by the introduction of Coke Zero in Europe and raw material costs that rose less than expected.

The judge asked the lawyer for New York City a hypothetical question: If a police officer used a video camera to record a political group that he had no reason to believe was breaking the law, was it a violation of Police Department rules? Yes or no?.
The proposal could reopen the way for a 190-mile power line through central New York that state and local officials tried to block last year.
After the fatal police shooting of a elderly woman in a botched drug raid, prosecutors are investigating a “culture of misconduct” in the Atlanta Police Department.
A top commander has been charged with nine violations of military law, a rare and serious accusation that could carry a death sentence.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 — Kobe Bryant was serenaded with chants of “M.V.P.,” a sea of gold shirts bounced late into the evening Thursday at Staples Center, and the Los Angeles Lakers looked very much alive.
Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama did not tangle, so it fell to their rivals to take cuts at them.
George J. Tenet said that the vice president and others pushed the country into war without ever conducting a “serious debate.”
Gen. David H. Petraeus was clearly making a case for more time to put the new security plan into full effect.
A symbol of Boston’s first World Series victory in 86 years, the veracity of Curt Schilling’s bloodied sock from Game 2 of the 2004 World Series has been called into question.
Saddled with enormous expectations, Daisuke Matsuzaka is still trying to prove that he can be as formidable here as he was in Japan.
A letter written by George Washington in 1787 was discovered among the private papers of a prominent New Jersey family.
When justices play doctor, watch out for women’s health.
Ford executives said that a smaller loss in the first quarter was proof that their corporate overhaul was working.
By throwing the game winning pass against Arizona State in September 2005, JaMarcus Russell became a Louisiana legend and made his first claim to becoming a franchise N.F.L. quarterback.
At least five marines from a Special Operations unit are expected to be charged for killing 10 civilians in Afghanistan last month.
The dean of admissions at M.I.T. admitted that she had lied about having an undergraduate degree.
President Bush has promised to veto the measure, forcing Democrats to begin confronting the difficult question of what to do after he acts.

A tractor-trailer slammed into traffic that had slowed for construction near Bristol, starting a pileup that killed eight people and injured two others, the police said. The crash started around 6:45 a.m. on a rainy stretch of the Indiana Toll Road. It was not clear why the driver did not slow, Sgt. Trent Smith of the state police said. The semi rear-ended one vehicle, starting a chain reaction involving two other tractor-trailers and some passenger vehicles, Sergeant Smith said.
Microsoft’s results suggested that early sales of its new Windows Vista operating system were off to a solid start.

A Republican state senator running for governor has become a Democrat. The candidate, Walter J. Boasso, a businessman from hurricane-scarred St. Bernard Parish, said the state Republican hierarchy had dismissed his candidacy and thrown all its support behind Representative Bobby Jindal. Without support from Republicans, Mr. Boasso said, he decided that his reform ideas would get more attention from voters if he ran as a Democrat. “It’s going to give me a platform, to let me be heard,” Mr. Boasso said. The election is set for Oct. 20.

A woman pleaded guilty on Wednesday to using fake ID to pose as a lawyer and enter a Baltimore prison to have sex with an inmate, prosecutors said. The woman, Tiffany G. Weaver, 29, of Reisterstown, Md., was charged with identity theft and use of false government identification after entering the prison in November to meet the inmate, Jason B. Moody, who is serving 30 years for manslaughter. Ms. Weaver, left, arrived at the prison with a bar association security pass with a photo and a business card with the name of a real lawyer from Annapolis, Amanda C. Sprehn, who was on maternity leave.
The visit by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan to Washington is as much about fostering personal ties as diplomatic ones.

A 1913 nickel, the best specimen of only five that are known, was bought on Wednesday by an anonymous collector in California for $5 million, said Ronald J. Gillio, the dealer who arranged the sale. It is the second-highest price ever paid for a single coin, after the $7.59 million paid for a 1933 $20 gold piece in 2002. The 1913 nickel, with the head of Liberty on one side and a large V on the reverse, once belonged to the financier Louis Eliasberg, the only person known to have assembled a complete collection of every United States coin by date and mint mark.

The Justice Department notified Congressional investigators that it was withholding more than 170 documents on the ouster of eight United States attorneys, saying it would be inappropriate to turn over material on inquiries from members of Congress and the news media. It did provide a list of the e-mail messages it was withholding. They included exchanges last January between D. Kyle Sampson, then the attorney general’s chief of staff, and Harriet E. Miers, then the White House counsel, about replacement prosecutors. The list also refers to “talking points” provided to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales for conversations with members of Congress.
It can be hard to tell whom the Bush administration considers more of an enemy at the Guantánamo Bay detention camp: the prisoners or the lawyers.
Canadian industries must cut the rate at which they produce gases linked to global warming by 18 percent over the next three years.
The nation, like the family of Cpl. Pat Tillman, deserves nothing less than the full truth of war.
A meeting between President Bush and Representative Charles B. Rangel lifted prospects for bipartisan agreement on trade legislation.
Ségolène Royal accused Nicolas Sarkozy of having “apologized” to President Bush for France’s decision not to back the U.S. militarily in Iraq.
He may be known as a deal maker but Joseph R. Perella is also one of the financial industry’s sharpest recruiters.
Both French presidential candidates, Nicolas Sarkozy and Ségolène Royal, are members of unconventional couples.
The surplus, the city’s fourth straight one, was fueled by tax revenues that were $1.3 billion higher than the mayor’s office projected in January.
Legislation would give the attorney general discretion to bar terrorism suspects from buying firearms, seeking to close a gap in federal gun laws.
At the request of the governor, Avi Schick wears a double hard hat.
A vote cleared the way for the state to become the fourth to allow the civil unions and the first to do so without a court order or pending lawsuit.
In a move to alleviate chronic overcrowding, lawmakers have approved the largest single prison construction program in the nation’s history.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey made his first public statements Thursday since he was injured in a traffic accident two weeks ago.
The Pakistani community in Lodi, Calif., was traumatized after the arrest of a father and son accused of terrorism.
Trooper David C. Brinkerhoff, who was shot and killed Wednesday by a fugitive in the Catskill Mountains, had recently become a father.
The Lifetime Channel announced the appointment of a longtime ABC network executive, Andrea Wong.
Jack Valenti became a confidant of President Lyndon B. Johnson and then a Hollywood institution, devising a voluntary film-rating system.
The gossip of the blogosphere has tossed Jets linebacker Jonathan Vilma into the National Football League’s tradewinds.
Amid a season-long absence of power and runs batted in, Mets third baseman David Wright is encountering his first truly uncomfortable moments as a major leaguer.
The drug maker said it would go with the interim chief, James M. Cornelius, extending his contract for two years until he turns 65.
The announcement underscored the Kremlin’s anger at the U.S.  for proposing a new missile defense system.
With a bribery scandal widening and its two top executives leaving, the company struggled to maintain an air of normal operations.
EMI Group hired the longtime industry executive Roger Ames, a former chairman of Warner Music Group, to revive its North American operation.
The large oil services company pleaded guilty to violating the foreign corrupt practices act by bribing foreign officials.
As this year’s N.F.L. draft approaches, the Giants have plenty of needs to fill, including linebacker, cornerback, defensive tackle and offensive tackle.
The Food and Drug Administration believes that only 6,000 hogs may have eaten the reconstituted feed.
Mr. Bareiss was a businessman who amassed vast collections of African, Western classical and contemporary art, much of which found homes in museums.
First-quarter profit for Dow Chemical fell 20 percent while Eastman Chemical said profit fell 27 percent.
Amazon.com is expanding a program to allow independent sellers — even vendors who sell through eBay — to use its shipping services.
The city is building a series of extensions to the sidewalk along lower Broadway that should make it easier for buses to load and unload.
Mr. Pickett’s Boris Karloff impression propelled the song “Monster Mash” to the top of the charts in 1962, making him one of pop music’s most enduring one-hit wonders.
Ms. Sunstein was an independent scholar known for her biographies of Mary Wollstonecraft and Mary Shelley.
Joe Torre was disappointed in Kei Igawa’s start on Monday, so at least for now, Jeff Karstens will start Friday against the Boston Red Sox.
Thousands of families living in government-provided trailers will be offered the opportunity to buy them for a few hundred dollars.
The two-time points champion of Nascar’s premier series accused Nascar of using caution flags to shape races.
President Bush declared parts of New Jersey a federal disaster area Thursday as a result of heavy rain and flooding almost two weeks ago.
A modest advance gave the Dow Jones industrial average another record close.
Infant mortality has dropped by 18 percent in Afghanistan, one of the first real signs of recovery for the country.
Matt Carle and Mike Grier scored midway through the first period, and Evgeni Nabokov made 34 saves to lead San Jose to a 2-0 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.
Ken Kutaragi will retire in June as Sony struggles for dominance in the video-game industry.
Americans think immediate action is necessary to curb the effects of warming, a Times/CBS News poll finds.
The company postponed its midterm targets by a year after sales collapsed in the United States and Japan.
Members of the World Bank’s anticorruption team said the controversy over Paul D. Wolfowitz’s conduct was undermining their work.
The biotechnology developer said that profit fell 87 percent because the company received less money from a marketing partner.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,327 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
ABN Amro came under fire from shareholders for not considering a rival bid, and said it was soliciting higher bids for its American unit.
Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, asked for a review of the Education Department’s policies against conflicts of interest.
Sosa  set a major league record Thursday with home runs in his 44th ballpark at Jacobs Field, breaking a tie with Ken Griffey Jr. and Fred McGriff.
The Bush administration insisted that meetings between White House aides and government agency officials to discuss Congressional elections did not violate the law.
The number of laid-off workers filing claims for unemployment benefits fell last week by the most in nearly two months.
First-quarter profit increased 80 percent, in part helped by a one-time gain from the dissolution of a joint venture with Time Warner Cable.
After a 5-2 loss to Buffalo, the Rangers tried to absorb the blow of defeat and  brush away any sense of doom on Thursday.
Teenagers in an Israeli town known for its underground pop-rock scene are grappling with the music that comes out of it and the rockets that come into it.
Mitt Romney, who has been criticized for changing his position on abortion and gay rights, engaged two of his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination.
Jim Moran became a billionaire by selling cars and building one of the largest closely held companies in the United States.
The regulatory network may provide new clues to the working of the body’s immune defenses and the generation of a class of cancers.
China would like Taiwan to be part of the domestic route in what would be the longest torch relay in Olympic history.
Absolut vodka will discontinue its ad campaign, changing approaches for the second time in 15 months.
Bishop Fu Tieshan sparred with the Vatican over China’s insistence on appointing its own bishops.
Kidd strained his left knee when Raptors power forward Chris Bosh collided with him on the first play of Game 2 on Tuesday night.
The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 20 through April 24 with 1,052 adults throughout the United States.
On asphalt courts and empty parking lots throughout the country, cycling enthusiasts and others are gathering to play bicycle polo.
In perhaps his most noteworthy decision, he ruled as a State Supreme Court justice that the state prison system must recognize Black Muslims.
Ali Mohammed Gedi declared a turning point in his battle with insurgents after a month of heavy combat.
The oil company reported another surge on stronger earnings from its refining, marketing and chemicals businesses.
People.
If Columbine has taught us anything, it is that we should avoid a legal stalemate over depositions by the parents of the gunman in the Virginia Tech massacre.
In the case of Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch, overzealous politicians and a frenzied press distorted the facts.
“Passio” is an austere fusion of silent film and modern sacred music that has its debut New York performance as part of the Tribeca Film Festival.
The ensemble gave assured, elegant and fully seasoned interpretations of works by Schubert, Dvorak, Britten and Haydn at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday.
“Russian Hamlet,” as seen on Wednesday at City Center, lacked attractive and varied choreography, and had muddled storytelling and exhausting scene changes.
“LoveMusik” leads Drama Desk nominees, arrest warrant issued for Richard Gere in India, Cam’ron apologizes for '’60 Minutes’' remarks and more culture news.

In its almost 30 years of existence, Symphony Space has evolved into a multifarious performing arts presenter and a home to readings, classical music marathons and dance.
The ballets in the troupe’s second all-Balanchine program are  glorious works of art to behold and to inhabit.
There was much to enjoy in watching the students learn focus and support in their performance of  Cimarosa’s “Italiana in Londra” on Wednesday.
AROUND TOWN.
On the surface of the daytime talk show, everything is sunny and serene, but underneath lies a noisy colony roiling with slights, rifts and rivalries.
The Juilliard Opera Center offered a simple, intelligent production of Mozart’s ludicrously complicated piece on Wednesday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater.
The performance of Charles Mingus’s famously unwieldy suite for 31 musicians was well-practiced and well-executed at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Wednesday.
Richard Oelze at Ubu Gallery, Jonathan Lasker at Cheim & Read, Delia Brown at D’Amelio Terras and more.
Now’s the moment to get outside and head for a favorite spot to see your favorite spring blooms. Here are prime spots to soak up the season.
The pioneers of Italian modernism and their art are the focus of a rare, compressed, mercurial exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum.
The proposed buyout of Harman has an unusual feature, known as a stub, that lets shareholders keep a stake in newly private company.
PBS’s show will not change the way you love your canine companion, but it may change the way you look at him.

8 P.M. (TCM) ALL THE KING’S MEN (1949) Turner Classic Movies presents two dramas written and directed by Robert Rossen, starting with this adaptation of Robert Penn Warren’s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about the rise and fall of a rural politician in the 1930s South. At the Oscars, the film was named best picture and Broderick Crawford, above, best actor for his portrayal of Willie Stark, a rural idealist turned corrupt — if popular — governor, a role seemingly inspired by Huey P. Long, the former governor and senator from Louisiana (a connection Warren denied). “All the King’s Men” was selected for preservation in the National Film Registry after the Library of Congress deemed it culturally significant in 2001. At 10, Paul Newman and Jackie Gleason sidle up to the pool table in “The Hustler” (1961), the tale of Fast Eddie Felson, a small-time hustler with a self-destructive streak who challenges Minnesota Fats to a world championship match. George C. Scott plays the gambler with his money on Fats; Piper Laurie is Sarah, the wilted flower with eyes only for Eddie.

It's best not to worry too much about the exact locations of the eerily desolate landscapes depicted in Carla Klein's paintings, with their expansive horizons, unpopulated terrain and moody, turbulent skies. The works, on view at Tanya Bonakdar Gallery, are simply empty, anonymous spaces, sites between destinations in the Southwest that she photographed -- from the side of some road, from a truck-stop parking lot or from the passenger seat of a speeding car -- and then transformed into panoramic paintings. Each painting, however, bears some witness to its origins as a humble snapshot. White borders on the canvas represent areas where the photographic images were cropped, and black lines mark the borders, while droplets of paint refer to scratches on the negative. Sometimes she has even included telling details, like reflections on the car's windshield, the side rear-view mirrors or the top of the dashboard. But over all these paintings are about the fantastical, even dreamlike qualities of the American West, especially the desert, rendered at its most stark, dramatic, serene and severe through a restricted, high-contrast palette of black, blue, gray and white paint. The results (above, ''Untitled,'' 2007) seem simultaneously familiar and foreign, real and imaginary, pleasing to the eyes and eminently collectable. (Through May 5, Tanya Bonakdar Gallery, 521 West 21st Street, Chelsea, 212-414-4144, www.tanyabonakdargallery.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

The top military commander in Iraq, Gen. David H. Petraeus, warned Thursday that an American troop pullback this fall would lead to an escalation in sectarian killings and worsening violence. ''My sense is that there would be an increase in sectarian violence, a resumption of sectarian violence, were the presence of our forces and Iraqi forces at that time to be reduced,'' General Petraeus said at a Pentagon news conference.

Boasting celebrity guests like Bono, Il Divo and Jack Black, Day 2 of the ''Idol Gives Back'' charity edition of ''American Idol'' was commanding as usual in the ratings. Fox garnered more viewers than ABC, NBC, CBS and the CW combined as the two-hour telethon attracted an average of 26.4 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., increasing in every half hour, according to Nielsen's estimates. In a twist, the ''Idol'' host Ryan Seacrest announced that the night's generosity would extend to the contestants: the six remaining finalists were granted a one-week reprieve. However, the 70 million votes cast this week will be counted in next week's scoring when two contestants will face elimination. Mr. Seacrest also announced that, as of Wednesday night, the special had already raised $30 million. In the 10 p.m. hour, ABC's ''Lost'' (11.6 million) edged out CBS's ''CSI: NY'' (11.2 million). Although ratings for ''Lost'' remain down, it still posted the night's second-highest numbers among adults 18 to 49, propelling ABC to second place for the night in that demographic, even as CBS drew more total viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

Between a Rock and a Soft Place Tibor de Nagy 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street Through May 19 The title of the 10th New York gallery show of Kathy Butterly, the immensely talented and original ceramic sculptor, announces a problem borne out by its contents. Wonderful as they are, her latest efforts seem suspended between the rock of genuine risk and the soft place of tried-and-true success. They are too much like their predecessors: radiantly colored, exquisitely detailed, suggestively deflated, discreetly lascivious and rife with decorative, corporeal and stylistic asides.

Opens today in the New York metropolitan area. Directed by Bruce Leddy Not rated; 94 minutes In ''Sing Now or Forever Hold Your Peace,'' Bruce Leddy's ensemble dramedy about a seven-man college a cappella group reuniting after 15 years to perform at a classmate's wedding, midlife crisis is the prevailing refrain. At a Hamptons rehearsal weekend, an office technician (David Harbour) frets about age; a divorced lawyer (Reg Rogers) bemoans bachelorhood; a fired money manager (Alexander Chaplin) fears for his marriage. Also on hand are three wives, a girlfriend and a fetching Swedish nanny.

SMUIN--Michael. The Board and staff of The Joyce Theater mourn the passing of Michael Smuin, a talented choreographer and master showman. In ballet and on Broadway, he enthralled audiences from coast to coast. We offer our sincere condolences to his family, and the Smuin Ballet company.

ALPERT--Warren. A Memorial Service celebrating the life of entrepreneur and philanthropist Warren Alpert will be held on Sunday, April 29 at 11:30am, at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, New York City. Mr. Alpert served as past President of Sutton Place Synagogue.

Bank of America's chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, has a reputation as an aggressive deal maker. This week's proposed $21 billion deal for LaSalle Bank of Chicago would be Bank of America's third big acquisition, including its role in the $25 billion buyout of Sallie Mae, in just six months.

How do you investigate a crime against music? According to Bruce Adolphe, you hire a private ear. For Mr. Adolphe, director of family programs for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, this conceit is more than a joke that you might see printed on the back of a cereal box. It is the basis for ''Sherlock Key Meets Claude Debussy,'' a concert production that will have its world premiere on Sunday. As Mr. Adolphe explains it, Debussy was such an innovator that many critics in his period misunderstood or disliked his work.

In Poll, Americans Express Concern Over Warming Americans in large numbers say the heating of the earth's atmosphere is having serious effects on the environment and think it is necessary to take steps to reduce its effects, a New York Times/CBS News poll finds. China named Yang Jiechi, a former ambassador to the United States, as its foreign minister on Friday, shuffling its diplomatic team as its rising economic power has given it greater sway in world affairs. Mr. Yang, 56, formerly a vice minister, is fluent in English and known for his courteous but cautious manner. He was the ambassador to the United States from 2001 to 2005.

In his continuing effort to find new ways to get people to listen to old jazz, Wynton Marsalis has put together these concerts by the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, which look at the repertory through the lens of a record label known for meticulous recordings and distinctive album covers. Mr. Marsalis and several other orchestra members have done big-band arrangements of some of their favorite Blue Note recordings. The choices are mostly from the label's hard-bop heyday, including pieces by Jackie McLean, Lee Morgan, Bud Powell and Horace Silver, and the hope is that the audience will happily recognize them. ''These are the songs that taught us jazz music,'' said the trombonist Vincent R. Gardner, who did the arrangements for Herbie Hancock's ''Maiden Voyage'' and Kenny Dorham's ''Trompeta Toccata.'' ''They're the ones that have touched us the most, and will touch them the most.'' (Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Rose Theater, Jazz at Lincoln Center, Broadway at 60th Street, 212-721-6500 or jalc.org; $30 to $120.) MIKE HALE

Felicity and Caprice D'Amelio Terras 525 West 22nd Street, Chelsea Through May 4 A decade and a half into the figurative painting boom, artists are still raiding pockets of forgotten academic art and illustration and baiting viewers with their cringe-worthy finds. Delia Brown hasn't been particularly successful at this game. Her paintings often mirror their gilt and fashion-heavy sources a little too directly. She gains some ground here, though.
