Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Heidi Specogna In Spanish, English and German, with English subtitles Not rated; 89 minutes Lance Cpl. José Antonio Gutiérrez, the subject of this nonfiction film, was a Guatemalan immigrant who became the first American soldier killed in the invasion of Iraq. Official accounts presented a classic tale of an up-by-your-bootstraps immigrant -- a young man who fled poverty and violence in his native land, then enlisted in the Marines in hopes of earning his green card more quickly.

What does the phrase ''hula dancing'' bring to mind? For some it's the Elvis Presley movie ''Blue Hawaii.'' Or plastic flowers, cellophane skirts, perhaps even a coconut brassiere. It is unlikely to suggest the image of Hi'iaka, the patron goddess of Hawaii, dancing for her sister Pele, the goddess of volcanic fire, to introduce a sacred ritual. But that's where it all started, according to this solo show, written and performed by Keo Woolford, whose first name, he says, is pronounced ''like O.K. backwards.'' To Mr. Woolford, left, hula is more than Hollywood kitsch. It is an important aspect of his identity and that of his home state. His show, he said after a recent preview performance, ''is not a history lesson or educational device,'' though it does much to counteract the perception that Hawaii is merely a vacation fantasy land. As Mr. Woolford reveals his journey, from growing up in Hawaii to starring in ''The King and I'' on the West End to performing with the Hawaiian boy band Brownskin, his sense of humor is apparent throughout. Created with and directed by Roberta Uno, and produced by the Ma-Yi Theater Company, ''I Land'' features plenty of dancing too -- a combination of hula, hip-hop and even a dose of disco -- choreographed by the hula kuma (teacher) Robert Cazimero and Ana (Rokafella) Garcia. But the show's serious underpinnings are clear. ''We wanted to open this window, so that you would actually ask yourself the question, 'What do I now know about this world that I assumed I knew everything about?' '' Ms. Uno said. (Through May 13, the Culture Project, 55 Mercer Street, at Broome Street, SoHo, 212-352-3101, theatermania.com; $38; $25 for students; $35 for 65+.) STEVEN McELROY

IT was like movie night in a dorm. As they waited in flimsy seats for the lights to dim, several people in the audience read books. ''The Man Who Knew Too Much,'' a Hitchcock classic, appeared on the screen, but without sound. In the same theater, 24 hours later, some of New York's leading contemporary musicians took part in a program devoted to the connection between music and weaving. Philip Glass was in the audience, hearing, for the first time, a piano and flute transcription of his Piano Concerto No. 2. Unannounced, he joined other composers and performers on the program to talk about the piece.

A man and woman from Whitestone were arrested Wednesday after police officers seized 30 handguns and an assault rifle from their home, the police said yesterday. Keith Boyer, 45, and Roberta Boyer, 39, both of 148th Street, were charged with criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. Mr. Boyer was also charged with reckless endangerment. The police said they also recovered three silencers and 5,000 rounds of ammunition. Officers searched the home after receiving a 911 call reporting a man with a gun at the location, the police said.

Drawings From Palisades, Scenes From the Life of Charon Kentler International Drawing Space 353 Van Brunt Street, Red Hook, Brooklyn Through May 6 Elaine Smollin's works on paper sound great on paper. She makes multipanel charcoal drawings on thick watercolor fiber. She creates the charcoal herself from cherry, elm, willow and birch trees near her home in Palisades, N.Y. According to the gallery, Ms. Smollin even returns and rearranges panels, so the drawings remain in flux rather than being static or ''finished.''

THE BENT FESTIVAL (Tomorrow) Children sometimes enjoy breaking toys almost as much as playing with them. This festival, presented by the Tank, is all about short-circuiting battery-powered playthings to create electronic instruments. Two workshops are suitable for children: ''Intro to Circuit-Bending,'' at 11 a.m. (take sound-making toys and batteries), and ''Introduction Into the Giant Chaotic Circuit-Bending Merzbau Jungle,'' at 2 p.m., an interactive exploration of the artist Andreas Stoiber's electronic installation. At Eyebeam Atelier, 540 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 563-6269, bentfestival.org; free. 'BUG BOY BLUES' (Tomorrow and Sunday) Kafka for kids? That's the idea behind this show, which explores the mind of young Gregor Samsa, subject of ''The Metamorphosis.'' It also includes non-Kafkaesque elements, like a jam band and dancing insects. (Through June 3.) Tomorrow at noon and 2 p.m., Sunday at 2 and 4 p.m., the Looking Glass Theater, 422 West 57th Street, Clinton, (212) 352-3101; $12; $10 for 12 and under. CROSS-GENERATION CHESS (Sunday) The chessboard is common ground in this monthly program, which brings together children from kindergarten through high school with elderly adults. Players of any level are invited for games, live classical music and, most important, conversation. Lunch is free. From 2 to 5:30 p.m., the Chelsea Recreation Center, 430 West 25th Street. Registration (optional): (917) 822-3141, crossgenerationchess.com; free. 'A DOLPHIN UP A TREE!' (Sunday) A little magic can be a dangerous thing. In this musical a girl casts a spell that brings her stuffed toys to life and turns her into the creature of the title. At 11 a.m. and 12:30 p.m., 78th Street Theater Lab, 236 West 78th Street, Manhattan, (212) 868-4444; $15. 'EVERYTHING ABOUT SCHOOL (ALMOST)' (Tonight through Sunday) This musical, revived by Tada!, humorously underscores that the bossy, self-dramatizing second grader usually turns into a bossy, self-dramatizing teenager, and that the boy who teases a girl in seventh grade often swoons at her feet later. (Through May 13.) Tonight at 7, tomorrow and Sunday at 2 and 4 p.m., Tada! Theater, 15 West 28th Street, Chelsea, (212) 252-1619, Ext. 28; $18; $8 for 15 and under. Tonight only, buy a ticket and receive one free. 'FINDING PEACE' (Tomorrow) Peace, in all its elusive forms, will be explored in this reading for teenagers, part of PEN World Voices: the New York Festival for International Literature. Isabel Hoving of the Netherlands, Rita Williams-Garcia of the United States and Markus Zusak of Australia will participate. At 1 p.m., the Rubin Museum of Art, 150 West 17th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 620-5000, Ext. 344; pen.org/festival. Free with museum admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+. FLEECE FESTIVAL (Tomorrow and Sunday) Everyone is shedding layers in the warm weather, and the Prospect Park Zoo's sheep and alpacas are to follow suit. Visitors can watch the shearing, attend zookeeper and artisan demonstrations and even dye a little wool. Noon to 4 p.m., 450 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, (718) 399-7339, prospectparkzoo.com. Free with admission: $6; $2.25 for 65+; $1 for 3 to 12; under 3, free. 'THE GREATEST LITTLE CIRCUS ON STRINGS' (Sunday) There will be more than one kind of string in this concert at the 92nd Street Y, presented by the cellist Steven Isserlis, the actor Samuel West and guest musicians. Marionettes from the Bob Brown Puppets will perform the title piece, to Siebert's Dance Suite for Cello and Piano, and play creatures in Saint-Saëns's ''Carnival of the Animals.'' At 3 p.m., 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500, 92y.org/concerts; $16. 'HOOFERS ON PARADE' (Tonight through Sunday) Busby Berkeley's 1930s films were the inspiration for this musical, a collaboration between the youth theater company Downtown Art and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Expect lots of toe-tapping. (Through May 20.) Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 2 p.m, Downtown Art, 61 East Fourth Street, sixth floor, East Village, (212) 479-0885; $8; $5 for students. KIDS 'N COMEDY (Sunday) The class clown gets applause, not detention, at this series, in which comics 11 and older perform stand-up. (Don't worry; the material is clean.) At 1 p.m., Gotham Comedy Club, 208 West 23rd Street, Chelsea; $15 with a one-soda minimum. Reservations required: (212) 877-6115. KITEFLIGHT: SKYSCRAPERS (Sunday) Imaginations will soar at this workshop to build and fly kites at Socrates Sculpture Park, sponsored by the park and the Noguchi Museum. Children will use the Manhattan skyline as inspiration. From 11 a.m. to 2 p.m., rain or shine, Broadway and Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 956-1819; socratessculpturepark.org; free. 'MISS NELSON HAS A FIELD DAY' (Tomorrow and Sunday) Miss Nelson, that sweet teacher, and Viola Swamp, the stern substitute who suspiciously resembles her, are back in another musical based on the books by Harry Allard and James Marshall. (Through May 20.) At noon and 2 p.m., Manhattan Children's Theater, 52 White Street, near Church Street, TriBeCa, (212) 352-3101; $15. 'ONCE UPON A PANDORA'S BOX' (Tonight through Sunday) The Greek myth has been adapted into a play, presented by the New Acting Company, in which a sister and brother discover a mysterious box in their New York apartment. (Through May 6.) Tonight at 7, tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m., Sunday at 2 p.m., the Philip Coltoff Center, 219 Sullivan Street, near West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 868-4444; $15 in advance; $18 at the door. PEARSONWIDRIG DANCE THEATER (Tomorrow) New Orleans and Guatemela will be among the places visited in this playful company's family matinee. At the end all audience members will be invited onstage to dance. At 2 p.m., Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $15.

KAUFMAN--Lenore, 61, deeply loved by her husband David, sons Jake and Adam, and adored by her father, brother and sister. A dedicated educator and impassioned teacher, she taught hundreds of children the joy of reading and the writing for joy. She will be greatly missed by all the worlds she touched as parent, teacher, musician and supportive friend. She was an inspiration to all. Donations can be made to The Research Fund of the St. Vincent's Comprehensive Cancer Center.
HEFFNER--Simon O., April 27, 2007, on your 100th Birthday. A wonderful, loving, kind man who continues to be a role model in all of our lives. We miss you. Harvey, Nancy, Andrea, Simon

Opens today in New York and selected cities Directed by Betsy Blankenbaker Not rated; 64 minutes. Short, sweet and sentimental, ''Something to Cheer About'' tells the story of Indiana's Crispus Attucks Tigers, who, in 1955, became the first all-black high school basketball team to win a state championship. Like last year's ''Glory Road,'' Betsy Blankenbaker's documentary celebrates a victory over much more than just rival teams.

The Bush administration insisted Thursday that a series of meetings between senior White House political aides and officials at government agencies to discuss Congressional elections did not violate a law that prohibits the use of federal departments for political purposes. White House officials acknowledged that aides to Karl Rove, the president's chief political adviser, held about 20 briefings in the past two years with officials at 16 departments to discuss Republican political strategies, including which Congressional Democrats were being singled out for defeat and which Republicans were most vulnerable.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column yesterday, about the weekly Billboard album chart, misstated the number of copies that Avril Lavigne's new album, ''The Best Damn Thing,'' sold in its first week of release to open at No. 1 on the chart. It was 286,000, not 381,000.

FRANKEL--Norma, age 74, died on April 26, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Frankel, daughter of the late Harry and Helen Frank, mother of David, Ross, Harriet, and Charles, and daughters-in-law Lynn and Caren and son-in-law Marc. Loving and adoring grandmother of Deborah, Hilary, Melissa, Nina, Bradley, Emily and Leah. Graduate of NYU at age 19, she returned to school for a Masters degree in Library Sciences and served as medical librarian at LIJ Hospital for more than 30 years. Lover of literature, bridge and the NY Mets (she had no choice). Funeral Sunday, April 29th, at ''Riverside - Nassau North Chapels'', 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Catharine Margaret Pasmantier Fund, c/o Mark Pasmantier, M.D., 407 E. 70th St., NY, NY 10021.
Carolyn Brown's memoir, ''Chance and Circumstance,'' recounts, from the inside, the exhilaration of working with Cunningham, Rauschenberg and Cage. A review, Page 33.

The Penn Relays, the oldest and largest track and field carnival of its kind, began at Franklin Field in Philadelphia yesterday with 19,000 athletes from 260 colleges, 975 high schools and 100 clubs competing. With a crowd of 23,996 watching on a chilly day, the distance medleys were won by Tennessee among college women (11 minutes 9.16 seconds) and Southern Regional of Manahawkin, N.J., among high school girls (11:45.54). FRANK LITSKY

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column yesterday about ''The Pacific,'' a World War II mini-series that will be shown on HBO, referred incorrectly to one of the three marines the series will feature. John Basilone was killed on Iwo Jima in February 1945; he did not return home after V-J Day.

GURIAN--Elias on April 25, 2007 in his 91st year. Devoted and beloved husband and friend of Lil (Leah) for 65 years. Father of Stephen, Bonny and Marvin Rosen, Donald and Karen Gurian. Grandfather of Alyson and Steven Justman, Melanie and Robert Gallucci, Justin Gurian, Ariel Gurian. Greatgrandfather to Jordyn, Alexa and Tyler. Founder of Gurian Fabrics, Inc. Inventor of the Fabrak. Served with the US Air Force during WWII. He was a member of The American Arbitration Association and was active in many Philanthropies including UJA/ Federation, Lubavitch Youth, State of Israel Bonds. Former Chairman of the Board of Congregation Beth Shalom. Long time resident of Lawrence, NY, and then Boca Raton, FL. He will be missed by the numerous people whose lives he enhanced by virtue of his great sense of humor, his kindness and his loving generosity. Graveside service at Old Montefiore Cemetery in Springfield Gardens, Queens, at 2pm on Friday, April 27. He wanted to be remembered, not mourned, since he had a most satisfying life.

BAREISS--Walter. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the death of Walter Bareiss. A businessman, collector, and passionate art lover, Walter was a longstanding friend of the Museum. He joined the Museums Junior Council in 1949 and would go on to serve as Trustee from 1964-1973 and Acting Director from 1969-70. He also served as Chairman of the Painting and Sculpture, Drawings, and Prints and Illustrated Books committees and Chairman of the Art Lending Service. We deeply appreciate Walters generosity to the Museum, particularly his many gifts of art and acquisition funds. We will remember Walter for his commitment, intelligence, sense of humor, remarkable eye, and boundless curiosity about contemporary developments in the art world. We extend our deepest sympathy to his five children and eleven grandchildren. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Robert B. Menschel, Chairman Marie-Jose Kravis, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art
To the Editor: Re ''Giuliani Says a Democratic President Would Make the U.S. Less Safe'' (news article, April 26):

It is heroic hosiery to Red Sox Nation, a sock bloodied in postseason combat, a symbol of Boston's first World Series victory in 86 years. This most intrepid sock, a cottony artifact of triumph, covered Curt Schilling's right foot in Game 2 of the 2004 World Series. He had had a surgical procedure on an ankle tendon, and sometime during his four-hit, six-inning performance, the sock was discolored, presumably with his blood, just as one of his socks had been during his victory over the Yankees in Game 6 of that season's American League Championship Series.

City health officials warned yesterday that some brands of imported eye makeup contain high levels of lead and could pose a health hazard to users. The products, which are called kohl, kajal and surma, often do not have a list of ingredients on the package, officials said. Sara Markt, a health department spokeswoman, said consumers should not buy products if they are uncertain about the content. Among the products the city found to contain lead are Hashmi Surma Special, Hashmi Kajal and Hashmi Kohl Aswad, all made in Pakistan, and Pure Kohl From the Waters of ZamZam. ''You should be looking for some sign that the product is approved, or there are listed ingredients,'' she said. Officials issued the warning after investigating several recent cases of children and pregnant women reporting lead poisoning, she said.

VARET--Frances Goldberg. Died peacefully at home on April 24th age 91. Beloved wife of the late Guster V. Varet and adored mother of Ellen Bock and Michael A. Varet. Also survived by her devoted grandchildren, Lauren Schwartz and her husband Adam, Joseph Varet, Sarah Varet and David Varet, her darling great-granddaughter, Alexandra Schwartz, her daughter - in - law Elizabeth Varet and son-in-law Charles Bock. Graduate of the Class of 1935 at Long Island University and for many years a much admired teacher of English at Midwood High School where she especially enjoyed her work with students who needed to improve their reading skills. Funeral will be private. The family will observe Shiva at the home of Elizabeth and Michael Varet on Thursday from 5pm until 8pm, Friday afternoon from 2pm until 5pm, Sunday from 2pm until 8pm, and Monday and Tuesday from 6:30pm until 9pm. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate contributions to the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, 475 West 250th Street, Riverdale, NY 10471, or to the UJA-Federation of Greater New York, 130 East 59th Street, New York, NY 10022.

The top military commander in Iraq, Gen. David H. Petraeus, warned that an American troop pullback this fall would lead to an escalation in sectarian killings and worsening violence. Although General Petraeus did not address the political debate over a withdrawal deadline, he was clearly making a case for more time to put the new security plan into full effect. Page A16.

A brief art review in Weekend last Friday about an exhibition of photographs at the Cohan and Leslie gallery in Chelsea misspelled the surname of a photographer. He is Ari Marcopoulos, not Marcopolous. The article also referred incorrectly to newspaper headlines shown in one of his photographs. They were headlines the day after the death of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the leader of Al Qaeda in Iraq, not headlines the day after Saddam Hussein's execution.

The Justice Department notified Congressional investigators that it was withholding more than 170 documents on the ouster of eight United States attorneys, saying it would be inappropriate to turn over material on inquiries from members of Congress and the news media. It did provide a list of the e-mail messages it was withholding. They included exchanges last January between D. Kyle Sampson, then the attorney general's chief of staff, and Harriet E. Miers, then the White House counsel, about replacement prosecutors. The list also refers to ''talking points'' provided to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales for conversations with members of Congress. ERIC LIPTON

An article on Wednesday about an investigation into the propriety of political briefings at federal agencies incorrectly described the Office of Special Counsel, the agency conducting the inquiry. The office, which investigates allegations of improper influence in the civil service, is an independent agency headed by a presidential appointee. It is not part of the Justice Department.

INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Democrats Weigh Answer To Veto of War Funding Bill The Senate sent President Bush a war spending measure he has promised to veto, forcing Democrats to confront the question of what to do after the president acts. A1 Russia to Suspend Arms Treaty Russia's president said his country would stop complying with a treaty on conventional arms in Europe that was forged at the end of the cold war, underscoring the Kremlin's anger at an American proposal for a missile defense system in Europe. A1 French Rivals Exchange Barbs The Socialist candidate in the French presidential election accused her opponent of having ''apologized'' to President Bush for France's decision not to take part in the Iraq war. A10 Both candidates are members of unconventional couples. The Socialist candidate is not married to the father of her four children, and the conservative candidate and his wife are often apart. A1 Serious Charge for Ranking G.I. The American military has charged a top commander at Camp Cropper near Baghdad with violations of military law, including ''aiding the enemy,'' a serious accusation that could carry a death sentence. A16 World Bank Team Complains Members of the World Bank's anti-corruption team said the controversy over Paul Wolfowitz's conduct was undermining their work. A6 Afghanistan Infant Deaths Drop Health officials said that Afghan infant mortality has dropped by 18 percent. A12 NATIONAL A18-25 Dean at M.I.T. Resigns After Lying on Résumé The dean of admissions at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Marilee Jones, who became famous for urging stressed-out students competing for elite colleges to calm down and stop trying to be perfect, has resigned after admitting that she had fabricated her own educational credentials. A1 Concerns Over Warming Issues Americans in large bipartisan numbers say the heating of the earth's atmosphere is having serious effects on the environment now or will soon and think that it is necessary to take immediate steps to reduce its effects, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds. A20 Bush Criticized by Candidates The eight Democratic presidential candidates used their first joint appearance to assail President Bush for threatening to veto legislation that would set a deadline for bringing troops out of Iraq. A24 New Bill on Buying Guns The Justice Department proposed legislation that would give the attorney general discretion to bar terrorism suspects from buying a firearm, seeking to close a controversial gap in federal gun laws. A18 SCIENCE/HEALTH Genes Linked to Diabetes Researchers said they had identified seven new genes connected to the most common form of diabetes, the latest result of an intensifying race to find genes linked to a range of diseases. A22 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Slain Trooper Took Part In Another Deadly Manhunt David C. Brinkerhoff, the New York State trooper who was fatally shot by a fugitive this week, spent days tracking Ralph J. Phillips, another fugitive who had shot and killed a trooper, before Mr. Phillips was captured last September. B1 Bloomberg Proposes Budget Mayor Bloomberg proposed a $59 billion budget that maintains tax cuts he promised earlier this year and includes a record-setting $4.4 billion surplus. B1 Sincerely, George Washington A letter written by George Washington in May or July of 1787 was recently discovered in a brown leather scrapbook started by a young New Jersey girl in 1826. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Losses Shrink at Ford Ford Motor announced a $282 million loss in the first quarter. Company officials said the loss, much smaller than last year's, was proof that a restructuring plan was working. C1 Investors Get Into the Deal The $8 billion private equity buyout of Harman International Industries, the maker of speakers and home theater systems, breaks new ground by offering shareholders a chance to share in profits made if the company is sold or taken public again. C1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES C10-11 Jack Valenti A confidant of President Lyndon B. Johnson and a Hollywood institution, he was 85. C10 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: After the lawyers; crippling government from within; Corporal Tillman haunts the Pentagon; Dorothy Samuels on the new abortion ruling and the Roberts court. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Paul Krugman. Crossword E5 Public Lives B2 TV Listings E24 Weather B7

A brief art review in Weekend last Friday about an exhibition by Althea Thauberger, at John Connelly Presents in Chelsea, misidentified Ms. Thauberger's nationality. She is Canadian, not German. The review also referred incorrectly to the participation of eight young German men in a DVD that is the exhibition's centerpiece. The participation by the men, who are contributing social service in lieu of military service, does in fact count as part of that social service. The review also misstated the length of the military service that is being replaced with social service. It is nine months, not seven months.

The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about the start-up of Joost, the Internet television service, misidentified Nick Loria, a Joost executive who explained the company's advertising formats. He is senior vice president for global advertising, not general manager of North American sales and operations.

A report in the Metro Briefing column on Monday about the deaths of two men in shootings in Brooklyn and Queens referred incorrectly to the location of the Brooklyn shooting. It took place at Nostrand Avenue and Church Avenue, not Church Street.

AUGUST--Sid. Hineni expresses sympathy to our devoted members Glenn and Deborah August on the passing of their father/father - in - law. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Your Loving Hineni Family

MORROW--Susan, 63, of Greenwich Village and Hollowville, NY, on April 18, 2007. Survived by her sister Claudia and many loving friends. Service Saturday, April 28 at 3pm, Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square West. Donations to International Primate Protection League, P.O. Box 766, Summerville, SC 29484.

Things are messed up around Yankee Stadium, the Yankees announced last night. This observation had nothing to do with the current losing streak, which increased to six games when the Toronto Blue Jays beat them, 6-0, while spoiling the major league debut of the pitching prospect Phil Hughes.

Opens today nationwide. Directed by Scott Wiper 100 minutes Tailor-made for those who like their violence multifaceted and their women monosyllabic, ''The Condemned'' tosses a selection of action movies-- ''Con Air,'' ''The Running Man,'' ''Series 7: The Contenders'' -- into a blender and serves up the resulting mush. A simpleminded vehicle for the wrestling star Steve Austin, the movie will slide into foreign markets with no need for elaborate subtitles or cultural translation. The language of pain is universal.

An article on April 18 about Westfield High School in Chantilly, Va., from which the killer in the Virginia Tech massacre and two of his victims graduated, referred incorrectly to the academic background of Steve Webb, who visited friends at the high school a day after the killings. He transferred to an alternative educational program in the district; he did not drop out of school.

SCHINDLER--Mark, on April 24, 2007. Loving companion and best friend. He brought laughter and joy to all he met. His strength of character, integrity and devotion were unsurpassed. His uncanny memory for trivia and all sorts of facts was unrivaled. Our every day together will be a treasured memory. Always , Your Barbara

To the Editor: In ''Off to Work She Should Go'' (Op-Ed, April 25), Linda Hirshman argues that while it may be ''easier in the short term'' for a new mother to leave her job and stay at home, she should resist the easy road and return to work.

Cheim & Read 547 West 25th Street, Chelsea Through May 5 Jonathan Lasker's system seems to be working. For nearly 30 years he has pursued his born-again, refried formalism, using a strictly limited vocabulary without painting himself into a corner. His current exhibition of starkly frontal, what-you-see-is-what-you-see canvases is possibly the best of his career.

'LoveMusik' Leads Drama Desk Nominees ''LoveMusik,'' a musical suggested by the letters of Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya that doesn't open officially until Thursday, led the way with 12 nominations when the 52nd annual Drama Desk Awards were announced yesterday by James Naughton and Beth Leavel, previous winners, at the New York Friars Club. Three other musicals -- ''Curtains,'' ''Legally Blonde'' (opening on Sunday) and ''Spring Awakening'' -- received 10 nominations each, along with the Tom Stoppard play ''The Coast of Utopia.'' ''In the Heights,'' an Off Broadway musical, got nine nominations, and six went to ''Mary Poppins.'' With Kristin Chenoweth as host, the awards will be presented on May 20 at LaGuardia Concert Hall at Lincoln Center. Arrest Warrant Issued for Richard Gere in India Richard Gere was a wanted man yesterday after a judge in India issued arrest warrants for him and the Bollywood star Shilpa Shetty, saying their kiss at a public function, right, ''transgressed all limits of vulgarity,'' according to news media reports cited by The Associated Press. Judge Dinesh Gupta issued the warrants in Jaipur in response to a citizen's complaint that the incident this month, when Mr. Gere planted kisses on Ms. Shetty's face at an AIDS awareness rally in New Delhi, offended local sensibilities, the Press Trust of India reported. It said that the judge, who viewed television coverage of the event, called it ''highly sexually erotic.'' Ms. Shetty, 31, was criticized by the judge for not resisting the kisses and ordered to appear in court on May 5. Her spokesman, Dale Bhagwagar, said she was upset by the news and wished that people would focus on ''AIDS awareness, and not three pecks on her cheek.'' Lawsuits against celebrities, often filed by publicity seekers, are common in conservative India. Mr. Gere, 57, whose films include ''An Officer and a Gentleman,'' ''American Gigolo'' and ''Pretty Woman,'' is a frequent visitor to the country, where he addresses health issues and the cause of Tibetan exiles. Stars Reinforce Lineup For Diana Concert Kanye West, Rod Stewart, Status Quo and Lily Allen, below, along with James Morrison, Natasha Bedingfield, the American rock band Orson and the British pop act the Feeling, have joined the lineup of the memorial concert on July 1 for Diana, Princess of Wales, after its organizers expressed concern that it might be eclipsed by the Live Earth extravaganza the following week at the same place, the new 90,000-seat Wembley Stadium in London, Agence France-Presse reported. Elton John and Duran Duran, the princess's favorite band, were previously announced attractions. Organizers said yesterday that the event will also include a performance by the English National Ballet and songs by Andrew Lloyd Webber, The Associated Press reported. The first round of tickets for the charity ''Concert for Diana'' sold out in 17 minutes; another 10,000 go on sale today. The event was planned by Diana's sons, Princes William and Harry, as a tribute on what would have been her 46th birthday. She died in a car crash in Paris on Aug. 31, 1997. Australia Slams the Door On Snoop Dogg What kind of guy is the rapper Snoop Dogg? ''He doesn't seem to be the sort of bloke we want in this country,'' Australia's Immigration Minister Kevin Andrews told Macquarie Radio in Sydney, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Andrews was explaining that a visa for Snoop Dogg, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, had been canceled because he failed to pass Australia's character test, which takes criminal convictions into account. The rapper was to have flown to Sydney this week to be a host of the MTV Australia Video Music Awards. Last month, he and Diddy canceled the British leg of their European tour after Snoop Dogg was denied entry to England. He has 28 days to appeal the Australian ruling. Donald Etra, his lawyer in Los Angeles, said he had not heard from Snoop Dogg about the cancellation. The rapper was convicted in 1990 of cocaine possession and was charged with gun possession in 1993 and pleaded guilty in 1997. He was acquitted of a murder charge in 1996 but was arrested last April at Heathrow Airport outside London in connection with a brawl. The Wide World Of Entertainment Hugh Grant was arrested after a photographer complained that the actor had hurled a tub of baked beans at him, The Associated Press reported. The Metropolitan Police in London do not identify suspects who have not been charged, but they said a 46-year-old man was arrested on Wednesday night on suspicion of assault and released on bail. Ian Whittaker, a photographer, told The Daily Star that Mr. Grant, above, had kicked him and shouted abuse before tossing the beans. Lawyers for Mr. Grant, whose credits include ''Four Weddings and a Funeral'' and ''Notting Hill,'' said that an incident was under investigation, the BBC reported. Jonathan Rhys Meyers, 29, whose credits include Henry VIII in the Showtime miniseries ''The Tudors,'' as well as ''Bend It Like Beckham'' and ''Match Point,'' has entered treatment for alcohol abuse, The Associated Press reported.

Infant mortality has dropped by 18 percent in Afghanistan, one of the first real signs of recovery for the country five years after the fall of the Taliban regime, health officials said Thursday. ''Despite many challenges, there are clear signs of health sector recovery and progress throughout the country,'' Dr. Muhammad Amin Fatimi, the health minister, told journalists here.
RICHMAN--Leonard R., 10/27/25-4/27/06. Its been a long and lonely year. Lenny dear, you are lovingly remembered and missed. Your Family

People James W. Hirschmann III is stepping down as president and chief operating officer of Legg Mason. He will remain chief executive of the company's bond unit, the Western Asset Management Company. Raymond A. Mason, Legg Mason's chairman and chief executive, will serve as president.

Iranian and European officials said progress had been made in talks on Iran's nuclear program but said they had fallen short of the breakthrough needed to restart formal negotiations. ''We have not made miracles, but we have tried to move the dossier forward a little bit,'' Javier Solana, left, the foreign policy chief for the European Union, said in Ankara, Turkey, at the end of two days of talks with Iran's negotiator, Ali Larijani. ''The fact that we are again together, I think it's in itself a very important development.'' Mr. Larijani had hinted that the Europeans seemed to be offering a new formula for conditions for talks to resume, but a spokeswoman for Mr. Solana said no new offers were on the table. On CNN Turk, Mr. Larijani said: ''There were new ideas rising up. These ideas need time to grow and develop. But you can say this was a good first step.'' The two agreed to meet again in two weeks. SABRINA TAVERNISE

HALBERSTAM--David. His family and friends wish to express heartfelt gratitude to all those who mourn his untimely death. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, June 12 at 4:00pm in Riverside Church (490 Riverside Dr. at 121st Street), Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in David's name to Teach For America, Mississippi Delta, 299 South 9th Street, Suite 212, Oxford, Mississippi 38655.

Ségolène Royal, the Socialist candidate in the French presidential election on May 6, accused Nicolas Sarkozy, her conservative opponent, on Wednesday of having ''apologized'' to President Bush for France's decision not to back the United States militarily in Iraq. Mr. Sarkozy's campaign team called her words ''lies.''

Two of the world's most repressive nations, Myanmar and North Korea, restored diplomatic relations after more than two decades of estrangement. The agreement was signed without fanfare during a three-day visit to Myanmar, formerly Burma, by Deputy Foreign Minister Kim Yong-il of North Korea. Myanmar's deputy foreign minister, Kyaw Thu, said it would be up to the North Koreans to decide whether to open a diplomatic mission in the remote new capital, Naypyidaw, 200 miles north of Yangon, the largest city and former capital. Relations between the nations have been quietly warming over recent years as both sought allies under pressure from the West. SETH MYDANS

Kobe Bryant was serenaded with chants of ''M.V.P.,'' a sea of gold shirts bounced late into the evening Thursday at Staples Center, and the Los Angeles Lakers looked very much alive. Bryant scored 45 points in 45 minutes, and the Lakers restored a measure of belief in their anxious fan base with a 95-89 victory over the Phoenix Suns. The Suns lead the best-of-seven series, 2-1, with Game 4 here Sunday.

May his memory serve as an eternal blessing. Service 11:15am Sunday, from Union Temple of Brooklyn, 17 Eastern Pkwy, Brooklyn, NY. Dr. Linda Henry Goodman, Rabbi Dr. A. Stanley Dreyfus, Rabbi Emeritus Doris Klueger, President

''There was never a serious debate that I know of within the administration about the imminence of the Iraqi threat.'' GEORGE J. TENET, the former director of central intelligence, in a new book. [A1]

A headline in Business Day on Wednesday about the drop in sales of existing homes in March to 6.12 million units, on a seasonally adjusted annual basis, misstated the historical context of those sales. While the drop of 8.4 percent was indeed the steepest monthly decline since January 1989, when sales fell by 12.6 percent; the sales did not fall to the 1989 level. (The sales rate for 1989 was 3.29 million units.)

Commissioner Bud Selig said yesterday that he believed that Marvin Miller deserved to be in the Baseball Hall of Fame, a surprising endorsement considering that Miller created the Players Association that was in protracted conflict with the owners for many years. Selig put in a word for the retired Miller as he spoke of the need for ''adjustments'' in the Hall's reconstituted veterans committee.

WHO -- Deahni Kipnis, 47, owner of a skin-care salon WHAT -- 2-bedroom house WHERE -- Taos, N.M. Taos is truly a solar capital and is very much into sustainable living. Even our local radio station is solar powered. This house isn't off the grid, but when I converted it to solar power, I effectively removed it from dependence on the local utility. I invested $50,000 in the project and took out a second mortgage to do it, but I didn't go solar expecting that I would ever recoup all of the costs. It was driven more by who I am and how I want to represent myself. That said, I do save $1,500 to $2,000 a year on electricity and propane bills.
To the Editor: Re ''Turning the Election Green'' (column, April 25):

Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition. Theater Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater. Previews and Openings 'BEAUTY ON THE VINE' In previews; opens on Wednesday. Zak Berkman's romantic fable follows a man falling in love with a budding star of right-wing radio (2:10). Clurman Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. 'CORAM BOY' In previews; opens on Wednesday. An adaptation of Jamila Gavin's novel about two orphans is the latest National Theater hit to move from London to Broadway (2:30). Imperial Theater, 249 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. 'CYMBELINE' Opens on Wednesday. Declan Donnellan stages this Cheek by Jowl production of one of Shakespeare's last plays (2:40). Harvey Theater, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100. 'DIXIE'S TUPPERWARE PARTY' In previews; opens on May 10. Dixie Wingate has left her Alabama trailer park to sell Tupperware in New York in this irreverent comedy (1:15). Ars Nova, 511 West 54th Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444. 'DEUCE' In previews; opens on May 6. The grandes dames Angela Lansbury and Marian Seldes play retired tennis players in this new Terrence McNally comedy. Michael Blakemore directs (1:45). Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. 'LEGALLY BLONDE' In previews; opens on Sunday. Laura Bell Bundy plays the smiling, ditsy sorority girl who takes Harvard Law by storm in this musical adaptation. Jerry Mitchell directs (2:20). Palace Theater, 1564 Broadway, at 47th Street, (212) 307-4100. 'LOVEMUSIK' In previews; opens on Thursday. The Tony winners Michael Cerveris and Donna Murphy star in a musical about the relationship between Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya (with songs by Weill). Harold Prince directs (2:40). Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200. '110 IN THE SHADE' In previews; opens on May 9. Audra McDonald stars in the Roundabout's revival of the musical version of N. Richard Nash's ''Rainmaker.'' Studio 54, 254 West 54th Street, (212) 719-1300. 'PASSING STRANGE' Previews start on Tuesday. Opens on May 14. The Joe's Pub veteran and pop singer Stew tries his hand at musical theater, with a rock-theme score and a story about the journey of a bohemian (2:30). Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555. 'RADIO GOLF' In previews; opens on May 8. The last play in August Wilson's cycle is set in 1997 and centers on the vital question of what will be done with the fabled Aunt Esther's house. Tonya Pinkins (''Caroline, or Change'') stars (2:30). Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. Broadway 'A CHORUS LINE' If you want to know why this show was such a big deal when it opened 31 years ago, you need only experience the thrilling first five minutes of this revival. Otherwise, this archivally exact production, directed by Bob Avian, feels like a vintage car that has been taken out of the garage, polished up and sent on the road once again (2:00). Schoenfeld Theater, 236 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Ben Brantley) * 'THE COAST OF UTOPIA' Lincoln Center Theater's brave, gorgeous, sprawling and ultimately exhilarating production of Tom Stoppard's trilogy about intellectuals errant in 19th-century Russia. A testament to the seductive powers of narrative theater, directed with hot and cool canniness by Jack O'Brien and featuring a starry cast (Brian F. O'Byrne, Jennifer Ehle, Martha Plimpton, Josh Hamilton and Ethan Hawke, among others) in a tasty assortment of roles. Vivian Beaumont Theater, 150 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'COMPANY' Fire, beckoning and dangerous, flickers beneath the frost of John Doyle's elegant, unexpectedly stirring revival of Stephen Sondheim and George Furth's era-defining musical from 1970, starring a compellingly understated Raúl Esparza. Like Mr. Doyle's ''Sweeney Todd,'' this production finds new clarity of feeling in Sondheim by melding the roles of performers and musicians (2:20). Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'CURTAINS' This musical comedy about a musical-comedy murder -- featuring songs by John Kander and Fred Ebb and a book by Rupert Holmes -- lies on the stage like a promisingly gaudy string of firecrackers, waiting in vain for a match. The good news is that David Hyde Pierce, playing a diffident Boston detective, steps into full-fledged Broadway stardom. Scott Ellis directs a talent-packed cast that includes Debra Monk and Karen Ziemba. (2:30). Al Hirschfeld Theater, 302 West 45th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'FROST/NIXON' Frank Langella turns in a truly titanic performance as Richard M. Nixon in Peter Morgan's briskly entertaining, if all-too-tidy, play about the former president's annihilating television interviews with the British talk show host David Frost (the excellent Michael Sheen). Michael Grandage directs with the momentum of a ticking-bomb thriller and the zing of a boulevard comedy (1:40). Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'GREY GARDENS' Christine Ebersole is absolutely glorious as the middle-aged, time-warped debutante called Little Edie Beale in this uneven musical adaptation of the notorious 1975 documentary of the same title. She and the wonderful Mary Louise Wilson (as her bedridden mother), in the performances of their careers, make ''Grey Gardens'' an experience no passionate theatergoer should miss (2:40). Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'INHERIT THE WIND' Doug Hughes's wooden revival of this worthy war horse, based on the Scopes ''monkey'' trial of 1925, never musters much more velocity than that of a drugstore fan. Be grateful that the cast includes Christopher Plummer, in savory form as a Will Rogers of jurisprudence. An oddly subdued Brian Dennehy plays his pompous adversary (2:00). Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'JOURNEY'S END' A splendid revival of R. C. Sherriff's 1928 drama of life in the trenches during World War I. Acutely staged (by David Grindley) and acted by a fine ensemble led by Hugh Dancy and Boyd Gaines, this production offers an exemplary presentation of that theatrical rarity, an uncompromising, clear-eyed play about war and the experience of day-to-day combat. An essential ticket (2:40). Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'MARY POPPINS' This handsome, homily-packed, mechanically ingenious and rather tedious musical, adapted from the P. L. Travers stories and the 1964 film, is ultimately less concerned with inexplicable magic than with practical psychology. Ashley Brown, who sings prettily as the family-mending nanny, looks like Joan Crawford trying to be nice and sounds like Dr. Phil. Directed by Richard Eyre and Matthew Bourne (2:30). New Amsterdam Theater, 214 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4747. (Brantley) 'LES MISÉRABLES' This premature revival, a slightly scaled-down version of the well-groomed behemoth that closed only three years ago, appears to be functioning in a state of mild sedation. Appealingly sung and freshly orchestrated, this fast-moving adaptation of Victor Hugo's novel isn't sloppy or blurry. But its pulse rate stays well below normal (2:55). Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'A MOON FOR THE MISBEGOTTEN' Kevin Spacey gives a bizarre, beat-the-clock performance, as lively as a frog on a hot plate, as James Tyrone in this off-kilter revival of Eugene O'Neill's last play. Mercifully, he does not block the view of Eve Best, who maps the contradictory levels of Tyrone's strapping love interest with clarity and intelligence (2:50). Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'THE PIRATE QUEEN' How to river-dance your way to the bottom of the ocean, courtesy of the songwriters of ''Les Misérables'' (2:30). Hilton Theater, 213 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) * 'SPRING AWAKENING' Duncan Sheik and Steven Sater's bold adaptation of the Frank Wedekind play is the freshest and most exciting new musical Broadway has seen in some time. Set in 19th-century Germany but with a ravishing rock score, it exposes the splintered emotional lives of adolescents just discovering the joys and sorrows of sex. Performed with brio by a great cast, with supple direction by Michael Mayer and inventive choreography by Bill T. Jones (2:00). Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Charles Isherwood) * 'TALK RADIO' The most lacerating portrait of a human meltdown this side of a Francis Bacon painting. Playing an abrasive radio talk show host with a God complex, the astounding Liev Schreiber seems to fill the air as inescapably as weather in Robert Falls's gut-grabbing revival of Eric Bogosian's 1987 play (1:40). Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING' Joan Didion's arresting but ultimately frustrating adaptation of her best-selling memoir about being blindsided by grief, starring Vanessa Redgrave. The tension between style and emotional content that made the book such a stunner does not translate to the stage. The substance here is in the silences, when the focus shifts from words to Ms. Redgrave's wry, wounded face (1:40). Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) Off Broadway 'THE ACCOMPLICES' Bernard Weinraub, a former reporter for The New York Times, has chosen a worthy subject for his first play: In 1940, the young Zionist Peter Bergson was determined to persuade the United States government to open its arms to Jewish refugees fleeing the Nazis. Unfortunately, this production takes a hagiographic approach to its protagonist, emphasizing his heroism at the expense of more complex characterization. (2:00). Acorn Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. (David Ng) 'ALL THE WRONG REASONS: A TRUE STORY OF NEO-NAZIS, DRUG SMUGGLING AND UNDYING LOVE' John Fugelsang's amiable solo show mixes memoir and stand-up comedy in a tale of family, faith and Roman Catholic guilt. Slight but engaging (1:30). New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 460-5475. (Isherwood) * 'APOSTASY' Gino Dilorio's fearless play about a dying white Jewish woman who falls under the spell of a black televangelist is pretty good; the acting that delivers it is terrific, especially Susan Greenhill as the woman, and Susan Louise O'Connor as her daughter (2:00). Urban Stages, 259 West 30th Street, (212) 868-4444. (Neil Genzlinger) 'BE' A high-energy, low-content Israeli show that blends music, dance and sex appeal in the latest attempt to tap into the ''Stomp'' market (1:30). Union Square Theater, 100 East 17th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 307-4100. (Jason Zinoman) 'THE BIG VOICE: GOD OR MERMAN?' Think of two gifted and smart gay men with years of life together deploying their considerable talents from the two pianos you happen to have in your living room. The result is a hilarious and very touching memoir of two decades of love and the funky glories of show business life (2:00). Actors Temple Theater, 339 West 47th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Honor Moore) 'BILL W. AND DR. BOB' This insightful new play about the founders of Alcoholics Anonymous subtly makes the claim that the recovery movement was born as a series of accidents. Patrick Husted is excellent as Bob Smith, Bill Wilson's partner in combating addictions (2:15). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Ginia Bellafante) 'BIOGRAPHY' A revival of S. N. Behrman's hoary 1932 comedy about a society portraitist and the men who keep trying to reign her in feels slight as a needlepoint pillow. As the play's supposedly beguiling heroine, Marion Froude, Carolyn McCormick never beguiles (2:15). The Pearl Theater, 80 St. Mark's Place, at First Avenue, East Village, (212) 598-9802. (Bellafante) * 'BLACKBIRD' David Harrower's stunning new drama looks back at a sexual relationship -- between a 40-year-old man and a 12-year-old girl -- that transforms, cripples and paralyzes. Jeff Daniels and Alison Pill, both extraordinary, peel their characters down to their barest souls. Joe Mantello is the masterly director (1:30). Manhattan Theater Club at City Center Stage I, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212. (Brantley) 'THE FANTASTICKS' A revival -- well, more like a resuscitation -- of the Little Musical That Wouldn't Die. This sweet-as-ever production of Tom Jones and Harvey Schmidt's commedia-dell'arte-style confection is most notable for Mr. Jones's touching performance (under the pseudonym Thomas Bruce) as the Old Actor, a role he created when the show opened in 1960. Mr. Jones also directs (2:05). Snapple Theater Center, 210 West 50th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) * 'IN THE HEIGHTS' Lin-Manuel Miranda's joyous songs paint a vibrant portrait of daily life in Washington Heights in this flawed but enjoyable show. Essentially a valentine to the barrio -- conflict of a violent or desperate kind is banished from the picture -- the musical contains a host of funny performances and brings the zesty sound of Latin pop to the stage. (2:10). 37 Arts, 450 West 37th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Isherwood) 'THE J.A.P. SHOW: JEWISH AMERICAN PRINCESSES of comedy' Laughs along with longueurs (1:30). Actors Temple Theater, 339 West 47th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Lawrence Van Gelder) 'A JEW GROWS IN BROOKLYN' You don't have to be Jewish or Brooklynish to empathize with Jake Ehrenreich, but in terms of fully appreciating his essentially one-man show, it probably helps. Especially the Catskills jokes (2:05). 37 Arts, 450 West 37th Street, (212) 560-8912. (Anita Gates) * 'SPALDING GRAY: STORIES LEFT TO TELL' A disarming collage of selections from the monologues and journals of Mr. Gray, the ultimate stand-up solipsist, who died in 2004. Directed by Lucy Sexton, and read by five performers, none of whom resemble Mr. Gray, with an affection that shrewdly stops short of hero worship (1:30). Minetta Lane Theater, 18 Minetta Lane, Greenwich Village, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'THE VIEW FROM K STREET STEAK' An attempt at political satire that misses with just about every shot, this play ends up being simply confusing and boring, neither funny nor timely (1:50). Altered Stages, 212 West 29th Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-3101. (Wilborn Hampton) Off Off Broadway 'DENIAL' An engrossing and timely legal drama about a Holocaust denier being defended by a Jewish lawyer, this play examines the moral and ethical dilemma inherent in the First Amendment and asks how much sufferance can a free society give its crackpots and maintain its individual liberties (2:30). Metropolitan Playhouse, 220 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 995-5302. (Hampton) Long-Running Shows 'ALTAR BOYZ' This sweetly satirical show about a Christian pop group made up of five potential Teen People cover boys is an enjoyable, silly diversion (1:30). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) 'AVENUE Q' R-rated puppets give lively life lessons (2:10). Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'BEAUTY AND THE BEAST' Cartoon made flesh, sort of (2:30). Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, (212) 307-4747. (Brantley) 'CHICAGO' Irrefutable proof that crime pays (2:25). Ambassador Theater, 219 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE COLOR PURPLE' Singing CliffsNotes for Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel (2:40). Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, at 53rd Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'FORBIDDEN BROADWAY: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT' Often more entertaining than the real thing (1:45). 47th Street Theater, 304 West 47th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'HAIRSPRAY' Fizzy pop, cute kids, large man in a housedress (2:30). Neil Simon Theater, 250 West 52nd Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'JERSEY BOYS' The biomusical that walks like a man (2:30). August Wilson Theater, 245 West 52nd Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE LION KING' Disney on safari, where the big bucks roam (2:45). Minskoff Theater, 200 West 45th Street at Broadway, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'MAMMA MIA!' The jukebox that devoured Broadway (2:20). Cadillac Winter Garden Theater, 1634 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA' Who was that masked man, anyway? (2:30). Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'RENT' East Village angst and love songs to die for (2:45). Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'SPAMALOT' A singing scrapbook for Monty Python fans (2:20). Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE 25TH ANNUAL PUTNAM COUNTY SPELLING BEE' ''A Chorus Line'' with pimples (1:45). Circle in the Square, 254 West 50th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) 'WICKED' Oz revisited, with political corrections (2:45). Gershwin Theater, 222 West 51st Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) Last Chance 'DEFENDER OF THE FAITH' This grim tale by Stuart Carolan of low-level I.R.A. agitators trying to identify the informer in their midst features some visceral performances and a set by Charles Corcoran that makes excellent use of the Irish Rep's small stage. If only the cause itself didn't feel so small in these days of global terrorism (1:30). Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-2737; closes on Sunday. (Genzlinger) * 'DYING CITY' Christopher Shinn's crafty and unsettling play about grief and violence, set in the shadow of the Iraq war. Directed by James Macdonald and fiercely acted by Pablo Schreiber and Rebecca Brooksher, this quiet, transfixing production turns passive aggression into a theatrical dynamic (1:30). Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, 150 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-7600; closes on Sunday. (Brantley) 'EXITS AND ENTRANCES' Athol Fugard casts a tender glance back at an actor whose dedication to theater helped spark his own in this warm if insubstantial stage memoir. Morlan Higgins capably excavates the emotional core of a role that might have seemed generic, playing an aging gay actor reckoning with the end of an up-and-down career. William Dennis Hurley plays the Fugard stand-in (1:30). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200; closes on Sunday. (Isherwood) * 'JACK GOES BOATING' Bob Glaudini's gentle comedy about pothead losers in love is a reminder of how engrossing uneventful lives can be in the hands of the right actors. Peter DuBois directs the easygoing ensemble, brilliantly led by Philip Seymour Hoffman (2:00). Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555; closes on Sunday. (Brantley) 'LA MAGNANI' Theresa Gambacorta reincarnates the Italian film star Anna Magnani in this one-woman show, which reveals her to be more irritating than interesting: loud and self-absorbed (1:10). Arclight Theater, 152 West 71st Street, (212) 279-4200; closes on Sunday. (Genzlinger) 'MARIE ANTOINETTE: THE COLOR OF FLESH' Joel Gross's intriguing play features impeccable performances by Amanda Jones, Samantha Ives and Jonathan Kells Phillips as the three corners of a triangle of love and friendship caught up in the French Revolution. It's no ordinary triangle: Ms. Jones plays Marie Antoinette, and Ms. Ives the real portraitist who often painted her (1:30). The 45th Street Theater, 354 West 45th Street, Clinton, (212) 254-9533; closes on Sunday. (Genzlinger) 'MUD BLOSSOM' This brooding drama about three generations of suffering Southern women wallows in its own despair (1:50) Walkerspace, 46 Walker Street, near Church Street, SoHo, (212) 352-3101; closes tomorrow. (Zinoman) Movies Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/movies. 'A DIOS MOMO' (No rating, 108 minutes, in Spanish) Directed by Leonardo Ricagni, this crude, sugary melodrama follows the uplifting misadventures of Obdulio (Mathias Acuña), an 11-year-old newspaper boy. Obdulio is illiterate and refuses to go to school, but he's obsessed with the Murgas, a troupe of traveling singers. He learns to read when his newspaper's watchman, Barrilete (Jorge Esmoris), dispatches him to the singers' practice room to scrawl Barrilete's lyrics on a chalkboard. This fairy-tale touch might work if the movie weren't so pleased with its own pie-eyed naïveté, and so eager to imitate the stalest aspects of films by the director's chief inspiration, Federico Fellini. (Matt Zoller Seitz) * 'ALICE NEEL' (No rating, 82 minutes) The fascinating documentary ''Alice Neel'' -- a biography of this influential, emotionally troubled portrait artist, by her grandson Andrew Neel -- juxtaposes relaxed interview footage and archival clips with more ragged, personal footage that reveals a filmmaker struggling to define an indefinable woman. The result is a film that seems more unfinished -- and thus more present tense -- than other examples of its type, and makes its subject, who died in 1984, seem very much alive. (Seitz) 'AQUA TEEN HUNGER FORCE COLON MOVIE FILM FOR THEATERS' (R, 87 minutes) Not as funny as the title or the Cartoon Network series on which it's based. (A. O. Scott) 'Blades of Glory' (PG-13, 93 minutes) In this fast, light, frequently funny comedy about a male figure-skating team, Will Ferrell and Jon Heder stake an early claim to being the comedy couple of the year. (Stephen Holden) 'DISTURBIA' (PG-13, 104 minutes) A pleasant, scary, well-directed variation on the killer-next-door theme, with the engaging Shia LeBeouf as Kale, a young man who turns house arrest into an occasion for voyeurism and crime-fighting. (Scott) * 'ELECTION' (No rating, 100 minutes, in Cantonese) This intricate gangster entertainment, the first episode in a two-part sequence from the prolific Hong Kong action maestro Johnnie To, offer some acute lessons in the pitfalls of democracy. Also a feast of fighting, humor and fine acting, in particular from Simon Yaw, who plays a soft-spoken, businesslike candidate for chairman of Hong Kong's oldest criminal organization. (Scott) 'FRACTURE' (R, 111 minutes) A glib entertainment that offers up the spectacle of that crafty scene-stealer Anthony Hopkins mixing it up with that equally cunning screen-nibbler Ryan Gosling. (Manohla Dargis) 'THE GLAMOROUS LIFE OF SACHIKO HANAI' (No rating, 90 minutes, in Japanese) A wayward bullet turns a hooker into a brainiac in this Japanese clutter of soft-core political parody, hard-core narrative nonsense, breezy sexism and penny-ante surrealism. (Dargis) 'GRINDHOUSE' (R, 180 minutes) A double feature, complete with fake previews for schlocky exploitation pictures, that pays nostalgic tribute to disreputable traditions of moviemaking and moviegoing. Robert Rodriguez contributes ''Planet Terror,'' a purposely incoherent zombie gross-out flick that flaunts is own badness the way Rose McGowan (as a go-go dancer named Cherry Darling) shows off her weaponized prosthetic leg. For his part, Quentin Tarantino, more of a connoisseur than his collaborator (and a much better filmmaker), turns out a brutal, talky and satisfying car-chase revenge movie in ''Death Proof,'' starring Kurt Russell. (Scott) * 'THE HOAX' (R, 115 minutes) A first-rate performance by Richard Gere drives this true story of Clifford Irving (Mr. Gere), who claimed to be the authorized biographer of Howard Hughes. Shadowed by the paranoia of its period (the early '70s), this movie, crisply directed by Lasse Hallstrom from an excellent script by William Weaver, is less a morality play than an entertaining portrait of a literary gambler. (Scott) * 'HOT FUZZ' (R, 121 minutes) A British parody of Hollywood-style action flicks from the wits behind ''Shaun of the Dead.'' Think of it as ''The Full Monty'' blown to smithereens. (Dargis) 'IN THE LAND OF WOMEN' (PG-13, 98 minutes) This meek, mopey comedy is the film equivalent of a sensitive emo band with one foot in alternative rock and the other in the squishy pop mainstream. The movie would like to think of itself as a softer, fuzzier ''Garden State.'' (Holden) * 'KILLER OF SHEEP' (No rating, 83 minutes) Largely hidden from view for three decades, Charles Burnett's lyrical film about a working-class family living in a broken-down home in a bombed-out stretch of Los Angeles is an American masterpiece, independent to the bone. (Dargis) 'LONELY HEARTS' (No rating, 100 minutes) This beautifully photographed remake of Leonard Kastle's 1970 cult B movie ''The Honeymoon Killers'' succeeds better than many modern crime dramas in balancing the philosophical with the visceral, although its villains' dirty deeds still trump its deeper strain of melancholy. (Holden) 'PATHFINDER' (R, 100 minutes) It's all grunting, all goring in this witless period flick about some Norsemen of the apocalypse come to wreak bloody ruin in the New World. (Dargis) 'PERFECT STRANGER' (R, 109 minutes) There is enough of a grain of truth in this noirish, paranoid thriller set in the New York media world that even after it lurches from the farfetched into the preposterous, the movie leaves a clammy residue of unease. (Holden) * 'PRIVATE FEARS IN PUBLIC PLACES' (No rating, 120 minutes, in French) A film from the venerable French auteur Alain Resnais about love and cinematic spaces, elegant camera moves and six heavenly bodies as seen through a mighty telescope. (Dargis) * 'RED ROAD' (No rating, 113 minutes) Andrea Arnold's first feature falls into melodrama and implausibility at the end, but along the way it is a remarkably assured and complex piece of work, anchored by the director's formal control and by Jackie Dick's quietly heartbreaking performance as a Glasgow video-surveillance officer with an unhappy past. (Scott) * 'ROCK THE BELLS' (No rating, 103 minutes) Casey Suchan and Denis Henry Hennelly's lively documentary follows the independent music promoter Chang Weisberg as he struggles to reunite the original members of the Wu-Tang Clan for a 2004 hip-hop concert. Capturing onstage and off with equal energy, the movie is a fascinating glimpse of a dreamer and a music culture that has always depended on them. (Jeannette Catsoulis) 'STEPHANIE DALEY' (R, 91 minutes) There is a fine line between a human drama with an autonomous life and an issue-oriented dramatic essay. If this drama about a teenage girl prosecuted for murdering her baby didn't have its ear so perfectly attuned to the tone and language of intergenerational dialogue, it would come across as a dry, cinematic essay. (Holden) * 'SYNDROMES AND A CENTURY' (No rating, 105 minutes, in Thai) Apichatpong Weerasethakul, a Thai director who has become a star of the international festival circuit, makes films that are difficult, abstract and mysterious in the best art-cinema tradition, but at the same time characterized by unusual warmth and generosity of spirit. ''Syndromes,'' suggested by the lives of the filmmaker's parents and the music of Mozart, is a two-part invention on the themes of chance and longing, shot with an intoxicating mix of suavity and sensuality. (Scott) * 'TRIAD ELECTION' (No rating, 93 minutes, in Cantonese) The surfaces gleam as luxuriously in Johnnie To's exemplary gangster thriller ''Triad Election'' as those in a similarly slicked-up Hollywood film, but the blood on the floor here seems stickier, more liable to stain. A brutal look at the shadows darkening the Hong Kong triads, the film picks up the narrative line first coiled and kinked in Mr. To's companion thriller, ''Election.'' (Dargis) 'VACANCY' (R, 80 minutes) This banal horror retread involves a couple of critters (Luke Wilson, Kate Beckinsale) flailing inside a sticky trap for what is, in effect, the big-screen equivalent of a roach motel. (Dargis) * 'THE VALET' (PG-13, 85 minutes, in French) If you love to hate the superrich, this delectable comedy, in which the great French actor Daniel Auteuil portrays a piggy billionaire industrialist facing his comeuppance, is a sinfully delicious bonbon, a classic French farce with modern touches. (Holden) * 'YEAR OF THE DOG' (PG-13, 97 minutes) Mike White's touching comedy about a woman who loses a dog and finds herself is funny ha-ha but firmly in touch with its downer side, which means that it's also funny in a kind of existential way. Molly Shannon stars alongside a menagerie of howling scene-stealers. (Dargis) 'ZOO' (No rating, 76 minutes) Robinson Devor's heavily reconstructed documentary is, to a large extent, about the rhetorical uses of beauty. It is, rather more coyly, also about a man who died after having sex with a stallion. (Dargis) Film Series avant-garde features (Tonight) Anthology Film Archives, the East Village repository of avant-garde cinema, begins this monthly series devoted to that least commercial of formats, the feature-length experimental film. The initial offering, ''La Raison Avant la Passion,'' Joyce Wieland's 80-minute film from 1969, is a reflection on the author's home country, Canada. It consists of images from a cross-country trip on the Trans-Canada Highway combined with anagrams drawn from the title phrase, a quotation from a speech by Pierre Trudeau. Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 505-5181, anthologyfilmarchives.org; $8. (Dave Kehr) * COMMITMENT AND GRACE: THE FILMS OF CARLOS SAURA (Tomorrow, Sunday, Monday and Wednesday) Mr. Saura is, of course, one of Spain's greatest filmmakers. But for those who love dance, he will always be an artist who speaks vivid new truths about Spanish dancing and the relationship of film and dance. This tribute covers 50 years of work. (Through May 3.) Mr. Saura's magisterial ''Flamenco,'' as much about a nation as about a national dance form, will be shown tomorrow at 9:30 p.m. and Monday at 3 and 7 p.m. Sunday programs are devoted to dance, with ''Blood Wedding'' and ''Sevillanas'' shown at 2 p.m., ''Carmen'' at 4:25 p.m. and ''El Amor Brujo'' (''Love the Magician'') at 6:30 p.m. Wednesday's dance films are ''Blood Wedding,'' at noon; ''Carmen,'' at 1:30 p.m.; and ''El Amor Brujo'' at 3:30 p.m. Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5600, filmlinc.com; $11; $7 for students with ID; $7 for 65+ at weekday screenings before 6 p.m. (Jennifer Dunning) FARES TO REMEMBER (Friday through Sunday) This monthlong series of films set in and around taxicabs comes to an end at the IFC Center with two prime examples of this curious sub-genre: Phil Karlson's first-rate film noir ''99 River Street'' (1953), with John Payne as a taxi-driving former heavyweight champ who finds himself accused of his wife's murder, and Jim Jarmusch's 1991 ''Night on Earth,'' five tales of nocturnal taxi rides set in New York, Paris, Los Angeles, Helsinki and Rome. IFC Center, 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 924-7771, ifccenter.com; $10.75. (Kehr) FILMMAKERS AT MACDOWELL: THE STUDIO SYSTEM RECONSIDERED (Wednesday and Thursday) MoMA begins a series of 26 films and video pieces from directors who have passed through the fellowship program at the MacDowell Colony in New Hampshire with a newly commissioned work, ''Seasons of MacDowell.'' It is a four-part film that features contributions by Michael Almereyda, George Griffin, David Petersen and Elisabeth Subrin. (The four filmmakers, along with the chairman of MacDowell, Robert MacNeil, will be present for the Wednesday night screening.) Films being shown on Thursday include work by Cindy Stillwell, Joel Katz, Chris Schiavo, Fern Seiden and Stacey Steers. The series continues through May 16. Museum of Modern Art Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters, (212) 708-9400, moma.org; $10. (Kehr) 'MANY FACES OF CHIKA' (Tuesday) The North American premiere of the one fiction feature directed by the pre-eminent Japanese documentary filmmaker Kazuo Hara (''The Emperor's Naked Army Marches On''). Anticipating Todd Solondz's ''Palindromes,'' Mr. Hara uses four different actresses to play a single character, that of a woman who abandons her husband and infant son to wander the chaotic world of Japan in the late 1960s and early '70s. After the 7 p.m. screening, Mr. Hara and his longtime writing and producing partner, Sachiko Kobayashi, will participate in a discussion led by the Village Voice film critic Ed Halter. Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 715-1258, japansociety.org; $13. (Kehr) Pop Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. ACID MOTHERS TEMPLE (Tonight) This prolific Japanese band describes its style as ''extreme trip music,'' which basically means big, sloppy noise jams. It doesn't necessarily mean peasant frocks and long wizard's robes, but Acid Mothers Temple usually has those too. At 9, Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, near Sterling Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0236, spsounds.com; $15. (Ben Sisario) * KAREN AKERS (Tonight and tomorrow night, and Tuesday through Thursday) The songs in ''Simply Styne,'' Ms. Akers's beautiful tribute to the composer Jule Styne, have been arranged into a touching, tongue-in-cheek cabaret answer to ''Scenes From a Marriage.'' The pianist Don Rebic is her witty partner in deconstruction. At 9, with additional shows tonight and tomorrow night at 11:30, Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 419-9331, algonquinhotel.com; $60 cover; $65 dinner charge at 9; $25 minimum at 11:30. (Stephen Holden) * AWESOME COLOR, DIRTY PROJECTORS, DEERHUNTER, BLACK MOTH SUPER RAINBOW (Tonight) Awesome Color's gruff, retro garage-blues is self-consciously noisy as only New York rock can be, but it is also indebted -- and seems partly a homage -- to the vintage Detroit proto-punk of the Stooges and the MC5. Dirty Projectors builds elaborate ''glitch operas'' with stark pluckings of strings and precise, ecstatic harmonies, all arranged slightly out of whack. Deerhunter, from Atlanta, weaves sweet guitar and vocal melodies into patterns that seem both florid and evil. Black Moth Super Rainbow, from Pittsburgh, delivers its shimmering psychedelia through a screen of pulsating keyboards and blissed-out, robotic vocals. At 10, Silent Barn, 915 Wyckoff Avenue, at Hancock Street, Bushwick, Brooklyn, toddpnyc.com; $8. Black Moth Super Rainbow also plays tomorrow at midnight at Pianos, 158 Ludlow Street, near Rivington Street, Lower East Side, (212) 505-3733, pianosnyc.com; $10. (Sisario) BELMONT PLAYBOYS (Tomorrow) A sturdy quartet from Charlotte, N.C., the Belmont Playboys play rockabilly forged in a punk esthetic, with energy and respect. At 10:30 p.m., Rodeo Bar, 375 Third Avenue, at 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 683-6500, rodeobar.com; no cover. (Ben Ratliff) BISHOP ALLEN (Tomorrow) Borrowing from the playbook of early Jonathan Richman, this Brooklyn band puts a boyish smile on spunky, angst-ridden guitar-pop, and nurses worries about the slow crawl toward the workaday adult life: ''Burn, calendar, burn.'' With Miguel Mendez. At 6:30 p.m., Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3132, knittingfactory.com; $10. (Sisario) * BJORK (Wednesday) It's been a long time since Bjork's combination of wailing indie-rock, eroticized electronica and use of random musical props -- Inuit choirs, African kora players -- has been truly avant-garde, or even surprising. But her latest album, ''Volta'' (Elektra), still sounds fresh and energized, with every sound becoming her exotic plaything, whether somber brass, tribal rhythms or staticky beats by Timbaland. At 8 p.m., Radio City Music Hall, (212) 307-7171, radiocity.com; $61 to $86. (Sisario) CANNIBAL CORPSE (Sunday) The guttural grind of this veteran Buffalo band comes with a punishing regularity, like some nightmarish war machine. Onstage the band is ragged and battle-ready, with guitars clutched like weapons and long hair swirling in ritualistic synchronization. With Behemoth, the Red Chord, Job for a Cowboy and Psyopus. At 7 p.m., Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800; $22 in advance, $24 at the door. (Sisario) CRIBS (Wednesday and Thursday) Jeez, the Strokes really are an incredibly influential band. This British trio, with two albums under its belt and a third coming in July, sounds awfully familiar playing those sneering melodies and sharp, uptight chords. The Cribs do it well, and seem to be having a great, sweaty time with it, but still, haven't we been through this before? At 10 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700, mercuryloungenyc.com; $15. (Sisario) THE KILLERS (Tomorrow) Not many young bands have the songwriting chops to back up their big-league arrogance the way the Killers do. Three years ago this Las Vegas quartet became instant stars with ''Hot Fuss,'' whose adrenalized update of new-wave rock cloaked some of the blasé cynicism of its lyrics (''Dreams aren't what they used to be''). ''Sam's Town'' (Island/Def Jam), released last fall, is grandiose and aloof where its predecessor was sharp and hungry, though it still has a few songs you won't easily get out of your head. At 8 p.m., Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741, thegarden.com; $30 and $45. (Sisario) PAMELIA KURSTIN, BARBEZ, BIG LAZY (Tonight) Ms. Kurstin plays the theremin, the eerie-sounding electronic instrument ubiquitous in 1950s horror movies, which is controlled by gesturing in the air around two metal rods. It's not easy to develop a recognizable style on the instrument, but she has earned a reputation for her lyrical solos and walking bass lines (really). Here, celebrating the release of her solo album, ''Thinking Out Loud'' (Tzadik), she is joined by Barbez, an avant-cabaret band she plays in; and Big Lazy, whose instrumentals taste of twangy rockabilly and the gutter jazz of the Lounge Lizards. At 9, Brooklyn Lyceum, 227 Fourth Avenue, at Union Street, Park Slope, (718) 857-4816, brooklynlyceum.com; $10. (Sisario) * LIGHTNING BOLT, SUN RA ARKESTRA (Tonight) At first it's hard to believe that all the glorious chaos of Lightning Bolt is being made by only two people. But as the sound comes into focus, a playful give-and-take becomes clear, as the bassist Brian Gibson and the drummer and vocalist Brian Chippendale toss back and forth gigantic metal riffs and giggly high notes, creating rainbows of dissonance. In the kind of smart cross-genre pairing that happens all too rarely, the band is playing with the Sun Ra Arkestra, which carries on its namesake's legacy of liberating cacophony. At 6, Pratt Institute Main Lawn, 200 Willoughby Avenue, between Hall Street and Emerson Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, toddpnyc.com; free. (Sisario) MAD PROFESSOR (Tuesday) Mad Professor is a master of dub reggae, the music of subterranean bass lines, eerie echoes and unexplained fissures in the fabric of space-time. At 10 p.m., S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940, sobs.com; $22. (Jon Pareles) NELLIE McKAY (Tonight) Since her ejection from the mainstream record industry a year ago, Ms. McKay has been keeping busy with other projects: a stint on Broadway, appearances at Lincoln Center. She's doing O.K. Tonight she brings her winky-wink amalgam of American Songbook pop, rap and '50s-style bubblegum (''I'm gonna pounce/Meow/Like a pussy cat'') to Zankel Hall. At 8:30, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $38 to $43. (Sisario) * MODEST MOUSE (Sunday and Monday) A band so emblematic of 21st-century indie rock that it was mentioned by name in the Supreme Court's decision on MGM v. Grokster two years ago, Modest Mouse, from Issaquah, Wash., links antsy, catchy guitar lines to vocals that are always just a few shrieks away from a destructive tantrum. The addition of Johnny Marr, the innovative former guitarist of the Smiths, has thickened the band's sound without making it any less volatile. At 8 p.m., United Palace Theater, 4140 Broadway, at 175th Street, Washington Heights, (212) 307-7171, bowerypresents.com; sold out. (Sisario) MOE (Wednesday and Thursday) One chord is all Moe needs to start one of its nimble, quick-fingered jams. Its music starts with the Grateful Dead-Allman Brothers hybrids that most jam bands use, and from there it takes off toward Southern rock, spacey interludes or the borderline of funk. At 9 p.m., Highline Ballroom, 431 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 414-5994, highlineballroom.com; sold out.
