(Pareles) VAN MORRISON (Sunday) Jazz, penitent country and lots of tasty, Celtic-favored R&B fuel Mr. Morrison's incantatory performances, which can smolder intensely or rest in a meditative stillness according to his mood. At 7:30 p.m., Theater at Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741, thegarden.com; $90 and $175. (Sisario) GRAHAM PARKER AND THE LATEST CLOWNS (Tonight) Emerging from England just before the arrival of punk rock, Mr. Parker used the sturdy structures of soul and '60s rock, spitting out angry, articulate songs that chafed against dishonesties large and small. These days he's less furious and more cranky, but he's still holding the world around him to high standards. At 8, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3132, knittingfactory.com; $25. (Pareles) Shahid Parvez (Tomorrow) Shahid Parvez carries on a legacy of sitar playing that goes back seven generations in his family. He is one of India's more celebrated younger musicians, prized especially for the vocalistic phrasing of his raga improvisations. He is to play duets with Aditya Kalyanpur on tabla. At 8 p.m., Philip Coltoff Center, 219 Sullivan Street, near West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 477-5239, virsaonline.com; $25. (Pareles) * PETER BJORN AND JOHN; FUJIYA & MIYAGI (Tuesday and Wednesday) The latest sharp and impeccably stylish import from Sweden, Peter Bjorn and John sets breathy, heavy-hearted vocals over peppery band arrangements that recall 1960s folk-pop. Fujiya & Miyagi, a British trio -- ''We are only pretending to be Japanese,'' goes one lyric -- plays bubbly perpetual-motion figures of guitar and keyboard. Its sound has been heard plenty of times before (Stereolab, Neu!), but it's too fun and innocuous to ever tire of. At 8 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; sold out. (Sisario) * LOU REED (Monday) Representing the best of New York rock's past, Lou Reed might seem an odd choice to open a new club. But hey, it's Chelsea 2007, and that means glitz and fame and velvet ropes, so Mr. Reed, 65, is the first booking in the 700-capacity new Highline Ballroom. His onstage manner, never exactly warm, has stiffened in recent years, but he still expertly walks a line between aloof cynicism and naked, affecting vulnerability. With Okkervil River, a hyperliterate band from Austin, Tex. At 9 p.m., 431 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 414-5994, highlineballroom.com; sold out. (Sisario) ROSE HILL DRIVE (Tomorrow) Like the blues-rock power trios of yore, Rose Hill Drive, from Boulder, Colo., puts all its attention to bruising, jammable riffs, leaving the edges deliberately rough. At 8:30 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700, mercuryloungenyc.com; $15. (Sisario) Keely Smith (Tonight and tomorrow night) This ''queen of swing,'' as she has been nicknamed, may be the last surviving top-of-the-line entertainer from the Rat Pack era of Las Vegas. She is still in reasonably good voice. At 8:45 and 10:45, Café Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, Manhattan, (212) 744-1600, thecarlyle.com; $75 to $125. (Holden) AMON TOBIN (Tomorrow) A decade ago this Brazilian D.J.'s warped, flagellum rhythms seemed about as far out as dance-based music could get. His new album, ''Foley Room'' (Ninja Tune), is just as squiggly and disorienting, though it has lost what it now appears was its most significant trait: novelty. At 9 p.m., Blender Theater at Gramercy, 127 East 23rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171; $23. (Sisario) TRANS AM (Thursday) This trio from Washington plays tightly coiled, retro-futuristic electronic rock like a band stuck in the light matrix of ''Tron'' (or at least one with a serious Kraftwerk fetish). With Zombi and Psychic Paramount. At 8 p.m., Studio B, 259 Banker Street, between Meserole Avenue and Calyer Street, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 389-1880, clubstudiob.com; $10. (Sisario) * YO LA TENGO (Sunday) The model of indie-rock perseverance, Yo La Tengo is led by its songwriters, the husband-and-wife team of Ira Kaplan on guitar and Georgia Hubley on drums. They prize succinct, tuneful songs about the modest pains and pleasures of daily life and love; they also love excursions into feedback and fuzz-tone. With the Brooklyn psych-rock masters Oneida. At 7:30 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; $25. (Pareles) Jazz Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. REZ ABBASI'S BAZAAR (Tonight) On his most recent album, ''Bazaar'' (Zoho), the guitarist Rez Abbasi infuses Southeast Asian motifs with rock bombast and jazz flexibility. At midnight, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $10, with a $10 minimum. (Nate Chinen) ANDY BISKIN (Tomorrow) Mr. Biskin is a clarinetist who often spikes his sturdy compositions with a wily sense of humor. He presents new music for a quartet with Shane Endsley on trumpet, Eivind Opsvik on bass and Take Toriyama on drums. At 8, the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; $10. (Chinen) ABRAHAM BURTON/ERIC McPHERSON GROUP (Tomorrow) The saxophonist Abraham Burton and the drummer Eric McPherson share a brisk command of post-bop traditions, as they prove with this quartet. At midnight, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $10, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) TAYLOR HO BYNUM SEXTET (Tonight) On his new album, ''The Middle Picture'' (Firehouse 12), the cornetist Taylor Ho Bynum advances an avant-garde chamber music jostling with odd intervals and useful frictions. Most of the musicians joining him here, like the guitarist Mary Halvorson and the drummer Tomas Fujiwara, are longtime compatriots with an established rapport. At 9 and 10:30, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $15. (Chinen) STEVE DAVIS QUINTET (Tonight and tomorrow night) ''Update'' (Criss Cross), a recent album by the trombonist Steve Davis, earns its title by gently bringing 1950s hard bop into a modern sphere. Mr. Davis undertakes a similar process with his quintet, which features the saxophonist Mike DiRubbo. At 8 and 9:45, Kitano Hotel, 66 Park Avenue, at 38th Street, (212) 885-7119, kitano.com; cover, $25, with a $15 minimum. (Chinen) * JOEL FRAHM (Tuesday through Thursday) Mr. Frahm's tenor saxophone playing has rarely sounded roomier or more relaxed than it does on ''We Used To Dance'' (Anzic), an album featuring Kenny Barron on piano, Rufus Reid on bass and Victor Lewis on drums. That group begins an engagement at Sweet Rhythm next Wednesday; on the previous night, Mr. Frahm holds down his regular trio engagement at the Bar Next Door. Tuesday at 8 and 10 p.m., Bar Next Door, 129 MacDougal Street, West Village, (212) 529-5945, lalanternacaffe.com; cover, $8, with a one-drink minimum. Wednesday and Thursday at 8 and 10 p.m., Sweet Rhythm, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street, West Village, (212) 255-3626, sweetrhythmny.com; cover, $20, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) * KENNY GARRETT (Tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday) Mr. Garrett is a terror on the alto saxophone, and an artisan on the soprano; he uses both instruments to explore aesthetic territory associated with John Coltrane. Tomorrow he shares a bill in Newark with the fine post-bop trumpeter Nicholas Payton, each leading a quartet. On Wednesday he begins an engagement with a band featuring the tenor saxophonist and Coltrane contemporary Pharoah Sanders, who appeared on Mr. Garrett's last album, ''Beyond the Wall.'' Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722, njpac.org; $44 to $54. Wednesday and Thursday (Through May 6) at 8:30 and 10:30 p.m., Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $40, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) JERRY GRANELLI, JAMIE SAFT AND J. ANTHONY GRANELLI (Sunday) The drummer Jerry Granelli and his son J. Anthony Granelli, a bassist, have teamed up on a number of worthy projects, including ''The Sonic Temple'' (Songlines), an atmospheric live album. They collaborate here with Mr. Saft, a texture-minded keyboardist. At 8:30 p.m., Center for Improvisational Music, 295 Douglass Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (212) 631-5882, schoolforimprov.org; cover, $12; $8 for students. (Chinen) ROY HARGROVE BIG BAND (Thursday) The trumpeter Roy Hargrove has been a paragon of small-group hard bop since the early 1990s. But he has also led a powerful big band, on and off, for roughly the same span of time. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $25; $10 for members. (Chinen) THE HEATH BROTHERS (Wednesday and Thursday) Two years after the loss of their brother Percy, a bassist and cellist, the saxophonist Jimmy Heath and the drummer Albert (Tootie) Heath soldier on. The pianist Jeb Patton and the bassist David Wong round out the band. (Through May 5.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080, birdlandjazz.com; cover, $40, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) FREDDIE HUBBARD AND FRIENDS (Tonight through Sunday night) The sleek and fiery hard-bop of Mr. Hubbard's trumpet-playing prime provides source material for this all-star affair, which variously includes longtime peers (like the trombonist Slide Hampton) and worthy inheritors (like the bassist Christian McBride). At 8:30 and 10:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow night, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $40 ($35 tonight), with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) SUSIE IBARRA AND ROBERTO RODRIGUEZ (Wednesday) Ms. Ibarra is a drummer with a passion for texture and abstraction, and a composer committed to the idea of cultural exchange. ''Electric Kulintang,'' her percussive collaboration with Mr. Rodriguez, adds a contemporary sheen to the chiming kulintang music of the Philippines. At 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778, joespub.com; cover, $15, with a two-drink minimum. (Chinen) MICHAEL MUSILLAMI TRIO +1 (Wednesday) As he demonstrates on his recent album, ''Fragile Forms,'' the guitarist Michael Mussillami favors a bright and slippery variety of post-bop. So his trio should provide a hospitable environment for the sharply expressive violinist Mark Feldman. At 8 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) STEVE NELSON (Tonight and tomorrow night) Mr. Nelson, a vibraphonist best known of late for his role in the Dave Holland Quintet, brings thoughtful poise to this top-flight ensemble with another powerful bassist, Robert Hurst III. At 8, 10 and 11:30, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662, smokejazz.com; cover, $28. (Chinen) JEFF NEWELL'S NEW-TRAD OCTET (Tonight) This aptly named band, led by the saxophonist Jeff Newell, celebrates the release of its first album, ''Brownstone,'' with a respectfully revisionist set of early jazz, gospel and parade music. At 8, Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177; cover, $10 suggested donation. (Chinen) JEREMY PELT QUARTET (Tuesday through Thursday) Jeremy Pelt, a trumpeter with a big tone and bracing technique, leads a locomotive band with Danny Grissett on piano, Derek Nievergelt on bass and Willie Jones III on drums. (Through May 6.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover, $20, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) LUIS PERDOMO TRIO (Tomorrow) On ''Awareness'' (RKM), his most recent album, the pianist Luis Perdomo plays with exploratory urgency, and his compositions take unforced yet unexpected turns. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $15. (Chinen) * PIANO PARTY: 80 AND ONWARD (Tomorrow) The pianist Dick Hyman, an emeritus presence at the 92nd Street Y, celebrates his new octogenarian status there with help from friends like the trumpeter Joe Wilder, the pianists Bill Charlap and Derek Smith, the guitarist Bucky Pizzarelli and the clarinetist Evan Christopher. At 8 p.m., 92 Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500, 92y.org; $45. (Chinen) KURT ROSENWINKEL (Sunday) Mr. Rosenwinkel is a guitarist with a fluid technique and a resonant, warm-blooded tone. Making an infrequent appearance at the club where he honed his craft roughly a dozen years ago, he leads an intuitive trio. At 8:30 and 10:30 p.m., Smalls, 183 West 10th Street, West Village, (212) 252-5091; cover, $20. (Chinen) PONCHO SANCHEZ (Tonight through Sunday night) Mr. Sanchez, a high-spirited conga player, has been a leading figure in Latin jazz for over 20 years, thanks to this working band. At 8 and 10:30, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $35 at tables, $20 at the bar, with a $5 minimum. (Chinen) DAVE SCOTT (Wednesday) Mr. Scott, a trumpeter, presents a version of the hard-bop quintet heard on his new album, ''Naiveté'': Rich Perry on tenor saxophone, Jacob Sacks on piano, John Hebert on bass and Take Toriyama on drums. At 10 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177; cover, $10. (Chinen) * KENDRICK SCOTT ORACLE (Tuesday) Kendrick Scott is a drummer conversant in an ultramodern sense of propulsion, and as he proves on a new album called ''The Source,'' he's a thoughtful composer as well. His band, Oracle, includes versatile peers like the alto saxophonist and bass clarinetist Myron Walden, the guitarist Mike Moreno and the pianist Aaron Parks. At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $20. (Chinen) EMILIO SOLLA AND NY TANGO (Tonight and tomorrow night) The pianist Emilio Solla fashions a modern jazz translation of the popular music of his native Argentina, with help from the saxophonists Donny McCaslin and Chris Cheek, the accordionist Victor Prieto, the bassist Pablo Aslan and the drummer Jeff Ballard. At 8:30 and 10:30, Smalls, 183 West 10th Street, West Village, (212) 675-7369, fatcatjazz.com; cover, $20. (Chinen) E. J. STRICKLAND QUINTET (Tonight) Crisp and assertive post-bop from the drummer E. J. Strickland and a capable crew: John Ellis and Miguel Zenon on saxophones, Luis Perdomo on piano and Massimo Biolcati on bass. At 10, 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, near Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 929-9883, 55bar.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) BEN WALTZER QUINTET (Tomorrow) Ben Waltzer manages a brand of pianistic modernism that coexists peaceably with a buoyant, un-self-conscious sense of swing. In this group he features a pair of excellent saxophonists, Bill McHenry and J. D. Allen. At 9 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen) * CASSANDRA WILSON (Wednesday and Thursday) A jazz singer by training and temperament, Ms. Wilson takes obvious pleasure in a boundless repertory, a tendency borne out vividly on her most recent album, ''Thunderbird.'' She makes a rare nightclub appearance with some estimable longtime colleagues: the guitarist Marvin Sewell, the drummer Herlin Riley and the bassist Reginald Veal. (Through May 5.) At 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $55 at tables, $35 at the bar, with a $5 minimum. (Chinen) STEVE WILSON'S GENERATIONS (Tonight through Sunday night) It has been nearly a decade since the release of ''Generations,'' a rewarding album by the alto saxophonist Steve Wilson featuring Mulgrew Miller on piano, Ray Drummond on bass and Ben Riley on drums. The quartet has regrouped periodically, always with sturdy results. At 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow night, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $30; $25 on Sunday. (Chinen) * JAN WRoBLEWSKI QUARTET (Tuesday) Mr. Wroblewski, the tenor saxophonist and composer, has been one of the most celebrated jazz musicians in Poland for the last four decades. Now in his 70s, he has a new album, ''Supercalifragilistic,'' and a strong rhythm section, with Wojciech Niedziela on piano, Jacek Niedziela on bass and Marcin Jahr on drums. This performance, sponsored by the Polish Cultural Institute, is a rare opportunity to hear him in person. At 7 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080, birdlandjazz.com; cover, $25, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) Classical Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music. Opera * 'IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA' (Monday) Bartlett Sher's breezy production, introduced at the Metropolitan Opera in November, conveys the comic confusions of the story through its fluid staging and a wonderfully abstract set: a matrix of movable doors, staircases and potted orange trees, behind which the characters spy on one another. The heated sexuality in this tale of romantic intrigue also comes through strongly, thanks to Mr. Sher's subtle directing of a handsome cast, notably the captivating young mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato, a vocally agile and feisty Rosina. Lawrence Brownlee, in his debut role with the company, sings Almaviva, and the hardy baritone Russell Braun sings Figaro. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; sold out. (Anthony Tommasini) * 'GIULIO CESARE' (Tonight) The Metropolitan Opera's successful run of John Copley's production of Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' closes tonight. The countertenor Lawrence Zazzo, who was a fine Tolomeo in previous performances this season, his debut season at the Met, takes over from David Daniels in the difficult title role. The Australian soprano Danielle de Niese takes over from Ruth Ann Swenson as Cleopatra. The rest of the cast is unchanged: the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote is excellent as Sesto, and so is Patricia Bardon in her role as Cornelia. Harry Bicket, a Handel specialist, conducts an elegant performance. At 7:30, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $320. (Vivien Schweitzer) * 'ORFEO ED EURIDICE' (Wednesday) The Met is wrapping up an innovative, colorful season with what may be an innovative, colorful production: Mark Morris, the choreographer, is making his company debut, along with Isaac Mizrahi as costume designer. Gluck's so-called ''reform'' opera, calm and tuneful and slightly static, is something of a departure for James Levine, who conducts, but not at all for the countertenor David Daniels, who is having a great year at the Met and will sing Orpheus. The four performances of this piece are dedicated to the memory of the singer Lorraine Hunt Lieberson. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; sold out. (Anne Midgette) * 'IL TRITTICO' (Tomorrow and Tuesday) The Met's new ''Trittico,'' Puccini's triptych of one-act operas, is now the most elaborate production in the company's repertory. The director Jack O'Brien has created grandly old-fashioned yet insightful and effective stagings of these three very different operas: ''Il Tabarro,'' a grim love triangle aboard a barge in Paris; ''Suor Angelica,'' a tender, mystical and ultimately devastating story of a young nun's yearning to be with her dead child; and ''Gianni Schicchi,'' an irreverent comedy about the avaricious relatives of a miserly old man. Maria Guleghina as the beleaguered barge-owner's wife, Barbara Frittoli as Sister Angelica, and Alessandro Corbelli as Schicchi are stand-outs, though the powerhouse mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe almost steals each show playing three supporting roles. James Levine conducts vibrant and beautifully refined performances. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; sold out. (Tommasini) 'TURANDOT' (Tomorrow and Thursday) Puccini's extravagant image of a mythical East, made more extravagant in Franco Zeffirelli's grandiose production, offers another look at the soprano Erika Sunnegardh, who stepped in for Andrea Gruber in the title role a few weeks ago, just as she stepped in for Karita Mattila in ''Fidelio'' a year ago. Tomorrow at 8:30 p.m., Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; sold out. (Bernard Holland) Classical Music * AMERICAN COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA (Tonight) The composer John Adams leads this specialist orchestra in a program of his own works, including ''My Father Knew Charles Ives,'' ''The Wound-Dresser'' and ''The Violin Concerto.'' The violinist Leila Josefowicz and the bass-baritone Eric Owens are the soloists. At 8, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $16 to $43. (Allan Kozinn) AMERICAN FESTIVAL OF MICROTONAL MUSIC (Sunday and Wednesday) For fans of microtonal music -- music in non-standard tunings -- this annual festival opens on Sunday with a performance by MicroJam, an ensemble from Boston, and Dave Taylor, the trombonist, who will perform Johnny Reinhard's ''Zelig Mood Ring'' and stay on for a jam with Mr. Reinhard and MicroJam. The second installment, on Wednesday, includes more music by Mr. Reinhard and works by Elodie Lauten, Kyle Gann and Joseph Pehrson. At 10 p.m., Bowery Poetry Club, 308 Bowery, at Bleecker Street, East Village, (212) 517-3550, afmm.org; $10. (Kozinn) * AUSTRALIAN CHAMBER ORCHESTRA (Sunday) This excellent orchestra and its artistic leader, the violinist Richard Tognetti, play concertos by Vivaldi and Corelli in their program at Zankel Hall, an acoustically lively space for chamber ensembles. The arresting and intelligent Dutch cellist Pieter Wispelwey is the soloist in Haydn's Concerto in C. The program ends with Tchaikovsky's beguiling ''Souvenir de Florence.'' At 7:30 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $32 and $44. (Tommasini) * CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER (Tonight and Sunday) The British composer Nicholas Maw, born in 1935, is associated with the Neo-Romantic movement in contemporary music. But it is hard to categorize his elegantly written and strikingly personal music, which is multilayered, complex and spiked with modernistic elements. The Chamber Music Society presents the premiere of Mr. Maw's Sextet for Strings on a smartly conceived program that offers works by composers who have inspired him: Haydn, Schumann, Bruckner, Strauss and Britten. Tonight at 8 and Sunday at 5 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org; $28 to $50. (Tommasini) CURTIS ORCHESTRA (Wednesday) If the standards of other training orchestras that have passed through Carnegie Hall recently are any measure, the Curtis Orchestra surely won't disappoint. The orchestra, conducted by Christoph Eschenbach, the Philadelphia Orchestra's music director, will be joined by Roberto Díaz, a violist and the new president of the Curtis Institute, in Penderecki's Viola Concerto. The program also includes Bernstein's ''Symphonic Dances'' from ''West Side Story'' and Stravinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps.'' At 8 p.m., (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $15 to $100. (Schweitzer) 'GOOD NIGHT ALICE' (Monday) Alice Tully was so identified with her most visible act of patronage that a possibly apocryphal story has a partygoer addressing her as ''Miss Hall.'' It's that hall that's now being sent off musically to slumber in a cocoon of reconstruction: it will be closed for a season, reopening in late 2008. Its lullaby is a benefit concert for Lincoln Center's redevelopment project featuring the Juilliard Orchestra, led by David Robertson, in a program that arcs from Bernstein to Bernstein, with other works by Messiaen, Wynton Marsalis and Mozart. Tom Brokaw will serve as host of the event, which PBS will broadcast nationwide on Thursday. At 7 p.m, Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $1,500 and up for gala tickets, which include cocktails and a post-concert dinner. (Midgette) SERGEI KHACHATRYAN (Monday) This talented Armenian violinist, winner of both the Sibelius competition in Helsinki and the Queen Elizabeth Competition in Brussels, makes his New York recital debut with Lusine Khachatryan, his sister, as his accompanist. The program includes Bach's Chaconne in D minor from the Violin Partita No. 2; Franck's Sonata in A; and Shostakovich's Sonata. At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; sold out. (Schweitzer) EVGENY KISSIN (Thursday) In sheer talent, Mr. Kissin may be the most gifted pianist of his generation. Here he brings his big, Romantic, if somewhat inflexible approach to music by Beethoven, Brahms, Schubert and Chopin. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $44 to $140. (Holland) KRONOS YOUNG ARTISTS CONCERT (Tomorrow) Four emerging quartets will perform repertory they have studied in workshops this past week with the innovative Kronos Quartet, which champions contemporary music and frequently commissions new works. The lineup features pieces either written for or arranged for Kronos, including Steve Reich's ''Triple Quartet,'' John Zorn's ''Cat o' Nine Tails'' and Alexandra du Bois's String Quartet, as well as arrangements by Osvaldo Golijov and others. At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $15. (Schweitzer) * LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC (Tomorrow, Sunday, Wednesday and Thursday) Esa-Pekka Salonen recently announced that he would turn over the podium of the orchestra he has rejuvenated over the last several years, so it will be good to see him lead it in a week of concerts in (and near) New York. The visit begins tomorrow at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, when Mr. Salonen leads a suite from Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet''; a work of his own, ''Helix''; and Ravel's Concerto for the Left Hand, with Jean-Yves Thibaudet. That program is repeated at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday. On Wednesday Mr. Salonen leads one of his most successful recent endeavors, ''The Tristan Project,'' a semistaged version of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' with video by Bill Viola and a cast that includes Christian Franz and Christine Brewer in the title roles. And on Thursday the soprano Renée Fleming sings music of Strauss and Korngold with the orchestra, and Mr. Salonen leads Sibelius's ''Lemminkainen'' Suite. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722, njpac.org; $24 to $88. Sunday at 3 p.m., Wednesday at 6 p.m. and Thursday at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $35 to $69 (Sunday and Thursday), $175 to $275 (Wednesday). (Kozinn) MANNES CONTEMPORARY MUSIC FESTIVAL (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday) Works by the Pulitzer Prize-winner Paul Moravec; an evening of percussion that includes Steve Reich's ''Drumming''; world premieres by Davide Zannoni and others; and pieces by leading figures, like Iannis Xenakis, are all part of this festival, which takes on various aspects of the contemporary. Performers include chamber and percussion ensembles and, of course, the Mannes School Orchestra. At 8 p.m., Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85th Street, Manhattan, (212) 496-8524, mannes.newschool.edu; free. (Midgette) MAURIZIO POLLINI (Sunday) A musician of high accomplishment and uncompromising dignity, Mr. Pollini makes one of his regular stops at Carnegie Hall in a recital including Chopin pieces, Book II of the Debussy Études and the Boulez Second Sonata. At 3 p.m., (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $34 to $108. (Holland) GIL SHAHAM AND FRIENDS (Wednesday) The talented Mr. Shaham seems to be onstage playing his violin every time we look up. Here he is again with six colleagues in an all-Brahms program that includes the String Sextet. At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; sold out. (Holland) * DAWN UPSHAW (Sunday) This radiant soprano, who has recently begun performing again after being treated for breast cancer, opens the fifth season of Free for All at Town Hall concerts with a typically versatile program. She will sing works by American composers like Ruth Crawford Seeger and Ives, as well as pieces by Ravel, Fauré, Debussy, Schumann and Wolf. She finishes with three of William Bolcom's ''Cabaret Songs.'' Her accompanist, Gilbert Kalish, will also play a Brahms intermezzo. At 5 p.m., 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 707-8787, freeforallattownhall.org; free, but tickets are required. (Schweitzer) VERTAVO STRING QUARTET (Tonight) This dynamic Norwegian all-female quartet has been playing to acclaim for over 20 years. Founded in Oslo, it is known for its vibrant performances and special affinity for contemporary music. On this New York stop, though, the newest work the Vertavo will play is Bartok's Third Quartet, from 1927. Still, it should be invigorating to hear Bartok's path-breaking piece along with Haydn's inventive Quartet in D (Op. 20, No. 4) and Grieg's moody Quartet in G minor, a signature work in this ensemble's repertory. At 7:30, Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $44. (Tommasini) VOX VOCAL ENSEMBLE (Tomorrow) George Steel's superb chamber choir, supported by the Manhattan Choral Ensemble, the Graham Ashton Brass Ensemble and the organist Robert McCormick, sings a program divided between early music (works by Allegri, Palestrina, Eccard and Isaac) and music of the 19th century (including works by Brahms, Mendelssohn, Wolf and Bruckner). At 8 p.m., Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46th Street, Manhattan, (212) 854-7799, millertheater.com; $35. (Kozinn) Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. * ABT STUDIO COMPANY (Tonight and tomorrow) In addition to spotting the dance stars of the future while they are still hungry for stage space and choreography, these programs offer new and innovative dances as well as classics. The company will perform Antony Tudor's ''Jardin aux Lilas''; the pas de deux from August Bournonville's ''Flower Festival in Genzano''; and Brian Reeder's new ''Ghost Light,'' a collaboration with the filmmaker Elliot Caplan. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, New York University, 566 La Guardia Place, at Washington Square South, Greenwich Village, (212) 279-4200, skirballcenter.nyu.edu; $28. (Jennifer Dunning) CHAMECKILERNER (Tuesday through Thursday) Rosane Chamecki and Andrea Lerner, both originally from Brazil, are known for their dark, exaggerated and often raw depictions of human behavior. In their new multimedia ''EXIT,'' they create a funeral rite for themselves in which colleagues offer eulogies and flashbacks as they watch from the afterlife. (Through May 5.) At 8 p.m., the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793, Ext. 11, thekitchen.org; $10. (Dunning) CHEZ BUSHWICK PRESENTS: AMBUSH (Tomorrow) This project devoted to new works by the mostly young will present ''Notes on a Van Guard,'' which includes work by Eija-Liisa Ahtila, Nathan Davis, Light in August, Joe Levasseur, Moving Theater and Matthew Rogers and Jack Ferver, with a talk on French dance tucked in for good measure. At 8 p.m., Bushwick Starr, 207 Starr Street, between Irving and Wyckoff Streets, Bushwick, Brooklyn, info@thebushwickstarr.org; $5. (Dunning) EL COLEGIO DEL CUERPO -- LA COMPANIA (Sunday) This company of young dancers from Cartagena, Colombia, will perform ''Fragments,'' a piece drawn from 10 years of repertory created by the company directors Álvaro Restrepo and Marie France Delieuvin. At 3 p.m., Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 760-0064, queenstheatre.org; $28; $20 for students. (Dunning) CONNECTICUT BALLET (Tomorrow) The company celebrates its 25th anniversary with the appropriately titled ''Razzle Dazzle!,'' a gala program featuring ballet and modern, African, flamenco and tap dance by guest artists from the United States, Brazil, Europe and West Africa. At 7:30 p.m., Rich Forum, 307 Atlantic Street, Stamford, Conn., (203) 325-4466, stamfordcenterforthearts.org; $25 to $50. (Dunning) EIFMAN BALLET (Tonight through Sunday) Boris Eifman's ''Anna Karenina'' will be performed this weekend, the close of its season at City Center. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 2 and 7 p.m., City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212, nycitycenter.org; $35 to $100. (Dunning) 'FROM TAP TO TOE!' (Tomorrow) Fifteen dance troupes will perform in this four-hour marathon, among them Hilary Easton & Company, RumbaTap and Troika Ranch. At 7 p.m., Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org; $15. (Dunning) ANDRÉ GINGRAS/KORZO PRODUCTIES (Thursday) From the Netherlands, Mr. Gingras and his company will present ''CYP17,'' a mixed-media piece that aims to present ''the 'freak show' that is our future,'' as its publicity puts it. Rock on. (Through May 5.) At 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194, danspaceproject.org; $15. (Dunning) KENNEDY DANCERS (Tonight and tomorrow night) Based in Jersey City, this modern-dance troupe will mark its 30th anniversary with a program of dances by the company director, Diane Dragone, with one work by a different guest group each night. Tonight, Nimbus Dance Works and Synthesis Dance Project; tomorrow, Arch Dance Company. At 7:30, Baryshnikov Arts Center, 450 West 37th Street, Manhattan, (201) 659-2190; $20; $18 for students and 65+. (Dunning) ALONZO KING'S LINES BALLET (Tuesday through Thursday) This San Francisco company dances ballet with an unusual streamlined and extra-active body line and attack. Mr. King's new ''Moroccan Project'' is set to African drumming and oud and violin music. His ''Migration,'' also new, will be danced to music by Pharoah Sanders, Miguel Frasconi and Leslie Stuck. (Through May 6.) Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $40. (Dunning) 'LA MAMA MOVES!' (Tonight through Thursday) This modern-dance version of a three-ring circus spills out into three theater spaces at La MaMa, with nine programs featuring more than 50 companies and soloists. (Through May 13.) La MaMa E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 475-7710, lamama.org; $15. (Dunning) LAVA (Thursday) Sarah East Johnson and her all-female company, which specializes in acrobatic modern dance spiced with double-trapeze work, will present ''Tides,'' a new piece that incorporates time-capture video of the Rockaway shoreline and ocean-wave patterns. (Through May 27.) At 7 p.m., Flea Theater, 41 White Street, between Broadway and Church Street, TriBeCa, (212) 352-3101, theatermania.com; $10 to $30. (Dunning) 'LET'S SPEAK TANGO!' (Tonight through Sunday, and Thursday) Well, why not? For the record, this latest celebration of that sultry dance form was choreographed by Valeria Solomonoff, one of the show's eight performers, and directed by Carlo Magaletti. (Through May 6.) Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Sunday at 3 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., American Theater of Actors, 314 West 54th Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com; $40. (Dunning) AMY MARSHALL DANCE (Tonight and tomorrow night) Ms. Marshall's dances will address the beauty of the human body, the last days of Joan of Arc and, to music by Mike Seeger and the New Lost City Ramblers, the textile industry in Spartanburg, S.C. Clearly this is a choreographer with eclectic interests. At 8, Ailey Citigroup Theater, 405 West 55th Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com; $30; $20 for students and 65+. (Dunning) * MIRO DANCE THEATER (Wednesday) The company directors, Amanda Miller, who danced with the Pennsylvania Ballet and studied choreography with Siobhan Davies, and Tobin Rothlein, a video artist and designer, do better than most at combining visuals and movement to make a third, poetically expressive form. Their new dance, ''Pitch Black,'' addresses human connections and disconnections in urban life. It is set to music for sax and boombox by JacobTV, to be performed live. At 8 p.m., Whitney Museum of Art at Altria, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (800) 944-8639; free. (Dunning) THE MOVEMENT MOVEMENT & FRIENDS MOVE IN (Tomorrow and Sunday) Advance information on this event is about as unclear as its title, but it all has something to do with changing rooms, streaming video and an empty 7,000-square-foot retail space. Reassuringly, the performers include Scotty the Blue Bunny. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Sunday at 7 p.m., Front and Beekman Streets, next to 207 Fulton Street, South Street Seaport, (917) 531-1171, info@themovementmovement.org; $15; $10 ''for those that are starving.'' (Dunning) * NEW YORK CITY BALLET (Tonight, tomorrow and Tuesday through Thursday) Lincoln Kirstein, who founded the company with George Balanchine, will be celebrated in three different all-Balanchine repertory programs (tonight and tomorrow afternoon and evening). Then comes Peter Martins's eagerly awaited new production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' (Tuesday through May 13), with lead roles performed by some of City Ballet's youngest up-and-comers. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. (no Sunday performance), Thursday at 8 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycballet.com; $30 to $86; $15 student rush tickets available day of performance. (Dunning) NEW YORK THEATER BALLET (Tonight and tomorrow night) The program includes William Dollar's rarely performed piece ''Le Combat,'' Agnes de Mille's ''Carousel'' ballet and dances by Donald Mahler and Sallie Wilson. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan (212) 355-6160, nytb.org; $30; $15 for students and 65+. (Dunning) 'THE NOTHING FESTIVAL' (Tonight and tomorrow night) The choreographer Tere O'Connor asked eight other choreographers to each contribute a new piece made from scratch, with no story, music or nondance source to guide them. The festival closes this week with works by Luciana Achugar, Walter Dundervill, Jon Kinzel and Susan Rethorst. At 7:30, Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org; $20. (Dunning) STREB SLAM 9 (Tonight through Sunday) Elizabeth Streb and her high-flying, death-defying performers will perform repertory favorites featuring a swivel harness, two huge plywood panels and, for the audience, popcorn and cotton candy. (Through June 17.) Tonight at 7, tomorrow at 3 and 7 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., S.L.A.M., 51 North First Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (212) 352-3101, strebusa.org; $20; $10 for children. (Dunning) VANGELINE DANCE THEATER (Tonight and tomorrow night) The program includes new Butoh dance by the company director, Vangeline, and Nicole LeGette. It also features modern dance by Eva Perotta in a program called ''La Porte Étroite: (Apothéose Mystique),'' a title drawn from a novel by André Gide. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Puffin Room, 435 Broome Street, between Broadway and Crosby Street, SoHo, (212) 343-2881; $15. (Dunning) * YOUTH AMERICA GRAND PRIX 2007 GALA (Monday) This international competition, which awards scholarships for ballet study, is usually a big, joyous mess of dancing by talented young finalists and professionals. This time the companies include the Paris Opera Ballet, the Stuttgart and the Royal Ballet, as well as several leading American dance troupes. At 7 p.m., City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212, nycitycenter.org; $45 to $150. (Dunning) Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. Museums BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'KINDRED SPIRITS: ASHER B. DURAND AND THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE,' through July 29. This show of about 60 works by one of the greats of 19th-century American landscape painting has as its centerpiece ''Kindred Spirits'' (1849), a tribute to the landscapist Thomas Cole and his friend the poet-journalist William Cullen Bryant. A founder of the Hudson River School, Durand (1796-1886) favored the realistic approach to landscape advocated by the English critic John Ruskin. Durand explored forest interiors with close attention to the ways of trees, foliage and rocks and ground cover in smaller works, while his larger and more elaborate exhibition pictures, influenced by European masters, are Arcadian visions suffused with light, color and atmospheric perspective. If the show reveals some of Durand's weaknesses -- repetitive themes and borrowings from other artists -- it also reveals his strong sense of artistic mission and his potent role in shaping the aesthetic of 19th-century America. 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org. (Grace Glueck) * JAPAN SOCIETY: 'Awakenings: Zen Figure Painting in Medieval Japan,' through June 17. Japan Society has a history of producing exquisite shows of Buddhist art. And this one, with four dozen paintings of Buddhists gods and saints hung in shrinelike alcoves, is transporting. It covers a broad swath of geography, bringing together 13th- to 16th-century hanging scrolls, not only from Japan but also from China, where Zen Buddhism, called Chan in Chinese, originated. 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155, japansociety.org. (Holland Cotter) The Jewish Museum: Dateline: Israel: 'New Photography and Video Art,' through Aug. 5. Roughly every decade, the Jewish Museum offers a survey of contemporary art from and about Israel. This year non-Israeli artists from Europe and the United States -- and a single artist from Palestine -- have been added to the mix. There's some very good work here, though, on the whole, the show grapples with crucial political issues in an indirect way. 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200, jewishmuseum.org. (Cotter) * the Metropolitan Museum of Art: 'Journeys: Mapping the Earth and Mind in Chinese Art,' through Aug. 26. Every six months or so, the Met rotates all the work in its Chinese painting galleries to preserve the delicate silks and papers, and each time, the curator in charge, Maxwell K. Hearn, produces a new and illuminating thematic exhibition, as is the case with ''Journeys.'' Outward-bound and inward-bound are the directions taken by Chinese landscape painting, and it carries us on some fascinating voyages in a show that mixes classical and contemporary art. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Cotter) * the met: 'Venice and the Islamic World, 828-1797,' through July 8. At its peak in the Renaissance, Venice, the Most Serene, was a giant, clamorous Costco-on-the-Rialto. All the necessities, and most of the luxuries, of life flowed into and through it, with many items arriving from Islamic Africa and the Near East. With classic Met largesse, this exhibition suggests the spectacle of two different cultures meeting in one fantastic city, in which commerce and love of beauty, those great levelers, unite them in a fruitful bond. (See above.) (Cotter) * the Museum of Modern Art: JEFF WALL, through May 14. This majestic show makes a great case for Mr. Wall as the most complete, if traditional, of the untraditional artists who emerged from the turmoil of Conceptual Art. His often immense color transparencies mounted on light boxes are enthralling visual vehicles, intent on giving pleasure while making a point or two about society, art, history, visual perception, the human animal or all of the above. An imposing blend of painting, street photography and movies, they blur reality and artifice, narrative and form, detail and the big statement. You can't stop looking at them. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (Roberta Smith) Studio Museum in Harlem: 'Philosophy of Time Travel,' through July 1. Many art historians consider Constantin Brancusi's ''Endless Column'' (1938), a 96-foot-tall cast-iron work designed to memorialize Romanian soldiers killed in World War I, the quintessential example of Modernist sculpture. It still stands in Tirgu Jiu, Romania. But a rendition of it is also part of this installation. The work of five artists -- Edgar Arceneaux, Vincent Galen Johnson, Olga Koumoundouros, Rodney McMillian and Matthew Sloly -- it reimagines Brancusi's sculpture. The concept began with a wish to create an installation that would symbolize the clash of African and Western cultures. The result is seven rhomboids, about the same size as the original, which appear to have torn through the gallery's ceiling, splintering the surrounding drywall and smashing into the floor. The collective succeeds in ridding ''Endless Column'' of its Modernist sanctity by turning it into something more akin to a Hollywood blockbuster than a memorial sculpture. 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500. (Bridget L. Goodbody) Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Taryn Simon,' through June 24. Ms. Simon couches the show in the intellectual, power-to-the-people oratory of leftist politics, yet she clearly delights in exposing, in a quasi-tabloid fashion, America's underbelly. Though she has also worked in war-torn areas, Ms. Simon is best known for ''The Innocents,'' a series of portraits of men and women who were wrongly convicted but later cleared by DNA test results. Ms. Simon can work as long as a year to gain permission to photograph high-security zones like the government-regulated quarantine sites, nuclear waste storage facilities, prison death rows and C.I.A. offices on view in the show. There are also pictures with lighter themes: the sandpit where the Grucci family tests fireworks, ski slopes being dynamited for avalanche control and the second Death Star, from ''Return of the Jedi,'' at George Lucas's Skywalker Ranch. Ms. Simon is at her artistic best when her delight in the strangeness of American culture shines. (212) 570-3676, whitney.org. (Goodbody) * Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Lorna Simpson,' through May 6. This tight, refined and impassioned survey covers more than 20 years of Lorna Simpson's career, from her photo-and-text meditations on race and sexism in the 1980s, to her more recent short films, which unite American history and personal history in forceful and lyrical ways. It would be easy to put some of this work on a shelf as ''identity art,'' but with an African-American woman holding one of the highest offices in the United States government, an African-American man running for president, and the nation embroiled in what some people view as an ethnic war, this art is entirely of the moment. (See above.) (Cotter) Galleries: Uptown DELPHINE COURTILLOT From O. Winston Link to Anna Gaskell and ''The Blair Witch Project,'' there are far too many borrowed bits in these large watercolors based on staged photographs of people in dark, desolate landscapes. But the larger question is why the images wouldn't do just as well in their original photographic form. Tilton Gallery, 8 East 76th Street, (212) 731-2221, through May 5. (Smith) Galleries: Chelsea * WALTER DE MARIA Counting and space -- important to both Minimal and Conceptual Art -- come together with unusual clarity, if a bit too much in the way of gleaming metal, in two large installations by the creator of ''The Lightning Field'' earthwork. Both pieces consist of several dozen shiny, meter-long stainless-steel rods presented in spaces that couldn't be much more pristine. Experience the spatial levitation and note the number of sides on the rods; in both cases, they increase row by row. Gagosian Gallery, 522 West 21st Street, (212) 741-1717, and 555 West 24th Street, (212) 741-1111, gagosian.com, through May 5. (Smith) Galleries: Other * SOL LEWITT: DRAWING SERIES If the greatness of Sol LeWitt, the Minimal-Conceptual artist who died this month (April 7) at 78, has so far escaped you, this exhilarating show of 14 of his mind-teasing, eye-filling wall drawings from the late 1960s and early '70s may do the trick. Selected and arranged by the artist, they proceed in carefully sequenced contrasts and echoes that are both insightful and idiosyncratic. Since their generating instructions are part of their titles, they reduce the creative process to a short, highly visible straight line. But their crisp geometries, accumulating marks and radiating patterns force us to mind the gap between artistic thought and artistic action, to experience the inability of language to account fully for visual outcome. Dia:Beacon, 3 Beekman Street, Beacon, N.Y., (845) 440-0100, through Sept. 10. (Smith) Last Chance LEE BONTECOU: VACUUM-FORMED SCULPTURES AND RELATED DRAWINGS This artist has never topped her glowering black-and-white canvas reliefs of the 1960s, but these menacing fish and vigilant, thick-stalked flowers from the 1970s are second-best. The flowers, especially, amass some of the armed-and-dangerous sinisterness of the canvas reliefs behind their seemingly beatific auras. Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550; closes tomorrow. (Smith) * 'C.R.E.E.P.' For its second show, this small, new bare-bones Lower East Side storefront gallery is showing work by two collaborative artists called C.R.E.E.P., who multitask as performance artists, magazine publishers, performing artists and clothing designers. One of their two pieces is big, polished and brashly self-announcing. The other is minute, hard to find and terrific. As to 127 itself, all I can say is: watch that space. 127, 127 Henry Street, near Allen Street, (646) 416-1517; closes on Sunday. (Cotter) 'Gifts of the Forest: Native Traditions in Wood and Bark' Drawn from the collections of the Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center in southeastern Connecticut, this show celebrates the trees of the rich forests that once covered the Northeast, yielding essential materials to the Pequot and other Eastern Woodland cultures. The objects run from ancient woodworking tools to contemporary objects that carry on tribal traditions. Many things here were made in the 19th and 20th centuries: handsome woven baskets, decorated cradle boards for carrying babies, and an elegant birch-bark hamper whose sides bear a stylized tree motif. UBS Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, between 51st and 52nd Streets, (212) 713-2885, ubs.com; closes today. (Glueck) * Kim Gordon and Jutta Koether: 'Dead already' Two artist-musicians collaborate on a show that's partly objects, partly performance and partly in the air. The objects are paintings displayed in flip-through racks. (The ones with glitter are Ms. Gordon's; the ones done in black liquid glass, Ms. Koether's). The center of the gallery is fenced off for action: Ei Arakawa and Eleanor Erdman will do a Martha Graham piece this Sunday, bound to be memorable. Reena Spaulings Fine Art, 165 East Broadway, at Rutgers Street, Lower East Side, (212) 477-5006; closes on Sunday. (Cotter) INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: 'HENRI CARTIER-BRESSON'S SCRAPBOOK: PHOTOGRAPHS, 1932-46,' This show has more than 300 of the prints the photographer glued into an album and toted to New York for curators at the Museum of Modern Art to cull. Captured by the Nazis, he had been presumed dead when the Modern planned his retrospective. Then he turned up alive -- the ''posthumous'' exhibition opened, with him in attendance, in 1947. The current exhibition surveys the revolutionary work Carier-Bresson shot in Spain, Italy, Mexico, Britain and France. Here are the familiar and, more interestingly, some less familiar, shots of crowds in Hyde Park in London at George VI's coronation, of picnickers on the banks of the Marne in France and whores in Valencia, Spain. His taste for uncanny detail linked him to Surrealism and Surrealist wit, but unlike many Surrealists, he remained committed to human values. Boys mug at his camera. Prostitutes swan. Their gazes equalize them with us. 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000, icp.org; closes on Sunday. (Michael Kimmelman) INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: 'MARTIN MUNKACSI: THINK WHILE YOU SHOOT!' Munkacsi, who inspired Cartier-Bresson, was, by contrast, self-taught, a creature of his own devising. This is the most complete retrospective, with a thick catalog (not too well researched) and dozens of vintage prints from the 1920s through the early '60s. He favored scenes of daily life, absorbing avant-garde ideas about odd angles and abstract compositions. In 1928 he moved to Berlin, where the opportunities were better, and traveled the world on assignment to Brazil, Algeria and Egypt. Munkacsi was a stylist, and he made catchy images the only way he knew how, in a modernist mode, which, being an opportunistic form, could serve any master. He became a celebrity in America. He photographed Fred Astaire dancing and Joan Crawford poolside. In the breezy layouts of Harper's Bazaar, the work looked brilliant. (See above.) Closes on Sunday. (Kimmelman) * 'THOMAS STRUTH: Making Time' Through the 1990s, the German photographer Thomas Struth became an art-world celebrity for his outsize, absorbing portraits of crowds interacting with artwork in the world's great museums. As a follow-up, he is presenting the American premiere of two new series of pictures of audiences beholding single masterpieces in the Museo Nacional del Prado in Madrid, and the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia. The show, which cannily allows us to look safely at others looking at art, is one of the most visually sumptuous and thought-probing in the city. Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 977-7160, mariangoodman.com; closes tomorrow. (Benjamin Genocchio) JAMES TURRELL: 'LIGHT LEADINGS' From an artist known for meditative light installations, a show of sped-up versions made with computerized neon and holographic works reminiscent of Malevich abstractions. They amount to gorgeous, high-priced, high-tech equivalents of lava lamps, in which color comes either in diaphanous clouds or with hard edges. PaceWildenstein Gallery, 534 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-7000, pacewildenstein.com; closes tomorrow. (Smith)
A picture caption last Friday about the celebration of the Day of the Indian throughout the Amazonian basin misspelled the name of the country of the children shown. It is Suriname, not Surinam.

A blackout hit much of Colombia, trapping commuters in subways and traffic jams and temporarily halting commerce in some of the largest cities. Internet and cellphone services were also interrupted before electricity was partly restored in some regions by late afternoon. Senior government officials quickly ruled out the possibility of an attack on the electrical grid by guerrilla groups, contending that the power collapse was caused by a glitch at a substation in Bogotá. SIMON ROMERO

The Fox Broadcasting Company is seeking to patent a way to replace ''old'' commercials with ''new'' ones when viewers replay Fox shows they have taped on digital video recorders. Jon Nesvig, president for sales at Fox, part of the News Corporation, described the technology yesterday at a conference sponsored by the trade publication MediaPost. Fox hopes to test the process, developed by Andrew G. Setos, president for engineering at the Fox Group, with TiVo, Mr. Nesvig said.

PROTERO--Dodi. The Juilliard community mourns the passing of Dodi Protero, a member of the Juilliard Evening Division faculty since 1991. She will be fondly remembered by her colleagues and students at Juilliard as a gifted, dedicated, and exuberant educator. We send our deep condolences to all her students and family. Joseph W. Polisi, President Katherine Gertson, Evening Division Director
HAZAN--Leslie Beth. To my daughter on her 44th birthday. You are in my heart now and always.

An article on Oct. 19 about the collapse of the actor Richard Easton during a performance of ''The Coast of Utopia'' at Lincoln Center misidentified his final line before he collapsed, and also misidentified an actor onstage at the time. The line was ''That is my last word,'' not ''You can't go to Berlin!'' One of the actors onstage was Martha Plimpton, not Amy Irving. The errors were discovered last week during the editing of an article about distractions actors encounter during performances.

Estonia began excavating the earth surrounding a Soviet-era war memorial in the capital, Tallinn, a step toward relocating it to a military cemetery. The monument, the Bronze Soldier, commemorates the victory over Nazi Germany but is viewed by many Estonians as a symbol of the Soviet occupation that followed. Proposals to remove the monument have brought strong reactions from ethnic Russians in Estonia and from the Russian government. STEVEN LEE MYERS

The police found the bodies of a 25-year-old Sunni man and a 12-year-old Sunni boy whose abduction on Monday had already prompted concerns of rising sectarian tensions. The bodies were found in a field southeast of Beirut after an anonymous call to a television station. Their families are members of the pro-government party of the Druse leader Walid Jumblatt, an opponent of Hezbollah, the militant Shiite organization. Local reports said the two were kidnapped by members of a Shiite clan to avenge the killing of a relative in January. Mr. Jumblatt appealed for calm. NADA BAKRI

FORD SEES A FUTURE -- Ford Motor Company executives said that a smaller loss in the first quarter was proof that their corporate overhaul was working. [Page C1.] LOOKING FOR A BIG HIT -- Perella Weinberg Partners may be just a year and a half old as an investment bank, but can it deliver the headline-grabbing, blockbuster mergers that made a name for its founder, Joseph R. Perella? [C1.] SOLD ON EBAY, SHIPPED VIA AMAZON -- Amazon.com is expanding a program that allows independent sellers -- even vendors who sell through Amazon's e-commerce rival, eBay -- to use its network of distribution centers to store and ship their products. [C1.] A NEW KIND OF BUYOUT -- An $8 billion bid by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Goldman Sachs for Harman International Industries, the maker of JBL speakers, has a potentially groundbreaking twist: The buyers have offered Harman shareholders a chance to retain a stake in the company, and share in any profit made if the company is later sold or taken public again. [C1.] STRONG QUARTER FOR MICROSOFT -- Microsoft reported quarterly sales and profits that surpassed Wall Street's expectations, suggesting that early sales of its new Windows Vista operating system were off to a solid start. [C3.] RISING PROFIT AT EXXON MOBIL -- Exxon Mobil reported another surge in profits for the first quarter of the year because of stronger earnings from its refining, marketing and chemicals businesses. The results -- Exxon said they were its best ever for any first quarter -- were particularly noteworthy given the mixed earnings picture reported in recent days by other large oil companies. [C4.] BETTER CHANCES FOR TRADE BILL -- Prospects have suddenly improved for bipartisan agreement on trade legislation in Congress, thanks in part to a talk between President Bush and Representative Charles B. Rangel, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. [C3.] BRISTOL CHOOSES INTERIM CHIEF -- After an eight-month search for a new chief executive, the drug maker Bristol-Myers said it would go with the interim chief, James M. Cornelius. [C2.] PUBLIC CONCERNED OVER WARMING -- Americans in large bipartisan numbers say the heating of the earth's atmosphere is having serious effects on the environment now or will soon and think that it is necessary to take immediate steps to reduce its effects, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. [A20.] EMI'S NORTH AMERICAN UNIT -- EMI Group, the struggling British music giant, has hired the longtime industry executive Roger Ames, a former chairman of Warner Music Group, to revive its North American operation. The appointment of Mr. Ames, left, comes more than three months after a management shake-up in which EMI ousted the two senior executives overseeing its recorded music operation. [C7.] A MODEL OF CONSISTENCY, ONCE -- For 25 years, Absolut vodka ran a humorous campaign celebrating its distinctive bottle, and became renowned for the consistency of its pitches to consumers. Now the brand is changing advertising approaches for the second time in 15 months. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C3.] MORE SUSPECTED BRIBES AT SIEMENS -- A day after the chief executive of Siemens announced he would step down, the company warned that it expected to report a ''significant increase'' in the number of possible bribes identified in an internal investigation. [C7.] MYSPACE.COM HEADING TO CHINA -- Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is taking MySpace.com to China, a latecomer to China's crowded field of online social networking sites that is betting it can overcome that handicap by competing unconventionally as a start-up. [C7.] CANADIAN RULES ON EMISSIONS -- Canadian industries must cut the rate at which they produce gases linked to global warming by 18 percent over the next three years, the federal government said. [C7.] PROFIT NEWS HAS LITTLE IMPACT -- Stocks ended mixed as strong profit reports from companies like Apple Inc. and 3M failed to galvanize Wall Street. Still, a modest advance gave the Dow Jones industrial average another record close. [C9.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The US Airways Group reported that profit edged up 2 percent in the first quarter on modest revenue growth, and repeated its forecast for a profitable year. (AP) The health insurer Aetna reported an 8 percent increase in first-quarter profits, pointing to membership growth as proof that consumer marketing applied to health insurance is working. (AP) The 3M Company, considered a bellwether for the economy, posted a far better-than-expected quarterly profit, sending its shares up. (REUTERS) Coca-Cola Enterprises reported a 6 percent decline in earnings but beat Wall Street estimates, helped by the introduction of Coke Zero in Europe and raw material costs that rose less than expected. (REUTERS) The Belo Corporation, publisher of The Dallas Morning News, reported a drop in quarterly profit and revenue because of decreasing sales of classified and other advertising. (REUTERS)

JASANOFF--Edith, of Ft. Lee, NJ, wife of the late Milton, mother of Jay H. Jasanoff and Joan Reyna, grandmother of Alan Jasanoff, Maya Jasanoff, Emily Reyna and Julie Reyna, great-grandmother of Nina Jasanoff. Services Sunday, 11:30am ''Gutterman and Musicant'', 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ.
DEERING--Etheldreda A. June 23 ,1912 -April 27, 2006. We think of you every day and miss you deeply, mother. Your Loving Family

STARR--Adele. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Adele Starr, and extend sincere condolences to her family. Charles J. Block, President

Paintings and Drawings From the 1950s & 1960s Ubu Gallery 416 East 59th Street, Clinton Through May 12 The art of the German Surrealist Richard Oelze may be a taste you never acquire, but his obsessive union of the fleshy, the feathery and the geological into soft, decaying, Piranesi-esque grottos is worth knowing about. It is doubly so if your interests already run to German artists like Hans Bellmer, Wols, Konrad Klapheck or Erwin Pfrang. This exhibition of 22 paintings and 19 drawings from the 1950s and '60s is the first in this country devoted to Oelze (1900-1980).

In the 1960s the town of Jindabyne was intentionally flooded by the damming of a river and left at the bottom of a newly created lake in the middle of the Snowy Mountains in southeastern Australia. Present-day Jindabyne, a skiing and fly-fishing resort, is the setting of Ray Lawrence's somber new film, in which the old settlement, now underwater, is occasionally mentioned. When it is, the implication of submerged life becomes a haunting, obvious metaphor, since ''Jindabyne'' concerns itself with emotions that lie under the surface of daily experience, and with a mysterious past murkily visible through the membrane of the present. Claire (Laura Linney) is a transplanted American who lives in Jindabyne with her husband, Stewart (Gabriel Byrne), a former race car driver, and their young son, Tom. The marriage is shadowed by an earlier episode -- Claire had some kind of breakdown and deserted the household shortly after Tom's birth -- and by the unwelcome presence of Stewart's smiling, meddling mother (Betty Lucas).

The rapper Cam'ron apologized yesterday for saying on ''60 Minutes'' that cooperating with the police would hurt his professional reputation. The comments by Cam'ron, left, whose real name is Cameron Giles, were made in an interview with Anderson Cooper for a segment last Sunday about how hip-hop stars discourage blacks from reporting crimes or helping in criminal investigations. Responding to public outcry, he called his remarks ''an error in judgment'' and said in a statement: ''I can see how those comments could be viewed as offensive, especially to those who have suffered their own personal tragedies or to those who put their lives on the line to protect our citizens from crime.'' But Cam'ron, who is from Harlem and was the victim of a shooting two years ago, added that there is a ''dark reality'' in many American cities: ''Where I come from, once word gets around that you've cooperated with the police, that only makes you a bigger target of criminal violence.'' BEN SISARIO

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was professorial and emphatic as she spoke Thursday night about health care, Iraq and whether Wal-Mart was good for America (a ''mixed blessing,'' she decided) . Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, by reputation a dynamic performer, was reserved and cautious as he talked about a donor with a shady past, how he would respond to a terrorist attack on American shores and his biggest mistake (not doing more to stop Congress from intervening in the Terri Schiavo case, he said).

Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has joined the board of a holding company that owns a troubled commercial college in New York City, and will head a new educational oversight committee, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Kennedy, above, an environmental lawyer, is a director of the EVCI Career Colleges Holding Corporation, which owns Interboro Institute, a two-year business college that has come under scrutiny for improprieties involving student financial aid. In 2005, state education officials directed Interboro to reduce its size so it could better deal with the issue. The company said the problems were isolated, but its stock plummeted and it was sued by investors. Mr. Kennedy said visits to the college convinced him that it was an ''extraordinary'' school that outperformed ''virtually every school in the nation'' in helping disadvantaged minority students. EVCI also announced an agreement for a $17 million financial package with a private equity firm. KAREN W. ARENSON

These married musicians, above, who are opening an extended engagement at the Café Carlyle on Tuesday, have been called the ''Nick and Nora of cabaret,'' a sobriquet that only begins to describe their upbeat sophistication. They fuse two distantly related musical worlds into a larger whole in which Stephen Sondheim; Lambert, Hendricks & Ross; Dave Frishberg; and Paul Simon join hands. Mr. Pizzarelli is a whiz kid on the jazz guitar, an amiable crooner and stand-up clown and mimic whose musical chops are matched by his onstage charm. Though Ms. Molaskey comes out of theater and semiclassical art song, she swings, and her happy-sad voice is an exquisitely expressive instrument. So deep is her psychological insight into lyrics that you might describe her as a pop intellectual, but her interpretations have a lightness and ease that make them almost tossed off. When Mr. Pizzarelli accompanies her on guitar and vocals, supplying witty musical quotations and spontaneous comic shtick, their repartee suggests a dialogue between contemporary Noël Coward characters. Both have new albums. Mr. Pizzarelli's ''Dear Mr. Sinatra'' (Telarc) is a big-band record in which he emphasizes the sunny side of Ol' Blue Eyes. The songs on Ms. Molaskey's ''Sitting in Limbo'' (PS Classics), produced by Mr. Pizzarelli and to be released on May 8, portray relationships and modern American life as a bipolar roller-coaster. It is a profound pop-jazz album that connects traditional American pop with the present in a way that has never been done before. (Tuesdays through Thursdays at 8:45 p.m., Fridays and Saturdays at 8:45 and 10:45 p.m., through May 26, Café Carlyle, at the Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, Manhattan, (212) 744-1600, thecarlyle.com; $75 and $125 Tuesday through Thursday; $85 Friday and Saturday. Mr. Pizzarelli is also performing tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11 at Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, 212-581-3080, birdlandjazz.com; $40 and $50). STEPHEN HOLDEN

With 157 feature films to choose from, moviegoers can be forgiven for opting to take a break from screenings at the Tribeca Film Festival. Fortunately, festival organizers predicted as much: they are offering a panoply of talks and events that take place beyond the cineplex. The Tribeca Talks series, at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, offers 12 panels on a range of topics. On Tuesday Don Cheadle and others will grapple with the question of whether movies like ''Blood Diamond'' can actually effect change; on Sunday Debra Messing and Rachel Dratch discuss whether women are funny; and on Wednesday the rapper and actor Ludacris (Chris Bridges) will talk about broader themes in music and movies. ''We draw from the films at the festival, but the series has a life of its own,'' said Annie Leahy, the Talks director. There are also activities tied to the screenings. In the Tribe ca Drive-In series, a luau precedes the outdoor showing of the film ''Surf's Up'' tonight, and a break-dancing performance takes place before tomorrow's screening of ''Planet B-Boy.'' Next weekend the Tribeca/ESPN Sports film festival will end with Sports Saturday, a free outdoor event with sports-related games and demonstrations. (Tribeca Talks through May 5, TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, 199 Chambers Street; $25. Tribeca Drive-In, tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, World Financial Center Plaza; free. Sports Saturday, May 5, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., at North Moore Street between Greenwich and West Streets. Information: tribecafilmfestival.org.) ROJA HEYDARPOUR

The army said it was reviewing its decision to allow Prince Harry, the younger son of Prince Charles and the third in line for the throne, to serve with his army unit in Iraq. ''Prince Harry's deployment to Iraq is, as we've always said, under constant consideration,'' a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Defense said. But, she added, ''it is still our intent that Harry will deploy as a troop leader.'' British news outlets have reported that the Defense Ministry has grown increasingly nervous about the security implications of such a move. Eleven British soldiers have been killed in Iraq in the past month, including two whose armored reconnaissance vehicle -- the same kind Harry would be using -- was hit by a roadside bomb. SARAH LYALL

The first two rounds took 9 hours and 20 minutes. That's insanely long! I could have watched "Gone With the Wind" three times since the Raiders' first pick in round one. In the third round, each team gets five minutes to make a pick. But the third round this year is longer than you might think. Four teams - San Diego, San Francisco, Indianapolis and Oakland - have compensatory picks at the end of the round. What's a compensatory pick? I had to double-check myself. When a team loses a free agent, the league awards that team a compensatory pick, based on that player's value, as determined by the league. Confused? You're not alone. Let's say the Colts lose Edgerrin James to free agency. The league might award Indianapolis an extra third-round pick. That's exactly what happened this season. If a player has little value, in the league's eyes, a seventh-round pick (or maybe none at all) might be awarded.

I finally nailed a pick (the Bears taking Dan Bazuin from Central Michigan with the 62nd selection)! I would be celebrating if I had Champagne on me. I watched Bazuin train for the N.F.L. Scouting Combine a few months ago, so I had a good feeling he would be picked on the first day. Bazuin told me in February that he thought he could go on the first day. At the time, he was slated as a late fifth- or sixth-round pick. It just goes to show you what a good performance at the N.F.L. Combine (and some confidence) can do for a player's stock.
The Bears did take Bazuin. I heard it just now from his agent. The pick has not been announced but it will be soon.

There have not been many shockers in the draft so far. Sure, Ted Ginn Jr. seemed like a reach by the Dolphins with the ninth overall pick. And who could have predicted Brady Quinn's freefall to the 22nd pick? But by this stage in the draft - late second round, early third round -- it's very tough to predict picks. Heck, it was tough to get things exactly right in the first round. But here is a name to look out for in the third round: Daniel Bazuin, a defensive end from Central Michigan. Bazuin is 6-foot-3 and 266 pounds, and he ran the 40-yard dash in 4.81 seconds. I bet the Bears could even pick him at the end of round two.

It's time for another update on the scene at Radio City. If you're watching ESPN, it looks like there's tons of life here. Actually a lot of the fans have left. Only the diehards are still here, and even some of them have begun to sleep in their seats. Commissioner Roger Goodell is no longer in sight (I bet you he went to Carnegie Deli for a corned beef sandwich). The concession stands are closing up. But we still have about 90 minutes to go, and anything could happen in that time.

In Sunday's column I lay out the attempts to reach a "grand bargain" between the U.S. and Iran, before Bush administration hard-liners killed the effort in 2003. Here I'm providing more background and the full documents.
SAN DIEGO -- Count at least one of the Democratic presidential candidates a critic of the way the first candidate debate was conducted.
So we finally have the winners of my second annual Win-a-Trip contest.

A noteworthy trade was just made. The Raiders sent their fourth-round pick to Detroit for wide receiver Mike Williams and quarterback Josh McCown. This is significant for two reasons. The acquisition of Williams sets the stage for a potential trade of Randy Moss. The Packers and Patriots are possible destinations for Moss. Also, McNown will now be the starter on opening day for the Raiders if they think JaMarcus Russell is not ready.

The Giants are on the clock. They need a linebacker most but the fans here are chanting for Brian Leonard, a fullback/halfback from Rutgers. With Tiki Barber gone, Leonard, who is from Gouverneur, N.Y., might make sense. What do you think?

The Jets just traded up to get David Harris, an inside linebacker from Michigan. It's a great value (and it's the second time they made a trade). There had been rumors that the Jets might trade Jonathan Vilma, who seemed constrained by Eric Mangini's 3-4 defense last season. It's more likely Harris will play alongside Vilma next season, beefing up the interior defense.

Tony Ugoh was just taken by the Colts, who traded their first-rounder in 2008 to Minnesota to move up. That's a hefty price but Ugoh was a steak at that position (10th in the second round). I just spoke with Alan Herman, Ugoh's agent. Herman text-messaged Ugoh about 15 minutes ago, telling him to hang in there. I saw his reply: "I'm not disappointed." Herman noted that the difference between being selected in the second round instead of the first was a four-year deal instead of a five-year deal. But that means Ugoh, if he is really that good, can become a free agent and strike a long-term deal after four years (instead of five).

So, who are the best players available? In my opinion, it's David Harris (linebacker, Michigan) and Tony Ugoh (offensive tackle, Arkansas). Both players trained together in Paramus, N.J., before the Combine. Teams looking for a value pick should draft one of these guys. I thought Ugoh should have been picked at the end of the first round.

Well, I finally got a pick right. I suggested that the Chargers would take a safety with the fifth pick in the second round, and they did! Eric Weddle of Houston. Too bad I didn't mention Weddle's name. Truth be told, I don't know much about the guy. But he should be able to help the Chargers since they really need help at this position. That makes three correct picks (JaMarcus Russell and Calvin Johnson being the others).

More bad news for Philly fans. The Eagles just picked Kevin Kolb, a quarterback from Houston. The pick makes sense only if Donovan NcNabb goes down (and he is injury-prone). But if McNabb stays healthy, Kolb does not get any playing time, remaining inexperienced. The Eagles fans were practically expressionless when the pick was announced.

Down here in Washington, life with the Mets is slightly more placid than it is in Tyler's neck of the woods. The only hot seat for Willie Randolph is the heated seats in his rental car. But it doesn't necessarily mean that Randolph is immune to second-guessing. He made a few decisions in Friday's game that I suppose could be argued both ways.

The first round just ended six hours and eight minutes after Roger Goodell declared the draft open for business. I keep looking up at the ESPN stage, where Keyshawn Johnson and Chris Berman, et al, are seated. Man, those guys look tired. It was the longest first round in the history of N.F.L. drafts. For some reason the fans cheered when Goodell announced this. Goodell said this was not a record he hoped to break. At this rate, we will all get home early Sunday morning.

ELKO, Nev. - Sometimes, this week, as Senator John McCain traveled the nation on the official rollout of his presidential campaign, it was almost as if he were campaigning against Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic majority leader.

I just got back from interviewing Tom Brady, Joe Montana, Dan Marino, Peyton Manning and Jeremiah Trotter. Well, I didn't exactly speak to them. But I did speak to guys wearing their jerseys. The second balcony at Radio City is teeming with fans from every team. It sort of feels like the United Nations (even though I have never actually been inside the U.N.). The second balcony is where the diehards sit, and I quickly gravitated to the Philadelphia Eagles fans. I expected them to be rowdy, like they were a few years ago when the Eagles picked Donovan McNabb over Ricky Williams. The fans in that draft were known as the "Dirty 30."

SAN DIEGO -- Here's an early report, from where the Democratic presidential candidates are speaking this weekend at the famously rowdy - and always entertaining - California Democratic Party convention.

I don't know who picks the music they play in between each pick. While the talking heads on television are analyzing picks, they play music with themes here at Radio City. It was Frank Sinatra's "New York, New York" when the Giants were on the clock. They played Elton John's "Philadelphia Freedom" until the Eagles just traded the 26th pick in the first round to the Dallas Cowboys.
