I can't identify what they're playing now, but it sounds a lot like the Red Hot Chili Peppers. Are they from Dallas? The Cowboys had dealt their 22nd pick to Cleveland, which used it on Brady Quinn. Speaking of Quinn, I wonder how Charlie Frye must be feeling right now. His theme song today could be Billy Joel's "Movin' Out."
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is set for a busy Sunday. She'll be on ABC's "This Week with George Stephanopoulos," CBS's "Face the Nation," and CNN's "Late Edition with Wolf Blitzer."

Jeff Karstens threw one pitch today and got drilled on the right leg with a line drive. He fell to the ground immediately, gamely stayed in for one more hitter, and then had to leave. It has been that kind of season for the Yankees.

The Giants and Jets have picked, and Brady Quinn is off the board. Things have definitely quieted down here at Radio City. The Panthers are up at No. 25. This is where the Jets would have picked had they not traded up to get Darrelle Revis, a cornerback, with the 14th overall pick. So let's take a look at which cornerbacks are available now. Daymeion Hughes of California, Tanard Jackson of Syracuse and Marcus McCauley are still around, but none of them are considered first-rounders.

FINALLY The Cleveland Browns just made a trade with the Dallas Cowboys for the 22nd pick, which they used on Brady Quinn. The fans here cheered when Quinn's name was announced, and Quinn bolted out of the green room in record time. He looked so relieved, and he kept pointing to the sky and exhaling as he walked on stage. Quinn is still on stage now, with family members and friends. He is carrying a Browns jersey with "1" on the front. The pick makes sense for Cleveland but it came at a premium. In return, Dallas gets the Browns' second-rounder this season (36th over all) and their first-rounder in 2008.

Did I write Posluszny? I meant Aaron Ross from Texas. Honestly, it was just a type-o. My fingers just sort of slid over those keys and accidentally typed Posluszny. The pick makes sense on some levels. Ross is a cornerback, and the Giants need a cornerback. But I think they need a linebacker more. Look for them to pick a linebacker with their second-rounder.
6:45 to go before the Giants pick. I say they take Paul Posluszny, a linebacker, from Penn State. Please, oh, please, let me finally be right.

The Bengals got Leon Hall, cornerback, Michigan, with the 18th pick. This is one of the best values in the draft so far. This is a player many so-called "experts" figured would be gone by the 10th pick. By the way, whatever happened to that quarterback from Notre Dame, Brady what's-his-name? Quinn is now the forgotten man in the draft. Once Miami passed on him at No. 9, we all knew it would be a long wait for Quinn. But everyone was buzzing about him until about the 14th or 15th pick. Now no one is mentioning his name. Look for Kansas City to grab him at 23. Of course, I'll probably be wrong about that, too. I was hyping Quinn at No. 3. I'm now wearing a hat, sunglasses and a fake mustache.

Another trade! The Jaguars give up their first-rounder (17th over all) to Denver in exchange for the Broncos' first-rounder (21st), third-rounder (86th) and sixth-rounder (198th). What a steep price to move up four spots in the first round. "And with the 17th overall pick in the N.F.L. Draft, the Denver Broncos select Jarvis Moss, defensive end, Florida).

A trade during the N.F.L. Draft always gets the fans' attention. A trade involving the Jets? Well, let's just say the fans here went bananas when it was announced that the Jets had acquired the 14th overall pick from Carolina. About 10 minutes later, Commissioner Roger Goodell announced the Jets had selected Darrelle Revis, a cornerback from Pittsburgh. The fans really got into it then, cheering and pumping their fists. I bet Coach Eric Mangini and GM Mike Tannenbaum were doing the same - behind closed doors, of course.
The Jets just made a huge trade.

The draft is now about two and a half hours old. Only 15 and a half more hours to go! The atmosphere here is much more relaxed. During the first 10 picks, the tension in the air was palpable. But things settled down ever since the 10th pick. Former Buffalo Bills star Bruce Smith, not Commissioner Roger Goodell, announced the 11th pick (linebacker Patrick Willis to the 49ers). The fans have settled into their seats, and the beer lines are even vacant (err, beer is off limits at this event). Goodell is now circulating around Radio City Music Hall, chatting with reporters.

Where on earth will Brady Quinn end up? He is this year's Aaron Rodgers, a quarterback who was supposed to get picked in the top 10 but plummeted. Rodgers went to the Green Bay Packers in 2005 with the 24th pick of the first round. Look at the next 11 picks: None of these teams really need a quarterback. Quinn could fall to Kansas City at No. 23. Amazing! The Buffalo Bills at 12 and the St. Louis Rams could reach for Quinn. But they have J.P. Losman and Marc Bulger, respectively.

I was right! Not about the Dolphins taking Brady Quinn at No. 9. As predicted, the fans started chanting Quinn's name after Miami picked Ted Ginn Jr., wide receiver, Ohio State. Only they were mocking Quinn, not cheering for him. (I just got their motivation wrong. A minor detail.) Nearly everyone expected Quinn to land in Miami. What a shocker! How far will he fall? Quinn is becoming a main story line this afternoon. I sort of felt sorry for him. He's sitting in the green room, and the cameras were all over him after Ginn's name was called. His girlfriend was at his side.

"Brady Quinn!!! Brady Quinn!!!" Fans will be shouting his name in a matter of minutes. The Miami Dolphins have to take him here. What a steal. Quinn was projected as a top-three pick in many mock drafts. In fact, I think I just heard some fans already begin to scream his name . Quinn has been groomed for this moment. He spent the past week making appearances on talk shows, hoping, I guess, to boost his profile (could it be any higher?). Soon he will take center stage.

Boy, did Adrian Peterson look relieved to be drafted by Minnesota at No. 7. The Falcons won't pick Brady Quinn at No. 8, so he will probably fall into Miami's lap at No. 9. So, what will Atlanta do here? Your guess is as good as mine? They wanted LaRon Landy, who is now off the board. Maybe someone will trade to grab this pick and beat Miami to the chase. It would be the day's first deal, and this place would explode with cheers and boos if one is announced.

By the way, did anyone notice that the Redskins used nearly all of their allotted 15 minutes to pick LaRon Landry with the sixth pick? Didn't they learn anything from Minnesota a few years ago? The Redskins' representatives looked like they were scrambling before submitting their pick with seconds remaining. Minnesota is up now. I wonder if they'll blow it again. Oh, wait, they just picked

The Redskins just picked LaRon Landry, safety from Louisiana State. It's a pick that makes little sense. Don't the Redskins already have Shawn Springs in their defensive backfield? Well, all that means is that Brady Quinn is still available for Minnesota at No. 7. Everyone hear at the draft is beginning to wonder, 'How far will Quinn fall?" I say the Vikings pick Quinn. But aside from the top two picks, I haven't gotten any right! Ah, the joys of covering the NFL Draft live on the Internet ...

Like the Cardinals last season, stopping the run was problematic for the Washington Redskins. Will they go for need or the best player available (and then possibly make a trade)? Amobi Okoye, Adrian Peterson and Brady Quinn are still available. What do you think they'll do?

Arizona probably would have taken Gaines Adams but now they must go to Pan B. Adams was just drafted by Tampa Bay. Peterson and Quinn are still out there, but the Cardinals have Matt Leinart and Edgerrin James. If they want to boost their defesinve line, Amobi Okoye looks like a good fit here.

OK, the Browns didn't take Quinn or Peterson. That means they're there for Tampa Bay to pick. The fans here sure didn't like the Browns' pick of left tackle Joe Thomas of Wisconsin, who skipped New York this weekend to go fishing with his father. Unflattering chants aimed at Cleveland swept through Radio City Music Hall after Commissioner Roger Goodell announced Thomas's name. I see the concerns of the Browns' fans. Cleveland now has a good left tackle but no quarterback to protect.

The Browns pick third and they sure could use a running back. Adrian Peterson, perhaps. Brady Quinn of Notre Dame is another possibility. Quinn, who is from Ohio, has appeared all over the top 10 in mock drafts in recent weeks. Will he freefall, like Aaron Rodgers a few years ago, or will the Browns grab him here? Quinn has a high football I.Q., so it would make sense to take him here.
The Raiders just took JaMarcus Russell with the first pick in the draft. It looks like Al Davis wanted him all along. Eight of the last ten No. 1 overall picks have been quarterbacks.

For the first time in several months, the No. 1 spot on our political best seller list no longer belongs to Senator Barack Obama's "The Audacity of Hope.'' It's slipped down a notch, to make way for the tale of a former child soldier in Sierra Leone's civil war.

The Chicago Tribune reports that, though President Bush has been careful not to show support for a specific Republican contender, his allies appear to have split their support between the campaigns of Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney.
Let us give thanks for what “Wind Chill” largely is: a moody, spooky tale, rendered with laudable economy.
“Kickin’ It Old School” is actually much more amusing than it has a right to be, considering that you know exactly what’s coming.
Scenes from Day 1 of the 2007 Coachella music festival in California.
Writer Don Sherman compares hydrogen-fueled vehicles from Ford, Toyota, General Motors, BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Honda.
“The Invisible,” the latest recycling of foreign-grown frights, shows less interest in horror than in healing.
“Ta Ra Rum Pum” may take place entirely in New York, but that doesn’t stop it from being a classic example of Bollywood family values.
Representatives toured the province to gain a better understanding of a plan that would grant Kosovo independence.
The Raiders had been expected by many to pick JaMarcus Russell, who appears to have the size, arm strength and mobility to become a franchise player.
In Baghdad, the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr berated President Bush for  failing to heed widespread demand for an American troop withdrawal.

WASHINGTON, April 28 — Arriving as president of the World Bank in the summer of 2005, Paul D. Wolfowitz told colleagues he was eager to tackle issues like poverty in Africa and corruption in aid to poor countries. But almost immediately he became consumed instead by frustrating negotiations with bank officials over the status of his companion, an employee at the bank, documents released this month show.

TOKYO, April 28 — In his first visit to the United States as Japan’s leader, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe quickly got on a first-name basis with President Bush and secured an invitation to the ranch in Crawford, Tex., for the next time.

JERUSALEM, April 28 — The Israeli army shot four Palestinian militants near the border fence in Gaza this morning, killing three and seriously wounding one, an army spokeswoman said. The armed militants were spotted trying to plant an explosive device, she said. A spokesman for the military wing of Hamas said they were members of Hamas’s Izz al-Din al-Qassam Brigades on a “jihad mission.”.
Even on his worst days, Mariano Rivera rarely suffered the indignity of handing the ball to Manager Joe Torre in the middle of an inning. This April is a different story.
The Rangers were penalized only four times, yet Buffalo prevailed to take a 2-0 lead in the Eastern Conference semifinals.
The Yankees gave a lead to Andy Pettitte in the middle innings on Friday, yet their best starter couldn’t hold the lead and yet another game slipped away.
Oliver Pérez, the king of inconsistency, pitched well but the Mets couldn’t find the offense to complement his performance.
Matsuzaka rebounded from a forgettable fourth inning to retire six consecutive batters and stymie the Yankees.
Randall L. Tobias’s name had come up in an investigation of a suspected prostitution ring, an official said.

A picture caption in The Arts last Saturday with an article about “India Now,” a film series at the Museum of Modern Art, included erroneous information from the museum about the actress shown in a scene from “Dor,” a film in the series. She was Gul Panag — not Ayesha Takia, one of the movie’s stars.

An article Thursday about the formal start of Senator John McCain’s campaign for the Republican presidential nomination misspelled the surname of the United States attorney general, whom Mr. McCain urged to resign, in two of four references. The attorney general is Alberto R. Gonzales, not Gonzalez.

A sports article yesterday about quarterback JaMarcus Russell’s emergence as a star at Louisiana State University referred imprecisely to one of his statistics. Russell had 342 passes during his senior season, not in his collegiate career. (His career number was 797.).

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Thursday about receiver Calvin Johnson on the eve of the N.F.L. draft misattributed a quotation about the influence of his family’s values on Johnson. It was Johnson’s father, Calvin Sr. — not Johnson himself — who said the family “wouldn’t tolerate a lot of being foolish.” The article also referred imprecisely to Johnson’s leaping ability. He performed an 11-foot-7-inch standing long jump, not just a long jump.

The “Living In” article in the Real Estate section this weekend, about Pleasant Plains, Staten Island, incorrectly describes the borders of the neighborhood. As correctly shown on the map with the article, Pleasant Plains is bordered on the south by the waterfront, on the west by Cunningham Road, on the north by the Korean War Veterans Parkway and on the east by a vague line created by Lemon Creek, Bayview Avenue and Lenevar Avenue.
An obituary last Saturday about Frank H. Westheimer, a chemist who did research on enzymes, misspelled part of the name of an enzyme he studied. It is alcohol dehydrogenase, not dehydrogenate.

An article Thursday about the formal start of Senator John McCain’s campaign for the Republican presidential nomination misspelled the surname of the United States attorney general, whom Mr. McCain urged to resign, in two of four references. The attorney general is Alberto R. Gonzales, not Gonzalez.

An article on Tuesday about a Congressional hearing in Brooklyn at which speakers urged the Environmental Protection Agency to address contamination and medical problems in areas outside Lower Manhattan resulting from the Sept. 11 attack included incorrect information about the hearing from a spokeswoman for the E.P.A. Although the agency itself was not invited to testify, the agency’s inspector general, who operates independently, was. (He declined the invitation.).

An article in Business Day on Monday about start-up companies pursuing the idea of advertising-supported digital music misspelled part of the name of a company that was being formed to sell such ads. It is Rebel Digital, not Rebal.
Calvin Sims and Times correspondent Steve Weisman discuss Paul Wolfowitz, who is engulfed in a scandal over a large pay package he arranged for his companion.
The Devils leading scorer missed the team’s  5-4 loss on Thursday to Ottawa due to the flu, but said his ailment was nothing more than a severe bug.

The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved the lifting of a 2001 blockade of the sale of so-called blood diamonds from Liberia that fueled wars in West Africa. Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, the Liberian president, had pressed for an end to the embargo as necessary to revive the economy of her impoverished nation, and Emyr Jones Parry, left, Britain’s ambassador to the United Nations, said the decision reflected confidence that the country now met the standards of the Kimberley Process, an industry initiative certifying the origins of diamonds entering international trade. The Council lifted similar restrictions on Liberian timber sales in June.

This month is set to become the warmest April in Britain since records began to be kept nearly 350 years ago. Britain’s weather service said temperatures in central England averaged 52 degrees, the highest since records began in 1659. The service warned of a repeat of the European heat wave of 2003, which killed 35,000 people and which scientists attributed to global warming. It said temperatures from Belgium to Italy were running above the 30-year norm. A Dutch weather institute said April had broken records as the warmest, driest and sunniest month there.

United Nations envoys heard Albanians plead for the independence of Kosovo while the Serbian minority opposed it and the West made another diplomatic concession to placate Serbia’s backer, Russia. Bishop Artemije, head of the Serbian Orthodox Church in Kosovo, told reporters: “Independence in any form is unacceptable. Kosovo will not be independent.” The envoys toured the monastery in Gracanica, south of Pristina, an enclave where Serbs live under NATO protection.

China named Yang Jiechi, who was ambassador to the United States from 2001 to 2005, to become foreign minister, shuffling its diplomatic team as its rising economic power has given it greater sway in world affairs. Mr. Yang, 56, formerly a vice minister, is fluent in English and well known for a courteous but cautious manner. He replaces Li Zhaoxing, another English speaker and former ambassador to Washington, who is 66. No reason was given for the replacement, but Mr. Li had passed the retirement age for ministerial officials. Mr. Yang assumes the helm at a time when China has greatly expanded its diplomatic activities around the world, especially in Asia and Africa, and as its economic growth and increased military spending have raised concerns in some quarters that it may begin to challenge Washington for leadership in world affairs.

A court in Milan upheld the acquittal of the former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, on corruption charges. The court upheld a 2004 decision that cleared Mr. Berlusconi, who is Italy’s richest man. He had been accused of paying a $434,000 bribe to a Rome judge in 1991 to rule in his favor during the takeover battle for an Italian food conglomerate. The prosecutors had challenged the earlier acquittal and had asked for a five-year sentence.

A Palestinian security officer was shot dead in a clash with local residents at the Rafah border crossing in southern Gaza, Palestinian officials said. The officer, Abdulrahman Abu Teir, 24, was killed after armed members of a family tried to barge into the terminal without waiting in line, witnesses said. Palestinian security forces control the passenger crossing into Egypt, under the supervision of European monitors, but Israel determines when it will be open. The crossing was opened Thursday for the first time since April 19, but it was too crowded to operate, a spokeswoman for the European monitoring mission said. Up to 5,000 Gazans arrived at the crossing yesterday. It remained open all day, the spokeswoman said, because the unrest occurred outside the terminal itself.

Law enforcement officials said they had arrested two drug dealers who disguised themselves as Mexican soldiers last year, crossed into Texas and confronted sheriff’s deputies and police officers. The suspects, Óscar Alonso Candelaria Escajeda and Iván Gándara Trejo, were caught Thursday in Ciudad Juárez, across the border from El Paso. The American authorities initially thought the men were soldiers, and the January 2006 incident strained relations between the countries.
A legal construction device that measures asphalt and concrete using low-level radioactive isotopes set off a police lieutenant’s radiation detector.
The banks, led by Royal Bank of Scotland, said they would make a bid worth more than an earlier offer from Barclays for $87 billion.

The Rev. V. Gene Robinson, the Episcopal Church’s first openly gay bishop, said he and his partner want to be among the first couples in New Hampshire to unite officially under a civil unions measure soon to be signed into law. The state is set to become the nation’s fourth to offer civil unions for gay couples after legislation approved by the Senate was sent to Gov. John Lynch, who has said he will sign it. “I think this moves us one step closer to the American promise to all its citizens of equality under the law,” Mr. Robinson, 59, told The Associated Press. “My partner and I look forward to taking full advantage of the new law.” Mr. Robinson and his partner, Mark Andrew, have been together for 18 years.

The authorities dropped charges against an aide to Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, who carried a loaded gun into the Capitol complex. “After reviewing and analyzing all of the evidence in the case, we do not believe the essential elements of the crime of carrying a pistol without a license can be proved beyond a reasonable doubt,” Jeff Taylor, the local United States attorney, the top prosecutor in the District of Columbia, said. The aide, Phillip Thompson, 45, was arrested March 26 after Capitol Police spotted the loaded pistol and two loaded magazines in a briefcase being scanned by an X-ray machine at the entrance of the Russell Senate Office Building. Mr. Thompson told an officer that the weapon belonged to Mr. Webb. The senator said later that he had not given the gun to Mr. Thompson, but he refused to say whether it was his.

The mayor of Jackson and two police bodyguards were acquitted of malicious mischief and conspiracy in connection with an August incident in which a duplex they considered a crack house was damaged. The mayor, Frank Melton, 57, would have been forced to resign if convicted of any of the felony counts, and he could have faced prison time. Prosecutors said the defendants had no reason to bust windows and tear down walls in the home. The defense acknowledged that the house was damaged but told jurors there had been no malice involved.

All six campuses of Broward Community College and two university campuses in South Florida were evacuated and searched by the police after a note threatening an attack was found. The note, mentioning the Virginia Tech killings and threatening a similar attack at the community college, was written on a poster board and found at a Hollywood construction site, said Capt. Tony Rode, a spokesman for the Hollywood police. Florida Atlantic University officials evacuated two campuses that share space with the community college. Earlier this week, the police arrested a man they say admitted writing a note threatening to bomb a Hollywood middle school and another one threatening to set fire to an apartment building. The man, Larry Boynton, 52, is considered a person of interest in the college threat, Captain Rode said.
Thomas Vanek — the star of Game 1 — scored the winning goal for Buffalo on a terrific pass from Drew Stafford in the third period.
Jason Kidd had the 10th triple-double of his playoff career, as the Nets took a 2-1 lead in their N.B.A. first-round playoff series.
Former Mets recalled that Kirk Radomski, who pleaded guilty Friday to distributing steroids to baseball players, was a musclebound, avid weightlifter.
Chicago is one victory from sending the defending N.B.A. champion Miami Heat home for the summer — in stunning style.
Sammy Sosa hit his 595th career home run, and Mark Teixeira and Brad Wilkerson each had two-run homers as the Texas Rangers defeated the host Toronto Blue Jays, 5-3.
The association will pay $128 million to settle lawsuits brought by doctors who said that they had been underpaid on insurance claims.
Judge Karen Cassidy also called the sexual orientation of former Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey insignificant to the case.
James B. Davis was the leader of the Dixie Hummingbirds, one of the longest-lasting and most influential groups in gospel music.
Work will stop pending the outcome of an investigation into the partial collapse of a building being prepared for demolition to make way for the Atlantic Yards project.
The military hinted that it might act against the Turkish government if it strayed too far from secularism.
The Anglican archbishop of Nigeria, Peter J. Akinola, a fierce critic of the Episcopal Church for its acceptance of homosexuality, is arriving in Washington next week.
Citigroup will introduce a new message in the company’s first global brand campaign since it was formed nearly a decade ago.
George J. Tenet’s account of tensions between intelligence officers and Bush administration policymakers fills in new details, and some of his critics have begun to reply.
Prosecutors portrayed the former audit committee member as a talented economist who had been duped.
The slowdown underscores how the persistent housing slump continues to drag on the American economy.
Mr. Rostropovich was renowned as a great musician and also as a champion of freedom in the Soviet Union.
Michael S. Dell is now thinking about changing the way the company markets its computers.
Martin A. Armstrong, a financial adviser, will begin serving a five-year sentence for conspiracy to commit fraud.
A Canadian businessman bought former residents of New Orleans a $2.4 million, 791-acre sugar cane field to create “an environment of opportunity.”
Quellos Investments is being investigated over its design and sale of questionable tax shelters to wealthy investors.
The North Carolina attorney general’s investigation of the Duke lacrosse case found that the accuser had “insurmountable credibility issues.”
If prison legislation approved Thursday in California is any indication, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger’s postpartisanship results in new laws that make almost everyone angry.
Some maple syrup producers are using used vegetable oil instead of heating oil to boil their sap in an effort to help the environment.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed legislation that would make New York the second state in the country to legally sanction same-sex marriage.
The bridge linking the Golden State Warriors’ last heyday to their current renaissance starts with Don Nelson and ends with Don Nelson.
With fire deaths down, the decision by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to allocate $1.4 million for 32 more fire marshals might seem to come at a curious time.
Coppin State did not lose Wednesday, as a game against Lehigh was called a rainout. That’s a major accomplishment for a team that has been outscored 521-43 this season.
Rick Wagoner’s compensation nearly doubled even though he voluntarily reduced his salary to aid the automaker’s restructuring effort.
A day after appearing at the first presidential debate of the year, the field of Democratic hopefuls descended on a different South Carolina stage: Representative James E. Clyburn’s fish fry.
A man described as the top aide to Osama bin Laden is the first terrorism suspect known to have been held in secret C.I.A. jails since last September.
Three sea lions will return from an 18-month sojourn at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island to the Bronx Zoo Wildlife Conservation Park.
With anxiety running high after the Virginia Tech attacks, authorities in Sacramento arrested four secondary school students on Thursday.
The Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum is one of the rare museums that relies mostly on private money.
The Interior Department has put the final touches on a five-year plan to expand oil and gas drilling in the Gulf of Mexico and offshore from Alaska and Virginia.
New Jersey’s top two legislators said Gov. Jon S. Corzine was not interested in talking about policy or politics.
As Senator Christopher J. Dodd ambles through the early voting states, there is a decided “Why the heck not?” feel to his joyous orbit.
Edward E. Whitacre Jr. will be succeeded by Randall L. Stephenson, the company’s chief operating officer.
Despite giving up four earned runs on Thursday, Yankees pitcher Phil Hughes will face the Rangers in Texas on Tuesday.
The fees tacked onto clothing as it enters the U.S. may be the last legal form of sex discrimination in the country.
Investors tried to reconcile a weaker-than-expected estimate of first-quarter economic growth with fresh evidence that corporate profits remain robust.
Now appearing in public service ads urging youngsters to exercise, Shrek is also the star of a soon-to-open sequel whose image is being used to promote all sorts of “junk foods.”
A soldier stationed at the Fort Drum Army base and his wife were attacked in retaliation for a restraining order, the authorities said.
The raids are part of the government’s Operation Return to Sender, in which more than 23,000 people have been arrested nationwide.
Recent studies suggest that the current policy of emphasizing abstinence in sex education and minimizing contraceptive use should be turned around.
The best thing Paul Wolfowitz can do for the World Bank, the country and himself is to step down.
Many filmmakers have been frustrated, flummoxed or downright infuriated by what may turn out to be Jack Valenti’s most enduring legacy, the film rating system.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,328 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
A former biology teacher at an East Side Roman Catholic school for girls has been charged with raping or molesting three additional students.
A woodcarver said he had erupted in rage when a Peace Corps volunteer bumped into him as he was fuming over a feud with a neighbor.
In January, Jerry Reese became the third African-American general manager in N.F.L. history. Yet Saturday’s draft serves as his symbolic, public beginning.
Officials said a terrorist ring was planning to blow up oil installations and attack public officials and military posts.
A $26 million museum honoring the Tuskegee Airmen is planned for a renovated 35,000-square-foot hangar at Detroit’s airport, an organizer said Friday.
President Bush and Democratic leaders hinted at a willingness to compromise on the war spending bill.
Google’s $3.1 billion deal for the online advertising firm DoubleClick could put the company at odds with itself.
At 24, Tyson Gay is ranked first in the world at 200 meters and second at 100 meters. And he’s getting even better.
Trainer Michael Matz is trying not to be consumed by the memory of the now deceased colt that won the Kentucky Derby last year.
Despite declaring for the N.B.A. draft and not having played football in four years, the L.S.U basketball player Glen Davis could be a late-round pick in the N.F.L. draft.
The starting safety Anthony Scirrotto faces the most serious charges: felony counts of burglary and criminal solicitation.
The four Iraqi men are also suspected of taking guerrillas from Iraq to Iran for training.
The state police had believed that David C. Brinkerhoff was killed by a suspect he and other officers had cornered.
Three days after likening the sport to professional wrestling, Tony Stewart emerged from a meeting with Nascar officials saying he had it all wrong.
In recent years, the team holding the top pick in the N.F.L. draft has tried to sign the player to a contract before the draft begins. This year isn’t so predictable.
In a celebration of Blue Note Records on Thursday, Wynton Marsalis and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra unveiled nearly a dozen new arrangements of songs from the label’s catalog.
Japan’s highest court denied compensation to wartime sex slaves and forced laborers from China but acknowledged the coercion.
A judge indicted three U.S. soldiers in the 2003 death of a Spanish journalist who was killed when their tank fired at a hotel in Baghdad.
Former State Senator John Ford, a prominent member of a politically powerful family here, was convicted Friday of accepting bribes.
Most schools that scored as poorly on standardized tests as English High School would have been shuttered by now. Instead, the state has moved to salvage the school.
Insurgents have melted back into Mogadishu and hundreds of families began to return home.
The missile defense initiative risks driving Moscow further from Europe and dividing Europe’s public over the future of its security.
ABC has been pretending to hope that no one notices what could be its biggest winner in next fall’s television season, a spinoff of its hit nighttime soap opera “Grey’s Anatomy.”
A second-round draft pick in 1977, he  caught 163 passes in a seven-year N.F.L. career spent entirely with the Giants.
How well is Congress performing under its new Democratic leadership? Look to the numbers.
Twelve lawmakers held hostage by leftist guerrillas for five years sent a message to President Álvaro Uribe urging him to negotiate their release.
Was that blood? Probably not, but it wasn’t easy to tell with the Atlanta-based band Deerhunter onstage at the Mercury Lounge on Thursday night.
Any change in market conditions would vary the size of Intel’s profit, but for A.M.D. it can mean the difference between a big profit and a big loss.
A former Mets clubhouse assistant pleaded guilty on Friday to distributing performance-enhancing drugs to dozens of former and current players.
Blue chip stocks surged all week as many big companies reported better-than-expected results, though mixed economic data might quiet the enthusiasm next week.
Gere conciliates, Shetty diversifies, Albee presents, courts giveth and taketh, Diedre’s tour detour and more culture news.
Bruce D. Hertzke, chairman and chief executive of Winnebago Industries, spoke about high gas prices and about how some people save the fancy trimmings for their R.V. instead of their house.
Our Time Theater, a theater devoted to young people who stutter, held a benefit gala on Monday and performed alongside established veterans.
The U.S. protests came after Britain canceled an inquiry into allegations of bribery by Britain’s top military contractor.
Extended Stay Hotels recently announced it planned to keep its smokers welcome policies in place.
It was the most lethal day for Russian authorities in the volatile North Caucasus region since late 2005.
The new official must put in place the transportation-oriented initiatives that are part of the mayor’s environmental program for the city.
The removal of the monument prompted a renewed diplomatic fury in neighboring Russia.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York said that his administration would use trees, fees and cleaner fuels to remove “disease-causing soot” from the air.
Federal reports that criticized conditions at Colorado veterans’ nursing homes have legislators scrambling to allocate new money to the homes.
Just naming the nine programs in the La MaMa Moves! festival must have been exhausting; it’s hard to imagine the other logistics that the co-curators must have dealt with.
The decision had been widely expected ever since a panel of F.D.A. advisers voted against approval of the drug Arcoxia because of health concerns.
Any discussion of a future generation of hydrogen cars inevitably leads to the same question: Where will I fill the tank?
“American Fiesta” is as topically ambitious a theatrical effort as you will experience Off Broadway right now.

(Showtime) EDMOND (2005) After a tarot card reader tells him, “You are not where you belong,” a nebbishy businessman walks out on his marriage and unleashes his long-suppressed rage — and sexual desires — in this explosive adaptation of David Mamet’s 1982 one-act play. Stephen Holden, writing in The New York Times, said that William H. Macy, above, “a master at playing sticks of human dynamite in mild-mannered camouflage,” gives “the nerviest screen performance of his career.”.
Tere O’Connor’s provocative Nothing Festival was intended to get dance back to basics, without the worries of marketing, fund-raising or suitable production values.
The organ Carol Williams plays in San Diego is one of the few in the world that stands out in the open.

The most popular regional is held in Gatlinburg, Tenn., in April. This year’s, which ended on April 15, set a record, with more than 10,000 tables in play during the event’s seven days.

Edward E. Whitacre began as a facilities engineer with Southwestern Bell in 1963, ascending the corporate ladder of what would eventually become AT&T as it grew into the world’s largest telephone company.
A consortium of three banks notified ABN Amro’s board that it would make a bid worth more than the Barclays offer of $87 billion.

A Palestinian security officer was shot dead in a clash with local residents at the Rafah border crossing in southern Gaza, Palestinian officials said. The officer, Abdulrahman Abu Teir, 24, was killed after armed members of a family tried to barge into the terminal without waiting in line, witnesses said. Palestinian security forces control the passenger crossing into Egypt, under the supervision of European monitors, but Israel determines when it will be open. The crossing was opened Thursday for the first time since April 19, but it was too crowded to operate, a spokeswoman for the European monitoring mission said. Up to 5,000 Gazans arrived at the crossing yesterday. It remained open all day, the spokeswoman said, because the unrest occurred outside the terminal itself. ISABEL KERSHNER

Opened yesterday in New York, Los Angeles, Phoenix, Seattle, Dallas, Houston, Atlanta, Miami, Chicago and Minneapolis. Directed by Gregory Jacobs 87 minutes Of Gregory Jacobs's thriller ''Wind Chill,'' let us first give thanks for what it isn't: a procession of teenage corpses, and, to avoid the more vulgar expression, torture-tainment. That said, let us give thanks for what it largely is: a moody, spooky tale, rendered with laudable economy.

KRAMER--Carole A. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Philatelic Foundation wishes to extend our heartfelt sympathy to Chairman George J. Kramer on the passing of his beloved Carole. Robert G. Rose, Vice Chairman $(6$)KRAMER--Carole Arch, age 70, died peacefully on April 26, 2007 after a battle with melanoma. Carole was born in Harrisburg, PA and lived with her husband of 47 years, George, in Clifton, NJ and Peru, VT. Carole attended the University of Pennsylvania where she studied Journalism and distinguished herself as President of the Freshman Class in 1954, President of the Delta Phi Epsilon Sorority, President of the Alumni Class of 1958 and First Chief Justice of Women's Supreme Court. She also received the University of Pennsylvania Outstanding Graduate Award from the American Association of Undergraduate Women. Carole devoted herself to a life of community service in Greater Clifton-Passaic and served as President and Co-President of the Sisterhood of Temple Emanuel, Editor of the Temple Emanuel Newsletter, President of the Women's Auxiliary of Beth Israel Hospital, Chairwomen of the Womens Division and General Chairman of the United Jewish Campaign of the Jewish Federation of Greater Clifton-Passaic, and as a Member of the Beautification Committee of the City of Clifton. She traveled the world with her husband and is a member of the Seven Continents Society. She also ran a personalized stationery business, Pretty Papers, for over 30 years. Carole's dogs were her passion. Her beloved Champion Kismet Pearlbrook Andante, Champion Touches Cartel of Ashford and Champion Touches Pearlbrook Heartbreak each won the Best of Breed award at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show and she served as President of the Lowchen Club of America and as Secretary of the Garden State Non - Sporting Group. Carole's philatelic collection, For the Love of Dogs, won two National Gold Medals and will be exhibited at the Philatelic World Championships this June in St. Petersburg, Russia. Carole is survived by her husband, George, her brother, Martin, her mother-in-law, Adeline, three children, four grandchildren, four Lowchens and the many lives that she has touched and enriched. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 29, 1:30pm, at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, New Jersey and burial will take place on Monday, April 30, 2pm, at the Park Lawn Cemetery, Bennington, VT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Wylies Day Foundation, 1434 Treetop Lane, Ambler PA 19102 and to the Second Chance Animal Center, P.O. Box 620, Shaftsbury, VT 05262.

After spending weeks plotting the world's biggest banking takeover, Barclays on Monday announced an $87 billion stock deal to buy the Dutch bank ABN Amro. ABN Amro was in a hurry because Fred Goodwin, chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotland, and his counterparts at Banco Santander Central Hispano of Spain and Fortis, a Belgian banking group, also wanted to buy ABN Amro but intended to split its assets among them.

Opened yesterday nationwide. Directed by David S. Goyer 97 minutes A transdimensional romance for the CW network crowd, ''The Invisible'' proves that it's tough to be in love and in limbo at the same time. A retread of the 2002 Swedish film ''Den Osynlige'' (based on a novel by Mats Wahl), this latest recycling of foreign-grown frights shows less interest in horror than in healing. Seems there's nothing like a near-death experience to repair those stubborn emotional wounds.

The ''Living In'' article in the Real Estate section this weekend, about Pleasant Plains, Staten Island, incorrectly describes the borders of the neighborhood. As correctly shown on the map with the article, Pleasant Plains is bordered on the south by the waterfront, on the west by Cunningham Road, on the north by the Korean War Veterans Parkway and on the east by a vague line created by Lemon Creek, Bayview Avenue and Lenevar Avenue.

It is clear that this is some of the effects of what is happening in Iraq, in terms of training and in terms of learning from the Iraqi experience.'' In what would be the largest acquisition ever of a biotechnology company, AstraZeneca agreed Monday to pay $15.6 billion to acquire MedImmune, maker of the FluMist nasal spray flu vaccine. The deal, with AstraZeneca beating out several rivals, reflected the eagerness of big pharmaceutical companies to obtain new products to maintain growth as older products lose patent protection. So-called biologic drugs made in cell cultures look like a new area of growth to companies like AstraZeneca that have typically made chemical pills.

An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day Thursday about online services for photo retouching misstated the given name of a proprietor of one such service, Touch of Glamour. He is Boris Kobrin, not Bruce.
An obituary last Saturday about Frank H. Westheimer, a chemist who did research on enzymes, misspelled part of the name of an enzyme he studied. It is alcohol dehydrogenase, not dehydrogenate.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10 White House Scales Back Expectations for Iraq Senior White House officials said in interviews that they are scaling back their expectations for the Iraqi government. The timelines they are now discussing suggest that the Bush administration may maintain the increased numbers of American troops in Iraq well into next year. A1 The American military said it had detained four Iraqi men suspected of helping to smuggle homemade bombs from Iran to Iraq and bringing guerrillas from Iraq to Iran for training. The men are suspected of having ties to a kidnapping ring. A10 Saudi Arrests Break Terror Ring Saudi security officials said that they had broken up a vast terrorist ring, arresting 172 men who planned to attack public officials and military posts, and storm a prison to free terrorist suspects. A1 Japan Rejects Compensation Japan's Supreme Court rejected compensation claims filed by former wartime sex slaves and forced laborers from China but acknowledged that they had been coerced by the Japanese military or industry. A8 Russia Copter Crash Kills 18 A Russian military helicopter crashed in Chechnya, killing all aboard, according to Russian news agencies. A8 Formal U.S. Protests to Britain The British government confirmed that it received two diplomatic protests from the United States in January after it canceled an inquiry into allegations of bribery by a top military contractor to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia. A8 Somalia Claims Lull as Victory After fighting that killed more than 1,000 people, insurgents melted back into Mogadishu, and hundreds of families began to return home. The transitional government claimed victory, but insurgents say they intend to simply switch tactics. A8 NATIONAL A11-14 ;18 New Orleans Evacuees Give Farm Life a Try Nearly 200 former New Orleans residents have signed on to work 791 acres of land near Simmesport, La. They have to perform eight hours a week of community service and look for work or go to school. In return, they can live rent free in a three-bedroom two-bath mobile home. A1 Archbishop to Come to U.S. The Anglican Archbishop of Nigeria, a fierce critic of the Episcopal Church for its acceptance of homosexuality, is coming to Virginia next weekend to install a bishop to lead congregations that want to break with the American church. A11 Raids Anger Bay Area Federal immigration agents have conducted surprise raids in the Bay Area as part of the government's ''Operation Return to Sender.'' And while the raids have upset many pro-immigrant groups, that displeasure has been particularly acute in the Bay Area, where many cities consider themselves sanctuaries for illegal immigrants. A14 Colorado Aids Veterans Federal reports that criticized conditions at Colorado veterans' nursing homes prompted legislators to allocate new money to the facilities. A12 Results on Duke Lacrosse Case The North Carolina attorney general's investigation of the Duke lacrosse case found that the accuser, whose account was pivotal for the prosecution, had ''insurmountable credibility issues,'' including frequently changing statements that were contradicted by physical evidence and photographs, other witnesses and her own previous assertions. A14 Sacramento Students Arrested Law enforcement officials in Sacramento arrested four secondary school students, including one youth carrying a loaded gun, averting what the police say was a plot to shoot two fellow students. A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 State Trooper Was Killed By Fellow Officer's Bullet The bullet that killed a New York State trooper during a shootout Wednesday morning inside a farmhouse in the Catskill Mountains came from the gun of a fellow officer, not the suspect they had cornered, the state police said. A1 Spitzer Offers Gay Marriage Bill Governor Spitzer proposed legislation that would make New York the second state to legalize same-sex marriage, fulfilling a longtime pledge to supporters of gay rights. Mr. Spitzer has acknowledged that he does not expect the bill to pass. B1 Religion Journal B6 SPORTSSATURDAY D1-8 Guilty Plea in Steroid Case A former Mets clubhouse assistant pleaded guilty yesterday in federal court in San Francisco to distributing performance-enhancing drugs to dozens of former and current Major League Baseball players for a 10-year period, the latest blow to a sport that has been battered by the issue of steroid use. A1 OBITUARIES A15 Mstislav Rostropovich A cellist and conductor who was renowned as one of the great instrumentalists of the 20th century and an outspoken champion of artistic freedom in the Soviet Union during the last decades of the cold war, he was 80 and lived in Paris. A1 ARTS B7-16 ABC Mum on 'Grey's' Spinoff ABC is hoping that no one notices what could be its biggest winner in next fall's television season, a spinoff of its hit nighttime soap opera ''Grey's Anatomy.'' B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Tariffs and Gender The tariffs on imported clothing, which penalize men in some instances and women in others, may be the last legal form of sex discrimination in the United States. Now, several apparel makers are challenging the tariffs in lawsuits against the federal government A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A16-17 Editorials: The abstinence-only delusion; far past time to go; a glacial pace on warming; cutting Shrek down to size. He was a Princeton University graduate, Class of 1970, and Stanford Law School graduate, Class of 1973. He was an avid golfer at Siwanoy CC in Bronxville, NY. Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543-5357. The partners, attorneys and staff of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel LLP mourn the untimely passing of our partner and friend, John Daniel. John was a leader within our Intellectual Property Group, a valued colleague to his clients and respected by his peers. John was elected Treasurer of the New York Intellectual Property Law Association and recently nominated for Second Vice President. John was born in Yonkers, NY in 1948. He was a 1970 cum laude graduate of Princeton University and earned his J.D. from Stanford Law School in 1973. John was a true gentlemen, a brilliant lawyer and a friend to many. His wit, wisdom and ability to light up a room with laughter and song will long be remembered.

To the Editor: I disagree with Maureen Dowd's take on Michelle Obama's public airing of Barack Obama's domestic dirty laundry (''She's Not Buttering Him Up,'' column, April 25). I think that it is politically brilliant for three reasons:

Just two weeks after Simon & Schuster indefinitely postponed a book tour for Deidre Imus, the wife of the talk show host Don Imus, the publisher has quietly reinstated two appearances -- with Mr. Imus possibly along for the ride. The couple will be at R. J. Julia, a bookstore in Madison, Conn., on May 9 and at the public library in Westport, Conn., on May 22 to promote ''Green This! Volume 1: Greening Your Cleaning,'' a paperback guide to environmentally friendly house cleaning. ''There are many booksellers who wanted her to appear and still do,'' David Rosenthal, publisher of Simon & Schuster, said. Mr. Imus, he added, had offered to join his wife, but the details have not yet been worked out. The book was published April 10, just days before CBS Radio canceled ''Imus in the Morning'' after he made racially and sexually derogatory remarks about the Rutgers University women's basketball team. A day after the cancellation, Simon & Schuster postponed Ms. Imus's tour, citing the ''enormous pressure that Deirdre and her family are under.'' That tour was also to have included numerous television appearances, with Mr. Imus included on two of them: ''Larry King Live'' on CNN and ''The Tim Russert Show'' on CNBC. Victoria Meyer, a spokeswoman for Simon & Schuster, said that television appearances were again under discussion but that nothing had been scheduled. Ms. Imus is donating all the profits from the book -- including her seven-figure advance for the current book and four others -- to the couple's ranch for children with cancer in New Mexico. MOTOKO RICH

ALPERT--Warren. A Memorial Service celebrating the life of entrepreneur and philanthropist Warren Alpert will be held on Sunday, April 29 at 11:30am, at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, New York City. Mr. Alpert served as past President of Sutton Place Synagogue.
To the Editor: Re ''Pill That Eliminates the Period Gets Mixed Reviews'' (front page, April 20):

A soldier stationed at the Fort Drum Army base in upstate New York and his wife were attacked by nearly a dozen fellow soldiers at the couple's off-base apartment this week in retaliation for a restraining order the wife recently filed against another soldier, the authorities said yesterday. The couple -- Carl Laws, 22, and Emily Hernandez, 21 -- were inside their apartment on Virginia Smith Drive in Calcium, N.Y., on Wednesday shortly before 10 p.m., the New York State police said, when a group of soldiers came in and attacked them.

Gere Conciliates A day after a judge in India issued a warrant for his arrest for kissing the Bollywood actress Shilpa Shetty in public, Richard Gere offered an apology and asked the media ''to end the circus'' over the matter, Reuters reported yesterday. Mr. Gere's conciliatory statement marked a change from Thursday, when he said on ''The Daily Show With Jon Stewart'' that the controversy was the fault of ''a very small, right-wing, very conservative political party in India,'' adding that he expected the warrant to be thrown out. But yesterday, the actor, who twirled Ms. Shetty in his arms, dipped her backward and then kissed her several times on the cheek at an event in New Delhi this month to promote AIDS awareness among Indian truckers (above), said in a statement that ''my clumsy attempt at a 'Shall We Dance' dance move was a naïve misread of Indian customs.'' He added that he had intended no offense and described the charity event as a celebration of courageous people fighting H.I.V. and AIDS in India. And Shetty Diversifies As Mr. Gere sought to calm India's kiss-troubled waters, Ms. Shetty, the kissee and the winner of Britain's reality television show ''Celebrity Big Brother,'' said she would open a chain of Indian curry houses in Britain, Reuters reported. Ms. Shetty, who became a popular figure in Britain after she was insulted by some of her ''Big Brother'' housemates, triggering allegations of racial abuse, was reported in an Indian daily to be starting a chain of curry restaurants in the country, to be named the Shilpa Shetty Dining Hall. Albee Presents The playwright Edward Albee inaugurated a new drama award on Thursday, presenting the Yale Drama Series prize for aspiring playwrights to an Irish writer for a play about Siamese twins, Reuters reported. John Austin Connolly, a retired psychologist from Dublin, is the first winner of the new competition for emerging playwrights, with a prize of $10,000. Mr. Albee judged the competition, which drew more than 500 entries, organizers said. Mr. Connolly's play ''The Boys From Siam'' is based loosely on the lives of Chang and Eng Bunker, conjoined twins who in the 19th century became the original so-called Siamese twins. The play will be published by Yale University Press. Courts Giveth and Taketh Hugh Grant, who was arrested Wednesday by police over allegations that he threw a container of baked beans at a photographer, accepted undisclosed damages Friday from a British newspaper publisher over false claims about his relationships with his former girlfriends Jemima Khan and Elizabeth Hurley, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Grant had sued Associated Newspapers, publisher of The Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday, over stories published in February. Mr. Grant's lawyer, Simon Smith, said the actor would give the money to a cancer charity. In a statement, Mr. Grant said he had taken legal action because he was tired of the newspapers ''publishing almost entirely fictional articles about my private life for their own financial gain.'' Associated Newspapers apologized to Mr. Grant and agreed to pay his legal costs. Footnotes Kevin Kline will make his New York Philharmonic debut as the narrator of Prokofiev's ''Peter and the Wolf,'' July 5 at 7:30 p.m. and July 6 at 8 p.m. at Avery Fisher Hall, and on July 7 at 8 p.m. at the Bethel Woods Center for the Arts in upstate New York. The Mexican singer Mariano Barba dominated the 2007 Billboard Latin Music Awards on Thursday, even winning for top song of the year, a prize usually reserved for pop stars like Shakira, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Barba won three awards in the Mexican regional music category, and his ballad ''Aliado del Tiempo'' (''Ally of Time'') won for hot Latin song. Colombia's Shakira and the Haitian-American rapper and producer Wyclef Jean won best duet for ''Hips Don't Lie.'' The Venezuelan singer Ricardo Montaner was honored for his work with disabled children.

Allegedly as mayor of New York City, he befriended them. As a presidential candidate, he denounces the proposed legislation offered by President Bush that would provide illegals with amnesty.

A court in Milan upheld the acquittal of the former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, on corruption charges. The court upheld a 2004 decision that cleared Mr. Berlusconi, who is Italy's richest man. He had been accused of paying a $434,000 bribe to a Rome judge in 1991 to rule in his favor during the takeover battle for an Italian food conglomerate. The prosecutors had challenged the earlier acquittal and had asked for a five-year sentence. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

Philip Johnson's Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., will open to the public for the first time on Monday. The architect, who died in 2005, donated the house and its 47-acre property to the National Trust for Historic Preservation, which is starting a study center on the estate. The 1949 house, above, a single room 56 feet by 32 feet, is among the symbols of Modernist architecture, and Mr. Johnson, who died there at 98, had wanted the estate to become a museum. Three other structures on the site, also designed by Mr. Johnson, will be open as well. Two contain art that he collected with his partner, David Whitney, who also died in 2005. Tours, at $25 for 90 minutes and $40 for two hours, are limited to 10 people and require reservations; the official opening is June 23. The house will be closed from November to April each year. Reservations: philipjohnsonglasshouse.org ROBIN POGREBIN

To the Editor: ''The Plot Against Medicare,'' by Paul Krugman (column, April 20), and your April 21 editorial ''The Medicare Privatization Scam'' correctly noted the higher costs of private for-profit health insurance. They might also have noted that a recent J. D. Powers survey found consumers more satisfied with not-for-profit private insurance plans than with investor-owned plans.

Life today is lived on slippery slopes. Which ones seize our attention and crystallize our fears? What moral outrages or absurdities, lurking at the bottom, stir our energies? How steep is the incline? Where can we throw up a railing, dig a trench, clear a landing, keep our footing? Questions like these determine a great deal of public moral debate. That fact was amply demonstrated by the Supreme Court's decision upholding the constitutionality of the Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act of 2003 and the reactions the ruling engendered. There was wide agreement that the ruling would directly affect few abortions but wide disagreement on what the ruling meant.

An article in Business Day on Monday about start-up companies pursuing the idea of advertising-supported digital music misspelled part of the name of a company that was being formed to sell such ads. It is Rebel Digital, not Rebal.
A leader of Al Qaeda was captured last fall and held in a secret prison, then moved last week to Guantánamo Bay, officials said. Page A9.

China named Yang Jiechi, who was ambassador to the United States from 2001 to 2005, to become foreign minister, shuffling its diplomatic team as its rising economic power has given it greater sway in world affairs. Mr. Yang, 56, formerly a vice minister, is fluent in English and well known for a courteous but cautious manner. He replaces Li Zhaoxing, another English speaker and former ambassador to Washington, who is 66. No reason was given for the replacement, but Mr. Li had passed the retirement age for ministerial officials. Mr. Yang assumes the helm at a time when China has greatly expanded its diplomatic activities around the world, especially in Asia and Africa, and as its economic growth and increased military spending have raised concerns in some quarters that it may begin to challenge Washington for leadership in world affairs. JOSEPH KAHN

Post, member of New York Artists/Craftmans Guild, and longtime member of the PW Library Art Advisory Council. She will be missed by all. A mentor to many and an inspiration to all who knew her. In lieu of flowers: contributions to JCC Ceramic Studio, 334 Amsterdam Ave., NY, NY 10023.

The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved the lifting of a 2001 blockade of the sale of so-called blood diamonds from Liberia that fueled wars in West Africa. Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, the Liberian president, had pressed for an end to the embargo as necessary to revive the economy of her impoverished nation, and Emyr Jones Parry, left, Britain's ambassador to the United Nations, said the decision reflected confidence that the country now met the standards of the Kimberley Process, an industry initiative certifying the origins of diamonds entering international trade. The Council lifted similar restrictions on Liberian timber sales in June. WARREN HOGE

Those drafted in the first round of the N.F.L. draft will wonder what lies ahead. A look back at the 1997 class provides a glance, both promising and sobering. Of the 30 players chosen in the first round that day, 13 are still in the league. One is dead, and another is in prison. The rest are moving on with their lives. ''Enjoy it -- you've earned it,'' said Tommy Knight, a cornerback from Iowa chosen ninth over all in 1997, on what he would tell this year's class. Knight, who played seven seasons, lives in Chandler, Ariz., and hopes to build a broadcasting career. ''But be smart with your money, plan for your future and enjoy your time.''

CAPORALE--Ralph Jr., March 12, 1917-April 24, 2007. WWII Veteran. Inspirational Educator and Civic Leader. Adjunct Professor, Hunter College; Principal, IS 51 Staten Island; Principal, PS 208 Manhattan; Assistant Principal Francis Scott Key JHS, Brooklyn; Math teacher Galvani JHS Manhattan; Advocate for increased funding for education; early organizer of teachers (HSTA ''picket''), leading to creation of UFT with Al Shanker and other pioneers; CSA; Exec. Board JHS Principals Association. Devoted, beloved, extraordinary husband to Stella, father to Lynn, Judy, Barbara, Jill; father-in-law to Jeff Lape; grandfather to Brooks, Michael, and Parker Lape and Rockella Caporale. Gentle, upbeat, warm, hard-working, generous, compassionate, determined, humanitarian. Loved by so many. Asked that his students would take with them ''an awareness... of the need for compassion towards others, and growth in the knowledge and skills needed for a full and rich life.'' Donations, to support education and other programs for children in NY and around the world, to the Ralph and Stella Caporale Fund of the NY Community Trust. Taken painfully from us due to medical misjudgments. Services Riverside Chapel 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Manhattan. 2pm Sunday April, 29.

Law enforcement officials said they had arrested two drug dealers who disguised themselves as Mexican soldiers last year, crossed into Texas and confronted sheriff's deputies and police officers. The suspects, Óscar Alonso Candelaria Escajeda and Iván Gándara Trejo, were caught Thursday in Ciudad Juárez, across the border from El Paso. The American authorities initially thought the men were soldiers, and the January 2006 incident strained relations between the countries. MARC LACEY

YEARGANS--Kay (nee Schneeweiss). 80. Died unexpectedly on April 26, 2007. Beloved mother of Kara, devoted sister of Sam and Sarah, and aunt of Elliot and Sheryl Gordon. Service Tuesday, May 1st at 2pm at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave., Manhattan.

It was another busy week for Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, which joined with Stefano Pessina, an Italian billionaire, on Tuesday to claim victory in a takeover battle for Alliance Boots, Britain's largest drugstore chain, sealing Europe's biggest leveraged buyout. Kohlberg Kravis and Mr. Pessina, Alliance Boots' deputy chairman and its largest shareholder, agreed to pay £11.1 billion ($22 billion) for Alliance Boots after raising their bid three times.

SCHIFF--Charles R., 88, a longtime resident of New York, died April 21, 2007. He was the husband of Carolyn (Sydell) Schiff. Born in Spring Lake, New Jersey, he was a son of the late Harry and Rachel (Salzman) Schiff. Mr. Schiff was a graduate of New York University and an owner of the former Superior Manufacturing and In strument Corp. in Long Island City, NY. Besides his wife, he is survived by his daughter, Suzannah Schiff Holiday of MA; his sister, Doris Greenberg of NYC; his granddaughter, Courtney; and several nieces and nephews. He was the brother of the late Bernice Switzen. Interment was in Rhode Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to your favorite charity. Services by SugarmanSinai Memorial Chapel.

In June 2001, Fortune magazine put Steven P. Jobs on its cover. This, I realize, is not exactly breaking news; the magazine put Mr. Jobs on its cover with shameless regularity. This time was different, though. The headline read, ''Inside the Great CEO Pay Heist,'' and Mr. Jobs, Apple's legendary chief executive, was showcased not because he had some slick new product to peddle, but because in January 2000, he had been granted 10 million stock options.

The Central Intelligence Agency held a captured Qaeda leader in a secret prison since last fall and transferred him last week to the American military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, officials said Friday. Abd al-Hadi al-Iraqi, an Iraqi Kurd who is said to have joined Al Qaeda in the late 1990s and ascended to become a top aide to Osama bin Laden, is the first terrorism suspect known to have been held in secret C.I.A. jails since President Bush announced the transfer of 14 captives to Guantánamo Bay last September.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Thursday about receiver Calvin Johnson on the eve of the N.F.L. draft misattributed a quotation about the influence of his family's values on Johnson. It was Johnson's father, Calvin Sr. -- not Johnson himself -- who said the family ''wouldn't tolerate a lot of being foolish.'' The article also referred imprecisely to Johnson's leaping ability. He performed an 11-foot-7-inch standing long jump, not just a long jump.
ADAM--Yehuda, M.D., died on March 3rd. Missed by wife Eva; children Ron and Orit; and grandchildren Oren and Ronah. Call 011-972-9957-2664. Jutka and Ervin

A picture caption in The Arts last Saturday with an article about ''India Now,'' a film series at the Museum of Modern Art, included erroneous information from the museum about the actress shown in a scene from ''Dor,'' a film in the series. She was Gul Panag -- not Ayesha Takia, one of the movie's stars.

Blue chip stocks surged all week as many big companies reported better-than-expected results, though mixed economic data might quiet the enthusiasm next week. No such hesitation was evident among cash-rich equity buyers, though, as acquisitions continued apace, one with a new feature. A DOW MILESTONE -- The Dow Jones industrial average broke through the 13,000 mark this week and kept climbing, even as concerns mounted about the slowing economy and the housing market.

NACEY--John, on April 26, 2007. Beloved husband of Susan, loving father of Ellen, Kathy, Hillary and Jeffrey. Adoring grandfather of Emily, Lauren, Chloe, Celine, Sophie, Kristin and Kathy. Great-grandfather of Bronwyn and Gemma. Dear father-in-law of Christine, Richard and Robert. Service Sunday, 11:15am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

An article on Tuesday about a Congressional hearing in Brooklyn at which speakers urged the Environmental Protection Agency to address contamination and medical problems in areas outside Lower Manhattan resulting from the Sept. 11 attack included incorrect information about the hearing from a spokeswoman for the E.P.A. Although the agency itself was not invited to testify, the agency's inspector general, who operates independently, was. (He declined the invitation.)

An article Thursday about the formal start of Senator John McCain's campaign for the Republican presidential nomination misspelled the surname of the United States attorney general, whom Mr. McCain urged to resign, in two of four references. The attorney general is Alberto R. Gonzales, not Gonzalez.

The freefall in the housing market continued, but evidence this week suggested the problems would not cause widespread damage to the economy. Existing home sales last month suffered their biggest monthly decline since 1989. And while new home sales rose slightly last month, the government said that its calculations of new home sales in December, January and February overestimated the strength of the market. But outside real estate, the picture was less bleak. Durable goods orders, an important measure of business investment, rose for the second consecutive month. And the Federal Reserve's beige book, which monitors economic activity across the 12 Fed regions, found moderate growth in most areas, a slight improvement from its last report. Housing sales were poor in most places, but consumer spending was healthy and prices were largely steady.

Grandmother of William (Aly), Joanna, Julie, Robert, Daniel, and Benjamin. Greatgrandmother of Mackenzie, Zoe, and Elijah. A sports article yesterday about quarterback JaMarcus Russell's emergence as a star at Louisiana State University referred imprecisely to one of his statistics. Russell had 342 passes during his senior season, not in his collegiate career. (His career number was 797.)
In the hours after he coached Pakistan's national team to an embarrassing World Cricket Cup loss in Jamaica, Bob Woolmer was murdered by strangulation. The police have confirmed that much.

Last week saw the end of a little drama that had been playing out on the campus of the University of Rhode Island for some months. On April 26 the student senate turned back a committee recommendation to "derecognize" the College Republicans because the group refused to apologize for one of its actions. What the College Republicans had done was invite applications for the "First Annual White Heterosexual Male Scholarship," otherwise known by the acronym WHAM. Applicants were asked, first, to certify that they were indeed white, heterosexual, American and male and then to answer two questions: "In 100 words or less, what does being a White Heterosexual American Male mean to you? As a White Heterosexual American Male, what adversities have you had to deal with and overcome?"Many of the 40 or so who sent in applications recognized the satirical intention (to ridicule and parody raced-based scholarships and other forms of campus affirmative action) of the obviously bogus scholarship and wrote in the same spirit. But the student senate was not amused, and in February the Student Organizations Advisory and Review Committee demanded that the College Republicans: A) not award the $100 scholarship, B) apologize in writing for having violated the anti-discrimination section of the senate's bylaws, and C) seek permission from the senate before mounting any programs in the next 12 months. The group cheerfully agreed to A - why not? - and declined to comply with B and C.
Todd Pletcher has won a lot of races, but never the Kentucky Derby. Will this be his year?

If you want your jaw to drop, if you want to see an extraordinary meeting and mélange of two worlds, to more fully understand what the past meant and what the present means...watch this absolutely amazing moment of Nick Heidfeld driving around the old Nurburgring this weekend in today's Formula One car. Try to find the video footage; I just watched it at this site where BMW Sauber made it available, but there may be other places.
The 2007 N.F.L. Draft is officially over. The last player picked was Ramzee Robinson, a cornerback from Alabama who went to the Detroit Lions.

There are only seventeen picks left! Our long journey is almost over. I am relieved and saddened at the same time. The big question now is: Who will be Mr. Irrelevant? The title (and a free trip to Disneyland) goes to the last player drafted in the seventh and final round. Detroit holds the final pick (255th over all). It's a compensatory selection (see my "E=MCompensatory2" entry from yesterday for an explanation of compensatory picks).
A roundup of real estate-related news:

Things on this end are dragging. We're going into our 49th hour (at least it feels that way). I see lots of people either napping or kicking back in their chairs. The liveliest people here are the talking heads on television. These guys must drink a lot of caffeine. There are two networks covering the draft, ESPN and NFL Network, which was launched in November 2003 and began covering the draft last season. They both have stages at Radio City, recognizable on-air personalities and plenty of airtime to fill. But it is sort of an odd scene since they are competing against each other for viewers. ESPN is clearly the top dog here. But both broadcasts are being shown on oversized screens (without sound). According to an NFL official, preliminary ratings indicate this will be the second-highest-rated draft ever, behind last year's draft.

It's very moving meeting all these bright young people who won't get into Harvard. Recent news articles make it sound unbearably tragic. Several Ivies, including Harvard, rejected a record number of applicants this year.

We're getting to the bottom of the barrel now. Only 54 picks before the draft is declared done. The Green Bay Packers had three consecutive picks in the middle of the sixth round, 191 to 193. Were they able to find value? They picked Korey Hall (linebacker, Boise State), Desmond Bishop (linebacker, California) and Mason Crosby (kicker, Colorado). Crosby is the only player of the three I had heard of. He was the third kicker taken in the draft, and he can consistently hit from beyond 50 yards. So, yes, I'd say they found value with such a late pick. And there are other value picks out there, such as Jacob Ford, a defensive end from Central Arkansas.
I'm always impressed by how many Yankees fans wear players' uniforms or T-shirts to the games. Every time I look down from my press box seat here, it seems like every third fan has a different shirt.

I was close. Houston went for help along the offensive line, and they stayed in the neighborhood. Only they went with Kasey Studdard of Texas, not Hall. Keep an eye out for Dallas, which owns the 26th pick in the sixth round (200th over all). They might use it on Hall.
Leana Wen, a medical student from Washington University in St. Louis, and Will Okun, a teacher from Chicago, will travel with Times columnist Nick Kristof on a reporting trip to Africa.

Houston is on the clock right now. Look for them to take Gabe Hall, an offensive lineman from Texas Tech. Hall, a Texas native, would love stay at home and play for the Texans. I heard that the Dallas Cowboys called him today, but that just might be to set up a signing through free agency. Hall played tackle in college but he is big enough (6-foot-4, 313 pounds) to slide to the guard position. The knock on Hall is that he is not physical enough.

The Eagles selected C.J. Gaddis, a safety from Clemson, with the 22nd pick of the fifth round. They took Brent Celek, a tight end from Cincinnati, three picks later. This just gives me another opportunity to pan the Eagles for taking a quarterback with their first pick in the second round yesterday, quarterback Kevin Kolb of Houston. I think the Eagles really wasted a pick there. Their fans booed the Gaddis pick, but I think they are just still fuming about trading with Dallas to get a quarterback.

ESPN just made an interesting point. There are some big-name quarterbacks still out there. Remember Troy Smith? Didn't he win some kind of award this season? The Heisman Trophy winner is still on the board, but his two top receivers at Ohio State (Ted Ginn Jr. and Anthony Gonzalez) were picked in the first round.

Jeff Karstens sat alone on the Yankees' bench during batting practice this morning, a purple-gray bruise covering the lower part of his right leg. He rubbed the bruise now and then, staring impassively out at the field.

Here is some interesting info on Zak DeOssie's father, Steven DeOssie. He was a linebacker and a long snapper for Boston College and then three N.F.L. teams, the Cowboys, Giants and Patriots. He played on the Giants team that went to the 1990 Super Bowl. During his career in the N.F.L., he had numerous problems with substance abuse.

Where to start? The biggest news this morning is that Orlando Hernandez is flying to New York this afternoon to have his right shoulder examined. Hernandez, who threw a bullpen session yesterday, arrived at RFK Stadium this morning complaining of tightness. Omar Minaya said no specific tests had been ordered, but it's unlikely that Hernandez will make his scheduled start tomorrow against the Marlins. Assuming he can't pitch, they would almost ask Aaron Sele (who threw only 21 pitches Saturday night) to go because Mike Pelfrey threw a bullpen session this morning in preparation for Tuesday's start.
With the 17th pick in the fourth round (116th over all), the Giants drafted Zak DeOssie, an outside linebacker from Brown. Brown? Does the school really have a football team?
I thought the second day of the draft would be more boring than waiting for the B train to come on a Sunday morning. But we're off to a blazing start.
A huge (HUGE!) trade just happened. The Raiders dealt Randy Moss to the Patriots for New England's fourth-round pick (110th over all). More on this soon

We already have our first brouhaha. Gene Washington of the N.F.L. opened the festivities by announcing the Raiders as the "Los Angeles Raiders." Say what? When he announced the pick minutes later, Michael Bush of Louisville, he carefully referred to the O-a-k-l-a-n-d Raiders. Good thing he didn't mistakenly say they had selected "Reggie" Bush.

An article on March 25 in T: Travel magazine, about the resurgence of Dallas, referred incorrectly to a negative report by The Dallas Morning News on the state of crime, schools and growth in Dallas. The report was published in 2004, not last year. Since then, some improvements have been reported in those areas. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on April 9, and this correction was delayed for research.

A picture caption with an article on Page 44 of The Times Magazine today about the Muslim Brotherhood misstates the dates of the photographs. The protest with brandishing of the Koran, in the first and fourth pictures, was in March of this year, not the fall of 2006. The other two photographs were taken in February of this year (the protester surrounded by the police) and in November 2006 (the protesters holding signs), not the in the spring of this year.

I agree with many of the points made by Thomas L. Friedman regarding the need to convert to a more sustainable energy policy (April 15). But I cannot believe that he uncritically accepts the inclusion of increased nuclear power as a part of the solution. Nuclear power is anything but “clean.” Sure, the actual nuclear process produces no carbon dioxide, but the mining and transport process is itself CO2 intensive. And we still have no long-term solution to the problem of nuclear waste.
