To the Editor: I’m afraid that William Logan’s review of Derek Walcott’s “Selected Poems”(April 8) is shot through within accuracies. For instance, Logan asserts that the poetry Walcott has written since receiving the Nobel Prize in 1992 — particularly his most recent volume, “The Prodigal” (2004) — is “haunted by the dissolutions of mortality” and reads like a “roll call of the dead”; then Logan cites, as an example, Walcott’s “elegy for Joseph Brodsky” and quotes the first stanza of “The Forests of Europe.” But “The Forests of Europe” is neither an example of Walcott’s post-Nobel work nor an elegy for Brodsky; the poem was published in “The Star-Apple Kingdom” in 1979, some 13 years before Walcott received the Nobel Prize, and some 17 years before Brodsky’s death.

Smile at a stranger in Russia and he might think you're an idiot. Gesture ''O.K.'' to someone in France, and it might come across as an insult. Shake a woman's hand in India and risk a comeuppance. These are some of the lessons one can glean from the ''Culture Smart!'' book series, which explores local customs and etiquette and is now available in the United States. The compact editions, published in England since 2003, cost $9.95 in stores and cover dining, business rituals and etiquette, gift-giving and general local culture. There are 49 titles, including Argentina, Vietnam, China and Japan. In June, editions on Austria, Chile, Guatemala and Indonesia will hit the stores (www.culturesmartguides.com or www.randomhouse.com). Moms celebrating Mother's Day in New York are the focus of a package offered by the Paramount Hotel (www.nycparamount.com) and Exhale Spa. The one-night package, which costs $513, includes a deluxe room for two, 30-minute fusion massage, facial, lavender paraffin manicure, Exhale products and a four-course meal in the Mezzanine Restaurant (only on Mother's Day, May 13, from noon to 10 p.m.). The experience is available by phone reservation only at (212) 764-5500. Hertz customers may now rent a 2008 Ford Shelby GT-H Mustang convertible (below) at some airports. The vehicle, part of the company's Fun Collection, has a starting rate of about $140 a day. Other cars in the collection include Mazda Miatas, Jeep Wranglers and H3 Hummers (www.hertz.com). From June 1 through September, Preferred Hotel Group will spearhead a charitable program called ''The Giving Room.'' Participating hotels and resorts, including the Majestic in Barcelona and the Derek in Houston, will donate 10 percent of the proceeds of a designated room or suite toward a specific charity. Some properties, like Peter Island Resort in the British Virgin Islands, are offering an entire villa. For more information, visit www.phggiftts.com. HILARY HOWARD

Public Service Electric and Gas has said it will lend nearly $100 million to customers to install solar panels over the next two years, hoping to reduce pollution and move residents across the state toward cleaner fuel. The initiative meets goals outlined in New Jersey's energy master plan and will be available to all P.S.E.&G. customers by the end of this year, if the State Board of Public Utilities gives its approval. The plan calls for 20 percent of the state's power to be fueled by renewable energy by 2020.

Jan Brenneisen, 28, from Rostock, Germany: ''I'm a professional tattoo artist, but I had never had anything to do with the text-based style of tattoos that the monks at this temple do. I was fascinated. While I was helping out during the ceremonies, calming the people being tattooed and holding their skin taut, the monk tattooed someone with a pyramid-like design. I liked it and said, 'Beautiful.' He looked at me slightly surprised. The monk said the more standard kind of tattoos like I already had were beautiful, and that the tattoos he gives were not nice looking but rather useful. Each evening after we helped the monk, he said he'd like to give us tattoos. He thought it would do us good, protect us, bring us luck. Each day I said, 'No, maybe tomorrow.' After three days, I finally said yes.'' As told to Tim Mohr

Janaki String Trio: 'Debut' Janaki String Trio. Yarlung Records 62376; CD. THE Janaki String Trio, formed in Los Angeles in 2005, clearly regards Krzysztof Penderecki's String Trio as its signature work. A vigorous reading of the work was the centerpiece of the group's New York debut concert early this year, and it is offered twice -- in a studio production and a live recording -- on this introductory CD. The difference between the two recorded accounts is not enormous: the live version is a hair faster and perhaps a touch wilder in spirit. Replacing one with another work would have been better. Still, it is easy to see the Penderecki's appeal to these musicians, whose repertory tilts toward contemporary music. It begins with an explosion of fortissimo percussive chords, repeated with an almost brutal vehemence. In the work's 12-minute span, its two connected movements push toward extremes of brashness and beauty and demand an interpretive flexibility to make the transitions plausible.

Your article might have mentioned the power women are exercising in the marketplace by buying ''green'' products. In the long run, of course, we need regulation and legislation. In the short term, intervention by those who rule the marketplace -- women -- may provide the tipping point.

It is no secret that some of the richest candidates are some of the most successful. The combined net worth of Mayor Michael Bloomberg, Gov. Jon Corzine of New Jersey and Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York is enough to buy not just an election, but a small country. The way to deal with this mega-millionaire's advantage is not to open the floodgates to large contributions from other wealthy people, companies and unions, the way New York State does now. It is to offer public financing to candidates who are qualified but not rich.

A chart last Sunday on daily gun deaths in the United States included an extraneous symbol in some editions. The symbol, a bullet, represented a single death of a person over 40. There should have been 39 bullets depicted, as the text indicated, not 40.

Andrew Russo: 'Dirty Little Secret' Andrew Russo, pianist. Endeavour Classics END 1019; CD. IN a recent recital at Zankel Hall, the pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard mapped a sweeping genealogy of solo keyboard music through short compositions and excerpted movements. The program, while audacious, inspired debate, since Mr. Aimard's representation of the 20th and 21st centuries clung largely to a post-Schoenberg strain of bristling modernism, ignoring more playful alternatives.

To the Editor: Regarding ''36 Hours: Portland, Ore.'' by David Laskin (April 15): Living in Portland's ''highly caffeinated neighbor to the north,'' I often spend time in the Rose City and can attest to the delights of staying at the quirky Kennedy School hotel. Sometimes, however, its mellow new-age livability can be overbearing. Once, I awoke at 5 a.m. to the sound of a bird aggressively chirping, seemingly just outside my window. ''Wow,'' I thought, ''that bird is loud!'' The initially pleasant but incessant warbling soon became simply annoying because I could no longer sleep.

ON a Sunday morning a few months back, I interviewed my final Harvard applicant of the year. After saying goodbye to the girl and watching her and her mother drive off, I headed to the beach at the end of our street for a run. It was a spectacular winter day, bright, sunny and cold; the tide was out, the waves were high, and I had the beach to myself. As I ran, I thought the same thing I do after all these interviews: Another amazing kid who won't get into Harvard.

Oleg V. Deripaska, the second-richest man in Russia, further pushed the boundaries of his automobiles-to-aluminum empire last week when his holding company, Basic Element, bought 30 percent of the Austrian construction company Strabag for $1.6 billion. Mr. Deripaska, 39, a former nuclear physicist, along with the other Russian billionaires known as oligarchs, is making ever-bolder forays outside Russia. In recent years, Basic Element has snapped up assets from Guyana to Britain.

Connecticut last week became the first state to take action against a new high-caffeine energy drink called Cocaine -- marketed as ''a legal alternative'' -- when authorities ordered that some 300 cases be held in warehouses. The move came a week after Attorney General Richard Blumenthal threatened to sue the maker of the drink, Redux Beverages of Las Vegas, and minority groups expressed outrage at the drink's name, saying Redux was preying on vulnerable urban communities.

''We need the first green president,'' Friedman says. But we would be selling ourselves short to suggest that we never had a president who was concerned about protecting the environment. We've had earth-conscious presidents from the start. To quote George Washington on crop management: ''Nothing in my opinion would contribute more to the welfare of these states than the proper management of our lands.'' And it was only 30 years ago that we had our most green president, Jimmy Carter, leading the way to reduce our oil usage. We need to get our green groove back.

EARLIER this year, Gov. Eliot Spitzer reached an agreement with the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe that brought New York one step closer to having a $600 million Las Vegas-style casino in Sullivan County, in the Catskills. The casino, which still needs final federal approval and faces a lawsuit from environmental groups, could generate up to $100 million for the state and $20 million for the county a year. But the economic and environmental downside of this deal needs to be more carefully examined. Particularly worrisome is the casino's planned location within 12 miles of the Catskill Park and New York City's (and parts of Westchester's) water supply.

To the Editor: Re ''When You Meet an Imus,'' by Bob Morris (Age of Dissonance, April 22): As a criminal defense attorney, dealing with racial prejudice is important in jury selection. I was taught to ask a series of questions about prejudice and bias: Ever heard an ethnic joke? Ever told one, or have one told about your ''kind'' while you were present? The follow-up questions about what they might have thought about it and why they picked on a particular group, led to other questions: When you heard it, and didn't like it, did you say anything about it? When you said it, did anyone tell you it wasn't funny?

A picture caption with an article on Page 44 of The Times Magazine today about the Muslim Brotherhood misstates the dates of the photographs. The protest with brandishing of the Koran, in the first and fourth pictures, was in March of this year, not the fall of 2006. The other two photographs were taken in February of this year (the protester surrounded by the police) and in November 2006 (the protesters holding signs), not the in the spring of this year.

PROTERO--Dodi, 76, died of heart and lung failure on April 22, 2007. Born in Toronto, Canada, she went to Italy at 17 and made her European debut with the San Carlo Opera, Naples, in 1956 in 'Die Zauberflote'. Other opera engagements followed in Salzburg, Cologne, Glyndebourne, The English National Opera. She returned to Canada in the mid 1960's and sang many roles with the Canadian Opera Company, Toronto. As a Voice Teacher she was on the faculties of the School of Fine Arts, Banff, Alberta, Canada, The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, The Academy of Vocal Arts, Philadelphia, Opera Music Theater Institute (OMTI), Newark, NJ, The Juilliard School, Evening Division. She is survived by her sister Shirley and six nieces and nephews. A Memorial Service will be held on May 23 at 5pm at The Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th St. at Central Park West. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The American Heart Association, 122 East 42nd St., NYC, NY 10017.

WIENER--Ernest Guest, 91, died peacefully in his sleep, surrounded by his family, on April 10th, 2007. He was in hospice care for liver cancer and lived with his daughter, Ann, in Riverside, California for his last five months. Born in Pilzen, he left Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia in February, 1940. In December, 1942 he joined the US Army Air Corps and became a US citizen a few months later. Sent to England with the 392nd Heavy Bombardment Group, he married Peggy Rhodes in December, 1944 and had four children. He worked as a diplomat for the US Department of State from 1948-1970. He served in Washington DC and Germany, (Berlin, Frankfurt and Bonn), Vienna, Geneva, New York, Moscow and Brasilia. He retired in Brazil and worked for Standard Electrica (ITT) in Rio de Janeiro for ten years until he retired again, to Key Biscayne, Florida.

THE rumors have thinned the morning lines of immigrant men who gather on Morris Street, looking for work. The news -- that the local police might have a hand enforcing federal immigration policy -- has spread throughout this historic, diverse town on the edge of New Jersey's horse country, and a few people have even started to move away. It started in early March with Mayor Donald Cresitello's proposal to enroll the police in a small but growing federal program -- now in place in 10 states -- that trains local officers to help enforce federal immigration laws.

A CONTRACTUAL THING The News -- Rosie O'Donnell said she would leave the ''The View'' in June after failing to agree to a contract extension with ABC. Behind the News -- Ms. O'Donnell has raised the profile of the morning kaffeeklatsch since joining in September and dispensing provocative views on everything from the Iraq war to Oprah Winfrey. There was also her running verbal brawl with Donald Trump. (She called him a ''snake-oil salesman,'' among other things; he called her ''disgusting,'' among other things.) Ratings rose by 17 percent. Of her departure, she said, ''That's show biz.'' CASUALTY OF CORRUPTION The News -- Klaus Kleinfeld, the head of Siemens, the German engineering company and manufacturer, said he would step down in the face of a corruption scandal. Behind the News -- Though Mr. Kleinfeld has not been implicated, he said he would leave in September to give Siemens ''clarity about its leadership.'' Prosecutors are investigating reports that some $500 million in bribes were paid to foreign officials and that other bribes went to an Italian energy firm and a labor leader who represented Siemens workers. The scandals have shaken corporate Germany. A LITTLE TOO PERFECT The News -- The dean of admissions at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology resigned after admitting that she fabricated her academic credentials. Behind the News -- The dean, Marilee Jones, has been at the forefront of the debate over college admissions criteria, urging stressed-out students competing for admission to elite colleges to calm down and stop trying to be perfect. In a new book, Ms. Jones warns that a ''fear of imperfection'' among students will ''stifle their creativity, impede their ability to experience joy and ultimately interfere with their success.'' NEXT YEAR, SOMEONE NEW The News -- President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia reiterated his intention to step down when his second term ends next spring. Behind the News -- Russia's Constitution bars the president from serving three consecutive terms, but there have been calls by politicians loyal to Mr. Putin to set the rule aside. In his annual address to Parliament, Mr. Putin said, ''In the spring of next year, my duties end and the next state-of-the nation speech will be delivered by a different head of state.'' Mr. Putin took power in 1999 after the surprise resignation of Boris Yeltsin, who died last week. FLOATING AWAY The News -- The British cosmologist Stephen Hawking, who is paralyzed by Lou Gehrig's disease, escaped Earth's gravitational pull on a zero-gravity jet flight. Behind the News -- The jet flies a roller-coaster trajectory to produce periods of weightlessness. Dr. Hawking, 65, who has been in a wheelchair for nearly four decades, floated weightless eight times, each for about 25 seconds. ''It was amazing,'' said Dr. Hawking, who says he believes that humanity's survival depends on colonizing other planets. He hopes to make a suborbital flight next. ''Space,'' he said, ''here I come.''
To the Editor: Re ''Passing the Baton: Be Bold, New York [April 15]:

KAYE--Bernard, 85, died from complications of diabetes and Alzheimer's. Born in Brooklyn, the son of Bessie and Morris Kabikow, he grew up in impoverished circumstances. His entire emotional life was colored by the hardships of his childhood. His family found the challenge of raising their developmentally delayed son George more than they could cope with. When their parents passed away, he assumed responsibility for George's care. Bernard was predeceased by his four siblings. After his graduation from Brooklyn College in 1942, he served in the US Army. In 1957 he married Sivia Karansky of Boro Park, Brooklyn, and had two children, Beth Kaye and Glenn Novarr. With the encouragement of his in-laws, he became a CPA. His passions were playing tennis and trading stocks. Since June 2005, he lived in Portland, OR. He is survived by his wife and children, who will cherish his memory. Donations appreciated: JDRF and Layton Alzheimer Center, both in Portland OR.

THE managers and coaches for Ardsley's Little League teams squeezed into the child-size seats in the Concord Road Elementary School cafeteria late last month to go over the rules and regulations for this season. Many of the safety procedures were familiar: catchers' masks need a throat guard; no parents on the field; baseball bats must be regulation size. But this policy was addressed for the first time: mandatory limits on the number of pitches.

THE first time I walked into my mother's apartment after she died, I turned and bolted. The smell of her perfume and the sight of her eyeglasses, her magazines and her comb were just too much. But no matter how much I wanted to avoid it, there was the inevitable work of clearing out the place where she had lived for 37 years.

ACKERMAN--Dr. Martin P., 80, died April 24, 2007. Beloved husband of the late Kitty, father of Linda (Alice) and David (Cassie), stepfather of Lori and Jayni, grandfather of Grant and Grace, and stepgrandfather of Irene and Jordan. Captain, United States Air Force, Dental Corps 19491952. Practiced dentistry for 53 years. Police Department, City of New York Honorary Police Surgeon since 1970. He will be deeply missed by all. Contributions may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

I agree with many of the points made by Thomas L. Friedman regarding the need to convert to a more sustainable energy policy (April 15). But I cannot believe that he uncritically accepts the inclusion of increased nuclear power as a part of the solution. Nuclear power is anything but ''clean.'' Sure, the actual nuclear process produces no carbon dioxide, but the mining and transport process is itself CO2 intensive. And we still have no long-term solution to the problem of nuclear waste.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the billionaire businessman Philip F. Anschutz referred incorrectly to the Corporate Library, a research firm that focuses on corporate governance. It is a for-profit business, not a nonprofit.

Jay Leno Some sad news, I'm sure you've heard. The former president of Russia, Boris (Buy Me a Drink) Yeltsin, has passed away. He left behind a bar tab of $3.2 billion. In a speech Sunday, before a church group, San Francisco mayor Gavin Newsom said that he is going to make San Francisco a sanctuary for illegal immigrants so they can go there and not worry about being deported to their home country of Los Angeles.

The ''Living In'' article in the Real Estate section this weekend, about Pleasant Plains, Staten Island, incorrectly describes the borders of the neighborhood. As correctly shown on the map with the article, Pleasant Plains is bordered on the south by the waterfront, on the west by Cunningham Road, on the north by the Korean War Veterans Parkway and on the east by a vague line created by Lemon Creek, Bayview Avenue and Lenevar Avenue.

ORLAND--Paul I., 95, a 1933 graduate of the NYU School of Commerce, passed away on Wednesday, April 25. Beloved husband for 62 years of the late Helen Kurtz Orland. Survived by his loving children Laura (Franklin) Adler and Malcolm (Andrea) Orland and cherished grandchildren Amy and Gabrielle Adler and Daniel and Adam Orland. Funeral services will be held Monday in Los Angeles. In lieu of flowers, donations requested to the charity of your choice.

SZOGYI--Alex, esteemed professor, devoted friend and dear mentor. He brought the world of George Sand to light and to life. Natalie Datlof: Merrick, NY $(6$)SZOGYI--Alex (1929 - 2007), who served as chairperson of Hunter College's Romance Language Department for seven years left us on Monday, April 23. Professor Szogyi's academic accomplishments included more than forty years as a professor at Universities including Yale University, Wesleyan College, CUNY Graduate Center, and Hunter College. He received his undergraduate degree in Mathematics from Brooklyn College and a Ph.D. in French from Yale University. Professor Alex Szogyi was an expert in seventeenth century French literature and advised numerous Ph.D. theses. Professor Szogyi is a former president of Phi Beta Kappa and studied at the Sorbonne in Paris. Alex Szogyi was known for his varied interests and contributions to the theater, film, food, and astrological worlds. He cofounded the APA Theatre Company with Rosemary Harris and Ellis Rabb and the New York chapter of the George Sand Society. He acted in the French film Balzac starring Jeane Moreau and Gerard Depardieu whom he considered dear friends. He was responsible for Lillian Hellman teaching at Hunter College and was a friend of Patricia Highsmith who dedicated one of her novels to Alex. Alex Syogyi did hundreds of astrological consultations with clients ranging from Whoopi Goldberg and Candicae Bergen to Ruth Reichl and was an expert graphologist. He was a food critic with the Village Voice and contributed articles to both Bon Apatite and Gourmet magazines. Professor Szogyi was a member of New York's Century Club. He translated every play written by Anton Chekhov into English and had several of these plays produced in theater productions including OffBroadway. His translation of Maxim Gorky's The Lower Depths is still being produced throughout the country. He was also an expert on the works of the painter Caravaggio. Alex Szogyi was a published Author in the United States and France with works including his novel Carnaval, and books on the pleasures of chocolate, Moliere, and the fables of La Fontaine with preface by Jeanne Moreau and illustrations by Claudine Suret - Canale. Professor Szogyi was a member of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures (NBR) in New York City. Professor Alex Szogyi is survived by his beloved life-partner of forty-six years Philip ''Bill'' Thompson.

''COMMITMENT AND GRACE: THE FILMS OF CARLOS SAURA,'' presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center through Thursday, includes five films by the Spanish filmmaker that delve spectacularly into Spanish dancing. Three -- ''Blood Wedding,'' ''Carmen'' and ''El Amor Brujo'' (''Love the Magician'') -- are collaborations with the flamenco artist Antonio Gades. Mr. Saura's 1992 ''Sevillanas'' is a primer on how to look at and film dance; no master shots for him. And his sweeping 1995 ''Flamenco'' is an ode, majestic yet intimate, not only to the dance form itself but also to a proud nation and the men, women and children who perform it, both famous and unknown. Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5600, filmlinc.com; $11, $7 for members and students. One minute MARK MORRIS is opening the New York Stock Exchange and the next he is (or will be this week) directing and choreographing an opera at the Met. The work, Gluck's ''ORFEO ED EURIDICE,'' stars David Daniels and Maija Kovalevska, and opens Wednesday. This is Mr. Morris's second go at the opera, which he choreographed for a 1996 tour by the Handel and Haydn Society. And he has directed opera before, though never for the august Met. But New York City's favorite Renaissance man of modern may well give the Gluck a whole new look, with a corps that includes members of his own company, costumes by Isaac Mizrahi and sets by the Broadway designer Allen Moyer. Wednesday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 1:30 p.m., Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; sold out. Excerpts from TINA CROLL'S recent ''ANCIENT SPRINGS,'' a dance of airy and mysterious beauty, joy and humor, are being performed this week in the La MaMa Moves festival. Ms. Croll's performers are wittily individual, and they share the program with the endearingly antic Yoshiko Chuma. Wednesday through Saturday, La MaMa, 74A East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 475-7710, lamama.org; $15, $10 for students and 65+.

Tom Glocer, chief executive of the Reuters Group, the news service company based in London, has no qualms about using the photographers on his staff as his own personal camera consultants. He recently polled three of his favorite photographers at the company to find out what would be the best camera to take on his safari to South Africa. Mr. Glocer and his wife, Maarit, headed to the Singita Private Game Reserve in Kruger National Park for a long weekend in late January; they took along a Canon 30D semi-pro digital camera and lens set, as recommended by his photographers. ''I've got the pictures of the big cats to show for it,'' he gloats.

To the Editor: In similar situations, I have found useful the comment, ''I am surprised that you would say that.'' When the offender says something to the effect, ''What did I say?'' I reply, ''You know what you said, and you look much more intelligent than your comment or your question.''

Last fall there was widespread agreement -- and some surprise -- that Daniel Craig, in ''Casino Royale,'' was the best James Bond in a while. It is also generally agreed that no Bond could surpass Sean Connery, who owned the franchise in its first decade. And while I wouldn't necessarily dissent from either consensus, there will always be a special place in my affections for the suave, silly, overblown Bond adventures with Roger Moore. ''THE SPY WHO LOVED ME,'' the best of these, was the first Bond movie I saw in a theater and also one of the first movies to blow me away with its visual and sonic extravagance. In my memory, that Carly Simon theme song played continually for months, though I don't remember if I actually bought the single or just heard it on the radio. ''The Spy Who Loved Me'' will be shown on Wednesday at Film Forum as part of its generous ''VINTAGE 007'' program, which started Friday and will continue through May 17. The Moore and Connery schools are well represented, but what lifts the series above the level of basic-cable weekend marathon is a sidebar, called '' '60s Spies A-Go-Go,'' consisting of lesser-known films that, while not technically James Bond movies, partake of the 007 gestalt of globe-trotting espionage, swordsmanship and superior haberdashery. These range from the Italian horror maestro Mario Bava's crazy ''Danger: Diabolik'' (1968) to Martin Ritt's wrenching and melancholy adaptation of ''The Spy Who Came in From the Cold'' (1965), starring Richard Burton and Claire Bloom, which gives off an existential, political chill far deeper than one of 007's martinis. 209 West Houston Street, South Village, (212) 727-8112, filmforum.org.

To the Editor: Re ''An Accounting of Daily Gun Deaths'' (Week in Review, April 22): Each year, I ask my seniors at Manual Arts High School in South Los Angeles if they have had direct experience with gun violence. They all raise their hands. They say they plot their paths to school based on the safest routes. They say gun violence is a reason that so many of their peers drop out of school. They and their younger siblings don't play outside.
Because of an editing error, the Generations column last Sunday omitted a word from the title of a television show. It is ''Da Ali G Show,'' not ''Da G Show.''

Westchester's 9/11 memorial, ''The Rising'' -- unveiled last September at Kensico Dam Plaza in Valhalla -- is an Eiffel Tower-like sculpture with 109 intersecting steel rods reaching skyward, one for each county resident who perished. There were 110 victims, however.

J. Terrence Lanni, chairman and chief executive of MGM Mirage, has rung up big travel bills on the shareholders' tab in recent years. Perhaps that will change once his $8.7 million condominium in the company's CityCenter development in downtown Las Vegas is ready. According to the casino operator's proxy statement, Mr. Lanni and the controlling shareholder, Kirk Kerkorian, put down 10 percent deposits in January on CityCenter apartments with price tags of more than $8.6 million each.

FRANKEL--Norma, age 74, died on April 26, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Frankel, daughter of the late Harry and Helen Frank, mother of David, Ross, Harriet, and Charles, and daughters-in-law Lynn and Caren and son-in-law Marc. Loving and adoring grandmother of Deborah, Hilary, Melissa, Nina, Bradley, Emily and Leah. Graduate of NYU at age 19, she returned to school for a Masters degree in Library Sciences and served as medical librarian at LIJ Hospital for more than 30 years. Lover of literature, bridge and the NY Mets (she had no choice). Funeral Sunday, April 29 at 9am, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Catharine Margaret Pasmantier Fund, c/o Mark Pasmantier, M.D., 407 E. 70th St., NY, NY 10021.

LEYNSE--Judith Light, 68, died in her sleep on April 15th at her home in New York. Her life was full of hope, love and purpose, and she will be greatly missed by all who knew her. She is survived by her sons, James and Andrew Leynse; their loving wives, Wendy Leynse and Mary Bacon; and two grandchildren, whom she adored. Donations in her name can be made to Primary Stages Co., Temple Emanu-El or the Ronald McDonald House. Services Monday, April 30th, 2pm at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.
To the Editor: Re ''Unsettling History of That Joyous 'Hallelujah' '' [April 8]:
To the Editor: Re ''Corzine's Wild Ride,'' by Jamie Lincoln Kitman (Op-Ed, April 22):

To the Editor: At the insistence of our 11-year-old, environmentally conscious daughter, we are working very hard to become more green. After reading your article, all I can say is that this is one article I can't wait to deposit in the recycling bin. Beth Stone West Bloomfield, Mich.

To the Editor: Oh, please! I was so disgusted by the tone of ''Tweens 'R' Shoppers,'' by Lesley Jane Seymour (April 22), and put off by the photos of these spoiled, super-sophisticated sub-teens. If the majority of children in our country grow up with these values, we're in deep trouble.

Branch Brook Park in Newark has a great many cherry trees, and in the spring, the 360-acre grounds erupt in a flurry of pink and white. But the nearly 2,000 cherry trees the park has are not nearly enough, according to local officials.
Because of an editing error, the Generations column last Sunday omitted a word from the title of a television show. It is ''Da Ali G Show,'' not ''Da G Show.''

To the Editor: So, if Don Imus says ''nappy-headed ho,'' he's a pariah, and should be pilloried. Your friend responds to a question from a stranger that can only remotely be considered race related, and responds with the same epithet against an uninvolved person, and, coming from him as a black person, it is heralded as brilliant repartee against the scourge of racism, or at least social oafishness.

THE rumors have thinned the morning lines of immigrant men who gather on Morris Street, looking for work. The news -- that the local police might have a hand enforcing federal immigration policy -- has spread throughout this historic, diverse town on the edge of New Jersey's horse country, and a few people have even started to move away. It started in early March with Mayor Donald Cresitello's proposal to enroll the police in a small but growing federal program -- now in place in 10 states -- that trains local officers to help enforce federal immigration laws.

To the Editor: Re ''3 Suspects Talk After Iraqi Soldiers Do Dirty Work'' (front page, April 22): This article, which reports that Iraqi security officers beat information out of a suspect, reiterates the danger of permitting, explicitly or implicitly, even some torture when dealing with terror suspects.

KANAREK--Dorothy S., born in NYC on October 20, 1917, passed away on March 23, 2007 in Annandale, VA. Mother of Kathryn James of Annandale, and David A. Kanarek, M.D. (Alexis) of Highland Park, IL. Grandmother of Jordan and Emily Kanarek. Funeral services were held in Virginia on March 29, 2007.

ON a Sunday morning a few months back, I interviewed my final Harvard applicant of the year. After saying goodbye to the girl and watching her and her mother drive off, I headed to the beach at the end of our street for a run. It was a spectacular winter day, bright, sunny and cold; the tide was out, the waves were high, and I had the beach to myself. As I ran, I thought the same thing I do after all these interviews: Another amazing kid who won't get into Harvard.

To the Editor: Re ''At 75, a Battle-Tested but Unwavering Cardinal'' (front page, April 23): Cardinal Edward M. Egan feels that the finances of the Archdiocese of New York are his secret to keep -- or to share only with those he calls ''the best possible people.'' But membership in the Catholic Church that Cardinal Egan serves is not limited to ''the best possible people.''

EMERY--John C., Jr., of New Canaan, CT on April 19, 2007. Retired Chairman of the Board and CEO of Emery Air Freight, a company created by his father. Husband of Fran, father of John Emery, Michael Emery, Ann Emery, Susan Quinby and Tricia McGean. Grandfather of seven. Services will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Darien on Friday, May 11, 2007 at 11:00am. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the St. Croix Foundation for Community Development, 72 Flag Drive, St. Croix., U.S. V.I. 00820 or Person-to-Person, 1864 Post Road, Darien, CT 06820.

To the Editor: ''OSHA Leaves Worker Safety Largely in Hands of Industry'' (front page, April 25) demonstrates how the voluntary compliance approach favored by business interests and put into effect by the Bush administration fails to protect workers' safety and health. Labor's movement for safety and health rights was inspired by the civil rights movement of the 1960s and culminated in the passage of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. For the first time in American history, workers had the right to resist unsafe working conditions, to have OSHA inspect their workplace and to know if the materials they were working with violated OSHA safety standards.

CROSS--Lucille V., died in Auburn, CA, on March 21, 2007, in her 98th year. She formally lived in Pompano Beach, FL, and was the wife of the late Edwin J. Cross, founder of the Wall Street investment firm Roosevelt & Cross. She is survived by her daughter Nancy, of Lake Orion, MI, and her son Edwin J. Cross, Jr., of Meadow Vista, CA, two grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Funeral services will be held on May 5, in Westwood, NJ.

The article alludes to our national addiction to oil, but it is really our addiction to cars. If we had more compact, walkable villages and cities connected by reliable mass transit, we would need fewer cars and less oil.

To the Editor: Kudos to Clyde Haberman for pointing out the facts of congestion pricing in ''Who Pays for Driving in Manhattan?'' (NYC column, April 24). Critics of this proposal are quick to call Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg elitist and eager to repeat their mantra that this will hurt the working class and the boroughs, but the facts simply don't support this. What of the few who drive to work because nearby transit is inefficient? The $500 million a year that congestion pricing will generate for improvements and the corresponding decrease in traffic will benefit the outer boroughs just as much as it will benefit Manhattan. As the mayor said, these improvements would even begin before congestion pricing goes into effect.

Houston's selection of defensive end Mario Williams with the top overall pick in last year's draft elicited loud boos from those in attendance at Reliant Stadium. But when the Texans used the 10th pick yesterday to choose the 19-year-old Louisville defensive tackle Amobi Okoye, they were cheered enthusiastically.

Faced with complaints of censorship from students, Yale University last Monday reversed a ban on the use of realistic-looking prop weapons in plays. The university imposed the ban on April 19, in response to the shootings at Virginia Tech. The Yale Daily News, a student newspaper, reported that two plays made changes last weekend. ''Red Noses'' used wooden swords, while ''Orpheus in the Underworld'' used swords made of balloons.
The 36 Hours column on April 15 about weekend activities in Portland, Ore., misspelled the name of an indie band that performs there. It is the Decemberists, not the Decembrists.

Sunrise Senior Living said last week that it had suspended its chief financial officer -- with pay -- because his actions ''were not consistent with the document retention directives issued by the company.'' The company did not say how long the executive, Bradley B. Rush, would be suspended. Mr. Rush, 46, joined the company in 2005. Sunrise, which operates 440 senior-living and assisted-living facilities, is in the process of restating its financial statements from 2003 through 2005. In February, the company estimated that the restatement could reduce company's profits by as much as $107 million. The company also has an inquiry under way into insider stock sales.

Because of an editing error, the Generations column last Sunday omitted a word from the title of a television show. It is ''Da Ali G Show,'' not ''Da G Show.''

Re ''For N.F.L. Draft, the Biggest (XXXXXXL) Sleeper,'' April 25: Walter Thomas may turn out to be a great player in the N.F.L., but at what price? After recent articles in The Times profiling former N.F.L. players who have Alzheimer's after sustaining head injuries, it seems absurd to put another 370-pound player on the field. The league should calculate the future medical costs of these clashing Goliaths.

ROWE--Jan Olivia. Family, friends, colleagues, and students mourn the death of Dr. Jan Rowe who died on Sunday, April 22, in Seattle. Jan Rowe was born in Statesboro, Georgia in 1947. She received her B.A. and doctorate in Counseling Psychology from Georgia State University. In 1982, Jan Rowe joined the Psychology faculty at Seattle University where she was Chair of the department for 10 years and subsequently became the Director of the graduate program in existential-phenomenological psychology. Dr. Rowe was a dedicated and skilled clinician who provided supervision for graduate students for over 20 years, and taught courses on psychotherapy for both undergraduate and graduate students. She was Co-founder of a Psychotherapy Cooperative in Seattle which provides affordable therapy to the community. As a researcher she was a pioneer in developing collaborative approach to qualitative research and in studying the experience of forgiveness. Above all, she will be remembered for the depth of her humanity and her down-to-earth wisdom. She is survived by her sisters Jill Rowe of Decatur, GA, and Joy Barnes, her brother -inlaw Al Barnes, and nephew Todd Barnes of Oakland, CA, niece Dhia Barnes, and greatniece Soleil Jordan of New York City, as well as many other family members and loved ones. Jan Rowe will be greatly missed in the Seattle University Psychology community.

The Israeli Army shot four Palestinian militants who were trying to plant explosives near the border fence in Gaza on Saturday morning, killing three and seriously wounding one, an Army spokeswoman said. A spokesman for the military wing of Hamas said they were members of the Hamas Izzedine al-Qassam Brigades on a ''jihad mission.'' The violence on Saturday occurred shortly after the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, of Fatah, and Khaled Meshal, the exiled leader of Hamas, met in Cairo to try to reinforce a tenuous five-month-old cease-fire and to call on the international community to lift its economic embargo of the Palestinian government.

John Adams: Complete Piano Music Ralph van Raat and Maarten van Veen, pianists. Naxos 8.559285; CD. JOHN ADAMS does not write a lot of piano music, but ''Phrygian Gates,'' ''China Gates,'' ''Hallelujah Junction'' and ''American Berserk'' offer looks at his trajectory as a composer since the two ''Gates'' pieces from 1977. Ralph van Raat plays all four items for Naxos, with Maarten van Veen as the second pianist in ''Hallelujah Junction.''

Roosevelt, the only school district in New York under state control, is looking for a superintendent for the second time in three years. Richard P. Mills, the state education commissioner, announced the resignation of Ronald O. Ross, who was appointed by the state three years ago to take over the troubled district. It went under state oversight in 2002 because of years of low student test scores and poor financial management.

SCHACTER--Herbert, age 79 died on April 24, 2007. Beloved husband and best friend of Barbara; loving and devoted father of Ira and his wife Janice, Alan and his wife Sherri and Howard and his girlfriend Deena; and doting ''Papa'' to Michael, Matthew, Arielle and Jared, his adored grandchildren. They adored him. We will miss him everyday of our lives. His second family consisted of his working life: his partners, office staff and his many clients. He was a CPA and a partner in the firm of Needleman & Schacter for more than 30 years. He loved his work and he loved the wonderful people he worked with. He had a full and rich life. After graduating from City College he served in the US Army for two years, starting his accounting career after his discharge. He and Barbara would have celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary this coming June 15th. Theirs was a 51 year long love affair. He passed away from the ravages of esophageao cancer. May he rest in peace.

It's FRANK STELLA season at the Met. While primarily known as a painter, Mr. Stella has also been making free-standing sculpture for public spaces and developing architectural projects since the 1990s. These works range from an aluminum band shell, built in downtown Miami in 1999, to a monumental sculpture installed outside the National Gallery of Art in Washington in 2001. Starting on Tuesday, the METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART will focus on this body of his work in an exhibition called ''Frank Stella: Painting Into Architecture.'' The show, in the museum's Kimmelman Gallery, will feature works ranging from small models to a full-scale portion of a building. The architectural elements will be accompanied by a selection of paintings, wall reliefs and sculpture. Through July 29, (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. In a separate show opening at the same time, the Met is presenting Mr. Stella's stainless-steel and carbon-fiber works in the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Roof Garden. The artist produced a series of dense abstract sculptures composed of found and cast elements. The two exhibitions mark Mr. Stella's first solo presentation at the Met. Through Oct. 28 (weather permitting). In Boston, THE MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS is turning its attention to EDWARD HOPPER with a major retrospective that opens next Sunday. The exhibition -- which includes 50 oil paintings, 30 watercolors and 12 prints -- focuses on the period from 1925 to midcentury, when the artist produced many of his best-known works, including ''Nighthawks,'' ''Chop Suey'' and ''Lighthouse and Buildings.'' The show was organized with the National Gallery of Art and the Art Institute of Chicago. Through Aug. 19, 465 Huntington Avenue, Boston, (617) 267-9300, mfa.org.

RECENTLY, high school students in Wilton tried to stage a play they had written titled ''Voices in Conflict,'' about the war in Iraq. The production proved controversial enough that the teenagers were forbidden to proceed. As a young adult novelist, I dealt with this scenario -- a community divided, students, parents and principal struggling with issues of free speech, education and censorship -- in one of my books. Like the Wilton case, the play in my book was ultimately staged off campus, though not at the Public Theater in New York City, where ''Voices in Conflict'' will appear in June.

A picture caption last Sunday with the Night Out column, about the composer and two stars of the Broadway show ''Spring Awakening,'' misspelled the surname of one of the actors. He is Jonathan Groff, not Goff.
To the Editor: Re ''In Search of the Man Who May Have Created Jazz,'' by Michael Cieply [April 22]:

A federal plan to redraw air routes over the coast of Connecticut drew strong criticism at a public hearing in Stamford last Tuesday, with local residents saying they fear a decline in their quality of life and their property values from more planes flying at lower altitudes over their homes. The comments came at a public hearing held by the Federal Aviation Administration that drew more than 150 people.

BALL--Dr. Eugene R., died April 25, 2007, age 84. He had a private practice in dentistry and was a Associate Attending Dental Surgeon at St. Luke's Hospital. He served as a US Navy officer in the Pacific during World War II. He was a Fellow of the American College of Dentists. He was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club, the Tuxedo Club, the Society of Mayflower Decendents, the Military Order of Foreign Wars and the Society of Colonial Wars. He is survived by his wife Sally Ball and his children, Perry Ball and Martha Ball Heppenheimer, his grandchildren, Geoffrey Heppenheimer, Elizabeth Heppenheimer, Katherine Ball and Victoria Ball. Funeral Service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. at 90th Street at 3:30 pm May 3rd. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

THE managers and coaches for Ardsley's Little League teams squeezed into the child-size seats in the Concord Road Elementary School cafeteria late last month to go over the rules and regulations for this season. Many of the safety procedures were familiar: catchers' masks need a throat guard; no parents on the field; baseball bats must be regulation size. But this policy was addressed for the first time: mandatory limits on the number of pitches.

An article last Sunday about investing in bonds referred imprecisely to the Federal Reserve's cutting of interest rates early in this decade. The Fed began cutting rates in early 2001 and finished in mid-2003; it did not start the cuts in early 2003.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''All Those Who Wanted A-Rod Gone, Raise Your Hand,'' April 22: George Vecsey is certainly correct in implying that the Yankees are fortunate not to have traded Alex Rodriguez.

Broadway is missing lots of things these days -- decent comedies, low prices and impressive new American plays, to name just a few -- but there is no shortage of brilliant leading actresses. In the next few weeks, no fewer than five major stars will open in new productions, guaranteeing a crowded field in the best-actress categories for the upcoming Tony Awards. In addition to Angela Lansbury (a four-time Tony winner) and Marian Seldes (one Tony) in ''Deuce,'' and Audra McDonald (four Tonys) in ''110 in the Shade,'' there's TONYA PINKINS (one Tony) and DONNA MURPHY (two Tonys), both playing formidable wives. In ''RADIO GOLF,'' the final drama of August Wilson's 10-play series, Ms. Pinkins, who was last seen on Broadway as the maid in ''Caroline, or Change,'' is the partner of a rising political star who hopes to be the first African-American mayor of Pittsburgh. In ''LOVEMUSIK,'' a new musical, Ms. Murphy brings to life Lotte Lenya, who was married (twice) to Kurt Weill (played by Michael Cerveris). Weill's music makes up the score to this new work, staged by Hal Prince. ''Radio Golf,'' in previews, opens May 8, Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200; $31.25 to $96.25. ''Lovemusik,'' in previews, opens Thursday, Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200; $76.26 to $101.25. Time is running out for you to see CHRISTOPHER SHINN'S ''DYING CITY,'' an ambitious, taut drama set in the shadow of the Iraq war, featuring superb performances by Pablo Schreiber and Rebecca Brooksher. Act fast, because after Sunday it's gone. 3 p.m., Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200; $75.

To the Editor: Re ''Those Young People, They're So Unpredictable'' (Week in Review, April 22): I am 18 years old, and I find some of the results of your poll of young Americans troubling. Nevertheless, I can think of a possible reason why many young people approve of the president and the Iraq war.

LIEF--Ruth Hurok, daughter of impresario Sol Hurok died at home at the age of 99. She leaves a daughter Nessa Hyams Picker, a son Peter Hyams, three grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. She was a friend and hostess to most of the greatest dancers and musicians of the 20th Century. She led her incredibly long life with her very own style and her very own humor. She was as unique as she was loved.
Budgets proposed by Westchester school districts for 2007-8 contain an average increase of 5.6 percent in the tax levy, down from 7.6 percent last year.
DEERING--Etheldreda A. June 23 ,1912 -April 27, 2006. We think of you every day and miss you deeply, mother. Your Loving Family

EARLIER this year, Gov. Eliot Spitzer reached an agreement with the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe that brought New York one step closer to having a $600 million Las Vegas-style casino in Sullivan County, in the Catskills. The casino, which still needs final federal approval and faces a lawsuit from environmental groups, could generate up to $100 million for the state and $20 million for the county a year. But the economic and environmental downside of this deal needs to be more carefully examined. Particularly worrisome is the casino's planned location within 12 miles of the Catskill Park and New York City's water supply.

Keyport, in Monmouth County, became the first New Jersey municipality to pass a law that bans smoking in cars while children are present. Under the law, approved by a 5-to-1 vote of the Borough Council last Tuesday, Keyport, population 8,000, can levy fines of $75 to drivers who smoke with passengers under the age of 17 inside their vehicles. Chatham, in Morris County, rejected a similar ban last month.
COMRAS--Oscar, ''Ozzie''. Always in our hearts and thoughts. Lovingly remembered these many years. Blanche & Children

Dr. Shawn Leslie Reiser, the daughter of Jeffrey H. Reiser of Manalapan, N.J., and the late Judith E. Reiser, is to be married today in Las Vegas to Sean Michael Orzol, the son of Kathleen and Michael J. Orzol of Southgate, Mich. Rabbi Craig Rosenstein is to officiate at the Wynn Las Vegas hotel. Dr . Reiser, 30, is keeping her name. She practices podiatry as an associate at Community Podiatry Group in Flint, Mich. She graduated from the University of Michigan and received her degree in podiatric medicine from Temple University.

Joe Torre handled the questions yesterday with the calm assurance that has characterized his tenure as Yankees manager, even though his status may be as shaky as it has ever been. ''The losing is much worse than the questions,'' Torre said. ''So don't worry about it. Knock yourselves out.''
Because of an editing error, the Generations column last Sunday omitted a word from the title of a television show. It is ''Da Ali G Show,'' not ''Da G Show.''
To the Editor: I found myself shaking my head in disgust while reading about the self-involved socialites seeking to make green the new Prada.

Even though it's still April, the May sweeps period has begun, and this week ABC offers one of the month's most special episodes: the two-hour ''GREY'S ANATOMY'' that will serve as Kate Walsh's audition for her (that is, Dr. Addison Montgomery's) own series (Thursday, 9 p.m.). Auditioning along with her will be guest stars like Taye Diggs, Tim Daly and Amy Brenneman, who will reportedly pop up when Ms. Walsh's character makes a trip to California to visit old school friends. Some other May sweepings: In an episode titled ''Rocket Man'' (NBC, Tuesday, 9 p.m.), ''LAW & ORDER: CRIMINAL INTENT'' rips from the headlines the sad case, barely four months old, of the astronaut Lisa Marie Nowak. In this telling the possible romantic rival has been murdered, and the space-shuttle-piloting object of everyone's affections is played by Tate Donovan. And My Network TV, still trying to find its way after abandoning one of television's most short-lived programming strategies (telenovelas? in English?), presents ''BODY DOUBLES: INTERNATIONAL TWINS SEARCH'' (Tuesday, 9 p.m.), billed as a ''most beautiful twins'' competition. Last week in this slot, My Network TV gave us ''Ujena Bikini Jam.'' Such, apparently, is the value of prime-time broadcast real estate these days. At the higher end of the culture scale, Turner Classic Movies presents a new two-part documentary, ''BRANDO'' (Tuesday and Wednesday, 8 p.m.). Talking heads, including Martin Scorsese, Al Pacino and Edward Norton, share their memories of watching and working with the great actor (Mr. Scorsese: ''Every day cinema was being reinvented.''). TCM will also be showing eight Brando films over those two nights, including ''THE WILD ONE'' (Wednesday, 9:30 p.m.) and ''ON THE WATERFRONT'' (Thursday, 12:30 a.m.). On PBS, ''American Masters'' has a two-hour profile of the pop-music impresario Ahmet Ertegun, who died in December. ''ATLANTIC RECORDS: THE HOUSE THAT AHMET BUILT'' (Wednesday night on most PBS stations; check local listings) includes interviews with Mr. Ertegun covering a four-year period. And ''American Experience'' and ''Frontline'' have combined to produce ''THE MORMONS'' (Monday and Tuesday nights on most PBS stations), a four-hour examination of the Mormon Church's history and influence.

ON a Sunday morning a few months back, I interviewed my final Harvard applicant of the year. After saying goodbye to the girl and watching her and her mother drive off, I headed to the beach at the end of our street for a run. It was a spectacular winter day, bright, sunny and cold; the tide was out, the waves were high, and I had the beach to myself. As I ran, I thought the same thing I do after all these interviews: Another amazing kid who won't get into Harvard.

DRINKWATER--Frederica Plimpton, in Bedford, MA, April 21, 2007, at the age of 90, after a brief illness. Formerly of Panton, VT and Hingham, MA. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Davis C. Drinkwater. Frederica and her husband lived an adventurous life, 17 years of farming in Vermont, followed by many years of sailing. She was also involved in her community of Panton, VT serving as Overseer of the Poor for many years and working as a volunteer at Planned Parenthood in Burlington, VT where she won an award for her contribution to that work. She is survived by her brother, John Plimpton of Sherborn. Loving mother of Susan P. Martin of Stonington, CT, Frederica P. Perera of New York City, Polly B. Drinkwater of Lincoln, MA, and Davis C. Drinkwater, Jr. of Nashville, TN. Also survived by 11 grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. A private Memorial Service will be held in May. For online guestbook visit: www.concordfuneral.com

A federal plan to redraw air routes over the coast of Westchester and Connecticut drew strong criticism at a public meeting in Stamford last Tuesday, with local residents saying they fear a decline in their quality of life and their property values from more planes flying at lower altitudes over their homes. The meeting was held by the Federal Aviation Administration and drew more than 150 people. The session, one of five public forums scheduled to take place around the region, came a month after the F.A.A. revealed its long-awaited plan for coping with airspace congestion. The administration said the plan would reduce delays at area airports like La Guardia by an average of six minutes per flight, for an overall reduction in delays of 32 percent.

To the Editor: Thank you for Joanna Kakissis' ''Salonika: Greek Youth Remake 'Seattle Of the Balkans' '' (Next Stop, April 8), which noted that Thessaloniki (the Greek name for Salonika) is more than just ''the ignored, unloved and lonesome little sister of Athens.'' But to truly appreciate the unique history of Thessaloniki -- especially its rich Jewish and Muslim history -- one should have in hand Mark Mazower's remarkable book ''Salonica, City of Ghosts.'' Stephen A. Silver Walnut Creek, Calif.

VALENTI--Jack. The Board and staff of Save the Children mourn the passing of our wonderful friend, supporter and board member, Jack Valenti. Known to most for his 38 years as visionary CEO of the Motion Picture Association of America, and as press officer in President Johnson's White House, we know him as a man passionate in support of the global fight against poverty and disease, a force in making the world better for all of its children. Our condolences to his wife, Mary Margaret and their children Courtenay, John and Alexandra and their families. Jack named ''A Man for All Seasons'' his favorite film. This title so well described him. Robert Daly, Board Chair Charles MacCormack, President Save the Children

WENDLINGER--Robert I. (April 11, 1922-April 27, 2007). Award-winning newspaper photographer, nominated for PulitzerPrize in photography, WWII veteran. Will be remembered lovingly by his companion Shirley Kurtzberg, his children Patti and Steve Rosen, Ronald and Elaine Wendlinger, his sister Marilyn W. Goldberg, his grandchildren Kara Rosen, Amanda Wendlinger, and Chelsea Wendlinger, and by his step-daughters and their families. Bob will be missed by family and friends and by Duke. Internment will be at Sharon Gardens. Donations may be made to the Lymphatic Research Foundation.

THE managers and coaches for Ardsley's Little League teams squeezed into the child-size seats in the Concord Road Elementary School cafeteria late last month to go over the rules and regulations for this season. Many of the safety procedures were familiar: catchers' masks need a throat guard; no parents on the field; baseball bats must be regulation size. But this policy was addressed for the first time: mandatory limits on the number of pitches.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended April 14, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. Editor's Choice Other recent books of particular interest THE GRAND SURPRISE: The Journals of Leo Lerman. Edited by Stephen Pascal. (Knopf, $37.50.) Lerman, a contemporary of Truman Capote, was a larger-than-life figure in the magazine world who also gave great parties. DEEP ECONOMY: The Wealth of Communities and the Durable Future, by Bill McKibben. (Times Books/Holt, $25.) The noted environmentalist aims to change attitudes about economics and consumption in an age of global warming. ... AND I HAVEN'T HAD A BAD DAY SINCE: From the Streets of Harlem to the Halls of Congress, by Charles B. Rangel with Leon Wynter. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $24.95.) This memoir from the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee brims with brio. THE WILD TREES: A Story of Passion and Daring, by Richard Preston. (Random House, $25.95.) The strange biological world at the tops of giant redwoods obsesses a group of climbers. BLACK & WHITE, by Dani Shapiro. (Knopf, $24.) The protagonist of Shapiro's novel is driven into exile by the notoriety of the raw art photos her famous mother made of her as a child. EASTER EVERYWHERE: A Memoir, by Darcey Steinke. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) A minister's daughter confronts her own spiritual rootlessness. WAY MORE WEST: New and Selected Poems, by Edward Dorn. Edited by Michael Rothenberg. (Penguin Poets; paper, $20.) Dorn, who died in 1999, was the quintessential Black Mountain poet. BURIED IN THE BITTER WATERS: The Hidden History of Racial Cleansing in America, by Elliot Jaspin. (Basic Books, $26.95.) A troubling investigation of a dozen locales that engineered mass expulsions of blacks from 1890 to 1930. HUNK CITY, by James Wilcox. (Viking, $25.95.) The globalized marketplace has pressed its thumb on Tula Springs, La., the town Wilcox introduced in his 1983 novel, ''Modern Baptists.'' ANT FARM: And Other Desperate Situations, by Simon Rich. (Random House, $12.95.) Very short, very sweet Monty Python-esque humor vignettes from a former Harvard Lampoon president.The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

Federal regulators said last week that they intended to fine the Indian Point nuclear power plants $130,000 for failing to make an April 15 deadline to activate a new emergency siren system. The new system, mandated by an amendment to the federal Energy Policy Act of 2006, will provide backup battery power for all 150 emergency sirens throughout the region in the event of an electrical power failure, said Jim Steets, a spokesman for Entergy Nuclear Northeast, which owns the plant; the current system does not have backup power. In an emergency at Indian Point, in Buchanan, the sirens warn residents to turn on their TVs and radios.

Friedman writes: ''We don't just need the first black president. We need the first green president. We don't just need the first woman president. We need the first environmental president . . . a president who is tough enough to level with the American people about the profound economic, geopolitical and climate threats posed by our addiction to oil -- and to offer a real plan to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels.'' Hey, he is talking about Al Gore!

THE first time I walked into my mother's apartment after she died, I turned and bolted. The smell of her perfume and the sight of her eyeglasses, her magazines and her comb were just too much. But no matter how much I wanted to avoid it, there was the inevitable work of clearing out the place where she had lived for 37 years.

Q. In January 2008 I will turn 65. Is there a statute of some sort that will limit my next rent increase because of my age? A. David Hershey-Webb, a Manhattan lawyer who represents tenants, said that under New York City's Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption Program, commonly known as Scrie, rent-regulated tenants may be eligible to have their rent frozen at its current level. To qualify for the program, Mr. Hershey-Webb said, the head of the household must be 62 or older, and the total household income cannot exceed $26,000. Deductions are allowed for federal, state and local income taxes; union dues; court-ordered support payments; and Social Security taxes. The rent must be at least one-third of the household's net income, and rent-stabilized tenants must have a valid one- or two-year lease.

To the Editor: In ''The Hunt'' on April 22, an apartment hunter laments that he was not aware of buyers' brokers in the Bronx. Since February 2006, we have been selling prewar co-ops ranging from 550-square-foot studios to 1,500-square-foot three-bedroom, two-bath apartments.

Brady Quinn arrived at Radio City Music Hall yesterday morning with a number in mind: nine. That was where the Miami Dolphins were scheduled to pick in the first round of the N.F.L. draft. Like someone conducting a very personal mock draft, Quinn, the former Notre Dame quarterback, identified it as the spot that he could not imagine himself falling beyond. He had worked out for the Dolphins, and Miami certainly had a need for a quarterback in its endless quest for the next Dan Marino. So, as each of the first few picks went by, as the green room backstage began to empty of the other top prospects, Quinn could still manage a smile, secure in his own calculations.

It is no secret that some of the richest candidates are some of the most successful. The combined net worth of Mayor Michael Bloomberg, Gov. Jon Corzine of New Jersey and Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York is enough to buy not just an election, but a small country. The way to deal with this mega-millionaire's advantage is not to open the floodgates to large contributions from other wealthy people, companies and unions, the way New York State does now. It is to offer public financing to candidates who are qualified but not rich.

To the Editor: There's nothing to make me want to chuck my compact fluorescent light bulbs and leave my car idling in the school pickup line more than a room of billionaires' wives patting themselves on their designer backs for buying $140 eco-friendly cleaning kits for the household staff.

The Syosset Sanitation District serves 762 homes in its affluent community in eastern Nassau County. In 2004, 14 people went to the polls to elect the three commissioners who run the district. Several voted from the same addresses as the commissioners. The commissioners met 128 times in 2004, picking up $60 in pay per meeting, according to an audit by the office of the county comptroller, Howard S. Weitzman, who concluded that the district was wasting money. District officials said they were providing a valuable service, and no residents were complaining about the cost.

Last October, I bought a ticket from American Airlines to travel from Los Angeles to Hong Kong. I tried to upgrade to business class using American AAdvantage miles, but was told that this was not possible because I was on a code-share flight operated by Cathay Pacific, a partner in the Oneworld Alliance. I now wonder, what is the ''alliance'' in Oneworld? It seems that airlines are making it more and more difficult for frequent fliers to take advantage of the loyalty we show them. -- David Anderson, Jakarta, Indonesia Remember that frequent flier programs are a marketing tool for airlines; they are not necessarily run as a benefit to travelers. Airlines award disproportionately more miles to travelers who pay the most for their tickets. And they often make it difficult to redeem miles. Alliances normally allow you to earn and redeem miles in airline partners' programs, but this often applies only to awards for free flights. There is often less reciprocity when it comes to other benefits, such as upgrades. Airlines' own customers invariably have priority over members of partner airlines' programs.

To the Editor: I was amused to read in the April 8 Travel section two particular letters from brave Times readers. One suggested that recovery from jet lag takes one day per hour of difference in time (so a New Yorker returning from India would need at least one week to recuperate), and another insisted that nothing short of demolition would remove all traces of cat dander from a hotel room. If this keeps up, some may find it impossible to leave their apartments. It seems travelers are bifurcating: there is the hardy adventurer who wants to climb a Tibetan mountain in her bare feet, dining only on local rodents, and the insulated capsule dweller, who can't tolerate the tea that is 5 degrees too cool. It must be a challenge to serve both types. Glenn Mercer Shaker Heights, Ohio

HASHMALL--Frank, 87. Born in Manhattan. City College graduate,1940. Pratt Institute graduate with Honors, 1962. President of L.M. Rabinowitz Company until retirement at 75.
