Of all the perquisites John E. Rooney received last year as the chief executive of U.S. Cellular, the one that may have been the most valuable did not count, according to the audit committee of the company's board. The Chicago White Sox gave Mr. Rooney one of the 432 gold-and-diamond rings they had made to commemorate their 2005 World Series championship, according to U.S. Cellular's 2007 proxy statement. On each ring, more than two karats of diamonds spelled out ''Sox'' on a black onyx face.

With the Islanders trailing, 4-3, and only 15 seconds from elimination in Game 5 of their opening-round series against Buffalo, Isles wing Miroslav Satan accepted a pass at the top of the right face-off circle and turned on the afterburners. Satan blew past Sabres defenseman Henrik Tallinder and cut in on goal. Ryan Miller, the Sabres' goalie, started to go down at the right post, but Satan did not shoot -- instead he zipped across the crease with the puck.

An article on April 15 about cooking classes around the world for tourists gave an incorrect telephone number for the Sarnic Hotel in Istanbul, the site of one of the classes. The number is (90-212) 518-2323.

To the Editor: The comment of a Department of Sanitation spokeswoman that Jose Adames has never been fined for his posting of more than 20,000 posters in the past two years because, according to your April 22 article ''Frequent Fliers, and He Who Posts Them,'' ''his posters do not provide his address or telephone number, which the department requires to issue a summons,'' is both absurd and outrageous.

SHERWIN--Cynthia Lynn, 33, died Thursday, April 26, 2007. Cindy suffered a brain aneurysm while biking, an activity she loved. She was an ardent and experienced tri-athlete and was in training for her first Ironman competition. Cindy was the beloved daughter of Richard and Margot Sherwin and Elaine and Earle Schaller. She is survived by her sister Lauren Sherwin, brother and sisterin-law Jeffrey and Amanda Sherwin, grandmother Sylvia Roberts, a large extended family of loving step-sisters and brothers including Jessica DaSilva, Julie Augur, Linda Schaller, Joseph Schaller, Matthew Schaller, William Schaller and her partner, Seth Timen. Cindy was a passionate health and fitness advocate. She graduated from Staples High School in Westport, CT, and earned a B.S. in Motion Science from the University of Michigan. Her interest in the fields of health and wellness led her to certification as a Registered Dietician and later, Masters Degrees in both Applied Physiology and Nutrition Education from Columbia University. Cindy was so much more than the sum of all her degrees and athletic accomplishments. She was, a warm, loving, caring and empathetic person who was beautiful both physically and spiritually. A foundation is being established in Cindy's name to support a wide range of health and wellness issues. Donations should be sent to: The Cindy Lynn Sherwin Memorial Foundation, c/o: Mr. Richard Sherwin, 182 Leetes Island Road, Guilford, CT 06437.

Yes, government can impose new carbon and gasoline taxes to raise the price of energy and to reduce fuel consumption. It will be an inconvenience for the rich but a tragedy for the poor. Wealthy families may decide to live with one S.U.V. instead of three. However, on the far side of town, many families will sink deeper into debt as they try to pay for heat and light and for basic transportation in an automobile-dominated culture.

TEWKSBURY--Willard G. Kluge died at home on Friday April 20, 2007. He was 82. Born in Philadelphia on September 18, 1924 to the late Willard and Alice (Perry) Kluge, he lived in Montclair for 72 years before moving to Tewksbury 10 years ago. He was the president and CEO of the textiles firm of Artistic Identification Systems for over 50 years, retiring in 1996. He was a veteran of the United States Air Force during WWII, and trained as a navigator before the end of the war. He had a BA Degree from the Philadelphia Textile Institute, attended Montclair Academy, and graduated from the Kimball Union Academy. Mr. Kluge is survived by his wife, the former Kathleen Madigan; two sons John P. Kluge of Maryland and Chris Kluge of Newton; four daughters, Linda Kluge of Idaho, Janet Wiggin of Califon, NJ, Barbara Hickox of Boonton Twp., and Jennifer Kluge of California; two sisters, Nancy Hall Rumery of North Carolina, and Barbara Kluge Deming of Connecticut; fourteen grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his former wife, Margaret Hulst Jenkins, mother of John, Chris, Linda, Janet and Barbara. For more information contact Bailey Funeral Home, 176 Main Street, Peapack, NJ 07977 (908) 234-0590. All services are private at the request of the family. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the charity of your choice would be appreciated by the family.
BROOKS--Patricia, died April 14. Her service will be Sunday May 6th at 3pm. Riverdale Presbyterian Church, 4763 H. Hudson Pkwy., Bronx, NY.

THE rumors have thinned the morning lines of immigrant men who gather on Morris Street, looking for work. The news -- that the local police might have a hand enforcing federal immigration policy -- has spread throughout this historic, diverse town on the edge of New Jersey's horse country, and a few people have even started to move away. It started in early March with Mayor Donald Cresitello's proposal to enroll the police in a small but growing federal program -- now in place in 10 states -- that trains local officers to help enforce federal immigration laws.

To the Editor: So the monks of the Franciscan Friars of the Renewal play punk music (''Monks Who Play Punk,'' April 22). They still infringe on women's reproductive freedom by protesting at a South Bronx women's health center and trying to convince pregnant teenagers, poor women and others that it is immoral to choose not to give birth. They should be ashamed of themselves. Donna Minkowitz Park Slope, Brooklyn To the Editor: It is amazing to me that men who choose a lifestyle that will never enable them to reproduce, experience fatherhood or become a husband find that they must picket outside a medical clinic to protest that most painful and serious decision of choosing not to reproduce. Instead, why don't they protest outside restaurants that don't pay minimum wages to employees trying to raise their families, or outside buildings whose owners don't repair homes that families live in? These monks have the ability to make a difference; let them not do it by castigating women. Regina Gradess Inwood To the Editor: I would suggest to the Franciscan Friars of the Renewal that they offer to serve as godfathers for all the babies born as the result of their efforts. Besides begging for cornflakes, they can beg for diapers and formula. In between meditating, they can offer all-day child care, so the babies' mothers can earn a living. Once a week, they can host a group sleepover, so the mothers can rest, and so they can experience what it is to get up for work at 5 a.m. after a night with a crying child. As the children grow older, they can provide after-school tutoring and guitar lessons and can share their nutritious dinners with both the children and their ''emotionally, spiritually and physically'' exhausted working mothers. As each cohort of children graduates high school, they can help pay for their college educations. Once they have spent a couple of decades giving up ''bling-bling'' for the sake of those unborn babies, they will be justified in telling terrified and vulnerable young women that ''God will take care of your child.'' Susan Leicher Upper West Side

Budgets proposed by Long Island school districts for 2007-8 contain an average increase of 4.7 percent in the tax levy, down from 6.2 percent last year. Residents in the Island's 124 districts will vote on the proposed budgets on May 15. To look up the tax increase in a district, go to nytimes.com/intheregion.

To the Editor: Lesley Jane Seymour's unabashed reveling in tween shopping habits (''Tweens 'R' Shoppers,'' April 22) proclaims this young group of girls, ages 8 to 15, as a new economic power base in consumer spending. Really this is not new at all -- young girls from wealthy suburban towns have been power shopping for decades, displaying insatiable tastes for designer labels, fueled by parents' seemingly limitless budgets to support such spending.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended April 14, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

To the Editor: Your April 15 editorial ''On Rethinking the Javits Center'' hit just the right notes. But the concerns you raised -- constructing a secure and workable center, engaging the waterfront and promoting the development of the West Side -- cannot be achieved unless the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's western railyard is included in convention center expansion plans.

''I want him to go to Kentucky, but I want him to go with a chance to win. I don't think people understand what a feat it is to get to the Derby, about how much you endure to get there.'' ELIZABETH VALANDO, the owner of a Kentucky Derby contender, Nobiz Like Shobiz. [SP 8]

No luxury homes or condos will be built on the Meyers farm property in Woodbury, one of the five remaining working farms in Nassau County. On Tuesday, Thomas R. Suozzi, the county executive, said that as part of a campaign to save Nassau's remaining parcels of open space, the county had bought the development rights for the eight-acre farm at the intersection of Picquets Lane and Woodbury Road for $4.27 million.
A report in the April 15 In Transit column, about wine-oriented tours in Tuscany, misstated a popular dish there. It is pollo con peperoni (chicken with peppers), not pollo con pepperoni.

Commissioner Roger Goodell said yesterday that it was realistic to think the Super Bowl could someday be played outside the United States. He said that the N.F.L. had received plenty of interest from cities that could play host to the game and was considering places like London, Toronto and Mexico City. The league will play its first game outside of North America in 2007. JUDY BATTISTA

RAPAPORT--Harold, April 11, 1922-April 25, 2007, 85. Beloved father of Hannah and Martin, father-in-law of Baba Salia and Carol Rapaport, adored grandfather of Rachel and Mariama Salia and Molly, Owen, Emmett, and Maggie Rapaport. Beloved brother-in-law of Florence, brother of Marlene, uncle of David, Lise, Daniel and Ellen. Summa cum laude graduate University of Pittsburgh, Brooklyn Polytechnic. US Navy WW II. GI Bill instrumental in his education. Accepted Fellow on Atomic Energy Commission 1949. RCA, ITT, and General Instrument Executive Vice President Rapaport Association helped companies achieve their goals. His amazing creative and analytic intellect was far reaching. Harold generously supported many organizations, individuals, and his family over the course of his lifetime, consistently putting others needs before his own. He was always there for people. His ability to listen carefully, explore the micro and macro pieces of a problem, and come up with wonderfully creative solutions was unparalleled. Harold will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Memorial May 1st, 11:30, Frank Patti & Kenneth Mikatarian F.D., Ft. Lee, NJ.

I resent the guilt trip laced behind the Ethicist's advice to ''find another way to do your fair share for the health-care community of which you are a member and from which you benefit'' (April 15). Because I do not wish to have residents or interns present during my examination does not mean I haven't done my fair share by paying my (staggering) medical-insurance premiums or by waiting for what often is an interminable amount of time for my appointment.

CANTER--Lenore Engel, 70, died Sunday morning, April 22, 2007. Beloved mother of Sheryl Canter, Neil Canter, and Nina Canter Fresco, and adored grandmother of Maia, Chloe and Melina Canter, and David and Eli Fresco. Lenore was an extraordinary, gifted woman. She loved the theater and her native New York City, and touched hundreds of lives through her love, friendship, and work as an astrologer. She will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society. A memorial service will be held at The Village Temple, 33 East 12th St., New York City, on Sunday, May 20 at 11 am.

ROSTROPOVICH--Mstislav. On behalf of America's orchestras, the American Symphony Orchestra League mourns the loss of Mstislav Rostropovich, inspirational musician, passionate advocate of music, humanitarian, and friend, whose vitality will be missed by all. Henry Fogel President & CEO $(6$)ROSTROPOVICH--Mstislav. Farewell dear Slava, Tsarstvo Tebe Nebesnoye. Malko $(6$)ROSTROPOVICH--Mstislav. Curtis mourns the loss of Mstislav Rostropovich, former faculty member, beloved colleague, master cellist, conductor, and human rights crusader. Maestro Rostropovich conducted the Curtis Symphony Orchestra in memorable concerts at Philadelphia's Academy of Music and at the Rencontres Musicales d'Evian in France. In 1999 Rostropovich received the first-ever Curtis Award in recognition of his remarkable artistic and humanitarian achievements. One of the great cellists of his time, he was a friend to many of the 20th century's most important composers and writers, including prominent dissidents whom he defended publicly at significant personal cost. Curtis remembers Maestro Rostropovich with profound gratitude for the many unforgettable musical and educational experiences he provided for its students, and offers deepest sympathies to his family. Roberto Diaz, President H.F. ''Gerry'' Lenfest, Chairman The Curtis Institute of Music

Accustomed to Ejection With his ejection on April 22 in a game against the Mets, Braves Manager Bobby Cox has been ejected from a game as a manager 124 times, the most in baseball history. Not Just a Pretty Glove OMAR VIZQUEL of the Giants, known more for his defense (he has won 11 Gold Glove awards), is 11 hits from 2,500. Of his 2,489 hits, 2,484 have come as a shortstop, the most in baseball since 1974. San Francisco is scheduled to be home for 10 straight games starting tomorrow. The most hits by a shortstop since 1974: Good Start, Bad Start JOSH BECKETT of the Red Sox, off to a 5-0 start, is set to start against Oakland on Wednesday. He has struck out 28 while walking 7. A's designated hitter Mike Piazza is 5 for 20 in his career against Beckett without a home run. Since hitting his first home run of the season on April 5, Piazza has gone 70 at-bats without a homer. By All Appearances Trevor Hoffman appeared in his 802nd game as a Padre on Friday night, tying Walter Johnson and Elroy Face for the most appearances by one pitcher with the same team. Hoffman's 802 Padres appearances and 830 over all (28 in 1993 for the Marlins) have all been in relief. The Nationals will visit San Diego for a three-game series starting tomorrow. Watch List Cliff Lee should return to the Indians' rotation this week after throwing five scoreless innings Friday night in a rehab start, and he could unveil a new slider when he does. The Indians have not said what Lee's return means for Fausto Carmona, above, but a trip to the minors seems likely. Carmona does not project as a late-inning reliever; he failed as the closer last season, and batters are hitting .294 against him with runners in scoring position. His lone bad outing this season came with long rest, making the long reliever/spot starter role unlikely.

MAXWELL--Dr. Margaret. The Finch College Alumnae Association Foundation deeply mourns the loss of Dr. Margaret Maxwell, our inspirational mentor, professor and guiding light in the organization's formation, who died April 17. She has been our best friend and supporter in carrying forth the mission of the foundation: To provide continuing college education for women. We extend our deepest sympathy to her sister, Betty Leech and family. A memorial service will be held at 3 pm, Saturday, June 9, at the Birch Wathen Lenox School, 210 East 77th Street. Donations in Dr. Maxwell's memory may be made to the Finch College Alumnae Association Foundation, 1471 Third Avenue, #

The Earth Mother She recycles -- for the entire school -- and gives hand-me-downs as birthday gifts. She's going to save the earth, even if she has to ruin everybody else's day doing it. White & Warren sweater-tee made of eco-friendly bamboo in white, black and terra ($90 at whiteandwarren.com). The Stepford-in-Law Three husbands in, she's still smiling, although she's clamped down so tightly, you'd swear she was making a diamond in her jawbone. She can barely pick her grandchildren out of a police lineup, but she's always ready to pour you another Scotch. Lacoste new stretch polo with two-inch-longer hemline and five-button placket for easier fit ($75 at Lacoste boutiques). The GlamoraMa She's gorgeous, stainless, childless-looking. Come to think of it, shouldn't someone unleash your inner GlamoraMa? The Grace dress by the new Ella Moss Black Label collection ($380 at shopbop.com). The Sanctimommy She does Mommy and Me yoga. She keeps track of playdates in a neat agenda. She refers to her offspring as ''munchkins.'' And you don't! Casall workout clothing ($66 to $205 at powerpilates.com). MomAgenda day planner with scheduling columns for Mom and up to four kids ($42 in pink, green, blue or chocolate at the Scholastic Store in New York, 212-343-6166). The Newly Bred The new (or nearly) mom is the most expectant mother on the list, so note to dads: Don't botch this first Mother's Day. (P.S. Skip the romantic hotel room: She's not in the mood.) Cartier's new diamond love bracelet with a brown toile de moire strap, in stores in June, available for preorder at (800) 227-8437 ($2,550); without diamonds on a leather strap ($1,300, both at Cartier boutiques); Louis Vuitton diaper bag in pink, blue or brown monogram ($1,870 at Louis Vuitton boutiques). The Real-Life Mom She can go from American Girl to American Idol to American Pastoral in 60 seconds. When she kisses the kids good night, she'll lie down for a little nap -- only to wake with a start at 1 a.m. and pack the lunches. From dawn to dusk, she's the star of the show. Prada gold aviator sunglasses with brown gradient lenses and tortoise arms ($265 at Bergdorf Goodman in New York, 212-753-7300). Mum's the Word pajamas by Scanty in superwashed cotton ($95 for camisole and pants set at sleepyheads.com). The Other Mother Where would you be without nanny or Granny or the faithful neighbor, ready to step in when long days get longer? Everybody needs an Other Mother -- make sure you lavish thanks on yours. Bliss Simply the Zest Lemon and Sage Spa in a Box ($36 at blissworld.com) and Fresh Hesperides gift set ($38 at fresh.com).

To the Editor: As the person who initiated the renaming of 94th Street at 52nd Avenue in Elmhurst, Queens, I find ''Turn Left at [Your Name Here],'' by Stuart Miller (Op-Ed, April 22), elitist and condescending.

BACON--Dr. Isaac. The Yeshiva University family deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Isaac Bacon, who served for 18 years as the fourth dean of Yeshiva College. The fatherin-law of Dr. Karen Bacon, The Dr. Monique C. Katz Dean of YU's Stern College for Women, he was a linguistic specialist and an innovative educator who left his indelible mark on YU. During his deanship, he introduced many new programs, courses and seminars at YC, including joint programs with YU's graduate programs, Columbia University, the Polytechnic Institute of NY, and Baruch College; and a cooperative program for outstanding high school students. Upon his retirement in 1977, he was appointed consultant to the Vice President for Academic Affairs at YU. Condolences to his wife, Esther, sons YU Associate Professor Dr. Joshua (and Rena), YU Professor Dr. Stephen (and Karen), and Ari (and Sari) Bacon, and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees

THE BOOKS, a duo of New Yorkers-turned-New Englanders, make quiet bricolage folk songs that sound as if they'd crumple if you touched them. They use daily-life sound samples, including a lot of talking voices on tape behind their own real-time sung voices. The result is meticulously structured and right on the edge of wispy, but it glows with a feeling of solitary effort. And it's hard to pin down in the spectrum of current music, too, which makes it feel just right for WORDLESS MUSIC, a concert series aiming to please and divert both modern classical and rock audiences. Opening for the Books is the contemporary chamber trio REAL QUIET. Monday at 7:30 p.m., New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, Manhattan, wordlessmusic.org; $20 The collaboration between the saxophonists KENNY GARRETT and PHAROAH SANDERS has been good for both. With Mr. Garrett's mastery of patterns and paradigms -- he is a hero figure for jazz students -- and Mr. Sanders's supernatural free-jazz roar, they cover a huge amount of ground in one 90-minute set. Of course, everything relates in some way to John Coltrane, who is Mr. Garrett's idol and was Mr. Sanders's employer in the mid-'60s. But it's not just a Coltrane-repertory show, and it has a lot of ways of becoming raw and exciting. Wednesday through Sunday, Iridium Jazz Club, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $35 to $40.

To the Editor: In ''The Infinite Variety of the Lady Stanwyck'' [April 22], Terrence Rafferty writes that Barbara Stanwyck excelled at playing ''a woman men just can't seem to get a fix on.'' Andrew Gerle and I spent the last five years trying to get a fix on Ann Mitchell, her reporter in ''Meet John Doe.'' Ann ruins lives, but Stanwyck somehow keeps you on her side. In adapting the film for a stage musical, we agonized over Ann's likability until we realized it's the moral ambiguity that makes Stanwyck's characters worth spending several hours, or five years, getting to know. Eddie Sugarman Western Springs, Ill. The writer is the lyricist and a book writer of ''Meet John Doe.''

Nicolas Sarkozy, the likely winner of the French presidential elections, may have only limited influence over domestic affairs in France (David Rieff, April 15). Traditionally, the prime minister and cabinet ministers are responsible for internal matters, while the president concerns himself more with foreign affairs.
SONNENBLICK--Annie. March 21, 1958-April 29, 1984. Dearest sister, daughter and friend. Deeply loved and missed.

Two exceptionally thoughtful performers are giving recitals Sunday afternoon, and it's just possible (advisable, even) to catch them both. The pianist MAURIZIO POLLINI, whose concerts invariably put familiar works in an unusual light, begins with works by Chopin and plays Book II of Debussy's Études, but the real dazzler here is likely to be his performance of Pierre Boulez's Sonata No. 2. 3 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $34 to $108. Around the time that Mr. Pollini leaves the stage, the soprano DAWN UPSHAW, and the pianist GILBERT KALISH, will begin the first Free for All concert of the season at Town Hall with a promising program that includes songs by Ruth Crawford Seeger, Fauré, Ravel, Messiaen, Weill and William Bolcom, and piano works by Ives (the ''Concord'' Sonata) and Brahms. 5 p.m., 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, freeforallattownhall.org; free but tickets are required. The INTERNATIONAL CONTEMPORARY ENSEMBLE is devoting a program in its ICE All Over Festival to music by the inventive young composer Huang Ruo, including ''The Lost Garden,'' from the ensemble's recent recording of Mr. Huang's four chamber concertos, and the premiere of ''Atmosphere and Environment.'' Tuesday at 9 p.m., Mo Pitkin's House of Satisfaction, 34 Avenue A, near Third Street, East Village, (212) 777-5660, iceorg.org; $5. The festival runs through Saturday, with concerts at several halls and performing spaces in Manhattan. Two composers whose music draws on pop influences are being given a spotlight this week as well. The cellist FELIX FAN and the pianist BLAIR McMILLEN will perform chamber works written for them by ANNIE GOSFIELD, and Ms. Gosfield will lead her own hybrid rock band in ''EWA7,'' a work composed for a factory in Germany. Thursday at 8 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 501-3330, kaufman-center.org; $20; $25, day of the show. And JACOB TER VELDHUIS, a Dutch composer whose works have the energy of rock and the instrumentation of chamber music (plus boomboxes, occasionally) is the subject of ''Grab It: The Music of JacobTV,'' a three-concert festival. Wednesday through Friday at 8 p.m., Whitney Museum of American Art at Altria, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (800) 944-8639, whitney.org; free.

To the Editor: ''Tweens 'R' Shoppers'' (April 22), Lesley Jane Seymour's account of the tween shopping craze, seems unduly kind. The mall can be romanticized as a place for ''sophisticated, thoughtful, opinionated'' consumers to try on ''identities and selves.'' More realistically, however, given Ms. Seymour's observation that most tweens flock to major brands like Abercrombie & Fitch and American Eagle Outfitters, the trend represents exactly the opposite: the desire to be just like everyone else.

DANIEL--John E., born in Yonkers, NY, January 15, 1948. Son of deceased immigrant parents from Czechoslovakia, Emrich Daniel and Anna Behun Daniel. Brother of deceased Zlata Daniel Zidik. Survived by his beloved wife Janet Nolan, nephew John Zidik (Christine), and niece Jana Zidik Krieger. He was a Princeton University graduate, Class of 1970, and Stanford Law School graduate, Class of 1973. He was an avid golfer at Siwanoy CC in Bronxville, NY. Donations can be made to his favorite charities: Gilda's Club Worldwide: 322 Eighth Avenue, Suite 1402, New York, NY 10001; Jumpstart MidAtlantic Region: 505 Eighth Avenue, Suite 602, New York, NY 10018; and Princeton University (Class of 1970): P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543-5357. A memorial tribute for John will be held Tuesday May 15, 2007 at 4pm at The Princeton Club of New York: 15 West 43rd Street (between 5th and 6th Avenues). $(6$)DANIEL--John E. The partners, attorneys and staff of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel LLP mourn the untimely passing of our partner and friend, John Daniel. John was a leader within our Intellectual Property Group, a valued colleague to his clients and respected by his peers. John was elected Treasurer of the New York Intellectual Property Law Association and recently nominated for Second Vice President. John was born in Yonkers, NY in 1948. He was a 1970 cum laude graduate of Princeton University and earned his J.D. from Stanford Law School in 1973. John was a true gentlemen, a brilliant lawyer and a friend to many. His wit, wisdom and ability to light up a room with laughter and song will long be remembered.

(914) 669-5033. Peekskill ''The Art of Persuasion,'' prints from the New York Society of Etchers. Through June 29. Paramount Center for the Arts, 1008 Brown Street. (914) 739-2333. Poughkeepsie Photography by Claudia Gorman. Tuesday through June 10. Guided daily house tours. Tuesday through Nov. 30. $6 and $9. Locust Grove, 2683 South Road (Route 9). (845) 454-4500, Extension 17. Purchase ''On the Cusp,'' an installation by Laurel Garcia Colvin. Through May 12. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. and by appointment. Brownson Gallery, 2900 Purchase Street. (914) 323-5331. Purchase ''Fugitive Artist: The Early Work of Richard Prince, 1974-77.'' Through June 24. ''Lesley Dill: Tremendous World,'' installations. ''New Media: When,'' group show. Through May 20. $3 to $5; members and children 12 and under, free. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Neuberger Museum of Art, 735 Anderson Hill Road. (914) 251-6100. Rye ''Spotlight on Historical Costumes,'' a collection of seasonal costumes. Through June 7. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Square House Museum, 1 Purchase Street. (914) 967-7588. Tarrytown ''Year Around,'' paintings by Tjasa Owen. Through May 16. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, to 5 p.m. Gallery du Soleil, 39 Main Street. (914) 332-4554. Tivoli ''The Body Eclectic,'' mixed-media group show. Through April 29. ''Energy of Nature,'' paintings by Lara Chkhetiani. Friday through May 27. To the Editor: Re the encouraging renewal of Long Island Sound (''Renewal in the Sound,'' editorial, April 22), two points, one hopeful, the other scary, need to be added. The first is to give due credit for the progress you cite to the Long Island Sound Study, the partnership that has been implementing the 1998 cleanup agreement you refer to. The other can be summed up in a word: Broadwater.

LANE--Madeleine, 94. Resident of Port Washington, NY, formerly of Plandome Manor. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Frederick E. Lane, and mother of Joseph, Ila Lane Gross, Lewis, and Edward; mother-in-law of Bobbi, John Gross, Nancy, and Judy. Loved and adored grandmother of 11 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. An active potter throughout her life, she was former Assistant Professor of Art (Ceramics) Adelphi University for more than two decades, Visiting Artist at L.I.U.C.W. Post, member of New York Artists/Craftmans Guild, and longtime member of the PW Library Art Advisory Council. She will be missed by all. A mentor to many and an inspiration to all who knew her. In lieu of flowers: contributions to JCC Ceramic Studio, 334 Amsterdam Ave., NY, NY 10023.
ALLER--Frank W., May 9, 1947 -Sept. 12, 1971. Service in Honor of his 60th Birthday, May 10, 3pm at OPC Spokane Valley, WA. Read and share at frank60.wordpress.com

Friedman's message to go ''green'' was most welcome, with one exception: after espousing the benefits of the free market, he goes on to recommend massive government intervention in the energy market to promote nuclear power. To be consistent, government action should adhere to his original premise of limiting overall carbon emissions and then letting market forces determine the best means of achieving those limits.
After allowing a late tying goal, the Devils defeated Ottawa in the second overtime, 3-2, to even their playoff series at 1-1. Page 7.

Startling news from the Galapagos: Lonesome George could have company. The giant tortoise became an international symbol of conservation as the last surviving member of his species -- the "rarest living creature," according to Guinness World Records. But now it looks as if he's not the only Pinta island tortoise left on Earth.

President Bush this week will formally reject the Iraq spending bill, with its timeline for winding down the war. But that will hardly bring the matter to a close for the Democratic presidential hopefuls, especially those in the Senate.
"What's your favorite novel?" is a perennial campaign question, the answer to which presumably gives insight into leadership.

The Democrats' debate last week offered a prime site for presidential hopefuls to promote their ideas, credentials and, most important, affection for Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina.
Ken Nedimyer has started a nursery for staghorn coral in the Florida Keys.
A few things you should know before you bet on the race.

Deborah Jeane Palfrey, facing charges of running a prostitution ring in Washington, opened her remarks in Washington today with an apology to the first casualty of her defense strategy, which is to name her clients and then call them as witnesses at her trial.

Comparison shopper alert: Is Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton the Brand X presidential candidate, and Senator Barack Obama the Brand Y?While former President Bill Clinton, for one, doesn't see much difference between the two when it comes to Iraq, the two rivals apparently part ways on their drinking preferences.

We seem to be a rather polarized country. According to views often expressed in the media, especially online, Republicans revel in the idea of torture and detest our Constitution, while Democrats want to bring the troops home from Iraq only to accomplish the dastardly double-trick of surrendering our country to the terrorists and kicking off a genocide in the Middle East.

Nothing can divide a nation more than war does - as we can see for ourselves today. But the most effective way to keep that division from widening and leaving permanent scars is for a president to reach out to the opposition party and bring it aboard. Various presidents have successfully done this.

As a British court sentenced five men to life sentences for plotting terrorist attacks using fertilizer bombs, the nation's domestic intelligence service took what the BBC described as an "unprecedented step."

Allen & Company's annual conference in Sun Valley, Idaho, is known as a wellspring of media deals. (See the agreement between BET founder Robert L. Johnson and The Weinstein Company.) It appears we can add another offer to that list: the bid by the investment firm Tornante to acquire Topps, the baseball card maker.
Who is the world's biggest private equity firm?
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his Apr. 30 column, "Another Economic Disconnect."
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's Apr. 30 column, "Working the Truth Beat."
Readers respond to David Brooks's April 29 column, "Grim Old Party."
For a familiar advertising character, the lonely Maytag repairman, a new life is beginning at 40 as he gets a major personality makeover.

In Nascar, Jeff Gordon passed Number 3 for sixth place on the all-time Cup wins list, and the classy fans at Talladega couldn't have been happier. Really, they're excited. It's Miller Lite they're showering onto Gordon's car -- the Champagne of beers.

There was a big reaction (both in the markets and on DealBook) to Friday's report on General Electric from analysts at Citigroup, who suggested that a partial breakup of the conglomerate could help its stock break out of its multiyear rut. Some DealBook readers, like Motley Fool's Nathan Parmelee, commented on the irony that the report came from Citi, a financial giant that some shareholders and investors have also said could benefit from a breakup.

Andrew Braccia, who had been vice president of consumer Web search at the Internet giant Yahoo, has apparently caught the venture capital bug. Mr. Braccia is joining Accel Partners, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm whose investments include the social-networking site Facebook and the mobile ad network AdMob. Accel said Monday that Mr. Braccia will help it look for new investments in consumer Internet and software companies, with a focus on search, digital media and online advertising.
For a familiar advertising character, the lonely Maytag repairman, a new life is beginning at 40 as he gets a major personality makeover.

An Update: The Yankees' principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner issued a statement today saying that the team's performance is "clearly not acceptable to me or to Yankee fans." But the boss backed his general manager, Brian Cashman, and Manager Joe Torre by saying, "I believe in them."

In 1996, Congress passed a minimum-wage bill with a provision to help small companies set up employee stock ownership plans. Eleven years later, the real estate mogul Samuel Zell is using that provision to the utmost in his buyout of the newspaper company Tribune, which creates an entity that is shielded for years from paying income tax. Newsweek's Allen Sloan sees some irony at work here. He called up John Breaux, the former United States senator who sponsored the 1996 provision, to ask him about the Tribune deal, and Mr. Breaux said: "I wanted to encourage employee ownership. I wasn't trying to encourage tax avoidance."

Three days after its controversial removal from the center of Talinn, Estonia's capital, the statue of a Red Army soldier is standing upright again at its new location: the Defense Forces Cemetery in another part of the city.

Appearing today at an Albany middle school, Gov. Eliot Spitzer seemed in high spirits, even somewhat defiant, in response to questions about his prodigious campaign fund-raising and whether or not it conflicts with his message of tighter campaign finance limits.

The Mets placed Orlando Hernandez on the disabled list today, retroactive to April 25, with bursitis in his right shoulder. Chan Ho Park, who was 3-1 but had a 7.29 earned run average for Class AAA New Orleans, was recalled to start tonight against the Florida Marlins at Shea Stadium.

As with most things on Wall Street, last week's surge in Amazon.com's stock created some big winners and big losers. In the winners' column: Bill Miller, the mutual-fund manager from Legg Mason whose legendary 15-year streak of beating the S&P 500 ended last year when some of his value fund's top stock picks -- including Amazon -- failed to pay off. As recently as January, Mr. Miller doggedly defended his Amazon pick, writing in a letter to shareholders of his fund that "investors wrongly believe today's low operating margins [at Amazon] are going to be the norm for years."

There's a good chance that George Steinbrenner will issue some kind of statement about Joe Torre today. It's an off day at the end of a 9-14 April, after five losses in six games to the Boston Red Sox. Steinbrenner will want to show the fans that he's still with it, that he's still riled up about the awful start to the season.
AT&T had sued Microsoft, alleging that computers running Windows infringed on AT&T’s speech technology. The ruling restricts the reach of patent holders overseas.
On a flight to speaking engagement last week, this is what I encountered:
Plans for an $800 million home for the Yankees were unveiled on Wednesday.

Shareholders of Carrefour, the global retailing company, granted board seats to representatives of Bernard Arnault and Colony Capital at the company's annual meeting on Monday. But they also complained about the company's lack of disclosure over its internal troubles, the Financial Times reported.

On the market: The Old Theatre on Queenstown Road in the Battersea section of London at a guide price of £1.6 million -- or $3.2 million. This 3,200-square-foot residence is an awesome space with three bedrooms, three bathrooms, and three reception rooms, plus a large roof terrace. Impeccably refurbished, the property's being marketed through Knight Frank in London.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey will be leaving the hospital this afternoon and will speak briefly with reporters beforehand. He has indicated he'll take up to a week to decide when he will resume his duties. (Update: He's out.)

If you're searching for a new car, there should be plenty on dealers' lots to choose from. April appears to have been one of the worst sales months in recent years, not only for Detroit's automakers but for their competitors as well. Nearly the major automakers are expected to post declines when they report the month's results on Tuesday, so many dealers are undoubtedly eager to bulk up their April numbers before closing the books tonight. (Edmunds.com forecasts that Toyota and Nissan will come out slightly ahead when the numbers are adjusted for the fact that April '06 had two more selling days than April '07.)
Or, as the illiterate signs on more than one building have it -- "no menu's." (And don't get us started on "flyer.")

Another journalist has left newsprint for financial fine print. The Philadelphia Inquirer said Monday that its managing editor, Anne Gordon, will leave the paper to become a partner at Dubilier & Company, a private equity firm based in Stamford, Conn.

Against a Kiss Now that Richard Gere has apologized for a public display of affection in India that earned him an arrest warrant, the Christian Science Monitor takes a closer look at a "nation's struggle to come to terms with its views of women and sexuality."

Reason contributing editor Julian Sanchez has a question: What exactly did Rudy Giuliani do on Sept. 11, 2001, that qualifies him to be president of the United States? "I'm not so much interested here in the broader question of whether he'd make a good president, but why this, in particular, seems to be given such incredible weight," Sanchez writes on his personal blog, Notes From the Lounge. He adds, "[T]they seem to half mean it in the theatrical sense of the word: the image of a strong, calm leader he projected to the city and the nation." He continues:
"Do you have a view?"
The running theme of the war in Iraq underlines many campaign appearances of the candidates from both the Republican and Democratic fields.

A three-mile wall around a neighborhood of Baghdad became a symbol of the American occupation that Sunnis and Shiites could united against, with Iraq's Shiite leader playing the unlikely role of champion of the Sunnis.
A look at some of the performers at the 2007 Jazzfest in New Orleans.
Banks and investment firms have recently been pouring money into roads and other public infrastructure. BusinessWeek's Emily Thornton smells romance in the air. She writes:

More than half of the 100 top-grossing law firms in the United States had profits per equity partner of $1 million or more last year, according to American Lawyer. It was the first time that more than half the Am Law 100 has cracked the $1 million mark in profits per partner, the magazine said. At more than $4.4 million per partner, Washington-based Wiley Rein ranked first, thanks to $245 million in fees it earned for its work on the settlement of patent litigation between NTP and Blackberry maker Research in Motion. It was followed by Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz and Cravath Swaine & Moore, both of which pulled in more than $3 million per partner, American Lawyer said.
The Galápagos Islands, which inspired Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution, are the scene of a war between man and goat.

Telefónica of Spain and a group of Italian investors agreed on Saturday to pay 4.1 billion euros ($5.6 billion) for a controlling 18 percent stake in Telecom Italia, allowing the Spanish telecommunications giant to expand into the Italian market and extend its presence in Latin America.

As perhaps the most prominent longtime venture capital firm with roots outside the Silicon Valley or Boston, New Enterprise Associates is accustomed to defying expectations. So with a string of solid exits in the past year and more likely on the way, the 21-year-old firm is comfortable harvesting technology winners without relying on any chart-busting deals in emerging media or other more flashy segments, according to The Deal.com.

Vista Capital, a private equity joint venture of Banco Santander of Spain and the Royal Bank of Scotland, entered the fray circling the Spanish airline Iberia, saying on Friday that it would join with the Texas Pacific Group, raising the possibility of a bidding war.

Dresdner Kleinwort reportedly plans to double the number of hedge fund specialists in its investment bank over the next three years as the bank, owned by the insurer Allianz, seeks to raise hundreds of millions of euros in revenue from the rapidly growing industry.

Cable & Wireless, Britain's second-biggest phone company, said it has no immediate plans to sell or spin off its businesses after the Observer said the company might split itself in two. "Any discussion of spinning off our businesses is premature," the company said Monday. Cable & Wireless is focused on building its British and international units and the strategy is "progressing well.''
For only the second time in President Bush's tenure, Congress is preparing for a veto.
The London headquarters of HSBC Holdings was bought by the Spanish real estate company Metrovacesa for 1.09 billion pounds ($2.2 billion), a record for a British building.
Is Citigroup next?
Porsche said the offer period for its low-ball 35.9 billion-euro ($48.9 billion) bid for Volkswagen, intended to stave off a hostile takeover, will run for four weeks, starting Monday.

Shares of ICICI Bank, India's most valuable lender, were set for the biggest drop in three years on concern a planned 200 billion rupee ($4.9 billion) stock sale will cut returns for investors as profit growth slows, Bloomberg News reported. ICICI slumped as much as 9.6 percent on the Bombay Stock Exchange.

Eni, the European oil company, agreed to buy Dominion Resources' exploration and production assets in the Gulf of Mexico for $4.8 billion to triple its output from the region. The purchase will raise Eni's production in the Gulf to 110,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day by the second half of 2007, from 36,000 barrels a day now, the Rome-based company said Monday.
T. Ananda Krishnan, the second-richest person in Malaysia, plans to buy full control of Maxis Communications, Malaysia's No. 1 mobile-phone operator, which is valued at $9.6 billion.

The European bank consortium seeking to top ABN Amro's agreed sale to Barclays has lined up much of the financing needed to pay for its approximately 72.27 billion-euro ($98.66 billion) bid, in what could ultimately represent a record amount for fund raising, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Cititgoup's new tagline, "Let's Get It Done", could double as a rallying cry for the bank's chief Charles O. Prince III.

Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver's profile in the capital during the Spitzer administration has, at times, seemed lower than his voice, which registers so far down on the bass clef that we have to lean in to hear.

A former audit committee member of Hollinger International, began testifying Friday in the criminal trial of Conrad M. Black, the former chairman, with prosecutors portraying her as a talented economist who had been duped while the defense suggested she had failed to carry out her financial duties.

Goldman Sachs is the most undervalued of the five major United States investment banks, but all of their stocks are good investments, James Cramer, the former hedge fund manager and host of CNBC's "Mad Money," wrote in his column in New York magazine. He argued that Goldman and the rest of the quintet -- Bear Stearns, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley -- are reaping the benefits of a global merger boom. They also have lucrative asset management arms as well as in-house hedge funds and private equity funds.

A federal judge lifted a seven-year-old civil contempt sanction on the financial adviser Martin A. Armstrong on Friday, allowing him to begin serving a five-year sentence for conspiracy to commit fraud.

Federal prosecutors in Seattle are conducting a criminal inquiry into Quellos Investments, a prominent money manager for pension funds, over its design and sale of questionable tax shelters to wealthy investors. The inquiry signals a widening of a federal investigation into tax shelters promoted by banks, accounting firms and law firms in recent years.

The investment banks that helped Enron managers conceal the truth about Enron could get off, but Ben Stein writes in the New York Times that the Supreme Court could correct what he suggests is the mistreatment of shareholders.

As Clear Channel Communications bidders Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners scramble to persuade shareholders to back their $19.4 billion bid for the company, a proxy advisory firm has dealt the potential deal another blow.

A judge in United States district court raised concerns Friday that the law firm Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati might have a conflict of interest in litigation over options backdating at Brocade Communications Systems. The conflict of interest, it seems, is the law firm's own chairman, the famed Silicon Valley lawyer Lawrence W. Sonsini.

After fending off a proposed $19 billion buyout from private equity suitors led by CVC Capital Partners, the British supermarket chain J Sainsbury now finds itself under pressure from shareholders to split up its businesses.

Michael Marks, a senior adviser with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, has joined the board of Sun Microsystems as part of a $700 million investment the firm made in the storage and software company earlier this year.

When it comes to alternative energy, investors clearly aren't jumping on every concept. Shares of Ocean Power Technologies, which makes systems that extract energy in ocean waves and convert it to electricity, have been sinking since its initial public offering last week.

Several top officers of Tribune have joined the chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, in limiting or declining their slice of a "transaction bonus pool" related to the company's $8.2 billion bid to go private.

A diagnostic test maker, Biosite, said Thursday that its board had determined that a $1.6 billion buyout offer from Inverness Medical Innovations is a "superior proposal" to an earlier $1.55 billion offer from Beckman Coulter.

Money is flowing into alternative energy companies so fast that "the warning signs of a bubble are appearing," according to a report on investment in clean technology by a New York research firm, Lux Research. The report also suggests that companies that make equipment to cleanse air or water, or that process waste, have been overlooked by investors.

For the second time this month, China has ordered banks to hold more of their deposits in reserve as it seeks to prevent credit and investment growth from destabilizing the economy. The People's Bank of China said on its Web site on Sunday that big banks would have to hold 11 percent of their deposits in reserve at the central bank beginning on May 15, up from 10.5 percent now.

Weeks after Google spent $3.1 billion to buy the Internet advertising company DoubleClick, a rival search giant is reaching into its wallet in a bid to compete. Yahoo has agreed to pay about $680 million to acquire the rest of Right Media, a privately held company that runs an advertising marketplace, in part to bolster its position as a seller and broker of ads outside its own sprawling network of Web sites, The New York Times reported.

The New York Times magazine takes a look at how a former banker with a bondage fetish and a Ph.D. in finance created Kink, arguably the country's most successful fetish porn company. Kink's founder, Peter Acworth, is a former a Barings Brothers employee, and Kink's vice president for marketing, Reena Patel, is a former Merrill Lynch-er with an M.B.A. Ms. Patel told the magazine that while the image of pornographers is still "a bunch of sleazy guys that are drunk all day," the business has changed.
Frank Langella will recreate the role of Richard M. Nixon in the screen adaptation of "Frost/Nixon."
The European Commission has passed legislation that would keep bad reviews from looking good.
“Young Frankenstein” will hold its pre-Broadway tryout in Seattle starting in August.

Since the verdict in the Hurwit trial on Friday, I've interviewed three of the twelve jurors, and they told pretty much the same story. They said that the jury considered Dr. William Hurwitz to be a doctor dedicated to treating pain who didn't intentionally prescribe drugs to be resold or abused. They said he didn't appear to benefit financially from his patients' drug dealing and that he wasn't what they considered a conventional drug trafficker.
Cycle past coastal villages that teeter on limestone peninsulas, and inland, through Istria’s uncrowded interior where medieval villages perch on fortified hilltops.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
If your beliefs are any good, you needn’t be afraid to bring them out into the light. The proof: “The Mormons,” a thoughtful two-part series on PBS.

Services that merge mobile phones and the Web are bringing the culture of exhibitionism to more personal locations, encouraging people to share the details of their lives around the clock through pictures, video and text.
John Adams conducted the orchestra in an all-Adams program to commemorate his 60th birthday this year.
This nonstop sugar rush of a show is a high-energy, empty-calories and expensive-looking hymn to the glories of girlishness.
Like no other horseman in the world, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoumhas learned that it is easier to build the world’s tallest building than it is to win a Kentucky Derby.
The Iraqi Consensus Front said Iraq's government had failed to deal with Sunni concerns.
Male ducks may have extreme genitals because the females do too.
He also hinted that he would discuss whether to resign if the board clears him of misconduct.
President Bush said he hoped that Paul D. Wolfowitz would remain in his post.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine apologized to New Jersey residents Monday as he left the hospital 18 days after a devastating car crash.
Drivers in the Bay Area mostly avoided the roads near a critical highway interchange that collapsed Sunday.

PARIS, April 30 — The month of April was so warm and so dry across Western Europe that it rewrote the weather record books in country after country, national weather services said today, as hot air masses from Africa and the effects of a changing climate combined to drive up temperatures and drive away rain.
The Supreme Court found that a deputy’s decision to ram his car to end a high-speed chase was reasonable.
A senior commander at the main U.S. detention center in Iraq testified that Lt. Col. William H. Steele breached military law and Iraqi cultural norms.
The interim findings say that Prime Minister Ehud Olmert “made up his mind hastily” to launch the campaign last July against Hezbollah guerrillas.
The five men found guilty today of a conspiracy involving fertilizer bombs were tied to a Qaeda training camp and two of the 2005 London bombers.
Golden State, the eighth-seeded team in the Western Conference, has a 3-1 lead in the best-of-seven series and can oust the top-seeded Mavericks on Tuesday in Dallas.
The sixth-seeded Nets won for the second consecutive time at home to take a 3-1 advantage in the series. They are a game from knocking off the third-seeded Raptors.
All work on New York subway tracks was suspended after the second fatal subway accident in less than a week.
Gov. Jon. S. Corzine will be released from a Camden hospital 18 days after he was critically injured in a traffic accident, his office announced.

The Suffolk County police shut down a stretch of the Long Island Expressway yesterday afternoon after a multicar pileup in Brentwood left the highway strewn with debris. No major injuries were reported, the police said. The police said a disabled vehicle was parked on the shoulder when another vehicle crashed into it about 2:30 p.m., setting off a chain of collisions involving as many as 10 other vehicles. The eastbound lanes of the expressway were closed between the Sagtikos Parkway and Wicks Road for nearly three hours.

A Brooklyn councilman has proposed legislation that would make it illegal to distribute menus, fliers and other circulars to homes and apartment buildings that display a sign indicating promotional material is unwanted. The councilman, Simcha Felder, a Democrat, has proposed a fine of at least $50 for distributors who leave the materials anyway. Mr. Felder said his constituents had complained about the number of fliers left at their doors. His mother, he said, received a $100 fine from the Sanitation Department for circulars left on her stoop. “You shouldn’t be responsible for cleaning up someone else’s garbage,” he said.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday that he would introduce legislation to lower costs for local governments, including changing a controversial law requiring multiple contractors for public construction projects. The law, called the Wicks Law, requires multiple contractors for projects costing more than $50,000, a threshold that has not been increased since the 1960s. The governor’s proposal would increase the threshold to $1 million for projects upstate and $2 million for projects in New York City and would adjust the numbers annually for inflation. Other proposals include steps aimed at giving local governments more flexibility in procurement and allowing them to use administrative proceedings, rather than court action, to handle housing code violations. “This bill will promote fiscal savings for our taxpayers, increase flexibility for our municipalities and ensure the long-term economic stability of our state,” the governor said.

Several lawmakers representing areas along the Jersey Shore say the state needs to quickly form a group to evaluate changes in hurricane evacuation routes. The Assembly passed legislation establishing the group, the New Jersey Coastal Evacuation Task Force, on Jan. 30, and called for it to convene within 60 days. With the Legislature tied up with the budget process and other matters, the task force has not yet been formed, Assemblyman Jeff Van Drew told The Press of Atlantic City. Assemblyman Brian E. Rumpf, one of the bill’s sponsors, said, “I realize there are a lot of pressing issues in the state, but none more pressing than a hurricane bearing down upon us.”.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency opened six flood damage recovery centers yesterday in New Jersey communities hit hard by the April 15 northeaster. Businesses and individuals who register with the agency can go to the centers to discuss options for federal assistance, said Barbara Lynch, an agency spokeswoman. Nine counties — Bergen, Burlington, Essex, Hudson, Middlesex, Morris, Passaic, Somerset and Union — have been declared federal disaster areas. The centers, in Bound Brook, Fairfield, Hackensack, Lumberton, Manville and Paterson, will be open from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. indefinitely, she said.

A man was scheduled to appear in State Superior Court in Milford today to face accusations that he led the state police on a 60-mile highway chase on Saturday that reached speeds of 100 miles per hour. The man, Michael Tanych of Milford, was arrested and charged with driving under the influence and reckless driving after crashing his car on Interstate 84 at the end of a 43-minute pursuit, the police said. The state police told The Connecticut Post that the chase began after another driver called 911 and reported that a motorist was assaulting someone in the back seat. Mr. Tanych was alone in his car, the state police said.

A fire on Saturday that killed an 87-year-old woman as she was preparing for her daughter’s surprise birthday party was started by children who were playing with a cigarette lighter, the Fire Department said yesterday. The fire started around 3:30 p.m. at 1136 Croes Avenue, in the Soundview neighborhood, in the ground-floor apartment of the victim, Carmen Davila. The flames quickly spread throughout the building. Ms. Davila’s daughter, Antonia Povod, lived on the third floor and was out getting her nails done when the fire began. Seven people escaped from the building, and except for Ms. Davila, no one was seriously injured, the Fire Department said.

A Bronx man was stabbed to death on Saturday night when an argument he was having with three other men escalated, witnesses told the police. The police said that officers responding to a 911 call found the man, Nasario Santiago Santiago, who they said was in his 20s, in front of 537 East 137th Street in Mott Haven at 9:10 p.m. with several stab wounds to his torso. He was taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, where he was pronounced dead. The police said yesterday that there had been no arrests, and that the case remained under investigation.
Corrections: For the Record
Barack Obama’s campaign has put a strain on the close relationship he forged over 20 years with his pastor.

The Jack Abramoff specter should be a warning as the Democratic House confronts its election promise to crack down on the sordid giving and taking of outsized chunks of special-interest lobbying money.
On the day Dale Earnhardt would have turned 56, Jeff Gordon won a race and passed him on the Nascar Nextel Cup career victory list.
So far, Maine has not come close to its goal of covering some 130,000 residents without insurance by ’09.
All the presidential candidates who spoke at the California Democratic Party convention were praised as they denounced the war in Iraq.
A fiery predawn accident sent concrete crashing onto a highway below and hobbled a vital Bay Area interchange.
The stage is set for the first cabinet-level meeting between Iran and the U.S. since the end of 2004.
On the volatile topic of immigration, Republicans are falling over themselves to convince voters that where they stand is not where they stood.
Militiamen loyal to the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr clashed with American forces in northern Baghdad on Sunday.
Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland, who has governed in a parliamentary coalition since 1997, has called for a general election to take place on May 24.
The Houston Rockets still have home-court advantage against Utah. Everything else seems to be going the Jazz’s way.
Playing at home after losing two games in Buffalo, the Rangers take this jolt of momentum into Tuesday’s Game 4 at the Garden.
After 12 years as the Democratic foil to a Republican governor, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has largely tried to stay out of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s way.
The Claremont Riding Academy, the oldest continuously operated stable in New York City, shut its doors for good on Sunday.
None of the additions will arrive at training camp as projected starters, but the Giants hope several of their choices will eventually find the top of the depth chart.
Every day that young Genarlow Wilson remains in prison for consensual sexual activity is a further indictment against the prosecutors, lawmakers and judges of the Georgia legal system.
Early on April 16, a student dropped off his girlfriend at her Virginia Tech dormitory; soon after, she would be the first victim of a gunman.

(Cinemax) HELMUT BY JUNE Helmut Newton’s photographs — eroticized, subversive, sometimes disturbing images of lush-bodied women in sadomasochistic poses — earned him the nickname the King of Kink. Newton, who died in 2004, said his models, including Cindy Crawford, Claudia Schiffer and Helena Christensen, were a commodity “paid to be made into what I want.” In this documentary June Newton, his wife of 56 years as well as his muse and model, turns her lens on her husband (above; she is holding the camera with him) as he stages photo shoots in the 1990s and blurs the line between fine art and pornography.

An article April 20 about House passage of legislation that would entitle the residents of the District of Columbia to a full voting representative in Congress incompletely described where members of Congress met after fleeing Philadelphia in 1783, one of the events that led to the creation of the district as a home for Congress. They reconvened first in Princeton, N.J., and later in Annapolis, Md., and Trenton, N.J., before moving to New York in 1785. They did not go directly from Princeton to New York.

The three most aggressive teams at this year's draft: 1. Cleveland Browns: Took left tackle Joe Thomas with the third overall pick, then made a trade and claimed Brady Quinn later in the first round. In the second round, took cornerback Eric Wright, a first-round talent whose stock declined because of character issues. 2. New England Patriots: Acquired an immediate starter in safety Brandon Meriweather, then made the biggest steal of the draft, acquiring Randy Moss for a fourth-round pick. 3. Oakland Raiders: Remade the franchise by acquiring quarterbacks Josh McCown and JaMarcus Russell and finally getting rid of Moss. The least aggressive: 1. Miami Dolphins: Inexplicably passed on Quinn to take Ted Ginn Jr. Still have not completed proposed trade for quarterback Trent Green. 2. Giants: Needed a cornerback, but instead of moving up for a better one, settled for Aaron Ross. Took Steve Smith, a receiver they will not need for a year. 3. Chicago Bears: Stayed put to select tight end Greg OlsEn with the 31st pick, but their next three picks on the first day raised eyebrows. The Lance Briggs standoff is still not resolved. JUDY BATTISTA

Neither the governor nor the people in his ambitious political operation have made a secret of their designs on the Republican-led Senate, which holds a two-seat majority in the 62-member chamber. One of the targets in the 2008 election is Sen. Hugh T. Farley, a Republican from Schenectady, but their preferred candidate to replace him appears to be changing. Last week, Mr. Spitzer, left, speaking from the steps of the Schenectady City Hall, chided Mr. Farley for joining Senate Republicans in opposing the governor's campaign finance reform plan. Notably absent during that speech was the city's mayor, Brian U. Stratton, once the Democrats' favorite to take on Mr. Farley. Party officials now prefer Assemblyman Paul D. Tonko of Amsterdam, who has represented the 105th District since 1983, because internal polls show him running more strongly than Mr. Stratton against Mr. Farley, said one person with knowledge of the Democrats' deliberations.
To the Editor: Re ''Pushing Co-ops to Explain Why You Can't Buy'' (front page, April 21):

SCHULTZ--Rev. Dr. John Frederick, 63, died Friday. He graduated from University of North Carolina and served in the Peace Corps in Nigeria. He completed his M.Div. at Union Theological Seminary and Ph.D. at Columbia. He worked for Church World Service from 1974-1990. He was ordained a Presbyterian minister in 1986. In 1990, Dr. Schultz joined Christian Children's Fund, the international child development agency, and was elected president in 1998. In 2004, he received a Distinguished Alumnus award from the University of North Carolina honoring his ''outstanding contributions to humanity through his work with relief and development efforts throughout the world.'' Dr. Schultz is survived by his wife of 38 years, Patricia Kelsey Schultz, his three children, two brothers, and two sisters. Memorial service in Richmond, Virginia. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The John F. Schultz Memorial Fund for the Greatest Needs of Children at Christian Children's Fund, 2821 Emerywood Parkway, Richmond, Virginia 23294.

A fire on Saturday that killed an 87-year-old woman as she was preparing for her daughter's surprise birthday party was started by children who were playing with a cigarette lighter, the Fire Department said yesterday. The fire started around 3:30 p.m. at 1136 Croes Avenue, in the Soundview neighborhood, in the ground-floor apartment of the victim, Carmen Davila. The flames quickly spread throughout the building. Ms. Davila's daughter, Antonia Povod, lived on the third floor and was out getting her nails done when the fire began. Seven people escaped from the building, and except for Ms. Davila, no one was seriously injured, the Fire Department said. MICHAEL WILSON

The daily press briefing was routine. Marie Okabe, a spokeswoman for the secretary general, read a five-minute update on Somalia, Darfur and the Security Council's actions, and about 30 journalists quietly listened. In the third row, Matthew Lee tapped away at his laptop and scribbled on two notepads with the intensity of a graduate student at thesis time. When Ms. Okabe asked for questions, Mr. Lee, the resident blogger of the United Nations press corps, pounced, asking almost as many questions in 20 minutes as the other correspondents combined.
An Op-Ed article on Wednesday, about the Supreme Court abortion ruling, misidentified the state involved in a similar abortion case in 2000. It was Nebraska, not Kansas.

BALL--Dr. Eugene R., died April 25, 2007, age 84. He had a private practice in dentistry and was a Associate Attending Dental Surgeon at St. Luke's Hospital. He served as a US Navy officer in the Pacific during World War II. He was a Fellow of the American College of Dentists. He was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club, the Tuxedo Club, the Society of Mayflower Decendents, the Military Order of Foreign Wars and the Society of Colonial Wars. He is survived by his wife Sally Ball and his children, Perry Ball and Martha Ball Heppenheimer, his grandchildren, Geoffrey Heppenheimer, Elizabeth Heppenheimer, Katherine Ball and Victoria Ball. Funeral Service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. at 90th Street at 3:30 pm May 3rd. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

Granny Linda to Jamie and Jack. Dearest friend of Valerie and Butch Elias. She will forever be in our hearts and greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. Services Tuesday, 12:30pm at The United Jewish Center, 141 Deer Hill Ave, Danbury, CT 203-748-3355.

Frank Langella will recreate the role of Richard M. Nixon when the Peter Morgan play ''Frost/Nixon'' is adapted for the screen under the direction of Ron Howard, Variety.com reported. Michael Sheen, starring as the interviewer David Frost opposite Mr. Langella on Broadway, will reprise his role in the film, scheduled to go before the cameras on Aug. 27.

HALBERSTAM--David. The Brearley School community deeply mourns the passing of David Halberstam, a Brearley past parent, former Trustee and great friend of the School. We extend our profound sympathies to his family.
BROWN--Themis Anastasia. Each day, each year we love and miss you more. Mom and Dad

MARRITT--Sondra. Beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother on April 28, 2007 after suffering with Alzheimer's Disease for many years. Matriarch of a large family, the last of six sisters and two brothers, keeping everyone together was one of her greatest accomplishments. Past President of B'nai Brith, Hewlett chapter. New York City resident for the last 19 years. Sandy was an inspiration to all in her fight against Alzheimer's and thanks to the love and care she received, was able to maintain her dignity throughout. Survived by her daughters and their husbands Joanne and Roy, Ina and Mark, grandchildren Gary and wife Julie, Jeremy, Matthew and wife Cindy, Michele, Stewart and wife Kathi. Great-grandchildren Zachary, Max, Joshua, Sami, Miranda and Sydney. Donations in her memory may be made to: Fisher Alzheimer's Program at NYU School of Medicine, attn: Barry Reisberg, M.D., adrc NYU Medical Center Rm MHL-316, 550 1st Ave, NY, NY 10016

Steve Hardwick joined Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group unit of the WPP Group, as president of the New York office, a post that was long vacant. He had been president of the New York office of StrawberryFrog since last September. Tammy Greenberg joined the Radio Advertising Bureau, New York, as senior vice president for marketing, a post being created as the bureau intensifies efforts to encourage advertisers to buy radio commercial time. Ms. Greenberg had been vice president for client partnerships at the Time Warner Global Media Group, New York, part of Time Warner, where she worked with Jeffrey M. Haley, now the president and chief executive of the bureau.
