MUKHADZE--Nana. On May 2, at 2pm at the Columbarium of the Cathedral of St. John Divine there will be a memorial gathering to mark the one year anniversary of Nana Mukhadze's tragic death. Her grieving mother and brother, her many loving friends, and the public that was inspired by her pianism continue to miss her terribly.

They are underdogs no more. In fact, the Golden State Warriors may need to get used to a new identity. The Warriors defeated the Dallas Mavericks again Sunday night, 103-99, and are now one victory away from completing one of the biggest upsets in N.B.A. history.

A front page article Friday on the resignation of Marilee Jones, M.I.T.'s dean of admissions, misidentified Leslie Perelman, a faculty member who commented on her resignation. He is the director of Writing Across the Curriculum at M.I.T., not the director of the M.I.T. program in writing and humanistic studies.

Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver's profile in the capital during the Spitzer administration has, at times, seemed lower than his voice, which registers so far down on the bass clef that Empire Zone has to lean in to hear. And so it remained as Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, skirmished last week. On Monday, the governor howled after Mr. Bruno rejected his proposed campaign finance reforms, and by the next morning, Mr. Spitzer was kicking off a statewide tour to bash Senate Republicans, beginning in Mr. Bruno's district upstate.

Tori Amos American Doll Posse (Epic) Tori Amos recently announced that her new album was ''an opportunity to reclaim the segmented pieces of the female psyche'' -- and, she added, to ''reunite them.'' Is that all? To this end, Ms. Amos has created five personae -- Isabel, Clyde, Pip, Santa and, confusingly, Tori -- to sing the 23 songs on ''American Doll Posse.'' Before you ask: yes, each persona does maintain a personal Web site.

With the 17th pick in the fourth round (116th over all), the Giants drafted Zak DeOssie, an outside linebacker from Brown. DeOssie, whose father, Steve, played in the N.F.L. for 12 seasons, was the only player drafted from the Ivy League this year, and he was the first from Brown since Sean Morey in 1999. Since 1936, Brown has produced only 27 players who were drafted. But jumping to the N.F.L. from the Ivy League is not uncommon. The Giants have one Ivy Leaguer, Jim Finn, who went to Penn.

JOSEPH--Richard V., 51, of Manhattan, passed away on April 26th at home, after a long and courageous struggle with brain cancer. Richard was born in Chicago. He attended high school in Tarrytown, NY, and moved to NYC at the age of 19. In his heart, he always was and always will be a City guy. His lifelong love of music is reflected in his choice of careers. He was the general manager at the Bitter End in Greenwich Village and, in the late 70's, was stage manager at the Bottom Line. During the late 70's and early 80's, he worked on the road for a variety of groups and performers including The Knack and the Rolling Stones. In the late 80's he founded his own travel company, Travel Tech, which specialized in travel arrangements and logistics for some of the world's largest touring bands. His clients included Paul Simon, AC/DC, Metallica, Barney, Prince, Janet Jackson, David Bowie, Bon Jovi, the Rolling Stones, Tina Turner, U2, and The Wiggles. He was a great guy who was loved by all he met, from rock stars to roadies. He will never be forgotten by the life-long friends he made while in the business, including Marc and Susan, Roger and Fitz, Jake and so many more. He was predeceased by his father, Richard C. Joseph. He is survived by his devoted and beloved wife, Meg, who cared for him with so much love during his illness. She was his rock, and she remains one now for all who knew and loved Richard. His truly loved and adored daughter, Florence ''Flory'' Lorraine Joseph, will always be their true treasure and greatest gift he has given to the friends and family he has left behind. Also surviving are his loving mother and stepfather, Lorraine and Charles Strachan of Guntersville, AL, his devoted sister, Linda Joseph of Moffat, CO, his wife's brothers and sisters and their children, who found their uncle to be one of the coolest and funniest guys on the planet. Services are being handled by Charles Peter Nagel, Inc., at 352 East 87th St. (between 1st and 2nd Ave.) in Manhattan. Visitation will be on Tuesday, May 1st, from 2 to 5 PM and from 7 to 9 PM. A Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated at Holy Trinity RC Church, 213 West 82nd St, on Wednesday, May 2, at 11 AM. A reception will follow after Mass in the parish center. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers his family asks that donations be made in his honor to ''Have A Chance'', 26 School House Rd., Morristown, NJ, 07960 (www.haveachance.org) or the New York Brain Tumor Project at the New York Weill Cornell Medical Center, 525 E 68th St, NY, NY 10021.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.91 percent.

Ne-Yo Because of You (Def Jam) Pity the R&B star Ne-Yo. All he really wants to do is write a few hits (he helped compose Beyoncé's ''Irreplaceable''), croon a few slow jams (his breakthrough single was ''So Sick,'' a winsome ode to a loser), sell a few million albums (he's getting there). But it's never that easy. Mere months after he recorded his heavy-breathed treatise on the importance of bedroom mirrors, a shocking rumor started circulating: it was whispered that the young singer suffered -- not unhappily, perhaps -- from sex addiction.
To the Editor: Re ''His Own Pope Yet?'' (Op-Ed, April 23):

A book review in Science Times last Tuesday about ''Hooked: How Medicine's Dependence on the Pharmaceutical Industry Undermines Professional Ethics,'' by Howard Brody, misstated part of the publisher's name. It is Rowman & Littlefield, not Bowman.
An Op-Ed article on Tuesday, about Boris Yeltsin, misspelled the given name of his wife. It is Naina, not Raina.

GARY--Raymond Bedros, Age 78 died peacefully on Saturday, April 28, 2007 after a short illness. He was the beloved husband of Prudence Gibb Gary for 36 years and the adored father of their daughter Amelia Mai Gary. He is also survived by his brother Captain Stanley Platt Gary and his family. B.A. Yale University 1950, M.A. Harvard University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, 1951. U.S. Navy 1951-1954, Morgan Stanley 1955, Partner 1964, Advisory Director 1983. Raymond was on the Board of Directors of the Third Street Music School Settlement and Stone Oil Corporation. There will be a service held at the Union Chapel, Fishers Island, N.Y. at 12:30pm on Friday, May 4, 2007 and a private family burial. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 East 11th Street, New York 10003 would be appreciated by the family.

ELIAS--Werner K., on April 27, 2007, at the age of 93. Beloved husband of the late Jean. Devoted father of Raymond (Lonnie). Dear grandfather of David and Debbie. Brother of Irmgard Hermann. Companion of Rose Gershowitz.

Angelique Kidjo Djin Djin (Razor & Tie/Starbucks Entertainment) The second half of ''Djin Djin,'' by Angelique Kidjo, finds this Beninese singer in characteristically good form. Backed by a choice selection of musicians, including her countrymen Crespin Kpitiki and Benoit Avihoue on percussion, she handily reinforces her stature as an upbeat heroine of contemporary Afro-pop.

TELECOM DEAL IN ITALY -- Telefónica and a group of Italian investors have agreed to pay about $5.6 billion for an 18 percent stake in Telecom Italia, which would let Telefónica, Europe's second-largest telecommunications provider, enter the Italian market and extend its presence in Latin America. [Page C1.] ALL ME, ALL THE TIME -- The social networking phenomenon is leaving the confines of the personal computer. Powerful new mobile devices are allowing people to send round-the-clock updates about their vacations, their moods or their latest haircut. [C1.] A NEW FILM RISK -- If the horror at Virginia Tech has changed the chemistry of America's popular culture, those who count box-office receipts at Lionsgate will be among the first to know. The independent studio still plans to release on June 8 its ''Hostel: Part II,'' about the torture killing of college students. [C1.] SPEAKING VIAGRA -- In promoting Viagra, its impotence treatment, Pfizer has irritated regulators with its wink-and-a-nod ads. Now it has ads feature middle-aged men and women talking in a made-up language, save for one word. [C1.] YAHOO MAKES A DEAL -- Yahoo plans to acquire Right Media, a privately held company that runs an advertising marketplace. [C2.] U.N.'S SOLE ACCREDITED BLOGGER -- Matthew Lee, left, is the only blogger at the United Nations with media credentials, entitling him to free office space and access to briefings and news conferences. The United Nations is one of the few institutions of size and importance that allow bloggers not affiliated with larger, more traditional media companies. [C6.] THE FIVE-MINUTE 'STARSKY' -- The Sony Corporation has shrunk episodes of '70s and '80s television series to three and a half to five minutes, hoping to create a new business in retooling old shows for a new era of entertainment. [C4.] COMPETITIVE VOCABULARY -- Now that spelling bees have been turned into a hit Broadway show and crossword puzzles into a movie, the publishers of the American Heritage dictionary are hoping to create a cultural moment with a competitive game about word definitions. [C4.] ALL YOUR STUFF, ONLINE -- At least three companies have emerged in recent months with the aim of helping people catalog and value their possessions and post them online. The plan is to attract millions of people, then find retailers who want to sell them more items to go along with their possessions. [C8.] MORE GARDEN THAN GUN -- The title of Garden & Gun, a new lifestyle magazine from Charleston, S.C., might not have raised eyebrows had it not been for the fact that the premiere issue hit newsstands just days before the shootings at Virginia Tech on April 16. [C6.] GOOGLING STATE DATA -- Four states have joined forces with Google to make information from their Web sites more directly accessible through Internet searches. [C8.] INVESTING IN CLEAN ENERGY -- Money flowing into alternative energy companies is raising the threat of a bubble, according to a research firm, but investors may be overlooking other clean technologies. [C7.] A PLUG FOR PHONE LEAKS -- Drumming up business would seem to be an easy task for those who sell encrypted cellphones in Italy. All they have to do is browse the major newspapers, looking for leaked telephone conversations. [C6.] EX-ABC NEWSMAN MOVING TO TIME -- Mark Halperin, the longtime political director of ABC News and a pioneer of online reporting, is moving to Time magazine. [C2.] ADS FOR INTERNET RADIO -- A start-up company, TargetSpot, is trying to turn the nascent field of Internet radio into a viable business, and CBS Radio is its first customer. [C10.] CHINA TIGHTENS MONEY AGAIN -- For the second time this month, China has ordered banks to hold more of their deposits in reserve as it seeks to prevent credit and investment growth from destabilizing the economy. [C2.] BEST PLACES TO BLOG ABOUT -- Clinton Hill in Brooklyn is the most blogged-about neighborhood in America, says a Web site that found a link between gentrification and the number of people who feel compelled to think out loud about the changes in their backyards. [C6.] WHAT GOES AROUND -- The pop culture magazine Radar has accused a Chilean magazine of ripping off its story on ''Toxic Bachelors,'' but freely admits that it borrowed the concept from other sources, like a book by Danielle Steele and the ''Sex and the City'' series. [C6.]

PERESS--Fahmi Moshi, beloved uncle, in his 90s at home on April 26 in Fort Lauderdale. Baghdad-born businessman, US Army Sergeant in World War II, the last surviving grandson of Heskel Ezra Peress and Salha Rahmin Masri the Babylonian Jewish progenitors of our proud far-flung family spread throughout the United States, Israel, Canada, France, England, Switzerland and Brazil. In memory of our father, Henry Moshi Peress. Herbert Peress and family Maurice Peress and family

INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Iran Announces Intentions To Attend Iraq Conference The government of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran announced that it would attend a regional conference on Iraq this week, setting the stage for the first cabinet-level meeting between Iran and the United States since 2004. A1 Stephen J. Hadley, the national security adviser, is interviewing candidates for a new high-profile job that people in Washington are calling the war czar. The official would brief President Bush every morning on Iraq and Afghanistan, then prod cabinet secretaries into carrying out White House orders. A1 Militiamen loyal to the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr clashed with American forces in northern Baghdad, an Interior Ministry official said, the latest in a series of indications that the militia may be emerging from two months of self-imposed dormancy. A5 Ireland Head Calls for Elections Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland called for a general election next month. Under Irish law Mr. Ahern had to call elections by midsummer. He said he would campaign for re-election on the strength of the economy and helping restore Northern Ireland's stalled peace process. A6 Conduct Report Looms in Israel As an official report on the Israeli government's failings during the recent war against Hezbollah in Lebanon is about to be published, the main topic of public debate is whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert will be able to hang onto power. Current polls show his approval ratings hovering between 2 and 3 percent. A6 U.S.-Afghan Raid Kills 6 American and Afghan troops raided a suspected bomb-making compound killing six people, including two women, and wounding two children, Afghan officials said. Angry villagers took the bodies of victims onto the main Kabul-to-Pakistan highway and demonstrated for more than five hours. A6 NATIONAL A14-18 Maine's Health Overhaul Harbors Costly Lessons Maine's new health care system was intended to provide universal care and cover 130,000 uninsured residents. But so far only 18,800 people have signed up for the state's coverage, DirigoChoice. The story of Maine's health program may harbor lessons for the country, as efforts to cover the uninsured take center stage in nearly every state. A1 Obama's Religious Background Senator Barack Obama converted to Christianity as an adult after an upbringing that offered him a course in comparative religion but no belief to call his own. Now his ties to a controversial Chicago minister have become a delicate issue for him as a presidential candidate. A1 Freeway Collapses in Bay Area A tanker truck accident caused a freeway overpass near downtown Oakland to collapse, sending hundreds of feet of concrete crashing onto a highway below, injuring the driver of the tanker truck. The repairs are likely to complicate the lives of Bay Area commuters for months. A14 Democrats Divided Over Veto The Democratic presidential field is divided over how to respond to President Bush's expected veto of legislation setting a timeline for removing troops from Iraq. While the candidates agree that the war should be ended, they differ over how fast troops should be withdrawn. A16 Spokesman Returns to Work Tony Snow, the White House press secretary, is to return to work today, while undergoing chemotherapy after a five-week absence after having discovered his colon cancer had spread to his liver. A15 Wrong Suspect Copes With Loss The killing of the first victim of the Virginia Tech shootings, Emily Hilscher, initially drew suspicion to her boyfriend, Karl D. Thornhill. Although he was soon cleared of wrongdoing, he is still coping with losing his girlfriend and being suspected in her death. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-4 Patrons Take a Final Ride As Historic Stable Closes The Claremont Riding Academy, the oldest continuously operated stable in New York City, has officially closed its doors. What made Claremont unique was not so much what it was but where it was: in the heart of the Upper West Side. B1 Little Relief for Over-65 Set When Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders announced $1.3 billion in new property tax relief, they did not mention that taxpayers 65 and older ended up with hardly any more money than they received last year under the plan. B1 An Artist's Legacy It would be impossible to mention Eddie Boros, an artist from the East Village who died on Friday, without describing his most visible work: a looming sculpture that rises 65 feet. The structure's survival over more than two decades has elevated it to the status of a neighborhood institution. B3 SPORTSMONDAY D1-10 Cardinals Pitcher Dies in Crash Josh Hancock, a relief pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, died in an automobile accident. His death was being compared to the 2002 death of Cardinals starting pitcher Darryl Kile. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Deal for Telecom Italia Telefónica of Spain and a group of Italian investors agreed to buy a controlling stake in Telecom Italia, allowing the Spanish telecommunications giant to expand into Italy and Latin America. C1 Film Tests Appetite for Horror ''Hostel: Part II,'' a movie about the torture killing of college students, will serve as a test of the public's interest in graphic violence in the wake of killings at Virginia Tech. C1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES A19 Polly Hill A horticulturist who stretched the boundaries of plant hardiness, she was 100. A19 Michael Malone A tattoo artist renowned for helping popularize and standardize tattooing through vivid images of dragons, daggers and crests, he was 64. A19 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: The amnesty sideshow; who's afraid of pay go?; Georgia's shame; bundling in the Capitol. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E7 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E8 Weather B5
A poem by Kurt Vonnegut on April 20 carried an incorrect description of its history. It had appeared in The Cornell Daily Sun in 2005; it was not unpublished.

To the Editor: Re ''Bloomberg Draws a 25-Year Blueprint for a Greener City'' (news article, April 23):

Irish Leader Calls Election Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland, who with his centrist party, Fianna Fail, has governed in a parliamentary coalition since 1997, has called for a general election to take place on May 24. PAGE A6 Saddling Up For a Final Ride Patrons said goodbye and some got in one last ride on the final day of operations for the Claremont Riding Academy on the Upper West Side. The academy, a patch of un-Manhattan in the middle of Manhattan, was the oldest continuously operated stable in New York City. PAGE B1 Social Networking by Phone The social networking experience is going mobile, with powerful new devices that allow people to share round-the-clock updates about their vacations, their moods or their latest haircut. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Bay Area Overpass Collapses A fiery tanker truck accident caused the collapse of an overpass near downtown Oakland, Calif., hobbling a vital interchange. The driver had second-degree burns; no other injuries were reported. PAGE A14

ZUPNICK--Beatrice. Bea, the love of Alex's life. Alex, the love of her life. They met at age 13 in French class at Lincoln High School. Married at 21 for 66 amazing years. He taught her about music and opera. She taught him about art and ballet. Both loved reading, theater, movies, and traveling the world. They were dubbed Bealex, a one unit dynamo. Loving nurturing mother-a fierce lioness. Child actress in Yiddish theater with Maurice Schwarz, loved to laugh, feisty, passionate, beautiful, bright, avid crossword puzzle practitioner. Life long friends, Dorothy Leviss and Jean Wardell were her partners in a gallery of Asian art in Great Neck. Her family were among her closest friends -brother Sy, his wife Audrey, and the entire Bruckner clan, Alex's sister Annie and husband Marty Weis, (Alex's childhood Friend). She was very proud of having raised a doctor and a judge and deeply loved Eileen, her daughter-in-law and Allen Kopelson, her son in law. She was most proud of her two grandsons Hunter and Cody Zupnick. Sheer luck to have been born to two people we considered two of our closest friends. Jerry Zupnick and Robin Kopelson.

''I was in a mall walking by the arcade and I saw these kids playing D.D.R., and I was just stunned. There were all these kids dancing and sweating and actually standing in line and paying money to be physically active.'' LINDA M. CARSON, a physical education professor, on the video game Dance Dance Revolution. [A18]

The Suffolk County police shut down a stretch of the Long Island Expressway yesterday afternoon after a multicar pileup in Brentwood left the highway strewn with debris. No major injuries were reported, the police said. The police said a disabled vehicle was parked on the shoulder when another vehicle crashed into it about 2:30 p.m., setting off a chain of collisions involving as many as 10 other vehicles. The eastbound lanes of the expressway were closed between the Sagtikos Parkway and Wicks Road for nearly three hours. TRYMAINE LEE

YEARGANS--Kay (nee Schneeweiss). 80. Died unexpectedly on April 26, 2007. Beloved mother of Kara, devoted sister of Sam and Sarah, and aunt of Elliot and Sheryl Gordon. Service Tuesday, May 1st at 2pm at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave., Manhattan.

Asking consumers to help create commercials is a hot trend in advertising. Now, the public is being invited for the first time to choose the winner of an advertising award. The One Club for Art and Copy in New York has put up a Web site (oneshow.tv) where consumers can select their favorite commercial from among the spots from 2006 that are finalists for awards. At the One Show awards ceremony on May 9, the commercial with the most consumer votes will receive a People's Choice Award, said Mary Warlick, executive director of the club.

And now, more entries from the legislative bad behavior blotter. For starters, there was Assemblyman Mike Cole's admission last week that, after a night of drinking last month, he had slept on the floor of an Albany apartment where a 21-year-old female intern lived. The incident got the intern fired and landed Mr. Cole, 35, a Republican who represents parts of Erie and Niagara Counties, in front of the Assembly's ethics committee.

International Olympic Committee, Lausanne, Switzerland, chose the United Group, part of the WPP Group, as its creative agency. Spending was estimated at $125 million. A review included the incumbent, Saatchi & Saatchi, part of the Publicis Groupe, which created ads for the 2004 and 2006 Olympics. Chili's Grill and Bar, part of Brinker International, Dallas, placed its creative account in review after having spent almost 20 years with GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group. Spending was estimated at $120 million. GSD&M, which created campaigns like the ''I Want My Baby Back'' ads for baby-back ribs, will not take part in the review.

An article in Business Day last Monday about changes at The Philadelphia Inquirer, using information supplied by the newspaper, misstated the source of a photograph of two Amish women taken after last year's shooting at a schoolhouse. The photograph, which hangs near the office of Brian P. Tierney, the publisher, was in The Daily News, not in The Inquirer.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday that he would introduce legislation to lower costs for local governments, including changing a controversial law requiring multiple contractors for public construction projects. The law, called the Wicks Law, requires multiple contractors for projects costing more than $50,000, a threshold that has not been increased since the 1960s. The governor's proposal would increase the threshold to $1 million for projects upstate and $2 million for projects in New York City and would adjust the numbers annually for inflation. Other proposals include steps aimed at giving local governments more flexibility in procurement and allowing them to use administrative proceedings, rather than court action, to handle housing code violations. ''This bill will promote fiscal savings for our taxpayers, increase flexibility for our municipalities and ensure the long-term economic stability of our state,'' the governor said. DANNY HAKIM

When the telephone rang in Bruce Evans's home in Vestavia Hills, Ala., at 6:30 a.m. yesterday, the sound jolted him. The news that Evans then received stunned him. He learned that Josh Hancock, a relief pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, had died in an automobile accident. Evans, the baseball coach at Vestavia Hills High School, coached the junior varsity team while Hancock was pitching the varsity to three consecutive state titles from 1994-96. Evans said Hancock was a free spirit whose days and nights revolved around baseball.

The Fred Hersch Trio Night & the Music (Palmetto) There's a pristine quality to the pianism of Fred Hersch that can give the false impression of conservatism. On ''Night & the Music,'' Mr. Hersch undercuts that feeling in subtle ways: a tremulous two-handed run here, a quietly mounting tension there. He sounds unfailingly articulate, on songbook standards as well as on several original tunes, and at times it all seems a bit too relaxed, if not exactly easy.

A Bronx man was stabbed to death on Saturday night when an argument he was having with three other men escalated, witnesses told the police. The police said that officers responding to a 911 call found the man, Nasario Santiago Santiago, who they said was in his 20s, in front of 537 East 137th Street in Mott Haven at 9:10 p.m. with several stab wounds to his torso. He was taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, where he was pronounced dead. The police said yesterday that there had been no arrests, and that the case remained under investigation. THOMAS J. LUECK

Because of an editing error, a television review last Monday about ''The Real Wedding Crashers,'' on NBC, omitted the first word of the title of a forthcoming book on weddings by Rebecca Mead. The title is ''One Perfect Day: The Selling of the American Wedding.''

QUARTERLY REPORTS -- Earnings season continues, led by Verizon (Monday), Time Warner (Wednesday) and General Motors and CBS (Thursday). Other reports will come from Humana, Kellogg, Loews, RadioShack and Tyson Foods (Monday); Archer Daniels Midland, Avon Products, Chiquita Brands, DreamWorks Animation, MetLife, Procter & Gamble, Qwest Communications, Sirius Satellite Radio and Yum Brands (Tuesday); Biogen Idec, Blockbuster, Credit Suisse, JDS Uniphase, Jones Apparel, MasterCard and Sprint Nextel (Wednesday); Cablevision, Electronic Data Systems, IAC/InterAc-tiveCorp, International Paper, Royal Dutch/Shell, Sanofi-Aventis, Starbucks, UBS and Unilever (Thursday); and Eastman Kodak, Hyundai Motor, Total and Weyerhaeuser (Friday). ECONOMIC MARKERS -- The main economic news will be the unemployment report for April (Friday). Other reports will include personal income and spending for March, the Chicago purchasing managers' index for April and construction spending for March (Monday); the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index for April (Tuesday); factory orders for March (Wednesday); and first-quarter productivity, the Institute for Supply Management's service index and weekly jobless claims (Thursday). ET CETERA -- Automakers will report April sales (Tuesday). The trial of Conrad Black continues in Chicago.

WEINSIER--Philip, April 28, 2007, age 91, at home and, as always, with class. Handsome, beloved husband of the late Joan Tuby Weinsier, cherished and treasured father of Michael Weinsier (Marcy) and Wendy Segal (Danny) and loving and adored grandfather of Matthew and Jacqueline. Sweet, kind sonin-law of Evelyn Tuby and admired brother-in-law of Suellen Globus. Loving brother of the late Grace Maslow and Shirley, Saul and Randolph Weinsier. ''Ace'' was his name, golf was his game and race horses were his passion. Graduate of Washington and Lee University, WWII Army Lieutenant. The last of the great gentlemen, with humor 'til the end. A gracious man. Funeral private. Donations can be made in his name to the American Cancer Society or the Visiting Nurse Service of New York Hospice Care.

LEVINE--Anne F. The Peninsula Hospital Center and Peninsula Center for Extended Care and Rehabilitation families are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of one of its most admired and cherished friends, Anne F. Levine, PHC Auxiliary Co-President, Benefactor, devoted advocate for the hospital center and beloved mother of Robert V. Levine, President and Chief Executive Officer of Peninsula Hospital Center. Anne's gracious warmth and charming presence will be dearly missed. $(6$)LEVINE--Anne F., 80, passed away on April 28, 2007. Her life was full of optimism, love and charity. Beloved wife of the late Morton G. Levine, cherished mother of Rose (Sylvan), David (Pam) and Robert (Phyllis); loving and adoring grandmother of Joshua (Tiffany), Jessica, and Alanna; Danny and Michael; and Jordan and Scott. Graduate of Brooklyn College, Anne Levine was a NYC school teacher of over 30 years and Co-President of the Peninsula Hospital Center Auxiliary for many years, and involved in various community activities in the Rockaway section of Queens. Funeral services, Monday, April 30, 12:00 PM at Boulevard-Riverside-Hewlett Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11577.

A picture caption Friday with a front-page article about fear among Pakistanis in Lodi, Calif., after the arrest last year of two local men on terrorism charges misstated the name of a boy pictured with Raheela Hayat, whose brother, Hamid Hayat, was found guilty in the case. He is Jalal Hashim Usman, not Hamid. In some copies, the caption misstated the boy's relationship to Hamid Hayat. He is his nephew, not his son.

While a film's box-office take during its first weekend doesn't guarantee a huge gross, it helps to open with a bang. Each of the top 10 films, with the exception of ''X-Men'' and ''Lost World,'' attracted more than $300 million, after adjusting for inflation. ''Spider-Man 3,'' above, opens on Friday, and it will probably join this list. But it will have a long way to go to top ''Spider-Man,'' which earned an inflation-adjusted $461 million, not to mention ''Titanic'' (1997), at $769 million, and ''Star Wars'' (1977), at $1.6 billion. SHELLY FREIERMAN

HAUSMANN--Rosalie L. On Sunday April 29, 2007, of Chevy Chase, MD. Wife of the late David S. Hausmann, mother of Beth Mauser, grandmother of Amy Mauser and Elizabeth (Eric) Goldstein, great-grandmother of Brittany, Dana and David. Graveside services on Tuesday, May 1, 2007, 2 pm at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Memorial contributions to The Barker Foundation, 7979 Old Georgetown Rd., Bethesda, MD 20814 or to Children's National Medical Center, 111 Michigan Ave. NW, Washington D.C., 20010. Services by Torchinsky Hebrew Funeral Home, Washington D.C., 1-800-5005401.

Tonight, when the strains of Juilliard Orchestra violins have died away and Audra McDonald's vibrato is a fading memory, Alice Tully Hall will bid New York a temporary adieu and go dark until late 2008. This evening's gala, ''Good Night Alice,'' signals the start of a major transformation of the stage and surrounding spaces as part of Lincoln Center's ambitious redevelopment plan. The work is expected to take 18 months.

An article last Monday about the prosecution of an American business executive in Kazakhstan on charges he stole $40,000 from his company omitted the company's name and misidentified its owners. The company is Arna Inc., and it is owned by GIMV, a Belgian investment company; the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development; and Murat Zhunussov, a Kazakh investor. Arna is not a Kazakhstan subsidiary of Golden Telecom, a Moscow-based Internet and telecommunications company.
If you're a political junkie with Internet access looking for cheap laughs - and if you're reading this column, you probably are - take a minute, go to YouTube and search for "Nixon" and "Rove."
The Rev. Louis Braxton Jr. runs a homeless shelter in Queens for young transgendered men working as prostitutes.

Today is the 16th anniversary of one of those fun days in baseball history, when Rickey Henderson broke the career stolen-base record in the afternoon and Nolan Ryan fired his seventh no-hitter at night.

Just a short while ago, President Bush made good on his promise, and vetoed the war spending bill that included a timeline for troop withdrawal passed by the Democratic-controlled Congress last month. He made his action public in a short announcement, saying the Democrats had approved a plan that set a "rigid and artificial" deadline that "would impose impossible conditions for our commanders and troops in combat."

We were told by spies for The Caucus that Fred D. Thompson was taking his stealth campaign for president here to New York, the media capital of the world. The venue? The St. Regis Hotel, for an event sponsored by Guggenheim Advisors, the giant hedge fund, where Mr. Thompson and Lawrence B. Lindsey were slated to deliver an "economic policy and national security briefing."
How does a four-star restaurant look through the eyes of a New York teenager eating at one for the first time?
California and New York and other big boys can move up their 2008 presidential primaries to influence the nominating contest all they want, but tiny New Hampshire still has political muscle to spare.

As protesters rally around the country in support of citizenship for undocumented workers, a different group of immigrants and their descendents sat quietly at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor seeking the G.O.P. presidential nomination, walked a careful line while addressing immigration before the Latino Coalition's Small Business Economic Conference.

When Tony La Russa, the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, was told that Ned Yost, the manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, said that he would do anything to help them deal with the death of reliever Josh Hancock, La Russa nodded his head in appreciation.

In a bid as high-profile and potentially contentious as News Corporation's $5 billion offer for Dow Jones & Company, it's only natural that the players in the drama would reach for the big guns. And so they have.
Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a favorite spring recipe for risotto with asparagus.

I always knew I was special. And now research from San Diego State University proves that I am just as unique as everybody else: I and my collegiate peers are 30 percent more narcissistic than the fluffy-haired and spandex-clad college students of 1982.
The Associated Press reported that a Mets fan who pleaded guilty Tuesday to shining a high-powered flashlight at two Atlanta Braves players last month will be banned from Shea for three years.
Time for round two in News Corporation's quest to win Dow Jones & Company.
Rupert Murdoch has left the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, in a difficult position.

A Duke University judicial panel's determination that 34 M.B.A. students cheated on an exam has some people wondering whether the spate of ethics classes - introduced in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom scandals - are doing any good.

The headline number is eye-catching, but the logic behind Rupert Murdoch's $5 billion offer for Dow Jones & Company may be even more interesting. Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation already has an array of broadcasting, film, print and Internet assets. What does he want with Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal?
In "Brando," the documentary that starts tonight on Turner Classic Movies, there's an amazing home video made by Brando and Montgomery Clift.
