If you stumbled upon the beginning of Willie Randolph's postgame press conference last night, it was pretty easy to tell how displeased he was with Chan Ho Park's performance.

Rumors that the Bancrofts would sell Dow Jones, the 125-year-old publishing company they control through family trusts, have circulated for years. Usually, they peter out as observers note the family's loyalty to management and its fealty to the idea that The Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones's flagship publication, is a public trust and not just an asset.

Whenever I take a road trip for more than a few hundred miles, I make a playlist. And while I was putting together some tunes for my Indiana trip last month, I realized I had enough current car songs and songs mentioning cars for a list of their own.
The Safety Board created a video of the flight, combining animation with footage of the impact recorded by a surveillance camera.

Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno, the state's top Republican, said he would not support Gov. Eliot Spitzer's bill to legalize gay marriage, most likely dooming the measure. This was the expected outcome, which even the governor had predicted.

It's trendy these days to make fun of PowerPoint pitches. "Death by PowerPoint" is a hilarious buzzword that refers to truly awful boardroom pitches in which the speaker dully reads the bullet points off PowerPoint slides.

Shares of several newspaper publishing companies posted big gains after Dow Jones disclosed that it received an unsolicited takeover offer from News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's global media empire. Dow Jones said Tuesday it was considering the proposal but warned that a deal might not happen; nevertheless, investors bid up shares of its peers, apparently hoping that they might also become takeover targets.
Campaigners at Greenpeace India this week named the light bulb manufacturer Philips as one of the country's big contributors to greenhouse gas emissions.
The American Lung Association released its rankings of most polluted cities in America, and Los Angeles once again found itself leading the pack.
I am going to Paris in August with my 13-year-old daughter. How can I make the best of perhaps the worst month to go?

In January, John Browne, chief executive of BP, the British energy company, announced that he would step down in July, more than a year earlier than expected. But he didn't make it that long: Mr. Browne quit Tuesday as head of the company after a judge lifted a ban on newspaper reports that alleged that he had spent company funds on a Canadian man with whom he had a relationship.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential team is holding a "major supporter briefing" at the Phoenix Park Hotel in Washington this afternoon, followed by a reception at her home this evening, in an effort to engage both new and long-time donors through strategy and policy briefings and rally-the-troops remarks from campaign officials, according to several donors who plan to attend.

News Corporation has made an unsolicited bid for Dow Jones that values the publisher of The Wall Street Journal and Barron's at about $5 billion. Dow Jones, a 125-year-old company controlled by the Bancroft family, said it is evaluating the offer, which may come either as a cash bid or cash and News Corp. stock.

The governor is in California today, attending what a spokeswoman, Christine Anderson, described as a series of private fundraising meetings in San Franciso. It is one of his few trips out the state since he became governor.

The Property Finders, an international buying agency, has extended its service into the French Riviera with the appointment of Martha Saavedra. Ms. Saavedra will be covering the French Riviera from Mandelieu to Menton including St. Tropez and the East-Var.

David Sidwell, who as chief financial officer at Morgan Stanley helped guide the firm through a turbulent management shake-up, will retire at the end of the year. He will be succeeded by Colm Kelleher, the head of global capital markets, Morgan Stanley said Tuesday.
Cost cutting and an increase in high-speed Internet subscribers helped the phone company earn $240 million for the quarter.

Donald G. Drapkin, who had been vice chairman of Ronald Perelman's investment firm, MacAndrews & Forbes, has taken a position at Lazard, the publicly traded investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein. Lazard said in a news release Tuesday that Mr. Drapkin joined Lazard as of May 1 as vice chairman of its international unit and chairman of its investment committee. Among other things, he will help the firm look for strategic investments and initiatives, Lazard said.

If you only know him as Arthur Branch, the "Law & Order" district attorney, then you absolutely must read Carl Hulse's latest on Fred D. Thompson. The Times's top congressional correspondent outlines the strengths, weaknesses and next steps for the man with the greatest potential to scramble the G.O.P.'s top tier.

An Iraqi security official's announcement today of the death of Abu Ayyub al-Masri, the leader of Al Qaeda's Iraq operations, prompted a denial from an Iraqi insurgent Web site and cautious responses from the chief spokesman of the Iraqi government and the United States military.

"Attorney General Alberto Gonzales signed a highly confidential order in March 2006 delegating to two of his top aides - who have since resigned because of their central roles in the firings of eight U.S. attorneys - extraordinary authority over the hiring and firing of most non-civil-service employees of the Justice Department," Murray Waas reports in National Journal. "A copy of the order and other Justice Department records related to the conception and implementation of the order were provided to National Journal."

The chief executive of the private equity firm TA Associates, Kevin Landry, offers a new take on talk of a private-equity bubble. Speaking to The Boston Globe's Steven Syre about all the private equity cash sloshing around and the unprecedented scale of leveraged buyouts, Mr. Landry said:

Like deep-dish pizza, the Cubs and a mayor named Daley, LaSalle Bank has long been a Chicago institution. But until a few weeks ago, few would have called it a global banking prize. Now, LaSalle is at the center of what could be the biggest bank deal ever, as a trophy for at least two banking titans: Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine left the hospital yesterday, with no public events scheduled this week while he recuperates at Drumthwacket, the official residence of New Jersey governors. For the record, here is what he had to say about his failure to wear a seat belt in the crash that led to his serious injuries:
A year ago today, hundreds of thousands of immigrants marched in dozens of cities across the United States. Today, the numbers are expected to be much smaller.

Alibaba.com, China's leading e-commerce company, is planning to go public later this year in what could be the biggest initial public offering ever for a Chinese Internet company, The New York Times reported, citing people briefed on the deal. Three Wall Street investment banks, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank, are advising Alibaba on the public offering, which The Times said could raise $1 billion.

Campaign strategies, endorsements, advertising content and hairdo management. Many factors can influence a political race, and every handicapper has an equation for predicting. Since the late 1980's, a group of psychologists at the University of Pennsylvania has had a system based on a single factor: optimism.

Microsoft has emerged as a contender to buy the online advertising firm 24/7 Real Media in an effort to stay competitive with online rivals Google and Yahoo, The New York Post reported Tuesday. Citing unnamed sources, the Post said that Microsoft is considering a bid of about $1 billion, a hefty premium over the $600 million value that analysts have given the firm.

Royal Bank of Canada's investment banking arm said it would acquire Seasongood & Mayer, a municipal bond firm based in Cincinnati, for an undisclosed price. RBC Capital Markets said in a news release that the deal, which it expects to close in the second quarter, would bolster its position in the municipal investment banking market in the United States.

While most buyout funds are getting bigger, Silver Lake Partners, one of the first heavyweight firms to focus exclusively on technology, is broadening its horizons - by looking at smaller deals, Adam Lashinksy notes in his Go West blog for Fortune.

The cross-examination of Marie-Josée Kravis, a crucial witness at the trial of Conrad M. Black, grew heated on Monday when a defense lawyer attempted to portray the witness as forgetful or inept. In response, Mrs. Kravis, a former director of Mr. Black's company, Hollinger International, maintained that she and other directors were misled about millions of dollars in payments Mr. Black and other executives received.

As the line between private equity and hedge funds becomes ever more blurred, The Financial Times reports that D.E. Shaw, the $29 billion hedge fund, is considering setting up a private equity fund into which it could inject some of its existing holdings, potentially including the storied toy shop FAO Schwarz.

Adding fuel to the speculation it could be a suitor for Wendy's, The Triac Companies said Monday that it was selling its controlling stake in the money management firm Deerfield & Company for about $300 million to become a pure play restaurant operator.

Pure Digital, a tech firm with some impressive financial backing, is hoping to piggyback on the success of YouTube and other online video sites with a new, inexpensive camcorder geared to older consumers who may not be as tech-savvy as their kids.
BCE, Canada's largest telephone services provider, said Monday that it intends to attract multiple takeover bids as it considers going private.

Reuters announced on Monday that it would acquire a text analytics company, ClearForest, to enhance its advanced search capabilities. Up until this point, ClearForest had primarily marketed its products, text analytics technologies and a tagging platform, to business clients that need to manage and facilitate access to large amounts of information.
A former Tyco International executive has agreed to settle civil charges that he helped inflate the company's profits through sham transactions, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Monday.

Comcast said Monday it would pay $570 million for an interest in two regional cable sports networks, one in San Francisco and the other in New England. In a cash transaction withRainbow Media Holdings, Comcast will purchase a 60 percent interest in FSN Bay Area and a 50 percent interest in FSN New England.

The pressure on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to raise its bid for the Chicago Board of Trade intensified on Monday as the premium in the rival offer from the Intercontinental Exchange touched $1.5 billion for the first time, The Financial Times said.

The Interactive Brokers Group, an electronic broker and market-making firm controlled by Thomas Peterffy, increased the size and price range of a proposed initial public offering on Monday and said it expects to raise about $1 billion.

IMG, the sports and media marketing firm led by the financier Theodore J. Forstmann, said Tuesday it would buy the Collegiate Licensing Company, a trademark licensing agency whose clients include the Rose Bowl, the Heisman Trophy and the N.C.A.A. Terms were not disclosed.

Castle Harlan, the private equity firm, will make about two and a half times its money after just a year when it sells the tubing company RathGibson to DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, according to The Deal.com. DLJ Merchant Banking, the private equity arm of the Credit Suisse Group, said Monday that it would pay $440 million for RathGibson.

Delta Air Lines emerged from bankruptcy protection Monday after surviving a hostile takeover bid and cutting billions in costs in a 19-month overhaul. The board will now turn its attention to picking a successor to its chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, and deciding whether to sell or spin off its regional feeder carrier, Comair.

The optical implant developer ReVision Optics raised $25 million in a Series D financing led by Domain Associates to support clinical trials in its quest to deliver the first commercial implants to replace reading glasses in an aging population.

Low interest rates aren't the only reason that private equity firms are having a buyout bonanza, Derek DeCloet writes in The Globe and Mail. These firms have something that fund managers and the public markets seem to lack: A long-term perspective.
New Century Financial, the subprime lender, has a host of woes at the moment and it seems it can add the use of a certain accounting technique to that list.

The German stock exchange operator Deutsche Börse said Monday it is in discussions to buy the American options exchange International Securities Exchange Holdings for $2.8 billion. Deutsche Börse said its offer would value the exchange at $67.50 a share, a premium of nearly 50 percent over its closing stock price on Friday. Deutsche Börse said that it had agreed to pay $67.50 a share for the exchange, a 48 percent premium over its closing price on Friday.

Lululemon, a Canadian retailer of yoga-inspired apparel, filed with regulators to raise as much as $230 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq and the Toronto Stock Exchange. The company's backers include private equity firm Advent International and venture capital firm Highland Capital Partners.
Merrill Lynch said Monday that it would buy back as much as $6 billion of its common stock over time, as the firm looks to return capital that is building up on its balance sheet to investors.

Two former executives at Westar Energy, David C. Wittig and Douglas T. Lake, will face trial for a third time on criminal charges that accuse them of trying to loot the utility, a federal prosecutor said Monday.
Cablevision is near a deal to sell the company to its founding family, the Dolans, for about $10.5 billion.
Some of the largest of the demonstrations were in Los Angeles and in Chicago.
As this documentary makes clear, hitting its points with style, Marlon Brando wasn’t like other movie stars.
An enormous movie theater in Washington Heights has been turned into a major indie music venue, bringing scores of scenesters to 175th street.
Tour a 135-acre Vermont estate, a contemporary home in Sun Valley, Idaho, and a three-bedroom condo on the beach in Malibu, Calif.

Globalization and new manufacturing capabilities have changed the makeup of the food that Americans put on their table. Food processors in the United States are buying a greater number of ingredients from other countries, becoming more of an assembler in the nation's food supply chain.

Please post your comments here on my Tuesday column about education. I particularly welcome comments from teachers or others who have seen these issues first-hand. And if you disagree with me, tell me what you would like to see as school reforms.
Lord John Browne of Madingley resigned abruptly amid a legal battle with a tabloid newspaper over his gay sex life.
The mayor wants to turn the enclave of junkyards and auto-repair shops near Shea Stadium into a retailing and entertainment district with new homes and office space.
Tens of thousands of people pressing for immigrant rights demonstrated in  cities across the country.
A report said the Yankee pitcher’s plane crash was caused by “inadequate planning, judgment and airmanship.”
The timing of Prime Minister Tony Blair’s remarks was significant since Labor marked the 10th anniversary today of its landslide general election victory in 1997.
The president called the bill, which set a timetable for troop withdrawal, a blueprint for failure and defeat, intensifying a showdown with the Democratic-controlled  Congress.
Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s aides say the coalition is holding together in the wake of a damning report.
The ruling was more political than legal, as the court is part of Turkey’s secular establishment.
The ailing Cuban leader, who was said to have resumed some of his duties, did not appear at the May Day parade.
An agreement on lawyers’ fees seemed to open the way for progress on procedural rules in the Khmer Rouge tribunal.

Juan Duntugan, a woodcarver, admitted on television and in a written statement to the police that he killed Julia Campbell, 40, from Fairfax, Va., in a fit of rage while both were walking along a trail.

Iraqi authorities are investigating reports that the alleged leader of Al-Qaeda in Mesopotamia, Abu Ayyub al-Masri, has been killed in a struggle within his own group, the interior ministry said Tuesday.

Because of an editing error, a Media Talk report in Business Day yesterday, about an accusation by the magazine Radar that a Chilean publication had plagiarized its article “Toxic Bachelors,” misspelled the surname of a book author who had previously used the title phrase. She is Danielle Steel, not Steele.

Wages in Japan fell for a fourth month in March, signaling that growth in consumer spending will be limited. Monthly wages, including overtime and bonuses, fell 0.4 percent after dropping 1 percent in February, the labor ministry said. In China, manufacturing activity expanded at the fastest pace in more than two years in April, according to a survey of purchasing managers. The Purchasing Managers’ Index rose to 58.6 from 56.1 in March, the statistics bureau said. That is the highest since the index started in January 2005.
Ray Emery stopped 25 shots and Tom Preissing scored 4 minutes 46 seconds into the third period for the Ottawa Senators, who took a 2-1 lead over the Devils in the best-of-seven series.
The jury heard graphic testimony of the first day of the sex-abuse and kidnapping trial of Peter Braunstein, a former writer for Women’s Wear Daily.

The oil company, Eni, said it would pay Dominion Resources $4.76 billion for exploration and production assets in the Gulf of Mexico to increase its output. “Through this transaction we reach the necessary critical mass for our activities in the Gulf of Mexico,” Eni’s chief executive, Paolo Scaroni, said. The sale is part of a broader move by Dominion to sell most of its North American oil and gas exploration and production assets, which could be worth as much as $15 billion, to focus on its electric utilities and energy pipeline business. Eni said the deal would increase its production in the area by more than 74,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day in the second half of 2007.

HSBC Holdings said it sold its global headquarters in London to Metrovacesa of Spain for more than $2 billion in the biggest single property deal in British history. Metrovacesa paid £1.09 billion ($2.18 billion) for a 998-year lease on the tower at 8 Canada Square in Canary Wharf, London’s second financial district. HSBC will remain in the building under a 20-year lease, with a five-year option. The company moved into the building in 2002. It houses 8,000 staff members in 1.1 million square feet of floor space.
Nelson Peltz will receive $50 million when he steps down in June as part of the company’s plan to focus on its Arby’s fast-food business.

A Malaysian tycoon, Ananda Krishnan, plans to buy out the country’s largest mobile phone operator, Maxis Communications, the company said on Monday, in a deal that could be worth at least $5 billion. Maxis gave no reason for the buyout plan, but industry analysts speculated that Mr. Krishnan, left, might want to relist Maxis offshore and raise foreign capital to finance international expansion. Maxis, which faces a price war and a maturing market at home, is expanding into larger and less-developed Asian markets to drive growth. Chong Tjen San, a telecom analyst at Malaysia’s Aseambankers, said the buyout plan could be a first step toward raising money to finance major investments in India and Indonesia. Usaha Tegas, which is controlled by Mr. Krishnan and is a major shareholder in Maxis, has notified the company that it and its affiliates will make an offer by Thursday, Maxis said.

A front-page article on Friday about a new book by George J. Tenet, the former director of central intelligence, gave the incorrect name in some copies for the 2004 award bestowed on him by President Bush. It is the Presidential Medal of Freedom, not the Presidential Medal of Honor.

An article on Friday about a federal investigation of misconduct in the Atlanta Police Department misidentified an officer charged in a botched drug raid whose lawyer is John Garland. He is Jason R. Smith — not Arthur Tesler, another officer charged in the raid.

An article on Sunday about Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign misstated the cause of a fire aboard the aircraft carrier Forrestal, which killed 134 of Mr. McCain’s shipmates during his Navy career. It resulted from the explosion of an American rocket on the deck, not an attack.

An article on Feb. 3 about efforts by Gov. Rick Perry of Texas to require sixth-grade girls to be vaccinated against a virus that causes cervical cancer misstated the length of time over which the vaccine’s three shots are administered. (The error was pointed out after it was repeated in an article on Thursday.) They are given over six months, not eight months.

A front-page article on Friday about a new book by George J. Tenet, the former director of central intelligence, gave the incorrect name in some copies for the 2004 award bestowed on him by President Bush. It is the Presidential Medal of Freedom, not the Presidential Medal of Honor.

Because of an editing error, a Media Talk report in Business Day yesterday, about an accusation by the magazine Radar that a Chilean publication had plagiarized its article “Toxic Bachelors,” misspelled the surname of a book author who had previously used the title phrase. She is Danielle Steel, not Steele.

An article on Thursday about a New York subway track worker who was struck and killed by a train at Columbus Circle included erroneous information from the State Transportation Department about an investigation of the accident. New York City Transit is investigating — not the Transportation Department, which investigates only passenger accidents.

An article on Thursday about a reduction in the number of schools that the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation says it can build or rehabilitate with the money it has on hand referred incorrectly to the status of the agency’s previous projects and to their costs. Fifty-six — not zero — projects have been completed in the past five years, including 30 new schools and 26 major renovations. The more than $5 billion spent so far includes $1.25 billion for these projects as well as land acquisition and planning for others; the $5 billion was not spent on land purchases and planning costs alone.

An obituary on April 21 about the French film actor Jean-Pierre Cassel omitted some survivors. Besides his son the actor Vincent Cassel, they include another son from his first marriage, Matthias; his second wife, Anne Célérier; and their daughter, Cécile.

An article on Saturday about plans by the injured New Jersey governor, Jon S. Corzine, to leave a Camden hospital early this week and continue his recovery at Drumthwacket, the governor’s mansion in Princeton, gave an erroneous figure in some copies for the estimated value of his assets, as reported in a 2005 financial disclosure form for the United States Senate, where he served before being elected governor. He said his assets were worth up to $261 million, not up to $61 million. An article about Governor Corzine’s discharge from the hospital yesterday appears today on Page B1.

A picture caption in The Arts on Saturday with an article about Carol Williams, the civic organist for San Diego, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph, of the organ she plays and the pavilion that shelters it, was by Robert Harrington, not Donald MacKenzie.
First-quarter profit climbed 42 percent on gains in its insurance, cigarette and oil-drilling units.
The Mets had an impressive April. But on the last day of the month, they were confronted with injuries to two prominent players, then were hammered by the Florida Marlins at Shea Stadium.

Azzam al-Ahmad, the deputy Palestinian prime minister, a Fatah leader, said a six-week-old unity government led by Hamas should be disbanded if a Western embargo is not lifted in three months. His statement was the first of its kind by a leader of the government that Hamas Islamists formed with President Mahmoud Abbas’s secular Fatah faction. “If the economic and national siege on the Palestinian people is not lifted in three months, this government should leave,” Mr. Ahmad told public schoolteachers holding a one-day strike in Ramallah over unpaid wages. “I do not see any justification to continue as ministers if the siege goes on,” he said.
The Albanian Parliament appointed Lulzim Basha, 33, the former transport minister, to replace Foreign Minister Besnik Mustafaj, who resigned.

A Congolese military court cleared the opposition politician Marie-Thérèse Nlandu and nine others of inciting an armed insurrection. The tribunal in Kinshasha ordered their acquittal and release after finding the charges unfounded. “This is God’s victory,” Ms. Nlandu said. The 10 were arrested in November after clashes with the police.

The Security Council endorsed a resolution extending by six months the 10,000-member United Nations mission that helps enforce the 2005 peace accord that ended decades of civil war in southern Sudan. The measure expressed “grave concern” over the crisis in Darfur, in western Sudan, but to achieve the unanimous backing of the 15-member Council the United States had to drop language putting pressure on Sudan to accept a proposed United Nations-African Union peacekeeping force there.

A United Nations exhibit on the Rwandan genocide that was dismantled three weeks ago after Turkey objected to a reference to the Armenian genocide was opened in revised form by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon. Where the original exhibit had an entry called “What is genocide?” that cited the deaths “following World War I” of a million Armenians “in Turkey,” the revised entry is called “Defining the Crime” and refers to “mass killings of Armenians in the Ottoman Empire during World War I.” Some 1.5 million Armenians were killed by Ottoman Turks, but Turkey says they were victims of war and unrest instead of genocide. The exhibit observes the 13th anniversary of the 100-day slaughter in Rwanda of 800,000 Tutsis by Hutus.

Morocco and the Polisario Front, which are struggling for control of resource-rich Western Sahara, agreed to hold direct talks for the first time under the terms of a unanimously passed United Nations Security Council resolution. Morocco, which annexed the Front in 1979, hopes to incorporate it as an autonomous province with its own regional government. The Polisario Front wants a referendum that will offer the 260,000 residents the choice of autonomy or independence from Morocco.

The Tamil Tigers threatened more strikes after their war planes bombed oil plants near Colombo on Sunday. The military said it killed 14 rebels. The Tiger spokesman Rasiah Ilanthiraiyan said: “We have no other way than to take our own measures. There will definitely be more.”.
Struggling with weak television sales, Circuit City said that it expected a first-quarter loss and withdrew its forecast for the first half.

The police have identified the man who killed two people in a mall parking lot on Sunday before he was shot dead by officers as David W. Logsdon, 51. “He had been an employee of that Target store and had been turned down for a private security license,” Chief James Corwin said. “His objective was to go to the mall and cause havoc.” The victims were Leslie N. Ballew, 33, of Kansas City, and Luke A. Nilges, 30, of Shawnee, Kan. Chief Corwin said they appeared to be random victims.

Senator Tim Johnson, Democrat of South Dakota, was released from the hospital on Friday and is undergoing daily therapy, his office said. There was no word on when he would be able to return to Capitol Hill. Doctors performed emergency surgery on Johnson in mid-December to stop a brain hemorrhage caused by malformed blood vessels.

A man described by prosecutors as possibly Los Angeles’s most prolific serial killer was convicted of murdering 10 women and one victim’s unborn child in the 1980s and ’90s. The man, Chester D. Turner, 40, is already serving an eight-year prison sentence for the 2002 rape of a woman on Skid Row. His DNA in that case linked him to the serial killings that spanned from 1987 to 1998.

A series of e-mail messages threatening violence at five community college campuses led officials to close the schools for a third day of classes. Two campuses of the school, Delaware County Community College, received about a dozen threatening messages last week, according to the police, who suspect the sender may be a student. The campuses will remain shut today.

Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, 37, Republican of Washington, became the fifth member of Congress to give birth, and the first in more than a decade, her office said. The child is a boy named Cole.
New York City’s Department of Education has begun a $2 million citywide survey concerning attitudes about the public schools.
A civil suit would hold a Long Island church responsible for sexual abuse by its youth ministry director.
Immigrant families are hunkering down and plotting ways to avoid detection and resist deportation, advocates say.
A commander in the U.S. military’s main detention center in Baghdad said Lt. Col. William H. Steele gave gifts to the daughter of a high-value detainee.

New Yorkers who moved to Staten Island to escape congestion and pollution will be disappointed to hear that while air quality deteriorated in all five boroughs over the past year, it is worst in Staten Island, according to the eighth annual air pollution report by the American Lung Association. The report, which is scheduled to be released today, found that ozone pollution — or smog — is highest on Staten Island. And particle pollution, usually known as soot, has become substantially worse there, as well as in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Louise A. Vetter, chief executive of the American Lung Association of the City of New York, said that among the factors that contribute to Staten Island’s pollution are the heavy volume of vehicular traffic and diesel exhaust from ferries and barges in New York Harbor. Prevailing winds and other meteorological phenomena may also cause pollution from other states to hover over Staten Island, Ms. Vetter said.

Police detectives posing as the owners of a run-down house invited bids for repair work from unlicensed contractors, then arrested 16 of them when they showed up, officials said yesterday. The contractors, charged with operating without a license, could be sentenced to up to a year in jail and fined $1,000 if convicted, said Thomas Belfiore, the Westchester County police commissioner. The three-week sting operation used a three-story county-owned house in Yorktown that was “perfect for the job,” said Gary Brown, Westchester’s director of consumer protection. “It needs a lot of work,” he said. “Any contractor who came in would find work he could do.” To get a Westchester license, a home improvement contractor must pass a background check, have adequate insurance, supply proof of financial responsibility and explain any unresolved consumer complaints.

Three men posing as police officers pulled over a vehicle on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday afternoon, forced the passengers to the ground and stole the car, the state police said. The victims, who were not identified, told the police that three men in a white Ford Explorer pulled alongside their southbound Toyota Avalon near the Alexander Hamilton rest area on the turnpike, held up silver badges on chains around their necks, and motioned for the driver to pull over, said Sgt. Jeanne Hengemuhle, a spokeswoman for the state police. The men pulled into the rest area, where they were forced out of the car and onto the ground. One of the men from the Ford got into the Toyota, which had a New York license plate, DUU-2791, and both cars sped off, the sergeant said.

A City Council committee heard testimony yesterday on a proposal to increase penalties for public lewdness to one year in jail from 90 days. The legislation would also make the offense a more serious misdemeanor and increase the possible fine to $1,000 from $500. Flashing and groping have long been problems in New York, and last year, the Police Department started Operation Exposure to catch subway flashers, resulting in 29 arrests in five sting operations. Testifying before the Public Safety Committee, Karen Agnifilo, general counsel to the city’s criminal justice coordinator, said that last year, the police made 556 arrests for public lewdness, up from 408 in 2005.
Critics warn that the F.D.A. is woefully understaffed and underfinanced to keep America’s food supply safe.

A bus carrying a Connecticut prep school lacrosse team overturned yesterday on the way to a game, shaking up the team and injuring four people slightly, the state police said. The accident, on Route 9 in Middletown, involved a bus carrying 15 people with the Williams School junior varsity lacrosse team. The team was on its way from New London to Waterbury for a game against Chase Collegiate. The state police said the northbound lanes of the four-lane highway were closed after the accident.

A Brooklyn man who was arrested Sunday on drunken-driving charges near the scene of a hit-and-run accident that killed a 13-year-old boy riding a bicycle was charged yesterday with vehicular manslaughter, the police said. They said that the boy, Anthony Delgado of Brooklyn, was struck just after midnight on Sunday at the intersection of Palmetto Street and Central Avenue in Bushwick. The man, Melvin Morales, 34, was arrested a short time later, after being stopped for a reason unconnected to the hit and run, the police said. Investigators said that evidence on his sport utility vehicle linked it to the hit and run, and that a surveillance camera had captured images that would provide evidence against Mr. Morales.

Three New Jersey counties — Camden, Gloucester and Mercer — were added yesterday to President Bush’s disaster declaration in regard to the northeaster of April 15. Last week, the president declared disaster areas in Bergen, Burlington, Essex, Passaic, Somerset and Union Counties, with Hudson, Middlesex and Morris added on Saturday. Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey had requested that the entire state receive the designation, which gives residents access to federal aid. The president also allowed for infrastructure repairs to municipalities in 11 counties.
Evidence revealed during a trial showed links between the five men and two of the attackers who blew themselves up on London’s transit system.
Members of Parliament’s largest Sunni bloc are frustrated over the government’s failure to act on Sunni concerns.
Most major highway bridges and overpasses are not fireproof and probably never will be.
The police did not violate a speeding driver’s rights by ramming his car, the Supreme Court ruled.
Turkey's financial markets plunged Monday after the country's secular leaders promised to challenge the nation's prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Fred D. Thompson, the actor and politician, is of the Republican presidential campaign but not in it. Yet.
The World Bank president defended himself on Monday, but also hinted that he would discuss his resignation if the board cleared him of misconduct.
Coming off a two-game tour de force, the Nets stars Jason Kidd and Vince Carter are showing why they may be considered among the N.B.A.’s greatest perimeter tandems.
The decision by Gov. Theodore R. Kulongoski of Oregon to live on $3 a day in grocery money for a week could confound the surest cynic.
Responding to Viacom’s $1 billion copyright infringement suit, Google said that it would not back off, declaring that the law was on its side.
The Food and Drug Administration would have more power and money to ensure that drugs were as safe as advertised.
The commute was relatively painless for Bay Area drivers, as an expected rush hour nightmare largely failed to materialize.

In an effort to deter diploma mills, the N.C.A.A. will limit high school students to one core course that would count toward college eligibility after a student’s four-year high school graduation date.
Facing criticism about the company's business dealings in Iran, a Halliburton executive said Monday that his firm had not broken any laws.
Over 20 subway maintenance projects remain on hold after the recent deaths of two track workers.
The Warriors are poised to complete one of the biggest upsets in N.B.A. playoff history and Baron Davis, their fiery, focused floor leader, is poised to complete a great transformation.
The cross-examination of a crucial witness grew heated when a defense lawyer portrayed the witness as forgetful or inept.
Investigators said that byproducts from pet food contaminated with wheat gluten imported from China were used in chicken feed on some farms in Indiana.
The Supreme Court made it more difficult to get a patent on new products that combine elements of existing inventions.
Terrorist attacks against noncombatants in Iraq and Afghanistan accounted for a 29 percent increase in terrorism worldwide.
Josh Hancock, the Cardinals pitcher who was killed in an automobile accident early Sunday in St. Louis, was involved in an auto accident days before his death.
One of the men suspected in the dismemberment of a Staten Island woman in Panama has been returned to his native country by Costa Rican authorities.
LaSalle is at the center of what could be the biggest bank deal ever, as a trophy for Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland.
Scientists may have significantly underestimated the power of global warming to shrink the cap of sea ice on the Arctic Ocean.
Executives from the Mets and Yankees claim they are not competing with each other over who will have the better new ballpark. Both stadiums are scheduled to open in 2009.
Like no other horseman in the world, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum has learned that it is easier to build the world’s tallest building than it is to win a Kentucky Derby.
Pratt Institute found that a deal it had with a student loan company was not so good for its student borrowers.
The less committed a president is to the law, the more need there is for Law Day, which makes it a holiday whose time has come.
Colleges and universities will need to embrace creative solutions in order to drive down the cost of textbooks.
The current Congress can begin to fix the federal disability program by providing the needed funds in the coming budget for 2008.
The long struggle between Turkey’s generals and the growing popularity of parties rooted in Islam has taken a dangerous turn. Both sides need to step back from the brink.
Democratic leaders in Congress are planning a special ceremony on Tuesday afternoon to send President Bush a bill that sets timetables for troop withdrawal from Iraq.
Since the dismissals of eight United States attorneys, second guessing of the integrity of the legal system has surfaced with increasing frequency.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine apologized to New Jersey residents as he left the hospital 18 days after a devastating car crash.
Mayor Shirley Franklin defended the police chief against charges that a “culture of misconduct” contributed to a shooting death last fall.

Kirk Radomski, the former Mets clubhouse assistant who has admitted dealing performance-enhancing drugs to players, testified last Thursday to the federal grand jury investigating steroid use in sports.
Business 2.0 failed to heed its own advice about backing up computer files when its editorial system crashed and the backup server failed to back up.
An accounting technique called gain on sale is haunting New Century Financial as it faces bankruptcy and federal investigations.
Prime Minister Ehud Olmert suffered a further blow today when a Labor minister resigned over the report.
The health insurance provider reported a 15 percent drop in first-quarter earnings from results that included a hefty gain a year ago.
The slowdown indicated that higher gasoline prices and a sagging housing market are chipping away at a mainstay of economic expansion.
U.S. Special Forces said Monday they killed more than 130 Taliban in recent heavy fighting. But villagers said dozens of civilians were also killed.
The electronics retailer posted a better-than-expected first-quarter profit as cost cuts helped offset weaker sales.
pro football.
Like “therapy courts” devoted to drugs and spousal abuse, a gambling court offers counseling in lieu of jail time.
Octavio Frias de Oliveira built one of Brazil’s biggest and most influential media empires.
If there were an award for octogenarian nightlifer of the year, Jules Peimer, who has been fluttering around parties for 65 years, would seem a shoo-in.
In hedge fund and equity funds, the track record and personality of the main investment manager are critical factors in attracting investors.
The company also revised its earnings guidance for the fiscal year, saying it expected a profit of 65 cents to 90 cents a share.
The investment bank will buy back as much as $6 billion of its common stock over time, as the firm looks to return capital that is building up on its balance sheet to investors.
Despite the slide, two New York City tabloids continued to buck the trend, posting the largest gains among major papers.
First-quarter earnings climbed 17 percent, helped by stronger snack sales and a tax benefit, and the company raised its full-year outlook.
Under pressure from European allies, President Bush said Monday he was intensifying his efforts to convince Russia to work with the U.S. on missile defense.
The lonely Maytag repairman is getting a personality makeover in a change meant to appeal to a new generation of shoppers.
China Team won its first race at the Louis Vuitton Cup on Monday, upsetting the leader of the America’s Cup challengers series, BMW Oracle Racing of the United States.
During Sunday’s victory over the Sabres, Rangers Coach Tom Renney diligently used his whole lineup in order to manage his players’ time on the ice.
A political feud in Albany seems likely to delay further what would be the first raise for judges in eight years.
The case of a Mexican citizen on death row in Texas has embroiled the World Court, the Bush administration and the State of Texas.
The move would end a ban on drilling in environmentally sensitive areas along the coasts of Alaska and Virginia.
Gov. Timothy M. Kaine closed a loophole that allowed a mentally disturbed student to buy the guns used in a shooting rampage.
A federal judge ruled that the pharmaceutical industry could continue to use computerized data showing which doctors are prescribing what drugs.
N.F.L. teams grappled with how a crackdown on misbehavior should affect the ordering of their draft boards.
A federal judge struck down a New Hampshire law that makes doctors’ prescription-writing habits confidential.
A study found that tooth decay in young children’s baby teeth is on the rise.
The Galápagos Islands, which inspired Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution, are the scene of a war between man and goat.
Investors cashed in some profits on the last trading day of April, the Dow Jones industrial average’s best month in more than three years.
The German stock exchange operator said it had agreed to buy International Securities Exchange Holdings for $2.8 billion.
Kevin Mitchell was a former National Football League linebacker who played for the San Francisco 49ers and the New Orleans Saints.
After a revered statue was defaced, parishioners at St. Martin of Tours Church in the Bronx suggested putting Jesus on lockdown.
The Italian cyclist Ivan Basso quit the Discovery Channel team after Italian authorities reopened an investigation into his role in a Spanish doping scandal.
A mass shooting has bound the community of Blacksburg, Va., like never before.
The former executives will face trial for a third time on criminal charges that accuse them of trying to loot the utility.

Atlanta Braves pitcher Tim Hudson had a lot on his mind last night. He took the mound with the initials “JH” on the front of his jersey. Before every inning, he scribbled the letters “VM” in the dirt with his cleats.
The good-humored backup bandleader on “The Tonight Show” had earned fame as Johnny Carson’s comical punching bag.
Public suspicion and mistrust surround the company’s federally mandated cleanups of the Hudson and Housatonic Rivers.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,337 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war.
Profit was down 8.4 percent but the company continued to have strong growth in wireless and broadband subscriptions.
Tishman Speyer Properties sold the historic headquarters of The New York Times Company for $525 million, less than three weeks after putting it on the market.
Thirty-four first-year graduate students cheated on a take-home final exam, a judicial board has found.

CESSNA DELIVERS VERY LIGHT JET As the very light jet market stirs to life, the Cessna Aircraft Company delivered its first retail Citation Mustang jet last week to Goode Ski Technologies. Goode is currently flying a Cessna 310 twin-engine piston propeller aircraft, and says it bought the Mustang to make it easier to travel to ski locations to test its products. Cessna already has two Mustangs flying for marketing purposes. The $2.5 million, four-passenger Mustang is the latest model of a very light jet to enter commercial service. 8 P.M. (TCM) BRANDO “Before Brando, actors acted,” says Michael Winner, who directed Marlon Brando in “The Nightcomers.” “After Brando, they behaved. That is the difference — an extraordinary effect on the history of drama and the history of movies.” This two-part documentary tries to unlock the enigma of Brando (above, in “The Wild One,” from 1953) through interviews with everyone from his former high school classmates to the likes of Al Pacino, Martin Scorsese, Jon Voight, Jane Fonda, Robert Duvall and Dennis Hopper. It also includes film of Brando onstage and on screen, from “Truckline Café,” which first earned him recognition on Broadway, through “A Streetcar Named Desire,” which catapulted him over the top, with stops at “Julius Caesar,” in which he proved he could enunciate; “The Godfather,” his signature work; and the intimate “Last Tango in Paris.”.

Q. Is balding an indicator of more rapid aging and a shorter life span? A. No evidence of a link between hair loss and premature death was found in a large and well-known Danish study published in 1998 in The Journals of Gerontology. Perhaps surprisingly, other signs of aging like wrinkles and gray hair were not linked to early deaths, either. The study, involving a random sample of 20,000 men and women in the Copenhagen City Heart Study, recorded the extent of baldness, gray hair, wrinkles and a ring around the cornea, called arcus senilis, that often occurs in old age. The group was followed for 16 years.

To the Editor: Re ''Diplomacy at Its Worst'' (column, April 29): Bravo to Nicholas D. Kristof for publishing a document showing Iranian willingness to reach a ''grand bargain'' with the United States in 2003. It shows what is missing in the current debate about Iran.

KRAMER--George P., 80, died at home on April 27, 2007. He was born in Holyoke, MA, graduated with the class of 1950 from Harvard College, and received his LLB in 1953 from the Harvard Law School. At Harvard, he was an editor of The Crimson and a member of the Signet Society. He served as a lieutenant in the USN. As a young lawyer at Watson and Leavenworth, he developed an interest in trademark law and was recognized as an authority in the field; he was senior counsel at Hunton and Williams when he died. He served as Secretary of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and, later, on its Executive Committee. In 1971, he accompanied the U.S. Antarctic Policy Group South Pole Expedition and planted an anniversary-year flag of the Bar Association at the Pole. After college, George established the Caleb Cheeshahteamuck 1665 Fund at Harvard in memory of its first Native American student. He was the longest serving Secretary of the Harvard Club of New York and a trustee of Hancock Shaker Village. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth, his daughter, Alice Truax, his sons, Hawley and Charles Truax, his daughters-in-law, Jane Thrailkill and Julie Truax, and his grandchildren, Olivia, Naomi, and George. A memorial service will take place on May 4 at 5pm at the Union Church in Tyringham, MA. On Sunday, May 6, friends may call at the family apartment in NYC between 5 and 8pm. Contributions in George's memory may be made to Hancock Shaker Village, PO Box 297, Pittsfield, MA, 01202 or to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, NY, NY 10003.

ZUPNICK--Beatrice. Bea, the love of Alex's life. Alex, the love of her life. They met at age 13 in French class at Lincoln High School. Married at 21 for 66 amazing years. He taught her about music and opera. She taught him about art and ballet. Both loved reading, theater, movies, and traveling the world. They were dubbed Bealex, a one unit dynamo. Loving nurturing mother-a fierce lioness. Child actress in Yiddish theater with Maurice Schwarz, loved to laugh, feisty, passionate, beautiful, bright, avid crossword puzzle practitioner. Life long friends, Dorothy Leviss and Jean Wardell were her partners in a gallery of Asian art in Great Neck. Her family were among her closest friends -brother Sy, his wife Audrey, and the entire Bruckner clan, Alex's sister Annie and husband Marty Weis, (Alex's childhood friend). She was very proud of having raised a doctor and a judge and deeply loved Eileen, her daughter-in-law and Allen Kopelson, her son in law. She was most proud of her two grandsons Hunter and Cody Zupnick. Sheer luck to have been born to two people we considered two of our closest friends. Jerry Zupnick and Robin Kopelson

Morocco and the Polisario Front, which are struggling for control of resource-rich Western Sahara, agreed to hold direct talks for the first time under the terms of a unanimously passed United Nations Security Council resolution. Morocco, which annexed the Front in 1979, hopes to incorporate it as an autonomous province with its own regional government. The Polisario Front wants a referendum that will offer the 260,000 residents the choice of autonomy or independence from Morocco. WARREN HOGE

To the Editor: We take offense at Paul Krugman's April 20 column, ''The Plot Against Medicare.'' Not only was the column insulting, but it also ignored our goals to ensure adequate, affordable health care for the communities we represent. Many African-American and Latino seniors prefer Medicare Advantage plans to traditional Medicare. Of those low-income seniors who make just enough to be ineligible for Medicaid but who lack access to employer-sponsored supplemental coverage, 54 percent of Latinos and 38 percent of African-Americans choose Medicare Advantage.

To the Editor: Re ''Treating the Awkward Years'' (April 24): As a teenager and patient, I was interested to read the recent article on adolescent medicine. RAWLEY--Ruth Kolb Otis, of Baldwin, NY died April 24, 2007 in Cairo, Egypt after a short illness. She was visiting her son James W. Rawley, United Nations Resident Coordinator in Egypt, and his family. Born April 12, 1921, Mrs. Rawley was raised adjacent to the Holtsville Tuberculosis Sanatorium where her father Edwin Kolb, M.D. was the Medical Director. She was an accomplished Cellist and the first woman hired by the Syracuse Symphony. Mrs. Rawley volunteered with the League of Women Voters and the American Red Cross. A family memorial will be held June 24, 2007. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Red Cross or UNICEF would be appreciated.

SCHULTZ--Rev. Dr. John Frederick, 63, died Friday. He graduated from University of North Carolina and served in the Peace Corps in Nigeria. He completed his M.Div. at Union Theological Seminary and Ph.D. at Columbia. He worked for Church World Service from 1974-1990. He was ordained a Presbyterian minister in 1986. In 1990, Dr. Schultz joined Christian Children's Fund, the international child development agency, and was elected president in 1998. In 2004, he received a Distinguished Alumnus award from the University of North Carolina honoring his ''outstanding contributions to humanity through his work with relief and development efforts throughout the world.'' Dr. Schultz is survived by his wife of 38 years, Patricia Kelsey Schultz, his three children, two brothers, and two sisters. Memorial service in Richmond, Virginia. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The John F. Schultz Memorial Fund for the Greatest Needs of Children at Christian Children's Fund, 2821 Emerywood Parkway, Richmond, Virginia 23294.

To the Editor: Re ''At Trial, Pain Has a Witness'' (Findings, April 24): As a chronic pain sufferer, I know finding a doctor willing to treat pain is nearly impossible due to our government's war on drugs. Prescribing pain medications is a balance between aiding patients and leakage of drugs to illegal markets. It's alarming that our government is controlling how doctors treat patients and prescribe medication. Had a medical board found Dr. William E. Hurwitz's practices ''too generous,'' I'd be willing to accept their finding. But it wasn't doctors that busted the pain specialists, it was bureaucrats. Let's leave pain treatment and care to the medical community. Jesse Alt Baltimore To the Editor: Doctors on the front lines of pain management are often caught between a rock and a hard place. On one side there is the real possibility of improper drug diversion and sales, and on the other the potential for failing to alleviate a patient's suffering. A physician can end up a defendant in a criminal trial or a defendant in a civil lawsuit. Chronic pain is not like an infection. There aren't concrete tests that can prove its existence. One must rely on the patient's description. There are inherent risks, but collaborative groups of physicians, pharmacists and nurse practitioners have developed some truly effective ways of preventing drug diversion and setting standards for prescribing them. Peter Nelken San Francisco

Coming off a two-game tour de force, the Nets stars Jason Kidd and Vince Carter are showing why they may be considered among the N.B.A.'s greatest perimeter tandems. But they are still without a championship, and their place in history remains to be determined. For now, the Nets will gladly leave that debate in the air, so long as they continue to get the panache from Kidd and Carter that vaulted them to consecutive victories against the Toronto Raptors and a 3-1 advantage in their first-round Eastern Conference playoff series.

If lowering sodium intake reduces the risk of high blood pressure, and high blood pressure can lead to heart disease, does eating less salt improve the health of one's heart? It seems obvious that it would, but in a new study, researchers offer what they say is some of the first good evidence that it really does.

A United Nations exhibit on the Rwandan genocide that was dismantled three weeks ago after Turkey objected to a reference to the Armenian genocide was opened in revised form by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon. Where the original exhibit had an entry called ''What is genocide?'' that cited the deaths ''following World War I'' of a million Armenians ''in Turkey,'' the revised entry is called ''Defining the Crime'' and refers to ''mass killings of Armenians in the Ottoman Empire during World War I.'' Some 1.5 million Armenians were killed by Ottoman Turks, but Turkey says they were victims of war and unrest instead of genocide. The exhibit observes the 13th anniversary of the 100-day slaughter in Rwanda of 800,000 Tutsis by Hutus. WARREN HOGE
ARROWSMITH--Sandra, on April 27th, 2007. Beloved daughter of the late William and Keay. Dear sister of Joan and Anne.

Campaign strategies, endorsements, advertising content and hairdo management. Many factors can influence a political race, and every handicapper has an equation for predicting. Since the late 1980s, a group of psychologists at the University of Pennsylvania has had a system based on a single factor: optimism. The researchers, by analyzing stump speeches, have found that the most optimistic candidate usually wins, taking more than 80 percent of the presidential elections since 1900.

Because of an editing error, a Media Talk report in Business Day yesterday, about an accusation by the magazine Radar that a Chilean publication had plagiarized its article ''Toxic Bachelors,'' misspelled the surname of a book author who had previously used the title phrase. She is Danielle Steel, not Steele.

MORE than six million Americans are walking around with no idea that they have an insidious disease with the potential to wreak havoc throughout the body. The disease is diabetes, and it causes high blood sugar levels that can damage arteries and lead to heart disease, strokes, kidney failure, amputations and blindness. It is the sixth-leading cause of death in the United States.

CBS's exclusive interview with the former director of central intelligence George J. Tenet on ''60 Minutes'' on Sunday might have captivated Washington, but it made only minor ripples in the ratings. According to Nielsen's estimates, the news magazine led the 7 p.m. hour with a below-average 10.8 million viewers, ranking second in the time period among adults 18 to 49, behind ABC's ''Funniest Home Videos,'' which drew 8.4 million total viewers. Although CBS tied ABC as the most-watched network of the night, it ranked third over all in the 18 to 49 set. Among viewers in that demographic, ABC's lineup of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (10.3 million), ''Desperate Housewives'' at 9 (16.9 million) and ''Brothers & Sisters'' at 10 (11.5 million), remained dominant over all. Fox finished second with its animated comedy lineup, which included a first-ever victory for ''Family Guy'' (8.2 million) over ''Desperate Housewives'' at 9 among viewers 18 to 34. NBC was a distant fourth for the night in the 18 to 49 set. Its broadcast of the film ''Along Came Polly'' from 9 to 11 averaged 5.1 million viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

Some studies have found that people who suffer from migraines do not seem to lose any of their thinking skills as a result of the headaches. Other studies have found that they do. In either case, a new study has found that women who have migraines experience less cognitive decline than women who do not.

Wolfowitz, saying he had been the victim of ''a smear campaign,'' declared vigorously that it would be ''unjust and frankly hypocritical'' for the World Bank's board to find him guilty of ethical lapses. But he also hinted that he would discuss whether to resign as bank president if the board cleared him of misconduct. The Democrats' debate last week offered a prime site for presidential hopefuls to promote their ideas, credentials and, most important, affection for Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina. Few endorsements have been as coveted as that of Mr. Clyburn, the House majority whip, African-American leader and prominent figure in an early primary state.

An article on Saturday about plans by the injured New Jersey governor, Jon S. Corzine, to leave a Camden hospital early this week and continue his recovery at Drumthwacket, the governor's mansion in Princeton, gave an erroneous figure in some copies for the estimated value of his assets, as reported in a 2005 financial disclosure form for the United States Senate, where he served before being elected governor. He said his assets were worth up to $261 million, not up to $61 million. An article about Governor Corzine's discharge from the hospital yesterday appears today on Page B1.

AT age 39, with diabetes and high blood pressure in her family, Linda M. was starting to worry about her weight and its health consequences. She was 5 feet 6 inches tall and weighed 170 pounds, which placed her in the overweight category, according to the standard definition. Although she was not officially obese, she said, ''I realized I was not at my ideal weight.'' But Linda was in for a surprise during an appointment last fall with Dr. Judith Korner, an obesity specialist at Columbia University. Instead of weighing her, Dr. Korner whipped out a tape measure and measured her waist.

To the Editor: In ''China Needs an Einstein. So Do We'' (column, April 27), Thomas L. Friedman writes that ''if Einstein were alive today, he would be telling both America and China that they have homework to do.'' I suggest that a starting assignment might be to turn off the television for little children and read out loud to them, and give them open-ended questions and see what they come up with. Questions like ''What makes the sky blue?'' or ''Why does the grass grow up?'' or ''What is inside of a tire when it becomes flat?''

To the Editor: Re ''Understanding Empathy: Can You Feel My Pain?'' (Behavior, April 24): There is a fine line between a practitioner sharing the experiences of the patient and simply having the background to understand those experiences.

''What's your favorite novel?'' is a perennial campaign question, the answer to which presumably gives insight into leadership. A ''Moby-Dick'' lover may understand the perils of obsessively chasing of a goal. A fan of ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' may well focus on racial justice.

To the Editor: Re ''M.I.T.'s Admissions Dean Resigns; Ends 28-Year Lie About Degrees'' (front page, April 27): One should not lie about one's formal qualifications. But on the other hand, as your article made clear, Marilee Jones had been doing the job well for a decade.
REICH--Jay. May 1, 2004. Always in our hearts and thoughts. We miss you everyday. June and your children

The Security Council endorsed a resolution extending by six months the 10,000-member United Nations mission that helps enforce the 2005 peace accord that ended decades of civil war in southern Sudan. The measure expressed ''grave concern'' over the crisis in Darfur, in western Sudan, but to achieve the unanimous backing of the 15-member Council the United States had to drop language putting pressure on Sudan to accept a proposed United Nations-African Union peacekeeping force there. WARREN HOGE

BLAY--Freda Robinson, 86, died on April 27, after a brief illness. Predeceasing her was her beloved husband John S. Blay and her sister Ruth Joseph. Born in Syracuse, NY to the late Harry and Anna Rubenstein, she was a graduate of Syracuse University College of Fine Arts. Professionally known as Freda Robinson, she was Vice President of Parfums Nina Ricci Paris from 1962-1983 and a consultant to the company until 1993. After retiring she became an officer on the Board of Directors for the New York City chapter of the Alzheimers Association. As in her life, Freda's last weeks were filled with grace, dignity and thoughtfulness for her friends and relatives. All will miss her strength and delicacy but none more than her beloved Heidi, Kate and John Zdrojeski. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Alzheimers Association, New York City chapter, 360 Lexington Avenue, NY 10017 and Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, NY 10003. Burial will be private.

State judges have gone more than eight years without a pay raise. It appears they may not get one soon. While all sides in Albany agree that judges are overdue for a raise, the matter appears to be caught up in the escalating feud between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, who have found little to agree on since they struck a budget deal in late March.

MAJOR PATENT RULING -- The Supreme Court, in its most significant patent ruling in years, made it more difficult to get a patent on new products that combine elements of existing inventions. [Page C1.] SAFEGUARDING FOOD -- As Food and Drug Administration inspectors head to China to investigate contaminated pet food, critics in Washington are warning that the agency is wholly understaffed and underfunded to safeguard America's food supply. [C1.] DELTA EXITS BANKRUPTCY -- Delta Air Lines has emerged from bankruptcy protection after cutting billions in costs during a 19-month reorganization. Its board must now find a new chief executive to replace Gerald Grinstein, above, and decide whether to sell or spin off Comair, its regional feeder carrier. [C6.] LURE OF LASALLE -- For Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland, acquiring LaSalle Bank of Chicago would offer each an efficient way to gain a strong foothold there and throughout the Midwest, where LaSalle has 140 branches. [C1.] QUESTIONABLE TECHNIQUE -- An accounting technique called gain on sale is haunting New Century Financial, a subprime mortgage lender now facing bankruptcy and investigations by federal prosecutors and securities regulators. [C1.] PROMISE OF PLANKTON -- Some Silicon Valley technocrats are betting plankton can save the planet. Several groups are working on ventures to grow vast floating fields of plankton that could absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and carry it to the depths of the ocean. [C1.] WOLFOWITZ DEFENDS HIMSELF -- Paul D. Wolfowitz, the president of the World Bank, told bank directors it would be unfair and hypocritical to dismiss him, but he hinted he might be willing to resign if he was cleared of any misconduct. [A3.] HALLIBURTON DENIES BREAKING LAW -- A Halliburton executive insisted during a Senate hearing concerning the company's business dealings in Iran that it had done nothing wrong. [A6.] DEBATE OVER CHANGES FOR F.D.A. -- he Senate debated legislation that could fundamentally change the way the F.D.A. operates by providing it with more power and more money to insure that drugs are as safe as advertised. [A18.] AN ENERGY CHALLENGE -- With the increasing use of coal inevitable, clearing a hurdle to burn it on a big scale -- separating the carbon dioxide and sequestering it -- could turn out to be one of the major engineering challenges of the century. [Science, F3.] CHINESE WEB COMPANY TO GO PUBLIC -- China's leading e-commerce company, Alibaba.com, is planning to go public later this year in what could be the biggest initial public offering there for an Internet company. [C10.] GROUP CRITICIZES WAL-MART -- Human Rights Watch contends that Wal-Mart's efforts to keep out labor unions have often violated federal law and infringed on workers' rights. Wal-Mart, with more than 1.3 million workers at nearly 4,000 stores in the United States, strongly defended its practices. [C3.] UPDATING 'OL' LONELY' -- The Maytag repairman, who started appearing in national commercials in 1967, is becoming more active and gregarious in a change meant to update the concept of ''Ol' Lonely'' for a new generation of shoppers. [C3.] GOOGLE RESPONDS TO VIACOM SUIT -- In an initial response to the lawsuit filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, Google says Viacom's $1 billion copyright infringement suit over video clips on YouTube is unfounded and ought to be dismissed. [C2.] PROFIT DECLINES AT VERIZON -- Verizon's profit declined in the first quarter, but the company continued to have strong growth in wireless and broadband subscriptions as it begins to offer Internet and television services. [C2.] GOOD NEWS FOR TWO TABLOIDS -- With the exception of two New York tabloids that showed solid gains -- The New York Post and The Daily News -- newspaper circulation continued a sharp decline nationally, new figures show. [C10.] KELLOGG'S EARNINGS RISE -- Kellogg's first-quarter earnings climbed 17 percent, helped by stronger snack sales and a tax benefit. The company, which makes food like cereal, cookies and waffles, also raised its full-year outlook. Kellogg's North American sales rose 7 percent as revenue rose 9 percent. Excluding the tax benefit, earnings were 70 cents a share. [C11.] DEUTSCHE BÖRSE BUYS EXCHANGE -- The German stock exchange operator Deutsche Börse has agreed to buy International Securities Exchange Holdings, an options exchange in New York that is the largest after the Chicago Board Options Exchange, for $2.8 billion. [C10.] WHEN THE BACKUP FAILS -- When the editorial computer system crashed at Business 2.0, a Time Inc. magazine that has written about the importance of backing up computer files, its back-up server failed to do its job. Luckily, the monthly magazine has been able to recover. [C11.] LESSONS FOR HEDGE FUNDS -- Hedge and equity funds are discovering the they may need to develop a credible public persona to capitalize on the keen interest in their high-returning funds and to go public. [C10.] WHEN TRAVELING, TAKE FOOD -- Dieticians and nutritionists recommend taking along a stash of food, which can help relieve stress if you should get stuck on the tarmac. [C5.]
