An article on Thursday about a reduction in the number of schools that the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation says it can build or rehabilitate with the money it has on hand referred incorrectly to the status of the agency's previous projects and to their costs. Fifty-six -- not zero -- projects have been completed in the past five years, including 30 new schools and 26 major renovations. The more than $5 billion spent so far includes $1.25 billion for these projects as well as land acquisition and planning for others; the $5 billion was not spent on land purchases and planning costs alone.

CALDER--Elizabeth Ann (Libby), 86, a resident of Watch Hill, RI, died April 28th. Born in Boston, MA, the eldest child of Peter and Elizabeth Sullivan Naphen, Libby was raised in New Canaan and Darien, CT and lived for many years in Armonk, NY with her late husband, Louis Calder, Jr. and their three children. Predeceased by her eldest son Louis Christopher Calder, her two brothers, Peter and Fred Naphen, and her sister, Marie Kane, she is survived by her son, Peter D. Calder of New Canaan, CT, her daughter Elizabeth C. McEwen of Wilmington, VT, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will held at a later date. Donations in Libby's memory may be made to the Westerly Adult Day Care Services, Inc. 85 Wells Street, Westerly, RI 02891.

'Sesame Street' Takes On a Role in the Middle East ''Sesame Street'' is returning to Israel and the Palestinian territories. Years after the original episodes went off television because of a lack of financing, the show is returning in Israeli and Palestinian versions, The Associated Press reported. For the first time, the Israeli version, ''Rechov Sumsum,'' will feature an Israeli Muppet of Arab origin, Mahoub, who speaks Hebrew and Arabic. And new human actors will include Russian and Ethiopian Jewish immigrants, who have been unwelcome to some Israelis. The Palestinian show, ''Shara'a Simsim,'' seeks to offer positive role models to boys in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Gary Knell, the president of Sesame Workshop, the New York-based nonprofit organization behind ''Sesame Street'' programming worldwide, said, ''There's a desire of the political leaders to change the endless debate that seems to be passed down from generation to generation.'' New Law to Protect Critics From Being Misquoted The European Commission has passed legislation that would keep bad reviews from looking good, the London newspaper The Independent reported. The measure, to take effect in December, will make it illegal for advertisers to misquote reviewers by taking a positive word or phrase from a theater review if it gives a misleading sense of the whole review. The Unfair Commercial Practices Directive bars advertising that includes ''false information'' or any claim that ''deceives or is likely to deceive the consumer'' and thus ''causes or is likely to cause him to take a transactional decision that he would not have taken otherwise.'' Helen Kearns, the commission's spokeswoman on consumer affairs, said the measure would be ''policed on a case-by-case basis'' by the Office of Fair Trading. ''It should apply to misleading advertising right across the board,'' she added, ''from airline tickets to theater tickets.'' Egypt Seeks Loan Of Museum Antiquities Egypt plans to appeal to museums abroad for the temporary return of some of its most precious artifacts, including the Rosetta Stone and a bust of Nefertiti, above, The Associated Press reported. Zahi Hawass, secretary general of Egypt's Supreme Council of Antiquities, said the Foreign Ministry would send letters this week to France, Germany, the United States and Britain asking for the loan of the ancient works, to be exhibited either in 2011 at the opening of the Egyptian Museum near the Great Pyramids at Giza or in 2010 at the opening of the Atum Museum in the Nile Delta city of Meniya. The 1,680-pound Rosetta Stone, a key to deciphering ancient hieroglyphics, is in the British Museum, where a spokeswoman, Hannah Boulton, said a loan request would be considered. Germany has already balked at requests to lend the 3,000-year-old bust of Nefertiti from its Egyptian Museum in Berlin. Mr. Hawass said he was also seeking the zodiac ceiling painting from the Dendera Temple, now in the Louvre; the statue of Hemiunu in the Roemer and Pelizaeus Museum in Hildesheim, near Hanover, Germany; and the bust of Anchhaf at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. Barbra Streisand To Tour Europe Barbra Streisand will start what is billed as her first tour of continental Europe when she sings on June 21 in Vienna, and on July 18 she will give her first concert in England since 1994, Concert Productions International has announced. The European tour will take her to Paris on June 26, Nice on July 10 and Dublin on July 14. The promoters said additional dates would be announced shortly. Ms. Streisand is to be accompanied by a 58-piece orchestra. The complete lyrics of Sting, including those of hits like ''Roxanne,'' ''Every Breath You Take'' and ''Spirits in the Material World,'' will be published in the fall in book form under the title ''Lyrics by Sting'' by Dial Press, an imprint of the Bantam Dell Publishing Group, The Associated Press reported. Langella to Play Nixon In Ron Howard Movie Frank Langella, above, will recreate the role of Richard M. Nixon when the Peter Morgan play ''Frost/Nixon'' is adapted for the screen under the direction of Ron Howard, Variety.com reported. Michael Sheen, starring as the interviewer David Frost opposite Mr. Langella on Broadway, will reprise his role in the film, scheduled to go before the cameras on Aug. 27. Ridley Scott, who directed Russell Crowe in ''Gladiator,'' will direct him again when he stars in ''Nottingham,'' Variety. com reported. The film, scheduled to go into production next year, is a revisionist version of the Robin Hood legend that presents the Sheriff of Nottingham as noble and brave (though he works for a wicked king).

A picture caption in The Arts on Saturday with an article about Carol Williams, the civic organist for San Diego, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph, of the organ she plays and the pavilion that shelters it, was by Robert Harrington, not Donald MacKenzie.

WHILE the annual number of new H.I.V. infections is sharply lower than in the peak years of the 1980s, the effort to reduce the infection rate further has stalled in the last decade. So the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention now recommends screening for H.I.V. as a routine part of health care, and not just for people in known risk groups. With other sexually transmitted diseases, or S.T.D.'s, the usefulness and cost effectiveness of testing depend on the population being screened. Although general screening for all S.T.D.'s is not recommended, pregnant women, adolescents and gay men require special attention, and there are times when even people who fall into none of these groups should also be tested.

Already stripped of much of its travertine cladding, Alice Tully Hall has shut down for an 18-month makeover led by the architects Diller Scofidio & Renfro. The renovation, the first major phase of a redevelopment project at Lincoln Center, involves replacing much of the travertine with glass to foster a sense of communication between the interior and the street. In the new incarnation, a glass-enclosed dance rehearsal studio of the Juilliard School will be visible just above a soaring three-story Alice Tully lobby. HAEYOUN PARK and GRAHAM ROBERTS

An article on Feb. 3 about efforts by Gov. Rick Perry of Texas to require sixth-grade girls to be vaccinated against a virus that causes cervical cancer misstated the length of time over which the vaccine's three shots are administered. (The error was pointed out after it was repeated in an article on Thursday.) They are given over six months, not eight months.

To the Editor: Re ''Bees Vanish; Scientists Race for Reasons'' (April 24): As a child, I was fascinated by the honeybees in our backyard. I wondered how such tiny beings were able to visit hundreds of flowers each day and find their way back home.

Alibaba.com, China's leading e-commerce company, is planning to go public later this year in what could be the biggest initial public offering ever for a Chinese Internet company, according to people briefed on the deal. Alibaba.com, which is controlled by the Alibaba Group and partly owned by Yahoo, could raise $1 billion, making the stock offering bigger than those of other high-flying Chinese Internet companies in recent years, including Baidu.com, the Chinese Internet search engine, and Tencent.com, which runs the popular QQ instant messaging service.

If creating a comic book and having it published is your dream, help is on the way to make it a reality. The second Comic Book Challenge, from Platinum Studios, begins today at comicbookchallenge.com. ''We're significantly raising the bar for entrance,'' said Scott Mitchell Rosenberg, the chairman of the company. Last year pitches with strong story concepts that were illustrated with stick figures were considered. This year the company is seeking a more polished product of completed pages: penciled, inked, lettered and colored. In July a panel of judges will narrow the submissions, which last year spanned 12 countries, to 10. Votes cast online will decide the winner, whose story will be published in a graphic novel or comic book in 2008. The winner of last year's challenge, ''Hero by Night,'' by D. J. Coffman, will have its third issue published on May 16. The four-issue series is about Jack King, who discovers the lair and weaponry of a long-missing superhero. Mr. Coffman said the story was about ''what it takes to do the right thing in today's society.'' GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

To the Editor: Re ''Limits Sought on 'Robocalls' in Campaigns'' (front page, April 25): Your right to speak freely does not convey a requirement for me to listen, especially if you intend to intrude into the privacy of my home to do so. Nobody thinks you have the right to open my front door and drop your newspaper inside without specific prior consent. Neither would any city permit you to ring my doorbell daily after I have filed a nuisance complaint.

An obituary on April 21 about the French film actor Jean-Pierre Cassel omitted some survivors. Besides his son the actor Vincent Cassel, they include another son from his first marriage, Matthias; his second wife, Anne Célérier; and their daughter, Cécile.

Elliott P. Skinner, a former United States ambassador to the Republic of Upper Volta, the West African nation now known as Burkina Faso, and a former chairman of the anthropology department at Columbia University, died April 1 at his home in Washington. He was 82. The cause was heart failure, said his wife, Gwendolyn Mikell, director of African studies at the Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University.

To the Editor: ''Still Waiting for Answers'' (editorial, April 29) demands Congressional investigations into the administration's use of suspect intelligence before the invasion of Iraq. These investigations, for the purpose of informing the American people, are probably the only way to end this catastrophic war. After four years of spiraling death and destruction, the Bush administration and Congressional Republicans absurdly deny reality in Iraq. Only the forceful opposition of a broad majority of Americans from across the political spectrum can end the conflict.

Family will receive friends on Tuesday May 1st, 2007 from 3pm to 8pm at 6040 Boulevard East in West New York, NJ. Cremation services will be private.

Wells is 51 and lives in Manhattan. She is a marketing-and-advertising consultant. Before her career in the advertising industry, Wells was a social worker. She has never been married.
Beitler is 48 and lives in Manhattan. He is a primary-care doctor. He was married for 14 years to a woman he met in medical school. They have a daughter.

Neeley is 57 and lives in Montclair, N.J. She is a high-school biology teacher. Neeley was married for five years. Through her 20s and 30s, she was in long-term relationships with two different women.
Hockenberry is 50 and lives in Brooklyn. He was an award-winning correspondent for NPR, ABC and NBC's ''Dateline'' and is now a freelance journalist and a distinguished fellow at M.I.T.'s Media Lab.

The Coalition for the Homeless, a leading advocacy organization, issued a statement questioning the city's announcement that street homelessness has declined slightly, according to the Homeless Outreach Population Estimate, a citywide survey conducted annually since 2005. Mary Brosnahan, the coalition's executive director, called the decline "statistically insignificant and certainly nothing to cheer about." In a statement, she said:

It is three years and a few days since CBS News published the first photos documenting the systematic abuse, torture and humiliation of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison. The Bush administration and the American military have worked hard to firmly establish the "few bad apples" explanation of what happened. Eight low-ranking soldiers were convicted, and Staff Sgt. Ivan Frederick II, who was found guilty of assault, conspiracy, dereliction of duty and maltreatment of detainees, is now halfway through his eight-year prison sentence.

Today's presidential candidates are understandably cautious when it comes to foreign policy, especially about stepping into the minefields of Iraq. But in their remarks, it is possible to discern an assumption about the rightness of American leadership in world affairs - a notion that is the legacy of Woodrow Wilson.
Thomas is 60 and lives in Brooklyn. She teaches English language to international college students. Three years ago, Michele separated from her husband of 20 years. They have one child.
Duszynski is 46 and lives in Maplewood, N.J. He is an occupational therapist. He has been married for 18 years and has three children.
Handler is 59 and lives in Philadelphia. He owns a furniture-making studio. His first marriage ended in divorce after eight years; he now lives with his second wife.
Sartwell is 48 and lives in Glen Rock, Pa. He is a college philosophy professor and the author of numerous books, including most recently ''Six Names of Beauty.''
Cook is 62 and lives in Pound Ridge, NY. She is an corporate consultant and the author of a memoir, ''Second Life.'' She is a former Ford model. Cook has been married for 22 years.
WASHINGTON, May 2--And you thought he was still "the decider."

One of the topics most frequently covered and debated on this blog is restaurant reservations: the difficulty of getting them, the rules that come with them, the efficiency with which restaurants honor them, the consistency with which diners follow through on them.
Which Rudolph W. Giuliani will show up Thursday night in California for the debate among 10 Republican presidential candidates? The hard-hitting prosecutor? Or Mr. Nice Guy?

As readers know, I've tangled a few times with Bill O'Reilly, ever since I challenged him to put his passport where his mouth is and travel to Darfur. At the time, I compared him to Father Coughlin, and now we have some research to back up the parallel. An academic study looked at Father Coughlin's use of various standard propaganda devices versus Bill O'Reilly's and -- you guessed it -- O'Reilly uses them on the whole even more than Father Coughlin did. Take a look at the study.

Scott Boras, the powerful agent, had a conversation with Yankees' General Manager Brian Cashman recently about one of his clients who is itching to return and play for New York. But it was not Bernie Williams, the reclusive outfielder. It was Ron Villone, the reliever who is playing in Class AAA.

While the allusions to F. Scott Fitzgerald and Jazz Age parties may be trite, it is hard not to think of them when it comes to Southerly, a 10,000-square-foot Long Island estate that is now on the market for $15.8 million.

Many Wall Street analysts are still gaping over the $5 billion unsolicited bid that Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation made for Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. At $60 per share, it was 67 percent above the company's recent stock price and represented a multiple of about 16 times Dow Jones's projected 2007 Ebitda. (Other recent newspaper deals have come in at about eight times Ebitda.) A former financial adviser to the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, has called the bid "absolutely, insanely high."
New York City recorded 3,755 homeless individuals living without shelter according to the latest Homeless Outreach Population Estimate, which the city has conducted each year since 2005.

In its proxy fight with billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn, Motorola is giving as good as its getting. One day after Mr. Icahn used a full-page ad in The Wall Street Journal to compare comments by Motorola chief executive Ed Zander to "something straight out of Alice in Wonderland," Motorola is trying a similar strategy of using its adversary's words against him.
An advertisement for TiVo.

Royal Ahold, the Dutch food retailing giant, will sell its U.S. Foodservice business to two United States-based private equity firms for $7.1 billion. Clayton Dubilier & Rice and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed to buy the unit, which was the focus of an accounting scandal that emerged in 2003. U.S. Foodservice is the second-largest food service company, behind Sysco.
Here are a few items on Virginia Tech that we've spotted in our travels today around the Web.

The invitation looks pretty normal at first: Rosina Rubin, a donor to Democratic candidates, is hosting a fund-raiser for Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign next Tuesday, with former President Bill Clinton as the special guest. The event will be in a New York City suburb at "the home of Rosina Rubin and Jeff Rose," her husband and another prominent Democratic contributor.

How hot is the mergers and acquisitions market? Consider this: April marked an all-time high for the value of worldwide mergers announced in a single month, lifted in large part by a bidding war that broke out for Dutch bank ABN Amro. Thomson Financial calculates that the combined value of deals announced last month came to $626.3 billion, surpassing the previous record of $518.1 billion set in January 2000, when America Online announced its $165 billion bid for Time Warner.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's May 2 column, "The Hail Mary Pass."
So it turns out they have the Internet in France! Who knew?
The saga of Marilee Jones added another layer today when The Boston Globe reported that she indeed had a bachelor's degree.
How "Frank Stella on the Roof," a show of architectural pieces by Mr. Stella, was installed in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's roof garden.
After Greg Huddy and I descended from the cherry picker, we all sat down over iced tea to talk about requirements.

As deal makers survey the media scene following News Corporation's offer for Dow Jones, one name that keeps popping up is Pearson, the British book publisher and owner of The Financial Times. There were lots of scenarios being laid out for Pearson, whose $14 billion market capitalization makes it about three times the size of Dow Jones. It could enter the bidding for Dow Jones. It could itself be a takeover target. It could break itself up.
Images from the various segments of "Paris Je T'Aime."
Readers raised several kinds of objections to my education column. You can read the reader comments under the blog entry below. So let me try to summarize and respond to some of the objections.

My friend Mukhtar Mai (Mukhtaran Bibi), the Pakistani woman I've often written about, is visiting New York for a few days. She has campaigned relentlessly for women's rights in Pakistan, and as it happens her visit coincides with a report reaching me of another horrific incident:
By Marshall Sonenshine
The casino company run by billionaire Sheldon Adelson said it is bringing the Tony Award-winning musical to its newest casino project, the Palazzo.

On May 4, 1970, soldiers from the Ohio National Guard who had been sent onto the campus of Kent State University to disperse a demonstration against the Vietnam War suddenly opened fire. When the dust settled, four students were killed and nine were wounded during at least 13 seconds of shooting.
The Dolans seem to have finally hit the magic number.
UPDATE: The Yankees fired strength coach Marty Miller on Wednesday.

As summer approaches and travelers plunk down nonrefundable deposits to secure their vacation plans, many will inevitably be pressed to purchase travel insurance. But is it really worth it? Share your thoughts.

The Washington Post's Dan Balz and David Broder report that Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama encouraged Democrats to continue the fight over the war supplemental bill, which President Bush vetoed because of the included withdrawal timeline, while other contenders called for more drastic steps to end the war. John Edwards's campaign will tell Democrats, "Don't back down to President Bush" in ads set to air in Washington, the first of his campaign.
The right gear takes some of the dirty work out of seasonal chores.
Take home a little piece of Battery Park, a light transportable yurt for today's nomad, playful peel-and-stick art and more.
Note | 8:59 PM ET: The Times has published an article on the subject, focusing on "How a Number Became the Latest Web Celebrity"

Paul Wolfowitz's failures as a war architect and as a World Bank president flow from the same source, suggests Washington Post columnist David Ignatius: "The lesson of Wolfowitz's failure is that you can't change things unless you truly understand them. That was true in Iraq, and it was true at the World Bank."
Has Rupert Murdoch made the Bancroft family an offer they can't refuse?

Things were looking increasingly dismal for the private equity firms bidding for Clear Channel Communications Tuesday as a second proxy advisory firm urged shareholders in the broadcasting company to reject a sweetened offer from Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners.

The Texas Pacific Group is mulling selling a 20 percent stake in itself to a couple of pension funds, in a move that could signal an initial public offering of the private equity group, The Deal.com reported.

Shares of Coates Hire, the largest machinery rental company in Australia, rose the most in more than five years after it said it had been approached by buyout firms. Coates hired Macquarie Bank as an adviser and said Tuesday it would review operations, which may take "some months." Shares in Coates, which is based in Sydney, closed 8.7 percent higher, valuing it at 1.5 billion Australian dollars ($1.2 billion).

Citigroup agreed to buy a fund administrator, the Bisys Group, for $1.47 billion. Citigroup will pay $11.85 a share and a special dividend of 15 cents a share at closing, the New York-based bank said today in a statement distributed by Business Wire.

Credit Suisse Group said Wednesday that first-quarter net profit rose 5 percent helped by excellent markets for trading stocks and bonds and more commissions from wealthy clients. Credit Suisse, Switzerland's second-largest bank, said net profit for the three months was 2.7 billion Swiss francs ($2.23 billion), from 2.6 billion francs a year earlier.

In February, when Sirius Satellite Radio's chief executive, Mel Karmazin, announced plans to merge his company with the rival XM Satellite Radio, he pegged the chances of winning approval from regulators at "better than 50 percent." At the time, many investors and analysts agreed with his math.

Segetis, a green chemistry company, has raised $15 million from Khosla Ventures. The Minneapolis-based Segetis is one of a number of outfits trying to displace petroleum in household products like countertops, bottles and other items with agricultural-waste products.

A $3 billion loan package secured by the NYSE Euronext has some industry observers speculating that the exchange is plotting to muscle in on Deutsche Börse's agreed $2.8 billion deal for the International Securities Exchange.

Hawaiian Telcom is selling its phone directory publishing business for $435 million and will use the money to pay down debt and make service improvements. The sale to Local Insight Media was announced Tuesday and is subject to approval by the Public Utilities Commission.

Virgin Mobile USA, the leading mobile virtual network operator in the United States, plans to raise $100 million in an initial public offering, the company said on Tuesday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Bockbuster, the No. 1 U.S. movie retail chain, said on Wednesday it had sold its British video game retailer, Game Station, to Game Group of Britain for $150 million. The move is part of Blockbuster's ongoing efforts to sell off non-core assets and some international operations, while it heightens Game Group's presence in the British market.
The volume went up a notch Tuesday in the ongoing saga between Motorola and the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, who is seeking a seat on the cell phone maker's board.

Conrad M. Black and other Hollinger International executives improperly diverted more than $15 million to a holding company Mr. Black controlled, former Illinois Gov. James R. Thompson told jurors in Chicago Tuesday.
One possible suitor may be out of the battle over ABN Amro's LaSalle Bank, the Chicago institution that its Dutch parent agreed to sell to Bank of America for $21 billion.
For a number of reasons, I've been falling behind on my magazine reading. And I just got to the April issue of Evo last weekend.
the buyout shop Apollo Management revised its offer for Countrywide, Britain's largest real estate agency, on Tuesday after an 11th-hour offer by an anonymous bidder threatened to spoil the deal.
Sweden will sell a stake in telephone company TeliaSonera valued at about 19.7 billion kronor ($2.9 billion) to institutional investors, the first sale of a state holding by the new government.

ChannelAdvisor, an 8-year-old maker of on-demand software that helps retailers sell goods through Amazon, Shopzilla and eBay, on Tuesday announced $30 million in fresh funding to expand into new markets.

Under pressure from a group of disgruntled investors, NBC Universal and a hedge fund, the Citadel Investment Group, have again raised their takeover offer for family friendly TV network Ion Media Networks, The New York Post reported.

DealBook was chosen as the Best Business Blog in the 11th Annual Webby Awards, which highlight excellence on the Internet. Other nominees in the category included Bannerblog, paidContent, TechDirt and UX Magazine.

Cablevision Systems is near a deal to sell the company to its founding family, the Dolans, for about $10.6 billion in cash, according to people involved in the discussions. With the addition of debt, the total price tag would come to nearly $23 billion.
PBS’s “American Masters” series cannily presents Ahmet Ertegun’s biography — along with the story of the great pop musicians of the 20th century he helped make famous.

An academic study of the National Basketball Association found that, during the 13 seasons from 1991 through 2004, white referees called fouls at a greater rate against black players than against white players. A corresponding bias was found in which black officials called fouls more frequently against white players, though that tendency was not as strong.
“Missing Victor Pellerin” is an enigmatic and utterly compelling story of incinerated art, unbridled egos and exotic plants.
Kurdish and Sunni Arab officials expressed deep reservations over a draft of a bill that establishes a framework for the fair distribution of oil revenues.
On his recent jaunt to Mexico, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg fielded questions from Mexican reporters and, to the surprise of many, responded in Spanish.
Attending a conference, the president of the World Bank was forced to dodge questions about an intensifying  ethics scandal.
Protesters disrupted a news conference by the Estonian ambassador, harassed diplomats at the embassy and briefly blocked trucks crossing the border near St. Petersburg.
Meanwhile, his party began to press for constitutional changes that would bring it advantages in the election.

The majority of those voters say they are satisfied with the Bush presidency. But some have lost faith, and those who have say it is because they can no longer back Mr. Bush’s support of the war in Iraq.
The $10.5 billion deal resolves the tortured stalemate between the Dolans and the board over the future of the company.
Thaksin Shinawatra, the former Thai prime minister, has taken the first step toward purchasing Manchester City.
The statement by Tzipi Livni added to pressure on the prime minister, but it  disappointed some of his critics, who were expecting her to lead a rebellion.
Britain’s ruling Labor Party registered a last-minute gain to make a crucial regional election too close to call, according to an opinion survey published in The Scotsman newspaper.
A Turkish native was arrested after he and others disrupted a book reading about the Armenian genocide at a Barnes & Noble store on the Upper East Side last night, the police said.
Buffalo’s Daniel Brière tried to stuff the puck past Henrik Lundqvist’s outstretched right leg late in the third period. The puck rolled to the goal line, but was not ruled a goal.
Working on a no-hitter in his second major league start, Phil Hughes had one out in the seventh inning when he grabbed his left hamstring and was forced from the game.

Jason West, the village mayor who drew national attention for presiding over the unofficial weddings of same-sex couples in the Hudson Valley in 2004, lost his re-election bid yesterday. Mr. West was defeated by a village trustee, Terry Dungan, in a 514-to-379 vote, according to unofficial results announced shortly after the polls closed. Mr. West had been charged with 24 misdemeanor counts of violating the state’s domestic relations law when he performed public marriage ceremonies for two dozen gay and lesbian couples in February 2004. The Ulster County district attorney later dropped the charges, saying that a trial would be needless and divisive.
Replay officials could not definitively say Daniel Brière’s shot with 17 seconds left in the third period had crossed the line, preserving the Rangers’ victory. The series is now tied, 2-2.
The Raptors built a big lead early and did just enough late to keep hope alive as Toronto held off the Nets to avoid elimination. The Nets lead the series, 3-2.
Mike Pelfrey pitched into the seventh inning and David Wright had three hits, including his first home run of the season, but the Mets still lost to the Florida Marlins.
Twelve people, including eight children, were taken to hospitals after a school bus was struck by a stolen sport utility vehicle that the police were chasing in Queens.
Australia’s central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged.

Dan Johnson doubled home the winning run in the 10th inning after Jonathan Papelbon had his first blown save in the ninth and the visiting Oakland Athletics defeated the Boston Red Sox, 5-4, last night.

British manufacturing slowed in April as expected, but price growth rebounded to near record levels, a survey showed. The Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply/Royal Bank of Scotland purchasing managers’ index fell to 53.9 in April from a downwardly revised 54.2 in March. Analysts had predicted a decline to 54.0. The data is unlikely to alter expectations that the Bank of England will raise interest rates to 5.5 percent next week.

The Barrick Gold Corporation reported a first-quarter loss as it took a $557 million charge to exit hedge positions and take advantage of strong spot gold prices. Barrick, the world’s biggest gold producer, reported a loss of $159 million, or 18 cents a share, in contrast to a year-earlier profit of $224 million, or 29 cents a share. Stripping out the charge to eliminate forward sales contracts, adjusted earnings were $398 million, or 45 cents a share, up from $263 million, or 33 cents a share. Barrick said its hedge book for current production has been completely eliminated.

The Loblaw Companies, a supermarket chain, reported a decline in first-quarter profit, hurt by restructuring charges. Loblaw said it earned 54 million Canadian dollars ($48 million), down from 140 million Canadian dollars a year earlier. Loblaw said it took a charge of 75 million Canadian dollars for restructuring costs in the first quarter and a charge of 14 million Canadian dollars related to the closing of stores in the Quebec and Atlantic markets. Sales in the quarter gained 3.3 percent, to 6.347 billion Canadian dollars. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 2.4 percent.

South Korea’s trade surplus unexpectedly narrowed in April as import costs accelerated because of price increases for oil and natural resources, the government said. The trade surplus narrowed 27 percent, to $799 million, from $1.10 billion a year earlier, the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Energy said in a preliminary report. Exports rose 17.8 percent, to $30.15 billion, while imports jumped 19.9 percent, to $29.35 billion, the figures showed. Exports were raised by demand for semiconductors, automobiles, steel and machinery.

An article on Monday about the public debate in Israel over whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert could retain power despite a government report criticizing his leadership in the 34-day Lebanon war misstated the date the war began last year. It was July 12, not June 12.

A music review on Monday about the premiere of David Carlson’s opera, “Anna Karenina,” by the Florida Grand Opera in Miami, misidentified a work in which Tchaikovsky used the Czar’s Hymn, a variant of which Mr. Carlson uses as a fate motif. In addition to the “1812” Overture it was the “Marche Slav,” not the Fourth Symphony. (Tchaikovsky used a fate motif in that work.).

An article in Weekend on Friday about Symphony Space and the various arts programs it presents referred incompletely to the American Symphony Orchestra’s presence in New York City. While the orchestra is moving its annual series of concerts at Miller Theater to Symphony Space, it will continue its annual series of concerts at Lincoln Center.

An obituary yesterday about Tommy Newsom, the backup bandleader for “The Tonight Show” whom Johnny Carson used as a comical target, misstated part of the name of the Air Force jazz ensemble in which he played. It is the Airmen of Note, not Airman.

A picture caption in some copies on Sunday with a Sports of The Times column about the PGA Tour’s handling of Tiger Woods given his support among corporate sponsors misidentified the man shown with Woods. He is AT&T’s chairman and chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr. — not Tim Finchem, the PGA Tour commissioner.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about the success of the trainer Todd Pletcher in horse racing and his efforts to win the Kentucky Derby misstated the length of the Derby and the distance run by 14 Derby winners in preparation for the race. The Derby is a mile and a quarter — not a mile and an eighth, which is the distance those winners had run.

A front-page article on Saturday about an announcement by the New York State Police that the bullet that killed a trooper during a shootout with a fugitive in a Catskills farmhouse came from the gun of a fellow trooper — not from the fugitive — gave an incorrect surname at one point in some copies for the acting state police superintendent. He is Preston L. Felton, not Mr. Preston.

An article on Monday about the public debate in Israel over whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert could retain power despite a government report criticizing his leadership in the 34-day Lebanon war misstated the date the war began last year. It was July 12, not June 12.

An article on Saturday about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britain’s top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation when it was first made in January. It was made by the Serious Fraud Office — not by Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general.

An article on Friday about the identification of new genes connected to the most common forms of diabetes misspelled part of the name of the research organization preparing a report on seven major diseases. It is the Wellcome Trust in London, not the Welcome Trust.

An article in Business Day on Monday about Mark Halperin, who stepped down as the political director of ABC News and will join Time magazine, misstated his role at both media outlets. He is a political — not a policy — analyst. Because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to John F. Harris who, with Mr. Halperin wrote a book about the 2008 presidential race. Mr. Harris, who was at The Washington Post when the book was published last fall, is now editor in chief of The Politico, which covers national politics.

An article on Sunday about the frequency of Jon S. Corzine’s out-of-state travel during his tenure as governor of New Jersey rendered incorrectly in some copies comments on the matter from Zulima V. Farber, then the New Jersey attorney general, in an April 2006 memo. She wrote, “We do not believe that, in the circumstances you describe, an occasional, overnight stay in New York City following a workday in New Jersey and a return to this state in the morning constitutes an absence of the governor that would trigger the devolution of gubernatorial power.” The erroneous version said “circumstance” instead of “circumstances” and omitted the words “and a return.”.
A listing yesterday of American service members killed in Iraq misidentified the branch of service of Sgt. Michael R. Hullender. It is the Army, not the Marines.
Prosecutors in the sex-abuse and kidnapping trial of Peter Braunstein played a tape of a harrowing 911 call from a Chelsea woman.
Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s aides say his coalition is holding together in the wake of a damning report.
The president called the bill a “prescription for chaos and confusion,” setting up a further battle with Congressional Democrats.
Efforts to create a capable Afghan Army and a police force have been accompanied by a mix of achievements and frustrations.
A commander in the main U.S. detention center lent prisoners his cellphone and used public funds to supply Saddam Hussein with hair dye, investigators claimed.
Citing recent terror plots, U.S. officials want to curb the access of British citizens of Pakistani origin to America.
Supporters of Abdullah Gul said the decision was simply an attempt to hold on to power by Turkey’s secular elite.
The country would be better off if politicians worried less about the gun lobby’s cash and more about Americans’ safety.
You have to admire the work of the investigating commission appointed to analyze Israel’s botched war in Lebanon last summer.
President Bush has submitted a bill that would enact enormous, and enormously dangerous, changes to the 1978 law on eavesdropping.
PRO FOOTBALL.
A firm that lobbies aggressively for coal-fired power plants has helped Rudolph W. Giuliani to gain support in Texas.
Mayor Michael Bloomberg wants to turn gritty Willets Point into “a dynamic center of life, energy and economic activity.”
The Scottish Nationalist Party, which is poised to become the biggest party in the Scottish Assembly, has promised a referendum on seeking independence.
A Mets fan has been sentenced to 15 days in jail and barred from the Mets’ ballpark for three years after pleading guilty to shining a high-powered flashlight at two players.
It was impossible to walk past the stables on West 89th Street and not feel that they provided a secret entrance to a different city.
The more home runs Barry Bonds hits on his way to Hank Aaron’s career record, the hotter baseball’s steroids controversy seems to burn.
Mr. von Weizsäcker wrote more than 30 books and founded the prestigious Max Planck Institute for Social Sciences.
Morehouse College has selected Robert M. Franklin Jr., a professor at the Candler School of Theology at Emory University, as its 10th president.
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission announced tighter security requirements for the nation’s 33 research and test reactors, most located at universities.

Death rates and heart failure in hospitalized heart attack patients have fallen sharply in the last six years, most likely because of better treatment, the largest international study of its kind suggests.

Six teenagers were wounded in two shootings near downtown Jacksonville that the police said might have been retaliation for a fight about a girl. All six victims, ages 15 to 17, were being treated at a hospital, said Ken Jefferson, a spokesman for the Jacksonville sheriff’s office. In the first shooting, four of the teenagers were sitting on a porch and were peppered with birdshot from a shotgun fired from a passing car around 2:30 p.m., Sheriff John Rutherford said. About a block away, shots were fired between two cars, and the police said two people were wounded in that exchange.
The campaign of Representative Rick Renzi, Republican of Arizona, agreed to pay a $25,000 fine for underreporting contributions and expenses, the F.E.C. said.
The request by Representative George Miller carries his inquiries into education policy-making beyond the Education Department itself and into the Bush White House.
A study suggests that a racial bias found in other parts of American society also exists on the basketball court.

Secretary General Ban Ki-moon chose three international figures to help him chart a way for the United Nations to take the lead in addressing climate change. The special envoys are Gro Harlem Brundtland, a former prime minister of Norway; Ricardo Lagos, a former president of Chile; and Han Seung-soo, a former foreign minister of South Korea and president of the General Assembly in 2001. Michèle Montas, Mr. Ban’s spokeswoman, said the three would prepare proposals for the opening of the General Assembly in September when national leaders come to New York and for a United Nations conference in Bali, Indonesia, in December. Last month, the first-ever debate on climate change was held in the Security Council.

Prime Minister Tony Blair offered an indirect endorsement of Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, as his successor, saying that “in all probability, a Scot will become prime minister of the United Kingdom.” Mr. Blair did not identify Mr. Brown by name when he addressed Labor Party supporters in Edinburgh. Labor is expected to lose ground in regional voting on Thursday, which would help set Mr. Blair’s schedule to resign as party leader.

The police have filed a murder complaint against a woodcarver who confessed to bludgeoning to death a Peace Corps volunteer who was hiking in the mountains on April 8. They said the woodcarver, Juan Duntugan, 24, told them he had hit the volunteer, Julia Campbell, of Fairfax, Va., with a stick and a rock because he was angry at a neighbor. Asked by an investigator how long he had hit her, The Associated Press reported, he replied: “I think about five minutes. I don’t remember how many times I hit her with that stone.” Ms. Campbell, 40, had worked as a freelance journalist for a number of publications including The New York Times.

Liberia restarted its diamond trade, four days after the United Nations lifted an embargo, hoping the revival of the industry will pay for reconstruction rather than lead to more bloodshed. Trade in rough diamonds from riverbeds and mud pits in Liberia and neighboring Sierra Leone was a major factor in civil wars that killed a quarter of a million people in this corner of West Africa during the 1990s. Ten offices are being set up to ensure that diamonds are certified under the Kimberley Process, an industry-led effort to prevent illicit sale of gems from conflict areas, known as blood diamonds. “This process means a lot for this country, and we want for our diamonds to be used for development and not to support conflict,” said President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf after opening the first two offices.

Efforts to bring Darfur rebel groups to southern Sudan for peace talks with the Khartoum government could take up to three months, an official in charge of organizing the possible negotiations said. The semiautonomous Government of Southern Sudan, based in Juba, which emerged after a 2005 peace deal that ended 21 years of civil war with the north, has set up a task force to try to bring rebel groups to talks and its secretary, Achier Deng Akol, said that may take until July.
Former Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois told jurors that Hollinger executives improperly diverted more than $15 million to a holding company.

Palestinian Authority officials said the kidnappers of Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent in Gaza who was abducted March 12, have made specific but unacceptable demands, the first time there has been formal contact. Azzam al-Ahmed, the deputy prime minister, said the demands were “linked with ideology and politics” but refused to detail them. Another security official told a Palestinian newspaper that the kidnappers were known, but that the British had urged that force not be used to free Mr. Johnston, 44, whom Palestinian officials say is alive.
A troubled African boy and his American guardian struggle to cope with the physical and psychological effects of war.
Boston had been the only race in the World Marathon Majors series to prohibit pacesetters. The marathons in Berlin, London and Chicago use them.

St. Lucia, a Caribbean island nation, became the 25th country with diplomatic ties to Taipei instead of Beijing. Liu Jianchao, a Foreign Ministry spokesman in Beijing, denounced St. Lucia for reversing its 1997 decision to recognize Beijing, and said the Chinese ambassador in St. Lucia would lodge a protest. Taiwan has struggled to maintain relations with small countries in Africa, Central America, the Caribbean and the South Pacific, frequently providing them with aid, while larger countries have recognized Beijing as the sole government of all of China, including Taiwan.

A court in Tashkent sentenced Umida Niyazova, a journalist and human rights worker, to seven years in prison. Amnesty International has called Ms. Niazova a prisoner of conscience. According to local reports, her lawyer was given only 30 minutes warning before the resumption of the trial, in which she was found guilty of smuggling and distributing illegal material. Four days earlier, the authorities had sent a well-known Uzbek doctor, Gulbahor Turayeva, who advocated for patients’ rights, to prison for six years. She was arrested in January when the police said she possessed several banned books.

The United States and Japan expect North Korea to immediately meet its initial obligations under a six-nation disarmament pact, the American secretary of state, Condoleezza Rice, said two weeks after the North missed a deadline for shutting down its main nuclear reactor. “We agreed that we must continue to expect North Korea to immediately fulfill its initial action agreements,” Ms. Rice said in Washington after talks with her Japanese counterpart, Taro Aso; the American defense secretary, Robert M. Gates; and the Japanese defense minister, Fumio Kyuma.
Joe Torre called George Steinbrenner on Monday night to thank him for his latest statement, in which Steinbrenner said he believed in Torre and the rest of the Yankees.
State privacy laws have thwarted repeated efforts to improve the reporting of mental health records to the federal database used for background checks.

Senate Republicans said yesterday that they would seek to increase by $200 million the school property tax rebate checks that taxpayers 65 and older are eligible to receive, but Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration indicated that it would not support the proposal. Under a budget deal announced in late March, state officials added $1.3 billion to the state’s School Tax Relief Program, making it a nearly $5 billion-a-year program. But the several hundred thousand elderly homeowners who are eligible for higher benefits saw almost no increase when tax exemptions and rebate checks available under the program were taken into consideration. “It’s clear we have the resources available to give seniors greater tax relief,” Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, said in a statement. But Jeffrey Gordon, a spokesman for the governor’s Budget Division, said Mr. Spitzer “will include more relief in next year’s budget” and “will not bust the budget by adding more spending on property tax relief this year.”.
A Newark man was convicted yesterday of conspiring in the murder of a witness against him in a drug case, federal prosecutors said.

The city’s Conflicts of Interest Board has found that Councilman Michael E. McMahon, left, had one of his staff members perform personal tasks for him on city time, including helping his 12-year-old daughter with her homework. The inquiry began last year when city officials received an anonymous letter claiming that Mr. McMahon, a Staten Island Democrat, was using his city-paid staff for political campaigning. Mr. McMahon was cleared of that allegation, but investigators found that he had allowed his administrative assistant to type a poem for his daughter while she was visiting his Council office. Mr. McMahon also had his assistant call parents of a youth soccer team he coached to tell them of scheduling changes or that he would be late for games or practices because of Council-related business. Mr. McMahon, who did not dispute the findings, said his staff would no longer perform personal tasks because “that is the strict letter of the rules.” The board recommended no fines or penalties, given the limited nature of the violation. City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said she would refer the findings to the Council’s Standards and Ethics Committee for further review.

A Manhattan woman has been charged with larceny for accepting hundreds of dollars as payment for puppies she advertised for sale on the Internet and failing to deliver the dogs, prosecutors said yesterday. The woman, Janet Goris, 33, of Stanton Street, was arraigned in Criminal Court on Friday on charges including grand larceny and conspiracy, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Ms. Goris accepted $300 to $400, wired to a Western Union office in East Elmhurst, from each of four people for an English bulldog puppy. Mr. Brown said Ms. Goris told investigators that she kept 10 percent and sent the rest of the money to an accomplice in Nigeria. “It is doubtful the puppies even existed,” Mr. Brown said in a statement.

Cracking down on video piracy, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law yesterday a measure that increases penalties for unauthorized recordings of public performances to six months in prison, with criminal fines of up to $5,000. The penalties were formerly 15 days in jail, with fines of up to $250. Mr. Bloomberg also announced the start of a marketing campaign to discourage New Yorkers from buying pirated DVDs, which the Motion Picture Association of America estimates cost the city $903 million a year in lost earnings, according to a study released yesterday. The campaign, which includes a trailer-style spot showing very blurry footage from “Happy Feet” that has been rated F for Fake, is to be shown on broadcast and cable stations starting on Monday.

Several Vineland residents have reported seeing a large animal similar to a panther in the area recently, but environment officials said they had found no evidence of such an animal. “I can’t tell you if it was a panther, but I can tell you it wasn’t a domesticated house cat,” said Felicia Fiocchi, who said she spotted the animal near her house on Sunday. A state conservation officer visited the area three times over the weekend but found nothing to indicate that a panther was in the area, said Darlene Yuhas, a spokeswoman for the Department of Environmental Protection. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Four JetBlue workers and a city correction officer have been charged with identity theft in a case involving credit card numbers stolen from airline passengers and used for a spending spree at restaurants, liquor stores, Bloomingdale’s and other shops, prosecutors said yesterday. Investigators began looking at the group after someone rushing to catch a flight forgot his credit card at a JetBlue counter at Kennedy Airport, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said. Later, the card was used to run up $508 in charges, the office said. JetBlue officials said the four workers, three customer service agents and a flight attendant were suspended.

Gov. M. Jodi Rell has asked President Bush to declare Connecticut a disaster area in the wake of a storm on April 15 that brought up to eight inches of rain to some areas and caused major flooding. The declaration would make Connecticut eligible for federal funds, which would help to cover some of the $43 million in expenses incurred by state and local governments and property owners, the governor’s office said in a statement yesterday. The storm damaged 179 businesses and more than 2,400 homes, her office said. Government costs associated with the storm and its aftermath total $12 million, and private losses stand at more than $31.2 million. Compiled by John Sullivan.

10 P.M. (22, 26) ATLANTIC RECORDS: THE HOUSE THAT AHMET BUILT Ahmet Ertegun, left, was living in Washington when he first heard African-American music in that city’s segregated clubs. The son of a Turkish diplomat, he exported that sound to England, where he merged it with a European sensibility, and then brought it back to the United States, where he started an independent label with Herb Abramson and a $10,000 loan from his dentist. One result was the boogie-based, saxophone-driven “Atlantic Sound,” which changed the face of contemporary American music. Mr. Ertegun’s roster at Atlantic Records included Ray Charles, Ruth Brown, Big Joe Turner, LaVern Baker and the Drifters. In this documentary, Eric Clapton, Aretha Franklin, David Geffen, Mick Jagger, Kid Rock, Henry Kissinger, Jimmy Page, Robert Plant and Jann Wenner, among others, talk about the musical influence of Mr. Ertegun, who died in December.

In “Mindless Eating” (Bantam Books, 2006), the Cornell professor Brian Wansink explains the psychological cues that lead people to overeat. The human stomach isn’t sensitive enough to notice small caloric differences, and it often doesn’t register how much has been eaten until 20 minutes or more after the food has been swallowed. So people instead rely on their eyes, ears and noses to tell them when to stop eating. And they often overeat as a result.

MURDOCH BIDS FOR DOW JONES Rupert Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation, has made an unsolicited $5 billion offer to buy Dow Jones & Company, the venerable publisher of The Wall Street Journal that he has long coveted. [Page A1.] ABRUPT RESIGNATION FOR BP CHIEF John Browne, a British magnate who transformed BP into one of the most successful global companies, resigned abruptly after losing a court battle with a London tabloid over disclosure of his sexual relationship with a younger man. [C1.] LATIN AMERICAN MULTINATIONALS An intrepid group of successful and suddenly multinational Latin American companies are mounting a broadening surge of investment in the United States and elsewhere in the world. [C1.] FORD'S EDGE CAN'T STOP TOYOTA Ford's new Edge, a crossover vehicle, is meeting its sales expectations, but it could not prevent Toyota from replacing Ford as the second-largest seller of vehicles in the United States, after General Motors. [C3.] DOLANS NEAR DEAL FOR CABLEVISION Cablevision Systems Corporation is nearing a deal to sell itself to its founding family, the Dolans, for about $10.5 billion in cash, according to people involved in the discussions. With the addition of debt, the total price tag would come to nearly $23 billion. [C1.] YUM OVERCOMES ADVERSITY Yum Brands reported strong first-quarter earnings, as surging overseas sales and growth offset reduced business in the United States. The restaurant chain, which operates KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut, reported higher earnings despite two recent back-to-back public relations disasters -- first an E. coli outbreak at its Taco Bell franchise, and then a widely publicized rat infestation at one of its restaurants in New York City. [C3.] EX-GOVERNOR TESTIFIES Conrad M. Black and other Hollinger International executives improperly diverted more than $15 million to a holding company Mr. Black controlled, former Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois told jurors in Chicago. [C2.] MEDICARE COVERAGE OF STENTS The government has dropped its previously announced plans to expand Medicare coverage for the use of stents to prop open neck arteries to prevent strokes. [C3.] QWEST PROFIT UP ON COST CUTTING Qwest Communications, the telephone carrier, reported that its quarterly profit nearly tripled mostly because of cost cuts and an increase in broadband Internet customers. But the surge in profit was not accompanied by sales growth, an indication that the company is still struggling to transform itself into a multifaceted telecommunications company. Revenue declined less than 1 percent. [C2.] NO MELAMINE FOUND IN HUMAN FOOD Sampling by the Food and Drug Administration for melamine, which has been implicated in the deaths of dogs and cats, has not yet turned up the chemical in food meant for humans. And even if small amounts were found, it would be unlikely to pose a threat to humans. [A16.] CAMPAIGN FOR AN AIRLINE A campaign by Delta Air Lines to restore luster to its tarnished brand image comes from a creative agency whose principals are known for their work for political candidates as well as for brands. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C13.] NBC HIRES EX-NEWSWEEK EDITOR NBC named the former editor of Newsweek magazine, Mark Whitaker, as senior vice president for news, a job that will make him the No. 2 executive in the network's news division. [C13.] DISAPPEARING BOOK REVIEWS Newspapers are cutting book sections or running more reprints of book reviews from wire services. To some readers, these moves amount to a nail in the coffin of literary culture. But others, including bloggers, see it as a step toward a new, more democratic literary landscape. [E1.] JUST ASK Xerox has introduced software that allows the user to adjust the shadings on a color printer by using simple English, like ''Make the sun a brighter yellow.'' [C4.] MARKETS UP ON TAKEOVER FERVOR Stocks moved higher on Wall Street, spurred by revived enthusiasm about takeover activity, and the Dow Jones industrial average reached another record close, its 38th since last October. [C16.] RISKY COMMERCIAL MORTGAGES Spurred by the collapse of the subprime mortgage market, the leading bond rating agencies are beginning to crack down on what they see as risky lending practices in commercial real estate. [C11.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. CHIQUITA BRANDS International, the distributor of bananas, other fruits and salad mixes, posted a quarterly loss, hurt by higher costs, lower banana prices in Europe and a charge related to a decision to exit unprofitable farms in Chile. (REUTERS) AVON PRODUCTS reported quarterly profit that topped Wall Street expectations, helped by strong sales in China and Russia. (REUTERS) METLIFE, THE INSURANCE GIANT, said that first-quarter profit rose 38 percent compared with a year ago and that it had amassed a record $537.8 billion in total assets. (AP)

An article in Weekend on Friday about Symphony Space and the various arts programs it presents referred incompletely to the American Symphony Orchestra's presence in New York City. While the orchestra is moving its annual series of concerts at Miller Theater to Symphony Space, it will continue its annual series of concerts at Lincoln Center.

To the Editor: Re ''Lingering Fog of Chemotherapy Is No Longer Ignored as Illusion'' (front page, April 29): The treatment of many cancers has become more sophisticated and successful. Each year, the number of survivors grows, as many such individuals begin to live with essentially a chronic, treatable illness.

The police have filed a murder complaint against a woodcarver who confessed to bludgeoning to death a Peace Corps volunteer who was hiking in the mountains on April 8. They said the woodcarver, Juan Duntugan, 24, told them he had hit the volunteer, Julia Campbell, of Fairfax, Va., with a stick and a rock because he was angry at a neighbor. Asked by an investigator how long he had hit her, The Associated Press reported, he replied: ''I think about five minutes. I don't remember how many times I hit her with that stone.'' Ms. Campbell, 40, had worked as a freelance journalist for a number of publications including The New York Times. SETH MYDANS

GARY--Raymond B. The Board and staff of Third Street Music School Settlement are deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend and Board member Ray Gary. For more than two decades, Ray's commitment to our mission was steadfast. From applauding young musicians at student concerts to building the School's financial stability as its longtime Treasurer, Ray's down-to-earth, ever-positive outlook helped ensure that music, dance and art are accessible to everyone. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Prue, Amelia and the entire family. David M. Huggin, Chairman Lee Koonce, Executive Director $(6$)GARY--Raymond Bedros, Age 78 died peacefully on Saturday, April 28, 2007 after a short illness. He was the beloved husband of Prudence Gibb Gary for 36 years and the adored father of their daughter Amelia Mai Gary. He is also survived by his brother Captain Stanley Platt Gary and his family. B.A. Yale University 1950, M.A. Harvard University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, 1951. U.S. Navy 1951-1954, Morgan Stanley 1955, Partner 1964, Advisory Director 1983. Raymond was on the Board of Directors of the Third Street Music School Settlement and Stone Oil Corporation. There will be a service held at the Union Chapel, Fishers Island, N.Y. at 12:30pm on Friday, May 4, 2007 and a private family burial. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 East 11th Street, New York 10003 would be appreciated by the family.

A court in Tashkent sentenced Umida Niyazova, a journalist and human rights worker, to seven years in prison. Amnesty International has called Ms. Niazova a prisoner of conscience. According to local reports, her lawyer was given only 30 minutes warning before the resumption of the trial, in which she was found guilty of smuggling and distributing illegal material. Four days earlier, the authorities had sent a well-known Uzbek doctor, Gulbahor Turayeva, who advocated for patients' rights, to prison for six years. She was arrested in January when the police said she possessed several banned books. ILAN GREENBERG

CALDER--Elizabeth Ann (Libby), 86, a resident of Watch Hill, RI, died April 28th. Born in Boston, MA, the eldest child of Peter and Elizabeth Sullivan Naphen, Libby was raised in New Canaan and Darien, CT and lived for many years in Armonk, NY with her late husband, Louis Calder, Jr. and their three children. Predeceased by her eldest son Louis Christopher Calder, her two brothers, Peter and Fred Naphen, and her sister, Marie Kane, she is survived by her son, Peter D. Calder of New Canaan, CT, her daughter Elizabeth C. McEwen of Wilmington, VT, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will held at a later date. Donations in Libby's memory may be made to the Westerly Adult Day Care Services, Inc. 85 Wells Street, Westerly, RI 02891.

Palestinian Authority officials said the kidnappers of Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent in Gaza who was abducted March 12, have made specific but unacceptable demands, the first time there has been formal contact. Azzam al-Ahmed, the deputy prime minister, said the demands were ''linked with ideology and politics'' but refused to detail them. Another security official told a Palestinian newspaper that the kidnappers were known, but that the British had urged that force not be used to free Mr. Johnston, 44, whom Palestinian officials say is alive. STEVEN ERLANGER

Tom Poston, an Emmy-winning comic actor whose television characters ranged from the slow-witted Everyman on ''The Steve Allen Show'' to a cantankerous closet-dwelling clown on the recent sitcom ''Committed,'' died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85. Mr. Poston died after a short illness, his wife, the actress Suzanne Pleshette, said.

An article on Friday about the identification of new genes connected to the most common forms of diabetes misspelled part of the name of the research organization preparing a report on seven major diseases. It is the Wellcome Trust in London, not the Welcome Trust.

President Hugo Chávez on Tuesday seized control of the last remaining oil projects in Venezuela controlled by large American and European energy companies. The move to take over the projects, announced in January, is the centerpiece of recent actions aimed at consolidating his government's control over the economy. Dressed in red fatigues, Mr. Chávez delivered a fiery speech at the coastal oil refining complex of Jose, denouncing America's economic influence before thousands of supporters also clad in red, the color of his revolution.

The Republican majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, said on Tuesday that he would not support Gov. Eliot Spitzer's proposed legislation to legalize same-sex marriage in New York. His remarks came as thousands of gay rights supporters marched to the State Capitol to voice their support for the proposal and praise Governor Spitzer, who introduced the bill on Friday even as he conceded that it was unlikely to become law anytime soon. Mr. Bruno has indicated his opposition to the bill in the past; his counterpart in the Assembly, Speaker Sheldon Silver, has taken no position on it.

KLUGE--Willard G., died at home on Friday, April 20, 2007. He was 82. Born in Philadelphia on September 18, 1924, to the late Willard and Alice (Perry) Kluge, he lived in Montclair for 72 years before moving to Tewksbury 10 years ago. He was the president and CEO of the textiles firm of Artistic Identification Systems for over 50 years, retiring in 1996. He was a veteran of the United States Air Force during WWII, and trained as a navigator before the end of the war. He had a BA Degree from the Philadelphia Textile Institute, attended Montclair Academy, and graduated from the Kimball Union Academy. Mr. Kluge is survived by his wife, the former Kathleen Madigan; two sons John P. Kluge of Maryland, and Chris Kluge of Newton; four daughters, Linda Kluge of Idaho, Janet Wiggin of Califon, NJ, Barbara Hickox of Boonton Twp., and Jennifer Kluge of California; two sisters, Nancy Hall Rumery of North Carolina, and Barbara Kluge Deming of Connecticut; fourteen grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his former wife, Margaret Hulst Jenkins, mother of John, Chris, Linda, Janet and Barbara. For more information contact Bailey Funeral Home, 176 Main Street, Peapack, NJ 07977. (908) 234-0590. All services are private at the request of the family. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the charity of your choice would be appreciated by the family.

An obituary yesterday about Tommy Newsom, the backup bandleader for ''The Tonight Show'' whom Johnny Carson used as a comical target, misstated part of the name of the Air Force jazz ensemble in which he played. It is the Airmen of Note, not Airman.

Prime Minister Tony Blair offered an indirect endorsement of Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, as his successor, saying that ''in all probability, a Scot will become prime minister of the United Kingdom.'' Mr. Blair did not identify Mr. Brown by name when he addressed Labor Party supporters in Edinburgh. Labor is expected to lose ground in regional voting on Thursday, which would help set Mr. Blair's schedule to resign as party leader. ALAN COWELL

Few farms remain within an hour's drive of New York City, and to have one added instead of subtracted is an achievement. In Bedford Hills, N.Y., a Westchester County playground for moguls, Lisa and Mark Schwartz gradually accumulated 35 acres that they turned into Rainbeau Ridge, where they have 24 Alpine goats and make cheese. Ms. Schwartz, above, a former management consultant who studied the craft in France, makes several delicately tangy cheeses, including an ash-coated pyramid, a soft herb-flecked one and another with a tender, bloomy rind. The cheeses ($16 to $22 a pound) are sold at Bedford Gourmet in Bedford Village, N.Y.; Darien Cheese & Fine Foods in Darien, Conn.; and in the cafe at Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

To the Editor: Re ''Olmert Rebuked by Israeli Panel on Lebanon War'' (front page, May 1): You report that an Israeli commission, appointed by the government of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, excoriated him for ''severe failures'' in the war against Hezbollah in Lebanon.

ROBERTSON--Heather Merriweather, 38, died this past weekend in Buenas Aires, Argentina. Heather, a screenwriter, director and filmmaker, was the daughter of actors Dina Merrill and Cliff Robertson. She is survived by her brother Stanley H. Rumbough and her sisters Nina Rumbough of Greenwich, Connecticut and Stephanie Saunders of Charlesston, South Carolina. Family services will be held privately. Friends may send memorial contributions in Heather's name to St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH 03301-2591

President Bush has made fighting AIDS and malaria in poor nations signature issues, and now the three leading Democratic presidential candidates are laying claim to the theme of educating children in poor countries. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York proposed legislation yesterday to spend $10 billion over five years to build classrooms, train teachers and get millions of children, especially girls, into school in the developing world. Senator Barack Obama of Illinois and John Edwards of North Carolina have made their own ambitious education proposals for poor nations in recent speeches.

Schoolchildren to Dance With Berlin Philharmonic One hundred twenty New York City public-school children will dance with the Berlin Philharmonic when Simon Rattle, right, leads the orchestra in two performances of Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' in the fall at the United Palace Theater at Broadway and 175th Street in Washington Heights, Carnegie Hall said yesterday. The dancing, choreographed by Royston Maldoom and rehearsed for nearly eight weeks by the schoolchildren from the Choir Academy of Harlem, the Bread and Roses Integrated Arts High School, Public School 153 and Public School 161, will take place on Nov. 17 and 18. Designed by Thomas W. Lamb (1871-1942), one of the foremost American theater architects of the 19th and 20th centuries, the United Palace Theater opened in 1930 as Loew's 175th Street, seating more than 3,000. On Nov. 13, 14 and 16, the Berlin Philharmonic is to appear at Carnegie Hall, where it will perform Mahler's Symphony No. 9, ''The Song of the Earth,'' and the unfinished Symphony No. 10 in the version by Deryck Cooke. Twain Prize for Crystal Billy Crystal, below, was named yesterday to receive the 10th annual Mark Twain Prize for American Humor. The honor will be bestowed on Oct. 11 at the Kennedy Center Opera House in Washington and broadcast nationwide by PBS in the fall. In a statement, Stephen A. Schwarzman, chairman of Kennedy Center, said: ''The work he has created for stage, film and television has made an indelible impression. It is the work of not just a humorist but also a humanist.'' Mr. Crystal, who said he was honored to receive an award previously given to Richard Pryor, Steve Martin and Neil Simon, said, ''As my grandfather said, if you hang around the store long enough, once in a while they'll give you something.'' Scientists Fiddle And Out Comes a Strad In the latest miracle of modern science, researchers at Manchester University in England say they have developed an electronic device that can make a cheap violin sound like a rare Stradivarius, The Guardian of London reported. The device is called the Sound Wizard. Patrick Gaydecki, a professor of digital signal processing who leads the research team, said: ''The violin is like a bell or any resonant system. It vibrates with a characteristic signature.'' To extract the signature, the researchers use a laser pulse to record the vibrations before subtracting from the full violin sound the sound of the strings, which is essentially the same for every violin. Then they give the resulting sound the amplification provided by the body of a Stradivarius. ''In effect, the processing system becomes the violin body,'' Dr. Gaydecki said. Magicians Seek Cash For Coin Trick Exposure Forty-nine Japanese magicians have sued two Japanese television networks for showing viewers the secret behind their coin tricks, Agence France-Presse reported. The magicians are seeking 1.97 million yen ($16,400) -- and apologies -- from Nippon Television Network and TV Asahi. ''There was no need to reveal the secrets of tricks, and the defendants infringed upon the value of secrets of tricks, which are assets shared by magicians,'' the group of plaintiffs said in the lawsuit filed in Tokyo District Court. In November the networks' news programs showed how coin tricks were done, after the arrest of a magician and a pub operator for punching holes in coins for use in sleight of hand. Japanese law bars damaging or melting coins. Shintaro Fujiyama, 52, a plaintiff, said: ''It takes us many years to develop a coin trick as a professional tool. They must understand how all the time we have spent is wasted by exposure of the trick.'' Nippon TV declined to comment. TV Asahi said it believed there was no problem with its program. A Baby Girl for Star Of 'Whale Rider' Keisha Castle-Hughes, 17, below, who became the youngest actress nominated for the Academy Award for best actress when she appeared on the ballot in 2004 for her performance in the 2003 New Zealand film ''Whale Rider,'' gave birth to a girl last Wednesday, Agence France-Presse reported. Gail Cowan, her manager, said Felicity-Amore, the seven-pound, six-ounce infant, was ''beautiful.'' In a television interview broadcast last week, Ms. Castle-Hughes said she had wanted to hide after a public controversy over her pregnancy by her boyfriend, Bradley Hull, 19. ''I felt like it was bad for me to be happy about it,'' she said. Last year, she starred as the Virgin Mary in ''The Nativity Story.'' Footnotes Jason Patric has left MCC Theater's production of Neil LaBute's ''In a Dark Dark House'' over what the show's spokesman called ''creative differences.'' Frederick Weller (''Glengarry Glen Ross'') will take Mr. Patric's place, opposite the previously announced Ron Livingston. Performances begin on May 16 at the Lucille Lortel Theater. Rowan Atkinson (''Mr. Bean'') is to portray Mr. Micawber in the first big-screen adaptation of Dickens's ''David Copperfield'' since the 1935 George Cukor film, starring W. C. Fields in the role, Variety.com reported. ''David Copperfield,'' to go before the cameras next year, will be directed by Peter Howitt, who directed Mr. Atkinson in ''Johnny English.'' The Michael Crichton best seller ''The Andromeda Strain,'' about a deadly disease from outer space, will become a four-hour A&E mini-series, Variety.com reported. Production is to begin in the summer. The novel was previously adapted for a 1971 movie.

An article on Monday about the public debate in Israel over whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert could retain power despite a government report criticizing his leadership in the 34-day Lebanon war misstated the date the war began last year. It was July 12, not June 12.

St. Lucia, a Caribbean island nation, became the 25th country with diplomatic ties to Taipei instead of Beijing. Liu Jianchao, a Foreign Ministry spokesman in Beijing, denounced St. Lucia for reversing its 1997 decision to recognize Beijing, and said the Chinese ambassador in St. Lucia would lodge a protest. Taiwan has struggled to maintain relations with small countries in Africa, Central America, the Caribbean and the South Pacific, frequently providing them with aid, while larger countries have recognized Beijing as the sole government of all of China, including Taiwan. KEITH BRADSHER

A well-made dry martini is a serious, contemplative drink, one that can easily overwhelm anything served with it. But a nibble that offers a touch of fat and salt is always welcome. Good potato chips would be the ticket. A search for something showier and more elaborate can lead to a batch of fresh French fries.

All winter, people questioned whether the Mets had enough starting pitching to contend for the National League pennant this season. The Yankees, on the other hand, had a full rotation, welcoming Kei Igawa to the United States, Andy Pettitte back home and Carl Pavano back to work. But one month into the season, the Mets have had one of the more effective starting rotations in their league -- Monday night's game notwithstanding -- and the Yankees have had one of the least effective rotations in the American League -- last night's game notwithstanding. The same can be said for the respective bullpens.

A picture caption in some copies on Sunday with a Sports of The Times column about the PGA Tour's handling of Tiger Woods given his support among corporate sponsors misidentified the man shown with Woods. He is AT&T's chairman and chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr. -- not Tim Finchem, the PGA Tour commissioner.

An article in Business Day on Monday about Mark Halperin, who stepped down as the political director of ABC News and will join Time magazine, misstated his role at both media outlets. He is a political -- not a policy -- analyst. Because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to John F. Harris who, with Mr. Halperin wrote a book about the 2008 presidential race. Mr. Harris, who was at The Washington Post when the book was published last fall, is now editor in chief of The Politico, which covers national politics.

An article on Saturday about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britain's top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation when it was first made in January. It was made by the Serious Fraud Office -- not by Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general.

David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A. B. Bressman Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft President
