INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Bush Vetoes Iraq Bill Containing Timetable President Bush vetoed a $124 billion war spending bill, opening the second round in his battle with Congressional Democrats who are determined to use their budgetary power to force the White House to shift course in Iraq. Mr. Bush said he could not sign the bill because it contained timetables for troop withdrawal. A1 The Iraqi government said that it was investigating reports that the leader of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia had been killed. American military commanders said they could not confirm the reports. A10 Turkish Court Blocks Candidate Turkey's highest court blocked a candidate with a background in Islamic politics from being appointed president, pitching the country into early elections and a referendum on the role of religion in its future. A1 Visa Loophole Worries U.S. The ringleader of the thwarted London bomb plot who was recently sentenced to life in prison was a Briton of Pakistani descent and, as a British citizen, could have entered the United States without a visa. American officials, citing the number of terror plots in Britain involving British Pakistanis, have expressed concern over the loophole. A1 Wolfowitz Claim Is Disputed Two former officials at the World Bank disputed the contention of Paul D. Wolfowitz that they knew about his actions on behalf of his companion who was employed there when he joined the bank, according to recently released testimony. A13 NATIONAL A16-19 Immigrants' Rights Rallies Smaller Than Last Year Tens of thousands of people pressing for immigrants' rights demonstrated in dozens of cities across the United States, but with advocates splintered over tactics, the crowds paled in comparison with last year's turnouts. A18 Giuliani Finds Support in Texas For a native New Yorker mounting a first bid for national office, Rudolph W. Giuliani has shown an impressive ability to raise money in Texas, where his Republican presidential campaign collected $2.2 million, far more than any other candidate, during the first quarter of the year. A1 Momentum on a Gun Measure Momentum is building in Congress behind a measure that would push states to report their mental health records to the federal database used to conduct background checks on gun buyers. But a thicket of obstacles have thwarted repeated attempts to improve the reporting of such records. A16 Debate Over Spy Program Senior Bush administration officials told Congress that they could not pledge that the administration would continue to seek warrants from a secret court for a domestic wiretapping program, as it agreed to do in January. A18 Chemical Harmless to Humans Small amounts of melamine anywhere in the American food supply are unlikely to pose much of a threat to humans, toxicologists said. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Lax Safety Enforcement In Transit Accidents Transit officials cited lax enforcement of safety rules, as well as failing to set up proper warning signals, as possible factors in two recent accidents that killed track workers. B1 A Scarred Boy's Challenges An 8-year-old Ugandan boy, scarred in a rebel conflict and brought to the United States by an American woman, ended up in a psychiatric ward at a New York City hospital after a breakdown in March at Kennedy Airport. The hospital plans to discharge him soon, and his future is uncertain. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-16 Murdoch Pursues Dow Jones Rupert Murdoch's media conglomerate, the News Corporation, has made an unsolicited $5 billion offer to buy Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. Dow Jones shares rose more than 50 percent on news of the bid, but members of the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, have indicated they will vote against the proposal. A1 Cablevision Weighs Offer Cablevision Systems Corporation is near a deal to sell the company to its founding family, the Dolans, for about $10.5 billion in cash. The Dolan family failed in three earlier attempts to buy out the public shareholders of Cablevision. One week after returning to Monday's schedule with reduced yet still potent ratings, NBC's ''Heroes'' eked out another win as the night's highest-rated show among adults 18 to 49. Despite earning some of its lowest ratings of the season, the science-fiction drama remains especially popular among younger demographics. In total viewers, ''Heroes'' drew 11.9 million at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, far fewer than either ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' from 8 to 9:45 (18.5 million) or CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' at 10 (17.2 million). ABC finished first for the night, followed by CBS. NBC ranked third, dragged down in the 10 p.m. hour by low ratings for ''The Real Wedding Crashers'' (5.9 million). Fox was fourth over all. Its serial drama ''24'' once again finished last at 9, but it attracted a slightly improved 10.8 million viewers largely due to the substitution of a ''House'' repeat at 8 (7.2 million) in place of ''Drive,'' which was pulled from Fox's schedule just weeks after its April 15 premiere. BENJAMIN TOFF

Secretary General Ban Ki-moon chose three international figures to help him chart a way for the United Nations to take the lead in addressing climate change. The special envoys are Gro Harlem Brundtland, a former prime minister of Norway; Ricardo Lagos, a former president of Chile; and Han Seung-soo, a former foreign minister of South Korea and president of the General Assembly in 2001. Michèle Montas, Mr. Ban's spokeswoman, said the three would prepare proposals for the opening of the General Assembly in September when national leaders come to New York and for a United Nations conference in Bali, Indonesia, in December. Last month, the first-ever debate on climate change was held in the Security Council. WARREN HOGE

TO the casual observer, and even to a slightly more diligent one, the two women have more in common than not. They are roughly the same age (let's say over 50), their roots are in Veracruz -- their food shows it -- and they learned to cook at home from their mothers and grandmothers. After leaving home, they were essentially self-taught, came to the restaurant business more or less by accident and became symbols of strong, independent women in an industry long dominated by men. Most important, they run two of the best and most distinctive restaurants in Mexico City. Which is another way of saying they run two of the best and most distinctive Mexican restaurants in the world.

MAGNUS--Margaret, Dr., RN, Ph.D. Born in Athenry, County Galway, Ireland. Professor Emerita at the Hunter-Bellevue School of Nursing where she worked for 25 years. Passed-President of the Faculty Delegate Assembly and Executive Board Member of the Alpha-Phi Chapter of Sigma Theta Tau. She is survived by her beloved husband Joseph, her only daughter Tanya, and her dog Misty. Viewing at Village Chapels, Inc. 67-67 Eliot Ave., Middle Village, Wednesday, 8:45am. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday 9:45am at Our Lady Of Hope RC Church. Interment at Mt. Olivet Cemetery.

Little, Brown & Company has moved up to June 19 the publication date for ''Her Way: The Hopes and Ambitions of Hillary Rodham Clinton,'' by Jeff Gerth and Don Van Natta Jr., both reporters for The New York Times. The new date coincides with the publication of a rival biography of Senator Clinton by Carl Bernstein, the journalist who, with Bob Woodward, uncovered the Watergate scandal for The Washington Post more than three decades ago. Last month Alfred A. Knopf announced that it would publish Mr. Bernstein's ''A Woman in Charge: The Life of Hillary Rodham Clinton'' on June 19. Little, Brown originally planned to publish ''Her Way'' on Aug. 28. MOTOKO RICH

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about the success of the trainer Todd Pletcher in horse racing and his efforts to win the Kentucky Derby misstated the length of the Derby and the distance run by 14 Derby winners in preparation for the race. The Derby is a mile and a quarter -- not a mile and an eighth, which is the distance those winners had run.

ALL cooks have their share of culinary mishaps and I'm no exception. I've made muffins with salt instead of sugar, baked cookies at 450 instead of 350, put on a pot of oatmeal and fallen asleep until the smoke alarm screamed and, one sadly memorable time, braised a brisket in expensive red wine vinegar instead of wine. Most of the time, my kitchen calamities end with me dumping the debacle. But not so with my latest victim, a pot of chicken vegetable soup brutalized by an accidental assault of chili paste.

BP Chief Resigns After Losing Battle to Conceal Gay Lover The British magnate John Browne, who as its chief executive transformed BP into one of the most successful global oil companies, resigned abruptly after losing a court battle with a London tabloid over disclosure of his sexual relationship with a younger man. Mr. Browne admitted having made false statements to a court during hearings on the case. Despite speculation, he did not make his first public appearance since undergoing emergency surgery nine months ago. I had the opportunity last year to see it made by the chef Mario Batali. (Mr. Batali is a frequent guest on ''The Best Recipes in the World,'' a television show of which I am the host and The New York Times is a producer.)

A front-page article on Saturday about an announcement by the New York State Police that the bullet that killed a trooper during a shootout with a fugitive in a Catskills farmhouse came from the gun of a fellow trooper -- not from the fugitive -- gave an incorrect surname at one point in some copies for the acting state police superintendent. He is Preston L. Felton, not Mr. Preston.

Wild fennel is commonplace in Sicily, where it is used in a springtime pasta dish with fresh sardines, currants, pine nuts and toasted bread crumbs. Now, with wild fennel from California available for about two weeks, pasta con le sarde, as the dish is called, can be made here.
For Rupert Murdoch, the timing of his offer to buy Dow Jones may be perfect. Talking Business, by Joe Nocera. Page C1.

Cracking down on video piracy, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law yesterday a measure that increases penalties for unauthorized recordings of public performances to six months in prison, with criminal fines of up to $5,000. The penalties were formerly 15 days in jail, with fines of up to $250. Mr. Bloomberg also announced the start of a marketing campaign to discourage New Yorkers from buying pirated DVDs, which the Motion Picture Association of America estimates cost the city $903 million a year in lost earnings, according to a study released yesterday. The campaign, which includes a trailer-style spot showing very blurry footage from ''Happy Feet'' that has been rated F for Fake, is to be shown on broadcast and cable stations starting on Monday. DIANE CARDWELL
JOSEPH--Richard. Metropolitan Montessori School sends deepest condolences to the family of Richard Joseph, husband of Meg and father of Flory. A loving parent, he will be much missed.

To the Editor: Re: ''Foie Gras Makers Struggle to Please Critics and Chefs,'' by Juliet Glass, April 25: We all love a solution that works for everyone. However, there can be no pleasing the critics of foie gras if the chefs and consumers of the diseased livers of geese continue to participate in this barbaric process. The critics are people who recognize that no animal should be made to suffer so that someone can slather a cracker with an animal's innards. (It's safe to assume that the animals themselves belong in the critics' circle.)

SIEGAL--Abraham, on April 30th, 2007, in his 81st year. My darling husband Abe Siegal passed away suddenly yesterday. He is survived by his son Scott Siegal, daughter-inlaw Carolyn and grandchildren Daniel and Blair of Altadena, California, and daughter Lisa of New York City. Papa Abe is also survived by his extended family Adam, Susan, Andrew, Max and Jordan Sahn of New City, NY, Jonathan, Kathy, Samantha, and Erin Sahn of Boca Raton, Florida, and Eric, Amy, Zach and Lucas of Redwood City, CA. Abe will be remembered by his friends and family as a man who lived life to the fullest. Whether it was zip gliding with his grandkids to celebrating his 75th birthday, traveling the world with me, or dancing the night away, he did everything with gusto and a smile on his face. He was a dedicated businessman who started with nothing and built a successful electronics sales company. Abe was a friend to everyone; he would kibbitz with everyone he met from the server in a restaurant, a taxi driver, and the unsuspecting Chinese food delivery man. His family will especially remember the love he showed them and the wonderful example he set by seemingly enjoying every moment of every day. He embraced his extended family as if they were his own and cherished the time he spent with all of us. I will miss him. Funeral services will take place Thursday, May 3rd, at 11:45 at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave. and 16th St. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Abe's memory to: UJA Federation of NY, 130 E 59th St., NY 10022. Love, Dorothy Siegal

CAPLOW--Alvin ''Cappy''. Remembered joys are never past. Love, M

To the Editor: In ''Preserving Fossil Fuels and Nearby Farmland by Eating Locally,'' April 25, Jessica Prentice has it right: ''Eating locally is an interesting exercise.'' But if we are truly interested in a sustainable food system, we must consider the producer's point of view as well as the consumer's. From the producer's perspective, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, olive oil and wine are products that could not survive if they had to depend on local-only consumption. ''Locavores'' should understand that there's a difference between indulging in tasteless midwinter raspberries and supporting the efforts of indigenous farmers whose livings depend on offering their unique products to a global market.

KRAMER--George P., 80, died at home on April 27, 2007. He was born in Holyoke, MA, graduated with the class of 1950 from Harvard College, and received his LLB in 1953 from the Harvard Law School. At Harvard, he was an editor of The Crimson and a member of the Signet Society. He served as a lieutenant in the USN. As a young lawyer at Watson and Leavenworth, he developed an interest in trademark law and was recognized as an authority in the field; he was senior counsel at Hunton and Williams when he died. He served as Secretary of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and, later, on its Executive Committee. In 1971, he accompanied the U.S. Antarctic Policy Group South Pole Expedition and planted an anniversary-year flag of the Bar Association at the Pole. After college, George established the Caleb Cheeshahteamuck 1665 Fund at Harvard in memory of its first Native American student. He was the longest serving Secretary of the Harvard Club of New York and a trustee of Hancock Shaker Village. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth, his daughter, Alice Truax, his sons, Hawley and Charles Truax, his daughters-in-law, Jane Thrailkill and Julie Truax, and his grandchildren, Olivia, Naomi, and George. A memorial service will take place on May 4 at 5pm at the Union Church in Tyringham, MA. On Sunday, May 6, friends may call at the family apartment in NYC between 5 and 8pm. Contributions in George's memory may be made to Hancock Shaker Village, PO Box 297, Pittsfield, MA, 01202 or to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, NY, NY 10003.
To the Editor: Re ''Justices Raise Doubts on Campaign Finance Law'' (front page, April 26):

To the Editor: Re: ''Feed Me: A Soft Spot for the Anti-Artisanal,'' April 25: I hate running into friends in the supermarket lest I suffer the raised eyebrow of shame when they spy my Kraft mac 'n' cheese (only the orange version) or Cheez Doodles (only the orange version) hidden under the diversionary VitaMuffins and organic arugula.

KitchenAid's heavy-duty stand mixer, a mainstay in home kitchens for decades, has serious competition. Cuisinart has introduced a stand mixer that offers all of the features of the KitchenAid and then some. Cuisinart's mixer, which takes up about the same amount of counter space, is a more powerful machine (a 1,000-watt motor) and has a seven-quart bowl. (There is also an 800-watt model with a 5.5-quart bowl, close to KitchenAid's.)

The New York Times is introducing an online section on small business this week that will feature several exclusive columns, along with news and resources for entrepreneurs, managers and people interested in starting a business and changing careers. The regular columns, to appear at various intervals and updated frequently with additional material, include Shifting Careers by Marci Alboher; Entrepreneurial Edge by James Flanigan; Tool Kit by Paul Brown; and In the Hunt by Brent Bowers. Look for it at nytimes.com/smallbusiness.

Stuck in a marriage to a man she loathes, inconveniently pregnant with his child, oppressed by long hours waiting tables for a grouchy boss, Jenna finds relief baking pies. As lovingly filmed as they are made, these creations serve as both therapy and art. Jenna gives them whimsical names -- ''I don't want Earl's baby pie,'' for instance -- and combines unlikely ingredients to unfailingly delicious effect. Adrienne Shelly, who wrote and directed ''Waitress'' (and who plays one of Jenna's co-workers), demonstrates a similar confectionary gift. The movie, her third and last feature before she was murdered in November, blends familiar elements into something both satisfying and surprising. Part feminist fable, part romantic fairy tale, it is by turns tart and sweet, charming and tough, rather like its heroine and like Keri Russell, the plucky, pretty, nimble actress (still perhaps best known as Felicity, from the television coming-of-age melodrama of the same name) who plays her.

ROBBINS--Harvey A., April 29th, 1922, to May 1st, 2007. Survived by loving wife Carolyn, devoted father of Peggy Jacobson and James A. Robbins, and proud grandfather of Peter Jacobson and Brian Jacobson. Funeral private.
To the Editor: Re ''After Virginia Tech, Testing Limits of Movie Violence'' (Business Day, April 30):
A listing yesterday of American service members killed in Iraq misidentified the branch of service of Sgt. Michael R. Hullender. It is the Army, not the Marines.

WEISS--Paula, mother of Peter, mother-in-law of Cora, grandmother of Judy, Tamara and Danny, great-grandmother of Jules, Noah, Maria, Catherine and Simon, died April 29, age 104. She lived a courageous life, as a mater familias, a business woman, early feminist, opera fan and inspiration to her family, friends and admirers. Service at Riverside Chapel 75th St and Amsterdam, Friday May 4th at 4pm. Contributions to Center for Constitutional Rights, 666 Broadway, NYC 10012.

It's the Friday night fights, of the video game kind, at NYClan, a place on West Fourth Street in Greenwich Village that is dedicated to devotees of such pursuits. Players in the Fight Club get together and compete far into the night at games like Virtua Fighter 5.
To the Editor: In ''Planet of the Apes'' (column, April 28), Robert Wright asks, ''What does it mean that we haven't heard a thing from any corner of this vast universe?''

An article on Sunday about the frequency of Jon S. Corzine's out-of-state travel during his tenure as governor of New Jersey rendered incorrectly in some copies comments on the matter from Zulima V. Farber, then the New Jersey attorney general, in an April 2006 memo. She wrote, ''We do not believe that, in the circumstances you describe, an occasional, overnight stay in New York City following a workday in New Jersey and a return to this state in the morning constitutes an absence of the governor that would trigger the devolution of gubernatorial power.'' The erroneous version said ''circumstance'' instead of ''circumstances'' and omitted the words ''and a return.''

IF Ingo Maass has anything to say about it, ''new Arabian'' will become a cuisine worth noticing. Mr. Maass, a cheery 36-year-old German chef, works in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, and with several other chefs he is now on the fast track to modernize the centuries-old, traditionbound food of the Arabian peninsula. He was in the United States a couple of months ago for meetings and to promote the new book that sets out his ideas for Arabian food, ''Dubai: New Arabian Cuisine'' (Umschau, 2006), written with Lutz Jäkel, a photojournalist who inspired the project, and three other chefs.

Senate Republicans said yesterday that they would seek to increase by $200 million the school property tax rebate checks that taxpayers 65 and older are eligible to receive, but Gov. Eliot Spitzer's administration indicated that it would not support the proposal. Under a budget deal announced in late March, state officials added $1.3 billion to the state's School Tax Relief Program, making it a nearly $5 billion-a-year program. But the several hundred thousand elderly homeowners who are eligible for higher benefits saw almost no increase when tax exemptions and rebate checks available under the program were taken into consideration. ''It's clear we have the resources available to give seniors greater tax relief,'' Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, said in a statement. But Jeffrey Gordon, a spokesman for the governor's Budget Division, said Mr. Spitzer ''will include more relief in next year's budget'' and ''will not bust the budget by adding more spending on property tax relief this year.'' DANNY HAKIM

COHEN--Linda Kay, died April 29, 2007. Beloved and adored wife of Stephen R., loving mother of Ricky and Todd, daughter of Henrietta and the late Jerome Eisenberg; stepmother to Lisa (Eric) and Jason; ''Granny Linda'' to Jamie and Jack. She will forever be in our hearts and greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. Donations can be made to the Linda and Stephen R. Cohen Endowed Chair in Vascular Surgery at Danbury Hospital, Danbury, CT. Con tact(203)797-7780.

KOBOCOW--Bella (nee Shapiro), age 86 of Maitland, FL. Graduate of NYU and Columbia University. Loving wife of Sol, beloved mother of Sara (Mark) Abbey, devoted sisters Ruth (Al) Lisman and Florence Rosenberg. Graveside services Thursday, 11am, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ.

To the Editor: ''Why Congress Should Embrace the Surge,'' by Owen West (Op-Ed, May 1), suggests that Congress and the American public should trust those who started and executed this war with 10 more years to ''win.'' This misses the forest (a wrong war) for some trees (how to win).

A music review on Monday about the premiere of David Carlson's opera, ''Anna Karenina,'' by the Florida Grand Opera in Miami, misidentified a work in which Tchaikovsky used the Czar's Hymn, a variant of which Mr. Carlson uses as a fate motif. In addition to the ''1812'' Overture it was the ''Marche Slav,'' not the Fourth Symphony. (Tchaikovsky used a fate motif in that work.)

FELKAY--Michael M., May 11th, 1914 to April 26th, 2007. Beloved husband, father, and grandfather, passed away at home surrounded by his family on Thursday, April 26th, 2007. Private services were held by the family according to his wishes. He will be remembered with love and gratitude by many whose lives he touched.
ORY--Edward B., died on April 29 after a brief illness. He is survived by his wife Iris Bianchi, three children and four grandchildren. Private service was held.
When their unborn child was diagnosed with Down syndrome, one couple found it difficult to envision their future family. Then they met Troy.
Some parents of children with Down syndrome want prospective parents to know the positive side of raising a child with the genetic condtion.

The After-Party: Now that we've had a chance to look over the transcript, we've caught a couple of moments that are worth going back to. One is that exchange with Mr. Giuliani about Christians. Mr. Matthews asked if the increased influence of Christian conservatives in the Republican party had been good for the party. Mr. Giuliani: "Sure, the increased influence of large numbers of people are always good for us." Then he used his time to go back to an earlier question and said this: "Neither party has a monopoly on virtue or vice." His context seemed to be that if the Republicans were going to win, they had to reach out to Democrats, but that was an unusual way to say it.

The very same morning that I began to read the new essay collection: "One of the Guys: Women as Aggressors and Torturers," which examines the role of women in the Abu Ghraib prison scandal and in other instances of American military abuse, I came upon a man out for a walk with his baby daughter. He was wearing shorts; she was in a sunsuit. He wore a hat; she wore a bonnet. He carried her in a BabyBjörn-like-thing on his chest, and as he reached down for a moment to hike up her bottom (reassuring himself, I imagine, that she was still hanging in there), he looked so blissfully happy, so beatific, in fact, that I had to give him a smile.
Andrew C. Revkin, an environment reporter at The Times, has spent the week covering talks in Bangkok on the latest report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a U.N.-sanctioned body.

The first important decision any president makes comes well before taking office: his choice of a running mate at the time of his own presidential nomination, or even before. Presidential nominations now are all but assured well in advance of the party conventions.
"Hey, Dick, I'll never forget the look on your face when that guy died on your show."

The decision to assign agents to protect Senator Barack Obama, a full nine months before the Democratic primary, is the earliest the Secret Service has ever issued security detail to a presidential candidate. Russ Knocke, a spokesman for the Department of Homeland Security, said today he could not comment on whether the decision was made in response to a specific threat against Mr. Obama or his family, but that several criteria were taken into account before the authorization was made.
"Gilmore Girls": goodbye, sweet princess.

Jerry Hairston just took Luis Vizcaino into the left-field seats to tie the game here, 3-3. That's the third time this season the bullpen has blown a potential victory for Andy Pettitte. It'll be hard for him to reach 200 wins at this rate; he has 187 now.
A.O. Scott reviews "Away from Her," about an aging couple dealing with the ravages of Alzheimer's.

No surprises here: The Mets optioned Chan Ho Park to Class AAA New Orleans today. In his place, however, they summoned the reliever Lino Urdaneta and not, as expected, Jorge Sosa. Willie Randolph will say in a few hours who will replace Park in the rotation, but it is likely that Urdaneta will take over Aaron Sele's spot, and Sele will pitch Saturday. The Mets may have just added Urdaneta to be available today and tomorrow and then send him back to New Orleans and recall Saturday's starter.

New Century Financial, the biggest subprime mortgage company to declare bankruptcy, will close its home-lending unit and fire about 2,000 employees after failing to find a buyer. Chief Executive Brad Morrice informed employees of the failed search in a conference call Thursday, said Dan Gagnier, a spokesman for the Irvine, Calif.-based company.

The vast majority of New York City residents who drive in Manhattan on weekdays do not do so because they lack mass-transit options, according to a survey just released by the Partnership for New York City, an influential business group that has prodded Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to support a charge on driving into the city.

Assemblyman Peter M. Rivera, a Bronx Democrat, said today he plans to introduce a bill that would make "An Inconvenient Truth," the global warming documentary produced by Al Gore, mandatory viewing for all school age children.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, on the Senate floor just a few minutes ago, proposed Oct. 11, 2007 as the "expiration date" for the Iraq war.
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's May 3 column, "An Invisible War."
Readers respond to David Brooks's May 3 column, "Wolfowitz's Big Mistake."

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the buildings commissioner, Patricia J. Lancaster, today presented a comprehensive overhaul of the city's building code to the City Council -- the first since 1968. The mayor said the rewriting of standards and rules would improve safety, efficiency and environmental sustainability.
But this time, it is the unusual distinction of winning the title of the Best Place to Work in Europe 2007.

In Chicago, there is no question who carries the title of the Big O. That would be Oprah Winfrey. It's a safe bet that Senator Barack Obama doesn't mind playing second fiddle to the talk show icon, particularly when he has her endorsement at his disposal.

Private equity firms have historically looked askance at technology companies, whose volatile earnings don't always mix nicely with heavy debt loads. Which is why the recent findings by Jason Bazinet, a media analyst at Citigroup, are fairly remarkable. Using what he called "fairly conservative assumptions," Mr. Bazinet screened 100 global media stocks and decided that most of them are not likely to be targets of a leveraged buyout offer anytime soon. Of those that made the cut, however, most were Internet companies.

Credit Suisse is moving Paul Raphael from London to Hong Kong to run its investment banking group in Asia, excluding Japan, the firm said in an internal memo. In London, Mr. Raphael was co-head of the European global markets solutions group. Mr. Raphael is taking a role previously held by Joe Gallagher, who becomes Credit Suisse's head of mergers and acquisitions for the Asia-Pacific region, a new position at the firm. Jim Amine, who had been co-head of European global markets solutions with Mr. Raphael, takes over as the group's sole head.
As business school students prepare for graduation, they will face an inevitable barrage of questions from friends and relatives -- most prominent among them: So, where are you going to work?

Let's face it: It's hard out there for an analyst who wants to stand out from the crowd, especially if you stick to the standard buy-hold-sell script. Last year, a Credit Suisse semiconductor analyst, Mike Masdea, shook things up with a mass voicemail to clients in which he imitated rapper Eminem as he gave his take on the chip business. The voicemail made the rounds on Wall Street and was preserved for posterity on Dealbreaker. ("Masdea may want to check himself before he wrecks himself," one trader quipped to the New York Post.)

Compass Diversified Trust, a publicly held private equity firm, said on Thursday that it would hold a $128 million follow-on public offering to repay its corporate debt. In a press release, the firm, which currently holds six middle-market companies in a range of sectors, will sell eight million shares at $16 a share.
Earlier today, the Iraqi interior ministry announced another insurgent leader's death. This time, it was Abu Omar al-Baghdadi, said to be the leader of an umbrella group, The Islamic State of Iraq.

I don't know how the other Times columnists keep up with all their reader e-mail, but I'll tell you how I handle mine: with great difficulty. I try to answer pretty much all of it, thanks to some kind of weird Midwestern sense of obligation.

If New York City ordered that the nearly 13,000 Ford Crown Victorias be replaced with Kia Rondos -- the compact, minivan-like vehicles shown at the Taxi07 exhibition last month -- it could potentially save 22.3 million gallons and $66.2 million worth of fuel each year and reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, a leading greenhouse gas, by 88,400 tons per year, according to a new analysis by Consumer Reports.

This happens to be a painful post for me to write because it concerns Montrachet, a formative restaurant for both American wine lovers and for me personally. Montrachet closed last summer with not nearly the ceremony it deserved. In fact, as late as January 2007 Drew Nieporent, one of the owners, still had not acknowledged that the restaurant's run was over. But if you were still holding out hope, forget it. Next Friday, May 11, Zachys will auction off what it bills as "a significant offering from the cellars of Montrachet.''

Hoping to fend off the News Corporation's $5 billion bid, employees at Dow Jones & Company are pushing back. Jesse Drucker, a Wall Street Journal reporter and representative of the paper's union, has written an e-mail to his colleagues, asking them to write short letters to three members of the Bancroft family, which controls more than 60 percent of Dow Jones.
Following is the draft script of the weekly "Only in New York" audio podcast. Listen at left or download it to a portable player.
New shows in New York include "Coram Boy" and "American Fiesta."
Walter Schirra was the only man to fly on all three of NASA's early space missions.
Largest and southernmost in the Hawaiian chain, the Big Island of Hawaii is synonymous with stunning landscapes and luxurious retreats.
Hold that deal.
The Los Angeles Police Department is facing public outrage over its officers' use of batons and nonlethal rubber bullets to disperse an immigrant-rights rally on Tuesday.

Shareholders of Dow Jones & Company, whose stock price until recently has languished in the mid-30's, are not the only ones that could see a windfall if the company ends up being acquired by News Corporation at $60 per share. The deal is far from certain: A majority of the Bancroft family, which has a controlling interest in the company, currently stands opposed to Rupert Murdoch's proposal. Still, The New York Times's Eric Dash looked through regulatory filings and found that a sale, if it happened, might mean multimillion-dollar paydays for the top managers of Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.
One of the most distinctive residences in the Cayman Islands has come on the market for $3.95 million.
David Pogue’s list of the best electronic equipment... for now.

LOS ANGELES -- The Republican presidential candidates are gathering this evening at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library - at the invitation of Nancy Reagan - for their first debate. It begins at 8 p.m. Eastern time, lasts for 90 minutes, and will be broadcast on MSNBC, which is sponsoring it with Politico.com. The moderator is Chris Matthews.

A year ago, some fateful missteps by Barbaro in the Preakness resulted in a fractured right hind leg that eventually led to his being put down in January. But the sad ending appears not to have swayed the thinking of horse racing fans about the inherent safety of the sport. A recent New York Times/CBS News poll of people who said they followed racing showed that 63 percent think the sport is safe for the horses, and only 21 percent said it was too risky. Ten percent said it depends on certain factors like track conditions, and 5 percent said they don't know.

The decision by Barack Obama's campaign to seize control of a MySpace page created by a (former) Obama supporter has angered many of the activists in the Democratic netroots. "[T]he Obama campaign's reputation as the most net-savvy of 2008 has taken a big hit," writes Micah L. Sifry of techPresident. "And MySpace executives have been forced to take extraordinary action to resolve a dispute between two high-profile users of their invaluable site, one a passionate volunteer with a huge network of friends and the other a front-running presidential candidate who has helped make MySpace a new factor in the 2008 contest."

When I started on the Mets beat in August 2005, my first road trip was an Arizona-San Francisco swing - just like this one. The Mets swept the D-Backs in four games, prompting a few to wonder whether I was a good-luck charm. Then they lost two of three in San Francisco, and that took care of that.

As the G.O.P. contenders gather for their first debate in at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library tonight in Simi Valley, Calif., each will clamor to mount praise on the Gipper. But another Republican president is causing more of a strategic conundrum. The Times's Adam Nagourney reports:

I am currently traveling throughout SE Asia and would like to add Vietnam to my itinerary. However, Vietnam requires that American tourists obtain a visa through a local consulate prior to arrival. I'm not able to travel to a city that has a consulate and wait two days for my application to be processed. Do you know of any reputable companies that can help expedite the visa for me?

George W. Bush's disastrous presidency is linked to the fact that the United States is a country that is "anxiously hypermasculine," writes Mark Dery on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. "George W. Bush learned an unforgettable lesson about the anxious nature of American masculinity when Newsweek branded his father a 'wimp,' a perception Bush 41 never really overcame," Dery writes. "The resolve never to look like a wimp is the key to Dubya's psychology." Dery adds:

In what Reuters describes as its "sternest warning to date" on the state of the hedge-fund business, the New York Federal Reserve said Wednesday that the funds could represent the biggest risk for a financial crisis since 1998, when the implosion of Long-Term Capital Management threatened global markets.

In a shocking move, UBS said it would scrap its hedge fund, Dillon Read Capital Management, after losses at the unit contributed to a third straight decline in quarterly profit. "We concluded that the DRCM initiative did not meet our expectations,'' UBS's chief executive, Peter Wuffli, said in a statement.

Cablevision Systems' board said Wednesday it had accepted a $10.6 billion buyout offer from its founding family, the Dolans, but the deal is far from assured. The buyout is subject to approval of more than half of Cablevision's shareholders, excluding the Dolans and the company's directors and officers, and analysts and investors are still concerned that the price is too low.

The University of Texas Investment Management Company, the investing arm of the University of Texas's pension system, has hired Bruce Zimmerman, former chief investment officer and global head of pension investments at Citigroup, as its new chief executive.
And now for the charm offensive.

The Jones Apparel Group, the owner of Barneys New York and Nine West, said Wednesday that it would close or sell some of its moderately priced apparel brands by year-end, a move that would help reduce its exposure to department stores.

The Russian metals giant Norilsk Nickel said on Thursday it was making an all-cash bid worth 5.3 billion Canadian dollars ($4.8 billion) for LionOre of Canada, trumping an offer from London-listed Xstrata.
Citigroup borrowed 1.45 trillion yen ($12 billion) in a syndicated loan to pay for its purchase of Nikko Cordial, according to Bloomberg News.
Ron Burkle, the Los Angeles billionaire who lost his bid to buy Tribune, is now sizing up the tabloid publisher American Media, according to The New York Post.

A.G. Edwards will pay nearly $4 million for a role in the mutual fund market-timing trading scandal. The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday accused the firm of failing to supervise several brokers who allegedly engaged in illegal market-timing activities.

Cumberland Pharmaceuticals intends to raise $115 million in an initial public offering, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The firm, which plans to list on the Nasdaq Stock Market, did not say how many shares it planned to sell, or at what price.

Clear Channel Communications said on Wednesday it had agreed to sell 362 radio stations for $820 million as it divests assets in accordance with its embattled $27 billion plan to go private. Clear Channel, the nation's largest radio station operator, did not name any of the buyers.

Morgan Stanley has hired a former banker at Credit Suisse, Carlos Oyarbide, as chief operating officer in China. Mr. Oyarbide, 48, will be a managing director, reporting to Wei Christianson, chief executive of Morgan Stanley's operations in China. He will start in July, Morgan Stanley said.

The Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group may join forces to bid as much as 2.7 billion Australian dollars ($2.2 billion) for Ten Network Holdings, Australia's third most-watched television station, Bloomberg News reported.
As the Nasdaq Stock Market and the New York Stock Exchange battle each other at home and abroad for new listings, China has become a key battleground, BusinessWeek notes.

As expected, Malaysian billionaire T. Ananda Krishnan has offered to buy full control of Maxis Communications, the country's biggest mobile-phone company, for 15.8 billion ringgit ($4.6 billion) to facilitate its overseas expansion.

D.E. Shaw, the $29 billion hedge fund, announced Wednesday that it had hired Michael Joseph, a former banker at Lloyds TSB, to head its fledgling European private equity unit, D. E. Shaw Direct Capital. Mr. Joseph, a former managing director of structured finance at Lloyds TSB, also served as an investment director at the British buyout shop 3i Group.

An Internet retailer, Delivery Agent, raised $18.5 million in an insider round led by Bessemer Venture Partners to take advantage of partnerships with television networks and other content distributors that steer audiences to its online store to purchase goods featured on the air.

Friendly Ice Cream, the struggling restaurant chain, postponed next week's annual shareholder meeting, delaying a showdown with activist investors who are trying to gain more control of the company. Friendly said its executives needed more time for a review of the company's strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the business, that was disclosed in March.

A buyout shop, Littlejohn & Company of Greenwich, Conn., has struck a deal to take the Intertape Polymer Group,a maker of plastic tape, private for $500 million, including $305 million of debt. Littlejohn has agreed to buy all the company's common stock at $4.76 a share, valuing the company's equity at $195 million.
Shares in a networking semiconductor start-up, Cavium Networks rose more than 27 percent in their first day on the Nasdaq stock market Wednesday.

As cash-rich private equity firms continue to buy many of the largest public companies, there is a new focus on one question: Do these big buyouts create jobs or destroy them? The claim that private equity shops are enriching themselves on the backs of employees at their portfolio companies has been circulating in European for some time. Last week, a report by The Service Employees International Union, which represents nearly 2 million United States workers including health care employees and janitors, raised similar concerns.

The auto parts maker Magna International, which is considering a bid for Chrysler, is in talks with Canadian and American auto unions about adding Magna's tens of thousands of workers to their ranks, according to the president of the Canadian union.

The biggest takeover battle in the banking industry, the fight for control of ABN Amro Holding, the Dutch bank, brings head to head two very different personalities atop Europe's banking world. The New York Times takes a look at how the distinct styles of the two chieftains affect their deal making and the institutions they run.

Fujitsu plans to buy GFI Informatique of France for 419 million euros ($569 million) to add computer-services clients and reduce its reliance on Japan. Fujitsu, based in Tokyo, intends to offer 8.50 euros for each GFI share and 3.15 euros for each warrant of the company, a computer consultant based in Paris.

Lawrence Best, chief financial officer of Boston Scientific and the architect of the company's $27 billion Guidant acquisition, will leave his job in July, Boston Scientific said Wednesday. He will be succeeded by Sam Leno, chief financial officer of Zimmer Holdings, a maker of artificial knees, hips, and other orthopedic implants.

After several Web sites posted a secret code used to prevent piracy of high-definition movies, corporate lawyers demanded that the code be removed. Internet users responded by distributing it even more widely in what was characterized as an exercise of free-speech rights.
New camcorders from Sony and JVC give home movies the same kind of clarity as Hollywood releases.

The world will need to divert from today’s energy sources, the top body studying climate change will conclude.

The death today of Walter Schirra, one of the original “Mercury Seven” astronauts who flew pioneering space missions in the 1960s and 1970s, leaves only two living members of that group, who were as famous as movie stars in the exciting early days of space travel: John Glenn and Scott Carpenter.
Scientists hope a test for the variant will enable physicians to assess patients at risk more accurately.
The bill, extending “hate crime” protections to include sexuality, is likely to face a veto from President Bush.
Politicians from across the political spectrum in Israel called in parliament for the prime minister to resign.
Today’s vote was depicted by political analysts as a final verdict on the prime minister’s 10 years in office.
Officers stopped Busta Rhymes’s car in Manhattan and smelled alcohol on his breath, the police said.
The senior minister of information for Al Qaeda in Iraq was killed in a firefight during a raid north of Baghdad.
The meeting at a conference in Egypt today was the first diplomatic contact at such a high level between the two countries in years.
Carl Pavano said he planned to call James Andrews on Thursday to schedule a visit for a recurrence of the tightness in his strained right forearm.

Despite being the size of Jupiter and made mostly of hydrogen, a planet around a star 440 light-years away is denser than Earth, astronomers announced.
A bill giving gay couples in Oregon the benefits of marriage through domestic partnerships won final legislative approval.
A highway ramp shut down by the collapse of an overpass near the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge will not have to be rebuilt from scratch and could reopen within 10 days, the governor said.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates embraced recommendations for improving care of wounded soldiers and said Walter Reed Army Medical Center should be closed, as planned.
The Army is taking stronger steps to warn soldiers that they will be punished if they reveal sensitive military information on Web sites or blogs.
The mayor of Los Angeles  demanded an investigation into a clash between the police and pro-immigration protesters, saying he was “deeply concerned” by televised images of the episode.
Dany Heatley set up Daniel Alfredsson’s goal, then scored unassisted, leading the Ottawa Senators to a victory against the Devils for a 3-1 edge in their playoff series.
The result of a video review puts the crowd, television audience and teams in technological purgatory and the Rangers have found themselves in that anxious position in the past two games.

Brookfield Asset Management said it would focus on its real estate holdings, which include the World Financial Center in Manhattan, by spinning off about $1 billion in infrastructure assets to shareholders. The assets, which will be held by a newly created company, Brookfield Infrastructure Partners, include 1.2 million acres of timberlands in Canada and the United States, as well as electrical transmission facilities in Canada, Brazil and Chile. Brookfield Asset, based in Toronto, will hold a 40 percent stake in the new company. Brookfield Asset also said it would split its shares 3-for-2.

The Hyundai Motor Company said profit fell for a fifth straight quarter as sales fell on labor strikes, a stronger South Korean won and intense competition in China. Hyundai said first-quarter profit fell 10.2 percent, to 307.4 billion won ($329.22 million), from 342.39 billion won a year earlier. Sales fell 2.6 percent, to 6.684 trillion won ($7.16 billion). The company said sales improved in April, and its shares rose 4 percent.

Credit Suisse said first-quarter profit rose 5 percent, helped by favorable markets for trading stocks and bonds and more commissions from wealthy clients. Profit was 2.7 billion Swiss francs ($2.23 billion), compared with 2.6 billion francs a year earlier. Overall revenue rose 6 percent, to 11.62 billion francs ($9.61 billion). The private banking arm benefited from healthy markets, with commissions and fees up 18 percent. Oswald J. Grübel, 63, is stepping down as chief executive tomorrow, and will be succeeded by Brady W. Dougan. Mr. Dougan, 47, is chief of Credit Suisse’s investment bank.

BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, said first-quarter profit rose 4.6 percent, to 499 million Canadian dollars ($450 million) because of lower restructuring costs and an extraordinary gain. Poor performance in the wireless unit meant that Bell Canada revenue rose just 0.4 percent over the same quarter a year earlier, reaching 3.58 billion Canadian dollars ($3.22 billion). Bell Mobility signed up just 13,000 cellphone subscribers during the period compared with 76,000 a year earlier. Recent price increases by Bell Mobility have not been matched by competitors. BCE said last month that it was in talks with Canadian pension funds and private equity investors that might lead to its going private.

Fujitsu plans to buy GFI Informatique of France for 419 million euros ($569 million) to add computer-services clients and reduce its reliance on Japan. Fujitsu, based in Tokyo, intends to offer 8.50 euros for each GFI share and 3.15 euros for each warrant of the company, a computer consultant based in Paris. The companies have no formal agreement, Fujitsu said.

A Sports of The Times column in some copies on Sunday, about the continuing problems with steroids in Major League Baseball, referred incorrectly to the origin of a rule covering “conduct detrimental” to the sport. The top professional leagues included a conduct clause in their governing agreement in 1896, and baseball historians say the notion probably emerged before that. The concept was not created by Kenesaw Mountain Landis, who was elected baseball’s first commissioner in 1920, and who is credited with rigorous enforcement of the conduct clause.

A picture in some copies with an article on Monday about the funeral and burial of the Russian cellist Mstislav Rostropovich was published in error. It showed a farewell ceremony for the actor Kirill Lavrov, not the burial of Mr. Rostropovich.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the inspection of imported foods by the Food and Drug Administration referred imprecisely to the Senate panel on agriculture appropriations that received a letter from Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, warning that the F.D.A.’s resources were overtaxed. It is a subcommittee, not a standing committee.
An obituary yesterday about Donald P. Lay, a federal appeals court judge, gave the incorrect date in some copies for his death. It was Sunday, not Tuesday.
A chart with the Off the Charts column in Business Day on Saturday misstated the performance of Merck stock from March 24, 2000, to April 27, 2007. It fell 11.3 percent; it did not rise 37.5 percent.

A books column in Weekend on Friday, about several books on Shakespeare released to coincide with his birthday last month, referred incorrectly to the porter’s actions in “Macbeth.” He opens the gate; he does not knock on it.
Corrections

An article last Thursday about the burial of Boris N. Yeltsin, Russia’s first democratically elected president, at Novodevichy Cemetery, erroneously included a writer among other Russian notables interred there. Boris L. Pasternak is buried in a writers’ village in Peredelkino.

An article on Monday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to hire 32 more New York City fire marshals misstated the number of fires in 2006 and included an erroneous comparison to statistics from earlier years. There were 27,817 fires in 2006, according to the Fire Department — not 6,023, which was the number of fires investigated that year. In the early 1980s, fire marshals investigated about 13,000 fires a year; that is not the number they fought.

A front-page article yesterday about the News Corporation’s bid for Dow Jones & Company referred imprecisely to the number of paid subscribers to WSJ.com, the online version of The Wall Street Journal. It has 931,000, rather a lot “more than 700,000.”.
David Bistricer is now bargaining with the owner of Starrett City over lower sale price and devising a plan that he hopes will pass muster with government officials.

To the people who met him in the days before and just after he dressed up as a firefighter and, prosecutors say, sexually molested a former co-worker in her Chelsea apartment, Peter Braunstein seemed perfectly normal, as if he had nothing to hide.
The verdict was in favor of Alcatel-Lucent in a digital music patent dispute against Microsoft.
Orders at U.S. factories rose 3.1 percent in March, the biggest gain in a year and above the 2.1 percent analysts were expecting.
Nicolas Sarkozy and Ségolène Royal went after each other in the kind of vivid confrontation that has disappeared from the American political scene.
Such a conclusion by members of the World Bank board would increase pressure on Paul D. Wolfowitz to resign.
The Republican presidential candidates are wrestling over how to deal with the president as they gather for their first debate.
After an alarming run of hamstring injuries, the Yankees fired strength and conditioning coach Marty Miller.
Defense lawyers questioned the memory, business acumen and integrity of the former governor of Illinois, James R. Thompson in the trial of Conrad M. Black.

The grave of Hungary’s last communist ruler, Janos Kadar, was pried open and his remains and his wife’s urn were thought to have been stolen, the police in Budapest said. The marble cover stone of Mr. Kadar’s grave was removed and his coffin was broken. Graffiti that read “a murderer and traitor may not rest in holy ground” was nearby. “The bones appear to be missing, and it also looks like his wife’s urn is gone, too” said a spokesman for the police, Endre Kormos. Mr. Kadar ruled Hungary from 1956, when Soviet troops crushed the anti-Communist uprising, until 1988 when he retired. He died a year later in July 1989, less than a year before the country’s first free post-Communist elections.

The Security Council has ruled that 700 former Bosnian police officers dismissed by United Nations police trainers after the 1992-1995 civil war for misconduct or alleged involvement in war crimes can reapply for law enforcement work, though not necessarily the same jobs they had. Emyr Jones Parry, the British ambassador to the United Nations, president of the council in April, said in a letter to Bosnian authorities that the country’s standards for recruitment and selection were now acceptable and that individuals could regain police jobs as long as they met those standards. In recent years, 260 of the officers have protested their firings, saying they were guilty only of minor misconduct. Mr. Jones Parry said that his letter should not be interpreted as guaranteeing reinstatement.

The Central Standing Committee of the opposition Nationalist Party nominated Ma Ying-jeou, the former mayor of Taipei, to be the party’s candidate in presidential elections to be held early next year. A full party congress on June 24 is expected to confirm the nomination. Mr. Ma, a Harvard-educated lawyer, has long been seen as the most likely Taiwanese official to bring about a partial reconciliation with the mainland. But he stepped down as party chairman in February after he was indicted for using $339,000 from a mayoral expense account for personal needs; prosecutors have begun a crackdown on the widespread practice among Taiwanese officials of treating expense budgets as part of their personal compensation.

An Egyptian court sentenced Howayda Taha, a producer of Al Jazeera, to six months in jail, or a fine of $1,760, for her part in producing a feature on torture by the Egyptian police. Ms. Taha was arrested in January while the Arabic television channel was collecting material for the feature, including recordings of real torture incidents and reconstructed torture scenes using actors. She was charged with damaging the country’s supreme interests and possessing fabricated video material that would damage Egypt’s reputation, with intent to broadcast it. Released earlier on bail, Ms. Taha is in Qatar, where Al Jazeera is based, and did not attend the trial. Al Jazeera’s office in Cairo said she would appeal the verdict and the sentence.
Undefeated but untested, the Kentucky Derby favorite Curlin is trying to outrun history and will have to do so from a difficult post: the No. 2 hole.
In an emotional letter, the new head of the New York City Transit called for a greater emphasis on safety in the wake of two recent track worker deaths.
Many experts agree that climate change has meant a longer growing season and a more robust selection.

Tens of thousands of Palestinian workers staged a one-day strike to protest against the government’s inability to pay full wages since Hamas came to power more than a year ago. “Today’s strike is a warning. If the government does not heed our demands, then I am afraid we are heading towards an open-ended strike,” said the head of the government workers’ union, Bassam Zakarneh. Tensions between Hamas and Fatah remain high, and a ban on direct aid to the government remains in place. Union leaders said that as many as 80,000 Palestinian government workers were taking part in the strike, shutting down government ministries and buildings.

Austrians will be able to vote in all elections from the tender age of 16 under a new law. The new voting age, the lowest in the European Union, is one of several changes promised by the coalition of social democrats and conservatives that took power in January. The minimum age to stand for election has also been lowered to 18, except for presidential candidates, who must be at least 35 years old. The changes are expected to be approved by Parliament before the summer.

South Korea confiscated property of the descendants of nine people who collaborated with Japan when the Korean peninsula was colonized in 1910, a state agency said. The Investigative Commission on Pro-Japanese Collaborators’ Property said the nine were Lee Wan-yong, Song Byung-joon and Kwon Jung-hyun, and six others. As reward for their work, they received Japanese court titles and money from Tokyo. “This is only the beginning,” a spokesman of the commission said, adding that the agency would continue investigating and confiscating assets acquired as a result of collaborating with Japan. Under a special law enacted in 2005, the commission has listed 452 people who collaborated with the 1910-1945 colonization. The land that was seized by the state was estimated to be worth $3.9 million. The government plans to use the proceeds from the confiscated assets to compensate pro-independence activists and their offspring, the commission said. It is the first time since the peninsula was liberated in 1945 that South Korea has taken such action against alleged collaborators.
The deal is still subject to approval of shareholders and many analysts and investors are concerned that the offer may be too low.

In an interview, Dr. Dean W. Richardson reflected on his treatment of Barbaro, the colt’s greatness and spirit, and on the public outpouring for the 2006 Kentucky Derby winner.

The expressed goal of Saturday night’s Floyd Mayweather-Oscar De La Hoya junior middleweight title bout is to shatter the record of 1.99 million pay-per-view buys.

An article in Business Day on Saturday reported that federal prosecutors in Seattle were conducting a criminal inquiry into Quellos Investments, a hedge fund group, over its design and sale of questionable tax shelters. It said that the investigation became public because of a related civil lawsuit.
The Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere has developed a strategy to enlist the support of  affluent women 35 and older.
Tiger Woods, the owner of 12 major championships, gladly shared the stage at the Wachovia Championship with Michael Jordan, the owner of six N.B.A. titles.

The Mavericks are still in a precarious spot, trailing the eighth-seeded Warriors by 3-2, with Game 6 in Oakland on Thursday. But no one has to wonder any more when Dirk Nowitzki will join the fray.
The movie rental company said its first-quarter loss had widened because of a soft market for movie rentals and heavy spending on its online program.
Royal Ahold said it had agreed to sell the U.S. Foodservice distributor to a consortium of private equity firms for $7.1 billion.

New Paltz, N.Y., was thrown off balance when it awoke to find that its celebrity mayor, Jason West, had been soundly defeated by a former political ally.

President Hamid Karzai said that the Afghan people could no longer tolerate such casualties.
A psychiatrist hired by the Roman Catholic diocese on Long Island testified hat two sexual abuse victims exaggerated their emotional suffering.

A state commission plans to recommend that New Jersey’s therapeutic drug courts be expanded to include people with more than two previous offenses.

James E. McGreevey, who resigned as New Jersey governor after saying that he had had an extramarital affair with a man, wants to be ordained as an Episcopalian priest, according to a published report.
The company also expected to report lower earnings for 2006 and named a new chief financial officer.

An investigation into sexual abuse and mismanagement at the Texas Youth Commission has led to the dismissal of 66 employees with records of felony charges or arrests.

American air safety investigators attributed a disastrous collision over the Amazon last year partly to cockpit systems’ failure to alert the crew of a business jet that its anti-collision equipment had failed.
Ousted as prime minister in a coup last September, Thaksin Shinawatra has made a move to console himself with the purchase of an English soccer club.

Scientists have identified a gene that makes roundworms live longer when they eat less, a finding they hope could lead to drugs that promote human longevity.

Offensive coordinator Kevin Gilbride and quarterbacks coach Chris Palmer hope that their decades of experience and familiarity can untie the riddle of Eli Manning’s stalled development.
Tzipi Livni said she would not organize an effort to oust Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, who has been criticized over Israel’s war against Hezbollah.

The Dow jumped past 13,200 for the first time after a strong reading on factory orders helped spur investor optimism.

A letter on Saturday from Newtonville, Mass., about the no-period pill referred incorrectly to the hormone endothelin. It increases blood pressure; it is not an “antihypertensive agent.”.

ALL nail guns can cause serious injury, said Hester Lipscomb, an associate professor in occupational and environmental medicine at Duke University Medical Center who has studied nail-gun safety. But those with sequential-trip triggers carry half the risk of those with contact-trip triggers, according to her research.

A report in the Currents column last Thursday about the Dutch designer Tord Boontje misidentified the work shown in an accompanying photograph. It was the 7-by-11-inch brass-plated steel panel called “Ivy 1,” which sells for $59, not a curtain made of Tyvek called “Until Dawn.”.

Last year, I got one tasty zucchini before all six of my plants wilted and died. A gardening neighbor said the culprit was a worm that eats stems from the inside. She said all I could do was try to skewer the worm with a pin stuck through the stem. Is there anything else?
James Bond is in demand on everyone’s ’007 party circuit and competition is fierce for any item or idea that distinguishes one event from the next.

It’s just about time to head back to the ski areas. Summer is becoming increasingly busy at mountain resorts, which are concocting inventive ways to lure year-round customers and boost the bottom line. At Sugarbush Resort in Vermont, mountain biking returns after a 12-year break; Tahoe’s Northstar Resort, closed to riders last summer, also re-opens its fat-tire trails. For the first time, Jackson Hole in Wyoming will crank up the Bridger Gondola to 9,095 feet for paragliding, rock climbing and backpacking. And Whistler-Blackcomb in British Columbia has the best of both worlds: a new mountain-top yoga session at Whistler and schussing throughout the summer on Blackcomb’s glacier.

The 133rd running of the Kentucky Derby will take place on Saturday, and if it’s the only horse race you bet on all year, as it is for many casual fans, then recent history provides this enticement beyond the simple $2 win bet: the superfecta, in which you select the first four horses in order. It’s difficult, but rewarding: last year, even with Barbaro winning at low odds, it paid $84,860.40. In 2005, when a 50-to-1 horse, Giacomo, won and Closing Argument finished second at 70-to-1, the payoff was a hefty $864,253.50.

Bia Figueiredo continues her climb through the lower levels of car racing in the hope of making it all the way to the elite Formula One division. Since PLAY wrote about Figueiredo last November, she finished second in the season’s final race last December and ended up fifth overall in the South American Formula Three division. “After that we started to negotiate my future in Europe and we are almost closing on it,” she said in a recent e-mail message from her native Brazil. “I am still racing F3, but now I will start to drive the British F3 car in the U.K.” It could lead to an opportunity to race bigger cars, she said, “and I would love to do it.”.

Carlo Rotella writes about the Mayweather-De la Hoya bout and the current state of boxing. Gretchen Reynolds looks at personal heart-rate monitors and whether the average athlete needs all the data they provide.

Every time a great college football player slides toward the bottom of the N.F.L. draft, I get a feeling like mind erasure. The player’s rejection by the pro teams seems to stand as a repudiation of his college achievements. Wait a second, I think, wasn’t this guy a holy terror on Saturdays?.

Best friend of one great-granddaughter and one dear sister. For further information call Andrett Funeral Home, 212475-2024. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

Avril Lavigne has the No. 1 album for the second week in a row, though music sales across the board last week were bleak. Ms. Lavigne's ''Best Damn Thing'' (RCA) sold 122,000 copies, a 58 percent drop, according to Nielsen SoundScan. ''Ain't Nothing Like Me'' (Jive), the sixth album by the R&B singer Joe, opens at No. 2 on the Billboard chart this week with 98,000 sales. Last week's No. 2, Nine Inch Nails' ''Year Zero'' (Interscope), sold 58,000, a 69 percent decrease that put the album at No. 3; in its fifth week out, Vol. 24 of ''Now That's What I Call Music!'' lost 19 percent of its sales from the week before, moving 55,000 to reach No. 4. The Arctic Monkeys' ''Favourite Worst Nightmare'' (Domino), the only other new album in the Top 20, bowed at No. 7 with 44,000. BEN SISARIO

Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates embraced recommendations for improving care of wounded soldiers and said Walter Reed Army Medical Center should be closed, as planned. Mr. Gates appeared at a Pentagon news conference with Togo D. West Jr. and John O. Marsh Jr., two former Army secretaries who were co-chairmen of an independent review group appointed in February after disclosures of poor conditions and bureaucratic delays at Walter Reed, the Army's main hospital for treating soldiers wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan. Some members of Congress have called for reconsidering a Pentagon plan to close the medical center by 2011. But Mr. Gates said it would be ''far better to make an investment in brand-new 21st-century facilities.'' DAVID CLOUD

It may have been Bon Jovi night on ''American Idol'' Tuesday, but temporarily upstaging the rocker were President Bush and his wife, Laura. The first couple made a taped appearance on the show to thank viewers for helping raise $70 million during the ''Idol Gives Back'' charity drive last week. The latest installment of Fox's singing competition dominated the ratings as usual, drawing 25.8 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Fox easily won the night over all, as ''House'' led the 9 p.m. hour by a similarly wide margin, attracting 21.3 million viewers. In a competitive three-way race for second place Tuesday, CBS maintained a slim edge over both ABC and NBC. ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show at 9 (15.8 million) tied NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' at 10 (11.3 million) as the night's third highest rated show among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF
CLOSTER--Reuven. Ten years have transpired since you departed this vale of tears beloved Rueven. Your wisdom and humor made it more bearable for many; your absence leaves an inconsolable void. -Steve

Many product designers, including those doing the most innovative work, are focused on serving the world's wealthiest people. But increasingly, according to an exhibition that opens tomorrow at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, those designers are turning their attention to products to help the poor. The Sierra Portable Light mat, bottom, is made by weavers in Mexico using L.E.D.'s; it extends the workday for people living off the grid in rural areas. The PermaNet has an insecticide bonded to its fibers, making it a long-lasting fighter of malaria, which kills more children worldwide than any other infectious disease, said Cynthia E. Smith, the show's curator. The clay pot-in-pot cooler, below, was designed by a Nigerian engineer. Fill the middle space with sand and water, and as the water evaporates it pulls the heat from the inner pot, cooling the contents. In Nigeria, tomatoes typically stay fresh for two or three days; inside this pot, they might last three weeks. ''These objects are ways for us to tell stories about larger issues,'' Ms. Smith said. ''Design for the Other 90 Percent'' runs through Sept. 23 at the Cooper-Hewitt, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 (cooperhewitt.org). PENELOPE GREEN

SPRING is erratic. It's not uncommon for temperatures to veer from 80s and cloudless to 50s and rainy in a few days. Cyclists who don't want a closet full of gear need clothing versatile enough to handle vast fluctuations in conditions -- especially wind and sudden showers. The trick to dressing right for a spring ride is layering and wearing clothes with strategically placed zippers for ventilation, said Tom LaFera, an owner of Table Rock Tours and Bicycles, in Rosendale, N.Y. ''I like jackets with zippered sleeves for venting,'' he said. ''It really extends the jacket's temperature range, being able to let in a lot of air.''

More than 3,000 perennials divided from plants propagated in the Battery Park gardens will be sold today at the annual Battery Plant Sale. Many are from hybrids cultivated in the Netherlands by Piet Oudolf, the Battery Park landscape designer; all have adapted to the local climate because they were raised in the park. Warrie Price, below, the president of the Battery Conservancy, a nonprofit group that helps run the park, and a team of volunteers will offer advice on choosing plants. The sale will benefit the conservancy's efforts to rebuild and maintain the park. It will be held on the Battery prominade at Gangway 1, in front of the Battery Gardens restaurant, from 11 a.m. until 6 p.m. For information: (212) 344-3491, ext. 10, or thebattery.org. SHEVA FRUITMAN

Brookfield Asset Management said it would focus on its real estate holdings, which include the World Financial Center in Manhattan, by spinning off about $1 billion in infrastructure assets to shareholders. The assets, which will be held by a newly created company, Brookfield Infrastructure Partners, include 1.2 million acres of timberlands in Canada and the United States, as well as electrical transmission facilities in Canada, Brazil and Chile. Brookfield Asset, based in Toronto, will hold a 40 percent stake in the new company. Brookfield Asset also said it would split its shares 3-for-2. IAN AUSTEN

To the Editor: Re ''A Vestige of the Past Shutters Its Stalls'' (news article, April 30):

The Central Standing Committee of the opposition Nationalist Party nominated Ma Ying-jeou, the former mayor of Taipei, to be the party's candidate in presidential elections to be held early next year. A full party congress on June 24 is expected to confirm the nomination. Mr. Ma, a Harvard-educated lawyer, has long been seen as the most likely Taiwanese official to bring about a partial reconciliation with the mainland. But he stepped down as party chairman in February after he was indicted for using $339,000 from a mayoral expense account for personal needs; prosecutors have begun a crackdown on the widespread practice among Taiwanese officials of treating expense budgets as part of their personal compensation. KEITH BRADSHER

Despite being the size of Jupiter and made mostly of hydrogen, a planet around a star 440 light-years away is denser than Earth, astronomers at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass., announced. The astronomers were able to measure the size of the planet, designated HAT-P-2b, because it passes directly in front of the star every 5 days and 15 hours, causing it to dim slightly. HAT-P-2b, in the constellation Hercules, is more than eight times the mass of Jupiter, and the immense gravity crushes the planet down to its relatively small size and Earth-like density. KENNETH CHANG

The ancient Mongolian yurt is going modern. Stephanie Smith, above, a designer based in Los Angeles who runs a company called Ecoshack, has introduced the Nomad yurt, a structure that is light, flexible, movable and small, like a traditional yurt. But, Ms. Smith said, it has been updated ''in terms of aesthetics and materials'' to appeal to North American customers. The Nomad has a podlike shape; a minimalist frame made of bamboo, top and bottom left; a WeatherMax fabric cover, center left; and a modular plywood floor. The structure is 12 feet wide and 7 feet tall, and sells for $8,300.

Butch & Harold, a new line of wall decals created by two sisters, Michele and Ariane Gold, is instant art. The large peel-and-stick images with frame-like borders can be moved without damaging a wall's surface and would work well in a summer rental, where hammering nails into the walls is forbidden. Butch and Harold, the dogs the sisters fantasized about having as children, are each the subject of a single decal (Butch is shown at right). There are also three wallpaper-like patterns and a bright yellow bird in a tree. Five of the decals are 25 inches square and cost $50; one is 24 by 30 inches and costs $55. They are available at butchandharold.com or (212) 960-4396. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

As they gather Thursday night at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library for their first debate, the Republican presidential candidates are thrilled at the chance to associate themselves with Reagan. But they may not be able to escape the challenge created for them by the current president. As much as Iraq or health care or any other issue, the question of how to deal with President Bush is vexing the Republican field. Do they embrace him as a means of appealing to the conservative voters who tend to decide Republican primaries? Or do they break from him in an effort to show that they will lead the nation in a new direction? Do they applaud his policies or question his competence -- or both?

An article on Monday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to hire 32 more New York City fire marshals misstated the number of fires in 2006 and included an erroneous comparison to statistics from earlier years. There were 27,817 fires in 2006, according to the Fire Department -- not 6,023, which was the number of fires investigated that year. In the early 1980s, fire marshals investigated about 13,000 fires a year; that is not the number they fought.
An obituary yesterday about Donald P. Lay, a federal appeals court judge, gave the incorrect date in some copies for his death. It was Sunday, not Tuesday.
An article last week about technology's intrusion on celebrities' privacy misspelled the first name of a divorce lawyer who has represented prominent clients. He is Raoul Felder, not Raul.
A letter on Saturday from Newtonville, Mass., about the no-period pill referred incorrectly to the hormone endothelin. It increases blood pressure; it is not an ''antihypertensive agent.''

Which Rudolph W. Giuliani will show up tonight in California for the debate among 10 Republican presidential candidates? The hard-hitting prosecutor? Or Mr. Nice Guy? Mr. Giuliani has played both in his short debate history. Now, with polls showing him as the front-runner of the Republican field, his performance may well be the most-watched tonight. But it has been a decade since Mr. Giuliani last debated as a political candidate, and his two closest challengers, Senator John McCain of Arizona and former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, have more recent experience.
