To the Editor: Re ''Bush Vetoes Bill Tying Iraq Funds to Exit Schedule'' (front page, May 2):

The heirs of a Dutch art dealer whose collection was seized by the Nazis during World War II and a California art foundation that bought an artwork confiscated by the Soviet officials in the late 1920s have filed lawsuits against each other in federal court in Los Angeles over the ownership of a 16th-century diptych now hanging in the Norton Simon Museum of Art in Pasadena. The work, ''Adam and Eve,'' right, is a pair of life-size oil paintings on wood panels created around 1530 by Lucas Cranach the Elder. The paintings were appraised last year for insurance purposes at $24 million. The Norton Simon Foundation, which has lent the works to the similarly named museum, bought them at auction in 1970 and 1971 from an heir to the Stroganoff dynasty of Russia. Around 1930 they were sold at auction by Soviet officials to the Dutch art dealer Jacques Goudstikker. Seized by the Nazis, the works were returned after World War II to the Dutch government, which recognized the Stroganoff family as the rightful owner and transferred ownership to it. Now Marei Von Saher, a Connecticut heir of Mr. Goudstikker, has laid claim to the works. In the lawsuits each side asks the court to rule that it has lawful title to the art. EDWARD WYATT

WALTON--Marcia Dana, passed away peacefully on March 29, 2007 after a short illness. Marcia was born on June 25, 1920 in Muskegon, MI to James and Dorothy Dana Walton. Her early years were spent in Madison, WI. After the early death of her father she moved to New York City where she and her mother spent many happy years. Marcia worked as a City Librarian and later as a stock market analyst. She was a world traveler and a dedicated patron of the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Ballet. She recently stated that, she ''was grateful to have had a very long, happy and adventurous life''. Marcia will be deeply missed by her New York City friends as well as her friends in Wisconsin. She was preceded in death by her parents and her sister, Judith D. Walton, M.D. At Marcia's request, no funeral or memorial services were held.

LIKE any other activity, gardening is more appealing if you have the right equipment. Whether you are watering lawns, hauling dirt or clipping bushes, good tools make it easier on the hands and back. (Just try cutting a thorny bush without gloves.) Organizing and storing the tools is important too, and there are many choices of racks and bins to help keep everything at hand. 1. The Dual Hose Programmable Timer allows two hoses to be programmed up to seven days in advance to water for any interval of time between one minute and 23 hours. The timer takes a 9-volt battery; $129.95 from Hammacher Schlemmer, (800) 321-1484 or hammacher.com. 2. The rolling Water Wagon has a three-gallon tank and a wand with a trigger-operated spray, making it possible to water distant corners of the yard without dragging a hose or lugging a watering can. It is $79.95 from Plow & Hearth, (800) 494-7544 or plowandhearth.com. 3. The Tool Tree will accommodate up to 48 garden tools on a garage wall or in any other storage area; $99.95 from Brookstone, (800) 846-3000 or brookstone.com. 4. The Large Chicken Coop Cubby stores pots, tools and other garden paraphernalia in individual bins. Made of cedar, the unit is 34 1/2 inches wide by 15 inches deep by 30 inches high; $179 from Smith & Hawken, (800) 940-1170 or smithandhawken.com. It also comes in a smaller size, 27 1/2 inches wide by 11 inches deep by 26 inches high, for $149. 5. The Garden Rocker's curved bottom permits movement in all directions so you can sit without bending, and an optional seat cushion has pockets to hold tools; $34 (plus $15 for the cushion), at Home Depot, (800) 553-3199 or homedepot.com. 6. Brookstone's powder-coated metal outdoor sink attaches to a garden hose and comes with its own drain hose. It has a stainless steel faucet and sits in a wood frame with fold-down shelves and a backsplash; $249.95 from (800) 846-3000 or brookstone.com. 7. The Vigoro Dumping Garden Cart is made of plastic and has a quick-release mechanism; it is $59.99 and is available only at Home Depot stores (for locations, 800-553-3199 or homedepot.com). 8. Vermont Country Store's machine-washable gloves have small resin plates sewn between the layers of the soft, flexible fabric to prevent thorns and wires from cutting your hands; $34.95 from (802) 362-8460 or vermontcountrystore.com.

HONIG--Jerome, on May 1, 2007. He loved and was very much loved by his wife, of 57 years, Loretta, his daughter Marcia, his son Norman, sonin-law Tony Reiner and his adored grandson David Reiner. Interment was private.

Britney Spears Back Onstage, Briefly Wearing knee-high go-go boots, a short white skirt and a sparkly pink bra, showing off her navel decoration, a brown-wigged Britney Spears turned up at the House of Blues in San Diego late Tuesday night to deliver a brief five-song set that kicked off with her classic ''Baby One More Time,'' The Associated Press reported. The appearance by Ms. Spears, 25, was believed to be her first public concert performance in nearly three years. Backed by four dancers and using a cafe chair as a prop, Ms. Spears pranced around the small stage singing songs from her albums, albeit for less than 15 minutes. Rumors of an impending appearance had spread on the Internet and on local radio, prompting a run on tickets that packed the club, where some members of the audience paid upward of $125 each. The marquee advertised only a show by ''The M+Ms,'' and not until an hour after the doors opened did a disc jockey mention Ms. Spears's name. In the last year she has spent time in a rehabilitation facility after bizarre behavior that included shaving her head, being tattooed and attacking a car with an umbrella. She also reached a divorce settlement with Kevin Federline, with whom she has two children. In January she wrote on her Web site, ''I look forward to coming back this year bigger and better than ever.'' Here Comes the Queen A new formal portrait of Queen Elizabeth II, snapped by the photographer Annie Leibovitz, whose works include a naked, very pregnant Demi Moore and a nude John Lennon hugging a clothed Yoko Ono, has divided the critics, Reuters reported. Taken at Buckingham Palace to commemorate the queen's six-day visit to the United States, beginning today, the photograph drew praise from British critics and a thumbs down from The Washington Post's culture critic Henry Allen, who told BBC Radio it had ''all the personality of a marble bust of George Washington.'' But the British critic William Feaver expressed satisfaction with the traditional pose. ''You do not want to see Her Majesty break-dancing or bathing in a vat of asses' milk,'' he told BBC Radio. Berlin Philharmonic To Revisit Nazi Era The Berlin Philharmonic has agreed to cooperate in an investigation of its role during the Nazi era, Agence France-Presse reported. ''We've never really come to terms with the history of the Philharmonic Orchestra under National Socialism,'' Pamela Rosenberg, the general manager, said in Berlin. A book, to be published this year, will focus on the period from 1933 to 1945 and particularly on the ambiguous relationship between the orchestra's renowned conductor Wilhelm Furtwängler and leading Nazis. A film for public television and an exhibition on the subject are also planned. Mr. Furtwängler was chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic from 1922 to 1945 and from 1952 until his death in 1954. Often deferential toward the Nazis, who used him as a propaganda tool, he also worked to protect his Jewish musicians. Although his reputation was tainted, after World War II his name was cleared. Warner Brothers Options Frank Miller's 'Ronin' ''Ronin,'' a new movie adapted from a graphic novel by Frank Miller, below, the creator of ''300,'' has begun its journey to the screen. Warner Brothers optioned the rights to the novel for a live-action feature film to be directed by Sylvain White (''Stomp the Yard''), Variety.com reported. In the novel, published by DC Comics, a ronin, or disgraced samurai warrior, bears the responsibility for the assassination of his master by a shape-shifting demon in Japan in the 13th century. When the master's sword is unearthed in New York in the 21st century, the ronin and demon return to life, battling mutants and thugs for the mythical weapon.
To the Editor: Re ''U.S. Asks Court to Limit Lawyers at Guantánamo'' (front page, April 26):

ZOUDERER--Herman J., of Winter Park, FL. He was predeceased by his wife of 59 years, Marian. He will be missed by his children Sheila and Marvin Strauss, Dale and Gary Silverstein. His grandchildren Robin and Ira Rashbaum, Debra and Matthew Zik, Pamela Silverstein and Eric Silverstein. His greatgrandchildren Benjamin Rashbaum, Joshua Rashbaum, Jacob Zik and Flora Zik. His sisters Libby Fleischer and Shirley Prussin. Services Today at 1pm at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, LI.

A former New York police officer pleaded guilty in Federal District Court yesterday to conspiring to rob drug dealers while she was still on the force, federal prosecutors said. The former officer, Kirsix De La Cruz, pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy to distribute cocaine and conspiracy to commit robbery, prosecutors said. While serving as a police officer, Ms. De La Cruz introduced the men who planned to commit the robberies to someone who could direct them to stash houses, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Though Ms. De La Cruz did not personally take part in any robbery, she faces 10 years to life in prison when she is sentenced in September, prosecutors said. ALAN FEUER

Children's birthday parties in Manhattan can be extravagant, if not extraordinary. But even the most jaded young New Yorkers have probably never seen a feast like the one to be presented on Saturday: Two waiters will lead guests around a table with about 20 place settings. At one, a murmuring pea will roll about. At another, an exquisite rose will freeze. At a third, a quacking suitcase will open to reveal -- on video -- a graceful swan.

A prominent critic of Iran's nuclear policies over the past two years was arrested this week on spying charges, the semiofficial Fars news agency reported Wednesday. The critic, Hossein Moussavian, who served as a senior nuclear negotiator until President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad took office in 2005, was arrested after he appeared before a court Monday evening, Fars reported.

BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, said first-quarter profit rose 4.6 percent, to 499 million Canadian dollars ($450 million) because of lower restructuring costs and an extraordinary gain. Poor performance in the wireless unit meant that Bell Canada revenue rose just 0.4 percent over the same quarter a year earlier, reaching 3.58 billion Canadian dollars ($3.22 billion). Bell Mobility signed up just 13,000 cellphone subscribers during the period compared with 76,000 a year earlier. Recent price increases by Bell Mobility have not been matched by competitors. BCE said last month that it was in talks with Canadian pension funds and private equity investors that might lead to its going private. IAN AUSTEN

Wal-Mart has agreed to withdraw some types of vinyl baby bibs sold under the brand Baby Connection under an agreement with attorneys general in New York and Illinois, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said yesterday. The company agreed to the withdrawal after testing conducted by state officials revealed high levels of lead in the vinyl material used to make the bibs, Mr. Cuomo said. But Rick Locker, a lawyer for the Juvenile Products Manufacturers' Association, said testing by the federal Consumer Product Safety Commission found that the levels of lead were within acceptable limits and that ''vinyl bibs are safe and children are not at risk.''

JACOB--James Palmer, educator on three continents and former admissions director for the Collegiate School, died early Saturday, April 21, in his home surrounded by his family. He was 82 years old. Mr. Jacob is survived by his wife Mary Louise, his children Abigail, John, Bill and Sarah, his sister Betsy, and grandchildren Sarah, Chelsea, Breck, Acadia and Henry. A memorial service will be held on Monday, May 7th, at 4:00 pm at the West End Collegiate Church on West End and 77th Street, with a reception to follow in the Alumni Gymnasium of the Collegiate School. A short graveside service and interment will take place on Tuesday, May 8th at 11:00 am, at the Warwick Cemetery in Warwick, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Columbia University Memory Research Disorder Group. Checks should be made out to ''Trustees of Columbia University'' with a memo notation ''In memory of James Jacob for Memory Disorder Research''. Checks should be mailed to: The Taub Institute, Physicians & Surgeons, Box 16, 630 West 168th Street, NY, NY 10032.
